headline: Even With a Struggling Stephen Drew on Bench, the Yankees Go Quietly Against the A’s
abstract: The Yankees are having a hard time finding a productive replacement at second base for Robinson Cano, whom they will face again this week when they play the Mariners in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — It is hard to argue with the Yankees’ decision to let Robinson Cano leave for Seattle as a free agent, not when the Mariners committed $240 million to him through the age of 40. This is especially true at the moment, when Cano is off to a worrisome start, having just hit his second home run on Saturday.

headline: Dennis Hastert’s Name Removed by Alma Mater
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Names, Organizational', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']

Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, announced on Sunday that it had scrubbed his name from the school’s public policy center, after his indictment on charges that he lied to the F.B.I. about financial transactions he made to cover up past sexual misconduct.

headline: Louis Johnson, Bassist and Singer for the Brothers Johnson, Dies at 60

Despite the big fall in energy prices over the last year, consumers have been cautious about spending, one reason that experts think consumption in April was muted.

headline: And They’re Off: Crowd Numbers Will Be Smaller at the Belmont Stakes
abstract: After a variety of problems at Belmont Park during California Chrome’s bid for a Triple Crown last year, crowd size will be curtailed to 90,000 as American Pharoah takes his shot.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly four decades since the last sweep of horse racing’s coveted Triple Crown, 12 horses have left the Belmont Stakes starting gate with a shot at the feat. The New York Racing Association promoted those events and attracted gigantic crowds, including 102,199 last year, when the popular colt California Chrome failed to secure a sweep. A record 120,139 showed up in 2004, when Smarty Jones lost his bid.

One has been described by the United States military as an opium drug lord and an associate of Osama bin Laden. Another was a top official in the feared intelligence service of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Stun Guns', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — It was late on a Sunday in May 2014 when Officer Michael T. Slager of the North Charleston Police Department stood outside an apartment and faced off with a man whose fists, he said, were clenched as he assumed an “aggressive stance.” Mr. Slager, who said he had just watched the man assault a roommate, forced him to the ground with a five-second burst of electricity from a Taser.

headline: Removing the Fangs From Ty Cobb’s Notoriety
abstract: When he began work on “Ty Cobb: A Terrible Beauty,” Charles Leerhsen expected to uncover “new examples of monstrous monstrosity.” But the man and the myth did not line up.
lead_paragraph: When he began work on a new biography, “Ty Cobb: A Terrible Beauty” (Simon & Schuster), Charles Leerhsen expected to uncover fresh depictions of the player as a racist and a spikes-sharpening attacker of opposing infielders. If Cobb was the meanest man in baseball flannels, additional animosity would not be difficult to find.

headline: ‘Viagra for Women’ Gets Push for F.D.A. Approval

headline: Betrayed by the 76ers, a Warriors Fan Is Born

headline: ‘Curious Incident’ and ‘Hamilton’ Are Big Winners at Drama Desk Awards
abstract: The Drama Desk Awards were announced Sunday night, with “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” winning six and “Hamilton” winning seven.
lead_paragraph: “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” and “Hamilton” led the pack at the Drama Desk Awards, which were announced Sunday night. “Curious Incident” scooped up six prizes, including those for outstanding play, outstanding actor (Alex Sharp) and outstanding director of a play (Marianne Elliott). “Hamilton” won seven, including those for outstanding musical and outstanding director of a musical (Thomas Kail); its creator, Lin-Manuel Miranda, won for music, lyrics and book.

headline: Review: The Western Wind Performs ‘L’Amfiparnaso’ at a Distance
abstract: The vocal ensemble tackled Orazio Vecchi’s madrigal comedy at the West End Theater, and attempted to soften some its more dated humor.
lead_paragraph: At its premiere in Modena, Italy, in 1594, Orazio Vecchi’s “L’Amfiparnaso” must have been a barrel of laughs. The characters in this madrigal comedy are a mix of stock figures from commedia dell’arte, supplemented by caricatures with foreign manners and silly accents: a preening Spaniard, a wily servant from Bergamo and that mainstay of Italian Renaissance thigh-slapping hilarity, Jews babbling among themselves in synagogue. There are also serious scenes of true love tested and a happy ending, all skillfully woven into a sequence of five-part madrigals.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:15 A.M. (Sundance) ORLANDO (1993) A beautiful young nobleman (Tilda Swinton, above) adored by an aging Queen Elizabeth I (Quentin Crisp) falls asleep one night in the 17th century and wakes up five days later as a woman. “Same person, no difference at all,” she says, unflustered. “Just a different sex.” She continues to learn about life through the centuries up until the present, pondering the differences between men and women — as well as their similarities — in this adaptation by Sally Potter of Virginia Woolf’s 1928 novel. Charlotte Valandrey plays Sasha, a wanton Muscovite princess with whom the male Orlando falls in love. Billy Zane is the American with whom Orlando’s female version has a more enduring if less sexually demanding relationship. “This ravishing and witty spectacle invades the mind through eyes that are dazzled without ever being anesthetized,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Orlando’ could well become a classic of a very special kind, not mainstream perhaps, but a model for independent filmmakers who follow their own irrational muses, sometimes to unmourned obscurity, occasionally to glory.” More than anything else, he added: “ ‘Orlando’ is Ms. Swinton’s triumph. With the firmest but lightest of touches, she has spun gossamer.”

headline: Scientists Who Cheat
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Research', 'Cheating', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Academic and Scientific Journals']
abstract: The retraction of the study on same-sex marriage from the journal Science raises the question of just how much cheating goes on.
lead_paragraph: Cheating in scientific and academic papers is a longstanding problem, but it is hard to read recent headlines and not conclude that it has gotten worse. Falsified or erroneous results have forced authors and editors to retract papers from journals that let themselves be duped into publishing them. Researchers at some of the nation’s most prestigious universities have been implicated. There are ways to minimize this kind of fraud, but it will require changing the process, from how scientists share their data to how their peers review it and who is allowed to enforce academic standards.

headline: That 1914 Feeling
keywords: ['World War I (1914-18)', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Despite good intentions on both sides, it is not certain that a deal will be reached between Greece and its creditors.
lead_paragraph: U.S. officials are generally cautious about intervening in European policy debates. The European Union is, after all, an economic superpower in its own right — far too big and rich for America to have much direct influence — led by sophisticated people who should be able to manage their own affairs. So it’s startling to learn that Jacob Lew, the Treasury secretary, recently warned Europeans that they had better settle the Greek situation soon, lest there be a destructive “accident.”

headline: Who’s Willing to Fight for Iraq?

After the devastating loss of the Iraqi city of Ramadi to the Islamic State in May, he told CNN that while Iraqi troops vastly outnumbered the brutal extremists, they “just showed no will to fight.”

headline: Surviving Child Sexual Abuse
abstract: We need to understand the nature of such acts and help the survivors, and not use the issue for political points.
lead_paragraph: Last month came the news that Josh Duggar, now-former executive director of the Family Research Council’s lobbying arm and eldest son on the TLC reality show “19 Kids and Counting,” had apologized and said he had “acted inexcusably.” As In Touch Weekly magazine put it: “Josh Duggar was investigated for multiple sex offenses — including forcible fondling — against five minors. Some of the alleged offenses investigated were felonies.” Those minors apparently included his sisters. Duggar was around 14 years old when the reported assaults took place.

abstract: They seem to like the acclaim and influence that come from appearances before friendly audiences, though many of them appear wary of more general public scrutiny.

She discussed her triumphs as a litigator, dodged oblique questions about gay rights and described an opera that premieres next month called “Scalia/Ginsburg.”

headline: Price Tag on a Brooklyn Park Reaches $225 Million, and That’s Only the Beginning
abstract: The owner of land needed by the city as part of the promised deal for the Brooklyn Inlet Park is seeking $500 million for his 11-acre site.
lead_paragraph: Is a neighborhood park in Brooklyn worth a half-billion dollars? That may be the ultimate cost of Bushwick Inlet Park, which you’ve probably never heard of. This time of year, it’s full of children from around the city playing soccer. But it’s not much to look at.

headline: What Are Some ‘Words of Wisdom’ That Guide Your Life?
abstract: Whose words do you hear in your head, offering you guidance, in times of difficulty?
lead_paragraph: In difficult times or in just trying to choose between several equally good options, many people find guidance in expressions or sayings, like “one day at a time” or “don’t sweat the small stuff.” Then there are more personal credos, like the words of a wise family member or even a hero from a book or movie that come to mind in times of uncertainty.

headline: ‘Reagan: The Life,’ by H. W. Brands
abstract: A new biography tries to understand our elusive 40th president.
lead_paragraph: For a man who lived most of his life on camera, Ronald Reagan eludes focus. There was, and remains, a gauziness to the picture; Reagan retained, throughout his political career, the remoteness of a screen idol, though he never achieved that status as a movie actor. He was ubiquitous for decades and, as president, left a lasting imprint on America’s political culture. Yet he was all the same an unknowable man — even to those nearest him. In White House meetings, he was mostly silent, often leaving his aides to guess at (and feud over) his views. In his personal relationships, he was unfailingly warm but rarely intimate. “He doesn’t let anybody get too close,” one observer said. “There’s a wall around him.” That the observer was his wife, Nancy, should give pause to any politician or pundit who claims to know what Reagan would do if he were here today. (It should, but it won’t.)

headline: ‘Loving Day,’ by Mat Johnson
abstract: Mat Johnson’s new novel tells a semi-autobiographical story about race and mixed-race in America.
lead_paragraph: “A house divided against itself cannot stand,” Abraham Lincoln declared in his 1858 speech presaging the Civil War. Such a house sits at the heart of Mat Johnson’s ribald, incisive novel “Loving Day.” Bequeathed to the narrator, Warren Duffy, by his deceased father, it’s a roofless, ramshackle mansion in a black neighborhood in Philadelphia: “I look at the buckling floors. I look at the cracks in all the walls, the evidence of a foundation crumbling beneath us. I smell the char of the fire, the sweet reek of mold, the insult of mouse urine. I see a million things that have to be fixed, restored, corrected, each one impossible and each task mandatory for me to escape again.”

headline: How to Find That Vintage Cast-Iron Pan
abstract: Hunting down cookware that will last a lifetime; easy, low-budget ramen; and more advice, from a man who knows his way around a kitchen island.
lead_paragraph: Men in the kitchen, and those who deal with men in the kitchen, occasionally have questions about recipes, cooking and food. They send them to FoodEditor@nytimes.com. I answer their queries herewith.

headline: New Tactics for Battling Head Lice
abstract: The American Academy of Pediatrics has updated its advice to doctors on how best to treat children and families affected by head lice.
lead_paragraph: Relatively few school-age children escape the scourge of head lice, among the many organisms that show no respect for socioeconomic status or hygiene. Even though the insects do not endanger health or spread disease, head lice often provoke extreme anxiety and disgust among parents, and the time and money spent detecting and eradicating them costs consumers and schools an estimated $1 billion a year.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

lead_paragraph: The song by an amateur hip-hop artist briefly went viral on Chinese social media, but it was quickly blocked by government censors.

headline: Medicine’s Hidden Roots in an Ancient Manuscript
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Manuscripts', 'Museums', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Translation and Interpreters']

headline: World’s 50 Best Restaurants Announced Amid Criticism Over Voting
abstract: El Celler de Can Roca in Spain was named the No. 1 restaurant; American restaurants lost stature.

abstract: Monday: More on three-quarter housing, pouring rain, and roller-skating from coast to coast.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this sopping Monday.

headline: Shaking Up the Status Quo in Nepal
abstract: A new volunteerism, community spirit and social consciousness have emerged from disaster.
lead_paragraph: “Ke garne?” an old lady said to us, tears pouring down her cheeks, as we visited her earthquake-battered village in the Dhading district of Nepal last month: “What to do?” With a history of repeated crises — political, economic and natural — it has become the Nepali way to shrug one’s shoulders and hope for the best.

headline: Lindsey Graham Enters White House Race With Emphasis on National Security
abstract: The South Carolina senator could inject a hawkish foreign policy voice into a crowded field of Republican contenders.
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL, S.C. — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina returned Monday to the neighborhood where he was raised to announce that he is running for president, injecting a hawkish foreign policy voice into a crowded field of Republican contenders.

headline: Can Victory Be More Than a Mirage?
abstract: ISIS's persistence has dashed hopes for Iraqi success and challenged the power of foreign arms.

lead_paragraph: A look at the French auction house.

headline: Dusting the Furniture of Our Minds
abstract: What sort of existential anxiety are we avoiding when we clean?
lead_paragraph: Dust is everywhere. We contribute to its multiplication through our polluting industries, by wearing clothes and using things around us, and in the course of merely living — shedding skin cells, hair, and other byproducts of our life.

headline: G.O.P. Women in Congress: Why So Few?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans have not matched the rise of Democratic women, partly because moderate G.O.P. women are reluctant to run, research suggests.
lead_paragraph: The rising number of women in Congress can obscure another trend: The number of Republican women has remained roughly stagnant for more than a decade.

headline: Today in Politics: N.S.A. Program Expires as Senate Staring Match Continues
abstract: Sweeping National Security Agency surveillance powers lapsed at midnight after Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, refused to allow quick approval of a House-passed measure that would have kept the laws in place while a new program is introduced.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from Washington, where the Capitol continues to offer its condolences to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for the death of his son Beau. Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina will announce his plans to run for president on Monday and will begin a busy week on the campaign trail, but most eyes are on the Senate, where the deadline to extend a National Security Agency surveillance program has passed.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | June 1, 2015
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Morning Agenda: Intel Takeover of Altera Is Expected
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computer Chips', 'Executive Compensation', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Intel Takeover of Altera Is Expected | Humana Said to Consider Sale | Big Payouts in Charter-Time Warner Cable Merger | Vanguard and Fidelity Resist Proxy Access
lead_paragraph: INTEL TAKEOVER OF ALTERA IS EXPECTED | Just days after  Avago Technologies agreed to buy Broadcom for about $37 billion, the semiconductor industry is on the verge of yet another takeover deal, this time between Intel and Altera,  Michael J. de la Merced and Quentin Hardy write in DealBook. Intel is in talks to buy the chip maker Altera for more than $15 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday. Intel is expected to pay about $54 a share for Altera, whose specialized chip designs would help Intel expand beyond chips for personal computers, this person said. An agreement could be announced this week, but the person said the talks are continuing and might still collapse. Shares in Altera rose 4 percent on Friday, to $48.85, after  The New York Post reported that the two companies were close to an agreement.

headline: Chubby Blue Cat Hints at Thaw in Ties Between China and Japan
abstract: A Doraemon movie is the first Japanese film to be shown in Chinese theaters since Tokyo nationalized a group of disputed islands in the East China Sea in 2012.
lead_paragraph: The first Japanese film character to appear in Chinese theaters since tensions increased three years ago between China and Japan over disputed islands is a chubby blue cat.

headline: Q. and A.: Willy Wo-Lap Lam on ‘Chinese Politics in the Era of Xi Jinping’

lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, Willy Wo-Lap Lam has been one of the most widely read analysts of elite politics in China.

keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney and his daughter Liz Cheney are planning to make their presence felt in the 2016 presidential campaign through their advocacy group, Alliance for a Strong America.
lead_paragraph: The rise of the Islamic State in the Middle East has pushed Republicans toward embracing a more interventionist foreign policy, and now one prominent Republican family wants to be sure the party stays that way.

headline: The Finnish Disease
abstract: The classic problem surfaces.
lead_paragraph: A followup to my post inspired by troubles in Finland: it’s worth emphasizing just how bad Finland’s performance has been. For Finns, the great depression they remember is the slump at the beginning of the 1990s, driven by a combination of a bursting housing bubble and the collapse of the Soviet Union next door. The result was a very nasty slump, and a delayed recovery. But this time, although the slump in per capita GDP never got quite as deep, has been far more persistent:

headline: Surveillance Bill Awaits Verdicts on Amendments From Hawks in Senate
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The White House pressed the Senate to refrain from making substantive changes to the legislation, so that the N.S.A. program could be reinstated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fractious debate over restarting the government’s sweeping surveillance program is expected to reach its final Senate showdown on Tuesday, when defense hawks make an urgent appeal to preserve more power for security agencies to gain access to Americans’ phone records.

headline: A Tearful Tracy Morgan  Says He Doesn’t Remember Accident
abstract: In his first interview since the deadly accident last year, the comedian told the “Today” show, “Right now my goal is just to heal and get better. Because I’m not 100 percent yet.”
lead_paragraph: In his first television interview since he was badly injured in a highway crash last year, an emotional Tracy Morgan told NBC’s “Today” show that he did not remember the accident and was not yet ready to return to his comedy career.

headline: Today’s Travel News and Tips
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including hotel-booking websites that may not be what they seem.

We’d love your feedback as we refine the format and focus, so please email travmail@nytimes.com or comment below to share your thoughts.

headline: Intel Agrees to Buy Altera for $16.7 Billion
keywords: ['Computer Chips', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The deal would be the latest in a wave of consolidation as chip makers look to increase their scale and product offerings.
lead_paragraph: Computers stuffed with superfast chips are going everywhere: home appliances, cars, smartphones and giant data centers. This creates rich opportunities for makers of semiconductors, vastly increasing the number of places they can sell ever-smaller chips.

headline: Illinois Legislative Session Ends, but Battles Over Deficit and Taxes Are Only Beginning
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Police', 'State Legislatures', 'Taxation']
abstract: The state has a new budget, but with a shortfall, and while lawmakers said they would keep meeting as needed, there was little hope for a deal.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With an unresolved state budget deficit and a mounting standoff over fundamental issues like tax increases and business regulations, Illinois’s political leaders are braced for a long, difficult fight in the aftermath of a legislative session that officially came to an end Sunday night.

headline: Hillary Clinton Focuses on Drug Addiction After Learning Scale of Problem
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton calls heroin and methamphetamine addiction in rural America a “quiet epidemic” and has told policy advisers to put the issue on the list of priorities in her campaign platform.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s carefully choreographed round-table discussions with voters don’t lead to many moments of surprise. But Mrs. Clinton has seemed to have had some legitimate jolts when conversations in Iowa and New Hampshire repeatedly drifted back to drug abuse.

headline: Fredrik Berselius to Open New Restaurant in South Williamsburg
abstract: The chef, who was awarded a Michelin star for his Nordic-inspired cuisine at Aska, which closed last year, has finally found a new place to cook.
lead_paragraph: After more than a year without a restaurant, Fredrik Berselius, a chef whose Michelin-starred work at Aska in Brooklyn reflected his passion for the Swedish countryside of his childhood, has finally found a new place to cook.

headline: The Living Is Easy, But the Puzzles Are Not
abstract: In which we dig deep for your June Times Insider puzzles.

headline: Foster Farms to Eliminate Human Antibiotics in Poultry
abstract: The giant poultry producer is following a growing consumer demand for antibiotic-free meat.
lead_paragraph: Stepping into line with many of its competitors, Foster Farms, one of the nation’s largest poultry producers, is moving to stop using antibiotics that are also administered to humans.

headline: To Be Sued Less, Doctors Should Consider Talking to Patients More
abstract: Studies say that good communication matters more than anything else in preventing malpractice suits.
lead_paragraph: Doctors call it defensive medicine. They order extra tests, perform extra procedures or push for more office visits because they think that without them, they’re at greater risk of being sued.

headline: Maria Sharapova Can’t Shake a Cold or Her Opponent; Serena Williams Advances

headline: Bangladesh Police Charge 41 With Murder Over Rana Plaza Collapse
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: More than 1,100 people were killed in the 2013 collapse of the building, which housed several clothing factories, in what is the garment industry’s worst disaster.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The police in Bangladesh filed formal murder charges on Monday against 41 people accused of involvement in the 2013 collapse of a building that housed several clothing factories, leaving more than 1,100 people dead in the worst disaster in garment industry history.

headline: Daily Report: Intel Agrees to Buy Altera for $16.7 Billion
abstract: The deal would be the latest in a wave of consolidation as chip makers look to increase their scale and product offerings.

headline: American Pharoah Eyes Triple Crown Sweep
abstract: For the 14th time since 1978, a horse will have a chance to become a Triple Crown champion at Belmont Park. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: When the Belmont Stakes is run June 6, American Pharoah has a chance to become horse racing’s 12th Triple Crown champion, and the first since Affirmed in 1978. California Chrome was in the same position last year, but finished in a dead heat for fourth. Here is what you need to know going into the race.

headline: Love Locks Removed From Paris Bridge
abstract: Tourists lamented the removal of 45 tons of padlocks from Paris’s Pont des Arts on Monday. Authorities say their weight is damaging the structure, and will replace them with plexiglass panels.
lead_paragraph: Tourists lamented the removal of 45 tons of padlocks from Paris’s Pont des Arts on Monday. Authorities say their weight is damaging the structure, and will replace them with plexiglass panels.

headline: Beijing Cracks Down on Smoking

lead_paragraph: The Chinese capital has raised fines on smoking indoors. Unlike with previous bans, restaurants appeared to be respecting the rules, but questions remained about enforcement.

headline: Review: ‘Unforgettable’ by Scott Simon: Saying Goodbye 140 Characters at a Time

lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of hand-wringing these days about the importance of having The Talk — not the one parents have with their mortified tweens, but the one we shy from having with aging parents or those terminally ill. The one about death and dying.

lead_paragraph: QUANG NGAI, South Vietnam — As the main body of Viet Cong forces in embattled Quang Ngai province continued to retreat under aerial bombardment, a Viet Cong suicide squad today [June 1] infiltrated the provincial capital to kill the senior commanders directing the battle.

keywords: ['Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']

headline: The Population Bomb, Then and Now
abstract: A video examines why the “population bomb” first scared us, then fizzled, and is still debated.

headline: Fighting in Ukraine Eases, but Abuses Continue on Both Sides, U.N. Says
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Fighting in eastern Ukraine has eased recently, but at least 6,417 people have died in the conflict and abuses that may amount to war crimes continue to be committed by both sides, the United Nations said Monday.

lead_paragraph: TOWN OF WALLKILL, N.Y. — Don Crawford comes from a long line of Orange County farmers. Though he no longer tends dairy cows, he still cuts hay for the thriving equestrian industry, and cringes at the creep of the suburbs.

headline: Review: Stan VanDerBeek at Andrea Rosen Gallery
abstract: These experimental films form one of the best shows in Chelsea right now.
lead_paragraph: Projected on four walls of a small space, Stan VanDerBeek’s experimental 16-millimeter films (transferred to video) form one of the best shows in Chelsea right now. They also create a pulsing environment that increases our understanding of this pioneering, experience-oriented artist, who died at 57 in 1984.

headline: American Pharoah Flies Around Track; Next Stop, Belmont

headline: FIFA Case Could Strengthen Justice Dept.’s Global Power
keywords: ['World Cup (Soccer)', 'Soccer', 'Money Laundering', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: The United States government will have a powerful weapon against international corruption if it is able to successfully use the RICO Act in the latest case involving soccer.
lead_paragraph: Teddy Roosevelt was fond of the West African proverb to “speak softly and carry a big stick; you will go far.” The Justice Department is wielding one of its biggest sticks — the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, better known as RICO — to go after bribery and kickbacks that have been rife in international soccer for decades.

headline: Inside the Rauschenberg Warehouse
abstract: The late artist Robert Rauschenberg’s archive-in-progress in Mount Vernon, N.Y., reveals a stockpile of old neckties, Polaroids and letters from famous friends.

abstract: The week’s two biggest games with global appeal are, alas, on the same day. But Saturday will be huge.

headline: Staying Out of Your Neighbor’s Business
abstract: Drawing conclusions about wealth and status based on visual clues is not just a risky business — it’s none of your business.
lead_paragraph: Humans can be a competitive lot. The way we posture and position ourselves to stand out in a group seems to happen instinctively. After all, in the past we competed for resources and survival. Our lives depended on it. Today, we still compete, but for different reasons.

abstract: A handful of things to see, hear and do, chosen by critics for The New York Times.

headline: American Journalist Is Freed by Yemen’s Houthi Rebels
abstract: The release of the journalist, Casey L. Coombs, came the same day that a video of a Frenchwoman seized in Yemen three months ago surfaced online.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Houthi rebels in Yemen on Monday released an American freelance journalist who had been in their custody for about two weeks, the State Department and the journalist’s family reported.

headline: Paul Salomon’s Imbalance Puzzles
abstract: From the new book “Playing With Math,” imbalance puzzles by Paul Salomon.
lead_paragraph: Our challenge this week is an original by Paul Salomon, who teaches math and mathematical art at the John Burroughs School in St. Louis. The puzzle appears in the recently released “Playing with Math” by Sue VanHattum. Before getting to Paul’s puzzle, I’d love to say a bit about Sue’s new book, which was published by Natural Math.

headline: Supreme Court Overturns Conviction in Online Threats Case, Citing Intent
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Social Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The justices, ruling in the case of a self-styled rapper angry at his estranged wife, said prosecutors must prove comments were intended as threats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday made it harder to prosecute people for threats made on Facebook and other social media, reversing the conviction of a Pennsylvania man who directed brutally violent language against his estranged wife.

headline: Hillary Clinton Still Strong in Iowa Poll, Though Negative News Is a Concern
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton continues her sizable lead in a poll of Iowa Democrats, many of whom say they are also worried that revelations about her could hurt in the general election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to command a sizable lead in a poll released on Monday of Iowa Democrats, who will cast the first votes of the presidential nominating race early next year. At the same time, Democrats are worried that revelations about Mrs. Clinton could hurt her in the general election.

headline: 1915: German Airship Bombs London
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: German airship bombs London
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Admiralty issues the following statement as a continuation of its announcement made early this morning [June 1] with regard to last night’s raid by a German airship over the Metropolitan area: ‘‘Late last night about ninety bombs, mostly of an incendiary description, were dropped from a hostile aircraft in various localities not far distant from each other. A certain number of fires were caused by the bursting of these bombs. Only three of these fires were large enough to require the services of fire-engines. All the fires were promptly and effectively dealt with.’’— The New York Herald, European Edition, June 2, 1915

headline: ‘Fifty Shades’ Author to Offer Grey’s Perspective
abstract: E.L. James announced Monday that she would publish a 576-page story, written from the point of view of the billionaire Christian Grey.
lead_paragraph: E.L. James is giving fans of her best-selling erotica series “Fifty Shades of Grey” a little something to tide them over before the next installment of the movie franchise.

headline: A Nose for Fashion
abstract: Carolina Herrera and her daughter have teamed up on a collection of six new fragrances — and made-to-order dresses to match.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Carolina Herrera and her daughter Carolina Herrera de Báez have teamed up on Herrera Confidential, a collection of six new fragrances. With a bit of synesthetic whimsy, the senior Herrera has created made-to-order dresses tailored to each scent: A sumptuous cashmere ensemble matches with warm amber, a lustrous silk cocktail dress with citrusy neroli. The most opulent of the offerings, Oud Couture, has been paired with a midnight-blue gown embellished with crystal embroidery.

headline: More Opponents Stand in the Way of the Triple Crown . . .
abstract: American Pharoah could set a record for most horses beaten on the way to the Triple Crown.

headline: Data Shows Large Rise in List Prices at Hospitals
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Medicare', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Data from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services include payments and services connected with the 100 most common Medicare hospital stays.
lead_paragraph: The prices that hospitals ask customers to pay for a series of common procedures have increased by more than 10 percent between 2011 and 2013 — more than double the rate of inflation.

headline: Alvin Ailey’s Linda Celeste Sims and Her Pas de Cuisinart
abstract: With her itinerant food processor, the lead dancer makes sure room service isn’t the only option for her and members of the company on the road.
lead_paragraph: When Linda Celeste Sims arrives in a hotel room — a common occurrence in the nine months she spends on the road each year as a lead dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater — she unpacks her hot plate, pot, sauté pan and Cuisinart food processor. For china, utensils and napkins, she calls room service; her suitcase is only so big.

headline: New York Triathletes Mourn JackRabbit’s Loss of Independence
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Triathlon', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Running']
abstract: Before being bought by RSG, JackRabbit was considered a “community hub” for athletes, but the loss of employees and inventory has changed the environment.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the Running Specialty Group bought JackRabbit Sports in March, the changes began behind the scenes. Some employee positions were eliminated immediately, and a popular commission program for sales employees was discontinued.

headline: Refining a Familiar Form: Mariano Rivera’s Son Improves His Pitching and His Prospects
abstract: Mariano Rivera III, the son of the former Yankees closer Mariano Rivera, continued pitching for Iona after being chosen in the 29th round of baseball’s 2014 draft.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — It was a simple county park, with no scoreboard and a chain-link fence demarcating the outfield perimeter, where children scrambled after foul balls and aluminum pings echoed toward an ice-cream vendor across the parking lot.

headline: Muslim Woman Denied Job Over Head Scarf Wins in Supreme Court
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Discrimination', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The justices, voting 8 to 1, reinstated a job discrimination lawsuit filed against Abercrombie & Fitch, saying the company had acted improperly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday revived an employment discrimination lawsuit against Abercrombie & Fitch, which had refused to hire a Muslim woman because she wore a head scarf. The company said the scarf clashed with its dress code, which called for a “classic East Coast collegiate style.”

headline: Jeb Bush Faces Challenge in Winning Over Brother’s Team
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While many in George W. Bush’s circle are enthusiastic, many of those who worked for him have not rushed to join his brother’s emerging 2016 operation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When George W. Bush first ran for president, he liked to say he had inherited half of his father’s friends and all of his enemies. For Jeb Bush, now preparing his own bid for the White House, that may ring familiar.

headline: A New Album With Artsy Bona Fides (and an Assist from Leonard Cohen)
abstract: The Seoul-born singer Jihae has garnered comparisons to Lou Reed and Debbie Harry.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve always been interested in social psychology and why certain groups of people do things while others don’t,” says the singer Jihae of “Illusion of You,” her forthcoming fourth record, out this week. “The overall theme of the album is based on individual illusions about self-identity as well as the societal illusions that create divisions between cultures, religion, class and gender.”

headline: Petrobras Seeks to Sell a 100-Year Bond
abstract: A high yield is expected to be the price the troubled petroleum giant pays to return to the global capital markets.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Petrobras, Brazil’s troubled petroleum giant, is returning to the global capital markets with plans to sell a 100-year bond issue.

headline: Time Warner Cable C.F.O. Leaves Company
abstract: The chief financial officer, Arthur Minson Jr., will become president and chief operating officer of the WeWork office space-sharing company.
lead_paragraph: Arthur T. Minson Jr., who helped guide Time Warner Cable through the collapse of the $45 billion takeover attempt by Comcast, then the $56 billion proposed sale to Charter Communications, is leaving his position as chief financial officer of the company to work as president and chief operating officer of WeWork, a company that rents shared office space.

headline: Climate Model Suggests Everest Glaciers Could Nearly Disappear
abstract: A new computer model suggests that without changes to greenhouse gas emissions, the Everest region of Nepal could lose 99 percent of its glaciers by the end of the century.
lead_paragraph: By the end of this century, the landscape around Mount Everest may drastically change. As the planet continues to warm, the Everest region of Nepal could lose most of its glaciers, according to a study published in the journal The Cryosphere.

headline: Disney’s Top Financial Officer to Step Down
abstract: James Rasulo, the company’s chief financial officer since 2010, was considered out of the running to succeed Robert Iger as the chief executive.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney’s chief financial officer, James A. Rasulo, will step down on June 30, a departure that had been expected after his removal from consideration as next chief executive.

headline: Japanese Companies Attack Neglected Diseases
abstract: In a joint effort, three drug companies in Japan are allowing searches of their chemical compounds for ways to treat Chagas and leishmaniasis.
lead_paragraph: Several Japanese drug companies have joined a new project to find medicines to treat two neglected parasitic diseases, Chagas and leishmaniasis.

headline: Two Ways to Be Happy
abstract: Controlling how you respond to your circumstances may matter as much as controlling the circumstances themselves, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve read any self-help books, you’ve probably heard the adage that even if you can’t control what happens to you, you can control how you feel about it. Now there’s scientific evidence that the latter really does help — managing how you react to setbacks can make you feel better about life, maybe even more than avoiding those setbacks altogether.

headline: Paris Bridge’s Love Locks Are Taken Down
abstract: Weighing heavily on the famed Pont des Arts, the countless padlocks — their keys thrown into the Seine — are being removed from the bridge.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The padlocks that weigh heavily on the sides of the Pont des Arts tell stories dear to the lovers who affixed them to the celebrated bridge’s iron grillwork.

lead_paragraph: In April, Bruce Jenner spoke about her transition to being a woman in a television special that drew nearly 17 million viewers.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Rally in New York, Then Tour Early Voting States
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign is shifting into higher gear with a June 13 rally on Roosevelt Island in New York City, while also trying to lower expectations.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton will hold the first major rally of her presidential campaign on June 13 on Roosevelt Island in New York City, before embarking on a five-day swing through the four states with the earliest Democratic nominating contests, her campaign said on Monday.

headline: Work and Play in Paris's Silicon Sentier
abstract: The area of central Paris around rue du Sentier, once home to part of the garment district, is now home to a hive of innovation.

headline: A Step Toward Justice for Rana Plaza Victims
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)']
abstract: Charges filed against the building’s owner are important, but many victims of the collapse still need compensation.
lead_paragraph: Police in Bangladesh filed murder charges on Monday against 41 people involved in the collapse of a garment factory building that killed more than 1,100 people in 2013. Though it took more than two years, these charges represent progress in a country that has historically done too little to help factory workers and hold factory owners responsible for crimes.

headline: Met Opera Sets Lineup for Free HD Screenings
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s Summer HD Festival will run from Aug. 28 through Sept. 7.
lead_paragraph: The Jets and the Sharks will return to the West Side — and the music of Leonard Bernstein and dance of Jerome Robbins will return to Lincoln Center — when the Metropolitan Opera opens its Summer HD Festival on Aug. 28 with a free screening of the 1961 film “West Side Story.” Ten nights of free opera screenings will follow on the plaza in front of the Met.

headline: Little Sister Lauds Lindsey Graham, the Bachelor, for Raising Her
abstract: Lindsey Graham’s family was featured prominently at his presidential announcement event. His sister, Darline Graham Nordone, who he helped raise after their parents’ deaths, introduced the South Carolina senator.
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL, S.C. — If elected, Senator Lindsey Graham would be the first bachelor to win the White House since Grover Cleveland. But that does not mean he will be on the campaign trail without any family members in tow.

headline: The Upper Crust in a Tectonic Plate Collision
abstract: Oceanic and continental plates have different levels of buoyancy that help determine which one winds up on top in a meeting of the two.
lead_paragraph: Q. The recent earthquakes in Nepal made me wonder: When tectonic plates collide, what determines which one winds up on top?

headline: Chicago Schools Chief Resigns Amid Federal Investigation
abstract: Barbara Byrd-Bennett, on leave from Chicago Public Schools since April, has been the subject of a federal investigation into possible misconduct.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The chief executive of the public school system here, Barbara Byrd-Bennett, who has been the subject of a federal investigation into possible misconduct, has resigned, the district announced Monday.

headline: Patz Prosecutor Takes On Ex-Congressman in Staten Island District Attorney’s Race
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Elections, District Attorneys']
abstract: Joan Illuzzi will run as a Republican against the former Representative Michael E. McMahon, a Democrat, setting the stage for a contest between a pair of unusually high-profile candidates.
lead_paragraph: Joan Illuzzi, a longtime Manhattan prosecutor who handled the Etan Patz case, has resigned her post to run for Staten Island district attorney as a Republican, setting the stage for a contest between a pair of unusually high-profile candidates.

headline: Ben Bernanke Says Fed Can’t Get Caught Up in Inequality Debate
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The former Fed chairman expressed uncertainty about the impact of quantitative easing on economic inequality, and said it was beside the point.
lead_paragraph: Ben S. Bernanke, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has given short shrift to those who doubt the economic impact of his bond-buying campaigns in helping to bring the American economy out of the Great Recession.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Q. and A.: Tobias Menzies on Playing the Brutal Black Jack
abstract: The show’s villain on that unforgettable season finale.
lead_paragraph: “Shock and horror are legitimate feelings to experience when you’re watching a story,” said Ron Moore in a recent interview about the Season 1 finale of Starz’s “Outlander.” And it was hard not to feel both emotions while watching “To Ransom a Man’s Soul,” in which we see in flashback the brutalization of Jamie, the show’s male hero, by the villain Black Jack Randall. As I wrote in my episode recap, because of the way it addressed sexual assault, it was “an important episode of television because it takes the time to fully explore what recovery actually looks like and understands that it’s by no means simple or straightforward.”

headline: Chip Deals in Search of Greater Pricing Power
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Investors have lifted the shares of both semiconductor acquirers and their targets in hopes for cost cuts and improved top lines. That may be too optimistic.
lead_paragraph: Revenue synergies can be an elusive goal in mergers. Yet three big acquisitions in the chipmaking sector — the latest Intel’s $17 billion swoop on Altera — are promising plenty of them. Some acquirers may manage to work magic on their top lines, but it’s optimistic to think all of them will.

headline: Djokovic vs. Nadal: A Quarterfinal That Feels Like a Final
abstract: Novak Djokovic beat Richard Gasquet and Rafael Nadal beat Jack Sock on Monday to set up their anticipated match. Andy Murray and Roger Federer also advanced.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As most had hoped and everybody had expected, there was no altering the collision course.

headline: No Food Fights for Large African Herbivores
abstract: So many large, plant-eating animals coexist in Africa because each species has its own diet, a new study concludes.
lead_paragraph: How is it possible that so many large herbivores coexist in Africa? That incredible diversity is possible because each species has a distinct diet, a new study concludes. Little is known about the specific plants that elephants, impalas, zebras and other large herbivores eat. With a technique called DNA metabarcoding, researchers at Princeton University analyzed the feces of seven species, matching gene sequences they found to a reference library of plant DNA. All of the species consumed different diets, the scientists found, even those similar in size, digestive physiology and location. The findings, which appear in the Proceedings of the National Academy of the Sciences, may help researchers maintain wildlife diversity in the African savannas.

headline: Washington’s Wine Surge
abstract: Washington’s winemaking production has more than doubled in the last decade, and one reason is the drought.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s winemaking production has more than doubled in the last decade, and one reason is the drought.

headline: Drought Is Bearing Fruit for Washington Wineries
abstract: The state, which has long lagged California in winemaking, has seen its industry double in the last 15 years, and the expansion may be accelerating.
lead_paragraph: YAKIMA, Wash. — American wine, for all the hype and hyperbole in recent years about Idaho rieslings or Pennsylvania pinot noirs, is still overwhelmingly a California thing. Even in an off year, wineries there produce more than 20 times as much wine as the vineyards here in Washington State, the perennial No. 2 in the rankings.

headline: A Likely Path for Senate Approval of a Surveillance Bill
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A look at how the vote to pass the House-backed U.S.A. Freedom Act might play out in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Senator Rand Paul forced the temporary expiration of some of the government’s surveillance powers on Sunday night, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to take up a bill approved by the House that would renew some of those powers but also shift the storage of telephone records from the government to the phone companies.

headline: Gazans’ Hopes for Rebuilding After War Give Way to Deeper Despair
abstract: Hamas quietly initiated new import fees in an effort to cover the salaries of some 40,000 employees, raising prices in already depressed markets.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — On a street here crammed with glittery clothing and electronic shops, Mahmoud Matar flipped through the receipt book for his appliance store, much of it blank: His lone sale that day was a $7 kettle. It was clear whom he blamed for his poor sales: Gaza’s Islamist Hamas government.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Little Help to Struggling Homeowners
abstract: The court handed banks a victory on Monday but homeowners continue to have no easy way out of the mortgage crisis.
lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas and his Supreme Court colleagues decided on Monday that the bankruptcy code would continue to be of little help to underwater homeowners, though he suggested that he perhaps wished it could be otherwise.

headline: London’s Newest Private Club Will Always Be at Least 51% British
abstract: South Kensington Club has wellness at its core, and values niceness when considering potential members.
lead_paragraph: London has a long history of private clubs, with perhaps more members-only establishments per capita than any other city in the world. That latest is the South Kensington Club, which officially opens today and has wellness as its focus. Luca Del Bono, the owner and a co-founder of Quintessentially concierge service, says he got the idea while living in New York, where he’d often go to the Russian Turkish Baths in the East Village. “At the time, Londoners were too prudish. Fifteen years ago, an English man would not even admit they would have a massage,” he recalls. “But nowadays people are so conscious about being healthy and fit.” He describes South Kensington Club as a “members club with a gym, a bathhouse and a saltwater Watsu pool.”

headline: English Abbey’s Caffeinated Wine Gains Popularity and Scrutiny
abstract: A favorite of young drinkers, especially in Scotland, the product has been blamed for contributing to crime, and lawmakers are considering bans unless its contents are changed.
lead_paragraph: BUCKFAST, England — Sticky, sweet and flavored like spiced wine, with a hint of violet and a jolt of caffeine, the alcoholic drink produced here for the last century by Benedictine monks is the heart of a thriving enterprise.

headline: Dozens of Museum Leaders Sign Protest Letter Over Exclusion of Gulf Labor Activists
abstract: Curators and museum officials, including the directors of MoMA and the Tate, have criticized the United Arab Emirates for barring entry to protest organizers who have criticized labor practices there.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of curators and museum officials from around the world have signed a letter opposing recent decisions by the United Arab Emirates to prevent three people who have publicly criticized labor practices there from entering the country.

abstract: Microsoft has finally said when Windows 10, one of its biggest products in years, will be available: July 29.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has finally said when Windows 10, one of its biggest products in years, will be available: July 29.

abstract: Competitors from 48 states and as far away as New Zealand came to submit their best specimens.

headline: Masters of Taxidermy Seek to Replicate More Than an Animal’s Appearance
abstract: The World Taxidermy Championships have long been seen as the premier competition in the field. Now, one judge says, they expect to see a snapshot of behavior and habitat.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Mo. — They entered through the convention hall lobby — a mounted menagerie of dead mammals, birds and fish whose owners paused in the natural light to primp them to perfection before the show. A man in a camouflage cap tweezed a pheasant’s plumage into place. Another man, wielding a blower-vacuum, fluffed the mane of a lion suspended midpounce over a warthog, and a woman brushed what looked like a perfectly coifed weasel.

lead_paragraph: Red-carpet looks from the fifth annual awards show at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: A Trio of Classic Cocktail Recipes, Made New Again With Trendy Añejo Tequila
abstract: Mixologists from New York bars Cosme, the Up & Up and Extra Fancy created riffs on the Negroni, the Blood and Sand and the Rob Roy.
lead_paragraph: Tequila is growing up and expanding its boundaries — no longer a mere cheap foundation for obliterating, sugary-sweet cocktails. Darker, premium golden-amber-hued añejos, hailing from the rainy highlands and arid valleys outside of Guadalajara, Mexico and aged in wooden barrels for at least 12 months, garner attention all on their own for their sophisticated flavor. This spring gives rise to a new wave of pricier, ultra-aged extra añejos (casked in wood from three to seven years), like Patrón’s rare and limited Extra Añejo 7 Años, which are best enjoyed sipped (pass on the snifter and opt for Riedel’s Vinum Tequila glass — a Champagne-style flute), not mixed into a margarita.

headline: Four Militants Killed in Gun Battle With Indian Troops
abstract: Clashes in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir left four militant fighters dead, the Indian Army said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A gun battle in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, in an area close to the disputed border with Pakistan, left four militant fighters dead, the Indian Army said on Monday in a statement.

headline: U.A.B. Set to Reinstate Football After Outcry
abstract: The University of Alabama, Birmingham, on Monday was expected to announce that it would keep playing football, a reversal from six months ago, when the program was terminated.
lead_paragraph: The mood six months ago at the University of Alabama at Birmingham was one of shock, sadness and anger when President Ray L. Watts announced that the university would be the first in nearly two decades to drop its top-tier football program, blaming the rising costs of the sport.

headline: Review: A ‘Ship of Fools,’ Each Stuck in Isolation
abstract: This dance-theater work by Niv Sheinfeld and Oren Laor, at Abrons Arts Center, asks whether people can understand one another.
lead_paragraph: “Ship of Fools,” by the Israeli team of Niv Sheinfeld (choreographer) and Oren Laor (director), begins with its three characters separated into lanes like lap swimmers. These lanes are metaphors for the boundaries between selves, and this 2011 dance-theater work, which had its New York premiere at Abrons Arts Center over the weekend, is a kind of play about whether these people can break out of their solipsistic prisons, understand one another and be understood.

headline: Review: Maria Schneider Orchestra’s ‘The Thompson Fields,’ Connections to the Natural World
abstract: There’s a grand naturalist compulsion in Ms. Schneider’s writing for a large ensemble, and this album teems with observant references to the pastoral world.
lead_paragraph: MARIA SCHNEIDER ORCHESTRA

abstract: Cleo Tucker and Harmony Tividad, the group’s only members, offer untrained vocals and simple patterns in songs about teenage anxieties.
lead_paragraph: GIRLPOOL

headline: What Judy Blume’s Books Meant
abstract: As Ms. Blume prepares to promote her new novel, “In the Unlikely Event,” Lena Dunham, Samantha Bee and others discuss how her work influenced them.
lead_paragraph: People have intense feelings about Judy Blume. Fans, readers, booksellers — even other authors and celebrities — often dissolve into tears upon meeting her, confessing that books like “Forever ... ” and “Are You There, God? It’s Me, Margaret” got them through adolescence; taught them about sex, love and friendship; and provided their first glimpse of adulthood. Ms. Blume has come to expect overwrought reactions.

headline: Hillary Clinton Lawyer Accuses Wisconsin of Trying to Suppress the Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s top campaign lawyer has filed a second voter-access suit accusing a Republican-led state of trying to suppress the vote — this time in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s top campaign lawyer has filed a second voter-access lawsuit accusing a Republican-led state of trying to suppress the vote — this time in Wisconsin, home to Scott Walker, the governor and likely Republican 2016 presidential candidate.

headline: Review: ‘The Shepherd’s Life,’ by James Rebanks, an English Sheep Farmer
abstract: This book about the author’s small sheep farm in England explores a way of life essentially unchanged for centuries in an era full of change and flux.
lead_paragraph: James Rebanks’s captivating new book about his family’s small sheep farm in England is also a book about continuity and roots and a sense of belonging in an age that’s increasingly about mobility and self-invention. It’s a book about a way of life essentially unchanged for centuries in an era that’s all about change and flux. And it’s a book about a farming family whose history has played out in the fields, hills and villages between the Lake District and the Pennines for at least six centuries.

headline: On Eve of Tony Awards, Broadway Box Office Dips
abstract: Three of the Tony-nominated new musicals still had good news to report.
lead_paragraph: After a big Memorial Day weekend brought a strong end to a record-breaking season, Broadway’s box office sales sagged a bit last week.

headline: A Simple Sanctuary
abstract: The Chequit on Shelter Island reopens, and boasts a new restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Finding a place to stay in the Hamptons during the summer can be a greater headache than the traffic, hence the anticipated reopening of the Chequit on Shelter Island. Built in 1872 as a dining hall for a local Methodist group, it has been transformed into a quaint boutique hotel with bright, airy rooms overlooking the harbor. There’s also a new restaurant, Red Maple — named after the towering tree in the center of the outdoor terrace — that serves up small plates such as smoked bluefish rillettes and oysters from nearby Montauk.

headline: Obama Plans to Nominate Roberta Jacobson to Be Ambassador to Mexico
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Ms. Jacobson, a Mexico specialist who rose through the ranks of the State Department, has been at the center of Mr. Obama’s overhaul of American policy toward Cuba.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate Roberta S. Jacobson, the top State Department official for Latin America and his point person in negotiations to re-establish diplomatic ties with Cuba, to be the United States ambassador to Mexico, the White House said Monday.

headline: Review: ‘Ever After,’ a Slipperless Cinderella Tale, at the Paper Mill Playhouse
abstract: This premiere of a stage musical based on the popular 1998 Drew Barrymore film features Christine Ebersole as the wicked stepmother, with direction and choreography by Kathleen Marshal.
lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — The Cinderella story received a realistic reboot in the 1998 movie “Ever After,” in which Drew Barrymore portrayed the heroine as a spunky, take-charge girl who wins her prince without benefit of any supernatural intervention, or even a glass slipper. The popular film has now become — surprise! — a storybook-pretty if bland stage musical, making its premiere at the Paper Mill Playhouse, with Margo Seibert supplying the requisite spunk in the central role, Christine Ebersole taking over from Anjelica Huston as the wicked stepmother, and the experienced Kathleen Marshall directing and supplying the dances.

headline: Bribery Inquiry Drawing Closer to FIFA’s President, Sepp Blatter
abstract: Law enforcement officials said that Jérôme Valcke, FIFA’s secretary general, made a 2008 bank transfer to a soccer official accused of taking a bribe.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities believe that Sepp Blatter’s top lieutenant at FIFA made $10 million in bank transactions that are central elements of the bribery scandal engulfing international soccer, United States officials and others briefed on the case said Monday. The revelation puts the money trail closer to Mr. Blatter, FIFA’s president, than had been previously known.

headline: Review: Jinkx Monsoon Is Back, and Pregnant, in ‘The Vaudevillians: Bringing Up Baby’
abstract: Kitty Witless and Dr. Dan return to the Laurie Beechman Theater for more drag debauchery that comes complete with an onstage birth.
lead_paragraph: Poor Kitty Witless. It’s a little embarrassing not being quite sure who fathered your unborn child, but she also seems hazy on whether the conception took place in this century or the last.

abstract: The Carnegie Museum of Art enlisted writers to reflect on the archives of the pioneering African-American photographer Charles (Teenie) Harris to better understand Pittsburgh today.

headline: Review: New Amsterdam Singers Perform a Text-Inspired Concert
abstract: Excerpts from a van Gogh letter inspired the highlight work of this ensemble’s concert at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church.
lead_paragraph: Concert programmers often try to create thematic links between seemingly disparate works. But the New Amsterdam Singers event on Thursday at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church on the Upper West Side was united by only what was described in the program as “unusually appealing texts.”

headline: Red-Tailed Hawk Is Winning White House Turf Battle
abstract: The hawk has perched outside a second-story window to hunt for gray squirrels, despite efforts by blue jays and crows to get it to leave.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A newcomer has arrived at the White House, provoking fierce turf battles and carrying out more than one lethal confrontation in broad daylight. But this is no political power struggle; it is nature.

headline: Hundreds Missing After Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks on Yangtze
abstract: China’s official news agency said the ship sank Monday night in a storm, and as of Tuesday morning, local media reported the rescue of only a small number of people.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Most of the 458 people aboard a chartered cruise ship in China were still missing on Tuesday morning, more than a dozen hours after the vessel sank during a torrential rainstorm along the central Yangtze River, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: Rikers Island Health Care Provider May Lose Deal With New York
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Corizon, a for-profit company, has been accused by state investigators of neglecting and improperly treating inmates at the jail complex, a dozen of whom have died.
lead_paragraph: A private health care company that has been criticized for doing such a poor job at the Rikers Island jail complex that its medical performance contributed to several inmate deaths is expected to lose its contract with New York City, according to two high-ranking city officials.

headline: An Art Festival in Bushwick, Tim Burton Movies at Lincoln Center
abstract: The Bushwick Open Studios presents group exhibitions and Community Day. The David Rubenstein Atrium screens Tim Burton’s “Batman” and “Pee-wee’s Big Adventure.”
lead_paragraph: Bushwick’s art scene can seem impenetrable from the outside.

headline: Becoming Caitlyn Jenner
abstract: The transformation throughout the years it took for Bruce Jenner to become Caitlyn Jenner.
lead_paragraph: The transformation throughout the years it took for Bruce Jenner to become Caitlyn Jenner.

headline: Tanith Lee, Fantasy and Horror Novelist, Dies at 67
abstract: Ms. Lee became the first woman to win the British Fantasy Award for best novel with “Death’s Master” in 1980.
lead_paragraph: Tanith Lee, who could not read until she was 8 but started writing when she was 9 and went on to compose more than 90 science fiction, fantasy and horror novels, died on May 24 at her home in East Sussex, England. She was 67.

headline: Reflections on Stress and Long Hours on Wall Street
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Working Hours']

lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, a 22-year-old first-year analyst at the Goldman Sachs office in San Francisco was feeling overwhelmed by the all-nighters and 100-hour workweeks.

headline: Justices Curb Bankruptcy Filers’ Ability to Have Second Mortgages Canceled
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Home Equity Loans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that second mortgages may not be voided if the property is worth less than the mortgage debt.
lead_paragraph: Handing banks a victory, the Supreme Court ruled that financially struggling homeowners who file for bankruptcy may not expect to have their second mortgage loans canceled, even if they owe more on their homes than the properties are worth.

headline: Presidential Hopefuls on the N.S.A.

lead_paragraph: Here is where some of the 2016 presidential hopefuls stand on the government’s vast surveillance authority.

headline: African Countries Are Urged to Investigate Reports of Abuse by Peacekeepers
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The United Nations’ top human rights official has urged African members to prosecute what he called longstanding abuse allegations by troops sent to keep the peace in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The top human rights official at the United Nations has urged several African members to “intensify their efforts” at prosecuting what he described as longstanding allegations of egregious abuses, including summary killings, by troops they had sent to keep the peace in the Central African Republic, one of the continent’s most dysfunctional and chaotic countries.

headline: Missouri Reports Wide Racial Disparity in Traffic Stops
abstract: Officers were 75 percent more likely to stop black motorists than white motorists, according to the state attorney general.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Police officers in Missouri were 75 percent more likely to stop black drivers than white drivers last year, and 73 percent more likely to search black drivers, according to a report released Monday by Chris Koster, the state’s attorney general.

headline: Americans and Turks Discuss ISIS Threat
abstract: Officials are discussing a joint effort to clear Islamic State fighters away from Turkey’s southern border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and Turkish officials are discussing a joint effort to clear Islamic State fighters away from Turkey’s southern border, a senior State Department official said on Monday.

headline: Iran’s Nuclear Stockpile Grows, Complicating Negotiations
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Iran’s nuclear material has increased during talks with the United States, despite the Obama administration’s assertion that the program had been “frozen.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With only one month left before a deadline to complete a nuclear deal with Iran, international inspectors have reported that Tehran’s stockpile of nuclear fuel increased about 20 percent over the last 18 months of negotiations, partially undercutting the Obama administration’s contention that the Iranian program had been “frozen” during that period.

headline: FIFA Film: An Epic Fantasy
abstract: The film “United Passions,” which is making its American premiere on Friday, is a star-dappled epic about FIFA, underwritten by FIFA and portraying Sepp Blatter as a champion of ethics.
lead_paragraph: First came an international roundup of several of its top officials on federal corruption charges, including a hotel sweep down the street from its headquarters. Close behind came the pageant of its autocratic president’s re-election on a platform of: Eh, just a few bad apples.

headline: Gunplay Rises in New York, Reviving Issue for de Blasio
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Firearms', 'Gun Control', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Police']
abstract: Homicides by gunfire, seen as a key measure of preventable violence, are up steeply this year — of the 135 killings through May, 98 involved a gun.
lead_paragraph: Shootings in New York City have been rising for two straight years, the first time that has happened since the end of the 1990s, when the city was still in the early years of a remarkable downturn in crime.

headline: Seeking Rate Increases, Insurers Use Guesswork
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Many insurers say they are asking for higher premiums because they remain unsure about the future and what their medical costs will be.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of the tumult in the health insurance industry under the Affordable Care Act, companies are seeking wildly differing rate increases in premiums for 2016, with some as high as 85 percent, according to information released on Monday by the federal government for the 37 states using HealthCare.gov as their exchange.

headline: The Safety Net That Ruth Built
abstract: Babe Ruth went on an insurance-buying binge before the 1920 season, including a policy to protect against sickness or accidents that cost him $266.67, documents indicate.
lead_paragraph: In March 1920, soon after being purchased by the Yankees, Babe Ruth sought a disability insurance policy from what was then called the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company.

headline: In Debate Over Patriot Act, Lawmakers Weigh Risks vs. Liberty
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'USA PATRIOT Act']
abstract: Even if Congress restricts domestic surveillance, the counterterrorism infrastructure built in recent years has become firmly embedded in society.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just one senator voted against the Patriot Act, calling it a violation of civil liberties when it passed in the frightening, angry days after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Nearly 14 years later, 77 senators voted to advance a bill ratcheting back its expansive scope.

headline: European Leaders Assemble for Urgent Meeting on Greek Crisis
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece is under mounting pressures from many sides, and European leaders hope to help his cash-starved country swiftly meet its financial obligations.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As the Greek government faces a looming debt payment, top European leaders met in Berlin on Monday night to reach a consensus over what to do about Greece, signaling the urgent need to unlock emergency financing for the cash-starved country and avoid a devastating default.

headline: Betsy Palmer, 88, Dies; From TV Panelist to ‘Friday the 13th’ Villainess
abstract: Ms. Palmer is bound to be remembered by different generations for different career incarnations — as a live television performer, a game show panelist and a bloodthirsty camp cook.
lead_paragraph: Betsy Palmer, an actress bound to be remembered by different generations for different career incarnations — as a performer on live television, as a panelist on game shows and as one of Hollywood’s more bloodthirsty villainesses — died on Friday in hospice care near her home in Danbury, Conn. She was 88.

headline: Bluff Called, Mitch McConnell Misplays His Hand in Phone Data Fight
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: In the struggle over surveillance powers, the senator is finding that some of the new, ambitious conservatives do not adhere to the old rules of operating on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican entering his sixth month in his dream job of majority leader, the congressional struggle over National Security Agency surveillance powers produced a lose-lose-lose result.

headline: Warriors’ Andrew Bogut Seems Content With Role Defined for Him
abstract: Bogut, Golden State’s center and a former No. 1 overall pick in the N.B.A. draft, has been a rim-protecting rebounder for a team not always recognized for its stingy defense.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Andrew Bogut, the starting center for the Golden State Warriors, was watching the Cleveland Cavaliers play the Atlanta Hawks in the Eastern Conference finals on television last week when a conversation among the analysts caught his attention.

headline: South Korea: 2 Die of MERS Virus
abstract: The two patients were being treated for respiratory ailments in a hospital last month when they had contact with the nation’s first MERS patient.
lead_paragraph: Two South Koreans have died of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, the government said  Tuesday, the country’s first confirmed deaths from the virus. The two patients — a woman, 58, and a man, 71 — died Monday, the Health Ministry said in a statement. Both were being treated for respiratory ailments in a hospital last month when they had contact with the nation’s first MERS patient, a 68-year-old man who tested positive after a trip to the Middle East. South Korea has so far detected 25 MERS cases — mostly found among the hospital’s staff, patients and visitors — and more than 680 people have been placed in isolation after having contact with those infected. The syndrome has killed hundreds of people in the Middle East.

headline: Takata Says It Will No Longer Make Side Inflater Linked to Airbag Defect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The auto supplier is preparing for a congressional hearing on Tuesday where it will be asked about repairs for defective vehicles, and why it took so long to recall them.
lead_paragraph: As it prepared for a congressional hearing on Tuesday, the Japanese auto supplier Takata vowed on Monday to stop producing the driver-side inflaters that have been tied to a defect in its airbags. But the company said it would continue using an airbag propellant that experts said was dangerous.

headline: Sub
abstract: In which Bruce Haight ask us to find someone to look up to.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Anyone hungry? Pull up a chair and tuck in, because Bruce Haight is catering today’s Wordplay gathering, which is darned nice of him, if you ask me.

keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']

headline: Cuomo and de Blasio Put Their Gloves Back On

headline: Lots of Ailments but No Excuses From Rangers
