lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Amid the usual “next year will be better” chatter after their Game 7 playoff exit in the Eastern Conference finals, the Rangers are grateful there will be a next year for Mats Zuccarello.

headline: Pineda Outpitches His Old Mentor and Wins in Return to Seattle
abstract: Michael Pineda, in his first start at Seattle since the Mariners traded him, took a shutout into the seventh as the Yankees handily defeated Felix Hernandez.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In recent days, Michael Pineda’s voice had been giddy and his face expressive when he was asked about his impending return to Seattle, where on Monday night he would face Felix Hernandez, his friend, former teammate and onetime mentor.

headline: Former Ranger Brad Richards Rediscovers Postseason Success
abstract: Richards, who signed a one-year, $2 million deal with Chicago, has played a starring role as the No. 2 center on a team set to begin the Stanley Cup finals Wednesday against the Tampa Bay Lightning.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Whether he has been overlooked, overpaid or overjoyed, Chicago Blackhawks center Brad Richards has managed to stay in the playoff picture.

headline: After Punter Steve Weatherford Is in Wreck, He Practices With the Giants
abstract: Weatherford escaped serious injury when his rental car hydroplaned on the New Jersey Turnpike as he was rushing to return from the birth of his fourth child in California.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A majority of the Giants’ off-season workouts are voluntary, although in the N.F.L., where contracts are not guaranteed, attendance is expected and most players comply.

headline: A New Suite of Pure Hair Products
abstract: Susanne Kaufmann brings her hippie sensibility to the all-natural realm of haircare.
lead_paragraph: Since Susanne Kaufmann first launched her holistic skincare line over 10 years ago in her Austrian spa, her hand-packaged creams and cleansers have gained a cult following for their hippie essence: built with natural ingredients and perfumed with non-allergenic scents. Her new haircare collection — a suite of seven products to wash, condition and repair free-flowing strands — is equally pure. “Our focus was purely to encourage the natural beauty of the hair from within, hair that is strong and grows well, without any extra help or wild promises,” Kaufmann says. “Just let that hair grow and give it what it needs, and the result will be hair just as it should be.” The range uses silk and sugar-based cleansing systems and is free from synthetic additives, silicone and chemical agents. Next, Kaufmann plans to introduce styling products.

headline: Robert McKinley’s Beach-Chic Style at Home in Chelsea
abstract: The designer, hotelier, artist, creative director (and, D.J.) infused his Chelsea apartment with relics of his various design projects and a life well lived.
lead_paragraph: “This piece of wood, I can see having for the rest of my life,” says Robert McKinley, rubbing his hand along the edge of an ash wood table in the Chelsea apartment he shares with his fianceé, Kate Nauta. “Maybe it will be a bench or something else one day,” says the 38-year-old designer, hotelier, D.J., artist and creative director. “I try to reuse wood as much as possible.” The slab of wood began its life as the leftovers of a project: McKinley brought the scrap home while designing the hotel Ruschmeyer’s in Montauk. Now, it sits atop matte black powder-coated tubular steel legs in the couple’s third-floor brownstone space, where they like to entertain. “He makes fabulous pasta,” says Nauta, a model, actor and singer who just returned from the Bahamas, where she recorded her first album with Lenny Kravitz as producer.

headline: Rock Posters With a Mod Touch
abstract: A new book provides a retrospective of indie music flyers by the graphic artist Dan Stiles, who has also worked for IBM and with the President’s farm-to-table initiative.
lead_paragraph: The Portland, Ore.-based artist Dan Stiles is known for his bright colors, clean lines and witty abstractions. Over the course of his two decades as a graphic designer, he’s worked with some of the world’s most recognizable corporations (IBM, Old Navy, the X Games), reimagined book jackets by beloved 20th-century authors (Anthony Burgess, Bohumil Hrabal) and even created unique soda packaging in honor of the President’s commitment to farm-to-table eating. In his new book, “One Thing Leads to Another” ($25, PowerHouse) Stiles’s work is given a career-spanning retrospective, with full-color pages that showcase his eye-popping, overprinted style.

headline: Teenagers Seek Health Information Online, but Don’t Always Trust It
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mobile Applications', 'Research', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']

lead_paragraph: Four out of five teenagers turn to the Internet for health information, but they don’t always put much stock in what they find, according to a national survey released on Tuesday.

headline: Jacob deGrom Flirts With No-Hitter and Settles for Another Win
abstract: DeGrom retired the first 15 batters and allowed only two hits in eight innings as the Mets routed the San Diego Padres, 7-0.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Three years ago to the day, Mets Manager Terry Collins had been a nervous wreck, watching Johan Santana push past his pitch count. Santana, the Mets’ prized ace, was still working his way back from shoulder surgery, but he refused to leave the mound, and that night at Citi Field, he threw the first no-hitter in franchise history.

headline: Reining In Federal Prosecutors
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Abusive cops aren’t the only problem with the justice system. Overzealous attorneys and expansive drug laws are causing lasting damage too.
lead_paragraph: IN recent months, police departments and prison systems have been taking heat for the systemic abuses that mar our nation’s justice system. But one key player has been notably absent: For decades, our federal court system has been quietly perpetrating some of the deepest injustices in the name of the war on drugs.

headline: Vladimir Putin Hides the Truth
abstract: The president of Russia continues to insist that his soldiers and weapons are not involved in the conflict with Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: For President Vladimir Putin of Russia, the manipulation and suppression of facts is as much a tool of his war in Ukraine as an AK-47 or a rocket launcher. He continues to insist that Russian soldiers and weapons are not involved in the conflict in the eastern sector of the country, despite evidence to the contrary from NATO, the United States and independent journalists.

headline: Finding a Slave Ship, Uncovering History
abstract: A recent discovery puts the modern world in touch with the depravity of the slave trade.
lead_paragraph: The trans-Atlantic slave trade that sent 12.5 million human beings in chains from Africa to the Americas — killing about two million along the way — has been described by the historian David Brion Davis as “one of history’s greatest crimes against humanity.” It was driven not by hatred, but by greed. The colonizers — including Spaniards, Portuguese, Dutch, British, French, Danes, Swedes, Brazilians, and North Americans — wanted cheap labor for sugar, tobacco, coffee, indigo and other goods demanded by the aristocracy.

headline: For the Poor, the Graduation Gap Is Even Wider Than the Enrollment Gap
abstract: Overcoming odds in high school is just a start; poor students fall further behind affluent ones in trying to complete college.
lead_paragraph: Rich and poor students don’t merely enroll in college at different rates; they also complete it at different rates. The graduation gap is even wider than the enrollment gap.

headline: What Silicon Valley Can Learn From Seoul
abstract: South Korean companies are building software for smartphones that’s chaotic, multifunctional and exciting — everything that American apps aren’t.
lead_paragraph: Like most young people in the Bay Area, Mike Kim grew up believing that the future of technology was being forged in Silicon Valley. Raised in Piedmont, an affluent suburb of Oakland, Kim was in college during the rise of Facebook, and he watched in amazement as tech start-ups transformed the world around him. After graduating in 2006, he found work in the industry, at Zynga, Monster.com and LinkedIn.

headline: Two World War I Soldiers Posthumously Receive Medal of Honor
abstract: President Obama said the valor of the Army men — Pvt. Henry Johnson, an African-American, and Sgt. William Shemin, who was Jewish — was receiving belated recognition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday awarded the Medal of Honor to two American soldiers, one African-American and one Jewish, whose valor and sacrifice on the French front lines during World War I had not been fully recognized.

abstract: Following April’s earthquake, young Nepalis organized to bring help and hope where aid groups couldn’t.

headline: Fatal Construction Accidents Are Rising in New York
abstract: Eight people have died in construction-related accidents this year, as many as in all of 2014. Most in the industry agree that a simple equation is at work: The more construction, the more danger.
lead_paragraph: If a falling air-conditioner is one of New Yorkers’ worst fears, what happened on Sunday could have been a nightmare of mammoth proportions: A 12-ton heating and air-conditioning unit broke free from a crane and fell 30 stories to the pavement on Madison Avenue.

keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Coca (Plant)', 'Land Use Policies']

lead_paragraph: VISTA HERMOSA, Colombia — White Brahman cattle munched grass under a mango tree as Bernardo Velasco stretched out his right hand, pointing to a section of green pasture on his farm.

headline: Do You Say ‘Kind of, Sort of’ More Than You Realize?
abstract: Do you have any verbal tics or filler phrases that you overuse?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever sort of wondered what words have crept into your speech that you kind of like didn’t even notice? Perhaps you’ve caught yourself filling in pauses with “you know” or “ummm.” But what about words that hedge what you’re saying or water down your point?

headline: Few Triumphs in Frantic Hunt for 430 in Yangtze River
abstract: More than a day after the Oriental Star capsized in Hubei Province, China, most of the people on board were still missing.
lead_paragraph: JIANLI, China — Zhu Hongmei, 65, had somehow managed to work her way into an air pocket in the capsized cruise ship. She stayed there for 15 or so hours despite the cold and the currents and the darkness.

headline: Gunmen in Northern Afghanistan Kill 9 Local Aid Workers
abstract: The victims were two drivers, two guards and five staff members of the Czech charity People in Need, the group’s country director said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gunmen barged into the compound of an aid agency in northern Afghanistan early Tuesday, killing nine workers before fleeing, officials said.

headline: ‘The Making of Zombie Wars,’ by Aleksandar Hemon
abstract: Aleksandar Hemon’s comic novel about alienation and the undead.
lead_paragraph: The Summer of Love rolled into town and left behind an S.T.D. otherwise known as 1968. The Vietnam War ratcheted up the body count. Racial strife led to nationwide riots. The murders of Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy must have made the end times seem at bloody hand. Cue Nixon and that silent majority. Forty-seven years later we still live in the era’s apocalyptic shadow, those events a zombie horde in ever-present pursuit — race issues, ill-considered wars, the Russians — that infects us with the undead past. Oh, and you can also blame 1968 for that unfortunate metaphor, because in October of that year George A. Romero’s “Night of the Living Dead” introduced us to a new kind of zombie: slow yet relentless, brainless yet hungry, endlessly symbolic yet always supercool. These flesh eaters have fed well on our culture, evolving from B-movie ghouls to bankable, if thankless, stars of film and screen, book and video game, to the point where they should probably unionize. We are living in peak zombie. Now, into this fray tiptoes Aleksandar Hemon with his latest novel, “The Making of Zombie Wars.”

headline: ‘Girl at War,’ by Sara Novic
abstract: This first novel explores how the experience of war can be conveyed to those who don’t know it.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t need to experience something to remember it,” a former child soldier remarks in the final pages of Sara Novic’s outstanding first novel, “Girl at War.” She’s describing how the memory of the Yugoslav civil war will be conveyed to future generations, but she might also be describing the possibility that good literature allows: Charge language with enough vitality and its story will be remembered by readers a world away.

headline: Does the Size of a Book Suggest Significance?
abstract: Mohsin Hamid and James Parker debate whether more is necessarily more.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Mohsin Hamid and James Parker debate whether more is necessarily more.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Smart Desks to Keep You Moving
abstract: A new batch of so-called smart desks can monitor your movements, track your calories and even nudge you to stand up without interruption or loss of concentration.
lead_paragraph: You might want to sit down for this. Or stand up. Better yet, do both.

headline: The Inflationista Puzzle
abstract: Why the refusal to admit the obvious?
lead_paragraph: Martin Feldstein has a new column on what he calls the “inflation puzzle” — the failure of inflation to soar despite the Fed’s large asset purchases, which led to a very large rise in the monetary base. As Tony Yates points out, however, there’s nothing puzzling at all about what happened; it’s exactly what you should expect when interest rates are near zero.

headline: Eurozone Consumer Prices Rise for First Time in Six Months
abstract: A 0.3 percent increase in May from a year earlier was still far below the European Central Bank’s target.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Consumer prices in the eurozone rose for the first time in six months, an official report showed on Tuesday, but they remain far below the European Central Bank’s target level.

headline: New York Today: It’s Raining, It’s Pouring
abstract: Tuesday: Flash flooding (did we mention rain?) and awards for public servants (not rain-related).
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this wet Tuesday.

headline: Brookfield to Buy Center Parcs U.K. From Blackstone Group
abstract: Brookfield Property Partners will acquire the operator of five short-stay vacation sites in England, including one in Sherwood Forest.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Brookfield Property Partners said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire Center Parcs U.K., an operator of woodland resort sites in Britain, from the private equity firm Blackstone Group for an undisclosed amount.

headline: The Long Conversation
keywords: ['ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: What have 45 years of therapy with the same person given me? In short: myself.
lead_paragraph: Today, discussions about the treatment of mental health problems usually focus on medications and short-term therapies. It is almost as though we have forgotten the matchless healing power of relationships, a power that I can attest to, since I have been on the couch for almost 45 years with the same person.

headline: N.Y.U.’s Opponents Threaten Open Spaces
abstract: If the plan’s opponents succeed, municipalities will be less likely to allow their open spaces to be used for recreation and other outdoor purposes.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s Court of Appeals is scheduled to hear a challenge today to New York University’s plan to build new academic buildings. The outcome could jeopardize the way open space is used throughout the state.

headline: How the Civil War Changed the Constitution
abstract: It wasn’t just the amendments that followed the fighting. The war changed the very way Americans relate to their government.
lead_paragraph: The most obvious constitutional result of the Civil War was the adoption of three landmark constitutional amendments. The 13th ended slavery forever in the United States, while the 14th made all persons born in the United States (including the former slaves) citizens of the nation and prohibited the states from denying anyone the privileges and immunities of American citizenship, due process or law, or equal protection of the law. Finally, the 15th Amendment, ratified in 1870, prohibited the states from denying the franchise to anyone based on “race, color, or previous condition of servitude.”

headline: Americans’ Views on Money in Politics
abstract: Most Americans say that money has too much of an influence on politicians and that campaign finance changes are needed.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans say that money has too much of an influence on politicians and that campaign finance changes are needed.

headline: Testing Android Smart Watches for Travel
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Wearable Computing', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: If you want a smartwatch to make travel easier, Apple Watch is hard to beat. But what about all those Android competitors?
lead_paragraph: If you want a smartwatch to make travel easier, Apple Watch is hard to beat. But what about all those Android competitors? There are too many to list here, including models from Sony and Samsung. Still, after taking Apple Watch for a test run several weeks ago, I gave a few popular watches for Android users a whirl (one nimble contender, Pebble, is compatible with both Android and iOS devices).

keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Triathlon', 'Mountaineering', 'Cycling, Mountain Bike', 'Swimming', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']

headline: Poll Shows Americans Favor an Overhaul of Campaign Financing
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Americans of both parties reject the regime of untrammeled money in elections, but more than half are pessimistic that improvements will be made.
lead_paragraph: Americans of both parties fundamentally reject the regime of untrammeled money in elections made possible by the Supreme Court’s Citizens United ruling and other court decisions and now favor a sweeping overhaul of how political campaigns are financed, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Today in Politics: Democrats Seek an Early Start to the Endorsement Season
abstract: The three candidates officially running for president as Democrats will begin the endorsement screening process on Tuesday with the American Federation of Teachers, a union led by a longtime ally of Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. Many of the Republican candidates are heading to Disney World to discuss the economy and to try to lay a foundation in a crucial primary state. And the Democrats are also reaching out for a hold on a critical strategic cog: the American Federation of Teachers.

headline: The Migrant and Refugee Crisis
abstract: How should these mass migrations at sea be handled so as not to overwhelm nations that could provide safety?

headline: Morning Agenda: Reflections on Wall Street Culture
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Data Centers', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Reflections on Wall Street Culture | Urgent Meeting on Greek Crisis | Rising Costs of Chips Spur Semiconductor Mergers | Consumer Advocacy Group Hires Top House Aide
lead_paragraph: REFLECTIONS ON WALL STREET CULTURE | Last week, Thomas J. Hughes, a 29-year-old banker at Moelis & Company, was found dead with drugs in his system after falling from a building in Manhattan. In April, Sarvshreshth Gupta, a 24-year-old first-year analyst at Goldman Sachs, was found dead in San Francisco after telling his father about suffering from intense stress. The official cause of death has not yet been determined in either case, but a recent string of deaths among young Wall Street workers have prompted financial firms to re-evaluate their work policies’ impact on staff members,  Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. It’s difficult to definitively link a death to a firm’s work conditions, and Mr. Sorkin notes that studies have suggested that financial service employees are at higher risk than those in many other industries. “Still, the string of deaths on Wall Street appears to rise above the level of simple coincidence,” he writes.

headline: Serious Eats and Roadfood Are Sold to Fexy Media
abstract: The two food-focused websites, which are largely associated with food at diners, noodle shops, pizzerias, taquerias and neighborhood bakeries, are being bought by the Seattle-based company.

headline: In Performance: Germán Jaramillo of ‘Hierba Mala Nunca Muere’ (in Spanish)

lead_paragraph: This week’s video features Germán Jaramillo in a Spanish-language excerpt from “Hierba Mala Nunca Muere” (“Weeds Just Won’t Die”), a farce by Juan Claudio Lechín at Repertorio Español. Set in Cuba, the show is a comedic look at Fidel Castro (Mr. Jaramillo) as he rants about his country’s future from his deathbed. “The pain I feel is a feline that is clawing at my heart,” he says.

headline: Bernie Sanders Finds Appreciative Audience on Late Night TV

abstract: For the first time, I feel that whether we have BlueJay for a month or a year or a lifetime, it doesn’t matter. At least we have this.
lead_paragraph: The sun is shining bright and warm as my foster son, BlueJay, and I cross the parking lot, hand-in-hand.

headline: Sepp Blatter Decides to Resign as FIFA President in About-Face
abstract: Four days after he was re-elected, Mr. Blatter said that he would resign his presidency of world soccer’s governing body in the wake of a corruption inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Sepp Blatter, who led world soccer’s governing body for 17 years and who was regarded as one of the most powerful people in global sports, said Tuesday that he would resign his position. He made his announcement in Zurich as law enforcement officials in the United States confirmed that he was a focus of a federal corruption investigation.

headline: A Snarled Route to Driver’s Licenses for Immigrants in Colorado
abstract: Though the state began handling driver’s license applications from undocumented immigrants, they face extended waits and long trips to the handful of offices granting them.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — For weeks, Fernando Gonzalez stayed up until 3 a.m., reloading a state government web page to snag a scarce appointment for his wife, Mara, to get her driver’s license. They came here illegally from Mexico nine years ago, and they are among the hundreds of thousands queuing up across the country as states expand driver’s license programs for undocumented immigrants.

headline: 1915: Attempt to Soothe Wilson Fails
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: German ambassador, Von Bernstorff fails to appease President Wilson in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In an effort to soften the effect of Germany’s heartless reply to the Lusitania Note, Count Bernstorff, the German Ambassador in Washington, is reported to have called on President Wilson to-day, and, although the President would not even give a hint of the object of the Ambassador’s call, cablegrams received here agree that Count Bernstorff assured the President that the Kaiser does not want war with the United States.

lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece elevated the game of brinkmanship with its international lenders on Tuesday, as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced that his government had sent creditors a new proposal, on Greece’s own terms, to unlock financial aid that the struggling nation desperately needs.

lead_paragraph: To understand the true chameleon that is Jason Derulo, it’s instructive to start with “Broke,” a collaboration with Mr. Derulo, Stevie Wonder and Keith Urban. There are no typos or factual errors in that sentence.

headline: U.S. Surveillance in Place Since 9/11 Is Sharply Limited
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'USA Freedom Act', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Trying to Overcome a Devastating Loss in Turkey
abstract: People in Elmadere, Turkey, are still grieving a year after an explosion and fire in a coal mine in nearby Soma killed 301 men in the deadliest industrial accident in the country’s modern history.
lead_paragraph: People in Elmadere, Turkey, are still grieving a year after an explosion and fire in a coal mine in nearby Soma killed 301 men in the deadliest industrial accident in the country’s modern history.

headline: Anger and Grief Simmer in Turkey a Year After Soma Mine Disaster
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Soma, Turkey, Mining Disaster (2014)', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Widows and Widowers', 'Reparations']
abstract: Widows of coal miners say they have been left to face the future on their own after an explosion and fire at a mine in Soma killed 301 men in May 2014.
lead_paragraph: ELMADERE, Turkey — Through the lace curtains of her window, Beyhan Yilmaz cannot help but see the raw gash of the new coal mine carved through the green hills near her village. She is stung by the sight.

headline: Review: ‘Entourage,’ the Screen Is Bigger, but Nothing Is Better
abstract: By the time the show reached the end of its HBO run in 2011, it had grown staler than last night’s Axe body spray. The passing of a few more years has not improved the aroma.
lead_paragraph: “Entourage” begins in the waters off Ibiza, with a yacht party attended by many women, some of whom seem to have misplaced their bikini tops. The host is Vince Chase (Adrian Grenier), the movie star whose short marriage has just ended in a no-hard-feelings split. Also in attendance are his half brother Johnny (Kevin Dillon) and their pals Turtle (Jerry Ferrara) and Eric (Kevin Connolly), who is also Vince’s manager. A phone call raises Ari Gold (Jeremy Piven), Vince’s longtime agent who is coming out of retirement to run a studio.

headline: A.C.L.U. Asks Judge to Force Improvements at Baltimore Jail
abstract: Despite assurances that conditions would be improved, Maryland still keeps inmates in buildings where unsanitary conditions spread disease, a court filing says.
lead_paragraph: Despite longstanding assurances that conditions would be improved in the Baltimore jail, the State of Maryland still keeps inmates in fetid buildings where heat and unsanitary conditions spread disease, and delays in care for mental and physical ailments have led to unnecessary suffering, according to a court filing on Tuesday by the American Civil Liberties Union.

headline: What Caitlyn Jenner Can Teach Our Daughters
abstract: Caitlyn Jenner looks great on the cover of Vanity Fair—and there’s a lesson in that.
lead_paragraph: Magazine covers can often start conversations with children what with their lurid headlines and provocative imagery. I frequently find them hard to explain: There is no really comprehensible answer, for an 8-year-old, to the question of why the girl on the cover of Sports Illustrated is taking off her swimsuit bottom. (And there’s really no comprehensible answer for me about why our general store stacked those up next to the brownie mix).

headline: Jean Ritchie, Lyrical Voice of Appalachia, Dies at 92
abstract: Ms. Ritchie brought hundreds of traditional songs from her native Appalachia to a wide audience and performed with major names in folk music, including Pete Seeger and Doc Watson.
lead_paragraph: Jean Ritchie, who brought hundreds of traditional songs from her native Appalachia to a wide audience — singing of faith and unfaithfulness, murder and revenge, love unrequited and love lost — and in the process helped ignite the folk song revival of the mid-20th century, died on Monday at her home in Berea, Ky. She was 92.

headline: 3 Teenagers Are Arrested in Rape in Chinatown
abstract: The 16-year-olds, who live in a Boys Town residence in Brooklyn, were charged with raping and robbing a woman they encountered at an Internet cafe, the police said.
lead_paragraph: At 5:10 a.m. Monday, a woman, beaten and bleeding, stumbled into a corner deli in Chinatown. Minutes earlier, the police said, three 16-year-olds the woman had just met at an Internet cafe a block and a half away attacked her, and two raped and robbed her.

headline: Speeding Up Hardware Through an Accelerator and Marketplace
abstract: The manufacturer that bought the once-hot ecommerce website Fab has an innovative way of developing new hardware companies. Some of the products from the hardware start-ups may soon be put into the online marketplace.
lead_paragraph: The cool things now in hacker space are physical products, like personalized drone racing, centrifugal force-brewed coffee, and hyper-efficient air purifiers that use ultraviolet light.

headline: Instagram to Open Its Photo Feed to Ads
abstract: The mobile photo sharing service, which has been mostly ad-free, is opening its feed to all advertisers and allowing them to target its users demographically.
lead_paragraph: Instagram is cranking up its money machine, and that means a lot more ads in your photo feed.

headline: Morels and Peas Are Pasta’s Springtime Companions
abstract: Pair morels with pasta, peas, Parmesan and butter for a fast and satisfying meal.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to so-called luxury ingredients, wild mushrooms are among the most accessible, for a couple of reasons. One, if you have the energy and a guide and the right location, you can forage for them. O.K., very few of us are going to do that. Alternatively, you buy them, and in those places where the foraging is local the price isn’t at all outrageous, especially because a little can go a long way.

headline: Disney Unveils Playmation, Toys That Play Back
abstract: Disney’s new Playmation uses wireless systems, motion sensors and wearable technology to engage children with interactive missions.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif. — For more than two years, inside a Walt Disney laboratory built to resemble a child’s bedroom, grade schoolers have been secretly testing an at-home version of Iron Man’s high-tech armor.

headline: Tsonga Scratches Out a Win, and a Roland Garros Love Note
abstract: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga saluted the home crowd after outlasting Kei Nishikori to advance to the French Open semifinals, where he will meet Stan Wawrinka, a victor over Roger Federer.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a match dented by collapses of all sorts, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga managed to fall to the ground in joy in the end.

headline: Lawmakers Press Takata on Propellant in Airbags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Calling the messaging around the recalls “tortured at best,” lawmakers expressed frustration with both the airbag maker and a federal auto safety agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as Takata, the Japanese auto supplier, has acknowledged that its airbags are prone to rupture and has vastly expanded their recall, it has maintained that the underlying explosive that powers the airbags can be used safely.

headline: Debate Over Government Surveillance

headline: Hamas Forces Kill Leader of Islamic Splinter Group in Gaza
abstract: The fatal shooting came amid a campaign by Hamas to crack down on groups that follow the more radical Salafist stream of Islam, some of whom now adhere to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — The local leader of an extremist Islamic splinter group was fatally shot Tuesday in a clash with Hamas forces who had come to arrest him. The death raised tensions in Gaza at a time when Hamas, which controls the territory, has been cracking down on radical jihadists.

headline: Scott Walker Vows to Compete in Florida
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin promised to compete in the Florida presidential primary, even though two favorite sons, Senator Marco Rubio and former Gov. Jeb Bush, are expected to try hard to win the state.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. – Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin wants to make sure everyone knows he loves Florida.

lead_paragraph: Looks from the collection.

headline: Automakers Report May Sales Beat Forecasts
abstract: Easier consumer credit, gas prices and new models kept demand strong during the month, with pickups and S.U.V.s driving sales.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Automakers on Tuesday reported that sales of new vehicles in May exceeded forecasts and reached the highest seasonally adjusted rate in nearly a decade.

headline: An Easy Broth That Stands In for Fish Stock
abstract: Anchovies, pounded with garlic and almonds, enhance a halibut dish that follows a classic sear and simmer braising procedure.
lead_paragraph: It’s amazing what you can do with a couple of anchovies. I wanted to make a one-pot meal with fresh Alaskan halibut that did not require the extra time and ingredients for a fish stock. But I did want broth that tasted of the sea, so I did what many cooks in Southern France and Italy do, and pounded anchovies in a mortar and pestle with garlic. I also pounded almonds for body and texture.

headline: City Point Project in Brooklyn Gets Unlikely Partner in Extell
abstract: Known for high-priced condos in Manhattan, the Extell Development Company signed a deal to build a rental tower at City Point with 500 units.
lead_paragraph: City Point, a major development in Downtown Brooklyn, is offering touches that seem to cater to Brooklyn’s homespun, forward-thinking spirit: a movie theater that serves beer. A reinvented shopping mall. A food hall for start-up restaurateurs.

headline: Understanding the Rate Increases for Health Care Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Requests for rate increases can be misleading, and some that look hefty now may turn out to be more modest once regulators weigh in.
lead_paragraph: Insurance companies have begun announcing rate increases for the health care plans they will sell next year on the Obamacare marketplaces, and a handy new website from the federal government makes searching for rate change requests easier than ever.

headline: Investigating Why the Oriental Star Capsized on the Yangtze River
abstract: At about 9:20 p.m. that evening, the Oriental Star had passed a cargo ship that had anchored to wait out the storm.
lead_paragraph: At about 9:20 p.m. that evening, the Oriental Star had passed a cargo ship that had anchored to wait out the storm.

headline: Verbatim: Two Retired Democrats Are Winners With Republicans
abstract: “We hope it will be properly aired out after our departure.” — John Dingell, remarking on the spectacle of two Democrats (himself and Carl Levin) receiving the Gerald R. Ford Medal for Distinguished Public Service at the National Republican Club of Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: — Former Representative John Dingell, remarking on the spectacle of two Democrats (himself and former Senator Carl Levin, both from Michigan) receiving the Gerald R. Ford Medal for Distinguished Public Service at a dinner Monday at the National Republican Club of Capitol Hill.

headline: Breaking Up Companies Creates Extensive Costs, Too
abstract: If companies are going to fight activist investors who call for breakups or spinoffs, they should also be more honest about downsides of mergers.
lead_paragraph: Acquisitive corporate chieftains love to talk about “synergies” from the deals they’re planning while they de-emphasize costs. On the flip side, managers who are trying to resist pressure to split their companies may overstate the “dis-synergies” such moves would create, but such costs are still real.

headline: Do Millennials Need Fun Banking?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Millennial Generation', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The startup Qapital aims to make banking simpler, but will it actually help young people save?
lead_paragraph: “We believe that banking should make your life better,” reads the frequently-asked-questions page on the website of the startup Qapital.

abstract: The defendant, Shabaka Shakur, is serving two consecutive prison terms in a case investigated by the retired detective Louis Scarcella, whose work has been under review by Brooklyn authorities.
lead_paragraph: In a decision released on Tuesday, a judge ordered a new trial for Shabaka Shakur, a man serving two consecutive terms of 20 years to life for a 1988 double homicide in Brooklyn.

headline: Anti-ISIS Coalition Makes Little Progress at Paris Meeting
abstract: The coalition of countries arrayed against the Islamic State has been hobbled by a variety of weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With Islamist militant fighters on the ground in Syria and Iraq moving faster than the international coalition arrayed against them, a meeting in Paris by coalition members on Tuesday seemed unlikely to reverse the momentum anytime soon.

headline: Pinterest Brings E-Commerce to Social Scrapbooking With ‘Buy It’ Button
abstract: Pinterest, the online scrapbooking site, enters the ecommerce realm with a “Buyable Pins” button that enables people to purchase items through its site.
lead_paragraph: Pinterest, the online social scrapbooking service, has long claimed to help people discover new things in the real world. Soon users will be able to buy those things, too.

headline: Boko Haram Steps Up Attacks in Northeast Nigeria, Killing Scores
abstract: The intensification of the attacks, including a suicide bombing on Tuesday, began less than a week after Nigeria’s new president vowed to crush the group.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Less than a week after Muhammadu Buhari, a former army general, took over as Nigeria’s president and vowed to crush Boko Haram, the group has intensified its attacks in the country’s northeast, killing scores in a series of assaults and suicide bombings.

headline: Rand Paul Begins to Make Believers Out of His Father’s Supporters
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act']
abstract: Backers of Ron Paul, who had been reluctant to support his son Rand, are warming up to Rand Paul’s positions on the N.S.A. and on foreign intervention.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is usually no quicker way to make Rand Paul’s face pucker than to ask him how he is different from his father. That is because for the better part of four years, the Kentucky Republican has tried to create a political identity distinct from the man whose legacy provided the foundation for his success.

headline: High Line Founder to Lead World Monuments Fund
abstract: Joshua David, who founded Friends of the High Line with Robert Hammond in 1999, will succeed Bonnie Burnham.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine Joshua David moving on from Friends of the High Line, which he founded in 1999 with Robert Hammond. But now he is starting a new chapter as president of the World Monuments Fund, making him the third leader in that organization’s 50-year history.

headline: Why Americans Hate Cable Companies
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Television']
abstract: Phone and satellite companies may be trying just a little harder to please their customers.
lead_paragraph: Not that there should have ever been any doubt, but consumers like competition.

headline: Dueling Claims From Herbalife and Hedge Fund

lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman made a billion-dollar bet that Herbalife was a “pyramid scheme.” Now both sides are spending millions of dollars shaping the public narrative and federal investigations.

headline: Philip Glass to Perform Inside a Richard Serra Installation
abstract: Mr. Glass and the violinist Tim Fain will play a special concert inside Mr. Serra’s heavy-duty installation at the David Zwirner Gallery.
lead_paragraph: The composer Philip Glass once worked as an assistant for the sculptor Richard Serra, after the two befriended each other in Paris in the early 1960s and swapped cultural touchstones. “Phil took me to see Buster Keaton films,” Mr. Serra told The New Yorker, “and I took him to Brancusi’s studio.”

headline: Monks, Wine and Caffeine: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Reporter Stephen Castle shares some of the story behind the story of a Benedictine monastery that makes caffeinated wines.
lead_paragraph: In Europe, monks and alcohol share a long history; after all, one of the pioneers of winemaking techniques used in champagne was Dom Pérignon, a Benedictine monk.

headline: White House Meeting Elicits Pledges to Reduce Antibiotic Use
abstract: The forum, attended by representatives of hospitals, food producers, professional medical societies and restaurant chains, highlighted the problem of antibiotic resistance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration convened representatives of hospitals, food producers, professional medical societies and restaurant chains on Tuesday and extracted pledges to reduce the use of lifesaving antibiotics, whose effectiveness is waning because of overuse.

headline: Paris Police Clear Out Migrant Camp and Destroy Tents
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Police']
abstract: The camp in north central Paris held 380 people, mostly from East Africa, who were moved to housing for asylum seekers or shelters.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French police evacuated hundreds of migrants from a camp in Paris early Tuesday in the latest attempt to control a growing population of migrants arriving on European shores after crossing the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Macedonia to Hold Early Elections Amid Political Turmoil
abstract: The agreement to hold elections in April was announced after eight hours of negotiations. The government has been under fire for months over a wiretapping scandal.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Macedonia will hold early elections next April under a tentative deal to defuse a political crisis that has been rocking the country for months, a mediator said.

headline: Head Scarves Before the Supreme Court
abstract: The Abercrombie & Fitch case should be a reminder to all employers that inclusiveness is the best policy.
lead_paragraph: “This is really easy,” Justice Antonin Scalia said on Monday morning as he announced the Supreme Court’s 8-to-1 decision in favor of a Muslim woman who was denied a job at the clothing-store chain Abercrombie & Fitch because her head scarf violated the company’s “Look Policy.”

headline: ‘Dames at Sea’ Will Sail to Broadway This Fall
abstract: “Dames at Sea,” which helped make Bernadette Peters known, will arrive on Broadway for the first time this fall.
lead_paragraph: “Dames at Sea,” the musical that gave Bernadette Peters her big break more than 40 years ago, will finally arrive on Broadway at the Helen Hayes Theater this fall.

headline: Restaurants Add Reservation Cancellation Fees to the Menu
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Reservations (Airlines, Hotels, Etc.)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: The dark secret of credit card charges for no-show diners is that almost no one has to pay them.
lead_paragraph: Booking a table used to feel pretty good. Sure, it wasn’t always easy to get the time and date we wanted, but once we did, there was a sense of accomplishment. And most of the time, the call ended with the first sweet embrace of hospitality, as the nice person on the phone promised your table would be waiting and the whole staff would be looking forward to your arrival.

headline: Chief Says I.R.S. Struggles to Stay Ahead of Online Attackers
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The head of the Internal Revenue Service said the agency was hamstrung in protecting taxpayer identities by software so antiquated that its makers are no longer updating it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Koskinen, the head of the Internal Revenue Service, on Tuesday attributed a recent online attack that exposed the information of more than 100,000 taxpayers to the agency’s inability to keep up with increasingly sophisticated threats.

headline: MRI Report
abstract: The patient’s MRI report.
lead_paragraph: The patient’s MRI report.

headline: At Ruschmeyer’s Summer Surf-Art Installation, Hotel Guests Are Invited to Pitch In
abstract: The mosaic artist Jason Dussault will begin a four-week residency at the Montauk lodge this month.
lead_paragraph: “I believe some of the best of art is born from a juxtaposition that makes you smile,” says the artist Jason Dussault, who this summer will spend four weeks creating a surf-inspired art installation in an on-site residency at Ruschmeyer’s hotel — a “commune for the cool,” as Dussault puts it. Dussault will be setting up his temporary workspace and makeshift showroom in the communal lawn, the Magic Garden, at the center of the boutique hotel’s 19 guest rooms; among the picnic and Ping-Pong tables, he’ll be creating and displaying mosaic sculptures on vintage surfboards. Using canvases sourced from eBay and local surf shops, the work Dussault is creating for the series, “Off Duty,” portrays Lego-like superheroes on vacation — a Lego Wolverine, for example, wearing a “Kiss the Cook” BBQ apron and using his talons as shish kebabs.

headline: Klimt’s ‘Portrait of Gertrud Loew’ to Be Auctioned
abstract: The 1902 painting, which has been in private hands for over a century, is estimated at $18 million to $28 million.
lead_paragraph: London — A painting by Gustav Klimt that has been in private hands for over a century will be auctioned at Sotheby’s Impressionist and Modern Art Evening Sale here on June 24. The work, “Portrait of Gertrud Loew,” painted in 1902, has an estimated sale price of 12 million to 18 million pounds (about $18 million to $28 million), and is for sale as a result of a settlement between the Felsovanyi family, the heirs of the painting’s subject, and the Klimt Foundation.

headline: U.S. Envoy Held Talks With Houthi Rebels of Yemen
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Anne W. Patterson, the American envoy, met last week in Oman with the Houthis to discuss violence in Yemen and the capture of several Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior State Department official held talks last week with the Houthi rebels of Yemen, opening a new round of diplomacy aimed at persuading the warring factions in that country to participate in a peace conference in Geneva, American officials said Tuesday.

headline: Texas Lawmakers Pass a Bill Allowing Guns at Colleges
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Gun Control', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: The campus-carry bill, expected to be signed by Gov. Greg Abbott, affects licensed gun users at public and private universities.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Students and faculty members at public and private universities in Texas could be allowed to carry concealed handguns into classrooms, dormitories and other buildings under a bill passed over the weekend by the Republican-dominated Legislature. The measure is being hailed as a victory by gun rights advocates and criticized by many students and professors as irresponsible and unnecessary.

headline: Support for the European Union Is Rising, Survey Suggests
abstract: A poll carried out in France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Spain and Britain found that a more resilient European economy was helping to restore faith in the bloc.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Faith in the European Union is reviving in Europe, even as parties that are skeptical of the bloc threaten to divide and polarize the Continent, according to a new survey by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Cause of Amtrak Train’s Speeding Still Unknown, Panel Is Told
abstract: Regulators told Congress they were still working to understand why the train was traveling at double the designated speed when it derailed last month, killing eight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators told Congress on Tuesday that they were still working to understand why an Amtrak train was traveling at double the designated speed when it derailed in Philadelphia last month, killing eight people and injuring about 200.

headline: Congress Holds Hearing on Amtrak Crash

headline: Mitch McConnell’s N.S.A. Debacle
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Law and Legislation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: He’s gone from opposing a House bill to overhaul the agency to urging the Senate to amend it — just not too much.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a bad few days for Republican defenders of the late-2001, be-very-afraid, security-trumps-liberty mindset, the one that gave us the Patriot Act, the Iraq War, Gitmo, Abu Ghraib, warrantless wiretapping, the vast collection of Americans’ phone-call “metadata” and the overwhelming sense that this government — specifically the eavesdropping trolls at the National Security Agency — is not to be trusted.

headline: Review: Mark Vanhoenacker’s ‘Skyfaring: A Journey With a Pilot’ on Joy of Flight
abstract: Mr. Vanhoenacker’s first book is an unusual entry into the air travel genre. For one, he is a commercial pilot. For another, he doesn’t speak of flying disasters.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade when I was in my 20s and 30s, I was terrified to fly. Like John Updike’s character Henry Bech, I had an especially morbid fear of “being dropped from the tail-end lavatory.” Sometimes I made it as far as the boarding gate with my ticket before turning back in shame, also in relief, to head to the bus or train station.

headline: Greece’s Alliances Fade in European Debate About Its Debt Crisis
abstract: The promise of the leftist Greek government to roll back German-led austerity policies has met an unexpectedly unified opposition.
lead_paragraph: ROME — If Europe is finally coming to a moment of reckoning in the Greek debt crisis — a standoff now rattling financial markets and threatening European unity — then the critical meeting apparently occurred late Monday night, when Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany summoned critical players to an emergency summit meeting in Berlin. Everyone was invited, except Greece.

headline: Detective Charged in Biker Attack Says He Fled Because He Was Scared
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Hit-and-Run Drivers']
abstract: Wojciech Braszczok, testifying in his own defense, said that he was frightened for his own safety and did not intervene to help the driver in the 2013 assault in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: An undercover New York City police detective accused of being one of 11 motorcyclists who assaulted a driver in Upper Manhattan testified on Tuesday that he became frightened for his own safety when he saw the man being pummeled and fled instead of intervening to help him.

headline: Review: ‘A Pigeon Sat on a Branch,’ Roy Andersson’s Rumination on Life
abstract: Mr. Andersson’s signature style as a writer and director comes through in “A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence.”
lead_paragraph: “A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence” begins with three vignettes on death. In one of them, a man has expired in a cafeteria on board some kind of ferry or cruise ship. Officers and passengers stand around him with expressions of concern, but the server has a more practical worry: what to do with the beer and the shrimp sandwich the dead customer had already paid for. A stout older gentleman shuffles forward. “I guess I’ll take the beer,” he says with a shrug.

headline: Blatter’s Fall Leads to Rejoicing Online From His Critics
abstract: Sepp Blatter had the support of soccer officials but was broadly unpopular with fans of the game, so his fall was greeted with some glee.
lead_paragraph: Sepp Blatter’s sudden announcement that he would resign as president of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, after 17 years, triggered a global wave of reaction on social networks on Tuesday.

headline: Research Pays When New Grads Buy a Car

abstract: College graduates have a lot to consider when buying their first car.
lead_paragraph: After graduating from college, many young adults rush to buy a car. But there is a lot to consider before you take on the expense of your own set of wheels.

headline: Off-the-Leash Summer Looks
abstract: In this exclusive photo shoot for Men’s Style, we share the Menswear Dog’s looks for making a statement at destination weddings.
lead_paragraph: In this exclusive photo shoot for Men’s Style, we share the Menswear Dog’s looks for making a statement at destination weddings.

headline: Review: ‘Every Last Child,’ a Front-Line View of the Polio Crisis in Pakistan
abstract: Tom Roberts’s documentary examines the struggles of health workers in Pakistan to vaccinate children against polio in the face of mistrust and Taliban attacks.
lead_paragraph: “Every Last Child,” a compelling documentary by Tom Roberts, gives a street-level view of the polio crisis in Pakistan, where that crippling virus remains endemic. While a program by the World Health Organization goes door to door administering oral vaccinations to infants, Pakistani Taliban militants have killed dozens of health workers since 2012.

headline: Rikers Inquiry Expands to Include Union Chief’s Financial Dealings
abstract: Federal prosecutors are looking into whether Norman Seabrook, president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, enriched himself in his two decades running the union, according to a copy of a subpoena.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have opened a new front in their investigation of Rikers Island, embarking on a far-reaching examination of the financial dealings of Norman Seabrook, the powerful president of New York City’s correction officers’ union.

headline: Review: Interpreting Gertrude Stein in ‘Composition ... Master-Pieces ... Identity’
abstract: David Greenspan’s all-Stein solo show at the Connelly Theater consists of two lectures, one poem and a string of insights from the years between the wars.
lead_paragraph: Genius or crackpot? Your opinion of Gertrude Stein, in case you hadn’t already formed a firm one, may zigzag between those poles, ultimately landing somewhere in between, as you listen to David Greenspan‘s fascinating new exploration of this singular writer’s work. “Composition ... Master-Pieces ... Identity,” presented by Target Margin Theater at the Connelly Theater, consists of three pieces of Stein’s writings — two lectures and a poem — read or performed by Mr. Greenspan, who also conceived the show.

headline: Jeb Bush on His ‘Good Friend Marco.’ Rubio, That Is.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio railed against “outdated leaders” in recorded remarks at an Economic Growth Summit in Florida, but Jeb Bush said he did not think the remarks were directed at him.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. – Senator Marco Rubio railed against “outdated leaders” in a recorded video shown at the Economic Growth Summit on Tuesday morning. But Jeb Bush said he did not think the remarks were directed at him.

headline: Chevron and North Sea Rivals Race to Keep an Oil Region Relevant
abstract: Oil producers in Britain are contending with plummeting prices as they seek new ways to bolster the aging infrastructure of the North Sea industry.
lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, Scotland — Even before Craig May, a longtime Chevron executive, moved to this North Sea port city two summers ago, he knew that the oil wealth in Britain’s waters was on the steepening slope of a decades-long decline.

headline: Sale of Old Masters Sets Off an Outcry in Ireland
abstract: A plan to sell off nine works from the art collection at Russborough House, including two paintings by Rubens, has sparked protest.
lead_paragraph: Over the past four decades, the art collection at Russborough House has drawn both the attention of I.R.A. thieves and the interest of more than a million visitors to this 18th-century Georgian mansion near Dublin.

headline: Decline of North Sea Oil Fields Forces Political Shifts in Britain
abstract: The dropping revenue has inspired changes of tactics by British leaders as well as Scottish nationalists, who had counted on oil as an economic mainstay.
lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, Scotland — For the oil industry, the decline of the North Sea fields is part of a global challenge.

headline: Who Will Succeed Sepp Blatter?
abstract: A look at the possible candidates to succeed FIFA president Sepp Blatter.
lead_paragraph: A look at the possible candidates to succeed FIFA president Sepp Blatter.

headline: Review: American Ballet Theater Revives ‘La Bayadère’ Using Familiar Choreography
abstract: Marius Petipa’s 1877 ballet returns to the Metropolitan Opera House, using Natalia Makarova’s demure version of the choreography.
lead_paragraph: One of the sovereign images of ballet classicism is — or can be — the processional entrance of the female corps de ballet of spectral Shades in Marius Petipa’s 1877 ballet “La Bayadère.” Slowly, one after another, the women descend a ramp onto the stage until their zigzag formation fills the floor. Tick-tock, tick-tock: tick (they lean forward, raising a stretched leg behind them in arabesque), tock (they arch back with arms framing their heads in halo shapes); tick-tock, forward and back. It’s an accumulation, and it’s mesmerizing.

headline: Prosecutor Says Police, Not Boston Bombers, Probably Shot Transit Officer
abstract: The district attorney said it was “highly likely” that Richard Donohue was accidentally struck by officers, but that using deadly force was justified.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The transit officer who nearly bled to death during a chaotic shootout with the Boston Marathon bombers in 2013 was most likely wounded by police gunfire, the Middlesex County district attorney said Tuesday.

headline: Mississippi Cuts Work Program for Prisoners
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: State prisoners have been shifted to county jails to perform services for local governments, but the cost has been deemed burdensome for many state budgets.
lead_paragraph: POPLARVILLE, Miss. — With the lunch hour near and the temperature in the 80s, the only souls in sight outside the courthouse here were two men taking turns aiming a pressure washer’s nozzle at the steps of the building.

headline: Mark Rylance and ‘Streetcar’ Are Part of St. Ann’s New Season
abstract: St. Ann’s Warehouse announces its 2015-16 season, which is scheduled to be presented in its new home, the Tobacco Warehouse in Brooklyn Bridge Park.
lead_paragraph: St. Ann’s Warehouse, the nonprofit Off Broadway theater that after a long battle is preparing to move into a new home in Brooklyn, announced on Tuesday that its next season will feature a play starring Mark Rylance, an opera by Enda Walsh, and contemporary stagings of classics by Shakespeare and Tennessee Williams.

headline: Chris Hughes, Publisher of The New Republic, to Hold a Fund-Raiser for Hillary Clinton
abstract: Chris Hughes, the publisher of The New Republic, and his husband, Sean Eldridge, will hold a fund-raiser for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign, two people briefed on the invitation said.
lead_paragraph: Chris Hughes, the publisher of The New Republic, and his husband, Sean Eldridge, will hold a fund-raiser for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign, two people briefed on the invitation said.

headline: Girls Rule in an Indian Village
abstract: In the remote village Mawlynnong, a matrilineal society inspired a photographer to make portraits of self-assured young women.
lead_paragraph: In the remote village Mawlynnong, a matrilineal society inspired a photographer to make portraits of self-assured young women.

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Nubank Raises $30 Million to Challenge Banking in Brazil
abstract: The company offers a digital credit card and looks to take business from banks that have benefited from some of the world’s highest interest rates.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Nubank, the financial technology start-up founded by a former partner at Sequoia Capital, said on Tuesday that it had raised $30 million in a new funding round led by Tiger Global Management.

headline: Living In NoHo
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: New buildings are popping up, some of them sleek high-rises, while 19th-century industrial buildings are being transformed into luxury residences.
lead_paragraph: New buildings are popping up, some of them sleek high-rises, while 19th-century industrial buildings are being transformed into luxury residences.

headline: A Chef Shares Stories and Recipes From His Family Farm in Martha’s Vineyard
abstract: In a new cookbook, Chris Fischer returns home and recalls the 12 generations, and dishes, that came before him.
lead_paragraph: In “The Beetlebung Farm Cookbook” ($35, Little, Brown), the chef and farmer Chris Fischer pairs each recipe with a story. Together, these paint a picture of Martha’s Vineyard, where his family has lived for 12 generations, and his family’s farm there, which his grandfather built on a 5-acre corner plot near Menemsha Harbor in Chilmark.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: We’re trying something new: a quick rundown of the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new: a quick rundown of the day’s top stories.

headline: The Woman Behind Caitlyn Jenner’s Vanity Fair Cover
abstract: Jessica Diehl, the magazine’s fashion and style director, explains the extraordinary efforts that resulted in a cover that set the world atwitter.
lead_paragraph: As dramatic entrances go, it didn’t lag far behind that of Venus emerging from the foam.

headline: Ackman Takes Stake in Nomad Foods, an Acquisition Vehicle
abstract: Pershing Square Capital Management owns 22 percent of the special purpose acquisition company, co-founded by Martin Franklin and Noam Gottesman.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor William A. Ackman has taken a large stake in Nomad Foods Limited, a company that acquires food businesses.

headline: The Downloaders
abstract: In the ‘digital bamako’ markets of Mali, vendors fill old phones with new songs — and jump-start a homegrown musical community.
lead_paragraph: In the ‘digital bamako’ markets of Mali, vendors fill old phones with new songs — and jump-start a homegrown musical community.

lead_paragraph: An occasional series on vintage comics.
