lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: A Conversation With Amale Andraos
abstract: Ms. Andraos is dean of Columbia University’s Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation, and a founding principal with her husband, Dan Wood, of the architecture firm WORKac.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Andraos, 42, is the newly appointed dean of Columbia University’s Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation. She is also a founding principal, with her husband, Dan Wood, of WORKac, an architecture firm based in New York whose local projects include “edible schoolyards” in public schools and a new condominium conversion in TriBeCa.

headline: Bequest Issue Arises in New York City Opera Bankruptcy Case
abstract: Lawyers in the case said that they were exploring whether the company could be reorganized so it could emerge from bankruptcy and accept a multimillion dollar bequest from a benefactor.
lead_paragraph: The long-running court battle over the remains of the bankrupt New York City Opera took a new turn on Tuesday. Lawyers in the case said in court that they were exploring whether the company could be reorganized so it could emerge from bankruptcy and accept a multimillion dollar bequest from a benefactor who died during the troupe’s last days.

headline: Chimpanzees Would Cook if Given the Chance, Research Says
abstract: Scientists from Harvard and Yale found that chimpanzees would give up raw food on the possibility that it might emerge cooked later. [Article plus video.]
lead_paragraph: Chimpanzees have the cognitive ability to cook, according to new research, if only someone would give them ovens.

headline: ScienceTake | Could Chimps Cook?
abstract: Almost. Scientists found that chimpanzees have the patience and foresight to hold off on eating raw food and put it in a device that seems to cook it.
lead_paragraph: Almost. Scientists found that chimpanzees have the patience and foresight to hold off on eating raw food and put it in a device that seems to cook it.

headline: On Gray Day, American Pharoah Takes Up Residence at Belmont
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: American Pharoah, which left Louisville, Ky., in a plane at around 11:15 a.m., arrived at Belmont Park four and a half hours later, stepped off a van and walked straight into his barn.
lead_paragraph: The more the rain pelted the grounds outside the refurbished Barn 1 at Belmont Park on Tuesday, the more the crowd grew. Fans came in raincoats and boots, umbrellas in one hand and cameras in the other. There were grooms, security guards, racing officials and members of the news media. Satellite trucks from CNN, CBS, Fox News, NY1 and more lined the narrow streets. They assembled for one reason: the arrival in New York of American Pharoah, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner.

headline: Pierre Audi Is Named Next Artistic Director of Park Avenue Armory
abstract: Mr. Audi, who has led the Dutch National Opera since 1988, succeeds Alex Poots and will join the Armory in October to begin planning its 2017 season.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Audi is a serious multitasker.

headline: Californians Are Encouraged by Sharp Drop in Water Use
keywords: ['Water', 'Drought', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: Californians cut their water use in April by 13.5 percent over the same month two years ago, the first indication of how the state is reacting to mandatory water cutbacks.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Californians cut their water use in April by 13.5 percent over the same month two years ago, a big improvement from March and the first indication of how the state is reacting to mandatory water cutbacks imposed by Gov. Jerry Brown to deal with the region’s ongoing drought.

headline: Climate Deal Badly Needs a Big Stick
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Fruitless efforts to seriously curb greenhouse gas pollution suggest a new approach is warranted — making it costly not to join an international consortium committed to fighting climate change.
lead_paragraph: Few economists are as versed in the global diplomatic effort to combat climate change as Nicholas Stern of Britain.

headline: Rochelle Shoretz, Founder of Cancer Support Group, Dies at 42
abstract: Ms. Shoretz, a lawyer who clerked for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court, founded Sharsheret in 2001 after learning she had breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: As a 28-year-old who had just learned she had breast cancer in 2001, Rochelle Shoretz founded a support group for cancer patients while sitting in her oncologist’s office awaiting chemotherapy. She called it Sharsheret, Hebrew for chain. In 2009, the cancer returned.

headline: South Sudan: U.N. Dismayed by Decline
abstract: The United Nations expressed alarm over the recent heavy fighting that had displaced more than 100,000 people and blocked aid deliveries to 650,000.
lead_paragraph: United Nations officials expressed alarm Tuesday over a further deterioration in South Sudan, where they said recent heavy fighting had displaced more than 100,000 people and blocked aid deliveries to 650,000. Adrian Edwards, a spokesman for the United Nations refugee agency in Geneva, told reporters that at least 60,000 South Sudanese had fled since January, mostly to Sudan, Ethiopia and Uganda, bringing the total number of refugees to 555,000 since December 2013, when the conflict erupted. Mr. Edwards said that 1.5 million people had been displaced within the country and that a third of the population lacked sufficient food. The news came a day after United Nations officials said South Sudan’s government had decided to expel the organization’s aid coordinator there, Toby Lanzer, who has criticized the South Sudanese armed forces for their role in the fighting. He was nearing the end of his tenure anyway, but Secretary General Ban Ki-moon condemned the expulsion.

headline: Antitrust Scrutiny for 3 Big U.S. Theater Chains
keywords: ['Movies', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: As large movie theaters have negotiated with studios for the exclusive rights to show films in certain geographic areas, some smaller independent theaters have taken legal action.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A simmering federal investigation into whether the big movie theater chains are misusing their market clout to keep new films away from independent competitors gained steam on Tuesday.

headline: Video Shows James Holmes Recalling Colorado Theater Shooting
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Forensic Science']
abstract: Forensic psychologists say a taped interview with James E. Holmes provides an exceedingly rare and chilling window into the plotting and psyche of a mass killer.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The gunman’s voice was flat, unshaded by emotion, as he told a psychiatrist how he had slipped through the emergency exit door of a packed movie theater and opened fire on the crowd. He was on autopilot, he said. He turned up the electronic music in his headphones to drown out the screams. He knew he would probably end up arrested or dead, but he was carrying out what he called “the mission.”

headline: Tribe Opening New Casino Says a Competitor’s Site Is Too Close for Comfort
abstract: A conflict between the Oneida Indian Nation and the developer Wilmorite has led to accusations of parasitic business plans and a possible casino war in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: CHITTENANGO, N.Y. — The state’s newest casino opened here on Tuesday, brimming with hundreds of slot machines, scores of smiling employees and four flying-monkey sculptures adorning a “Wizard of Oz”- — — themed gambling floor.

headline: De Blasio Calls New York ‘the Safest Big City’ Despite Some Crime Statistics
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Firearms']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed further action against violence during a news conference on Tuesday, after police officials released statistics showing shootings and homicides have increased this year.
lead_paragraph: One day after police officials outlined a pronounced increase in shootings and homicides in the city so far this year, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday moved to reassure residents that New York remains “the safest big city in America,” dismissing any suggestion that his policies are responsible for the rise.

headline: Huffington Post in Limbo at Verizon
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: It is not completely clear what Verizon might want with The Huffington Post or how a relationship between them might work. The future role of the site’s founder, Arianna Huffington, is also uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Over the last couple of years, an array of media companies, venture capitalists and wealthy individuals have quietly explored buying a stake in The Huffington Post. The most recent valuation, according to half a dozen people briefed on the matter: about $1 billion.

headline: Officers Kill Suspect Who Wielded Knife in Boston
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A man under surveillance by antiterrorism investigators was shot and killed on Tuesday by an F.B.I. agent and a Boston police officer after brandishing a long knife.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A man under surveillance by antiterrorism investigators was shot and killed Tuesday by an F.B.I. agent and a Boston police officer after he waved a long black knife at them and refused to back down, officials said.

headline: Families Tell Lawmakers of Americans Held Hostage in Iran
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The relatives of four United States citizens were pressing the Obama administration to do more to free the captives before the June 30 deadline for reaching an international agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of three Americans imprisoned in Iran and of a fourth who vanished there eight years ago gave emotional testimony Tuesday to lawmakers in Washington, pressing the Obama administration to do more to free the captives before the June 30 deadline for reaching an international agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: A Plan to Combat Mistaken Identifications and False Confessions
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Forensic Science', 'Police', 'Confessions', 'Witnesses', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: For generations, evidence at crime scenes has been collected in ways to reduce contamination. Now, under a proposal in New York State, similar care would be taken to gather the memories of witnesses.
lead_paragraph: For generations, physical evidence at crime scenes has been collected using techniques to reduce contamination. Technicians wear gloves on their hands, masks on their faces, bootees over their shoes. With sterile tools, they tweeze, swab and dust for hairs, bloodstains and fingerprints, and place them in individual packets for lab analysis.

headline: 13% Left Health Care Rolls, U.S. Finds
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Obama administration says that many people had failed to pay their share of premiums, leaving enrollment at 10.2 million people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About 13 percent of people who signed up for health insurance coverage in 2015 under the Affordable Care Act have fallen off the rolls, many because they failed to pay their share of premiums, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

headline: Jim Bailey, Character Actor in Drag, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Bailey, who performed in the guise of pop divas like Judy Garland and Barbra Streisand, was a Las Vegas favorite, but he also played supper clubs, cabarets, Carnegie Hall and the London Palladium.
lead_paragraph: Jim Bailey, an actor and singer who specialized in performing in drag, especially in the guise of pop divas like Judy Garland and Barbra Streisand, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 77.

headline: E.P.A. to Set New Limits on Airplane Emissions
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Global Warming', 'Clean Air Act']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to report as early as Friday that greenhouse gas emissions from airplanes endanger human health through global warming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is set to announce that it will require new rules to cut emissions from airplanes, expanding a quest to tackle climate change that has included a string of significant regulations on cars, trucks and power plants.

headline: Sponsors React Meekly to Sepp Blatter’s Resignation
abstract: World Cup sponsors issued statements that read as if one very careful public relations executive had written several versions of the same message.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after Sepp Blatter announced Tuesday that he would resign as president of FIFA, World Cup sponsors issued statements that read as if one very careful public relations executive had written several versions of the same message that was now so safe to deliver with Blatter on the way out. Only two of the five statements I received even cited Blatter, who, after all, was the star of the day.

headline: New York City Creates Replacement for Student Data Website
abstract: A website for the city’s public schools will allow parents to view information on their children like attendance and report card grades.
lead_paragraph: Starting next week, parents of students in New York City public schools will be able view their children’s attendance, grades and, ultimately, scores on Regents exams and state reading and math tests on a new website, NYC Schools.

headline: Steven Stamkos and Jonathan Toews Welcome Leading Roles
abstract: Stamkos, of Tampa Bay, and Toews, of Chicago, eagerly accept the added responsibility that comes with leading their teams as captains in the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Large banners of Stanley Cup-winning captains were unfurled around the room, creating a hockey shrine of sorts and reminding Steven Stamkos why he has often awaked in anxiety and expectation amid the rising pressure of these playoffs.

headline: Sepp Blatter: From Defiant to Defeated in Four Fateful Days
abstract: After 17 years as FIFA’s president, Blatter decided, just days after his re-election, that he did not want to run world soccer anymore after all.
lead_paragraph: It must have been some sort of rotten long weekend for Sepp Blatter for him to decide, just days after his re-election Friday as FIFA’s president, that he didn’t want to run world soccer anymore, after all.

headline: Review: ‘The Spoils’ Stars Jesse Eisenberg as Narcissist
abstract: In this play, Mr. Eisenberg plays a self-centered character who wants to win of love of an engaged woman whom he’s been smitten with since childhood.
lead_paragraph: As both actor and playwright, Jesse Eisenberg loves rolling in the sties of self-contempt, places where privileged human pigs sniffle and suffer and smear themselves with muck. Even if these are areas you usually choose to avoid, it must be said that Mr. Eisenberg gives good wallow.

headline: Pickup Line
abstract: Herre Schouwerwou picks up the lot of us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Well, this one by Herre Schouwerwou made me laugh out loud. It took a while to trickle through my brain, but when it finally did, the payoff was fabulous. But I had to stare at it for a while.

headline: Airstrikes in Yemen Kill Allies of Saudi-Led Coalition, Witnesses Say
abstract: The coalition killed at least 16 of its own allies, including three senior leaders, according to a fighter who was near the site of the bombing.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Warplanes from a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia carried out airstrikes Tuesday in Yemen that killed at least 16 fighters allied with the Saudi-led group, witnesses said.

headline: Irwin A. Rose, Nobel-Winning Biochemist, Dies at 88
abstract: Dr. Rose’s early interest in the problem of protein disposal helped lead to the development of a new class of cancer-fighting drugs.
lead_paragraph: Irwin A. Rose, who shared the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with two collaborators for unraveling the mystery of how cells identify old and damaged proteins and transform them into pieces for new proteins — discoveries that led to the development of a new class of drugs to fight cancer — died on Tuesday in Deerfield, Mass. He was 88.

headline: NBC Expected to Extend Belmont Stakes Rights Through 2020
abstract: No financial details were available for a deal that will help NBC in its quest to secure the long-term rights to all three Triple Crown races.
lead_paragraph: The NBC Sports Group is expected to announce Wednesday at the Belmont Stakes draw in Manhattan that it will carry the third leg of thoroughbred racing’s Triple Crown through at least 2020.

headline: Maryland: Vote Is a Setback for Scientology-Linked Rehab Center
abstract: The Frederick County Council voted 6 to 1 against placing a fishing retreat on a local register of historic places, making it unlikely that a drug rehabilitation program with ties to the Church of Scientology will be opened.
lead_paragraph: The Frederick County Council on Tuesday voted 6 to 1 against placing a fishing retreat on a local register of historic places, making it very unlikely that a drug rehabilitation program with ties to the Church of Scientology will be opened. The retreat, near Camp David, has been visited by several presidents. The vote against adding the property, known as Trout Run, to the historic list will deny the retreat the zoning it would need for a Narconon facility. The Council was urged by its lawyer to consider only Trout Run’s historic character and not the practices of Narconon. Narconon is likely to appeal.

headline: NYRA Chairman, Anthony Bonomo, Is Taking a Leave of Absence
abstract: Mr. Bonomo has been accused of providing a no-show job to the son of Dean G. Skelos, the former New York State Senate majority leader.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Bonomo, the chairman of the New York Racing Association, is taking a leave of absence in the wake of allegations that he provided a no-show job to the son of Dean G. Skelos, the former New York State Senate majority leader.

headline: New York Police Officer Charged With Using Dead Man’s Credit Card
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Identity Theft', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: Officer Ymmacula Pierre, who found the man after responding to a 911 call, pleaded not guilty to using the card to buy a diamond ring online.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer was arrested on Tuesday and charged with stealing a dead man’s credit card and using it to buy a diamond ring. She pleaded not guilty on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: All-In on Tanaka, Yankees Can Only Hope His Elbow Holds Up
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka will be back pitching Wednesday, and if his elbow blows out now, it is likely too late for him to be able to return next season.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — After taking a month off to rest and recover from tightness in his right wrist, Masahiro Tanaka pronounced himself fit and ready, so the Yankees will saddle him up Wednesday against the Seattle Mariners and see how far they can ride him.

headline: Uncertainty Clouds David Wright’s Potential Return to Mets
abstract: Even if Wright returns, the team is unsure what it can expect from him, which only adds weight to all the questions about his recovery and the Mets’ search for a stopgap replacement.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — David Wright walked through the visitors’ clubhouse at Petco Park on Tuesday afternoon, greeting teammates he had not seen in several weeks. He moved gingerly, his posture straight as a board in an effort to protect his back as much as possible. When he stands, it often feels achy and tight and uncomfortable.

headline: Roger Goodell to Hear Tom Brady’s Appeal
abstract: Over the objections of the players’ union, the N.F.L.’s commissioner said he would be the one hearing an appeal of the four-game suspension he gave to the Patriots’ quarterback.
lead_paragraph: Over the objections of the players’ union, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said that he would be the one hearing an appeal of the four-game suspension he gave to New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady. In a letter sent to the N.F.L. Players’ Association on Tuesday, Goodell said that under the collective bargaining agreement, he had the right to hear appeals involving “conduct detrimental to the integrity of the game.”

headline: Onwards and Upwards
abstract: Whether a messy bun or an elegant chignon, nothing signals efficiency like an updo.
lead_paragraph: Whether a messy bun or an elegant chignon, nothing signals efficiency like an updo.

headline: A Sneak Peek at a Futuristic Multimedia Performance
abstract: The musician Tyondai Braxton’s “Hive” show will take place over three nights at the New York venue the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: “In a lot of a visual art, you complete the project, and by the time you present it, it’s done,” says Tyondai Braxton, whose multimedia project “Hive” will be the centerpiece of an upcoming three-night residency at the New York venue the Kitchen. After a pause, he admits: “But maybe you’d want to have it completely completed when you play the Guggenheim.” Braxton is the former frontman of the experimental indie-rock band Battles, as well as a performer with two decades of experience in the New York music world. “Hive” did indeed have its first show in at the Guggenheim in 2013, for which it was originally commissioned, before making stops at locations including the Sydney Opera House, the MONA FOMA festival in Tasmania and the Barbican Centre in London. Now, Braxton is ready to unveil the finished product. “I feel like I’ve arrived at the first incarnation of what I want this to be,” he says. “Everyone understands the music, understands the vibe of it, and we’re really interfacing in a way that’s exciting.”

headline: Chelsea Boots 2.0
abstract: This season, the often black and understated shoes have graduated to showstopper status.
lead_paragraph: This season, the often black and understated shoes have graduated to showstopper status.

headline: Female Directors Fare Better in Festivals Than in Hollywood, Study Finds
abstract: They account for 29 percent of documentaries and 18 percent of features shown at American fests. By comparison, women only direct about 7 percent of top-grossing Hollywood movies.
lead_paragraph: Women may direct only a fraction of the top-grossing films – about 7 percent, a number that helped lead the American Civil Liberties Union to call for investigations into Hollywood hiring practices – but they continue to enjoy better representation in film festival fare.

headline: Word of the Day | dapper
abstract: This word has appeared in 132 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: dapper • \ˈda-pər\ • adjective

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:15 P.M. (IFC) AMERICAN HISTORY X (1998) In an Oscar-nominated role, Edward Norton plays Derek Vinyard, a white supremacist who goes to prison for a gruesome killing. He renounces racism there, but his younger brother, Danny (Edward Furlong), a high school student, remains steadfast in the attitudes he learned from Derek. After Danny writes a book report on “Mein Kampf,” his principal, Dr. Robert Sweeney (Avery Brooks, above left, with Mr. Norton), creates a remedial course for him called American History X. Dr. Sweeney visits Derek in prison and they agree to try to persuade Danny to give up his bigotry. “ ‘American History X’ has enough fiery acting and provocative bombast to make its impact felt,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this film directed by Tony Kaye. “For one thing, its willingness to take on ugly political realities gives it a substantial raison d’être. For another, it has been directed with a mixture of handsome photo-realism and visceral punch.”

headline: Robert Rauschenberg’s Endless Combinations
abstract: A railroad crossing sign and 300 neckties. Dozens of bicycles and a stash of Polaroids. Robert Rauschenberg lived surrounded by the everyday objects he might have turned into art. His archive contains worlds of creative possibility — and is virtually impossible to categorize.
lead_paragraph: WHEN YOU’RE LOOKING for the Robert Rauschenberg archive, everything starts to resemble a Rauschenberg. The chance juxtaposition of a vibrant yellow school bus next to a red Staples sign seems somehow intended, part of the artist’s grand design. So too might the pale lavender blossoms of wisteria that frame the gray painted door tucked away in a hardscrabble industrial zone of lots and chain-link fencing.

headline: Syndergaard’s Flying Start Crashes to Earth
abstract: The Mets’ Noah Syndergaard gave up seven runs and 10 hits in four innings as the Padres cruised to victory in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Noah Syndergaard had just thrown the worst inning of his young major league career, and as he came off the mound, he held his glove to his face. He shouted into it so loud and so forcefully that his head thrust forward, his neck veins popped, and he had to use his right hand, his off hand, to hold the glove in place.

headline: Girls Rule in an Indian Village
abstract: In the remote village Mawlynnong, a matrilineal society inspired a photographer to make portraits of self-assured young women.
lead_paragraph: Though small and remote, the village of Mawlynnong, bordering Bangladesh in India’s northeastern state of Meghalaya, attracts tourists from all over the globe.

headline: The Airport Security Sieve
abstract: A recent investigation of airport security agents made clear the need for stable leadership at the Transportation Security Administration.
lead_paragraph: The performance of airport security screeners on a recent investigation by undercover agents was appalling. The screeners failed to detect weapons, mock explosives and other prohibited items 95 percent of the time at airports across the country, which may be a shock to travelers who assumed the hassle of screening was worth it if it kept them safe.

headline: When a School Board Victimizes Kids
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Jews and Judaism', 'State Legislatures', 'Local Government', 'Minorities', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: In East Ramapo, N.Y., a school board controlled by members of the Orthodox Jewish community has neglected its mission.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK STATE has a proud tradition of local decision making in public education. However, students in the public schools in East Ramapo, about 30 miles north of Manhattan, in Rockland County, are being denied their state constitutional right to a sound basic education by a board that has grossly mismanaged the district’s finances and educational programs.

headline: Lost Opportunity on Nuclear Disarmament
keywords: ['Editorials', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Major differences among the world’s nuclear powers remain over the future of nuclear weapons and what efforts should be made to eliminate them.
lead_paragraph: The United States and other nuclear powers failed to use a recent United Nations conference to advance the cause of nuclear disarmament. The meeting in May was supposed to strengthen international efforts to contain nuclear weapons. Instead, it was a reminder of the deep divisions over the future of nuclear weapons and what efforts should be made to eliminate them.

headline: Planting Seeds in Baltimore
abstract: The SEED School of Maryland has just graduated its first class, sending them on to colleges all over the country.
lead_paragraph: On a warm Saturday in late May 2008, my wife, Ann, talked me into going to an auditorium in Baltimore to watch a lottery. It was no ordinary lottery. Numbered balls were cranked out of a bingo machine, and the winners got a ticket to a better life. It was the lottery to choose the first 80 students to attend a new public college-prep boarding school: the SEED School of Maryland based in Baltimore. (My wife chairs the foundation behind the SEED schools.) SEED Maryland — SEED already had a branch in the District of Columbia — was admitting boys and girls from some of the toughest streets and dysfunctional schools in Maryland, and particularly Baltimore, beginning in sixth grade. Five days a week, they would live at the school in a dormitory with counselors — insulated from the turmoil of their neighborhoods — and take buses home on weekends. Last Saturday, I attended the graduation of that first class.

headline: Drew’s Two Hits Help the Yankees Snatch a Victory
abstract: Stephen Drew, hitting .160 entering the game, tied the score with a double in the ninth, then started the winning rally with a single in the 11th.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Perhaps it was the two days Stephen Drew spent reviewing years-old video and tinkering with his swing in the batting cage. Maybe it was a reversal of his miserable fortunes. Or possibly it was the haircut he got a couple of hours before the first pitch.

headline: Rival Pro-Democracy Rallies Planned for June 4 in Hong Kong
abstract: The various demonstrations are a reflection of growing divisions over Hong Kong’s identity, its relationship with the Chinese mainland and where democracy advocates should concentrate their efforts.
lead_paragraph: Every June 4 for a quarter-century, people in Hong Kong who want to commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown have known where to go: Victoria Park, site of the world’s largest public gathering mourning the hundreds, possibly thousands, of civilians killed when troops were deployed to suppress pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing.

headline: O.E.C.D. Sees Slow Recovery Worldwide
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Gross National Product (GNP)', 'Interest Rates', 'Unemployment']
abstract: The organization of the world’s richest nations forecast that growth should be healthier by the end of 2016.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The world economy continues to heal at a disappointingly slow pace, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said on Wednesday, but it predicted that growth should return to a healthier rate close to its long-term goal by the end of 2016.

lead_paragraph: In “Paris Bridge’s Love Locks Are Taken Down,” Alissa J. Rubin and Aurelien Breeden write about a new look for a Paris landmark.

headline: NoHo’s Cinderella Moment
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: New buildings are popping up, some of them sleek high-rises, while 19th-century industrial buildings are being transformed into luxury residences.
lead_paragraph: For many years, NoHo was the “forgotten stepsister to SoHo, although they both have similar cast-iron architecture, zoning, loft tenants and a great backdrop of artists and bohemian culture,” said Jeanne Wilcke, a leader of the NoHo Neighborhood Association and a 24-year resident.

headline: Remembering Last Night’s Music Festival in the Morning
keywords: ['Music', 'Festivals', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Governors Ball Music Festival', 'Bonnaroo Festival (Manchester, Tenn)', 'Electric Zoo Festival (NYC)']
abstract: When some music festival fans quit drinking or taking drugs, they thought they would have to give up the gatherings, but safe spots at some festivals offer support.
lead_paragraph: When Grace McClellan attends two music festivals — Governors Ball in New York and Bonnaroo in Tennessee — this month, she will be among friends who feel more like family. Their shared bond, along with a love of live music: They’re all sober.

headline: Uber’s French Resistance
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Automobiles']
abstract: In cities from New York to New Delhi, the car service Uber has faced threats and bans from regulators but usually comes out on top. Has it met its match in Paris?
lead_paragraph: Around midnight on a windswept Saturday in April, three unmarked cars slowed to a halt on the Rue de Rivoli, near the ornate 19th-century facade of the Hôtel de Ville. The doors swung open, and six police officers, part of a special Paris law-enforcement brigade known as the Boers, hopped out in civilian clothing, with pistols strapped to their waists. They formed a silent huddle as their leader, Capt. Thierry Pujol, issued their marching orders for the evening.

headline: Out of the Ashes, a Rebuilt Synagogue With a Basketball Court on Top
abstract: Four years after a devastating fire, Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun on East 85th Street in Manhattan has been restored, renovated and expanded.
lead_paragraph: Anyone else might be able to enter the rebuilt synagogue of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun at 125 East 85th Street later this summer, take a quick look around and think: “It’s just like it used to be, only spruced up a bit.”

headline: Can the Swiss Watchmaker Survive the Digital Age?
keywords: ['Watches and Clocks', 'Wearable Computing', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Masters of one of the world’s most revered forms of analog craftsmanship take on the smartwatch.
lead_paragraph: Pim Koeslag designs and fabricates some of the world’s most complicated mechanical timepieces. Especially ambitious is his Grand Tourbillon Minute Repeater, created for Ateliers deMonaco, a watch company he helped start. When I visited his bright, sunlit factory in Geneva in May, he opened a refrigerator-size safe to show me one of them.

headline: Jeb Bush, Taking His Time, Tests the Legal Definition of Candidate
abstract: He has crisscrossed the country and raised millions of dollars. That should subject him to limits that declared candidates for president face, experts say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeb Bush is under growing pressure to acknowledge what seems obvious to some voters and election lawyers: He is running for president.

headline: ‘Jurassic World’ Puts Colin Trevorrow in the Driver’s Seat
abstract: The director Colin Trevorrow had one feature to his name when Steven Spielberg hired him for “Jurassic World.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In “Jurassic World,” scientists create a living theme park attraction called Indominus rex by splicing the DNA of two very different dinosaurs. They are ecstatic. Behold! The glorious future, a ticket-selling machine.

headline: Should Women’s Basketball Lower the Rims?
abstract: Would having players shoot on lower rims make the game more popular?
lead_paragraph: Female basketball players are about seven inches shorter than their male counterparts in both the pros and the college ranks, yet 10-foot rims are still the standard for both men and women. Does keeping rims at the same height promote equality in athletics? Or does it just slow down the game for women?

headline: Spotify Wants Listeners to Break Down Music Barriers
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Spotify says that because online streaming services let users listen to anything they want, people are increasingly breaking away from rigid genres.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, my two children, ages 4 and 2, have suddenly become obsessed with Simon and Garfunkel.

headline: Fears of MERS Virus Prompt Broadening of Cautions in South Korea
keywords: ['MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Viruses', 'Hospitals', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: Officials nearly doubled the number of quarantined people, temporarily closed over 700 kindergartens and schools, and refused to identify the hospitals where infections had been confirmed.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Fears of the deadly virus that causes Middle East respiratory syndrome enveloped South Korea on Wednesday as the authorities nearly doubled the number of quarantined people they say may have been exposed, temporarily closed more than 700 kindergartens and schools and refused to identify the six hospitals where infections had been confirmed.

headline: ‘The New World,’ by Chris Adrian and Eli Horowitz
abstract: A surgeon learns a shady company has her husband’s head.
lead_paragraph: Whither the digital novel? Weren’t we all excited, back in the ’90s, about what technology would actually do to storytelling? Weren’t we talking about ­hyperlinks and cybertext and interactivity? I gather there’s still a vogue in English departments for digital humanities, whatever that is. But for most of us the whole concept has been domesticated. It turns out we don’t want tech-aided experiments in form so much as little Kindles lighting our faces on subways and planes and in darkened bedrooms. We want more room in the suitcase.

headline: ‘The Wonder Garden,’ by Lauren Acampora
abstract: These linked stories provide a group portrait of a WASPy town.
lead_paragraph: Edith Wharton’s first published book was a nonfiction work called “The Decoration of ­Houses.” In it, she wrote that “the essence of a style lies not in its use of ornament, but in its handling of proportion. Structure conditions ornament, not ornament structure.” She was arguing that home décor and architecture had to be linked, that content must be connected to form: an aesthetic theory that could just as easily apply to writing.

headline: Forgetting the Pain of Exercise
abstract: Some marathon runners forget over time just how much they hurt, depending on how much they enjoyed the race.
lead_paragraph: Completing a marathon can be exhilarating but also agonizing. Thighs cramp. Backs ache. Toes bleed. Stomachs churn. Afterward, leg muscles can become so sore and tight that finishers must ease themselves backward down stairs and request assistance to rise from the toilet.

headline: Why Kathy McCabe Loves Italy
abstract: The host of “Dream of Italy” on PBS says to know the country, get to know its people.
lead_paragraph: For the past 12 years, Kathy McCabe has written and published Dream of Italy, a subscription newsletter devoted to travel in Italy. Her infatuation with the country began with her first trip there in 1995 to visit Castelvetere sul Calore, home of her maternal ancestors near Naples. The town was full of families bearing her mother’s maiden name (Nargi). “It was like Brigadoon,” she said. “The town had come to life for one day.” That led to annual visits with trips farther afield. “In starting the newsletter, I realized there were a lot of people like me who went to Italy over and over.”

headline: Today’s Travel News and Tips

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Unemployment in the eurozone fell to 11.1 percent in April, the lowest rate in three years, according to official figures published on Wednesday.

headline: Backward Induction and Brad DeLong (Wonkish)
abstract: Consider me slightly baffled.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong is, unusually, unhappy with my analysis in a discussion of the inflationista puzzle — the mystery of why so many economists failed to grasp the implications of a liquidity trap, and still fail to grasp those implications despite 6 years of being wrong. Brad sorta-kinda defends the inflationistas on the basis of backward induction; I find myself somewhat baffled by that defense.

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — They are dissatisfied with the way things are going in the state. They are losing confidence in Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For the past month, I have been banned from giving interviews, and so I am offering this essay to mark the 26th anniversary of the crackdown of June 4, 1989, when the authorities suppressed dissent in cities across China.

headline: Fear of Almonds

lead_paragraph: I can’t tell you how many times in the last month someone has come up to me and said something like, “Do you think I should stop eating almonds?” or “I really miss almond butter, but I just can’t bring myself to buy it anymore.”

abstract: The forces contributing to contemporary class stratification are beyond the reach of the classroom alone.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has invested heavily in a data-based drive to improve the math, reading and science skills of the nation’s school children.

lead_paragraph: The 50th anniversary of Medicare next month is an opportunity to consider what the goals of medicine should be in our aging society and how we want to live in relation to medicine’s evolving tools.

lead_paragraph: “When everyone’s an elite flier, no one is,” Delta Air Lines explained in an email to frequent fliers last fall.

headline: Stephen Curry Gave Davidson Good Publicity, and a Bad Rap

lead_paragraph: The confidence and charisma Stephen Curry has shown during the Golden State Warriors’ march to the N.B.A. finals was on display in 2009 when he sent an email to the entire Davidson College student body. It was an invitation to the premiere of his first rap video.

headline: Today in Politics: Welcome to the Party, Lincoln Chafee

lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where the Senate finally reached an agreement on the National Security Agency surveillance bill. Hillary Rodham Clinton has a new advocacy group, and a previously reluctant segment is warming up to Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky. And the presidential race is set to add another name to its roster.

keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'News and News Media', 'Cruises', 'Social Media', 'Censorship']

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shenzhen Stock Exchange', 'Venture Capital']

lead_paragraph: GREECE CHALLENGES ITS LENDERS | As the top representatives of Greece’s creditors moved toward completing a proposal to give the country the bailout aid it badly needs, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece said on Tuesday that his government sent its own proposal to creditors, on its own terms,  Liz Alderman writes in The New York Times. On Wednesday, the prime minister will discuss the Greek proposal with Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission, in Brussels, according to a Greek government official.

headline: Sepp Blatter’s Resignation Removes an Obstacle to FIFA Overhaul

headline: European Central Bank to Stick With Bond-Buying Plan, Citing Results
abstract: The central bank said it would stay on track with its stimulus program. But much of the discussion involved Greece.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank left its main borrowing rate unchanged on Wednesday, but intends to continue with its bond-buying program, meant to stimulate the eurozone economy, as long as necessary to raise the inflation rate from its dangerously low level.

headline: The Times Should Push Back Hard on ‘Background’ Sourcing

lead_paragraph: The all-too-common Washington practice of “background briefings” and “background press releases” brings to mind a quip often attributed to Mark Twain: Everybody complains about the weather but nobody does anything about it.

headline: Classical Music This Week: A Jersey Search, Beethoven Galore and Schulhoff
abstract: This week’s look ahead at the world of classical music.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, classical fans. Does the start of June have you wanting to range free a little? Not too far from the New York border, some choice performances await.

headline: South Korea Says It Tested Missile That Can Strike Anywhere in North
abstract: The country has been developing a new ballistic missile since the U.S. agreed in 2012 to allow it to extend the range of those arms up to 500 miles.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea successfully test-fired its first ballistic missile on Wednesday with a range far enough to hit any part of North Korea, Defense Ministry officials said.

headline: Whitman Paints a Vague Picture of Hewlett Packard Enterprise
abstract: At a meeting of HP’s biggest corporate customers, Meg Whitman gave some details of the enterprise business she’ll create Nov. 1. She’s counting on making her company a big consulting partner.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Meg Whitman, chairwoman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, explained her dream Tuesday for Hewlett Packard Enterprise, the new company she’s creating after HP is split in half. She also indicated her dilemma.

headline: Even in Safety of Malaysia, Rohingya Migrants Face Bleak Prospects
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The arrivals who landed last month joined 75,000 others already there, but their marginalization in the region has muted their voice in the debate over their future.
lead_paragraph: AMPANG, Malaysia — For refugees from Myanmar who have reached Malaysia, life may well be better than the grim marginalization and persecution they fled. But even here, poverty and exclusion threaten to rob them of a voice in determining their own future.

headline: Moroccan Film About Prostitution Creates Uproar
abstract: After six minutes of excerpts appeared online, the government last week banned the movie "Much Loved" by the Moroccan filmmaker Nabil Ayouch from theaters.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A prostitution-themed film from Morocco that had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival in May has set off a furor there: After six minutes of excerpts appeared online, the government last week banned the movie from theaters, the female stars received death threats and a male actor was attacked with a knife.

headline: $1,350,000 Homes in Alabama, Pennsylvania and Ohio
abstract: This week’s properties include a cabin in Alabama, a modern house in Pennsylvania and a 1928 stone and stucco house in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, ALA.

headline: Will the John Galliano Repackaging Work?
abstract: The brand is getting a new look, but it may not be enough.
lead_paragraph: John Galliano — the brand, not the man — has a new “visual identity” (translation: logo and packaging) and a new business strategy (contemporary!) to signal what Dominique de Longevialle, its chief executive, is calling a “resurgence.”

headline: Florida House That Brought Marco Rubio Grief Is Finally Sold
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: A house that two budding Republican state legislators, Marco Rubio and David Rivera, bought in Tallahassee, Fla., in 2005, received negative publicity over the years and was nearly foreclosed upon.
lead_paragraph: At long last, Senator Marco Rubio has sold a home in Tallahassee, Fla., that has brought him grief over the years — selling for $18,000 less than the sale price and $8,000 less than its most recent listing price.

headline: ‘Cuddles,’ From Joseph Wilde, Turns the Tables on a Fear of Horror
abstract: Mr. Wilde talks about his unnerving vampire tale at 59E59 Theaters, which depicts two women — one all-controlling, the other wrapped up in fantasy tales.
lead_paragraph: Mirrors frightened him when he was a child. Windows, too. Even now, at 29, the London writer Joseph Wilde can get a little freaked out by turning his back on a darkened room.

headline: Daily Report: Spotify and the End of Musical Genres

headline: Tired of Waiting for U.S. to Act, States Pass Crowdfunding Laws and Rules
abstract: Twenty-two states have enacted rules that allow small businesses to seek financial backers online and middle-income people to invest in them.

headline: Caitlyn Jenner Documentary Series Reveals Title and First Promo

lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Caitlyn Jenner revealed her name to the world in a cover story for Vanity Fair. That article and the Annie Leibovitz images accompanying it were a sensation. Now, the E! network, which airs “Keeping Up With the Kardashians,” the reality show on which Ms. Jenner has long appeared, has released its first look at the documentary series that will document the 65-year-old’s transition from Bruce to Caitlyn.

headline: Review: Mark Morris and Haydn Join to Brighten Houston Ballet Program
abstract: The premiere of Mr. Morris’s “The Letter V” was part of a triple bill with the work of two other choreographers.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Why hasn’t Mark Morris set more dances to works by Joseph Haydn? An important part of this famously musical choreographer’s talent has been applied to pieces by composers from the late 17th century to the late 18th — notably Purcell, Bach, Handel, Gluck and Mozart. Haydn (1732-1809) isn’t just a central composer of that period; he also often exemplifies the same qualities as Mr. Morris: high spirits, terrific humor, a strong inclination to the pastoral and a keen instinct for structural experimentation. Last week, the Houston Ballet gave the premiere of Mr. Morris’s “The Letter V” — choreographed to Haydn’s Symphony No. 88 in G (1787). (Some Haydn symphonies were once known by letters of the alphabet; V was assigned to this one — hence this ballet’s title.)

headline: Farewell, My Lovely Cigarettes
abstract: A lifelong smoker takes his final puff and looks back on a 30-year habit.
lead_paragraph: Like every other Gen Xer, I learned to smoke because a neighborhood girl named Tammy had a grandmother who was dying of cancer and therefore didn’t have time to notice that Tammy was stealing her Benson & Hedges 100s.

headline: ‘Primates of Park Avenue’: Reporter’s Notebook

Most hadn’t read the book on which the essay was based — its publication date was June 2 — but everyone seemed to have an opinion.

headline: In Hindi Films, Strong Women Are a Formula That Works
abstract: The most popular Hindi films in recent months have been led by women. They have been made for the purest reason in commercial cinema: They make money.
lead_paragraph: In the hit Hindi film of the season, an architect cares for her cantankerous father, enduring his careful analysis of his own constipation, his contempt for marriage, which he claims is for “low I.Q. people,” and his appreciation for the fact, which he shares with others, that his unmarried daughter’s sex life is purely “need based.” In another Hindi film, a woman who is estranged from her husband flirts with available men, bringing much misery to their lives.

headline: John Paulson Gives $400 Million to Harvard for Engineering School

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Muslims and Islam']

headline: 1965: U.S. Astronaut Cavorts in Space
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The American astronaut Edward H. White goes for a spacewalk in 1965.
lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla. — Astronaut Edward H. White pushed himself free today [June 3] from a spaceship traveling at more than 17,500 miles an hour and became the world’s first self-propelled man in space. It took only a little push to give Maj. White a 20-minute joyride, with only a slender golden tether tying him to his Gemini-4 ship. And what a ride. He danced, he jiggled, he laughed, he teased, he used his space gun to whip himself through the void, and he snapped pictures with two cameras. Four and a half hours earlier, earth’s gravity tied him to the ground. But now he was free. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 4, 1965

headline: Multipliers and Reality
abstract: What consumers don’t know can hurt your modeling efforts.
lead_paragraph: The fiscal multiplier — the increase in real GDP per dollar of government stimulus spending, or the fall per dollar of austerity cuts — has assumed a lot of significance in recent years. When Bernstein and Romer assumed that it was 1.5, Robert Lucas accused them of “shlock economics“, and smeared Romer’s professional ethics. Since then there has been quite a lot of empirical work, which generally indicates a multiplier of about … 1.5.

headline: 36 Hours in Savannah, Ga.
abstract: Yes, there are live oaks and elegant squares, but also innovative cuisine, a lively bar scene and a lush 30-acre park to stroll.
lead_paragraph: Some of Savannah’s best-known attractions — mossy cemeteries, old mansions, ghost tours — give the misleading impression that the city is a macabre vestige of its storied past. In truth, Savannah is alive and kicking: How could it not be when a large swath of the historic downtown enjoys liberal open-container alcohol policies that make “go-cup” a popular term in the local lexicon? More recently, a cultural revival has been converting abandoned properties into everything from craft breweries to a contemporary art museum. So now Savannah’s antebellum beauty of live oaks and elegant squares coexists with cool shops and innovative restaurants. Welcome to the new South.

lead_paragraph: With the financial crisis still reverberating, this 2010 gathering appears to be the only recorded meeting between Lanny Breuer, a top Justice Department official, and representatives from big Wall Street banks.

headline: Abuses by Nigeria’s Military Found to Be Rampant in War Against Boko Haram
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Torture']
abstract: Amnesty International said that torture, mass shootings, starvation and the use of deadly fumigation chemicals in overcrowded cells have been routinely employed by the Nigerian military.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — In the course of Nigeria’s war against the Boko Haram terrorist group, at least 7,000 people have died in government detention because of brutal conditions, an additional 1,200 have been “extrajudicially executed” by Nigerian security forces, and at least 20,000 have been “arbitrarily arrested” by the authorities, Amnesty International said in a report released Wednesday.

headline: In London, Conrad Shawcross’s Colossal Moment
abstract: The artist unveiled a massive steel sculpture on the heels of a recent installation in Dulwich Park in London’s Southwark — and on the eve of an exhibition of his smaller-scale works.
lead_paragraph: It’s a monumental moment in the career of Conrad Shawcross. The 38-year-old British artist, who is the youngest member of London’s prestigious Royal Academy of Arts, has just unveiled “The Dappled Light of the Sun,” a colossal steel sculpture that scales the institution’s classical courtyard like an alien landing. Even for Shawcross — an artist celebrated for his feats of engineering, spanning rope machines, reconfigured robots and even a pair of rotating wooden arms for Raf Simons’s runway — this is ambitious. Each of the 8,000 pieces has been handmade in five diminishing scales; when laid flat, the piece comprises about 7 ½ miles of welded steel and weighs in at around 30 tons. “It exploits the geometry of the tetrahedron,” Shawcross explains of the mass of pyramid shapes. “Seen on their own, they’re very rational and ordered, but together, they become totally unruly. So the finished work is full of energy and movement. It looks anarchic against the order and stillness of the courtyard space.”

headline: European Central Bank President Hints at Concession for Greece
abstract: Mario Draghi said “social fairness” should be part of a Greece deal, signaling that at least one influential eurozone leader would make concessions.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The message to Greece from European Central Bank headquarters in Frankfurt on Wednesday was, on the surface, much the same as it has always been: Stick to the program.

headline: Jeremy Shamos, a Nice Guy Who Likes Playing the Jerk
abstract: The actor is quite in demand for roles that require jerks and moral cowards.
lead_paragraph: Offstage, the actor Jeremy Shamos is charming and socially adept. He is reasonably relaxed and seemingly sane, not especially prone to fits of rage or self-recrimination.

headline: Upload the Pictures, and Let Google Photos Do the Rest
abstract: Take all the photos you want, back them up automatically into the cloud and use Google’s image search abilities to find them later.
lead_paragraph: I DON’T take a lot of photographs. I have a pretty decent camera with me at all times — my iPhone 5s — but organizing hundreds or thousands of photos has never seemed worth the effort.

headline: Classical Playlist: Brahms, Arvo Pärt and Gorczycki
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BRAHMS: Symphony No. 4 Claudio Abbado, conductor; Berlin Philharmonic(Deutsche Grammophon)Carlos Kleiber’s Brahms Fourth with the Vienna Philharmonic is supposed to be in a league of its own. Truthfully, though, I turn more often to Claudio Abbado’s recording with the Berlin Philharmonic, as I did again last week to prepare for Manfred Honeck’s superb appearance with the New York Philharmonic. Not everything Abbado recorded remains worthwhile listening, but his marriage of the cavernous Karajan sound with Italianate lyricism worked wonders in the Brahms he released in the early 1990s. (David Allen)

headline: Lincoln Chafee on the Issues
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Mr. Chafee, a former Republican and independent who is running for the Democratic nomination, favors a warming in relations with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Chafee, 62, a former governor and senator from Rhode Island, on Wednesday entered the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. He was appointed to the Senate in 1999 as a Republican to replace his father, John H. Chafee, who had died. He was elected the next year and was the only senator in his party to vote against going to war in Iraq. After being defeated by Sheldon Whitehouse in 2006, Mr. Chafee was elected governor in 2010 as an independent but later became a Democrat. He did not seek re-election. Here are his stands on important issues.

headline: Rick Perry Hones His Image as ‘Texas Miracle’ Fades
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The backers of former Gov. Rick Perry say his policies spurred jobs, but many economists contend that differences in state policies play a limited role in fueling growth.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Not long ago, what former Gov. Rick Perry and other conservatives like to call “the Texas Miracle” — the booming Texas economy — looked like a potential steppingstone to national office. But as Mr. Perry jumps into the ever-widening race for the Republican presidential nomination, his state’s economic performance appears considerably less miraculous.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple began selling the Apple Watch in April, Phillip Ryu did not rush to create an app for it. Because apps on the device have limited animation and the software takes several seconds to load, Mr. Ryu, a founder of Impending, which makes mobile games, said he was constrained in terms of what programs he could create for the watch.

lead_paragraph: It was three days before Thanksgiving in 2013. In Zurich, FIFA issued a news release announcing that it was fighting match-fixing, and Sepp Blatter, FIFA’s president, celebrated after a Swiss initiative to cap soccer managers’ pay had failed.

headline: Sepp Blatter’s Resignation and Soccer Reform
abstract: Mr. Blatter should leave immediately and allow an interim president to start introducing reforms.
lead_paragraph: It’s not entirely clear yet what led Sepp Blatter to decide to step down as president of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, only four days after he was defiantly re-elected to a fifth term. It may be that his lawyers advised him this was the best way to combat corruption charges that would soon entangle him, or that major sponsors urged him to move along. In any case, his departure clears the way to start reforming the culture of corruption and impunity that have long tarnished the world’s most popular sport.

headline: Turkey’s Elections Will Test Power of the President
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is not on the ballot, but wants to increase his authority through a constitutional change if his allies win enough seats in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Fighter jets raced across the Istanbul sky, painting the Turkish flag with ribbons of colored smoke, as a military band with nearly 600 musicians marched below. Hundreds of thousands of people looked on, in an event that quickly took on the fervor of a religiously infused political rally.

headline: Review: American Contemporary Music Ensemble Beckons, Playfully, at Miller Theater

lead_paragraph: Timo Andres’s music has tutelary deities, and he’s not shy about acknowledging them. “Thrive on Routine” for string quartet (2010) takes its inspiration, as Mr. Andres writes on his witty and informative website, from accounts of Charles Ives’s morning regimen.

lead_paragraph: In the now classic 1999 movie “The Matrix” machines enslave humans for use as battery-like sources of energy. On the new Netflix series “Sense8,” it’s almost as if Tinder has taken control of the planet.

Her auburn curls tumble over alabaster shoulders. Can she really be the avatar of personal freedom and self-expression the media claims her to be?

headline: Crystal Bridges Museum to Announce Major Purchases
abstract: The museum has acquired Jasper Johns’s “Flag” (1983) and four works by Louise Bourgeois, which aids its mission of featuring more women in its collection of American artists.
lead_paragraph: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art will soon announce major purchases that fill gaps in its collection and fulfill its mission to include more women in the canon of American art: Jasper Johns’s renowned “Flag” painting from 1983, which the museum bought at Sotheby’s in November for $36 million (outlasting three other ardent bidders), and four works by Louise Bourgeois, including her monumental bronze, steel and marble spider sculpture “Maman.” The Bourgeois purchases, concluded in December 2014, together are worth an estimated $35 million to $40 million.

headline: Review: New York City Ballet, With Heartfelt Pas de Deux, in ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’
abstract: An Act II dance in this George Balanchine work is the largest point of several in which Balanchine does something unlike Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: At the center of Act II of George Balanchine’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” is an intricate, hushed, slow, gentle, spellbinding pas de deux that has nothing to do with either the ballet’s story or the Shakespeare play on which it is based. Danced by an anonymous woman and man during the divertissement given by Duke Theseus for the triple wedding, it is an image of perfect chivalrous love and cooperation. On Tuesday night, when “Midsummer” made its annual return to City Ballet repertory at the David H. Koch Theater, it was danced by Tiler Peck and Tyler Angle as beautifully as I have ever known it, the legato of their phrasing spinning threads like gossamer.

headline: Review: Brian Brooks Moving Company Keeps Things Off-Center at the Joyce Theater
abstract: The choreographer staged five short works (including “Division,” a New York premiere) with his troupe.
lead_paragraph: Brian Brooks has been a regular at the Joyce Theater lately, performing last week with Wendy Whelan in “Restless Creature,” for which he was one of four choreographers, and this week with his Brian Brooks Moving Company. Watching his fine dancers in a program of five short works, which opened on Tuesday, you can see why Ms. Whelan, looking to break out of ballet’s verticality, would gravitate toward Mr. Brooks. He treats the body as an axis that’s never upright, or only upright on its way from one incline to another. The body’s momentum, whipped up by a brisk calligraphy of the limbs, keeps the axis swaying off-center.

headline: Morocco Defends Ban of ‘Much Loved’; Attack on Actor Is Called Unrelated
abstract: The film, which shows scenes of prostitutes in Marrakesh servicing wealthy Saudi clients, had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Morocco’s communications minister on Wednesday defended the government’s decision to ban the film “Much Loved,” which shows scenes of prostitutes in Marrakesh partying and servicing wealthy Saudi clients. Meanwhile, the state-run news agency said there was no link between the film and a knife attack on a cast member.

headline: Chuck Blazer Court Papers Made Public
abstract: The sealed papers from the soccer official Chuck Blazer's criminal case were released on Wednesday. Blazer pleaded guilty in 2013 to charges that included racketeering, wire fraud, money laundering and income tax evasion.
lead_paragraph: The sealed papers from the soccer official Chuck Blazer's criminal case were released on Wednesday. Blazer pleaded guilty in 2013 to charges that included racketeering, wire fraud, money laundering and income tax evasion.

headline: Review: ‘Primates of Park Avenue,’ Making Fun of the Rich
abstract: Wednesday Martin’s anthropologically themed memoir examines the women of the Upper East Side of Manhattan — their snootiness, their Birkin bags and their derrières in gymwear.
lead_paragraph: No book in recent memory has been as splashily misrepresented as Wednesday Martin’s “Primates of Park Avenue.” It is supposed to have blown the lid off the darkest secrets of the wealthy, glamorous Upper East Side wife-and-mommy set. Ms. Martin unearthed these secrets — including that of the buzzed-about “wife bonus,” which her book barely mentions — by living among and masquerading as one of those rich RoboMoms while also doing “fieldwork” in anthropology and primatology, like an urban Jane Goodall with an interest in social-climbing and fashion.

headline: At Least 19 Killed in Fighting in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Fighting broke out Wednesday between rebels and Ukrainian soldiers on the outskirts of the city of Donetsk, threatening an already fragile cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: MARIUPOL, Ukraine — Fighting broke out Wednesday between separatist forces and Ukrainian soldiers on the outskirts of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, killing at least 19 people, officials from both sides said, and threatening an already fragile cease-fire.

headline: A Sardinian Chef Dishes on His Parisian Pleasures
abstract: Simone Tondo, who will serve cannolis at Paris’s three-day food festival “La Revanche des Faubourgs” on Saturday, shares his favorite spots in the 11th Arrondissement.
lead_paragraph: “Nutella is my drug,” says the chef Simone Tondo, while lighting a cigarette and sipping a café on the terrace of Le Square Trousseau in Paris. The Sardinian-born chef of the restaurant Roseval may know a thing or two about mackerel and heirloom tomatoes, but it’s hazelnut spread that really gets him going — that and the on-demand car service Uber. “It’s my new friend,” he says.

lead_paragraph: At the CFDA Fashion Awards on Monday, speeches ran long (very long); the dress code said black-tie, though many wore jeans; waiters served pasta that few people ate; and Kanye West presented a fashion-icon award to Pharrell Williams but talked mostly of himself.

headline: For NGOs in China, a Sense of Party Creep
abstract: Is Xi Jinping’s government pushing out the gains made by civil society since 1995, as some Chinese critics are whispering?
lead_paragraph: In 1995, hundreds of members of nongovernmental organizations descended on Beijing, including Kazakhs calling for an end to nuclear testing, New Yorkers seeking equal pay for women and Europeans advocating sex workers’ rights, during the United Nations’ Fourth World Conference on Women. They dazzled Chinese hungry for change, and the concept of civil society took off. Within months, it seemed as if everyone was setting up an NGO.

headline: Review: ‘Pretty Raw’ Recounts Helen Frankenthaler’s Influence on the Art World
abstract: An exhibition at the Rose Art Museum in Waltham, Mass., tells how Ms. Frankenthaler became a leading figure in Color Field painting.
lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass. — A groundbreaking show at the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis University here clears a more prominent place for Helen Frankenthaler in the history of postwar New York painting. “Pretty Raw: After and Around Helen Frankenthaler” re-examines her 1952 invention of stain-painting and traces some of its repercussions up to the present.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka’s Sterling Return Lifts Yankees Over Mariners
abstract: Tanaka, back from the disabled list, gave up one run and three hits in seven efficient innings, allowing his only base runners in the third inning.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The Yankees have acted cautiously with Masahiro Tanaka, treating him as if he were made of Venetian glass rather than flesh, blood and sinew. On Wednesday, he reminded everyone why he is such a treasure.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York

lead_paragraph: With resort season in full swing, Robert Clergerie is teaming up with Joe Coffee to offer free iced coffee outside its Chelsea showroom each morning from 9 to 10:30 through June 16. Even if you are not part of the fashion tribe, you can still grab a cup of joe; each comes in a sleeve printed with the Robert Clergerie logo and the tag line “Living is Sharing.” At 545 West 25th Street.

headline: High-Waist Jeans Make a Comeback

headline: Gay Parties on Fire Island and on Rooftops in Manhattan

The dockside spots were rebuilt and sold this year to a partnership that includes Ian Reisner, an owner of the Out NYC hotel in Hell’s Kitchen, and P. J. McAteer, who owns Sip-n-Twirl and other Pines establishments.

lead_paragraph: The day before her first book was released, Ali Adler was sitting in the lobby of the Chateau Marmont in West Hollywood, Calif. She was enjoying a latte and telling an anecdote about someone who had gotten an early peek but wouldn’t get to read her book for many years. That is, if he ever chooses to read it at all.

headline: St. Vincent, an Experimenter in Music and in Makeup
abstract: For the singer St. Vincent, trying new things is all part of the journey, come failure or come success.
lead_paragraph: St. Vincent (nee Annie Clark), 32, has been performing under that name since 2006. In February, she won her first Grammy, for Best Alternative Album, for her self-titled album. When she’s not on tour, the singer, who grew up in Dallas, lives in the East Village in Manhattan, which will be her home base when she performs at the Governors Ball Music Festival on Friday and at Barclays Center for the “Contemporary Color” concert June 27 and 28. Here, she discusses her beauty regimen. BEE SHAPIRO

As Fitzpatrick neared the boundary, Revis started laughing. So did Allen, who told Fitzpatrick, “You’ve got some wheels, man.”

headline: Long Path to the Top of Racing for Larry Collmus, the Voice of the Triple Crown
abstract: Collmus, the successor of the renowned Tom Durkin, began calling races at age 18 and has called the Triple Crown races since 2011.
lead_paragraph: Larry Collmus was practicing his equine scales in the race announcer’s booth at Belmont Park. “Regia Marina, Clearly Cheating — that’s a nice name — Tiger Moth,” he said, speaking to himself, memorizing the six new names before doing it again. “Clearly Cheating. Regia Marina, Fast Retailing.” His pace picked up. “Il Mulino, Majestic Empire, Tiger Moth.”

lead_paragraph: Julian Niccolini, a longtime co-owner of the Four Seasons, was arrested on Wednesday on a charge that he sexually abused a 28-year-old woman during a party at the celebrated Manhattan restaurant, the police said.

lead_paragraph: SENATOBIA, Miss. — The commencement ceremony last month for Senatobia High School, its graduating seniors dressed smartly in blue gowns, scarcely seemed like an event that would provoke multiple allegations of criminal conduct.

lead_paragraph: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — When the weather gets sultry here at company headquarters, Walmart workers everywhere brace for an icy blast.

headline: Argentina: Rallies to Protect Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Domestic Violence', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Thousands of people rallied in cities across Argentina on Wednesday to demand more robust action to prevent violence against women after a spate of murders.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people rallied in cities across Argentina on Wednesday to demand more robust action to prevent violence against women after a spate of murders. On Twitter, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner denounced “a culture that devastates women.” More than 1,800 women died between 2008 and 2014 in episodes of domestic violence, according to La Casa del Encuentro, a local women’s rights group. Organizers of the rallies urged officials to enforce the provisions of a 2009 law devised to crack down on violence against women. Speaking in Buenos Aires, Juan Minujín, an actor, said: “This is a unanimous cry for coordinated action that tackles the problem. We don’t want more tears of mourning.”

headline: To Find the Next Nicklaus, Don’t Look to a Nicklaus
abstract: Jordan Spieth, 21, and Rory McIlroy, 26, are successful young golfers, but youth is rare in a sport that has been called slow, difficult and expensive by a younger generation.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — At 21, Jordan Spieth is younger than a few of the golfers on the Louisiana State and University of Southern California teams that squared off Wednesday in the N.C.A.A. Division I match-play final. Spieth, one of the marquee players in this week’s Memorial Tournament, is the closest pursuer to the world No. 1, Rory McIlroy, who last month turned 26, leading Jack Nicklaus, the Memorial host and 18-time major champion, to observe, “The game of golf is in pretty good hands.”

headline: Gaza: Militants Fire Rockets Into Israel
abstract: Palestinian militants launched two rockets from Gaza toward southern Israel late Wednesday, the Israeli military said.
lead_paragraph: Palestinian militants launched two rockets from Gaza toward southern Israel late Wednesday, the Israeli military said. The rockets landed in open ground and caused no injuries but were a blow to the informal cease-fire that ended last summer’s 50-day Gaza war. It was the second rocket attack in eight days after a period of relative calm. Although Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, has worked to enforce the cease-fire with Israel, smaller, more radical groups are thought to have been responsible for the recent rocket fire, a sign of internal Palestinian tensions. One such group claimed responsibility for firing the rockets on Wednesday, but Israel says it holds Hamas responsible for all fire emanating from Gaza. In retaliation, Israel on Thursday bombed three militant training camps, but there were no casualties, Reuters reported.

lead_paragraph: One of the hardest things to come by in sports is objectivity without emotion. You can find desire on the fields, devotion in the stands and anger on the radio.

lead_paragraph: Mario Cooper, a former Democratic political operative who gained prominence in the 1990s by pressing leaders in Washington and the black community to address the disproportionate effect of AIDS on minorities, died on May 29 in Washington. He was 61.

headline: Massachusetts: President Quits Boston Library as Art Goes Missing
abstract: The president of the Boston Public Library resigned Wednesday amid a federal investigation into the disappearance of two artworks reported to be worth more than $600,000 from the library’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The president of the Boston Public Library resigned Wednesday amid a federal investigation into the disappearance of two artworks from the library’s collection. Amy Ryan, who became the president of the library system in 2008, stepped down hours after announcing new security measures for the system’s holdings. The two works, a 1634 Rembrandt etching valued at $20,000 to $30,000 and a 1504 Albrecht Durer engraving valued at $600,000, were discovered missing in April. Officials said the Rembrandt was believed to have been gone for more than a year. It was unclear whether the pieces were stolen or misfiled.

headline: A Team With More Twists Than the Cuyahoga, and Just as Much Grit
abstract: After a struggle of a season, filled with slumps, spurts and injuries, the Cavaliers enter the finals with a city’s hopes on their shoulders.
lead_paragraph: There is considerable drama — some might even say poetic justice — in the Cleveland Cavaliers’ run to the N.B.A. finals. The story began as a tight, neat narrative, constructed out of max contracts and free agency, at a time when professional basketball teams were not so much built as they were cast, like boy bands.

headline: Günther Schneider-Siemssen Dies at 88; Envisioned Elaborate Opera Stage Sets
abstract: Mr. Schneider­-Siemssen originally studied to be a conductor until he was persuaded to use his artistic ability to interpret music visually instead.
lead_paragraph: Günther Schneider-Siemssen, the opera stage designer who created the Romantic, naturalistic sets that allowed a generation of Wagnerites at the Metropolitan Opera to watch Rhinemaidens frolic in the Rhine and hear Meistersingers sing in a fairy-tale Nuremberg, died on Tuesday in Vienna. He was 88.
