lead_paragraph: When Mayor Bill de Blasio signed legislation a year ago that increased the number of older New Yorkers eligible to have their rents frozen, he called it a “godsend” and an “extraordinary lifeline” for people whose incomes could not keep pace with the cost of living.

headline: Gary Bettman Denies Brain Disease Link
abstract: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman on Wednesday stood by his recent comment that there was no definitive evidence linking hockey and chronic traumatic encephalopathy.
lead_paragraph: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman on Wednesday stood by his recent comment that there was no definitive evidence linking hockey and chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease that scientists have found in many athletes who played contact sports. Bettman said his views echoed those of the federal court judge who approved a settlement between the N.F.L. and thousands of retired players. The N.H.L. is being sued by former players who say the league did not warn them of the dangers of concussions.

headline: At Home With Ana Kras, New York Design Star of the Moment
abstract: The Serbian-born furniture designer, illustrator, photographer and model opens up her Lower East Side apartment to T.
lead_paragraph: “It’s an improvisation of an apartment,” says Ana Kras, the Serbian-born furniture maker, illustrator, photographer and model, of the whitewashed one-bedroom she recently moved into on New York’s Lower East Side. With its double-size windows and high ceilings, the space feels substantially larger than its 500 square feet. The spontaneous, uncluttered aesthetic is due in part to circumstance: Kras has only been living in this apartment a week or so, and most of her things are still with her parents in Belgrade, where she grew up and studied at the University of Applied Arts, and in Los Angeles, her home base until she relocated to New York two years ago. In addition, she has just returned from a 5-day trip to Marfa, Tex., where she shot the fall/holiday look book for Lou & Grey as the new face of the brand (she has also contributed to the Ampersand, its new online magazine).

headline: New Research Says Robots Are Unlikely to Eat Our Jobs
abstract: Clever software and smart machines are automating jobs. But a new McKinsey Global Institute study and a Harvard Business Review article point to an upside: technology as a helper and partner.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of angst about the relentless advance of digital technology and what it means for the work force, if not humanity. Dire warnings have come from no less than Elon Musk, Stephen Hawking and Bill Gates. “Summoning the demon” was Mr. Musk’s evocative phrase to describe the potential danger posed by artificial intelligence.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (AMC) JAWS (1975) Steven Spielberg directed this summer blockbuster classic. Amity Island, a beach town, is on alert after a shark attack, but local officials want to avert economic disaster at the height of the tourist season. Martin Brody (Roy Scheider) is the police chief, new to Amity Island, who teams up with the oceanographer Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) and the grizzled fisherman Quint (Robert Shaw, above right, with Mr. Scheider, center, and Mr. Dreyfuss) to hunt the shark. “It may not look like much but it puts good actors to the test,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “They have to work very hard just to appear alive, and Mr. Scheider, Mr. Shaw and Mr. Dreyfuss come across with wit and easy self-assurance.”

headline: Rohingya Refugees: Stateless in Southeast Asia
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Photography', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Smuggling']
abstract: A Bangladeshi photographer has dedicated himself to covering the plight of Rohingya refugees who fled Myanmar only to find themselves stateless.
lead_paragraph: The Bangladeshi photographer Saiful Huq Omi has spent six years photographing Rohingya Muslims who fled persecution in Myanmar only to find themselves stateless. When he visited refugees in Bangladesh, where more than 200,000 Rohingya now live, he heard stories of torture, rape and murder as well as those about a lack of basic freedoms. While few other people in the world were interested in the plight of these stateless refugees at the time, he felt compelled to focus on them. For Mr. Huq it was personal.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg, Let Me Pay for Facebook
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Media', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: “Free” social networking sites cost more than we think.
lead_paragraph: FACEBOOK. Instagram. Google. Twitter. All services we rely on — and all services we believe we don’t have to pay for. Not with cash, anyway. But ad-financed Internet platforms aren’t free, and the price they extract in terms of privacy and control is getting only costlier.

headline: Voting Case Has Potential to Put House Further Out of Reach for Democrats
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The Supreme Court will decide whether districts should have equal numbers of eligible voters or equal numbers of people.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Republicans won a majority of seats in the House even though more people voted for Democratic candidates over all. This is because of structural biases, factors that allow a party to outperform its share of the popular vote. The Republicans are expected to again have a big advantage in 2016 because of such factors, which include gerrymandering and the tendency of Democratic voters to be concentrated in cities.

headline: ‘Transgender, at War and in Love’
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Discrimination']
abstract: This short documentary shares the challenges of a transgender military couple, who are banned from serving openly.
lead_paragraph: This Op-Doc video profiles a transgender airman named Logan Ireland, who recently completed a deployment serving as male, the gender he knows himself to be. Remarkably, after telling his leaders and some peers that his sex was assigned female at birth, he received their support—despite military policy that prevents transgender people from serving openly. Meanwhile, his fiancée, Laila Villanueva, who was assigned male at birth, has a similar scenario, but works without the support of her command.

lead_paragraph: Staff Sgt. Loeri Harrison could receive the paperwork any day now, forms certifying that after an exemplary eight-year Army career, she is no longer fit for duty and must leave Fort Bragg because she is transgender.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Woman Behind Caitlyn Jenner’s Vanity Fair Cover
abstract: Do you think Caitlyn Jenner’s very public introduction to the world was successful?
lead_paragraph: In “The Woman Behind Caitlyn Jenner’s Vanity Fair Cover,” Matthew Schneier writes about designing the cover.

headline: Test Yourself | Best in Show at the World Taxidermy Championships

lead_paragraph: Below, several paragraphs from a June 1 article, “Masters of Taxidermy Seek to Replicate More Than an Animal’s Appearance.”

headline: In Downtown Brooklyn, a Rental With No Stairs
abstract: Chuck and Cindy Nemser left their long-held townhouse in Park Slope, Brooklyn, for a rental that offered easier living.
lead_paragraph: When Chuck and Cindy Nemser bought their Park Slope townhouse in 1966, an aunt of Ms. Nemser’s observed that there was no bathroom on the main floor.

headline: Welcome to the Age of Digital Imperialism
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Smartphones', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Silicon Valley is spreading a peculiarly American vision of the future. How will the rest of the world respond?
lead_paragraph: In March, the Culture Ministry of Thailand sent out an unusual communiqué. Women, it seems, both locals and tourists, were snapping pictures of their breasts from beneath, in an act known colloquially as the “underboob selfie.” The ministry reminded women that sharing such images was banned under the Computer Crime Act of 2007 and that offenders could face five years in prison. Since the shots were cropped below the face, a ministry spokesman acknowledged to Reuters, prosecuting the scofflaws would be difficult. But this flaunting of flesh, the spokesman feared, might tempt others toward the same indelicacy. “We can only warn people to not take it up,” he said. “They are inappropriate actions.”

headline: Is Translation an Art or a Math Problem?
keywords: ['Translation and Interpreters', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: Google and other tech dreamers think machines can make languages superfluous.
lead_paragraph: One Enlightenment aspiration that the science-­fiction industry has long taken for granted, as a necessary intergalactic conceit, is the universal translator. In a 1967 episode of “Star Trek,” Mr. Spock assembles such a device from spare parts lying around the ship. An elongated chrome cylinder with blinking red-and-green indicator lights, it resembles a retracted light saber; Captain Kirk explains how it works with an off-the-cuff disquisition on the principles of Chomsky’s “universal grammar,” and they walk outside to the desert-­island planet of Gamma Canaris N, where they’re being held hostage by an alien. The alien, whom they call The Companion, materializes as a fraction of sparkling cloud. It looks like an orange Christmas tree made of vaporized mortadella. Kirk grips the translator and addresses their kidnapper in a slow, patronizing, put-down-the-gun tone. The all-­powerful Companion is astonished.

headline: New Convertibles Invite Drivers to Come Out and Play
abstract: The coming 2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata is just one sign of the resurgence of a type of car associated more with sun and fun than practicality.
lead_paragraph: CONVERTIBLE makers and fans might be forgiven for humming a few bars of “Here Comes the Sun.”

headline: A Music-Sharing Network for the Unconnected
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Folk Music']
abstract: In Mali’s “digital Bamako” markets, vendors fill old phones with new songs — and jump-start a homegrown musical community.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades, cellphones have ushered in a communications revolution in Africa. The entire country of Mali, for example, has just 120,000 landlines to serve a population of 15 million. But as of 2012 there were enough cellphones in service in Mali for every man, woman and child. The spread of cellphones in this way has driven innovation across the continent. M-Pesa, a text-message-based money-transfer system, has made financial services available for the first time to millions. Another enterprise tells rural farmers by text what their crops might sell for in distant markets; mass-texting campaigns have helped promote major public health initiatives.

headline: In Philippe Parreno’s ‘H{N)Y P N(Y}OSIS,’ Art Is the Big Idea
abstract: The artist prepares to open his largest exhibition to date in the United States, at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: When he was young, the French artist Philippe Parreno had a fantasy in which he would open his mouth and a beam of projector light would shoot out, casting his thoughts onto whatever was in front of him, medium and message in one human head. “My imagination would just be easy and available,” he once told the computer scientist Jaron Lanier.

headline: Art-Directing a Garden in Bucks County
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: Richard Ferretti and James Gager, creative directors of Estée Lauder and MAC Cosmetics, created a sometimes fantastical landscape at their Pennsylvania farm.
lead_paragraph: Memorial Day weekend was a working holiday this year for Richard Ferretti and James Gager. Coltsfoot Farm, their place in Bucks County, Pa., was opening to the public on June 6, for a garden tour to benefit the New Hope Historical Society, and they were busy grooming it.

headline: What Has YouTube Taught You?
abstract: Are there any how-to video series that you go back to over and over?
lead_paragraph: Online how-to videos are available on seemingly any subject. Want to learn how to apply mascara? Caulk a bathtub? Slay Minecraft’s Ender Dragon?

headline: Moldova, Hunting for Missing Millions, Finds Only Ash
abstract: The disappearance of the cash from three lenders, which are now insolvent, has exposed deep-rooted corruption and the power of business oligarchs.
lead_paragraph: IALOVENI, Moldova — A thick carpet of white ash in the back of a burned-out Volkswagen van is all that remains of the final, desperate act in a banking swindle so enormous that it cost this impoverished Eastern European nation the equivalent of an eighth of its annual economic output.

headline: A Stamp, Tiny and Rare, Fulfills a Boyhood Dream
abstract: The 1856 One-Cent Magenta that Stuart Weitzman, the shoe designer, bought anonymously for $9.5 million last year will be displayed at the National Postal Museum in Washington for two and a half years.
lead_paragraph: As a boy in Queens with a couple of stamp albums, Stuart Weitzman stared at the blank spaces for two of the world’s most famous stamps — spaces that he figured he would never fill. One was for an 1856 One-Cent Magenta from British Guiana, and there is only one One-Cent Magenta in all the world.

headline: Review: In ‘Spy,’ Melissa McCarthy Is a C.I.A. Drudge Who Goes Rogue
abstract: Ms. McCarthy leads a starry cast in this action-comedy about an intelligence officer who proves her mettle in heroic and ridiculous ways.
lead_paragraph: In “Spy,” a wild, profane, surprisingly bloody caper-comedy, Melissa McCarthy appears on screen with various sidekicks, nemeses, foils, straight men (and women) and human punching bags. Among them are Jason Statham, Jude Law, Allison Janney, Bobby Cannavale and Rose Byrne, who are accomplished and by now fairly well-established banterers and counterpunchers in their own right. Even better — and less familiar — are Peter Serafinowicz and the marvelous Miranda Hart (Chummy to all you “Call the Midwife” fans out there) as two of the unlikelier C.I.A. employees in recent cinema.

headline: Steve Kerr and David Blatt Reached N.B.A. Finals on Unconventional Paths
abstract: The series will be a matchup of Kerr and Blatt, first-time head coaches whose personal histories have forcefully crashed the borders of conventionalism.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — It was appropriate that the first substantial meeting between two worldly, soon to be first-year N.B.A. head coaches would take place in an international airport.

headline: Correction Commissioner Calls Overhauling Rikers a ‘Long, Heavy Lift’
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Joseph Ponte has been caught off guard by the New York City jail complex: Just over a year into his tenure, the level of violence is higher than ever, and corruption persists.
lead_paragraph: This is what counts for success nowadays at Rikers Island.

headline: High-Speed Rail Aids Disaster Deployments by Chinese Military
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'High-Speed Rail Projects', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The presence of uniformed personnel on a Shanghai train platform this week highlighted how high-speed rail had facilitated not just family reunions and business deals, but troop movements and disaster relief.
lead_paragraph: Loudspeakers screeched no-smoking warnings as scores of men in blue camouflage uniforms massed on platforms No. 6 and 7 at the Hongqiao Railway Station in Shanghai early Tuesday afternoon, 16 hours after the capsizing of the Oriental Star cruise ship with 456 people on board.

headline: ‘Mislaid,’ by Nell Zink
abstract: Nell Zink’s novel about the making and unmaking of an American family lays bare our assumptions about race and sexuality.
lead_paragraph: Toward the middle of Nell Zink’s “Mislaid,” a screwball comic novel of identity, Karen, a Southern white girl whose lesbian mother has raised her as black for complicated reasons, innocently asks a new friend, as though she were inquiring about her major: “What minority are you?”

headline: Stephen King: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “Finders Keepers” has never read Jane Austen. “I do not say this with either pride or shame (or prejudice, for that matter). It’s just a fact.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “Finders Keepers” has never read Jane Austen. “I do not say this with either pride or shame (or prejudice, for that matter). It’s just a fact.”

headline: Biking Through History in Philadelphia
abstract: A new bicycle sharing program, and a challenging race, are two reasons to see Philadelphia on two wheels.
lead_paragraph: With the April launch of Indego, Philadelphia’s 24-hour bike share program, the city now has a network similar to New York’s Citi Bike; Washington, D.C.’s Capital Bikeshare; and bike programs in other cities. (Philadelphia is also on our list of 52 Places to Go for 2015.) A bike can be rented with a credit or debit card at any Indego docking station for $4 per half-hour, an ideal option for neighborhood trips. There is also an option to find open bikes at individual stations online.

headline: Today’s Travel News and Tips
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including a new guide to Brooklyn and a health care app for women on the road.
lead_paragraph: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Behind Picasso’s Curtain, the Ballet That Got Away
abstract: With the New-York Historical Society unveiling Picasso’s work for “Le Tricorne,” it’s worth asking why the ballet has become a rarity.
lead_paragraph: Why has the ballet “Le Tricorne” — often performed in English-speaking countries as “The Three-Cornered Hat” — become a rarity? This was one of the artistic triumphs of the first half of the 20th century. A study in Spanish folk vitality presented by Serge Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes (which spent 1916 to 1918 in Spain), it had music by Manuel de Falla, designs by Pablo Picasso and choreography by Léonide Massine (who danced the lead role, the Miller).You’d think that the sheer celebrity value of its designs would make companies want to stage it, and the colorful energies of its score are intoxicating.

headline: New York Today: Where Falcons Nest
abstract: Thursday: Newborn falcons, overcast skies and a view from the top.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this mild Thursday.

headline: Ex-FIFA Official Jack Warner Threatens to Spill ‘Avalanche’ of Secrets
abstract: Mr. Warner said that he feared for his life and that he had evidence linking soccer’s governing body to an election in Trinidad and Tobago.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jack Warner, the former FIFA vice president who was among 14 people indicted by a United States grand jury as part of an inquiry into corruption in world soccer, says he knows why the organization’s president, Sepp Blatter, announced plans to step down.

headline: Romanticizing ‘Broken Windows’ Policing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Some communities are being asked either to accept collateral damage in the war on crime, or complain about excessive force only to have criminals roam free.
lead_paragraph: There has been a recent spike in violent crimes, particularly shooting, in major cities in the United States. What precisely is fueling it is hard to know. There are more theories and conjecture than there is data. There may in the end be many contributing factors.

headline: Rick Perry to Run for President in 2016, Shrugging Off 2012 Missteps
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Perry is the latest candidate to enter a crowded field of Republican contenders, declared and undeclared, several of whom have Texas ties.
lead_paragraph: ADDISON, Tex. — Rick Perry, the former Texas governor whose 2012 campaign for the White House turned into a political disaster that left him humbled and weakened, announced Thursday that he would run for president again in 2016, exuding confidence in front of a crowd of veterans while making no specific reference to his first unsuccessful bid.

headline: In Vermont, Frustrations Mount Over Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Though other states have also struggled to establish exchanges, Vermont, which saw the law as a bridge to a single-payer system, has acutely felt its problems.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Just a few years ago, lawmakers in this left-leaning state viewed President Obama’s Affordable Care Act as little more than a pit stop on the road to a far more ambitious goal: single-payer, universal health care for all residents.

headline: Today in Politics: All Eyes on Texas
abstract: The field for the Democratic nomination grew to four on Wednesday, and Mrs. Clinton now heads to Texas to give what her aides are describing as a major speech on voting rights and protections.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where just across the Potomac in Arlington, Va., Lincoln Chafee, the former Rhode Island senator and governor, announced his candidacy for president with some words on measurements. But the campaign spotlight swings to Texas, where former Gov. Rick Perry will make his own announcement outside Dallas, and Hillary Rodham Clinton will discuss voting rights in Houston. And another politician with Texas ties, Jeb Bush, has a big announcement planned for June 15.

headline: Why a Presidential Campaign Is the Ultimate Start-Up
abstract: Managing a presidential candidate’s campaign is a lot like steering a hot tech start-up through its early years, and if successful, having to scale up very fast.
lead_paragraph: A new start-up in Brooklyn Heights has 80,000 square feet of freshly leased office space, computer boxes used as improvised furniture and enormous ambitions.

headline: Scenes from the Tiananmen Memorial Events in Hong Kong
abstract: Twenty-six years after the military suppression of the protests at Tiananmen Square in Beijing, thousands gathered in Hong Kong to mourn those killed.
lead_paragraph: June 4 marks the 26th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on protesters in Beijing, which left hundreds, possibly thousands, of people dead. In Hong Kong, residents have long gathered to remember those killed. This year, different groups in the semiautonomous Chinese city held separate vigils, a sign of the increasing complex sense of local identity and concerns among some that commemorating the 1989 protests at Tiananmen Square detracts from efforts to cultivate democracy in Hong Kong, as Crystal Tse and Alan Wong report.

headline: Hong Kong’s Young People Feel Less Invested in Fight for Democracy on Mainland
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Divisions over how to commemorate the Tiananmen crackdown show how Hong Kong residents are increasingly seeing the push for a freer China as someone else’s fight.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For the first time in years, Hui King-to chose not to take part in the candlelight vigil in Victoria Park here commemorating those who died during the Chinese government’s suppression of protests in Tiananmen Square in Beijing on June 4, 1989.

headline: Hillary Clinton, in Texas, Tries to Win Over Forlorn Democrats
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s decision to deliver a substantive, high-profile speech on voting rights in Houston can do much to assuage concerns that the state is merely a fund-raising stop.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It’s lonely to be a Democrat in Texas these days.

headline: Morning Agenda: Dish and T-Mobile Said to Be Discussing Merger
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Dish and T-Mobile Said to Be Discussing Merger | Elliott Management Takes On Samsung Group | Positive Signals on Greek Debt Deal | Unasked Questions in Justice Meeting With Goldman
lead_paragraph: DISH AND T-MOBILE SAID TO BE DISCUSSING MERGER | The American media and communications sector could see yet another big merger soon,  The Wall Street Journal reports, this time involving Dish Network and T-Mobile. Citing people familiar with the matter, the newspaper reports that the talks are in “the formative stage” but that the two sides are in close agreement about the structure of the enlarged company, with Charlie Ergen, Dish’s chief executive, as the new entity’s chairman and John Legere, T-Mobile’s chief executive, as the new chief executive.

headline: Global Stock Markets React to Uncertainty in Asia and Europe
abstract: Fluctuations in Chinese stocks, concerns about the Greek debt crisis and a rout in European bonds contributed to shares’ fickle movements.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Volatility weighed on global stock markets on Thursday as a roller coaster trading day in China added to the grinding uncertainty about the debt crisis in Greece. A rout in European bonds continued.

headline: ‘Joan of Arc at the Stake,’ Distilled to Her Essence at the New York Philharmonic
abstract: After centuries of appropriation of the French warrior for political ends, Arthur Honegger’s 1938 oratorio depicts Joan as a naïve teenager.
lead_paragraph: In the Metropolitan Museum of Art hangs a large, mesmerizing painting of Joan of Arc by the 19th-century French painter Jules Bastien-Lepage. Joan’s gaze is both innocent and determined, her blue eyes focused on something that seems to hold her in thrall.

headline: A Short Blast of Optimism About Democracy and The Press
abstract: Heading off the grid for a few days to talk and listen at IRE conference.
lead_paragraph: There aren’t many days when I feel optimistic about American democracy and how the press is functioning in its role of watchdog and keeping citizens informed. But Wednesday was one of them.

headline: Speaking Out Against Autism Speaks, Even if It Means No Ice Cream
abstract: An ice-cream-cone-size donation to a charity I disagree with isn’t much — but it’s too much.
lead_paragraph: Last month, my 5-year-old daughter told me that her after-school program was raising money for Autism Speaks. She was excited because (as explained via emails and fliers from the school), the fund-raiser would take place at a local ice cream store and all her friends would be there. The money would go to support a particularly beloved teacher running the New York marathon on behalf of the charity. My daughter, very excited, asked if we could go.

headline: First Draft Focus: Saying Goodbye to Beau Biden
abstract: Mourners lined up to sign a condolence book in the Senate reception room at the Capitol Building after the death of Beau Biden, son of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Throwback Thursday | On Summer Hiatus
abstract: What did you think of this feature? We began it last July and have covered everything from shark attacks and Disneyland to the Scopes Trial and the Space race — all with the goal of showing students how easy and fun it can be to use the Times archives to investigate American history and culture.
lead_paragraph: We began this feature last July, with a post about Disneyland, and followed it with entries on topics from the Scopes trial to the space race, shark attacks, “Star Wars,” teenage slang and the Simpsons. Along the way, we hope we showed students how easy and fun it can be to use the New York Times archives to investigate American history and culture.

headline: Cheered Up by a Blue Crab
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young, unemployed acting student was feeling depressed until he saw something worse off than he: a blue crab walking up 10th Avenue.

keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: British regulators are expected to fine the lender in excess of $153 million as part of a settlement, according to a person familiar with the discussions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British regulators are preparing to impose a substantial fine on the Lloyds Banking Group for its handling of customer complaints related to a contentious insurance product that has cost the industry billions of dollars, a person familiar with the settlement discussions said on Thursday.

headline: Are New Fashion Capitals on the Rise?
abstract: An exhibition at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology considers cities like Tokyo and Lagos, Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: One of the thorniest questions in fashion today is brand nationality.

headline: Turkey's Election Sends Message to Erdogan
abstract: Several features of the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was once seen as a role model for the Middle East, show him to have spent more than a decade silencing political dissent and amassing power.
lead_paragraph: Several features of the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was once seen as a role model for the Middle East, show him to have spent more than a decade silencing political dissent and amassing power.

headline: SoundCloud Reaches Royalty Deal With 20,000 Record Labels
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Royalties', 'Music', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The popular music streaming service, which says it has 175 million monthly users, has been facing industry pressure to strike formal licensing deals.
lead_paragraph: With its sleek design and easy integration with social media, SoundCloud has become one of the most popular sites for streaming music. But it has long had a tense relationship with the music industry because it lacked formal licensing deals, and so paid no royalties.

headline: Daily Report: Apple to Announce Developer Tools for Watch, Plus Music Streaming Plan
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Software', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: Apple is set to unveil new app tools for its watch on Monday, as well as software updates and a streaming music service.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Apple will begin its annual developer conference, where the company is set to release new tools for software developers to create smarter apps that will gain deep access to the watch’s heart-rate and motion sensors, among other components, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Gas Station Explosion in Ghana’s Capital Kills Around 100
abstract: The blast occurred overnight while the station was packed with people seeking shelter from knee-high water caused by rain that has flooded much of the city.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Roughly 100 people have died after an explosion sent flames coursing through a gas station in the center of Accra, the Ghanaian capital, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Jack Warner Says He Knows FIFA’s Secrets
abstract: Mr. Warner, a former vice president of soccer’s governing body and a central figure in its scandal, vowed on Wednesday to reveal all he knows about Sepp Blatter and corruption within the organization.

headline: 3 People Are Fatally Shot in a Car on Long Island

lead_paragraph: WYANDANCH, N.Y. — Three people sitting in a parked car were shot and killed late Wednesday night and a fourth was wounded in the gunfire on a residential street in this Long Island community, the authorities said.

headline: What Rick Perry Would Need to Do to Win
abstract: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is announcing his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday. Here is a look at what he will need to do if he hopes to win.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is announcing his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday. Here is a look at what he will need to do if he hopes to win.

headline: Rick Perry on the Issues
abstract: Mr. Perry left office in January after 14 years as governor of Texas, during which he kept taxes low and eased government regulation of the private sector.
lead_paragraph: Rick Perry, the longest-serving governor of Texas, on Thursday entered the race for the Republican presidential nomination. He left office in January after running the state for 14 years, during which he promoted business-friendly policies like keeping taxes low and easing government regulation of the private sector. Here are his stands on important issues.

headline: South Korea Confirms 2 More Deaths in MERS Outbreak
abstract: Two men, ages 82 and 76, were the country’s latest victims of an illness that has forced over 1,160 schools and kindergartens to shut down temporarily.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The number of people who have died of Middle East respiratory syndrome in South Korea increased to four on Friday after officials confirmed two more deaths in what has become the largest outbreak of the virus outside the Middle East.

headline: In Spotlight, Chinese Officials Are Reluctant to Embrace Transparency After Yangtze Disaster
abstract: Efforts to rescue any survivors among the 345 people still missing from a capsized ship on the Yangtze River were to proceed with “urgency.”
lead_paragraph: JIANLI, China — On the main Chinese state television network Thursday night, a news anchor read out pronouncements that President Xi Jinping and the Communist Party’s other six leaders had made at a meeting that day.

headline: Tsipras and Greece Buy Time From I.M.F.
abstract: Amid tense negotiations, Athens invoked a little-used option to defer June payments to the International Monetary Fund until the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As it tries to negotiate a new bailout deal with creditors, Greece got some breathing room on Thursday by deferring a series of debt payments until the end of the month.

headline: Yvonne Rainer Prepares Her Newest Dance for New York
abstract: The choreographer, 80, reflects on her work, including her 1966 solo “Trio A.”
lead_paragraph: “Either I’m not warmed up, or I’m too old for this,” Yvonne Rainer said on a recent afternoon, as she demonstrated a brain-teasing section of her 1966 solo “Trio A.” About 20 students, from highly trained dancers to adventurous novices, had gathered at Danspace Project in the East Village to learn a work that, perhaps more than any other piece of choreography, has become synonymous with the term postmodern dance.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Strange Vision
abstract: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a healthy 31-year-old woman who starts seeing wavy patterns before her eyes, followed by terrible headaches, odd tingling sensations and tiny strokes?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a healthy 31-year-old woman who, while working in Africa, starts seeing wavy patterns before her eyes, followed by terrible headaches, odd tingling sensations and tiny strokes that just won’t stop?

lead_paragraph: In a video released online Thursday, Rick Perry, the former Texas governor, announced that he was joining the Republican field for the 2016 presidential race.

headline: 1940: U.S. Urged to End Neutrality
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The New York Herald Tribune urges the U.S. to end Neutrality, 1940.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The New York Herald Tribune, in an editorial entitled ‘‘An End of Neutrality,’’ today [June 4] said: ‘‘In the judgment of this newspaper the time has come for the United States to stand up before the nations of the world and declare that while reasserting its non-belligerence, its neutrality in respect to the European war has come to an end.

headline: New E.T.F.s Appeal to Those With Bigger Appetites for Risk
abstract: One new fund tracks the dividends that companies pay, while another mimics core hedge fund strategies.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a fund that offers exposure to the strategies of the world’s sharpest hedge fund investors. Or one that tracks the steady dividends paid by companies like Apple, instead of their more volatile shares.

headline: The Most Cursed Sports Cities in America
abstract: The N.B.A. finals feature two fan bases that have endured years of suffering: Cleveland’s and Oakland’s. Here, we rank the top 13 cities by sports agony.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. finals feature two fan bases that have endured years of suffering: Cleveland’s and Oakland’s. Here, we rank the top 13 cities by sports agony.

headline: Ahead of Election, Erdogan Cracks Down on Critics
abstract: In his latest attack on the media, he accused a newspaper editor of espionage.
lead_paragraph: It’s three days before Turkey’s hotly-contested parliamentary election on Sunday and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the strongman of Turkish politics, is feeling desperate. How else to explain his incessant and outlandish attacks against the media and other critics?

headline: In Sardinia, an Affordable Family-Run Farm Stay
abstract: The farm and guesthouse Agriturismo La Sorgente provided a glimpse into Sardinia’s rural past and still rural present.
lead_paragraph: The lone albino donkey, Michael Malloru explained as he petted the good-natured fellow, was named for the captain that sunk the Costa Concordia cruise ship in 2012 and was later convicted of manslaughter. “The asno is named Capitano Schettino, and Capitano Schettino is an asino,” he said in Italian, using an alternative word for donkey. “Get it?”

headline: Boston and Pittsburgh, America’s Most Successful Sports Cities
abstract: Championships are commonplace in some cities. Elsewhere, painful, late playoff losses are the norm.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a Boston sports fan over the age of 30, it may be emotionally difficult for you to think of your teams as successful. (Disclosure: I am, and it is.) But the facts are pretty clear: Boston is America’s most successful modern sports town.

headline: Poll Finds Big Support for Pathway to Citizenship
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Nearly three-quarters of Americans say they support a pathway to legal status for undocumented immigrants, according to a poll published by the Pew Research Center.
lead_paragraph: With presidential contenders on all sides struggling to refine their positions on the prickly issue of immigration, nearly three-quarters of Americans say they support a pathway to legal status for undocumented immigrants, according to a poll published Thursday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Swiss Prosecutors End HSBC Inquiry Without Filing Charges
abstract: HSBC will pay about $42.8 million to settle the inquiry into possible money laundering at its Swiss private bank and won’t face criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prosecutors in Switzerland said on Thursday that they had ended an investigation into possible money laundering at HSBC’s Swiss private bank without filing any criminal charges.

headline: I.M.F. Urges Fed to Delay Raising Interest Rates
abstract: Citing slower-than-expected economic growth, the International Monetary Fund said early 2016 would be a better time to raise the benchmark rate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund said Thursday that the Federal Reserve should wait until next year before raising its benchmark interest rate, citing the stubborn persistence of sluggish inflation.

headline: Fracking and the Texas Non-Miracle
abstract: A pretty big deal.
lead_paragraph: Grr. I’ve been meaning to write about the Texas economic stumble, but have to some extent been scooped by the business desk. Still, there’s more to say, particularly about the role of the energy sector in the previous boom.

headline: Review: Robert Irwin Shows a Calming Installation at Dia:Beacon
abstract: Today’s art world can seem like a boiling caldron of bile and tears heated by a bonfire of money. This transporting show offers relief.
lead_paragraph: A lot of contemporary art is agitating. Gratuitous sexual provocation and moral bullying; sensory irritation and intellectual grandiosity; gaudy spectacle and cults of personality. Roiled by such strident forms of sociopathology, today’s art and its attendant New York society can sometimes seem like a boiling caldron of bile and tears heated by a bonfire of money. In many ways, it’s not so different from the mainstream cultures of music, movies, television and politics, and it’s usually not as entertaining.

headline: Official Describes Ghana Gas Explosion
abstract: Prince Billy Anaglate, a spokesman for the local fire service, said on Thursday that a blast at a gas station in Ghana was caused by a nearby fire that spread to other buildings.
lead_paragraph: Prince Billy Anaglate, a spokesman for the local fire service, said on Thursday that a blast at a gas station in Ghana was caused by a nearby fire that spread to other buildings.

headline: Dog Days at Men’s Style
abstract: The editor of Men’s Style introduces the section’s latest star, a dog named Bodhi.
lead_paragraph: A while back I noticed an exciting development in men’s fashion – the appearance of Menswear Dog on Tumblr.

headline: A Collection of Dutch Artifacts 50 Years in the Making
abstract: George Way can remember where he bought almost everything and how much he paid.
lead_paragraph: The antiques collector George Way navigates his one-bedroom apartment on Staten Island via narrow passageways amid a profusion of dark oak armchairs and daybeds. Given the density, the untrained eye would never suspect that his home is actually a little less crowded these days. That’s because about 130 of his antiques now fill three galleries at the Orangetown Historical Museum & Archives in Orangeburg, N.Y., for the exhibition “From Holland to Here: Featuring the George Way Collection of Dutch Artifacts,” running through Nov. 15.

headline: Celebrating 100 Years of Pyrex
abstract: This exhibition showcases glass vessels in patriotic, psychedelic and Op Art motifs.
lead_paragraph: The Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., is exploring the strategies of mid-20th-century cookware marketers with its new exhibition, “America’s Favorite Dish: Celebrating a Century of Pyrex,” opening on Saturday. Glass vessels in patriotic, psychedelic and Op Art motifs will be displayed along with the advertisements that suggested the products would make for happy marriages, easy meals and spotless kitchens.

headline: A Johannes Spitler Chest Goes to Auction
abstract: The circa 1800 piece, one of about two dozen chests attributed to Spitler, is expected to fetch $200,000 to $300,000.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen colorfully painted chests have been attributed to Johannes Spitler, a furniture maker briefly active in Virginia around 1800. Descendants of an original owner of a Spitler chest, painted with tulips and birds, have consigned it to a June 20 sale at the Jeffrey S. Evans & Associates auction house in Mount Crawford, Va. It is expected to sell for $200,000 to $300,000.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Movies', 'Theater', 'Music', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Need something to do? The Times’s arts team is here for you.
lead_paragraph: Need something fun to do?

headline: Hunting for Hackers, N.S.A. Secretly Expands Internet Spying at U.S. Border
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Searching for evidence of computer hacking originating abroad, the Obama administration has stepped up warrantless monitoring, documents show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Without public notice or debate, the Obama administration has expanded the National Security Agency‘s warrantless surveillance of Americans’ international Internet traffic to search for evidence of malicious computer hacking, according to classified N.S.A. documents.

headline: Azorean Diaspora Can’t Resist the Powerful Pull of Home
abstract: For North Americans born in or descended from the Azores, ties to the mid-Atlantic Portuguese archipelago remain vital even generations later.
lead_paragraph: PONTA DELGADA, Portugal — Before a recent religious procession here, a wooden statue of the Holy Christ of Miracles was draped in a new cape, but with a distinctly non-Portuguese twist: Images of Canadian maple leaves were woven into its silk and velvet embroidery.

headline: Ronald Perelman Puts Financial Clout Behind Lindsey Graham
abstract: The billionaire businessman Ronald O. Perelman has emerged on the national finance committee list rolled out by Lindsey Graham, the South Carolina senator seeking the Republican nomination for president.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Rodham Clinton left the State Department in 2013, one of the earliest meetings she held was with an old friend, Ronald O. Perelman, the cosmetics billionaire and a major political donor.

headline: Barnard College, After Much Discussion, Decides to Accept Transgender Women
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Gender']
abstract: The new policy welcomes applicants who “consistently live and identify as women, regardless of the gender assigned to them at birth.”
lead_paragraph: Barnard College announced on Thursday that it will begin accepting transgender women, joining a slate of women’s colleges that have created formal policies on whether to admit students who do not identify with their birth sex.

headline: Leaked Snowden Documents Show Expansion of Cybersurveillance by U.S. Agencies
abstract: As the threat of malicious hacking has grown, the National Security Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation have secretly expanded their surveillance of Internet communications flowing to and from the United States, documents provided by the former intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden show.
lead_paragraph: As the threat of malicious hacking has grown, the National Security Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation have secretly expanded their surveillance of Internet communications flowing to and from the United States, documents provided by the former intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden show.

headline: New York Court Rules for Immigrant in Fight to Become Lawyer
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: Cesar Vargas, a Mexican-born New Yorker, became the first immigrant in the state without legal status to be approved to work as a lawyer after an appellate court granted his application to the bar.
lead_paragraph: His legal fight to become a lawyer lasted three years. This week, Cesar Vargas, a Mexican-born 31-year-old New Yorker, became the first immigrant in the state without legal status to be approved to work as a lawyer.

headline: Free TVs in Mexico Are Seen as Having Political Strings Attached
abstract: While the government describes the giveaway as an effort to bring all Mexicans into the digital age, opposition parties call it old-fashioned vote buying.
lead_paragraph: ECATEPEC DE MORELOS, Mexico — Isabel Valdez Rodríguez is expecting to pick up two free 24-inch digital televisions — one for herself; the other for her mother — courtesy of President Enrique Peña Nieto’s government.

headline: How to Enjoy Brooklyn Bridge Park’s New Public Art, According to the Artist
abstract: In a lighthearted instructional video, Jeppe Hein explores the labyrinth of mirrors, interactive fountain and bright benches in his new “Please Touch the Art” space.
lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn Bridge Park, Jeppe Hein’s 18 new installations include a labyrinth of mirrors (reflective planks that recall the Manhattan skyline across the water), timed-cycle fountain (walls of water shoot up from the ground, rotating every so often to create distinct rooms where guests can stand without getting wet) and 16 bright red, playfully shaped benches. The artist aptly titled the lot “Please Touch the Art” — and shows us, in the above video, how to do just that.

headline: Sheryl Sandberg’s Post on Late Husband Sets  Off Meditations on Grief
abstract: Sheryl Sandberg’s post on her late husband, Dave Goldberg, marking the end of a 30-day mourning period, has sparked numerous meditations on grief.
lead_paragraph: Sheryl Sandberg helped women think about their careers. Now she may also help people manage their grief.

headline: 20 Indian Soldiers Killed in Ambush in Manipur
abstract: The attack on a convoy of army vehicles on Thursday by militants in the remote northeast of India is one of the deadliest confrontations in recent years.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least 20 Indian soldiers were killed during an ambush Thursday by militants in the remote northeast of the country, in one of the deadliest confrontations in recent years.

headline: Rick Perry ‘Super PAC’ Ads Going Up in Iowa
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Running ads this early is not particularly effective in terms of luring voters, but it is likely an attempt to raise former Gov. Rick Perry’s profile to help him qualify for the early Republican debates.
lead_paragraph: The “super PAC” supporting former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has made a large reservation for television ad time in two Iowa markets, just as the former Texas governor has announced his second campaign for the White House.

headline: Edinburgh Fringe Will Be Biggest Ever
abstract: The annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August will have over 3,314 shows at 313 venues.
lead_paragraph: The bulky printed program for the 2015 Edinburgh Festival Fringe is being distributed to libraries, stores and other sites around Scotland on Thursday, marking the official start of the annual arts festival that will run Aug. 7-31. This year, 3,314 shows spread across 313 venues will make up the largest Fringe to date (last year’s program included 3,193 shows), organizers announced in Edinburgh on Thursday morning.

headline: Tim Robbins Plays Secretary of State in ‘The Brink’
abstract: Mr. Robbins, once known for “Bob Roberts” and his activism, directs and stars in a political comedy series for HBO.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, in the thick of the presidential campaign between George H. W. Bush and Bill Clinton, Tim Robbins wrote, directed and starred in the barbed political satire “Bob Roberts,” about a conservative Senate candidate and folk singer who co-opts Dylanesque imagery in hopes of winning the election.

headline: Letters: Bloom’s Day
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Harold Bloom’s “The Daemon Knows,” Martin Ford’s “Rise of the Robots” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Burt Reynolds and Johnny Cash Highlight CMT Documentary Lineup
abstract: A documentary on champion chicken breeders is also coming, next year, from the Nashville-based CMT, which is available in 92 million homes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – A documentary billed as “a charming and fascinating look” at champion chicken breeders. A film produced by Morgan Spurlock about “Americans exercising their God-given freedoms, no matter the cost.” An examination of how Burt Reynolds “redefined Southern pride” in 1977 with “Smokey and the Bandit.”

headline: Vahram Mateosian, Owner and Operator of Mr. Ned
abstract: A New York suit maker discusses his trade and the latest men’s fashions.
lead_paragraph: On the fourth floor of a building on lower Fifth Avenue, Vahram Mateosian and his team of veteran tailors and cutters make custom suits, many of which cost $950. The shop, Mr. Ned, has been open since 1965 — long before it became the go-to suit maker for Wes Anderson and a bevy of bankers and lawyers.

headline: Our Father, Who Art on Broadway
abstract: God has assumed many forms on New York stages.
lead_paragraph: God has assumed many forms on New York stages.

headline: British Government to Sell Remaining Stake in Royal Mail
abstract: The move comes nearly two years after an initial public offering for the operator of Britain’s postal service and follows criticism of its pricing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government said on Thursday that it would sell its remaining stake in the Royal Mail as part of an effort to reduce the country’s debt.

headline: 1965: Russia: At Least We Had TV
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Alexei Leonov’s first space walk is transmitted to Russian TV in 1965.
lead_paragraph: Newsreel footage, with no sound, of a Russian cosmonaut outside his spacecraft in 1965. (britishpathe.com)

headline: Critic’s Notebook: Frick Collection Spares a Prized Garden
abstract: The Frick, nudged back to the drawing board by City Hall, has a chance to devise a creative plan for expansion that will leave its Russell Page-designed garden intact.
lead_paragraph: City Hall did the right thing this week, nudging the Frick Collection back to the drawing board, where it should have returned a year ago. Until recently, that museum had clung to its plan to demolish a prized garden on East 70th Street in Manhattan and replace it with an ungainly six-story addition. A coalition of architects, preservationists and landscape designers, joined recently by the Municipal Art Society, had been trying for months to stop the plan.

headline: Stüssy Celebrates 35 Years and More
abstract: Plus: The Ace Hotel has teamed up with Tokyobike; Salvatore Ferragamo’s make-your-own moccasin and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Plus: The Ace Hotel has teamed up with Tokyobike; Salvatore Ferragamo’s make-your-own moccasin and more shopping news.

headline: Public Enemy No. 9
abstract: When Luis Suárez runs out onto the field for Barcelona in Saturday’s Champions League final against Juventus, there will be no shortage of players with a score to settle with him on the other side.
lead_paragraph: When Luis Suárez runs out onto the field for Barcelona in Saturday’s Champions League final against Juventus, there will be no shortage of players with a score to settle with him on the other side.

headline: Zac Posen Resort 2016
abstract: Looks from the collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the collection.

headline: Pakistan’s Pace of Executions Alarms Rights Groups
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A rights group estimated that at least 135 executions have already taken place this year since the lifting of a moratorium on the death penalty in December.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD — Human rights groups expressed concern over the fast pace with which Pakistani authorities are executing death row prisoners, as the total number of executions for the year reached at least 135 this week, higher than for any full year in a decade.

headline: The Liberalism of Adult Autonomy
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'ADULTERY', 'Children and Childhood', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: On the moral commitments of contemporary social liberalism.
lead_paragraph: Reflecting both on Caitlyn né Bruce Jenner and the Gallup data that inspired my own sojourn into polygamy, Damon Linker argues that social conservatives (in particular, his friend and mine Rod Dreher) are wrong to portray the rise of social liberalism as a matter of individualism unbound from all moral restraint. Rather, it represents the triumph of one distinctive moral code, the morality of rights, over another, the morality of ends:

headline: Appealing to Union, Hillary Clinton Calls Teachers ‘Scapegoats’
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: In a Q. and A. with educators this week, Hillary Rodham Clinton said: “It is just dead wrong to make teachers the scapegoats for all of society’s problems. Where I come from, teachers are the solution.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton made an appeal for an endorsement from the American Federation of Teachers this week, suggesting in a private meeting with union officials that critics have turned teachers into “scapegoats for all of society’s problems.”

headline: Ali Smith Wins Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction
abstract: Ms. Smith won the prize for her novel “How to Be Both.”
lead_paragraph: Ali Smith won the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction on Wednesday at a ceremony in London, for “How to Be Both,” an innovatively structured novel about a young girl in modern-day England and a painter in Renaissance Italy.

headline: As Republican Debates Near, Candidates Vie to Make Cut
abstract: Fox News and CNN say only candidates polling in the top 10 will be invited to their debates, sending waves of anxiety into the campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Carly Fiorina is on the clock, a nine-week clock to be exact. That is when the first Republican debate of the 2016 election will happen. And if she does not get her poll numbers up, she will not make the cut.

headline: Did the American Civil War Ever End?
abstract: The conflict revolutionized society, and has resonated through history ever since.
lead_paragraph: When did the Civil War end? Many have answered never. As late as 1949, in an address at Harvard, the writer Ralph Ellison said that the war “is still in the balance, and only our enchantment by the spell of the possible, our endless optimism, has led us to assume that it ever really ended.”

headline: What Do You Know? A Civil War Pop Quiz.
abstract: If you read the series (or if you’re just a huge Civil War nerd), what have you learned?
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t noticed, Americans have been commemorating the sesquicentennial of the Civil War for the past four years. There have been large-scale public events, battle re-enactments and lecture series. There have been books, articles and blog posts. The New York Times started Disunion in October 2010 and its columns have detailed events large and small; people famous and obscure; and causes won, lost, remembered and forgotten between 1861 and 1865.

headline: French Telecom Executive’s Remarks on Israel Incite Furor
abstract: The executive of Orange, licenser to a major Israeli cellphone provider, hit a nerve in Israel, where angst over a pro-Palestinian boycott is growing.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A growing global pro-Palestinian movement to boycott Israel instantly created a national furor on Thursday after the top executive of Orange, a leading French telecommunications company, said he would withdraw from the Israeli market if he could.

headline: Sharing Data, but Not Happily
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Many Americans do not think the trade-off of their data for personalized services, giveaways or discounts is a fair deal, a University of Pennsylvania study found.
lead_paragraph: Should consumers be able to control how companies collect and use their personal data?

headline: New York Festival of Song Announces New Season
abstract: The new season of the New York Festival of Song will include Rachmaninoff and Beatles songs.
lead_paragraph: The New York Festival of Song once again has a busy, diverse season ahead, with works by Rachmaninoff, John Lennon and Paul McCartney, and the contemporary composer David T. Little.

headline: Fracking Has Not Had Big Effect on Water Supply, E.P.A. Says While Noting Risks
abstract: The agency said that though it had found no evidence that hydraulic fracturing has had a widespread effect on drinking water, it has the potential.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A landmark Environmental Protection Agency report on the impact of hydraulic fracturing has found no evidence that the contentious technique of oil and gas extraction has had a widespread effect on the nation’s water supply, the agency said Thursday.

headline: Review: Alexander Calder’s Intimate, Encompassing ‘Multum in Parvo’
abstract: If you require further proof of the greatness of Alexander Calder, this exceptional show should do the trick.
lead_paragraph: If you require further proof of the greatness of Alexander Calder, this exceptional show should do the trick. Intimate and encompassing, it is like a drawing retrospective in three dimensions: a selection of nearly 50 small mobiles and stabiles, a few less than two inches tall, that this American sculptor executed between the mid-1930s and around 1970.

headline: Review: Harry Dodge Meditates on Identity With ‘The Cybernetic Fold’
abstract: A solo show reflects on the fluid nature of the self and how technology alters bodies and consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Harry Dodge is a transgender artist, and although his current solo show — his second for this gallery — doesn’t specifically address his own trajectory or biography, it meditates seriously, and deliriously, on the fluid nature of identity and how technology alters bodies and consciousness.

headline: 3-D Film About Twin Towers High-Wire Walk to Open New York Film Fest
abstract: Joseph Gordon-Levitt will play Philippe Petit in the 3-D movie, directed by Robert Zemeckis.
lead_paragraph: Continuing a recent tradition of using its prestigious opening-night slot to highlight an Oscar aspirant from a mainstream studio, the New York Film Festival said on Thursday that it would open its 53rd installment in late September with the world premiere of “The Walk,” a 3-D dramatic thriller directed by Robert Zemeckis.

headline: When Ownership Changed in 2007, So Did the Blackhawks
abstract: When he took over the Chicago Blackhawks upon his frugal father’s death in 2007, Rocky Wirtz modernized business practices and made the team ascendant.
lead_paragraph: The most common way to turn around a terrible sports franchise is to acquire better players or bring in a new coach. But in the case of the Chicago Blackhawks, the most important change may have been the passing of team ownership from a father to a son.

headline: Dish Network Joins Deal Mania With Bid for T-Mobile
abstract: A deal would provide an answer to what Dish plans to do with its vast wireless spectrum holdings.
lead_paragraph: Merger mania has taken over the media business.

headline: Chloé Resort 2016
abstract: Looks from the collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the collection.

headline: Religious Leaders Urge U.S. to Fund Abortions for Rape Victims in Conflicts Abroad
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'United States International Relations', "Women's Rights", 'United States Politics and Government', 'Foreign Aid', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: A coalition of religious and human rights leaders demanded the aid for girls and women raped by fighters for groups like the Islamic State and Boko Haram.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A starkly worded ad began appearing this week at bus stops near the White House. Next to a silhouette of President Obama’s back reads the words: “Don’t walk away from women and girls raped in conflict. Act now.”

headline: Belmont Stakes 2015: Predictions and Analysis
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: Can American Pharoah win the Triple Crown? A look at the horses in the 147th running of the Belmont Stakes with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert.
lead_paragraph: The horses for the 147th running of the Belmont Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Eric Donovan of Belmont Park.

headline: Corsican Wines Speak a Language of Their Own
abstract: The culture of the Mediterranean island shapes both the personality of the bottles and the character of their producers.
lead_paragraph: PATRIMONIO, France — Antoine Arena was a promising law student in Paris in 1975 when the Corsican independence movement took a violent turn.

headline: Review: Deborah Kass Takes Mug Shots of the Art World
abstract: In an update of Warhol’s “13 Most Wanted Men,” Ms. Kass is showing images of some big names.
lead_paragraph: Considering Deborah Kass’s smart and funny show of screen-printed, black-and-white images apparently copied — and much enlarged — from police mug shots, the casual gallery visitor might wonder: Who are these people? What crimes did they commit? Those who know their Pop Art history will recognize Ms. Kass’s “America’s Most Wanted, 1998-1999” as a late-1990s update of Andy Warhol’s 1964 work “13 Most Wanted Men,” which featured the most wanted criminals of 1962. Seven of Ms. Kass’s works, each seven-and-a-half-feet wide, show their subjects in profile and from the front with a fake police identification placard in the lower left corner. Three more are single head shots.

headline: Flu-Driven Mass Slaughter of Midwest Poultry Conveys the Scale of Our Meat Habit
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Avian Influenza', 'Chickens', 'Meat', 'Meat Packers and Butchers']
abstract: The massive flu-driven slaughter of poultry in the Midwest is tiny compared to the routine slaughter to keep market shelves stocked.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a brief look behind headlines from the Midwest about the scope of the poultry slaughter necessitated by the spread, since last December, of the H5N2 strain of bird flu.

headline: Review: Tom Burckhardt Juggles the Geometric and Organic
abstract: Mr. Burckhardt’s ingeniously thin-skinned paintings may be too appealing to be taken as seriously as they deserve.
lead_paragraph: Tom Burckhardt’s ingeniously thin-skinned paintings may be too appealing to be taken as seriously as they deserve. Brilliant-colored collagelike abstractions, they segue effortlessly between organic and geometric forms that somewhat cartoonishly intimate figures, buildings and landscapes, and resonate with the similarly small, ambiguous paintings of Howard Hodgkin and Thomas Nozkowski.

headline: Every Virus a Person Has Had Can Be Seen in a Drop of Blood, Researchers Find
abstract: The test, which is still experimental, can be performed for as little as $25 and could become an important research tool for tracking patterns of disease in various populations.
lead_paragraph: Using less than a drop of blood, a new test can reveal nearly every virus a person has ever been exposed to, scientists reported on Thursday.

headline: Global Warming ‘Hiatus’ Challenged by NOAA Research
abstract: The new findings try to correct for problems in the way global temperatures were measured and suggest there has not been a slowdown in global warming since 2000.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have long labored to explain what appeared to be a slowdown in global warming that began at the start of this century as, at the same time, heat-trapping emissions of carbon dioxide were soaring. The slowdown, sometimes inaccurately described as a halt or hiatus, became a major talking point for people critical of climate science.

headline: Ad Backing Martin O’Malley Jabs at Hillary Clinton and Jeb Bush
abstract: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley has focused his campaign message on the anti-Wall Street sentiment popular among the Democratic left. An ad supporting him frames the critique around political dynasties as well.
lead_paragraph: A new TV ad from the “super PAC” supporting former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland is titled “Wall Street’s Public Enemy No. 1.” But it seems the intended target of the ad is Hillary Rodham Clinton and Jeb Bush.

headline: Burials From Germanwings Flight Are Delayed by Paperwork Errors
abstract: A bureaucratic mistake in France made victims’ death certificates invalid, infuriating relatives who had until now largely maintained a stoic public silence.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than two months after a Germanwings co-pilot deliberately crashed his airliner into the French Alps, the families of the 150 people who perished in the disaster had, at long last, been preparing to put their loved ones to rest.

headline: SunGard Files to Go Public After a Decade Owned by Private Equity
abstract: The filing by SunGard, a financial software provider, is another example of private equity firms’ seeking to take advantage of buoyant stock markets.
lead_paragraph: One of the last megadeals from the buyout boom is headed back to the public markets.

headline: FIFA Paid Ireland Not to Protest Costly Hand Ball
abstract: The chief executive of Ireland’s soccer association said it was paid after a controversial hand ball by France’s Thierry Henry prevented Ireland from qualifying for the 2010 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Ireland’s soccer association said Thursday that FIFA had quietly paid compensation to his federation after a controversial hand ball by France’s Thierry Henry prevented Ireland from qualifying for the 2010 World Cup.

headline: Recent Reporting on College: A Reading List for High School Students
abstract: A categorized collection of Times articles and Opinion pieces from the 2014-15 academic year about all aspects of higher education — from getting in, to thinking about why you’re there, to considering how to fix what’s broken. We think you’ll find plenty to discuss.
lead_paragraph: Most Junes we mark the end of the school year by rounding up commencement-speech advice and suggesting ideas for teaching and learning from it.

headline: About Last Night
abstract: In the Villa Aurelia, a 17th-century wonder surrounded by acres of gardens, the 2015 McKim Medal Laureates were feted under twinkling Italian stars.
lead_paragraph: In the Villa Aurelia, a 17th-century wonder surrounded by acres of gardens, the 2015 McKim Medal Laureates were feted under twinkling Italian stars.

headline: Crawling Back From the Ledge
abstract: Awakening to the truth that was always there after coming close to losing it all.
lead_paragraph: The thing about marrying the boy you fell in love with at 18 is that it can be hard to see him as anything other than the lanky, nervous teenager you kissed by your locker after class when you thought no one was looking.

headline: Serena Williams and Lucie Safarova Reach French Open Final
abstract: Williams, seeded No. 1, lost the first set but rebounded to beat Timea Bacsinszky in one semifinal; Safarova, seeded No. 13, beat Ana Ivanovic to advance to her first major final.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lucie Safarova triumphed over her nerves Thursday, Serena Williams over her health.

headline: Bowled Over
abstract: Questions about sweets at the office, formal attire, a boyfriend’s secret and an unwanted sales pitch.
lead_paragraph: I have a job and a boss that I love. I keep a bowl of chocolates on my desk for everyone to enjoy. My boss has given me gift cards to thank me for keeping it full. Yesterday, she went to the doctor. Before she returned, her husband, who also works in the building, took me aside and said his wife’s tests indicated that she should no longer eat sweets, or she will face the same early death as her mother. He also told me not to tell her we spoke. When she returned, my boss said she was in top shape. What to do?

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news from leather shoelaces to cow surrogates.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced a plan to address the troubling decline in honeybee populations by making seven million acres of federal land more bee-friendly. But environmentalists say that by not addressing the pervasive use of toxic pesticides, the president’s measures don’t go nearly far enough.

headline: Tourists in South Korea on MERS Scare
abstract: Tourists in South Korea on Thursday described their feelings about the outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome in the country.
lead_paragraph: Tourists in South Korea on Thursday described their feelings about the outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome in the country.

headline: Obama to Meet With Iraqi Prime Minister to Discuss ISIS’ Advance

lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday charged a Bulgarian man with misusing an important federal database for filing securities documents to submit false takeover bids for two companies, Avon Products and Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory.

lead_paragraph: Fortunately for Anthony Perosi, his truck broke down.

headline: Governors Ball, Now in Its Fifth Season, Hits Its Stride
abstract: The music festival, returning on Friday, has profited from a tenacious indie spirit, a 2012 move to Randalls Island and success in booking major acts.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Big Boi was touring as a solo act in 2011, he played a brand-new festival on Governors Island in New York Harbor. “The sound was banging — the crowd was bananas,” he reminisces. Most fondly, he recalls he had to take a ferry to get there.

abstract: The former governor of Texas, Rick Perry, formally announced in a rally on Thursday that he will be seeking the Republican nomination for president in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The former governor of Texas, Rick Perry, formally announced in a rally on Thursday that he will be seeking the Republican nomination for president in 2016.

lead_paragraph: A look at the subjects photographed by Maryam Sahinyan in her 20th-century Turkish portrait studio.

headline: Colbert Picks Jon Batiste as ‘Late Show’ Bandleader
abstract: Jon Batiste will be the bandleader when Stephen Colbert takes over “The Late Show.”
lead_paragraph: Now that Stephen Colbert has started to give audiences a sense of what he really sounds like (at least when he’s not playing his blowhard pundit character from “The Colbert Report”), he’s letting viewers know what his version of “The Late Show” will sound like, too.

headline: 1913: Atomic Bombs End a World War
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mark Bulik takes a look back at the first references to the “atomic bomb” in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: A Chandelier That Stands the Tests of Time
abstract: The architect and glassblower Alison Berger’s latest lighting fixture is inspired by the anatomy of a pocket watch.
lead_paragraph: “I like instruments that try to quantify the ephemeral; a barometer traces air pressure, or an astrolabe charts the stars, and this measures the passing of time,” says the artist Alison Berger, gesturing to a printout from the book “Pocket Watches: From the Pendant Watch to the Tourbillon.” The anatomy of the once-everyday trinket, and her training as an architect and as a glassblower, informed her latest creation, the Clock Chandelier. “One gear moves slowly and the other moves quickly — large and small, fast and slow,” she says, a rhythm articulated in the spacing of the chandelier’s lightbulbs and candles suspended from three interlocking bronze and steel rings. Berger, who has made so-called heirlooms for the upcoming generation (think cereal bowls, in lieu of egg cups) for Hermès and has constructed a new façade for a Comme des Garçons store, considered each detail: The candlelit lanterns can be unhooked for cleaning and the rings fit together using pins, as they would in a timepiece. “The chandelier looks open and endless from one view, but on the other side it is more compressed,” Berger says — a metaphor, she explains, for the feeling of, “Oh my god, it’s already 5 o’clock.”

headline: Universal Pictures Named in Wrongful Death Lawsuit
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The off-screen drama surrounding the coming music biopic about the rap group N.W.A., “Straight Outta Compton,” increased this week when the studio behind the film, Universal Pictures, was named in a related wrongful death lawsuit.
