lead_paragraph: Two workers at a group home for boys in Brooklyn have been fired after an investigation revealed that they were falsifying logbooks intended to keep track of residents, a person familiar with the case said on Thursday.

headline: Dinosaur Fossil Is From a Close Relative of Triceratops
abstract: After studying a fossil skull recovered from Alberta, the researchers named the new dinosaur Regaliceratops peterhewsi.
lead_paragraph: A newly described horned dinosaur with peculiar ornamentation was a close relative of Triceratops, paleontologists have found. The dinosaur had a longer nose horn than Triceratops, and two small horns above its eyes. But its most distinctive feature was a radiating frill, a set of large, pentagonal plates like a crown atop its head. Researchers at the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology in Canada named their find Regaliceratops peterhewsi. They first stumbled on the bones sticking out of a cliff along the Oldman River, in southeastern Alberta, about a decade ago. Like other horned dinosaurs, Regaliceratops probably evolved during the late Cretaceous, 65 million to 100 million years ago. Its nearly complete skull is described in the journal Current Biology.

headline: Okonomi
abstract: Japanese breakfast served daily in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Japanese breakfast served daily in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: At Okonomi, Don’t Look for French Toast
abstract: The Japanese breakfast at this quiet dining room in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is a small-scale version of the nine-course omakase dinners that its sister restaurant offers on weekends.
lead_paragraph: The egg lies in a cup like a clouded eye. At the edges, ruffles of white have half-set, wispily afloat in a sauce of sake and soy. The center is mere veil, the yolk a faint glow beneath, firmer than the white but still ready to run. You don’t eat it, you pour it — into your bowl of rice, as you would milk into oatmeal, and stir.

headline: The Duffel Bag, Updated
abstract: Perfect for weekend, these carryalls are roomy enough for shoes and clothes but still fit under the seat in front of you.
lead_paragraph: Perfect for weekend, these carryalls are roomy enough for shoes and clothes but still fit under the seat in front of you.

headline: Beware a Bluff From Dish’s Poker-Playing Boss
keywords: ['Radio Spectrum', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Charles Ergen would be making a bold bet by merging his satellite operator with T-Mobile US. Yet he is also known for playing his cards very carefully.
lead_paragraph: A poker pro like Dish Network’s chief executive, Charles Ergen, knows it is possible to win without the best cards. His hand may be getting weaker, however, as the cable and telecommunications industries consolidate rapidly around him. Mr. Ergen would be making a bold bet by merging his $35 billion satellite operator with similarly sized wireless provider T-Mobile US. Investors may want to guard against a bluff.

abstract: Bill Pohlad narrates a sequence from his film about Brian Wilson, featuring Paul Dano.
lead_paragraph: Bill Pohlad narrates a sequence from his film about Brian Wilson, featuring Paul Dano.

lead_paragraph: This exhibition at the Queens Museum examines Indian modern art from 1947 through the 1970s, and contemporary art from 1997 to the present.

headline: Rick Perry’s Close Bond With ‘Lone Survivor’ Marcus Luttrell
abstract: Standing with Rick Perry as he announced his presidential campaign was Marcus Luttrell, a retired member of the Navy SEALs who wrote a best-selling book about his experiences in Afghanistan that was later turned into a movie.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas made clear on Thursday that his passion for the military will be front and center during his second bid for the White House.

headline: ‘Love & Mercy’ (With Movie Trailer): Bill Pohlad Narrates a Scene
abstract: Bill Pohlad discusses a sequence from his biopic about the musician Brian Wilson, portrayed in his early years by Paul Dano.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Bill Pohlad tells the story of the musician Brian Wilson at two stages in his life in “Love & Mercy.” The drama shows the Beach Boys singer-songwriter as a young man (played by Paul Dano) preparing the album “Pet Sounds” in the studio. And a parallel narrative follows the musician two decades later (and played by John Cusack), struggling to repair his life and meeting Melinda Ledbetter, the woman he would fall for.

headline: Living With Cancer: Keep On Cooking
abstract: The food gurus seem oddly irrelevant to those in treatment for cancer.
lead_paragraph: Julia put a glass jar of turkey-tail mushrooms on the restaurant table. Drinking home-brewed tea helps her combat the side effects of treatment. The day before a blood test — which would reveal whether or not an experimental drug was working — I placed one delicate bit on the center of my palm. The ridged striations and concentric ruffles reminded me of the tiny angel-wing shells that Leslie’s partner had collected on Sanibel Island for our cancer support group.

headline: Rehearsing to Break a Leg at the Tonys
abstract: A look at preparations onstage and off for Sunday’s Broadway awards celebration.
lead_paragraph: A look at preparations onstage and off for Sunday’s Broadway awards celebration.

headline: Indian Artists Look Westward, and Homeward, at the Queens Museum
abstract: The exhibition “After Midnight” offers Modernist painting from the early years of independence as well as multimedia work from the past few years.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Jane Farver, the farsighted and much-loved American curator who died in April in Venice, put together an influential exhibition called “Out of India: Contemporary Art of the South Asian Diaspora” at the Queens Museum.

headline: Inaugural Seattle Art Fair Announces Lineup of Galleries
abstract: Some large galleries have said that they would participate in a new art fair this summer.
lead_paragraph: First-time art fairs often struggle for recognition, for an audience and for participation by the kinds of galleries that might actually draw collectors and a crowd. But the new Seattle Art Fair, to take place at the end of July, is not your average first-time fair.

headline: Abacus Bank Found Not Guilty of Mortgage Fraud and Other Charges
abstract: A jury rejected the Manhattan district attorney’s attempt to prove that the bank lied for years to the Federal National Mortgage Association.
lead_paragraph: A jury found Abacus Federal Savings Bank and two of its senior officers not guilty of grand larceny and other charges on Thursday after a four-month trial, rejecting the Manhattan district attorney’s attempt to prove that the bank systematically lied for years to the Federal National Mortgage Association about the qualifications of its mortgage applicants.

headline: Dish and T-Mobile: Last of the Telecoms Mega-Deals?
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The possible merger seems natural to many analysts, but it could cause problems.
lead_paragraph: If it seems like the telecommunications industry has been playing a game of musical chairs, the music might be about to stop. That’s because Dish Network, the satellite-TV company, is in talks to buy T-Mobile US, the wireless phone company, in what would probably be the last mega-deal in the industry for a while.

headline: Ouest on the Upper West Side Will Close
abstract: Tom Valenti’s fine-dining restaurant is not taking reservations after June 13.
lead_paragraph: Ouest, Tom Valenti’s reliable Upper West Side restaurant for the last 14 years, will be closing, though no date has been set. “I told the staff not to take any reservations after June 13 because I wasn’t sure how much longer we’d be open, whether it would be another week or two, or whatever,” Mr. Valenti said in a phone conversation on Thursday.

headline: ‘Viagra for Women’ Is Backed by an F.D.A. Panel
abstract: The vote on flibanserin by an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration follows two rejections and a campaign for the drug’s approval.
lead_paragraph: After an intense lobbying campaign, a federal advisory panel recommended approval of what would become the first drug to treat a lack of sexual desire in women.

headline: A Starlit Dinner in Rome
abstract: Last night, the 2015 McKim Medal Laureates — Carlo Petrini, the founder of the Slow Food Movement, and the filmmaker Paolo Sorrentino — were honored by the American Academy in Rome.
lead_paragraph: Last night, the American Academy in Rome honored Carlo Petrini, the founder of the Slow Food Movement, and the filmmaker Paolo Sorrentino at a dinner chaired by Ginevra Elkann. The McKim Medal Laureates were feted (by the likes of chef Alice Waters and T’s editor in chief, Deborah Needleman) under twinkling Italian stars at the Villa Aurelia, a 17th-century wonder surrounded by acres of gardens, for their contributions to the arts and humanities — and received medals designed by Cy Twombly. The photographer Gianni Cipriano captured the evening for T.

headline: Ahmed Zayat’s Journey: Bankruptcy and Big Bets
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']
abstract: The associations and dealings of Mr. Zayat, who made his fortune selling beer in Egypt and became a successful horse owner, have resulted in myriad legal proceedings.
lead_paragraph: Before his name was on the lips of horse lovers, American Pharoah was known simply as Hip No. 85 and was drawing attention two summers ago for all the wrong reasons. He was a large, lovely bay yearling with a tiny scrape on the back of a front ankle that was beginning to swell. His sales price was dropping each time prospective buyers watched him walk amid the barns at the Fasig-Tipton Saratoga Sale in upstate New York.

lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — For nearly as long as the Taliban have been at war, Maulvi Abbas has been in the middle of it, leading a small squad of insurgent fighters in Nangarhar Province and demonstrating a certain talent for survival and success.

headline: A Brooklyn Bartender Inspired by Guatemala
abstract: A trip to Guatemala led to a career behind the bar for Ivy Mix, who makes a mean cocktail of her own invention called the Tia Mia.
lead_paragraph: Ivy Mix has been a competitive equestrian. She has run with the bulls in Pamplona, Spain. She has smuggled mezcal over the Guatemalan border.

headline: Burundi Postpones Elections Amid Violence
abstract: President Pierre Nkurunziza’s decision to seek a third term touched off weeks of protests that left dozens of people dead and drove tens of thousands to flee the country.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — After weeks of unrest that left dozens of protesters dead and drove tens of thousands of people to flee the country, the government of Burundi has postponed parliamentary and presidential elections that were scheduled for this month.

headline: Review: ‘Notes of a Native Song’ Is Stew’s Homage to James Baldwin

lead_paragraph: The singer and songwriter Stew pays homage to the great African-American writer and activist James Baldwin in “Notes of a Native Song,” a song cycle adorned with some casual commentary and video — or, as Stew puts it in a program note, “just a bunch of songs with banter in between.”

headline: Task Force Formed to Investigate Northern Colorado Shootings
abstract: The death of a 65-year-old man in downtown Loveland on Wednesday was preceded by two shootings, one fatal, in April and May.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The random shootings of a bicyclist killed on a county road and a woman shot in the neck as she drove home from work have stirred unease across suburban communities in northern Colorado and prompted the local police, county sheriffs and the F.B.I. to form a task force to investigate.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Gives Mozart His Due
abstract: Jeffrey Kahane is guest conductor and soloist for a program of Mozart’s “Prague” Symphony and two piano concertos.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic, soon to vacate Avery Fisher Hall for the summer, is stealing a march on the Mostly Mozart Festival, which moves in next month. As the festival continues to evolve in directions that have less and less to do with its namesake, the Philharmonic, perhaps sensing an opportunity, offers a Mozart program of its own this week: the “Prague” Symphony and the Piano Concertos No. 20, in D minor, and No. 21, in C, with Jeffrey Kahane as guest conductor and soloist.

headline: June 4, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Myanmar, China, Greece and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Myanmar, China, Greece and Syria.

headline: Review: Cedar Lake Ballet Taking Its Final Bows
abstract: This well-loved company, which lost its entire funding base when a Walmart heiress withdrew her support, will leave 15 dancers seeking work after a farewell performance.
lead_paragraph: As ballet companies across the country struggle to build audiences, especially young audiences, the troupe with one of the youngest, most adoring fan bases is closing. Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was founded 12 years ago by Nancy Laurie, a Walmart heiress who, through an unusual single-patron model, financed most of the enterprise — until recently, when she decided to stop. Suddenly, the company was preparing to vacate its Chelsea theater; its next New York show would be its last.

headline: Paddle8, Art Auction Site, Sees Growth
abstract: The site’s highest price points are rising and it is seeing a rising trend of single-owner sales.
lead_paragraph: It’s still an open question whether high-end art buying on the Internet will take off. But one online auction site, Paddle8, says it is enjoying a bit of a breakthrough. Its highest price points are rising, regularly breaking $100,000, according to Kate Brambilla, a senior director of business development. And as both buyers and consignors become more comfortable with the Web, the site is seeing a rising trend of single-owner sales — those where a single collector is willing to consign a group of works to the auction house for sale at once.

headline: When Low Turnout Is to a Party’s Benefit
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: To understand the dispute over how voting districts should be constructed, it helps to think about the nonvoters living in them.
lead_paragraph: Equal-population congressional districts help Democrats win with fewer voters. They outperform their share of the popular vote in House elections because they tend to fare best in the districts with large numbers of ineligible voters.

headline: MoMA Acquires Hundreds of August Sander Photographs
abstract: The museum has acquired a complete set of 619 photographic prints from his sweeping chronicle of German society, “People of the 20th Century.”
lead_paragraph: A procession of faces from another era is coming to the Museum of Modern Art.

lead_paragraph: The Frick Collection has decided it’s time for a new look at Anthony van Dyck.

lead_paragraph: “Be the first to know,” says the website teasing the great day (“6.15.15”) when apparently Jeb Bush is going to announce something big.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 5, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Entourage,” “Spy” and “Testament of Youth.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Entourage,” “Spy” and “Testament of Youth.”

headline: Review: William Styron’s ‘My Generation,’ Musings of a Pacing Lion
abstract: The book, a collection of Styron’s reminiscences, reviews, reportage, speeches and essays, prompts reflection on his outsize life and how his prose has weathered the years.
lead_paragraph: William Styron’s literary reputation was in limbo, if not apocalyptic decline, well before his death in 2006. His big novels — “Lie Down in Darkness” (1951), “The Confessions of Nat Turner” (1967) and “Sophie’s Choice” (1979) — can seem like elegiac museum pieces, or mass-market paperbacks left too long in the sun.

headline: A Good Stamp Is Hard to Find
abstract: A new Flannery O’Connor stamp doesn’t really convey the writer’s strange and majestic vision. And what happened to her signature glasses?
lead_paragraph: English majors, say hooray: Flannery O’Connor is on a postage stamp. It comes out Friday and costs 93 cents.

headline: Tony Voters Speak, in a Royal We
abstract: An unscientific survey of 44 eligible voters finds good odds for “The King and I” and Helen Mirren as Queen Elizabeth II, and tougher races in other categories.
lead_paragraph: Three actresses play the graphic novelist Alison Bechdel at different stages of her life in the Tony-nominated musical “Fun Home,” and this year three of us worked the phones — and the cocktail-party circuit — to predict who might win Broadway’s top prizes at Sunday night’s ceremony.

headline: Review: ‘Testament of Youth’ Recalls the Great War With Little Nostalgia
abstract: Adapted from Vera Brittain’s antiwar memoir, the film, which stars Alicia Vikander, describes battlefield devastation and damage that returned home.
lead_paragraph: “Testament of Youth,” James Kent’s stately screen adaptation of the British author Vera Brittain’s 1933 World War I memoir, evokes the march of history with a balance and restraint exhibited by few movies with such grand ambitions. Most similar films strain at the seams with bombast and sentimentality. This one, with a screenplay by Juliette Towhidi (“Calendar Girls”), is consciously old-fashioned — or should I say traditional? — while maintaining a sober perspective.

headline: The Tony Awards Broadcast: Broadway’s Chance to Woo America
abstract: There is more than one way to win at the Tony Awards on Sunday. For producers, it’s about enticing ticket-buyers with a compelling musical number.
lead_paragraph: THE funeral home jingle is an upbeat crowd-pleaser in a show that more often prompts tears. Three winsome children, emerging from hiding in a coffin, pretend to record a TV spot for their family business, and the comic lyrics and antic dance moves invariably provoke rousing applause from the rapt audiences that are now packing into Circle in the Square Theater to see “Fun Home.”

headline: Review: Mark Morris and Haydn Join to Brighten Houston Ballet Program
abstract: The premiere of Mr. Morris’s “The Letter V” was part of a triple bill with the work of two other choreographers.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Why hasn’t Mark Morris set more dances to works by Joseph Haydn? An important part of this famously musical choreographer’s talent has been applied to pieces by composers from the late 17th century to the late 18th — notably Purcell, Bach, Handel, Gluck and Mozart. Haydn (1732-1809) isn’t just a central composer of that period; he also often exemplifies the same qualities as Mr. Morris: high spirits, terrific humor, a strong inclination to the pastoral and a keen instinct for structural experimentation. Last week, the Houston Ballet gave the premiere of Mr. Morris’s “The Letter V” — choreographed to Haydn’s Symphony No. 88 in G (1787). (Some Haydn symphonies were once known by letters of the alphabet; V was assigned to this one — hence this ballet’s title.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: In ‘United Passions,’ a Fictionalized FIFA, Underwritten by the Soccer Group
abstract: While the soccer world is exploding with arrests and corruption charges, its governing body has released a dramatization of its history.
lead_paragraph: It turns out there is such a thing as bad publicity after all. Just ask Sepp Blatter.

headline: Hacking Linked to China Exposes Millions of U.S. Workers
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The intrusion, which appears to have involved information on about four million current and former government workers, was the third such breach in the last year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday announced what appeared to be one of the largest breaches of federal employees’ data, involving at least four million current and former government workers in an intrusion that officials said apparently originated in China.

headline: Review: ‘Wild Horses,’ a Film by and Starring Robert Duvall
abstract: This melodrama, Mr. Duvall’s first directorial effort since “Assassination Tango” in 2003, also stars James Franco and Josh Hartnett.
lead_paragraph: Could Robert Duvall’s incoherent melodrama “Wild Horses” have been salvaged by a skillful editor? Probably not. Mr. Duvall’s first directorial effort since “Assassination Tango” in 2003, this film is the story of Scott Briggs (Mr. Duvall, now 84), a hard-bitten Texan rancher deep into his twilight years. It has majestic man-on-horse-under-the-Southwestern-sky cinematography, and in its best scene, Scott’s three grown sons get drunk in a roughneck bar and stumble into a brawl with some cowboys. But such moments are too scattered to make this jumble of a film come together.

headline: 12 Hours Before Yangtze Disaster, Tourists Enjoyed a Morning on Land
abstract: The last port of call for the hundreds presumed dead after their ship capsized was Chibi, a small town known as the site of a pivotal battle in the ancient legend of the Three Kingdoms.
lead_paragraph: CHIBI, China — The tourist park here beside the Yangtze River was bustling on Monday with cruise ship passengers on a port of call. They strolled through the lush grounds, laughing and taking pictures. Some sat next to a lake and a line of toy cannons pointed over the water.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: We’re trying something new: a quick rundown of the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new: a quick nightly rundown of the day’s top stories. What do you think? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.

abstract: Ilvy Njiokiktjien got a glimpse into Dutch culture when she photographed birthday celebrations for people from 1 to 100 years old.
lead_paragraph: Ilvy Njiokiktjien got a glimpse into Dutch culture when she photographed birthday celebrations for people from 1 to 100 years old.

headline: In Greek Debt Puzzle, the Game Theorists Have It
abstract: In talks with European officials, Yanis Varoufakis, Greece’s finance minister, is playing the kind of game that his friend John Nash Jr., the mathematician, had in mind.
lead_paragraph: That Yanis Varoufakis, the rakish Greek finance minister, would meet with senior European officials wearing a leather motorcycle jacket and open-collar shirt would probably have fascinated John F. Nash Jr., the Nobel prize -winning mathematician, game theorist and Princeton professor who was thrown from a taxi and killed last month.

lead_paragraph: TKTKTKTKTK

headline: Review: Emmet Gowin’s Poignant Pairings at the Morgan Library
abstract: Mr. Gowin paired more than 100 items from the Morgan Library & Museum with images from his decades as a photographer.
lead_paragraph: When a museum invites an artist to make an exhibition by selecting works from its permanent collection, the outcome rarely disappoints. Something magical often ensues from artist and institution joining forces and, forsaking the usual rigors of art-making or exhibition-shaping, going slightly off the grid.

headline: Review: ‘Insidious: Chapter 3’ Keeps a Franchise Rolling
abstract: In this prequel to the original movie, directed by Leigh Whannell, a teenager enlists ghost hunters to try to connect with her dead mother.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, James Wan’s “Insidious,” the tale of a family terrorized by malign spirits, was the little horror movie that could: On a budget of $1.5 million, it made almost $100 million worldwide. Its sequel, in 2013, cost about $5 million and took in around $162 million. How did these modest pictures, virtually devoid of gore, nudity and cursing, prove so profitable? With decent actors, for one thing. And with simple but cohesive plots, tidy production values, effective “Boo!” moments and a sense of humor. What more could a 14-year-old at the mall on a Friday night ask for?

headline: Movie Listings for June 5-11
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret for June 5-11
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘The Nightmare,’ Rodney Ascher’s Look at Sleep Paralysis
abstract: Mr. Ascher uses re-enactments to help tell the stories of eight people with this disorder.
lead_paragraph: In “Room 237,” the director Rodney Ascher invited armchair experts to share their theories about secret meanings in Stanley Kubrick’s movie version of “The Shining.” Annotated clips allowed viewers to play along.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Spy’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Spy.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Spy.”

headline: Comedy Listings for June 5-11
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 5-11
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for June 5-11
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Entourage’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Entourage.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Entourage.”

headline: Dance Listings for June 5-11
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for June 5-11
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: The Tallest Man on Earth’s Solo Act Gets a Backing Band
abstract: This folk singer, whose real name is Kristian Matsson, played songs from his new album, “Dark Bird Is Home,” at the Beacon Theater.
lead_paragraph: The Tallest Man on Earth — the (inaccurate) stage name of the songwriter Kristian Matsson — rarely stands still when he performs. In his sold-out concert at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday, he used every inch of his long guitar cord to roam the stage: darting around, crouching, stretching, hip-twitching, perching briefly and jittering away, but always ending up back at the microphone when he had more words to sing.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 5-11
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: Vanity Fair knew how to strike with an image.
lead_paragraph: 96 YEARS AGO

headline: Spare Times for June 5-11
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 5-11
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Science Fair’

headline: Boston Officials Move Quickly to Share Video in Terrorism Suspect’s Shooting
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Terrorism']
abstract: After Usaama Rahim was shot by the police this week, officials made it a priority to release any surveillance video, honoring a vow they made after another fatal shooting in March.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Immediately after the police and the F.B.I. on Tuesday shot and killed a black Muslim man who had been under surveillance for possible terrorism, law enforcement officials moved quickly to share information with civic and religious leaders, hoping to quell any potential unrest.

headline: Power Lunch Proceeds at Four Seasons Despite Abuse Case Against Co-Owner
abstract: A day after Julian Niccolini was charged with a felony count of sexual abuse, the talk among the full house at his famous restaurant seemed to be about the usual things.
lead_paragraph: It looked like any other lunch hour at the Four Seasons: Power brokers here, A-listers there. There were boldface- name types like Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, and Henry R. Kravis, the private equity billionaire. There was small talk at the bar.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Testament of Youth’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Testament of Youth.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Testament of Youth.”

headline: Review: ‘Love & Mercy’ Gets Inside Brian Wilson’s Head
abstract: In Bill Pohlad’s Beach Boys biopic, Paul Dano plays Mr. Wilson in the 1960s, making “Pet Sounds,” and John Cusack plays him in the 1980s, making peace.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you see in “Love & Mercy” is an extreme close-up of Brian Wilson’s ear. It’s a startling image, and it holds out a twofold promise: that the film will take viewers inside its protagonist’s head and that it will pay particular attention to the role that sound played in his life.

headline: Black Caucus Is Wooed for Trade Pact Votes
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Organized Labor', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: African-American lawmakers are feeling the presidential touch as President Obama reaches out for votes on his trade bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About a week ago, Representative Cedric Richmond of Louisiana, a passionate champion for the poor in New Orleans and the lone Democrat in the state’s congressional delegation, received a phone call from President Obama, pleading for his vote to enhance the president’s trade negotiation powers.

headline: Petco Takes ‘Full Responsibility’ for Retriever’s Death, but Says Heat Was Not the Cause
abstract: After Colby, the golden retriever, recently died in a drying cage at one of its Virginia locations, the pet supplies company released a statement disclosing findings from an internal investigation.
lead_paragraph: The sad question of what happened to Colby, the golden retriever, has gripped dog lovers for days.

headline: Review: ‘Hungry Hearts,’ a Drama About Love and Obsession
abstract: Saverio Costanzo’s film stars Adam Driver and Alba Rohrwacher as a New York couple whose relationship takes a dark turn after the birth of their baby.
lead_paragraph: Saverio Costanzo’s “Hungry Hearts” begins promisingly with a meet-cute scene that compresses the progress of relationship intimacy into just a few minutes. Jude (Adam Driver) and Mina (Alba Rohrwacher) find themselves locked in the bathroom of a Chinese restaurant, where they are forced to share close quarters, endure unpleasant odors and get to know each other.

headline: Ted Cruz Wonders About Jeb Bush’s Viability
abstract: In an interview with Fox News, Mr. Cruz questioned descriptions of Jeb Bush as a “front-runner” and whether Mr. Bush could win an early state in the nominating contests.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has said he will not take shots at his Republican rivals for the presidency, but on Thursday he questioned descriptions of Jeb Bush as a “front-runner” and wondered whether Mr. Bush could win an early state in the nominating contests.

headline: Review: In ‘We Are Still Here,’ Ghostly Inhabitants Can Be the Toughest to Evict
abstract: A couple’s move into an isolated handyman special built in 1859 is not quite the fresh start they were seeking.
lead_paragraph: Trying to make a fresh start after their college-age son, Bobby, dies, Anne and Paul Sacchetti (Barbara Crampton, “Re-Animator” and Andrew Sensenig, “Upstream Color”) make a move in bleakest winter. Like many judgment-impaired horror movie couples, they leave “the city,” presumably Boston, where they must have friends and perhaps livelihoods, for creepy Aylesbury, Mass., a village of strangers. Their new home? A charmless, isolated, hideously decorated handyman special built in 1859 for the short-lived town undertaker.

headline: Gawker Media Employees Vote to Form a Union, and the Bosses Approve
abstract: The vote to form a union was a first for a prominent digital media outlet. Workers characterized the push to unionize as a natural outgrowth of a maturing company.
lead_paragraph: Employees at Gawker Media, the company that publishes websites like Gawker and Jezebel, voted by a substantial margin on Wednesday to form a union, a first for a prominent digital media outlet.

headline: N.I.H. Finds Contamination at Pharmacy
abstract: The National Institutes of Health said on Thursday that it had suspended operations at a pharmacy that is part of its clinical center in Bethesda, Md., after fluid used in experimental studies was found to be contaminated with fungus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Institutes of Health said on Thursday that it had suspended operations at a specialized pharmacy that is part of its clinical center in Bethesda, Md., after fluid used in experimental studies was found to be contaminated with fungus.

headline: Ben Carson’s Speaking Career Turned Lucrative Fast, Filing Shows
abstract: Mr. Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, earned $4.1 million from 141 speeches from early 2014 to last month, according to a personal financial disclosure he filed on Thursday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: ​A speech at the National Prayer Breakfast in 2013 that started rumblings about a Ben Carson presidential campaign also began a lucrative speaking career.

headline: Third Trial Is Set for Mubarak in Killing of Egyptian Protesters
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A conviction of the former Egyptian president is seen as unlikely, but a legal cloud remains since the 2011 uprising that led to his ouster.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A judge on Thursday ordered former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to again stand trial on murder charges in the killing of protesters during the 2011 uprising against his 30-year rule.

headline: Senator Seeks Inquiry Into Visa Program Used at Disney
abstract: About 250 Disney workers were laid off last year and many were replaced by immigrants hired by an outsourcing company based in India.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bill Nelson of Florida, a Democrat, called on Thursday for the Department of Homeland Security to investigate a temporary visa program for highly skilled immigrants after a report in The New York Times that technology employees at Walt Disney World in Orlando and other companies lost their jobs to immigrants and had to train their replacements.

headline: Review: In ‘Charlie’s Country,’ a Refugee in His Homeland
abstract: The Aboriginal star David Gulpilil plays the title character in Rolf de Heer’s film about a man who feels out of place in his own country.
lead_paragraph: In Australian cinema, the wilderness has long served as a rebuke to the primacy of Western civilization. With “Twelve Canoes“ and now “Charlie’s Country,” the Dutch-Australian director Rolf de Heer has portrayed the lived experience of Aboriginals that are often treated as part of an exotic landscape. Using a combination of bleak realism, fatalistic humor and a healthy dose of sentimentality, Mr. de Heer traces the downward spiral of a man who has become a refugee in his own homeland.

headline: Review: ‘Freedom’ Stars Cuba Gooding Jr. as a Slave Fleeing to Canada
abstract: Peter Cousens’s film follows two narratives: one set in Virginia and points north in 1856, the other on a trans-Atlantic slave ship in 1748.
lead_paragraph: “Freedom” takes a compelling chapter in American history — the flight of slaves from Southern bondage to Canada via the Underground Railroad — and flattens its drama. The film pursues twin narratives: one, starting in 1856, presents the trek of a slave, Samuel Woodward (Cuba Gooding Jr.), and his family from the Richmond, Va., area to points north; the other, beginning in 1748, follows the fact-based story of John Newton (Bernhard Forcher), an English slave trader voyaging from Gambia to Charleston, S.C.

headline: Review: ‘Doomsdays,’ a Jaunt Into Strangers’ Homes in the Catskills
abstract: Two vagabonds go on a Catskills adventure in this film from Eddie Mullins.
lead_paragraph: “Nowhere in particular” is only a throwaway line in “Doomsdays,” but it couldn’t be more essential to our understanding of its two main characters. It’s where they’re from, where they’re going and where their heads are at, these vagabonds who invade empty vacation homes in the Catskills and squat until forced to move on.

headline: Margaret Juntwait, the Voice of the Met on Radio, Dies at 58
abstract: Ms. Juntwait, who became the Met’s third radio host in 2004, hosting 229 Saturday radio broadcasts, also presided over 898 broadcasts on the Met’s satellite-radio channel.
lead_paragraph: A teacher who heard Margaret Juntwait talking had some advice: “You should consider a career in radio.” She did not pay much attention. She was preoccupied with studying for a sixth-grade math test.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Israel Share a Common Opposition
abstract: Two rivals in the Middle East share a similar concern about Iranian interests, and have quietly exchanged intelligence about Iran for years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new merging of strategic interests between Saudi Arabia and Israel was on display on Thursday as two former officials from those countries appeared on the same stage to discuss their concerns about Iran’s actions across the Middle East.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says G.O.P. Rivals Try to Stop Young and Minority Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Minorities']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton laid out an ambitious agenda intended to appeal to two key Democratic constituencies in the 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday accused Republicans including her potential rivals Jeb Bush, Scott Walker and Rick Perry of “deliberately trying to stop” young people and minorities — both vital Democratic constituencies — from exercising their right to vote, as she presented an ambitious agenda to make it easier for those groups and other Americans to participate in elections.

headline: Hardening of Positions Undercuts Ukraine Peace Accord
abstract: A hardening of positions on both sides of the Ukraine conflict is undermining the Minsk peace accord and could lead to another war, military experts and politicians say.
lead_paragraph: SHYROKYNE, Ukraine — The trenches near this battered town in southeastern Ukraine slice surreally for miles across fields of sunflowers, in places running in three lines separated by a mile or two of mined ground, Ukrainian commanders say.

headline: Pat Perez, a Late Bloomer at 39, Finds Success Both on and Off the Course
abstract: Pat Perez, who is 39, has redefined success for himself — and has reduced the number of his on-course tantrums — as his professional and personal lives have evolved.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — No way did a young Pat Perez picture himself where he popped up Thursday, strolling the exquisitely manicured golf course that Jack Nicklaus built and grabbing, albeit briefly, a share of the lead in the first round of the 40th Memorial Tournament.

headline: Bevo Francis Dies at 82; Scored 116 and 113 Points in College Basketball Games
abstract: In 1954, Francis scored 113 points in a single college basketball game, setting an N.C.A.A. record that stood for nearly six decades.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, Bevo Francis scored 113 points in a single college basketball game, setting an N.C.A.A. record that stood for nearly six decades. But he may be remembered as much for a game that was wiped from the books, when he piled up 116.

headline: What You Need to Know About MERS
abstract: The outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome in South Korea has raised fears about the disease’s potential for further contagion.
lead_paragraph: Q. What is MERS?

headline: One Day, Italy’s Gianluigi Buffon Wants to Call the Shots, Not Stop Them
abstract: Buffon, the goalkeeper for Juventus and Italy’s national team, plans to stay in Italy for now. Still, Buffon does have broader dreams, including running the United States national men’s team.
lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — It is hardly surprising that Gianluigi Buffon, the longtime goalkeeper for Juventus and the Italian national team, thinks often about the future.

headline: ‘Hand to God’ Play Sued by Abbott and Costello Heirs Over Use of ‘Who’s on First?’
abstract: The comedians’ estate filed a lawsuit just days before the Tony Awards ceremony on Sunday, claiming copyright infringement, after having sent cease-and-desist requests in April.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway play “Hand to God” has ridden its foul-mouthed humor, as well as a wry use of Bud Abbott and Lou Costello’s “Who’s on first?” baseball routine, to five Tony nominations.

headline: Review: In ‘Patch Town,’ Animated Toys Work the Factory Line
abstract: The director Craig Goodwill’s musical fairy tale, inspired by Eastern European folklore, features vivified toys that revolt against an unscrupulous corporate overlord.
lead_paragraph: Give “Patch Town” credit for seeking a fresh niche: It’s not as though we have a glut of musical fairy tales inspired by Eastern European folklore in which vivified toys revolt against an unscrupulous corporate overlord.

headline: Edward Snowden: The World Says No to Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'USA PATRIOT Act']
abstract: A post-terror generation is finally standing up for the right to privacy.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — TWO years ago today, three journalists and I worked nervously in a Hong Kong hotel room, waiting to see how the world would react to the revelation that the National Security Agency had been making records of nearly every phone call in the United States. In the days that followed, those journalists and others published documents revealing that democratic governments had been monitoring the private activities of ordinary citizens who had done nothing wrong.

headline: Yemen: Civilians Bombed, Officials Say
abstract: Airstrikes carried out by a military alliance led by Saudi Arabia have killed at least 50 people in the northern Yemeni province of Saada.
lead_paragraph: Airstrikes carried out by a military alliance led by Saudi Arabia have killed at least 50 people in the northern Yemeni province of Saada, officials and the director of a hospital said Thursday. The victims of the bombings, in two separate districts, were mostly civilians, according to Dr. Muhammed Abdulwahab Hajar, the director of the Republican Hospital in Saada. Since the beginning of its offensive against Yemen’s Houthi rebels in late March, the Saudi-led coalition has been accused of killing hundreds of people in airstrikes that have at times failed to distinguish between military targets and civilian facilities, according to human rights groups. Saudi officials, who say their offensive is aimed at restoring to power Yemen’s ousted president, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, have accused the Houthis of fighting from populated areas. Dr. Hajar said airstrikes on one village on Wednesday killed at least 42 people, including many who were killed in nine homes that were destroyed by the bombing.

headline: Fed Deflects Outside Aid to Investigate Data Leaks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Insider Trading', 'Inspectors General', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s practices are the focus of investigations by the Justice Department, the House Financial Services Committee and the Fed’s inspector general.
lead_paragraph: A review of the Federal Reserve’s response to recent leaks about its bond-buying plans raises new questions about the central bank’s efforts to police interactions with investors who can profit handsomely from inside information.

headline: Portrait of Suspect in Boston Is Disputed
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Social Media', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Through a lawyer, the family of the man killed by Boston police said they knew nothing of his alleged affinity for Islamic extremists or the reports that he threatened to behead police officers.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Usaamah Rahim’s family walked through a parking lot near a CVS here on Thursday and came to a stop near where Mr. Rahim was killed two days earlier by law enforcement officers.

headline: Barnyard Buddies Curl Up at Belmont
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'ANIMALS', 'Goats', 'Pigs', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: High-maintenance thoroughbreds often enjoy the companionship of less-demanding companion ponies or sometimes other species, such as pigs and goats, to soothe their nerves.
lead_paragraph: People watching American Pharoah take his exercise at Belmont Park on Thursday morning could not help noticing that he had a friend with him. It happened to be a 6-year-old gelding named Smokey, who has been serving as general companion and calmer of nerves for American Pharoah during the horse’s potentially stress-filled attempt to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978.

headline: A Stunning Link to New York’s Past Makes a Long-Awaited Return
abstract: The High Bridge made modern New York possible, the final link in an aqueduct that first carried pure water to Manhattan from upstate in 1842. On Tuesday, it will reopen to the public after about 40 years.
lead_paragraph: At age 10, Maaret Klaber tried to find a spot alongside the Harlem River to watch a swim race around Manhattan. “It was weeds over my head there,” she said on Wednesday. Also, sinkholes with cars halfway in. “But,” Ms. Klaber said, “you could tell there was a path there.”

headline: Problems Accompany W.N.B.A.’s New Success
abstract: The W.N.B.A. opens its season this weekend, looking to move past an off-season filled with controversy.
lead_paragraph: After the Phoenix Mercury swept the Chicago Sky in the W.N.B.A. finals last September, the league had reason to fondly reflect on the 2014 season.

headline: Unions Subdued, Scott Walker Turns to Tenure at Wisconsin Colleges
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Tenure']
abstract: Gov. Walker and leaders in Wisconsin’s Republican-held Legislature are pushing the University of Wisconsin system to give a board largely picked by the governor far more control over firings and even curriculum.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who began building a national profile four years ago by sharply cutting collective bargaining rights for most government workers, has turned his sights to a different element of the public sector: state universities.

headline: Will Holt, Who Wrote ‘Lemon Tree’ and for the Musical Stage, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Holt spent much of his musical career creating theater projects.
lead_paragraph: Will Holt, a songwriter whose lyrics for the 1970 musical “The Me Nobody Knows” were nominated for a Tony Award, and whose Latin-tinged folk song “Lemon Tree” became a musical signpost of the 1960s, covered by myriad artists and finding its way into advertising and the literature of the Vietnam War, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: An Italian Mayor Makes His First Trip to Manhattan, and Likes What He Tastes
abstract: Seeking to bolster ties between his city and Little Italy, Mayor Luigi de Magistris of Naples made a stop in the heart of New York City’s shrinking Italian enclave.
lead_paragraph: “Little” is the operative word these days in Little Italy. The Manhattan neighborhood south of Houston and west of the Bowery is now nearly bereft of the Italian immigrants who once packed tenements and opened so many restaurants serving marinara-drenched tastes of home that in its heyday Mulberry Street was a veritable Via Veneto.

headline: Between the Lines
abstract: James Mulhern offers us a crunchy, challenging Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — First, let’s get this out of the way: I’ve gone on record that I don’t like RE- words in my puzzles, especially when it seems like it might be a made-up word whose express purpose is to get a constructor out of a tight corner.

headline: Judge Orders Shabaka Shakur Freed From Prison After 27 Years
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Mr. Shakur had been granted a new trial because of ineffective counsel and questions about the methods and credibility of retired Detective Louis Scarcella, who worked on the case.
lead_paragraph: Shabaka Shakur’s 27 years behind bars came to an official end on Thursday in State Supreme Court on Staten Island.

headline: Review: Anna Sperber Plays With Light, Movement and Architecture in ‘Ruptured Horizon’
abstract: A series at the Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center that encourages experimentation by midcareer artists yields a dance work that examines movement and the space in which it occurs.
lead_paragraph: “Ruptured Horizon” isn’t the first time Anna Sperber, a Brooklyn choreographer, has shown a fascination for the light and architecture of a space and then turned it into a frame for a non-narrative dance. How does movement alter a room? How does it make a space expand and recede?

headline: French Firm Latest Target of Palestinian-Led Movement to Boycott Israel
abstract: A telecommunications C.E.O. said he would like to cut ties to an Israeli cellphone service provider operating in the West Bank, but activists want more.
lead_paragraph: While many Israelis were enraged by comments from the chief executive of the French telecommunications company Orange, who told journalists in Egypt that he would like to cut ties to an Israeli cellphone service provider that operates in the occupied West Bank, pro-Palestinian activists working to isolate Israel argued that the statement was insufficient.

headline: American Legion Band Maestro Kept Baton Moving at 96
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Music']
abstract: In the weeks before he died, Irwin Meyer rehearsed his big brass band, went swing dancing, did curating sessions at Fort Hamilton’s military museum and made his usual rounds visiting veterans at local hospitals.
lead_paragraph: Irwin Meyer, 96, was an old Navy man who used to take his evening constitutional down to Sheepshead Bay from his apartment on East 21st Street in south Brooklyn.

headline: Bronx Boy, 7, Killed After Car Crashes Into Restaurant
abstract: A boy was killed and his father and sister were injured at Kennedy’s Chicken and Sandwiches on Thursday, the police said. The driver, 73, was arrested and charged.
lead_paragraph: A 7-year-old boy was killed and his father and sister were injured when a car crashed into a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx late Thursday afternoon, the police said. The driver, identified by the authorities as Kwasi Oduro, 73, fled but was quickly caught.

headline: A Michigan Lawyer Coaches His Way to the N.H.L.
abstract: Jon Cooper’s path to the Stanley Cup finals as coach of the Tampa Bay Lightning began with a high school team in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1999, Tom Brennan was at a sizable disadvantage when he started looking for someone to coach his son’s varsity hockey team at Lansing Catholic High School in Michigan. The position paid very little and the program had not been competitive in 25 years.

headline: Silver Addresses Playoff Themes and a Dramatic Void
abstract: Commissioner Adam Silver was hoping for a classic finish starring the Cavaliers’ LeBron James and the Warriors’ Stephen Curry, despite a lack of playoff drama for almost three weeks.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Kicking off his second championship series since replacing David Stern as the N.B.A.’s commissioner last year, Adam Silver expressed excitement over the matchup of LeBron James’s Cleveland Cavaliers and Stephen Curry’s Golden State Warriors in his annual news conference before Game 1.

headline: Have Wary Police Brought an End to the Drop in Crime?
abstract: Have protests over police tactics led to a crime wave because of officers' reluctance to be aggressive?

headline: Niese Is Having Trouble, but the Mets Have a Prospect
abstract: The left-hander Steven Matz appears ready to jump to the Mets from their Class AAA affiliate, but the Mets would likely need to get rid of a starter before calling him up.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Jon Niese, the only left-handed pitcher in the Mets’ rotation, went through his normal routine here Thursday in anticipation of his next start, on Friday.

headline: L.I.R.R. Outlines Changes to Ease the Wait for a Stampede of Fans Heading Home
abstract: Though there still likely will be a wait for the Long Island Rail Road after American Pharoah’s Triple Crown bid at the Belmont Stakes, improvements have been made.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, the Long Island Rail Road formally unveiled a series of measures on Thursday designed to prevent thousands of fans who attend the race from having to wait hours afterward to get on a train and go home.

headline: Charles Laughton, Man of Many Outsize Portraits, in ‘The Hunchback’
abstract: Charles Laughton’s formidable presence fleshes out Alfred Hitchcock’s “Jamaica Inn”; Laughton let his own convictions inform “The Hunchback of Notre Dame” the same year.
lead_paragraph: There are actors who are so singular in their appearance, inventive in their mannerism and outsize in their eccentricities that they might be called creatures. Peter Lorre was one. Charles Laughton was another — and perhaps the greatest in his dedication to his art.

headline: Big Test for American Pharoah’s Jockey, Too
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: In Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, much will depend on the split-second decisions made by the jockey Victor Espinoza and his counterparts in a grueling mile-and-a-half contest.
lead_paragraph: American Pharoah will be only part of the equation in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday as he attempts to become the 12th Triple Crown champion and the first since Affirmed in 1978. Much will depend on the split-second decisions made by the jockey Victor Espinoza and his counterparts in a grueling mile-and-a-half contest that tests the mental acuity of riders as much as it does the stamina of horses.

headline: Tony Award Nominees: In Performance
abstract: A look at a special In Performance event, hosted by The Times ahead of this year's Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: For the second annual In Performance Live concert, The Times invited six Tony Award nominees to sing at a lunchtime performance at 54 Below. The actors got one chance to get it right.

headline: At Home With a Brooklyn Restaurant Designer, Nominated for a James Beard Award
abstract: At tonight’s ceremony, Matthew Maddy — who takes T on a tour of his Clinton Hill duplex — will find out whether he’s won for Outstanding Restaurant Design.
lead_paragraph: If there can be said to be a Brooklyn look in the restaurant world today, Matthew Maddy is at least partially responsible for it. Many of the borough’s most beloved and stylish eateries sport warm, eclectic and detail-rich interiors created by the designer-builder-entrepreneur: the tile-adorned cocktail den Weather Up, name-checked on “Girls”; the Fort Greene institution No. 7; Grand Army, a new project whose partners include the owners of Mile End and Rucola and which opens to the public this week; and the casually elegant Colonia Verde, for which Maddy is nominated for the James Beard Foundation Award for Outstanding Restaurant Design, to be awarded tonight. (He has also been involved with places in Manhattan, London, Oakland and beyond.) But to hear Maddy tell it, his design signature is really about not having one. “My aesthetic is just having an opinion and knowing what I like,” he says. “It’s not a principled school of thought. All the restaurants involve such different people and cultures and communities.”

headline: Duro Olowu, Inspired by the World
abstract: The Nigerian-born, British-educated lawyer-turned-fashion-designer merges riotous prints with daring shapes for collections that transcend trends — and global boundaries.
lead_paragraph: The Nigerian-born, British-educated lawyer-turned-fashion-designer merges riotous prints with daring shapes for collections that transcend trends — and global boundaries.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:48 A.M. (Comedy Central) NATIONAL LAMPOON’S ANIMAL HOUSE (1978) Delta House, the misfit fraternity at Faber College, is put on double secret probation by Dean Vernon Wormer (John Vernon) in an attempt to boot it off campus. In response, the fraternity members (Tim Matheson, John Belushi, above, and others) concoct a series of stratagems to improve their grades while making mischief. “At its best,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, “the movie isn’t strictly satirical, because it doesn’t need to be. The filmmakers have simply supplied the appropriate panty-girdles, crew-neck sweaters, frat-house initiation rites and rituals of the toga party, and let all that idiocy speak — very eloquently, and with a lot of comic fervor — for itself.”

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: 2015 N.B.A. Finals: With Overtime Surge, Stephen Curry and Warriors Squeak by Cavs
abstract: The Warriors slipped past LeBron James, who scored a game-high 44 points, and the Cleveland Cavaliers to take Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Golden State Warriors had the best home-court advantage in the N.B.A., the season’s most valuable player and 40 years of bottled enthusiasm uncorked for the chance at another championship.

headline: Mets Record a Victory and, Possibly, a Key Loss
abstract: Behind the pitching of Matt Harvey, the Mets defeated the Diamondbacks, but Daniel Murphy had to leave the game with a leg issue.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Daniel Murphy hit a chopper toward shortstop in the third inning and sprinted out of the box, his legs churning, his jersey flapping. It was a routine baseball play, the kind that happen every day, the kind a youth coach might show his team as an example of how even All-Stars hustle. But Murphy eased up as he neared first base.

headline: One Year: A Century of Birthdays
abstract: Ilvy Njiokiktjien got a glimpse into Dutch culture when she photographed birthday celebrations for people from 1 to 100 years old.
lead_paragraph: For Ilvy Njiokiktjien, a stint as the Dutch national photographer turned into a never-ending party. Given the task in 2013 of exploring the theme of “Family,” she wondered about the moments that united extended clans. “I thought of times when you see your relatives: funerals and birthdays,” she said. “The latter seemed more fun, and appropriate.”

abstract: A writer representing almond farmers responds to a column by Nicholas Kristof about farmers’ use of limited water supplies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lone Star Stumble
abstract: Remember how Texas was supposed to have the economy that couldn’t falter?
lead_paragraph: Remember the Texas economic miracle? In 2012, it was one of the three main arguments from then-Gov. Rick Perry about why he should be president, along with his strong support from the religious right and something else I can’t remember (sorry, couldn’t help myself). More broadly, conservatives have long held Texas up as a supposed demonstration that low taxes on the rich and harsh treatment of the poor are the keys to prosperity.

headline: New Regulations for Philanthropy?
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article that suggested that the recent cases of fraud require greater scrutiny and regulation of charities.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hillary Clinton, Voting Rights and the 2016 Election
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s bold but common-sense proposals would make it easier for more American citizens to vote.
lead_paragraph: A basic fact often gets lost in the propaganda that swirls around voting laws in this country: between one-quarter and one-third of all eligible voters — more than 50 million Americans — are not registered.

headline: Don’t Back Down on Russian Sanctions
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: After strong measures, including a ban on Russian rocket engines, the White House should not ease the pressure on Putin and his occupation of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s invasion and annexation of Crimea, an egregious violation of Ukraine’s sovereignty, prompted a strong response from the United States. President Obama used his executive authority to impose sanctions on Russia and Congress voted to ban the purchase of Russian-made rocket engines, which have been used to launch military and intelligence satellites since 2000. The White House also lobbied the European Union to enact economic sanctions.

headline: The Separation Strategy on Iraq
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States International Relations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Kurds']
abstract: It’s time to shift course on Iraq. The current approach from the Obama administration isn’t working.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, Joe Biden, Les Gelb and many others proposed plans to decentralize power in Iraq. Biden, then a United States senator from Delaware, Gelb and others recognized that Iraqi society was fracturing into sectarian blocs. They believed that governing institutions should reflect the fundamental loyalties on the ground. According to the Biden plan, the central Iraqi government would still have performed a few important tasks, but many other powers would have been devolved to regional governments in the Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish areas.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Chinese Leaders, in Stilted Talk, Urge Empathy for Families of Cruise Ship Victims
abstract: Why have families expressed anger and frustration at the Chinese government, the ship operator and the travel agencies involved?
lead_paragraph: In “Chinese Leaders, in Stilted Talk, Urge Empathy for Families of Cruise Ship Victims,” Edward Wong and David Barboza write about one of the worst maritime accidents in Asia in decades.

headline: Test Yourself | Saying Farewell to a Childhood Classic
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a May 27 article, “Goodbye F.A.O. Schwarz: Toy Lovers Prepare for Store’s Closing.” Can you choose the best word or phrase for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below, several paragraphs from a May 27 article, “Goodbye F.A.O. Schwarz: Toy Lovers Prepare for Store’s Closing.”

headline: OPEC, Keeping Quotas Intact, Adjusts to Oil’s New Normal
abstract: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to keep production quotas unchanged, despite low oil prices.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to keep the oil pumping, with no change in its production quotas, at the group’s meeting here on Friday.
