abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from the scene of a fatal Brooklyn shooting and the “sky portal” at One World Observatory.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from the scene of a fatal Brooklyn shooting and the “sky portal” at One World Observatory.

headline: Settlement Awards Free Rent for Tenants Living in Construction
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: Tenants at 101 West 78th Street who have faced hardships during the building’s condo conversion will live rent free for two years.
lead_paragraph: In a rare and major victory for tenants that could sound alarm bells for developers, state prosecutors have ordered that rents be waived for 11 residents of a building on the Upper West Side, after their landlord improperly tried to convert their building into a condominium.

headline: Midtown’s Vanishing Historic Architecture
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Building (Construction)', 'Zoning', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Churches (Buildings)']
abstract: Preservationists often decry the loss of beautiful old buildings. Sometimes, a developer hears their protests even as the bulldozers roll.
lead_paragraph: The Rizzoli bookstore on West 57th Street. An automobile showroom designed by Frank Lloyd Wright on Park Avenue. And the Bancroft Building, a 19th-century red-and-white-striped limestone office building on West 29th Street. All three of these structures were gutted or leveled within the past two years, despite attempts to preserve them.

headline: Re: Continental Divide
abstract: The sharp approach to eurozone negotiations taken by Greece’s finance minister is received sharply.
lead_paragraph: In our May 24 cover story, Suzy Hansen profiled the new finance minister of Greece, Yanis Varoufakis, whose defiance in financial negotiations with his European counterparts over austerity measures threatens the notion of a united Europe. Varoufakis stated that he would rather resign than lead Greeks further into economic ruin. “It’s not good for Europe,” he told Hansen, “and it’s not good for Greece.”

headline: Dronestagram’s View
abstract: Looking at the world from on high.
lead_paragraph: Smartphones have sneaked a camera into every pocket and purse, but there is much they can never witness. The drone, though, sees and shares all. On the social network Dronestagram, users upload images and videos they’ve captured in midair, soaring over cathedrals and waterfalls and fireworks from a vantage point we once described as bird’s — or God’s — eye. (Dronestagram is not to be confused with @dronestagram, an Instagram account that shows the sites of attacks by U.S. military drones.) This photograph was shared by Grant Sheehan, who flew his drone over the Kereru Sheep Station in Hawkes Bay, New Zealand. In the gaze of its ovine inhabitants, we glimpse their dim recognition that a new sort of shepherd has arisen.

headline: A Life in a Password
abstract: The string of numbers that allowed me to stay close to home, and to her.
lead_paragraph: In a triumph of rotten timing, I began dating my first girlfriend in my final weeks of high school, just before I was to leave India for college in the United States. It was 1999, but it already feels like an unrecognizable age. We had no Skype, and phone calls would have broken the bank. Personal email addresses, however, were newly popular in India, and she had a Hotmail ID. We walked to a cybercafe, near my house in Chennai, to sign me up for a MailExcite account. In my password, I included her date of birth.

headline: Self-Googling in 1997
abstract: The innocent narcissism of the early Internet.
lead_paragraph: On a spring afternoon in 1997 in Vienna, I googled myself for the first time. Technically speaking, of course, I didn’t. Google didn’t exist yet. Altavista’s search engine was the best one around then.

headline: Snail Mail and the Safety of Distance
abstract: Hiding in the long pauses of an ink-and-paper correspondence.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1994, eight years after emigrating from Leningrad to the United States, I started using email on a regular basis. But when I wrote to my friends and parents back home, I avoided this new mode of correspondence, continuing to exchange letters with them. The reasons were not technological but emotional.

headline: Hit Send, Then Pray
abstract: When an Internet connection was as spotty as it was essential.
lead_paragraph: We lived on a hill in a mountainous region of Maharashtra, India. The 200 16- and 17-year-old boarding-school students were from nearly every corner of the world. The Internet connection was unreliable, as was the power plant generating electricity for the entire school. Communicating with our families was a matter of calcu­lating probabilities: The longer it took to write an email, the higher the chance of losing your Internet connection.

headline: Making and Unmaking the Digital World
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Data Centers', 'Rare Earths', 'Cloud Computing', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: From mining to power to waste, there is a physical footprint in the online experience.
lead_paragraph: The center of the virtual world, economically and culturally, may still be the United States, but the work of creating that world leaves a real and growing footprint overseas. American technology giants have established data centers in about two dozen countries, and electronics manufacturers draw on materials fraught with ethical and environmental concerns. Those include the so-called conflict minerals — tin, tantalum and tungsten (and also gold) — as well as rare earth metals that are available almost exclusively from China. At the same time, the rapid cycle of obsolescence and replacement that feeds the expansion also produces a lot of garbage — nearly 42 million metric tons of toxic e-waste in 2014, less than a sixth of which made it into the regulated recycling stream, with much of the rest being broken down by workers at dumps throughout the developing world. Following are a few scenes from the digital life cycle.

headline: Strong Job Growth Data Eases Concerns After Winter Dip in Economy
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Employers added 280,000 jobs in May, a figure that is likely to strengthen the resolve of Federal Reserve officials who are hoping to start raising interest rates later this year.
lead_paragraph: You could almost hear the sighs of relief.

headline: ‘Le Selfie’
keywords: ['Slang', 'Language and Languages', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: How our Internet-speak translates around the world.
lead_paragraph: In the 19th century, language scholars coined a new word — “wanderwort” — to describe old words that wandered global trade routes from one language to the next. Back then the word referred to spices and other exotic goods: “Cumin” can be traced linguistically to ancient Sumerian, “ginger” began its journey in Sanskrit and “coffee” and “orange” started in Arabic. The wanderwörter of the information age travel more quickly, of course, and now even the French, ever resistant to vulgar Anglicisms, have accepted “email” and “le selfie,” which in 2016 will make its debut in France’s Larousse dictionary. Here we collect some of the other adjustments that high-tech terminology has made to languages around the world.

headline: Video of Mexican Prison Riot Highlights a Crisis as Elections Near
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Guards', 'Drug Cartels', 'Organized Crime', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The footage of a deadly melee illustrated the difficulty the government has in controlling inmates in its overcrowded and violent prison system.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — With little interference from guards, the inmates rampage.

headline: Turn-Ons: Peppermints, Cool Breezes. Turnoffs: Mares Who Move Too Fast.
abstract: American Pharoah’s sire, Pioneerof the Nile, is a picky stallion, but his breeding fees could soar if his offspring wins the Belmont Stakes and the Triple Crown.
lead_paragraph: VERSAILLES, Ky. — One by one, the stallions marched into the brick-and-stone breeding shed for a date that, if successful, would cost the mare’s owners anywhere from $5,000 to $100,000. Most of the stallions — including Bellamy Road, whose nickname around the barn is Bam Bam — knew exactly why they were there and consummated the relationship within minutes.

headline: Recession, Politics and Policy Stretch Arizona School Budgets
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'States (US)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Charter Schools']
abstract: Arizona has been crippled by several years of targeted cuts at the state level and voters’ repeated refusals to raise property taxes to offset shortfalls.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In the rural Saddle Mountain Unified School District 50 miles west of Phoenix, three new libraries have been locked since last year. In a neighboring county, an elementary school closed last month because there was no money to keep it open, even after the district agreed to shift to a four-day week.

headline: Would You Be Willing to Pay for Facebook or Google in Exchange for Your Privacy?
abstract: Are you concerned about the amount of information Internet companies are collecting about you?
lead_paragraph: Almost everywhere else in life, we have to pay for the goods and services we use. Except on the Internet, where the business model is flipped. In return for giving us free email and social media accounts on Facebook, Google and Instagram, companies collect data on us and sell it to advertisers.

headline: High Inflation Makes Ukraine’s Troubled Situation Worse
abstract: While the rest of Europe tries to shrug off low inflation, Ukraine is dealing with sharply rising prices. The costs of many goods have doubled or tripled.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Olesia Verchenko looked over a selection of blackened avocados at a supermarket here recently.

headline: Vodafone Confirms Talks on a Liberty Global Deal
abstract: The announcement is the first time Vodafone has confirmed the discussions after market speculation about a potential deal has circled the telecom companies for months.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British telecommunications company Vodafone said on Friday that it was in early-stage talks with Liberty Global, the European cable and wireless operator controlled by John C. Malone, over exchanging assets between the companies.

headline: German Stance on Russia Complicates Long-Cultivated Tie as G-7 Meets
abstract: Germany’s role in seeking to isolate President Vladimir V. Putin has left it feeling rankled and mournful about the rupture of a relationship it had nurtured for decades.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When seven world leaders meet this weekend in Germany, their agenda will include maintaining pressure on Russia over Ukraine, a policy on which the host country’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, has proved a reliable ally for President Obama.

headline: Today’s Travel News and Tips
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including cruises for volunteers and a new elevated trail in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: The French Side of Basque Country
abstract: Spain may be the more vocal segment of the region that straddles the two countries, but in France, it also has a singular identity.
lead_paragraph: At the end of October, summer had returned to the Basque Country. Swimmers joined the surfers along the coast. A strong sun turned the Atlantic Ocean from green to blue. On a late Sunday morning, in the French fishing village of Ciboure, townspeople poured out of L’Église St.-Vincent, a 16th-century church with an octagonal tower. Some stopped to chat by a tall gray cross speckled with lichen. Little girls in poufy dresses ran in circles, squealing. A young man tended to his stooped grandfather, who negotiated old flagstone with a cane. Freshly coifed women with short-handled pocket books lingered in the courtyard. “Bonne journée,” called the priest to his congregation as they headed off into the narrow streets on their way home for lunch.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: 191st Street Tunnel, Now in Technicolor
abstract: Friday: Bright spots of street art, more clouds and the original Belmont Stakes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this cloud-covered Friday.

headline: Lloyds Bank Fined $180 Million Over Handling of Insurance Complaints
abstract: British regulators announced the penalty as part of a settlement for unfairly treating customers after they complained about the improper sales of payment protection insurance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British regulators on Friday said they had imposed a fine of about $180 million on the Lloyds Banking Group over its handling of customer complaints about a contentious loan insurance product that has cost the industry billions of dollars. As a result, the bank said it would cut its 2015 bonus pool.

headline: To Caitlyn, From a Caitlin
abstract: A special welcome to the newest member of the sisterhood of people who share my name.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hello, Caitlyn! It is my pleasure indeed to #callyouCaitlyn, as everyone #callsmeCaitlin. Yes, I, too, am a Caitli(y)n, and I’m so pleased to welcome you to the sisterhood. You’re in excellent company! Like Caitlin Lowe, another American Olympian, Caitlin FitzGerald, a talented actress currently on “Masters of Sex,” and Caitlin Macnamara, who became Caitlin Thomas when she married the poet Dylan Thomas.

headline: What to Be Afraid Of
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The sun, for starters. Also lightning, choking on a chicken bone, drowning in the bathtub, and people who text and drive. But probably not terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Some time ago, a friend of mine was hit by a bus in New York, one of almost 5,000 pedestrians killed in traffic every year. I also lost a nephew to gun violence — one of more than 11,000 Americans slain by firearms in this country. And I fell out of a tree that I was trying to prune in my backyard. I was O.K. But the guy next to me in the trauma ward was paralyzed from his fall. He was taking down his Christmas lights.

headline: When It’s a Crime to Withdraw Money From Your Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: A look at what the former House speaker Dennis Hastert is accused of, and why the government is so interested in what people do with their money.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Hastert has not been indicted on a charge of sexual abuse, nor has he been indicted on a charge of paying money he was not legally allowed to pay. The indictment of Mr. Hastert, a former House speaker, released last week, lays out two counts: taking money out of the bank the wrong way, and then lying to the F.B.I. about what he did with the money.

headline: Today in Politics: Campaign Trail Makes Room for Long Fly Balls and Weekend
abstract: When seven Republican presidential hopefuls roll into Iowa this weekend for Senator Joni Ernst’s inaugural “Roast and Ride,” only one — Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin — will truly be cruising on a motorcycle.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington. Though the ever-growing Republican field will make for a hectic late summer, for now, there’s room to mix work and play, as, for example, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey proved deft with a softball bat, and as a group of Republican candidates prepared for a day of roast pork and motorcycles.

headline: Closing the Broccoli Gap
abstract: Special coupons to buy food at farmers’ markets are growing as a tool to improve nutrition among those on food stamps and to support the markets as well.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, New York City’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene invented Health Bucks, a program designed to help the city’s poor to eat more vegetables and fruit. City agencies and community groups distributed Health Bucks in high-poverty areas. If you spent $5 in food stamps at a farmers market, the Health Bucks program would give you a coupon for $2, which you could use or save.

headline: North Korean Defector Opens Up About Long-Held Secret: His Homosexuality
abstract: In an autobiographical novel and a recent interview, Jang Yeong-jin described his experiences as a gay man growing up in the totalitarian country.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — WHEN the North Korean defector Jang Yeong-jin arrived in South Korea in 1997, officials debriefed him for five months but still hesitated to release him. They had one crucial question unanswered: Why did Mr. Jang decide to risk crossing the heavily armed border between the two Koreas?

headline: Selling E-Commerce While Avoiding Amazon
abstract: Amazon is by far the largest e-commerce player. Six hundred smaller fry gathered in Chicago this week to work out strategies for competing against or even cooperating with the Seattle giant.
lead_paragraph: For all of the noise and hype — drones! one-hour delivery! get more toilet paper painlessly! — e-commerce is showing the first signs of maturing as a business. Figures from the research firm eMarketer show the rate of domestic growth falling from 16.5 percent in 2013 to 14.2 percent this year to 11.6 percent in 2018. By that point, e-commerce in the United States will still be less than 10 percent of all retail. The death of the physical store, so widely anticipated in the last few years, is nowhere in sight.

headline: Ukraine Repels Separatists in Fierce Fighting, Poroshenko Says
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko, speaking at a news conference in the capital, described the battle as a show of strength and resolve by his country’s military.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In what amounted to a multidimensional confidence-building campaign, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine tried on Friday to rally international support for his country and to maintain pressure on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, including economic sanctions.

headline: Morning Agenda: Merger Mania in Media Sector
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Cable Television', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Merger Mania in Media Sector | Vodafone in Early Talks With Liberty Media on Asset Sale | Greece Puts Off Debt Payment | Bulgarian Man Accused of Making Fake Takeover Bids
lead_paragraph: MERGER MANIA IN MEDIA SECTOR | Faced with a future controlled by digital and mobile, media companies are on the hunt for acquisitions as they bet that a larger scale will help them survive the disruption to their sector,  Emily Steel and David Gelles write in DealBook. Dish Network and T-Mobile are the latest to seek a merger, according to people briefed on the discussions, in a year that has already seen deals in the global media and entertainment sector reach $155.3 billion. What’s driving the frantic pace of acquisitions is the rapidly changing habits of consumers, who are increasingly shunning cable television subscriptions in favor of streaming services. “Netflix and digital is pressuring the entire system,” said Anthony DiClemente, a Nomura media analyst. If Dish does acquire T-Mobile, one person briefed on the negotiations said that instead of trying to bundle a Dish satellite television subscription with a T-Mobile wireless package, the new company would focus on creating a network that can stream mobile video to smartphones and tablets.

headline: South Korea Reports Nine New Cases in MERS Virus Outbreak
abstract: Five of the new cases announced Saturday stemmed from transmissions at Samsung Medical Center in Seoul, one of the country’s best hospitals.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Nine new cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome were discovered in South Korea on Saturday, five of them stemming from transmissions at one of the country’s largest and best hospitals, as officials struggled to contain the virus that has so far infected 50 people, killing four.

headline: Pressure from Chinese Authorities Forces Ex-Detained Feminist to Shutter Organization
abstract: Wu Rongrong, the founder of the Weizhiming Women’s Center, said she had to shut down her advocacy group on May 29 after several employees and volunteers left because they and their families had come under police investigation.
lead_paragraph: A women’s rights organization linked to two of the five Chinese feminists whose detention in March set off an international outcry ceased operations after pressure from the authorities led most of its staff members to quit and funding dried up.

headline: Woman Says Dennis Hastert Abused Her Brother in High School
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In an interview on Good Morning America, the woman said the former House speaker had sexually abused her brother when Mr. Hastert was a wrestling coach.
lead_paragraph: YORKVILLE, Ill. — As an enthusiastic young teacher and wrestling coach at the high school here, former House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert reliably had one student at his side, former classmates say. Stephen Reinboldt, a smart, slender, likable student who rose to become class president, was the wrestling team’s equipment manager. For four years, he arrived at practice early and stayed late, traveled with Mr. Hastert to overnight tournaments, even when only one wrestler was competing, and went for long rides in the coach’s sports car, sometimes driving it.

headline: 68 Migrants Are Found Locked Inside Trucks at British Port
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: They had been crammed into the vehicles, and several were suffering from chest and abdominal pain, the local ambulance service said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sixty-eight migrants, including two pregnant women and 15 children, have been found locked inside four trucks at a port in southeast England, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Europe’s Shared Responsibility for Migrants
abstract: A proposed system of quotas would ensure that European countries do their fair share in handling the huge number of people seeking asylum.
lead_paragraph: The European Commission’s proposal last week of a system of quotas to distribute migrants among the European Union’s 28 member states is a welcome step toward a permanent, more equitable process for dealing with the waves of migrants seeking safety and opportunity in Europe.

headline: Jesse Andrews Learns on the Fly to Write ‘Me and Earl and the Dying Girl’
abstract: Mr. Andrews had never written a script before as he set out to adapt his novel for the screen.
lead_paragraph: When he set out to be a filmmaker, Jesse Andrews had to be convinced that spending $200 on screenplay-writing software was a good investment. He admits he didn’t know the first thing about writing a script. On the other hand, he was already the author of a best-selling novel, had drawn the attention of A-team Hollywood and had a production company waiting to film the movie adaptation he was just sitting down to write.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Spy,’ ‘Entourage’ and ‘Testament of Youth’
abstract: Times critics on “Spy,” “Entourage” and “Testament of Youth.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times Critics share their thoughts on “Spy,” “Entourage” and “Testament of Youth.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | May 2015
abstract: Our monthly collection for May also features teenage winners of essay contests sponsored by the Opinion, Business and Style sections.
lead_paragraph: As regular readers know, this monthly feature is a roundup of recent articles about young people that have appeared in The Times. This month, however, writing by teenagers popped all over the paper.

headline: Norway Will Divest From Coal in Push Against Climate Change
keywords: ['Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds']
abstract: Parliament voted to order the nation’s pension fund to shift holdings out of billions of dollars of stock in companies that rely at least 30 percent on coal.
lead_paragraph: Norway’s $890 billion government pension fund, considered the largest sovereign wealth fund in the world, will sell off many of its investments related to coal, making it the biggest institution yet to join a growing international movement to abandon at least some fossil fuel stocks.

headline: Mary Schapiro and Richard Kovacevich to Join Hedge Fund
abstract: The appointments add two more prominent names to Hudson Executive Capital, an activist hedge fund that aims to be helpful to companies.
lead_paragraph: Hudson Executive Capital had already set out to not be the typical activist hedge fund. Its stated mission is to be constructive in dealing with corporate boards, rather than taking combative stances of the likes of William A. Ackman and Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Seven Leading Architects Defend the World’s Most Hated Buildings
abstract: Can the field’s top minds change the way we think about a doomed housing project in Naples or the most abhorred skyscraper in Paris? Allow them to try.
lead_paragraph: Can the field’s top minds change the way we think about a doomed housing project in Naples or the most abhorred skyscraper in Paris? Allow them to try.

headline: Polite in His Own Way
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A stranger in a Dunkin’ Donuts seemed loud and scary looking, but he just wanted to address a woman of his faith.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The French Open: From Court to Catwalk
abstract: Tennis players have worn color-block outfits, leopard prints and even a classic French style.
lead_paragraph: It must be Paris. Playing in the French capital, which in a couple of weeks will host the fall men’s wear and the couture shows, seems to have had a trickle-down effect on the French Open. As the tournament draws to a close this weekend, amid all the surprises thus far — upsets of Eugenie Bouchard, Maria Sharapova, Rafael Nadal — the most surprising thing of all has been the clothes.

headline: The Jobs Recovery Is Going Strong
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Productivity', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: The 280,000 jobs added in May is the strongest number since December, and even a rise in the unemployment rate can be seen as good news.
lead_paragraph: The recovery in the job market that became more robust in late 2014 and early 2015 wobbled a little in the spring. The message from the May numbers released Friday morning was this: Don’t worry. Everything is just fine.

headline: Rubios on the Road Have Drawn Unwanted Attention
abstract: According to a search of the Miami-Dade and Duval County court dockets, Marco Rubio and his wife have been cited for numerous infractions over the years for incidents that included speeding, missing stop lights and careless driving.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio has been in a hurry to get to the top, rising from state legislator to United States senator in the span of a decade and now running for president at age 44.

headline: Daily Report: Rising Resistance Among American Consumers to Data-Mining Practices
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Protection', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Many Americans do not think the trade-off of their data for personalized services, giveaways or discounts is a fair deal, a University of Pennsylvania study found.
lead_paragraph: Should consumers be able to control how companies collect and use their personal data?

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
abstract: A celebration of the shortest day of the year in Australia, a new home for contemporary art in Moscow and theater from around Europe and beyond in Transylvania.
lead_paragraph: Hobart, Tasmania

headline: Updating the Mac’s Software
abstract: Some updates, such as security patches, are essential, but it can make sense to research others before taking the plunge.
lead_paragraph: Q. Should I always install updates of Mac OS X and individual applications? I’ve heard that over time, they can really slow down one’s computer. How do you know which are important?

headline: Jason Derulo Glides Across Genres
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Jason Derulo’s new album.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Jason Derulo’s new album.

headline: Chinese Workers Lift Sunken Ship
abstract: On Friday morning, crews using cranes and machinery righted the Oriental Star, which capsized in the Yangtze River on Monday.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, crews using cranes and machinery righted the Oriental Star, which capsized in the Yangtze River on Monday.

lead_paragraph: County records show Senator Marco Rubio and his wife, Jeanette, have been cited for numerous driving incidents over the years.

headline: Penguins With Parent Problems No. 6: Dance Like Nobody’s Watching
abstract: A Random Penguin to brighten your day.
lead_paragraph: What’s this? A Random Penguin! Let it brighten your day. You can read more about the Penguins here.

headline: 1965: U.S. Astronauts Will Reach Moon Before ’70
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Apollo program chief, Joseph Shea, predicts U.S. astronauts will reach the moon before 1970.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Apollo program chief Joseph Shea predicted yesterday [June 5] that the United States would put two men on the moon ‘‘comfortably before the end of the decade.’’ Mr. Shea’s project is the $20-billion program that is building and testing a three-man spaceship for the man-to-the-moon shot, America’s No.1 goal in space. His prediction, made at a news conference, was the most optimistic that any U.S. space official has made recently concerning America’s chances of getting men to the moon before 1970.

headline: Our ‘Sense of Resignation’ About Data Collection
abstract: Americans don’t like companies collecting their data, a new study finds, but they feel that they can’t do much about it.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to data privacy, Americans seem to have given up.

headline: U.S. Was Warned of System Open to Cyberattacks
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Government Employees', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The same attackers who breached the records of millions of government workers appear to be behind similar thefts at Anthem and Premera Blue Cross, cybersecurity experts say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The inspector general at the Office of Personnel Management, which keeps the records and security clearance information for millions of current and retired federal employees, issued a report in November that essentially described the agency’s computer security system as a Chinese hacker’s dream.

headline: Demand and Expectations Grow for Green Retirement Communities
keywords: ['Sustainable Living', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)']
abstract: Many older adults are seeking residences that offer eco-friendly amenities, but the challenge is ferreting out which facilities are legitimate.
lead_paragraph: A DIE-HARD community gardener and composter, David Conrad, 77, wanted to age in a retirement community that complemented his love of all things green. So seven years ago, he and his wife, Sally, moved to earth-friendly Wake Robin in Shelburne, Vt.

abstract: This week’s properties are found in Alphabet City, the Financial District, and Kensington, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are found in Alphabet City, the Financial District, and Kensington, Brooklyn.

headline: Millionaires Who Are Frugal When They Don’t Have to Be
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Recent research shows that single-digit millionaires, at least, are generally far more mindful about how they save, spend and invest their money.
lead_paragraph: BOB WEIDNER likes to play a game when he goes to a high-end outlet store like Brooks Brothers or Ralph Lauren: How many things can he buy and not spend more than $100? On his last visit, the answer was seven.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and New Canaan, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and New Canaan, Conn.

headline: 1940: French Planes Hit Nazi Targets
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: French planes hit Nazi targets in Germany and northern France.
lead_paragraph: The French Ministry of Air last night [June 4] issued the following communiqué describing the French air raids over Germany and northern France during the last thirty-six hours: The activity of the French aviation has been unusually intense. Our bombing squadrons have attacked military objectives at Mannheim, Ulm, Ludwigshafen and Munich. The Badische Anilin factory was set on fire. These flames, rising to a great height, were plainly visible from the French frontier.

headline: More Bodies Are Found as Yangtze Ship Is Lifted
abstract: With no hope of finding survivors in the submerged hull of a cruise ship that capsized this week with 456 people aboard, officials turned their attention on Friday to recovering the dead.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Grieving relatives of the hundreds of people who died in the Yangtze River cruise ship disaster expressed growing frustration on Friday at the lack of answers from officials over why the boat capsized during a storm and at the government’s attempts to muzzle their outrage.

abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and New Canaan, Conn.
