headline: Short-Term Health Insurance Attracts Many Despite Drawbacks
abstract: The plans offer primarily catastrophic coverage for major injuries and premiums are low, but benefits are limited.
lead_paragraph: TEMPORARY, bare-bones insurance plans that don’t meet the requirements of the Affordable Care Act are still attracting consumers, online insurance brokers report. But health experts caution consumers to be wary of the plans.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are found in Alphabet City, the Financial District, and Kensington, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: ‘And Down the Stretch They Come!’ (All Rights Reserved)
abstract: From horse racing to basketball, announcers have often sought copyright protection for their signature calls.
lead_paragraph: Whether he is calling an ordinary horse race or a Triple Crown event, Larry Collmus is never tempted to say, near the end, “And down the stretch they come!” Collmus, who will announce Saturday’s Belmont Stakes on NBC, said: “When I hear it from another announcer, I say: ‘That’s awful. You can’t say that. It’s Dave Johnson’s line.’ ”

headline: ‘Our Souls at Night,’ by Kent Haruf
abstract: Kent Haruf’s final novel traces a budding late-in-life relationship.
lead_paragraph: Kent Haruf, who died in November at the age of 71, was best known for his justly praised novel “Plainsong” (1999). Haruf set all of his books in the fictional small town of Holt, Colo., integrating his bare-bones descriptions of the high plains so strikingly and crucially into his plots that setting is generally the first thing people mention about his work. But this emphasis can make Haruf sound parochial. In fact, his great subject was the struggle of decency against small-mindedness, and his rare gift was to make sheer decency a moving subject.

headline: Inventing Reagan
abstract: H. W. Brands’s new book is the latest attempt to capture the 40th president on the page.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century after Ronald Reagan left the White House, he remains a beacon — and a mystery — to many Americans. This week, Jeff Shesol reviews a new biography by H. W. Brands, the latest attempt to capture the 40th president on the page.

headline: ‘Paris, He Said,’ by Christine Sneed
abstract: A painter and a gallerist enter an open relationship.
lead_paragraph: If the American dream is a steady income, a home of one’s own and the promise of a better future for the kids, then the American Fantasy might be summed up in one word: Paris. (Paree!) A Parisian vision of romance, indulgence and beauty has resided in the less responsible quarter of our national psyche since Ben Franklin spent nine years there, wined and dined, wooing and wooed. Franklin, Hemingway, Stein — and Carrie Bradshaw, too. The imagined Parisian life is a heady one, so when the aspiring painter Jayne Marks, the central figure in Christine Sneed’s intricate new novel, “Paris, He Said,” is offered an all-expenses-paid existence in the City of Light by Laurent Moller, a handsome, elegant, older gallery owner who also happens to be her lover, how can she possibly turn him down?

headline: ‘Words Without Music,’ by Philip Glass
abstract: Philip Glass recalls his Baltimore childhood and the friends and teachers who influenced him.
lead_paragraph: Given that all the events of a long, rich and full artistic life can scarcely be squeezed into a moderate-size book, how does one choose, at age 78, what to put into a memoir and what to leave out? The Promethean composer Philip Glass provokes this question in his lively and colorful new book, “Words Without Music,” in which he offers stories from his life in varyingly detailed magnification. Whatever you think of him as a ­composer — self-­imitator or icon of postmodern symphony and opera — Glass is one of the most articulate composers around. Insight and practical common sense pervade his new book, and reading it reminded me of hearing him speak: He’s ever thoughtful and ­loquacious, but he doesn’t answer any questions he doesn’t want to.

headline: ‘Billy Martin: Baseball’s Flawed Genius,’ by Bill Pennington
abstract: Few in baseball have been as fiery, and as misunderstood, as Billy Martin.
lead_paragraph: They were both All-Star Yankee infielders, won five championships apiece in their playing days, and have yet to be elected to baseball’s Hall of Fame (though one of them is surely on his way). Derek Jeter and Billy Martin share this much — and little else. Jeter was the game’s ice-cold ambassador. Martin, who may be the only manager to have thrown dirt at an umpire, was anything but. Jeter’s self-effacing persona positioned his success front and center. Martin’s histrionics nudged his achievements offstage, madness overshadowing the method. In “Billy Martin: Baseball’s Flawed Genius,” the New York Times sportswriter Bill Pennington gives long-overdue flesh to the caricature.

headline: ‘Jonas Salk: A Life,’ by Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs
abstract: A biography of Jonas Salk, the first man to develop a vaccine against polio and a popular hero.
lead_paragraph: Nobody could recall a medical press conference quite like this one. On April 12, 1955, families huddled around radios, as if listening to the World Series or a championship fight. Crowds watched on television sets lining department store windows. Work stopped in offices and factories as word spread and tearful celebrations erupted. “Polio Is Conquered,” the headlines screamed. The vaccine developed by Jonas Salk, a 40-year-old University of Pittsburgh researcher, had been judged safe and effective following the largest public health experiment in our history.

headline: ‘The Edge of the World,’ by Michael Pye
abstract: Michael Pye sees the North Sea and its periphery as crucial to the development of Europe.
lead_paragraph: Michael Pye’s new book is bristling, wide-ranging and big-themed. It’s the sort of historical work whose thesis is virtually impossible to prove, but it’s also a reminder that history isn’t an exact science. At its most meaningful, history involves a good deal of art and storytelling. Pye’s book is full of both.

headline: ‘Spectacle: The Astonishing Life of Ota Benga,’ by Pamela Newkirk
abstract: In the early 1900s, Americans flocked to see the “African Pygmy.”
lead_paragraph: The internment of “exotic” peoples in expositions and world fairs was no rare event in the 19th century, when Europeans swarmed Africa and other colonial lands in search of “subhumans” to display. Bodies, typically brown and black, were exhibited by scientists as well as impresarios like P. T. Barnum. In fact, Barnum’s first success was an 1830s attraction featuring Joice Heth, fictitiously billed as the 161-year-old “mammy” of George Washington.

headline: ‘How I Shed My Skin,’ by Jim Grimsley
abstract: A novelist’s coming-of-age in 1960s and ’70s North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, the actress Nichelle Nichols, who played Lieutenant Uhura on “Star Trek,” recounted the story of meeting Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. She told King that she planned to leave “Star Trek,” and he persuaded her to stay. “Stop! You cannot!” she recalled him saying. “You are the first nonstereotypical role in television. . . . For the first time, not only our little children and people can look on and see themselves, but people who don’t look like us . . . from all over the world, for the first time, the first time on television, they can see us, as we should be.”

headline: ‘The Thrilling Adventures of Lovelace and Babbage,’ by Sydney Padua
abstract: The real-life scientific career of Lord Byron’s daughter provided the inspiration for this graphic novel.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, a French computer scientist under contract to the United States Defense Department developed Ada, a programming language for military computer systems. Today the language is widely used in “safety critical” settings: in the military, in banks and nuclear power plants, in medical devices and air traffic control. Ada was named for the woman who has been called the world’s first computer programmer, Augusta Ada Byron King, Countess of Lovelace ­(1815-52), daughter of Lord Byron.

headline: ‘The Given World,’ by Marian Palaia
abstract: Lives in the U.S. are turned upside down by the Vietnam War in this debut novel.
lead_paragraph: The story of Riley, the heroine of “The Given World” — Marian Palaia’s ardent, ambitious debut novel — might sound familiar at first. It has all the elements of a particular kind of post-60s American ­coming-of-age story: Farm kid leaves home for the big city (in Riley’s case, rural Montana is abandoned for San Francisco) and dives headlong into adulthood, with all of its requisite heartbreak. Drugs are ingested, Janis Joplin is played on a jukebox, and many drives are taken through the countryside on motorcycles or a beat-up Mustang. But “The Given World” contains what feels like 12 times the usual dose of tragedy within its pages, because Riley and her generation come of age poisoned by the Vietnam War. They are its secondhand casualties; the war has upended their world and rewritten its rules of gravity, so that they fall hard and fall often.

headline: ‘The Anchoress,’ by Robyn Cadwallader
abstract: A teenager in medieval England becomes a religious hermit.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, three British-born Muslim girls, ages 15 and 16, ran away from London to Syria to join ISIS. What could possibly have attracted them to a sect of fundamentalist thugs who use religion to justify violence and misogyny? Might the rebellious, hormonal storm of their age be partly to blame? Robyn Cadwallader, probably didn’t have ISIS in mind when she sat down to write “The Anchoress,” her affecting novel about a teenage girl walled up in a village in 1255 England, but the parallels are there if one chooses to consider them.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ‘Coup de Foudre,’ by Ken Kalfus
abstract: This novella is a thinly — or not so thinly — veiled account of the Dominique Strauss-Kahn affair.
lead_paragraph: You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style, as Nabokov’s Humbert Humbert admitted, and in his spectacular novella “Coup de Foudre,” Ken Kalfus has created an equally articulate monster. First appearing in Harper’s and collected now with his latest short stories, “Coup de Foudre” is a thinly — or possibly barely — veiled account of the Dominique Strauss-Kahn affair, in which Strauss-Kahn was accused of sexually assaulting a housekeeper at a New York City hotel. The criminal charges, which led to the disclosure of a hidden world of sex parties and erotic compulsion, came to nothing. But Strauss-Kahn eventually paid a hefty fine after a civil action, and his reputation was ruined, perhaps because of the question that was impossible to ignore: “What made him do it?” What would cause the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, wealthy and successful beyond measure, to risk everything in such a fashion?

headline: ‘Orhan’s Inheritance,’ by Aline Ohanesian
abstract: A Turkish photographer must confront the past when his grandfather leaves the family home to an Armenian woman.
lead_paragraph: Orhan Turkoglu, the protagonist of Aline Ohanesian’s first novel, stands to gain a lot when his 93-year-old grandfather, Kemal, dies in 1990. But although the old man’s will grants him the family’s thriving rug business, their home in Anatolia is, to everyone’s surprise, left to a stranger, a woman named Seda Melkonian, now 90 and living in a nursing home in Los Angeles. Wasting little time, Orhan is soon boarding a flight to California, intent on confronting this mystery woman. Who is she, and what was she to Kemal?

headline: Robert Goddard’s ‘The Ways of the World,’ and More
abstract: The dashing protagonist of Goddard’s historical espionage thriller is a refreshing throwback to an earlier romantic tradition of heroes.
lead_paragraph: In the company of fictional detectives who emerged from their wartime experiences shellshocked and haunted, former Lt. James (Max) Maxted, the dashing protagonist of Robert Goddard’s historical espionage thriller THE WAYS OF THE WORLD (Mysterious Press, $25), is a refreshing throwback to an earlier romantic tradition of heroes. Max was an ace fighter pilot with the Royal Flying Corps in World War I, and having had what the British call “a good war,” he’s not content to settle down on his family’s ancestral estate now that it’s over. But Max’s dreams of starting a flying school are dashed when his diplomat father, Sir Henry Maxted, falls to his death while in Paris as a member of the British delegation laboring over the Treaty of Versailles.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Chuck Palahniuk, whose “Make Something Up” is No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list, is also promoting his first graphic novel, a sequel to his 1996 novel “Fight Club.”
lead_paragraph: Save the Ducklings: Chuck Palahniuk — who remains best known for the 1996 novel “Fight Club,” despite a string of subsequent hits — has another hardcover best seller with his first story collection, “Make Something Up,” new at No. 8. There’s no mistaking Palahniuk’s sense of plotting. Here’s how Robert Brink of the website The Hundreds sums up the collection: “So this one kid, he’s pledging for a frat and drops acid, the Hello Kitty kind, right before he’s about to be a contestant on ‘The Price Is Right.’ And this other guy, he slaps his prostate-cancer-­ridden, morphine-­pickled father square in the face with a pie as he’s dying in his hospital bed. And then there’s these high school kids who begin to lobotomize themselves with cardiac defibrillators because they discovered the key to true happiness.” Yep, that’s Palahniuk. Even casual fans, though, may be interested to know that “Make Something Up” is not the only new book Palahniuk is promoting — he’s also written his first graphic novel, and it’s a sequel bearing the straightforward title “Fight Club 2.” In an interview with The Wrap, he explained he needed some distance before he felt ready to revisit this story. “If I followed it up too soon,” he said, “my whole career would be writing progressively less interesting sequels to ‘Fight Club.’ ” He chose the comics format, he said, because “if it was written as a novel or a film, it’d be compared to previous versions. . . . Certain things work in comics because there’s a slight aspect of unreality.” Given his reputation for disturbing readers, Palahniuk was asked, what makes him personally squeamish? “I saw a headline about animal abuse recently,” he replied. “ ‘Man Runs Over Ducklings With Lawnmower.’ That kind of stuff.”

headline: A Quiet Benefit of Interactive Journalism
abstract: It helps teach us what we don’t know.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Stuff We Liked
abstract: Rent increases around New York; the partisan leanings of various professionals; graphing the public boredom on presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: Here are the things on the web that delighted us this week:

headline: Families in Fiction
abstract: New books by Jane Smiley, Mary Morris, Karel Schoeman and Polly Samson.
lead_paragraph: EARLY WARNINGBy Jane Smiley476 pp. Knopf, $26.95.

headline: Walmart Board Elects New Chairman
abstract: Greg Penner will replace Rob Walton, who has been chairman for 23 years. Mr. Penner’s earlier roles have included senior vice president for finance.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — Walmart’s board elected a new chairman on Friday, only the third chairman in the retail giant’s history. The post again passed on to a member of the founding Walton family.

headline: California Farmers Dig Deeper for Water, Sipping Their Neighbors Dry
abstract: Those who can afford to are drilling deeper, hoping to tap new aquifers, but those new wells threaten to arouse long-dormant water disputes in the state.
lead_paragraph: Early one morning in late April, Parvinder Hundal stood beside a hole in the ground at the edge of his almond farm near Tulare in the Central Valley of California. The hole, which was about the size of a volleyball and was encased in a shallow block of concrete, was the opening of a well, one that went hundreds of feet into the earth. He had paid $100,000 to have it drilled, but it wasn’t producing water. Mr. Hundal was hoping that if he cleaned out the well, the water would start flowing again.

headline: Even Low-Level Air Pollution May Cause Harm
abstract: Even low levels of air pollution may not be safe, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Even low levels of air pollution may not be safe, a new study suggests.

headline: Tsipras Declares Creditors’ Debt Proposal for Greece ‘Absurd’
abstract: The prime minister, in a speech to rally his party’s dissenters, took a defiant stand but said Athens’s negotiating strategy would “soon bear fruit.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras declared on Friday that his government would not accept a new bailout plan proposed this week by Greece’s creditors, telling a cheering assembly of the Greek Parliament in Athens that he would not allow the creditors to “humiliate” the country.

headline: Every Lash of a Whip Adds to Urgency for Its Critics
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']
abstract: Riding crops used by jockeys to spur racehorses have been the center of much discussion over many years, one that still continues despite restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Present it so that the horse understands.

headline: Carryalls That Carry it All
abstract: Finding a bag to tote gear for the sports-minded newlyweds.
lead_paragraph: Finding a bag to tote gear for the sports-minded newlyweds.

headline: Divided S.E.C. Reaches Compromise in Computer Sciences Case
abstract: The agency extracted a $190 million penalty from the company and brought civil charges against eight former employees and executives.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has long sought to make an example out of the Computer Sciences Corporation, a large technology company with government contracts around the world. And on Friday, the S.E.C. seized the opportunity, bringing civil charges against eight former employees and executives and extracting a $190 million penalty from the company for “manipulating financial results.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: FORCING THE SPRING: Inside the Fight for Marriage Equality, by Jo Becker. (Penguin, $18.) Becker, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, offers a riveting fly-on-the-wall account of the five years of legal battles over Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage, culminating in the Supreme Court case that led to its repeal.

headline: Meeting Caitlyn, Saying Bye to Bruce — and Pronoun Confusion
abstract: Liesl Schillinger, an author and T contributor, asks: “He said, she said… it said?”
lead_paragraph: What do you call a “he” who once was a “she,” or vice-versa? For grammar freaks and logolepts, Caitlyn Jennifer (formerly Bruce) Jenner’s very public transformation from man to woman provides an undreamed-of opportunity — and need — to create new go-to pronouns for people whose gender identification is fluid — or who reject pronouns like “he,” “him,” “she” and “her” on grounds that they are sexist or overly narrow.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: DAUGHTERS OF THE SAMURAI: A Journey From East to West and Back, by Janice P. Nimura. (Norton, $26.95.) In 1871, three clueless Japanese girls were sent to America, to learn how to educate their countrywomen in modern ways.

headline: George Soros Bankrolls Democrats’ Fight in Voting Rights Cases
abstract: The billionaire has agreed to invest up to $5 million in litigation contesting limits to early voting and ID requirements that Democrats consider onerous.
lead_paragraph: A Democratic legal fight against restrictive voting laws enacted in recent years by Republican-controlled state governments is being largely paid for by a single liberal benefactor: the billionaire philanthropist George Soros.

headline: Champions League Final Is Latest Moment in Spotlight for Olympiastadion
abstract: The massive stadium, which was built for the 1936 Olympics, has hosted N.F.L. Europe, the World Cup, exhibition baseball and much more.
lead_paragraph: A legendary track performance in front of Hitler. A record-breaking baseball game. The most famous head-butt in sports. Guns N’ Roses and the N.F.L. Europe.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: “Reagan: The Life”
abstract: This week, Jeff Shesol discusses H. W. Brands’s new biography of Ronald Reagan; Alexandra Alter has notes from the publishing world; Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs talks about her new biography of Jonas Salk; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jeff Shesol discusses H. W. Brands’s new biography of Ronald Reagan; Alexandra Alter has notes from the publishing world; Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs talks about her new biography of Jonas Salk; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Profits of Drug Trade Drive Economic Boom in Myanmar
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Heroin', 'Black Markets', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Companies with past ties to trafficking are building ports, dams and hotels as Myanmar strives to modernize after decades of dictatorial rule.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Visitors flying into this buzzing tropical metropolis step into a modern glass-and-steel airport that symbolizes both Myanmar’s aspirations to rejoin the wider world after years of isolation and the country’s troubled past.

headline: Phone Data Labyrinth Hinders Investigation of Amtrak Derailment
abstract: The way data is stored has made tracking the phone use of the engineer in last month’s derailment in Philadelphia more complicated than investigators expected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Christopher A. Hart, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, appeared before a congressional panel this week to discuss the investigation into last month’s deadly Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia, lawmakers wanted to know one thing: Was the train’s engineer using his phone at the time of the accident?

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: “Reagan: The Life”
abstract: This week, Jeff Shesol and Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jeff Shesol and Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs.

headline: Vietnamese Bluefish
abstract: Melissa Clark cooks bluefish fillets in a robust, peppery sweet sauce.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark cooks bluefish fillets in a robust, peppery sweet sauce.

headline: Don’t Fear the Bluefish
abstract: If you like tuna, swordfish and striped bass, you’ll adore this sustainable variety. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Bluefish are feisty, both on the line and on the plate.

headline: Stadium of Dreams, and Nightmares
abstract: Olympiastadion in Berlin has been the site of numerous famous, and infamous, sports events.
lead_paragraph: Olympiastadion in Berlin has been the site of numerous famous, and infamous, sports events.

headline: ‘Hannibal’ Season 3 Premiere Recap: Let It Be a Fairy Tale
abstract: Seven thoughts on one delicious episode.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 1: “Antipasto”

headline: Trailer: ‘Bridge of Spies’
abstract: A preview of “Bridge of Spies,” the new film from Steven Spielberg starring Tom Hanks.
lead_paragraph: A preview of “Bridge of Spies,” the new film from Steven Spielberg starring Tom Hanks.

headline: ‘Latin Lover,’ a Sendup of Italian Screen Heartthrobs
abstract: “Latin Lover,” to be screened at Film Society of Lincoln Center on Monday, depicts a fictional Italian actor whose memorial service draws offspring from his various relationships.
lead_paragraph: Saverio Crispo (Francesco Scianna), a dashing fictional film idol, has been dead for 10 years but still exerts a powerful magnetism. In the Italian comedy “Latin Lover,” the women in his life gather in his hometown for a memorial service and reunion attended by his two wives, Ramona (Marisa Paredes) and Rita (Virna Lisi, in her final screen appearance) and assorted offspring. He left behind five daughters from relationships in different countries. The film, directed by Cristina Comenici, opened the Film Society of Lincoln Center series “Open Roads: New Italian Cinema 2015” and has one more screening on Monday at the Walter Reade Theater.

headline: Wildcat! Wraps Up ‘Forward Ferguson’ at JACK in Brooklyn
abstract: The final two programs in this series about oppression and injustice are offered by a collective specializing in dance, performance art and sound design.
lead_paragraph: The performance space JACK is easy to miss, blending into a nondescript block of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. What happens inside leaves a stronger impression. Directed by Alec Duffy, this three-year-old organization, the recipient of an Obie Award, makes room for rowdy, resourceful, politically conscious live art.

headline: Adjusting to a World That Won’t Laugh With You
abstract: In an angry and polarized social climate, humor has become as divisive a force as any other. It can also be a catalyst for arguments about issues we’d rather avoid.
lead_paragraph: It is often said that we are living in a golden age of comedy, when new varieties of funny sprout from every screen and nightclub stage. We are lucky to be around in the era of Hannibal Buress and Amy Schumer, of “Jane the Virgin” and “black-ish,” of “Broad City” and “Louie,” of Amy Poehler and Tig Notaro and a “Saturday Night Live” cast that may have finally broken that show’s 40-year cycle of tokenism and dude-centrism. Every week, on cable and the networks, YouTube and Twitter, boundaries are breached, categories scrambled and stereotypes shattered as hot-button topics are transformed into grist for fresh riffs, gags and flights of goofiness.

headline: ‘Joan of Arc at the Stake,’ Brahms on a Barge and a Russian Day Treat
abstract: Classical offerings include a performance by the St. Petersburg Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: June is traditionally a less busy time for classical music in New York, though the New York Philharmonic has a big week with its staged performances of Honegger’s “Joan of Arc at the Stake” (7:30 p.m., Wednesday through Friday, 8 p.m. Saturday, nyphil.org.) But Bargemusic, everyone’s favorite floating recital hall in Brooklyn, never slows down. An enticing concert takes place Sunday afternoon.

headline: ‘Bridge of Spies’ Trailer: A First Look at the Steven Spielberg-Coen Brothers Film
abstract: This Cold War thriller marks another collaboration between Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg, but this time without John Williams.
lead_paragraph: When word came that Steven Spielberg would be making his next film from a Coen brothers script, movie fans wondered what that collaboration would look like. Now the first trailer for their project, “Bridge of Spies,” offers some answers.

headline: In ‘Love Finds You in Charm,’ an Amish Woman Ponders a Bigger World
abstract: The UP channel tries for movie-franchise momentum on Sunday night with its second film adapted from the romance-novel series.
lead_paragraph: Second-tier cable channels looking to build an audience need anchors. A solid series can be one, of course, but so can a movie franchise, whether it’s the Hallmark Channel’s “Good Witch” collection or Syfy’s “Sharknado” invasion. The UP channel tries for movie-franchise momentum on Sunday night at 7 with “Love Finds You in Charm,” its second film adapted from the romance-novel series.

headline: In ‘Albert Oehlen: Home and Garden,’ a Restless, Foraging Painter
abstract: In what is billed as the artist’s first major New York show, the New Museum conveys the startling range of the German painter’s work.
lead_paragraph: With an oeuvre encompassing fabric paintings, collage portraiture and pint-size pieces on paper, Albert Oehlen has been called the most unpredictable German painter working today. Starting Wednesday, a selection of his self-portraits from the 1980s, his “Computer Paintings” and “Switch Paintings” from the 1990s and more recent works, including appropriated advertising signage, will be on view at the New Museum. Billed as his first major New York exhibition, the show, “Albert Oehlen: Home and Garden,” was organized by Massimiliano Gioni, the museum’s artistic director.

headline: Henry Threadgill and Jenny Hval Release New Albums
abstract: New releases also include “Relative Resonance,” the second album by the drummer and composer Devin Gray, and “Family First,” from Mark Guiliana Jazz Quartet.
lead_paragraph: Henry Threadgill Zooid

headline: Giorgio Moroder, the Cat in the ’Stache, Comes Back
abstract: Hugely influential as a disco pioneer and hitmaker in the 1970s and ’80s, Mr. Moroder has assembled a new dance-pop album with collaborators including Sia, Kelis, Kylie Minogue and Britney Spears.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Giorgio Moroder’s living room proudly displays souvenirs from a career as a disco pioneer and pop hitmaker — a career that Mr. Moroder, who recently turned 75, is about to resume.

headline: Climate Change May Drive Fish and Coral From Equator, Studies Say
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Global Warming', 'Coral']
abstract: New research suggests that as the oceans warm, fish and coral species could be displaced to cooler waters.
lead_paragraph: As the climate warms, fish may flee the Equator for cooler waters with more oxygen, according to a new study in the journal Science.

headline: Stock Buybacks That Hurt Shareholders
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: Not all stock buybacks are the same. Some can be quite costly and destroy value rather than create it.
lead_paragraph: We’re in a stock buyback binge. Companies are tripping over themselves to repurchase their own shares this year, and most investors see this as a bonanza.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Reagan: The Life’
abstract: Jeff Shesol talks about H. W. Brands’s new biography of Ronald Reagan, and Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs talks about her new biography of Jonas Salk.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Jeff Shesol reviews H.W. Brands’s new biography of Ronald Reagan. Mr. Shesol writes:

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Libido, Lice and Drinking to Excess
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: House Value Jumping? Save Your Home Improvement Receipts
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Solid gains in home values mean more homeowners could face a hefty tax when they sell. Keeping track of home improvement costs could help defray that tax.
lead_paragraph: A tax time bomb is ticking for an increasing number of people who have been lucky enough to see big gains in the values of their homes.

headline: German Child Care Workers’ Strike Brings Debate on Priorities
abstract: Germany is on track this year to have the most days lost to labor action in nearly a decade, and the strikes have focused attention on wage disparities.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — At 8:05 a.m. at a day care center in northern Hamburg, Alexandra Kölling’s 4-year-old son clung to her leg, crying. A breakfast of bread, butter, cheese, ham and milk waited, but no teachers came to coax Mika gently away from his mother and over to his place at the low table.

headline: LeBron James Misses, and a Sense of Destiny Evaporates
abstract: James, tightly guarded by Andre Iguodala with the score tied near the end of Game 1, made a potentially costly decision in opting for a long jumper instead of driving to the basket.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In those final, frantic seconds of regulation that must have felt like the interminable eight-day wait for the start of the N.B.A. finals, Andre Iguodala was alone against the best basketball player on the planet.

headline: ‘White Lies’ on Mortgage Applications Are Costly to Lenders
abstract: Some borrowers who plan to rent out a property rather than live in it aren’t truthful about their intent — a form of misrepresentation called occupancy fraud.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage lenders have good reason to require borrowers to specify whether they intend to live in a house they are financing.

headline: French Open 2015: Stan Wawrinka Beats Jo-Wilfried Tsonga to Advance to Final
abstract: Wawrinka, the eighth-seeded Swiss player, advanced to his first final at Roland Garros with a 6-3, 6-7 (1), 7-6 (3), 6-4 win over France’s Tsonga.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stan Wawrinka had made it into his first French Open final at age 30, and the first question that came his way at his news conference involved Roger Federer.

headline: Safety Agency Admits Missing Clues to G.M. Ignition Defects
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration identified a series of failings that allowed millions of small cars to go unfixed for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Ever since General Motors began recalling cars with a defective ignition switch that has been linked to at least 109 deaths, Mary T. Barra, its chief executive, has repeatedly apologized for the automaker’s failings in what became the gravest safety crisis in its history.

headline: Escalating Demands at Work Hurt Employees and Companies
abstract: The work demands for employees have become untenable. Meeting people’s core needs makes it possible for them to work more effectively.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I had a call with the chief executive of a $5 billion company who has traveled four to five days a week for many years. She sounded utterly exhausted. “When times get tough,” she told me, “the only way I’ve ever known is to muscle through. I just can’t do it anymore. I’ve hit bottom. The problem is that I’ve been numb for so long, I’m honestly not sure if I can find my way back to a sane life.”

headline: A Tireless Witness to Lost Worlds
abstract: The photographer Edward S. Curtis spent 30 years on his remarkably ambitious project of photographing all the remaining Indian tribes in North America.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Edward S. Curtis spent 30 years on his remarkably ambitious project of photographing all the remaining Indian tribes in North America.

headline: Russia’s Expanded Garage Museum Aims to Be a Global Art Player
abstract: The Garage Museum of Contemporary Art is opening a vast renovated home that it hopes will resonate far beyond the Moscow art world.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Members of the relatively small modern art clan in Moscow still vividly recall the opening party for the Garage Center for Contemporary Culture seven years ago. Amy Winehouse stumbled around onstage, the caterer was imported from London, and the worlds of global art, fashion and fabulous Russian wealth converged here as never before.

headline: Johnny Depp for Dior, a Bath & Body Works Fragrance Renaissance and Barbie in Flats
abstract: Plus, Melissa McCarthy’s Jon Stewart kimono, “Shop Now” on Instagram and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Photographer Edward S. Curtis’s Southwest
abstract: Curtis spent 30 years on his remarkably ambitious project of photographing all the remaining Indian tribes in North America.
lead_paragraph: A wind knifed high across the desert, bounded up and over the mesa top and side-winded through the alleys of Acoma Pueblo, pummeling us. We shuffled toward the centuries-old San Estevan del Rey Mission Church, whose portals lay mercifully open. Acoma, also known as Sky City, sits atop a 367-foot-high sandstone bluff in western New Mexico, and is utterly exposed to the elements. A bunch of us had come up from the Sky City Cultural Center, 30 tourists clinging to one another’s sleeves, angling our torsos into the wind. At one point I was almost horizontal as I clenched an older woman’s hand, hanging on for dear life.

headline: The Faces of ‘85 and Up’
abstract: Men and women age 85 and above are one of the city’s fastest-growing groups, but they are almost invisible. It is a time of love, pain and abrupt change. Six New Yorkers share their stories.
lead_paragraph: Men and women age 85 and above are one of the city’s fastest-growing groups, but they are almost invisible. It is a time of love, pain and abrupt change. Six New Yorkers share their stories.

headline: Corruption in FIFA? Its Auditors Saw None
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS']
abstract: Despite longstanding suspicion of corruption, FIFA has received a clean bill of financial health for 16 consecutive years from KPMG, one of the world’s top auditing, accounting and consulting firms.
lead_paragraph: Despite longstanding suspicion of corruption, world soccer’s governing body has received a clean bill of financial health for 16 consecutive years from KPMG, one of the world’s top auditing, accounting and consulting firms.

headline: 85 and Up
abstract: Articles in this series looked at the lives of a group of New Yorkers age 85 and older, and how they navigate life at the upper end of old age in this city.
lead_paragraph: Articles in this series looked at the lives of a group of New Yorkers age 85 and older, and how they navigate life at the upper end of old age in this city.

headline: France Says It Opposes Boycotting Israel
abstract: The French foreign minister responded after a partly state-owned telecommunications company said it would seek to withdraw from the Israeli market.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — France is “firmly opposed” to a boycott of Israel, the French foreign minister said Friday, after the partly state-owned French telecommunications company Orange said it would seek to withdraw its brand from the Israeli market.

headline: A Group Portrait of New York’s ‘Oldest Old’
abstract: People age 85 and above are one of the city’s fastest growing groups, but they are almost invisible. Six New Yorkers share their stories of love, pain and abrupt change.
lead_paragraph: It was an average week in an aging city. Frederick Jones, 88, fell in the kitchen of his Crown Heights apartment and went to sleep on the floor, resting until he felt strong enough to pull himself up. Ping Wong, 90, told her daughter that she could not make their annual spring trip to Atlantic City — the drive was too long, her back and joints too sore. Helen Moses, 90, decorated an enameled copper pin for the man who lives two doors down in their Bronx nursing home. He held her hand in a loving squeeze.

headline: James Rebanks, Man of Sheep, Man of Letters
abstract: James Rebanks, whose family has farmed in the Lake District of England for about 600 years, has a best seller to add to his credentials as Unesco adviser and sheepherder.
lead_paragraph: MATTERDALE, England — James Rebanks picked up a newborn lamb by the scruff of its neck and set it on its feet. It stood, shaking and weak. “We’re going to lose that one,” he said. He got back onto the quad bike that he uses to patrol his farm, 300 acres of hilly land near this parish in the Lake District, where his family has farmed for about 600 years. “Sometimes it happens,” he said stoically.

headline: On Location | Greenwich Village
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A lofted sleeping area in a remodeled one-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village provides space for a family of four.
lead_paragraph: A lofted sleeping area in a remodeled one-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village provides space for a family of four.

headline: Frenchman in Vegetative State Can Be Taken Off Life Support, Court Rules
abstract: The case of Vincent Lambert, who was paralyzed in a car accident seven years ago, has been at the center of debates on end-of-life decisions in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A 38-year-old Frenchman who is in a vegetative state after being paralyzed in a car accident seven years ago can legally be taken off life support, the European Court of Human Rights ruled on Friday.

headline: Pakistan Says Court Has Freed 8 of 10 Accused in Attack on Malala Yousafzai
abstract: The men were tried by a secretive court, and a report released Friday contradicted the police, who said in April that all 10 had been sentenced to 25 years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Pakistani officials said Friday that a court had released eight of the 10 men accused of conspiring in the shooting of the schoolgirl activist Malala Yousafzai, in an admission that brought new scrutiny of Pakistan’s faltering efforts to try Islamist militants in the courts.

headline: Here’s How Ancient Romans Got Wild Animals Onto the Colosseum Floor
abstract: A reconstructed version of a complex lift and trap-door system, powered by workers turning a wheel, is on display at the Colosseum in Rome.
lead_paragraph: ROME – The archaeological ruins of the Colosseum in Rome may be majestic, but they only give a vague sense of the marvel-inducing pageantry that ancient visitors would have experienced attending a spectacle at the ancient arena inaugurated in 80 A.D.

headline: New York Philharmonic Names Opening Acts for Parks Concerts
abstract: As part of the 50th anniversary of its parks concerts, the New York Philharmonic will be joined by local warm-up acts and food trucks.
lead_paragraph: Some of the New York Philharmonic’s free parks concerts later this month will feature local warm-up acts — and, for the gastronomically inclined, food trucks.

headline: Disney Layoffs and Immigrant Replacements Draw Deluge of Comments
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Visas', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A Times article about Disney employees who claim they were fired and then asked to train their foreign replacements struck a chord with readers and received more than 2,700 comments.
lead_paragraph: An article in The Times, about American employees of Disney who said they lost their jobs to immigrants from an Indian outsourcing firm and had to train their replacements attracted a torrent of online reaction. The singer and actress Bette Midler reposted the article on Twitter and exhorted her followers, “But be sure to read the comments. Whew.”

headline: Are We Helping Our Kids or Nagging Them?
abstract: When we correct a child too often, the message is that she’ll never get it right.
lead_paragraph: It’s a parent’s job to teach our children: to do the right thing, use the right words, learn and practice the skills they’ll need to handle life at school and out in the world. But some mornings — after a seemingly endless stream of corrections intended to help my daughter — I end up feeling as if I am sending my unlucky child off to school with the extra burden of never getting anything right.

headline: Jeffrey Peek Named an Executive Vice Chairman at Bank of America
abstract: The longtime banker, once a top executive at Merrill Lynch, will focus mainly on working with banks, insurers and other financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey M. Peek, who once lost a race to become the chief executive of Merrill Lynch, is coming home, in a way.

headline: Park Avenue Penthouse With Views for $32.6 Million
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'ART DECO']
abstract: A full-floor apartment with a sprawling roof deck in a converted Art Deco rental building was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A raw, full-floor penthouse at 737 Park Avenue, an Art Deco brick-and-limestone building acquired by Macklowe Properties and the CIM Group in 2011 and converted from 104 rental apartments into 56 luxury condominiums by Handel Architects, sold for $32,658,763.13 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Republican Candidates Assail Hillary Clinton on Voting Rights
abstract: Three Republican presidential hopefuls struck back at Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday after she accused them of trying to curtail voting rights.
lead_paragraph: Three Republican presidential hopefuls struck back at Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday after she accused them of trying to curtail voting rights.

headline: The Cherries on Top: Three Desserts for Summer
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Cherries', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts']
abstract: The best early-summer dessert may be a simple bowl of cherries, but sometimes dinner guests warrant a bit more indulgence.
lead_paragraph: Even if strawberries and rhubarb are in, to me it never feels as if summer has begun until there are cherries. Cherries herald the beginning of the stone fruit season, and for a brief period they have star billing before apricots, peaches, nectarines and plums arrive.

headline: A Three-Dimensional, LED-Lit Dance Costume that Exposes the Performer — Or Hides Her
abstract: The artist Elizabeth Tolson’s dress will be worn by the dancer Emily Smith at a show this weekend in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: There are more than seven different ways to wear the artist Elizabeth Tolson’s new performance-art dress, which features a stunning three-dimensional, expandable LED-lit attachment. At the debut of “In the Presence of Myself,” a performance premiering this weekend at Bushwick’s Open Studios, the dancer Emily Smith will demonstrate them all. Tolson built the costume’s focal point by crafting rings with plastic boning. When Smith pushes the exoskeleton out, the viewer is forced to see how it juts out, like a tiered wedding cake; but when she pulls it back in, it collapses flat against the body. Tolson also tucked a hundred lights inside the sack dress’s silver and white sheer cotton, and the layers of fabric diffuse the battery-powered LEDs and illuminate Smith with a fuzzy white-yellow glow. “I wanted the lights to shine toward the body instead of out,” Tolson says.

headline: Mishearings
keywords: ['Ears and Hearing', 'Language and Languages', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: As my deafness increases, the mistakes that result are a source of both confusion and delight.
lead_paragraph: A FEW weeks ago, when I heard my assistant Kate say to me, “I am going to choir practice,” I was surprised. I have never, in the 30 years we have worked together, heard her express the slightest interest in singing. But I thought, who knows? Perhaps this is a part of herself she has kept quiet about; perhaps it is a new interest; perhaps her son is in a choir; perhaps .…

headline: Lincoln Chafee Draws Life Lessons From Having Worked With Horses
abstract: As he embarks on the campaign trail to begin his long-shot bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, Lincoln Chafee, the former governor of Rhode Island, draws on a transformative experience that gives him a sense of confidence: his previous life as a farrier.
lead_paragraph: As he embarks on the campaign trail to begin his long-shot bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, Lincoln Chafee, the former governor of Rhode Island, draws on a transformative experience that gives him a sense of confidence: his previous life as a farrier.

headline: Catholic Archdiocese in Minnesota Charged Over Sex Abuse by Priest
abstract: A criminal case accuses Catholic leaders of St. Paul and Minneapolis of misdemeanors in the handling of complaints about a priest who is now in prison.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Prosecutors in Minnesota filed criminal charges on Friday against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis, accusing church leaders of mishandling repeated complaints of sexual misconduct against a priest and failing to follow through on pledges to protect children and root out pedophile clergymen.

headline: Gagosian Expands With Third London Gallery
abstract: The square mile around Berkeley Square, in the heart of Mayfair, has become an obligatory investment for contemporary dealers.
lead_paragraph: Gagosian Gallery is starting a third space in London. A 18,000-square-foot gallery at 20 Grosvenor Hill, in the heart of Mayfair, it will open with an exhibition by the American abstract painter Cy Twombly on Oct. 8, just before the Frieze London art fair.

headline: Small Steps Beat Big Leap for Vodafone and Liberty Global
abstract: Combining Vodafone’s and Liberty Global’s footprints makes sense, but a full-scale merger would be difficult and unwieldy.
lead_paragraph: It is good to talk. And Vodafone, the $100 billion British mobile giant, is right to open formal, if noncommittal, lines of communication about asset swaps with Liberty Global, Europe’s leading cable group.

headline: A Greenwich Village Loft for a Family of Four
abstract: With some modification, a high-ceilinged one-bedroom apartment meets everyone’s needs.
lead_paragraph: When Yaron Schwartzman and Alexandra Polier were hunting for a two- or three-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village a couple of years ago, their real estate agent suggested they look at a large one-bedroom instead. They were dubious, to say the least.

headline: Friday Night Music: I’m With Her
abstract: Simple and wonderful.
lead_paragraph: Busy day in Oxford, city of ancient halls, dreaming spires, and countless sellers of selfie sticks. So no substance until tomorrow. But here are three incredibly talented ladies having a very good time:

headline: Romanian President Calls for Premier to Resign Amid Graft Inquiry
abstract: Prime Minister Victor Ponta, who has been named as a suspect in 17 counts of forgery and other charges, said on Facebook that he would not step down.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Romania’s president called for the resignation of the country’s prime minister, Victor Ponta, after the country’s anticorruption agency opened criminal investigations into whether he was involved in forgery, money-laundering and other crimes when he was still a practicing lawyer.

headline: Some Germanwings Victims’ Remains to Be Returned on Schedule
abstract: The announcement by the airline’s parent company ended uncertainty for the families after the transfer was suspended because of a bureaucratic error.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The remains of some of the 150 people who died in the crash of a Germanwings jet in the French Alps will be returned to relatives early next week, Lufthansa, the airline’s parent company, said Friday evening. The announcement brings to an end more than two days of uncertainty for the families after the transfer was suspended because of last-minute paperwork errors.

headline: Gay Pride Week in Tel Aviv-Jaffa
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: The city of Tel Aviv-Jaffa’s annual Gay Pride Parade will focus for the first time on Israel’s transgender people.
lead_paragraph: The city of Tel Aviv-Jaffa is expecting a crowd of 180,000 revelers from all over on June 12 for its annual Gay Pride Parade, which will focus for the first time on Israel’s transgender people.

headline: How a Carried Interest Tax Could Raise $180 Billion
abstract: Taxing carried interest at ordinary income rates would raise an additional $180 billion over 10 years — about 10 times what the government estimates.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Rodham Clinton opened her campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination in Iowa, the first substantive issue she raised was a safe one: carried interest. “There’s something wrong when hedge fund managers pay lower tax rates than nurses or the truckers that I saw on I-80 as I was driving here,” she said.

headline: Me, Myself and Mx.
abstract: A gender-neutral alternative to the usual honorifics like Ms. and Mr. gains ground.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes cultural shifts rumble at a glacial pace. Sometimes they gather momentum so quickly that our language can only surge ahead in an effort to catch up. Think selfie, or vape, or normcore.

headline: Walmart, Lagging in Online Sales, Is Strengthening E-Commerce
abstract: Trailing Amazon in e-commerce sales, Walmart is starting a new online shipping program, hiring tech employees and pledging to invest $1 billion in online operations.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — In the world of brick and mortar, Walmart is a titan, ringing up more than $1 billion of sales a day.

headline: When the Warriors Lost Home-Court Advantage to the Ice Follies
abstract: When Golden State last made the N.B.A. finals, in 1975, the team’s arena had already been booked for a touring skating show, forcing the team to play at the Cow Palace, near San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Golden State Warriors are in the N.B.A. finals for the first time since 1975, playing Games 1 and 2 in the same arena they called home 40 years ago.

headline: Finding Love Online, and Off
abstract: After meeting at a wedding, two online specialists kept looking for ways to meet up without the interference of a screen.
lead_paragraph: After meeting at a wedding, two online specialists kept looking for ways to meet up without the interference of a screen.

headline: The French Open’s Courtwalk
abstract: Tennis players wore eye-catching and creative outfits.
lead_paragraph: Tennis players wore eye-catching and creative outfits.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Strange Vision Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the real-life case of a young woman with wavy lines before her eyes and a series of tiny strokes.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a previously healthy 31-year-old woman suddenly began having strokes. I thought this was a particularly tough case – all the more so since I had never heard of the disease she was ultimately diagnosed with. Apparently I was not alone. Only a few dozen of the 400 plus readers who wrote in were able to make this difficult diagnosis.

headline: Versace Resort 2016
abstract: Looks from the collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the collection.

headline: Review: Linda Lavin, Scratching Out Fresh Starts, at 54 Below
abstract: Ms. Lavin, 77, tells musical stories with a sense of humor and an upbeat philosophy in her latest show.
lead_paragraph: Cabaret may be a sideline for that human whirlwind Linda Lavin, but you can be sure that she takes a nightclub performance as seriously as any Broadway role. Her latest show, “Starting Over,” which opened on Thursday at 54 Below, is a fully developed concept in which Ms. Lavin, 77, tells her story mostly in song. As the title suggests, this is not a conventional summing up with a beginning, a middle and an end, but a repeated cycle of new beginnings, the latest of which is her seemingly blissful 10-year marriage to Steve Bakunas, the drummer in her band.

headline: Review: American Classical Orchestra Takes on Friedrich Witt
abstract: The period-instrument ensemble offered a program of Beethoven, Haydn and Witt in its season finale at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a conversation starter: What’s easier to bear? A boring performance of a boring piece or a boring performance of a masterpiece? On Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, under the direction of Thomas Crawford, offered both in a lackluster season finale. The program opened with a humdrum performance of Friedrich Witt’s justifiably overlooked Symphony in A and ended with a slack reading of Beethoven’s “Pastoral” Symphony.

headline: My First Time in a Strip Club
abstract: The first time most guys go into a strip club, it’s party time. My first time was a little different.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: Austin Meyer is the winner of Nicholas Kristof’s 2015 Win-a-Trip contest. He will receive his master’s in journalism from Stanford University later this month.

headline: Digital Experts Head Offline for Love
abstract: After meeting at a wedding, two online specialists kept looking for ways to meet up without the interference of a screen.
lead_paragraph: Michael Noland-Conlow first saw Kristen Titus in December 2011 as she stood on a balcony inside the Renaissance hotel in downtown Pittsburgh.

headline: Review: Pairing Beethoven With George Walker at Mannes College
abstract: The Mannes Beethoven Institute offered two Beethoven trios along with George Walker’s “Lyric for Strings” and his Violin Sonata No. 2.
lead_paragraph: The unimaginatively named Mannes Beethoven Institute has in recent years reached far beyond Beethoven, pairing his works with those by contemporary composers. Stephen Hartke and Peter Lieberson were recently featured; for this year’s lineup, music by the New Jersey-based composer George Walker is in the spotlight.

headline: Greek Premier Addresses Parliament
abstract: The Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, addressed parliament on Friday after the country postponed a repayment of its bailout.
lead_paragraph: The Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, addressed parliament on Friday after the country postponed a repayment of its bailout.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Medal of Honor (US)']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton is honored in Texas, Senator Lindsey Graham joins the presidential race and more.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton is honored in Texas, Senator Lindsey Graham joins the presidential race and more.

headline: Review: ‘J. Edgar Klezmer: Songs From My Grandmother’s F.B.I. Files’ Tells All at Here Arts Center
abstract: Eve Sicular’s play documents her grandmother’s life, with help from J. Edgar Hoover’s watchful eye and meticulous records.
lead_paragraph: The klezmer bandleader Eve Sicular is hardly a fan of J. Edgar Hoover, the F.B.I.’s first director, whose Cold War hunt for Communists put her grandmother in his sights. But he did keep meticulous records, and she can’t help being grateful for that.

headline: Review: John Zorn’s Spirit of Restless Invention Flows Forth
abstract: Mr. Zorn’s work was performed at both the Cloisters and the Miller Theater in recent days, testifying to his enduring energy.
lead_paragraph: On the title page of the score of “The Aristos,” John Zorn’s 2014 piano trio of “ten metaphysical ambiguities,” the composer quotes T. S. Eliot: “We shall not cease from exploration/And the end of all our exploring/Will be to arrive where we started/And know the place for the first time.”

headline: Making the Invisible Visible
abstract: Dave Greer documents the infrastructure of the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Dave Greer documents the infrastructure of the Internet.

headline: The Internet I.R.L.
abstract: Photographs of the physical infrastructure that enables our online lives.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever wondered how the Internet works or, perhaps, what it actually looks like, your first impulse was probably to Google it (or maybe you looked on Wikipedia). For Dave Greer, a Philadelphia-based photographer, it all started with a building — specifically, the sale of a building.

headline: Review: Metropolitan Playhouse Tackles Labor History in ‘Injunction Granted’
abstract: This 1936 play, created by the Living Newspaper Unit of the W.P.A.’s Federal Theater Project, has been given a devoted if rickety revival.
lead_paragraph: This year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York recommended raising New York City’s minimum wage to $11.50, with a minimum of $10.50 elsewhere in the state. Lawmakers rejected the proposal, which is not really a surprise if you know the history that inspired “Injunction Granted.” A 1936 play created by the Living Newspaper Unit of the W.P.A.’s Federal Theater Project, it has been given a devoted if rickety revival by the Metropolitan Playhouse.

headline: Grim Reality: Czech TV Makes Game of Nazi Era
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Television', 'Public Broadcasting', 'Reality Television']
abstract: A Czech series has, not surprisingly, stirred intense reactions about mixing such a dark period in history into an entertainment format more often associated with the Kardashians.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — We have seen toddlers in tiaras, been left “Naked and Afraid” and met more real housewives than a postman.

headline: In Grim Rape Statistics, Signs of Progress
abstract: Outreach efforts by the police and victims’ services groups have helped more survivors report sexual assaults and rapes.
lead_paragraph: Last week, as Mayor Bill de Blasio worked to quell anxieties over rising instances of violence in the city, a young woman in Lower Manhattan found herself victim of the kind of terrifying crime that now seems almost to belong to another era in New York. Early on Monday in Chinatown, the police said, three teenage boys attacked a woman they had just met at an Internet cafe. Investigators said two raped and robbed her before the group headed to her apartment with the keys they had stolen from her. Video from surveillance cameras at the cafe and at a deli where she later sought help, which ultimately led to arrests, showed her battered and bloodied.

headline: De Blasio, on Radio, Starts Conversation With His Constituents
abstract: New York’s mayor was quizzed on the police, library funding and fights in Albany while on a call-in show on WNYC radio.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio sat cross-legged at a small table in his office, scribbling notes like a debate competitor. He pantomimed a drinking motion, and an aide returned with tea. He nodded vigorously at speakers who could not see him, flattering their inquiries with care.

headline: Sail, Paddle or Row?
abstract: Participants in “The Race to Alaska” will race in boats without motors for 750 miles from Port Townsend, Wash., to Ketchikan, Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Participants in “The Race to Alaska” will race in boats without motors for 750 miles from Port Townsend, Wash., to Ketchikan, Alaska.

headline: Human-Powered Vessels Race to Alaska
abstract: Race to Alaska organizers, in putting up a $10,000 prize for the first vessel to cross the finish line in Ketchikan, 750 miles away, said they wanted to see what human imagination and muscle could do.
lead_paragraph: Race to Alaska organizers, in putting up a $10,000 prize for the first vessel to cross the finish line in Ketchikan, 750 miles away, said they wanted to see what human imagination and muscle could do.

headline: A Race to Alaska: No Motors, but No Limits on Imagination
abstract: Fifty-four vessels started off Thursday from Port Townsend, Wash., in the 750-mile event. To the winner goes $10,000; to second place, steak knives.
lead_paragraph: PORT TOWNSEND, Wash. — Scott Veirs and Thomas Nielsen have a little wooden plank mounted on their boat, just in front of the seat where they plan to take turns, for days on end, pedaling a bike-chain-driven propeller shaft all the way to Alaska.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fringe Movement
abstract: The fringe skirt adds motion to fashion and is ina contrast to the movement to put women into a functional uniform.
lead_paragraph: The fringe skirt adds motion to fashion and is in contrast to the movement to put women into a functional uniform. The current iteration of fringe started with Michael Kors skirts last October and is now a genuine fashion expression. It’s even made it onto evening dresses. But fringe has some tangled problems: One woman’s heels were trapped by her dress’s strands.

headline: In Afghanistan With ISIS and the Taliban: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Joseph Goldstein describes the challenges of reporting in Afghanistan as tension and fighting between the Taliban and the Islamic State increases.
lead_paragraph: There are not many places in the world where journalists – not to mention government officials – might still rely on passing shepherds to bring them reports of political significance. But that is how one of the early descriptions of an Islamic State training base in western Afghanistan first surfaced back in January.

headline: Evening Hours | Silver Linings
abstract: The unseasonal rain and cold didn’t slow the parties down.
lead_paragraph: The unseasonal rain and cold didn’t slow the parties down.

headline: Tariq Aziz, Top Aide and Fervent Ally of Saddam Hussein, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister and deputy prime minister, was for decades the most public face of Mr. Hussein’s government.
lead_paragraph: Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister and deputy prime minister who for decades was the most public face of Saddam Hussein’s government on the world stage, died on Friday in Nasiriya, Iraq, where he had been imprisoned. He was 79.

headline: The Tony Red Carpet
abstract: Over the last few years, fashion at the Tony Awards has been mixed.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, fashion at the Tony Awards has been mixed.

headline: Paul Molitor’s Attention to Detail Has Twins Off to Fast Start
abstract: Molitor, a Hall of Famer who spent most of his career with the Brewers, led Minnesota to a 32-22 record entering Saturday by helping his players focus on the finer points of the game.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The first impression Paul Molitor made on Trevor Plouffe was profound. It was a decade ago in Beloit, Wis., and Plouffe, now the third baseman and cleanup hitter for the Minnesota Twins, was 19 years old. Molitor, a Hall of Famer with 3,319 career hits, was a roving instructor in the Twins’ farm system.

abstract: Photos from China, Turkey, Syria and Burundi.
lead_paragraph: Photos from China, Turkey, Syria and Burundi.

headline: The Tony Awards Get Dressed Up
abstract: Fashion houses are offering clothes and services to nominees in an effort to jazz up outfits this year.
lead_paragraph: A little after 5 p.m. on Thursday afternoon, Beth Malone stood in the Manhattan offices of the fashion public relations company KCD trying not to appear out of place. It was a losing battle.

headline: Why Is U.S. Women’s Soccer Still Fighting to Exist?
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'World Cup 2010 (Soccer)', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Women and Girls', 'Soccer', "Women's World Cup (Soccer)"]
abstract: Americans are losing out on building not just a sport, but also a business.
lead_paragraph: With two minutes to go in stoppage time in the quarterfinal match of the Women’s World Cup 2011, Brazil was leading the United States 2-1. As the U.S. offense advanced for its last possible possession, the crowd in Dresden chanted “U-S-A!” But on ESPN, the announcer Ian Darke was already calling it. “It will go down as the U.S.A.’s worst performance ever in the Women’s World Cup,” he told his viewers: going home a top-eight loser in the quarters.

headline: Blackhawks Build a Juggernaut With Talent on Ice and in Front Office
abstract: A rare core of talented players and aggressive marketing by the Chicago Blackhawks have made them one of the most popular teams in professional sports.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When the Chicago Blackhawks and the Anaheim Ducks met in Game 7 of the Western Conference finals, the Blackhawks’ owner, Rocky Wirtz, had an idea about where besides Chicago he would find a jittery audience: Rockefeller Center, home of NBC, the N.H.L.’s broadcast partner.

headline: Relying on Butterfly Wings to Survive
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Butterflies and Moths', 'Pollen', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Flame azaleas must depend almost entirely on butterflies to reproduce, researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: With flowers in bursts of orange and red, flame azaleas attract several types of pollinators. But these azaleas must rely almost entirely on butterflies to reproduce, researchers have found.
