lead_paragraph: Photos from China, Turkey, Syria and Burundi.

headline: Patrick Lynch, Police Union Chief Who Fought de Blasio, Wins a 5th Term
abstract: Mr. Lynch overcame two opponents, his first challengers in a decade, by taking 70 percent of the vote to lead the New York City Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association.
lead_paragraph: Beating back his first challenge in a decade, Patrick J. Lynch, the irascible police union boss, was re-elected on Friday as the president of the New York City Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association.

headline: Elizabeth Reaser Is Game for Anything, Onstage and Off
abstract: Being spanked in public eight times a week can have residual effects.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Reaser sat down carefully.

headline: LightSail, a Private Spacecraft, Goes Unexpectedly Quiet
abstract: The craft, launched last month and meant to demonstrate the possibilities of using sunlight for propulsion, has run into trouble before.
lead_paragraph: Since it launched last month, LightSail, a little, privately financed spacecraft meant to demonstrate the potentially revolutionary technology of using sunlight for propulsion, has been alive, dead and revived.

headline: A Tokyo Treasure
abstract: The Okura, almost surreal in its beauty and a favorite of stars for decades, will be demolished to make way for glass towers.
lead_paragraph: The Okura, almost surreal in its beauty and a favorite of stars for decades, will be demolished to make way for glass towers.

headline: The End of a Treasure in Tokyo
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The Okura, almost surreal in its beauty and a favorite of stars for decades, will be demolished to make way for new towers.
lead_paragraph: On the bus ride from Narita Airport to the Hotel Okura in Tokyo last April, I noticed something peculiar and touching — rows upon rows of trees, gently propped up with wooden braces. What care these limbs get! What attention is paid to the crooked and the lame! I saw many such struts for many such trees throughout Japan — in parks, in cities, on sidewalks, on highways.

headline: Carmakers Zoom Away From Retro
abstract: After years of recreating old classics, car designers at Ford and and other automakers are unveiling sleek future-mobiles.
lead_paragraph: Like aging rockers, car designers fell into the habit of trotting out their greatest hits, producing faithful copies of beloved classics, including the Volkswagen Beetle, Ford Mustang and Mini Cooper. Now that movement, called retro design, is giving way to a forward-looking approach.

headline: Alice Goffman’s Heralded Book on Crime Is Disputed
abstract: Since her book “On the Run” was published, the author has achieved a measure of fame that is rare​ for a young sociologist, but ​she now faces criticism over her facts and methods.
lead_paragraph: Since her book “On the Run: Fugitive Life in an American City” was published last year, Alice Goffman has achieved a measure of fame that is rarely visited on a young sociologist.

headline: Voting With My (Ugly) Feet?
abstract: After a snub against women who wore flats at the Cannes Film Festival, a writer looks back on a lifetime of missteps in cruel-fitting shoes.
lead_paragraph: Well, now I can never go to Cannes.

headline: These Dads Are Writing Their Own Tickets
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Men and Boys', 'Art', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The stay-at-home father and part-time artist is no longer quite as rare a sighting.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, Ben Fountain, then a 30-year-old lawyer in North Dallas, decided to quit his practice to stay at home with his child and learn how to write fiction. His wife, also a lawyer, made enough money to support the family and hire a nanny. Mr. Fountain used the six hours a day she was on call to write before picking up the caregiving slack and household maintenance in the afternoon.

headline: Henrietta Bingham’s Jazz Age Life
abstract: Henrietta Worth Bingham’s life shamed her family. Decades later, a great-niece decided to find out why.

headline: Mom and Dad Have Their Own Set of Finals
abstract: The concluding weeks of the school year have turned into a Sisyphean gantlet of activities for parents.
lead_paragraph: Jodi Gold, a Manhattan child psychiatrist and the mother of three children ages 6, 9 and 11, is accustomed to the perennial juggle. But at this time of year, all she can do is triage.

headline: Coffee and Haircuts: The New Classic
abstract: Barber shops are offering drinks with their usual offerings.
lead_paragraph: Barber shops are offering drinks with their usual offerings.

headline: Kyrie Irving Out of N.B.A. Finals With Broken Kneecap, Cavaliers Say
abstract: The injury, which Irving is expected to take three to four months to recover from, ended his season.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — With Kyrie Irving officially gone for the remainder of the finals, the Cleveland Cavaliers must figure out a way to compete with a powerful Golden State Warriors team that may have been too much for them even when they were at full strength.

headline: You Want a Cappuccino With That Haircut?
abstract: Long in decline, barbershops are back, and are serving beer, bourbon and coffee along with shaves and trims.
lead_paragraph: Every couple of weeks, Andrew Livingston, 22, a co-founder of a Brooklyn men's wear company, stops on his way home from work for a drink — either a glass of pale ale or an espresso — in a setting where he typically finds like-minded guys.

headline: A Crisis at the Edge of Physics
abstract: Does science always need empirical evidence?
lead_paragraph: DO physicists need empirical evidence to confirm their theories?

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: How Uzo Aduba, Actor, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Aduba, a star of “Orange Is the New Black,” starts the day with “Scandal,” rides at SoulCycle and goes to bed with a good book.
lead_paragraph: Uzo Aduba, who won an Emmy Award last year for her portrayal of Suzanne Warren (Crazy Eyes) on Netflix’s “Orange Is the New Black,” finally feels like a New Yorker. Born to Nigerian immigrants, she grew up in Massachusetts and moved to the city after college to pursue theater. She was instantly enamored of New York and its rhythms. “It felt bigger than life,” she said. But it was not until she mastered the subway system that Ms. Aduba, 34, felt like part of the fabric. The actor, who lives in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, said that because she no longer consults the subway map she stands out less. But with the third season of “Orange” available for binge-watching on June 12, blending in may prove more difficult.

headline: A Lesson for New York City Ballet: The Past Is Always Present
abstract: Justin Peck’s “Rodeo,” which flies in the face of a Balanchine maxim, works well, but Balanchine’s rich legacy could still be mined more often.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine once said: “Put 16 women on the stage, and it’s everybody — it’s the world. Put 16 men on, and it’s always nobody.” His 1972 Stravinsky “Symphony in Three Movements” begins with 16 women, and his 1934 Tchaikovsky “Serenade” with 17 women. When we watch those ballets, we can still believe him. (“Symphony in Three” was danced early in the New York City Ballet season that ends this weekend. It and “Serenade” return to repertory next May.)

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire,’ on AMC, Switches Gears in Its New Season
abstract: The drama shifts gears to focus on the female leads, but it might be best to take a wait-and-see attitude.
lead_paragraph: Early in the new season of “Halt and Catch Fire,” AMC’s drama about daddy issues, 1980s home décor and the beginnings of the computer industry, the action takes place mostly in a beat-up Dallas house furnished with water guns and pizza crusts. It’s the headquarters of Mutiny, a nascent company offering early versions of online gaming and chat rooms, whose corporate structure consists of two more or less mature women trying to wrangle a herd of childish young men — Prodigy crossed with “Animal House.”

headline: Water for Israel
abstract: A reader weighs in on a news story about defeating the drought.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Britain’s Health Service Aided Struggling Computer Sciences
abstract: The National Health Service made payments that the company recorded in a way that made it look stronger than it truly was, according to the S.E.C.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s National Health Service has long provided free and universal health care to the country’s residents.

headline: Christopher Dodd Stays On as Top Hollywood Lobbyist
abstract: Mr. Dodd, a former Democratic senator from Connecticut, was given a three-year contract extension as chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Despite a tenure marred by a major legislative setback and a slow response to the Sony computer attack, Christopher J. Dodd, the leader of Hollywood’s top lobbying organization, was given a three-year contract extension on Friday.

headline: Review: Holly Herndon, With Laptops, at the Wick
abstract: Ms. Herndon produced sounds descended from techno, but not following its rules. There was lots of text, too.
lead_paragraph: Depending on your point of view, Holly Herndon’s work might seem incomplete, only partway toward the heart of a lot of interesting things. Or it might seem complete in its semidetached, casually obsessive relationship with all of them.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: We’re trying something new: a quick rundown of the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new: a quick nightly rundown of the day’s top stories. What do you think? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Yoshiko Chuma, in a Journey Across Borders
abstract: This choreographer’s “π=3.14 ... Nothing, or Everything” explores displacement at La MaMa Moves!
lead_paragraph: Just as pi stretches on indefinitely, so might Yoshiko Chuma’s “π=3.14 ... Nothing, or Everything.” At the outset of this multimedia work, which opened on Thursday at La MaMa, the performer Nick Vaughan explains that the dance has been in rehearsal “for 10 days, or three years, or continuously since 1976,” the year that Ms. Chuma, a veteran choreographer and activist, arrived in New York from her native Japan. “It is a work perpetually in progress.”

headline: The Value of a Mindless Summer Job
abstract: Humble work assignments give students a chance to build their character, if not their résumés.

headline: Magnum Chooses the Decisive, and Transforming, Photo
abstract: Magnum asked some 50 of its members to choose one “image that changed everything,” eliciting a range of responses, some unexpected.
lead_paragraph: Magnum asked some 50 of its members to choose one “image that changed everything,” eliciting a range of responses, some unexpected.

headline: Philharmonic Chooses Anna Thorvaldsdottir for Emerging Composer Program
abstract: Ms. Thorvaldsdottir, who has enjoyed a growing profile in recent years, will receive $50,000 and a commission to write for the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: Anna Thorvaldsdottir, an Icelandic composer known for richly textured works that are often inspired by nature, was named Friday as the New York Philharmonic’s second Kravis Emerging Composer — an honor that comes with $50,000 and a commission to write for the orchestra.

headline: Cabinet of Wonders
abstract: Beyond the shady exterior of Eclectic Collectibles and Antiques lives a kooky, pell-mell paradise: a forest of ephemera, an inchoate collision of the beautiful and revolting that’s open every day until midnight.
lead_paragraph: Beyond the shady exterior of Eclectic Collectibles and Antiques lives a kooky, pell-mell paradise: a forest of ephemera, an inchoate collision of the beautiful and revolting that’s open every day until midnight.

headline: Eclectic Collectibles and Antiques in Williamsburg Is a Cabinet of Wonders
abstract: In the Brooklyn shop with a 1940 Buick in front lives a kooky, pell-mell paradise: a forest of ephemera that’s open every day until midnight.
lead_paragraph: Music lures pedestrians into Eclectic Collectibles and Antiques at 285 Metropolitan Avenue. Oldies, specifically. “I Guess That’s Why They Call It the Blues” (Elton John, from 1983) blared from the entrance on a recent sunny afternoon. The nondescript storefront would be easy to miss if not for the music and a menacing antique car parked at the curb: a tar-black 1940 Buick Super that evokes pinstripe suits, Tommy guns and Sonny Corleone’s assassination in “The Godfather.”

headline: A Defender of Stonewall, and Himself
abstract: Williamson L. Henderson, as director of the Stonewall Rebellion Veterans Association, safeguards the memory of the birth of the modern gay rights movement, but not without some questions about his claims of arrest.
lead_paragraph: The monthly meeting of the Stonewall Rebellion Veterans Association was drifting into disorder last weekend when its director, Williamson L. Henderson, called for order by banging his gavel, which, to be technical, was really a kitchen tool.

headline: An App That Lets You Find and Share Articles
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: A new social network called This. allows users to share exactly one article a day from mainstream outlets and more obscure sites, as well as Tumblr posts, videos and even podcasts.
lead_paragraph: When you scroll through your Facebook feed, there are particular kinds of posts that you’re looking for, even if you don’t realize it. It could be that you favor items like your cousin Carly’s wedding pictures, an update on Nathan’s trip to Thailand or the interesting articles that you know your friend Anna is liable to share.

headline: Player Ratings: Netherlands (3) vs. United States (4)
abstract: Player ratings for the United States national team in Friday’s 4-3 win against the Netherlands in Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: For the United States national team, the past year has been marred by a sudden sting of defensive collapses. In Friday night’s exhibition in Amsterdam, the team turned the tables for a change. With three goals in the final 20 minutes, including one in the 88th minute and a 90th-minute winner, the Americans erased a two-goal deficit and stunned the Netherlands, 4-3, in a friendly in Amsterdam.

headline: Meth Finds a New Market in New York
keywords: ['Methamphetamines', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The popularity of the powerful drug, associated with sex parties, has spread from affluent gay white men to black and Hispanic gay men.
lead_paragraph: The waiting room of Gay Men of African Descent, a service agency near Downtown Brooklyn, is almost always quiet and empty. Artful photographs of naked men under tinted lights hang on the walls without an audience. Magazines for people who are H.I.V. positive sit untouched in a swirl on a carved African pedestal.

headline: A Manhattan Fortuneteller Cost Him Fortune After Fortune
abstract: Even those who are skeptical of scams may be surprised by the eye-popping payouts one Brooklyn man made to a Times Square psychic in hopes of being united with the woman he loved.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that when a man loves a woman, he can’t keep his mind on nothing else. He’ll spend his very last dime. Give up all his comfort, sleep out in the rain.

headline: Nepal: More Victims Reported in Helicopter Crash
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Earthquakes']
abstract: An American military helicopter that crashed last month in the mountains east of Kathmandu was carrying five more passengers than had previously been reported.
lead_paragraph: An American military helicopter that crashed last month in the mountains east of Kathmandu, the capital, was carrying five more passengers than had previously been reported, the Nepalese Army said Friday. Eight people — six United States Marines and two Nepalese soldiers — were initially reported to have been killed during a relief mission in the aftermath of a devastating earthquake in April. But Nepal’s Army said in a statement Friday that five additional passengers, all Nepalese civilians, had also been on the flight and had been killed. It has not been determined why the helicopter went down on May 12. The wreckage was found on a ridge at an altitude of 11,200 feet, the army statement said, close to the epicenter of a second major earthquake.

headline: A Money Horse
abstract: The rich could get much richer if American Pharoah, who has banked $3,730,300 for Zayat Stables can earn the winner’s share of $800,000.
lead_paragraph: The rich could get much richer if American Pharoah, who has banked $3,730,300 for Zayat Stables can earn the winner’s share of $800,000.

headline: Drawn to Estela but Not by a ‘50 Best’ List
abstract: Estela, in NoLIta, made the new rankings of the World’s 50 Best Restaurants, at No. 90, but Pinterest and MindShare employees ate there because they’d “heard it was good for groups.”
lead_paragraph: When the World’s 50 Best Restaurants announced its 2015 rankings last week, the only new American restaurant among upstarts from India, Dubai, South Korea and Russia — and perennial American contenders like Per Se and Le Bernardin — was Estela, a small, beverage-driven restaurant from Thomas Carter, the former beverage director of Blue Hill at Stone Barns, and Ignacio Mattos, a chef mentored by Alice Waters. While Estela is new to the list, coming in at No. 90 — naturally, the 50 Best list goes to 100 — it is not new to New York City, having occupied a space on East Houston Street in NoLIta for a couple of years.

headline: The Tale of the Red Queen, Communist Double Agent
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Cold War Era', 'Communism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Elizabeth T. Bentley, an American who managed a spy ring for the Soviet Union and became a double agent, had a crucial role in what was known as the Red Scare but died in obscurity.
lead_paragraph: Q. Wasn’t there a woman early in the Cold War known as the Red Queen?

headline: Pistons Hire Agent Arn Tellem as a Front Office Executive

lead_paragraph: Arn Tellem, one of the most influential and powerful agents in professional sports, has agreed to become the vice chairman of Palace Sports and Entertainment, the company that owns the Detroit Pistons.

headline: The Camera as Time Machine
abstract: David Battel, who has been taking black-and-white pictures in Midtown Manhattan for over 20 years, pays homage to luminaries like Garry Winogrand.
lead_paragraph: David Battel, who has been taking black-and-white pictures in Midtown Manhattan for over 20 years, pays homage to luminaries like Garry Winogrand.

headline: Street Photographer at Port Authority Captures Another Era
abstract: David Battel, who has been taking black-and-white pictures on Eighth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan for over 20 years, pays homage to luminaries like Garry Winogrand.
lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years, the street photographer David Battel has stalked Midtown with a Leica in tow. Most days, he arrives at the height of rush hour and aims his lens at those pounding the pavement, a heterogeneous pool of commuters, tourists, artists, students and scraggly folks who flow into and out of Manhattan.

headline: Real Estate Magnate Pushes for a Casino in North Jersey
abstract: Jeff Gural, who proposes a $1 billion venue at the Meadowlands Racetrack he runs, must overcome opposition from South Jersey and get a referendum on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Gural, the New York real estate tycoon, had cleaned up well.

headline: U.S. Says Russia Failed to Correct Violation of Landmark 1987 Arms Control Deal
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: At issue is the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty, known as the I.N.F. Treaty, which the Obama administration says the Russians breached by testing a cruise missile.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department reported on Friday that Russia had failed to correct a violation of a landmark arms control accord between Washington and Moscow that prohibits intermediate-range ground-launched missiles.

headline: Arthur Goldhammer
abstract: A French translator on keeping up with slang through TV shows and programming computers for fun.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Goldhammer is best known as a translator of French literature, having translated more than 100 works ranging from classics by Alexis de Tocqueville and Albert Camus to last year’s best-selling “Capital in the 21st Century,” by Thomas Piketty.

headline: Lehman to Pay Barclays $1.3 Billion to Settle Suit
abstract: The pact, if it wins court approval, would conclude about six years of fighting involving Barclays over the sale of Lehman Brothers.
lead_paragraph: One of the longest-running legal fights from the financial crisis, rooted in the dismantling of Lehman Brothers, is near an end.

headline: Pulses Are Zooming, and Opinions Are Flying
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: Everyone seems to have an opinion on whether American Pharoah will become the 12th thoroughbred to sweep the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes.
lead_paragraph: Conspiracy theorists, soothsayers and experts of all stripes feel truly at home in few places. The racetrack is one of these premier locales. The times when this assemblage of dreamers balances anxiety and gloom, hope and despair with the fervor of true believers are rarer still. The eve of a Triple Crown bid is such a time.

headline: Long Island Sees a Crisis as It Floats to the Surface
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'ALGAE', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Sewers and Sewage']
abstract: In the largest kill of its kind that anyone can recall, thousands of dead fish washed ashore in the Peconic Estuary in recent months, victims of the nitrogen pollution that is the bane of the region.
lead_paragraph: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The dead turtles, about 100 of them, started washing ashore near here in late April. Then came the dead fish, in numbers no one had seen before. By this week, tens of thousands of fish carcasses had bobbed to the surface of the Peconic River, which runs along the southern border of this town, and in adjoining Flanders Bay, washing ashore in putrid drifts.

headline: Health Care Expansion Is Rejected in Florida
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: It was the third time that legislators had considered and spurned some version of health care expansion since passage of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In another rebuke of the Obama administration’s efforts to expand health care to the uninsured, Florida’s Republican-led House of Representatives soundly rejected a plan on Friday that state officials said would have covered as many as 650,000 residents.

headline: Serena Williams’s Grand Slam March
keywords: ['Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Australian Open (Tennis)', 'Wimbledon Tennis Tournament', 'French Open (Tennis)']

lead_paragraph: On Saturday at the French Open, Serena Williams will go for her 20th Grand Slam singles title and third in a row. She is second on the Open era career list, behind Steffi Graf’s 22. Williams’s opponent, 13th-seeded Lucie Safarova, will be playing her first Grand Slam singles final, though she won the women’s doubles title at the Australian Open this year. A look at some of the numbers in Williams’s remarkable 18-year career at Grand Slam events:

headline: Days Before Election in Turkey, Blasts at Rally Kill 2
abstract: The explosions, which wounded more than 100, took place at a huge opposition political rally in a predominantly Kurdish city.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A huge opposition political rally in the predominantly Kurdish city of Diyarbakir on Friday ended with smoke, panic and defiance as two explosions killed two people and wounded more than 100 others, a senior government minister said.

headline: 2 Defendants in Manhattan Biker Assault Await Verdict From Judge
abstract: The prosecution and defense summed up their cases on Friday in the trial of two motorcyclists charged with beating up a driver during a raucous biker rally in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution and defense summed up their cases on Friday in the trial of an undercover New York police detective and another man accused of being among several motorcyclists who beat up a driver during a raucous biker rally in September 2013.

headline: Bergdahl Seeks Removal of General in Desertion Case
abstract: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has asked a military appellate court to disqualify the general in charge of the desertion case against him.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has asked a military appellate court to disqualify the general in charge of the desertion case against him. Eugene R. Fidell, Sergeant Bergdahl’s lawyer, said the general, Mark A. Milley, who has been nominated to be the Army’s chief of staff, should be removed because of his personal interest in being confirmed by the Senate. Sergeant Bergdahl, who disappeared from his post in Afghanistan in 2009 and was held by the Taliban for five years before being released last year in a prisoner swap, filed the request on Friday in the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces.

headline: Israel’s Allies in U.S. Challenge Boycott
abstract: Israel’s advocates in the United States, mirroring the reaction among many in Israel, are scrambling to respond to the pro-Palestinian economic and disinvestment campaign.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina has become the first state to enact legislation aimed at thwarting an international pro-Palestinian economic and disinvestment campaign intended to penalize Israel. Illinois will soon become the second, and advocates say plans are underway for similar laws in 18 more states.

headline: Women’s World Cup 2015: Door Opens for 24 Teams
abstract: Eight first-time entrants join the Women’s World Cup field this year, and the days of one or two dominant teams are long gone.

lead_paragraph: MEN often face pressure to measure up as alpha males, to “wolf up” as it were. Alpha male connotes the man who at every moment demonstrates that he’s in total control in the home, and who away from home can become snarling and aggressive.

headline: Leonid Plyushch, Soviet Dissident Punished in an Asylum, Dies
abstract: Mr. Plyushch, a Ukrainian mathematician, became a leading political dissident, prompting the Kremlin to commit him to a mental asylum for a nightmarish three years of drugs and deprivation.
lead_paragraph: Leonid Plyushch, a Ukrainian mathematician who became a leading political dissident in the Soviet era, prompting the Kremlin to commit him to a mental asylum for a nightmarish three years of drugs and deprivation in the early 1970s, died on Thursday near Paris.

headline: A Political Brand of Sominex
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Can’t sleep? Instead of counting sheep, how about counting up your 2016 presidential candidates?
lead_paragraph: When I have trouble falling asleep, I do lists. Like running through the names of all the presidents, along with several factoids for each one. I was rather proud of this talent until friends sent me a video clip of Ellen DeGeneres interviewing a 5-year-old girl who could do it better.

headline: Review: ‘The Twentieth-Century Way’ Explores a Moment in Gay History
abstract: Two actors try on a variety of roles in quick succession in this play by Tom Jacobson about a shameful period of harassment by the police.
lead_paragraph: Some underemployed actors answer phones. Some babysit or bar-tend or teach English as a second language. And some entrap and arrest gay men on charges of “social vagrancy.”

headline: Crime and Confusion in a Safer New York City
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police']

lead_paragraph: The New York City tabloids, TV news and other elements of the city’s early-warning system for the apocalypse have noted a steady rise in shootings and homicides. To some this smells like the beginning of the end of many years of falling crime, and with it, presumably, the mayor’s credibility as a leader who can keep the city safe.

headline: A Triple Crown Possibility Keeps Registers Ringing Around Belmont Park
abstract: Business picks up every year in neighborhood around the racetrack, as workers and crowds move in for the Belmont Stakes. The challenge is staying afloat when the visitors are gone.
lead_paragraph: The spectators who crowd into Belmont Park for the final leg of the Triple Crown like to dress for the occasion. They don pastel sun dresses and straw fedoras.

headline: Magic Object

lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Well, I was right, wasn’t I? I warned you to enjoy the Friday puzzle because, in all likelihood, the Saturday would be tougher. Today, we reflect (sorry) on the difficulty level of this puzzle by Jason Flinn.

headline: A Detainee Describes More C.I.A. Torture
abstract: Newly declassified statements by Majid Khan, a Guantánamo Bay prisoner, show that there is, indeed, more to the sickening story.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who had the time to read the summary of the 6,700-page report by Senate investigators on the federal government’s program of torturing detainees captured after the Sept. 11 attacks knew, or at least suspected, that there was more to the sickening story.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker’s proposal for weakening tenure at Wisconsin’s highly respected state university system and undermining the faculty’s role in campus governance will appeal to conservative voters whose support he needs to win the Republican presidential nomination.

keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Elderly']

keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Horses', 'Belmont Stakes']

headline: Daryl Hall Renovates Venue, for Music, Food and TV

lead_paragraph: In the 1970s and ’80s, Daryl Hall and his musical partner, John Oates, built a catalog of recordings that included six No. 1 hits, among them “Rich Girl,” “Private Eyes” and “Out of Touch.” The duo, who still attract sellout crowds on tour, were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame last year.

headline: Judge Rules Second Version of New York Teachers’ Exam Is Also Racially Biased

headline: Look, Ma, No Hands!

lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, during Google’s annual meeting, a shareholder named John M. Simpson stood up to question the company’s top executives about its self-driving car program. They were not friendly questions.

headline: Yankees Survive a Six-Run Rally by the Angels
abstract: Trailing by 8-1 in the ninth inning, the Angels scored six runs to turn a blowout into a close loss at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Daniel Murphy Heads to D.L. on Day of Losses for Mets
abstract: Before a defeat in Arizona, Murphy, one of the Mets’ top hitters, went on the 15-day disabled list with a strained quadriceps, and Kevin Plawecki was examined for a virus.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When the Mets’ clubhouse opened Friday, Daniel Murphy’s jersey and pants hung in his locker, as if he would be playing that night. Perhaps it was the product of wishful thinking. But when a player’s health is involved, not much has gone right for the Mets this season, and this was nothing more than a tease.

headline: Review: At Winston in Mount Kisco, the Play of Sweetness and Spice
abstract: Winston, named for the chef’s pit bull terrier, serves full-flavored dishes in an inviting space that also features cartoons of funny dogs.
lead_paragraph: The Moroccan duck breast is delicious: a fan of perfectly cooked rose-colored slices, with a top layer offering an intriguing interplay of sharp and sweet.

headline: Bringing In the Righty. And the Lefty.
abstract: Pat Venditte was called up Friday by Oakland and pitched two scoreless innings against Boston using each hand.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 years ago Greg Harris, a journeyman reliever, finally fulfilled his dream to pitch with each hand in a major league game. In the ninth inning of a loss to the Cincinnati Reds on Sept. 28, 1995, Harris, then with the Montreal Expos, came into the game as a right-hander and retired Reggie Sanders on his first pitch. He switched to his left arm to walk Hal Morris and retire Eddie Taubensee, then was back to his right to induce a groundout from Bret Boone.

headline: Isiah Thomas Era Opens With Liberty Defeating Atlanta

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 6, 2015.

headline: Review: ‘Guys and Dolls’ in East Haddam Revives the World and Patois of Damon Runyon’s New York
abstract: The musical, directed by Don Stephenson, resurrects the mobsters, hustlers and dames who inhabited Times Square.
lead_paragraph: What’s playing at the Goodspeed? I’ll tell you what’s playing at the Goodspeed. Story of a high-rolling gambler who wins way more than he bargained for when a mission doll upsets his game. Yes, Sky Masterson and Sarah Brown are back, along with their pals Nathan Detroit, Miss Adelaide (don’t call her Ms.!) and the whole gang of charming lowlifes who inhabit the Broadway of “Guys and Dolls.”

headline: A Review of Sayulita, Mexican Cuisine With a Twist
abstract: Named after a surfing village, Sayulita plays with south-of-the-border fare in a beach-styled space.
lead_paragraph: Some restaurants just grab you the moment you walk through the door. Named after a surfing village near Puerto Vallarta, Sayulita has a bright, beachy vibe, with distressed furniture and whitewashed pine booths, photos of oceanfront scenes and a Volkswagen Microbus, and Christmas lights draped festively across a mirror. Waitresses in jeans and gingham shirts complete the symphony of charm that the owner, Bill Driggs, has orchestrated.

headline: Review: All the Living Room’s a Stage in Madison Revival of ’27 Play by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber
abstract: The Cavendish clan, who mostly reside in a swank Manhattan duplex, are delightful people, and “The Royal Family” endures as one of the best comedies ever written about show folk.
lead_paragraph: That theatrical adage “Dying is easy; comedy is hard” is aptly demonstrated by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey’s current revival of “The Royal Family” in Madison.

headline: Restaurant Review: Talde Jersey City
abstract: In the celebrity chef Dale Talde’s latest venture, Talde Jersey City, he merges the traditional Filipino and classic American flavors of his childhood in a fun setting.
lead_paragraph: Celebrity chef restaurants get a lot of buzz but do not always live up to the hype. Talde Jersey City, the casual Asian-American spot from former “Top Chef” contestant-turned-entrepreneur Dale Talde, 36, has definitely gotten a lot of buzz.

headline: Review: In ‘The New Sincerity,’ Worldviews Are Constantly Changing
abstract: Alena Smith’s play, directed by Bob Balaban in its world premiere in Sag Harbor, tells of a journalist and her friends coming of age as the Occupy Wall Street movement develops.
lead_paragraph: What a minefield the world of political protest can be — almost as treacherous as interpersonal relationships, especially ones involving sex.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (MAX) BLADE RUNNER (1982) Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) is a blade runner — an agent tasked with eliminating, or “retiring,” rogue robots, or replicants. Deckard struggles with emotional connections to one replicant as he dangerously engages with others. Ridley Scott directed this gritty and ethereal noir. “Science-fiction devotees may find ‘Blade Runner’ a wonderfully meticulous movie and marvel at the comprehensiveness of its vision,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Even those without a taste for gadgetry cannot fail to appreciate the degree of effort that has gone into constructing a film so ambitious and idiosyncratic.”

headline: A Heartfelt Letter Home
abstract: The restaurant features dishes from the Argentine city its owner hails from, and its décor reflects Mendoza’s status as the capital of the nation’s wine country.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible to be anonymous when the owner of a restaurant greets you with a smile and a big hug. This happened to me recently at Café Mendoza in Commack. The person doing the hugging was Hugo Garcia, the owner of the almost four-month-old restaurant. Mr. Garcia, along with his business partner, Fabio Machado, also owns Café Buenos Aires and Bistro Cassis in Huntington as well as Bistro Citron in Roslyn and Manhattan.

headline: With First-Round Difficulties Forgotten, Blackhawks’ Corey Crawford Rights Himself for the Finals
abstract: Crawford, Chicago’s top goalie, has recovered after being benched in three games against the Nashville Predators.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The mood was light around Corey Crawford’s locker stall on Friday. He laughed along with the banter and joked with Chicago television reporters about their fresh Florida suntans.

headline: Views Differ on Shape of Macroeconomics
abstract: You call this a debate?
lead_paragraph: The doctrine of expansionary austerity — the claim that slashing spending would actually boost demand and employment, because it would have such positive effects on confidence that this would outweigh the direct drag — was immensely popular among policymakers in 2010, as the great turn toward austerity began. But the statistical underpinnings of the doctrine fell apart under scrutiny: the methods Alberto Alesina used to identify changes in fiscal policy did not, it turned out, do a very good job, and more careful work found that historically austerity has in fact been contractionary after all. Moreover, the experience of austerity programs seemed to confirm what Keynesians new and old had warned from the beginning — that the negative effects of austerity are much larger under conditions where they cannot be offset by conventional monetary policy.

headline: I Am a Bigamist
abstract: I’m happily remarried, but I didn’t stop loving my first husband when he died.
lead_paragraph: Among the many popular misconceptions about grief and its trajectory, one that particularly rankles widowed people is the assumption that if you’ve found a new love relationship, you’ve “moved on” from your grief. How very tidy.

headline: The Truth About AI (Silly)
abstract: It knows when you’ve been sleeping, it knows when you’re awake.
lead_paragraph: Izabella Kaminska, at a meeting about the future of artificial intelligence, muses/jokes that the AI might already be here, but choosing not to show itself. She’s not watching the right TV shows! That’s the premise of the terrific Person of Interest. Here’s Root (Amy Acker), a hacker temporarily confined to a mental health facility but still in contact with the Machine:

lead_paragraph: WASHOUGAL, WASH. — People talk about chucking their jobs. They say they will leave behind the madness of the city and hit the road.

headline: Mr. Market Speaks
abstract: And loudly declares his indifference.
lead_paragraph: Way back, when it wasn’t entirely silly to say that there was a real debate about the impact of fiscal and monetary policy in a liquidity trap, there were really two big issues on which academics like me and those who claimed to be wise about such matters but didn’t do models differed. One was inflation; the other was interest rates, where there were many dire warnings about the impact of budget deficits, but basic macroeconomics said otherwise.

headline: Why Am I A Keynesian?

headline: If Hastert Was Extorted, He Could Deduct Some Losses From His Taxes
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Federal Taxes (US)']

lead_paragraph: When I was researching my article about Dennis Hastert’s indictment on charges that he improperly withdrew large sums of money from a bank, one question I had was whether any tax was owed on the payments Mr. Hastert was said to have made.

headline: Hubris, and Sputnik, Doomed the Edsel
abstract: Gadgetry like Teletouch Drive, which allowed drivers to shift gears by pushing a button, came to be seen as frivolous gimmicks after the Soviets launched Sputnik.
lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company in the late 1950s gambled about $250 million (roughly $2.1 billion today) to create what The New York Times called the “first new brand name” to be introduced by one of the Big Three car companies (General Motors, Ford and Chrysler) since 1938. The car was the Edsel, a name that remains a synonym for a failed product.

headline: Taliban Overrun Remote District in Northeastern Afghanistan
abstract: Taliban fighters overwhelmed security forces in the Yamgan district of Badakhshan Province, where the government’s influence has waned considerably over the past two years.

headline: SEAL Team 6: A Secret History of Quiet Killings and Blurred Lines
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: The unit best known for killing Osama bin Laden has been converted into a global manhunting machine with limited outside oversight.
lead_paragraph: They have plotted deadly missions from secret bases in the badlands of Somalia. In Afghanistan, they have engaged in combat so intimate that they have emerged soaked in blood that was not their own. On clandestine raids in the dead of the night, their weapons of choice have ranged from customized carbines to primeval tomahawks.

headline: Obama Delivers Eulogy for Beau Biden
abstract: For Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who lost a daughter and his first wife decades ago, it was another day of grief as he buried a son in Delaware.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who began his life on the national stage more than four decades ago under the dark cloud of a family tragedy, laid his elder son, Beau, to rest on Saturday, marking yet another moment of grief in a long political career shaped by it.

headline: Third Time Is a Chore as Serena Williams Wins French Open Title
abstract: Williams overcame illness and shakiness to beat Lucie Safarova for her fifth three-set win in Paris, more than she had in any of her previous 19 runs to a Grand Slam singles title.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Serena Williams was too ill to get out of bed for most of Friday. She was too tightly wound to close out what would have been a routine straight-set victory against Lucie Safarova on Saturday.

headline: Novak Djokovic Tops Andy Murray to Reach French Open Final
abstract: Djokovic, the top seed, finally faced a stiff test at Roland Garros, but after five sets of extended rallies over two days, he advanced to a matchup with Stan Wawrinka.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After Novak Djokovic outclassed his first five opponents, including the ultimate clay-court master, Rafael Nadal, he finally had to overcome stiff resistance at this French Open.

headline: A Storied Trainer and a Witness to History
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: John A. Nerud has overseen a stable full of great horses, and he bred and owned Fappiano, American Pharoah’s great-great-grandfather.
lead_paragraph: OLD BROOKVILLE, N.Y. — At the end of a long and winding road shaded by trees sit two brick houses owned by a father and son who have often resided at the top of the thoroughbred industry. A sign with jockey silks and the name Nerud points the way.

headline: Scott Walker Riding With Joni Ernst in Iowa as Rivals Give Chase
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin was ready to mount a motorcycle Saturday for a “Roast and Ride” fund-raiser, but Republican challenges lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin throws his leg across his beloved Harley-Davidson Road King for a celebration of motorcycles and Iowa pork on Saturday, the political symbolism will be as thick as the smoke from the roasting pits.

headline: Northside Festival Features Luna’s Return and Other Indie Rock
abstract: Luna will play the Northside Festival, the band’s first New York show in a decade, at Brooklyn’s version of South by Southwest.
lead_paragraph: The Northside Festival, Brooklyn’s emulation of South by Southwest, continues to expand. Its core is still the indie-rock clubs of Williamsburg and Greenpoint and the local bands that play them. But it’s also attracting headliners with bigger names. Its opening-night concert, Thursday at McCarren Park, features the return — for its first New York show after a 10-year hiatus — of Luna, a band that carried the Velvet Underground legacy of drone-rock and deadpan insight from 1991-2004. There are also big showcases at 50 Kent Street — a.k.a. Live at the Inlet — with Neko Case and Rhye on Friday, Best Coast and Built to Spill on Saturday, and Run the Jewels and Sleigh Bells on Sunday. The Nigerian Afrobeat band Femi Kuti and the Positive Force visits Brooklyn Bowl on Thursday. But in a festival with hundreds of bands, leave time for lesser-knowns like Jacco Gardner, a Dutch psychedelic-pop revivalist, on Thursday at Rough Trade, or the Minimalist composer Delia Gonzalez next Sunday at Manhattan Inn. (northsidefestival.com.)

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: A new contributor to the Variety puzzles makes his debut.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — If the byline on today’s Puns & Anagrams puzzle looks different to you, it’s not a meta clue, nor is it a mistake. Constructor Mark Diehl makes his P&A debut today. I’ll let Will Shortz explain:

headline: Liz Rodbell on Taking the Time to Recognize Success
abstract: The president of Lord & Taylor and Hudson’s Bay department stores said she learned early on the importance of saying thank you to improve morale.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Liz Rodbell, president of Lord & Taylor and Hudson’s Bay department stores, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Pope Francis Urges a Divided Bosnia to Heal, Declaring ‘War Never Again!’
abstract: Pope Francis praised the progress Bosnia made since the bloody ethnic conflict of the 1990s and urged an end to the sectarian conflicts around the world.
lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — Coming to a country whose national anthem has no lyrics because its bickering ethnic groups cannot agree on them, Pope Francis on Saturday called for greater religious reconciliation and an end to the sectarian conflicts that still threaten Bosnia and proliferate around the world in “a kind of third world war being fought piecemeal.”

headline: The High Cost of Investing Like a Daredevil
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Personal Finances', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Exchange Traded Funds']
abstract: Research suggests that investors who think short term stand to miss out on thousands, or even hundreds of thousands, of dollars in returns.
lead_paragraph: Live in the moment: If you’re skiing, surfing or scuba diving, that’s the way to go. But if you’re investing, that approach can lead to disaster.

headline: Divine Intervention Is a Hope, Not a Horse, in the Belmont
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: American Pharoah’s jockey, Victor Espinoza, paid homage at the grave site of a Jewish leader who some believe has the ear of a higher power.
lead_paragraph: Just a few dozen furlongs from Belmont Park lies the grave site of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the rebbe of the Lubavitcher group of Hasidic Jews. Since Schneerson died in 1994, Jews from all over the world have made a pilgrimage to Montefiore Cemetery to pay homage to the charismatic rebbe.

headline: Task for Obama at Group of 7 Is to Reinforce Isolation of Russia
abstract: With Russia claiming a diplomatic victory after Secretary of State John Kerry’s visit, the challenge for the Obama administration becomes making sure Euro-American solidarity continues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One year after President Obama rallied core allies to join the United States in punishing Russia for its bellicose ways, he will use a gathering on Sunday of the world’s largest industrialized democracies to urge them to stand strong, and together, in isolating the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: No Wine (Really, Not One Bottle) Before Its Time
abstract: Customers are growing sour as they spend years waiting for a wine retailer to ship their pre-ordered vintages. What is a connoisseur to do?
lead_paragraph: The Haggler dislikes wine and finds all the trappings of wine connoisseurship — ordering, sipping, opining, ordering some more, opining some more — very tiresome. Everything the Haggler knows about wine could be written on the top of a bottle cork. With a Sharpie.

headline: A Stooper at Belmont Chases the Jackpot
abstract: Frankie Abbate scoops up betting slips at the racetrack in hopes of finding a few winners that bettors discarded prematurely or in error.
lead_paragraph: “This is my main turf,” Frankie Abbate, 52, said, weaving his way through a sea of bettors in the grandstand area of Belmont Racetrack on Friday just after the seventh race.

headline: A First for Snapchat
abstract: Snapchat, the social media platform, has just gotten its first political ad.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The fast-growing social media platform Snapchat just landed its first political ad.

headline: Oakland Is Home to Championship Teams, All of Them Looking to Leave
abstract: Oakland was once the most successful sports city in the nation. Now the Raiders, the Athletics and the Warriors are all looking to get out.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — There are times at this ugly concrete complex next to the freeway when you wonder why anyone would rather be anywhere else.

headline: Red Sox’ Pitching Change Is Paying Off
abstract: A group that looked overmatched early has settled down under a new pitching coach, Carl Willis, who was formerly with the Indians and the Mariners.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It was hard to play much worse than the Boston Red Sox did while losing on Thursday at Fenway Park. They blew a four-run lead, made three errors and ran the bases poorly, and their $95 million free-agent switch-hitter, Pablo Sandoval, went 0 for 4 while batting left-handed against left-handed pitchers. The forgiving American League East standings, at least, give the Red Sox hope. And as badly as they looked at the end of their four-game series with Minnesota, their pitchers did string together four quality starts. A group that looked overmatched early has settled down under a new pitching coach, Carl Willis.

headline: A Military Mind-Set Keeps a Yankee Prepared Amid Limited Action
abstract: A team-first attitude has helped Garrett Jones, a first baseman and right fielder for the Yankees, reconcile his lack of playing time with his team’s success.
lead_paragraph: Four months ago Garrett Jones arrived at Blackman High School in Murfreesboro, Tenn., with a small team of former Navy SEALs.

headline: Susan Axelrod of Finra: An Eye in the Sky Keeping Watch on Wall Street
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Ms. Axelrod keeps the financial industry following the rules from her office on the 48th floor of a building in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Susan Axelrod is the executive vice president for regulatory operations at the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, or Finra, in New York.

headline: 300 More Bodies Found in China Ship Disaster
abstract: China Central Television said investigators would begin examining the ship in an effort to determine the cause of the accident, one of Asia’s worst maritime disasters in decades.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese soldiers and paramilitary police officers have recovered nearly 300 more bodies from the cruise ship that capsized last week, and officials said Saturday that they would continue searching the muddy waters of the Yangtze for the more than 40 people who remained missing.

headline: At Site of Highs for Tiger Woods, One of a Different Sort: 85
abstract: Woods had a quadruple-bogey 8 on the 18th hole and recorded his worst score since he turned pro in 1996, with a 42 on the front nine and a 43 on the back in the third round of the Memorial Tournament.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — In 2000, Zac Blair managed to get Tiger Woods’s autograph in the Valhalla clubhouse during the week of the P.G.A. Championship, which Woods won on his way to holding all four major titles concurrently.

headline: Saudi Arabia Shoots Down Missile Fired From Yemen
abstract: The Saudis said the missile was fired by forces loyal to Yemen’s Houthi rebels. It was the first time Yemeni factions had used the weapon since the conflict began more than two months ago.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Saudi Arabia shot down a Scud ballistic missile fired from Yemen early Saturday by forces loyal to Yemen’s Houthi rebels, according to a statement by the official Saudi news agency. It was the first time Yemeni factions had used the weapon, signaling an escalation of the conflict and providing new evidence that a Saudi effort to pacify the rebels is faltering.

headline: Finding the Right Balance
abstract: The exercise we need is the one that’s best for the brain.
lead_paragraph: WE all fall down. But while a tumble for a toddler is a learning experience, and a stumble for an adult is usually just embarrassing, for older people it can be a serious, even fatal, incident.

headline: Differences in Depression Extremes
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Depression levels vary across red and blue states.
lead_paragraph: Depression levels vary across red and blue states.

headline: The F.C.C. Should Help the Poor Get Online
abstract: A proposal to extend the Lifeline phone-subsidy program to help the poor gain access to high-speed Internet service is a good, though modest, idea.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission has proposed expanding a telephone subsidy program to help the poor gain access to high-speed Internet service. A few Republican lawmakers — notably John Thune of South Dakota in the Senate and Fred Upton of Michigan in the House — have complained of fraud in the existing program. The complaints are overblown and are no reason to undermine an excellent idea.

headline: Differences in Depression Treatments
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'ANTIDEPRESSANTS']
abstract: Depression treatments vary across blue and red states.
lead_paragraph: Depression treatments vary across blue and red states.

headline: From Paris, With Tough Love
abstract: The French ambassador invents a new kind of (undiplomatic) diplomacy for the digital age.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: The Culture of Atheism
abstract: Readers react to a Sunday Review article about how secular humanists are gathering together and seeking greater acceptance.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Heroin Doesn’t Have to Be a Killer
keywords: ['Heroin', 'Naloxone (Drug)', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Even the near death of a Baltimore man didn’t turn him away from heroin, but treatment has helped him avoid getting high for four years.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Running Against Hillary
abstract: The handful of Democratic challengers to the presumptive Democratic candidate have little room to maneuver, but they can be useful in raising issues.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE anything else is said, they deserve the thanks of a grateful nation. Bernie Sanders, Martin O’Malley, even Lincoln Chafee: They are stepping up where others quailed, laying their bodies on democracy’s altar, saving their party’s nominating contest from resembling a presidential re-election in Kazakhstan.

headline: What Makes a Woman?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination', 'Brain', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: There is a collision course between feminists and transgender activists.
lead_paragraph: Do women and men have different brains?

headline: Hillary the Tormentor
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Democrats are rediscovering how cruel any romance with the Clintons is.
lead_paragraph: LATELY I’ve been running into people even more put off by the Clintons than the nefarious operatives in the “vast right wing conspiracy” ever were.

headline: The Case for a Carbon Tax
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Taxation', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: A carbon emissions tax is an easy, effective approach to climate change, steering companies and consumers toward lower-emission and renewable sources.
lead_paragraph: In a welcome development, businesses are asking world leaders to do more to address climate change. This week, the top executives of six large European oil and gas companies called for a tax on carbon emissions.

headline: How to Pose Like a Man
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature', 'Photography', 'Gender', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: If people were going to judge my book by its cover, what would they say about a different kind of author photo?
lead_paragraph: THE cover my publisher chose for my new novel, “The Unfortunate Importance of Beauty,” was indeed very beautiful, but more feminine than I would have ideally liked. It was mostly white, but all the way at the top were the gorgeous chin and red lips of a young woman. Not wanting to be a “difficult author,” I decided not to ask my editor to find a new cover. (She had already been kind enough to change it once.) Instead, I decided to counteract the cover by other means, starting with my author photo.

headline: Hackers Can Be Fought Without Violating Americans’ Rights
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: It is encouraging that more members of Congress have begun championing privacy in national security debates.
lead_paragraph: The scope and sophistication of recent cyberattacks on American government, business and personal accounts are chilling. The latest, a breach of federal personnel records that could affect more than four million current and former employees, is a reminder that enhancing the nation’s cyberdefenses has to be an urgent priority.

headline: Talking Red State Blues
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Depression (Mental)']
abstract: In Republican states, there is much less therapy than there is in Democratic ones, and people are suffering.
lead_paragraph: WHEN you mull over the differences between states that vote for Republicans in presidential elections and states that vote for Democrats, what do you think about? Perhaps religion: People in red states are far more likely to believe in God. Or maybe media consumption: More people in blue states like NPR.

headline: The Deadly Combination of Heat and Humidity
abstract: Steamy days can defeat the body’s natural cooling system, making high temperatures that much more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: THE most deadly weather-related disasters aren’t necessarily caused by floods, droughts or hurricanes. They can be caused by heat waves, like the sweltering blanket that’s taken over 2,500 lives in India in recent weeks.

headline: Why I Defaulted on My Student Loans
abstract: I refused to waste my life to pay back a pointless and overbearing debt.
lead_paragraph: ONE late summer afternoon when I was 17, I went with my mother to the local bank, a long-defunct institution whose name I cannot remember, to apply for my first student loan. My mother co-signed. When we finished, the banker, a balding man in his late 50s, congratulated us, as if I had just won some kind of award rather than signed away my young life.

headline: Ruben Tejada Is Making the Most of Another Chance With Mets
abstract: Injuries have forced Tejada back into the starting lineup, and he has become the hottest hitter on the team, batting .483 over seven games.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Ruben Tejada was sitting at his locker Thursday, examining the tattoo that circled his left wrist like a bracelet, when he was asked what the five ornately drawn letters signified.

headline: Break Serve? For Most Players, It’s a Struggle to Break Even
abstract: A long-simmering debate exists in tennis over fair compensation for players, especially those outside the top 100.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Fifty years ago this spring, Fred Stolle of Australia won the French International Tennis Championship by defeating his countryman Tony Roche in the final. Stolle and Roy Emerson, another Aussie, won the doubles crown as well.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Blatter Deserves Anything But Praise

headline: Young, Seeking Change Over Ideology, Power Right Wing in Poland
abstract: In the Polish presidential race, the incumbent tied to the party that governed Poland during eight years of prosperity was trounced by a conservative foe.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Sitting quietly in the bustle of the campus cafe, Daria Zysk paused to find just the right words to explain why she had voted for a presidential candidate whose party’s right-wing policies did not match her own views.

headline: Imagining the Lives of Others
abstract: Seeing the world from the perspective of another person may be a good thing, but is it possible?
lead_paragraph: What could be more exhilarating than experiencing the world through the perspective of another person? In “Remembrance of Things Past,” Marcel Proust’s narrator says that the only true voyage of discovery is not to visit other lands but “to possess other eyes, to behold the universe through the eyes of another, of a hundred others, to behold the hundred universes that each of them beholds.” This is one of the central projects of the humanities; it’s certainly part of the pleasure we get from art and literature.

headline: Discordant Notes Over Need to Practice on a U.S. Open Course
abstract: The feedback before the United States Open at Chambers Bay Golf Course has contained dissonant harmonies and unmistakable themes of angst, alienation and apathy.
lead_paragraph: Robert Trent Jones Jr., the architect of the public links-style course hosting this month’s United States Open, likens the circus descending on Chambers Bay Golf Course in less than two weeks to a symphony.

headline: Face of Soccer in Canada, on Field and on Stamps
abstract: Christine Sinclair entered Canada’s opening match Saturday night with 153 career goals, third on the international list behind Abby Wambach (182) and Mia Hamm (158).
lead_paragraph: EDMONTON, Alberta — GCanada had just been eliminated from the 2011 Women’s World Cup. Its captain, Christine Sinclair, sat on the turf, crying, angry, desolate. Her nose had been broken earlier in the tournament in Germany. Now, after a 4-0 rout by France in group play, her spirit felt broken as well.

headline: On Paper, U.S. Women Have Enough
abstract: The national team has the talent to win the World Cup, but it also has weaknesses in critical areas that could spell its downfall.
lead_paragraph: Can we win?

headline: A Long-Awaited Coronation
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: Belmont Park began filling up early on Saturday with spectators, trainers and riders in preparation for the Belmont Stakes, which American Pharoah won to complete his Triple Crown bid.
lead_paragraph: Belmont Park began filling up early on Saturday with spectators, trainers and riders in preparation for the Belmont Stakes, which American Pharoah won to complete his Triple Crown bid.

headline: Ben Carson’s Nascent Campaign Faces Personnel Turmoil
abstract: Mr. Carson’s presidential campaign has lost several top staff members just a month after he announced he would seek the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: BOONE, Iowa — Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon and Tea Party folk hero, has emerged as one of the most talked-about Republican candidates for president in 2016, buoyed by the strength of his outsider’s appeal and captivating life story.

headline: With Power Tools and a Ruse, 2 Killers Escape New York Prison
abstract: The New York State Police said the inmates had escaped from the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, a maximum-security prison about 170 miles north of Albany near the Canadian border.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — Two convicted murderers serving life sentences in adjoining cells staged an elaborate escape from New York’s largest state-run prison between Friday night and Saturday morning, fooling guards with makeshift dummies made out of sweatshirts and using power tools to drill out of their cells and past the prison’s 30-foot-tall walls, officials said.

headline: Presidential Hopefuls Descend on Iowa, Courting Favor With Joni Ernst
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Seven 2016 Republican candidates descended on Iowa for Senator Joni Ernst’s “Roast and Ride,” an event that was heavy on the hogs (both the bikes and the pork) and that offered the candidates a chance to make their pitch to primary voters.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Arriving at the kickoff of her inaugural “Roast and Ride” event here, fresh off a two-hour ride up from Red Oak on her 2009 Soft Tail Deluxe Harley-Davidson Saturday morning, Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa grinned as a friend pressed a Monster Energy drink into her hand.

headline: Barcelona Overwhelms Juventus to Win Fifth Champions League Title
abstract: Behind its three superstar scorers, Barcelona completed a so-called treble, having taken both the Spanish league and the Spanish cup titles.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It is not discussed often, but there is a deep and rich tradition of manager celebrations in high-level soccer, a veritable catalog of sideline revelry. On various occasions — and with varying degrees of dignity — men in suits have danced a jig, pretended to use a lasso and hydroplaned on their knees as if their coaching box had morphed into a water ride. Just a few months ago, one man in charge even ripped his trousers in a particularly robust fit of exuberant histrionics.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Irving Mondschein, Decathlete, Coach and Track Patriarch, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Track and Field', 'Olympic Games', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Decathlon', 'Olympic Games (1948)', 'Olympic Games (2012)']
abstract: Mr. Mondschein was a national champion in the decathlon and high jump in the 1940s, a college and Olympic coach and the patriarch of three generations of track and field stars.
lead_paragraph: Irving Mondschein, a national champion in the decathlon and high jump in the 1940s, a college and Olympic coach and the patriarch of three generations of track and field stars, died on Friday in Hershey, Pa. He was 91.
