lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: The Call of the Race
abstract: Samuel A. Donaldson calls it.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — That sound you hear is that of my brain unclenching after the Friday and Saturday puzzles.

headline: Surprising Saudi Rises as a Prince Among Princes
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 29, has swiftly accumulated more power than any prince has ever held, and he has become one of Saudi Arabia’s most visible leaders.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Until about four months ago, Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 29, was just another Saudi royal who dabbled in stocks and real estate.

headline: Tenure Firmly in Place, but Colleges Grow Wary of Lasting Commitments
abstract: Universities across the country are becoming far more cautious about awarding tenure, particularly in departments where enrollment is declining.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker’s move to weaken tenure in the Wisconsin public university system is bold — and, at least for a while, it is likely to remain an outlier.

headline: Transgender Children’s Books Fill a Void and Break a Taboo
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Mainstream publishing houses are increasingly giving visibility to transgender authors and their books, which are aimed at broader and younger audiences.
lead_paragraph: Sam Martin was browsing in a Boston record store 23 years ago when an unusual photography book caught his eye. Mr. Martin flipped through its pages, which featured portraits and interviews with women who had become men, and started to cry.

headline: American Pharoah Wins Belmont Stakes and Triple Crown
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: For the first time since Affirmed in 1978, a horse swept the Triple Crown races. American Pharoah became the 12th horse to accomplish the feat.
lead_paragraph: As American Pharoah came out of the far turn and squared his shoulders to let his rider Victor Espinoza stare down the long withering stretch of Belmont Park, a sense of inevitability surged through this mammoth old grandstand. The fans in a capacity crowd strained on the tips of their toes and let out a roar from deep in their souls. It was going to end, finally — this 37-year search for a great racehorse.

headline: Courts Budget Intensifies Kansas Dispute Over Powers
abstract: In an effort to ensure courts would remain open during a budget impasse, Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas signed into law a bill that funds the judiciary as long as it doesn’t strike down a 2014 law that reduced some if its authority.
lead_paragraph: The fight between Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas and the state’s judicial branch has escalated, with the governor last week signing into law a bill that could strip state courts of their funding.

headline: Spanish Tuna Fishing Melds to Japan’s Taste, Reshaping a 3,000-Year-Old Technique
abstract: In response to fishing quotas and consumer demand, companies that run the almadraba are shifting to ranching to help fatten the tuna, rather than lifting and killing their catch.
lead_paragraph: BARBATE, Spain — The fishing boats, swaying in the narrow strait that connects the Atlantic to the Mediterranean, maneuvered one recent morning around an intricate architecture of nets they had laid as a trap. Then the fishermen lifted just one section from the water, heavy with their prize.

headline: Dennis Hastert Rushed to Make Money as Payouts Grew
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former speaker of the House became more active in his lobbying firm at about the time that, according to a federal indictment, he began making large payments to a man known as “Individual A.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a relatively slow start to his career as a consultant and lobbyist, J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, became very busy in 2010. He was traveling to spots including Singapore and Montreal, meeting with clients about ventures as varied as futures trading and Formula One racing.

headline: Americans Dominate Boys’ Play in Paris
abstract: The boys’ singles final at the French Open featured two Americans, and other players from the United States made it deep into the tournament.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When North Carolina’s Tommy Paul beat San Diego’s Taylor Harry Fritz, 7-6 (2), 2-6, 6-2, Saturday in the first all-American boys’ final at the French Open, it formally ended a tournament in which the future of United States men’s tennis had already been declared the unanimous winner.

headline: Painkillers Resist Abuse, but Experts Still Worry
abstract: As thousands of addicts still find ways to abuse OxyContin and similar painkillers, called abuse-deterrent formulations, some experts caution that the protections are misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: Anthony DiTullio would pop a painkiller in his mouth but not just swallow it, as intended. He would chew it for 30 minutes, grinding through its protective coating and waxy unpleasantness, because the only pain he was treating was addiction.

headline: Hillary Clinton Traces Friendly Path, Troubling Party
abstract: Ms. Clinton appears to be dispensing with the nationwide strategy that won her husband two terms in the White House, opting instead to retrace Barack Obama’s narrower path.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to be dispensing with the nationwide electoral strategy that won her husband two terms in the White House and brought white working-class voters and great stretches of what is now red-state America back to Democrats.

headline: Putin Urges Western Pressure on Ukraine in Peace Effort
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called on the United States and Europe to pressure the Ukrainian government to comply with a cease-fire accord that was reached in February.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called on the United States and Europe on Saturday to pressure the Ukrainian government to comply with a cease-fire accord, saying that Russia would do what it could to influence separatists in the eastern Ukrainian regions of Donetsk and Luhansk but held no sway in Kiev, the capital.

headline: As G.O.P. Courts Iowa, Party Debates Relevance of State
abstract: Seven presidential hopefuls joined Senator Joni Ernst for her inaugural pig roast and motorcycle ride, heaping praise on the freshman lawmaker.
lead_paragraph: BOONE, Iowa — Wearing a black leather vest with a bald eagle on the back, black motorcycle boots and snug jeans, Senator Joni Ernst, a freshman Republican from Iowa, began her inaugural pig roast and motorcycle ride fund-raiser Saturday by easing her 2009 Softail Deluxe out of the Big Barn Harley Store in Des Moines.

headline: Gathering With Hopes of Witnessing a Coronation
abstract: Belmont Park began filling up early on Saturday with spectators, trainers and riders in preparation for the Belmont Stakes, where American Pharoah completed for the Triple Crown.
lead_paragraph: Belmont Park began filling up early on Saturday with spectators, trainers and riders in preparation for the Belmont Stakes, where American Pharoah completed for the Triple Crown.

headline: Adjustments Ease Crowd at Racetrack
abstract: After last year’s unwieldy crowds, insufficient food supplies and long train delays, new preparations were well received by visitors to Belmont Park.
lead_paragraph: The blueprint demanded a revamped train station, intentionally depressed ticket sales and a pillar of pop-rock music, circa 1998.

headline: Ronnie Gilbert, Bold-Voiced Singer With the Weavers, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Ms. Gilbert, as a member of the Weavers, helped propel folk music to wide popularity and establish its power as an agent of social change.
lead_paragraph: Ronnie Gilbert, whose crystalline, bold contralto provided distaff ballast for the Weavers, the seminal quartet that helped propel folk music to wide popularity and establish its power as an agent of social change, died on Saturday in Mill Valley, Calif. She was 88.

headline: Kyrie Irving Is the Latest Casualty in a High-Stakes Game
abstract: A tide of 19-year-olds, their bodies already taxed by years of A.A.U. showcases, has been thrust into an 82-game professional schedule before they are fully developed.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The kid had all the moves and a clever dribble. He was lightning quick to the seams of the defense. You could see his cockiness and conviction in the way he carried himself against older boys with more developed bodies. Yes, that kid, Kyrie Irving, was going places.

headline: An Elusive Trophy, Gleaming Through the Smudges of Hands and Lips
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: For 37 long years, as the Triple Crown trophy waited for a permanent home, those handling it almost always did so wearing cotton gloves. “It shows fingerprints easily,” an executive said.
lead_paragraph: For 37 long years, as the sterling silver Triple Crown trophy waited for a permanent home, those handling it almost always did so wearing white cotton gloves.

headline: After Series of Setbacks, Spacecraft Prepares to Unfurl Sail
abstract: LightSail, a privately financed project, aims to demonstrate the use of sunlight for propulsion. The command to deploy the sail was sent on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A small experimental spacecraft that uses a shiny sail to reflect sunlight to propel itself came back to life Saturday afternoon after a series of near-death experiences. In a rush to finish the mission before anything else goes wrong, the team behind the craft prepared to deploy the sail on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Get New York Times WhatsApp Alerts on Pope’s Latin America Trip
abstract: Subscribe to our new account on WhatsApp to receive updates on the pope’s trip to Latin America and how the leader of the Roman Catholic Church is received.
lead_paragraph: Our Vatican correspondent, Jim Yardley, will be traveling with Pope Francis during his trip to Latin America in early July. He will be on the papal plane and will provide a behind-the-scenes look as Francis visits Ecuador, Bolivia and Paraguay.

headline: The Belmont, From Every Angle
abstract: A 360-degree view of American Pharoah winning the Belmont Stakes and the Triple Crown.
lead_paragraph: A 360-degree view of American Pharoah winning the Belmont Stakes and the Triple Crown.

headline: MERS Cases Rise in South Korea, Health Officials Say
abstract: The Health Ministry said 87 people had contracted Middle East respiratory syndrome, and six people had died from the disease.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The number of South Koreans infected with Middle East respiratory syndrome increased to 87 on Monday after the government identified additional cases. It also said Monday that an 80-year-old man had died, bringing the number of deaths linked to the virus in South Korea to six.

headline: Fan Expected to Survive Injury From Shattered Bat at Fenway
abstract: The woman was in serious condition at a hospital a day after being hit in the head during a game between the Red Sox and the Athletics.
lead_paragraph: A woman who was struck in the head by a broken bat at Fenway Park on Friday night was in serious condition Saturday at a hospital in Boston, her family said in a statement.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 7, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “If you run a campaign trying to appeal to 60 to 70 percent of the electorate, you’re not going to run a very compelling campaign for the voters you need.”

headline: Korean Robot Makers Walk Off With $2 Million Prize
abstract: The robots were graded on their ability to complete eight tasks, including driving a vehicle, opening a door and operating a portable drill.
lead_paragraph: POMONA, Calif. — A team of roboticists from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology claimed a $2 million prize on Saturday that was offered by a Pentagon research agency for developing a mobile robot capable of operating in hazardous environments.

headline: Frustration Turns to Elation for Victor Espinoza
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: Espinoza had been thwarted twice in Triple Crown attempts at Belmont before riding American Pharoah to victory on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Before Victor Espinoza hopped aboard American Pharoah, carrying saddlebags full of his previous disappointment, and attempted to run toward history, he tried to lose himself in his routine.

headline: Lightning Pull Even With Blackhawks in Back-and-Forth Game
abstract: Tampa Bay and Chicago traded leads in Game 2, but the Lightning stood their ground and responded to a series-opening loss with an electric victory.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Tampa Bay Lightning’s lack of experience had already been baked into the Stanley Cup finals, a ready-made reason for them to acquit themselves well but ultimately lose to the Chicago Blackhawks.

headline: Angels’ Starter Is Out Early, and the Yankees Cruise
abstract: Garrett Richards was relieved before the first inning was over after the Yankees scored six runs off him, and they went on to win their fifth in a row.
lead_paragraph: As Los Angeles Angels Manager Mike Scioscia made a premature stroll out to the mound Saturday night, Garrett Richards could not look. He kept his neck craned and stared toward the video board in center field, where some ghastly first-inning numbers were being displayed for all to see: six runs and five hits allowed, and only two outs.

lead_paragraph: Catch up on the week’s top stories.

headline: New York Prison Escape Stirs Painful Memories for Victim’s Father
abstract: David Sweat, one of the inmates who escaped from a New York prison, was convicted of shooting and killing a Broome County, N.Y., deputy sheriff in 2002.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Tarsia is still haunted by the death of his son, Deputy Sheriff Kevin Tarsia, at the hands of David Sweat, one of two convicted murderers who fled into a rural expanse of northern New York after staging an elaborate escape from a prison that was discovered on Saturday.

headline: With Power Tools and a Ruse, 2 Killers Flee New York Prison
abstract: The state is offering a $100,000 reward for information leading to the capture of the inmates, or $50,000 for tips leading to each one.

headline: Mets’ Dillon Gee Unhappy With Move Back to the Bullpen
abstract: Manager Terry Collins, who is abandoning the strategy of a six-man rotation, apologized to Gee before the Mets’ loss to the Diamondbacks.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When Dillon Gee arrived at Chase Field on Saturday, Mets Manager Terry Collins summoned him to his office to apologize. Gee was not entirely sure why. The apology could have been for the frequent trade rumors, or the shifting of Gee between the bullpen and the rotation, or the general sense from the Mets that he was unwanted.

headline: Affirmed’s Owner and Jockey Share in a Celebration, 37 Years After Their Own
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: Patrice Wolfson and Steve Cauthen, whose Triple Crown feat went unmatched for decades, expressed admiration for American Pharoah and his team.
lead_paragraph: In the crazy euphoria of a historic racing moment, Patrice Wolfson stood in her box at Belmont Park on Saturday evening, soaking up the emotion and, like the rest of us, trying to digest what had just happened: American Pharoah, dominating almost from the start, had become the first horse in 37 years to win the Triple Crown.

headline: 1915: Turks’ Resistance in Gallipoli Slowly Waning
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: Turks’ resistance In Gallipoli Is slowly waning
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A telegram from Athens says that the general attack begun on Friday in the Gallipoli Peninsula is making splendid progress. The resistance of the Turks is visibly weakening on account of their enormous losses. The Allies, adds the despatch [sic], have occupied three rows of trenches where dead and wounded Turks are heaped together in masses.

headline: What’s Your Teenager Doing This Summer? In Defense of ‘Nothing’
abstract: Isn’t this summer the perfect time for your teen to kick around doing nothing? If not now, when?
lead_paragraph: Another school year has come to an end. And here’s what summertime looks like for America’s “luckiest” teenagers: a full-time internship, learn-to-code camp or college classes (to show you can do college work before you apply to college), plus an SAT prep class and a college-essay-writing intensive, plus, as summer draws to a close, sports camp or music lessons in prep for the fall competitions. Or maybe all of the above.

headline: Remittances at the Click of a Smartphone Button
abstract: Tech start-ups and traditional telecom operators are taking advantage of the rapid rise of smartphones in many emerging economies to reduce the barriers — and costs — of sending cash overseas.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Stellah Vardling was getting ready recently for her birthday party, she did what many 22-year-olds would have done. She asked her family for money to help pay for the party.

headline: Deutsche Bank Co-Chief Executives Resign
abstract: Anshu Jain and Jürgen Fitschen will be replaced by John Cryan, former chief financial officer of the Swiss bank UBS, Deutsche Bank said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Even as other European banks reduced their presence on Wall Street in the face of new regulations and legal challenges, Deutsche Bank has been the exception.

headline: Over Beer, Obama and Merkel Mend Ties and Double Down on Russia
abstract: Though President Obama enjoys an unusually close rapport with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, their bond has been tested by a complicated intelligence relationship.
lead_paragraph: KRÜN, Germany — President Obama sought to smooth over tensions with a crucial ally, bonding on Sunday with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany over beer, sausages and their shared determination to confront Russia over its aggression in Ukraine, as he declared her a “great friend and partner” during a summit meeting of world leaders.

headline: Erdogan’s Governing Party in Turkey Loses Parliamentary Majority
abstract: The election results represented a significant setback to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, an Islamist who has steadily increased his power.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkish voters delivered a rebuke on Sunday to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan as his party lost its majority in Parliament in a historic election that thwarted his ambition to rewrite Turkey’s Constitution and further bolster his clout.

headline: A Triumph of Racing, and Broadcasting, That Was Worth the Wait
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Television', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: NBC’s prerace broadcast seemed long, but in the end, the network’s Belmont Stakes coverage was worthy of a Triple Crown victory.
lead_paragraph: The prerace programming for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday on NBC lasted nearly two and a half hours. Despite the quality of the broadcast, it felt too long, but perhaps that was appropriate given the 37-year wait for a Triple Crown winner.

headline: A Muslim Lawyer Refuses to Choose Between a Career and a Head Scarf
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Zahra Cheema, a 25-year-old lawyer who started her own firm, said some employers are unwilling to put Muslims who wear religious garb in the public eye.
lead_paragraph: GARDEN CITY, N.Y. — The apprehension usually hits the night before a job interview or a big court case, as Zahra Cheema, a young lawyer, looks at the colorful head scarves and flowing abayas in her closet and silently wonders: “Should I try to make myself look less Muslim?”

headline: European Leaders Voice Frustration With Greece in Debt Crisis
abstract: One official, the head of the European Commission, said the Greek leader misled the country’s Parliament by not fully explaining the creditors’ proposals.
lead_paragraph: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany — World leaders on Sunday increased the pressure on Europe to resolve the crisis over Greek debt, hours after one of the chief European negotiators expressed exasperation with the way the Greek leader was handling the talks.

headline: ‘Spy’ and Melissa McCarthy Prove More Popular Than the Boys of ‘Entourage’
abstract: “Spy” took in $30 million between Friday and Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – In another gender-war weekend at the box office, the women of “Spy” humiliated the men of “Entourage.”

headline: French Open 2015: Stan Wawrinka Defeats Novak Djokovic for Title
abstract: Wawrinka’s four-set victory was his second in a Grand Slam event and denied Djokovic a career slam.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A memorable French Open men’s final full of long rallies and bold strokes had just ended, and Gustavo Kuerten appeared on the red clay to hand out the trophies.

headline: Notoriety and Scorn Shadow Clinton Prison
abstract: Nearly 90 percent of inmates at the Clinton Correctional Facility, a prison in the village of Dannemora, N.Y., have been convicted of violent crimes.
lead_paragraph: Clinton Correctional Facility, the state prison where two men serving murder sentences were discovered missing on Saturday morning, is a tough place to do hard time.

headline: Protections for Late Investors Can Inflate Start-Up Valuations
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Start-ups', 'Appraisals and Valuation (Property)']
abstract: Terms providing insurance against subsequent developments appeal to company founders because they provide new cash at the highest nominal valuation, reducing dilution if all goes well.
lead_paragraph: Warning: Some unicorns may be smaller than they appear.

headline: State Bills Tackle Drive-Thrus, Pop Tarts and Horse Tripping
abstract: State legislatures are often called the country’s “laboratories of democracy,” but as the 2015 legislative season comes to an end, some bills have inspired more laughter than respect.
lead_paragraph: State legislatures are often called the country’s “laboratories of democracy,” but as the 2015 legislative season comes to an end, some bills have inspired more laughter than respect.

headline: States Confront Wide Budget Gaps Even After Years of Recovery
abstract: Only 25 states have passed budgets for the coming year, and many of the bitterest fights are not between the two parties, but between conservative and centrist Republicans.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In Illinois, fights over the state budget and its $3 billion shortfall have hit such an impasse that Gov. Bruce Rauner, a Republican, issued a dire warning last week that a “major, major restructuring of the government” was around the corner.

headline: A Beat Calls Puerto Ricans to Their African Roots
abstract: Jose Ortiz is on a mission to reconnect Puerto Ricans to their heritage by teaching them bomba, an Afro-Puerto Rican traditional musical form.
lead_paragraph: Jose Ortiz stood on the steps of the Andrew Freedman Home on the Grand Concourse, a gorgeous Bronx palazzo bathed in sunshine, his barrel drum by his side. Before him, on the lawn, a circle of people gathered, passing a calabash or sage leaves as they blessed one another. As the faint scent of gardenia and lavender wafted through the air, Mr. Ortiz straddled his drum and played.

headline: Seeing a Different Type of Clinton Campaign
abstract: So far, a “superdelegate” from Massachusetts said, the campaign seems to be resisting chasing states that are realistically out of reach but that appeal to the Clintons’ sense of history.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was waging a campaign for Democratic “superdelegates” — party officials who could choose to back whichever candidate they wanted, regardless of whether that person had won their state — Bill Clinton worked the phones aggressively on her behalf.

headline: Egypt: Life’s Sentence
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Hend Nafea was sentenced to life in prison for protesting against Egypt’s military government. In this piece — filmed a day after the sentencing — she maintains her innocence.
lead_paragraph: Hend Nafea was sentenced to life in prison for protesting against Egypt’s military government. In this piece — filmed a day after the sentencing — she maintains her innocence.

headline: Syria: Brides of Peace
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The sisters Kinda and Lubna Zaour walked through the main souk in Damascus dressed as brides, a symbol of love and peace. They were arrested almost immediately.
lead_paragraph: The sisters Kinda and Lubna Zaour walked through the main souk in Damascus dressed as brides, a symbol of love and peace. They were arrested almost immediately.

headline: Bahrain: Our Oath
abstract: Dr. Nada Dhaif helped create a medical tent to treat injured protesters in Bahrain’s Pearl Roundabout — and was sentenced to 15 years in jail.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Nada Dhaif helped create a medical tent to treat injured protesters in Bahrain’s Pearl Roundabout — and was sentenced to 15 years in jail.

headline: Yemen: When Is the Time?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: In this conservative country — dubbed the worst in the world for women — the revolution offered feminists like Belquis Al Lahabi a faint glimmer of hope.
lead_paragraph: In this conservative country — dubbed the worst in the world for women — the revolution offered feminists like Belquis Al Lahabi a faint glimmer of hope.

headline: Libya: Wake Up, Benghazi!
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: On June 25, 2014, Salwa Bugaighis was shot dead in her home by unknown militants, marking a new milestone in the country’s descent toward anarchy: the first female political assassination.
lead_paragraph: On June 25, 2014, Salwa Bugaighis was shot dead in her home by unknown militants, marking a new milestone in the country’s descent toward anarchy: the first female political assassination.

headline: ‘Stripped, Beaten, Humiliated’ and Barred From Her Own Trial in Egypt
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Sexual Harassment', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Hend Nafea and several others were dragged, beaten and stripped by Egyptian security forces at another demonstration against military rule in 2011.
lead_paragraph: During the early days of the revolution against President Hosni Mubarak, a sense of shared purpose and community made Tahrir Square feel like the safest place in Cairo, for women and men. But that collapsed almost the moment Mr. Mubarak left office, on Feb. 11, 2011. Sexual assault and the harassment of women in public, an epidemic problem in Egypt for decades, became alarmingly common again.

headline: The Brutal Silencing of a Woman at the Forefront of Libya’s Rebellion
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Women and Girls', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Scores or perhaps hundreds of killings remain unsolved in Benghazi, Libya. But no victim has symbolized the crushed hopes of the Libyan uprising more than Salwa Bugaighis.
lead_paragraph: Scores or perhaps hundreds of killings remain unsolved in Benghazi, Libya, since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi nearly four years ago. But no victim has symbolized the crushed hopes of the Libyan uprising more than Salwa Bugaighis.

headline: A Quickly Stifled Attempt to Ease Suffering in Bahrain
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The way the government of Bahrain would react to an uprising became clear when security forces rounded up health workers who treated injured protesters.
lead_paragraph: The roundup of health workers who treated injured protesters set the tone for the furious and uncompromising reaction by Bahrain’s government to a popular uprising in 2011.

headline: In Yemen, a Brief Moment Before Women Were Pushed Aside Again
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: When protesters succeeded in ousting President Ali Abdullah Saleh in 2012, it seemed especially promising for women. But that hope has unraveled.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When protesters in Yemen succeeded in ousting President Ali Abdullah Saleh in 2012, their success stirred hopes for change in a place that had suffered mightily from poverty and corruption for decades under his autocratic rule.

headline: Making Herself Heard, Before and After Tunisia’s Uprising
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Before the revolution, Ghazala Mhamdi led the fight for jobs, freedom and human rights, and suffered for it. But when democracy arrived, she ran for Parliament.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — In December 2010 a fruit-vendor in Tunisia, Mohamed Bouazizi, set himself alight in a protest against the police who stopped him from setting up his stall and earning a daily wage. His act of self-immolation — he died three weeks later — triggered a popular uprising around the country, where thousands of Tunisians seized on Mr. Bouazizi’s singular act and took to the streets to stand against state oppression and government corruption.

headline: Brides of Syria Were Joined in Opposition to Violence
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: In a perilous act of defiance, several women in white, dressed as brides, stood shoulder to shoulder in Damascus and declared, “We want to live.”
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The blurry pictures circulating on social media showed several women in white, dressed as brides, standing shoulder to shoulder in a covered market in the old city of Damascus. The banners they carried were ostensibly innocuous, calling for “the end of all military operations.”

headline: Tunisia: Keeping the Promise
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Even before the revolution, Ghazala Mhamdi was leading the fight for jobs, freedom and human rights; then the veteran activist ran for Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Even before the revolution, Ghazala Mhamdi was leading the fight for jobs, freedom and human rights; then the veteran activist ran for Parliament.

headline: Lindsey Graham and Scott Walker Stick to Domestic Issues on Sunday Shows
abstract: The large and growing field of Republican presidential candidates and potential candidates is largely in agreement on foreign policy, so the hopefuls are looking to domestic and social issues as a way to differentiate themselves.
lead_paragraph: The large and growing field of Republican presidential candidates is largely in agreement on foreign policy, so the hopefuls are looking to domestic and social issues as a way to differentiate themselves.

headline: Up for Auction: Lucian Freud’s Letters to a Poet
abstract: As a teenager, Lucian Freud wrote colorful, affectionate letters to the poet Stephen Spender.
lead_paragraph: Lucian Freud’s colorful, affectionate letters to the poet Stephen Spender, written when the painter was a teenager, will soon be up for auction at Sotheby’s in London.

headline: Tempers Are Hot, but So Are the Yankees
abstract: The Yankees won their sixth straight as starter C. C. Sabathia lasted six innings against the Angels before being ejected.
lead_paragraph: Before their 6-2 win over the Los Angeles Angels at Yankee Stadium on Sunday, Yankees players posed for pictures, many of them selfies, with season-ticket-holding fans.

headline: John Lennon’s ‘Love Me Do’ Guitar Found, and Is Up for Sale
abstract: The guitar that John Lennon used in “Love Me Do” has mysteriously ended up in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: John Lennon’s 1962 Gibson guitar is a blip in the history of the Beatles. He played it for early hits like “Love Me Do,”  but it disappeared in 1963 and was quickly replaced. End of story.

headline: G.E. Nears Deal on Major Step in Retreat From Banking
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The sale of a division that finances leveraged buyouts would be part of General Electric’s plan announced in April to refocus on its industrial roots.
lead_paragraph: General Electric is near a deal to sell the bulk of a division that finances leveraged buyouts to a major Canadian pension fund, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday, as the industrial giant seeks to shed most of its GE Capital finance arm.

headline: The Art of the Rolling Stones’ “Sticky Fingers”
abstract: With the rerelease of the 1971 album, the designer Craig Braun is eager to share the story of what VH1 called the best album cover ever and that tongue logo.
lead_paragraph: With the rerelease of the 1971 album, the designer Craig Braun is eager to share the story of what VH1 called the best album cover ever and that tongue logo.

headline: Amid the Mud and Straw, Workers on the Backstretch Savor a Special Day
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: At a distance from the crowd and the pageantry, the rarely seen horse people at Belmont Park gathered to watch the historic run of American Pharoah on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: At the distant edge of the horse-and-track village called Belmont Park, even the sparrows were excited. Their evening chatter all but shouted out the faint strains of “New York, New York,” wafting over the stables and barns and ramshackle dorms where the horse people exist.

headline: Review: ‘Charlie Parker’s Yardbird’ Uses Opera to Tell a Jazz Story
abstract: This chamber opera pulls off the feat of making Charlie Parker its subject without putting his music in the score.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Writing an opera about a famous person who lived a well-documented life is difficult enough. Writing an opera about a famous musician is even harder, especially a figure like the towering jazz saxophonist and composer Charlie Parker, a pioneer of bebop, an artist whose music still defines the art form and remains as astounding as ever. How can a composer make Parker the subject of an opera without putting Parker’s music into the score?

headline: Review: With Evolution, Dr. Lonnie Smith Channels an Old Wisdom
abstract: The organist performed at the Jazz Standard as part of a sextet that just finished recording an album called “Evolution.”
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lonnie Smith plays the Hammond organ and works more or less within the style and sound of East Coast and Rust Belt organ jazz from the 1960s and ’70s. That’s his professional biography, anyway. He started in Buffalo, moved to New York City and worked with George Benson, then began a half-century of swing and funk and blues, from his early records on Blue Note through his octet album of a few years ago, “In the Beginning.”

headline: MERS Outbreak in South Korea
abstract: As seen from the North.
lead_paragraph: As seen from the North.

headline: Review: ‘Book of Numbers,’ by Joshua Cohen, Is Narrative as Rich as the Web
abstract: Joshua Cohen’s new novel, about a struggling writer and a tech billionaire who share the same name, hums with the static of the cosmos.
lead_paragraph: Alive with talk and dense with data, Joshua Cohen’s novel “Book of Numbers” reads as if Philip Roth’s work were fired into David Foster Wallace’s inside the Hadron particle collider.

headline: Art of the Rolling Stones: Behind That Zipper and That Tongue
abstract: Craig Braun, who became known in the ’60s and ’70s as the go-to inventor of elaborate album covers, reflects on the design of “Sticky Fingers” and the Stones’ logo.
lead_paragraph: As the Rolling Stones prepared recently to rerelease “Sticky Fingers,” their classic 1971 album featuring hits like “Wild Horses” and “Brown Sugar,” the manufacturing process hit a snag: The functional zipper from Andy Warhol’s bulging blue jean album cover, recreated for some new deluxe editions, was taking longer than expected to produce, Universal Music announced, pushing back the release to Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘Settlement House,’ a Tribute to Henry Street’s 100-Year History
abstract: Will Rawls’s choreographic installation at the Abrons Arts Center marks the centennial of the Henry Street Settlement neighborhood playhouse.
lead_paragraph: It has been 100 years since the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side opened its neighborhood playhouse, a little theater that became a home to Martha Graham, John Cage and Alwin Nikolais. On Saturday, “Settlement House,” a choreographic installation organized by Will Rawls, celebrated the playhouse’s centennial by performing there and next door at the Abrons Arts Center. A program note introduced the guiding questions: “whether one can actually dance about architecture” and “whether and how architecture might be made to dance.”

headline: Review: In ‘Odd Mom Out,’ Competition Among Manhattan’s Wealthy
abstract: This new Bravo series centers on a stay-at-home mother in Manhattan who tries to navigate the totems and taboos of wealthier, snootier women.
lead_paragraph: After complaining about the commute between Southampton and Capri, a Park Avenue socialite asks Jill Weber (Jill Kargman) a question: “Where do you guys summer again?” Jill defiantly replies, “We summer on 61st between Second and Third.”

headline: Turkey’s Ruling Party Loses Parliamentary Majority
abstract: The election results were a significant setback for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: The election results were a significant setback for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

headline: Shaded Answers
abstract: Peter A. Collins takes us to the movies.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a different way to present the “common-word-goes-after-theme-entry” theme, and it is made easy with a revealer at 38 Across and the shaded or circled entries in the puzzle.

headline: Benefits Grow for Public University Presidents, Survey Finds
abstract: A report by The Chronicle of Higher Education found that most leaders received housing and cars, and some got perks like personal trainers.
lead_paragraph: Even with college costs and student debt in the national spotlight, the pay packages — and especially the benefits — of public university presidents continue to grow. The median salary for public university presidents was $428,250 in the 2014 fiscal year, up about 7 percent from the previous year, according to an annual survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

headline: Publisher to Put Asterisk on ‘Primates of Park Avenue’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: After a report of errors in the book about New York’s elite, Simon & Schuster said it would note that license was taken for dramatic effect.
lead_paragraph: “Primates of Park Avenue,” a memoir on the secluded lives of Upper East Side wives, set off a rush of skeptical commentary over what appeared to be the outré rituals, like “wife bonuses,” of New York’s wealthy elite.

headline: Mets’ Bats Back Jacob deGrom in Win Over Diamondbacks
abstract: The often-punchless Mets hit four home runs, including two by Curtis Granderson, to help deGrom improve to 7-4.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Curtis Granderson hurried around the bases and straight for the dugout, his head down, as if he were worried the umpire would call his home run back. His manager, Terry Collins, greeted him with a firm and grateful handshake, and Granderson plopped down on the bench and let out a sigh.

headline: At CatCon, Breaking a Stereotype in Ears and Whiskers
abstract: The first CatCon, billed as a celebration of the stylish side of cat fancying, drew more than 10,000 people to a convention hall in downtown Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They arrived wearing whiskers and ears. They purred over new litter fragrances, and pawed through the cat clothes. Hissing? Well, the line was long for that keynote speech: “Photographing Cats — It Looks Easy, but It’s Not.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 8
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: After Silences and Setbacks, the LightSail Spacecraft Is Revived, Deploying Its Solar Sail
abstract: Twice since the LightSail spacecraft was launched last month, it fell into an unexpected silence. On Sunday, it finally did what it was designed to do.
lead_paragraph: After malfunctions, silences and other unexpected twists, a small experimental spacecraft testing the possibility of harnessing sunlight for propulsion finally did what it was designed to do on Sunday: It unfurled a large, shiny sheet of Mylar.

headline: Discovery of Missing Prints Fails to Save Boston Library Leader’s Job
abstract: Last week, Amy Ryan announced her resignation, effective July 3, after a two-month kerfuffle over reports that valuable items belonging to the library were missing.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — If the word “vindicated” had a picture in the dictionary, it might be the face of Amy Ryan.

headline: Sepp Blatter, FIFA’s Fallen Chief, Is Held Up as Hero at Home
abstract: The head of the world soccer federation is highly regarded in his small Swiss hometown, where he has kept close ties and attracted international stars.
lead_paragraph: VISP, Switzerland — His reputation may be deeply tarnished in the world of soccer, and beyond. A widening swirl of corruption allegations points to deep rot in the organization he has run. And after 17 years atop one of sports’ most powerful groups, his downfall was a shattering crash heard the globe over.

headline: A Map for Tiger Woods: Jack Nicklaus’s Late Career
abstract: As Nicklaus knows, professional golf does not become easier with age, and he suggested that Woods needed to tinker with his game on his own to remain at a high level.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — The 39-year-old legend could not win a golf tournament for trying, giving rise to amateur diagnoses that the infirmities in his game were incurable. On Sunday, Jack Nicklaus remembered that 1979 season, the first winless year of his Hall of Fame career.

headline: Bronx Cocktail
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poem about the sights, sounds and smells of early spring: magnolia petals, baby birds, mulch and more.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The 2015 Tony Awards
abstract: The 69th annual Tony Awards on Sunday night turned out the biggest stars of Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The 69th annual Tony Awards on Sunday night turned out the biggest stars of Broadway.

headline: HackerOne Connects Hackers With Companies, and Hopes for a Win-Win
abstract: HackerOne’s co-founders are betting they can persuade the world’s hackers to spend their free time solving security’s problems, not causing them, and that businesses will pay them a bounty for their service.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2011, two Dutch hackers in their early 20s made a target list of 100 high-tech companies they would try to hack. Soon, they had found security vulnerabilities in Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft, Twitter and 95 other companies’ systems.

headline: Passing Up Event at Home, David Lingmerth Wins the Memorial
abstract: Lingmerth earned his first PGA Tour win after opting not to participate in a European Tour event in his native Sweden.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — David Lingmerth reluctantly passed on the European Tour stop in his native Sweden this year, as he had the previous two. While his compatriot Alex Noren won by four strokes Sunday at PGA Sweden National, Lingmerth was more than 4,000 miles away, locking horns with the 2013 United States Open champion, Justin Rose, in the Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

headline: Monsanto Renews Its Pursuit of Syngenta, With $2 Billion Fee
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Defoliants and Herbicides']
abstract: Without raising its bid, Monsanto renewed that bid by saying it would pay Syngenta $2 billion if Monsanto were not able to get regulatory clearance.
lead_paragraph: Monsanto on Sunday made a new attempt to acquire Syngenta, the Swiss agricultural chemical manufacturer. But rather than increase the price it is willing to pay, Monsanto instead offered to pay Syngenta $2 billion if Monsanto cannot obtain the regulatory approvals necessary to complete the deal.

headline: Ex-Official Says Chris Christie Broke Grand Jury Law
abstract: The statement by David Wildstein, which says that Mr. Christie illegally revealed grand jury information, offers the first insider confirmation of a tale of New Jersey political corruption.
lead_paragraph: The players at the center of the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal are not finished causing headaches for Gov. Chris Christie.

headline: Russia Uses Money and Ideology to Fight Western Sanctions
abstract: Moscow is leveraging its economic power, financing European political parties and movements, and spreading alternative accounts of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The war in Ukraine that has pitted Russia against the West is being waged not just with tanks, artillery and troops. Increasingly, Moscow has brought to bear different kinds of weapons, according to American and European officials: money, ideology and disinformation.

headline: Lightning Owner Wants to Build to Last, in Tampa and on Ice
abstract: In five years, Jeff Vinik has turned the Tampa Bay Lightning around, but he is continuing to push with plans to develop the area round the team’s arena.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — As a money manager, Jeff Vinik made hundreds of millions of dollars by taking big bets on undervalued assets. But when he turned 50, he wanted to do something else. He did not play golf and could visit only so many museums.

headline: Wide Net Cast for Escaped Killers; They Could Be ‘Anywhere’
abstract: When two men escaped from Clinton Correctional Facility, high in the Adirondacks, they emerged into a world in which some of the best tracking targets available — cellphones, cars and credit cards — may not apply.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — The plot was more “Shawshank Redemption” than “CSI”: two hardened inmates using power tools, handmade decoys and their hands to chisel and crawl their way out of a maximum-security prison in a subterranean escape.

headline: New York City Ballet Announces Promotions in Dancer Ranks
abstract: Lauren Lovette and Anthony Huxley were named principal dancers with the company, and Ashly Isaacs was promoted to soloist.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet has a new pair of principal dancers: Lauren Lovette and Anthony Huxley, who had been soloists with the company, were promoted on Sunday afternoon by Peter Martins, its ballet master in chief.

headline: A Convicted Murderer’s Escape Alarms Investigators From His Past
abstract: For the authorities who investigated Richard W. Matt, who was convicted of a 1997 murder, news of his escape from a New York prison recalled a grim history.
lead_paragraph: NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y. — The disappearance of the businessman was initially handled as a missing person case. Then a detective noticed specks of blood near a cellar door and a fisherman found a human torso in the Niagara River.

headline: Obama Administration Criticizes Egypt in Report to Congress
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Egypt is moving away from democracy, stifling freedom of expression and failing to hold the security forces accountable for “arbitrary or unlawful killings,” the administration said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt is moving away from democracy, stifling freedom of expression, arresting thousands for political dissent and failing to hold the security forces accountable for “arbitrary or unlawful killings,” the Obama administration has determined in a formal report to Congress.

headline: At Center of FIFA Scandal, a Divisive Politician in Jack Warner
abstract: Warner, a former FIFA official who is accused of racketeering, is a polarizing populist in Trinidad and Tobago whose life has come to resemble Shakespearean theater.
lead_paragraph: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago — The prime minister of this Caribbean republic walked out of a session of Parliament on Friday, angrily chastising a fellow politician and former ally, Jack Warner, who finds himself and his two sons at the center of soccer’s widespread corruption scandal.

headline: ‘Straight Outta Compton’ Film Plays a Role in Suge Knight Murder Case
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Movies', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Music']
abstract: A video attached to a trailer for the film is a focal point in a murder and attempted murder case against the music entrepreneur.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In an editing room here, filmmakers are wrestling with a final cut of “Straight Outta Compton,” Universal Pictures’ new movie about the outlaw rap group N.W.A.

headline: Review: ‘Card and Gift,’ Set in a Seldom-Patronized Shop
abstract: Kate E. Ryan’s play at the Wild Project revolves around three women at a store in a New Hampshire town that has seen better days.
lead_paragraph: Small-town blues were once a dominant melody line in American drama. Their sound was probably most pervasive during the mid-20th-century, when the tear-splotched plays of William Inge ruled Broadway.

headline: After American Pharoah’s Runaway, Pondering Whether to Quit While Ahead
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: American Pharoah’s owner, Ahmed Zayat, said he and the trainer Bob Baffert “owe it to the sport” to keep racing the sport’s new ambassador.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows there is no cheering in the press box, and crying is frowned upon as well. Both rules were violated as American Pharoah thundered down the stretch and into the record books, setting off a cathartic celebration at Belmont Park and beyond among those who appreciate racehorses.

headline: De Blasio Prods New York State on Housing Laws
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: With a deadline looming, the mayor called on lawmakers to approve two of his housing initiatives: strengthening rent regulations and revising a program that gives tax breaks for creating affordable units.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio went to church on Sunday to talk about housing.

headline: High Hopes for John Cryan, Deutsche Bank’s New Chief, Known for His Pragmatism
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Mr. Cryan is smart, clinical and, perhaps most important, knows how to make big banks swallow bitter pills.
lead_paragraph: John Cryan, a former finance chief at UBS who Deutsche Bank said on Sunday would become the bank’s new chief executive, brings many qualities to the table, colleagues say.

headline: Community Remembers Reporter Shot in Washington
abstract: Charnice Milton, a journalist, was killed in May when gunman on dirt bikes used her as a human shield.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Charnice Milton was a little girl, she used the newspaper to overcome a speech impediment. Her mother, Francine Milton, encouraged her to strengthen her voice by reading the articles out loud.

headline: Obama’s Slap in Britain’s Face
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Shaker Aamer, a British resident held at Guantánamo since 2002, has been cleared for release. Why won’t the U.S. act?
lead_paragraph: London — Two weeks ago, we went to Washington to argue for the immediate release of Shaker Aamer, a detainee at Guantánamo Bay. Mr. Aamer’s wife and four children live in London but he has yet to meet his youngest child, Faris, who is now 13.

headline: Apple’s Conference, G.M.’s Annual Meeting, and a Trade Vote in Europe
abstract: This week’s business news will include Apple’s conference for software developers, G.M.’s annual meeting with investors, and the European Parliament’s vote on the plans for a landmark trade deal.
lead_paragraph: Apple is set to kick off its annual conference for software developers on Monday. The company is expected to show new and improved versions of OS X, its Mac operating system, and iOS, the mobile software system powering iPhones and iPads. The company will also introduce a new streaming music service that it developed with Beats Electronics, the company it acquired last year for $3 billion. Absent from the unveilings will be a long-anticipated upgrade for the Apple TV set-top box, which was pulled from the conference because of issues related to content and technology. —Brian X. Chen

headline: Henry Carr, Olympic Sprinter and a Football Giant, Dies at 73

lead_paragraph: Unlike the made-for-television drafts in the N.B.A. and the N.F.L., there is still some mystery that surrounds Major League Baseball’s draft despite this being the 50th anniversary of the event. So when Rob Manfred, M.L.B.’s commissioner, walks to the dais Monday night to announce who the Arizona Diamondbacks have taken with the No. 1 pick, the selection will be a surprise to nearly everyone other than Manfred, the team and the player selected.

headline: As if Karlie Kloss Could Be Any More Likable

headline: The Many Pals of Peaches
abstract: A new book of photos by the musician’s longtime tour photographer Holger Talinski features the artist with Drew Barrymore, PJ Harvey, Yoko Ono and many more.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, the performance artist and musician Merrill Nisker, better known as Peaches, has sought to upend gender norms, smash stereotypes and tackle taboos. In her new book, “What Else Is in the Teaches of Peaches” ($28, Akashic), the Berlin-based, Canada-born provocateur has teamed up with her longtime tour photographer Holger Talinski to look back at a brazen career that has captured the attention of outsider artists and massive pop stars alike, ranging from Michael Stipe to PJ Harvey to Iggy Pop. “Holger shows the exhaustion, the work, the relaxation, the elation, the parties, the quiet moments and the family visits,” writes Peaches in the foreword. “It is amazing for me to look back at these photos and understand how much I have packed into these years.”

headline: Critic’s Notebook: The Tonys Show Celebrates the Stage Without Any Real Theater
abstract: No one said or did anything excessively moving or embarrassing, if you don’t count the person who picked the lavender shorts suit Alan Cumming wore in the show’s opening.
lead_paragraph: In a season when Broadway drew bigger audiences and more dollars than ever, the Tony Awards broadcast on CBS on Sunday night resembled many an expensive musical: a big, bland, well-tooled entertainment machine. No one said or did anything excessively moving or embarrassing, if you don’t count the person who picked the lavender shorts suit Alan Cumming wore in the show’s opening. Pity the people who have to find moments suitable for YouTube clips on Monday morning.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:10 P.M. (HBO2) THOUGHT CRIMES: THE CASE OF THE CANNIBAL COP (2015) This documentary, directed by Erin Lee Carr, follows Gilberto Valle, left, the New York City “cannibal cop” who was convicted of conspiring to kidnap, torture, kill and eat women. The film questions whether someone can be found guilty of what Mr. Valle’s lawyer called “thought prosecution,” that is, thoughts without actions. “The film, though, is no knee-jerk defense of Mr. Valle’s right to talk about trussing up women like livestock and making centerpieces out of their heads,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “Ms. Carr (whose father was David Carr, the media columnist for The New York Times, who died in February) sprinkles the film with excerpts from Mr. Valle’s chats, which are appalling even if they are merely fantasies. She also gives voice to all sides in the debate over the implications of the case, not just the free-speech one.”

headline: Profit as an Incentive for Israeli-Palestinian Peace
abstract: A RAND Corporation report found that the Israeli and Palestinian economies would stand to gain $173 billion over the next decade if an independent Palestine emerged tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Supporters of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict generally start with a moral argument: Both peoples deserve the rights of self-determination and sovereignty; one should not rule over the other. Lately, President Obama and liberal American Jewish leaders also frame their case in security terms, saying Israel cannot survive as a Jewish democracy without ending its occupation of Palestinian territories.

headline: Tough-Talking El Bronco Wins Mexican Governor’s Race

Did the photo capture a historic moment or a turning point in the photographer’s life? Or was it simply about discovering new gear?

abstract: We say we dislike it, but we indulge in it. It’s time to stop.

If you chose the latter, I’m willing to wager it’s in part because of the destructive rhetoric that threatens to accompany the election. At least half of American adults felt that the last presidential campaign was too negative.

keywords: ['Editorials', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Attorneys General', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Vigilant oversight is needed to prevent drug companies from buying off competitors or forcing switches to newer drugs.
lead_paragraph: Two devious tactics by manufacturers of brand-name drugs to delay competition from cheaper generic drugs were appropriately slapped down recently by federal and state officials. That should help consumers, insurers and anyone else who foots the bill for prescription medicines. Generic copies, which can enter the market when patents on a brand-name drug expire, typically cost much less than branded versions and are just as safe and effective.

headline: G.O.P. Assault on Environmental Laws
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Clean Air Act', 'Clean Water Act', 'Water Pollution', 'Global Warming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Environment']
abstract: Despite the American landscape’s need for environmental protections, Republicans in Congress are determined to block clean air, water and ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has announced or will soon propose important protections for clean water, clean air, threatened species and threatened landscapes. Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, and other Republicans in Congress are trying hard not to let that happen — counterattacking with a legislative blitz not seen since Newt Gingrich and his “Contract With America” Republicans swept into office after the 1994 midterm elections bent on crippling many of the environmental statutes enacted under Presidents Johnson and Nixon. Bill Clinton threatened or used vetoes to block that assault. Mr. Obama should be prepared to do the same.

The waterfalls feed a narrow koi pond that runs the length of the living room and was scooped out in the shape of a scale replica of the Yangtze River in China.

headline: In Performance: Ruthie Ann Miles of ‘The King and I’
abstract: Ms. Miles, who won a Tony Award for her performance, sings “Something Wonderful” from “The King and I,” which also won the Tony for best musical revival.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features a song from Ruthie Ann Miles, who won the Tony Award on Sunday for best featured actress in a musical for her role as Lady Thiang in Lincoln Center Theater’s revival of “The King and I.” Here she sings the ballad “Something Wonderful” with Ted Sperling, the show’s music director, on piano. “The King and I,” which won the Tony for best musical revival, is at Lincoln Center’s Vivian Beaumont Theater.

headline: ‘The Sunken Cathedral,’ by Kate Walbert
abstract: Threats, real and imagined, loom in the lives of restive New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Kate Walbert’s new novel, her fourth, begins and ends amid high winds and storm surge, a lethal deluge that the book’s characters — post-9/11, post-Sandy New Yorkers — endure with nervous resignation. Walbert is in her element. She’s an anatomist of disaster, or, more precisely, of its psychic toll, of the myriad subtle ways calamities — natural, man-made, self-­inflicted — reverberate through lives and across generations. Her style is understated, elegiac, her perspective oblique. In her books, war and social crisis typically lurk just off the page; what she’s after is quieter, more elusive stuff: the collateral damage of haunted minds and thwarted ambition. Her characters, you might say, are afflicted by history.

headline: ‘The Architect’s Apprentice,’ by Elif Shafak
abstract: An elephant trainer becomes an apprentice to the Ottoman Empire’s chief architect.
lead_paragraph: If you happen to be born in an Indian village in the 16th century and end up on a ship sailing for the court of the Ottoman ruler Suleiman the Magnificent accompanied by a pet albino elephant named ­Chota, you had better be quick — on your feet and in your mind.

headline: ‘The Meursault Investigation,’ by Kamel Daoud
abstract: Kamel Daoud’s inventive novel looks at Albert Camus’s “The Stranger” with new eyes.
lead_paragraph: When I was 15, a shy and bookish sophomore at a high school in Morocco, my French class was assigned Albert Camus’s “The Stranger.” I remember being intrigued by the fact that the story was set in neighboring Algeria. I remember the novel’s indelible first line: “Mother died today.” I remember what an odd hero Meursault seemed to me, unabashed and remorseless, a man who shows no emotion at his mother’s funeral. And I still remember how distressing it was to come upon the crucial scene in which Meursault, walking on a beach under the midday sun, shoots a nameless Arab. Our class discussed Meursault, his mother, his fight with the priest, existentialism and the absurd. All the while, I had to quiet the voice inside me that kept asking, “But what about the Arab?”

headline: Fears, Not Facts, Support G.M.O.-Free Food
abstract: Despite much evidence that genetically modified organisms help make what we eat safer and healthier, more people are looking for food without them.
lead_paragraph: Despite myriad assurances from scientists that foods containing genetically modified ingredients are safe to eat, consumers are likely to see more and more products labeled “G.M.O.-free” in the not-too-distant future. As happened with the explosion of gluten-free products, food companies are quick to cash in on what they believe consumers want regardless of whether it is scientifically justified.

lead_paragraph: The reports in Chinese news outlets on Monday about an attack on a nurse in a hospital in the southwestern city of Kunming were brief and virtually identical, suggesting they were coordinated by the authorities — often a sign of a politically delicate issue. They described how on Sunday, around 12:30 p.m., a man stabbed the nurse at the First Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University, seriously wounding her.

headline: I Saw a Turtle, My Father Saw Food
abstract: To the man who was raised to hunt for his dinner, a visit from loggerhead wasn’t a nature sighting. What could I do?
lead_paragraph: The turtles didn’t stay on the beach that year. Maybe it had something to do with the stadium lights that lit up the nearby golf course so military officers could swing their clubs through the night. Or the big white domes that protected satellite dishes but looked like Epcot moons. We’d lived on MacDill Air Force Base near Tampa for a year, not far from the beach. I’d already seen two turtles who’d wandered from the surf — one in a sand trap and one by the side of the road. Then on one September day, I arrived home from school, and the loggerhead was there on the sidewalk leading to our mobile home, baking in the Florida sun.

headline: Morning Agenda: Shake-Up at Deutsche Bank
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Start-ups', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Shake-Up at Deutsche Bank | G.E. Close to Deal on Private Equity Financing Unit | Protections for Investors Inflate Valuations | Apollo in Talks to Buy Saint-Gobain Unit for $3.3 Billion
lead_paragraph: SHAKE-UP AT DEUTSCHE BANK | Now that Deutsche Bank’s co-chief executives, Anshu Jain and Jürgen Fitschen, have resigned, the company is likely to re-examine its status as the last European bank left standing on Wall Street,  Jack Ewing writes in DealBook. Mr. Jain, 52, will resign at the end of the month after three years as co-chief executive and will be replaced by John Cryan, 54, a former high-ranking executive of the Swiss bank UBS. Ayesha Farooq, Pakistan’s only combat-ready female air force pilot, has become both an international celebrity and a symbol of a new Pakistan, where women are breaking barriers and taking on roles traditionally closed to them. Yet Pakistan is also known as a country where women’s place in society yo-yos up and down. For example, in the 1990s it entrusted the leadership of the entire nation to Benazir Bhutto while still resisting girls’ education and advances in women’s rights.

headline: 1915: President’s Reply on Lusitania

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mr. Wilson’s new Note to Germany has been approved by the Cabinet and was to have been despatched to Berlin today [June 5]. It is understood that the communication is vigorous in tone and that it denies the allegations contained in Germany’s last Note that the Lusitania was armed or carrying explosives. According to the Daily Telegraph’s New York correspondent, it is hardly expected that Berlin will answer the new Note until Count Bernstorff’s envoy reaches Germany, so there is a prospect of two or three weeks elapsing before a reply is received.

headline: ‘The Story of Alice: Lewis Carroll and the Secret History of Wonderland’
abstract: A look at three very different lives: Lewis Carroll’s, Alice Liddell’s and that of the literary creation they both had a part in.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Carroll loved puns, like those about the tortoise who taught us, or the lessons that lessen the need for any more of them. He especially loved puns that could be found hiding in one word, like wonderland: a place full of wonders and a place where you wonder what is happening to you. These meanings are not only different, they can be read as opposites, as Robert ­Douglas-Fairhurst reminds us, quoting a Victorian evocation of a person “who, being in a chronic state of wonder, is surprised at nothing.” Sentimental memories of the Alice books often stress the first, dazzled meaning, but a fresh reading of Carroll is likely to leave us much closer to the second, which Douglas-Fairhurst neatly formulates as “being puzzled at what we do not know.” This is how the flowers talk in “Through the Looking-Glass”: “I wonder how you do it,” a rose says to ­Alice, referring to her odd human ability to move about. “You’re always wondering,” an irritated tiger-lily says.

But it seemed certain to most observers that U.S. troops were being fully committed to a direct ground war campaign against the Viet Cong. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 9, 1965

headline: 1915: Secretary of State Resigns
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Secretary of State William Jennings Bryan resigns in 1915.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Mr. William Jennings Bryan has resigned as Secretary of State. Friends asserted that the statesman from Nebraska felt that he, because of his influence in obtaining the Presidential nomination for Mr. Wilson, should have the leading voice in the Cabinet.

headline: Roger Vergé, a Founder of Nouvelle Cuisine, Dies at 85
abstract: His adaptation of Provençal cooking incorporated the flavors of Africa and the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Roger Vergé, a founding father of nouvelle cuisine who developed a highly influential version of Provençal cooking, which he called “the cuisine of the sun,” at his renowned restaurant Le Moulin de Mougins near Cannes, France, died on Friday at his home in Mougins. He was 85.

headline: When the Influence of a Patient’s Former Doctor Lingers
abstract: In a field with no one right answer, a doctor must deal with patients’ wanting a course of action that the doctor finds perplexing, if not wrong.
lead_paragraph: When is my patient not my patient? When he is Kevin, for one. I have cared for Kevin in both senses of the word for years now, but he still has his previous provider’s fingerprints all over him: he takes medications I never use and has health-maintainance routines I find somewhat perplexing.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Issue Falls Along Party Lines
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A new survey offers a snapshot of where Republicans and Democrats stand on same-sex marriage, an issue that will likely be injected into the 2016 presidential race as soon as the Supreme Court makes its ruling later this month.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is getting closer to making is long-awaited ruling on same-sex marriage and, whatever the outcome, the political response is expected to be vocal along party lines.

headline: A Second ‘Wolf Hall’ Soundtrack Album Is Coming
abstract: “Wolf Hall: The Tudor Music” includes some of the period music used in the television series.
lead_paragraph: “Wolf Hall” mania continues. Hilary Mantel’s award-winning novels about Thomas Cromwell, the blacksmith’s son who became Henry VIII’s most trusted adviser, have already spawned a two-part adaptation by the Royal Shakespeare Company that is currently on Broadway and a six-episode series that was shown this spring on PBS’s “Masterpiece.”

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Empire Expands to Include Coloring Book
abstract: The “Game of Thrones Coloring Book,” set to come out this fall from Bantam, will feature 45 original black-and-white illustrations from multiple artists.
lead_paragraph: Sharpen your Valyrian steel … pencils.

headline: Apple Music Is Unveiled, Along With Operating System Upgrades
abstract: The new streaming service, which will cost $10 a month, will compete with Spotify and be offered alongside an overhauled iTunes Radio.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s iTunes has grown stale. It is difficult to use and feels dated when compared with online music services like Spotify and Pandora. Pick your critique, and Apple has heard it.

headline: The Research and Development Lab Talks ‘Delta’
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: The New York Times Research and Development group looks beyond the next product cycle, identifying trends and technologies that will emerge in the next three to five years. Michael Dewar shares some of the thinking behind one recently built tool, called Delta, which is a visualization of NYTimes.com site traffic.
lead_paragraph: Delta is a visualization program built by Nik Hanselmann, a creative technologist in The Times’s Research and Development Lab. But what exactly does a visualization program like Delta do? Michael Dewar, who also works in the lab, explains.

headline: Where to Go in La Brea, Los Angeles
abstract: The L.A. neighborhood has more than a dozen trendy new restaurants and boutiques selling home goods and fashions from up-and-coming designers.
lead_paragraph: The L.A. neighborhood has more than a dozen trendy new restaurants and boutiques selling home goods and fashions from up-and-coming designers.
