abstract: Looks from the collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the collection.

headline: Peering Into a Black Hole
abstract: This is the story of the Event Horizon Telescope, a synchronized network of radio antennas as large as the Earth, that astronomers used to take the first ever picture of a black hole, an abyss so deep no light can escape.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of the Event Horizon Telescope, a synchronized network of radio antennas as large as the Earth, that astronomers used to take the first ever picture of a black hole, an abyss so deep no light can escape.

headline: Celebrating Hotel Il Pellicano’s 50th
abstract: Hollywood royalty and fashion-world darlings flew in to Italy to commemorate the property’s birthday.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood royalty and fashion-world darlings flew in to Italy to commemorate the property’s birthday.

headline: Nicola Sturgeon, Star of Scottish Politics, Vows to Secure More Power
abstract: Ms. Sturgeon, whose hatred of Margaret Thatcher’s politics first inspired her to run for office, said she would press Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain for more autonomy.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s feminist first minister, was inspired to run for office by Margaret Thatcher — not because Mrs. Thatcher was Britain’s first female prime minister, but because Ms. Sturgeon hated her politics and the unemployment her policies brought to Scotland.

headline: Black Hole Hunters
keywords: ['Black Holes (Space)', 'Sagittarius A*', 'Event Horizon Telescope', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Quasars', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Milky Way Galaxy']
abstract: Aiming to make the first portrait of the hungry monster at the center of our galaxy, astronomers built “a telescope as big as the world.”
lead_paragraph: PICO DE ORIZABA NATIONAL PARK, Mexico — Sheperd Doeleman’s project to take the first-ever picture of a black hole wasn’t going well.

headline: ‘The Visit’ Will Close on Sunday
abstract: The musical, a Fred Ebb and John Kander collaboration starring Chita Rivera, was a passion project for its producers.
lead_paragraph: “The Visit,” a haunting musical starring Chita Rivera, will close on Sunday after failing to win any Tony Awards.

headline: Balenciaga Resort 2015
abstract: Looks from the collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the collection.

headline: Santiago Calatrava Shares His Influences
abstract: The Spanish architect who designed the World Trade Center transit hub tells T about the spaces, artists, meals and more that inspire him.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish architect who designed the World Trade Center transit hub tells T about the spaces, artists, meals and more that inspire him.

headline: Arrests and Riot Gear After Scuffles at Summer Jam
keywords: ['Music', 'Summer Jam (Music Festival)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: Some attendees tried to force their way inside by climbing fences, the police said. Most of those arrested were charged with disorderly conduct.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A total of 61 people were arrested on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium during Hot 97’s Summer Jam, the annual hip-hop concert presented by WQHT-FM, the New Jersey State Police said on Monday. Ten officers sustained minor injuries during scuffles at an entrance gate as some attendees tried to force their way inside by climbing fences or pushing past security, the police said.

headline: Most Parents Got Top Choices for Pre-K, Mayor de Blasio Says
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that parents of about 57,000 children were offered places at one of their top three selections for the fall.
lead_paragraph: In a hopeful sign for the second year of his prekindergarten push, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday that parents of about 57,000 children in New York City were offered seats in one of their top three choices for programs in the fall.

headline: The Institute of Culinary Education Gets a New, Bigger Home
abstract: The culinary school more than doubles in size, the release of a sauvignon blanc, a new automatic coffee brewer, St. Anthony’s festival, and more.
lead_paragraph: To Study: Culinary School Moves To Battery Park City

headline: Activists for Change: Six Short Films and Teaching Resources on Women’s Roles in the Arab Spring
abstract: A six-part video series about the role of women in the Arab Spring, and free teaching resources for using them in the classroom. Does your organization, school, church, club or youth program teach with The Times? Let us know.
lead_paragraph: When students see news about war and unrest in the Middle East and North Africa, they typically see images of men. But when the Arab Spring revolutions began to sweep across the region in 2011, women were very much on the front lines — protesting, leading and even dying. What are their stories?

headline: The Grocery to Serve Its Final Meal
abstract: The modest restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, which earned stellar food ratings in the Zagat Survey, will close late this month.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Pachter and Charles Kiely, the owners of the Grocery in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, have announced that they will close the restaurant once the tables are cleared on June 27.

headline: Dov Charney and American Apparel Tussle Over Lawyers’ Fees
abstract: Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, may be able to compel the company to pay his legal fees, even though the firm is suing him.
lead_paragraph: The nasty fight between Dov Charney and the company he founded, American Apparel, over his firing in 2014 has been an endless source of fascination for many months.

headline: Families of Nepalese Killed in Marine Helicopter Crash Ask for Compensation
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Helicopters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Earthquakes', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: The civilians were among 13 people killed when the helicopter went down during an American relief mission sent to Nepal after an earthquake in May.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Relatives of some of the five Nepalese civilians killed in a Marine helicopter crash expressed anger Sunday at what they said was the slow pace of the investigation into the deaths, and demanded compensation from the governments of Nepal and the United States.

headline: Surveillance Video of Boston Shooting
abstract: Close-circuit video of last week’s fatal shooting of a terror suspect, Usaamah Rahim, by a Boston police officer and an F.B.I. agent was released during a press conference today.
lead_paragraph: Close-circuit video of last week’s fatal shooting of a terror suspect, Usaamah Rahim, by a Boston police officer and an F.B.I. agent was released during a press conference today.

headline: Review: In ‘Muse,’ the Publisher Jonathan Galassi Writes What He Knows
abstract: Mr. Galassi, president of Farrar, Straus and Giroux, draws on his longtime experience to give readers a portrait of the literary world.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Galassi’s keenly observed debut novel, “Muse,” is a carefully constructed literary echo chamber, haunted by the ghosts of two classics and peopled with some thinly veiled portraits of well-known publishing figures. As in Philip Roth’s “The Ghost Writer,” a young man with literary aspirations — in this case, an editor instead of a writer — finds himself torn between two rival father figures. As in Henry James’s “The Aspern Papers,” an editor obsessed with a famous poet goes to Venice in search of some answers about the poet and the poet’s lover and has a surprising encounter that will affect both his career and his apprehension of himself.

headline: Review: Only Suspense at Summer Jam Was Outside the Stadium
abstract: This annual summer concert was hampered by a modest lineup onstage and a face-off between police and concertgoers outside MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It seems that every year of late, the annual Summer Jam presented by the radio station Hot 97 has to find new purpose. In the 1990s and into the mid-2000s, it was the New York hip-hop concert of record. Now it is a showcase for the genre’s scattered regional identities and Hot 97’s decreasingly steady footing as an arbiter of its future. Summer Jam was once the essential proving ground; now it’s a hit-or-miss revue.

abstract: Looks from the collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the collection.

headline: With Chairmanship, McCain Seizes Chance to Reshape Pentagon Agenda
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As head of the Armed Services Committee, Senator John McCain is trying to control military expenses, while enabling priorities like more aid for Ukrainian defenses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John McCain has had many dreams.

headline: Alexander Melamid Begins Artenol, an Art Magazine
abstract: An artist known for his stunts professes despair over the state of art criticism and introduces a publication that strives for clarity and subversion.
lead_paragraph: As the artist-provocateur Alexander Melamid sees it, modern art is deathly ill, but he thinks he has the cure. It is Artenol, his new quarterly magazine, described on its website as “a purgative for an ailing art world, a palliative for afflicted aesthetes.”

headline: Pensions in Greece Feel the Pinch of Debt Negotiations
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Bonds', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Retirement']
abstract: As it confronts its creditors, the left-wing government in Athens faces few more daunting problems than how to meet the promises it has made to retirees.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Vasiliki Meliou did not want to retire at 53, but she had little choice, she said, after the state-owned bank she worked for was sold three years ago.

headline: Final Salvos Against Polio
keywords: ['Poliomyelitis', 'Movies', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Pashtun (Ethnic Group)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: The film “Every Last Child,” which opened in New York on Wednesday, documents vaccinators’ struggle for survival against the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Every Last Child” begins the way “Hill Street Blues” used to: A police commander says a few words to his men before they roll out into a hostile city. Their job is to protect polio teams going house to house in neighborhoods where Taliban assassins cruise on motorbikes.

headline: Square Unveils Mobile Wallet-Friendly Credit Card Reader
abstract: Square announced a new credit card reader that accepts mobile wallets like Apple Pay.
lead_paragraph: It will take years for smartphone-based wallets, like those offered by Apple and Google, to have a chance to truly catch on with mainstream consumers. But with the help of payments processors, mobile wallets may catch on a bit faster.

headline: Reaction to Slager’s Indictment
abstract: Prosecutor Scarlett Wilson, Rodney Scott and the Scott family’s lawyer spoke after Michael T. Slager, a former police officer in South Carolina, was indicted in the fatal shooting of Walter L. Scott.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutor Scarlett Wilson, Rodney Scott and the Scott family’s lawyer spoke after Michael T. Slager, a former police officer in South Carolina, was indicted in the fatal shooting of Walter L. Scott.

headline: Chris Christie Tries to Take On Hillary
abstract: Expanding early voting could increase voter fraud, he said, “and maybe that’s what Mrs. Clinton wants to do.”
lead_paragraph: Despite a homey backdrop — front porch, American flag, pots of red geraniums — New Jersey Governor Chris Christie sounded like a street fighter Sunday morning on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”  This time the notoriously aggressive governor was taking on every Republican’s favorite target — Hillary Clinton.  Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic frontrunner in the looming presidential primaries, had the nerve to blast Republicans like Mr. Christie for trying to keep people from voting in this country. As she put it pointedly: “What part of democracy are they afraid of?” (Note to Clinton camp: Are there bumper stickers yet?)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
abstract: Germany and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Germany and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: Photos from Germany, Ukraine, Turkey and New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Germany, Ukraine, Turkey and New York.

headline: With Backpacks and Exposed Skin, European Officials Roil Iranians
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Muslim Veiling', 'International Relations', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Members of the European Parliament’s foreign affairs committee set off a firestorm of criticism in Iran after they greeted officials in what was deemed inappropriate attire.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The woman wore form-fitting clothes and a scarf wrapped around her head that revealed a few of her blond tresses. The men carried backpacks to official meetings. Nothing all that unusual in most places, but enough to touch off a firestorm of criticism this weekend from Iranian lawmakers, who accused their visitors of flouting Islamic law by, as one put it, wearing “extremely weird clothing.”

headline: Former Soccer Player Sues Illinois, Saying Concussion Was Mishandled
abstract: Casey Conine, who seeks damages of at least $50,000, said the University of Illinois ignored its own protocol after she sustained a concussion in October.
lead_paragraph: A former women’s soccer player at Illinois has filed a lawsuit against the university, alleging that her concussion was mishandled and her career ruined after the team ignored protocol. The suit, filed Monday afternoon in Champaign County Circuit Court, seeks damages of at least $50,000, though the amount could be far greater.

headline: Six Elderly New Yorkers Provide Lessons on Aging: What One Reporter Learned
abstract: John Leland shares some of the insight he’s gathered from six months spent interviewing some of New York’s oldest residents.
lead_paragraph: Since the start of the year, I’ve been reporting on six New Yorkers over the age of 85, but the guiding voice in my head has often been that of a much younger man, Karl Pillemer, one of several gerontologists I interviewed at the start of the project. When Dr. Pillemer started in the field, he viewed old age the way many of us do, as a problem to be solved. People’s bodies broke down, their minds lost function, they drained billions out of the health care system. “I was busy rewriting the Book of Job,” he said. It made for grim work.

headline: N.Y. Police on Manhunt for Convicts
abstract: Maj. Charles Guess of the New York State Police said the hunt has intensified for two convicted murderers who escaped from a maximum security prison over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Charles Guess of the New York State Police said the hunt has intensified for two convicted murderers who escaped from a maximum security prison over the weekend.

headline: Turkey's Hung Parliament at a Glance
abstract: Voters denied an outright majority to the ruling party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. A multiparty coalition will need at least 276 votes in the 550-seat Parliament. Here are the four parties in contention.
lead_paragraph: Voters denied an outright majority to the ruling party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. A multiparty coalition will need at least 276 votes in the 550-seat Parliament. Here are the four parties in contention.

headline: Video Feature: The Apple Collector
abstract: Lonnie Mimms has been a collector all his life. But vintage computers are his real obsession, namely ones made by Apple. By his own estimate, he has invested more than a million dollars in his computer collection.
lead_paragraph: Lonnie Mimms has been a collector all his life. Even now, Mr. Mimms, 52, has a selection of hippopotamus figures displayed under track lighting in his bedroom. But vintage computers are his real obsession, namely ones made by Apple.

headline: Review: Antonio Sánchez With 2 Albums, ‘The Meridian Suite’ and ‘Three Times Three’
abstract: Mr. Sánchez, who wrote the score for the 2014 film “Birdman,” has a rangy, ambitious record that joins a double album released this spring.
lead_paragraph: ANTONIO SáNCHEZ

abstract: Many songs on the album are about this R&B singer anticipating the needs of her man, serving him and complimenting him.

abstract: This pop-punk trio, a do-it-yourself band from top to bottom, has released a record on which nearly every song is a puzzle.

headline: In Performance | Ruthie Ann Miles
abstract: Ms. Miles, who won a Tony Award for her performance in the revival of “The King and I,” sings “Something Wonderful,” a ballad from the musical. The show is on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Miles, who won a Tony Award for her performance in the revival of “The King and I,” sings “Something Wonderful,” a ballad from the musical. The show is on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

headline: Review: City Ballet Debuts in Season Finale
abstract: Three City Ballet performers shouldered the pressure of new roles in the company’s spring season finale.
lead_paragraph: Debuts occur all the time at New York City Ballet, where dancers, no matter their rank, get chances to shine in parts of all sizes. And then along came Miriam Miller.

headline: Kalief Browder, Held at Rikers Island for 3 Years Without Trial, Commits Suicide
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Mr. Browder, 22, who spent two of the years in solitary confinement, drew the attention of Bill de Blasio, Rand Paul and other public figures after he was written about last year in The New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: Kalief Browder was sent to Rikers Island when he was 16 years old, accused of stealing a backpack. Though he never stood trial or was found guilty of any crime, he spent three years at the New York City jail complex, nearly two of them in solitary confinement.

headline: Modi Under Fire for Calling Bangladesh’s Leader Tough, ‘Despite Being a Woman’
abstract: India’s prime minister was criticized on social networks after a backhanded compliment to Sheikh Hasina, his Bangladeshi counterpart.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India was ridiculed Monday on social networks for comments he made over the weekend during a state visit to Bangladesh, where he praised its prime minister for fighting terrorism “despite being a woman.”

abstract: Summer festival style on display Randalls Island at the Governors Ball.
lead_paragraph: Summer festival style on display Randalls Island at the Governors Ball.

headline: The Evidence Points to a Better Way to Fight Insomnia
abstract: A review of data shows that cognitive behavior therapy works better than sleep medications.
lead_paragraph: One weekend afternoon a couple of years ago, while turning a page of the book I was reading to my daughters, I fell asleep. That’s when I knew it was time to do something about my insomnia.

headline: Fifty Years of Chic at Hotel Il Pellicano
abstract: In Tuscany, the property celebrated its birthday with fireworks, many a French 75 and no shortage of Missoni-dressed guests.
lead_paragraph: Hotel Il Pellicano has a 50-year history of attracting a certain jet set — Hollywood royalty, fashion-world darlings, very beautiful and important humans — to its cliffside pool on the Tuscan coastline. And its impossibly chic creative director Marie-Louise Sciò, whose father, Roberto, bought the hotel in 1979, summoned regulars like the actor Josh Hartnett and his girlfriend, Tamsin Egerton, to celebrate the property’s birthday over the weekend. All gleefully flew in, heeding the suggested dress code: Missoni meets Slim Aarons (who photographed Il Pellicano’s socialite scene for more than 25 years). The crowd, co-hosted by T’s editor in chief Deborah Needleman, was as festive as the grounds, dressed up with colorful prints, strung with twinkling lights and toasted with fireworks after a fiery sun set below the perimeter’s cypress trees.

headline: With New Study, New Mothers Seeking IUDs Are No Longer Urged to Wait
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Caesarean Section', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: A new study suggests that receiving an IUD right after a cesarean delivery can help reduce unintended pregnancies and risks like prematurity.
lead_paragraph: After childbirth, some new mothers wishing to avoid another pregnancy ask their doctors to provide reversible contraception, like an intrauterine device. But normally, new mothers are told to return for contraception six weeks after giving birth — after fully half of them have already resumed sexual relations.

headline: Review: ‘Smile at Us, Oh Lord’ Depicts a Jewish Odyssey
abstract: This mournful play, adapted from a novel by the Israeli-based Lithuanian author Grigory Kanovich, is presented by the Cherry Orchard Festival.
lead_paragraph: Buried deep in the show, the old joke got a warm, rolling laugh on Friday night from the crowd at City Center.

headline: Street Style at the Governors Ball
abstract: Summer festival style on display Randalls Island at the Governors Ball.
lead_paragraph: The Governors Ball music festival, one of the biggest outdoor pop music events in New York City, drew more than 60 performers to its four stages this year. Over the course of three days, music lovers flocked to Randalls Island to hear Drake, Florence and the Machine, the Black Keys and many more. Many attendees donned their coolest outfits for the shows.

headline: U.N. General Assembly Report on Children and Armed Conflict
abstract: A report on the impact of armed conflict on children and violations against children in conflict zones in 2014.
lead_paragraph: A report on the impact of armed conflict on children and violations against children in conflict zones in 2014.

headline: First Draft Focus: Obama’s Trip to Germany
abstract: President Obama attended the summit meeting of the Group of 7 in the Bavarian Alps.
lead_paragraph: President Obama attended the summit meeting of the Group of 7 in the Bavarian Alps.

headline: Jeb Bush Shakes Up Campaign Staff, Week Before Campaign Becomes Official
abstract: Jeb Bush has reshuffled his political team a week before his formal entrance into the presidential race, the clearest indication yet that his bid for the Republican nomination continues to experience turbulence as he labors to distinguish himself from his famous family and present a compelling vision for his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush shuffled his political team on Monday, moving to address persistent questions surrounding his presidential candidacy a week before he plans to announce his formal entry into the race.

headline: Longtime Assistants Relish Ride With American Pharoah
abstract: After escorting American Pharoah on a whirlwind journey that ended with a Triple Crown, Bob Baffert’s assistants Jimmy and Dana Barnes are perhaps closest to the colt.
lead_paragraph: The assistant trainer Jimmy Barnes watched the race that changed everything from behind the winner’s circle. He was calm and introspective, thinking about his father, Laverne, who had died 15 years earlier, almost to the day. He watched his family, including his wife, Dana, who works alongside him in Bob Baffert’s barn, cheer and cry and cheer some more.

headline: ‘Fun Home’ Finds That Winning a Tony Is the Best Way to Market a Musical
abstract: The show’s producers said that ticket sales quadrupled on both Sunday and Monday after it was named best new musical.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award for best new musical is always a boon for the winning show. But for “Fun Home,” which claimed this year’s prize on Sunday night, the award is likely to be a major turning point, allowing the production to reach new markets, and new audiences, that might have been initially put off by its searing exploration of sexuality and suicide.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Municipal Art Society President to Step Down for New Lincoln Center Role
abstract: The job of raising the rest of the money to renovate Lincoln Center’s home of the New York Philharmonic is being taken on by Vin Copolla, of the Municipal Arts Society.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of David Geffen’s $100 million gift toward the $500 million transformation of Avery Fisher Hall, many have wondered how Lincoln Center and the New York Philharmonic would go about trying to raise the rest of such a daunting budget.

headline: I.O.C. Adds Four Events to Roster of 2018 Winter Games
abstract: The events — curling mixed doubles, mass start speed skating, an Alpine skiing event between nations and snowboard big air — have female participation and youth appeal in mind.
lead_paragraph: You can never have enough curling. That was one of the messages from the International Olympic Committee on Monday when it approved the addition of several events for the 2018 Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Jerusalem Passport Case
abstract: The court is right. The power to recognize foreign governments belongs to the president.
lead_paragraph: To whom does Jerusalem belong?

headline: Looking for Robots That Will Cooperate, Not Terminate
abstract: A Darpa robotic competition in California focused on machines that can perform ordinary tasks that were the furthest thing from the killer automatons of science fiction.
lead_paragraph: POMONA, Calif. — A robot that evoked a human form paused in front of a door leading to a simulated nuclear power plant accident and inexplicably stood motionless. Suddenly, from the grandstands overlooking the scene, a group of schoolchildren began to chant: “Go Robot! Go Robot! Go Robot!”

headline: Smithsonian Displays Ancient Artwork From City Threatened by ISIS
abstract: The Smithsonian, seeking to draw attention to the potential destruction of antiquities in Syria, is putting a funerary bust from Palmyra on display.
lead_paragraph: To highlight the cultural destruction threatening the ancient crossroads city of Palmyra, in the Syria desert, the Smithsonian Institution is putting an intricately carved funerary bust acquired in 1908 on long-term display, officials said on Monday.

headline: Calpers to Cut Ties With Many Fund Managers to Save on Fees
abstract: America’s biggest state pension fund is cutting off half of its external investment managers as the issue of costly fees turns increasingly political.
lead_paragraph: For years, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the country’s biggest state pension fund, paid Wall Street billions of dollars to help finance the retirement plans of teachers, firefighters, police and other state employees.

abstract: Our nightly rundown will catch you up quickly on the day’s top stories.

abstract: When the National Geographic photographer Vince Musi learned not to say no to assignments, he redefined his approach — and relationship — to photography.
lead_paragraph: When the National Geographic photographer Vince Musi learned not to say no to assignments, he redefined his approach — and relationship — to photography.

headline: A Wide Musical Lineup at Governors Ball, With Women Leading the Way
abstract: The fifth annual Governors Ball festival, on Randalls Island, featured strong and strange music by women, who were outnumbered by men.
lead_paragraph: The fifth annual Governors Ball festival, on Randalls Island, featured strong and strange music by women, who were outnumbered by men.

headline: Review: Governors Ball Is Ruled by Women
abstract: Women had the larger ideas and more ambitious sets at this festival, with acts like Lana Del Ray, Björk and Florence and the Machine offering the strongest, strangest music.
lead_paragraph: Women brought the strongest and strangest music to the fifth annual Governors Ball festival, held Friday through Sunday on Randalls Island. They were worldly and otherworldly, heroic and vulnerable, proudly pop-savvy or defining their own kinds of fringe. Of course, they were outnumbered by men, who held most of the headlining slots.

headline: Atlantic Broadband Deal Shows Small Operators Seek Growth, Too
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The frenzied appetite seen among the industry behemoths is catching on among the second-tier players.
lead_paragraph: As the big get bigger in the cable business, the small are trying to get a little bit bigger, too.

headline: Government to Forgive Student Loans at Corinthian Colleges
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Credit and Debt', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The decision could affect tens of thousands of students, and the education department said it would create a process to help others who were defrauded by colleges.
lead_paragraph: In a move against what he called “the ethics of payday lending” in higher education, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan announced Monday that the Education Department would forgive the federal loans of tens of thousands of students who attended Corinthian Colleges, a for-profit college company that closed and filed for bankruptcy last month, amid widespread charges of fraud.

headline: Cuomo Finds Prison Emergency Is Also an Opportunity
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has toured the airwaves over the last several days, hurling himself into a crisis generated neither by lawmaking procedures in Albany, nor by a federal prosecutor’s office.
lead_paragraph: Less than 48 hours after a whirlwind visit to the Clinton Correctional Facility, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was ready for a full-fledged media blitz.

headline: Review: Locrian Chamber Players at Riverside Church
abstract: Locrian chose six composers — deplorably, none of them women — in seven strongly performed pieces.
lead_paragraph: Classical music has too many rules for its own good, but the enterprising Locrian Chamber Players have two laudable ones. No. 1: Program notes are available only on the way out of its performance space, a room in Riverside Church’s tower, which yields views of the Hudson River and Grant’s Tomb. No. 2: Compositions from the past decade are the only ones on its programs.

headline: Review: New Jersey Symphony Orchestra
abstract: Jacques Lacombe and the New Jersey Symphony, who roam the state tirelessly, traveled to Englewood on Thursday evening to open the final subscription series of the orchestra’s season.
lead_paragraph: Bergen Performing Arts Center, Englewood, N.J.

headline: Review: Lisa Moore at DiMenna Center
abstract: Lisa Moore’s lucid, committed pianism made the best of four works, each dealing with an aspect of landscape or nature.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall offers free cough drops to the audience. Kettle Corn New Music offers free beer and popcorn. A contemporary-music series now in its third year, Kettle Corn has joined other concert series trying to make performances a less finicky affair. Led by the artistic directors Alex Weiser and Chris Rogerson, it does so much less awkwardly and far more engagingly than most.

headline: An Earthling’s Guide to Black Holes
abstract: Welcome to the place of no return — a region in space where the gravitational pull is so strong that not even light can escape it. This is a black hole.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the place of no return — a region in space where the gravitational pull is so strong that not even light can escape it. This is a black hole.

headline: Dennis Hastert Hires Thomas C. Green as His Lawyer
abstract: When J. Dennis Hastert is arraigned in federal court on Tuesday, he will be represented by Thomas C. Green, a former prosecutor who has defended members of Congress and other public officials accused of official misconduct.
lead_paragraph: J. Dennis Hastert is scheduled to be arraigned in federal court in Chicago on Tuesday, and he has hired a powerful and experienced Washington lawyer to represent him.

headline: Music and a Melee at Hot 97’s Summer Jam
abstract: The annual hip-hop concert was hampered by a modest lineup onstage and a face-off between the police and would-be concertgoers outside MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The annual hip-hop concert was hampered by a modest lineup onstage and a face-off between the police and would-be concertgoers outside MetLife Stadium.

headline: Cleveland Leaders Bypass Prosecutors to Seek Charge in Tamir Rice Case
abstract: Community leaders will invoke a seldom-used Ohio law and go directly to a judge to request murder charges against the police officers in the shooting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Community leaders in Cleveland, distrustful of the criminal justice system, said Monday that they would not wait for prosecutors to decide whether to file charges against the police officers involved in the fatal shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice last year. Instead, they will invoke a seldom-used Ohio law and go directly to a judge to request murder charges against the officers.

headline: Smells Like Hawaii (and Benzyl Acetate): Revealing the Chemicals in Glade’s Fragrances
abstract: Companies are becoming more responsive to customers who demand to know more about everyday products like air fresheners and cleaning products.
lead_paragraph: SC Johnson, the maker of Glade air fresheners, has decided to tell consumers more about the chemicals they are breathing.

headline: American Apparel Avoids Fight Over Board
abstract: Jeffrey Kolb, an ally of the retailer’s ousted chief executive, Dov Charney, agreed to withdraw his nominees, one of whom will advise the new chief, Paula Schneider.
lead_paragraph: American Apparel said on Monday that it had averted a proxy fight with an ally of its estranged founder and former chief executive, Dov Charney, as the retailer unveiled a turnaround plan meant to get it back on a growth track toward $1 billion in annual sales.

headline: Jack Livings Wins PEN Prize for Debut Fiction
abstract: Mr. Livings won for “The Dog,” a collection of short stories set in China.
lead_paragraph: Jack Livings won the $25,000 PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction on Monday night, for “The Dog,” a collection of stories set in China, where Mr. Livings lived for a time during the 1990s.

headline: Shot Clock Cut for Men in College Basketball
abstract: Men’s games will have a 30-second shot clock in the coming season, a reduction from 35 seconds, the N.C.A.A. announced.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to speed up games, the shot clock in men’s college basketball will be reduced to 30 seconds from 35, one of several changes for the coming season that the N.C.A.A. announced Monday on Twitter.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Tells New Jersey to Reject Deal With Exxon
abstract: The de Blasio administration has asked that New Jersey’s proposed $225 million pollution settlement with Exxon be rejected, saying it “appears wholly inadequate.”
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s proposed $225 million pollution settlement with Exxon Mobil Corporation has a prominent and new opponent: the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, which has asked that the deal be rejected, saying it “appears wholly inadequate.”

headline: Tuberculosis Case Prompts Search for Patient’s Fellow Airline Passengers
abstract: ​ The risk to the public is low, the C.D.C. said Monday, although the patient, who traveled from India in April, has been hospitalized in Maryland with a drug-resistant form of the disease.
lead_paragraph: Health officials are trying to identify people who may have come into contact with a woman who flew from India to Chicago in April and had a type of tuberculosis that is highly resistant to drug treatment.

headline: Regulator Said to Have Pressed for Exit of Deutsche Chiefs
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: German regulators played a role in the departures at the bank, according to two people briefed on the events that contributed to the leadership upheaval.
lead_paragraph: When the two executives who lead Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, unexpectedly announced their resignations on Sunday, pressure from angry shareholders was widely seen as the chief factor.

headline: Critical of FIFA, Publishers Flee
abstract: The publishers of a Cayman Islands newspaper said they feared for their safety after the territory’s premier described a recent editorial as “treasonous.”
lead_paragraph: Fallout from the FIFA soccer scandal has begun to affect journalism in the Cayman Islands.

headline: Earthquake Prods Nepal Parties to Make Constitution Deal
abstract: They agreed to a federal model with eight provinces that would allow them to form a government and rebuild the quake-ravaged nation.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — After almost a decade of friction over central constitutional issues, Nepal’s major political parties reached an accord on Monday night, agreeing to a federal model with eight provinces that would allow them to form a government involving all major parties and rebuild the quake-ravaged nation.

headline: Kentucky Governor Raises Minimum Wage With Executive Order
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'States (US)', 'Government Employees', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Wages and Salaries', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Gov. Steven Beshear signed an executive order raising the hourly minimum wage for certain state employees while Republicans worried that the move could hurt the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Steven L. Beshear of Kentucky signed an executive order on Monday raising the hourly minimum wage for certain state employees to $10.10. The change, which angered state Republicans and drew praise from the governor’s fellow Democrats, affects almost 800 employees, including those making the current hourly minimum of $7.25.

headline: Mergers Might Not Signal Optimism
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Usually confidence in a robust economy drives merger activity. With revenue growth dwindling, that might not be the case this time.
lead_paragraph: A boom in mergers and acquisitions usually signals confidence in the economy, and recent headline-grabbing deals evoke images of chief executives and directors cheering about their business prospects and overall growth.

headline: MERS Virus’s Path: One Man, Many South Korean Hospitals
abstract: The MERS virus found ideal conditions to spread quickly in South Korea, where emergency rooms are known to cram seats and beds closely together and patients hospital shop.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — At first, doctors thought the 68-year-old man might have simple pneumonia. He coughed and wheezed his way through four hospitals before officials figured out, nine days later, that he had something far more serious and contagious.

headline: At 50, Major League Draft Has Sharpened Its Focus
abstract: Top high school prospects, like the four who were in New York for the opening day of the draft, are the focus of greater attention today than they were years ago.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Rodgers had been to New York once before this month, to play at Citi Field in a summer showcase for top high school players. He has also played at Wrigley Field in Chicago and Petco Park in San Diego.

headline: Bronx Man Dies After Police Use Taser Stun Gun on Him
abstract: The man, identified as Mario Ocasio, went into cardiac arrest and died after a police encounter in which he refused to drop a pair of scissors.
lead_paragraph: A man brandishing a pair of scissors died on Monday after being shocked with a Taser stun gun during an encounter with police officers inside his Bronx apartment, the authorities said.

headline: Democracy Wins in Turkey
abstract: Voters made clear that they would not allow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, an increasingly authoritarian leader, to amass even more power.
lead_paragraph: Turkish voters reasserted their commitment to democracy in Sunday’s parliamentary elections. More than 86 percent of them cast ballots, a level of participation far above the 57 percent turnout posted by Americans in 2012. The Turks made clear they would not allow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, an increasingly authoritarian leader, to amass even more power, denying him a parliamentary majority while voting in significant numbers for a party representing the Kurdish minority.

headline: Israel and Hamas Are Kept Off a Grim List
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Civilian Casualties', 'International Relations', 'Child Soldiers', 'Palestinians', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, opted not to include them on a list of armies and guerrilla groups that kill and maim children in conflicts worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Under unusual pressure from Israel and the United States, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, opted not to include either Israel or Hamas on a list of armies and guerrilla groups that kill and maim children in conflicts worldwide, despite the recommendations of one of his senior envoys, diplomats say.

headline: LeBron James Has Nothing to Prove, but He’s Proving It Anyway
abstract: James, who has already won championships, fights to keep the Cavaliers competitive in the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — After the 11 makes and the 24 misses, after the 16 rebounds and the 11 assists and the 39 points, each of them hard won, LeBron James plopped down on a dais at Oracle Arena on Sunday night and reflected on the Cleveland Cavaliers’ first step in the N.B.A. finals toward a championship.

headline: Shortstops Loom Large at Top of Draft as Teams Pass on Pitchers
abstract: For the first time in the history of the major league draft, three shortstops were chosen with the top three picks, and four in the top 10.
lead_paragraph: SECAUCUS, N.J. — Dansby Swanson, a slick-fielding Vanderbilt shortstop with a line-drive swing, was selected No. 1 in the major league baseball draft by the Arizona Diamondbacks on Monday, a night that was notable for the arms selected for future major league infields but not for pitching mounds.

headline: Iran: Hearing Is Held in Reporter’s Trial
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: An Iranian revolutionary court convened the second hearing on Monday in the espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, who was arrested and imprisoned nearly a year ago.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian revolutionary court convened the second hearing on Monday in the espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who was arrested and imprisoned nearly a year ago. Iran’s official Islamic Republic News Agency reported briefly on the second hearing, which was closed to the public; it said that a third hearing was planned but that a date had not been announced. The secretive prosecution of Mr. Rezaian, 39, a California native who holds dual citizenship in Iran and the United States, has become an increasingly contentious point between the two countries, along with the imprisonment of at least two other Americans in Iran and the disappearance of another eight years ago. Mr. Rezaian’s brother, Ali Rezaian, said the Iranian defense lawyer for Mr. Rezaian, Leila Ahsan, was filing a complaint against the Mehr News Agency, a semiofficial news service in Iran that had reported what it said were details from the first hearing on May 26, in violation of a court-ordered ban.

headline: World Trade Center Parachutists Go on Trial
keywords: ['Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: Prosecutors say the men charged in the 2013 stunt endangered the public; defense lawyers say their clients are skydiving experts.
lead_paragraph: One of the three sky divers who parachuted off the 1 World Trade Center tower on a September 2013 night left a note for his mother before the covert jump. “Sorry mom, for what it’s worth,” the jumper, Andrew Rossig, wrote. “But I had to write some history.”

headline: New Prosecutor Is Selected for Patz Retrial
abstract: Joel J. Seidemann, a senior Manhattan prosecutor who handled the fraud trial of Brooke Astor’s son, will pick up the case against Pedro Hernandez in the murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz.
lead_paragraph: A senior Manhattan prosecutor who handled the fraud trial of Brooke Astor’s son has been given the task of retrying a former store clerk accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz, officials in the Manhattan district attorney’s office said on Monday.

headline: Alan Bond, Yachting Hero and Convict, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Bond funded Australia’s victory in the 1983 America’s Cup, but several of his other business ventures led to convictions of misconduct and the largest corporate fraud in Australian history.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Alan Bond, who bankrolled Australia’s historic victory in the 1983 America’s Cup yacht race, and who was also a brash billion-dollar dealmaker who was sent to jail for what at the time was the largest corporate fraud in Australian history, died on Friday in Perth, Australia. He was 77.

headline: By a Nose
abstract: A little sleight of hand on the part of the Puzzles & Games team brings you a relatively timely puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Roy Leban runs because of a different, four-legged runner. In case you missed it, AMERICAN PHAROAH won the Triple Crown on Saturday, after leaving the other horses in the dust at the Belmont Stakes. He is the first horse to win the Triple Crown since AFFIRMED won in 1978. That’s quite a long dry spell.

headline: Women’s World Cup: U.S. Shows Unease; Hope Solo Puts a Stop to It
abstract: Two goals by Megan Rapinoe and several key saves by Solo, who has had trouble off the field, helped the Americans recover from a shaky start against Australia.
lead_paragraph: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — The United States appeared nervous Monday when it opened the Women’s World Cup, often tattered in defense, frequently inert and faltering in attack.

headline: The King’s the Thing, Not the Play, for an Actor Who Would Be Lear
abstract: Forced to leave a role he always wanted to play, Edward Petherbridge returns in ”My Perfect Mind,” a piece he helped create about not playing King Lear.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, the English actor Edward Petherbridge flew to New Zealand to play King Lear. He’d never seen himself as the Lear type.

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Rapper Who Inspired a Teacher, Visits a High School That Embraces His Work
abstract: Mr. Lamar addressed the student body and talked with literature classes at High Tech High School in North Bergen, N.J., after reading that he was part of the curriculum.
lead_paragraph: When Brian Mooney’s students struggled in March to digest the literary themes and dense language in Toni Morrison’s novel “The Bluest Eye,” Mr. Mooney sought inspiration from an unorthodox teacher of his own: the two-time Grammy winner and world-famous rapper Kendrick Lamar.

headline: Dolores Spikes, Trailblazer as President of Southern University, Dies at 78
abstract: As president of the Southern University and A&M College System in Louisiana, Ms. Spikes opposed court-ordered desegregation of the state’s colleges to protect Southern’s identity as a black institution.
lead_paragraph: Dolores Spikes, who became the first woman to head a university system in the United States when, in 1988, she was named president of the Southern University and A & M College System in Louisiana, and who fought court-ordered desegregation of the state’s colleges to protect Southern’s identity as a black institution, died on June 1 in Baton Rouge, La. She was 78.

headline: Released After 27 Years, an Ex-Inmate Is Mindful of a Detective’s Cases
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In 1989, a jury found Shabaka Shakur guilty of a double homicide based on evidence amassed by a now retired detective, Louis Scarcella, whose work has been called into question.
lead_paragraph: Lanette Holmes had grown accustomed to waiting for her husband, Shabaka Shakur. He had spent the past 27 years in prison for a murder he insisted he did not commit, based largely on a confession that a judge ruled last week bore a “reasonable probability” of having been fabricated by a detective now accused of using rogue tactics to make his cases.

headline: Hints and Whispers Preceded Changes in Jeb Bush’s Team

headline: Ben Bishop Helps Tampa Bay Lightning Pull Ahead in Stanley Cup Finals
abstract: Bishop, hindered by an undisclosed injury that appeared to affect his mobility, made 36 saves to lead Tampa Bay to a two-games-to-one advantage over the Chicago Blackhawks.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Ben Bishop lay face down, arms spread above his head, and he did not move. He might not have wanted to, either. He had spent much of the game Monday night staggering from side to side in the crease and lumbering from front to back. He seemed to favor his left side.

headline: Inside Tony Oursler’s House of ESP Cards (Among Other Ephemera)
abstract: Ahead of the international photography festival Les Rencontres d’Arles, the artist takes T on a tour of his Lower East Side space.
lead_paragraph: “Sorry — this place is a total wreck,” says the video artist Tony Oursler of his Manhattan home and studio, which is in a constant state of precariousness: Touch one thing and three more take a tumble. “But that’s the fun of it! You’re in the midst of moviemaking magic,” he continues, and it’s true. Ahead of the international photography festival Les Rencontres d’Arles, the sets and props for his upcoming immersive 3D film occupy part of the building’s first floor and a model theater fills the rest. (The basement serves as an editing room for Oursler and his team.)

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1 P.M. (SYFY) THE PRESTIGE (2006) Robert Angier (Hugh Jackman) and Alfred Borden (Christian Bale) work together as assistants in magic performances before a tragedy turns them into lifelong enemies. As performing magicians, they seek vengeance on each other through obsessive one-upmanship. Rebecca Hall and Michael Caine play supporting roles as Angier’s wife and his manager. “ ‘The Prestige,’ directed by Christopher Nolan from a script he wrote with his brother Jonathan, is an intricate and elaborate machine designed for the simple purpose of diversion,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Set in a stylized late-Victorian world of dueling music-hall magicians and diabolically clever inventors, it has a satisfyingly puzzlelike structure, zipping around in time and scattering clues throughout its busy scenes and frames. Like ‘Memento,’ also directed by Christopher Nolan and based on a story by his brother, ‘The Prestige’ is a triumph of gimmickry, a movie generous enough with its showmanship and sleight of hand to quiet the temptation to grumble about its lack of substance.”

headline: Disputed Painting Is Declared an Authentic Rembrandt After Decades
abstract: After almost 50 years, the Mauritshuis museum in The Hague has declared ‘‘Saul and David,’’ one of Rembrandt’s most important biblical works, to be authentic.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — The painting was sliced down the middle and straight through its center in the 19th century, probably to be sold as two Rembrandt portraits. At some point in the next 40 years, it was sutured back together with pieces of an entirely different canvas, and layered with paint to cover up its scars.

headline: Rick Perry and the Hazards of One-Party Rule
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Texas Republican would be a better presidential candidate if he’d had to work harder to become governor.
lead_paragraph: Former Texas governor Rick Perry entered the presidential sweepstakes last week suggesting that financially downtrodden Americans “are looking for a second chance.” They’re not the only ones. Perry’s announcement on Wednesday — the first we’ve heard from him on the national stage since the oops-heard-’round-the-world throttled his previous candidacy in 2011 — was notable for both its muscular foreign policy rhetoric and its emphasis on his sun-scarred beginnings as a cotton farmer in Paint Creek, Tex. Then as now, however, Perry’s strong suit remains his self-professed status as Texas’ Job Creator in Chief. As he put it in his speech, “During my 14 years as governor, Texas companies created almost one-third of all new American jobs.” That distinction sets Perry apart from other current or former G.O.P. governors now favored over him in the polls: Jeb Bush, Scott Walker and Chris Christie.

abstract: Mr. Hastert, a former speaker of the House, faces federal charges of illegally structuring bank withdrawals and lying to investigators.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — After days of silence, J. Dennis Hastert, a former speaker of the House of Representatives, on Tuesday pleaded not guilty to federal charges that he illegally structured bank withdrawals and lied to the authorities about millions of dollars he had promised to pay someone for misconduct that occurred decades ago.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Career Bedeviled by Financial Struggles
abstract: Among presidential contenders, Mr. Rubio stands out for his youth, his meteoric political rise — and recurring doubts about how he manages his finances.
lead_paragraph: WEST MIAMI, Fla. — For years, Senator Marco Rubio struggled under the weight of student debt, mortgages and an extra loan against the value of his home totaling hundreds of thousands of dollars. But in 2012, financial salvation seemed to have arrived: A publisher paid him $800,000 to write a book about growing up as the son of Cuban immigrants.

headline: ‘The Love Object,’ by Edna O’Brien
abstract: Edna O’Brien’s tales trace a nation gripped by tradition and change.
lead_paragraph: Edna O’Brien’s 2012 memoir, “Country Girl,” was a roller-coaster ride. One downward plummet: The priest in O’Brien’s Irish hometown has her first book burned in public. But then there’s the rise to stardom and parties at which the chat is as barbed as the gossip of village life, though with more literary allusions.

headline: ‘Saint Mazie,’ by Jami Attenberg
abstract: Jami Attenberg’s novel, inspired by a 1940 New Yorker profile, centers on a bawdy, bighearted woman in Depression-era New York.
lead_paragraph: The story of a Jazz Age party girl who winds up in a cage as a ticket-taker in a Depression-era Lower East Side movie theater, Jami Attenberg’s “Saint Mazie” is full of love and drink and dirty sex and nobility and beef stew.

headline: Tuesday’s Travel News and Tips
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including a new LGBT travel guide and an intensive care unit on long-haul flights from Munich and Frankfurt.
lead_paragraph: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: How to Find a Truly Quiet Hotel Room
abstract: The quest for a silent night is often an elusive task for travelers, but there are ways to improve your chances.
lead_paragraph: Is there such a thing as a quiet hotel room anymore?

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Before Supreme Court Weighs in, Obama Makes His Case for Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Days before a ruling that could drastically undermine the Affordable Care Act, President Obama delivered a speech extolling its benefits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday condemned opponents of his signature health care law as “cynical” partisans seeking to deprive Americans of a benefit that has become an integral part of the country’s social safety net, building a tough political case against Republicans as the Supreme Court weighs whether to strike down a key element of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: New York Today: Gaming the Housing System
abstract: Tuesday: Playing with housing, wet weather, and the manhunt continues.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this sprinkling Tuesday.

headline: Police in Eastern India Say They Killed 12 Maoist Rebels
abstract: A prominent rebel commander, Anurag Ji, was among those who died in the gunfight early Tuesday, a police official said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Twelve Maoist rebels were killed in a firefight with the police in eastern India early Tuesday, a senior police official said.

headline: Orchestra in Turin, Italy, Names James Conlon as Principal Conductor
abstract: James Conlon, music director at Los Angeles Opera, takes on the post of principal conductor at the RAI National Symphony Orchestra in Turin, Italy.
lead_paragraph: James Conlon, the versatile New York-born maestro, is returning to Europe for his next podium: he will become the principal conductor of the RAI National Symphony Orchestra in Turin, Italy, in 2016, the orchestra said on Tuesday.

headline: W.H.O. to Look Into MERS in South Korea
abstract: Keiji Fukuda, the World Health Organization’s assistant director general for health security, spoke on Tuesday with experts in the country to investigate the recent outbreak of MERS.
lead_paragraph: Keiji Fukuda, the World Health Organization’s assistant director general for health security, spoke on Tuesday with experts in the country to investigate the recent outbreak of MERS.

headline: Macedonia at the Crossroads
abstract: Will the Balkan nation follow its former Yugoslavian neighbors into crisis?
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — “Have you ever been stuck in an elevator?” a Macedonian politician asked me recently. We were in Skopje, his country’s capital, where huge public protests have raged over the last year, including demonstrators occupying the government square and, in the Parliament, a nearly yearlong boycott by the political opposition. “Can you imagine being stuck like this for 20 years? This is what happened to us.”

headline: Norway Divests From Coal
abstract: Reducing investments in companies that mine and use coal is only a first step. There’s still all that oil to worry about.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian Parliament voted on Friday to order the country’s huge oil fund — at $890 billion, the world’s largest sovereign wealth fund — to pull billions of dollars of investments out of companies that derive 30 percent or more of their business from mining or burning coal. The move is a major boost to the three-year-old campaign to persuade large investors to divest their fossil fuel stocks. And it could add to the momentum toward concrete action at the climate-change summit conference to be held in Paris in December.

headline: Want to Bet That Jeb Bush Is Running?
abstract: Prediction markets would be a way to prevent candidates from sidestepping fund-raising restrictions.
lead_paragraph: The potential candidate Jeb Bush — who everyone knows is running — has not faced the fund-raising restrictions that election law imposes on those of his rivals who are officially declared candidates. He has accomplished this by seemingly pretending that he is not actually running for president.

headline: When You ‘Literally Can’t Even’ Understand Your Teenager
keywords: ['English Language', 'Slang', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Youth']
abstract: The sentence fragment ‘I can’t even’ is the latest in a long line of phrases deployed by millennials to obscure from adults what they really mean.
lead_paragraph: A little paradox of Internet celebrity is that a YouTube personality can amass millions upon millions of young fans by making it seem as if he’s chatting with each of them one to one. Tyler Oakley, a 26-year-old man who identifies as a “professional fangirl,” is a master of the genre. He has nerd glasses, pinchable cheeks, a quiff he dyes in shades of blue and green and more YouTube subscribers than Shakira. Some of his teenage admirers have told him that he is the very first gay person that they have ever seen. He models slumber party outfits and gushes over boy bands, giving the kids who watch him from their bedrooms a peek into a wider world.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Fear of a Black Hat’
abstract: The 1994 mockumentary about a gangsta-rap group is committed to its badness — and it holds up.
lead_paragraph: An hour or so into “Fear of a Black Hat,” a 1994 mockumentary about a gangsta-rap group called N.W.H. (the H is for “hats”), a peculiar negotiation takes place: Ice Cold, the crew’s politically awakened frontman, wants 15 dead cops on the cover of its forthcoming album. Citing the “moral watchdogs,” the white record executive politely requests that there be no dead cops. N.W.H.’s manager, played by a ponytailed Richard Lewis clone, has a compromise in mind.

headline: Today in Politics: Jeb Bush Heads to Europe to the Sound of Musical Chairs
abstract: A day after returning from Group of 7 meetings in Germany, President Obama will move his attention to defending his health care law, and where a senator clears time for blueberry muffins. And Jeb Bush begins his own Europe trip as he switches some job titles on his team.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where, a day after returning from Group of 7 meetings in Germany, President Obama will move his attention to defending his health care law, and where a senator clears time for blueberry muffins. And Jeb Bush begins his own Europe trip as he switches some job titles on his team.

headline: Using Dance to Connect With Locals
abstract: Learning local dances is a way of experiencing the culture in a direct (and fun) way — in a language that needs no words.
lead_paragraph: On a trip to Austria in 2013, I took a drop-in waltz class at the Rueff Dance School in downtown Vienna.

headline: The Architecture of Psychotherapy
abstract: Waiting rooms, consulting offices and much, much more.
lead_paragraph: If you listen to psychotherapists when they talk to one another, you will often hear them speak of something called the “therapeutic frame.” This term, coined by the psychoanalyst Marion Milner, refers to the set of conventions and ground rules that structure the therapeutic experience. Just as the frame of a painting defines the borders of a work of art, the therapeutic frame is the “container” in which the therapy takes place.

headline: ‘The Art of Dissent’
abstract: The filmmaker Laura Poitras documents the dissidents Ai Weiwei and Jacob Appelbaum as they collaborate on an art project.
lead_paragraph: Ai Weiwei and Jacob Appelbaum are artists, journalists, dissidents, polymaths — and targets. Their respective governments, China and the United States, monitor their every move. They have been detained and interrogated. Ai cannot leave China, and Appelbaum is advised not to return to the United States. They are separated from their families. Ai has been imprisoned and beaten by the police. Yet each continues his work and speaks out against government wrongdoing.

headline: Morning Agenda: HSBC Plans 50,000 Job Cuts in Global Overhaul
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Economy', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: HSBC Plans 50,000 Job Cuts in Global Overhaul | Regulator Said to Have Urged Deutsche Bank Chiefs’ Exit | What Mergers Say About U.S. Economy | Calpers Aims to Reduce Money Manager Fees
lead_paragraph: HSBC PLANS 50,000 JOB CUTS IN GLOBAL RESTRUCTURING | HSBC said Tuesday that it would cut as many as 50,000 jobs around the world and try to reduce costs by as much as $5 billion a year by 2017 as it laid out its plans to restructure its global businesses,  Chad Bray reports in DealBook. About 25,000 jobs will be lost through the sale of the bank’s businesses in Turkey and Brazil, and an additional 20,000 to 25,000 jobs will be eliminated as part of the restructuring. However, the bank is increasingly focusing on Asia, saying that it would expand its asset management and insurance operations in hopes of capturing “expected opportunities from emerging wealth in the region.” The bank also plans to increase its business in the Pearl River Delta in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong and in parts of Southeast Asia.

headline: How Would ‘Ulysses’ Be Received Today?
abstract: When James Joyce’s novel was first published in 1922, it was banned for obscenity and the U.S. Postal Service burned copies.

When James Joyce’s “Ulysses” was first published in 1922, it was banned for obscenity and the U.S. Postal Service burned copies. This week, in honor of Bloomsday on June 16, Charles McGrath and Rivka Galchen discuss how the book would be received if it were published for the first time today.

headline: The Party of Fiscal Responsibility in Action
abstract: Watch what they do, not what they pretend.

Paul Ryan presented budgets that combined huge tax cuts for the rich with not quite as huge benefit cuts for the poor, added some magic asterisks — basically deficit-increasing redistribution from the have-nots to the haves, with added fraudulence — and received awards for fiscal responsibility.

headline: 1915: No U.S. Goods Sent to Germany
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. was not sending goods to Germany in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Government analysis just published in Washington of America’s foreign trade in April, cables the New York correspondent of the ‘‘Daily Telegraph,’’ shows that the exports to the United Kingdom in that month were valued $94,000,000. Not a cent’s worth went to Germany. In April last year, however, the exports to that country were valued at $18,000,000. This is the first time that the Government has reported that for the whole month no goods, no copper, no resin, no cotton — nothing whatever — went to Germany from the United States. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 10, 1915

headline: The Star and the Creator of ‘Witnesses’ on Their New French TV Thriller
abstract: The six-part crime drama is available to stream on Netflix, iTunes, and Amazon.
lead_paragraph: In what world does a police officer run after a suspect, weapon drawn, in kitten heels? Why, in France, of course — at least in the France of Hervé Hadmar, the director and creator, with Marc Herpoux, of the Gallic thriller “Witnesses.” The six-part crime drama is available for streaming on iTunes, Amazon and Netflix. “It’s eerie with a hint of the supernatural, wrote Neil Genzlinger of The New York Times. “And paced just right.”

headline: Obama’s Corporate Tax Blunder
abstract: A new global deal could give multinationals even more reason to move overseas.

Short for Base Erosion and Profit Shifting, the BEPS Project is the focus of a rapidly moving effort by the Group of 20 countries to create a new set of international tax principles designed to better capture tax revenue from multinational companies like Apple, Google and Starbucks.

headline: Vincent T. Bugliosi, Manson Prosecutor and True-Crime Author, Dies at 80

Bugliosi, who successfully prosecuted the cult leader Charles Manson and several acolytes for the savage murders of the actress Sharon Tate and six other people in August 1969, then became a best-selling writer of true-crime books, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. headline: Pia Sundhage of Sweden Is a Coach at Home on the Move
abstract: Sundhage, who led the United States to two Olympic titles and will face her former team in the Women’s World Cup on Friday, was born in Sweden, but she has always been a wanderer.
lead_paragraph: LINKOPING, Sweden — When Pia Sundhage left the United States women’s soccer team in 2012 to become the coach of Sweden’s national team, U.S. Soccer’s news release said she was “returning home” to pursue opportunities. Most news media reports highlighted how she could not turn down the opportunity to lead her homeland’s team. Even Sundhage mentioned this notion of a homecoming to the American players when she told them the news, before serenading them with “Leaving on a Jet Plane.”

headline: It’s a Jungle Out There? Carry a Pocketknife

headline: A Giant Primary? Maybe Not
abstract: This year’s contest may look chaotic, at least on the Republican side, but a crowded slate is nothing new.
lead_paragraph: With ten Republicans already officially in the race, and five more likely to enter, are we looking at the biggest primary slate in recent memory? The answer turns out to be complicated.

headline: Court Gives Obama a Climate Change Win
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Air Pollution']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal court on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit by the nation’s largest coal companies and 14 coal-producing states that sought to block one of President Obama’s signature climate change policies.

headline: Police Swarm Willsboro, N.Y., in Search of Escaped Killers
abstract: After a report of a sighting of two men on foot, law enforcement officials descended on the town, about an hour from Clinton Correctional Facility, where two prisoners escaped over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: WILLSBORO, N.Y. — A dayslong manhunt for two escaped killers prompted a burst of police activity on Tuesday as investigators combed acres of remote, swampy terrain about 35 miles from the prison where the men had been incarcerated.

lead_paragraph: Eleven women who define what’s beautiful now.

headline: ISIS Stages Attacks in Iraq and Libya, Despite U.S. Airstrikes
abstract: In Libya, the Islamic State captured a critical power plant, while in Iraq, gunmen in suicide vests attacked a council building in Amiriyat al Falluja, southwest of Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Islamic State militants staged attacks near Baghdad and the Libyan city of Surt on Tuesday, underscoring the group’s persistent strength on both fronts despite a monthslong American-led air campaign against it in Syria and Iraq.

headline: Robert Gibbs Opts for a Burger and Fries With New McDonald’s Job

lead_paragraph: Alani Santos, age 11, has been preaching since she was 3.

headline: Science Fails to See Benefits of Eating Placenta
abstract: Though recommended for everything from pain reduction to preventing postpartum depression, researchers found no good evidence that the practice offered any health advantages.
lead_paragraph: Some believe eating human placenta — raw, cooked, or dried out, pulverized and encapsulated — has health benefits. But a review of the handful of studies on the subject has found no evidence that eating placenta is good for you.

headline: A Return to Play
abstract: School districts are again embracing play as a bedrock of kindergarten, Motoko Rich writes in The New York Times. Read more.
lead_paragraph: School districts are again embracing play as a bedrock of kindergarten, Motoko Rich writes in The New York Times. Read more.

headline: Top U.S. Military Official Seeks to Assure Israel on Security
abstract: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told his Israeli hosts that the United States would strengthen their arsenal.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — The Obama administration on Tuesday increased its efforts to ease Israel’s opposition to a possible nuclear deal with Iran, as the top American military leader assured Israeli officials that the United States would further strengthen Israel’s arsenal of arms, warplanes and cybertechnology.

headline: If You’re a Betting Man, It’s Time to Start Believing Donald Trump
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A prediction market has rated the chances that potential candidates will actually run for president, and Mr. Trump’s odds are the biggest surprise.
lead_paragraph: Politicians lie, but bettors have a habit of ferreting out the truth. And this is why my article this morning noted that it would be harder for politicians to evade the fund-raising limits that apply to candidates if we relied on prediction markets rather than lawyers to assess whether a politician was running for office.

headline: Tony Oursler’s Paranormal Possessions
abstract: The pioneering video artist has amassed a trove of occult ephemera in his Manhattan home and studio.
lead_paragraph: For the past 20 years, the pioneering video artist has amassed a trove of occult ephemera in his Manhattan home and studio: a deck of extrasensory perception cards, spirit photos (among them, a portrait of the former first lady Mary Todd Lincoln and her late husband’s alleged ghost), a gun-shaped film projector from a ’40s magic act and tons of ectoplasmic goop. Next month, the artist will release a 600-page book that brings his entire collection together in one place, and he will debut an immersive 3D film with actors playing Arthur Conan Doyle, Harry Houdini and the mystic Margery Crandon. He cryptically calls the video project, which will screen throughout the international photography festival Les Rencontres d’Arles, his “return to narrative.”

headline: The Least Worst Crisis
abstract: Iceland, still looking OK.
lead_paragraph: I was, I think, one of the first commentators to notice that a funny thing was happening in Iceland: the nation that was supposed to be Ground Zero for financial disaster was actually having a milder crisis than many others, thanks to heterodox policies — debt repudiation, capital controls, and massive devaluation. Now, as Matthew Yglesias points out, Iceland is getting ready to lift the controls, and its experience still looks remarkably good considering the circumstances.

headline: White House Press Room Is Briefly Evacuated After Bomb Threat
abstract: Journalists and White House officials were evacuated by the Secret Service in the middle of the daily briefing. They were allowed back in a short time later.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House briefing room was evacuated Tuesday afternoon during the televised daily session with reporters after the Washington police received a bomb threat by telephone, Secret Service officials said.

headline: American Billionaire Makes Risky Bet on Greece Debt Deal
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Wilbur Ross and others pumped billions into Greek banks, and now the fate of their money may hinge on Athens’s efforts to end an impasse with creditors.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The contrarian American billionaire Wilbur L. Ross Jr. made a bundle betting on the Irish banking system when it was down and out, and a similar wager on Cyprus now looks promising. But Greece may prove to be the toughest test yet of his knack for cashing in on eurozone crisis spots.

headline: Jeb Bush, on European Tour, Opens by Rebuking Putin
abstract: Visiting Germany, Jeb Bush delivered a forceful rebuke of President Vladimir V. Putin, calling the Russian leader a “ruthless pragmatist.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN – Jeb Bush on Tuesday delivered a forceful rebuke of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a city once sundered by Soviet aggression, calling him a “ruthless pragmatist,” demanding the isolation of the country’s “corrupt leadership” and vowing to reassert American primacy in the fight to contain Russia’s territorial ambitions.

headline: Rikers Island and the Death of Kalief Browder
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and state lawmakers should bring New York into the 21st century by passing a bill that would keep children out of adult prisons.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and the City of New York are expected to reach an agreement this month on a reform plan that is intended to end the barbaric abuses that have long dominated the Rikers Island jail complex.

headline: Details About the Indictment of Dennis Hastert
abstract: The former speaker of the House pleaded not guilty to federal charges on Tuesday afternoon in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On Tuesday, J. Dennis Hastert, a former Illinois congressman, appeared in federal court in Chicago to plead not guilty to charges that he structured cash withdrawals from banks to avoid detection and then lied to federal investigators about it. Mr. Hastert used the money to pay a former student — known only as Individual A — to not disclose that Mr. Hastert had sexually abused him decades ago, people briefed on the federal investigation have said.

headline: On Set | Amber Valletta
abstract: The 41-year old model discusses her definition of beauty — and wants women to rule the world.
lead_paragraph: The 41-year old model discusses her definition of beauty — and wants women to rule the world.

headline: Group Asks Court to Order Arrest of Cleveland Officers in Tamir Rice Case
abstract: Community leaders and activists voiced frustration with the pace of the official response to the death of the 12-year-old, who was fatally shot on Nov. 22.
lead_paragraph: More than six months after a Cleveland police officer fatally shot a 12-year-old boy, community leaders and activists on Tuesday made an unusual bid to bypass the usual legal process by directly petitioning a court to file criminal charges and order the arrest of the officer and his partner.

headline: Con Edison and New York City Are Faulted in East Harlem Explosion
keywords: ['East Harlem Explosion (March 2014)', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Natural Gas', 'Fires and Firefighters']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An explosion in East Harlem that killed eight people last year would not have happened if two of Consolidated Edison’s gas pipes had been welded together properly, federal regulators said on Tuesday.

headline: First Draft Focus:  Secret Service Evacuates White House
abstract: A Secret Service police officer oversaw an evacuation of parts of the White House complex on Tuesday, including members of the news media who were forced to leave the Eisenhower Executive Office Building.
