abstract: Mr. Cohen, a hedge-fund billionaire, bought another Giacometti work last year for $101 million.
lead_paragraph: The bidder who won Alberto Giacometti’s “L’homme au doigt (Pointing Man)” for $141.3 million (including fees) from an auction at Christie’s last month was the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen, according to two people with knowledge of the sale.

headline: What Excites and Inspires Santiago Calatrava
abstract: The architect behind the new World Trade Center transit hub shares influences ranging from Rothko to the music of Alexander Scriabin.
lead_paragraph: Santiago Calatrava is suddenly everywhere in New York. After much delay and even more expense, the World Trade Center transit hub (and shopping concourse) is slowly being revealed to the public, as are new PATH train platforms designed by the Spanish architect. Using one of his favorite words, the new spaces are indeed “monumental” – open and airy, a radical transformation of space in an area of the city that can often feel closed-in and tightly confined.

headline: Einkorn Risotto Is a Long Time Coming
abstract: The recipe for the ancient grain, which is one of the oldest varieties of wheat, is a perfect main dish or side for vegans as well as omnivores.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of reasons to love einkorn, one of the latest ancient grains to hit the shelves in markets. It’s a wheat berry like farro and spelt, but it’s softer and cooks in less time, especially if you soak it. The flavor is sweet and nutty, the texture chewy but yielding.

headline: Voldemort Is More Popular Than Jeb Bush
abstract: And the Terminator is more popular than all the 2016 frontrunners.
lead_paragraph: The Terminator, Darth Vader and the shark from “Jaws” all have higher favorability ratings than any of 13 candidates and likely candidates for president. And Voldemort has a higher rating than six Republicans, including Jeb Bush. That’s what Christopher Ingraham of Wonkblog found when he compared polling data on the presidential hopefuls with Google Consumer Survey results on the fictional characters.

headline: Corporations Open Up About Political Spending
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Corporations', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With companies increasing their disclosures about contributions, perhaps campaign finance reformers should turn their attention elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: In November 1999, Time Warner swore off “soft money” contributions to political campaigns. At the time, it might have seemed like a mistake. The company was about to join with America Online in a deal that would require approval from federal regulators. Yet Gerald M. Levin, Time Warner’s chairman, argued that soft money not only distorted American politics, it sullied the company as well.

headline: Belgium Unveils New 2.50 Euro Coin
abstract: Johan Van Overtveldt, the Belgian finance minister, spoke on Monday about the minting — even after France’s opposition — of a new 2.50 coin that commemorates the Battle of Waterloo.
lead_paragraph: Johan Van Overtveldt, the Belgian finance minister, spoke on Monday about the minting — even after France’s opposition — of a new 2.50 coin that commemorates the Battle of Waterloo.

headline: Canadian Senators’ Expenses Under Investigation After Auditor’s Report
abstract: The findings, involving current and former members, threaten to erode the standing of the Senate, which is under a cloud from a corruption trial.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — By global corruption standards, the amounts are relatively tiny: only about 840,000 Canadian dollars in questionable claims, spread over two years and 30 senators.

headline: Etsy Shares Rise on Back of Tiger Global Stake
abstract: Shares of the online marketplace surge after Tiger Global disclosed that it had raised its stake in the company to 8.9 percent as of late May.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Etsy on Tuesday received a healthy boost from a newly disclosed investment by Tiger Global Management — but it was barely enough to bring the stock back to its initial public offering levels.

headline: U.S. General Affirms Support for Israel
abstract: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, accepted an award from his Israeli counterpart and emphasized the American military’s strong relationship with Israel.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, accepted an award from his Israeli counterpart and emphasized the American military’s strong relationship with Israel.

headline: The Modern Face of British Folklore is Sure to Make You Smile (Maybe Giggle)
abstract: A photographer’s new book captures Straw Bears, Horn Dancers, Pearly Queens and one very prickly Burry Man.
lead_paragraph: The British love of dressing up takes a weird and wondrous turn in the latest book from the photographer and T contributor Henry Bourne. “Arcadia Britannica: A Modern British Folklore Portrait” ($30, out June 16 from Thames & Hudson) was shot in the style of Irving Penn’s “Small Trades,” capturing a sample of some of the 700 folklore traditions played out across the country every year. The origin of these strange and spectacular events, with characters that include Straw Bears and Horn Dancers and Pearly Queens, is often blurry. Yet when captured by Bourne’s lens, one thing is abundantly clear: Much like fancy dress at Halloween, modern folk is fun. Why else would a Scottish graphic designer choose to cover himself in over 10,000 thistles in the bizarre tradition of the Burry Man?

headline: ‘School of Rock’ Plans Fall Opening on Broadway
abstract: The Andrew Lloyd Webber adaptation of “School of Rock” is to begin previews at the Winter Garden Theater on Nov. 9.
lead_paragraph: May we have the attention of the class, please: “School of Rock” will indeed be in session on Broadway this fall. The Andrew Lloyd Webber musical adaptation of the 2003 Jack Black comedy has now solidified its Broadway plans, and is to begin previews at the Winter Garden Theater on Nov. 9 with its opening night scheduled for Dec. 6, its press representatives said Tuesday.

headline: Court Upholds Texas Limits on Abortions
abstract: A federal appellate court upheld some of the toughest provisions of a Texas law, putting more than a dozen abortion clinics at risk of permanently shutting.
lead_paragraph: WACO, Tex. — A federal appellate court upheld some of the toughest provisions of a Texas abortion law on Tuesday, putting about half of the state’s remaining abortion clinics at risk of permanently shutting their doors and leaving the nation’s second-most populous state with fewer than a dozen clinics across its more than 267,000 square miles. There were 41 when the law was passed.

headline: A Green Future for Blue Hawaii, Maybe
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Geothermal Power', 'Law and Legislation', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Windmills']
abstract: A new bill puts the state on a path to energy independence, but it won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: Gov. David Ige of Hawaii on Monday signed a bill to put his state on a path to total energy independence within 30 years. If this is for real, the state would go from being overwhelmingly dependent on imported oil to being a fossil-fuel-free paradise, powered by wind, sun, waves, tides, magma and whatever other energy sources the engineers come up with. Algae, maybe, or sunscreen.

headline: The Last of the Angola 3 Gets Released — Almost [Updated]
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Solitary Confinement']

lead_paragraph: After spending more than four decades alone in a 6-by-9-foot prison cell — possibly the longest anyone has endured that punishment in American history — Albert Woodfox could be forgiven for being skeptical at the prospect of his release, which a federal judge ordered on Monday.

headline: Amid MERS Outbreak, Readers Reflect on South Korean Hospitals
abstract: Responding on Facebook, readers who either live or have spent time in South Korea shared their experiences of the hospitals there.
lead_paragraph: As South Korea struggles to contain an outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome that has infected close to 100 people, the country’s health care system has come under scrutiny. Experts have said that the MERS outbreak may have been fueled by  a hospital system that encourages family members to take on nursing duties, reported Choe Sang-Hun, a New York Times correspondent based in Seoul.

headline: Dance This Week: A Classic ‘Beauty,’ Non-Virtuoso Dance and Ailey Returns
abstract: This week’s look ahead at the world of dance.
lead_paragraph: My greetings to dancegoers.

headline: Tunnels, Disguises and Sewers: Clinton Prison’s Inmates Have Found Many Ways to Flee
abstract: Since the Dannemora, N.Y., prison opened in 1845, dozens of inmates have escaped over, under or through the prison’s thick walls, their exploits detailed in newspaper reports of earlier eras.
lead_paragraph: In summer 1903, a former bank burglar serving a life sentence removed the last bit of earth from a tunnel that had taken him four years to complete and escaped with three other inmates under the walls of Clinton prison in far northern New York State. Almost three decades later, it was a diminutive prisoner that some newspapers called the “midget bandit” who fled the prison in a similar way.

headline: Review: In ‘Be More Chill,’ a Nerd Finds Popularity in a Sci-Fi Pill
abstract: This play at the Two River Theater, adapted from a novel by Ned Vizzini, centers on a teenager who turns cool after ingesting a tiny computer.
lead_paragraph: RED BANK, N.J. — Teenage angst: the grief that just keeps on giving, to popular culture, at least. The woes of the misfit and the wallflower, the snooty brutishness of the jocks and the mean girls have been a bottomless well of material for television, movies and books for decades, and the well shows no signs of running dry.

headline: In ‘Odd Mom Out,’ Mining the Upper East Side for Comedy Gold

lead_paragraph: Most people refer to the neighborhood where Jill Kargman lives with her husband and three children as the Upper East Side.

lead_paragraph: Anthologies offer short films an escape from the festival circuit and a chance to show regular moviegoers the rewards of discipline and constraint — even when their titles, like “2015 Sundance Film Festival Award-Winning Shorts,”  reveal neither attribute.

lead_paragraph: New York City has banned trans fats at restaurants, posted calorie counts on menus and tried, unsuccessfully, to limit the size of sodas.

headline: Andrew Lack Returns to NBC News Amid Turmoil
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Mr. Lack has returned to network news, a place he is said to be comfortable. But that doesn’t mean he isn’t facing some uncomfortable decisions.
lead_paragraph: By all appearances, Andrew Lack’s return to the top job at NBC News has gone smoothly.

headline: A Minimalist Film Score From an Indie-Rock Heavyweight
abstract: Daniel Rossen of Grizzly Bear created the sparkling soundtrack for “Valedictorian,” directed by his old NYU friend Matthew Yeager.
lead_paragraph: “It was very low-conflict,” says Daniel Rossen, the musician responsible for the band Grizzly Bear’s lush guitar arrangements and occasional vocals, who also records as Department of Eagles and under his own name. He’s talking about his first time scoring a film, “Valedictorian,” which was directed by his old NYU friend Matthew Yeager. Back in the day, the pair worked together at a store in the West Village that specialized in cinema classics and foreign film, in “the city that’s long gone,” as Rossen puts it. Rossen and Yeager bonded over understated films and music, an aesthetic that would later inform their own art. “In film and music, I think we prefer a much subtler approach,” Rossen explains. That’s evident in both “Valedictorian” itself, a poetic film about a young man detaching from his social and work landscape in New York City, and its sparkling, guitar-driven soundtrack, which streams exclusively here.

lead_paragraph: Hermann Zapf, whose calling in life — “to create beautiful letters,” as one of his students put it — found expression in lush, steady-handed calligraphy and in subtly inventive typefaces that have brought words to readers on paper, on signposts, on monuments and on computer screens for more than half a century, died on Thursday at his home in Darmstadt, Germany. headline: Greece: U.N. Warns That Migrants May Overwhelm Tourist Island of Lesbos
abstract: Roughly 600 refugees a day were arriving in the Greek islands, and that half of them were coming ashore in Lesbos, a picturesque tourist destination ill equipped to handle the flow.
lead_paragraph: United Nations officials expressed deepening concern on Tuesday about record numbers of desperate refugees from Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan arriving on the Greek island of Lesbos, a short boat ride from the Turkish coast. Adrian Edwards, a spokesman for the United Nations refugee agency in Geneva, said that roughly 600 refugees a day were arriving in the Greek islands, and that half of them were coming ashore in Lesbos, a picturesque tourist destination ill equipped to handle the flow. The Lesbos arrivals have grown steadily by the month, from 737 in January to more than 7,200 in May. Mr. Edwards said the arrivals, crammed into rubber dinghies and wooden boats, were “straining the island’s capacity, services and resources.” They are part of a broader exodus of people from the Middle East and Africa fleeing war and deprivations in their home countries for risky and sometimes deadly Mediterranean trips to Europe, which has created a crisis for the European Union. The refugee agency said there had been 103,000 refugee and migrant arrivals in Europe via the Mediterranean so far in 2015.

headline: Italy: Doctor Abducted in Libya Is Freed

lead_paragraph: Italian officials say an Italian doctor kidnapped in Libya in January has been freed. The official, speaking on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to provide details, said the Libyan authorities in Tripoli had helped with the release. Dr. Scaravilli was kidnapped Jan. 6.

lead_paragraph: Pontus Lidberg choreographs in loops and swirls. On Saturday at the Joyce Theater, this Swedish choreographer and filmmaker offered two impressions of his intimate, emotional vision in companion pieces. Bodies ripple up and down from the floor, partnerships dissolve with a meaningful pause and swooping turns in one direction are usually followed by the same thing in another.

keywords: ['Dogs', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Witnesses', 'Supreme Courts (State)']

A 30-year-old woman was describing the horrific ordeal she and her 5-year-old daughter endured for five months in 2012, bound by duct tape, assaulted and hidden away from the outside world.

headline: Pentagon Anti-Bias Policy Extended to Gays
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: The Pentagon has extended its equal opportunity policy to gay and lesbian troops, granting them an added layer of protection from discrimination and harassment.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon has extended its equal opportunity policy to gay and lesbian troops, granting them an added layer of protection from discrimination and harassment, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Tuesday at a gay and lesbian pride event at the Pentagon. But he, along with the rest of the Pentagon’s leadership, remained silent on the fate of transgender troops, who can still be forced out of the military because of their gender identity. The announcement was another step toward the acceptance of gay and lesbian troops, who could have been expelled from the military because of their sexual orientation until the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy in 2011. Extending equal opportunity protections to gay and lesbian troops ensures the military treats “sexual-orientation-based discrimination the same way it treats discrimination based on race, religion, color, sex, age and national origin,” Mr. Carter said.

headline: Colorado: 3 Are Removed From Theater Murder Jury
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Jury System', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Three jury members were dismissed Tuesday from the murder trial of the gunman who opened fire inside an Aurora, Colo.
lead_paragraph: Three jury members were dismissed Tuesday from the murder trial of the gunman who opened fire inside an Aurora, Colo., movie theater because of concerns they had been “tainted” by hearing or discussing news reports about the case during breaks from the trial. One dismissed juror said in court that her husband had called her to ask about reports of an errant Twitter message the district attorney in the case sent last week. Judge Carlos A. Samour Jr. had reprimanded the district attorney, George Brauchler, for his message outside the presence of the jury. The judge has warned jurors dozens of times not to discuss the death-penalty case or read about it, and to tell him if they accidentally hear any of its details outside the courtroom. Twelve jurors and nine alternates remain on the panel.

headline: San Francisco’s New All-Natural Boutique Isn’t for Hippies
abstract: Credo, the brainchild of a member of the executive team that first brought Sephora to the U.S., doesn't want you to sacrifice style for substance.
lead_paragraph: In certain hip neighborhoods of certain hip cities, an eco-beauty boutique is nearly as likely a sight as a single-origin coffee bar. But although green has gone mainstream, until now, many sustainability-oriented apothecaries have been more focused on niche items than necessities. That, however, is set to change with the arrival of Credo, a new natural and organic emporium whose first location has just opened on San Francisco’s Fillmore Street. The brainchild of Shashi Batra, a member of the executive team that first brought Sephora to the U.S., Credo offers an experience similar to that of the LVMH-owned superstore, minus the synthetic ingredients. “You may want your tomatoes farm-to-table, but I don’t think you should get your eye shadow or mascara farm-to-table,” Batra explains. “It should be in a place where you can test it and feel good about it. It shouldn’t be in bottles that look like dog shampoo. It shouldn’t smell like tree sap. It has to deliver on all those levels.”

headline: At the New York Botanical Garden, Jenny Holzer Channels Frida Kahlo
abstract: The contemporary artist debuted a new program of text projections to coincide with the exhibition “Art, Garden, Life.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m getting a free drink for using other people’s writing!” marveled the artist Jenny Holzer earlier this week, ahead of a dinner last night at the New York Botanical Garden. The occasion served a double purpose for the artist, who was honored by the Poetry Society of America and also premiered a new program of text projections, which will continue to scroll over the glass walls of the garden’s exhibition hall starting at dusk each day through Saturday.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 A.M. (IFC) INTOLERABLE CRUELTY (2003) George Clooney plays Miles Massey, the crème de la crème of divorce lawyers, in this Joel and Ethan Coen film. Catherine Zeta-Jones, above with Mr. Clooney, is Marylin, a silken beauty and Miles’s latest client, who becomes mired in a vicious divorce after she catches her husband (Edward Herrmann) cheating yet again. Billy Bob Thornton is her millionaire beau and Miles’s rival for her money-hungry affections. “The Coens, bless their hearts, are too smart to apologize for avarice — it’s what gave screwball comedies a kick, and sends this movie straight to your head,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “Keep in mind that it’s only a minor rush, but a rush nonetheless. It has a Jell-O-shot smoothness that makes you a little dizzy afterward in recollecting how assured and unremittingly smart ‘Intolerable Cruelty’ is.” In “Fantastic Mr. Fox” (2009), at 1:15 p.m., Mr. Clooney, Meryl Streep, Jason Schwartzman and Bill Murray lend their voices to this animated tale from Wes Anderson, adapted with Noah Baumbach from the Roald Dahl “anti-fable” about a fox who rallies his animal friends against three evil farmers. “It is precisely the movie that a child smitten with Roald Dahl’s fiction and fascinated by the enigmas of the adult world would dream of making: something to amaze and terrify the grown-ups and win the envy and adulation of his peers,” A. O. Scott wrote in The Times.

headline: Selected Poems by Juan Felipe Herrera
abstract: Poems by Mr. Herrera, the newly named poet laureate.
lead_paragraph: Poems by Juan Felipe Herrera, the newly named poet laureate.

headline: Juan Felipe Herrera, From Farm Fields to Poet Laureate
abstract: The son of migrant farmworkers, Mr. Herrera writes experimental poems that focus on Mexican-American identity.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday that Juan Felipe Herrera, a son of migrant farmworkers whose writing fuses wide-ranging experimentalism with reflections on Mexican-American identity, will be the next poet laureate.

headline: Juan Felipe Herrera, Poet Laureate With a Working-Class Voice Meant to Be Spoken
abstract: Mr. Herrera, who was named poet laureate of the United States on Wednesday, understands people who are drained from the day’s hassle.
lead_paragraph: The poet laureate of the United States — PLOTUS, in the lingo — tends to be busy, Howard Nemerov once said, because he or she spends so much time explaining what the job entails.

headline: New York Police Detective Shoots Gunman Who Wounded Man
abstract: A 26-year-old gunman was shot by police after he shot and injured a 21-year-old man in East Harlem, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A New York police detective in plainclothes shot a 26-year-old man who had shot another man in East Harlem at about 8 p.m. on Tuesday, the authorities said.

headline: N.B.A. Finals: LeBron James and Cavaliers Hold Off Warriors
abstract: The injured, undermanned Cavaliers survived a late rally to escape with a victory and seize a two-games-to-one lead in the best-of-seven series.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The game operations staff at Quicken Loans Arena chronicled Stephen Curry’s slow walk back to the visitors’ locker room late Tuesday by showing a few of his halting steps on the Humongotron, the enormous, flame-spewing video board that looms over the court here.

headline: Survey Points to Challenges NATO Faces Over Russia
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A substantial number of Europeans do not believe that their own countries should rush to defend an ally against attack, according to a comprehensive survey to be made public on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As NATO faces a resurgent Russian military, a substantial number of Europeans do not believe that their own countries should rush to defend an ally against attack, according to a comprehensive survey to be made public on Wednesday.

headline: 메르스 바이러스 확산 경로: 첫 환자가 여러 병원을 방문해
abstract: 한국은 중동호흡증후군(MERS)이 급속히 확산하기에 이상적인 곳일 수 있습니다. 한국의 병원 응급실에는 병상과 의자가 다닥다닥 붙어있고, 환자들은 여러 병원들을 골라 다닙니다.
lead_paragraph: 서울, 대한민국 — 의사들은 처음엔 이 68세 노인의 증상을 폐렴이라고 생각했다. 기침과 호흡곤란을 호소하며 병원 네 곳을 전전하던 환자였다. 실은 훨씬 심각하고 전염성이 강한 병이라는 걸 보건 당국이 알게 된 건 아흐레가 지난 뒤였다.

headline: How to Beat the Bots
keywords: ['Vocational Training', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy']
abstract: We have the workers. We have the jobs. Now we just need an employment dating service.
lead_paragraph: So here’s an interesting statistic from a 2014 labor survey by burning-glass.com: 65 percent of new job postings for executive secretaries and executive assistants now call for a bachelor’s degree, but “only 19 percent of those currently employed in these roles have a B.A.” So four-fifths of secretaries today would not be considered for two-thirds of the job postings in their own field because they do not have a four-year degree to do the job they are already doing! The study noted that an “increasing number of job seekers face being shut out of middle-skill, middle-class occupations by employers’ rising demand for a bachelor’s degree” as a job-qualifying badge — even though it may be irrelevant, or in no way capture someone’s true capabilities, or where perhaps two quick online courses would be sufficient.

abstract: A lawyer who represents detainees says he is not convinced that trials in federal courts would be fairer than military commissions.

headline: Let’s Help Create More Farmers
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Land Use Policies', 'Student Loans', 'Sustainable Living', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: We have to do something about the primary obstacle, which is the high cost of land.
lead_paragraph: Just about everyone agrees that we need more farmers. Currently, nearly 30 percent are 65 or older, and fewer than 10 percent are under 35. The number of farmers is likely to fall further with continuing consolidation and technological innovation.

headline: Who Gets to Go to the Pool?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Discrimination', 'Water', 'Swimming Pools', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: A white cop, black teenagers and this country’s long history of water as a site of racial anxiety.
lead_paragraph: IN a 1948 speech to fellow Dixiecrats, Strom Thurmond famously declared that the entire United States Army couldn’t force white Southerners to allow black people “into our theaters, into our swimming pools, into our homes, and into our churches.”

keywords: ['Editorials', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Credit and Debt', 'Consumer Protection', 'Colleges and Universities', 'For-Profit Schools']
abstract: The government needs to do more to shield people from predatory schools.
lead_paragraph: Education Secretary Arne Duncan’s decision to forgive the federal loans of tens of thousands of students who attended Corinthian Colleges will provide relief for those who were seduced into taking on debt in exchange for degrees and certificates that turned out to be useless.

headline: Saving Affordable Health Insurance
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: If the Supreme Court rules against subsidies, states will have to find ways to protect Americans’ health care, but it won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act, which has helped millions of people get health care, is now fully woven into the nation’s social fabric. As President Obama said Tuesday, there is something “deeply cynical about the ceaseless, endless, partisan attempts” to roll back the progress already made.

keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: When my friend wanted to end her life, an aid-in-dying law could have helped.
lead_paragraph: The California Senate’s passage of the End of Life Option Act last week, which would allow terminally ill people to choose to end their lives, filled me with both joy and sadness.

headline: Jeb Bush Says Staff Shuffle Was Based on Skills
abstract: In his first remarks on the moves, he pleaded for patience and played down the idea that he was displeased with his standing in a crowded Republican field.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Jeb Bush said Wednesday that he felt compelled to reorganize his political team — and pick a new, unexpected campaign manager — “based on the skills of people that I got to know” and the “magnitude of the journey” he faces as a candidate.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Kendrick Lamar, Rapper Who Inspired a Teacher, Visits a High School That Embraces His Work
abstract: Who would you want to visit your school to meet with students?
lead_paragraph: In “Kendrick Lamar, Rapper Who Inspired a Teacher, Visits a High School That Embraces His Work,” Colleen Wright reports on an out-of-the-ordinary school visit.

headline: The German Government’s Surveillance Hypocrisy
abstract: The Germans have secretly helped the N.S.A., even as they condemned U.S. spying in Europe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Over the last few weeks Germany has been rocked by a series of leaked government documents revealing new details on the extensive cooperation between the German foreign intelligence service and the National Security Agency, including spying on other European governments. At the same time, emails leaked to the news media have revealed that a promised “no spy” agreement, under negotiation since the revelation in 2013 of N.S.A. surveillance on German government officials, was nowhere close to completion, contrary to explicit claims by the office of Angela Merkel, the chancellor.

headline: Rocket Attack in Afghanistan Kills Civilian With U.S. Defense Dept.
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The employee, identified as Krissie K. Davis, 54, of Talladega, Ala., worked for the Pentagon agency managing the withdrawal of wartime equipment.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A civilian employee of the Defense Department was killed this week during a rocket attack on Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul, a spokesman for the United States military said on Wednesday.

headline: Tokio Marine of Japan Agrees to Acquire HCC Insurance for $7.5 Billion
abstract: The deal would expand Tokio Marine’s business in the United States and broaden its specialty product lines.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tokio Marine Holdings of Japan said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire HCC Insurance Holdings for $7.5 billion in cash in its latest bid to build on its business in the United States, the world’s largest insurance market.

headline: What Buildings Do You Love? What Buildings Do You Hate?
abstract: Has a building ever inspired strong emotion in you?
lead_paragraph: Has a building ever inspired strong emotion in you? For example, maybe the soaring space inside a church has awed you, or the coziness of a loved one’s house has comforted you. Or perhaps there is a building in your hometown or in a city you’ve visited that you’ve instantly felt repelled by for some reason.

headline: China’s Troubling Robot Revolution
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Will automation gut the country’s labor force, just as it needs consumer spending to bolster economic growth?
lead_paragraph: OVER the last decade, China has become, in the eyes of much of the world, a job-eating monster, consuming entire industries with its seemingly limitless supply of low-wage workers. But the reality is that China is now shifting its appetite to robots, a transition that will have significant consequences for China’s economy — and the world’s.

headline: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Family-Centric Community
abstract: The incorporated village of about six square miles 30 miles up the Hudson River, is known for excellent schools and expansive homes.
lead_paragraph: The borders of Briarcliff Manor aren’t always clear to newcomers, but something else is quickly evident: why so many of their neighbors have lived there so long.

headline: Support for Boston’s 2024 Olympic Bid Slips, Along With Time to Reverse It
abstract: A new poll shows that just 39 percent of voters statewide support the bid, while 49 percent oppose it.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — More bad news arrived Wednesday for the boosters of Boston’s bid to host the 2024 Summer Olympics: A new poll shows that just 39 percent of voters statewide support the bid, while 49 percent oppose it.

headline: Half-Days Fill Final Stretch of New York’s School Year
abstract: Quirks in the calendar can make it seem as though school is more off than on in June.
lead_paragraph: It is June, summer is tantalizingly close, and yet New York City public school students are still in class, looking longingly out the window while cramming in a few last weeks’ worth of material.

headline: Why I’m Breaking Up With the Apple Watch
abstract: After a six-week dalliance with a handsome, much-ballyhooed new suitor (a.k.a. the Apple Watch), a writer decides to move on.
lead_paragraph: I wanted it to work. I wanted to fall in love, like so many of my friends. “It takes a while,” they said. “Don’t expect a coup de foudre. Let it build over time.”

headline: Brothers of ‘The Wolfpack’ Step Out of Their World
abstract: The documentary, directed by Crystal Moselle, follows a group of siblings who were locked up in their Manhattan apartment for years.
lead_paragraph: Much has changed in the Angulo family since Crystal Moselle finished filming its extraordinary tale for her documentary, “The Wolfpack.”

headline: Nesting, the Vice Media Way
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Searching for zombie powder, interviewing PCP makers; it’s all in a day’s work for two correspondents for Vice Media who share a Brooklyn loft.
lead_paragraph: Hamilton Morris has had some truly terrible roommates: the guy who overindulged on synthetic cannabinoids and covered the apartment with vomit; the one who locked himself out while naked (how and why is still unclear) and broke down the front door; and the Dumpster diver who brought home 50 boxes of crackers teeming with moths, which led to a vicious infestation that Mr. Morris, 28, believes has still not entirely cleared up.

headline: A Valedictory to a House for Brotherhood and Fashion
abstract: Nationally known as the home of “Project Runway,” Brotherhood House in Manhattan was barely remembered by its name, or as a crucible of social advocacy in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: It is only 53 years old, but the cornerstone of a doomed building in Manhattan’s garment district reads like an impossibly hopeful sentiment from a distant time, from a world that can never be recovered.

headline: The Burden of Bail
abstract: When Dominick Torrence was arrested in Baltimore and unable to make bail set at $250,000, his girlfriend was faced with child care and other responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: When Dominick Torrence was arrested in Baltimore and unable to make bail set at $250,000, his girlfriend was faced with child care and other responsibilities.

headline: When Bail Is Out of Defendant’s Reach, Other Costs Mount
keywords: ['Bail', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Income Inequality', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Money bail, entrenched in most jurisdictions, is under new scrutiny, with some critics decrying what they see as racial and financial inequities.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Dominick Torrence, who has lived in this city all his life, has a long rap sheet for dealing drugs but no history of violence. So when he was charged with disorderly conduct and rioting on April 28, a night of unrest after Freddie Gray was fatally injured in police custody, he was shocked to learn the amount he would need to make bail: $250,000, the same amount as two of the officers facing charges over Mr. Gray’s death.

headline: Clemency for Raif Badawi
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Corporal Punishment']
abstract: A depraved sentence of 1,000 lashes for a Saudi blogger is a huge disgrace for Saudi rulers.
lead_paragraph: The decision on Sunday by Saudi Arabia’s Supreme Court to uphold the depraved sentence imposed on the blogger Raif Badawi last May by the criminal court in Jidda is tantamount to a death sentence for the “crime” of free expression. The criminal court sentenced Mr. Badawi, whose case has invited worldwide condemnation, to 1,000 lashes, 50 to be administered “very harshly,” in public, once a week for 20 weeks. In addition, he is to serve 10 years in prison and pay a fine of 1 million riyals, about $267,000.

headline: Jeb Bush, in Berlin, Says West Is Confronting a ‘More Aggressive’ Putin
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Jeb Bush labeled President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a “bully” and said that attempts to send him subtle signals were futile.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Jeb Bush said on Wednesday that the West was confronting a “different” Vladimir V. Putin from the man who has led Russia in the past, escalating his reproach of an adversary whose territorial ambitions have shaken the United States and its allies in Europe.

headline: Panasonic Healthcare to Buy Bayer’s Diabetes Business for $1.15 Billion
abstract: Bayer Diabetes Care has marketed and sold products manufactured by Panasonic Healthcare for decades.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Panasonic Healthcare Holdings of Japan said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire the German drug maker Bayer’s diabetes care business for 1.02 billion euros, or about $1.15 billion.

headline: ‘The Fixer,’ by Joseph Finder
abstract: A reporter is drawn into a family mystery when he finds millions in his father’s home.
lead_paragraph: In the post-“Gone Girl” thriller era, you’ve got to move your domestic malice along with zip, vigor and a sharp eye for The Way We Live Now. So it serves Joseph Finder well that his new suspense novel ­includes tartly informed themes about adult children caring for elderly parents, and the state of print journalism. His protagonist, Rick Hoffman, has abandoned his career as an investigative reporter at a newspaper and now writes puff pieces for a Boston-based city magazine, one of those glossies that stay fat with ads supplementing their fawning-over-the-wealthy ­editorial content.

headline: ‘A Complex Fate: William L. Shirer and the American Century,’ by Ken Cuthbertson
abstract: A new biography traces William L. Shirer’s arc from intrepid foreign correspondent to blacklist victim to mega-best-selling author.
lead_paragraph: In November 1957, a Newsweek column called “Where Are They Now?” noted that William L. Shirer, “made famous by his nightly radio reports from Berlin during the early years of the war and by his book ‘Berlin Diary,’ has been off the air nearly 10 years and is now a writer and part-time lecturer.”

headline: The Downside of Treadmill Desks
abstract: Treadmill desks can be good exercise, but they may impair the ability to concentrate and remember.
lead_paragraph: Treadmill desks are popular, even aspirational, in many offices today since they can help those of us who are deskbound move more, burn extra calories and generally improve our health.

headline: Wednesday’s Travel News and Tips
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including a music and fitness program in Austin, Tex., and a new app to check out wine lists.
lead_paragraph: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: In Shift, U.S. Will Send 450 Advisers to Help Iraq Fight ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The Obama administration will send hundreds of additional military trainers to help Iraqi forces retake Ramadi and repel the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has authorized the deployment of up to 450 more American troops to Iraq to train and assist the Iraqi forces battling the Islamic State, the White House announced on Wednesday, signaling a major shift of focus in the fight against the Sunni militant group.

headline: New York Today: Kung Pao for Right Now
abstract: Wednesday: Fun with your Chinese food, summery weather, and the fortune cookie.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this bright Wednesday.

headline: With Decision Near on Hong Kong Elections, Beijing Affirms Its Case
abstract: Hong Kong legislators are expected to vote soon on a proposal to allow all eligible residents to vote for the city’s leader, but only from a candidate list vetted by Beijing loyalists.
lead_paragraph: By the end of next week, residents of Hong Kong will probably know how their next leader will be selected, and People’s Daily has reminded readers — twice in recent days, in front-page editorials — that Beijing has already presented the only acceptable framework for the 2017 election.

headline: Michelle Kwan to Join Hillary Clinton’s Campaign
abstract: Michelle Kwan, a former figure skater and Olympic medal winner, will work from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s Brooklyn headquarters on outreach efforts.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign is getting a famous new staff member.

headline: The Decade Behind
abstract: What I got, what I didn’t.
lead_paragraph: While cleaning out my Princeton office, I became all too aware of the ephemeral nature of policy writing. A depressingly large share of the books on my shelves consisted of 30 years’ worth of books about the crucial decade ahead. Oh well. But as I added all those books to the giveaway pile, I found myself doing a bit of self-referential and maybe self-indulgent thinking, not about the decade ahead, but about the decade behind.

headline: The Decade Behind
abstract: What I got, what I didn’t.
lead_paragraph: While cleaning out my Princeton office, I became all too aware of the ephemeral nature of policy writing. A depressingly large share of the books on my shelves consisted of 30 years’ worth of books about the crucial decade ahead. Oh well. But as I added all those books to the giveaway pile, I found myself doing a bit of self-referential and maybe self-indulgent thinking, not about the decade ahead, but about the decade behind.

headline: Notes on Walmart and Wages (Wonkish)
abstract: The invisible hand’s surprisingly loose grip.
lead_paragraph: Walmart reports that its recent wage hike is paying off via reduced turnover, which produces cost savings that offset the direct expense of the higher wages. In other words, efficiency wage theory is vindicated. What are the political/policy implications? What follows is a slightly wonkish note, largely to myself.

headline: Malaysia Detains 4 Westerners Accused of Taking Nude Photos on Mountain
abstract: Some local officials have been quoted as suspecting a connection between the trekkers’ behavior and an earthquake weeks later that killed 18 people.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Four Western trekkers who were accused of taking nude photographs on Malaysia’s highest peak were ordered detained on Wednesday pending an investigation into public obscenity charges, their lawyer said.

headline: Illuminating North Korea
abstract: A photographer parts the curtains on one of the world’s least-known places and brings back pictures of a country that is defined for many by mystery and war.
lead_paragraph: A photographer parts the curtains on one of the world’s least-known places and brings back pictures of a country that is defined for many by mystery and war.

headline: Sorrow Revisits Town as Students Killed in Germanwings Crash Are Brought Home
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The 16 high school students and two teachers from Haltern am See, Germany, were among the first 44 of the 150 victims of the crash in the French Alps to be repatriated
lead_paragraph: HALTERN AM SEE, Germany — In this town of some 37,000 people, small enough for everyone to know someone who lost a daughter, grandson, niece or neighbor in the Germanwings crash on March 24, the procession of white hearses on Wednesday signaled a beginning and an end.

headline: European Businesses Hit by China’s Cooling Economy
abstract: Nearly 40 percent of European companies in China that were surveyed were planning to cut costs, and 61 percent of those said they would do so through layoffs.
lead_paragraph: China’s economic slowdown is the greatest challenge facing the European companies in the country, with about one in four planning layoffs and nearly one in six reporting falling revenue in 2014, according to the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China.

headline: Hedgehog Toothpicks and Other Everyday Objects From North Korea
abstract: In his more than 40 trips to North Korea since 2000, David Guttenfelder has collected and photographed objects he has encountered in his travels through the country.
lead_paragraph: In his more than 40 trips to North Korea since 2000, David Guttenfelder has collected and photographed objects he has encountered in his travels through the country.

headline: Travel Help for Families With Special Needs
abstract: Meghann Harris is the founder of SpecialGlobe.com, a new travel website for families with children who have physical and cognitive challenges.
lead_paragraph: Trekking into the great unknown is exhilarating for most, but if you are the parent of a child with special needs, the unknown is your biggest obstacle, said Meghann Harris, 47, the senior founder of SpecialGlobe.com, a new travel website for families of children with physical and cognitive challenges. “These families just aren’t traveling,” she said. “They fear what services are out there, whether their child will be welcomed by the world; they get caught up in thinking their child is too loud, too impatient, a runner.”

headline: A Taste of Taiwan
abstract: The mysteries of three-cup chicken explained.
lead_paragraph: The chicken is tender and velvety, a little crisp at its edges, surrounded by coins of ginger and cloves of garlic. The sauce is dark and pungent — soy sauce cut through with aged rice wine and studded with bits of scallion, perfect for ladling onto rice. There is a sweetness in there as well, sugar and sesame against the salt of the soy, with a faint hit of peppery fire. A handful or two of Thai basil added at the end imparts a floral punch.

headline: See and Be Seen
abstract: Glasses, once a nerdy punchline, have become a personal statement — the bigger the better.
lead_paragraph: More intimate than underpants precisely because they are plain for all to see, eyeglasses are no mere detail of costume. Acting as a mask that fuses with the features, glasses serve as a spotlight or a proscenium arch or a stage for the soul in the theater of everyday life. The bespectacled face asks the world to see it a certain way by telling the world something about how it is seen.

headline: The Lobbying Bonanza
abstract: The success of lobbyists representing the political agenda of the corporate sector in Washington is transforming the landscape of the city itself.
lead_paragraph: A once-decrepit section of downtown Washington has become a luxury marketplace, feeding off the lavishly paid men and women successfully representing the political agenda of the corporate sector.

headline: Today in Politics:  Court Ruling Removes a Bump From Chris Christie’s Path
abstract: The House is continuing to consider the trade bill and President Obama is making a fiery defense of his health care law ahead of a Supreme Court ruling.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where House Republicans face a crucial decision on trade and President Obama is making a fiery defense of his health care law ahead of a Supreme Court ruling. But another court’s ruling could breathe new life into Gov. Chris Christie‘s presidential hopes.

headline: U.S. Shifts Stance on Drug Pricing in Pacific Trade Pact Talks, Document Reveals
abstract: A newly leaked Trans-Pacific Trade Partnership annex dated December 2014 reveals the Obama administration is no longer demanding protection for pharmaceutical prices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing resistance from Pacific trading partners, the Obama administration is no longer demanding protection for pharmaceutical prices under the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership, according to a newly leaked section of the proposed trade accord.

headline: Live, From North Korea
abstract: During a recent trip to North Korea, the photographer David Guttenfelder used his smartphone to stream live video from his hotel room.

headline: Do I Have to Keep a Secret About a Family Member’s Health?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Medicine and Health', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The Ethicists consider if and when to share someone else’s medical news.
lead_paragraph: My uncle’s daughter texted this message to me a few days ago: “You didn’t hear this from me, and pretend this conversation didn’t take place. My dad went to the hospital this morning in an ambulance with a heart attack. My mom told me not to tell anyone, saying this is Dad’s news to tell, but I thought you would want to know. Whatever you do, please don’t tell your mom.” My uncle and I are very close, so I understand why his daughter would think I would want to know. Telling me this news when she was asked not to is her own ethical problem to resolve. However, knowing this information puts me in a very awkward position. Should I tell my 82-year-old mother about her 70-year-old brother’s health crisis? She would surely want to know this tidbit of info. Or do I honor my uncle’s family’s wishes not to tell my mother? How do we react when we’re officially told the news of the heart attack? If we pretend not to know anything happened, we’re lying, and that in itself is unethical. Or do we reply that we were told? NAME WITHHELD

headline: With U.S. as a Model, China Envisions Network of National Parks

The national parks program eventually expanded to include more than 450 sites and has become one of the country’s greatest tourist draws.

headline: Morning Agenda: China Moves Closer to Inclusion in MSCI Index
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments', 'Hedge Funds', 'Indexers and Indexing', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Insurance', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: China Moves Closer to Inclusion in MSCI Index | Wall Street Embraces Financial Tech Start-Ups | Tokio Marine to Buy HCC for $7.5 Billion | G.E. Sells Buyout Financing Unit for $12 Billion
lead_paragraph: CHINA MOVES CLOSER TO INCLUSION IN MSCI INDEX | Though MSCI decided on Tuesday that it would hold off on adding Chinese domestic shares to its emerging market index, China is moving closer to joining the global benchmark,  Neil Gough writes in DealBook. In its decision, the index company cited concerns over China’s cumbersome investment quotas, restrictions on money flows, and questions over the legal status of foreign shareholders. But MSCI said that in the coming months it would work with China’s main securities regulator to address the company’s concerns and that it may make a special decision to include Chinese stocks, also known as A-shares, in its benchmarks before the next scheduled annual review, which takes place a year from now. “It is clear from MSCI’s announcement today that it is only a matter of time before A-shares are added to global indexes,” Louis Lu, a portfolio manager at CSOP Asset Management, which invests in mainland shares, said in an email.

headline: A Guide to Reading Rituals
abstract: A new picture book is a “how to" manual for little people who have just gotten the hang of reading.
lead_paragraph: Agreed: We need to do more than just help children learn to read —we need to help them learn to love reading and make reading a habit, even a craving. But in many schools — unintentionally, tragically — a kind of creeping police state emerges around reading. It’s not enough for some teachers to tell children to read for, say, 20 minutes or half an hour each night. Many children must report back with a “reading log” in which they record not just the titles and authors of the books they’ve read, but also the number of minutes spent reading and pages read. Never mind that this exercise turns something private and immeasurable into a piece of data. Isn’t it teaching, above all, the art of the fudge?

headline: A Graceful Midcentury Armchair by Gio Ponti
abstract: The D.154.2 chair is a manifestation of the Italian master’s twin ideals of harmony and joy.
lead_paragraph: While he may be best known for the harmonica-like Pirelli Tower and the perfectly simple Superleggera chair, the midcentury design giant Gio Ponti was also a master of more organic and sensuous forms. His favorite commission was Villa Planchart, situated above Caracas, a building “made for the life of its inhabitants,” which he filled with silks, jades and orchids. The building, he wrote, “must have the grace and lightness of a resting butterfly.” The same could be said of the armchair he made for the villa in 1954, which hovers on slender legs, its arms swooping like wings. (An all-white version floated in the entrance; one with a plush green cushion perched in the living room.) Now in production by the Italian design house Molteni & C, the D.154.2 chair is an immediate and understated classic — a manifestation of Ponti’s twin ideals of harmony and joy.

headline: 1965: U.S. Suffers War’s Worst Loss
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. army and South Vietnamese suffer huge losses at Dong Xoai, 1965.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — A Viet Cong force of 1,500 today [June 10] overran a district capital and Special Forces camp 60 miles north of Saigon, inflicting the heaviest toll of U.S. combat casualties of the war. At least 27 Americans as well as hundreds of South Vietnamese were killed, wounded or missing, after a day-long battle at Dong Xoai in which the guerrillas routed the government defenders and then mowed down their reinforcements with a curtain of machine-gun fire. There were conflicting reports on the U.S. casualty breakdown. The number of dead ranged from a State Department report in Washington of seven dead and 13 wounded to an official Saigon report of eight dead, ten missing and 13 wounded. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 11, 1965

headline: Disunion: The Final Q & A
abstract: Four years ago, Disunion convened a panel of experts to discuss the outbreak of the Civil War. Now, those experts are back to discuss the war’s end, and its legacy.
lead_paragraph: In April 2011, the editors of Disunion, The New York Times’s series on the Civil War, convened a panel of historians to mark the 150th anniversary of the Confederate assault on Fort Sumter and the onset of the four-year conflict. Before a sold-out audience at the Times Center in New York City, the panelists – David Blight, Ken Burns, Adam Goodheart and Jamie Malanowski – discussed the origins of the conflict, the role of slavery and the immense challenges facing a still-new president.

headline: At Ohio Festival, a Tale of the Duct Tape
abstract: The Avon Heritage Duck Tape Festival is a celebration of duct tape with a parade, a fashion show and a scavenger hunt.
lead_paragraph: It calls itself the Duct Tape Capital of the World, and for good reason: Avon, Ohio, about a half-hour west of Cleveland, draws more than 60,000 duct tape enthusiasts annually from across the globe. The city, home to Duck brand duct tape, celebrates the shiny, sticky utility material each Father’s Day weekend with the Avon Heritage Duck Tape Festival, scheduled this year for June 19 to 21.

headline: DNA Deciphers Roots of Modern Europeans
keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: The results of two DNA studies indicate that today’s Europeans descend from three groups of people who moved into Europe at different stages of history.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, archaeologists have reconstructed the early history of Europe by digging up ancient settlements and examining the items that their inhabitants left behind. More recently, researchers have been scrutinizing something even more revealing than pots, chariots and swords: DNA.

headline: ‘Dope’ Revisits the ’Hood, With Joy and Wit
abstract: The film is a repudiation of and a reconciliation with streetwise black cinema of the early 1990s, movies like “Juice,” “Boyz N the Hood” and “Menace II Society.”
lead_paragraph: When Shameik Moore got the part of Malcolm, the soft guy in a tough world at the heart of the film “Dope,” he had a problem.

headline: Airlines Want Your Carry-On Bags to Be Smaller
abstract: At its annual summit in Miami Tuesday, the International Air Transport Association suggested a new standard for carry-on luggage, and it’s not getting larger.
lead_paragraph: The future of your favorite carry-on bag may be precarious. At its annual summit in Miami Tuesday, the International Air Transport Association suggested a new standard for carry-on luggage to be stowed in overhead bins, and it’s not getting larger.

keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Luxury Goods and Services']

headline: Review: ‘Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell,’ a Battlefield Where Magic Is the Weapon of Choice
abstract: This BBC America mini-series focuses on two magicians: Norrell, a humorless man obsessed with scholarship, and Strange, a natural talent who becomes Norrell’s student.
lead_paragraph: When the Duke of Wellington meets Jonathan Strange, the magician sent to the Continent from England to help him defeat Napoleon, he is not impressed. “What I chiefly require, sir, is more artillery and more men,” he barks at Strange. “Can you make them appear?” Unable to fill the general’s request, Strange offers instead to make it rain.

headline: Michelle Obama Talks About Race and Success, and Makes It Personal
abstract: The first lady has been opening up about her own struggles and the “insults and slights” that even living in the White House has not protected her family from.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — She looked around and saw herself three decades ago, young and uncertain, from a part of town where success is a struggle, not a birthright. She knew what they had been through, what it was like to take the long way home to avoid gangs, what it was like when the family strained to make ends meet.

headline: Kurds Have Bigger Prize in Mind After Political Gains in Turkey
abstract: After winning seats in Turkey’s Parliament, many Kurds hope the political empowerment will lead one day to the establishment of a Kurdish state.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Late into the night on Sunday on the shattered streets of Kobani, the Syrian Kurdish city devastated last year by battles with militants affiliated with the Islamic State, residents celebrated the outcome of the recent Turkish parliamentary election, honking horns, cheering and firing their guns.

headline: Trailers for 'Dope' and Other Movies in the Hood

headline: 36 Hours in Zagreb, Croatia
abstract: No longer just a stop on the way to the coast, Croatia’s capital has seen a surge in popularity, with lounges, bistros and chic designer ateliers in an Old World setting.
lead_paragraph: For years, Zagreb, Croatia’s chief city, was a layover on the way to the country’s island-studded coast. No more. Tourism had shot up more than 20 percent from 2011 to 2013, when Croatia joined the European Union. Accompanying that rise is a raft of modernized and recently built lodgings, including some three dozen hostels — important additions to the town’s once-inadequate accommodation scene. For those who fell in love with Zagreb, population 790,000, before its surge in popularity, fear not. Though the town has rejiggered its offerings with jazzy lounges, bistros and chic clothes-designer ateliers, this Slavic metropolis along the Sava River still retains plenty of cobbled-street charm.

headline: Billington’s Letter to President Obama
abstract: James Hadley Billington will step down from his post on Jan. 1 after nearly three decades leading the world’s largest library.
lead_paragraph: James Hadley Billington will step down from his post on Jan. 1 after nearly three decades leading the world’s largest library.

headline: In Washington Speech, Chris Christie Sounds as if He’s Ready to Run
abstract: In a speech in Washington, Gov. Chris Christie on Wednesday sounded like he was ready to join the presidential race, saying that he wanted to be part of “the leadership that brings our country to new heights.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told reporters on Tuesday that his family was completely supportive of a potential presidential run; his decision hinged on his will to do it.

headline: More Play or More Academics for Kindergarten?
abstract: Kindergarteners in more affluent districts are returning to play, while academics still rules in lower-income areas.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve watched a succession of siblings go through kindergarten, you may have noticed that things have changed, and are still changing. As Motoko Rich writes in Kindergartens Ringing the Bell for Play Inside the Classroom, after a national movement toward more academics in that first year of school, many kindergartens are bringing back play: sand tables, blocks, easels, toy kitchens.

abstract: The jazz pianist’s new album uses a traditional framework while demolishing the usual notions of conservatism.

abstract: The company, which makes the prized Moog synthesizer in North Carolina, is instituting a stock ownership plan for workers.
lead_paragraph: At the Moog synthesizer factory in Asheville, N.C., on Tuesday, Michael Adams, the company’s owner and chief executive, wanted to share some life-changing news with the entire staff.

headline: Review: In ‘ROBOT,’ Machines Perform With Humans at BAM
abstract: There are eight people dancing, but this 90-minute production perks up when the robots arrive.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old vaudeville adage cautioning adult performers against sharing a stage with children or animals. The warning needs an update: Never do a show with adorable toddler-size robots.

headline: 1963: Timothy Leary’s Long, Strange Trip
abstract: Mark Bulik shares some of the first mentions of Timothy Leary and his LSD experiments in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Jenny Diski’s End Notes
abstract: The English writer is facing death the only way she knows how: line by line.
lead_paragraph: Last July, when the English writer Jenny Diski was told she had inoperable lung cancer and, at best, another three years to live, she responded to the news characteristically — that is, in wry poor taste. “So,” she said, turning to her husband, the poet and academic Ian Patterson, “we’d better get cooking the meth.” The Poet — as Diski always refers to Patterson, with tender-ironic reserve, in her personal essays — was just about able to keep up his end of the morbid repartee that is the currency of their marriage: “This time we quit while the going’s good.” The oncologist and the nurse, apparently not watchers of “Breaking Bad,” looked on blankly.

headline: Fountains of Youth
abstract: Turning back the clock can be as simple as sipping a drink.
lead_paragraph: There are all sorts of magical creams and serums that promise tighter skin and fewer lines, but a new fad in cosmetics suggests that turning back the clock can be as simple as sipping a drink. The Beauty Chef’s Collagen Inner Beauty Boost mixes the wrinkle smoother with superfoods such as goji berries and acai berries. Beauty & Go’s grape-flavored Radiance drink is meant to improve elasticity with hyaluronic acid. For the follically challenged, there’s Fountain’s Hair Molecule, a silicon and biotin liquid that can be taken alone or mixed with a morning smoothie to produce extra strength and shine. The most too-good-to-be-true of the bunch comes in a six-pack: Precious, a collagen-infused beer from the Japanese brewery Suntory, is aimed at women who desire a healthy — and perhaps tipsy — glow.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Calls Out Education Department Over Student Loans
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren took the Department of Education to task on Wednesday for what she called a lack of transparency and failure to protect students from for-profit colleges.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren took the Department of Education to task on Wednesday for what she called a lack of transparency and failure to protect students from dangerous student loan servicers and for-profit colleges.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government is ready to exit the banking business, even if it means that it will record a loss on some of its holdings.

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Albert Woodfox has been close to the outside before, but rarely this close.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The police officer in McKinney, Tex., who resigned after a cellphone video was circulated showing him shoving a black teenager in a bikini to the ground outside a pool party offered an apology Wednesday through his lawyer, who tried to explain the officer’s actions by saying that he was under stress after responding to two earlier calls involving a suicide and a suicide attempt.

headline: Review: ‘Nabokov in America’ and Reaping Inspiration From Amber Waves
abstract: A writer argues that Vladimir Nabokov’s dive into American life and literary traditions informed and improved his work.
lead_paragraph: His private tragedy, Vladimir Nabokov once declared, was that “I had to abandon my natural idiom, my untrammeled, rich, and infinitely docile Russian tongue for a second-rate brand of English, devoid of any of those apparatuses — the baffling mirror, the black velvet backdrop, the implied associations and traditions — which the native illusionist, frac-tails flying, can magically use to transcend the heritage his own way.”

abstract: The artist created new work to coincide with the garden’s exhibition “Frida Kahlo: Art, Garden, Life.”

headline: Copa América Set to Begin Under a Cloud of Corruption Allegations

lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Just outside the gates to the field where Chile’s national men’s soccer team prepared for Thursday’s opening game of the Copa América, Cecilia Amaya, a second-grade teacher here, handed out small slips of paper bearing a list of demands.

headline: An Art Book from Devendra Banhart that’s as Eclectic as the Man Himself
abstract: “I Left My Noodle on Ramen Street” is part monograph, part scrapbooked personal history.
lead_paragraph: Devendra Banhart is exactly the sort of person for whom the term “multihyphenate” was coined. Though he’s attained a measure of mainstream notoriety as a musician, his undergraduate degree is in the visual arts, and for the last 15 or so years he has been steadily building, and occasionally exhibiting, a parallel body of work around drawings, paintings and, more recently, photography. “When you dedicate enough time to anything,” Banhart explains, “if the motives aren’t 100 percent egoic, then some things start to come to fruition.”

lead_paragraph: Smartphones have turned us all into photographers. Now with the help of some apps, we can also be photo artists, framing our snaps and making collages.

lead_paragraph: Strolling in stiletto heels amid the audience members, Panti gauged the crowd packed into the little auditorium at the Irish Arts Center. Then she gave a warning: Anyone seeking “inspiring words of wisdom” from her show would leave disappointed.

lead_paragraph: Small companies have to be especially nimble in spotting and taking advantage of market shifts, and this week, Sarah Max delves into how one online jeweler introduced a new service that became an instant hit. It’s a great example of how scrappy start-ups are changing the way business is done in large, traditional industries.

headline: Review: ‘Afghanistan, Zimbabwe, America, Kuwait,’ as Grim as It Is Cryptic
abstract: Much remains unresolved in Daniel Talbott’s play, which includes brief scenes of mostly mundane interactions between American soldiers in a remote desert.
lead_paragraph: A pair of American soldiers manning a remote desert outpost find themselves unraveling under the pressure of heat, hunger, boredom and anxiety in “Afghanistan, Zimbabwe, America, Kuwait,” a new play written and directed by Daniel Talbott at the Gym at Judson. As grim as it is cryptic — it is never clear where exactly we are, or even if one of the titular countries is involved — the play gains some force from the intense performances of its cast, led by a particularly captivating Seth Numrich as the jumpier of the soldiers.

abstract: Two teams of doctors, in an important advance for precision medicine, say that traits should be looked at first, not tissue samples.
lead_paragraph: Doctors can more effectively treat many brain tumors by first ascertaining their genetic characteristics, rather than studying tissue samples under a microscope, the standard practice, two teams of researchers reported on Wednesday.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Four years after the clothing retailer went private with Millard Drexler leading, the deal shareholders received remains a complicated matter.
lead_paragraph: J. Crew, Michelle Obama’s sometime clothing retailer, is yet another struggling private equity buyout. J. Crew’s owners, TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners, are stuck, tied to the bargain they struck with the company’s chief executive, Millard S. Drexler. Call it the “great man” problem.

headline: Behind the Burden of Bail: Reporter’s Notebook
keywords: ['Bail', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Shaila Dewan describes the reporting that went in to her recent article about the American bail system.
lead_paragraph: Most news stories begin long before they capture the reporter’s attention, and they go on for long afterward. But sometimes the reporter is paying attention before a story comes to fruition.

headline: Review: ‘The Concept of Dust’ Features Yvonne Rainer’s Eclecticism
abstract: The varied hallmarks of Ms. Rainer, a choreographer who rose to fame in the 1960s, are present in her latest work.
lead_paragraph: The dancer-choreographer Yvonne Rainer became a historic figure in the 1960s. Then she was a pioneering figure of that nebulous genre that was later labeled postmodern dance. Today you can’t get far in understanding that area of dance experimentalism without considering either the 1965 manifesto in which she announced “No to spectacle. No to virtuosity. No to transformations and magic and make-believe” (and more) or the 1966 solo dance “Trio A,” in which her matter-of-fact delivery and elaborately pedestrian vocabulary became a radical classic.

headline: The Human Rights Watch Film Festival Explores Social Justice
keywords: ['Movies', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: This annual film series, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the IFC Center, provides a global perspective and a commitment to showcasing work about thorny issues.
lead_paragraph: The compelling documentaries that open and close this year’s Human Rights Watch Film Festival, which begins on Thursday, are valuable, coolheaded explorations of America’s racially charged climate. In an atmosphere poisoned by fear, mistrust and inflammatory rhetoric, the films provide calm, reasoned assessments of roiling tensions that are not about to subside. These and other serious documentaries are all the more welcome because they arrive at the start of Hollywood’s silly season, when the pickings are slim for thoughtful films about thorny issues. Many of these selections have been shown in previous festivals, but the agglomeration of so many hard-hitting films speaks for itself.
