lead_paragraph: The Senate made it loud and clear on Wednesday that a bipartisan majority wants the Export-Import Bank to survive past June 30, when the federal agency’s authorization expires.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Learning Curve on Russia
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Mr. Bush criticized the president’s approach, but if he wants to be taken seriously, he’ll need to come up with an alternative.
lead_paragraph: Few world leaders are easier to criticize these days than President Vladimir Putin of Russia. There can be no defense of his decision to annex Crimea, worsen Ukraine’s civil war by sending troops and weapons to the eastern region and threaten nuclear responses if NATO tries to deter his aggression.

headline: College Rape Prevention Program Proves a Rare Success
abstract: The program focused on first-year students at three Canadian campuses who attended sessions on assessing risk, learning self-defense and defining personal sexual boundaries.
lead_paragraph: A program that trained first-year female college students to avoid rape substantially lowered their risk of being sexually assaulted, a rare success against a problem that has been resistant to many prevention efforts, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: A Sampling of Work by a Wave of New Illustrators
abstract: Coloring clothes in delightful ways.
lead_paragraph: Coloring clothes in delightful ways.

headline: Hackers Go After Little Fish, Too, While Trawling for Credit Cards
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Credit Cards', 'Small Business', 'Restaurants', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Computer Security']
abstract: In their efforts to steal credit card data, hackers have taken aim at small businesses, like Eataly’s food halls, as well as retail giants like Target and Home Depot.
lead_paragraph: Hackers are going local in their efforts to steal credit card information from United States customers, hitting small businesses with as much frequency as retail giants.

headline: Bill Clinton Says He Will Stop Giving Paid Speeches if Hillary Wins
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton said that if his wife won the White House, he would no longer give paid speeches.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton has made millions of dollars giving paid speeches since he left office, but he said on Wednesday that if his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, won the White House, he would no longer take money for talking.

headline: Seeing Fashion With a Sketchpad and Markers
abstract: An unlikely new tribe of fashion-world darlings has emerged, as illustration is again en vogue in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Saks Fifth Avenue held a press breakfast at its flagship store to unveil its “glam gardens” spring window installations, designed by beauty and fragrance brands. The guests were the usual blasé mix of magazine editors, bloggers and fashion writers. And then there was Blair Breitenstein, who had an art-school tote around her shoulder and the nervous, wide-eyed, am-I-really-in-Oz? look of a fashion obsessive newly arrived in New York.

headline: New Ride Services Forge Own Specialized Paths
abstract: Built on the Uber model, these start-ups target niche markets like students and van-pooling.
lead_paragraph: When Trae Vassallo’s children hop in the car to head to their after-school sports practice in the San Francisco Bay Area several times a week, it is not Ms. Vassallo, a full-time working mother of three, who drives them. Nor is it her husband, a nanny or any other caregiver.

headline: ‘Tempest’ in Central Park
abstract: Public Theater hosts annual gala at Delacorte Theater.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, the Public Theater cleaned up at the Tony Awards, where its show “Fun Home,” won five of the big prizes, including best musical. On Tuesday, the the Public Theater held its annual benefit celebrating Shakespeare in the Park, with a star-studded crowd that included Jon Bon Jovi, who arrived around 6:30 p.m. See the photos, above.

headline: How’s My Driving? The Insurer Knows
abstract: “Telematics” devices that track driver behavior promise better pricing of insurance premiums, but they raise concerns about privacy and could penalize some groups of consumers.
lead_paragraph: Stop? Or gun it? Those are often the competing voices running through drivers’ heads when they approach a yellow light.

headline: A Futurist Looks at Where Cars Are Going
abstract: Eric Larsen, who heads research in society and technology at Mercedes-Benz Research and Development, says that family values and connectivity are important to the future of cars.
lead_paragraph: Eric Larsen heads research in society and technology at Mercedes-Benz Research and Development in Sunnyvale, Calif. Mr. Larsen, 53, who joined the carmaker in 1995, wrote his thesis for a Ph.D. in sociology at the University of Washington on the failure of innovation in the Communist world. Now he thinks about how Mercedes can sustain innovation as technology transforms luxury cars.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Here’s the latest.

headline: Start-Ups Clamor to Be the Airbnb of Boats
abstract: Online boat rentals are a tiny niche market, but some companies are positioning themselves to be the next big thing by seeking venture capital for expansion.
lead_paragraph: Americans own about 22 million recreational boats, and on average they use them just 11 days a year, according to the latest data from the Coast Guard.

headline: Parking Apps Face Obstacles at Every Turn
abstract: Entrepreneurs have delved into satisfying the demand for street spaces, but apps like MonkeyParking and Haystack have been banned in some cities for selling something they don’t own.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Uber and Lyft reinvented driving, entrepreneurs cast about for the next unloved slice of the economy to upend. They found it in parking.

headline: Traffic Hacking: Caution Light Is On
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic and Parking Signals and Signs']
abstract: The threat is increasing that hackers could shut down so-called smart cities, where network sensors connect traffic, water, waste and air management systems and the electric grid online.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Cesar Cerrudo flew to Washington, strolled over to Capitol Hill and pulled out his laptop. Then he began to hack the city’s traffic system.

headline: A Dialogue of Car and Highway
abstract: One estimate shows that by next year 210 million cars on the world’s roads will be connected wirelessly in some form to the Internet and other services.
lead_paragraph: One peek at all the electronics under the hood is proof that today’s car is as much computer as engine. Examine the larger picture, and you’ll see how much the stuff around cars is becoming smarter, too.

headline: Britain Offers Itself as a Proving Ground
abstract: With support from the British government, three pilot projects have started to test the rules and develop the hardware for autonomous vehicles.
lead_paragraph: A nondescript industrial park in Coventry, England, two hours north of London, seems an unlikely place to find a state-of-the-art driverless car.

headline: Options for Simplifying the Commute
abstract: GPS, the wireless Internet and smartphones have brought back the principle of dial-a-ride, a short-lived service born in Silicon Valley in the 1970s that was a victim of its success.
lead_paragraph: In November 1974, the newly born Silicon Valley began an ill-fated “dial-a-ride” experiment. A phone call to a team of operators would send a bus to pick up and drop off a rider along a computer-customized route. After the 1973 oil crisis, however, the service quickly became a “success disaster.” The dial-a-ride, created by the Santa Clara County public transit system, groaned under a crush of 80,000 calls a day for weeks and led to busy signals, missed rides and low efficiency. Less than six months later, the service was essentially canceled.

headline: Options for Simplifying the Commute
abstract: GPS, the wireless Internet and smartphones have brought back the principle of dial-a-ride, a short-lived service born in Silicon Valley in the 1970s that was a victim of its success.
lead_paragraph: In November 1974, the newly born Silicon Valley began an ill-fated “dial-a-ride” experiment. A phone call to a team of operators would send a bus to pick up and drop off a rider along a computer-customized route. After the 1973 oil crisis, however, the service quickly became a “success disaster.” The dial-a-ride, created by the Santa Clara County public transit system, groaned under a crush of 80,000 calls a day for weeks and led to busy signals, missed rides and low efficiency. Less than six months later, the service was essentially canceled.

headline: Tipping Point in Transit
abstract: The future of driving is in many ways already here, and the changes are coming fast and furious. Many could see lower costs and more convenience, but not everyone may benefit.
lead_paragraph: One sunny morning a few weeks ago, I slipped into the inviting cockpit of a Mercedes-Benz S550 sedan, a ride equipped with massaging front seats, reclining back seats, a heads-up display worthy of a fighter jet and more speakers than a political convention. At $136,000, this was a car fit for a rap star or a European Union functionary, of which I am neither (yet).

headline: Texas Ruling on Abortion Leads to Call for Clarity
abstract: Legal experts say the Supreme Court could address the issue in taking up a case that could force many of Texas’ remaining abortion clinics to close.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, courts have struggled with a fuzzy legal standard set by the Supreme Court for judging abortion laws: When does a rule governing doctors or clinics or medical procedures become an unconstitutional “undue burden” on a woman’s right to an abortion?

keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']

lead_paragraph: Headed east this first steamy weekend in the city? There are many new places to shop, like the Orlebar Brown beach-shack-inspired pop-up, where you will find great summer pieces like trunks printed all over with a panoramic photo of surfers riding a wave ($345). At 23 Newtown Lane, East Hampton.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators say that the Chinese hackers who attacked the databases of the Office of Personnel Management may have obtained the names of Chinese relatives, friends and frequent associates of American diplomats and other government officials, information that Beijing could use for blackmail or retaliation.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Communism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Censorship']
abstract: Mr. Vaculik not only wrote some great books, one expert said, but he also “influenced events and spearheaded political changes” in Czechoslovakia, especially the “Prague Spring” of 1968.
lead_paragraph: Ludvik Vaculik, a leading Czech writer, dissident and intellectual, whose calls for human rights and trenchant critique of Communism helped foster a short-lived period of freedom that culminated in the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, has died. He was 88.

headline: South Korean Hamlet, Under MERS Quarantine, Symbolizes Weaknesses in System
abstract: “You can’t leave here unless you have wings,” said a Buddhist monk who runs a temple in the village, Jangdeok, where all residents are quarantined.
lead_paragraph: JANGDEOK, South Korea — No one in this tiny village of 73 households can leave. Teams of sentries, in round-the-clock shifts, block all access roads, lest any resident think about escape.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A coalition of Islamist militias in the Libyan city of Darnah has vowed to eliminate a local unit of the Islamic State, testing its strength and emphasizing the deep divisions among the country’s Islamist forces.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — EBay wants to celebrate its forthcoming spinoff of PayPal by calling people up and trying to sell them something.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to open a new base for an additional 450 American military trainers and other personnel in Anbar Province in Iraq is designed to give a badly needed lift to the Sunni tribes and Iraqi troops who have been struggling to hold their own against the Islamic State.

headline: Without Showing Games, ESPN Leaves a Mark on the N.B.A. Finals
abstract: The arrangement between ESPN and ABC keeps the telecasts of the N.B.A. championship all in the Walt Disney Company family.
lead_paragraph: The peculiar credit appears at the end of N.B.A. finals broadcasts on ABC. There is no reason for this single line to be shown publicly. The information it conveys is irrelevant to viewers and is an example of a major entertainment company speaking publicly to itself. But it tells you why N.B.A. games are carried by ABC, whose once-dominant sports division was buried long ago.

headline: Horst Brandstätter, Who Introduced Playmobil, Dies at 81
abstract: Frugality led to the development of small movable figures inspired by children’s drawings and crèche figurines.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Horst Brandstätter, owner of the company whose finger-high Playmobil figures can be found in playrooms around the world and who brought the Hula-Hoop to Europe in the 1950s, died on June 3. He was 81.

headline: Panel Tells F.D.A. to Back Second Drug to Help Heart
abstract: Early results of clinical trials raised hopes that the therapies would be critical new additions to the treatment arsenal for those at risk of heart disease.
lead_paragraph: An expert committee that advises the Food and Drug Administration recommended on Wednesday that the agency approve the second in a new class of drugs that can drive cholesterol levels down to unheard-of levels.

headline: The Bold Designs of Paul Bacon
abstract: Paul Bacon, who designed striking book jackets for major books, is dead at 91. A sampling of his work.
lead_paragraph: Paul Bacon, who designed striking book jackets for major books, is dead at 91. A sampling of his work.

headline: Paul Bacon, 91, Whose Book Jackets Drew Readers and Admirers, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Bacon designed the covers of “Slaughterhouse-Five” and “Jaws” in a style that came to be known as the “Big Book Look,” a bold, minimalist design with prominent lettering and a small conceptual image.
lead_paragraph: Paul Bacon, the influential designer known for creating radical, eye-catching book jackets for major literary works like Joseph Heller’s “Catch-22” and Philip Roth’s “Portnoy’s Complaint,” died on Monday in Fishkill, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: No-Hitter Is as Familiar to the San Francisco Giants as a Ring
abstract: Throwing a no-hitter might seem easy around the Giants, who have won three of the last five World Series behind a stingy pitching staff.
lead_paragraph: Chris Heston twirled a no-hitter against the Mets on Tuesday, Matt Cain has thrown a perfect game against the Houston Astros, and Tim Lincecum has twice kept the San Diego Padres hitless.

headline: Family Disputes Police Account of Bronx Man’s Stun Gun Death
abstract: While the police said the man was refusing to drop scissors before being stunned, his girlfriend and the family’s lawyer say there were no scissors and he was catatonic when officers arrived.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx man who died after being shocked with a Taser stun gun by a New York officer was not holding scissors or acting violently, a lawyer for the man’s family said on Wednesday. The account contrasted with one provided by the police.

headline: Lebanon: U.S. Puts 3 Lebanese on Blacklist Over Hezbollah Links
abstract: The Treasury Department froze any assets the Lebanese might have under United States jurisdiction and prohibited Americans from doing business with them.
lead_paragraph: Three Lebanese men and their businesses were blacklisted by American sanctions officials on Wednesday for what they described as extensive ties with Hezbollah, the Shiite political organization in Lebanon that the United States and Israel regard as a terrorist group. The Treasury Department said the actions against the Lebanese froze any assets they might have under United States jurisdiction and prohibited Americans from doing business with them. Its statement said the actions “underscore the direct ties between Hezbollah’s commercial and terrorist activities, as well as the group’s continued exploitation of the legitimate commercial sector for financial, organizational and material support.” The targets of the actions were identified as Adham Tabaja and his company, Al-Inmaa Group for Tourism Works, and its subsidiaries; Kassem Hejeij, a businessman who arranged financial services access for Hezbollah; and Husayn Ali Faour and his company, Care Care Center, which was accused of arranging transportation for Hezbollah, which is politically aligned with the governments of Syria and Iran. Mr. Faour was identified as a member of Islamic Jihad, a Hezbollah branch.

headline: ‘Everyone Has a Family Member Who Works Up There’
abstract: The economy of Dannemora, N.Y., a town near the Canadian border, revolves around the Clinton Correctional Facility, the maximum-security prison from which two inmates escaped last week.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — The most striking thing — the only striking thing, really — about the village of Dannemora, nestled in the Adirondacks, is a monolithic wall that both defines and divides it.

headline: Eugene Kennedy, a Voice for Change in the Catholic Church, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Kennedy, who left the priesthood in 1977, was a teacher, writer and social scientist who believed the hierarchical structure of the church put it out of touch with the modern world.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Kennedy, a psychologist, former priest and public intellectual who, inspired by the ideas of Vatican II, emerged in the 1970s as a powerful voice for reform and modernization of the Roman Catholic Church, died on June 3 in St. Joseph, Mich. He was 86.

headline: Review: In ‘10 out of 12’ at Soho Rep, the Audience Tunes In to the Crew
abstract: Anne Washburn makes a theater piece out of the chaos that characterizes the tech rehearsal of a play.
lead_paragraph: Ever been bored into rhapsody? Every so often, a strange and ecstatic vision rises from the carefully tended tedium of “10 out of 12,” Anne Washburn’s evocation of that special state of theater purgatory known as the tech rehearsal, which opened on Wednesday night at Soho Rep in a production directed by Les Waters.

headline: Well-Kept Secret
abstract: In which we welcome Lewis E. Rothlein as he makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Will Shortz has said that he looks for lively and sparkling fill in the puzzles that get submitted to him, so it’s easy to see why this one was accepted.

headline: Marguerite Patten, 99, Dies; Tutored Food-Rationed Britons in Home Cooking
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Chefs', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Starting out during the rationing years of the 1940s and 1950s, Ms. Patten, who wrote more than 170 books, was one of Britain’s first television chefs.
lead_paragraph: Marguerite Patten, a home economist who told ration-pinched British families how to make a satisfying meal out of nothing during World War II, and later became one of the country’s first television chefs and the author of more than 170 cookbooks aimed at average Britons, died on June 4 in Richmond, Surrey. She was 99.

headline: Papal Responses to Sexual Abuse in the Church
abstract: A tribunal set up by Pope Francis is the Vatican’s first mechanism to discipline negligent Roman Catholic bishops, rather than abusive priests.
lead_paragraph: In setting up a Vatican tribunal to discipline negligent Roman Catholic bishops, Pope Francis has taken the most concrete step of any pope in holding accountable church leaders who failed to prevent the sexual abuse of minors by priests. Although Francis and his most recent predecessors, Pope Benedict XVI and Pope John Paul II, made efforts to punish abusive priests, the tribunal is the Vatican’s first mechanism to punish their superiors.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Jury System', 'Missing Persons']

abstract: Having faced much resistance with mandates, city health officials, at the mayor’s urging, are trying a new approach to prevent herpes infections.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi David Niederman, an influential Orthodox leader in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, sat outside a meeting of the New York City Board of Health on Wednesday, staring at a brochure and frowning.

abstract: The package sped from Mayor Bill de Blasio’s office through a committee to the full body in less than 24 hours, drawing criticism from union representatives.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council approved a new package of disability pension benefits on Wednesday for police officers and firefighters in what union representatives and some council members described as a surreptitious process.

lead_paragraph: A day after San Francisco Giants starter Chris Heston pitched a no-hitter against his team, Mets Manager Terry Collins said that even such a disheartening loss was fleeting and that his players had already shifted their focus to Wednesday’s opposing starter, Tim Hudson.

Christine Sinclair has received lots of attention as the star of host Canada, and the heroics of Marta of Brazil and Homare Sawa of Japan from past World Cups are well remembered.

headline: Chicago Blackhawks Show Their Mettle in Tying Stanley Cup Finals
abstract: The pucks kept ringing off the post for Chicago, but it managed to get two goals past Tampa Bay’s rookie goaltender and win Game 4.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The shots kept ringing off the post and the crossbar for the Blackhawks — one, two, three, as the groans from the crowd at United Center grew ever louder, ever more insistent. Those clangs echoed in the second period and the third period until the puck sneaked into the net.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:35 A.M. (Starz Cinema) HIGHER GROUND (2011) Corinne Walker, a freewheeling teenage mother turned fundamentalist Christian (played by Vera Farmiga, who also directed, as an adult; her sister Taissa Farmiga as a teenager; and McKenzie Turner as a child) comes to question her faith — and her marriage — when faced with a crisis in this adaptation of “This Dark World,” a 2002 memoir by Carolyn S. Briggs. Joshua Leonard and Boyd Holbrook share the role of Corinne’s husband, a rock guitarist who saves their daughter from death after a bus crash, leading the couple onto the path of salvation. Norbert Leo Butz plays the pastor of their cultlike church. And Dagmara Dominczyk is Corinne’s best friend, who speaks in tongues to God and makes her feel loved. “There is something remarkable — you might even say miraculous — about the way ‘Higher Ground’ makes its gentle, thoughtful way across the burned-over terrain of the American culture wars,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Focused with sympathetic intensity on the ordeal of a single soul, it illuminates, as though from within, a complex spiritual struggle.” But, he added, “what faith and doubt have in common is that both are hard work, and the hard-won wisdom of ‘Higher Ground’ is that human nature does not necessarily distinguish between saints and sinners.”

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, June 11, 2015.

headline: Quotation of the Day

headline: Simple Life Among the Hutterites
abstract: Tim Smith was looking for a day picture when a quick glimpse of Hutterite women led him to pursue a project about their simple, communal life.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to feature photos, the more you drive the luckier you’ll get. Tim Smith learned that lesson one crisp spring day in 2009, when he was searching for something — anything — worth photographing. He needed to find a day picture to fill space on the pages of the Brandon Sun newspaper in Manitoba, Canada. Unfortunately, nothing much was happening in his corner of western Manitoba.

headline: The Myth of a White Minority
abstract: We use outdated, illogical racial and ethnic categories. Social reality is much more complex.
lead_paragraph: IN 2012, the Census Bureau announced that nonwhite births exceeded white births for the first time. In 2013, it noted that more whites were dying than were being born. In March, it projected that non-Hispanic whites would be a minority by 2044.

headline: Battle of the Abortion Decisions
abstract: It’s been a dismal stretch across the nation for a woman’s right to choose, but there is some good news from Idaho. Who knew?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a dismal stretch for a woman’s right to choose. Not everywhere — I swear that if you stay with me there’s going to be a bright spot. But, first, I’m afraid we’re going to have to talk about Texas.

lead_paragraph: When I recently saw the newly restored versions of Satyajit Ray’s Apu Trilogy, a wave of emotion swept up over me as I watched Apu grow up, become a writer and lose his family.

headline: Closing Off Abortion Rights
abstract: In Texas and across the country, women’s reproductive health is at risk.
lead_paragraph: For the last several years, opponents of abortion rights have cloaked their obstructionist efforts under all manner of legitimate-sounding rationales, like protecting women’s health. This has never been more than an insulting ruse. Their goal, of course, is to end all abortions, and lately they’re hardly trying to pretend otherwise.

headline: Don’t Weaken the F.D.A.’s Drug Approval Process
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medical Devices', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The 21st Century Cures Act could substantially lower the standards for approval of many medical products, potentially placing patients at unnecessary risk.
lead_paragraph: DURING the early days of the AIDS epidemic in the 1980s, there were no effective treatments against H.I.V., the virus that causes the disease. Because of this, many thousands of people died lingering deaths. The desperation of those times led to the rise of an activist movement that took to the streets and pressed government officials to expedite research on drugs to treat AIDS.

headline: Lost Brother in Yosemite
abstract: Dean Potter jumped. Graham Hunt followed. Potter’s longtime girlfriend snapped photographs. Then came confusion, hope and despair.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — Afternoon gave way to evening, and the parade of restless clouds and the occasional bursts of rain had moved on from Yosemite Valley. In their wake was the empty quiet of Taft Point, 3,000 feet above a famous green valley going gray in late-day shadow.

headline: Winning Belmont Bettors Hope to Cash In Online
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Gambling', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: More than 90,000 winning tickets from American Pharoah’s Triple Crown victory are unclaimed, with many bettors guessing their ticket is worth far more behind a frame, or on eBay.
lead_paragraph: As soon as American Pharoah galloped across the finish line at the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, another race began, as throngs of lucky gamblers swarmed the grandstand to trade in their ticket stubs for stacks of dollar bills.

headline: Russian Groups Crowdfund the War in Ukraine
abstract: Several groups are running online campaigns to brazenly raise money for rebels in eastern Ukraine, helping succor a conflict that has killed thousands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Novorossiya Humanitarian Battalion boasts on its website that it provided funds to buy a pair of binoculars used by rebels in eastern Ukraine to spot and destroy an armored vehicle. Another group, Save the Donbass, solicits donations using a photograph of a mortar shell inscribed with its web address and the names of donors. Yet another, Veche, states that its mission is to “create modern, combat-ready” military units fighting Ukraine’s central government.

headline: What Are You Doing This Summer?
abstract: According to a recent post on the Motherlode blog, too many teenagers spend their summers engaged in résumé-building activities and instead should be doing nothing. Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: Will you be working? Taking classes? Practicing for the SAT? Attending a sports or music camp? Interning?

headline: Nepal Landslides Kill at Least 21, With Others Trapped or Missing
abstract: Heavy rains arriving with monsoon season were undermining hillsides, many of which may have been destabilized by a devastating April earthquake.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Landslides caused by heavy rains struck several remote villages in eastern Nepal overnight on Thursday, killing at least 21 people, a local official said.

headline: Surveillance States
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The author of “Reading Lolita in Tehran” on writing under the eye of a watchful government.
lead_paragraph: For a while, every time I borrowed a book from my local library in Washington, D.C., I was greeted by an Orwellian poster: “Big Brother Is Watching You!” I often wondered if others paused to reflect on the implication of these words, if they understood how profoundly living under surveillance distorts a society. It transforms your perspective, your manners, your relationships with friends, colleagues, students, with every waiter and cabdriver you meet. It changes your relationship with yourself.

headline: Review: In ‘Jurassic World,’ the Franchise Feeds the Beast
abstract: The latest installment of the Jurassic franchise, set in a luxury resort, reminds you what a great action god Steven Spielberg is.
lead_paragraph: Clomp, clomp, clomp — here it comes, another new blockbuster ready for its shock-and-awe ch-ching close-up. With its global brand recognition, “Jurassic World” comes with more muscle than the average big-ticket behemoth, one that’s been built on best-selling novels, three earlier flicks, theme-park attractions and the usual marketing tie-ins. Once again, dinosaurs are on the roam, an unpeaceable kingdom that is an index of the folly of man trying to play God. In reality, there’s more flab than muscle packed on this galumphing franchise reboot, which, as it lumbers from scene to scene, reminds you of what a great action god Steven Spielberg is. Too bad he didn’t take the reins on this.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping of China vowed to hunt “tigers” as well as “flies” in his drive to rid the ruling Communist Party of corruption, and on Thursday he defanged the most dangerous tiger yet — Zhou Yongkang, the nation’s former chief of domestic security.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Wishful-Thinking Politics

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign took a beating from some pundits this week for telling the truth: She’s going to employ a strategy focused on a narrow set of the most competitive states.

headline: Exploring Franche-Comté, France’s Well-Kept Secret
abstract: This little-known region includes surprising museums, fragrant cheese caves and charming villages among its many attractions.
lead_paragraph: The Citadel of Besançon is an imposing 27-acre fortress on a bluff high above the city’s Renaissance-era center, which spills out from a teardrop-shaped oxbow on the Doubs River. This is now eastern France, about an hour from the Swiss border, but the unusual topography has drawn military attention at least since it was Celtic Gaul: Julius Caesar noted its potential as a defensive stronghold on his way through the region. Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban, Louis XIV’s celebrated engineer, designed the current structure, one of his 12 fortifications that collectively made the Unesco World Heritage list in 2008.

headline: Today in Politics: Mitt Romney Conference Promises Donors and Early Morning Hikes
abstract: The Supreme Court’s coming decision on health care is not the only court ruling on the law watchers have their eyes on. But most of Thursday’s action and focus will be on Utah, where Republicans will meet Mitt Romney’s list of donors and spend time in the sun.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where the Supreme Court’s coming decision on health care is not the only court ruling on the law watchers have their eyes on. But most of Thursday’s action and focus will be on Utah, where Republicans will meet Mitt Romney‘s list of donors and spend time in the sun.

headline: My Perennial Dilemma
abstract: For one gardener, a lifetime of instant gratification yields to longer-term commitment.
lead_paragraph: Thank goodness for farmers. As a mere gardener, I don’t know how they do it. The heartbreak. My phlox had powdery mildew last summer and it about killed me. The worry. Was I applying the right mildew spray? The doubt. Had I read the Department of Agriculture’s official Plant Hardiness Zone Map correctly? Was Provincetown in Zone 7A? I had to remind myself that my life and livelihood did not depend on my phlox crop.

headline: The Child Preachers of Brazil
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Ministers (Protestant)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Pentecostal Churches']
abstract: The youngest evangelists in the country’s Pentecostal churches try to balance the demands of their youth with those of their faith.
lead_paragraph: It was fall in Brazil, and rain drizzled under a gray moon. The faithful were beginning to arrive at the International Mission of Miracles, a Pentecostal church in the poor and working-class city of São Gonçalo, 10 miles from Rio de Janeiro. In front of the church, which was located between a supermarket and an abandoned lot, a banner staked in the muddy ground advertised a young girl named Alani Santos, whose touch could heal.

keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Volvo Ocean Race']
abstract: Since an inquiry into a crash that stranded members of Team Vestas Wind, small changes have been made to the rules in the Volvo Ocean Race, and officials have said there would be more.
lead_paragraph: Even though Chris Nicholson entered the Volvo Ocean Race only two months before the start last October, his four races’ worth of experience made him a favorite in the around-the-world event. He believed he could win.

headline: Soju for the Soul
abstract: Mellow and easy to mix, the Korean spirit is just the thing for a night in.
lead_paragraph: I took the news badly when my friend Jiwon said she was leaving New York and moving to Seoul. She was a beloved drinking and dining companion, a doting cat sitter and the person most likely to make me laugh until I cried. But she wanted to get to know the country where she was born, and she assured me it wouldn’t be forever.

headline: The Virtues of Political Disagreement
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Philosophy', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The fights between liberals and conservatives that seem to tear our democracy apart are actually the engines of a diverse, dynamic society.
lead_paragraph: This interview, the fifth in a series on political topics, discusses philosophical issues concerning political disagreement. My interviewee is Jerry Gaus, professor of philosophy at the University of Arizona. He is the author of “The Order of Public Reason: A Theory of Freedom and Morality in a Diverse and Bounded World.” — Gary Gutting

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi of Myanmar Meets With Xi Jinping in Beijing
abstract: For Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, the visit is seen as a step in her transformation from global icon of democracy to credible candidate to be Myanmar’s next leader.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace laureate who leads Myanmar’s opposition, met with President Xi Jinping of China on Thursday, the second day of a trip that appears likely to underscore her transformation from a global icon of democracy to a politician with ambitions to form her country’s next government.

headline: Morning Agenda: J. Crew’s ‘Great Man’ Problem
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: J. Crew’s ‘Great Man’ Problem | Hackers’ Growing Interest in Small Businesses | Britain Expects Losses From R.B.S. Stake Sale
lead_paragraph: J. CREW’S ‘GREAT MAN’ PROBLEM | As losses mount at J. Crew, the clothing retailer owned by TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners, it finds itself floundering after missteps in pricing and design, Julie Creswell writes in The New York Times. What compounds J. Crew’s troubles is the $1.5 billion in debt incurred through a leveraged buyout orchestrated by the chief executive, Millard S. Drexler, and the two private equity firms in 2011, Ms. Creswell writes. J. Crew executives blamed the most recent quarterly losses on some fashion mistakes, like the cropped “Tilly” sweater, and on Wednesday the company said it had replaced the head of women’s design and will cut 175 jobs. However,  in the Deal Professor column, Steven Davidoff Solomon contends that J. Crew doesn’t just have a fashion problem – it has a “great man” problem.

headline: Can a New Designer (Not Jenna Lyons) Fix J. Crew?
abstract: Somsack Sikhounmuong, head of design for Madewell, is moving up to the bigger brand’s women’s wear job.
lead_paragraph: J. Crew just isn’t selling. With sales down for another consecutive quarter, doomsayers are circling. Interestingly, however, while normally the first solution when product has not been resonating is, “Fire the creative director!” (see Gucci, which also fired its chief executive), that has not been this brand’s solution. Instead, it has replaced the design second-in-command.

headline: Syrian Druse Reconsider Alliances After Deadly Attack
abstract: Antigovernment activists said at least 20 Druse were killed on Wednesday night in Idlib Province, fueling fears for civilians and minority sects in the tumultuous region.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A deadly attack by Al Qaeda’s Syrian branch in the north and an advance by other insurgents into a previously quiet southern province are squeezing Syria’s Druse minority sect across the country, setting off urgent debates among Druse leaders about how best to protect their interests: Stick close to the government, reach out to Sunni insurgents or stand alone and defend themselves.

headline: No Justice in Pakistan
abstract: A system where confessions are obtained under torture and terrorism suspects are tried in secret results in outrage abroad.
lead_paragraph: In Pakistan, the innocent are executed and the guilty go free. On Wednesday, Aftab Bahadur, who was 15 years old when he was convicted of murder after a forced confession under torture, was executed. Mr. Bahadur had spent 22 years on death row. Two witnesses against him later recanted and declared him innocent. Meanwhile, it came to light last Friday that eight of 10 men who were reported to have been given life sentences by a secret military court in April for their role in the 2012 attack on the Nobel Prize winner and education activist Malala Yousafzai had quietly been released.

headline: Ornette Coleman, Saxophonist Who Rewrote the Language of Jazz, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Coleman was a leader in making jazz less beholden to rules of harmony and rhythm.
lead_paragraph: Ornette Coleman, the alto saxophonist and composer who was one of the most powerful and contentious innovators in the history of jazz, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 85.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Urban Areas']

lead_paragraph: Google’s ambitions and investments have increasingly broadened beyond its digital origins in Internet search and online advertising into the arena of physical objects: self-driving cars, Internet-connected eyeglasses, smart thermostats and a biotech venture to develop life-extending treatments.

headline: Germanwings Victims’ Remains Return Home
abstract: The mayor of Haltern am See, Germany, said townspeople lined the streets to welcome home the remains of 16 schoolchildren killed in the crash of a Germanwings plane in March.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Haltern am See, Germany, said townspeople lined the streets to welcome home the remains of 16 schoolchildren killed in the crash of a Germanwings plane in March.

headline: Trevor Noah Twitter Account Not Vetted Before ‘Daily Show’ Decision
abstract: A top Viacom executive said that the feed was not reviewed before Mr. Noah’s selection as the new host of “The Daily Show” and that he underestimated how viewers would respond to anyone who was named to succeed Jon Stewart.
lead_paragraph: A top Viacom executive said that the Twitter account of the comedian Trevor Noah was not vetted before his selection as the new host of “The Daily Show” and that he underestimated how viewers would respond to anyone who was named to succeed Jon Stewart.

headline: With ‘Significant Other,’ Joshua Harmon Happily Writes About the Unhappy
abstract: The playwright examines friendship and loneliness in a new play about a gay man who loses his three best girlfriends to marriage.
lead_paragraph: When the playwright Joshua Harmon was 10, his grandmother handed him a copy of a play and told him that if he read it, she would take him to see it on Broadway. After several weeks, he finished the script, and then they went to the show. “I was very excited,” he said recently over drinks. The play was Euripides’ “Medea,” which is not exactly children’s theater, unless you like your children violently murdered. “I loved it,” he said.

headline: Christopher Lee Dies at 93; Actor Breathed Life Into Nightmarish Villains
abstract: Mr. Lee, “tall, dark and gruesome” in his own words, made an indelible mark in roles like Count Dracula, Frankenstein’s monster and Saruman in the “Lord of the Rings” movies.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Lee, the physically towering British movie actor who lent his distinguished good looks, Shakespearean voice and aristocratic presence to a gallery of villains, from a seductive Count Dracula to a dreaded wizard in “The Lord of the Rings,” died on Sunday in London. He was 93.

headline: Campaign Kickoffs: Who Has Stumbled, Who Has Sparkled
abstract: For months now, the candidates have seemed like jittery aspiring actors strutting their stuff for choosy directors and producers. Here are some lessons learned so far.
lead_paragraph: For months now, the candidates have seemed like jittery aspiring actors strutting their stuff for choosy directors and producers. Here are some lessons learned so far.

headline: Student Loans and Defaults: The Facts
abstract: With rising debate over student debt, we look at what loan levels are typical.
lead_paragraph: Lee Siegel, an author, sparked a heated discussion about student debt after writing about his decision to default deliberately on his loans. He did so, he wrote in a New York Times Op-Ed article, so that he could pursue his career as a writer without the financial burden of paying his loans, and he called on other borrowers to join him in order to press politicians to address rising college costs.

headline: After Financial Crisis, Fates of Lender and Borrower Diverge
abstract: David Miller and his team at Credit Suisse made one of their most aggressive loans to Timothy Blixseth, a land and timber baron who now sits in jail.
lead_paragraph: Timothy L. Blixseth, a 65-year-old former billionaire, now sits in his eighth week of solitary confinement in a county jail in Great Falls, Mont., one of the few people being held accountable in connection with Wall Street’s profligate behavior in the years leading up to the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: China’s Ex-Security Chief Sentenced
abstract: Zhou Yongkang, China’s former domestic security chief, spoke after he was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday for accepting bribes, abusing power and revealing state secrets.
lead_paragraph: Zhou Yongkang, China’s former domestic security chief, spoke after he was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday for accepting bribes, abusing power and revealing state secrets.

headline: Fred Anton Maier, 76, Speedskating Champion and Record Setter, Dies
abstract: Maier won the Olympic gold medal in the 5,000 meters at Grenoble in 1968 but lost the 10,000 in a surprising upset.
lead_paragraph: Fred Anton Maier, one of Norway’s finest athletes in one of its signature sports, who set several world records in speedskating and won Olympic gold at 5,000 meters in Grenoble, France, in 1968, died on Tuesday at his home in southern Norway. He was 76.

headline: Dating With Schizophrenia
abstract: Dating when you’re a big guy with a serious mental illness is nearly impossible.
lead_paragraph: Dating is hard. Dating when you are overweight is harder. Dating when you are a big dude with a serious mental illness is nearly impossible.

headline: Mary Schapiro to Join London Stock Exchange Board
abstract: The former chairwoman of the S.E.C. will become a nonexecutive director at a time when the exchange is expanding its business in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London Stock Exchange Group said on Thursday that Mary L. Schapiro, the former chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would join its board as it continued to expand its business in the United States.

headline: Rupert Murdoch to Put Media Empire in Sons’ Hands
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Mr. Murdoch put the succession plan in place in March 2014 when he named his sons James and Lachlan to senior positions in his companies.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s long-held plan to hand over his media empire to his sons is now being realized.

headline: Affairs of the Wrist: The Apple Watch Comes Between Them
abstract: A conversation between Farhad Manjoo and Vanessa Friedman about the appeal and disappointment of Apple’s foray into wearable tech.
lead_paragraph: Is the Apple Watch just for gadget geeks? Farhad Manjoo, our technology columnist, “fell hard” for the watch back in April. But our fashion director, Vanessa Friedman, didn’t feel the sparks; she went public this week with her Apple Watch breakup. The two talked — over email, of course — about their wearable-tech turn-ons and turnoffs. Farhad composed his letters on his 5K iMac, watch on wrist. Vanessa replied from her MacBook Air, her wrist newly bare.

headline: Government Report Urges Changes in British Surveillance Law
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The report endorsed government efforts to fight terrorism but said the laws regulating them were “incomprehensible” and could erode public confidence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Amid growing debate in Europe over electronic spying, an independent report on Thursday called for changes to Britain’s surveillance laws, arguing that they are undemocratic and opaque, and that they risk eroding confidence in the oversight of intelligence agencies.

headline: Hire the Next First Lady
keywords: ['First Ladies (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Handling the social responsibilities of the presidency is a job in its own right. We should treat it like one.
lead_paragraph: If Lindsey Graham is elected president, he joked recently, “we’ll have a rotating first lady.” Since he’s single, his female friends and possibly his sister could take turns in the role.

headline: Pipeline of Young Talent Infuses the Blackhawks
abstract: The success of new players in the Stanley Cup finals, which is tied 2-2 after Chicago’s Game 4 victory, shows how the Blackhawks have built around their stars, infusing their roster with young talent.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Andrew Shaw walked into the locker room after the Chicago Blackhawks’ morning skate, looked around and muttered an expletive. Between him and his locker were several dozen members of a news media horde. Shaw had to dodge a boom microphone before he could get his equipment off.

headline: Lululemon’s Founder May Sell His Stake in Company
abstract: The yoga wear maker’s founder, Dennis Wilson, holds 14 percent of the company’s outstanding shares, valued at about $1.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: Lululemon Athletica disclosed in a filing on Thursday that its founder, Dennis J. Wilson, may sell his entire stake in the yoga wear maker, paving the way for Mr. Wilson to end an association that had become contentious.

headline: Unshaven and Proud: Winners of the Chinese Women’s Armpit Contest
abstract: A women’s rights advocate who organized the contest said she received 46 photos of unshaven armpits during the two-week contest.
lead_paragraph: Six Chinese women who proudly posted photographs of their unshaven armpits online have been named the winners of a contest held to challenge the notion that women must have hair-free armpits to be attractive.

headline: 1915: Appeal for American Peace
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Former Secretary of State, William Jennings Bryan, appealed for peace in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the heels of the publication of the second American Note to Germany, Mr. Bryan has issued an appeal to the American people. He declares that the real issue is not between President Wilson and himself, but between systems of government.

headline: Paris and Lovers Look to Move On After Breakup With Bridge’s Locks
abstract: It appears there is so much emotion attached to the locks that the city is trying to assure the brokenhearted that it will find alternatives to the gesture.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After Paris removed hundreds of thousands of locks affixed to the iron grillwork on the Pont des Arts last week, the romantics online were in mourning.

headline: British Revival of ‘A View From the Bridge’ Heads to Broadway This Fall
abstract: The Belgian experimental theater director Ivo van Hove will make his Broadway debut with his much-lauded staging of Arthur Miller’s “A View From the Bridge,” which will star Mark Strong.
lead_paragraph: A much-lauded British revival of Arthur Miller’s “A View From the Bridge” will transfer to Broadway this fall.

headline: Leaders From Myanmar and China Meet
abstract: Video from China’s state-run television shows a meeting on Thursday between President Xi Jinping and Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Video from China’s state-run television shows a meeting on Thursday between President Xi Jinping and Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in Beijing.

headline: World Cup Organizers Have a Reason to Root for the Home Team
abstract: The organizers of the Women’s World Cup in Canada are hoping that the home team and the United States enjoy good tournaments to help ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The organizers of the Women’s World Cup in Canada are hoping that the home team and the United States enjoy good tournaments, but not necessarily for reasons of patriotism or cordial relations with neighbors.

headline: Soon, Cars May Take Away the Keys of a Drunken Driver
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Tests (Sobriety)', 'Sensors']
abstract: Touch pads that detect alcohol in blood vessels beneath the skin and sensors that analyze normal breaths could be in vehicles by the end of the decade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IN the near future, cars will communicate with one another on the road, partly or entirely drive themselves and be packed with more entertainment options than most computers.

headline: Watching the Women’s World Cup — With Our Sons
abstract: The men filling the stadiums, the boys excitedly talking about the game—they’re not “supporters” of women’s soccer. They’re fans. And that’s huge.
lead_paragraph: It was my 13-year-old son who insisted that we rush back from a birthday shopping expedition for his sister so that we wouldn’t miss the start of the Women’s World Cup Soccer game between the United States and Australia earlier this week. “The women are going to do really well,” he told me. “They’re really good.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Demands Hillary Clinton Take Trade Stance ‘Right Now’
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders insisted that Hillary Rodham Clinton be more open with her positions on trade, climate change, the Keystone Pipeline, the renewal of the Patriot Act and the influence of the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont delivered a sharp critique of Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday for her reluctance to talk about issues as a presidential candidate and vowed that he is running against her to win.

headline: Manuel Valls, French Premier, Vows to Repay Cost of Taking Sons to Soccer Match
abstract: The prime minister, who has sought to fashion himself as a man of the people, was criticized for taking his children to the Champions League final on a government jet.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France said on Thursday that he would pay 2,500 euros to the state after he provoked an uproar by taking a government Falcon jet to watch the Champions League soccer final in Berlin with his two young sons over the weekend.

headline: Showtime Chief Matthew Blank to Step Aside Next Year
abstract: David Nevins, Mr. Blank’s second in command, will become chief executive on Jan. 1, the network announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Showtime’s longtime chief executive, Matthew C. Blank, will step aside early next year and be succeeded by his second in command, David Nevins, the network announced on Thursday. Mr. Blank will retain the title of chairman.

headline: Spain Approves Citizenship Path for Sephardic Jews
abstract: A law seeks to address the injustice of the 1492 expulsion of Jews, by giving descendants a chance to apply for citizenship; how many may qualify, however, is still unclear.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Seeking to redress one of the darkest chapters of Spain’s history, the Spanish Parliament on Thursday approved a long-awaited law devised to open the way for citizenship for thousands of Sephardic Jews whose ancestors were expelled in 1492.

headline: Ron Moody, Actor Best Known as Fagin in ‘Oliver!,’ Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Moody, a British character actor, flared to prominence in the role of Dickens’s guru of thievery, in the stage and screen adaptation of “Oliver!”.
lead_paragraph: Ron Moody, a British character actor who rose to prominence in the role of Fagin, Dickens’s guru of thievery, in “Oliver!”, the stage and movie versions of “Oliver Twist,” died on Thursday. He was 91.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld Will Direct Colin Quinn in New Stage Show
abstract: “Colin Quinn The New York Story” will be adapted from the comic’s new book.
lead_paragraph: With an accent that’s as emblematically Brooklyn as the Coney Island Cyclone or an artisanal pickle store, the comedian Colin Quinn is preparing for a return to the New York stage in a new show that takes a satirical look at his hometown and its history.

headline: On Health Care Reform, Nothing to Fear but the Scaremongers
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Republicans said the Affordable Care Act would lead employers to cut workers’ hours. That hasn’t happened.
lead_paragraph: A linchpin of the Affordable Care Act is that mid-sized and large employers must either provide health coverage for employees who work at least 30 hours a week, or pay a penalty.

headline: The Children of Gay Marriage
abstract: When the court considers same-sex unions, it often asks ‘what about the children?‘ Here are some answers.
lead_paragraph: When the court considers same-sex unions, it often asks ‘what about the children?‘ Here are some answers.

headline: I.M.F. Recalls Negotiators as Deadline Looms for Greek Deal
abstract: “Major differences” with the government of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras were reported as creditors and Athens pursue a deal.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The plotline is familiar by now in Greece’s long-running debt crisis, as bailout talks once again hit a major snag. But at this stage just weeks before the bailout expires, the latest twist could have more serious repercussions.

headline: Restaurant Report: Bastardo in Lisbon
abstract: The best dishes from the chef, Luis Miguel Rodrigues, are grounded in traditional cuisine, with only subtle twists.
lead_paragraph: Eating at a hotel restaurant in Lisbon is often a formal, expensive affair, the exact opposite of what Alexandre Martins, the chief executive of the Internacional Design Hotel in the Baixa neighborhood, was aiming for when he opened Bastardo in September. The brightly lit, 50-seat space has a colorful Pop Art aesthetic: mismatched tables and chairs, Lego block bread baskets and paper settings in bold font declaring “on this magic place mat calories don’t count,” and prices to match.

headline: France Opens Germanwings Crash Criminal Inquiry
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A panel of judges will investigate whether the airline or any individuals bear responsibility for failing to monitor the psychological health of the co-pilot who crashed the plane.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French prosecutor on Thursday formally opened a criminal inquiry into the crash of a Germanwings jetliner, appointing a panel of judges to investigate whether the airline or any individuals should bear responsibility for failing to adequately monitor the psychological health of the plane’s co-pilot, who is believed to have deliberately crashed the plane.

headline: When Doctors Withdraw Cancer Treatment
abstract: As oncology doctors and nurses, we place a person’s cancer treatment in his own hands. But the patient is not always willing to comply.
lead_paragraph: I first met my patient, a former truck driver, in 2009, when he was in his mid-50s and had just been diagnosed with acute lymphocytic leukemia, or A.L.L. Often when my patients first learn that they have acute leukemia, they ask me: “Do I have the good one?”

headline: Men’s Summer Skincare Essentials
abstract: Some of the season’s best products to cleanse, exfoliate, moisturize and protect.
lead_paragraph: These days, with the ever-expanding offering of skincare products designed specifically for men, a grooming regime like Patrick Bateman’s in “American Psycho” — the fictional investment banker used daily various cleansers, lotions and even an ice-pack — is quickly becoming commonplace for the modern man. And who’s to say there’s anything wrong with that? A good epidermis, especially in the harsh summer months, can be just what a guy needs to remain looking fresh and feeling good. Here, some of the season’s best products to cleanse, exfoliate, moisturize and protect the skin.

headline: Uber Releases Mobile Video Game to Recruit Drivers
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones', 'Software', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Uber is releasing a video game, developed in-house, as a new way to recruit and educate drivers.
lead_paragraph: For years, Uber has used rallies, ad campaigns and word of mouth to recruit tens of thousands of drivers to work for the company.

headline: Jeb Bush Defends Book That Called for Shaming Single Parents
abstract: Asked about the 1995 book’s passage while visiting Poland, Jeb Bush said his stances have evolved but that “my views about the importance of dads being involved in the lives of their children haven’t changed at all.”
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Jeb Bush on Thursday defended a passage in a 1995 book he co-authored calling for the restoration of shame as a way to curb out-of-wedlock births in the United States.

headline: Our Summer Calendar and a Question or Two for You
abstract: Our summer calendar, and a few questions we’ll be asking ourselves this summer to improve our offerings for next year. How would you answer them?
lead_paragraph: Happy summer!

headline: Music Streaming Service Aims at Japan, Where CD Is Still King
abstract: Japan, the world’s second-largest music market, has been resistant to streaming services, but Line Music is advertising 1.5 million tracks and low prices.
lead_paragraph: As listeners around the world turn to streaming music, there has been one important holdout: Japan. More than 80 percent of the sales in the country are still on physical formats like CDs, and the industry in Japan has been resistant to allowing streaming services to take root.

headline: Elliott Management Pushes Citrix Systems for Change
abstract: The activist hedge fund, which has made a lucrative practice out of shaking up tech firms, is urging Citrix to take steps to bolster its stock.
lead_paragraph: Elliott Management, the activist investor that has made a lucrative practice out of shaking up technology companies, has found a new target.

headline: First for Pina Bausch’s Tanztheater Wuppertal: New Commissions
abstract: Six years after Pina Bausch’s death, her company continues to thrive. Now for the first time in its history, choreographers will be invited to create new pieces next season.
lead_paragraph: The 2009 death of the choreographer Pina Bausch plunged the future of her company, the Tanztheater Wuppertal, into doubt. But the troupe, which has only performed Bausch’s epic tragicomic productions, has defied expectation, reviving old pieces, hiring new dancers and touring worldwide to the same rapturous responses that were received during the choreographer’s lifetime.

headline: Sex Dolls That Talk Back
abstract: In just two years, the creator of RealDoll says he will sell a robotic version with convincing artificial intelligence, blinking eyes and a mouth that moves.
lead_paragraph: This is the fifth episode in a Bits video series, called Robotica, examining how robots are poised to change the way we do business and conduct our daily lives.

headline: The Uncanny Lover
abstract: Matt McMullen is developing a sex robot that uses technology to create the illusion of sentience. But is it enough to generate real emotions in its user?
lead_paragraph: Matt McMullen is developing a sex robot that uses technology to create the illusion of sentience. But is it enough to generate real emotions in its user?

headline: Chris Hemsworth Gets the Call for Female ‘Ghostbusters’
abstract: The actor will play the receptionist role originated by Annie Potts.
lead_paragraph: Chris Hemsworth, the steely-eyed muscular blond best known as Thor, will be playing the receptionist in the forthcoming female revamp of “Ghostbusters.”

headline: For $7.99, You Too Can Be a Marvel Colorist
abstract: With the 72-page “Avengers: Age of Ultron” coloring book, amateur colorists can fulfill their own comic book dreams or at least see how they measure up against the professionals.
lead_paragraph: Colorists are often the unsung heroes of the creative team that produces a comic book. That may change when Marvel Comics releases its first coloring book for adults in October.

headline: Son-in-Law’s Stroke Causes George Pataki to Cancel Events
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Medicine and Health', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Former Gov. George Pataki of New York said in a statement that he was pausing his White House campaign’s schedule because his son-in-law, David Levy, 30, had a stroke and was in I.C.U. at a Chicago hospital.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. George Pataki of New York has canceled campaign events in New Hampshire to deal with a family health emergency.

headline: Serena Williams Is a Star Who Matches LeBron James, From a Different Court
abstract: If there is any athlete comparable to James in terms of physicality and willpower, it would have to be Williams, one of the most dominant athletes the sports world has seen.
lead_paragraph: This week, Steve Kerr was asked if he thought LeBron James was the best active athlete he could think of. After kiddingly throwing out the name of the Triple Crown winner American Pharoah, Kerr, the Golden State Warriors’ coach, added: “No, I think I said when I was a broadcaster with TNT, I think I might have made the comment that he’s arguably the best athlete that any of us have ever seen in terms of size and speed and strength. I mean, he’s a force.”

headline: F.T.C. Reaches Settlement in a Kickstarter Scheme
abstract: The agency said that a man who raised over $120,000 to create a board game spent the money instead on personal expenses.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday announced a settlement in its first Internet crowdfunding case, which involved a board-game maker who investigators say took in more than $120,000 on Kickstarter to fund a project but spent the money on personal expenses, including rent.

headline: Notable Names React to the Death of Christopher Lee
abstract: David Cameron, Josh Gad and Neil Gaiman were among those lamenting the passing of the actor.
lead_paragraph: From a seductive Count Dracula to a dreaded wizard in “The Lord of the Rings, Mr. Lee breathed life into nightmarish villains. On Thursday, actors, politicians and writers took to social media to remember his work. Mr. Lee died on Sunday in London. He was 93. For more on his life, read the New York Times obituary.

headline: Minimal Undies With Maximum Coverage and Comfort for the Win
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Lingerie and Underwear', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Budding lingerie brands create pieces meant to move with, not restrict, women’s bodies.
lead_paragraph: The movement away from tight, constricting undergarments continues as budding lingerie brands create pieces meant to move with, not restrict, women’s bodies. Produced for the VPL (visible panty line) uninhibited, the designs cede to comfort, using super-soft, breathable fabrics and high-waisted, full-bottomed, generally wire-free (and all around, very minimal) elements. Created for “the sport of womanhood,” Land of Women’s functional and classic cuts — think supple, everyday sports bras and ample bottomed briefs — support any feminine endeavor. Negative combines subtle seduction (perforated lace) and playfulness (albatross feather prints) for their uncomplicated and considered pieces. And Base Range uses unexpected details, like a small triangular opening at the sternum, and organic fabrics for sustainable support.

headline: 1965: Beatles in Queen’s Honors List
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Beatles are awarded the Order of the British Empire in 1965.
lead_paragraph: Beatles received their medals at the Buckingham Palace in October 1965. (britishpathe.com)

headline: Ornette Coleman’s Greatest Hits
abstract: Mr. Coleman challenged assumptions about jazz from top to bottom, bringing in his own ideas about instrumentation, process and technical expertise.
lead_paragraph: Ornette Coleman’s varied and provocative recordings reflect many bands and changes of sound, from post-bebop to symphonic music to an original version of funk. Here is a brief selection of high points, a dozen tracks from his late-1950s beginnings to 2007, including some of the most durable and influential jazz of the 20th century.

headline: I Love Paraguay
abstract: Rich Paraguayan food in Sunnyside, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Rich Paraguayan food in Sunnyside, Queens.

headline: I Love Paraguay, an Ode to a Homeland
abstract: The restaurant in Sunnyside, Queens, started out as a bakery and has broadened its menu and ambition.
lead_paragraph: The bread is coarse, flat and round, a moon at its peak, looking ready to crumble. A mix of cassava starch, milk, eggs and Muenster, given the barest amount of cohesion on a griddle, it suggests a further step in the evolution of a quesadilla, with the cheese not pent up but pervading every cranny, crazing the surface so that each bite is crispy and chewy at once.

headline: The Mutability of Wages
abstract: More on the loose grip of the invisible hand.
lead_paragraph: Arindrajit Dube enlarges on my post about efficiency wages, pointing out that the same logic applies to firms that have monopsony power. That’s a very good point — and I think we’re circling in on an important part of the logic behind the “new view” on inequality policy, which says that policies to enhance worker bargaining power can have major effects on the distribution of market income.

headline: The Mutability of Wages
abstract: More on the loose grip of the invisible hand.
lead_paragraph: Arindrajit Dube enlarges on my post about efficiency wages, pointing out that the same logic applies to firms that have monopsony power. That’s a very good point — and I think we’re circling in on an important part of the logic behind the “new view” on inequality policy, which says that policies to enhance worker bargaining power can have major effects on the distribution of market income.

headline: The Babe Ruth of Congress
abstract: The annual Congressional Baseball contest will be played tonight, and we’re here to answer the question: Can anybody here play this game?
lead_paragraph: Cedric Richmond, a House Democrat who represents New Orleans, is the Babe Ruth of the Congressional Baseball Game.

headline: Clips of Jazz Legend Ornette Coleman
abstract: Challenges to the traditions of jazz were the hallmarks of Ornette Coleman’s long career.
lead_paragraph: Challenges to the traditions of jazz were the hallmarks of Ornette Coleman’s long career.

headline: Letters: ‘Galileo’s Middle Finger’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Alice Dreger’s new book, Jim Shepard’s “The Book of Aron” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Top Chris Christie Aide Goes to His Political Action Committee
abstract: Maria Comella has been almost constantly by Chris Christie’s side since he became the governor of New Jersey in 2009, advising him a number of issues.
lead_paragraph: Maria Comella, the long-serving communications director to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, will move over to the governor’s political action committee in a senior role, the latest move that indicates he will run for president.

headline: Heroes or Killers? A Secret History of SEAL Team 6 Draws a Range of Reader Reaction
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A Times article on the secret history of SEAL Team 6, the Navy unit best known for killing Osama bin Laden, drew a range of reactions from readers in the comments section. While some lauded the team, others expressed cynicism about the secrecy surrounding their military operations.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Wartik is a news assistant and comment moderator.

headline: FIFA Spokesman’s Favorite FIFA Joke
abstract: Walter De Gregorio, FIFA’s former communications director, resigned on Thursday days after he told a joke about the association’s corruption scandal on Swiss television.
lead_paragraph: Walter De Gregorio, FIFA’s former communications director, resigned on Thursday days after he told a joke about the association’s corruption scandal on Swiss television.

headline: ‘Hand Foot Fizzle Face’ Digs Into an Odd Collaboration Between Beckett and Jasper Johns
abstract: A new play opening at Jack in Brooklyn was inspired by an enigmatic collaboration on a 1977 artists’ book by Samuel Beckett and Jasper Johns.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1970s, Samuel Beckett and Jasper Johns collaborated on a book, although “collaborated” is perhaps too strong a word, and “book” may not cut it, either.

headline: A Diamond Ring with Dual Personalities
abstract: The designer Kim Mee Hye’s “Swing Swing” design is fully reversible, to reveal either a jewel-encrusted or a plain metal side.
lead_paragraph: The night the Belgian jewelry designer Kim Mee Hye created her signature Swing Swing Ring, she says, felt almost Shakespearean: “Nearly a meter of rain fell in 48 hours. There was hail, there was thunder, and there was lightning.” The result? A piece that combines the impact of a blinged-out diamond ring with the understated energy of a simple, discreet one — depending on how it’s worn. It’s a ring, the designer says, created “for women who think of fine jewelry beyond the simple act of wearing a status symbol.”

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Need something to do? The Times’s arts team is here for you.
lead_paragraph: Looking for something to do this weekend?

headline: David Byrne’s Changing of the Color Guard
abstract: Mr. Byrne, who considers drill-team competitions as something of a folk art, is promoting it with a musical project called “Contemporary Color.”
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, OHIO — You may find yourself in a mall in this medium-size Midwestern city. And you may sit in a food court with a few dozen high school students. And you may discuss a song you have written for them. And they may explain how they will throw flags and rifles and sabers. And you may ask yourself: Well, how did I get here?

headline: Tapping Into the Potential of Falanghina
abstract: The best bottles from the two genetically distinct grapes from Campania are resonant wines that you’d want to come back to again and again over the course of a meal.
lead_paragraph: Ah, falanghina, I thought I knew you.

headline: Answering Questions About Your Relationship
abstract: Plus: What to do about getting a gift family quilt back, employment issues and free theater tickets.
lead_paragraph: Admittedly, my husband and I resemble each other slightly. We both have beards and thick-frame glasses (as well as two ears, a nose and mouth). But we are often asked by strangers if we are brothers (once even, if we are twins). This makes me uncomfortable. I doubt straight couples are asked if they are siblings. Why should we be treated differently? While remaining polite, I would like a reply that makes them uncomfortable, too, so they understand their question is inappropriate.

headline: Review: In ‘Me and Earl and the Dying Girl,’ a Comfort Zone That Cannot Last
abstract: Adapted from the young-adult novel, the movie centers on a teenage auteur, his filmmaking colleague and “the dying girl,” who balks at sentimentality.
lead_paragraph: The “me” in “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl” is a Pittsburgh teenager named Greg, a gangly, sarcastic young man — not quite a misfit, but also not a member of any recognizable high school social grouping — with a special fondness for movies. Greg (Thomas Mann) and Earl (RJ Cyler), his best friend since childhood, spend their spare time remaking classic films on video, using stop-motion animation and silly costumes and giving the results groan-inducing punny titles. (Samples from their extensive catalog include “The 400 Bros,” “Monorash” and “Eyes Wide Butt.”)

headline: In Draft, Yankees Try to Minimize Risk and Maximize Pitching
abstract: Trying to avoid players with injury histories, the Yankees selected pitcher James Kaprielian 16th and shortstop Kyle Holder 30th, and made pitchers 24 of their top 36 picks.
lead_paragraph: With two first-round picks, including the highest one the team has had in 22 years, the Yankees’ scouting director, Damon Oppenheimer, said Thursday in evaluating the team’s draft that he felt pressure to get this one right.

headline: Rupert Murdoch’s Step Back Will Propel Dynasty Forward
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'News and News Media']
abstract: But without Chase Carey, there is a risk that the Murdochs could lose their newfound discipline.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch is propelling his family dynasty forward by taking a step back.

headline: Bronx Rabbi Who Had Sauna Chats Is in Negotiations for Buyout
abstract: Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt of the Riverdale Jewish Center, who has been the focus of attention for having taken boys and young men to the sauna naked, anticipates a “very fair” deal, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: The prominent rabbi of a Bronx synagogue who has been the focus of attention for having taken boys and young men to the sauna naked is negotiating a buyout and expects to reach an agreement to step down “in the near future,” his lawyer said on Thursday.

headline: On City Parks, Mayor de Blasio Is Seen as Friend, Foe and Something in Between
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Critics of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s budget say it fails to address nagging maintenance problems in the system and lacks a vision for new parkland; City Hall officials defend his record.
lead_paragraph: In Mayor Bill de Blasio’s proposed budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, he allocates $1.27 billion to parks, including $150 million over four years to expand his program devoted to long-neglected parks and playgrounds in low-income neighborhoods.

headline: FIFA Spokesman Steps Down After Joking About Blatter Being Arrested
abstract: A joke about the FIFA president’s arrest apparently fell flat in the Zurich offices of world soccer’s governing body.
lead_paragraph: Suggesting once again that the FIFA saga might be beyond parody, the chief spokesman for world soccer’s governing body stepped down on Thursday, amid speculation that he was forced out for joking on Swiss television about the possible arrest of President Sepp Blatter.
