keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey leaned on the podium with his right elbow, his standard let-me-give-it-to-you-straight stance, and gave one of his classic blunt warnings, this time setting up a nearly hour-long speech laying out his educational platform.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey leaned on the podium with his right elbow, his standard let-me-give-it-to-you-straight stance, and gave one of his classic blunt warnings, this time setting up a nearly hourlong speech laying out his educational platform.

headline: Lindsey Graham, a Bachelor, Called ‘a Bro With No Ho’
abstract: A comment from Senator Mark S. Kirk about Senator Lindsey Graham led to an apology.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham’s bachelorhood became a hot topic in Congress on Thursday when Senator Mark S. Kirk was caught on an open microphone musing about Mr. Graham’s marital prospects.

headline: North Carolina Allows Officials to Refuse to Perform Gay Marriages
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Republican-controlled House overrode a veto to enact a law allowing court officials with a “sincerely held religious objection” to opt out of performing same-sex marriages.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Defying the governor, lawmakers on Thursday enacted a law that allows state court officials to refuse to perform a marriage if they have a “sincerely held religious objection,” a measure aimed at curtailing same-sex unions.

headline: Report Says Census Undercounts Mixed Race
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Census', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Native Americans']
abstract: Self-identification may account for Pew’s finding of 6.9 percent of adults as mixed race, compared with the 2010 census, which reported 2.1 percent of adults as multiracial.
lead_paragraph: The number of American adults with mixed-race backgrounds is three times what official census figures indicate, and the figure is rising fast, according to a survey released Thursday. But most do not call themselves multiracial.

headline: A Late-Bloomer Artist Finds Instagram — and Fashion
abstract: Unskilled Worker earned a mass following after being discovered by the fashion photographer Nick Knight and creating commissioned works for Gucci.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Helen Downie — the 50-year-old, London-based artist better known as “Unskilled Worker” (who hopes to retain a certain amount of anonymity) — had been clean of drugs for 10 months when she was diagnosed with breast cancer, and first felt the urge to paint. Today, she basks in her quick two-year rise from amateur painter to an Instagram sensation recently hired by Gucci to create portraits.

headline: As Supplies Dwindle, World Food Program Cutting Rations to Refugees in Kenya
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Food', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said the 30 percent cut, which could last for months, was designed to conserve dwindling supplies and funds.
lead_paragraph: The World Food Program, the anti-hunger agency of the United Nations, said Thursday that it was temporarily cutting rations to a half-million refugees in Kenya by nearly a third, an emergency move to conserve dwindling supplies and funds.

headline: JPMorgan Shakes Up a Banking Team
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: The head of the bank’s technology, media and telecommunications team, Kurt Simon, will become global chairman of mergers and acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase has shaken up its technology, media and telecommunications team, elevating several top bankers while giving the current head of the team a new senior deal maker role.

headline: Senate Rejects Measure to Strengthen Cybersecurity
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate failed Thursday to advance a measure that was intended to be part of the government’s response to a spate of computer attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the heels of a vast breach of the personal information of federal employees, the Senate failed Thursday to advance a cybersecurity measure, the third time in three years that a bipartisan effort to tackle the problem has fallen victim to procedural actions.

headline: Whimsy Just Doesn’t Show Up on a Spreadsheet
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: I always felt ashamed of my quantitative deficiencies, just as I felt a need to apologize for my creative side.
lead_paragraph: I have a soft spot for economists. I fell for a number of them and was fascinated by their thought processes, which struck me as so efficient, how they sized things up and appraised value with one glance. Their minds seemed to operate in ways mine never did.

headline: Review: Kota Yamazaki’s ‘OQ,’ a Work of Contrasting Themes
abstract: The singular qualities of Mr. Yamazaki’s Fluid hug-hug company were on display but were not enough to keep this stringent production flowing.
lead_paragraph: The palace in Kota Yamazaki’s imagination is neither made of pink plastic nor is it where princesses sneak off to dance the night away. It is stark, sealed off and vaguely forbidding. Mr. Yamazaki, a Butoh-trained choreographer, titles “OQ,” performed Friday at Japan Society, after the phonetic sound of the Japanese word for “palace” and draws inspiration from utakai, or poetry readings by Japanese aristocrats, and renga, collaboratively composed linked poems.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Becomes a Soccer Team Owner in Puerto Rico
abstract: Anthony, an eight-time N.B.A. All-Star, will be an owner of Puerto Rico F.C., an expansion team in the North American Soccer League, the league announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: While fans are wondering about his comeback from knee surgery and who will surround him on the Knicks next season, Carmelo Anthony has turned his focus to another sport.

abstract: Who are the best baseball players in Congress? An annual charity game offers some insight.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, members of Congress will head to Nationals Park, not to take in a game, but to take the field for the Congressional Baseball Game for Charity.

headline: Banded Mongooses and Careful Sex
abstract: The mammals, who never leave their social groups, have other ways to avoid mating with their nearest relatives.
lead_paragraph: Most mammals that live in social groups avoid inbreeding in a simple way: They don’t mate with others in their group.

headline: Shreveport Battles the Ravages of the Mighty Red
abstract: Residents are trying to gather what they can after a flood that has reached 37 feet, close to a historic peak in 1945.
lead_paragraph: SHREVEPORT, La. — Sheriff Steve Prator of Caddo Parish can barely recognize his house near Twelve Mile Bayou and the Red River in northern Shreveport.

headline: Tracy Antonopoulos and Gia Coppola Team Up to Salute (and Wink at) Italian Cinema
abstract: “The Magic Word,” a short film created for Peroni Nastro Azzuro’s Grazie Cinema Series, premieres online here.
lead_paragraph: “It wasn’t hard to conceptualize,” says the director Tracy Antonopoulos of her new short film “The Magic Word,” created in partnership with Peroni Nastro Azzuro for its summer Grazie Cinema Series, which debuted this week and is curated by Antonopoulos’s good friend and collaborator Gia Coppola. The five-minute film premieres online here, and begins in black and white as a girl (played by Courtney Falsey) wanders into a cafe dotted with patrons crying and looking down at their tables sullenly. After finally making eye contact with the inattentive bartender, the girl says a simple “grazie,” and the entire scene changes to a fanciful, colorful place of joy. “It’s really just about moody girls who get frustrated with the world,” Antonopoulos says bluntly. “And Fellini films, Italian cinema in general. I wanted the message to ultimately be that life can be a little bit more fun. The Italians kind of do that best.” Coppola concurs: “The film shows the lead character interacting with the world in a fun and kind manner, which is what I feel the word ‘grazie’ means,” she says. “Thanking, celebrating and saying cheers.”

headline: Women’s Pro League Offering Pay Signs Its First Player
abstract: Janine Weber signed with the New York Riveters of the National Women’s Hockey League, a new competitor for the established but nonpaying Canadian Women’s Hockey League.
lead_paragraph: Janine Weber became the first player to join the newly formed National Women’s Hockey League on Thursday, signing a free-agent contract with the New York Riveters.

headline: Review: Albert Oehlen, a Master of Disciplined Excess
abstract: Mr. Oehlen, one of the most noted artists of postwar Germany, reveals cross-fertilized chaos in this show at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: The German artist Albert Oehlen has been painting up a storm for more than 30 years, producing canvases that promulgate one kind of cross-fertilized chaos or another. The usual components include angst-free Abstract Expressionist brushwork, bits of popular advertising imagery, Surrealist automatist scribbles, spray-can vapor trails reminiscent of graffiti art and, at times, composite images built on the computer.

headline: Mylan’s Dutch Takeover Defense Is in Nasdaq’s Hands
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Mylan is taking advantage of Dutch takeover defenses to block a hostile bid by Teva Pharmaceuticals, but U.S. market rules may hamper its efforts.
lead_paragraph: These days, the pharmaceutical company Mylan is both the hunter and the hunted. The question is whether Mylan’s defense against a takeover attempt will run afoul of United States market rules and whether those rules will be enforced.

headline: Saying Goodbye After 84 Million Miles
abstract: The crew that launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Nov. 24 hands over command to a new crew led by Gennady Padalka of the Russian Federal Space Agency
lead_paragraph: The crew that launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Nov. 24 hands over command to a new crew led by Gennady Padalka of the Russian Federal Space Agency

headline: Six Personal Letters by Harper Lee to Be Auctioned at Christie’s
abstract: Correspondence from the author of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” written between 1956 and 1961 and estimated to be worth as much as $250,000, will be sold.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 12, 1960, Harper Lee sat down at her typewriter and wrote an exuberant letter to her close friend, the New York architect Harold Caufield, expressing her shock and delight at a glowing review of her debut novel.

headline: Following Smugglers in Kurdistan
abstract: Smuggling is an integral way of life in Kurdish villages where, for many, there is no other way to earn a living. It is a business that some families have practiced for generations.
lead_paragraph: Smuggling is an integral way of life in Kurdish villages where, for many, there is no other way to earn a living. It is a business that some families have practiced for generations.

lead_paragraph: A week after researchers at Baidu were barred from competing in an international computer vision contest after contest organizers discovered that scientists at the company broke the rules for the competition, the Chinese web service said that it had fired the team leader.

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For Turkey’s ubiquitous president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, it was a long time between television appearances: 3 days 22 hours 1 minute 45 seconds.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After replacing much of Twitter’s top management team last year, Dick Costolo told members of the company’s board that he wanted them to replace him as chief executive, too.

headline: The Man Who Stole Nazi-Era History From the Streets
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Archives and Records', 'ANTIQUES', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: After World War II, Zosa Szajkowski scoured the bombed-out streets of Europe for paperwork to send home to Jewish institutions — a kind of revenge for wartime atrocities.
lead_paragraph: During World War II, Zosa Szajkowski, a Polish-born historian living in Manhattan, joined the United States Army. He was later sent to Europe, where he learned how many of his Jewish relatives had been killed by the Nazis. He also scoured bombed-out streets for paperwork to send home to Jewish institutions — a kind of revenge for wartime atrocities.

headline: Saturn’s Ring of Dust and ‘Soccer Balls’
abstract: The planet’s enormous outer ring is made up of an unusual combination of fine dust and rocks the size of soccer balls, scientists have discovered.
lead_paragraph: Saturn’s outermost ring is made up of an unusual combination of fine dust particles occasionally interspersed with rocks the size of soccer balls, scientists reported in the journal Nature. The faint ring, discovered in 2009, is probably made of material ejected from one of Saturn’s moons, Phoebe. With images from NASA’s WISE spacecraft, researchers at the University of Maryland discovered that the ring was dominated by small particles, a rarity in our solar system, while the ring itself is enormous, 10 times as big as the E ring, the next largest.

headline: Virginia Is Latest Front in Democrats’ Voting Rights Battle
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'State Legislatures', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Democrats are challenging Virginia’s voter identification law, saying it will suppress turnout, especially among minorities, the poor and the young.
lead_paragraph: Democrats allied with Hillary Rodham Clinton have filed a voting rights lawsuit in Virginia, the third time they have done so in a crucial presidential battleground state in the last two months.

headline: Review: In ‘The Yes Men Are Revolting,’ Prankster Activists Take On Climate Change
abstract: The third documentary follows this comic duo through some personal struggles as they train their sights on global warming.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing for political pranksters to play dirty tricks on corporations whose agendas they oppose, but it’s quite another for their shenanigans to be carried out with the ingenuity and humor of comic performance art. Take the Yes Men, Mike Bonanno and Andy Bichlbaum (not their real names), subversive political satirists who dream up elaborate stunts to embarrass climate-change deniers.

headline: Pamela Paul, Book Review Editor, Talks Shop
abstract: Pamela Paul, editor of The New York Times Book Review, spoke to C-Span’s Book TV about how the weekly section comes together and the criteria for reviewed books.
lead_paragraph: “It feels terrible when it’s happening to you,” Pamela Paul, editor of The Book Review said when asked about the purpose of negative reviews in a conversation with C-Span’s Book TV. “But, you know what I remind myself when we have negative reviews is that we’re not a service arm for the publishing industry,” she said. “We’re here for the readers. And readers are trying to make a decision about what they should spend their time reading and their money buying if they’re buying a book.”

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Money Market Accounts']

lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Investors in mutual funds in New York and London may complain about the fees they pay, but they are getting no sympathy in Brazil.

headline: Cleveland Judge Finds Probable Cause to Charge Officers in Tamir Rice Death
abstract: The judge, Ronald B. Adrine, also said he did not have the power to order the arrest of the two officers without a complaint being filed by a prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Cleveland ruled Thursday that probable cause existed to charge two Cleveland police officers in the death of a 12-year-old boy, Tamir Rice, but the judge also said he did not have the power to order arrests without a complaint being filed by a prosecutor.

headline: Review: Robert Kurson’s ‘Pirate Hunters,’ a Real-Life Treasure Hunt
abstract: Mr. Kurson’s book recounts the search for the wreckage of a ship that was commandeered in the 1680s by a wily merchant sea captain who went rogue.
lead_paragraph: For all of Robert Kurson’s efforts to fill his latest book, “Pirate Hunters,” with hyperbolic thrills, its best pages are those that summarize his “Shadow Divers” (2004), one of the most fascinating, pulse-quickening true stories to hit best-seller lists in recent years.

headline: Elmer Crowell’s Barn Is Rebuilt in Cape Cod
abstract: The workshop of this premier decoy carver opens to the public on June 21.
lead_paragraph: The Cape Cod barn where the woodcarver Elmer Crowell produced decoy birds, which have sold for more than $1 million each, opens to the public on June 21. Mr. Crowell (rhymes with roll) worked a few miles from the Harwich Historical Society in Massachusetts, where his outbuilding has been reconstructed.

headline: Big Apple Barbecue Block Party Offers a Taste of Country
abstract: This festival and the Peekaboo Opry in Brooklyn cater to both food and music fans.
lead_paragraph: To take a last-minute trip to the South this weekend, you needn’t look farther than Madison Square Park.

headline: Egyptian Police Officer Convicted in Killing of Activist
abstract: The killing of the activist, Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, in January shocked and captivated Egyptians, because of her evident innocence of any crime.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian police officer was convicted Thursday of a form of manslaughter for killing a poet and activist by shooting her at close range with birdshot. The court sentenced the officer to 15 years in prison.

headline: Fighting Brutality at Rikers Island
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Criminal charges in the death of a 52-year-old inmate come just days after a former inmate’s suicide.
lead_paragraph: The house-of-horrors stories that federal prosecutors keep uncovering at New York City’s Rikers Island jail bear a striking resemblance to the torture that transpired at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq during the early days of the war — when prisoners were threatened, beaten, shocked, stripped and starved of food and sleep as a matter of course.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: A look back on how William Butler Yeats’s life and work was reported in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Saturday is the 150th anniversary of the birth of William Butler Yeats. A year of events (including an Irish Repertory Theater fund-raiser held on Monday at Town Hall in New York, at which the poet’s granddaughter read “The Lake Isle of Innisfree”) culminates with a festival in Sligo, Ireland, this weekend.

headline: Review: Torbjorn Rodland Mixes the Religious With the Evocative
abstract: Mr. Rodland’s “Drunken Man” and “The Mirror” photographs are part of his show at Algus Greenspon.
lead_paragraph: A Norwegian artist who lives in Los Angeles, Torbjorn Rodland creates photographs that are formally acute, conceptually playful and psychologically evocative. The most intriguing of the large color prints in his show have eccentric religious overtones.

headline: Camp After a Transplant: Harder on Mother Than Daughter
abstract: The entire point of my daughter’s transplant was not just to save her life, but to give her a full one. I had to let her go to camp.
lead_paragraph: Yet again, I debriefed Paula, the head nurse who stood before me with a ream of medical records.

lead_paragraph: In the months since the Federal Communications Commission voted to regulate the Internet like a public utility, opponents of the new rules have clamored to keep them from taking effect this Friday.

headline: I.R.S. Adds New Safeguards to Thwart Identity Theft and Fraud
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Identity Theft', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation']
abstract: The agency said it would require more rigorous authentication before releasing information and refunds, and would try to pinpoint patterns of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Reeling from an online attack that allowed criminals to steal personal information and divert tax refunds from tens of thousands of taxpayers, the Internal Revenue Service announced on Thursday a sweeping effort to step up protections against identity theft and fraud. The actions are expected to be completed by early next year, well before the April 15 filing deadline.

headline: Review: Rasheed Araeen Has First New York Solo Show at Aicon Gallery
abstract: Mr. Araeen’s conspicuously handmade sculptures are often overlooked, even though he’s been an art-world legend since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Born in Pakistan in 1935 and a London resident since 1964, Rasheed Araeen has been an art-world legend since the 1980s, when he founded and edited Third Text, a journal that not only gave a voice to contemporary non-Western and nonwhite artists but also helped initiate an entire rethinking of 20th-century art history. Mr. Araeen also produced some of the most influential writing of the time (I still have his clips from 30 years ago) and organized shows like “The Other Story” in London, which laid the foundation for the concept that modernism, far from being a Western phenomenon, had happened all over the world, on different schedules.

headline: Shares of Axovant, Alzheimer’s Drug Developer, Surge on Trading Debut
abstract: The company, which bought an unproven Alzheimer’s drug for $5 million, is now valued at nearly $3 billion. The successful debut renews concerns that biotechnology stocks are in bubble territory.
lead_paragraph: A 29-year-old former hedge fund manager has pulled off what is perhaps the largest initial public stock offering ever in the biotechnology industry, creating a company with a market value approaching $3 billion on the basis of an unproved drug for Alzheimer’s disease that it acquired for $5 million.

headline: Review: In ‘Joan of Arc at the Stake,’ Beasts With Burden of Judging
abstract: New York Philharmonic’s production of Honegger’s great French oratorio “Joan of Arc at the Stake” features the Oscar-winning French actress Marion Cotillard.
lead_paragraph: During a transfixing moment of the New York Philharmonic’s starkly dramatic staged performance of Honegger’s great French oratorio “Joan of Arc at the Stake” on Wednesday night, the superb actress Marion Cotillard, as Joan, a spoken role, stepped haltingly across a walkway extending past the orchestra into the auditorium. At first she looked dazed and distracted. Was Joan absorbed with spiritual reverie? Hearing heavenly voices again? Or out of her mind? It seemed eerily unclear.

headline: Review: From Joan Snyder, a Profusion of Flowers at Franklin Parrasch
abstract: Ms. Snyder continues her focus on rose paintings, here rendered with mud, rosebuds, straw and fabric.
lead_paragraph: Joan Snyder, who had her first solo show in New York in 1970, has always been extremely present in her paintings and, like them or not, this intensity is in itself an achievement. The best of her latest efforts, produced over the last two years, confront us with heavy textures, strong colors, bursting roseate motifs and sometimes fraught bits of language, which all coalesce into a visceral self-expression that uses nearly every means at a painter’s disposal, and then some. For Ms. Snyder, painting functions as a kind of scrapbook, diary, garden journal and bulletin board.

headline: Review: ‘Figuratively Considered’ Looks at Early American Modernists
abstract: This show at Kraushaar Galleries focuses on unsung artists from the early 20th century, before everything went abstract.
lead_paragraph: Never underestimate the gems by unsung artists to be found along the less-traveled byways of the New York gallery world. Case in point is a selection of paintings, drawings and prints by American artists at the Kraushaar Galleries, which was founded in 1885 and is still going.

headline: A Few of Christopher Lee’s 250 Faces
abstract: Christopher Lee’s many characters often turned from good to evil in franchises like “Lord of the Rings” and “Star Wars.” His turn as Dracula made him famous, but he also had quite the singing voice.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Lee’s many characters often turned from good to evil in franchises like “Lord of the Rings” and “Star Wars.” His turn as Dracula made him famous, but he also had quite the singing voice.

lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — Someday, museums will run out of themes for packaging van Gogh exhibitions, and that’s fine. He’s one of those artists you just want to spend time with, no pretext needed, because he’s some kind of instant soul mate, startling, difficult, vulnerable, always willing to make so much of himself available to you.

headline: James Holmes’s Ex-Girlfriend Recalls Awkwardness and Ghoulish Remarks
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Gargi Datta, the former girlfriend of the accused Aurora gunman, said in court on Thursday that Mr. Holmes had mused unsettlingly about evil and justice.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — They got to know each other during a study group and had their first date at a horror film festival. She was his first girlfriend, and though he said he loved her, she never felt close to him. He was awkward and introverted, and mused unsettlingly about evil and justice. She once told him he should see a therapist.

headline: ‘Me and Earl and the Dying Girl’ (With Movie Trailer): Alfonso Gomez-Rejon Narrates a Scene
abstract: The director discusses a scene from “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl.”
lead_paragraph: In the comedic drama “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl,” a movie-obsessed teenager named Greg (Thomas Mann) befriends his classmate Rachel (Olivia Cooke), who has been diagnosed with leukemia. The friendship begins reluctantly when Greg’s mother (Connie Britton) forces him to call Rachel in this early scene from the film. The sequence plays out in one continuous take as the camera roams through Greg’s home and we listen in on his conversation with Rachel.

abstract: This new one-acre children’s area abounds with opportunities to play, learn and get muddy.
lead_paragraph: Children’s gardens often have that unfortunate dumbing-down-of-nature quality — giant neon caterpillars, cutesy mushroom houses — but there is no such condescension at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s new Discovery Garden, which opened last Saturday.

headline: New Gallery to Inject a Bit of New York Into Downtown Art World of Los Angeles
abstract: Exhibition spaces are popping up in Los Angeles, while the Metropolitan Museum of Art is getting a gift from the Irving Penn Foundation that will become part of a retrospective.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t an expansion on the level of a Zwirner or Gagosian, but Michele Maccarone is adding a second gallery to her stable — this time in Downtown Los Angeles. Ms. Maccarone, known for her rough and funky spaces — originally on the Lower East Side and now in the West Village — is to open her new gallery on Sept. 19, one day before the scheduled debut of the Broad Museum nearby.

headline: Legislature May Make Lunar New Year a School Holiday in New York City
abstract: Bills in Albany suggest that legislators do not want to wait for the de Blasio administration to reach its own decision on the issue.
lead_paragraph: The State Senate voted unanimously this week to make the first day of the Asian lunar calendar a school holiday in New York City, and the State Assembly plans to consider a similar bill next week, suggesting that the Legislature does not want to wait for the de Blasio administration to reach its own decision on the issue.

headline: Costolo Exit at Twitter Kick-Starts Deal Speculation
abstract: Twitter executives and their advisers took pains to say that Dick Costolo’s departure as C.E.O. was not tied to an external event, but rumors persist.
lead_paragraph: For deal makers, the departure of a chief executive always raises an interesting question: Is that company for sale?

headline: The Comings and Goings of Twitter Executives
abstract: In the last three years, most of the top executives at Twitter have come and gone, including most recently its chief.
lead_paragraph: In the last three years, most of the top executives at Twitter have come and gone, including most recently its chief.

headline: Review: ‘The Wolfpack’ Shares the Story of Brothers and a Cinematic Lifeline
abstract: Six young men who steeped themselves in film when they were prevented from venturing past their apartment door are the subject of Crystal Moselle’s intimate documentary.
lead_paragraph: Movies can change your life, but can they save it? For most people that probably sounds foolish, but the six brothers featured in the astonishing documentary “The Wolfpack” aren’t most people. For much of their lives, these six ingenious young men used the movies to imaginatively if not physically break out of their Lower Manhattan apartment in a building run by the New York City Housing Authority. Even as their father all but imprisoned them (one year they never left the apartment), they made great metaphoric escapes by immersing themselves in the fictional realms created by directors like Francis Ford Coppola and Quentin Tarantino.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Jurassic World,” “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl” and “The Wolfpack.”

headline: Civic Group Sues to Halt Hudson River Park Backed by Barry Diller
abstract: Critics want construction on the $130 million project to stop until it undergoes an environmental review and wins approval from the State Legislature.
lead_paragraph: Critics of the billionaire Barry Diller’s plans for 2.4-acre park on a platform over the Hudson River asked a court on Thursday to halt construction of the $130 million project until it undergoes a new environmental review and is approved by the State Legislature.

headline: Israeli Report Backs Tactics by Military in Gaza War
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Ahead of a U.N. commission report, the Israeli military issued an update on its internal inquiries, saying neither Israeli nor international laws were broken in several deadly clashes.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With a United Nations commission expected to soon release its report on last summer’s war between Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip, the Israeli military late Thursday issued an update on its internal inquiries, saying neither Israeli nor international laws were broken in several attacks that led to civilian deaths.

headline: Facebook Offers a Glimpse of Oculus Rift Goggles
abstract: The company outlined ambitious plans for the virtual reality headset, but didn’t actually demonstrate the product.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook showed the world its first commercial version of virtual reality on Thursday — and offered tantalizing hints of how it hopes to turn three-dimensional goggles into a new kind of computing and communications device.

headline: Dog-Related Bills Flood Albany as Major Legislation Stalls
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: The canine subjects of dozens of measures awaiting passage are perennially popular with constituents, perhaps more so than the lawmakers themselves.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — They bark at their lobbyists, never talk to lawmakers, and periodically lose control of themselves in the halls of the State Capitol. And yet, for all of that, there is one constituency whose interests are exceptionally well represented in Albany this year.

headline: Review: ‘Madame Bovary’ Features Mia Wasikowska as a Notorious Adulteress
abstract: This costume-drama adaptation of Flaubert’s “Madame Bovary” stays true to the plot.
lead_paragraph: “Madame Bovary, c’est moi,” Gustave Flaubert said of his most famous fictional creation. Impulsive, vain and sometimes cruel, she is hardly the most sympathetic character in 19th-century literature, but she is among the most vivid and complicated. Flaubert illuminated her inner life and outward circumstances with a clarity that set a new standard for the novel, one that continues to beguile, and often to frustrate, his followers.

headline: De Blasio Calls Trans-Pacific Partnership a ‘Huge Mistake’
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York raised the possibilities of lower wages and costlier medicines if the trade agreement with nearly a dozen Asian nations is approved by Congress.
lead_paragraph: Reviving a public split with the White House, Mayor Bill de Blasio declared on the eve of a key vote in Washington that it would be a “huge mistake” for Congress to approve President Obama’s chief legislative priority, a sweeping trade deal known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

headline: Review: In ‘Chagall-Malevich,’ Two Painters Clash in Revolutionary Russia
abstract: A color-saturated Russian movie looks at Marc Chagall’s tumultuous time leading an art school in Vitebsk, where one of the teachers was Kazimir Malevich.
lead_paragraph: Set primarily in revolutionary-era Russia, Alexander Mitta’s “Chagall-Malevich” centers on the painter Marc Chagall and fictionalizes his real-life efforts to establish an artistic bulwark amid war and ideological ferment. It’s a literally colorful and playful attempt to portray battlefields of artistic ambition and political struggle. But its dialogue and characters are also written as subtly as a radical manifesto.

headline: Defying Obama, Many in Congress Press to Arm Ukraine
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Senate has included provisions in its military policy bill to arm Ukraine with antiarmor systems, mortars, grenade launchers and ammunition to aid in its fight against Russian-backed separatists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the peace process stalled and violence escalating in Ukraine, a bipartisan coalition in Congress is defying President Obama and European allies by pressing the administration to provide weapons to the embattled nation.

headline: Review: In ‘The 11th Hour,’ Fertility Anxiety Gets Thriller Treatment
abstract: A woman desperate to be a mother and a heroin-addicted dwarf journey to Eastern Europe for a baby.
lead_paragraph: An unborn baby and a ticking biological clock make the scariest sounds in “The 11th Hour,” a troubling example of what can only be called a fertility thriller.

headline: A Chinese Ebola Drug Raises Hopes, and Rancor
abstract: The production of an experimental Ebola treatment by a small Chinese company has led to patent infringement claims by American officials and disagreements among doctors.
lead_paragraph: After a nurse who contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone was discharged Wednesday from a Rome hospital, a doctor there described the experimental treatments the patient had received as “absolutely miraculous.”

headline: Save the Children Group Is Shut Down in Pakistan
abstract: The Pakistani authorities on Thursday shut down the aid group’s office in Islamabad and ordered its foreign staff members to leave the country within 15 days.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani authorities on Thursday shut down the aid group Save the Children’s office in Islamabad and ordered its foreign staff members to leave the country within 15 days.

headline: Review: ‘Eli Roth Presents the Stranger,’ a Tale Steeped in Blood
abstract: Guillermo Amoedo’s movie concerns an outsider with a strange but beneficial affliction.
lead_paragraph: Though the full title of Guillermo Amoedo’s “The Stranger” bears the name of one of the film’s producers, the horror specialist Eli Roth (“Hostel”), it has its own singular, and gruesome, distinctions.

headline: 2015 Women’s World Cup: Norway Holds Top-Ranked Germany to a Tie
abstract: Norway tied top-ranked Germany, 1-1, on Thursday, while the United States will have its most anticipated match of the group stage on Friday against Sweden.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S RESULTS

headline: Database May Help Identify Veterans on the Edge
abstract: Health care is increasingly using sophisticated algorithms to predict medical outcomes. Now the focus is on those who have served.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at the Department of Veterans Affairs and the National Institutes of Health have developed a database they say can identify veterans with a high likelihood of suicide, in much the same way consumer data is used to predict shopping habits.

headline: Review: ‘An Open Secret’ Spotlights Child Sexual Abuse in Hollywood
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: In this documentary, directed by Amy Berg, former child actors recount the manipulations, cover-ups and exploitations they encountered in the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: You may miss a few moments of “An Open Secret,” either while looking away during its unsettling stories or closing your eyes in frustration. This potent documentary elicits those kinds of reactions.

headline: A Court Keeps People Out of Rikers While Remaining Tough
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The Red Hook Community Justice Center has reduced jailings, recidivism and costs, but one city councilwoman has blocked an attempt to duplicate it in Brownsville.
lead_paragraph: Maybe we don’t need to have 12,000 people kept on Rikers Island.

headline: Louisiana Lawmakers Hold Their Noses as They Balance the Budget
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A funding solution to the state’s worst budget shortfall in decades evoked bipartisan criticism, but was viewed as a necessity to get a budget past Gov. Bobby Jindal.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — With less than two hours left in the 2015 session, Louisiana legislators agreed Thursday on a solution to the worst budget shortfall in decades, approving a funding arrangement that drew bipartisan criticism but was seen as the only way to gain the support of Gov. Bobby Jindal and avert fiscal disaster.

headline: Christen Press Went Abroad and Found a Place on the U.S. Team
abstract: Press escaped the pressure of American sports culture by playing soccer in Sweden, and the detour saved her passion for the game. She is now a staple of the United States national team.
lead_paragraph: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — When Christen Press scored a goal on Monday in the United States’ game against Australia, there was a lightness to her celebration.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Blogger’s Allies Rebuffed
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Saudi Arabia rejected foreign criticism of the flogging punishment of Raif Badawi, a blogger who has come to symbolize the kingdom’s oppressive restraints on free speech.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia on Thursday rejected foreign criticism of the conviction and flogging punishment of Raif Badawi, a blogger who has come to symbolize what human rights advocates call the kingdom’s oppressive restraints on free speech and its cruel justice system. The Foreign Ministry, in a brief statement carried by the official Saudi Press Agency, described the criticism as interference in the kingdom’s internal affairs. The United States government commission on religious freedom, the European Union and human rights groups have asked King Salman to pardon Mr. Badawi, 31, whose sentence of 1,000 lashes, to be administered in weekly rounds of 50 each, was suspended in January after the first round nearly killed him. But this month the kingdom’s highest court affirmed the validity of the conviction and the punishment, which also includes a 10-year prison term and a $267,000 fine. The court’s decision appeared to allow for the resumption of the floggings, which could happen as early as Friday.

headline: Once Down, James Murdoch Is Guided Back to the Top
abstract: When he left Britain in the wake of a phone-hacking scandal, the younger Murdoch seemed too tarnished to inherit his father’s mantle.
lead_paragraph: It would be hard to overstate how bad James Murdoch’s reputation was in London when he left town some three and a half years ago.

headline: Obama Makes Surprise Trip to Nationals Park to Lobby Pelosi
abstract: Facing the prospect of a devastating defeat in Congress, President Obama abruptly summoned his motorcade and raced to a charity baseball game to lobby his top Democratic ally in the House to stand with him on trade.
lead_paragraph: Facing the prospect of a devastating defeat in Congress, President Obama abruptly summoned his motorcade on Thursday night and raced to a charity baseball game to track down and lobby his top Democratic ally in the House to stand with him on trade.

headline: An Unfamiliar and Tricky Course Adds to the Challenge in an L.P.G.A. Major
abstract: Jenny Shin, with a seven-under 66 at Westchester Country’s Club’s West Course, held the lead after the first round of the Women’s P.G.A. Championship.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.Y. — On any given week on the L.P.G.A. Tour, Christina Kim’s routine has few wrinkles. Play some practice-round holes before the tournament starts, keep putting preparation to about 20 minutes, then go out and play. But that has changed this week.

headline: Review: ‘Set Fire to the Stars’ Unleashes Dylan Thomas on America
abstract: The film follows the poet to the United States in an era when the romantic notion that drunkenness was a shortcut to enlightenment held sway.
lead_paragraph: Time was when the lilting incantations of the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas were viewed as visionary outpourings of a holy bohemian by audiences entranced by his mellifluous voice. Thomas was one of the first modern poets who understood that poetry readings were as much show business as they were art. Those were the days — the late 1940s and early 1950s — when the romantic notion that drunkenness was a shortcut to enlightenment held sway, and a buttoned-up society allowed bad boys like Thomas, who died in 1953 at 39, relatively free rein to misbehave.

headline: Guns at Hand, a Prison Town Tracks a Manhunt for Escaped Convicts
abstract: In Dannemora, N.Y., where two killers escaped last weekend, caution and self-protection have been on the minds even of residents accustomed to living near the prison.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — In a town where residents are either corrections officers or live next door to one, few admit to being fearful about the two convicted murderers who escaped the walls of the prison here last weekend. But their actions reveal a heightened watchfulness.

headline: Sharks’ 1,400-Mile Truck Trip to Brooklyn Ends Too Soon
abstract: One of four fish being transported from Florida to the New York Aquarium died after a tire blew out on the truck carrying them.
lead_paragraph: Four sandbar sharks left their home in Marathon, Fla., on Wednesday morning, bound for their new home at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Season 3 Premiere Recap: Mother’s Day Visit
abstract: “Orange” is back and Litchfield is throwing a party.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 1: Mother’s Day

headline: For Twitter, Future Means Here and Now
abstract: Twitter should aim to become the first and only app that people load up to comment on the news.
lead_paragraph: Here, in 140 characters or fewer, is some free advice for Twitter’s next chief executive: Focus on live events. People never tire of gabbing about what’s going on right now. Twitter could be the best place for that. Do it fast.

headline: Review: ‘Live From New York!’ Celebrates 40 Years of ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: This documentary, directed by Bao Nguyen and part of the Tribeca Film Festival, chronicles that TV comedy show as a cultural institution but fails to explore its inner workings.
lead_paragraph: “Live From New York!,” Bao Nguyen’s unfocused, skimpy history of “Saturday Night Live,” resembles a smiley-faced Sunday morning infomercial for a vintage pop music collection. Stumbling upon such an ad, chances are you might linger long enough to feel a nostalgic tug upon hearing a fragment of a favorite oldie but goodie before changing channels. You are also reminded of how much time has passed and how quickly the years have flown. The show’s 40-year existence, after all, is roughly half a lifetime.

headline: Outsourcing Companies Under Scrutiny Over Visas for Technology Workers
abstract: The Department of Labor is investigating two India-based firms for possible violations of rules for visas for foreign technology workers under contracts they held with Southern California Edison.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Labor has opened an investigation into two India-based outsourcing companies for possible violations of rules for visas for foreign technology workers under contracts they held with an electric utility, Southern California Edison. The power company recently laid off more than 500 technology workers. Many said they were made to train replacements who were immigrants on temporary visas, known as H-1B, brought in by the Indian firms, Tata Consultancy Services and Infosys. Senators Richard Durbin of Illinois, a Democrat, and Jeff Sessions of Alabama, a Republican, announced the investigation after they were notified by the department.

headline: David Guttenfelder, a Photojournalist, Answers Readers’ Questions on North Korea
abstract: Mr. Guttenfelder has been to North Korea about 40 times. He answers questions on working conditions, local cuisine and American TV.
lead_paragraph: David Guttenfelder, a photojournalist and National Geographic Fellow, recently spent six days in North Korea on assignment for The New York Times. He answered readers’ questions during a Q. and A. on Facebook on Thursday on everyday life in North Korea and his working conditions there. Mr. Guttenfelder, who has been to North Korea about 40 times, received questions on a wide range of topics, including malnutrition, censorship and the availability of American TV shows like “Keeping Up With the Kardashians.”

headline: Former Worker Arrested in Brooklyn Group Home Investigation
abstract: City investigators said that Denzel Thompson, 24, had falsified logbooks and stopped monitoring the home’s residents, three of whom are accused of raping and robbing a woman in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A worker at a group home for boys in Brooklyn has been arrested after three boys he claimed he was monitoring slipped out of the home, city investigators said on Thursday. The boys are accused of raping, robbing and beating a woman while they were out.

headline: Review: ‘Guards at the Taj,’ Two Ordinary Guys Ordered to Do the Unthinkable
abstract: This two-hander by Rajiv Joseph dramatizes a dark myth about the construction of the Taj Mahal.
lead_paragraph: The Taj Mahal is among the world’s most ravishingly beautiful creations, but should you have a chance to see it in person after watching “Guards at the Taj,” a new play by Rajiv Joseph, you may find yourself viewing it through a bloodstained haze. In this mostly absorbing two-hander, which opened on Thursday in an Atlantic Theater Company production directed by the noted actor Amy Morton, Mr. Joseph dramatizes a dark myth about its building that stands as a grim allegory of the supreme divide between the powerful and the powerless in 17th-century India and, perhaps by extension, many places today.

headline: Emulate an Esne
abstract: Friday fun with David Steinberg, and why you should try to solve themeless puzzles, if you haven’t already.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Are you READY to roll with the crunchy fun of a themeless Friday puzzle? Or are you letting the white space and ramped-up clues frighten you away?

headline: 12 Held as Police Break Up Staten Island Heroin Ring
abstract: Officials said the operation was run by two stepbrothers, who enlisted their girlfriends and shared the proceeds with their mother, and extended to other New York City boroughs.
lead_paragraph: The New York police this week broke up a sprawling family-run network of drug dealers, according to the acting district attorney for Staten Island, who said the ring was run by two stepbrothers whose operation helped fuel an explosion of heroin use in the borough.

headline: Federal Money for Education Surpasses States’ Contributions
abstract: Much of the growth of federal higher-education spending has been increases in veterans’ education benefits and Pell grants.
lead_paragraph: Reversing a pattern, federal funding for higher education has in recent years outstripped state funding. According to a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts, the federal government supplied $75.6 billion in 2013, the latest year for which data is available, and state governments supplied $72.7 billion. From 2000 to 2012, federal per-student spending increased by 32 percent, while state spending dropped by 37 percent. Generally, the federal government provides financial help to individual students and specific research projects, while state funds go toward public institutions’ general operations. Much of the growth of federal higher-education spending has been increases in veterans’ education benefits and Pell grants.

headline: David Wilson Makes Jump (Actually Three) to Life After N.F.L.
abstract: Wilson, whose N.F.L. career with the Giants was cut short by a neck injury, will make his professional track and field debut in the triple jump on Saturday in the Adidas Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: Ten months after saying a tearful goodbye to football, the former Giants running back David Wilson is running again.

headline: Knee Injury Also Hurts Finances of New Jet
abstract: Stevan Ridley, who tore the anterior cruciate and medial collateral ligaments in his right knee in his final year before free agency, got a one-year contract from the Jets worth $1.25 million.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When Stevan Ridley excelled as a running back at Louisiana State, he dreamed of earning a lucrative N.F.L. contract one day and the material pleasures it would bring. When he signed a relatively modest deal as a third-round draft choice of the New England Patriots in 2011, he drew motivation from knowing that free agency could yield the big money he desired once he proved himself.

headline: Cuomo Seeks to Link Bills on Rent Regulation and Private School Tax Credits
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Education (K-12)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he was trying to play mediator by getting Assembly to approve the tax credits and the Senate to continue rent regulations.

headline: Mervin Field Dies at 94; Took Pulse of California as Pollster
abstract: Mr. Field, who started a research company in 1945, was an institutional memory of public opinion in an opinionated state.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mervin Field was a college dropout. He had no formal training in polling or statistics. He bagged groceries while growing up in Princeton, N.J. He went to San Francisco after World War II with the unlikely goal of starting a one-man marketing research firm. Business was so slow that he worked nights pumping gas.

They charged into the reporter’s house and reminded him that he had been warned many times that “he should not write anything against the minister.”

headline: Good Fortune Comes and Goes, but Mets Grind Out a Win

lead_paragraph: When Mets Manager Terry Collins ran into the Hall 0f Fame pitcher John Smoltz on Thursday afternoon, he had to reply with a mix of humor and curtness when asked how he was doing.

headline: At the Whitney’s Untitled Restaurant, Downtown Plates Mirror the Change in Scenery
abstract: The chefs discuss their High Line-influenced ethos.
lead_paragraph: When the Whitney Museum of American Art moved from the Upper East Side to the Meatpacking District this spring, it traded its proximity to the large green rectangle of Central Park for sweeping views of the High Line, where Piet Oudolf’s unruly garden landscape spills onto the former railroad trestle in the most organic of ways. In the above video, the chefs at the Whitney’s new restaurant, Untitled, discuss how the museum’s change in scenery inspires the dishes they serve and the atmosphere they have created within the new Renzo Piano-designed building. And below, they share a recipe off the Untitled menu for lobster toast.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:45 A.M. (Sundance) DOMINO (2005) Keira Knightley stars as Domino Harvey, the daughter of a jet-setting mother and the movie actor Laurence Harvey, who, despite her privileged upbringing, became a bounty hunter in South Central Los Angeles. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this biopic, whose ensemble cast features Mickey Rourke, Christopher Walken, Delroy Lindo, Jacqueline Bisset, Dabney Coleman and Mo’Nique, a “lollapalooza of delectable cheap thrills.” What makes it “the ultimate Tony Scott movie — or as a friend put it, ‘It’s all the Tony Scott you could possibly want in a Tony Scott movie!’ — is its uncharacteristically sharp screenplay,” she said of its script by Richard Kelly. “Mr. Scott has worked with talented writers before, but this is the first time he has shot a film written by a screenwriter who both cops to the great enjoyment that can be had from the modern action movie — perhaps best illustrated here by the sight of Ms. Knightley unloading two machine guns at once — and blows the action-movie tropes to smithereens.”

headline: Following Smugglers in Kurdistan
abstract: Smuggling is an integral way of life in Kurdish villages where, for many, there is no other way to earn a living. It is a business that some families have practiced for generations.
lead_paragraph: Born in the Sulaimaniyah Governorate of Iraqi Kurdistan, Aram Karim had long been aware of the smugglers whose covert businesses, ferrying all manner of goods, operated along the borders that fragmented his native land. Granted, he had a personal insight from years ago: He had tried — and failed — to be smuggled into Turkey three times. Yet while the struggles of these impoverished villagers living on the margins were widely known, they were rarely documented.

headline: How Adulthood Happens
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Age, Chronological', 'Books and Literature', 'Youth', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The “Odyssey Years” before age 30 are a crucial part of American adults’ formation.
lead_paragraph: Every society has its rites of passage, marking the transition from youth to adulthood. Most of these rites of passage are ritualized and structured, with adult supervision and celebration. But the major rite of passage in our society is unritualized, unstructured and unnamed. Most of the people in the middle of it don’t even know it is going on. It happens between ages 22 and 30.

headline: Seriously Bad Ideas
abstract: The financial crisis has given remarkable staying power to false explanations of big events. And they continue to warp policy.
lead_paragraph: Oxford, Britain — One thing we’ve learned in the years since the financial crisis is that seriously bad ideas — by which I mean bad ideas that appeal to the prejudices of Very Serious People — have remarkable staying power. No matter how much contrary evidence comes in, no matter how often and how badly predictions based on those ideas are proved wrong, the bad ideas just keep coming back. And they retain the power to warp policy.

headline: A Pill to Boost Female Libido
abstract: The drug should only be approved if measures are taken to reduce safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: A federal advisory panel has recommended that the Food and Drug Administration approve the first drug to treat a lack of sexual desire in otherwise healthy women. Some women’s groups are hailing this as a breakthrough in gender equality, a start to closing the gap between men, who have numerous drugs to treat sexual dysfunction, and women, who have none. But the panel’s recommendation was laced with so many caveats that it seems clear that this particular drug — flibanserin — is only marginally effective and carries some risk of serious adverse effects.

Andrew Cuomo and the Legislature have no excuse for failing to deal with some of the most urgent matters on their agenda, like housing in New York City.

headline: ‘The Tribe,’ Set at a Grim School for the Deaf, Forgoes Subtitles for Its Fierce Sign Language
abstract: This wordless Ukrainian drama, directed by Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy, depicts a student’s assimilation into a gang at a boarding school for the deaf.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that a film from Ukraine is released in the United States without subtitles. But “The Tribe” is in so many ways a special case: a crime drama about a teenage “deaf mafia” in which the only words used are sign language. As conceived, written and directed by Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy, the movie tells its story of violence and love through visuals alone, withholding translations of the nonprofessional actors’ passionate signing.

headline: ‘Goodfellas,’ 25 Years On: Cast Members Reminisce
abstract: Principals in the making of Martin Scorsese’s “Goodfellas” reminisce about the shoot on the film’s 25th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 25 years since Martin Scorsese’s seminal gangster film “Goodfellas” opened to the adulation of critics, among them Vincent Canby of The New York Times, who hailed it as “breathless and brilliant.” Though it’s now considered a classic, counted by the American Film Institute as one of the country’s 100 greatest films, its foul-mouthed tale of the rise and fall of the murderous Henry Hill; his wife, Karen; and his patron, Paulie, left early audiences cold. In a nod to the anniversary, Film Forum is screening a newly restored version of the movie starting next Friday.

abstract: Some 140,000 Rohingya Muslims, a persecuted ethnic group in Myanmar, are confined to a squalid government encampment in Sittwe. Tens of thousands have fled, setting out on a risky sea voyage. Many are still missing.
lead_paragraph: At a makeshift government encampment in Sittwe, Myanmar, holding 140,000 Rohingya, a persecuted Muslim ethnic group, I asked camp residents if they had relatives who had traveled to Malaysia.

headline: Scott Walker and the Fate of the Union
abstract: In Wisconsin, where the labor movement took root a century ago, a campaign by the governor has broken its power. His political allies hope he can take a similar campaign nationwide.
lead_paragraph: On his first day of work in three months, Randy Bryce asked his foreman for the next day off. He wanted to go to the Capitol in Madison, Wis., and testify against a proposed law. Bryce, a member of Milwaukee Ironworkers Local 8, was unloading truckloads of steel beams to build a warehouse near Kenosha, and he needed the job. He has an 8-year-old son, his debts were piling up and a 10-hour shift paid more than $300. But the legislation, which Republicans were rushing through the State Senate, angered him enough to sacrifice the hours. Supporters called it a “right to work” bill, because it prohibited unions from requiring employees to pay dues. But to Bryce, that appealing name hid the true purpose of the bill, which was to destroy unions.

headline: Mow the Lawn
abstract: Life is more repetitive than revelatory. To find happiness, perform the task at hand well.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — My youngest child, Adele, graduated from the American School in London this week. She’s off to college in California, whence I suspect she will never return. As places to stay go, California is up there. Whenever I’m there I wonder why I leave. Unencumbered by too much past, it offers the sunlit tug of the future.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — France’s privacy watchdog on Friday called on Google to apply a European data protection ruling to its global domains or face financial penalties.

headline: Advancing TB Test Technology, Where It Matters Most
abstract: Efforts to make tuberculosis detection portable and affordable enough to reach millions in rural areas are underway.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning in a Ho Chi Minh City intensive-care unit, Cao Thi My Hanh sat crying and clutching her 5-month-old granddaughter, Nguyen Dang Thanh Phuong. More than a month earlier she had noticed the baby coughing and struggling to breathe. Hanh took her granddaughter to see several doctors in her rural province, but they all failed to give her a proper diagnosis. When she finally reached this large urban hospital, she found out that Phuong had tuberculosis, and realized the weeks of inadequate care had given the life-threatening illness time to take hold.

headline: French Court Acquits Dominique Strauss-Kahn in Case That Put His Sex Life on View
abstract: The verdict closed a four-year legal battle that captivated France and shined an uncomfortable spotlight on the sexual activities of rich and powerful men.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, was acquitted on Friday of aggravated pimping charges, concluding a case that made the private lives of public figures fair game for the French news media, even if the French themselves still seemed inclined to overlook dalliances by their political leaders.

headline: Soil Contamination Found Near Huge Mine in Western China
keywords: ['Environment', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Soil', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: Greenpeace East Asia said that soil near a zinc and lead mine and smelting plant in Yunnan Province was unsafe for growing food.
lead_paragraph: Soil samples collected by Greenpeace East Asia researchers near Asia’s largest zinc and lead mine and smelting plant, in Yunnan Province, show severe heavy metal contamination, the organization says. The findings, it has reported, highlight the environmental and health hazards as industries react to tighter pollution constraints in eastern China by expanding operations in less developed areas in the west.

headline: How to Write a Country Song
abstract: Tell a story. Write longhand. Allow for melancholy.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t have to be from the country to write a country song — but it helps,” says Billy Joe Shaver, who started songwriting as a boy in Corsicana, Tex. Shaver, who is now 75 and lives in Waco, sings and plays guitar, but his lyrics are better known coming from the mouths of other performers. Willie Nelson, Kris Kristofferson, Johnny Cash, Waylon Jennings and Elvis Presley have all recorded his work. In the 1970s, Shaver wrote a number of anthems in the rougher, less-polished-than-Nashville subgenre called outlaw country.

headline: Outside, Looking In
abstract: Transported back to a former life as a prison inmate.
lead_paragraph: One day last November, at a stoplight on Route 34 in Derby, Conn., I noticed a truck idling in front of me. It was stout and white, with the requisite grime, and by outward appearance it could have been carrying anything: Portuguese rolls, hanging file folders or maybe replacement gas caps. But when the bumper sticker (Am I driving safely?) referred me to a government website, I became certain the truck was hauling human beings.

headline: ‘On the Brooklyn Bridge’
abstract: Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: Years before the Brooklyn Bridge was built, Walt Whitman’s poem “Crossing Brooklyn Ferry” anticipated the fascination so many poets have had with it, its power to compel us toward contemplation. Charles Simic’s poem shows that the bridge — the crossing — maintains its original attractions to the observant sojourner. It reminds me too of what I love about cities: the seemingly familiar faces in the midst of a crowd, a way of being both alone and not alone in the wide world.

keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Venture Capital']

lead_paragraph: TWITTER CHIEF’S EXIT SPARKS DEAL SPECULATION | To Twitter board members and friends of Dick Costolo, his plans to resign as Twitter’s chief executive was not a surprise,  Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac report in The New York Times. But  Michael J. de la Merced notes in DealBook that whenever a chief executive departs, it always raises the question of whether the company is now for sale – and Twitter is no exception. In fact, Twitter was the subject of takeover rumors as recently as last month, and a longtime Twitter investor, Chris Sacca, has mused over the last two weeks that Google might make a logical buyer.

headline: Baseball and Black History

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — LAST summer, a 13-year-old named Mo’ne Davis landed on the cover of Sports Illustrated, a national sensation after she pitched a shutout in the Little League World Series, where almost all of the other players are boys. She’s believed to be the only black girl ever to participate in the competition.

abstract: Stéphane Richard, the chief executive of Orange, the French telecom giant, tells Israel’s prime minister that he regrets the furor caused by his statements about doing business in the country.

headline: ‘Doctor Faustus’ and Christopher Marlowe Return to New York
abstract: This season is a banner one for that Elizabethan tragedian, and it continues with a new version of “Doctor Faustus” at the Classic Stage Company.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Marlowe’s plays are so rarely staged at New York’s major theaters that this season is a banner one for that Elizabethan tragedian, whose work influenced Shakespeare but has since been spectacularly overshadowed by that of his contemporary. First came a production of “Tamburlaine the Great,” starring the mighty John Douglas Thompson. Now the Classic Stage Company follows up with a new version of “Doctor Faustus,” adapted by David Brindel and Andrei Belgrader and directed by Mr. Belgrader.

headline: At Women’s World Cup, Seeing Signs of Lionel Messi, Not Mia Hamm
abstract: Fans, coaches, the news media and players at the World Cup are closely watching the stars of the women’s game. And then likening them to men.
lead_paragraph: Megan Rapinoe controlled the ball at the halfway line at the Women’s World Cup and sped forward. When she finally encountered a defender, she effortlessly jinked past her and shot the ball into the net to seal a victory for the United States over Australia on Monday.

headline: A New Manhattan Rental Designed to Feel Like a Resort
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The Moinian Group’s new rental building on the Far West Side will contain 1,175 apartments and many amenities, including outdoor pools, a Turkish bath, a yoga room and free daily breakfast.
lead_paragraph: With Sky, a shimmering new rental building on the Far West Side, the Moinian family says it is not content to merely keep up with the Joneses.

headline: The Second Coming of Sam Cooke
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Leon Bridges, the 25-year-old crooner from Fort Worth, Tex., exudes ’50s style and swagger.
lead_paragraph: Those lucky enough to have caught the Leon Bridges set at SXSW in March would be forgiven for feeling like they had traveled back in time. The 25-year-old crooner from Fort Worth, Tex., who until recently was washing dishes to make ends meet, exudes ’50s style and swagger in high-waisted pants and saddle shoes. His first album, “Coming Home,” out June 23, is a revelation: full of gently flowing songs about “Jezebels” and “tender sweet loving.”

lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 2: “Bed Bugs and Beyond”

headline: Red vs. Blue America on Marriage
abstract: Liberal states have more two-parent families than conservative ones. But it’s a more complicated story than many people believe.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Q. and A.: Zhang Weiwei on Why China Will Succeed Under the Communist Party
abstract: Mr. Zhang, a leading theorist of the “China model” of political and economic development, holds that China is on the right path and is destined to accomplish its goals.
lead_paragraph: When Zhang Weiwei was asked if it was true, as had been whispered among Chinese academics and officials, that President Xi Jinping had read his book “The China Wave: Rise of a Civilizational State” and recommended it to people such as the former World Bank president Robert Zoellick, he answered, “I’m glad he did.”

headline: 4 Tourists Plead Guilty to Obscenity for Posing Naked on Malaysian Peak
abstract: The Westerners, whose actions were blamed for causing an earthquake, were fined about $1,300 apiece, and were set to be deported.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Four Westerners who stripped atop Malaysia’s highest peak pleaded guilty on Friday to public obscenity and were due to be deported, their lawyer said.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Nothing to Hide and Nowhere to Hide It in Joshua Cohen’s Internet Novel
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A writer finds a wider audience with “Book of Numbers,” a novel about government spying and corporate big data that bears a close resemblance to reality.
lead_paragraph: A strange thing happened when Joshua Cohen was deep into writing his new novel, “Book of Numbers.” It started to come true. He had already written most of the book, a dense, dizzying story about a struggling novelist named Joshua Cohen who is hired to ghostwrite the memoir of the shady billionaire founder of Tetration, a Google-like technology company whose revolutionary mission is to “equalize ourselves with data and data with ourselves.”

headline: Before Official Announcement, Jeb Bush Shows Off Support Inside Florida
abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush, who is expected to announce his White House bid on Monday, unveiled endorsements in Florida from 11 members of Congress and three state cabinet members.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush unveiled a raft of endorsements from Republicans in Florida on Friday, demonstrating support in his home state ahead of next week’s expected announcement that he is running for president.

headline: Republicans Put Net Neutrality in Jeopardy
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Net Neutrality', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In trying to suspend neutrality rules, Republican lawmakers are going against the wishes of a majority of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Many Republican lawmakers hated regulations that the Federal Communications Commission approved earlier this year to prevent cable and phone companies from creating fast and slow lanes on the Internet. Now, they are trying to undermine those rules through an appropriations bill.

headline: Criminal Psychics See a Clear Path to Profits in the Desperate
abstract: A veteran detective says fraud schemes by psychics are not uncommon, although they are typically pulled off in amounts smaller than the $713,975 a woman was accused of taking from a client.
lead_paragraph: A detective paused between bites of a late lunch on Wednesday in a Midtown diner and said, “It’s not very often you see a customer in a psychic shop.”

headline: Wave of Protests Spreads to Scandal-Weary Honduras and Guatemala
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Embezzlement', 'Tax Evasion', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Middle-class citizens in both countries are fed up with bribery and other government scandals and increasingly demanding the resignation of their presidents.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In Guatemala, angry citizens marched under pelting rain, undeterred. In Honduras, they carried torches at dusk. A wave of protests against corruption scandals that is sweeping across Latin America has reached Central America.

headline: Daily Report: Under a New Chief, Twitter Has a Chance to Focus on Live Events
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: Twitter should aim to become the first and only app that people load up to comment on the news.
lead_paragraph: Here, in 140 characters or fewer, Farhad Manjoo writes in his State of the Art column, is some free advice for Twitter’s next chief executive: Focus on live events. People never tire of gabbing about what’s going on right now. Twitter could be the best place for that. Do it fast.

headline: Recording a Phone’s Screen on a Mac
abstract: Tips for mirroring your phone’s display on a Mac, and how to get desktop notifications from Gmail.

headline: 1890: High Prices for Art Works
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Fifty-three paintings were sold for a total of almost 1.5 million francs in Paris.
lead_paragraph: One and a half million francs — in exact figures 1,589,000 fr. — were realized by the sale of the fifty-three paintings of the Crabbe collection, at the Sedelmeyer Gallery, yesterday. The auction room of the spacious establishment in the rue de La Rochefoucauld was packed to its fullest. Corot’s enchanting ‘‘Matin,’’ which was sold in 1880 at the Hotel Drouot for 7,000 fr., and for which Senator Crabbe paid, three years ago, 42,000 fr., brought 63,000 fr.

headline: South Korea Steps Up MERS Fight
abstract: Workers sprayed disinfectant in a South Korean market as new cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome continue to be identified.
lead_paragraph: Workers sprayed disinfectant in a South Korean market as new cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome continue to be identified.

headline: ‘Hannibal’: 3 Steps to TV’s Scariest Soundtrack
abstract: The composer Brian Reitzell uses new sounds and nonmusical instruments to set the mood for the NBC series about the Hannibal Lecter saga.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, CALIF. — Over two seasons, “Hannibal” has presented some of television’s most beautifully disturbing imagery. A totem pole made of corpses. A field of corpses harvested to grow mushrooms. A corpse sewn inside a horse.

headline: 1915: Fierce Fighting in Gallipoli
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Allies meet success in Gallipoli in 1915.
lead_paragraph: Fierce fighting is reported from the Gallipoli Peninsula, with big successes for the Allies. According to despatches from Mitylene, a great battle began on Thursday in the Maidos sector, where the Allied troops delivered five furious attacks, and captured the heights dominating Maidos. They are now within two hours of the town, the occupation of which, telegraphs the ‘‘Times’’ Athens correspondent, was prevented by the fire of Fort Nagara and the coastal batteries, which bombarded the Allies with indirect fire.

headline: Chinese Premier Urges Officials to Fight Events That Led 4 Children to Drink Pesticide
abstract: The impoverished youths, three sisters and a brother ages 5 to 13, were some of the country’s “left-behind children,” and the police had explored the possibility that their deaths were suicides.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Li Keqiang, the Chinese premier, ordered officials across the country on Friday to avert the kind of events that led to the deaths of four children who drank pesticide this week, possibly to kill themselves, in an impoverished corner of the southwest.

headline: Lawyer on Ex-I.M.F. Chief’s Acquittal

lead_paragraph: Henri Leclerc, the lawyer for Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, spoke on Friday in Lille, France, after his client was cleared of pimping charges.

headline: Celebrating 50 Years of New York Philharmonic Outdoor Concerts

Schonberg wrote in The New York Times in 1965. “By and large the citizens are proud of their great orchestra; and, by and large, the citizens have never heard it.”

headline: ‘Deutschland 83,’ a SundanceTV Series About an Earnest Stasi Spy
abstract: This new series depicts a young East German posing as a NATO general’s aide in West Germany in 1983, when Cold War tensions were high and a peace movement was in full swing in Europe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With its clunky rotary phones, vinyl-coated swivel chairs and wooden desks, the Stasi Museum, located in the former headquarters of the dreaded East German secret police, provided the perfect retro look for “Deutschland 83,” a new eight-part German television series set in the last throes of the Cold War. The show, which was filmed partly at the museum, makes its United States debut Wednesday on SundanceTV.

headline: Ryn Weaver’s ‘The Fool’ Is Deeply Personal Indie Pop
abstract: Ms. Weaver is promoting her first album and building her brand with a tour and a “Tonight Show” appearance.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter Ryn Weaver is a chronic over-sharer — “to the max,” she said. “Once I feel like I can trust you, if it’s been like three minutes, I’m like” — she leaned in — “ ‘promise you won’t tell anyone.’ ”

lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton recreates Craig Claiborne’s classic cheesecake recipe.
