lead_paragraph: Aspiring to become a one-stop-shopping network for home buying, Nationstar Mortgage Holdings this week unveiled a service designed to allow purchasers to simply swipe and click their way through the entire process.

headline: Craig Claiborne’s Classic Cheesecake
abstract: The former New York Times food editor’s version is simple, rich and easily accessorized with ripe fruit or flavorings. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: There is perhaps no more New Yorkish a dessert than cheesecake, a dish best consumed with a hot coffee and a reading of the afternoon news. The dessert owes something to the cooking of Italy and the Baltic States, of course, but its smooth creaminess and contrasting crust are almost indigenous to the United States and particularly to the diners and coffee shops of New York City.

headline: New Releases From Marta Sánchez, Cloud Rat, Pete Rodriguez and More
abstract: Music from those artists and others deliver a soundscape of fervid screams, serenity, folk and Latin jazz.

headline: Cathedrals, R&B With a Dash of 1980s Rock, at Le Poisson Rouge
abstract: The singer Brodie Jenkins has a versatile voice paired with Johnny Hwin’s sultry, tender music.
lead_paragraph: Release, then clench. Release, then clench again. Everything about the Bay Area duo Cathedrals follows this simple, striking pattern. The singer Brodie Jenkins has a voice that’s both pulpy and ethereal — she leans heavy into big words, her voice robust, then fading ever so dreamily. (Ms. Jenkins is a versatile singer — as a teenager, she was signed to a country music label as part of a family band.)

headline: ‘Jaws’ Opens Manhattan Parks Summer Outdoor Movies
abstract: Free outdoor movie screenings are scheduled for Randalls Island, Bryant Park and Hudson River Park.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost summer, which means free outdoor movie screenings are popping up around Manhattan-area parks. On June 22, for example, the HBO Bryant Park Summer Film Festival, in Midtown, commences on Mondays; the Hudson RiverFlicks Big Hit Wednesdays series kicks off on July 8, on Pier 63 in Chelsea.

headline: Alvin Ailey Company Says Goodbye to Three Dancers
abstract: Three longtime members of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater are to make their final performances at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: Dancers don’t last forever. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater proves that this week as three artists bid farewell. Along with a married couple, Antonio Douthit-Boyd and Kirven Douthit-Boyd, is Alicia Graf Mack, who returns from her leave of absence for three guest appearances. This transcendent, statuesque dancer sways her hips with the company a final time as the parasol-waving woman in the “Wade in the Water” section of “Revelations” on Tuesday and Thursday and next Sunday night. Other highlights include the Douthit-Boyds in “Chroma,” “Grace” and “Revelations” on Thursday, and in “Night Creature” on Saturday. They will soon take over the Center of Creative Arts in St. Louis, where they’ll have some company. Ms. Mack, who recently gave birth to a son, will teach ballet and modern dance at Webster University and Washington University in St. Louis. There’s some solace: The next generation of Ailey is in good hands. (7:30 p.m., Tuesday through Thursday; 8 p.m., Friday and Saturday; 2 p.m., Saturday; 3 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. next Sunday; David H. Koch Theater, 212-496-0600, davidkochtheater.com.)

headline: ‘Navigating the West’ Celebrates George Caleb Bingham’s Paintings
abstract: This exhibition at the Met details Bingham’s depictions of life on the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: American 19th-century genre painting doesn’t often get the museum spotlight, though it should. It has a lot to tell us about where we’ve been and who we are, and some of our best artists made their careers in it. So for more than one reason, I’m looking forward to “Navigating the West: George Caleb Bingham and the River,” which arrives at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday.

headline: Jennifer Beals and Matthew Modine Star in TNT’s ‘Proof,’ on Life, Death and Beyond
abstract: A billionaire tech wizard with terminal cancer offers a doctor control of his estate if she’ll help him prove what, if anything, exists after the body flatlines.
lead_paragraph: Parachuting off Mount Everest doesn’t faze Ivan Turing, a tech wizard with a referential surname and a fondness for Steve Jobsian turtlenecks. But terminal adenocarcinoma has given him pause. “I’ve always hated unknowns,” he tells Dr. Carolyn Tyler, a cardiothoracic surgeon with little patience for speculation and a wellspring of grief all her own. “And now that I’m facing the biggest one there is, I want to know what to expect.” His offer: He’ll give her control of his $10 billion estate if she’ll help him prove what, if anything, exists after the body flatlines.

headline: Taking On Student Debt, and Refusing to Pay
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Credit and Debt', 'Credit Scores', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Personal Bankruptcies']
abstract: The ramifications of defaulting and remaining in debt deliberately are usually real and lasting.
lead_paragraph: Over the last couple of decades, we have been engaged in an enormous national experiment, taking impressionable and often ignorant teenagers and young adults and seeing just how much student loan debt they can handle.

headline: ‘Stalin’s Daughter,’ by Rosemary Sullivan
abstract: Stalin’s daughter tried to escape his shadow by defecting to the United States.
lead_paragraph: A young princess walks the corridors of an ancient palace, surrounded by adoring relatives, governesses and tutors. Her father is a beloved ruler of a vast country, and she is his only daughter and favorite child, his “little sparrow,” his “little fly.” She brings him presents of violets and strawberries, and he pets her, showering her in bristly kisses redolent of tobacco. She spends idyllic summers at the family dacha, where her father’s merry friends, whom she calls “aunts” and “uncles,” come on visits and regale her with stories and songs. The world she inhabits seems magical to her, “that place of sunshine.”

headline: ‘Backlands,’ by Victoria Shorr
abstract: Led by a charismatic, one-eyed rebel and his lover, an outlaw gang roams the Brazilian badlands in the 1920s and ’30s.
lead_paragraph: Usually when reviewing a novel, you must be careful not to give away too much plot. But in the case of Victoria Shorr’s “Backlands,” there’s no such danger: Shorr herself reveals the bare bones of the story in the first few pages. Put simply, “Backlands” is the fictionalized account of a real-life one-eyed bandit called Lampião and his lover, Maria Bonita — famous Brazilian outlaws who took from the rich and gave to the poor. From the early 1920s to his capture in 1938, Lampião and his gang controlled much of the Sertão, a huge and dusty swath of land in the northeast of the country, “almost the size of Spain.” More than once, they were cornered but managed to escape. For a long time, Lampião seemed invincible and his life, as Shorr puts it, “was a tango, full of beauty and danger, mixed.”

headline: Literary Lives
abstract: New novels explore the lives of Virginia Woolf, George Sand and Emily Dickinson.
lead_paragraph: ADELINEA Novel of Virginia WoolfBy Norah Vincent280 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $23.

headline: ‘The Dorito Effect,’ by Mark Schatzker
abstract: Food producers focus on factors such as yield, at the expense of flavor.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago I sat with a friend and looked at a menu, and we wondered why everything seemed to be flavored like a taco. Or Caesar salad or maple syrup. I couldn’t quite say what about it bothered me, but I held a conviction that something was wrong in a thing — a Mexican snack, salad dressing, tree sap — being turned into a flavor.

headline: Black or White? Woman’s Story Stirs Up a Furor
abstract: The parents of Rachel A. Dolezal, an N.A.A.C.P. leader in Spokane, Wash., say she is white, and her story has stirred a national debate about racial identity.
lead_paragraph: She has professed an affinity for black people since she was a teenager, when her parents adopted four black children. She chose a college where she could immerse herself in racial issues. She married a black man and built a reputation as an advocate for civil rights.

headline: Bizarre Court Case Puts a Violinist, and Leipzig String Quartet, in an Unflattering Light
abstract: Stefan Arzberger, a member of the music group, is fighting charges that he attacked a woman in a Manhattan hotel this spring.
lead_paragraph: The violinist Stefan Arzberger had planned to play the music of Beethoven, Haydn and Mendelssohn with his colleagues in the Leipzig String Quartet later this month at Wigmore Hall in London, where he fondly recalls once sipping sherry with patrons after a concert.

headline: Stuff We Liked
abstract: Web winners this week included measures of city affordability, snow totals and a graphic on graphic murders in “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: What stuff has our staff found for you this week on the web?

headline: Fresh Ricotta Turns a Simple Pasta Dish Sublime
abstract: As gardens burst with vegetables, the time is right to elevate a rudimentary recipe.
lead_paragraph: A recent trip to Sicily reminded me just how marvelous fresh ricotta can be. I had the chance to visit a family-run sheep dairy to observe a cheese master at work. The farm produces pecorino cheese, both young and aged, and ricotta too, which is essentially a by-product of the cheese-making process.

headline: Folkways and Family in America
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Marriages', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Getting beyond the “red family” versus “blue family” debate.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally in the debates about family structure in America, I’ve had reason to point out the limits of the popular “red family, blue family” dichotomy, which portrays a post-sexual revolution America divided between a late-marrying, lower-divorce-rate model of family formation in liberal regions and an earlier-marrying, frequently-divorcing model in more conservative and religious states. This portrayal, particularly associated with the sociologists Naomi Cahn and June Carbone, definitely captures one distinctive reality of American life — the fact that stable two-parent homes are more common among secular liberal Bobos in the BosWash corridor and elsewhere than they are in, say, certain regions in the Bible Belt. But it’s also important to recognize the exceptions to this pattern, from “red” social models (in the High Plains and Mormon Utah, in particular) that combine high marriage rates and birthrates and relative family stability to “blue” social models (inner city, Rust Belt, Southwestern) that are as unstable as anything Alabaman and Mississippian. (And that’s without getting into the issue of abortion as a necessary prop for “blue” stability.)

headline: Sherrie Levine Moves to David Zwirner
abstract: “She’s an ideal fit for us,” said Chris D’Amelio, a partner of David Zwirner.
lead_paragraph: Sherrie Levine is switching galleries, but she won’t be moving very far. After more than a decade and a half with the Paula Cooper Gallery, Ms. Levine will join the David Zwirner Gallery, just a couple blocks south in Chelsea.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Family Values
abstract: His past comments on single parents are getting attention, and his explanations haven’t been reassuring.
lead_paragraph: In many campaigns, one candidate or another is asked to answer for comments he or she made in the past. The answer is usually gibberish – that was a long time ago, or I was trying to say something else. This week’s entry is – not shockingly given how many times he has tripped over his own tongue lately – Jeb Bush.

headline: The Art Basel Fair: A Tough Club to Crack
abstract: Galleries seeking to exhibit at Art Basel encounter an intense, juried competition. While the fair says it works to find new faces, prime selling space on the ground floor is dominated by a roster of established dealers.
lead_paragraph: Galleries seeking to exhibit at Art Basel encounter an intense, juried competition. While the fair says it works to find new faces, prime selling space on the ground floor is dominated by a roster of established dealers.

headline: Nine Rooms on Park Avenue for $28.5 Million
abstract: An apartment that once belonged to Roone Arledge, who ran ABC Sports and News, at the exclusive co-op building 778 Park Avenue was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling, elegant apartment that once belonged to Roone Arledge, who ran ABC Sports and News, in the exclusive Rosario Candela-designed building 778 Park Avenue sold to a hedge fund manager and his wife, who also own Brooke Astor’s former co-op directly above it, for $28,500,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Explosion Destroys Ancient Cultural Heritage Site in Yemen Capital
abstract: The top cultural protection official at the United Nations condemned the damage of “one of the world’s oldest jewels of Islamic urban landscape.”
lead_paragraph: A protected 2,500-year-old cultural heritage site in Yemen’s capital, Sana, was obliterated in an explosion early Friday, and witnesses and news reports said the cause was a missile or bomb from a Saudi warplane. The Saudi military denied responsibility.

headline: From Tree to Greens, a U.S. Open Unlike Any Before
abstract: Chambers Bay Golf Course, which was completed in 2007 with the Open in mind, has three defining features that will set the tournament apart from its predecessors.
lead_paragraph: This is a story about countless blades of grass, a single tree and a freight train.

headline: Interpol Halts Use of FIFA Funds for Anticorruption Program
abstract: The international police agency said a deal worth about $23 million over 10 years would be frozen amid allegations of graft against soccer’s governing body.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Interpol suspended an agreement with FIFA on Friday that had called for the international police agency to receive 20 million euros over 10 years to fight corruption in soccer, citing the American investigations that have ensnared soccer’s world governing body.

headline: Asking Tough Questions to Understand ‘The Wolfpack’
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)']
abstract: Cara Buckley describes the delicate process of interviewing six brothers who had spent much of their lives locked in their apartment by their father.
lead_paragraph: The transfixing and troubling documentary “The Wolfpack” opens this week, telling the story of six young brothers who, until five years ago, had spent most of their lives locked up in their family’s apartment on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

headline: U.S. Will Call All Chimps ‘Endangered’
abstract: Wild chimpanzees have been deemed endangered for decades, but the new rules from the Fish and Wildlife Service will apply to captive chimpanzees as well.
lead_paragraph: All chimpanzees will be designated as endangered under the Endangered Species Act, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced Friday.

headline: Los Angeles Confronts a Spike in Homelessness Amid Prosperity
abstract: A report that the homeless population of Los Angeles County rose 12 percent in two years has set off a wave of concern and raised questions about gentrification.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Construction cranes dot the sky from Century City to the Sunset Strip. Once-downtrodden blocks downtown and in Venice are bustling with restaurants, coffee shops, sparkling new condominiums, theaters and office construction. The unemployment rate has dropped to almost half its double-digit high of five years ago. Much of Los Angeles these days seems the portrait of prosperity.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: IDIOPATHY, by Sam Byers. (Faber & Faber, $15.) In this debut novel, three characters — a former couple, now estranged, and their mutual friend freshly sprung from rehab — clumsily reunite against the backdrop of a bovine epidemic coursing through England. As our reviewer, Joshua Cohen, put it, the “characters worry that they’ll be infected too, though the idiotic futility of their chatter suggests they’re terminal already.”

headline: Gawker’s Moment of Truth
abstract: Gawker Media, which built a digital empire on snark, now finds itself confronting the same challenges as the establishment media companies it once aimed to upset.
lead_paragraph: “I’m pretty sure we have a revolution coming,” said Nick Denton, founder and chief executive of Gawker Media. “It’s not 100 percent guaranteed, but the existing corporate structure is looking pretty hollow.”

headline: The Friendly, Heavy Skies
abstract: A new oversize book showcases advertisements for air travel in the postwar years.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of books have crossed my desk, but until recently none of them had weighed 14 pounds. That behemoth, with the faceless, almost cryptic title “Airline Visual Identity 1945-1975,” is a massive collection mostly of full-page posters advertising the glamour and reach of air travel in the postwar years.

headline: Hope Fills the 7 Train for Mets Fans. The Next Stop: Reality.
abstract: To be a Mets fan as the team works through injuries and other problems after a promising start is to be caught between hoping and expecting the worst.
lead_paragraph: I fielded the phone call in late afternoon: The Mets are in first place, the world champion San Francisco Giants are in town, and we have our blond Viking strikeout machine, Noah Syndergaard, on the mound.

headline: ‘How to Bake Pi,’ by Eugenia Cheng
abstract: Recipes for tapping the logic and beauty of mathematics.
lead_paragraph: To make mathematics palatable for the lay reader, the author must sweeten the pill. There are many ways to do this, but Eugenia Cheng is surely the first to have approached the task literally, writing a math book in which almost every chapter begins with a recipe for dessert.

abstract: Ben Ratliff, Maria Sherman and Liz Pelly discuss the band’s new album and punk music.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff, Maria Sherman and Liz Pelly discuss the band’s new album and punk music.

headline: ‘Move: Putting America’s Infrastructure Back in the Lead,’ by Rosabeth Moss Kanter
abstract: What it will take to fix America’s crumbling infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: We seemed to be going in circles.

headline: At Moscow’s New Garage Museum, a Work Set to Debut in a Thousand Years
abstract: Taryn Simon’s “Black Square XVII” is made from nuclear waste and will go on view in 3015, once it has been sapped of radioactive material.
lead_paragraph: This week in Moscow, all of the exhibitions and works have been installed for the globally buzzy opening of the Garage Museum of Contemporary Art’s new Rem Koolhaas-designed building — including a Ping-Pong-based performance by Rirkrit Tiravanija called “Tomorrow is the Question?” and the selfie heaven of Yayoi Kusama’s “Infinity Theory,” the artist’s first-ever show in Russia — except for one, leaving a blank cube in the wall where it will eventually be placed. But don’t hold your breath for that: Taryn Simon’s “Black Square XVII” is made from nuclear waste, and it will take 1,000 years for the vitrification process to rid it of radioactive material. It’ll be on view in 3015.

headline: Roosevelt Island to Shine Under the Hillary Clinton Spotlight
keywords: ['Cable Cars and Trams', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: A children’s event has been rescheduled, but Roosevelt Island Day festivities will go on as planned on Saturday, when Hillary Rodham Clinton officially kicks off her candidacy for president.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s decision to use Roosevelt Island, the two-mile sliver of land mashed between Queens and Manhattan, as the backdrop Saturday for her first major stump speech sent a small but noticeable ripple through the island’s previously scheduled weekend plans.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: ‘It Starts With Trouble,’ by Clark Davis
abstract: William Goyen’s work harks back to his East Texas roots.
lead_paragraph: Chased out of many a yard, the title character of William Goyen’s 1947 short story “The White Rooster” has torn his feathers and “so tired himself that whatever he found to eat in random places was not enough to keep any flesh on his carcass.” Yet he keeps foraging, foiling society’s best efforts to extinguish him, and each new day finds him crowing, “a carillon-like sound” that bursts from “his straggly throat.” Even as he nears death, he is “most vividly alive, in some courageous way.”

headline: An Unsung Architectural Oasis
abstract: Modernism pushes tumbleweed aside in Tucson, where finding individualistic architecture only requires wheels and a map.
lead_paragraph: Modernism pushes tumbleweed aside in Tucson, where finding individualistic architecture only requires wheels and a map.

headline: Talks to Begin on Creating a Trade Zone Within Africa
abstract: After an agreement was signed linking the economies of eastern and southern Africa, momentum has continued for a long-term dream: a continental trading zone.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Trade within Africa has long faced many barriers, from the physical to nonphysical: bad roads, air routes that still favor old colonial ties to Europe, corruption and poor governance. Even as African economies have grown in the last decade, trade between African nations has lagged behind their exchanges with the rest of the world.

headline: ‘Léon Blum: Prime Minister, Socialist, Zionist,’ by Pierre Birnbaum
abstract: Léon Blum led France to reform in the Depression era.
lead_paragraph: Léon Blum, age 26, imagined Goethe writing a sequel to his renowned “Faust.” Blum’s protagonist, however, was not Goethe’s famous intellectual, who wagers with the Devil to experience everything possible. He was, instead, a socialist seeking justice — although impeded by Mephistopheles. Blum’s Faust passes reforms in Parliament, but “reaction” lands him in prison. Still, obstacles only make him resolute.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 5 Finale: 9 Questions That Need Answers
abstract: Here are some of the outstanding issues that need resolution in Sunday’s season finale.
lead_paragraph: It’s “Thrones” Friday, which means the pop culture cabal takes one last whack at the show before Sunday’s Season 5 finale.

keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computer Security', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Exploiting a vulnerability in server software used by Chinese Internet portals, hackers were able to unmask visitors to sites deemed hostile by the government.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Chinese hackers have found a way around widely used privacy technology to target the creators and readers of web content that state censors have deemed hostile, according to new research.

headline: Prison Worker Who Befriended Killers Is Accused of Providing Tools for Escape
abstract: Joyce E. Mitchell, a civilian employee at the Clinton Correctional Facility in northern New York State, brought the men hacksaw blades, chisels, a punch and screwdriver bit, according to a criminal complaint.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — More than a month before two killers escaped from a maximum-security prison in far northern New York State last weekend, a worker there who befriended them provided them with some of the tools to do the deed: hacksaw blades, chisels, a punch and a screwdriver bit, according to criminal complaints.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Judy Blume, whose adult novel “In the Unlikely Event” is No. 4 on the hardcover fiction list, had two million books in print in 1976, well before The Times had a children’s best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: Blume’s Day: In the summer of 1976, the Book Review took note of a “new frankness in children’s literature,” and cited as ­Exhibit A the novels of Judy Blume: “She is a kind of heroine to the kids who read and reread her books, and a kind of Little League Grace Metalious to the mothers.” Metalious, you may remember, was the author of “Peyton Place” — that decidedly Major League novel of suburban smut — and being seen as a junior version didn’t hurt Blume’s popularity any. Starting with “Wifey” in 1978 and continuing right up to “In the Unlikely Event” (new at No. 4 on the hardcover fiction list), all four of her adult novels have been best sellers. That’s more than you can say for her most celebrated children’s books, including “Blubber” and “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret,” although it’s not their fault: The Times didn’t introduce a children’s best-seller list until 2000. Had one existed in 1976, Blume would surely have been on it. She had some two million books in print that year, according to the Times article, which further observed that “Blume’s appeal lies in her ability to speak directly to her readers’ experience. Her characters are usually suburban kids, and not always nice ones.” Blume recently told NPR’s “Weekend Edition” that when she was an adolescent herself, she preferred grown-up literature. “Starting at 12, really, and onward, I was reading adult books,” she said. “Everything that I was curious about, about the adult world, I learned from reading those books. Or I got from them, you know, some idea of what it was like to be grown-up. Which is what I was very, very curious about.”

headline: Popcast: Tenement, Punk and the DIY Scene
abstract: Ben Ratliff, Maria Sherman and Liz Pelly discuss the band’s new album.
lead_paragraph: “Predatory Headlights” is the new album by Tenement, the punk trio from Appleton, Wis. It’s an accomplishment. It’s a double album, with 25 songs, and it took more than three years to make. It gives you an enlarged sense of what the primary songwriter, Amos Pitsch, is most trained at: tightly written riff songs with an almost classical pop sense, descended from pop-punk while transcending its clichés. But it also includes experimental compositions and arrangements involving strings and field recordings and an out-of-tune piano. “Predatory Headlights” is strong and strange and detailed and cohesive; if people are still listening to records from 2015 in 20 years, this might be one of them. Tenement started in 2006 and has spent a lot of its life on the DIY circuit, gigging in living rooms and basements. For quite a while, if you wanted a Tenement record, you had to buy one at a gig. It appears on bills and has recorded split EPs with far more noisy, simple straight-ahead hardcore bands, but it plays music that sounds as if it could have been almost popular at some point in the recent past. Where does Tenement fit into the current punk-hardcore-DIY scene?

headline: Edward Hibbert on His West Village Studio
abstract: The actor and literary agent gained space and a tree-filled view when he moved to his current apartment.
lead_paragraph: For years, the actor Edward Hibbert lived contentedly in a studio apartment in Hell’s Kitchen, an area that “has become so chic we now call it Chez Hades,” said Mr. Hibbert, 59, who is playing an uncannily prescient wedding planner in the Broadway musical “It Shoulda Been You.”

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Affordable Housing', 'State Legislatures']

Cuomo scouring the bowels of the Clinton Correctional Facility, immersing his head in the pipes and looking like Tommy Lee Jones in “The Fugitive.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LOVING DAY, by Mat Johnson. (Spiegel & Grau, $26.) Johnson’s hero is tragic not because of the stresses of his liminal racial status but because he, like most everyone else in the novel, is haunted by ghosts of painful pasts.

headline: City Schoolchildren Take to a British Sport
abstract: More than 70 teams in and around New York City played this month in the eighth annual Rugby Cup, and a frequent contender is a Brooklyn middle school.

headline: Brownsville’s Unlikely Rugby Dynasty
abstract: Hundreds of schoolchildren of both sexes play the imported British game citywide, and one of the leaders is a middle school in a low-income Brooklyn neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: On a patch of turf on the sidelines of crowded athletic fields on Randalls Island, under the rattle of the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge, a dozen middle school students gathered around a burly man with a ponytail and a goatee. This was Ovidiu Grozav, coach of two flag rugby teams — one boys, one girls — from Intermediate School 392 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and he was giving his boys a few words of encouragement before their first match.

headline: In Tucson, an Unsung Architectural Oasis
abstract: One of the city’s better-kept secrets is how often you can find significant examples of mid-20th century architecture.
lead_paragraph: “People tend to come to Tucson to figure something out,” Demion Clinco remarked one cool desert evening, beneath a sky so boundless it made all things seem possible. We were seated on the terrace of the 85-year-old Arizona Inn, drinking anachronistic cocktails. The cocktails produced an optimism of their own.

headline: James Last, Bandleader Known for ‘Happy Sound,’ Dies at 86
abstract: The internationally renowned German bandleader purveyed music that was considered staggeringly accessible, even by the standards of easy listening.
lead_paragraph: James Last, the internationally renowned German bandleader whose music was considered staggeringly accessible even by the standards of easy listening, died on Tuesday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86.

headline: First Condos Soon for Sale at Barclays Center Site
keywords: ['Atlantic Yards (Brooklyn)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Later this month, sales will be open on 550 Vanderbilt, the first of 14 residential buildings to be built at Pacific Park Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: By the time Barclays Center, the Brooklyn arena, opened in 2012 as a centerpiece to a massive redevelopment plan then called Atlantic Yards, the project had endured years of lawsuits, a financial downturn and no small measure of controversy. Thousands of new apartments, initially projected to be done by 2016, had not yet begun to materialize as timelines were pushed back again and again to as far off as 2035.

headline: Coffee Drinks Stake a Claim at the Bar
abstract: The Espresso Fizz has the air of a classic cocktail — it’s like an amaro and soda, only you can drink it before noon without apology.
lead_paragraph: The Espresso Fizz has the air of a classic cocktail, even though it’s made with espresso, not spirits, and was introduced to the coffee menu of the Manhattan restaurant Maialino earlier this year. Created by Ryan Clur, the head barista, it’s a shot of espresso floated over chilled tonic water that’s flavored with orange bitters and an orange twist.

headline: Before Crash, Germanwings Pilot Searched Web for Ways to Die
abstract: A prosecutor in Germany said Andreas Lubitz looked up terms like “living will” and “dying” and sought information about obtaining poisons.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The day before he crashed an Airbus 320 carrying 149 passengers and crew members into the French Alps, Andreas Lubitz safely flew an empty jet from Düsseldorf, Germany, to Berlin, then returned home to his iPad to search terms including “living will,” “suffering” and “dying.”

headline: Overcoming the Confidence Gap for Women
abstract: Recent studies show that women rate better than men in certain leadership qualities, but the number of women in leadership roles is slow to change.
lead_paragraph: When I met Lynne Doughtie this week, I was struck by how different it felt sitting with her than with any male chief executive I had met over the years. Six weeks ago, Ms. Doughtie was elected United States chairwoman and chief executive of KPMG. When she takes over the role on July 1, she will become the first woman to serve in both of those roles for a Big Four accounting firm. Cathy Engelbert was chosen as chief executive of Deloitte in February.

headline: World’s Tallest Passive House Breaks Ground on Roosevelt Island
keywords: ['Buildings (Structures)', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Sustainable Living', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: An apartment tower on the Cornell Tech campus site will be completed in 2017.
lead_paragraph: An apartment tower on Roosevelt Island that began construction this month will be the tallest passive-house high-rise in the world when it is completed in 2017, according to the Passive House Institute in Germany. And at about 270,000 square feet, it will also be the largest, said David Kramer, a principal with Hudson Companies, which is developing the building in partnership with Cornell Tech, the applied sciences campus of Cornell University, and the Related Companies.

headline: Warriors’ Andre Iguodala Re-emerges in His Season of Sacrifice
abstract: Andre Iguodala, who accepted a reserve role for the good of the team, got his first start of the season in Game 4 and led the Warriors to a crucial road win.
lead_paragraph: With the intricately structured salary cap in the N.B.A., depth is a luxury most teams cannot afford. The value of having options beyond your superstars was on full display in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night when Andre Iguodala led the Golden State Warriors to a road win that evened the series at two games apiece.

headline: The New Beauty
abstract: Models are never going to be an anything-goes lot, nor should they be. But they should represent fine aspects of us — all of us.
lead_paragraph: Many civilians, and by that I mean people who don’t breathe the hothouse air of the fashion industrial complex daily, have been struck of late by the rather odd looks — big noses, large foreheads, awkwardly coltish legs or squished mouths — of many of the current top models walking the runway and appearing in magazines such as this, and in its advertisements. The glamazon supermodels of yesteryear (Christy, Linda, Naomi), and today’s Sports Illustrated or Victoria’s Secret models (Gisele Bündchen, Kate Upton), are much easier to understand, more obvious in their beauty (especially to the average straight guy). Those girls are air-brushed-seeming goddesses of human perfection, while the new models are fairly unconventional, far more individual.

headline: The Party’s Over … Over My Budget, That Is
abstract: The expense of attending weddings and the events surrounding them can prove costly to finances and friendships.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that for couples and their families, planning and staging a wedding involves serious money.

headline: New Internet Regulations Take Effect, and Web Users See No Change
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: For all the buildup, the dawn of the new net neutrality rules was anticlimactic. For the average user weary of video interruptions and “buffering stream” pop-up messages, nothing changed.
lead_paragraph: Open Internet activists counted down to this Friday. After years of advocacy and months of legal procedure, the federal government’s rules for strictly regulating the web took effect: The democracy of the Internet became enforceable, with the government ready to protect the principles of net neutrality and Internet service providers required to load every site at the same speed.

headline: Tough Choices for Succession in the Family Business
abstract: When it’s time for founders to pass the torch, a fallout can occur, leaving adult children feeling slighted. But proactive steps can help ease the transition.
lead_paragraph: SHARON MADISON was enjoying a successful career in marketing and advertising at Verizon Communications when she took a leave of absence to work for her family’s business, United Building Maintenance. She joined her twin brother to help their father, who was ill. When their father died a few years later, she found herself running a company she had little interest in.

headline: Louisiana Court Blocks Release of ‘Angola Three’ Inmate
abstract: A three-judge panel ruled that Albert Woodfox, who has served nearly 40 years for the murder of a prison guard, should stay in prison as the state appeals a federal order to free him.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A three-judge panel of the federal appeals court here ruled on Friday against the immediate release of Albert Woodfox, who has served nearly four decades in solitary confinement for the murder of a prison guard, deciding that he should stay in prison as the state appeals a federal order to free him.

headline: In Belgium’s Strawberry Fields, Perfection’s in the Picking
abstract: Despite stiff competition, the Wépion growers maintain a strong hold on their small share of the regional strawberry market.
lead_paragraph: For many Belgians, Wépion has long been synonymous with strawberries. Carefully picked berries from this village, which has been in the strawberry growing business since the mid-17th century, are renowned for their fully ripe flavor. In Brussels, 50 miles to the northwest, Wépion berries fetch a premium price, roughly twice what the competition is going for.

headline: Inside T’s Beauty Issue
abstract: T’s latest issue celebrates models, gardens, maligned buildings and much more of what’s beautiful right now.
lead_paragraph: T’s latest issue celebrates beauty in its many forms. To that end, we’ve rounded up 11 of the most striking models working today — from the youthful Amilna Estevao to the 44-year-old fashion icon Stella Tennant — who epitomize what’s beautiful now. Ashley Brokaw already knows this. As the fashion industry’s leading casting director, she is largely responsible for the latest trend of unusual, unconventional beauties. As on the runway, so in architecture: In a special portfolio, seven leading architects tell us why maligned buildings from Paris to upstate New York are deserving of a second look. Elsewhere, the writer Dan Chiasson sorts through the rusted bicycles and myriad neckties of Robert Rauschenberg, whose archive-in-progress in Mount Vernon, N.Y., is a colorful manifestation of the late artist’s penchant for turning ephemera into art; a trip to Havana, Cuba opens the door to a grand home and cultural meeting place 15 years in the making; Christine Smallwood extols the introduction of so-called outsider artists into major institutions; the novelist and horticulturist Umberto Pasti pens a rumination on the art of gardening; and Natasha Lyonne and John Baldessari cast a critical eye on a zombie gnome and soap made from nightingale droppings. See all stories from this issue >>

headline: Lawsky’s Top Deputy to Succeed Him Temporarily

lead_paragraph: Anthony Albanese, chief of staff to Benjamin M. Lawsky, the New York State superintendent of financial services, will succeed his boss on an interim basis when Mr. Lawsky steps down next week.

abstract: Though many Republicans supported President Obama on the trade bill, his fellow Democrats in the House did not, contending that the legislation would exacerbate income inequality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He made it personal. He appealed to their loyalty. He asked them to give him what every modern president has had. He argued the facts, disputed the politics, quarreled over the history and at times lashed out at those who still refused to stand with him.

headline: Founding Member of Pussy Riot Detained in Moscow
abstract: Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, a founding member of Pussy Riot, was detained with another activist.
lead_paragraph: Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, a founding member of the activist group Pussy Riot, was detained along with another activist, Ekaterina Nenasheva, in Moscow on Friday, after setting up a brief protest performance in Bolotnaya Square, a central area where in 2012 thousands demonstrated in opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Paying Off the Mortgage Is Becoming Harder for Older Workers
abstract: A steep drop in home prices, high consumer debt, unexpected expenses and other factors keep workers from owning their homes outright before retiring.
lead_paragraph: LIKE Archie Bunker, who celebrated paying off his home mortgage by burning his documents in a 1975 episode of “All in the Family,” many workers once routinely timed retirement to coincide with paying off a mortgage.

headline: East Hampton Equestrian Compound for $55 Million
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Horsemanship and Equestrian Events']
abstract: A 23-acre compound, anchored by an 18,000-square-foot stone, stucco and shingled house reminiscent of an English manor, is poised to enter the market.
lead_paragraph: A 23-acre equestrian compound on the edge of East Hampton Village, anchored by an 18,000-square-foot stone, stucco and shingled house, is about to go on the market for $55 million. The annual real estate taxes on the property, which includes multiple barns, a 5,500-square-foot guesthouse, two cottages and nine buildable lots, are $118,523.76.

headline: YouTube Takes On Amazon With New Gaming App

abstract: Amazon beat Google to the acquisition of a popular gaming video service. Now Google is responding with a new YouTube Gaming application.

headline: Harper Lee Letters Fail to Sell at Auction
abstract: The letters were estimated to be worth between $150,000 and $250,000; the bidding opened at $80,000 and stopped at $90,000.
lead_paragraph: A collection of Harper Lee’s private letters failed to sell at auction at Christie’s on Friday. The six letters, which were written between 1956 and 1961 or were undated, were estimated to be worth between $150,000 and $250,000. The bidding opened at $80,000 and stopped at $90,000.

headline: California Cuts Farmers’ Share of Scant Water
keywords: ['Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Drought', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Water', 'Shortages']
abstract: Farmers with longtime rights to California water will face cutbacks, the first reduction in their usage since 1977, state officials announced Friday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Farmers with rights to California water dating back more than a century will face sharp cutbacks, the first reduction in their water use since 1977, state officials announced Friday. The officials said that rights dating to 1903 would be restricted, and that such restrictions would grow as the summer months go on, with the state facing a prolonged drought that shows few signs of easing.

headline: A Kids’ Camp on Catamarans
abstract: Exclusive Resorts and Broadreach are offering a summer program in the Caribbean that will include snorkeling, wakeboarding and paddleboarding.
lead_paragraph: In partnership with Broadreach, a summer adventure learning program, Exclusive Resorts is offering a new summer kids’ camp aboard private catamarans in the Caribbean. Each of the two sessions of the Voyagers Camp — Aug. 2 to 9 and Aug. 9 to 16 — starts in St. Martin and will give boys and girls between the ages of 10 and 16 the opportunity to snorkel, water ski, wakeboard, paddleboard, hike and earn a PADI Open Water scuba certification or International Yachting Certification.

headline: Work Spaces
abstract: Photographs of labor-union headquarters around the world.
lead_paragraph: Noel Bowler, an Irish photographer, has spent four years photographing the empty interior spaces of labor-union offices in 14 countries. He began the project, titled “Union,” during his M.F.A. studies in photography at the University of Ulster in Belfast. Bowler said the project was a way of engaging with “the debate and conversation about the changes in the workplace,” through an examination of the “spaces that influence decision-making.”

Sears, the flailing United States retailer that Mr. Lampert has led since 2013, wants shareholders to exercise rights to capitalize a real estate investment trust that will buy 235 stores. The danger is that Sears will waste the cash.

headline: The Aspirational R.S.V.P.: Saying Yes When You Mean No
abstract: Saying you will attend an event even though you know you won’t is the apotheosis of digital glibness.
lead_paragraph: Let’s call it the aspirational R.S.V.P. — when someone replies yes to an invitation, even though he knows, or is fairly certain, that he can’t or won’t attend.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Flames in the Garden
abstract: Some of the 600 guests at the Frick Collection's lawn and garden party wore the vibrant orange color of a painting that was the focus of the festivities.
lead_paragraph: The annual Fifth Avenue lawn and garden party at the Frick Collection was an exceptional experience made only more so by the rarity of the Fifth Avenue garden that’s part of the Gilded Age home. A painting was the focus of the festivities: “Flaming June” (above) by Fredrick Leighton, a Victorian artist and contemporary of James McNeill Whistler. It was shown alongside the Frick’s four Whistlers. Some of the 600 guests wore the vibrant orange color of the painting. All of the guests made a big effort to dress for the occasion. Many of the Frick family members were present.

headline: How Jane M. Rogers, Staten Island Yankees Executive, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Rogers, president and general manager of the minor league team, starts the day with a couple of cups of coffee and a call to her grandson and ends it with coffee and prayers before bed.
lead_paragraph: When the Staten Island Yankees begin their season on Friday, Jane M. Rogers, the team’s president and general manager, may reflect on the day she answered a want ad for a secretary 16 years ago. She was an at-home mother who had never seen a minor-league baseball game; the Yankees had not yet come to Staten Island. “I had no idea it was going to develop into a career,” Ms. Rogers, 59, said. Now she handles all team logistics and her husband, Michael, a retired sanitation worker, manages the stadium. The two live in Tottenville with a Shih Tzu named Rocket Rogers. “I hate to be called the team mom,” she said. “Sometimes they say that but I don’t like it. I feel like I’m sitting here baking cookies for them, which I don’t.” JOHN LELAND

headline: Review: San Francisco Symphony Stages ‘Missa Solemnis’ With a Visual Component
abstract: The orchestra closes its season with a three-week Beethoven festival performed with a vocal quartet, the San Francisco Symphony Chorus and the Pacific Boychoir.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Walking into Davies Symphony Hall here on Thursday evening, the audience was met with a promisingly unusual sight. Hanging above the stage were four large screens, more or less rectangular and arranged as if they’d been torn from one another to form a rough cross at the center. Dozens of smaller squares trailed from the rectangles on both sides, as if exploding outward from the cross — or, perhaps, rushing inward to form it.

headline: Review: Alvin Ailey Troupe Dances ‘Exodus’ at Koch Theater
abstract: The company gave Rennie Harris’s new dance its premiere as part of a program that included a tribute to Dudley Williams, the troupe’s longest-serving member.
lead_paragraph: When a choreographer creates a work for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, it can seem that only one option exists: try to make another “Revelations.” That, after all, is the signature work, the fail-safe masterpiece that closes nearly every performance. And although its representation of struggle and spiritual transcendence through dance has inspired many bad copies, it has also served as the model for many of the best pieces made for the troupe in recent years: Ronald K. Brown’s 1999 “Grace,” Rennie Harris’s 2011 “Home” — and now, Mr. Harris’s “Exodus.”

headline: Review: A Reunited Luna Plays Brooklyn’s Northside Festival
abstract: The concert in McCarren Park was a homecoming of sorts for the band, played in front of familiar faces and T-shirts.
lead_paragraph: “It is a pretty momentous occasion,” Sean Eden of Luna calmly observed between songs at the band’s concert on Thursday evening in McCarren Park in Greenpoint. It was a homecoming of sorts: the first New York City appearance in a decade by a band that had distilled a certain New York sound. It was also the first big concert of this year’s Northside Festival, which is striving to become Brooklyn’s version of the South by Southwest festival in Austin and continues through the weekend.

headline: Comfort Food From the Caucasus, Served Up in Brooklyn
abstract: Toné Café, a few blocks from the Atlantic Ocean in Brighton Beach, provides a taste of home to the area’s large Russian population.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday evening in Brighton Beach, a cool breeze made its way inland from the water, and Toné Café, New York’s oldest Georgian bakery, seemed a wrinkle in time, the stations of immigration all represented at once. A jazz band played just loud enough to drown out the conversation of a middle-aged trio of Russians at the corner table, two men and a woman with weathered faces methodically making their way through a bottle of vodka. At another table, four young men, recent immigrants from the Caucasus, argued and laughed. At a third table, two American families were enjoying the food and wine.

headline: Review: Either/Or, at University Settlement, Is Inspired by Boredom and Writer’s Block
abstract: This new-music ensemble presented a musical homage to a quote from Gustave Flaubert.
lead_paragraph: Writer’s block and boredom were the inspiration behind works presented at University Settlement on the Lower East Side by the new-music ensemble Either/Or. The good news: Anthony Coleman had managed to finish the score to his “Flaubert/Sofa/Sentence” ahead of time, and Giorgi Janiashvili’s “Muffling Fog: After Martin Heidegger” was only intermittently dull. A performance that includes an on-screen, nude Hitler salute by one of the composers can be called many things, but not boring. For the most part, the evening felt like a protracted fit of artistic petulance and self-indulgence.

headline: 25 Years of Drawn & Quarterly, Champion of Female Cartoonists
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Women and Girls', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: Back in 1990, comics pretty much looked like a Y chromosome. The Montreal publisher Drawn & Quarterly changed the landscape.
lead_paragraph: When the first issue of Drawn & Quarterly sneaked into comics shops in April 1990, it seemed as if its 23-year-old founder, editor and janitor, Chris Oliveros, was trying to single-handedly conjure a future for the testosterone-confused medium that most of his fellow fans and creators couldn’t imagine.

headline: Jeni’s Ice Cream Finds Listeria Again, and Closes Its Facilities
keywords: ['Listeria Monocytogenes', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Jeni’s closed its plant in Columbus, Ohio, this week after finding the bacteria, weeks after reopening after a recall for listeria contamination.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks after reopening, Jeni’s Splendid Ice Creams in Ohio has once again shuttered its production facility and retail locations after finding a potentially lethal food-borne bacteria in its factory.

headline: Review: ‘Hamari Adhuri Kahani’ Tours a Bad Marriage and the Jungle
abstract: Mohit Suri’s melodramatic film finds time amid its globe-trotting adventure to comment on domestic abuse in India.
lead_paragraph: For a romance, marriage — especially arranged marriage — does not get a good name in Mohit Suri’s florid melodrama “Hamari Adhuri Kahani” (“Our Incomplete Story”). The movie may suffer from a surfeit of excesses, but it does have arresting, if overwrought, things to say about domestic abuse in India.

headline: Beach Rose Thrives in Salt and Sand
abstract: The beach rose is happiest in nutrient-poor sand and gravel, where it grows three-inch blooms ranging from white to magenta.
lead_paragraph: As thorny as it is beautiful, the beach rose is as close to native as you can get without originating here. It is happiest in nutrient-poor, shifting sands and gravel, where it grows in full sun, sprayed with sea salt day and night through all four seasons.

headline: Photographs From the History of C-Squat, a Punk Homestead
abstract: The now legal residents of C-Squat pay “house dues,” which go toward utility bills and payments on a bank loan.
lead_paragraph: When squatters moved into 155 Avenue C in the late 1980s, they found the brick walk-up gutted by fire and abandoned; they climbed between floors using ladders. They later hung stairs and rebuilt the building, which was called C-Squat and in the ’90s became known for the punk shows in its basement.

headline: A Tale of Two Cities, in 1886, and Events That Shaped a State
abstract: New books portray Henry George, the “single tax” proponent, who was almost elected New York mayor, and look at significant chapters in the state’s history.
lead_paragraph: In 1886, 127 years before Bill de Blasio successfully invoked his “tale of two cities” metaphor to address income inequality, Henry George almost won the mayoralty of New York by juxtaposing the economic gains of the Gilded Age with the growth of poverty.

headline: Review: ‘Milkdreams’ Is Like Taking Dance Lessons From a Baby
abstract: Alexandra Beller was inspired by the antics of her young children for “Milkdreams,” at La MaMa Moves!
lead_paragraph: If you’re one of the more than 1,069,000 people who have watched the YouTube video “Baby Modern Dance,” or one of the more than 50,700 who have viewed the similar “Milkdreams Rehearsal With Ivo,” then you may have a sense of what goes on in Alexandra Beller’s “milkdreams.” In those videos, a few adult dancers allow a delighted toddler — Ms. Beller’s son Ivo Hart — to lead their rehearsal, following along with his resilient moves to cello music. Whether swatting the air or catching his own fall, Ivo turns out to be a resourceful improviser.

headline: Trade Deal’s Setback Left Wall Street Unmoved. Why?
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The market’s indifference to Friday’s surprising development suggests the stakes are lower than they appear for the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
lead_paragraph: The rejection earlier today by the House of a bill that was seen as essential for President Obama to make progress on his ambitious agenda of tighter economic integration with the Asia Pacific region came as a major surprise to most commentators.

headline: Chicago Court Gives Woman Frozen Embryos Despite Ex-Boyfriend’s Objections
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Infertility', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Child Custody and Support']
abstract: When the couple who created the embryos disagree, who gets custody? Here, a court ruled for a woman whose fertility was destroyed by cancer treatment.
lead_paragraph: In a closely watched, long-running dispute over who gets custody of frozen embryos when the man and woman who created them disagree, an appeals court in Chicago ruled 2 to 1 on Friday that a woman whose fertility was destroyed by cancer treatment could use embryos she created with her ex-boyfriend, over his objections.

headline: Honda Links a Rupturing Takata Airbag to a 7th Death
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: At least 34 million of the Japanese supplier’s airbags need to be recalled, but automakers have identified and recalled only 16 million cars.
lead_paragraph: Honda Motor on Friday confirmed that a rupturing airbag inflater fatally wounded the driver of a 2005 Civic in a crash in April. Counting this, at least seven deaths have been linked to defective airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata.

headline: MERS Tarnishes Korean President’s Image as Leader
abstract: President Park Geun-hye’s image as a strong leader who can keep a clear head in a crisis has come crashing down as her government struggles to contain an outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — It used to be an often-cited story about Park Geun-hye, the president of South Korea: When her father, the longtime dictator Park Chung-hee, was assassinated by his spy chief in 1979, her first reaction was to ask whether there was any unusual movement by the North Korean military along the border.

headline: Indianapolis Rallies Around Its Gay Citizens After a Law Sets Off a Flood of Support
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination']
abstract: At this week’s pride festivities in Indiana, gay residents say much has changed for the better since passage of the state’s religious exceptions law.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — In a state perhaps best known for its hallowed speedway and lean-to-the-right politics, the pageantry of the past week might have seemed unexpected.

headline: A Paleontologist Deconstructs ‘Jurassic World’
abstract: Velociraptors would not be able to snarl and other dinosaur facts that you can use to impress and annoy your friends.
lead_paragraph: Velociraptors would not be able to snarl and other dinosaur facts that you can use to impress and annoy your friends.

headline: Review: ‘H {N)Y P N(Y} OSIS,’ Out of This World, at Park Avenue Armory
abstract: The French artist Philippe Parreno brings his multimedia spectacle of music, film, sculpture, lights and live performance to the armory’s cavernous drill hall.
lead_paragraph: What happens when the Park Avenue Armory puts its immense Wade Thompson Drill Hall at the disposal of an artist, and money is apparently no object?

headline: City’s Diversity Effort Gets Financial Backers
abstract: New York City’s effort to promote diversity among the staffs, boards and audiences of its cultural organizations has been buttressed by $150,000 from foundations.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s effort to promote diversity among the staffs, boards and audiences of its cultural organizations — announced earlier this year — has been buttressed by $150,000 from foundations. The most recent award, of $100,000, comes from the Ford Foundation to support the roll out of the plan after the city’s Department of Cultural Affairs has completed a survey of arts groups later this year. The Mertz-Gilmore Foundation and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund each previously provided $25,000 to design the survey. Tom Finkelpearl, the department’s commissioner, was to announce the new funding on Saturday during a presentation on diversity with Jane Chu, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, at the annual Americans for the Arts convention in Chicago. “Getting a frank discussion started about the issue of diversity at cultural organizations is absolutely critical to the future of the sector and of the City,” Darren Walker, the president of the Ford Foundation, said in a statement. The survey, designed by the firm Ithaka S+R, will collect data on the diversity at cultural organizations, taking into account factors like age, race, ethnicity, disability and gender.

headline: Pakistan Warns Aid Groups to Follow Unspecified Rules
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Foreign organizations operating in Pakistan were told they faced greater scrutiny and the possibility of expulsion if they failed to adhere to unspecified rules and laws.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — After the police shut down the offices of a major Western aid group, Pakistan’s interior minister warned Friday that other foreign organizations operating in Pakistan faced greater scrutiny and the possibility of expulsion if they failed to adhere to unspecified rules and laws.

headline: Lightning Rookie Andrei Vasilevskiy Steps Up Confidently
abstract: With the Stanley Cup finals against Chicago tied at 2-2, Tampa Bay may have to rely on Vasilevskiy, its 20-year-old backup goalie.
lead_paragraph: BRANDON, Fla. — The Tampa Bay Lightning conducted practice as usual on Friday but without their starting goalie, Ben Bishop. Their highly skilled forwards shared and carried the puck with ease, knifed past defenders and launched shot after shot.

headline: Success of Kurdish Forces Is a Rare Bright Spot for U.S. Policy in Iraq
abstract: The ability of pesh merga forces to retake and defend territory has offered a glimmer of hope for the Obama administration’s policy of coordinating with local forces to battle the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: SULTAN ABDULLAH HILLS, Iraq — Since retaking these barren hills in northern Iraq from the jihadists of the Islamic State, Kurdish pesh merga forces have dug in: excavating trenches, unfurling barbed wire and coordinating with the United States-led military coalition to identify targets for airstrikes.

headline: Tunisian Consular Workers Are Seized by Libyan Militia
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Members of the group Libya Dawn were said to be behind the attack, in retaliation for the detention by Tunisia of their leader, Walid Qulaib.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — An armed group stormed the Tunisian consulate in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, and kidnapped 10 consular employees on Friday, the Tunisian Foreign Ministry said in a communiqué.

headline: No Putts on Sundays, but Bring Your Dog
abstract: The Sunday slumber for the Old Course, a rule dating back centuries, is simultaneously charming and maddening.
lead_paragraph: The Sunday slumber for the Old Course, a rule dating back centuries, is simultaneously charming and maddening.

headline: Sundays on the Old Course at St. Andrews: No Golfers Allowed
abstract: Visitors may find it odd that the course is closed to golfing on a weekend day, but the edict is a sacred part of the course’s traditions.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — For those who arrive at the birthplace of golf on a sunny Sunday morning, the rules of play are simple. You can pretty much do anything you want on the historic grounds of the Old Course, as long as it does not involve actually hitting a drive or rapping a putt.

headline: Young Murdoch Views TV as ‘Real Killer App’ in a New Digital World
abstract: James Murdoch, in partnership with his brother, Lachlan Murdoch, will be responsible for steering 21st Century Fox through the digital disruption of the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: Soon after James Murdoch moved back to New York from London a few years ago, a friend introduced him to a young tech entrepreneur named Joe Marchese.

keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']

headline: Business Leaders React With Dismay to Defeat of Trade Bill
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Corporations']
abstract: Corporate America has been nearly unified in its support of a deal that would lower various barriers to trade and investment between the United States and 11 other Pacific Rim nations.
lead_paragraph: As big a setback as Friday’s vote on Capitol Hill was for President Obama’s efforts to advance his trade agenda, it was an even bigger rebuff for the leaders of American business.

headline: Teenager Hopes to Skip School, of the Golf Variety
abstract: Brooke Henderson, 17, is hoping to finish the season in the top 40 on the money list, which would let her bypass the L.P.G.A.’s Q-School.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.Y. — The Henderson family experienced failure last week. Before arriving at the Manulife L.P.G.A. Classic a few hours from their home in Ontario, Brooke Henderson and her father, Dave, had talked about the goal they wanted to hit during the week. Dad is the caddie and, knowing his daughter’s game as he does, said that three under par would be ideal. Brooke agreed.

headline: Broken Boys, Thieves, Killers, and Now Escapees
abstract: Richard W. Matt and David Sweat emerged from curdled childhoods that included early displays of evil behavior, interviews and documents reveal.
lead_paragraph: The killers seemed the wrong match to put in adjoining cells, a combustible combination promising no good. They were both callous, early adopters of a life of lawlessness. They could be wily. One had demonstrated escape skills. The other was a systematic schemer, reading blueprints, sketching maps, mulling over the fine details of crime.

headline: Don’t Go to Music School
keywords: ['Music', 'Careers and Professions', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Digital Audio Players']

headline: Accounting for the Benefits of Mideast Peace
abstract: A new report from the RAND Corporation shows that Israelis and Palestinians would both be winners with a two-state solution.
lead_paragraph: In the endless Israeli-Palestinian conflict over claims to disputed land, what has been mostly lacking is a hard-nosed calculation of the benefits of peace, the costs of war and the gray zone of the status quo. A report published this month by the RAND Corporation, a nonpartisan think tank, attempts to offer that.

headline: Many Choices for Obama in Replacing Billington at Library of Congress
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: Michael S. Roth of Wesleyan, Drew Gilpin Faust of Harvard, and Douglas Brinkley, the historian, are among those mentioned as potential successors to James H. Billington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only 10 presidents have had the opportunity to nominate a librarian of Congress to oversee America’s largest trove of intellectual treasures and to serve as the chief of the sprawling research institution for the nation’s lawmakers.

headline: Jack Dorsey Returns to Twitter as Chief, to Shrugs and Quips
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Mr. Dorsey is a figure of legend to newer Twitter employees, and remembered with varying degrees of fondness and fear by those who worked with him during his earlier stints there.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last two years, the normally dapper Jack Dorsey has hardly been seen at the offices of Twitter, the social networking company he co-founded, even though he works a block away. So he shocked many when he returned on Thursday with a beard so wild that his own mother made fun of it on Twitter.

headline: Egyptian Doctors Shame Government With Facebook Images of Filthy State-Run Hospitals
abstract: Doctors have posted hundreds of photos of patients surrounded by filth, stray cats, sewage, rodent droppings and snakes.
lead_paragraph: In Egypt, where two presidents have been forced from office in the past four years after street protests largely organized on Facebook, the social network became a rallying point for anger at the country’s rulers again this week, in the form of a new page dedicated to showing images of deplorable conditions in state-run hospitals.

headline: Westchester’s Tortured Road
abstract: It’s time for the county to end its fight with the federal government over a court-ordered fair-housing plan.
lead_paragraph: Another summer, another opportunity to ask the nagging question: When will Westchester County end its fight with the federal government over a court-ordered fair-housing plan, set aside its impassioned resistance to desegregation and get on with its life?

headline: When Playing a Patient Is Part of the Training
abstract: Examining and being examined by classmates brings up significant privacy issues that schools need to address.
lead_paragraph: Students training to be doctors and other health care professionals need practice, and at some schools, that means practicing on other students. But examining and being examined by classmates brings up significant privacy issues that schools need to address.

headline: Scott Walker’s Wisconsin Audition
abstract: After union-busting in his home state, what would he do if he became president?
lead_paragraph: Anticipating a Republican presidential bid by Scott Walker, the two-term governor of Wisconsin, both The New York Times Magazine and The Washington Monthly recently published lengthy articles about him. (The Times feature, which is in the magazine this weekend, was published online Friday.) Both articles focus on Walker’s successful battles with labor. As they should: If he runs for president, his record of union-busting will be at the very center of his campaign.

headline: White House Weighs Sanctions After Second Breach of a Computer System
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Officials said that the second system contained files related to intelligence officials working for the F.B.I., defense contractors and other government agencies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday revealed that hackers had breached a second computer system at the Office of Personnel Management, and said that President Obama was considering financial sanctions against the attackers who gained access to the files of millions of federal workers.

headline: In College, Big Hits Are Back, Back, Back
keywords: ['Baseball (College)', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'Baseball', 'Baseball Bats', 'NCAA Baseball Championships', 'College World Series']
abstract: A change in baseballs leaves College World Series participants encouraged that home runs will increase after two years of record-setting lows.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — The American flag in center field at TD Ameritrade Park hung limp when Rhett Wiseman, the junior right fielder for Vanderbilt, the defending College World Series champion, stepped in on Friday afternoon for his turn in batting practice. Ten minutes later, the left-handed-hitting Wiseman counted six balls that had cleared the fence in right and right-center.

headline: ISIS Is Winning the Social Media War, U.S. Concludes
abstract: An internal State Department assessment says the Islamic State’s social message machine is trumping efforts by the Obama administration and its foreign allies to combat it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An internal State Department assessment paints a dismal picture of the efforts by the Obama administration and its foreign allies to combat the Islamic State’s message machine, portraying a fractured coalition that cannot get its own message straight.

headline: While Hillary Clinton Campaigns on Roosevelt Island, Mayor de Blasio Will Be in Brooklyn
abstract: Bill de Blasio, who has not endorsed Mrs. Clinton, says he is still waiting to hear her “vision for addressing income inequality.”
lead_paragraph: A quick roll call before Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign rally on Roosevelt Island on Saturday:

headline: In Europe, Leaders Take Note: Jeb Bush Isn’t His Brother
abstract: Mr. Bush, who will declare his candidacy for president on Monday, has shown a depth of knowledge and curiosity for which his brother, former President George W. Bush, was not known.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After emerging from a 45-minute meeting here with Jeb Bush, the foreign minister of Germany, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, told colleagues that what struck him most about the American was not the strength of his opinions but something simpler: the depth of his curiosity.

headline: Guns in Your Face
abstract: How would you react if the man in front of you in the Starbucks line had a gun dangling from his shoulder?
lead_paragraph: Life in America requires a lot of advance preparation. For instance, when you’re getting ready for a plane trip you imagine what you’ll do if a problem arises — flight delay, long lines at security. But I bet you haven’t considered the best way to react if the man in front of you on the airport escalator has a gun dangling from his shoulder.

headline: A Flushing Meadows Chronicler of Soccer and Immigration
abstract: Luis Muñoz, 82, is the last in a long line of photographers selling weekend soccer players in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park photos of themselves.
lead_paragraph: It was a recent Sunday morning and Luis Muñoz was in his usual place, the crowded soccer fields at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. He was not wearing cleats but white orthopedic-style tennis shoes. And he wove among the jerseys not with a ball but with a camera.

headline: Donors Speed-Date the G.O.P. Hopefuls
abstract: Donors took stock of the Republican field, hoping to find a candidate who not only excites them but who they believe can win a general election.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — When Republican donors and operatives descended on Mitt Romney’s annual retreat at a five-star European-style lodge here last year, they came to pay homage to Mr. Romney and try to regroup after losing the 2012 presidential race.

headline: Plea Deal in Case Tied to Derek Boogaard’s Death
keywords: ['Hockey, Ice', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'OxyContin (Drug)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Sports Injuries']
abstract: Boogard, a former left wing with the Rangers, died from an accidental overdose on alcohol and oxycodone.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Johnson, a former medical assistant for hockey’s minor league Utah Grizzlies, may have never met Derek Boogaard, the deceased N.H.L. left wing. But Johnson has agreed to plead guilty in a case involving painkillers he prescribed that may have ended up in the hands of Boogaard shortly before his death.

headline: Asian Migrants Say Australia Paid Smugglers to Turn Back
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: The migrants’ account has stoked debate over the hard-line policy on illegal immigrants that helped Prime Minister Tony Abbott win office in 2013 but exposed Australia to pointed criticism by United Nations agencies.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Asian migrants on a boat that was intercepted by the Australian authorities three weeks ago have told refugee workers that the Australians paid the smugglers to take them back to Indonesia, a United Nations official said on Friday.

headline: Jim Ed Brown, Smooth Voice on ‘The Three Bells’ and Other Hits, Dies at 81
abstract: A Grand Ole Opry star, Mr. Brown had a long string of songs on the country charts, both as part of the Browns, with Helen Cornelius, and as a solo act.
lead_paragraph: Jim Ed Brown, a Grand Ole Opry star whose smooth, sweet baritone made him a chart-topper as a solo act, in duets with Helen Cornelius and as one third of the close-harmony group the Browns, whose 1959 hit “The Three Bells” sold more than a million records, died on Thursday in Franklin, Tenn. He was 81.

headline: U.S. Soccer Defends Actions in Hope Solo Case
abstract: U.S. Soccer gave a detailed defense of its actions and of its decision not to suspend Solo from the national team for this month’s Women’s World Cup.
lead_paragraph: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — The United States Soccer Federation, under intensifying scrutiny for its handling of a case involving domestic violence accusations against goalkeeper Hope Solo, on Friday mounted a detailed defense of its actions and of its decision not to suspend Solo from the national team for the current Women’s World Cup.

headline: Madness in Great Ones
abstract: Crunch along with Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — With the exception of the unbelievably Scrabbly northwest, this was not as tough as I’d expect for a Saturday in the grid with Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson.

keywords: ['Taxation', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Income Tax', 'Sales and Excise Taxes']

lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — For weeks, a sense of frustration and desperation had hung heavy over the polished and airy Capitol here.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The beach, enrobed in a damp chill, was empty, the federal authorities said, except for three men hatching a terrorism plot.

headline: Jane Hart, Activist and Nearly an Astronaut, Dies at 93
abstract: Ms. Hart passed NASA’s astronaut training program while married to Philip A. Hart, a Democratic senator from Michigan who often found himself defending his wife’s liberal views.
lead_paragraph: Jane Briggs Hart, a flying enthusiast, would-be astronaut and competitive equestrian and sailor whose outspoken views on women’s rights, the Roman Catholic Church and the Vietnam War sometimes made political life a challenge for her husband, Philip A. Hart, a Democratic senator from Michigan in the 1960s and ’70s, died on June 5 in Bloomfield, Conn. She was 93.

headline: Police Review Board Seeks Grand Jury Records in Eric Garner Case
abstract: The Civilian Complaint Review Board argued in State Supreme Court on Friday that jury transcripts are needed to review police actions.
lead_paragraph: The debate over grand jury records connected to the chokehold death of Eric Garner at the hands of the police took a new turn on Friday as lawyers argued over whether the Staten Island district attorney’s office should provide that material to the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

headline: Robert Chartoff, Producer of ‘Raging Bull’ and ‘Rocky,’ Dies at 81
abstract: For two decades, beginning in 1967, Mr. Chartoff and his partner, Irwin Winkler, produced many of the signature Hollywood films of the era.
lead_paragraph: Robert Chartoff, half of the powerful Hollywood producing team behind “Rocky” and “Raging Bull” as well as other high-profile dramas, died on Wednesday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Bartolo Colon Earns Ninth Victory as Mets Defeat the Braves
abstract: Colon stymied the Braves through the first four innings, allowing one hit, a single by Freddie Freeman in the fourth.
lead_paragraph: Bartolo Colon strolled into the clubhouse at Citi Field three and a half hours before his start Friday. He was wearing sunglasses, jeans and a red T-shirt. He looked at ease.

headline: Women’s World Cup: U.S. Earns a Draw the Hard Way
abstract: Neither team would concede on Friday, although Sweden might have won late if not for an attentive defensive play from Meghan Klingenberg.
lead_paragraph: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — At 5 feet 2 inches, left back Meghan Klingenberg is the smallest player on the American women’s national team, but she made probably the biggest play on Friday night to preserve a 0-0 tie with Sweden in the World Cup.

headline: Michael Pineda’s Time Off Leads to a Forgettable Start
abstract: The Orioles rocked Pineda in an 11-3 drubbing of the Yankees at Camden Yards.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Over the course of a six-month grind of a baseball season, a night like Friday, when the Yankees were drubbed by the Baltimore Orioles, 11-3, is one that might normally be easily forgotten.
