headline: 6 Guantánamo Detainees From Yemen Are Transferred to Oman
abstract: The move of the Yemenis, who were lower-level prisoners held for 13 years, reduces the number held at prison in Cuba to 116.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has transferred six lower-level detainees from the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, where each had been held for more than 13 years, the military announced early Saturday. The departures, to Oman, were the first from the prison in six months and reduced the inmate population there to 116 prisoners.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) GET ON UP (2014) Chadwick Boseman shuffles, spins and splits as James Brown, “the hardest-working man in show business” — as well as a monumental egotist, perfectionist and harsh taskmaster with a streak of paranoia — in this biopic directed by Tate Taylor (“The Help”). Nelsan Ellis is Bobby Byrd, Brown’s longtime best friend, who sticks around as the wives and girlfriends come and go. “Brown’s music and show business ascendance are the heart and soul of a movie that takes his art very seriously,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “None other than Mick Jagger, who has made no secret of his indebtedness to Brown’s stage moves, is the music producer of this film, which puts music front and center, where it belongs. Brown’s real voice, which never sounds dubbed, is used in remixes of his original recordings.” And while the film “largely skirts the issue of race” along with Brown’s alienation of black audiences because of his support of Richard M. Nixon, “in the end, he stood above it all,” Mr. Holden added. “Having won the game, he dwelt in his own realm, where he ruled once and for always as the Godfather of Soul.”

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 13, 2015.

headline: Experts Fault South Korean Response to MERS Outbreak
abstract: The government’s failure to share information quickly contributed to worsening the outbreak, a panel that included experts from the World Health Organization said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean government’s failure to share information quickly with the public and establish an efficient disease-control system contributed to worsening the outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome in the country, a joint panel of experts from the World Health Organization and South Korea said Saturday.

abstract: Fabrice Grinda, who is worth an estimated $100 million, ditched his 20-acre estate and $300,000 sports car in search of an elusive happiness.
lead_paragraph: For a time, he lived on a 20-acre estate in Bedford, N.Y., overseen by a butler whom he paid $50,000 a year, and he hosted grand parties for 60 guests or more.

headline: Taliban Attack Police Base in Afghanistan, Killing 17
abstract: Afghanistan’s police force took another severe blow in the attack, which began after midnight Saturday in a strategically important district in Helmand Province.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s police force took another severe blow from the Taliban on Saturday, as 17 police officers were killed in a clash with the insurgents in the southern province of Helmand, officials said.

headline: New Nature Trail and Interactive Museum in the Adirondacks
abstract: When the Wild Walk opens on July 4, visitors to the Adirondacks will get to see the region’s lush landscape and diverse wildlife from a new perspective.
lead_paragraph: When the Wild Walk opens on July 4, visitors to the Adirondacks will get to see the region’s lush landscape and diverse wildlife from a new perspective. Billed as a “High Line for the Forest,” the Wild Walk is an elevated nature trail and interactive museum that weaves into the treetops of Tupper Lake in northern New York.

headline: Dallas Gunman Killed After Attack on Police Headquarters
abstract: The suspected gunman who attacked Police Headquarters from inside an armored van and left bags filled with pipe bombs around the building was shot and killed by a police sniper.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — A gunman attacked Police Headquarters at the edge of downtown here from inside an armored van early Saturday, shooting at officers and leaving bags filled with pipe bombs around the building in a brazen assault that led to an hourslong standoff. Hours after negotiators who had tried to persuade him to surrender lost contact, the suspect was found dead in the van after being shot by a police sniper, the police said.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from a treehouse in Washington State to the fashion world in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from a treehouse in Washington State to the fashion world in Manhattan.

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australian opposition lawmakers said Saturday that they would press Prime Minister Tony Abbott to reveal whether the government paid smugglers to turn a boat full of migrants back to Indonesia after intercepting it at sea.

headline: Decline and Fall of the Davos Democrats
abstract: Arguments from authority don’t work the way they used to.

But no, or not so far.

abstract: Some proposed privacy laws for students could unintentionally choke off the data’s original purpose: assessing and improving education.

headline: Should Stories in Print Reflect Early Reaction?
abstract: A reader’s question on the Rubio spending story prompts an editor’s description of editing practices
lead_paragraph: Last week’s stories on Marco Rubio’s traffic tickets and financial practices got a lot of reaction — much of it critical. Even Jon Stewart got in on the action, mocking The Times’s attention to the “oversize windows” in the home of the Florida senator who is running for president and to his occasional speeding infractions.

headline: Roosevelt Island Awakens to a Clinton Crowd
abstract: Early risers stumbled upon hundreds of Clinton supporters hoping for a ticket to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign kickoff speech on Roosevelt Island.
lead_paragraph: Though the usual early-morning risers were already walking their dogs and stretching their legs as they strolled along the East River, this was not a typical Saturday on Roosevelt Island. At the southern end of the island, the residents found themselves bumping into hundreds of supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton waiting in line hours before she was expected to give the kickoff speech of her 2016 campaign for president here.

abstract: The woods being searched for two escaped inmates are inhospitable in ways that could make finding food, water and shelter a challenge but also complicate efforts to track them down.
lead_paragraph: CADYVILLE, N.Y. — These rolling woods, just miles from the New York State prison where two convicted killers escaped a week ago, can be brutally unforgiving to the unacquainted. It is easy to get disoriented, local residents say, and between the bugs and the wet weather, it might be the second worst time of year for anyone to try seek refuge there. Winter, of course, would be far worse.

keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Depleted by decades of diminishing reach and struggling to respond to recent anti-union laws, the labor movement has nonetheless found a way to assert itself politically by wreaking havoc on President Obama’s trade agenda, a top priority of his final years in office.

headline: Long Island Restaurants Serve Up Tacos for Summer
abstract: Whether it’s Pico Tequila Grill in Bay Shore, Little Mexico Bar & Restaurant in Westbury or Chichimecas in Farmingdale, Long Islanders can get their fills of the Mexican staple.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island Railroad train periodically roared past Chichimecas Music and TAM Bar Restaurant in Farmingdale on a recent evening, but diners paid no mind. They were listening instead to Alejandro Gonzalez as he played a rousing guitar duet of “Guantanamera” with a fellow musician. The dining room, festooned with colorful Mexican flags, woven serape tablecloths, maracas and murals, captured the mood of a neighborhood social club buoyed by food, music and margaritas.

headline: Director Reflects on His Tenure at Long Island Arts Camp
abstract: After more than 30 years, Dale Lewis is saying goodbye to Usdan, in Huntington, which has alumni like Natalie Portman, Mariah Carey and Jane Monheit.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, I wish Usdan had existed for me,” Dale Lewis said, with both a sigh and a smile, in his office at the Long Island arts day camp, which is unusual in both its name and its offerings.

headline: Restaurant Review: Rye House in Port Chester
abstract: While diners can order the usual meatballs or sliders, the Southern-tinged menu at Rye House also offers more nuanced fare.
lead_paragraph: At first blush, Rye House looks a little like a mead hall, but once your eyes adjust to the dim light, it looks more like a loft apartment with bachelor accouterments: leather upholstery, rough-hewed posts and beams, tilted mirrors, dual flat screens and a well-stocked bar. Was it a surprise that on a Saturday night the Port Chester restaurant was packed with middle-aged guys in untucked Hawaiian shirts gripping frosty glasses of craft beer and goblets of red wine? Were they also holding tickets to hear the likes of Deep Purple at the nearby Capitol Theater? Showtime came and went, and few budged.

headline: Hillary Clinton, in Roosevelt Island Speech, Pledges to Close Income Gap
abstract: “I’m not running for some America,” Mrs. Clinton said at a rally at which she denounced Republican economic policies. “I’m running for all Americans.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in a speech that was at times sweeping and at times policy laden, delivered on Saturday a pointed repudiation of Republican economic policies and a populist promise to reverse the gaping gulf between the rich and poor at her biggest campaign event to date.

headline: The Chat: Hillary Clinton’s Rally Speech, Instantly Analyzed
abstract: The former first lady and secretary of state promised to “wage and win four fights” — to improve the economy, to help families, to improve national security and to overhaul campaign-finance rules to revitalize American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Two months after announcing her presidential candidacy by video, Hillary Rodham Clinton held her first campaign rally shortly before noon Saturday on Roosevelt Island in New York City. Over instant messages, two New York Times political correspondents analyzed Mrs. Clinton’s remarks in real time — as they did with Mrs. Clinton’s announcement video and with the campaign announcements of several other 2016 candidates. Here is an edited version of their chat.

lead_paragraph: Over the years, the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah has opened its summer stage early, and often, to notable premieres, from the American debut of Benjamin Britten’s trilogy of operatic church parables in the 1960s to the inaugural performance of David Ludwig’s “String Quartet No. 1: Pale Blue Dot” last year.

headline: Lost Voices of the World’s Refugees
abstract: Not enough is being done to respond to the millions of people forcibly displaced by conflict or persecution.
lead_paragraph: The global crisis of people forcibly displaced by conflict or persecution is expressed in many ways — in faceless numbers, always millions more than in the previous year; in the images of desperate people crowded onto rickety boats; in the pictures of endless tents on a barren, dusty field. Around the world, at least 50 million people either have been displaced inside their countries or have fled to foreign lands. Some, like Palestinians, have lived as refugees for generations; some, like Syrians and Ukrainians, are fleeing more recent conflicts; some, like the Rohingya of Myanmar, run from systematic persecution.

headline: For a Catcher Who Had a Pitcher’s Surgery, Recovery From a Different Angle
abstract: After spending the past year coming back from Tommy John surgery, Orioles catcher Matt Wieters has a new perspective, and a few theories, on an operation normally performed on pitchers.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Matt Wieters does not pitch for a living, but from every other angle, he is an expert on the pitching arm. As the catcher for the Baltimore Orioles, Wieters works with pitchers and hits against them hundreds of times a year. He also had Tommy John surgery last June.

headline: Lane Opens for Driver Who Hit Wall
abstract: In light of all that has happened the last two years — both to Martin Truex Jr. and his longtime girlfriend, Sherry Pollex — it has been a remarkable comeback.
lead_paragraph: Although the 16-car field for the 2015 Nascar Sprint Cup playoff will not be set until September, it isn’t hard to identify the drivers to beat this year. The six-time Cup champion Jimmie Johnson and last year’s winner, Kevin Harvick, have been the class of the series to date.

headline: Will Nebraska’s Death Penalty Come Back?
abstract: The Legislature did the right thing after an open and honest debate. Now comes the counterattack.
lead_paragraph: In a sensible, humane move last month, Nebraska lawmakers abolished the state’s death penalty by a 30-to-19 vote that crossed party lines and overrode a veto by Gov. Pete Ricketts. These lawmakers aren’t renegades; an April poll by the American Civil Liberties Union of Nebraska found that 58 percent of Nebraskans supported alternatives to the death penalty, like life without parole.

headline: Putting an End to Abusive Car Loans
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Automobiles', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Automobile Financing', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau needs to use its enforcement powers to end unfair and deceptive lending.
lead_paragraph: Auto loans have long been a bastion of predatory lending and racial discrimination. Until the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was established, auto lending by banks was only lightly regulated, and lending by nonbank finance companies escaped federal regulation altogether. Greater scrutiny of banks by the bureau since 2013 has resulted in fines totaling $18 million and in payments totaling $136 million to 425,000 black, Hispanic and Asian borrowers who were charged higher auto-loan interest rates than comparable white borrowers.

headline: U.S. Is Poised to Put Heavy Weaponry in Eastern Europe
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The proposal, if approved, would represent the first time since the end of the Cold War that the United States has stationed heavy military equipment in Eastern Europe.
lead_paragraph: RIGA, Latvia — In a significant move to deter possible Russian aggression in Europe, the Pentagon is poised to store battle tanks, infantry fighting vehicles and other heavy weapons for as many as 5,000 American troops in several Baltic and Eastern European countries, American and allied officials say.

headline: Restaurant Review: Jammin’ Crêpes in Princeton
abstract: Local cheeses, bacon, eggs, fruits or vegetables are stuffed into each whopper of a crepe.
lead_paragraph: Cookbook author and French food aficionado Richard Olney wrote of crepes that “their greatest pitfalls derive, no doubt, from their versatility — not in itself a fault, but a quality that teases many a cook into overstepping the boundaries of sense and taste. One should never lose sight of the fragile and delicate, thin, tender thing that is the crepe itself.” Olney, writing in the 1970s, proposed that home cooks roll savory crepes around calf’s brains or, for dessert, sauce them with chartreuse.

headline: Cavaliers’ Lucky Charm Teeters on Six Chairs
abstract: The Cavaliers are 3-0 when the 56-year-old acrobat known as the Amazing Sladek, who will be in Cleveland for Game 6 on Tuesday, performs the death-defying tower of chairs at halftime.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — On Sunday afternoon, Gary Borstelmann will load six wooden chairs into the back of his Chrysler minivan and set out for Cleveland from his home in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. He expects that the 1,200-mile drive will take two days, but at least he will have the company of his personal assistant, Patricia Murphy, and his pet turtle, Frick.

headline: How to Make Online Dating Work
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Online Dating', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Research']
abstract: Research suggests techniques for making the search for love more effective and less exhausting.
lead_paragraph: WE turn to screens for nearly every decision. Where to eat. Where to vacation. Where to eat on vacation. Where to get treatment for the food poisoning you got at that restaurant where you ate on vacation. Where to write a negative review calling out the restaurant that gave you food poisoning and ruined your vacation. So it’s no surprise our screens are becoming the first place we turn to when looking for romance — because you need someone to take care of you when you get food poisoning on your vacation, right?

headline: At Audible, Work Speaks Volumes
abstract: Founded in Montclair by the former journalist and author Donald Katz in 1995, Audible has been making itself heard at ever-increasing volume since moving to Newark from Wayne in 2007.
lead_paragraph: On a gray April morning in Newark, Jonathan Davis, an actor, sat in a conference room and paused to consider the value of his work.

headline: The Toxic Legacy of Lead Paint
keywords: ['Lead', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Paint', 'Children and Childhood', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Epidemics']
abstract: When my son was poisoned by lead, I had to act. But how?
lead_paragraph: New Orleans

headline: Review: Moxie in Madison
abstract: Moxie, which opening in November in Madison, brings a chic sensibility to demure surroundings, with regionally influenced American classics.
lead_paragraph: Coolness, in a restaurant or any other endeavor, is an elusive quality to pin down. A place that’s cool has to be stylish, but without seeming like it’s trying too hard. It may be unusual, even offbeat, but it can’t be off-putting. And it must somehow convey both exclusivity and affability. A cool hangout might make you feel a little self-conscious the first time you walk in, but you relax quickly. Because being welcomed there means you must be cool, too.

headline: Flawed Humans, Flawed Justice
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Discrimination', 'Police', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: We should use lessons from behavioral science to make police and courts more fair.
lead_paragraph: WHAT would it take to achieve true criminal justice in America?

headline: Review: ‘Good People,’ in Hartford, Deals With Characters in, and From, Southie
abstract: The playwright David Lindsay-Abaire drew from the Boston neighborhood he came from for his Tony Award-winning work, being staged at TheaterWorks.
lead_paragraph: When Margie Walsh, the tough-talking heroine of David Lindsay-Abaire’s “Good People,” tells her one-time boyfriend Mike that he’s become like someone on a television show, it’s far from a compliment. She means that as a well-off doctor living in a moneyed suburb of Boston, with a bespoke wife and a pampered child, he’s a traitor to their class and to their shared roots in hardscrabble Southie, the blue-collar South Boston neighborhood once famous for being poor, Irish and bigoted.

headline: Bearing My Father’s Byline
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'News and News Media', 'Baseball', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Sharing a profession and a name with a famous parent proved to be an honor and a weight for a young sportswriter.
lead_paragraph: Until he wandered into The Baltimore Sun in the fall of 1959 and found his calling in life, it would be fair to say that my father suffered from an acute identity crisis. Though his given name was George Melvin, no one called him that, if only to avoid confusion with my grandfather. Around the rowhouse in East Baltimore where Dad grew up, everyone always called him Sonny. As a high school athlete who lettered in three sports, he was known as Otts, the origins of which are unclear. In his incarnation in later years as a fledging bush-league baseball player, he adopted the sobriquet Randy because he felt it created the illusion that he could run faster. I’m not kidding. He actually thought that.

headline: Regulation and Arbitrage (Implicitly Wonkish)
abstract: What is “liquidity” anyway?
lead_paragraph: According to the FT, the financial fear du jour is no longer Greece, or inflation, or any of the other things that have obsessed markets in recent years; it’s liquidity. We are pointed to a recent column by Stephen Schwarzman, who warns that lack of liquidity is just like when Hitler invaded Poland (sorry, he said that about ending the tax loophole for equity managers) may cause a financial crisis; Nouriel Roubini agrees.

headline: Organ and Organist Lend the Lightning a Thunderous Grandeur
abstract: Krystof Srebrakowski, the organist at Tampa Bay Lightning games, has helped bring the crowd alive during the Lightning’s run to the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — At the south end of Amalie Arena, perched atop a stage, sits the largest organ in the N.H.L. It features five rows of keys, four rows of switches, a host of buttons and, underneath, several pedals. At times, Krystof Srebrakowski, the organist, seems to use every one of its features, bobbing his head, his eyes closed, his feet dancing between pedals, his fingers gliding along.

abstract: Composing with orchestral instruments was fine. But I found a richer palette of melody, counterpoint and rhythm already in the air.

abstract: Tim Glover, the top javelin thrower in the United States, competed Saturday at the Adidas Grand Prix in a sport that receives little attention.
lead_paragraph: Tim Glover, the top javelin thrower in the United States, shrugged off one indignity after another performing one of the less appreciated sports at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island on Saturday. Forget finishing in seventh place (“it happens”): it was not yet 10 a.m., and the stadium’s mostly containing the parents of 11-year-olds running relay races. But the music was too much.

headline: Three Simple Rules for Eating Seafood
keywords: ['Sustainable Living', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fish Farming', 'Seafood']
abstract: Eat American. Different kinds. Mostly farmed filter feeders, like oysters.

Mostly plants.” Ever since, a certain kind of progressive supermarket aisle has emerged: “Real” foods, calorie-limited portions and vegetarianism (or at least Meatless Mondays) have become culinary aspirations for millennials and boomers alike.

headline: Pope Francis to Explore Climate’s Effect on World’s Poor

abstract: When Francis releases his first major teaching letter on the theme of the environment and poverty, he may redefine a secular topic as a matter of morality.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Ban Ki-moon arrived at the Vatican with his own college of cardinals. Mr. Ban, the United Nations secretary general, had brought the leaders of all his major agencies to see Pope Francis, a show of organizational muscle and respect for a meeting between two global institutions that had sometimes shared a bumpy past but now had a mutual interest.

headline: Ronald A. Wilford, Manager to a Host of Legendary Maestros, Dies at 87
abstract: By orchestrating the careers of leading conductors, he became one of the most powerful figures in classical music in the second half of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Ronald A. Wilford, a spotlight-shunning manager who became one of the most powerful figures in classical music in the second half of the 20th century not by conducting orchestras but by orchestrating the careers of conductors, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Frank Zachary, Editor and Art Director, Dies at 101
abstract: Former colleagues remember Mr. Zachary as one of the last great editors and art directors from a golden age of magazines.
lead_paragraph: Frank Zachary, a celebrated magazine editor and art director who pioneered graphic innovations and creative photography while chronicling postwar America’s fascination with travel and leisure and the affluent society, died on Friday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 101.

headline: City Schoolchildren Take to a British Sport
abstract: More than 70 teams in and around New York City played this month in the eighth annual Rugby Cup, and a frequent contender is a Brooklyn middle school.

headline: Jeb Bush Works to Recover From a Shaky Start
abstract: As he prepares to make his presidential campaign official on Monday, Jeb Bush, a former governor of Florida, finds himself part of a pack of candidates and the target of questions about his competence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeb Bush had a plan for the last six months he spent as an unannounced candidate for president. He would raise tens of millions of dollars, distinguish himself from his brother’s controversial presidency, start winning over conservatives and establish himself as the Republican to beat for his party’s nomination.

headline: Sheriff’s Report Provides New Details on Tamir Rice’s Death, but Leaves Questions
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A lengthy report by the Cuyahoga County Sheriff’s Department does not answer whether a Cleveland police officer issued a warning before firing on the 12-year-old boy.
lead_paragraph: A lengthy report published Saturday revealed new details about the fatal shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice by a Cleveland police officer, but made no recommendation on whether the officer or his partner should face criminal charges.

headline: N.B.A. Finals: David Lee, a Former All-Star, Has Become a Stellar Substitute for the Warriors
abstract: Lee lost his starting job after straining his hamstring during the preseason, but he has come off the bench the last two games of the series to help confound the Cleveland Cavaliers.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — David Lee strained his left hamstring in the preseason, lost his starting job for the Golden State Warriors and never got it back. He played sparingly as the Warriors rolled to 67 victories in the regular season. His past as a two-time All-Star seemed like more of a stigma as his D.N.P.s — box-score code for “did not play” — accumulated like dust bunnies.

headline: Jacob deGrom Starts Strong, but Bullpen Stumbles as Mets Fall to Braves
abstract: With the closer Jeurys Familia unavailable, the Mets squandered a lead and lost in extra innings despite another solid outing from deGrom.
lead_paragraph: As it inched across the batter’s box at Citi Field on Saturday afternoon, the shadow from the light tower above the western grandstands provided cover for two starting pitchers who hardly needed the assistance.

headline: Man Discharges Gun at Waldorf Wedding Reception, Injuring 5
abstract: Four people were taken to hospitals for minor injuries and another person refused treatment at the scene, officials said.
lead_paragraph: An unidentified man attending a wedding reception at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in Manhattan on Saturday accidentally discharged a firearm and injured five people, including one woman who was struck in the head, the police said.

headline: Usain Bolt and Mary Cain Are Not at Their Fastest in Adidas Grand Prix
abstract: Bolt won the 200 meters as expected, but it was a narrow victory, and Cain finished fourth in the 1,000 meters behind three other Americans.
lead_paragraph: The Adidas Grand Prix had breakout performances on Saturday, but some top stars had uninspiring results.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 14, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “We clearly need a fundamental change of course, to protect the earth and its people — which in turn will allow us to dignify humanity.”

headline: Inbee Park, With Benefit of Early Homework, Takes Two-Stroke Lead in Women’s P.G.A. Championship
abstract: Park, ranked second in the world, is at 14 under for the tournament and leads second-place Sei Young Kim by two strokes.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.Y. — Brad Beecher thought it would be a good idea to get an early sneak peek. He had heard how demanding Westchester County Club’s West Course could be, so rather than fly from Canada on Monday for a first look, he and the player he caddies for, Inbee Park, played a handful of practice rounds last month. Beecher watched as Park got a grasp on how big and bold the course is.

headline: More Defensive Gaffes Bedevil the Yankees in Their Second Straight Loss
abstract: A miscommunication between Brian McCann and Mark Teixeira was the latest costly mistake for the Yankees, who fell into a virtual tie with Tampa Bay after the loss.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — For the second night in a row, the Yankees were troubled by an embarrassing failure to communicate. On Friday, two outfielders looked at each other as a fly ball landed between them, and it was catcher Brian McCann and Mark Teixeira who politely bumbled on Saturday.

headline: Hillary Clinton Recruits Supporters With ‘House Parties’
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton flew to Iowa on Saturday evening to urge Democrats to sign on to her presidential team rather than remain open to overtures from the growing political operations of Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Fresh off her first major campaign rally in New York City, Hillary Rodham Clinton flew to Iowa on Saturday evening to urge Democrats to sign on to her presidential team rather than remain open to overtures from the growing political operations of Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley, two rivals also working intently here.

headline: 30,000 Fans Greet American Pharoah in Festive Return to Churchill Downs
abstract: Cloaked in white cloth, American Pharoah was paraded like a war hero at the racetrack where he began his path to horse racing immortality with a win in the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — On a hot and humid day, American Pharoah, the 12th Triple Crown winner, returned to a king’s homecoming at Churchill Downs. The euphoric coronation began Friday, when he returned to the dirt at 6:45 a.m. for a jog. It ended Saturday evening before an estimated crowd of 30,000 who came from near and far to see the bay colt for themselves and fawn over the horse that has revitalized a proud sport.

headline: Simpler, Uncomplicated Timepieces Are Back
abstract: Remember the days of basic, good-looking watches with nylon straps? Those days are now.
lead_paragraph: Remember the days of basic, good-looking watches with nylon straps and uncomplicated mechanics? Those days are now.

headline: In the East Village and SoHo, Orley’s Family Values
abstract: The art-stuffed homes of the knitwear brand’s three designers influence their eclectic workspace.
lead_paragraph: Established in 2011 by Matthew Orley, his now-wife Samantha and Matthew’s younger brother, Alex, the jacquard-heavy, knitwear-centric brand Orley is 100 percent a family affair, from motivation to execution. With its men’s, and newly minted women’s, ready-to-wear lines, “our collections tend to be autobiographical,” Alex says. “The tenets of the brand take things a little nostalgic or familiar and recontextualize those retro feelings into something modern in their boldness. A lot of what we do comes from our grandparents’ strong sense of self. We grew up around them. They were very esoteric dressers.”

headline: Chicago Blackhawks Close In on Stanley Cup With Another One-Goal Victory
abstract: Antoine Vermette broke a 1-1 tie two minutes into the third period, and Chicago edged host Tampa Bay to move a victory away from winning the Stanley Cup.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Ben Bishop stood in the crease looking as brave as he could in the third period Saturday as the Chicago Blackhawks mounted another charge toward him. The Blackhawks knew that Bishop, the Tampa Bay Lightning goalie, was dealing with an undisclosed injury, and they had challenged him every chance they could, testing the limits of his will and his tolerance for pain.

lead_paragraph: The Adidas Grand Prix at Randalls Island attracted a wide range of athletes, from the very young to Olympians.

headline: At Art Basel, a Powerful Jury Controls the Market
abstract: Six jurors decide which galleries get to show their art at this influential Swiss fair, where billions of dollars’ worth of art is for sale.
lead_paragraph: The hundreds of gallery owners who apply each year to secure a coveted booth at Art Basel, the Swiss art fair, spend weeks on their admission applications. They describe the evolution of their galleries, track the history of their exhibitions and list the biographies of their artists. Then there is the matter of the “mock booths,” intricate sketches, miniature models, even virtual tours, of their planned exhibition spaces, complete with tiny reproductions of the exact works they hope to exhibit.

abstract: At least 12 people have been reported dead, and heavy rains destroyed the enclosures of the Georgian city’s main zoo.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Residents of Tbilisi, Georgia, were warned to stay off the streets on Sunday lest they encounter one of the lions, tigers, bears or other beasts set free from the city zoo after floodwaters devastated the center of the capital.

headline: A Hard Road to Health Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Diabetes', 'Dialysis']
abstract: In June 2015, the Times profiled David Elson, a chronically ill Kentucky man who signed up for insurance through the Affordable Care Act but lost it after not paying the premiums.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act was designed to help people like David Elson. He had a box full of unpaid medical bills, a result of uncontrolled diabetes and all the health complications that came with it. He badly needed health insurance, but as a self-employed alarm installer, he could not afford it — especially since insurers could charge chronically ill people much more before the new law took effect.

headline: Bid by Omar al-Bashir of Sudan to Avoid Arrest Is Tested in South Africa
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A South African court issued an interim order to prevent the Sudanese president from leaving the country after the International Criminal Court sought his arrest on genocide charges.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — As the only head of state wanted by the International Criminal Court on genocide charges, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan had spent years looking over his shoulder. He avoided countries where the risk of arrest seemed high. He visited friendly African nations hostile to the court, though he sometimes quickly left for home when the ground seemed to shift.

headline: Protesters Return to Hong Kong’s Streets
abstract: Days ahead of a vote that would turn Beijing’s election plan into local law, thousands are calling on lawmakers to honor pledges to veto the proposal.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of people returned on Sunday to streets near Hong Kong government headquarters — the site last year of months of student-led protests for freer elections — hoping to press lawmakers to block Beijing’s plan for selecting the city’s top official in 2017.

headline: 1890: Palais Royal Tower
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Shopkeepers of the Palais Royal in Paris have come up with a new way to attract customers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The disconsolate shopkeepers of the Palais Royal have hit upon a new scheme to attract the public to the comparatively deserted arcades. When the proposal to cut a new street through the gardens was abandoned, M. Martin-Ginouvier proposed to build in the centre of the enclosure a tower, 55 mètres high, of iron and crystal. A modification of this scheme has now been supplied by another architect M. Bourdais, and approved of at a meeting of the principal trade men of the Palais. M. Bourdais proposes to build, near the Galerie d’Orléans, a tower 100 mètres high, not of iron and glass, but of stone. His plans show four platforms, accessible by lifts and a staircase, with, at the summit, a lighthouse powerful enough to light the four central arrondissements. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 15, 1890

headline: Concern for the Men Still Behind Bars as Lockdown Continues
abstract: Clinton Correctional Facility has not allowed visitors since two men escaped a week ago, prompting concerns from family members about how life has changed on the inside.
lead_paragraph: For nine days, Geneva Perez has been trying to reach her husband in prison. And for nine days, she has been told she cannot talk to him.

headline: John Carroll, Editor Who Reinvigorated The Los Angeles Times, Is Dead at 73
abstract: Mr. Carroll, a widely admired newspaper editor, restored the reputation and credibility of The Los Angeles Times in the early 2000s even as he fought bitterly with the paper’s corporate parent.
lead_paragraph: John S. Carroll, a widely admired newspaper editor who restored the reputation and credibility of The Los Angeles Times in the early 2000s even as he fought bitterly with the paper’s cost-conscious corporate parent, died on Sunday at his home in Lexington, Ky. He was 73.

headline: Spanish Official Apologizes Over Twitter Joke About Holocaust
abstract: The new, left-wing government of Madrid faced its first test over the weekend as the politician charged with running culture apologized for a post from 2011 that he said was taken out of context.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The new, left-wing government of Madrid faced its first test over the weekend when the politician charged with running culture was forced to apologize for joking about the Holocaust on Twitter.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Ovation) SOUTHERN UNCOVERED WITH THE LEE BROS. Matt and Ted Lee, above from left, the James Beard Award-winning food and travel writers, explore the art, culture and cuisine of their native South, with stops in Atlanta, Dallas, New Orleans, Louisville and Ashville, N.C. They begin their tour in Charleston, S.C., their hometown, where they partake of a Lowcountry oyster roast, an undersea winery and dinner that comes with a side of dance lessons.

headline: At Gawker Media, New Economy Workers Strive to Form a New Kind of Union
abstract: Workers at the digital media outlet made headlines with their decision to form a union, but they say they are simply looking for a way to provide some stability in a turbulent industry.
lead_paragraph: The Facebook notification popped onto her screen in April: an invitation to the editorial staff at Gawker Media to “a union meeting about you.” Anna Merlan, a 28-year-old reporter with six months on the job, stared at her laptop, startled.

headline: 1940: Rout and Debacle of the French Army
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: German troops are advancing in France in 1940.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As the gray-uniformed battalions of Führer Adolf Hitler marched into Paris and raised the swastika banner over the capital in sign of conquest, the Nazi high command asserted that the whole northern front from the coast to the Maginot line east of Sedan had collapsed and that in all the sectors the enemy was in full retreat.

abstract: “The Rothschilds,” a musical by “Fiddler on the Roof” team Sheldon Harnick and Jerry Bock, is being adapted for Off-Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Before “Fiddler on the Roof” is revived for the fifth time on Broadway, another production by Sheldon Harnick and Jerry Bock will arrive in New York. “Rothschild & Sons,” a one-act rewrite of the 1970 musical “The Rothschilds,” will make its world debut Off Broadway as a production of the York Theater Company in October.

headline: At Margaret Howell, Wearing Black and White Is All About Restraint
abstract: The designer used the scheme in a subtle, relaxed way to show the perfect white shirt, a simple striped T-shirt and perfectly proportioned black trousers.
lead_paragraph: Much is said about the finale look of a show, but designers like Margaret Howell understand the importance of a first impression. In the opening looks she sent down the runway, it became apparent that black and white, an emerging trend this season, would be integral to the designer’s spring/summer 2016 men’s collection. But unlike her contemporaries, Howell used the scheme in a subtle, relaxed way — the perfect white shirt, a simple striped T-shirt, perfectly proportioned black trousers — that proved exercising restraint can, in fact, be bold.

abstract: The designer used the scheme in a subtle, relaxed way to show the perfect white shirt, a simple striped T-shirt and perfectly proportioned black trousers.

headline: America’s Seniors Find Middle-Class ‘Sweet Spot’
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Retirement', 'United States Economy', 'Series', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Income', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Those between 65 and 74, supported by Social Security, pensions and investments, have fared better than most other groups outside the superrich.
lead_paragraph: WAXAHACHIE, Tex. — Most Americans suffered serious losses during and after the recession, knocked off balance by layoffs, stagnant pay and the collapse of home values. But apart from the superrich, one group’s fortunes appear to have held remarkably steady: seniors.

headline: Throwback Tunes on the Spring/Summer 2016 Runways
abstract: From the after parties to today’s James Long runway, ’90s Britpop is having a moment.
lead_paragraph: Watch the video on YouTube.

headline: Regulars Mourn Closing of Ouest, Another New York Restaurant Lost to Escalating Rent
abstract: The closing of the restaurant on Broadway near 84th Street prompted a say-it-isn’t-so reaction from loyal customers.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Leitzes was disconsolate, so disconsolate that she was saying things she probably did not mean to be taken literally — things like, “I feel there’s no reason to stay in New York anymore.”

headline: At the London Collections Men, a Fresh New Face
abstract: The model Sol Goss walked on three of today’s biggest runways — and we have a feeling we’ll be seeing much more of him at the spring/summer 2016 shows.
lead_paragraph: We couldn’t help but notice the model Sol Goss when he walked in J.W. Anderson this morning. As the day unfolded, he resurfaced at Margaret Howell and Alexander McQueen, and we have a feeling things are beginning to take off for the fresh, new talent.

headline: With Little Fanfare, Mexican Supreme Court Legalizes Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Supreme Court of Mexico has said laws on the books in most of the country’s states are discriminatory, but gay couples still need costly injunctions from lower courts in order to wed.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — His church turned him away, his family discouraged him from a public fight and the government of the state where he lives vowed it would never happen.

headline: The Scene
abstract: Alexander McQueen at London Collections Men.
lead_paragraph: Alexander McQueen at London Collections Men.

headline: Charges Deferred After Gun Discharges at Waldorf Astoria
abstract: While the authorities investigate how a gun was fired at the hotel, charges against a Brooklyn man who was carrying the firearm are being deferred, an official said.
lead_paragraph: A man who the police said inadvertently discharged a gun at a wedding reception at the Waldorf Astoria hotel has been arrested, but prosecutors said on Sunday that charges would be deferred while the investigation continued.

headline: Photo Diary: Alexander McQueen Spring/Summer 2016
abstract: Scenes from London Collections Men, captured by Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from London Collections Men, captured by Kasia Bobula.

headline: ‘Jurassic World’ Tromps All Over the Box Office Competition
abstract: “Jurassic World” powered through squishy reviews to post $204.6 million in estimated weekend sales at the domestic box office, and about $512 million worldwide.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Critics be darned.

headline: Hillary Clinton Urges Obama to Listen to Democrats on Trade Deal
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday said President Obama should work with congressional Democrats and make changes to the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal that reflect their concerns about protecting American jobs and wages.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday urged President Obama to listen to congressional Democrats – particular the House minority leader, Nancy Pelosi – and make changes to the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal that reflect their concerns about protecting American jobs and wages.

headline: Israel’s Foreign Ministry Issues Report Defending Conduct in Gaza War
abstract: Ahead of a United Nations report, the ministry argues that Israel’s troops adhered to international law and blames Palestinian militants for the bulk of the civilian casualties in last summer’s war.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In a pre-emptive strike against a forthcoming United Nations report on the war last year between Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip, Israel’s Foreign Ministry on Sunday issued a lengthy paper arguing that its troops adhered to international law and blaming the militants for most of the civilian casualties in Gaza.

headline: What the Same-Sex Marriage Decision Means for Couples’ Rights and Benefits
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Wills and Estates', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: With the Supreme Court’s ruling, gay spouses will benefit in terms of taxes, estate planning, federal benefits and medical decision making.
lead_paragraph: Updated: June 26

headline: Same-Sex Parents’ Rights May Be Unresolved After Justices’ Ruling
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ADOPTIONS', 'States (US)']
abstract: A Supreme Court endorsement of gay marriage would still leave many parents fighting to share custody of their same-sex partner’s children.
lead_paragraph: When Jessica and Melissa Tincher take the four-hour road trip from their home in Lexington, Ohio, to visit relatives in Indiana, it is a two-vehicle affair: They need car seats for each of their four children — a 4-year-old, a 3-year-old and 2-year-old twins — along with Pack ’n Plays, high chairs, diapers and enough toys to keep everyone entertained. And then there are the two dogs, who together weigh 165 pounds.

headline: Review: Milan Kundera’s ‘The Festival of Insignificance’ Is Full of Pranks, Lies and Vanity
abstract: This novella about a group of friends in Paris reflects a fascination with tongue-in-cheek amusements, a departure from the Central European outlook evinced by the author’s early books.
lead_paragraph: In his groundbreaking novels “The Book of Laughter and Forgetting” (1980) and “The Unbearable Lightness of Being” (1984), the Czech-born Milan Kundera wrote about his country under the shadow of the Soviet Union, reinventing the form of the novel while examining the osmosis between the personal and the political there, and the subversive roles that humor and irreverence can play in a totalitarian state.

headline: Gieves & Hawkes: Spring 2016 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Review: Ayelen Parolin’s ‘25.06.76’ Evolves as She Does
abstract: The Argentine-born choreographer has performed the biographical dance solo more than 20 times over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: A person changes over time, so why should her autobiographical dance solo stay the same? The Argentine-born choreographer Ayelen Parolin, who lives and works in Brussels, first presented “25.06.76” in 2004. Named for her date of birth and performed more than 20 times over the past decade, the slapdash solo evolves as she does. On Friday, she showed its current iteration at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Review: San Francisco Opera’s ‘Two Women’ Depicts War’s Horror at High Pitch
abstract: Marco Tutino’s new opera (with a libretto by Mr. Tutino and Fabio Ceresa) adapts a 1958 novel by Alberto Moravia.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Near the end of Marco Tutino’s relentlessly impassioned new opera, “Two Women,” a character cries out “Basta, basta!”

headline: Dillon Gee Struggles, but Mets Outslug Braves
abstract: The Mets recovered from an early five-run deficit, thumping four home runs to overcome a dismal performance from Gee, whose 72 pitches resulted in eight runs and 11 hits.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, the Mets were no-hit for the first time since 1993; saw their ace, Matt Harvey, again get battered in a loss; and then blew a ninth-inning lead to the Atlanta Braves on Saturday before falling in 11 innings.

headline: ‘Something Rotten!’ Ad Celebrates Tony’s Best-Musical Defeat
abstract: A new ad from the creators of “Something Rotten!” draws attention to the company the musical joined when it lost the Tony race for best musical.
lead_paragraph: Oh cruel fate.

headline: Women’s World Cup: First Opponents to Face the Fury of U.S. Players? Older Siblings
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Families and Family Life', 'Athletics and Sports', "Women's World Cup (Soccer)"]
abstract: Top athletes tend to have older siblings, research shows, and that is true of 17 of the 23 players on the United States roster, many of whom showed a competitive drive from an early age.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Morgan Brian did not win many one-on-one soccer games played in the front yard against her sister, Jennifer, who is five years older.

headline: Judd Apatow’s New Book Is a Love Letter to Stand-Up Comedy
abstract: The director’s lively collection of interviews with comedians is an entertaining portrait of how stand-up has changed from its first boom in the 1980s to its current one.
lead_paragraph: Judd Apatow hadn’t performed stand-up comedy for more than 20 years when he approached the Comedy Cellar stage in New York in April of last year. “I was terrified,” he said.

headline: Review: ‘The Old Masters,’ Art Found, Artist Lost and Another Adrift
abstract: Sam Marks’s play, at the Flea Theater, tackles art-world pretensions and a frustrated painter and father-to-be’s existential crisis.
lead_paragraph: We do love a good, tragic back story to go with our artists. They’re so much easier to market that way.

headline: Saxophonist David Murray Part of Vision Festival Lineup
abstract: This year’s Vision Festival includes performances by Roscoe Mitchell and Wadada Leo Smith.
lead_paragraph: The Vision Festival, an annual New York festival built around the continuum of experimental jazz and free improvisation, is celebrating its 20th birthday, and has announced its schedule for this year’s edition, from July 5-12. This festival began in 1996; has been staged in various churches, theaters and community centers; and incorporates music, dance, visual art, poetry, and film. It runs without corporate financing under the auspices of the nonprofit, artist-run organization Arts for Art.

headline: Reviews: Chelsea Music Festival, Gregg Kallor and St. Petersburg Philharmonic
abstract: Performances in recent days have offered old staples and newer works.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA

headline: U.S. Airstrike in Libya Targets Planner of 2013 Algeria Attack
abstract: Libyan officials said the strike killed Mokhtar Belmokhtar, a former Al Qaeda leader and the mastermind of a 2013 terrorist seizure of an Algerian gas plant that left 38 foreign hostages dead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States carried out an airstrike in Libya early Sunday against the mastermind of the 2013 terrorist seizure of an Algerian gas plant that left 38 foreign hostages dead, American and Libyan officials said on Sunday.

headline: The Third Surprise
abstract: Did Clinton Rules get repealed?
lead_paragraph: This has been a weekend for political surprises. First, of course, was the shocking rejection of TPP by House Democrats. Second was Hillary Clinton’s unexpectedly liberal/populist campaign-launching speech on Roosevelt Island.

headline: The Third Surprise
abstract: Did Clinton Rules get repealed?
lead_paragraph: This has been a weekend for political surprises. First, of course, was the shocking rejection of TPP by House Democrats. Second was Hillary Clinton’s unexpectedly liberal/populist campaign-launching speech on Roosevelt Island.

headline: Sometimes Sold With Magnifying Glasses
abstract: Mike Buckley celebrates an anniversary.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Readers have asked me how, after four years of writing daily about crosswords, I still have something to say about them. These readers have obviously never met me in person, because I am really not one to lack an opinion about anything. Just ask Will Shortz.

headline: With Victory Over Orioles, Yankees Keep Slim Lead in East
abstract: A series of walks in the fifth inning gave the Yankees all the margin they needed in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The Yankees’ 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday was a much-needed one. It kept the Yankees in first place in the American League East — barely — and ended a three-game losing streak, with the help of a rally that required precious little exertion, even in sapping heat and humidity.

headline: Women Languish in Texas Immigration Detention Centers
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Women and Girls', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: Lawmakers, advocates and religious leaders say confinement only compounds the suffering of women fleeing from predatory gangs or domestic abuse at home.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers, advocates and religious leaders say confinement only compounds the suffering of women fleeing from predatory gangs or domestic abuse at home.

headline: Hope and Despair as Families Languish in Texas Immigration Centers
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Federal officials say a large immigration center in Texas is crucial to averting another mass influx, but the women there find the detention taking a severe toll.
lead_paragraph: DILLEY, Tex. — Workers are putting the finishing touches on rows of barracks in a 50-acre camp here, the largest immigration detention center in the country. It houses thousands of women and their children who were caught crossing the border illegally and are seeking asylum in the United States.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Season 3, Episode 5 Recap: Flaca Takes a Test
abstract: All of Litchfield is aflutter when it’s revealed that there’s a new job opening that pays a dollar per hour
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 5: “Fake It Till You Fake It Some More”

headline: Stop Revering Magna Carta
keywords: ['Magna Carta (1215)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Constitutions', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The document’s fame rests on huge myths. But those myths have become their own reality.
lead_paragraph: MAGNA CARTA, on which King John placed his seal 800 years ago today, is synonymous in the English-speaking world with fundamental rights and the rule of law. It’s been celebrated, and appropriated, by everyone from Tea Party members to Jay Z, who called his latest album “Magna Carta Holy Grail.”

headline: If a Car Rusts in the Forest ...
abstract: The Old Car City USA junkyard in White, Ga., no longer deals in spare parts. Its old vehicles have been abandoned in the woods and have become a tourist destination.
lead_paragraph: The Old Car City USA junkyard in White, Ga., no longer deals in spare parts. Its old vehicles have been abandoned in the woods and have become a tourist destination.

headline: Nature Helps Squeeze Out a Little More Mileage
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Photography', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Automobiles', 'Museums', 'Art']
abstract: Old Car City in Georgia has turned junk cars into rusty works of art, becoming a mecca for photographers. Other salvage companies have adapted to the computer age.
lead_paragraph: WHITE, Ga. — Not too long ago, Old Car City USA and its thousands of deceased autos was a junkyard like so many others that dotted — or blighted, depending on one’s point of view — the American landscape. Nestled in the ridges and valleys here about an hour north of Atlanta, the salvage yard was a veritable heaven for do-it-yourselfers looking to save money by opting for used over new.

headline: Fears of Greek Default Rise as Weekend Talks on Debt Payment Break Down
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The lack of progress increases the possibility that Greece will be forced to default on its mountain of debt, with 1.6 billion euros owed to the International Monetary Fund on June 30.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Just weeks before a crucial debt payment comes due, weekend talks between Greece and its European creditors broke down as both sides refused to soften their long-held bargaining positions.

headline: A Federal Reserve Meeting, the Joust for Jet Orders and Fitbit’s Stock Market Debut
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Paris Air Show', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Highlights of this week will include the Paris air show, a Federal Reserve meeting, an initial public offering by Fitbit and an economic conference in St. Petersburg, Russia.
lead_paragraph: The titans of the global aerospace industry will gather on Monday at Le Bourget Airport for the biennial International Paris Air Show. The traditional joust for jet orders between Airbus and Boeing, the world’s biggest commercial plane makers, will dominate the weeklong event as millions of dollars’ worth of hardware soars above the chalets and convention halls.

headline: Nek Chand, Creator of a Sculpture Kingdom in India, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Chand’s life work was the Rock Garden of Chandigarh, which comprises fountains and sculptures, many of them made from found objects.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nek Chand, an Indian artist who rose to prominence by quietly building a sprawling kingdom of folk sculptures in northern India that became one of the country’s most popular tourist destinations, died on Friday in Chandigarh. He was 90.

headline: As Magna Carta Turns 800, How Firm Is Your Grasp on Medieval Law?
abstract: The seminal document was written on June 15, 1215. Since then, its principles have been enshrined in laws and constitutions around the world. How did it come about 800 years ago, and what is its modern legacy? Test your medieval legal knowledge.
lead_paragraph: The seminal document was written on June 15, 1215. Since then, its principles have been enshrined in laws and constitutions around the world. How did it come about 800 years ago, and what is its modern legacy? Test your medieval legal knowledge.

headline: Magna Carta, Still Posing a Challenge at 800
abstract: Presented by 40 indignant English barons to their treacherous king in 1215, it has endured as perhaps the world’s first and best declaration of the rule of law. But some say that theory is a misreading of history.
lead_paragraph: It is relatively unsplashy, as these things go — not very long, not very elegantly written, just 3,500 or so words of Medieval Latin crammed illegibly onto a single page of parchment.

headline: Watching City Traffic on Camera
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The view from the network of cameras focused on city streets is a genuine reality show, with no acting.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Goose Exterminator of the Netherlands Enrages Animal Rights Activists
abstract: Arie Den Hertog has killed thousands of wild geese with carbon dioxide, drawing praise from farmers and Nazi comparisons from animal rights activists.
lead_paragraph: WIJK BIJ DUURSTEDE, Netherlands — The hiss of gas, released by a red lever turned by Arie den Hertog in the back of his white van, signaled the start of the massacre. The victims, crammed into a sealed, coffin-like wooden case, squawked as they struggled to breathe. Then, after barely two minutes, they fell silent.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 15
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Virtual Reality Headsets, Gaining Scrutiny at E3 This Week, Raise Very Real Concerns
keywords: ['Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3)', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: Users of the new generation of these devices will have to navigate the physical and emotional challenges of their real-life and simulated surroundings, often at the same time.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, a dozen or so people strap on virtual reality headsets, log on to the Internet and do something that would normally require driving to a local multiplex: watch a movie with a bunch of strangers.

headline: Houthi Rebels in Yemen Seize a Capital
abstract: Houthi rebel fighters seized Hazm, capital of Jawf Province, tightening their control of the country despite a monthslong, Saudi-led bombing campaign.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Houthi rebel fighters seized the capital of a northwestern Yemeni province bordering Saudi Arabia early Sunday, tightening their control of the country despite a monthslong, Saudi-led bombing campaign intended to force a retreat.

headline: Slicing Away a Body’s Tortured Past
abstract: Paul Mason, once informally known as the world’s fattest man, had already shed most of his 980 pounds, but his most difficult operation was to remove the giant folds of excess skin that had remained.
lead_paragraph: Paul Mason, once informally known as the world’s fattest man, had already shed most of his 980 pounds, but his most difficult operation was to remove the giant folds of excess skin that had remained.

headline: Down From 980 Pounds, With New Battles to Wage
abstract: For Paul Mason, who dropped 700 pounds, the last 50 made the biggest difference, when a team of surgeons in Manhattan removed his excess skin.
lead_paragraph: For a man who once weighed 980 pounds and had already lost 650 of them, the loss of 50 more — the amount that vanished after Paul Mason’s nine-and-a-half-hour operation last month — might not seem like a big deal.

headline: With Game-Winning Goals, Antoine Vermette Is Giving the Blackhawks a Lift
abstract: Vermette, whom Arizona traded to Chicago in February, has put himself in consideration for the Conn Smythe Trophy with his surprising postseason heroics.
lead_paragraph: Antoine Vermette watched Game 3 of the N.H.L.’s Western Conference finals on a television in the Blackhawks’ locker room while he exercised, riding a stationary bike and lifting weights. It was the third time this postseason he had been designated as a healthy scratch, a personal low point, and he wanted to use the time productively.

headline: California’s Water Czar, Part Empathetic Confessor and Part Friendly Scold
keywords: ['Water', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Drought', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Felicia Marcus, chairwoman of California’s Water Resources Control Board, has become the face of the state’s crackdown on water abusers.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Felicia Marcus peered over her desk the other day as the State Water Resources Control Board came to order in a hearing room here, bracing for another day of bad drought news. There would be warnings about die-offs of birds and fish. An anguished farmer describing how he is being forced to fallow fields of crops. An economic report projecting $2.7 billion in drought-related losses in 2015.

headline: Losing Custody of Son Appeared to Set Off Troubled Dallas Gunman, Family Says
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Losing a custody battle with his mother over his 11-year-old son seems to have incited the rage that led to James L. Boulware’s shootout with the police on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — In April, a judge here rendered a decision that seemed to finally upend James L. Boulware’s troubled life. Ending a fight that had played out for years in court, Mr. Boulware lost a custody battle with his mother over his 11-year-old son. At issue was his history of violence against his mother, who told the judge in court documents that he had mental problems, and whose allegation that he had tried to choke her led the police to arrest him in 2013.

headline: Under Armour Is Swinging for the Stars
keywords: ['Golf', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'United States Open (Golf)']
abstract: As the sportswear maker finds itself in business with two of the hottest athletes in the country, it is still figuring out how best to capitalize on those relationships.
lead_paragraph: Before he watched the final round of the Masters tournament at Augusta National Golf Club in April, Ryan Kuehl, an executive for the sportswear company Under Armour, left his cellphone in a rented sport utility vehicle. Hours later — after the 21-year-old Jordan Spieth had won in record fashion — Mr. Kuehl checked his phone.

headline: Rent Regulations on New York City Apartments Expire on Monday
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: State legislators had not reached an agreement on the law, which currently covers nearly one million city dwellings.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Rent regulations that limit how much landlords can charge for many apartments in New York City and a number of surrounding communities were set to expire on Monday and lawmakers here did not appear close to a deal to extend or modify them.

headline: Blackhawks Fans Show That Chicago Can Love a Winner, Too
abstract: If the Blackhawks win on Monday, it will be their third Stanley Cup since 2010 — a stunning prospect for a city that adores its sports teams, but rarely ponders championships.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The national anthem had barely begun, but the red mass of pounding, stomping, cheering people inside the United Center was in full frenzy. If there is a Midwestern version of Los Angeles’s star-speckled courtside scene, it was in this crowd: John Cusack, the actor; Danica Patrick, the auto racer; Billy Corgan, the musician.

headline: Philae Spacecraft Reawakens on a Speeding Comet With Data for Scientists
abstract: In November, the European Space Agency landed a probe on a speeding comet, but it lost battery power after 60 hours. The spacecraft began transmitting data packets to earth on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: After a seven-month slumber, a European spacecraft that landed on a speeding comet last fall has awakened from hibernation and phoned home, the European Space Agency said on Sunday.

headline: Once a First-Round Pick as a Shortstop, Sergio Santos Is Now a Reliever for the Yankees
abstract: Sergio Santos, picked up after he was designated for assignment by the Dodgers, was drafted by the Diamondbacks in 2002, when he envisioned himself as an Alex Rodriguez type.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When Sergio Santos, the latest reliever to audition for the Yankees, made his way to the mound Saturday night, not everybody knew him solely as a hard-throwing right-handed pitcher with a wipeout slider.

headline: Engaging Movie Fans, From Teaser to Premiere
abstract: A California start-up helps studios cultivate potential audiences’ enthusiasm with early sales of tickets and movie-related products.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Next month, 130,000 sweaty fans will swarm the San Diego Convention Center for the annual pop culture scavenger hunt known as Comic-Con International.

headline: A Plan to Fortify the U.S. Women, From a Pioneer
abstract: April Heinrichs, the technical director for the United States women’s national team, says talented young players should compete with older girls and boys.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — As a young girl in Colorado, April Heinrichs stuffed copies of Reader’s Digest into her socks as shin guards and slept in her cleats.

headline: Playground Legend Revisits the Streets, His Fall and His Rise
abstract: Carlton Greene, who was a promising basketball player before he became homeless for a time, is the subject of “Still Got Game,” written as a playbook for life.
lead_paragraph: Carlton Greene made his way up two steep flights of stairs, slowly, with great effort. Forty-five years ago, he took these steps two at a time, sometimes three. But that was then. Now he is 60, and his knees, hips and thighs have seen better days.

headline: The Trans-Pacific Partnership and a President’s Legacy
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The 12-nation deal President Obama has been negotiating in Asia could be imperiled, not by uncertainty abroad, but by challenges at home trying to convince Democrats of the deal’s importance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than six years, the short walk from the Oval Office downstairs to the Situation Room has all too often meant bad news or grim choices. Whether it was war in the Middle East, Russian aggression in Ukraine or the hunt for terrorists around the globe, President Obama’s foreign policy has felt consumed by guns and drones.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Remains a Superstar Hard to Forget, and to Embrace
abstract: Rodriguez, whose statistics are increasingly rarefied, is having a productive season, but his use of performance-enhancing drugs may deprive him of some adulation.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Rick Dempsey’s name stretches for three stories — vertically, in neon — on the warehouse beyond right field at Camden Yards. Dempsey, who has a restaurant here, batted .233 in the majors but was the most valuable player in the World Series the last time the Baltimore Orioles won it. Fans beg for his autograph every day, and he happily obliges.

headline: These Golden State Warriors Won Before. In April.
abstract: James Michael McAdoo and Ognjen Kuzmic could become the first players to win Development League and N.B.A. titles in the same season.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — James Michael McAdoo and Ognjen Kuzmic of the Golden State Warriors have not had starring roles in the N.B.A. finals. Through five games, including a 104-91 Golden State victory on Sunday at Oracle Arena, McAdoo has played a total of one minute in the series. Kuzmic, a 7-foot center, has yet to appear in uniform.

headline: Review: In ‘This Is Mary Brown,’ Mom Has Troubles but Is Quite a Character
abstract: Winsome Brown’s one-woman show remembers the performer’s cigarette-smoking, alcoholic and Dublin-born mother in a flesh-and-blood portrait.
lead_paragraph: The title character of “This Is Mary Brown” didn’t lead an exciting life, but she inspired a lovely little play. This one-woman show, written and performed by her daughter, Winsome Brown, never sugarcoats a somewhat sad story, and that honesty makes it all the more admirable.

headline: Review: In ‘The Qualms,’ a Sex Party Winds Up Being All Talk
abstract: This comedy, the latest play from the Pulitzer Prize-winning provocateur Bruce Norris, is directed by Pam MacKinnon at Playwrights Horizons.
lead_paragraph: A bouquet of colored condoms is tossed in the air, like naughty confetti, in “The Qualms,” the latest play from the Pulitzer Prize-winning provocateur Bruce Norris. But while sex is theoretically on the menu in Mr. Norris’s comedy, about a quartet of erotically adventurous couples, the main course (which is to say intercourse) never quite arrives. Those condoms, I’m afraid, are made airborne more out of frustration than excitement.

headline: Fainting at the Finish
abstract: Sam Peterman, a sophomore at Sweet Home High School near Buffalo, has a condition that causes her to collapse at the finish line of nearly every race.
lead_paragraph: Sam Peterman, a sophomore at Sweet Home High School near Buffalo, has a condition that causes her to collapse at the finish line of nearly every race.

headline: Race After Race, Teenager Crosses Finish Line, Then Collapses

lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Stephen Curry did what he does, prying for open space beyond the 3-point arc, shimmying with the dribble, bouncing the ball behind his back, stepping back and letting go with a shot as quick as a blink and as high as the 15th row.

headline: Beyond Caitlyn Jenner Lies a Long Struggle by Transgender People
abstract: As a broader understanding of gender identity emerges, a history of hatred, violence and discrimination continues.
lead_paragraph: By now, most Americans are probably familiar with the rights movement known by the initials L.G.B.T., but they may have a better sense of the L.G.B. part — lesbian, gay, bisexual. The T, for transgender, has eluded many people. That, however, may be quickly changing with a string of developments in recent years, not the least being the emergence this month of Caitlyn Jenner, a transgender woman who was a public figure for four decades as Bruce Jenner, Olympic decathlon champion and reality-show personality.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (AMC) THE MAKING OF THE MOB: NEW YORK Ray Liotta narrates this eight-part series, which uses re-enactments, archival footage, visual effects and interviews to chronicle the rise of the Mafiosi Lucky Luciano, Meyer Lansky, Bugsy Siegel, Frank Costello and Vito Genovese. Among those weighing in are former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York; Meyer Lansky II, Lansky’s grandson; the actors Chazz Palminteri and Joe Mantegna; the singer Frankie Valli; former Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas; and the historian David Pietrusza. A 25th-anniversary presentation of Martin Scorsese’s “Goodfellas” (1990), which stars Mr. Liotta as Henry Hill, the gangster turned mob informant whose testimony resulted in 50 convictions, leads in at 7. This programming block is the first in AMC’s Mob Mondays, which will partner each episode of the series with a classic mobster film.

headline: Burk Uzzle’s American Puzzle
abstract: In between assignments, Burk Uzzle took to side streets and back roads to find serendipitous visual moments.
lead_paragraph: If you ask Burk Uzzle what he has been up to lately, he’ll most likely tell you he has just been “poking around.” That means hitting the road with a couple of Leicas, a small shoulder bag and a few rolls of film. He’s done this for some 50 years, taking the time between assignments to drive somewhere along side streets and back roads, to get out and follow his whimsical vision.

abstract: Christie should show leadership by fixing crumbling infrastructure with a gas tax for New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Drivers in New Jersey enjoy boasting about cheap gas in their state, where prices at the pump rank among the lowest in the country — so low, in fact, that thrifty motorists passing through often pull off the New Jersey Turnpike to fill up. The reason for the low prices is New Jersey’s relatively modest gas tax.

lead_paragraph: It hardly needs saying that immigration policy should not undermine Americans’ jobs, wages or working conditions. The problem is that what some companies want — cheap, exploitable, disposable labor — is exactly what the system can be twisted into giving them.

headline: Hudson’s Bay to Buy Galeria Kaufhof Stores in $3.2 Billion Deal
abstract: The Canadian operator of Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor plans to acquire more than 100 stores in Germany and Belgium as it expands its international operations.
lead_paragraph: Richard A. Baker has been a master at skillfully using real estate to revive retail brands. He did just that with the Hudson’s Bay Company, a department store whose long history traces back to the New World era of fur trading. It was that panache that allowed him to snag the venerable brands of Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor when they were up for grabs.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Surprising Struggle With Moderates
abstract: He was expected to be weak among evangelicals and Tea Party voters. But his early weakness has been broader than that.
lead_paragraph: It was easy to see Jeb Bush’s path to the Republican nomination when he announced the formation of his super PAC in December. He wasn’t guaranteed to pull it off — not by any stretch — but he seemed well positioned to appeal to the coalition of party elites and blue-state voters that has allowed center-right establishment candidates to win the party’s last two contests.

headline: EasyJet Chief Leads Airline Through Turnaround

headline: Jeb Bush Announces White House Bid, Saying ‘America Deserves Better’
abstract: Mr. Bush declared he was running for president, and called upon his own record of ambitious, conservative-minded change as Florida’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Jeb Bush, a son and brother of presidents, formally declared a White House candidacy of his own on Monday, portraying himself as the most accomplished leader in the 2016 field, vowing to wage war on Washington’s political culture and insisting that his family name gave him no unique claim to the Oval Office.

headline: Justices’ Words Are Combed for Clues as Major Decisions Loom at Court
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Constitution (US)', 'Speeches and Statements']
