lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years ago this week, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg chided the news media for “publishing a steady stream of rumors and fifth-hand accounts” predicting how the court would rule on a constitutional challenge to President Obama’s health care law.

headline: An Architect Works With a Source of Inspiration: His Father
abstract: Jonathan Marvel is practicing architecture in New York City with his father, Thomas, who in Puerto Rico was one of the most prolific designers of his generation.
lead_paragraph: When he was growing up in San Juan, P.R., Jonathan Marvel would often visit his father’s architecture studio, awe-struck by the work around him. Schools, churches, hotels, apartment buildings, plazas and boulevards — seemingly all the things of daily life had come from the pen of his father, Thomas Marvel, one of the most prolific designers of his generation on the island.

headline: Quebec? Italy? No Shortage of Theories on Escaped Convicts’ Whereabouts
abstract: Residents near the maximum-security prison in Dannemora, N.Y., imagine all kinds of places where the killers might be hiding.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — There is no evidence that the two murderers who escaped a maximum-security prison here earlier this month are in Mexico, chuckling at investigators. There is no evidence that they are in Italy, Pennsylvania or a hunting camp in northern Quebec. And there is absolutely no evidence that the whole thing — the escape, the hunt, the days of combing the woods — was faked.

headline: 5 Things You May Not Know About Jeb Bush
abstract: The former governor of Florida met his wife while spending a trimester in Mexico, played tennis in college and was a journalist at age 10.
lead_paragraph: He is the son and the younger brother of presidents and was a two-term governor of Florida, now the nation’s third most populous state. But there is much voters can still learn about Jeb Bush, who announced his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination on Monday. Here are some things you may not know about him.

headline: Argentine Women Call Out Machismo
abstract: One woman snapped. A hashtag was born. And now the nation is debating its culture of sexual violence.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — It started with a single tweet. “They’re killing us.” A cry of deep despair from a female journalist that needed no explanation for women in Argentina: Within weeks, hundreds of thousands marched in cities across the nation with a single purpose — to demand an end to the killing.

headline: 2 Bishops Resign in Minnesota Over Sexual Abuse Scandal
abstract: The resignations come after prosecutors charged the archdiocese with having failed to protect youths from pedophile priests.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Two bishops in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis resigned their posts Monday, the second time this spring that American church leaders have stepped aside after complaints over their handling of sexual abuse claims involving priests.

headline: Egypt’s Vanishing Youth
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Youth']
abstract: The West sees President Sisi as a man it can do business with, never mind the repressions.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Esraa el-Taweel, 23, went out to dinner with friends on June 1 and has not been seen since. Ms. Taweel, a student and photojournalist who was shot in the spine last year while covering protests on the anniversary of Egypt’s 2011 revolution, is said to have difficulty walking. Her family believes she was forcibly “disappeared” along with two young friends, Sohaib Mohamed and Amr Mohamed.

headline: Do Corporations Have Minds?
abstract: Not really. But we often think and talk about them as though they do, and that is cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2007, Viacom filed a copyright infringement lawsuit. It alleged that the defendants had created a website that was hosting copyrighted Viacom videos, including everything from the “The Colbert Report” to “SpongeBob SquarePants.” But that was not all. Viacom made a series of allegations about the defendants’ mental states. It alleged that they specifically “intended” to host these illegal videos, that they were doing so “knowingly” and with “brazen disregard” for the law.

headline: To Lose Weight, Eating Less Is Far More Important Than Exercising More
abstract: Exercise is good for you, for many reasons, but studies show consuming less food is the key to weight loss.
lead_paragraph: One of my family’s favorite shows is “The Biggest Loser.” Although some viewers don’t appreciate how it pushes people so hard to lose weight, the show probably inspires some overweight people to regain control of their lives.

headline: ‘Concert by the Sea,’ a Jazz Classic by Erroll Garner, Is to Be Reissued
abstract: Few jazz albums have reached as wide an audience as the pianist Erroll Garner’s “Concert by the Sea,” one of the best-selling jazz albums ever.
lead_paragraph: Few jazz albums have reached as wide an audience as the pianist Erroll Garner’s “Concert by the Sea.” Recorded in Carmel-by-the-Sea, Calif., in 1955, it was released on Columbia and quickly achieved a rare sort of success — becoming not only a standout moment in Mr. Garner’s career but also an essential touchstone for pianists, and one of the best-selling jazz albums ever.

headline: Today in Politics: Jeb Bush Is Set to Make Official What Was Widely Known
abstract: After this week, nearly every presidential hopeful will be formally accounted for on the campaign trail, as Hillary Rodham Clinton held her official kickoff rally on Saturday and Jeb Bush tells us he is, indeed, running for president.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from Washington, where, yet again, there is work to be done and drama to watch over the trade bill. But after this week, nearly every hopeful will be formally accounted for on the campaign trail, as Hillary Rodham Clinton held her official kickoff rally on Saturday and Jeb Bush tells us he is, indeed, running for president.

headline: Britons, Some Raising a Pint, Celebrate Magna Carta’s 800th Anniversary
abstract: Commemorations of the document that inspired protections for civil liberties include a ceremony with the queen, seminars, a musical and plans for a national beer day.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The 800th anniversary on Monday of Magna Carta, a medieval political truce that inspired protections for some of the world’s most cherished liberties, prompted a range of celebrations in Britain that included a ceremony involving Queen Elizabeth II and a national beer day.

headline: E. Tautz: Spring 2016 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Europe Is Urged to Prepare for Greek Default as Stances Harden on Debt Deal
abstract: Athens and its creditors are hardening their positions in their debt talks as time runs short for Greece to make changes to unlock aid payments.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A chorus of voices on Monday called on European Union authorities to plan for Greece to default on its huge pile of debt after bailout talks between Athens and its creditors deteriorated over the weekend.

headline: Morning Agenda: Greek Debt Talks Break Down Again
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Greek Debt Talks Break Down Again | Conflicts of Interest in Private Equity Fee Practices | Challenges of Maintaining a Business Dynasty | Saks Fifth Avenue’s Owner to Buy German Chain
lead_paragraph: GREEK DEBT TALKS BREAK DOWN AGAIN | Another attempt at a bailout agreement for Greece fell apart on Sunday night after Greek officials angrily contended that their European counterparts in the weekend talks did not have the authority to negotiate any kind of deal,  James Kanter and Landon Thomas Jr. write in The New York Times. The Greek officials who traveled to Brussels for the talks were Nikos Pappas, a close confidant of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, and Yannis Dragasakis, the deputy prime minister. They met with senior-level European officials, none of whom had the same rank in their respective government posts. “They wanted us to hit our targets by slashing pensions and increasing taxes,” said one senior member of the Greek negotiating team, Mr. Kanter and Mr. Thomas write. “But they had no mandate to negotiate.”

headline: Shouting Grexit in a Crowded Theater
abstract: Keeping it cool for the moment.
lead_paragraph: Some readers have noted that I haven’t said much about the Greek crisis in the past few days. Indeed. It’s crunch time, and right now everyone involved needs to engage in quiet, cool deliberation. There’s really nothing more outsiders can say, at least in public, that we haven’t already said. So it seems to me that for now I should hold back a bit.

headline: Q. and A.: Holden Chow on China, Elections and Hong Kong’s Attitude
abstract: Mr. Chow, of the pro-Beijing Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong, said it would be a mistake to vote against a proposal to allow all those eligible to cast a ballot in the 2017 election for the city’s top leader.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s legislature is set to vote this week on a proposal to allow all eligible voters in the former British colony the chance to vote in the 2017 election for the city’s top leader, the chief executive. Supporters and opponents say the measure, which will require the support of two-thirds of the 70 delegates, is likely to be voted down.

headline: United Technologies Plans to Sell or Spin Off Sikorsky Unit
abstract: A decision on the fate of the 90-year-old company, which makes Black Hawk helicopters, is expected by the end of the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The United Technologies Corporation said on Monday that it planned to either sell or spin off Sikorsky Aircraft, the maker of the Black Hawk helicopters favored by the United States military.

headline: Omar al-Bashir, Leaving South Africa, Eludes Arrest Again
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The International Criminal Court said that the government was legally required to arrest Omar al-Bashir of Sudan, who faces charges of war crimes.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Shielded by the authorities, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan flew out of South Africa on Monday morning aboard his presidential jet, just hours before a South African court ruled that the government was legally required to arrest him.

headline: Absence of Jebmentum
abstract: Why him, anyway?
lead_paragraph: Nate Cohn notes Jeb Bush’s failure to nail down the GOP nomination, or even to establish himself as the candidate of the Republican “moderates” (I think we always need scare quotes in this context). Jeb is nowhere close to even having the kind of position Mitt Romney had at this stage.

headline: Why It Matters That Hillary Clinton Wore Ralph Lauren
abstract: She’s clearly considering fashion, as are her advisers, and using it to manipulate perception.
lead_paragraph: At her campaign opening rally on Roosevelt Island on Saturday (to be distinguished from her campaign announcement, in April), Hillary Rodham Clinton donned her now-signature look: a bright blue pantsuit with a matching bright blue shirt underneath. She stuck out a mile, matched her H campaign logo — which was also the design of her stage — and looked appropriately patriotic, especially when standing next to Bill Clinton in his red polo.

headline: China Ends Recovery Efforts on Ship That Capsized on Yangtze
abstract: Officials said that the vessel had 454 people on board at the time of the accident on June 1, not 456 or 458, and that there were 12, not 14, survivors.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has concluded rescue and recovery efforts surrounding a cruise ship that capsized this month on the Yangtze River and has revised its count of the number of people who were on board and the number of survivors, according to official news media.

headline: Vatican Sets Trial for Ex-Ambassador Accused of Sexual Abuse
abstract: The Vatican said that in July it would open a trial of its former envoy, Jozef Wesolowski, to the Dominican Republic on charges of sexually abusing boys and of possessing child pornography.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican announced on Monday that in July it will open a trial of its former ambassador to the Dominican Republic on charges of sexually abusing boys while serving in the Caribbean and of possessing child pornography.

headline: Homebuilders Standard Pacific, Ryland to Merge
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The deal would combine two of the nation’s largest builders of homes, creating a company with a combined market value of about $5.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: Two big California homebuilders, the Standard Pacific Corporation and the Ryland Group, have agreed to combine in a so-called merger of equals.

headline: CVS to Buy 1,600 Drugstores From Target for $1.9 Billion
abstract: Under the deal, CVS would acquire more than 1,600 pharmacies from Target in 47 states and operate them under its brand name within Target stores.
lead_paragraph: The voracious CVS Health is already a dominant player in nearly every corner of the health care world — it is the nation’s largest dispenser of prescription drugs, the biggest operator of health care clinics and the second-largest pharmacy-benefits manager.

headline: Owner of Kelley Blue Book and Autotrader to Buy Dealertrack for $4 Billion
abstract: The deal is expected to allow the technology providers to offer a broad range of software solutions for the automotive industry.
lead_paragraph: Cox Automotive, a provider of digital marketing and e-commerce services for the automotive industry, said on Monday that it would buy Dealertrack Technologies for $4 billion in cash.

headline: Beware of Greek Exit, E.U. Official Says
abstract: Martin Schulz, the president of the European Parliament, said a withdrawal from the eurozone would have drastic consequences for Greece as well as for the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Martin Schulz, the president of the European Parliament, said a withdrawal from the eurozone would have drastic consequences for Greece as well as for the European Union.

headline: What Jeb Bush Would Need to Do to Win
abstract: Mr. Bush has announced he is entering the race for the Republican presidential nomination. Here is a look at what he will need to do to win.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Bush has announced he is entering the race for the Republican presidential nomination. Here is a look at what he will need to do to win.

headline: Daily Report: Virtual Reality Tries to Establish Its Own Mores
abstract: Users of the new generation of these devices will have to navigate the physical and emotional challenges of their real-life and simulated surroundings, often at the same time.
lead_paragraph: The ability of virtual reality to transport people to locales both exotic and ordinary, is well known. Yet how the medium will fit into people’s online and offline lives is a new frontier, writes Nick Wingfield.

headline: Is LeBron James the N.B.A. Finals M.V.P., Win or Lose?
abstract: James’s 40-point triple-double in Game 5 was the first in the N.B.A. finals since Jerry West accomplished the feat in 1969.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James has been carrying the injury-riddled Cavaliers in the N.B.A. finals with one heroic performance after another. Now, down by three games to two, undermanned Cleveland may finally have run out of gas.

headline: 1965: Jewish Cemetery Vandalized
abstract: From the archives of the Intentional Herald Tribune: 1965: Jewish cemetery vandalized in Bamberg, Germany.
lead_paragraph: BAMBERG, GERMANY — The ancient cemetery was found grossly vandalized today [June 15] in what is one of the worst anti-Semitic outbreaks recorded in Germany since the war. Police reported that vandals had desecrated 23 tombstones in the cemetery with yard-high swastikas and anti-Semitic smearings such as ‘‘six million Jews were too few.’’ The desecration was discovered by two American families who had returned here to visit the graves of relatives. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 16, 1965

headline: Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Case on Pre-Abortion Ultrasounds
abstract: The justices refused to hear a case about a law that required doctors to describe and display the results of an ultrasound to women seeking abortions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to hear an appeal from North Carolina officials seeking to revive a state law that had required doctors to perform ultrasounds, display the resulting sonograms and describe the fetuses to women seeking abortions.

headline: Petra Collins Shares Her Influences
abstract: The Brooklyn-based artist, whose book “Babe” is out now, tells T about the movies, artists, activities and more that inspire her.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based artist, whose book “Babe” is out now, tells T about the movies, artists, activities and more that inspire her.

headline: Boston Muslims Struggle to Wrest Image of Islam From Terrorists
abstract: The recent fatal shooting of a Muslim man who pulled a knife on the police is yet another episode that weighs heavily on a mosque in Boston.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Yusufi Vali was hunched over his computer at this city’s biggest mosque, where he is executive director, when the first phone call came. The police had killed a man a few miles away. Soon there were reports that the man was a Muslim who had been under investigation for terrorism.

abstract: Hidden City Tours, which specializes in walking tours led by the homeless and formerly homeless, has a new Street Life tour of Barcelona.
lead_paragraph: Hidden City Tours, which specializes in walking tours led by the homeless and formerly homeless, has a new Street Life tour of Barcelona, Spain, focused on a side of the city tourists — and residents — don’t often see.

headline: Twists Outnumber Judges (So Far) in Case Against Arizona Sheriff
abstract: Lawyers for Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County want a new judge, who questioned the sheriff’s hiring of a rogue informant to investigate whether the judge was out to get him.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Judge G. Murray Snow pressed Sheriff Joe Arpaio to answer a bit of an odd question: Was the sheriff investigating the judge and his wife?

headline: Modi’s Yoga Day Grips India, and ‘Om’ Meets ‘Ouch!’
abstract: Yoga Day, the latest initiative introduced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has proved to be a cultural challenge in New Delhi, a capital diagnosed by some as having a “Western lifestyle.”
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On a sticky morning last week, Deputy Commissioner Chandra Shekhar Sahukar of India’s Agriculture Ministry (animal husbandry department, small ruminant section) found himself in a yoga class for the first time in his 57 years, miserably grasping his ankle.

headline: Joyce Mitchell, Prison Worker, Appears in Court as Search for Escaped Convicts Continues
abstract: The Clinton County district attorney, Andrew Wylie, said that additional charges against Ms. Mitchell, as well as additional arrests, were possible.
lead_paragraph: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y. — A prison employee made a brief appearance in court here on Monday morning after her arrest on charges that she helped two convicted killers make their dramatic escape from the state prison in nearby Dannemora.

headline: U.N. and Yemen Officials on Peace Talks
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, and Riyadh Yaseen, the foreign minister of Yemen, spoke on Monday as efforts to start peace talks in the country were delayed.
lead_paragraph: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, and Riyadh Yaseen, the foreign minister of Yemen, spoke on Monday as efforts to start peace talks in the country were delayed.

headline: Men at Kansas City Release Center Worry as Prison Plans to Move In
abstract: A looming question is what will happen to the 135 people housed in the Kansas City Community Release Center, which officials hope to have converted to a minimum-security prison.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When the Missouri Department of Corrections announced in February that it planned to open a minimum-security prison near this city’s downtown, the response from civic leaders was one that might seem surprising: joy.

headline: What Mountain Climbing Can Teach You About Business
abstract: In alpine-style climbing, you carry just what you need, which is not only a good lesson for life, but a good practice in running a business.
lead_paragraph: When we think of mountain climbing, we tend to think of Mount Everest and big groups of people climbing in long lines. Armies of Sherpas create base camps and ferry supplies and gear up and down the mountain. Miles of rope anchored to the mountainside helps climbers reach the top. For a very long time, many people considered this the best way to climb a mountain.

headline: Defining Hillary Clinton as a Fighter
abstract: Bob Meddaugh, an Iowa Democrat, compared Mrs. Clinton with President Obama during a Clinton campaign house party on Saturday night in Des Moines.
lead_paragraph: Bob Meddaugh, an Iowa Democrat, compared Mrs. Clinton with President Obama during a Clinton campaign house party on Saturday night in Des Moines.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Vows to ‘Fight’ Evoke a Populist Appeal and a Contrast With Obama
abstract: An emerging campaign theme is a way not only to appeal to the middle class but also to convey that when it comes to political combat, Hillary Rodham Clinton is not President Obama..
lead_paragraph: In a roughly 45-minute speech on Saturday, Hillary Rodham Clinton made 14 references to herself as a fighter.

headline: In Craig Kanarick’s Cutting-Edge Kitchen, a Dutch Oven Prevails
abstract: Unlike other parts of his kitchen, the wedding gift has never failed Kanarick, the C.E.O. of an online food marketplace.
lead_paragraph: Craig Kanarick’s kitchen is a study in modern culinary desire, every corner equipped with “things I can’t live without,” he said.

headline: In ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale, a Breakdown in Storytelling
abstract: The show has substituted sensation for imagination.
lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t have thought that a show based on a beloved series of books, with hundreds of pages of existing story to work from — a “mythology” that is an actual mythology — would become the “Lost” of its television generation. But that’s where “Game of Thrones” finds itself after Sunday night’s Season 5 finale: a wildly popular show that seems to have lost its way, and to be losing faith with a growing number of its viewers.

headline: 1940: Roosevelt Scorns Hitler
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: 1940: Roosevelt scorns Hitler’s word.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Roosevelt indicating his belief that Adolf Hitler’s word is worthless referred today [June 14] to Germany’s record of broken pledges to other nations as discounting the value of a reported statement by Chancellor Hitler that he had no intention of attacking the United States or any other part of the Western Hemisphere.

headline: Matt Enlow’s Rectangle Division Puzzle
abstract: Can you crack this rectangle division puzzle by Matt Enlow?

headline: Jeb Bush Is Still the Favorite, the Markets Say
abstract: His campaign has had a tough few months, but prediction markets don’t see them as very damaging in the long run.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush has had a rough few months. He fumbled a question about the war in Iraq. He has not consolidated the support of Republican elites, as Nate Cohn notes. And he has not scared off other candidates who could hurt him in the primaries, like John Kasich. There is no clever case to be made that Mr. Bush’s campaign has actually performed well this spring.

headline: Rachel Dolezal Leaves N.A.A.C.P. Post as Past Discrimination Suit Is Revealed
abstract: Years ago, Ms. Dolezal, who is accused of deceiving people about her race, apparently sued Howard University, charging that it had discriminated against her — in part for being white.
lead_paragraph: A few years before she began claiming to be black, an N.A.A.C.P. official who now stands accused of deceiving people about her race apparently sued a historically black university, charging that it had discriminated against her — in part for being white.

headline: Plan for Theme Park at Centuries-Old Chinese Caves Rattles Preservationists
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Buddhism']
abstract: The effort to restore and protect statues, figurines and frescoes of Buddha in Dunhuang has come against its toughest threat yet: tourists.
lead_paragraph: DUNHUANG, China — In the cool shadows of Cave 98, Li Lingzhi watched as workers in blue suits inspected the Buddhist frescoes commissioned in this Gobi Desert cliff grotto more than a millennium ago by a local ruling family.

headline: Ruling in A.I.G. Bailout Lawsuit
abstract: A judge ruled the government does not owe Maurice Greenberg and other shareholders any damages over the company’s 2008 bailout.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled the government does not owe Maurice Greenberg and other shareholders any damages over the company’s 2008 bailout.

headline: High Seas Style at Alexander McQueen
abstract: A modern riff on the perennial nautical theme caught the eye of T’s senior fashion editor.
lead_paragraph: In one of our favorite looks so far, Alexander McQueen featured a modern riff on the perennial nautical theme, pairing a patchwork knit with trim, cropped sailor pants. The beauty was in the details: two different widths of stripes spliced together at the top, and buttons anchoring the sides of the hems at the bottom.

headline: Building a Better Tortilla
abstract: The Bread Lab at Washington State University is working to improve the quality of Chipotle’s tortillas.
lead_paragraph: The Bread Lab at Washington State University is working to improve the quality of Chipotle’s tortillas.

headline: Chipotle’s Quest to Develop a Better Tortilla
abstract: The Bread Lab at Washington State University is working to improve the quality of the chain’s tortillas and make them as tasty as an abuelita’s.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT VERNON, Wash. — The latest piece of equipment at the Bread Lab, a heavenly smelling corner of the Washington State University campus here, is a tortilla press, a gift from Chipotle Mexican Grill.

headline: Companies Move On From Big Data Technology Hadoop
abstract: If you’re up on big data, you’ve heard of something called Hadoop. It may be worth billions, but some of Hadoop’s biggest backers look like they are moving on from it.
lead_paragraph: There is increasing evidence that Hadoop — one of the most important technologies of the past several years for big data analysis —is not keeping up with the world that created it.

headline: Feminine Fabrics Foray Into Men’s Wear
abstract: Ruffles, velvet and lace feel neither ladylike nor out of place in the spring/summer 2016 collections of Alexander McQueen, Wales Bonner and Burberry Prorsum.
lead_paragraph: More so than ever, fabrics traditionally perceived as feminine are being cut into convincing men’s wear silhouettes. At the spring/summer 2016 shows in London, tiers of ruffles cascaded down Alexander McQueen knits and Wales Bonner’s jewel-encrusted, velvet suits felt tough — not ladylike. This afternoon, Burberry Prorsum showed an entire collection of lace, both subtle — with shirts and ties peeping out of suits — and dramatic, as in this finale look. (And the actors Chiwetel Ejiofor and Samuel L. Jackson had front-row seats to the show.)

headline: Ex-A.I.G. Chief Wins Bailout Suit, but Gets No Damages
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Maurice Greenberg, the former chief of A.I.G., had been seeking nearly $40 billion, contending that the government overstepped its bounds in its 2008 bailout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, brought a class-action lawsuit against the government in 2011, contending that the Federal Reserve overstepped its bounds when it bailed out his company at the height of the financial crisis, the reaction was mainly befuddlement and outright ridicule.

headline: Letters to the Editor
keywords: ['Genetic Engineering', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Food', 'Elderly', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']

headline: Workers Can Be Fired for Marijuana Use, Colorado Court Rules
abstract: In a blow to marijuana advocates, the Colorado Supreme Court found that a satellite-television provider acted within the law when it fired an employee after he failed a drug test.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Even in one of the country’s most marijuana-friendly states, smoking pot off the job and away from work can still get an employee fired.

headline: Grace Wales Bonner’s High-Low, Gender-Defying Clothes You Might Actually Wear
abstract: Following her quiet breakthrough at last season’s Fashion East presentation, the designer introduced a smashing collection for spring/summer 2016.
lead_paragraph: Following her quiet breakthrough at last season’s Fashion East presentation, Grace Wales Bonner delivered on high expectations today, the last day of London Collections Men’s spring/summer 2016 shows. In a thoughtful, wide-sweeping collection with multicultural, high-low, gender-defying implications, Wales Bonner achieved the impossible: clothes you might actually wear. The former T cover star Nader Chaudhry modeled one of the strongest looks, a faded, checked linen shirt worn with wide topstitched denim.

headline: What Happens to Surplus Super PAC Money?
abstract: Mostly, it’s up to the super PAC.
lead_paragraph: This is only the second presidential election in which super PACs, which can raise unlimited money as long as they don’t coordinate directly with candidates, will play a role. Jeb Bush’s super PAC, for instance, was expected to raise $100 million, though it now appears it won’t reach that number this month.

headline: Peter Walter’s Voyage Into a Microscopic World
abstract: The biochemist discusses his path to studying how proteins within cells are coordinate their work.
lead_paragraph: Peter Walter, a professor of biochemistry at the University of California, San Francisco, studies how proteins within cells communicate with one another. His contributions have been instrumental in shaping scientific understanding of how cells are organized and how they function.

headline: In London, Hands-On Graffiti
abstract: Tours offer travelers hands-on insight into Barcelona’s “Street Life” and London’s graffiti scene.
lead_paragraph: The East End of London is famous for the vibrant graffiti art splashed throughout the streets, and now a new experience from the London-based experiential travel company NoteWorthy gives travelers a chance to get up close with its culture. The half-day excursion begins with a local graffiti artist giving guests an overview of the history behind the art form and a walking tour of murals, including works by the renowned Banksy.

headline: “Complicities”
abstract: A selection of Brigitte Lacombe photographs, which go on sale tonight through Phillips in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A selection of Brigitte Lacombe photographs, which go on sale tonight through Phillips in Manhattan.

headline: John Cleese and Eric Idle to Hit the Road Together
abstract: The Monty Python comedians have not appeared as a duo before.
lead_paragraph: They’ve been comedic collaborators for roughly half a century, and after all that time you’d understand if John Cleese and Eric Idle would prefer to spend the next 50 years as far apart as possible. But can it be that these two founding members of Monty Python might actually be … getting along?

headline: G.E. Said to Struggle to Find Buyers of Australian Units
abstract: Five GE Capital businesses that cater to commercial customers are valued at $2.9 billion in total but are drawing lukewarm interest.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — GE Capital, the financial arm of General Electric, is struggling to drum up interest in its Australian commercial lending and leasing businesses, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Warriors Prove Even LeBron James Can’t Do It Alone
abstract: Despite James’s superhuman efforts for the depleted Cavaliers, the Warriors have a 3-2 N.B.A. finals lead because of their options and depth.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — It was up to LeBron James again to try to salvage what he could against a superior team, to push the Golden State Warriors to the brink as he chased another improbable victory for the Cleveland Cavaliers. So he lined up a shot 34 feet from the basket, and nobody at Oracle Arena on Sunday night seemed terribly surprised when it went in.

headline: Kurds and Syrian Rebels Storm ISIS-Held Border Town
abstract: Capturing the town, Tal Abyad, on the Turkish border, would subvert a major ISIS supply line and help create a contiguous slice of Kurdish-held land.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A coalition of Kurdish militias and Arab rebels stormed into a strategic Syrian town on the Turkey border on Monday, seizing most of it from Islamic State fighters who had long used the area to smuggle supplies and fighters into their self-declared caliphate, according to Kurdish militia leaders and activists.

headline: Suicide Bombers Strike Chad’s Capital
abstract: At least 23 people were killed in the bombings in Ndjamena, and the president’s office said the Nigerian terrorist group Boko Haram was to blame.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Suicide bombers struck for the first time in the capital of Chad on Monday morning, apparently in retaliation for the leading role the country has played in a regional war against the Nigerian terrorist group Boko Haram, officials said.

headline: Review: ‘Deutschland 83’ Focuses on a Reluctant Cold War Spy
abstract: This eight-part series on SundanceTV follows a young East German soldier who is recruited, against his will, for espionage in West Germany.
lead_paragraph: Television has featured a fair amount of spying lately, and a fair amount of 1980s nostalgia, too. But “Deutschland 83,” an espionage series from Germany set in that wretched decade, is fresh and enjoyable nonetheless, distinguishing itself with a young protagonist and a losers’-history perspective.

headline: ‘Jurassic World’ Sets Box Office Record
abstract: Universal Pictures says the film took in $208.8 million at the North American box office over the weekend, Hollywood’s biggest opening ever.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A monster hit, indeed: “Jurassic World,” as it turns out, took in $208.8 million at the North American box office over the weekend, 2 percent more than estimated on Sunday and enough to enter Hollywood’s record books as the biggest opening ever, Universal Pictures said on Monday.

headline: Prison Employee Faces Charges
abstract: Joyce E. Mitchell, a woman charged with helping two convicted murderers escape from a maximum-security prison in New York, appeared in court on Monday as the manhunt continued.
lead_paragraph: Joyce E. Mitchell, a woman charged with helping two convicted murderers escape from a maximum-security prison in New York, appeared in court on Monday as the manhunt continued.

headline: Goldman Sachs Plans to Offer Consumer Loans Online, Adopting Start-Ups’ Tactics
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The unit will eliminate the costs of bank branches and tellers to allow Goldman to charge lower interest rates and still make a profit. But the venture holds risks.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has spent 146 years largely as the bank of the powerful and privileged.

headline: Jeb Bush Shows Loyalty to a Logo Derided by Some
abstract: The logo dates to Jeb Bush’s 1994 campaign, when he lost to Lawton Chiles, the incumbent Democratic governor. Mr. Bush stuck with it over the years, and in 2002 filed paperwork to trademark the logo.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush’s new campaign logo — Jeb! — was unveiled to guffaws that it was unoriginal and lacking in design elements, but for the former Florida governor, a throwback look appears to have been part of the plan.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
abstract: The Argentina-Uruguay match in Copa América will go head-to-head with the United States-Nigeria game in the Women’s World Cup on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Club soccer is so last month. It’s all internationals this week. The soccer editor Andrew Das tells you what to watch.

headline: Justices Uphold Denial of Visa to Afghan Husband of American Woman
abstract: The Supreme Court, voting 5 to 4, ruled that the denial did not interfere with her fundamental right to marriage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a fractured 5-to-4 decision with no majority opinion, the Supreme Court on Monday refused to second-guess the denial of a visa on national security grounds to the Afghan husband of an American woman.

headline: Too Much at Risk for Sepp Blatter to Renege on Vow to Resign
abstract: It is unlikely that Blatter will try to remain FIFA’s president, but it cannot be ruled out, if only because FIFA has proven itself capable of just about anything.
lead_paragraph: If social media is any indication, it is highly possible that many soccer fans have been so busy celebrating Sepp Blatter’s announcement that he will step down as FIFA president that they missed a number of key developments in the story.

headline: Science, Now Under Scrutiny Itself
keywords: ['Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Research', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Plagiarism', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A steady increase in study retractions has alarmed journals and scientists, raising difficult questions about how research is conducted.
lead_paragraph: The crimes and misdemeanors of science used to be handled mostly in-house, with a private word at the faculty club, barbed questions at a conference, maybe a quiet dismissal. On the rare occasion when a journal publicly retracted a study, it typically did so in a cryptic footnote. Few were the wiser; many retracted studies have been cited as legitimate evidence by others years after the fact.

headline: Women’s Bodies Safe from North Carolina Lawmakers, For Now
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Ultrasonic Imaging and Sonograms', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A North Carolina law that required women seeking abortions to get ultrasounds won’t be resurrected, but similar laws exist in other states.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of absurdly creative (or creatively absurd?) attempts by lawmakers around the country to prevent women from controlling what happens inside their own bodies.

headline: Brigitte Lacombe Shares Her Secret
abstract: The photographer, whose first-ever New York selling show opens tonight in Manhattan, discusses the key to her vast 40-year oeuvre.
lead_paragraph: Though their subjects include many of the most iconic celebrities of the last half-century, Brigitte Lacombe’s photographs have become classics of the genre because of their distinct lack of cinematic artifice. “It’s nothing to do with photography,” the French-born, New York-based lenswoman says of her approach. “It’s about what you can establish with a person within a very short period of time.”

headline: Women’s World Cup: How Each Team Advanced
abstract: What must the U.S., Canada and other teams do to move on, and what’s next for them if they do?
lead_paragraph: What must the U.S., Canada and other teams do to move on, and what’s next for them if they do?

headline: Pope Francis Calls for Climate Action in Draft of Encyclical
abstract: In the leaked 192-page document, posted by an Italian magazine, the pope offers a broad vision of an endangered planet and partly blames human activity for global warming.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis offers a broad vision of an endangered planet, partly blaming human activity and fossil fuels for climate change while calling for people of all religions to take swift action, according to a leaked draft of his much-awaited environmental encyclical that was posted online Monday by an Italian magazine.

headline: No. 2 Qaeda Leader May Have Died in U.S. Airstrike in Yemen
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Yemeni officials and extremists said Nasser al Wuhayshi, the leader of Al Qaeda’s Yemen affiliate, was killed last week; American officials said they could not confirm the reports.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Yemeni officials and extremists reported on Monday that the leader of Al Qaeda’s Yemen affiliate and recently the second-ranking official of the global terror network, Nasser al-Wuhayshi, had been killed in an American drone strike. American officials said they could not confirm the reports but were investigating.

headline: A Jellyfish That Quickly Puts Itself Back Together
keywords: ['Jellyfish', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Marine Biology', 'Biology and Biochemistry']
abstract: When a juvenile moon jellyfish loses tentacles, it rapidly reorganizes its remaining limbs in order to maintain symmetry, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: When a juvenile moon jellyfish loses tentacles, it rapidly reorganizes its remaining limbs to maintain symmetry, a new study says.

headline: Manhunt: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Jesse McKinley, a reporter, recounts what it has been like covering the manhunt for convicted killers who have escaped from jail in New York.
lead_paragraph: Batteries and chargers and GPS. Snacks and water and sensible shoes. And an awful lot of patience.

headline: Sand Fly Saliva Proves a Good Monkey Vaccine for Leishmaniasis
abstract: ­A new study suggests a vaccine against leishmaniasis that worked well in monkeys may have potential to work in humans as well.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine against leishmaniasis based on the saliva of sand flies has worked well in monkeys and may have potential to work in humans, according to a new study.

headline: N.B.A. Finals Have a Shot at Ratings Not Seen in Years

lead_paragraph: Twenty million people once routinely watched games in the N.B.A. finals — when Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush and Bill Clinton were in the White House.

lead_paragraph: In Terry Zwigoff’s 2001 film,  “Ghost World,”  a teenager, Enid, walks into the room where Seymour keeps his vast collection of old 78 r.p.m. records and says: “You are, like, the luckiest guy in the world. I would kill to have stuff like this.”

lead_paragraph: Spoilers follow for the season 5 finale of “Game of Thrones.” Like immediately.

keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Earthquakes', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Accidents and Safety']

lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The Nepal government declared several damaged heritage sites open to the public on Monday, in a bid to recover tourism revenues in the region hit by an earthquake, but United Nations officials worried that the buildings were not entirely ready.

headline: A Thirsty Colorado Is Battling Over Who Owns Raindrops
keywords: ['Water', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Drought', 'Shortages']
abstract: The debate over collecting rain in barrels, which is illegal in the state, is a microcosm of fights across the region over who should get to keep using water and who should have to cut back.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Jason Story bought an old soy sauce barrel to collect the rain dripping from his downspout, he figured he had found an environmentally friendly way to water his garden’s beets and spinach. But under the quirks of Western water rules, where raindrops are claimed even as they tumble from the sky, he became a water outlaw.

headline: State Museum in Albany Plans Overhaul of Its Galleries
abstract: The museum, one of the more popular ones in the state, will upgrade its galleries with a $14 million infusion of state funds.
lead_paragraph: Though its profile in New York City may be low, the New York State Museum is one of the largest museum attractions in the state, with 635,000 visitors a year – more than the annual attendance of the Frick Collection, for example, or the Brooklyn Museum.

lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission may soon be confronting the adage “be careful what you wish for.”

lead_paragraph: Gap announced on Monday that it planned to close one-fourth of its stores in North America over the next few years, potentially affecting thousands of jobs, as the brand struggles to turn around a business mired in a long sales slump.

headline: Expired Rent Regulation Rules Would Cause More Anxiety Than Chaos, Officials Say
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Landlords', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Tenant advocates and officials note that the regulations for New York City have lapsed before, with no dire consequences.
lead_paragraph: New York renters faced uncertainty about potential large rent increases as state lawmakers let rent regulations expire on Monday without renewing them. But the city has been there before, with no dire consequences.

headline: Abby Wambach Says U.S. Would Be Scoring More on Grass
abstract: Wambach, the leading scorer in women’s soccer history, has blamed the field surface, but scoring has been a persistent problem for the U.S. team all year.
lead_paragraph: Abby Wambach caused a stir at the Women’s World Cup over the weekend when she told reporters that the United States would have scored more goals in its first two games if the tournament was not being played on artificial turf.

headline: Royal Sibling Rivalry
abstract: Prince William and Prince Harry faced off against each other at a charity polo match in Gloucestershire, Britain.
lead_paragraph: Prince William and Prince Harry faced off against each other at a charity polo match in Gloucestershire, Britain.

headline: Fashion’s Ex-Enfant Terrible Launches an Auction House
abstract: Kai Kühne, a former member of the downtown collective Asfour, aims to shake up the sedate scene with his new venture Hasbeens & Willbees.
lead_paragraph: In his former life as a clothing designer and member of the downtown New York fashion collective Asfour, Kai Kühne was a notorious enfant terrible whose party-boy antics made him something of a tabloid habitué. In recent years, however, he has more or less forsaken the city in favor of a woodsy idyll in the western Catskills, embracing what he calls the “new luxury” of local and sustainable living and cultivating a life around upstate’s growing food, design and art scenes. After opening a pop-up farm-to-table restaurant and antiques gallery in the town of Andes in the summer of 2013, Kühne and his boyfriend, John Mollett, are launching a new project this week back in New York: an auction house under the name of Hasbeens & Willbees that will bring a bit of the Catskills ethos down to the city. They kick things off Wednesday with the sale of a trove of objets belonging to their late friend, the upstate-based interior designer Kenyan Lewis, who died suddenly of diabetes complications last December.

headline: St. Paul Bishop Assesses Resignations
abstract: The Rev. Andrew Cozzens, an auxiliary bishop for the archdiocese, called the resignation of Archbishop John Nienstedt and his aide “an opportunity for greater healing.”
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Andrew Cozzens, an auxiliary bishop for the archdiocese, called the resignation of Archbishop John Nienstedt and his aide “an opportunity for greater healing.”

headline: ‘The Prime of Life,’ by Steven Mintz
abstract: Steven Mintz’s new book gives a full historical timeline of the defining features of adulthood.
lead_paragraph: The notion that adulthood, despite its perks, is little more than a booby prize for surviving the scrapes and trials of youth has more or less become a cultural given in the modern age. From the 1950s narrative of soul-crushed men in gray flannel suits to the existential torment of hippies-turned-yuppies in the 1980s to the ­tyrannical scheduling demands of today’s Lean In movement, grown-up life in America is generally framed as a sort of bland entree following the assortment of colorful appetizers that make up childhood and young adulthood. Moreover, as any armchair social anthropologist will tell you, maturity seems to kick in later and later with each passing generation.

headline: ‘How to Raise an Adult,’ by Julie Lythcott-Haims
abstract: Julie Lythcott-Haims cautions against helicopter parenting that keeps kids from growing up.
lead_paragraph: When did the central aim of parenting become preparing children for success? This reigning paradigm, which dictates that every act of nurturing be judged on the basis of whether it will usher a child toward a life of accomplishment or failure, embodies the fundamental insecurity of global capitalist culture, with its unbending fixation on prosperity and the future. It’s no surprise that parenting incites such heated debates, considering how paradoxical these principles can be when they’re applied to children. When each nurturing act is administered with the distant future in mind, what becomes of the present? A child who soaks in the ambient anxiety that surrounds each trivial choice or activity is an anxious child, formed in the hand-wringing, future-focused image of her anxious parents.

headline: Petra Collins Shares Her Favorite Things
abstract: The photographer and artist’s book “Babe” is out this month; she discusses the artists, movies and more that inspire her.
lead_paragraph: Describing Petra Collins as a photographer is reductive, though it’s her photographs for which she’s best known. That said, she’s also well recognized from the many photographs that have been taken of her, notably by her mentors Richard Kern and Ryan McGinley. And she is probably most infamous for her drawings, particularly her “Period Power” illustration for an American Apparel T-shirt that generated significant media notoriety. (To further complicate things, that illustration was originally based on a neon light sculpture that Collins had previously created.)

headline: Review: Rachel Podger Plays Bach for Flute With Her Violin
abstract: This Baroque violinist played Bach’s Partita in A minor for solo flute, along with Tartini and Biber works, at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: As a rule, violinists rarely pilfer foreign repertory. They don’t need to. With so much first-rate music written for the violin, the motivation to adapt and transcribe works written for other instruments is low. So why did Rachel Podger, one of the leading performers on the Baroque violin, open her masterly recital at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Sunday with Bach’s Partita in A minor for solo flute, transposed into the key of G minor? Because when it comes to Bach, Ms. Podger told the audience, “You can’t get enough.”

headline: ‘Why Grow Up?’ by Susan Neiman
abstract: In her new book, the philosopher Susan Neiman takes on the predicament of maturity in an “infantile age” that dates back to the 18th century.
lead_paragraph: A great deal of modern popular culture — including just about everything pertaining to what French savants like to call le nouvel âge d’or de la comédie américaine — runs on the disavowal of maturity. The ideal consumer is a mirror image of a familiar comic archetype: a man-child sitting in his parents’ basement with his video games and his “Star Wars” figurines; a postgraduate girl and her pals treating the world as their playground. Baby boomers pursue perpetual youth into retirement. Gen-Xers hold fast to their skateboards, their Pixies T-shirts and their Beastie Boys CDs. Nobody wants to be an adult anymore, and every so often someone writes an article blaming Hollywood, attachment parenting, global capitalism or the welfare state for this catastrophe. I’ve written one or two of those myself. It’s not a bad racket, and since I’m intimately acquainted, on a professional basis, with the cinematic oeuvre of Adam Sandler, I qualify as something of an expert.

keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In his announcement speech on Monday, he pretended he will be a candidate to all people all the time.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida who has been pretending not to be a presidential candidate for months, stopped that charade today with an “announcement speech” in Miami in which he pretended some other things: that he is not part of a political dynasty, that he has shown how to cut government costs while protecting ordinary people, and that he will be a candidate to all people all the time.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Residents of two frequently shelled neighborhoods in Donetsk in eastern Ukraine staged a public antiwar protest on Monday, an exceedingly rare event in rebel-held territory.

headline: Review: Rebecca Stenn’s ‘Riparius (Belonging to the River)’ in Brooklyn Debut
abstract: The dance, a collaboration among Ms. Stenn and others, is performed at Gowanus Loft, near the canal.
lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn, near the Ninth Street Bridge over the notoriously polluted Gowanus Canal, a postindustrial wasteland seems to be in the early stages of gentrification. Amid warehouses with “For Rent” placards, one telling sign of change is the 19th-century factory building that has been converted into the Gowanus Industrial Arts Complex. On the top floor is a clean, white, airy space known as the Gowanus Loft. And it is here that the Rebecca Stenn Company is debuting its new work, “Riparius (Belonging to the River).”

headline: Parents’ Denial Fuels Childhood Obesity Epidemic
abstract: The majority of parents of preschool-age obese children described them as “about the right weight,” a recent study found.
lead_paragraph: Not only was the 16-year-old boy 60 pounds overweight, but a blood test showed he might have fatty liver disease. At last, his mother took him to a pediatric weight management clinic in New Haven. But she did not at all like the dietitian’s advice.

headline: From Plastic Tablecloths, Three-Dimensional Art Grows
abstract: The interdisciplinary artist Crystal Wagner’s latest mural, at 1515 Broadway, opens tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: The interdisciplinary artist Crystal Wagner isn’t “interested in people looking at art as an object on the wall, or a print over there,” she says. Instead, Wagner hopes to elicit a sense of wonder through her three-dimensional murals made from birthday party tablecloths stuffed into a chicken-wire armature, with paper embellishments. The ingredients are deliberate: “A lot of our aesthetic experience is defined by the places that we visit on a daily basis — you don’t even realize that they’re burning themselves into your retina,” she notes. “It’s the way that the cereals are lined up on shelves, or how Coke cans sit next to the Mountain Dew. So, I wanted to create organic bioforms that seem to grow, but using materials that people are exposed to.”

headline: Walkabout: Iceland Tourism Surges; Business Travel
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Longer Lines Tourism to Iceland has been on an upswing, with a 24 percent increase in visitors, with a total of 970,000 in 2014. The trend shows no signs of stopping; last month, the number of visitors from the United States increased 76 percent compared with last year. (Skift)

headline: Review: ‘The Last Beach’ and ‘The Narrow Edge’ Share Tales of Harm and Hope Along Our Coasts
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Beaches', 'Birds', 'Crabs']
abstract: Two recent books take a grim look at what may happen to coastlines and their animal inhabitants in a warming world.
lead_paragraph: In her song “Big Yellow Taxi,” Joni Mitchell gave voice to a lament we hear more and more these days: you don’t know what you’ve got till it’s gone. Her theme is the landscape — “paradise,” she calls it in the song, paved over for a parking lot.

headline: Jeb Bush Wants 4 Percent Growth. That Will Be Hard to Reach.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Productivity', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The next president is unlikely to see sustained 4 percent G.D.P. growth absent a remarkable, rapid upward shift in the nation’s productive capacity.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush wants to make the United States an “economic superpower like no other,” as he said in announcing his candidacy for president Monday. There is a good case, of course, that the nation already is an economic superpower like no other: It has the highest gross domestic product in the world by a margin of about $7 trillion.

headline: The Chat: Jeb Bush’s Announcement Speech, Instantly Analyzed
abstract: The former Florida governor said he was indeed a candidate for president, that the Republican contest was “wide open,” and that he would “run to win.”
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush formally entered the race for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination on Monday with a speech at the Kendall campus of Miami Dade College. Over instant messages, two New York Times political correspondents — Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman — analyzed Mr. Bush’s remarks in real time, as they did with the campaign announcements of several other 2016 candidates. Here is an edited version of their chat.

headline: Hillary Clinton Pushes to Expand Access to Pre-Kindergarten
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton pushed to broaden President Obama’s efforts to expand access to pre-kindergarten, proposing more federal money for states to provide preschool to children from moderate and low-income families.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday pushed to broaden President Obama’s efforts to expand access to pre-kindergarten, proposing more federal money for states to provide preschool to children from moderate and low-income families.

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

abstract: Mr. Bush, the former governor of Florida, announced that he was officially beginning his presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Bush, the former governor of Florida, announced that he was officially beginning his presidential bid.

headline: Rachel Dolezal’s ‘Passing’ Isn’t So Unusual
abstract: America's racial boundaries have always been porous.
lead_paragraph: Why do we care so much about Rachel Dolezal, the head of the Spokane, Wash., chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. who apparently misrepresented herself as African-American when, according to her parents, she is Czech, Swedish and German, with some remote Native American ancestry?

abstract: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan defied a court order to remain in South Africa until it ruled on an application for his arrest on genocide charges from the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan defied a court order to remain in South Africa until it ruled on an application for his arrest on genocide charges from the International Criminal Court.

headline: Facing Consumer Pressure, Companies Start to Seek Safe Alternatives to BPA
abstract: Although the chemical has been deemed safe by the F.D.A. at current levels, consumers and advocacy groups are urging companies to remove BPA or find safer alternatives.
lead_paragraph: For consumers, figuring out which canned foods and plastics contain the controversial chemical known as BPA can be nearly impossible. But determining whether newer alternatives are any safer may be even more difficult.

headline: Buried in Jeb Bush Website, a ‘Die Hard’ Surprise
abstract: For an hour or so this afternoon, buried in the source code of Jeb Bush’s website were several paragraphs summarizing the plot of the “Die Hard” movie franchise.
lead_paragraph: For an hour or so this afternoon, buried in the source code of Jeb Bush’s website were several paragraphs summarizing the plot of the “Die Hard” movie franchise.

lead_paragraph: Protesters in kayaks set up a blockade in Elliott Bay as Royal Dutch Shell’s drill rig left Seattle on its way to explore for oil in the Arctic Ocean off Alaska.

headline: After Blackout in California, a Squirrel Seems Too Convenient a Scapegoat
keywords: ['Squirrels', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Pacific Gas and Electricity blamed a squirrel for a power failure that struck 45,000 Bay Area residents last week. But the utility’s past transgressions have left many skeptical of that excuse.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Was it really all the squirrel’s fault?

headline: Karzai, Vowing That He’s Done, Discusses His Afghanistan Legacy
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Amid a steady stream of official visitors to his home, Hamid Karzai said in a rare, wide-ranging interview, “I have done my time.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Hamid Karzai, the former president of Afghanistan, wants to set a few things straight.

headline: Russia Urges U.S. Not to Deploy Weapons to Border Areas
abstract: The Foreign Ministry warned of “dangerous consequences” if the Americans station tanks and other heavy battle equipment to NATO states near Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Moscow issued muted warnings on Monday in response to the Pentagon’s possible stationing of battle tanks and other heavy weapons to speed the deployment of American troops if needed in NATO states bordering Russia.

headline: Conlon Nancarrow’s Player-Piano Works at the Whitney: No Live Performer Needed
abstract: “Anywhere in Time: A Conlon Nancarrow Festival,” an 11-day immersion that begins on Wednesday, focuses on the groundbreaking studies for player piano.
lead_paragraph: In a cramped alcove just off the airy 204-seat theater at the Whitney Museum of American Art’s new home downtown, Jay Sanders was seeing his player piano in action for the first time. Two technicians had been tinkering with the instrument, a 1921 Marshall and Wendell Ampico upright, and now they were letting it run.

headline: LastPass Password Manager Acknowledges Breach
abstract: LastPass, the online password manager, announced Monday that its network was breached and that hackers made off with user email addresses, password reminders and encrypted master passwords. It was the second time the service had been breached in four years.
lead_paragraph: LastPass, the online password manager, announced Monday in a blog post that its network was breached and that hackers made off with user email addresses, password reminders and encrypted master passwords.

headline: LastPass Password Manager Acknowledges Breach
abstract: LastPass, the online password manager, announced Monday that its network was breached and that hackers made off with user email addresses, password reminders and encrypted master passwords. It was the second time the service had been breached in four years.
lead_paragraph: LastPass, the online password manager, announced Monday in a blog post that its network was breached and that hackers made off with user email addresses, password reminders and encrypted master passwords.

headline: Review: ‘What Counts,’ a Lydia Johnson Dance Work, Attends to the Music
abstract: For Ms. Johnson, a choreographer, the relevance of the music was clear in works her company presented last weekend at Ailey Citigroup Theater.
lead_paragraph: Among the tasteful, finely wrought works that Lydia Johnson Dance presented at Ailey Citigroup Theater over the weekend was the premiere “What Counts.” What seems to count most for Ms. Johnson is music. The four pieces on the program all showed uncommon skill at matching ballet movement to music, both at the large scale of structure and in small, felicitous details.

headline: Review: ‘The Sleeping Beauty’ Spurs American Ballet Theater to Work on the Details
abstract: A series of performances of a new production of “The Sleeping Beauty” offered a reminder that no ballet better showcases the way in which a company operates.
lead_paragraph: As American Ballet Theater gave a series of performances of its new production of “The Sleeping Beauty” last week, it was easy to spot ways in which things could sound and look better. Tchaikovsky’s score should have been better played (especially by the brass and wind sections) and been more sensitively conducted, and Richard Hudson’s sets (inspired by Bakst) deserved to be lighted considerably better than they have been by James B. Ingalls.

headline: Bubble!
abstract: Never! mind! the! punctuation!
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting! to ridicule! Jeb Bush! over his ludicrous campaign logo! But it would be wrong.

headline: Jeb Bush Declares His Presidential Candidacy
abstract: Aiming to be the third member of his family to occupy the Oval Office, the former governor of Florida announced his plans in Miami.
lead_paragraph: Aiming to be the third member of his family to occupy the Oval Office, the former governor of Florida announced his plans in Miami.

headline: Spitzer Charges Into His Family’s Real Estate Business
abstract: Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer, his political career and his marriage behind him, has embraced his role as head of Spitzer Enterprises since his father’s death in November.
lead_paragraph: Much has changed for Eliot Spitzer since he resigned as governor of New York in 2008, only 15 months after taking office, amid revelations that he was a client of a prostitution ring.

headline: Sidney Blumenthal, Hillary Clinton’s Confidant, Turns Over Memos on Libya
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'E-Mail', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi had issued a subpoena to Mr. Blumenthal for any emails he had exchanged with Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Emails that a longtime confidant to Hillary Rodham Clinton recently handed over to the House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, raise new questions about whether the State Department and Mrs. Clinton have complied with a series of requests from the panel.

headline: Posing Questions of Photographic Ethics
abstract: In the aftermath of this year’s debates over manipulated photos, a new show sets out to explore the history of altered images in photojournalism.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of this year’s debates over manipulated photos, a new show sets out to explore the history of altered images in photojournalism.

headline: Israeli Helped Inspire U.S.-Russia Weapons Deal With Assad, Memoir Says
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The Israeli minister said he proposed the agreement that pressured the Syrian president to abandon his stockpile of chemical weapons two years ago.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The American-Russian deal that pressured President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to abandon his stockpile of chemical weapons two years ago was encouraged by an Israeli minister, according to a new memoir by a former Israeli ambassador to Washington.

headline: Walmart Accused of Using Charity to Sway Cities Where It Wants to Expand
abstract: The Walmart Foundation’s charitable contributions rose steadily in some cities as Walmart tried to curry support and win access to those markets, the complaint said.
lead_paragraph: A group of community and labor organizations is accusing Walmart of inappropriately using the nonprofit Walmart Foundation to help reduce local opposition to its expansion efforts in some urban areas like Washington, Boston, Los Angeles and New York.

headline: New York Comptroller, Taking Aim at ‘Three-Quarter’ Homes, Urges City Agencies to End Referrals
keywords: ['Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Homeless Persons', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: The office of Scott M. Stringer says it wants to independently review addresses of boardinghouses where city agencies send people, and weed out unscrupulous operators.
lead_paragraph: The office of the New York City comptroller plans to send letters on Tuesday to City Hall and various agencies demanding that they take steps to ensure that people in need of housing are not sent to illegal boarding homes, known as “three-quarter” houses, and to provide information that will help the office compile a list of such homes.

headline: Siena Tries to Regain Its Financial Footing, and Its Identity
abstract: Monte dei Paschi, the world’s oldest bank, was the center of life in Siena, Italy. So when it nearly collapsed, the city was left scrambling to fill the void.
lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — Operators of kindergartens and ambulance services had to find new sources of funds. A biotech company filed for bankruptcy. The local professional soccer team slipped into the minor leagues after it could no longer afford the salaries of its top players.

headline: After SAT Misprint, Two Sections Won’t Be Scored
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The College Board also says it will waive its fees for students who want to take the test again, after an error regarding the allotted time for a reading section on June 6.
lead_paragraph: After a misprint in test booklets about the time allotted for taking part of the SAT earlier this month, the College Board said on Monday that it would not score two sections of the exam, and would waive its fees for students who wanted to take the test again.

headline: Monica Lewis, 93, Dies; Her Apple-Pie Appeal Sold Chiquita Bananas
abstract: Miss Lewis began her career as a singer and actress at an early age and was still performing near the end of her life.
lead_paragraph: Monica Lewis, the dimpled, diminutive chanteuse who made her Broadway debut as a teenager, taught Americans how to ripen their newly imported bananas as the ubiquitous voice of Miss Chiquita, appeared on the inaugural episode of Ed Sullivan’s television variety show in 1948 and durably continued to perform jazz and pop hits for decades, died on Friday at her home in the Woodland Hills area of Los Angeles. She was 93.

headline: Kennedy Airport Hopes Work on Runway Won’t Add to Summer Delays
abstract: The busy, delay-plagued airport in New York City hopes to operate at almost-full speed while one of its four runways is being rebuilt.
lead_paragraph: In mid-March, travelers trying to fly out of Kennedy International Airport got a bitter taste of the misery that can prevail when a major hub finds itself with only one working runway. The start of a yearlong rebuilding effort on one of the airport’s four main runways left passengers stewing aboard planes that waited up to two hours to take off.

headline: Medical Use of Marijuana Doesn’t Increase Youths’ Use, Study Finds
abstract: The new analysis is the most comprehensive effort to date to answer a much-debated question: Does decriminalization of marijuana lead more adolescents to begin using it?
lead_paragraph: Marijuana use did not increase among teenagers in the states in which medical marijuana has become legal, researchers reported Monday.

headline: Classical Live Offers Orchestras Another Internet Stage
abstract: Five performing groups have united to create a new avenue for streaming their live recordings via Google Play Music.
lead_paragraph: With the pace of change in the recording industry making it challenging for some performers and their audiences to find one another, five leading orchestras joined together on Monday and began offering some of their recent live recordings online on Google Play Music.

headline: Bloomberg Philanthropies Gives $100 Million to Cornell Tech
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Philanthropy', 'Science and Technology', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: The graduate school will use the money for the first academic building on its Roosevelt Island campus, which is set to open in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Cornell Tech, the applied sciences graduate school of Cornell University, is expected to announce a $100 million gift from Bloomberg Philanthropies on Tuesday to construct the first academic building on the school’s Roosevelt Island campus.

headline: Review: Loudon Wainwright III’s ‘Surviving Twin’ Is a Father-Son Collaboration
abstract: Mr. Wainwright combines his work with that of his father, the writer Loudon Wainwright Jr., in his solo show.
lead_paragraph: The first song Loudon Wainwright III ever wrote for his son, Rufus, is more than 40 years old by now, an address to his child in utero.

headline: In A.I.G. Case, Surprise Ruling That Could End All Bailouts
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A decision that the Fed acted beyond its legal authority in bailing out A.I.G. could have far-reaching consequences should another financial crisis occur — and if history is any guide, one will.
lead_paragraph: For years, critics of the bailouts during the financial crisis argued that the rescue efforts weren’t harsh enough. The chief executives of failing institutions should have lost their jobs. Shareholders should have suffered more pain. Taxpayers should have received substantial compensation for the risk they took.

headline: Plea Deal for Chuck Blazer Is Unsealed
abstract: Blazer, a former American soccer official, secretly cooperated with a federal investigation of FIFA for nearly two years before pleading guilty.
lead_paragraph: The former American soccer official Chuck Blazer was providing information to federal prosecutors looking into corruption in world soccer’s governing body for nearly a year and a half while still a member of FIFA’s ruling executive committee, according to a plea agreement unsealed by a federal judge Monday.

headline: Invitations to a White House Party: Signed, Sealed, Delivered, but Private
abstract: Details about a White House party featuring Stevie Wonder and Prince and 500 dancing guests remain scarce.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has thrown an invisibility cloak over many issues during its nearly seven years in office: drone strikes in Yemen, the raid to kill Osama bin Laden in Pakistan, even provisions of a Pacific trade pact involving 12 nations.

headline: Best U.S. Open Courses Give Players a Lift, and Vice Versa
abstract: If Chambers Bay is to join the rotation of frequent United States Open hosts, it most likely needs a big-name winner.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, the United States Golf Association has staged its main Open championship on treacherously traditional courses across America, but this week it is in uncharted territory: links-like Chambers Bay on a sandy shore of Puget Sound near Tacoma, Wash.

headline: Alex Rodriguez, Back Home, Pops Out in His Chance to Shine
abstract: Rodriguez, who entered the game five hits from No. 3,000, was held out of the starting lineup, but he had many fans and supporters in attendance.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As Alex Rodriguez trotted out of the dugout in the ninth inning to pinch-hit Monday, he was met by a loud cheer from the opposing fans. After the game, as Rodriguez left the clubhouse, someone suggested to him that it was the loudest a Marlins crowd had been in years.

headline: A Summary Judgment for the Rachel Moore vs. Howard University Lawsuit
abstract: In 2005, courts documents show that Ms Moore, which was Rachel Dolezal’s married name at the time, failed to bring sufficient evidence to back her claims of discrimination against the historically black university.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, courts documents show that Ms Moore, which was Rachel Dolezal’s married name at the time, failed to bring sufficient evidence to back her claims of discrimination against the historically black university.

lead_paragraph: A lawsuit filed in 2002 by Rachel Moore, which was Ms. Dolezal’s married name at that time, claimed that the historically black university discriminated against her, that she was not hired for certain jobs and that a scholarship she was awarded was terminated because she was white.

lead_paragraph: R. A. Dickey crouched next to a video room outside the Mets’ clubhouse on Monday and waited. Suddenly, the door swung open.
