lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Vanderbilt shortstop Dansby Swanson still has not gotten over the double jolt of jubilation.

headline: Review: In ‘Preludes,’ a Hypnotist Tries to Get Rachmaninoff to Make Music Again
abstract: This new play by Dave Malloy, who wrote “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812,” is set in the hypnotized mind of Sergei Rachmaninoff.
lead_paragraph: Writer’s block turns out to be a lot more inspiring than you could ever have imagined — and sad and stirring and gloriously fun. In “Preludes,” which opened on Monday night at the Claire Tow Theater at Lincoln Center, Dave Malloy makes beautiful music out of a composer’s three years of creative silence.

headline: Who Says?
abstract: Peter A. Collins hopes you’re hungry.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — There are two kinds of solvers, in my opinion: those who curse the pop culture in crossword puzzles, and those who are grateful for it.

headline: Board Hears Support for Raising Food Workers’ Minimum Wage
abstract: Fast-food workers and supporters turned out for a public hearing, before a wage board created by Gov. Andrew Cuomo, to argue that they cannot support themselves on the money they now make.
lead_paragraph: The mayor who faced a multitude of excited New York City workers in Manhattan on Monday morning was not Bill de Blasio.

headline: South Africa’s Disgraceful Help for President Bashir of Sudan
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: Members of the International Criminal Court are supposed to respect its warrants, but South Africa didn’t.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan fled arrest in South Africa and is now safely back in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital. His escape is another blow to the International Criminal Court, which has been struggling to bring him to trial for six years on charges of crimes against humanity and genocide.

headline: Israeli Government Cartoon Mocks Foreign Coverage of Gaza
abstract: The video is part of Israel’s intensifying effort to undermine potential criticism from the United Nations of its military assault on Gaza last summer.
lead_paragraph: As part of Israel’s intensifying effort to undermine potential criticism from the United Nations of its military assault on Gaza last summer, the country’s Foreign Ministry released an animated YouTube video on Monday mocking coverage of the conflict by Western reporters as absurdly inaccurate.

headline: Prime Minister Modi’s Yoga Consultant, H.R. Nagendra
abstract: Dr. Nagendra, a yoga therapist in Bangalore, has been consulting with Narendra Modi, now India’s prime minister, since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: H.R. Nagendra, a yoga therapist in Bangalore, has been consulting with Narendra Modi, now India’s prime minister, since the 1980s, and has been called in to provide training to officials serving under Mr. Modi, first in Gujarat and later in New Delhi.

headline: Bush’s Announcement, in Two Languages
abstract: Jeb Bush announced his candidacy in Miami with an emphasis on his bona fides in the Latino and Hispanic communities.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush announced his candidacy in Miami with an emphasis on his bona fides in the Latino and Hispanic communities.

headline: With Blackhawks’ 3 Stanley Cups in 6 Years, Chicago Runneth Over
abstract: The Blackhawks ended a tightly contested series in Game 6, winning a championship on home ice for the first time since 1938.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chicago Blackhawks can rub shoulders with some of the greatest dynasties in hockey history after they won their third Stanley Cup in six years by beating the Tampa Bay Lightning, 2-0, on Monday to end a tightly fought six-game series.

headline: Women’s World Cup 2015: Norway Reaches Knockout Stage
abstract: Norway defeated Ivory Coast, while Germany routed Thailand and China tied New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S RESULTS

headline: A Playlist From Nowadays, the New Outdoor Bar From the Guys Behind Mister Saturday Night
abstract: Justin Carter and Eamon Harkin share some tunes sure to be on rotation at their new space on the border of Bushwick, Brooklyn, and Ridgewood, Queens.
lead_paragraph: About 18 months ago, Justin Carter and Eamon Harkin found an abandoned postindustrial space hugging the border of Bushwick, Brooklyn, and Ridgewood, Queens. The D.J. duo behind the wildly popular disco dance parties and record label known as Mister Saturday Night (and the offshoot Mister Sunday, which finds a spirited summer crowd gathering at Industry City, Brooklyn) knew it was home for their new all-outdoor urban oasis bar, Nowadays.

headline: Nick Cave Revisits Detroit, Soundsuits in Tow
abstract: The artist’s seven-month-long project, “Here Hear,” includes an exhibition at his alma mater, Cranbrook.
lead_paragraph: When the Cranbrook Art Museum asked to host his inaugural solo outing in Michigan, the artist and dancer — and Cranbrook Academy of Art alum — Nick Cave agreed, on one condition: “I said, I will only do it if I can do work in Detroit.” For the uninitiated, the school’s campus sits about 20 miles away from the downtown area, Cave’s first lesson upon his arrival in the late ’80s. “Girl, thank God for the city,” he says. “I got here and I was the sole black person, so Detroit saved my life. I became connected to this circle of creative people.” He recalls a fearlessness to the way they came together and fed off of one another. “I don’t know if I could have done Cranbrook without Detroit,” he avers. “That’s why this is so important; I’m reconnecting with the city that really allowed me to create a balance in my higher education.”

headline: Inside Nike’s Supersecret Showroom and Fitness Studio
abstract: At the brand's exclusive new SoHo space, its performance wear proves itself in workout classes for fashion editors, insiders and the like.
lead_paragraph: In the fashion world, showrooms are essentially a safe place for editors, buyers and stylists of very important clients to experience a collection — to ask questions, inspect details, feel fabrics and understand a garment’s nuances. At certain showroom appointments, models are even on hand to help visitors visualize pieces on the wearer — how they move with the body or drape across it, which features they accentuate and what proportions they require. And at Nike’s newest showroom, 45 Grand (so named for its address), the goal is, similarly, to educate and provide an experience. But the interiors are nothing like what the industry has come to expect.

headline: In the West Village, Modern Boutique Owners Who Live Where They Work
abstract: Michael and Caroline Ventura, who recently introduced the home store Calliope, open their doors to T.
lead_paragraph: “We’re both innately solvers,” Michael Ventura, the founder and CEO of the strategy and design practice Sub Rosa, says of himself and his wife Caroline, the jewelry designer of Brvtvs. He’s speaking of their traits, both at work — Sub Rosa specializes in elegant and efficient business solutions while Brvtvs counters the jeweled cacophony with restrained pieces — and at home — which shares an address with their new store, and abuts their individual businesses.

headline: Wearable Devices to Prevent Sunburn
abstract: New devices monitor sun exposure and nudge users to apply sunscreen and take other steps to protect their skin from too much sun.
lead_paragraph: Could new technology succeed where years of public health messages, doctor warnings and nagging moms have failed — to keep us safe from too much sun?

headline: Charitable Giving Rises Past Prerecession Mark
abstract: Contributions rose for the fifth year in a row and in all categories, according to a new report from the Giving USA Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Charitable giving rose for the fifth year in a row in 2014, rebounding past a prerecession peak to an estimated $358 billion, according to an annual report from the Giving USA Foundation.

headline: Word of the Day | adventitious
abstract: This word has appeared in one New York Times article in the past five years.
lead_paragraph: adventitious • \ˌad-(ˌ)ven-ˈti-shəs, -vən-\ • adjective

headline: Consumer Groups Back Out of Federal Talks on Face Recognition
abstract: Early Tuesday, nine civil liberties and consumer advocate groups announced that they were withdrawing from talks with trade associations over how to write guidelines for the commercial use of face recognition technology on consumers.
lead_paragraph: A central component of President Obama’s effort to give consumers more control over how companies collect and share their most sensitive personal details has run aground.

headline: Consumer Groups Back Out of Federal Talks on Face Recognition
abstract: Early Tuesday, nine civil liberties and consumer advocate groups announced that they were withdrawing from talks with trade associations over how to write guidelines for the commercial use of face recognition technology on consumers.
lead_paragraph: A central component of President Obama’s effort to give consumers more control over how companies collect and share their most sensitive personal details has run aground.

headline: New York Rent Regulation Laws Expire Amid Last-Minute Talks
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Rent regulations limiting how much landlords can charge for about one million apartments in New York City and its suburbs expired after lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on how to extend them.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Rent regulations limiting how much landlords can charge for about one million apartments in New York City and its suburbs expired on Monday night after lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on how to extend them.

headline: Blaze Starr, Burlesque Queen Who Was Linked to a Governor, Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Starr’s affair with Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana was the basis of her memoir and a 1989 movie.
lead_paragraph: Blaze Starr, the voluptuous stripper who was billed as the Queen of Burlesque and whose affair with a Louisiana governor was the basis of a 1989 movie, died on Monday in Wilsondale, W.Va., the coal country town in which she was born. She was 83.

headline: Review: Harrison Birtwistle’s ‘The Cure’ and ‘The Corridor,’ Myths With a Twist
abstract: The Aldeburgh Festival presented these two chamber operas, which draw from the story of Orpheus and Eurydice, and an episode in the varied life of Medea.
lead_paragraph: SNAPE, England — Harrison Birtwistle was once a radical presence at the Aldeburgh Festival. At the 1968 premiere of his violent production of seaside puppetry, “Punch and Judy,” the festival’s appalled founders, Benjamin Britten and Peter Pears, not so quietly excused themselves from the sonic carnage.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (TNT) PROOF Parachuting off Mount Everest doesn’t faze Ivan Turing, a tech wizard with a referential surname and a fondness for Steve Jobsian turtlenecks. But terminal cancer has given him pause. “I’ve always hated unknowns,” he tells Dr. Carolyn Tyler, a cardiothoracic surgeon with little patience for speculation and a wellspring of grief all her own. “And now that I’m facing the biggest one there is, I want to know what to expect.” His offer: He’ll give her control of his $10 billion estate if she’ll help him prove what, if anything, exists after the body flat lines. Beautiful minds (and some intriguingly nutty concepts) collide in this new series, which stars Jennifer Beals and Matthew Modine, and counts Kyra Sedgwick among its executive producers. As Dr. Tyler investigates the murky realm that believers call the afterlife, the doctor in her chafes at the notion that the nearly dead share experiences that science can’t explain. But as the mother of a teenage son killed a year earlier, she can’t help but want to believe herself.

headline: Sony Previews Game Lineup at E3
abstract: Sony showed off its lineup of PlayStation 4 games on Monday at the start of the E3 conference, including the whimsical titles The Last Guardian and Dreams.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sony, as is customary, got the last word of the first day of E3, the video game industry’s annual conference here.

headline: Vivian Gornick’s ‘The Odd Woman and the City’
abstract: Vivian Gornick’s memoir looks at the writer’s quotidian life and quirky encounters in New York.
lead_paragraph: Vivian Gornick’s new memoir, “The Odd Woman and the City,” has an unusually large cast of characters. There is her mother, the subject of her memoir “Fierce Attachments,” and her friend, Leonard, a gay man, whom she meets once a week. There are the people she sees at parties and the two men she was married to, briefly, in her youth. There are her lovers — one of whom we might recognize for his habit of telling women what they want (in “Fierce Attachments,” a glass of wine; in this memoir, anal sex) — and the couples whose relationships she likes to analyze with friends: “Who would have written this story, Wharton or James?”

headline: Posing Questions of Photographic Ethics
abstract: In the aftermath of this year’s debates over manipulated photos, a new show sets out to explore the history of altered images in photojournalism.
lead_paragraph: Most curators hope to get glowing reviews and popular acclaim when they mount an exhibit. Michael Kamber, on the other hand, is expecting some blowback for his latest show, “Altered Images: 150 Years of Posed and Manipulated Documentary Photography,” which opens this weekend at the Bronx Documentary Center.

headline: The Growing Right-Wing Terror Threat
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslim Americans', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Police']
abstract: U.S. citizens may fear homegrown jihadists, but law enforcement is more worried about right-wing extremists.
lead_paragraph: THIS month, the headlines were about a Muslim man in Boston who was accused of threatening police officers with a knife. Last month, two Muslims attacked an anti-Islamic conference in Garland, Tex. The month before, a Muslim man was charged with plotting to drive a truck bomb onto a military installation in Kansas. If you keep up with the news, you know that a small but steady stream of American Muslims, radicalized by overseas extremists, are engaging in violence here in the United States.

lead_paragraph: Last week, the Congressional Democrats defeated the underpinnings of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement. Let’s count up the things these Democrats will have done if this policy stands.

headline: How to Grade a Teacher
abstract: There are better ways to evaluate teachers than test scores alone.
lead_paragraph: This is the second column I’ve written about Deborah Loewenberg Ball, the dean of the University of Michigan School of Education. Ball believes the training that teachers get while they are in school needs to be drastically improved. Last year, I wrote about her effort to develop a professional training curriculum that would allow beginning teachers to be far better grounded in their craft than they are now.

headline: Central America’s Unresolved Migrant Crisis
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Central Americans are still seeking to migrate to the United States in droves, but a greater percentage are now being turned back in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: This time last year, migrants from Central America, including thousands of unaccompanied minors, were streaming into the United States, creating a problem for border communities and Obama administration officials. With far fewer people reaching American soil this year, it is tempting to conclude that the crisis is ebbing.

headline: California’s Pension System Clamps Down on High Investment Fees
abstract: The Calpers plan to cut investment fees could save billions.
lead_paragraph: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System’s decision to reduce the number of alternative investment firms, like private equity funds, it uses to manage its money is a prudent step that should help it save billions of dollars.

headline: Meet the New Common Core
abstract: But don’t get too excited. It’s the same as the old one.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — HATE the Common Core? You’re not alone. The national reading and math standards, set up by a bipartisan consortium of state governors, have turned into a political lightning rod for a coalition of angry parents and education activists. The math component has generated special peevishness. The comedian Louis C.K. was widely cheered in April when he tweeted: “My kids used to love math. Now it makes them cry. Thanks standardized testing and Common Core!”

headline: Sticker Shock in For-Profit Hospitals
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Medicare', 'Medicaid', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Two recent reports provide evidence of the hard-to-justify high prices that many hospitals charge for common procedures.
lead_paragraph: Two reports published this month provide fresh evidence of the hard-to-justify high prices that many hospitals charge for common procedures. The prices drive up premiums for many privately insured patients and can be ruinously expensive for those who are uninsured or inadequately insured or who go to a hospital or doctor outside their insurance network.

headline: Your Giant Carry-On Bag Is Safe for Now
abstract: An international association announced guidelines encouraging fliers to get smaller carry-on luggage. But airlines don’t seem eager to follow them.
lead_paragraph: Don’t worry, nobody is coming for your enormous rollaboard suitcase just yet.

headline: Europe’s Highest Appeals Court Backs Bond-Buying Program
abstract: The program, introduced in September 2012, has never been used. Despite that, it is credited with helping the European Central Bank rescue the euro.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Central Bank on Tuesday got a vote of confidence from Europe’s highest appeals court, which ruled that the bank has the authority to buy quantities of bonds from eurozone countries.

abstract: Why was Paul Mason’s surgery such a complex case?
lead_paragraph: In “Down From 980 Pounds, With New Battles to Wage,” Sarah Lyall reports on a man who at his heaviest was known informally as the world’s fattest man.

headline: Burberry, in a Class of Its Own
abstract: The fashion label’s shows, lavish and well coordinated, leave no room for comparison with its London competitors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As London men’s wear shows go, there is everybody, and then there is Burberry. Its dedication to scale makes classing its catwalk presentations with its competitors ludicrous. In scope and in price, for avidity and sheer concertedness — not only for the usual hundreds of elements, but also for a 24-piece orchestra — it is unmatched among the fashion week spectacles here.

headline: Why Jeb Bush’s Online Campaign Was Quiet
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Online Advertising', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: By delaying the declaration of his candidacy, he chose raising money over building a web presence. Time will tell if this was a good strategy.
lead_paragraph: If you searched for “Jeb Bush” using Google last week, you would have found thousands of results but no advertisement at the top directing readers to his organization. That kind of ad is what you saw when you did a web search for Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator, or Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic front-runner. Because there was no Jeb Bush campaign website, the top non-news result in Google for “Jeb Bush” was a Wikipedia page about him.

headline: Where Racewalking Is King, the Antidoping Officials Are Busy
abstract: Viktor Chegin has attained national hero status in Russia, but now he and his training center are at the center of one of track’s biggest scandals.
lead_paragraph: SARANSK, Russia — The palatial glass-and-steel Olympic Training Center of the Republic of Mordovia rises from the flattened landscape of this small industrial city in Russia’s rust belt. Saransk does not have much of a profile, even in Russia. Gérard Depardieu bought a house here to escape French taxes. It was once a popular spot for gulags. But it is basically the Russian equivalent of flyover country — unless you happen to be a fan of racewalking.

headline: For U.S., Killing Terrorists Is a Means to an Elusive End
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Killing terrorist leaders may be a victory for drone strikes, but it has not helped the Obama administration and its Western allies stem the chaos in Yemen and Libya.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Twice in the last week, the United States has focused its vast manhunting machinery on tracking down and striking terrorist leaders in anarchic countries that for the White House once embodied the promise of the Arab revolutions across the Middle East.

headline: Offering Services, ISIS Digs In Deeper in Seized Territories
abstract: The jihadists’ governing efforts, from inspecting food to offering perks to newlyweds, have brought a stability unavailable from national governments.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — In northern Syria, the jihadists of the Islamic State have fixed power lines, dug sewage systems and painted sidewalks. In Raqqa, they search markets and slaughterhouses for expired food and sick animals. Farther south, in Deir al-Zour, they have imposed taxes on farmers and shopkeepers and fined men for wearing short beards.

headline: Philippine Rebels Give Up Dozens of Weapons in Step Toward Peace Deal
abstract: The largely symbolic surrender of 75 weapons was seen as an important gesture, but full disarmament must await final approval of the pact by Congress.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Islamic militants in the southern Philippines turned over dozens of weapons on Tuesday as part of a tentative peace deal, an agreement that is facing stiff resistance from lawmakers since a firefight with rebels in January that killed dozens of police officers.

headline: Jonathan Galassi’s ‘Muse’
abstract: Jonathan Galassi’s novel of the world of literary publishing revolves around a rock-star poet.
lead_paragraph: Ida Perkins! There is surely no poet to equal her. Her stunning debut, “Virgin Again,” marked the beginning of a trail blazed through American letters. Published by T. S. Eliot, praised by Marianne Moore, she earned respect within the academy that didn’t hinder her rise to global celebrity. She was the only person ever to appear simultaneously on the covers of Rolling Stone, Interview and the recherché Tel Quel. Carly Simon and Carole King’s duet version of Ida’s song “Broken Man” went platinum in 1970. Will we ever see her like again?

abstract: Pay attention to the payment plans for SIM cards, take your chances with Wi-Fi or rely on data. These are just a few of the choices you’ll need to make.
lead_paragraph: As a general rule, I’m against an alien takeover of our planet — unless they bring along one thing: a global wireless system that would simplify the endlessly complex world of options for using cellphones abroad.

lead_paragraph: Priya Ollapally, product manager for special editorial projects, helped design The Times’s new tool (in Beta), Trending,  which shows what Times stories are most popular with readers online and in social media. She explains the thinking behind the new product.

headline: The Corrupt Rhetoric of the FIFA Scandal
abstract: Soccer officials decry an imperialist plot, as Western boosters claim a triumph of liberal values. Both are phony.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “We have fought colonialism and defeated it and we still fight imperialism and we will fight it whenever it manifests itself.” So claimed South Africa’s sports minister, Fikile Mbalula, recently. He was talking not of war or invasion but about the F.B.I.’s investigation into corruption involving FIFA, world soccer’s governing body. Other officials from Africa, Asia and the Caribbean have expressed similar sentiments.

headline: Why Germany Can’t Lead Europe
abstract: It is the most powerful country in Europe, but it isn’t quite ready to seize the moment.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Imagine a building in Berlin tall enough to provide a look across the entire continent — and beyond. What do you see?

headline: Nepal Quake Moved Everest About One Inch, Study Finds
abstract: Chinese researchers say the earthquake on April 25 was so strong that it moved the world’s highest peak southwest.
lead_paragraph: The devastating earthquake in Nepal in April killed thousands of people and displaced hundreds of thousands more. And it reduced hundreds of historic monuments to rubble.

headline: What You Need to Know About the Vote on Hong Kong’s Election Rules
abstract: Hong Kong lawmakers are to begin debating on Wednesday a Beijing-backed proposal to change how the city selects its top official. We offer a primer on the issues.
lead_paragraph: What’s at stake?

headline: Silent History
abstract: Coming out to a Turkish mother who might never come around — or so they both thought.
lead_paragraph: Knowing yourself and accepting yourself are two different things. I knew that I fancied boys from the time I was in kindergarten. Although you don’t know how to name it, especially in a very heterosexual society like Turkey’s, this is something that you feel. I didn’t accept who I was, on the other hand, until years later, during university, when I found myself coming out to 30 or 40 people at once onstage in a drama class. All my friends in the class came one by one to kiss and congratulate me. But even then I hadn’t opened the curtain all the way, because I hadn’t come out to my mother.

headline: George Takei Is Out for Justice
abstract: The actor uses his following on social media to change minds.
lead_paragraph: You’re very busy for someone your age. You’ve written three books; you have a web series; and your musical, “Allegiance,” based on your family’s time in an internment camp during World War II, will debut on Broadway in November. As a matter of fact, I just came back from the posting of the marquee at the Long­acre Theater. I just wish my father could have been there. Takei is his surname, and the play is about an event that affected him so profoundly. He came back to Los Angeles from the camp with nothing — literally penniless — and was living on Skid Row.

headline: Can Thulisile Madonsela Save South Africa From Itself?
abstract: Two decades after the fall of apartheid, the nation’s first female public protector tries to beat back corruption at the highest levels of government.
lead_paragraph: On a cloudy morning in March last year, dozens of reporters, photographers and camera crews gathered in the vast building that houses the offices of Thulisile Madonsela, South Africa’s public protector. The journalists assembled that day were searched by security, stripped of their phones, pens, notebooks and recording equipment and told to take a seat in a conference room. Madonsela’s staff gave each of them a thick document numbering almost 450 pages. Her assistants were posted by the windows, making sure no one was secretly leaking information. Outside, riot officers in armored vehicles stood watch. “There’s about 100 people in the room,” recalled Ranjeni Munusamy, a well-known editor at The Daily Maverick, a South African newspaper. “Everyone’s quiet and flipping through pages, and now and then you look up to see who is on what page. I went right to the end to look at the findings. When I saw them, I wanted to scream.”

headline: Janine Gibson, a Former Guardian Editor, Will Head BuzzFeed’s British Operation
abstract: Ms. Gibson, who left The Guardian after being passed over for the editor in chief post, will oversee an expansion of BuzzFeed news staff in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Janine Gibson, a former senior editor at The Guardian who left the newspaper recently after being passed over for its top editor’s post, will join BuzzFeed as the editor in chief of its British operation.

headline: Today in Politics: Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr. Donald Trump
abstract: Donald Trump day is upon us. The real estate mogul and reality television star, whose numerous feints at running for office haven’t resulted in an actual candidacy, is expected to formally declare his campaign for president on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where a confidant of Hillary Rodham Clinton is set to testify to a House committee about the attacks in Benghazi, Libya. As for the presidential candidates, the crowded Republican field finally found room for Jeb Bush, and now, it might have to again move over for a hopeful who needs only one name: Trump.

headline: Pete Seeger’s New York Roots
abstract: Considering the many places his music took him, you would be forgiven for forgetting that, in a deeply rooted sense, Seeger was a New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: The poet Carl Sandburg called him America’s tuning fork, and for good reason.

headline: Deaths of Irish Students in Berkeley Balcony Collapse Cast Pall on Program
keywords: ['Balconies and Terraces', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Visas', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Buildings (Structures)']
abstract: Six people were killed and seven others injured in a balcony collapse near the University of California, Berkeley, the police said, most of them young Irish students on a visa program.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — They come by the thousands — Irish students on work visas, many flocking to the West Coast to work in summer jobs by day and to enjoy the often raucous life in a college town at night. It was, for many, a rite of passage, one last summer to enjoy travel abroad before beginning a career.

headline: Hong Kong Election Plan Appears Unlikely to Win Lawmakers’ Approval
abstract: Lawmakers are set to decide that, rather than accept an election plan in which all candidates must effectively be approved by Beijing, they would rather have no direct election at all.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The issue of how to choose Hong Kong’s chief executive is once again threatening to convulse the city’s politics.

abstract: How much is Airbnb affecting the housing market in cities where rent is on the rise?

headline: Morning Agenda: Split Decision for Greenberg in A.I.G. Lawsuit
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Split Decision for Greenberg in A.I.G. Lawsuit | Goldman Sachs to Offer Consumers Online Loans | CVS’ Healthy Appetite for Expansion | 2 Giant Health Insurers Said to Court Smaller Rivals
lead_paragraph: SPLIT DECISION FOR GREENBERG IN A.I.G. LAWSUIT | On Monday, Judge Thomas C. Wheeler of the United States Court of Federal Claims sided with Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, ruling that the Federal Reserve illegally took over A.I.G. as part of its $185 billion bailout of the troubled company in 2008,  Aaron M. Kessler writes in DealBook. It wasn’t a complete victory for Mr. Greenberg, who is also one of the largest shareholders of A.I.G. – he wasn’t awarded any portion of the $40 billion in damages he was seeking because the judge also sided with the government in its argument that the bailout had saved A.I.G. from the bankruptcy.

headline: Fitbit Raises Price Range for I.P.O.
abstract: The maker of health-tracking devices now expects to price its initial public offering at $17 to $19 a share, a midpoint range that values the company at nearly $3.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: Fitbit, the maker of wearable health-tracking devices, raised the range for the expected pricing of its initial public offering to $17 to $19 a share, according to a filing on Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Jeb Bush Makes a Major Fashion Statement
abstract: No jacket. No tie. The politician declared his presidential candidacy in shirtsleeves.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush is his own man. How do we know this? Well, he says it a lot. But more important, he showed it on Monday in Miami — becoming the first candidate in his family, and possibly the first candidate ever, to announce his bid for the United States’ highest office in … shirtsleeves.

headline: Is Self-Loathing a Requirement for Writers?
abstract: Thomas Mallon and Anna Holmes discuss the role of self-hatred in creativity.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. “Self-loathing is the engine; fame is the fuel,” Karl Ove Knausgaard has said. This week, Thomas Mallon and Anna Holmes discuss the role of self-hatred in creativity.

headline: Dance This Week: Merce Cunningham, Twyla Tharp and ‘Romeo and Juliet’
abstract: This week’s look ahead at the world of dance.
lead_paragraph: Hail, dancegoers. Here is another installment of our weekly dance column, in which we draw attention to highlights in the field. This weekend, New York dance fans have important events uptown and downtown. If you time things right, you can see choreography by Merce Cunningham, Trisha Brown and Twyla Tharp in three (or even two) consecutive days, and catch American Ballet Theater’s “Romeo and Juliet,” which involves both debuts and departures. Please use the comments section to let us know what you think.

abstract: Nothing quite says “pretentious, overused buzzword” like “bespoke.” Partly because we seem to be using it as a synonym for “fancy” or “high-end,” the word has metastasized.

headline: Remembering King James, Before and After His Crowning
abstract: Dru Joyce II, the 60-year-old veteran coach of St. Vincent-St. Mary High School in Akron, knows LeBron James won’t change, win or lose.
lead_paragraph: Before we could suggest that northeast Ohio was on the verge of its worst depression since the great one of the 1930s, we consulted with Dru Joyce II, who returned from a cruise this week to find LeBron James and what’s left of his Cleveland Cavaliers one game away from losing the N.B.A. finals.

headline: The Foster Family Honeymoon Is Over
abstract: We’d been told it is common for a foster child to be on his best behavior for the first few weeks or months.

headline: Rachel Dolezal, in Center of Storm, Is Defiant: ‘I Identify as Black’
abstract: As Ms. Dolezal has refused to back down on her embrace of black identity, some people have applauded her work and others have deplored her methods and actions.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — When she moved into her uncle’s basement in the largely white town of Coeur d’Alene, Idaho, in 2004, Rachel A. Dolezal was still blond and pale-skinned and identified herself as a white woman — one who had left a black husband and had a biracial child.

lead_paragraph: Steve Martin and Edie Brickell are taking another step toward Broadway.

headline: Readers’ Turn: Fighting Fat
abstract: Upshot commenters share some strategies for staying away from overeating.
lead_paragraph: Each Tuesday, The Upshot’s newsletter will feature a selection of comments from an article that resonated with our readers in the past week.

headline: Napoleon Rides Again
abstract: The Battle of Ligny, Napoleon Bonaparte’s final victory, was re-enacted Sunday in Belgium to start a weeklong series of events commemorating the 200th anniversary of his ultimate defeat at Waterloo.
lead_paragraph: The Battle of Ligny, Napoleon Bonaparte’s final victory, was re-enacted Sunday in Belgium to start a weeklong series of events commemorating the 200th anniversary of his ultimate defeat at Waterloo.

headline: 200 Years After Waterloo, Napoleon Still Wins by Losing
abstract: As Europe observes the Waterloo bicentennial, the legend of the defeated emperor continues to draw crowds while Wellington, the victor, is often forgotten.
lead_paragraph: LIGNY, Belgium — Napoleon Bonaparte, also known as Frank Samson, a pudgy Paris lawyer who likes wearing gold braided uniforms and a black bicorne hat, won his last battle on Sunday in southern Belgium.

headline: 1890: Anarchists On The Warpath
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: 1890: Anarchists attack newspaper in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The invasion of a Paris newspaper office by a score of Anarchists, and a savage assault upon the rédacteurs who happened to be at their desks — this is the astonishing sequel to the disorderly meeting reported in yesterday’s Herald. ‘‘Mouchards’’ was the epithet by which the newspaper in question, the Egalité, described the men who had begun the fight at the Faubourg du Temple meeting. The cap apparently fitted the ‘‘compagnons’’ and ‘‘compagnes’’ of Anarchism, for about a score of them, men and women, betook themselves to the offices of the offending journal to wreak vengeance. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 17, 1890

headline: Tracing a 17-Year-Old’s Path From Britain to an ISIS Suicide Attack
abstract: Talha Asmal, a student from West Yorkshire, would be his country’s youngest known suicide bomber if his role in an attack in Iraq is confirmed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He was barely old enough to drive in Britain. But last Saturday, Talha Asmal, a 17-year-old high school student from West Yorkshire, is said to have detonated a Toyota Land Cruiser full of explosives at an Iraqi security facility. If true, he would be the youngest known suicide bomber from Britain.

headline: Hillary the Divider
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s campaign strategy and its consequences.
lead_paragraph: The weekend’s this-time-I-mean-it Hillary Clinton presidential announcement was preceded by an interesting pundit debate over whether her apparent presidential strategy — trying to recreate the Obama coalition, running a little more to the left than people anticipated, not even making an attempt to retrace her husband’s electoral path and ditching certain beyond-red-and-blue ideas once embraced by the current president — is a good idea, either for her or for America. The critics include my colleague David Brooks and National Journal’s Ron Fournier; Hillary’s defenders include Jonathan Chait and my Upshot colleague Brendan Nyhan. My own thoughts are … complicated, and fall into two parts.

headline: Feeling For
abstract: Vans partners with Japanese contemporary artist Takashi Murakami to create a lively capsule collection, available on June 27.
lead_paragraph: Vans partners with Japanese contemporary artist Takashi Murakami to create a lively capsule collection, available on June 27.

headline: F.D.A. Sets 2018 Deadline to Rid Foods of Trans Fats
abstract: Health experts said the elimination of artery-clogging, artificial trans fats from the food supply would save thousands of lives a year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday gave the food industry three years to eliminate artery-clogging artificial trans fats from the food supply, a long-awaited step that capped years of effort by consumer groups and is expected to save thousands of lives a year.

headline: Rebirth of a Transgender Teenager
abstract: As Katherine Boone, 18, recovered from gender reassignment surgery, she and her family talked about what they went through.
lead_paragraph: As Katherine Boone, 18, recovered from gender reassignment surgery, she and her family talked about what they went through.

headline: The New Girl in School: Transgender Surgery at 18
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Surgery and Surgeons']
abstract: It was not an easy transition for Katherine Boone, but the question is no longer whether gender reassignment is an option, but instead how soon it should start.
lead_paragraph: In a cozy cottage decorated with butterflies to symbolize transformation, Katherine Boone was recovering in April from the operation that had changed her, in the most intimate part of her body, from a biological male into a female.

headline: Americans Are Again Getting More Worried About the Climate
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Encyclicals']
abstract: Concern over global warming, having fallen after the financial crisis and President Obama’s election, has risen recently, Pew finds.
lead_paragraph: The financial crisis made Americans less worried about climate change. The Democrats’ attempt to pass sweeping climate legislation in 2009 and 2010 probably reduced Americans’ anxiety level as well, as paradoxical as that may sound. But now Americans are getting more worried again.

headline: Cardinals Investigated for Hacking Into Astros’ Database
abstract: The F.B.I. and the Justice Department are investigating whether officials for the St. Louis Cardinals hacked into the networks of the Houston Astros to steal information about player personnel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Front-office personnel for the St. Louis Cardinals, one of the most successful teams in baseball over the past two decades, are under investigation by the F.B.I. and Justice Department prosecutors, accused of hacking into an internal network of the Houston Astros to steal closely guarded information about players.

headline: Failure of Obama’s Trans-Pacific Trade Deal Could Hurt U.S. Influence in Asia
abstract: The death of the Trans-Pacific Partnership would be a new setback for American economic diplomacy in the region after a failed attempt to thwart a Chinese state-run infrastructure investment fund.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — With President Obama’s trade agenda in jeopardy in Congress, the nations of Asia are weighing the potential impact of a failed deal on local jobs and exports, but also something else: American influence in the region.

headline: From Style: Casual Jeb Bush
abstract: Jeb Bush becomes the first candidate in his family, and possibly the first candidate in modern history, to announce his bid for the United States’ highest office in … shirtsleeves.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush Makes a Major Fashion Statement

headline: Donald Trump, Pushing Someone Rich, Offers Himself
abstract: In his announcement, Mr. Trump brandished his wealth and fame as chief qualifications for the presidency in an improbable quest for the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the garrulous real estate developer whose name has adorned apartment buildings, hotels, Trump-brand neckties and Trump-brand steaks, announced on Tuesday his entry into the 2016 presidential race, brandishing his wealth and fame as chief qualifications in an improbable quest for the Republican nomination.

headline: How Rachel Dolezal Identifies Herself
abstract: Rachel A. Dolezal, who resigned as president of the N.A.A.C.P. chapter in Spokane, Wash., has been accused of misrepresenting her racial background. A look at how she’s identified herself.
lead_paragraph: Rachel A. Dolezal, who resigned as president of the N.A.A.C.P. chapter in Spokane, Wash., has been accused of misrepresenting her racial background. A look at how she’s identified herself.

headline: Antibiotics Are Effective in Appendicitis, Study Says
abstract: A Finnish study found that three out of four patients who took antibiotics to treat appendicitis, instead of having surgery, recovered easily.
lead_paragraph: For more than 100 years, the standard treatment for appendicitis has been surgery. Now a large Finnish study provides the best evidence to date that most patients can be treated with antibiotics alone.

headline: Turtle Island Quartet Finds New Cellist in Carolina Chocolate Drops
abstract: Malcolm Parson of the Carolina Chocolate Drops will be the new cellist in the Turtle Island Quartet.
lead_paragraph: A cello change is coming to the Turtle Island Quartet, a 30-year-old ensemble that has become known for crossover classical performances that reimagine works by artists as varied as John Coltrane and Jimi Hendrix for string quartet.

headline: Cole Hammer, 15, Enjoys Pro Treatment Ahead of U.S. Open
abstract: Hammer, the third youngest man to qualify for a United States Open, is from Houston, where he will be a high school sophomore in the fall.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Cole Hammer was being interviewed Monday evening at Chambers Bay Golf Course when Cody Gribble, a fellow Texan with whom Hammer had just finished a nine-hole practice round, sneaked up from behind, lifted the 125-pound Hammer off his feet in a bear hug, set him down and started to walk away.

headline: 1940: French abandon the Maginot Line
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: 1940: The French abandon the Maginot Line.
lead_paragraph: The German army was making a terrific drive today [June 14] to encircle the French troops defending the Maginot Line. The spokesman of the French War Ministry admitted tonight that the military situation is incontestably very grave. The Associated Press quoted reports from Basel, Switzerland, that the French were abandoning the Maginot Line entirely and had withdrawn their half million fortress troops to a new line extending from Belfort to the Langres plateau and thence to Troyes on the Seine river. — New York Herald Tribune, June 17, 1940

headline: Of All Teams to Hack, Why the Astros?
abstract: What would be the motivation for a phenomenally successful team like the Cardinals poking around the databases of a perennial loser?
lead_paragraph: It might seem a bit like a crooked politician breaking into the office of a rival who is at 2 percent in the polls, or a master spy choosing to snoop around the Embassy of Tonga.

headline: The Broad Museum Picks Up Its Art-Buying Pace
abstract: The collection prepares to open its new contemporary art museum in downtown Los Angeles on Sept. 20.
lead_paragraph: The Broad collection is perpetually growing — the philanthropists Eli and Edythe Broad are known to average one acquisition a week. But now, as the collection prepares to open its new contemporary art museum downtown in Los Angeles on Sept. 20, the Broads have picked up the pace.

headline: Morsi Death Sentence Confirmed by Judge
abstract: A judge in Egypt announced the confirmation of last month’s sentence of Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s first democratically elected president and a member of the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Egypt announced the confirmation of last month’s sentence of Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s first democratically elected president and a member of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Bernie Sanders on the Rise in New Hampshire Polling
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who won the 2008 New Hampshire primary by a whisker, still leads in a new poll, with support from 41 percent of voters in the state. But Senator Bernie Sanders had 31 percent.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont appears to be making headway against Hillary Rodham Clinton among Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire, according to a new poll. His strength is built on support from liberal voters and from men.

headline: Bernie Sanders on the Rise in New Hampshire Polling
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who won the 2008 New Hampshire primary by a whisker, still leads in a new poll, with support from 41 percent of voters in the state. But Senator Bernie Sanders had 31 percent.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont appears to be making headway against Hillary Rodham Clinton among Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire, according to a new poll. His strength is built on support from liberal voters and from men.

headline: Beware Casting Pope Francis as a Caped Climate Crusader
abstract: Efforts to cast Pope Francis’s climate push as a superhero’s mission could lead to disappointment.
lead_paragraph: All eyes are on the Vatican after an Italian news magazine leaked what is very likely the final text (the Italian translation) of Pope Francis’s forthcoming encyclical letter on humanity’s obligations to protect the environment, avoid dangerous climate change and overcome poverty and inequity. The official release of the letter, “Laudato Si’ — On the Care of Our Common Home,” comes Thursday, but interpretations abound already as translations spread. While there are allegations that traditionalists in and around the Catholic Church leaked the text to the magazine to deflate the impact of the release, I don’t see that happening.

headline: Donald Trump on the Issues
abstract: A look at the real estate mogul and celebrity host’s stand on a selection of topics.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s entry into the race for the Republican presidential nomination amounts to his first actual foray into elective politics after several threats. A real estate developer and host of “The Celebrity Apprentice,” he opines about many issues in colorful terms, and is fast on the trigger with denunciations, but does not always make his own policy recommendations clear.

headline: Takashi Murakami Has Been Wearing Vans for 10 Years
abstract: The artist celebrates his loyalty to the brand’s slip-on shoes with a summery capsule collection.
lead_paragraph: Vans and the contemporary artist Takashi Murakami partnered up to create a lively capsule collection of summer sneakers. The limited-edition designs will be released under the premium Vault by Vans line, with Murakami’s signature cheeky, anime-inspired motifs of flowers and skulls printed on unisex sneakers and tees for adults and toddlers. “For the past 10-plus years, without exaggeration, I have been wearing Vans slip-ons almost every single day,” he says. “For me, there are no other shoes that are so comfortably wearable that let me focus on producing my artwork.” Murakami also created skate decks (though they weren’t his first — and probably won’t be his last).

headline: Low Interest Rates Could Limit Growth of Federal Debt, Budget Office Says
abstract: The annual forecast by the Congressional Budget Office showed a small drop, attributable to continued low interest rates, in the long-term outlook for debt levels.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As large as the nation’s postrecession debt is, American taxpayers could catch a break for years to come from continued abnormally low interest rates, which hold down the cost of financing that debt and in turn limit the debt’s growth, congressional analysts said on Tuesday.

headline: Verbatim: The D.N.C.’s Tongue-in-Cheek Welcome to Donald Trump
abstract: A statement sent out to reporters from the Democratic National Committee, welcoming Donald Trump to the 2016 presidential race, with just the slightest hint of sarcasm.
lead_paragraph: — A statement sent out to reporters from the Democratic National Committee, welcoming Donald Trump to the 2016 presidential race, with just the slightest hint of sarcasm.

headline: Egyptian Court Confirms Death Sentence for Mohamed Morsi
abstract: The ousted president’s sentence was among more than 100 handed down last month by the same court after two sweeping mass trials.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian judge on Tuesday confirmed a death sentence against the deposed president Mohamed Morsi, condemning his rule as a “black night” and his Islamist movement as “satanic” and “diabolical.”

headline: What Donald Trump Would Need to Do to Win
abstract: Mr. Trump, a real estate developer and reality television star, has declared himself a candidate for the Republican nomination for president. Here is a look at what he will need to do if he hopes to win.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump, a real estate developer and reality television star, has declared himself a candidate for the Republican nomination for president. Here is a look at what he will need to do if he hopes to win.

headline: Colorado’s Unjust Marijuana Ruling
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Marijuana', 'Medical Marijuana', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The decision shows that the only real solution to marijuana prohibition is a federal solution.
lead_paragraph: It took the Colorado Supreme Court a year to come up with the ruling, issued on Monday, that upheld the firing of a man who used medical marijuana legally under state law to help ease the pain he has suffered since a car accident left him paralyzed. A lot of that time had to be devoted to twisting the logic behind the decision.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale Sets a Record
abstract: Sunday’s season finale drew 8.1 million viewers, the most for any episode of the series, which has become HBO’s most-viewed show.
lead_paragraph: “Game of Thrones” set a series record for total viewers with its season finale Sunday night with 8.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen. The HBO show’s previous record was the season premiere in April, which attracted eight million viewers. Last year’s season finale brought in 7.1 million viewers.

headline: Blanca
abstract: Adventurous food with an Italian underpinning from Carlo Mirarchi in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Adventurous food with an Italian underpinning from Carlo Mirarchi in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: Restaurant Review: Blanca in Bushwick, Brooklyn
abstract: An extensive tasting menu features dishes that demonstrate the chef Carlo Mirarchi’s serious approach to luxuriously crafted food.
lead_paragraph: When Blanca opened in 2012, a 27-course tasting menu served at a counter behind a pizzeria in Bushwick sounded like the setup to a joke. (Second prize is 30 courses.) The restaurant does have its sense of humor, but it quickly proved that about cooking for maximum pleasure, it was unswervingly serious.

headline: Haitian Workers Facing Deportation by Dominican Neighbors
abstract: Undocumented workers in the Dominican Republic have until Wednesday to register their presence in the country, in the hope of ultimately being allowed to stay.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Hundreds of thousands of migrant workers are facing deportation from the Dominican Republic, the latest in a series of actions by the government that have cast a light on the country’s long-troubled relationship with its Haitian neighbors.

abstract: The prime minister said austerity measures were humiliating and strangling his people as a meeting of European finance ministers neared.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Greece’s prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, on Tuesday blasted his country’s creditors for austerity measures that he said were humiliating and strangling his people as pressure mounted on Athens to present reforms in exchange for bailout funding.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']

lead_paragraph: DERRY, N.H. — Jeb Bush said Tuesday that the enhanced interrogation techniques deployed by his brother after Sept. 11 attacks were no longer appropriate, that he hoped the Supreme Court would rule against same-sex marriage, and mocked Hillary Rodham Clinton for passing few laws during her eight years in the Senate.

headline: Boston Revises Bid in Effort to Host 2024 Olympics
abstract: The city developed an overhauled plan that would move more events to other parts of Massachusetts, and maybe beyond.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Boston 2024, the private group organizing the city’s bid to host the 2024 Summer Olympics, unveiled its plans in January, it boasted that it would put on “the most walkable Games in modern times.”

headline: Kirk Kerkorian, Billionaire Investor in Film Studios and Casinos, Dies at 98

lead_paragraph: Kirk Kerkorian, the media-shy investor who became one of the richest Americans by betting his money on ventures like casinos and film studios, died Monday night at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 98.

headline: As Stress Drives Off Drone Operators, Air Force Must Cut Flights
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: Long hours and the psychological toll of the work have forced the Pentagon to abandon its goal of increasing the flights and to instead reduce the number.
lead_paragraph: CREECH AIR FORCE BASE, Nev. — After a decade of waging long-distance war through their video screens, America’s drone operators are burning out, and the Air Force is being forced to cut back on the flights even as military and intelligence officials are demanding more of them over intensifying combat zones in Iraq, Syria and Yemen.

headline: United to Leave J.F.K. and Shift West Coast Flights to Newark
abstract: The airline said it had failed to turn a profit at Kennedy International Airport in recent years because passengers had no options to connect once they landed there.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said on Tuesday that it would move out of Kennedy International Airport in October, after failing to make a profit there for seven years, and will shift all of its flights to Los Angeles and San Francisco to its hub in Newark.

headline: Choice Words From Donald Trump, Presidential Candidate

headline: House Moves to Delay Action on Trade Bill for 6 Weeks
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The effort would give the House until the end of July to try and line up votes needed to give President Obama fast-track trade negotiating authority.

headline: During Ramadan, Dates Are a Unifying Staple
abstract: Out of respect for tradition, Muslim communities of the world break their fasts with the fruit, which is always available.
lead_paragraph: When the chef Sameh Wadi was growing up — first in Kuwait, then in Jordan, and finally in Minneapolis and St. Paul — one of the few constants in his life was his mother’s cooking, especially the date-filled ring cookies called ka’ak that she made by hand and stockpiled during Ramadan.

headline: Belichick, Snowden and Hack Wilson: Twitter Reacts to Cardinals Scandal
abstract: Twitter reacted to the Cardinals-Astros hacking news as Twitter often reacts to sports stories: with witticisms, a sense of schadenfreude and Patriots jokes.
lead_paragraph: News that the F.B.I. and the Justice Department are investigating whether front-office officials for the St. Louis Cardinals hacked into the internal networks of the Houston Astros drew immediate reaction on social media on Tuesday. The Cardinals — one of the most successful teams in baseball — have a huge national fan base. But the Twitter-verse loves to see the mighty fall, and commenters rushed to jump on the pile:

headline: As Vladimir Putin Talks More Missiles and Might, Cost Tells Another Story
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: With the relationship between the Kremlin and the West growing more confrontational, a new arms race proceeds, though with less than Cold War vigor.
lead_paragraph: KUBINKA, Russia — They call it “Russia’s military Disneyland,” and the underlying idea that Russia will soon field a high-tech, modernized army was indeed part fantasy. But the bristling array of armaments underlined how military competition had overtaken diplomacy in East-West relations.

headline: Age 16, and Not Too Young to Join the Community Board
abstract: This is the first year that 16- and 17-year-olds can join New York City’s local advisory groups. Nineteen were appointed, and many of them began attending meetings this month.
lead_paragraph: Being a teenager in New York has always conferred unrivaled access to adult privileges. No cars are needed to get around town. Over-21 beverages are easily found.

headline: Black Like Who? Rachel Dolezal’s Harmful Masquerade
abstract: I will accept her as black like me only when society can accept me as white like her.
lead_paragraph: Rachel A. Dolezal, who stepped down Monday as president of the Spokane, Wash., chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., could have been a powerful ally to African-Americans. The participation of white allies has always been important to anti-racism work. By most accounts, she is educated about black cultures and an advocate for black causes. But empathy evolved into impersonation. And Ms. Dolezal’s subterfuge, made easier by the legacy of racism in America, undermines the very people she claims to support.

headline: Google Is Its Own Secret Weapon in the Cloud
abstract: Google is becoming more public about its data centers, talking about its network and how much fiber it owns. The idea is to show off assets that Amazon, Microsoft and IBM cannot match in the competition for cloud customers.
lead_paragraph: Google is wielding a new weapon against Amazon and Microsoft for cloud computing customers: itself.

headline: Israel’s Ludicrous Spoof of Western Journalists
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'News and News Media', 'Palestinians']
abstract: The Israeli government’s video lampooning Western journalists who cover Gaza is offensive and decidedly unfunny.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t have a good story to tell, a tried and tested tactic is to lampoon the press.

headline: Can DNA Testing Personalize Skin Care?
abstract: A London company says the testing can match skin care to the individual.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — What’s being billed as the future of skin care starts suspiciously like a visit to the dentist: with a mouthwash gargle. That’s to eliminate debris that may interfere with a good saliva sample, from which DNA will be extracted and serums tailored to one’s genetic blueprint.

headline: Reading About Racial Boundaries
abstract: Passing is a longstanding theme in American fiction and the subject of several riveting nonfiction books.
lead_paragraph: “I identify as black,” Rachel A. Dolezal told NBC’s “Today” show on Tuesday. Ms. Dolezal’s resignation of her post as an N.A.A.C.P. official in Washington State after accusations that she misrepresented her racial background is the water-cooler story of the week.

headline: A Chicken Tagine That Gives Rhubarb the Last Say
abstract: This dish replaces preserved lemon with poached rhubarb for a twist on a Moroccan classic.
lead_paragraph: When I was in Paris last month, I was inspired by the generous stacks of rhubarb in markets all over the city. It was the same last year when I visited my brother Dan and his dedicated rhubarb garden in Minneapolis. The plant has been in season since late April in temperate zones, and it will last through the summer.

headline: Review: Eddo Stern’s ‘Vietnam Romance’ Is Art You Can Watch or Play
abstract: With its video game metaphor, this exhibition at Postmasters examines the fuzzy border between war and games.
lead_paragraph: Video games surpassed Hollywood movies in popularity over a half-decade ago, but few artists have dealt seriously with the aesthetics or technology of the form. Eddo Stern is an exception, and his current project, “Vietnam Romance” (2015), is a seasoned meditation on the relationship between war and gaming.

headline: The Trans-Pacific Partnership: Questions and Answers
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Understanding the 12-nation trade deal and the issues affecting its consideration in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a decade of negotiations among a dozen nations, the trade deal known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, or T.P.P., is almost complete and ready for final consideration by Congress. But before President Obama can present the final document for approval, Congress must vote to give him the right to limit consideration of the T.P.P. to a single up-or-down vote, with no filibusters or amendments allowed. That is called trade promotion authority, or T.P.A., and, so far, Mr. Obama has failed to get it.

headline: MGM Buys Rights to ‘Primates of Park Avenue’
abstract: The book about Upper East Side wives was the subject of interest from several studios.
lead_paragraph: First it was gloated over for its schadenfreude, then it was denounced for supposedly being “full of lies.” Now, Wednesday Martin’s best-selling “Primates of Park Avenue” – an “anthropological memoir” of the author’s time among the super rich of the Upper East Side – is bound for the silver screen.

headline: Leak of Pope’s Encyclical on Climate Change Hints at Tensions in Vatican
abstract: The unexpected leak has raised questions about who caused it, whether they meant to embarrass the pope and if it portends larger fights to come.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The unexpected leak of Pope Francis’ much-anticipated environmental encyclical has meant the return of something that not long ago was fairly common around the Vatican but had become often dormant during the two-plus years of Francis’ mostly charmed papacy: intrigue.

headline: The Larger-Than-Life Highlights of Art Basel’s Unlimited Sector
abstract: Ryan McGinley, Leigh Ledare and Ai Weiwei contributed standout works to the fair’s scaled-up segment.
lead_paragraph: Opening a day before the main fair at Art Basel, the Unlimited sector is devoted to displaying gigantic, bright-hued, deeply ambitious, booth-bursting works that are so epic in scale as to inspire … a whole lot of double-taps on Instagram. And Basel undoubtedly will offer thousands of photo-worthy opportunities as the week goes on, both in and outside the main fair. Design/Miami is opening up across the street from Unlimited, with Standard Hotels head honcho Andre Balazs acting as curator of design at large. The hippest young kids show at Liste just across town, including the New York shops Essex Street and Bushwick’s Clearing. And of course there are the high-octane art dinners and parties: the trek out to the Foundation Beyeler, the salon between Tina Brown and Tino Sehgal followed by a feast at the Museum für Gegenwartskunst, Tolga Albayrak’s globetrotting art bash Tolga’s Fair Club and countless lavish nights at the city’s crown jewel, the Grand Hotel Trois Rois.

headline: A ‘Star Wars’ Inspired Runway Show With Galactic Support
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Movies', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: The designer Bobby Abley references Darth Vader, “Chewy” and more characters from the films in his spring 2016 London men’s wear show.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The force is with Bobby Abley, a London-based men’s wear designer who had his first solo runway show here on Monday. Much of Mr. Abley’s collection for the spring and summer of 2016 referenced characters from the “Star Wars” franchise.

lead_paragraph: American workers, entrepreneurs, immigrants and a few readers supporting big employers illustrated the complexity of the immigration reform debate with their responses to an editorial about abuses in a high-tech visa program.

abstract: The tour begins in September in Providence, R.I.
lead_paragraph: Abby Mueller is set to play the title role in “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical,” the role for which her sister, Jessie, won a Tony Award last year.

headline: Migrant’s Funeral in Berlin Highlights Europe’s Refugee Crisis
abstract: As part of demonstrations happening across the Continent, a reburial was staged for a Syrian woman who died at sea in March.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A 34-year-old woman was buried in a Berlin cemetery on Tuesday, thousands of miles from her home in Syria and hundreds from the shores of Italy that eluded her while she was alive.

headline: In Savannah, Where Change Is Slow, an Art District Is Catching On
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Art']
abstract: The Starland District, anchored by a former dairy, is attracting art studios, offices, galleries and cafes to what once was a derelict neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — The idea of a vanguard arts district may seem counterintuitive in this slow-paced city of courtly manners and stately architecture, but after almost two decades, an emerging area called the Starland District may finally be hitting its stride.

headline: More Florida Fun
abstract: Of bubbles and the saving grace of big government.
lead_paragraph: Others are picking up on the sheer amazingness — make that amazingness! — of Jeb! citing the record of bubble-era Florida as proof of his skill in economic management. Jim Tankersley adds some data to the picture. But I think there are a couple of additional important points to make here.

headline: Far-Right Parties Form Coalition in European Parliament
abstract: The new bloc, which opposes immigration and big government, will be led by Marine Le Pen, the leader of France’s National Front.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than a year after populist, far-right parties surged in elections for the European Parliament, several of them announced on Tuesday that they had finally banded together with the goal of raising their political profile.

headline: 21st Century Fox Announces New Murdoch Roles
abstract: The company confirmed expected changes in leadership, with James Murdoch becoming chief executive and his brother, Lachlan, executive co-chairman.
lead_paragraph: The media conglomerate 21st Century Fox announced on Tuesday that Rupert Murdoch’s two sons would assume new leadership roles in the company, continuing the elder Mr. Murdoch’s plans to keep control of the company in his family.

headline: Eager to Go, Giants’ Defense Waits on Jason Pierre-Paul
abstract: Pierre-Paul, who had 12 sacks last season, has mostly stayed away from team activities after the Giants tagged him as a nonexclusive franchise player.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Steve Spagnuolo’s eagerness to restore the Giants to the heights they enjoyed in his first tenure as defensive coordinator in 2007 and 2008 was readily apparent when he met with reporters Tuesday at the start of a mandatory three-day minicamp. So were his limitations.

headline: Military Spouses, Facing Deployment, but Not Alone
abstract: As I looked ahead to my husband’s long term deployment, I felt as if I were drowning—until the Navy issued me a life preserver.
lead_paragraph: “Drowning is silent.” During my high school life-guarding days, our manager used to repeat the phrase in earnest. Lately, the verbiage has played in a loop in my mind, as I struggle physically and emotionally with my husband’s coming deployment.

headline: Phoebe English Aces Men’s Wear With Her Debut Capsule Collection
abstract: The designer, one of fashion’s most exciting new designers, showed looks with just the right amount of frayed edges, natural fabrics and deconstruction.
lead_paragraph: Women’s wear designers don’t often succeed in translating their points of view to men’s wear — or vice versa. But in her debut effort today, Phoebe English made a seamless transition with a capsule collection of easy, oversize men’s clothes, appropriating just the right signatures — frayed edges, natural fabrics, deconstruction — to make it work.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting interesting stories from around the web. In this installment, great reads from Fernanda Santos, Jenna Wortham and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Generic A.D.H.D. Drug, Not Equivalent to the Brand, Is in Use Anyway
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Ritalin (Drug)']
abstract: The F.D.A. says that two generic versions of Concerta, an extended-release form of Ritalin for A.D.H.D., don’t measure up to the brand drug. But both are still on the market.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Louis Kraus, a chief of child psychiatry at a hospital in Chicago, writes prescriptions for patients who have attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, he often chooses Concerta, an extended-release form of the drug Ritalin that gives patients relief from their symptoms for as long as 12 hours.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week Street Style
abstract: Fashion fans and models take to the streets during the spring 2016 men’s collection shows in London.
lead_paragraph: Fashion fans and models take to the streets during the spring 2016 men’s collection shows in London.

headline: Review: ‘The Tribe’ Communicates Without Words
abstract: This Ukrainian film by the director Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy relies on body language — the actors speak using only sign language.
lead_paragraph: “The Tribe,” set at a Ukrainian boarding school for the deaf, unfolds without spoken dialogue or subtitles. The members of the nonprofessional, mostly deaf cast communicate in sign language, and while much of the audience will remain ignorant of the nuances, and even the basic sense, of their interactions — we learn the characters’ names only in the final credits — the film isn’t obscure or especially confusing. Written and directed by Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy, it’s something of a formal tour de force, a triumphant overcoming of self-imposed cinematic challenges.

headline: Trailer: BAMCinemaFest
abstract: A preview for the festival.
lead_paragraph: A preview for the festival.

headline: At Margaret Howell, J.W. Anderson, Burberry, Alexander McQueen and Craig Green, Bigger Is Not Necessarily Better
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Margaret Howell, J.W. Anderson, Burberry, Alexander McQueen and Craig Green embody the funk and finesse that set the men’s wear shows apart.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In this city, men’s fashion week wends inevitably, ineluctably to the pub. That British institution (unlike the suit, the coat, the tie, the shoe and almost any other institution that intersects with the twice-yearly men’s wear shows here) is all but impervious to change.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects 2 Antitrust Cases
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Liquid Crystal Displays', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The cases, one criminal and the other civil, involved an international cartel’s price-fixing of liquid-crystal displays used in computers and cellphones.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court this week declined to review a pair of antitrust cases involving an international price-fixing cartel, despite the urging of some legal experts, economists and the National Association of Manufacturers.

headline: Stained Glass at Riverside Church Removed for Repairs
abstract: Over the next few weeks, workmen will be taking down 30 windows for restoration. In the meantime, translucent photographs of some panels will be on display.
lead_paragraph: Chiseling at sooty, buckling and leaky portraits of medieval saints in radiant red and blue, workmen are hoisting about 30 stained-glass windows out of Riverside Church in Manhattan. For the next few weeks, crews from Clagnan Stained Glass Studio in Wall Township, N.J., advised by the Massachusetts consultant Julie L. Sloan, will be digging out chunks of caulk to release the panes. Designed in the 1920s by the prominent Boston glass workshops of Wilbur H. Burnham and Wright Goodhue, the the stained-glass panels will undergo a year of repair at Clagnan.

headline: Reading The Times With Santiago Calatrava
abstract: The architect Santiago Calatrava reads The New York Times of June 16, 2015.
lead_paragraph: Santiago Calatrava is a Spanish architect, structural engineer, sculptor and painter. His projects include the World Trade Center Transportation Hub, which opens this month; the Park Avenue Sculptures, installed last week along the central median on Park Avenue between 52nd and 55th Streets in New York City, are on view through November.

headline: BAMcinemaFest Opts to Be Unlikable and Thought-Provoking
abstract: BAMcinemaFest, with less expectations for buzz or deal-making, this year offers movies whose characters are uncomfortable in one another’s company.
lead_paragraph: At six years old, BAMcinemaFest is less encumbered by hype and expectation than other, more established festivals. It shares independent-film DNA (and a few high-profile films) with Sundance, but it doesn’t inspire the same level of hand-wringing about the State of Indie. Nor does it mimic the busyness and buzz — or the corporate slickness — of Tribeca. Even though its native turf in Brooklyn is highly contested, newly glamorous cultural space, the festival is defined by an aesthetic of intellectual curiosity, understated ambition and easygoing eclecticism. You go to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, see some movies, and wander into Fort Greene afterward, looking for a pint of craft beer and a place to sit and talk about what you saw.

headline: Review: ‘The Pavilion,’ a Class Reunion Drama, at Barrow Group Theater
abstract: In Craig Wright’s comic romance, Kari and Peter meet again at their 20th high school reunion, and he wants her back.
lead_paragraph: To have survived adolescence is to wish for a do-over, the chance to take another crack at some fundamental, inescapable decision made so badly the first time around.

headline: Focus and Strategy Shift in Hunt for 2 Escaped Killers
abstract: The New York State Police, seemingly no closer to finding Richard W. Matt and David Sweat, abandoned a “grid search” and said they would instead pursue fresh leads.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — On Friday, Maj. Charles E. Guess of the New York State Police sounded full of confidence, saying law enforcement officials were making progress tracking the two killers who had escaped from the maximum-security prison here.

headline: Moving Wikipedia From Computer to Many, Many Bookshelves
abstract: The interdisciplinary artist Michael Mandiberg’s exhibition, “From Aaaaa! to ZZZap!” at the Denny Gallery, features his larger project called “Print Wikipedia.”
lead_paragraph: The Wikipedia entry for “quixoticism” runs only about 255 words. But if anyone could argue for a personal mention, it might be Michael Mandiberg.

lead_paragraph: A family story about a grandfather who was lost and raised by another family led Jorge Panchoaga to “La Casa Grande” — “The Big House” — in which he explores notions of home and identity.

headline: In Return to Twitter, Jack Dorsey Aims to Follow Path of Steve Jobs
abstract: When Steve Jobs returned to Apple, he saved the company. It remains to be seen whether Jack Dorsey can do the same at Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps we should blame Steve Jobs for Jack Dorsey’s reappointment as Twitter’s interim chief executive.

abstract: At the Sorocaba Zoo in Brazil, a flamingo is walking again with a prosthetic leg.
lead_paragraph: At the Sorocaba Zoo in Brazil, a flamingo is walking again with a prosthetic leg.
