abstract: Robert Wiesenthal will become chief executive of Blade, an on-demand app service he co-founded that shuttles customers by helicopter and small plane.
lead_paragraph: Robert Wiesenthal, the chief operating officer of the Warner Music Group and a longtime entertainment industry executive, is planning to resign to lead a start-up company that promises to be the Uber of helicopters.

headline: Anne Gaylor, 88, Dies; Guarded Wall Between Church and State
abstract: Ms. Gaylor was the principal founder of the Freedom From Religion Foundation, the nation’s largest group of atheists and agnostics.
lead_paragraph: Anne Nicol Gaylor, who transformed a local campaign for abortion rights into a national crusade to maintain the separation of church and state, died on June 14 at a hospice in Fitchburg, Wis., near Madison. She was 88.

headline: Review: ‘The Astronaut Wives Club’ Examines the Paper Dolls Behind the Men of Steel
abstract: This new ABC series puts its own shiny gloss on the women married to the men of Project Mercury.
lead_paragraph: In “The Right Stuff,” Tom Wolfe writes that the first astronauts’ wives were presented as “seven flawless cameo-faced dolls sitting in the family room with their pageboy bobs in place, ready to offer any and all aid to the brave lads.”

headline: John Kasich, Ohio’s Republican Rebel, Nears Run for President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Kasich, the moderate, shoot-from-the-hip Republican governor of a crucial swing state, is expected to announce his entry into the race in July.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — The last time John R. Kasich contemplated running for president, as an ambitious congressman in 1999, he tried courting Republicans in Iowa only to discover that even the reporter trailing him from his home state, Ohio, was more enthralled with the Texas governor, George W. Bush.

headline: San Francisco Festival of Ethnic Dance
abstract: An annual dance festival celebrates the choreography native to the many cultures that have become American.
lead_paragraph: An annual dance festival celebrates the choreography native to the many cultures that have become American.

headline: Review: Ethnic Festival Dancers Follow the Footsteps of a Heritage
abstract: An annual dance festival celebrates the choreography native to the many cultures that have become American.
lead_paragraph: I know of no regular event that more effectively, more movingly, recommends this country’s diverse inclusiveness than the annual San Francisco Festival of Ethnic Dance. The companies appearing aren’t visitors from other countries; they’re American. But they perform the dances of other lands — in most cases, dances they are preserving as their racial or national heritage — and with exuberant pride. Each year, the festival presents a different program on each of four consecutive weekends. If I lived in or near California, I would attend all four, every year. (The auditions alone are celebrated.) Each year’s presentations contain surprises.

headline: Other Viewpoints on the Link Between Race and Identity
abstract: Reactions to statements by Rachel A. Dolezal, the former president of the Spokane, Wash., N.A.A.C.P. chapter and a university instructor in African-American studies, who has claimed for years that her heritage is partly black — a claim her parents say is a lie.
lead_paragraph: Reactions to statements by Rachel A. Dolezal, the former president of the Spokane, Wash., N.A.A.C.P. chapter and a university instructor in African-American studies, who has claimed for years that her heritage is partly black — a claim her parents say is a lie.

abstract: About a half-hour’s drive from Barcelona or from the coastal resort of Sitges, the home is on the market for $1,017,000.
lead_paragraph: About a half-hour’s drive from Barcelona or from the coastal resort of Sitges, the home is on the market for $1,017,000.

headline: Review: Vendela Vida’s ‘The Diver’s Clothes Lie Empty’ Offers Freedom to Escape
abstract: Ms. Vida’s fourth book is about a shifty American whose terrible decisions keep the narrative moving at a taut and suspenseful clip.
lead_paragraph: Vendela Vida’s heroines have a particular talent for suffering. When their marriages cool or ancient family secrets worm into the light, these women take their troubles on holiday. They prefer to do their grieving somewhere picturesque: the Philippines (“And Now You Can Go,” 2003), Finland (“Let the Northern Lights Erase Your Name,” 2007), Turkey (“The Lovers,” 2010). Ms. Vida has become known for these travel/trauma narratives, wry, amiable novels prone to some clunkiness; the gears always grind a bit loudly. Nothing in them anticipates the smooth engineering of “The Diver’s Clothes Lie Empty,” her fourth and finest book, a taut, suspenseful story that ticks along with marvelous efficiency, like a little bomb.

headline: St. Louis Cardinals Manager’s Reaction
abstract: Mike Matheny responded to an investigation by the F.B.I. and federal prosecutors into whether the St. Louis baseball team hacked into the computers of the Houston Astros.
lead_paragraph: Mike Matheny responded to an investigation by the F.B.I. and federal prosecutors into whether the St. Louis baseball team hacked into the computers of the Houston Astros.

headline: Greenberg’s Firm Vows to Appeal A.I.G. Ruling
abstract: While it prevailed in its legal argument, Starr International still thinks the government owes money to shareholders of the insurance giant.
lead_paragraph: A moral victory wasn’t enough.

headline: Stephen Curry’s Mouth Guard: An Investigation
abstract: On the oral fixations of athletes.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Curry is a delirious and incorrigible show-off: He not only throws no-look passes, he also shoots no-look 3-pointers. He’s a boy wonder: See him for the first time on television and you might mistake him for a 12-year-old. (In reality he is 27, and 6 feet 3 inches tall.) He’s an egomaniac, sort of (but who isn’t, in the N.B.A.?). In 2013, an interviewer asked him whom he would pick to shoot, given one chance to win a game and a lineup of Michael Jordan, Kobe Bryant, Ray Allen, Reggie Miller — and Stephen Curry. Curry said: Jordan. But after Jordan, he continued, “I’m No. 2.” At the time, he was 25. He has since become the game’s greatest scorer.

headline: As Fed Edges Toward Rate Increases, Investors Turn Cautious
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Fed officials have emphasized that they expect rate increases to disrupt financial markets, increasing volatility after a long period of tranquility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This is not the moment the Federal Reserve will start to raise interest rates. But that day is coming, and investors are getting nervous.

headline: Bird Flu Sends Egg Prices Up, but Slowing Demand Prevents Shortages
keywords: ['Eggs', 'Avian Influenza', 'Shortages', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: A decline in egg production by 341 million dozen this year is expected to mean a wholesale price of $1.60 to $1.66 for a dozen New York large eggs, a record high.
lead_paragraph: Are egg prices up significantly?

headline: Brooklyn Academy of Music Seeks to Unify Its Campus With Art
abstract: The Brooklyn Academy of Music plans to use four public art installations to create a campus feel for its multibuilding cultural center.
lead_paragraph: It’s a campus of sorts, but the Brooklyn Academy of Music‘s buildings can appear to be separate, individual structures. So BAM is looking to remedy that by starting a new public art program with $3.5 million from the Robert W. Wilson Charitable Trust, the academy is to announce on Tuesday.

headline: Blackhawks Bask in the Moment, but Salary Cap Concerns Loom
abstract: The Blackhawks’ front office will have to work to figure out how to keep some of the team’s best players.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In the what-have-you-done-for-me-lately world of professional sports, it was inevitable that Joel Quenneville, the coach of the newly minted Stanley Cup champion Chicago Blackhawks, would be asked Monday night how he planned to continue the team’s remarkable success, which has yielded three championships in six seasons.

headline: Nintendo Makes Unusual Move at E3: Sharing Its Characters
abstract: Nintendo announced that it had reached a deal with Activision to allow two iconic Nintendo characters – Donkey Kong and Bowser — to appear in the next Skylanders game.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – It was easy to miss, but Nintendo made something of an unusual move for the company at this E3 games conference.

keywords: ['Steel and Iron', 'Ruble (Currency)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']

lead_paragraph: CHEREPOVETS, Russia — Burly steel workers in this gritty industrial town have their choice of free services at the company spa in a leafy park down the road from the factory.

headline: A Candidate at Last, Jeb Bush Bounces Into New Hampshire
abstract: Jeb Bush, a former Florida governor, seemed playful and relaxed at a town hall-style meeting in Derry, N.H., a day after announcing his presidential candidacy.
lead_paragraph: DERRY, N.H. — On his first day as a full-fledged, no-longer-just-thinking-about-it candidate for president, Jeb Bush called his adopted hometown Miami “a crazy, wacky place.” He spoke of the trauma of discovering that a hacker had published personal emails he had written about the health of his father. He gave a long, emotional hug to a woman who told of her decades-long struggle with mental disabilities.

headline: College Student in Queens Is Charged With Conspiring to Support ISIS
abstract: Munther Omar Saleh, 20, a student living in Queens who was arrested Saturday, is accused of plotting to attack New York City on behalf of the Islamic State, the authorities say.
lead_paragraph: A college student in Queens has been charged with conspiring to support a foreign terrorist organization after a monthslong investigation found that he was planning to attack various New York City landmarks on behalf of the Islamic State, according to the authorities.

headline: Lodging Taxes and Airbnb Hosts: Who Pays, and How
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The “sharing” economy has led to more scrutiny from local governments that require hosts to collect and pay occupancy taxes for short-term rentals.
lead_paragraph: Renting out a spare bedroom, or your entire house, to make some extra money is easier to do these days, thanks to online listing services and the mushrooming “sharing” economy. But inexperienced owners may be unaware that they usually must collect and pay hotel taxes due on short-term rentals.

headline: Bravado and High Returns From Italian Fund Manager
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Investment returns match the bravado of Davide Serra, a London-based Italian hedge fund manager, who believes quantitative easing will continue.

headline: Palestinian Government Is Expected to Resign
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority told leaders of his political party on Tuesday that the government would resign within 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority told leaders of his political party on Tuesday that the government he formed a year ago after signing a reconciliation pact with the rival Hamas movement would resign within 24 hours, according to a senior Palestinian official and local news reports.

headline: Senate Votes to Turn Presidential Ban on Torture Into Law
keywords: ['Torture', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Interrogations', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: A 2005 law prohibited the Pentagon from using harsh interrogation methods, but did not apply to the C.I.A. and other agencies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted Tuesday to ban the use of torture, moving to ensure that the government does not return to interrogation techniques like waterboarding.

headline: Chip Makers Renew Pleas to Congress for Trade Bill
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Computers and the Internet', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Computer Chips']
abstract: American chip makers say that, without the trade deal, they will be squeezed out of the growing Asian market for computer chips by competitors in countries like China.
lead_paragraph: In mid-April, 33 executives from rival Silicon Valley companies hurried from building to building on Capitol Hill to push lawmakers to grant President Obama the authority to finish a trade deal with Asian countries. Showing a rare cooperative front, they told the lawmakers that the deal would protect intellectual property and the companies’ ability to sell electronics across the Pacific Ocean.

headline: New York’s Lawmakers Agree on Campus Sexual Assault Laws
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: The deal was announced on what was thought to be the penultimate day of this year’s legislative session, but a number of other issues remained unresolved.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — New York’s political leaders have reached a deal on one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s legislative priorities for 2015, saying they will adopt new laws intended to change the way sexual assaults on all college campuses in the state are handled.

headline: G.M. and Nissan Reusing Old Electric Car Batteries
abstract: The automakers’ efforts reflect the importance of finding a way to harvest used batteries because batteries are expensive to produce and hard to recycle or dispose of properly, said Karl Brauer of Kelley Blue Book.
lead_paragraph: For years, automakers have looked for ways to reuse the batteries from electric cars, which retain significant storage capacity even after they are no longer useful for transport.

headline: U.S. Could Lift Sanctions Before Iran Accounting
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: John Kerry suggested that major sanctions might be lifted before international inspectors get answers to questions about Iranian experiments and work that appeared aimed at developing a bomb.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry signaled for the first time on Tuesday that the United States was prepared to ease economic sanctions on Iran without fully resolving evidence suggesting that Iran’s scientists have been involved in secret work on nuclear weapons.

headline: Jeb Bush Slow Jams in Two Tongues With Jimmy Fallon
abstract: Jeb Bush, on “The Tonight Show” on Tuesday, covered his stance on immigration in Jimmy Fallon’s recurring Slow Jam the News segment.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush got the “slow jam” treatment from Jimmy Fallon on “The Tonight Show” on Tuesday night, and he reiterated in rhyme that he was finally ready to hit the campaign trail and have “spirited debates” with his fellow Republicans about how to solve America’s problems.

headline: A Conversation With James H. Coleman
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: Mr. Coleman is the founder and managing partner of Hanley Advisors, a boutique real estate consulting and advisory firm.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Coleman, 53, is the founder and managing partner of Hanley Advisors, a boutique real estate consulting and advisory firm based in New York. He recently served as an adviser and broker to the Swiss luxury goods company Richemont in its $700 million sale of a retail condominium at the St. Regis Hotel to Vornado Realty Trust.

headline: In Turnabout, Disney Cancels Tech Worker Layoffs
abstract: Employees who were previously laid off and had to train their foreign replacements have had their jobs restored with no explanation.
lead_paragraph: In late May, about 35 technology employees at Disney/ABC Television in New York and Burbank, Calif., received jarring news. Managers told them that they would all be laid off, and that during their final weeks they would have to train immigrants brought in by an outsourcing company to do their jobs.

headline: Stop and Quiz: Police Cast a Net for Runaways
abstract: Luna Raposo-Dean, 13, just wanted to get to her drum lesson, but an officer insisted on some by-the-book interference.
lead_paragraph: Last week, on one of those June half-days, Luna Raposo-Dean, 13, left her middle school on West 48th Street in Manhattan just after noon and walked a few blocks en route to a drum lesson. At the corner of 40th Street and Eighth Avenue, a police officer approached her. It was outside the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

headline: House Republicans Ease Opposition to Needle Exchanges
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Medicine and Health', 'States (US)', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Heroin', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Hepatitis', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The shift is a result of a health crisis related to a rise in heroin use in many of their home states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Faced with a health crisis resulting from a rise in heroin use in many of their home states, House Republicans are easing their longstanding opposition to federal funding in support of needle exchange programs.

headline: If Cardinals Hacked, Their Gamesmanship Crossed the Line
abstract: Hacking into a rival’s database would go beyond baseball’s usual boundaries.
lead_paragraph: The jokes came rolling in on Tuesday afternoon as the news spread that the F.B.I. and the Justice Department were investigating the St. Louis Cardinals, accusing them of breaking into the Houston Astros’ proprietary database network.

headline: Panel Urges Changes in Using U.N. Soldiers
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An independent review recommended holding peacekeeping soldiers more accountable for sexual abuse and other crimes, and urged that they no longer be used in counterterrorism operations.
lead_paragraph: An independent panel reviewing United Nations peacekeeping operations recommended sweeping changes on Tuesday to make the blue-helmeted soldiers more accountable for sexual abuse and other crimes, and urged that they no longer be used in counterterrorism operations.

headline: Pope’s Views on Climate Change Add Pressure to Catholic Candidates
abstract: A Florida archbishop will press the pope’s climate change message in the hope that it will resonate in particular with Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the steamy hurricane season descends on Miami, the city’s Roman Catholic archbishop, Thomas G. Wenski, is planning a summer of sermons, homilies and press events designed to highlight the threat that a warming planet, rising sea levels and more extreme storms pose to his community’s poorest and most vulnerable.

headline: Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson Hope for Revival at Open
abstract: For much of two decades, Woods and Mickelson have propped up American golf as its twin pillars, but lately their games have shown signs of decay.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — At 8 o’clock on an overcast Tuesday morning, several fans bearing steaming cups of coffee stood in the cold around the Chambers Bay practice green and watched Phil Mickelson chip. As Mickelson hit ball after ball close to the pins, one fan said, “If he can chip like that, he’ll give himself a chance.”

lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — The No. 1 player in the world does not usually play second fiddle to anyone. And yet, that is where Rory McIlroy has found himself on the eve of the 115th United States Open.

headline: Bahrain Opposition Leader Sentenced to 4 Years in Prison
abstract: Sheikh Ali Salman, secretary general of Al Wefaq, who had made speeches seeking reform, was convicted of inciting hatred and insulting institutions.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A court in Bahrain sentenced the leader of the country’s largest opposition movement to four years in prison on Tuesday, reflecting an escalating push by the government to silence dissident voices in the island kingdom.

headline: Suleyman Demirel, Seven Times Turkey’s Prime Minister, Dies at 90
abstract: A remarkable political survivor, Mr. Demirel dominated his country’s affairs for almost 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Suleyman Demirel, who served seven times as Turkey’s prime minister, dominating the nation’s politics when the country struggled with violence, economic stagnation and military rule, died on Wednesday in Ankara, Turkey. He was 90.

headline: De Blasio and Bloomberg Trade Rare Praise. No Hug, Though.
abstract: In a rare joint appearance, Mayor Bill de Blasio complimented former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Roosevelt Island.
lead_paragraph: There were handshakes and some chitchat, a shared smile or two, and, later, rare praise lobbed from across a stage.

headline: At 37, Tommy Haas Hopes to Make the Most of Latest Comeback
abstract: Haas, a German who recently came back from another shoulder surgery, lost in the first round of the Gerry Weber Open in Halle, Germany.
lead_paragraph: HALLE, Germany — Tommy Haas is largely unsure what the future holds for him, but he does have one set plan this week.

headline: Home of the Elves
abstract: David J. Kahn collaborates with Molly Young on her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I have a philosophy. [Here we go. Everyone get comfortable. –Ed.] This philosophy says that, if at first you don’t succeed, try, try again but, in all subsequent attempts, be as snarky as possible about it. [That’s not “your” philosophy. That’s your twisted interpretation of it. –Ed.]

headline: Review: David Mamet’s ‘Ghost Stories,’ Bedtime Tales With a Gunshot
abstract: The Atlantic Theater presents two early Mamet one-acts, “Prairie du Chien,” from 1979, and “The Shawl,” from 1985.
lead_paragraph: The lullaby of the locomotive has soothed the child to sleep. Or is it the soft, steady voice of the stranger in the train’s parlor car, telling a story to the boy’s father? Both noises are charged with a cadence that inspires even the wary to let go of worldly care and suspicions. Your eyelids grow heavy, heavier by the second.

headline: Review: ‘The Tempest’ Stars Sam Waterston and the Weather at Delacorte Theater
abstract: This Shakespeare in the Park production about a duke living in exile features well-known names and the unpredictability of the weather.
lead_paragraph: As befits a work called “The Tempest,” there’s thunder and lightning aplenty in the production that opened on Tuesday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Yet “rough magic” — which is abjured at the play’s end by its ruling wizard, Prospero (a sagely bearded Sam Waterston) — is scarce throughout this exquisite-looking interpretation of Shakespeare’s valedictory romance.

headline: U.S. Women Advance to Round of 16 on Abby Wambach’s Goal
abstract: Wambach scored on a corner kick in the 45th minute, and the United States won Group D.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Abby Wambach has sued over artificial turf and complained about it regularly, becoming a spiritual descendant of that great philosopher and former slugger Dick Allen, who memorably said, “If a horse can’t eat it, I don’t want to play on it.”

headline: How Fluid Is Race?
abstract: The chatter over Rachel Dolezal's identity highlights America's growing racial ambiguity.

abstract: The combination of a weak ruble and a strong dollar is bolstering industries like steel in Russia, where commodity companies are flourishing.
lead_paragraph: The combination of a weak ruble and a strong dollar is bolstering industries like steel in Russia, where commodity companies are flourishing.

headline: Matt Harvey Breaks Out of Slump With Commanding Performance
abstract: Harvey was sharp from the outset, lighting up the radar gun with 99-mile-per-hour fastballs and allowing only one hit in the first four innings.
lead_paragraph: Matt Harvey had performed like a mere mortal in recent starts, allowing three home runs his last time out while posting a 1-3 record with a 7.20 earned run average over his last four outings.

headline: Miami Provides 2 Homecomings and a Hammering
abstract: Nathan Eovaldi, a former Marlin, was shelled for eight runs in the first, and the lopsided game was a sour end to Alex Rodriguez’s homecoming.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For nine long innings, Alex Rodriguez watched helplessly from the dugout as his teammates came and went, looking glum. There would be no chance for late-game heroics in a pinch-hitting role, as he had had the night before, no chance for him to be showered in adulation. The Yankees were well on their way to a 12-2 loss.

headline: Hockey Delivers Viewers for NBC
abstract: The Chicago Blackhawks’ victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning to win the Stanley Cup was the third-most-watched Game 6 of the Cup finals on record.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Blackhawks’ 2-0 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning to win the Stanley Cup on Monday was seen on NBC by an average of eight million viewers, making it the third-most-watched Game 6 of the Cup finals on record.

headline: Neil Young Wants Donald Trump to Pick Another Song
abstract: Donald Trump drew Neil Young’s rebuke on Tuesday when he strode across the stage at Trump Tower to declare his presidential candidacy backed by Mr. Young’s song “Rockin’ in the Free World.”
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump wants to rock in the free world, but Neil Young is not having it.

headline: On Stand, World Trade Center Parachutist Stresses His Skill
keywords: ['1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: Testifying in a Manhattan court, Marko Markovich talked about the night that he and two others sneaked into 1 World Trade Center, climbed to the skyline’s highest point and took flight.
lead_paragraph: The night he leapt from 1 World Trade Center, Marko Markovich was enveloped in darkness, discernible only by the sound of his voice and the blinking red lights of the two GoPro cameras strapped to his helmet, seen in a series of popular YouTube videos.

headline: Taxicab Confessions
An Olfactory Ode to Narcissus
abstract: Régime des Fleurs' newest scent smells, according to one of its creators, like the forest reflected in a pond.
lead_paragraph: For a pair known for their noses, Ezra Woods and Alia Raza, the perfumers and co-creators of Régime des Fleurs, are surprisingly visual. They begin creating their scents by filling inspiration boards with what seem like random collages of contemporary art, ancient landscapes, baroque interiors and iconic clothing. Mirror, their newest bottle, is “a nod to Narcissus, who infamously gazed down at his own reflection in the water,” Raza says. “We also used a rare absolute of narcissus jonquil, which adds an earthy floral note without sweetness.” Made in collaboration with the fashion and design website the Line, the scent itself is “about a reflection of an image as opposed to the image itself, so the fragrance is a blurred, impressionistic take on a few different themes,” says Woods. In this case, notes of green galbanum, smoky gaiac wood, dry violet and clean charcoal come together, Raza says, like “a sketch of a forest reflected in a pond.”

headline: The Beachy Pad of Brooklyn’s Lone Pro Surfer
abstract: The wave-riding champion and surf filmmaker Mikey DeTemple opens the doors to his nautical-themed Williamsburg apartment.
lead_paragraph: Mikey DeTemple is a five-year ASP World Longboard tour vet, a four-time East Coast Surfing Champion and an accomplished filmmaker whose feature “Sight/Sound” was the best-selling surf film of 2011. For the past three years, the beach-blond, Brooklyn-bearded 30-year-old and his fiancée, Lisa Myers, have shared a second-floor Williamsburg walk-up. “I needed to be somewhere I could park my truck so I could take off to go surf,” explains DeTemple, who says he’ll drive anywhere within a six-hour radius for waves. (“If you want to do it in New York,” he says, “you’ve really got to work for it.”) A space that felt like Montauk — where DeTemple lived before meeting Myers, and where the couple continues to keep a home — was also essential. “We needed it to be bright,” DeTemple says. “At heart, we are beach people, no matter where we live,” Myers adds. “I would pour sand in here if I could.”

headline: Paris’s Newest Purveyor of France’s Finest Foods Was Inspired by New York Specialty Shops
abstract: At not quite two months old, La Maison Plisson has quickly garnered a dedicated following.
lead_paragraph: In Paris, La Maison Plisson, a stylish new cafe-restaurant-grocery store in the Marais, hasn’t even been open for two months, but it has already become something of a gastronomic institution. The large, airy shop showcases France’s finest foodstuffs, which is why the original inspiration for this project may come as a big surprise: the specialty food shops of New York City.

headline: Golden State Warriors End N.B.A. Title Drought With Victory Over Cavaliers
abstract: Golden State won its first N.B.A. championship since 1975 and denied LeBron James a title with Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Golden State Warriors launched some 8,900 shots this season. They attempted layups and 3-pointers, runners and elbow jumpers. They dazzled fans and overwhelmed opponents. But every time the ball left their fingertips, the Warriors seemed to be building toward something bigger and better, toward the brightest stage and the grandest prize.

headline: Seats That Move With the Onscreen Action Lift Revenue for Los Angeles Theater
abstract: The Regal Cinemas location has seen an 88 percent increase in attendance and a threefold increase in ticket revenue since installing 4DX technology last year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As American movie theater chains look for ways to increase profits, a Regal Cinemas location here has hit by removing standard seats and replacing them with ones that move with the film, using a technology called 4DX.

headline: Hundreds of Journalists Exiled Globally, Report Says
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Almost a quarter of journalists from Syria have been forced into exile since 2010, a leading press advocacy group said in a report released Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: At least 452 journalists around the world have been forced into exile since 2010, almost a quarter of them from Syria, a leading press advocacy group said in a report released Wednesday. The report by the group, the Committee to Protect Journalists, attributed the disproportionately large number of exiled Syrian journalists to their harassment and fear of imprisonment by the Syrian government, as well as to threats and attacks from the Islamic State and other militant groups embroiled in the country’s civil war. According to the committee’s research, the top countries from which journalists have fled over the past five years are Syria with 101, Ethiopia with 57 and Iran with 52.

headline: At Basilica Soundscape Festival, Electronics, Post-Punk and Noise
abstract: The Basilica SoundScape festival in Hudson, N.Y., will take place Sept. 11-13.
lead_paragraph: The Basilica SoundScape festival in Hudson, N.Y., has announced the lineup for its fourth edition on Wednesday, to run Sept.11-13. The festival, which takes place at Basilica Hudson, a reconditioned 1880s factory building near the Hudson River, is a three-day multidisciplinary festival of music, readings, film and visual art

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton’s longtime adviser Sidney Blumenthal testified before a congressional committee on Tuesday that dozens of memos he sent her when she was secretary of state were written by a longtime high-ranking C.I.A. official.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 P.M. (Sundance) DEUTSCHLAND 83 Martin (Jonas Nay), a 24-year-old East German, is extracted from his military existence and forced by the secret police to assume the identity of an aide to a West German general at the center of NATO’s nuclear-deterrence strategy in Anna and Jörg Winger’s new Cold War espionage series. Maria Schrader (above, with Mr. Nay) plays Martin’s manipulative aunt, who pushes him into the assignment by using his mother, who needs a kidney transplant, as a weapon. “The series doesn’t have the depth of that other ‘80s spy show, ‘The Americans’ on Fox, but intentionally so,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “It’s decidedly a drama — lots of close calls and complications for Martin to deal with — but there’s a slight wink throughout as well, as if it were saying, ‘Don’t take this too seriously.’ ”

headline: A Chinese Nurse Resigns, Bidding Farewell to Her Florence Nightingale Dream
abstract: Yan Xiaobing describes the harsher side of hospital life in China, where nurses endure long hours and low pay but suffer especially from verbal and physical abuse from patients and their families.
lead_paragraph: Each May 12, on International Nurses Day, nurses in Chinese hospitals recite the “Florence Nightingale Pledge,” written in honor of the English social reformer and founder of modern nursing.

headline: Lost, at Home in Colombia
abstract: A family story about a grandfather who was lost and raised by another family led Jorge Panchoaga to “La Casa Grande” — “The Big House” — in which he explores notions of home and identity.
lead_paragraph: Jorge Panchoaga was raised hearing stories about how his grandfather got lost as a child in the Colombian forest, wandering for two days until he was taken — and raised — by a baker and his family. Those tales took on special meaning in 2010, when Mr. Panchoaga was teaching photography to indigenous youngsters in the Cauca Department, the region his grandfather was from.

abstract: So many presidential candidates. So few daring ideas or trade-offs.
lead_paragraph: I don’t recall a time when more people were running for president and fewer of them offered anything more than poll-tested generalities designed to rally their own bases. No one surprises you with any daring. If we could tax their clichés, we’d balance the budget.

headline: Massachusetts Takes On a Failing School District
abstract: The state’s effort to reform a failing school district seems to be paying off.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts public schools consistently rank at or near the top in the nation for performance on the rigorous, federally backed math and reading exams known as the National Assessment of Educational Progress. The state has nonetheless struggled with how to improve chronically low-performing districts like the one in the impoverished former mill town of Lawrence.

abstract: Many promises were made in her campaign speech. Here are some of the economic policies that would back them up.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton made many promises in her campaign speech last weekend, including a vow to “make the economy work for everyday Americans, not just those at the top.” Unlike many politicians who cast the income-and-wealth gap as a result of impersonal forces, Mrs. Clinton rightly noted that growing inequality also comes from “choices we’ve made as a nation, leaders and citizens.”

headline: Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Where Stoop Life Still Thrives
abstract: Crown Heights was dogged by a reputation for intolerance and violence after the 1991 riots involving blacks and Hasidic Jews. But residents say it has shed those associations.
lead_paragraph: Crown Heights was one of the wealthiest neighborhoods in Brooklyn at the turn of the last century, and the alluring architecture of that era, along with new residential development, is attracting newcomers and spurring rapid change.

headline: Golf’s Golden Dropout
abstract: Jordan Spieth, 21, who won this year’s Masters and hopes to add a United States Open title this week, considers his inner circle a key to his success.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Well before Jordan Spieth was fitted for a Masters green jacket in April, he acquired a nickname from a few PGA Tour players, who took one look at his pinchable face, impeccable manners and bulletproof game and anointed him the Golden Child.

headline: Industry’s Growth Leads to Leftover Embryos, and Painful Choices
keywords: ['In Vitro Fertilization', 'Infertility', 'Families and Family Life', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The subject poses profound questions about the beginning of life, the definition of family and the advances opening new reproductive possibilities.
lead_paragraph: After years of infertility, Angel and Jeff Watts found a young egg donor to help them have a baby. They fertilized her eggs with Mr. Watts’s sperm and got 10 good embryos. Four of those embryos were transferred to Ms. Watts’s womb, resulting in two sets of twins — Alexander and Shelby, now 4 years old, and Angelina and Charles, not yet 2.

headline: Turkey at a Democratic Crossroad
abstract: After years of single-party rule, a reform-minded coalition is possible — but by no means a given.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — After last week’s elections brought an end to majority rule by one party, Turkey faces the prospect of a coalition government. What was once considered undesirable, even unthinkable, now offers an opportunity to overhaul Turkey’s political culture and inch the country toward becoming a genuinely liberal democracy. That would be a historic shift.

headline: The Waterloo They Remembered
abstract: Two centuries on, the Battle of Waterloo is still best understood through the eyes of its participants.
lead_paragraph: Two hundred years ago, in a shallow valley south of Brussels, three armies fought the Battle of Waterloo. Napoleon had returned from exile on Elba to face a coalition of European enemies, who were now determined to oust him a second time. The closest opponents were the Prussian and British-Dutch armies to his north, so he launched a campaign to destroy them both. At Waterloo, on June 18, 1815, he failed.

headline: Science Weighs In on High Heels
abstract: The heroine of “Jurassic World” runs from rampaging beasts in high heels, without turning a hair or an ankle. But research on the biomechanics of wearing heels, including a new study of the effects on ankle strength and balance, says of her equipoise, ha.
lead_paragraph: Many commentators have pointed out that the new movie “Jurassic World” is scientifically suspect, if not fantastical. But they have overlooked one of the more prominent ways in which the blockbuster diverges from established research. The movie’s heroine runs from rampaging beasts in high heels, without turning a hair or an ankle. But research on the biomechanics of wearing heels, including a new study of the effects on ankle strength and balance, says of her equipoise: “Ha.”

headline: Wednesday’s Travel News and Tips
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including slow cruises in Europe and a renovated Ryman Auditorium in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Jack Dorsey (and Beard) Retake Twitter
abstract: Twitter’s new interim chief executive comes with a history, and his new mountain-man look is challenging expectations on C.E.O. facial hair.
lead_paragraph: The tech and business worlds may have raised an eyebrow at the news last Thursday that Jack Dorsey, co-founder and chairman of Twitter, would assume the chief executive role he relinquished in 2008, at least on an interim basis, replacing the chief executive Dick Costolo. But the jaw dropping came later.

headline: Traces of Earliest Stars That Enriched Cosmos Are Spied
abstract: Astronomers said a recently discovered galaxy, known as CR7, holds the signature of a lost generation of stars that created the elements needed for life.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers said Wednesday that they had discovered a lost generation of monster stars that ushered light into the universe after the Big Bang and jump-started the creation of the elements needed for planets and life before disappearing forever.

abstract: Naguib Kheraj, a former executive at JPMorgan Chase and Barclays, will replace Ruth Markland in the post effective immediately, the bank said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British bank Standard Chartered said on Wednesday that it had named a new senior independent director on its board as the company continued to reshape its leadership.

headline: Ireland Mourns 6 Victims of Berkeley Balcony Collapse
abstract: Flags were flown at half-staff and tributes were paid after the deaths during a party in California prompted outpourings of grief across the country.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The flag flew at half-staff across Ireland on Wednesday, as the country struggled to come to terms with the tragedy that took the lives of six young people when a balcony collapsed during a party in Northern California.

headline: Experts on Aging, Dying as They Lived
abstract: The way my parents died — in comfort — was the way they cared for me after they were gone.
lead_paragraph: At 10 years old I knew my parents did not wish to be resuscitated nor plugged into machines in the event of serious illness. They told me they were not afraid of death but rather of being kept alive at any cost. I knew they would refuse medical interventions, if they felt there was no purpose except to separate the dying from their deaths. They were wary of doctors who my parents said were trained by a medical culture that had lost touch with what should be its major focus: ending suffering.

headline: R.B.S. Is Again Hit by a Technology Failure
abstract: About 600,000 customer transactions were not processed overnight, after an earlier episode left millions unable to access their accounts for several weeks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Wednesday that about 600,000 customer transactions had not been processed as a result of a technology failure overnight. The issue affected transactions at the company’s R.B.S., National Westminster Bank, Coutts and Ulster Bank brands.

headline: Dorothy Cann Hamilton Talks About the World Expo
abstract: Food is this year’s theme at the expo, and the president of the USA Pavilion will show American cuisine in a cultural context.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Cann Hamilton is no stranger to the world of food. In 1984 she started the French Culinary Institute, now the International Culinary Center, in New York and recruited renowned chefs like José Andrés and Jacques Pépin as teachers. Ms. Hamilton, 65, is the president of the USA Pavilion at the 2015 World Expo, in Milan through Oct. 31. The theme is “Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life,” and she is running a 35,000-square-foot pavilion that puts American food culture in the spotlight. Following are excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Hamilton.

headline: Taxicab Confessions
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Assaults', 'Lost and Found Property', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: What to do with a wedding ring from a brawl?
lead_paragraph: Last night I witnessed an assault on a taxi driver. After the passenger jumped out of the cab and kicked it repeatedly, the driver got out and confronted the man. The man suddenly began throwing punches, and a legitimate brawl ensued during which the man yelled things like “go back where you came from” and “I was born in this country, you weren’t.” A small crowd gathered to break up the fight. When the police arrived, I stuck around to defend the cabdriver. The police listened but told me they did not need me as an official witness. I wished the cabdriver luck and went across the street to watch the aftermath play out. The passenger, a black man, was claiming that the cabdriver would not take him to Harlem but that he probably would have if he were white. The police did not arrest the man, nor did they appear to do much of anything in the way of even taking information. During the brawl I heard a ring bounce toward me across the street. I picked it up, and after the cabdriver called the police, I asked him if the ring was his. He said it belonged to the other man. I asked somewhat conspiratorially if he wanted the ring anyway, but he said no. When I got home, I found it was a Cartier wedding band that sold new from $1,100 to $1,600. Today I found a posting on Craigslist, seemingly from the passenger, seeking his ring, lost during an assault, in exchange for a reward. So what do I do? J.P., NEW YORK

headline: Better Judgment
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: What should it take for judges to change their minds?
lead_paragraph: Nearly 100 years ago, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. stood at an upright desk in his study, dipped a pen into an inkwell inherited from his father and wrote a Supreme Court opinion allowing the government to imprison people for speaking out against World War I. Holmes was 77 on that day in February 1919. He came to Washington 16 years earlier from Massachusetts after stints as a law professor at Harvard and a judge on the state Supreme Court, and he looked the part of a patrician New Englander, with his handlebar mustache and a bristling shock of white hair.

headline: Our Bodies, Our Feeds
abstract: Two social-media campaigns take on how women’s bodies are (and are not) represented online.
lead_paragraph: Last month, my friend Tracy posted a series of messages on Twitter, including one that read, “I look like a marshmallow tied up in rubber bands.” Another said, “Scientific fact: Salt and vinegar chips taste 46% better when you’re on your period.” Once I stopped laughing, I noticed she was using a hashtag I had never seen before: #LiveTweetYourPeriod. A quick tour of the tag revealed hundreds of other posts, ranging from the oblique (images of junk food) to the grotesquely exaggerated — one tweet included an image of the pivotal pigs’ blood moment in “Carrie”; another, the part in “Alien” when a creature bursts from John Hurt’s chest.

headline: Responding to Readers’ Questions on Weight Loss
abstract: Many of you argued that exercise worked for you, so how could my arguments be true?
lead_paragraph: In an article on Monday, I discussed the evidence showing that diet is much more important than exercise when it comes to losing weight. You had many thoughtful comments and questions — so many that we thought it might be useful to respond to some of them here.

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign is based on the assumption that voters are angrier at the rich than they are at the poor.

lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where there is some potential movement on trade and even on the issue of needle exchange. But as a conference of Latino elected officials invites candidates to speak, immigration is sure to be back in the national conversation.

headline: Bipartisan Group Urges Overhaul of General Election Debates
abstract: A bipartisan panel released a series of recommendations aimed at overhauling the general election presidential debates, with the goal of drawing more viewers and allowing voters to emerge with a better understanding of the candidates and their positions.
lead_paragraph: A presidential debate season that begins in mid-September. A television studio backdrop without a live studio audience. And a “chess clock” model, where each candidate is allotted 45 minutes of speaking time, which begins ticking down when they start talking.

headline: Suspicious Swiss Bank Deals to Be Part of FIFA Investigation
abstract: The official leading the inquiry in Switzerland said about nine terabytes of data had been seized during a sweep of the Zurich offices of world soccer’s governing body.
lead_paragraph: An investigation by the authorities in Switzerland into the activities of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, will include the examination of more than 50 suspicious financial relationships, the country’s chief federal prosecutor said on Wednesday.

headline: The King of Tapas
abstract: Learning to make tortilla española from the owners of Despaña, Manhattan’s Spanish-food emporium.
lead_paragraph: It’s the house that jamón built, the castle of chorizo, the mansion of manchego. The Spanish food mecca Despaña, in SoHo, is a landmark shop for food lovers, its dark wood finishes and white subway-tile walls bringing together the sights of Spain and New York. When I arrived to meet its owners, Marcos and Angélica Intriago, they welcomed me with tortilla española: potatoes and onions fat with olive oil and bound with egg into a neat little cake — the king of tapas. “But the problem with tortilla,” Angélica said to me, “is that Americans don’t want to pay for it because it’s just potatoes and eggs, and Spaniards don’t want to pay for it because it doesn’t taste like their mother’s.”

headline: Who Owns Soccer?
keywords: ['World Cup (Soccer)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A radical idea for saving FIFA from itself.
lead_paragraph: Early this month, after Sepp Blatter trudged off the stage following his announcement that he would be retiring from the presidency of FIFA, he was followed at the podium by a man named Domenico Scala, the FIFA official who is charged with overseeing the election to replace him. Implicitly acknowledging the furor that prompted Blatter’s departure — the arrests of seven soccer officials in Zurich on corruption charges the week before — Scala said Blatter’s decision “created an opportunity for us to go further than FIFA has before — to fundamentally change the way in which FIFA is structured.” Scala also called Blatter’s announcement “courageous,” saying: “I know that he has truly acted with the best interests of FIFA and football in his heart. I have a great amount of respect for the president and the role that he has played in championing reform within FIFA.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Jobs’s Legacy Shadows Ousted Chiefs’ Return
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Jobs’s Legacy Shadows Ousted Chiefs’ Return | Hedge Fund Manager Backs Up Bravado With High Returns | Kerkorian Dies at 98 | Analysts Expect Greek Exit to Shake, But Not Shatter, Europe
lead_paragraph: JOBS’S LEGACY SHADOWS OUSTED CHIEFS’ RETURN | Jack Dorsey’s return to Twitter invites comparisons to another high-profile comeback of a chief executive who had been ousted from the company he founded – that is, Steve Jobs,  Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. “The legend of Steve Jobs lingers over Silicon Valley,” he writes. “One of its many forms encourages founders to return triumphantly to ‘‘save’ their brands.” Like Jobs, Mr. Dorsey will be rejoining his company as interim chief executive. And Mr. Dorsey, who is also the chief executive of the payments company Square, will now be running two companies at the same time, much like Jobs ran Apple and Pixar for nine years.

headline: 1890: Paris Eclipse
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Parisians gather to see an eclipse in 1890.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Much interest was taken in yesterday’s eclipse by Parisians. Thousands of persons arose far ahead of their accustomed hour, and, armed with pieces of smoked glass, sought the various points from which it was believed good views of the phenomenon could be had. The place de l’Hôtel de Ville was occupied by a crowd of 500 persons, who were anxious to avail themselves of a large equatorial telescope and four smaller ones that had been placed there by M. Joseph Vinot, of the Journal du Ciel. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 18, 1890

keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Discrimination', 'Encyclicals', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Global Warming', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Priests', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: Mr. Bush says religion shouldn’t influence politics, but many of his positions send the opposite message.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, whose presidential campaign was in beta for so many months and has now moved into the minimal viable product phase, offered some strong words about religion and politics yesterday. It turns out that he thinks religion should not bleed into the political arena — except of course when he thinks it should.

headline: In Detroit, Branson Celebrates a New Virgin Atlantic Route
abstract: Virgin Atlantic has a new daily flight from Detroit to London, and Sir Richard Branson saluted the Michigan city.
lead_paragraph: To promote Virgin Atlantic’s newest route, a nonstop daily round-trip flight between Detroit and London that began on June 1, the airline’s founder, Sir Richard Branson, recently took a whirlwind tour of Michigan’s largest city, admitting by visit’s end that he was pleasantly surprised by what he discovered.

headline: Podcasting Blossoms, but in Slow Motion
abstract: Podcasts — not a flash in the pan but not an instant success, either — are gradually picking up steam.
lead_paragraph: Is podcasting in the middle of a long boom or a short bubble? The future of radio, a medium already being buffeted by streaming music, may be riding on the answer.

headline: E.U. Agrees to Extend Economic Sanctions Against Russia
abstract: The decision to prolong the sanctions for six months frustrated a campaign by Moscow to win a blocking vote from one of the countries in the European bloc.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union is set to extend by six months economic sanctions against Russia, calming fears that Greece’s acrimonious negotiations over its debt crisis might allow Russia to break the unity of the 28-nation bloc in its response to the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: The End of the Sex Abuse Crisis
abstract: Pope Francis and the promise of systemic accountability within the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: The conversation about Catholicism and Pope Francis is about to be dominated by the topics of the environment and climate change, thanks to tomorrow’s (official; there have been leaks) release of the pontiff’s ecological encyclical, Laudato Si. But let me sneak in a belated comment on last week’s news that the Vatican is setting up a tribunal to handle accusations of negligence by bishops in sex abuse cases, with coincided, probably not coincidentally, with the resignations of the archbishop of Minneapolis-St. Paul and his auxiliary over their handling of a now-defrocked predator priest.

headline: To Cut Teen Smoking, Raise Tobacco Sales Age
abstract: A new study has found a simple way to significantly reduce teenage smoking: raise the tobacco sales age to 21.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found a simple way to significantly reduce teenage smoking: raise the tobacco sales age to 21. In 2005, Needham, Mass., did just that, while surrounding communities kept their age limit at 18.

headline: Florence and the Machine to Replace Foo Fighters at Glastonbury
abstract: With Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters recovering from a broken leg, Florence Welch, who broke her foot in April, will lead Florence and the Machine at Glastonbury as a replacement act.
lead_paragraph: The Glastonbury Festival in England is swapping one musician’s broken bone for another’s recently healed one.

headline: California Says Uber Driver Is Employee, Not a Contractor
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: The ride-hailing company has long positioned itself as a “logistics company” and says its drivers are contractors, not employees.
lead_paragraph: In a ruling that fuels a long-simmering debate over some of Silicon Valley’s fastest-growing technology companies and the work they are creating, the California Labor Commissioner’s Office said that a driver for the ride-hailing service Uber should be classified as an employee, not an independent contractor.

headline: Travel Diary
abstract: Highlights from the artist Mickalene Thomas’s four-city tour of Italy.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the artist Mickalene Thomas’s four-city tour of Italy.

headline: Alex Morgan and Abby Wambach Renew Partnership and Revive U.S. Hopes
abstract: The two United States strikers, happy to be reunited at the World Cup, may get a breather against lesser opponents after winning their group.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Chosen to start in a Women’s World Cup game for the first time on Tuesday, Alex Morgan said she jokingly sought pointers from left back Meghan Klingenberg, who has made all of three starts.

headline: After an Era of Ups and Downs, Home Prices Return to Sanity
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', "Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index"]
abstract: The housing market in much of the nation seems to be in a Goldilocks moment, neither too hot nor too cold, with low mortgage rates an added bonus.
lead_paragraph: WESLEY CHAPEL, Fla. — Donte and Anjoli Hill postponed their honeymoon indefinitely and squirreled away cash wedding gifts in order to afford the down payment on the four-bedroom house they bought a few months ago in this Tampa suburb.

headline: Straw Hats at Pitti
abstract: The straw hat is a fashion perennial at the men’s fashion fair in Florence, Italy.
lead_paragraph: The straw hat is a fashion perennial at the men’s fashion fair in Florence, Italy.

headline: The Biggest Cheats in Team Sports
abstract: A list of some of the most famous and unusual cheating scandals in team sports from around the world.
lead_paragraph: A list of some of the most famous and unusual cheating scandals in team sports from around the world.

headline: Review: Leon Golub’s ‘Riot’ Revisits Political Art With a Sense of the Absurd
abstract: Mr. Golub’s paintings at Hauser & Wirth reflect a sardonic sense of the absurd and an acute awareness of barbarous villainy around the world.
lead_paragraph: Intrinsically theatrical, oil painting is an ideal medium for political art. Leon Golub knew this and made the most of it in mural-size pictures of terrorists, torturers and hit-squad goons that more or less fought their way into existence, being repeatedly painted and scraped down and sometimes cut up and reconfigured. These are the kinds of paintings we see on the first floor of a career sampler of Mr. Golub’s work at Hauser & Wirth, a spinoff of a recent retrospective at the Serpentine Gallery in London.

headline: Pope Requests More Help for Migrants
abstract: During a general audience at the Vatican, Pope Francis calls for coordinated international action and asks forgiveness for those who close their doors to refugees.
lead_paragraph: During a general audience at the Vatican, Pope Francis calls for coordinated international action and asks forgiveness for those who close their doors to refugees.

headline: Greek Central Bank Warns of Financial Collapse if Debt Talks Fail
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: Absent a deal between Athens and its creditors, the bank predicted a default and exit from the euro, leading to soaring inflation and a recession.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The central bank of Greece warned on Wednesday that failure to reach a deal in the country’s long-running debt crisis would result in a default on its bailout loans and economic turmoil.

headline: Surely Not the Last Straw at Pitti Uomo
keywords: ['Hats and Caps', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Men and Boys']
abstract: The straw fedora was seen everywhere at the big men’s wear trade show held twice annually in Florence.
lead_paragraph: “A short brim and a high crown was two years ago,” Giacomo Tesi, a fifth-generation hatter, said on June 17 at the main pavilion of Pitti Uomo, the big men’s wear trade show held twice annually in Florence, the Italian city that not only gave birth to the Renaissance but also, in 1951, to the modern fashion show.

headline: Tiger Kills Man in Tbilisi, Georgia
abstract: A witness and the interior minister of Georgia described a deadly tiger attack on Wednesday in Tbilisi that killed one man after floods damaged the city’s zoo, causing some animals to escape.
lead_paragraph: A witness and the interior minister of Georgia described a deadly tiger attack on Wednesday in Tbilisi that killed one man after floods damaged the city’s zoo, causing some animals to escape.

headline: The Biggest Losers From A.I.G.: Taxpayers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Maurice Greenberg, the former chief executive of A.I.G., was never the real victim of the government’s bailout of the company.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Greenberg, the former chief executive of A.I.G., won support this week for his claim that the government acted illegally in 2008, when it bailed out A.I.G. But in his lawsuit against the United States, he wasn’t seeking support, he was seeking money – $40 billion, to be exact. He got nothing, which on Wall Street makes him a big loser.

headline: Valid Complaints on Story about Berkeley Balcony Collapse
abstract: A Times editor and reporter express regret, saying they never intended to blame victims
lead_paragraph: My office fielded hundreds of complaints Wednesday from readers who are – quite understandably – upset about an article that went online Tuesday night.

headline: 1965: U.S. Rejects Viet Cong Talks
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson rejects Viet Cong talks in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson today [June 16] rejected any idea of direct negotiations over Vietnam with the Viet Cong or their political arm, the National Liberation Front. ‘‘What would you think about the state of Mississippi negotiating for the United States?’’ the president asked at a surprise press conference. ‘‘I have no doubt that if the Viet Cong wished to negotiate, they would have no trouble in finding a government to negotiate for them,’’ he said. His statement was a reference to his administration’s firmly held belief that the South Vietnamese Communists are controlled, directed, supplied and now reinforced by North Vietnam. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 18, 1965

headline: Chile’s Copa América Star in Court After Crashing Ferrari
abstract: Arturo Vidal, the tournament’s leading scorer and the star midfielder for Chile, was arrested for driving under the influence on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Fans of the host nation at the Copa América were set on edge when Arturo Vidal, the tournament’s leading scorer and the star midfielder for Chile, was arrested and charged with driving under the influence after he smashed his red Ferrari on Tuesday night.

headline: Netflix’s ‘Sense8’: Watched It All? Let’s Talk.
abstract: Will we care enough to tune into again by the time Season 2 rolls around? Let the discussion begin.
lead_paragraph: The supernatural usually isn’t my calling when I’m looking for TV shows or movies to watch. But there was something about Netflix’s “Sense8” — a collaboration between the Wachowskis (“The Matrix,” “Cloud Atlas”) and J. Michael Straczynski (“Babylon 5”), with an alluring international cast and exotic locales — that called to me. (Read Alessandra Stanley’s review here.) And while some of you may have binged the entire series that first weekend of June, I’ve finally gotten around to doing so.

headline: 36 Hours in Lima
abstract: Lima’s winning formula: A rich pre-Columbian heritage, emerging art and fashion scenes, and remarkably great food.
lead_paragraph: Lima’s winning formula: A rich pre-Columbian heritage, emerging art and fashion scenes, and remarkably great food.

headline: Tough Tests for Teachers, With Question of Bias
abstract: Minority candidates have been lagging behind whites in passing the tests, jeopardizing a goal of diversifying the teaching force so it more closely resembles the makeup of the country’s student body.
lead_paragraph: Students are not the only ones struggling to pass new standardized tests being rolled out around the country. So are those who want to be teachers.

headline: 36 Hours in Lima, Peru
abstract: Lima’s attractions include a rich pre-Columbian heritage, ethnic diversity, and emerging art and fashion scenes, along with remarkably great food.
lead_paragraph: Peru’s capital may not have world-class architecture, but its old moniker “Lima the ugly” doesn’t hold true these days. Right away, a visitor notices its tidy streets, handsomely landscaped parks and sweeping ocean views. And then there are the less obvious but ultimately more compelling attractions: a rich pre-Columbian heritage, ethnic diversity, and emerging art and fashion scenes, as well as remarkably great food. Lima’s transformation into a culinary powerhouse, which started more than a decade ago, was propelled forward in recent years by a group of talented and enterprising chefs. Their creativity, inspired by the seemingly endless variety of native ingredients, has brought fame not only to their individual restaurants, but also to the entire city.

headline: New York Summer Love Stories
abstract: For a series on Summer Love, The Times asked readers to share their New York City summer love stories, both good and bad.
lead_paragraph: For a series on Summer Love, The Times asked readers to share their New York City summer love stories, both good and bad.

headline: How The Times Covers ISIS
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Propaganda', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Ben Hubbard provides a look at what it is like to report on life with the Islamic State, a difficult task when traveling to ISIS-occupied areas is impossible.
lead_paragraph: The hardest part of writing about the Islamic State is that there is no way for us to go and check out anything ourselves. The group has killed many journalists it has gotten its hands on and is more interested in putting out its own message through videos and social media, which allows it to idealize itself and entice recruits.

headline: For Art Metropole, a Sara Cwynar Tote Bag
abstract: The limited edition is on sale at Art Basel and online.
lead_paragraph: Among the stacks of miscellany packed into the multidisciplinary photographer Sara Cwynar’s studio is a selection of old trade manuals — including a 1960s or ’70s catalog for customizable shopping bags. “You would pick the kind of bag and the type to put on it,” she explains, “and there’s a simplicity to the imagery that doesn’t exist anymore,” she says of the book’s pages. Cwynar repurposed the images for a series of limited-edition canvas totes — the aptly named “Bags on Bags” — available in Art Metropole’s booth at Art Basel. True to form for an artist known for her vibrant works, she sold the Canadian institution on using four colors instead of two.

headline: F.C.C. to Fine AT&T for Slowing Data Speeds of Some Customers
abstract: The commission said the wireless carrier misled consumers with unlimited data plans when it slowed their service after they had used a certain amount of data.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday said it planned to fine AT&T Mobility $100 million, accusing the company of misleading millions of wireless customers with unlimited data plans by slowing down their service without adequately informing them.

headline: TPP Versus NAFTA
abstract: Why the different outcomes?
lead_paragraph: Many people — myself included — thought that TPP would, in the end, follow the model of NAFTA: a Democratic president would push the agreement through Congress, but the bulk of the votes would be Republican. But it doesn’t seem to be going that way. Why?

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Windows (Operating System)', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Social Media']
abstract: Microsoft is allowing those currently running Windows 7 or 8.1 to “reserve” a copy of its newest operating system more than a month before it’s released.
lead_paragraph: Q. An icon appeared on my computer offering me a free upgrade to Windows 10. Is this real? And if so, should I sign up?

headline: Tracking Entrepreneurship, and the State of the Sharing Economy
abstract: New research on start-up activity found that Montana has become a hotbed of entrepreneurial activity. Plus, a ruling in California could have a big impact on whether sharing-economy companies have employees or not.
lead_paragraph: The Kauffman Foundation’s annual analysis of start-up activity nationwide is a treasure trove of regional and demographic data. After five years of trending downward, new business starts reversed course last year and noticeably increased, but business creation remains below the historical average in most parts of the country.

abstract: Pope Francis discussed on Wednesday an eagerly awaited papal encyclical in which he is expected to address climate change.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis discussed on Wednesday an eagerly awaited papal encyclical in which he is expected to address climate change.

keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Lawmakers and diplomats got together at a Washington bar to celebrate a new group intent on helping to end the American travel and trade bans against Cuba.
lead_paragraph: The American travel and trade bans against Cuba are older than the 52-year-old senator Jeff Flake – “so yesterday,” he likes to chide his younger Senate colleague Marco Rubio, who opposes ending the bans yet campaigns for president as a new-generation candidate declaring, “Yesterday is over!”

headline: Ron Clarke, Australian Runner Known for World Records, Dies at 78
abstract: A middle- and long-distance runner who broke 17 world records, some by huge margins, in the mid-1960s but never won an Olympic gold medal.
lead_paragraph: Ron Clarke, an Australian middle- and long-distance runner who broke 17 world records, some by huge margins, in the mid-1960s but never won an Olympic or British Commonwealth gold medal, died on Wednesday in Gold Coast, Australia, where he had recently been mayor. He was 78.

headline: Kenneth Feinberg to Oversee Cuts in Multiemployer Pension Plans
abstract: The program signals an important break with federal pension law, which until now has allowed benefit cuts for active workers but not for retirees.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Wednesday that it had named Kenneth R. Feinberg to oversee a new program to allow certain pension plans to cut retirees’ benefits if that is the only way to keep them from running out of money.

headline: To Celebrate 50 Years, the Israel Museum Looks Back Much Further
abstract: In a country that seems be growing more insular in some ways, an exhibit at Israel’s national museum tries to convey a more universal message: the story of civilization’s origins and development.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A softly lit case displays a small, gnarled implement that is said to be the world’s oldest known complete sickle, dating back 9,000 years. On a wall nearby, a video installation called “Shopping Day,” made by the Israeli artist Doron Solomons and set in an immaculate supermarket, offers a wry reflection on the branding and packaging of modern consumer products.

headline: Warriors Fans Rejoice at N.B.A. Title

lead_paragraph: Warriors fans celebrate after their team beat the Cleveland Cavaliers to become N.B.A. champions.

headline: N.B.A. Plays Its Final Note, but What a Symphony It Was
abstract: America’s beautiful game, embodied in the Warriors, is changing at light speed, with its emphasis on artful, selfless passing and spectacular marksmanship.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — So the certifiably best basketball player on the planet, having just put in one of the great performances in N.B.A. playoff history, slips into his postgame seat, his red eyes shadowed by the rim of a handsome homburg.

keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Christmas', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']

lead_paragraph: In the grand James A. Farley Post Office in Manhattan, a century-old Christmas tradition unfolded, as workers playing the role of benevolent elves sorted gift lists from needy children and addressed boxes from Secret Santas.

headline: Philip Larkin to Get a Memorial Stone in Poets’ Corner at Westminster Abbey
abstract: The British poet Philip Larkin, who died in 1985, will be honored at Westminster Abbey next year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British poet Philip Larkin (1922-1985) — a malcontent with a reclusive streak and an acid take on his own success — will receive a jolt of posthumous recognition when Westminster Abbey adds a memorial stone in his honor to its Poets’ Corner, a site featuring tributes to 67 (soon to be 68) of the leading writers in the English language.

headline: A Spring/Summer 2016 Trend Worth Adopting Now
abstract: White trucker jackets, fitted and cut short, were everywhere during the London shows — on handsome buyers, in Swedish shows and (jazzed up) on the Tom Ford runway.
lead_paragraph: White trucker jackets, fitted and cut short, are quickly emerging as a spring/summer 2016 trend worth adopting early. On Saturday, the handsome, stylish Harvey Nichols buyer Darren Skey made his London Collections Men rounds in a white denim version by Common Sweden. The up-and-coming Swedish brand L’homme Rouge presented a lightweight Tencel zip-front jacket for next season; and earlier this week, Tom Ford showed the style’s most luxurious interpretation, in white leather. You can get one now at ourlegacy.se.

lead_paragraph: It’s been remarkable to see the lengthening line of Republican politicians, particularly presidential hopefuls, chiding Pope Francis for pressing the case for action to stem global warming given how much conservatives have stressed values-based arguments on important issues in the past.

headline: Women’s World Cup: How U.S. Fans Should Root Today
abstract: The American women’s soccer team could still face any of seven different opponents in the next round. The worst potential matchup: France.
lead_paragraph: The United States has advanced to the Round of 16 at the Women’s World Cup, but the next opponent remains a mystery. The four matches being played Wednesday will determine which of seven possible teams the United States will play Monday in Edmonton, at 8 p.m. Eastern.

abstract: Investigators said they had received no indication that the escaped killers had left the area around the Clinton Correctional Facility in northern New York State.

abstract: Since Sony stopped making replacement parts for its Aibo robotic dog, devoted owners are facing the loss of their mechanical pets.

headline: An Optimist’s View of Russia
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Cold War Era', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The country “will come back to democracy,” says Andrei Kozyrev, its former foreign minister.
lead_paragraph: With his invasion of Crimea, deployment of troops and weapons to eastern Ukraine and ruthless oppression at home, President Vladimir Putin of Russia has steered his country far off the democratic track. The promise of the early 1990s, when the collapse of the Soviet Union seemed to usher in a new era of rights and freedoms, is over.

abstract: Ms. Hopper’s new book, “The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic,” is by turns loose and warm and finicky and outraged.

headline: Rand Paul to Detail Flat Tax Plan

lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul will reveal his plan to overhaul the tax code on Thursday. Expect Steve Forbes to be pleased.
