abstract: Rand Paul, who is hoping his small-government, libertarian-inspired approach to governing will translate into support as he seeks the Republican presidential nomination, will call for a flat tax in the midteens, the senator has told supporters.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul will reveal his plan to overhaul the tax code on Thursday. Expect Steve Forbes to be pleased.

headline: Review: Polish National Ballet Shows Its European Side at the Joyce Theater
abstract: This company is making its New York debut with two works by its director, Krzysztof Pastor, and one by Emanuel Gat.
lead_paragraph: The company now known as the Polish National Ballet has an august history, tracing its origins to 1785. Its fortunes, like those of Poland, darkened greatly during and after World War II, but in recent years, as the country has become a member of the European Union, the ballet troupe has worked to rejoin, and catch up with, the rest of Europe.

headline: In Chile’s National Stadium, Dark Past Shadows Copa América Matches
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Stadiums and Arenas', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Copa America (Soccer)']
abstract: The stadium, which was used as a prison camp after the 1973 military coup that overthrew Chile’s Marxist president, is the site of six games in the Copa América soccer tournament.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A haunting yellowish glow radiates from the tiny section of empty wooden benches and crumbling concrete behind the north goal at Estadio Nacional. All around this space there is noise: 47,000 soccer fans screaming and jumping in delight as Chile’s national team plays Ecuador in the opening game of the Copa América.

headline: Review: ‘Catastrophe,’ on Amazon Prime, Shares a Special Comedy Relationship
abstract: In this comedy, Sharon Horgan and Rob Delaney play a couple brought closer together after an unexpected pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: “Catastrophe,” a bittersweet British television comedy making its American debut on Amazon Prime, is the product of an unlikely artistic union. One of its creators, Sharon Horgan, is a veteran sitcom writer and star who could be fairly called the Tina Fey of British TV, in stature if not style. The other, Rob Delaney, is an American comedian best known for having more than a million Twitter followers; he’s headlining a TV show for the first time.

headline: Top Plaintiff in Health Subsidies Case Awaits Edict Unperturbed
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: David M. King said that he believed the Supreme Court would rule against subsidies in the health care law, but that he was not worried because he has access to care through Veterans Affairs.
lead_paragraph: FREDERICKSBURG, Va. — Millions of people are waiting anxiously for the Supreme Court to decide the fate of President Obama’s health care law with a ruling this month on health insurance subsidies. But David M. King, a plaintiff in the case, is not among them.

headline: Where Christianity Ends
keywords: ['Atheism', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Religion and Belief', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: Bruce Jenner, Belgian euthanasia, and the line between the heretical and the post-Christian.
lead_paragraph: Last week I wrote a post on Bruce/Caitlyn Jenner and American religion in which I channeled Harold Bloom (via Will Wilkinson) and talked a bit about the Americanization of Christianity: What it means, whether it’s irresistible, and at what point in the process we should stop talking about American faith in terms of Christian heresy (my preferred terminology) and start talking about a new religion altogether.

headline: Power Struggle in Malaysia Pits Former Premier Against a Protégé
abstract: A battle between Mahathir Mohamad, a former premier, and the man he helped put into office, Prime Minister Najib Razak, has transfixed the nation.
lead_paragraph: PUTRAJAYA, Malaysia — Malaysia’s governing party is at war with itself, embroiled in a power struggle that is destabilizing the country and threatening the party’s nearly six-decade stretch of uninterrupted governance.

headline: Malaysian Ex-Prime Minister Unleashes Criticism
abstract: Mahathir Mohamad is forcing his way back into the center of Malaysian politics with comments against the current premier, whom he helped install.
lead_paragraph: Mahathir Mohamad, who served as prime minister of Malaysia from 1981 to 2003, turns 90 next month. He is forcing his way back into the center of Malaysian politics with a fire hose of criticism for the man he helped install in office, Najib Razak, the current prime minister.

headline: Rachel Dolezal’s Unintended Gift to America
abstract: Troubled as she is, she has opened a candid, long-delayed conversation about the meaning of racial identity.
lead_paragraph: In James Baldwin’s 1968 novel “Tell Me How Long the Train’s Been Gone,” a child points to his light-skinned mother’s relationships to offer a compelling case that she is indisputably black:

headline: Is Hillary Clinton Running a ‘Narrow’ Campaign? Not Really
abstract: Mrs. Clinton is targeting her base, which is what primary candidates do. And the issues she’s focused on aren’t actually so very narrow.
lead_paragraph: Is Hillary Rodham Clinton running a campaign focused on “secondary, base-ginning issues”?

headline: This Solstice, Skylight at Fulton Center Hub Will Get Its Day in the Sun
abstract: The sun’s rays will burnish the Sky Reflector-Net, a 79-foot-high convex tracery of aluminum panels and stainless steel cables in the transit center’s atrium, for more than nine hours on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Druids, take note.

headline: Minnesota’s Holding of Sex Offenders After Prison Is Ruled Unconstitutional
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal judge said Minnesota’s program, which holds more than 700 people for indefinite periods, had failed to release some who no longer met the criteria for being confined.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In a decision watched by officials in 20 states that hold some sex offenders after they complete prison sentences, a federal judge ruled this week that Minnesota’s program for such offenders was unconstitutional.

headline: Officials on Manhunt as It Nears 2 Weeks
keywords: ['Police', 'Search and Seizure', 'Prison Escapes', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The New York State Police and Clinton County officials said they had no “hard evidence” that two murderers who escaped from a maximum-security prison had left the area.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Police and Clinton County officials said they had no “hard evidence” that two murderers who escaped from a maximum-security prison had left the area.

headline: How to Take (the Right) Accessory Risks This Summer
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Summer (Season)']
abstract: These accessories pack a punch that can take a basic look to another level.
lead_paragraph: These accessories pack a punch that can take a basic look to another level.

headline: California Chrome’s Overseas Trip Hits a Detour
abstract: After a minor injury forced the reigning American Horse of the Year to miss his start at Royal Ascot, his trainer and co-owner remained optimistic about his next start.
lead_paragraph: ASCOT, England — Although a minor injury forced the reigning American horse of the year, California Chrome, to miss his chance to race in the Group I Prince of Wales’s Stakes on Wednesday at Royal Ascot, his trainer, Art Sherman, and co-owner Steve Coburn arrived at the racecourse with required top hats in tow.

headline: Utah University Adds Texting and Walking Lane to Its Stairs
abstract: Yes, distracted walking is a problem, too. The National Safety Council also issued a report Wednesday that pedestrians buried in their phones suffered an estimated 11,000 injuries over 11 years.
lead_paragraph: Phone carriers and local emergency rooms rejoice. Students at Utah Valley University have a new perk: a texting and walking lane.

headline: Utah University Adds Texting and Walking Lane to Its Stairs
abstract: Yes, distracted walking is a problem, too. The National Safety Council also issued a report Wednesday that pedestrians buried in their phones suffered an estimated 11,000 injuries over 11 years.
lead_paragraph: Phone carriers and local emergency rooms rejoice. Students at Utah Valley University have a new perk: a texting and walking lane.

headline: Pixar’s ‘Inside Out’ Takes a Journey to the Center of the Mind
abstract: Pete Docter and Ralph Eggleston discuss scenes from the new Pixar film and the way they visualized the act of imagination.
lead_paragraph: Pete Docter and Ralph Eggleston discuss scenes from the new Pixar film and the way they visualized the act of imagination.

headline: Compelling Works From Some of Today’s Most Innovative Artists and Designers
abstract: A new book, “Postdigital Artisans,” explores the influence of digital technology in creative fields.
lead_paragraph: In creative industries where ancient techniques originally set the standards for greatness, more and more contemporary talents are embracing, instead, digital technology. And it’s the job of people like Jonathan Openshaw, the editor of LS:N Global, developed by the Future Laboratory to help explain market and consumer trends, to keep a finger on the pulse of innovation. In a new book, “Postdigital Artisans” ($39, Frame Publishers), Openshaw explores the otherworldly processes and sensational creations of artists like Daniel Arsham, fashion designers like Iris van Herpen and a host of other up-and-coming talents. In the above slideshow, he shares with T 10 of the tome’s most compelling projects.

headline: Compelling Works From Some of Today’s Most Innovative Artists and Designers
abstract: A new book, “Postdigital Artisans,” explores the influence of digital technology in creative fields.
lead_paragraph: In creative industries where ancient techniques originally set the standards for greatness, more and more contemporary talents are embracing, instead, digital technology. And it’s the job of people like Jonathan Openshaw, the editor of LS:N Global, developed by the Future Laboratory to help explain market and consumer trends, to keep a finger on the pulse of innovation. In a new book, “Postdigital Artisans” ($39, Frame Publishers), Openshaw explores the otherworldly processes and sensational creations of artists like Daniel Arsham, fashion designers like Iris van Herpen and a host of other up-and-coming talents. In the above slideshow, he shares with T 10 of the tome’s most compelling projects.

headline: Mickalene Thomas’s Adventures in Italy
abstract: The artist recently wrapped up a 10-day tour of Capri, Rome, Florence and Venice, and shared photographic highlights of her trip with T.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the artist Mickalene Thomas returned home to Brooklyn after a trip to Italy spanning 10 days and four cities, organized around her participation in a conference, “Black Portraiture{s} II,” put on by NYU in Florence. “Since it was going to be my first time in Italy, and since the conference coincided with the Venice Biennale, it seemed like a great time for me to travel all over Italy and see what was happening in the art world in what, to a New Yorker, can feel like a different part of the universe,” she says. “There was all sorts of buzz around the Biennale, and I wanted to experience firsthand all of the things I’d been hearing about Italy for years: the architecture, the food, the people, the energy, the language. I got a taste of all of that.”

headline: Mickalene Thomas’s Adventures in Italy
abstract: The artist recently wrapped up a 10-day tour of Capri, Rome, Florence and Venice, and shared photographic highlights of her trip with T.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the artist Mickalene Thomas returned home to Brooklyn after a trip to Italy spanning 10 days and four cities, organized around her participation in a conference, “Black Portraiture{s} II,” put on by NYU in Florence. “Since it was going to be my first time in Italy, and since the conference coincided with the Venice Biennale, it seemed like a great time for me to travel all over Italy and see what was happening in the art world in what, to a New Yorker, can feel like a different part of the universe,” she says. “There was all sorts of buzz around the Biennale, and I wanted to experience firsthand all of the things I’d been hearing about Italy for years: the architecture, the food, the people, the energy, the language. I got a taste of all of that.”

headline: Economy Not Ready for Rate Hike
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, Federal Reserve chairwoman, said the United States economy is on track to grow between 1.8 percent and 2.0 percent this year.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, Federal Reserve chairwoman, said the United States economy is on track to grow between 1.8 percent and 2.0 percent this year.

headline: Britannia Rules the Chart Again as Muse Takes No. 1 Spot
abstract: The British band Muse replaces another British group, Florence and the Machine, atop the Billboard album chart.
lead_paragraph: Muse, the arena-filling British band, has topped the Billboard album chart for the first time with its seventh studio release, “Drones” (Helium-3/Warner Bros.), which sold 79,000 copies and 84,000 total album equivalent units, counting downloads and streams, according to Nielsen Music. The group had previously peaked at No. 2 with “The 2nd Law” in 2012.

headline: Unused Embryos, to Donate, Destroy or Debate
abstract: Embryo donors and recipients may be happy with their choices, but the larger debate over embryo status remains.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of frozen embryos — perhaps a million — sit in storage facilities nationwide, preserved in silver tanks of liquid nitrogen. Some belong to individuals and couples who are still trying to conceive, or are preserving the option. But most are leftovers from the successes of the booming assisted-reproduction industry. Families, clinics and the courts face difficult choices about what to do with those embryos — possible lives, without guarantee, unsustainable without aid, and ethically challenging, raising questions about the beginning of life and the definition of family.

headline: Will A.I.G. Decision Affect the Next Bailout? Don’t Bet on It
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)']
abstract: Although a judge had hash words in his ruling on the A.I.G. case, don’t expect the government to do anything different in the next financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A judge’s tone and harsh words in his ruling this week related to the taxpayer bailout of the American International Group seems to have put the government on notice that its tactics in rescuing the insurer during the 2008 financial crisis were improper and illegal.

headline: Review: ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Brings a Precise Pairing to the Met
abstract: Hee Seo and Cory Stearns, who made their debuts as the lovers in 2009, enlarge their performances in Kenneth MacMillan’s interpretation of Shakespeare’s tragedy at the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: In Kenneth MacMillan’s enduring 1965 production of “Romeo and Juliet,” there’s a spine-tingling moment in which the heroine sits on the edge of her bed stunned by her fate. She has married Romeo, who has killed her cousin Tybalt, and is engaged — against her will — to Paris, who repulses her a little more every time she sets eyes on him. With her feet propped on point and her shoulders limp, Hee Seo, portraying Juliet at American Ballet Theater on Monday, looked like an animal, both haunted and hunted.

headline: Review: ‘Tristan und Isolde’ Brings Thunder to the Longborough Festival
abstract: This classic Wagner opera is part of the 17th season of this festival in the English countryside.
lead_paragraph: LONGBOROUGH, England — A king, Marke, damns the treachery of his adopted son. A knight, Tristan, fights his betrayer, impaling himself on his assailant’s sword. His young lover, Isolde, rushes toward him, hoping he has not yet died the death she knows will come. An orchestra seethes. The stage goes black.

headline: Review: Theo Bleckmann Upends a Schumann Song Cycle
abstract: Performing with the pianist Uri Caine at the Stone, Mr. Bleckmann spliced the cycle with twangs, a yodel, electronic effects and nonsense words.
lead_paragraph: It’s usually not a good sign if a singer starts sounding like Elvis during a performance of Schumann’s “Dichterliebe” (“A Poet’s Love”). But then there was nothing predictable about Theo Bleckmann’s whimsical interpretation of the song cycle on Tuesday at the Stone, where he is in residence this week.

headline: Review: Washington Square Music Festival Features Joseph Anderer
abstract: A concert that was moved inside because of rain featured a Mozart work for alphorn and strings.
lead_paragraph: Some foods — like s’mores — are meant to be consumed out of doors. Certain musical instruments, too, fare best in the open: bagpipes, for instance, and alphorns. This idea was brought home on Tuesday by the Washington Square Music Festival’s endearingly awkward opening concert, which featured a rare performance of Leopold Mozart’s “Sinfonia Pastorella” for alphorn and strings.

headline: Things to Know About Embryo Donation
abstract: Tamar Lewin, a Times reporter, spoke with couples who are dealing with the agonizing decision of what to do with their unused embryos. Now, she is answering basic questions about embryo donation.
lead_paragraph: While reporting on the article about embryo donation, Tamar Lewin discovered widespread confusion about how the process works. Submit a question about embryo donation to lewin@nytimes.com. Some of the questions will be selected and answered here. Your name and comments may be published, but not your contact information.

headline: Miley Cyrus Honored at amfAR Gala
abstract: The pop star is joined by Andy Cohen, Anderson Cooper, Mary J. Blige and others at annual Inspiration Gala in New York.
lead_paragraph: The pop star is joined by Andy Cohen, Anderson Cooper, Mary J. Blige and others at annual Inspiration Gala in New York.

headline: AmfAR Gala Honors Andy Cohen and Miley Cyrus
abstract: Celebrities took in a runway, roast, auction and mini-concert at the nonprofit’s Inspiration Gala.
lead_paragraph: At amfAR’s Inspiration Gala on Tuesday night, the famous and not quite famous primped and posed in borrowed dresses as they arrived at Spring Studios in TriBeCa.

headline: Claims of Syrian Chlorine Bombs Counter News of Progress on Chemical Arms
abstract: News from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and testimony at a House hearing on chlorine bomb use presented contradictory pictures.
lead_paragraph: The monitoring group overseeing the destruction of Syria’s chemical arms stockpile said Wednesday that almost all effluent from the neutralized weapons had been eliminated, portraying the progress as a great success in the nearly two years since Syria agreed to give up its arsenal.

headline: Hillary Clinton Strikes Bipartisan Theme in South Carolina
abstract: Days after seeking to energize her liberal base with a major rally on New York’s Roosevelt Island, Hillary Rodham Clinton emphasized her role as a bipartisan problem solver in a campaign stop in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Days after seeking to energize her liberal base with a major rally on New York’s Roosevelt Island, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday emphasized her role as a bipartisan problem solver.

headline: Hillary Clinton Strikes Bipartisan Theme in South Carolina
abstract: Days after seeking to energize her liberal base with a major rally on New York’s Roosevelt Island, Hillary Rodham Clinton emphasized her role as a bipartisan problem solver in a campaign stop in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Days after seeking to energize her liberal base with a major rally on New York’s Roosevelt Island, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday emphasized her role as a bipartisan problem solver.

headline: Grace Wales Bonner, a New Designer Who Looks to African and Indian History
abstract: Showing for just the second time, a recent Central Saint Martins graduate looked to the 17th century for a collection with African and Indian influences.
lead_paragraph: One test of the quality of a fashion show is what sticks. There’s a sensory-overload component in spending several weeks on the road, seeing clothes upon clothes every hour on the hour. And even for the most dedicated scrutinizers, much of it comes and then goes, struts and frets its hour upon the stage and then — well, out of the memory it flies. Most of it is there on Style.com if you need it after that.

headline: U.S. Gets More Time to Consider Insider-Trading Appeal
abstract: Federal prosecutors have another month to decide whether to ask the Supreme Court to review a ruling that narrowed the definition of insider trading.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have another month to decide whether to ask the United States Supreme Court to review a critical ruling in an insider trading case involving two former hedge fund traders.

headline: Spotify Taps Barry McCarthy, Former Netflix Executive, as New C.F.O.
abstract: Mr. McCarthy, previously a Netflix C.F.O., will assume the role on July 6 and will step down from Spotify’s board, the company said.
lead_paragraph: The music streaming service Spotify announced on Wednesday that it had named Barry McCarthy, a former Netflix executive and a member of Spotify’s board, its new chief financial officer.

headline: The Girls of Summer
abstract: Young women are dressing for themselves.
lead_paragraph: Young women are dressing for themselves.

headline: Women Who Cover Up (Even as the Temperatures Climb)
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Shopping and Retail', 'Youth']
abstract: Women who choose not to dress for a man’s gaze even as the weather calls for the baring of skin.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday afternoon, Kelsey Lenoch, 21, a student and fashion intern, was walking along Metropolitan Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in a black velvet scoop-neck crop top from American Apparel beneath fitted woven-cotton, light-blue overalls. On her feet were black ruffled socks and platform wedge sandals by Free People. It was about 81 degrees.

headline: Hockey Player Turned Williamsburg Innkeeper
abstract: The proprietor of a bed-and-breakfast had ample training for the bruising world of New York real estate.
lead_paragraph: AGE 34

headline: Apple Music Streaming Service Terms Dismay Indie Record Companies
abstract: At least 71.5 percent of the revenue from Apple Music will be paid in royalties, but labels and music publishers will not be paid during a three-month trial.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s new streaming music service will not arrive until June 30, but the company has already upset independent record companies because of its proposed licensing terms.

headline: First Draft Focus: And Now, a Message From the Justice Department …
abstract: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch prepared to send her first Twitter message at the Justice Department before her investiture ceremony on Wednesday.

headline: Silent Discos Let You Dance to Your Own Beat
abstract: Festivals, bars and weddings are dodging noise complaints with silent discos, in which attendees use headphones to tune into sets by competing D.J.s.
lead_paragraph: Just after sunset on a recent Friday night, what looked like a silent flash mob or a mass game of charades was taking place in a cordoned-off cobblestone square in the South Street Seaport: some 300 people dancing wildly, sans music. Or so it seemed.

headline: Review: Devices Adapted to the Outdoor Life
abstract: Items made for the hiker or camper include a hard drive, solar charger, precision watch, water-activated light, map app and headphones.
lead_paragraph: Whether you are hiking a mountain trail, camping in a dense forest or just hanging out in your backyard, your devices need to be rugged enough to withstand the elements, as well as accidental drops. Here are a few noteworthy items to keep in mind for your next outdoor adventure.

headline: Académie Française Honor Highlights Fluid National Allegiances Among Writers
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Language and Languages', 'French Language']
abstract: Many authors on the global stage, like Dany Laferrière, claim multiple national allegiances regarding words and country.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the Académie Française, the most august literary institution in France, inducted Dany Laferrière last month, it insisted that that Haitian-Québécois novelist was the first non-French citizen to enter its ranks. It turns out that is not quite the case. The Académie later acknowledged that a handful of others — including the Belgian-born Marguerite Yourcenar, the French-born American writer Julien Green and the Algerian-born novelist Assia Djebar — had never taken French nationality, although they had been entitled to it.

headline: App Smart | Put the Apple Watch to Work
abstract: Many of the 3,500 available apps showcase the capabilities of the Apple Watch. Here are just a few that show off what our wearable tech can do.
lead_paragraph: Many of the 3,500 available apps showcase the capabilities of the Apple Watch. Here are just a few that show off what our wearable tech can do.

headline: Video Feature: Apple Watch Apps That Are Available Now
abstract: Before Apple’s new plan to increase app production takes off, try some of these existing offerings, including a real-time weather app and a seven-minute workout app.
lead_paragraph: AT its recent annual developer conference, Apple made a move to jump-start the production of apps for the Apple Watch by announcing a software tool kit that will enable developers to create more advanced programs for the new device.

headline: Does It Really Matter Exactly When the Fed Raises Rates?
abstract: Janet Yellen’s comments expose the yawning gap between how economists think and how markets react.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one message that Janet Yellen, Federal Reserve chairwoman, tried to hammer home in her news conference on Wednesday, it is this: Don’t make so much effort to discern the precise timing of the Fed’s decision to raise interest rates, which 15 of 17 Fed officials think is likely to be warranted by the end of this year.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales This Week in New York
abstract: Seaport Studios opens; the Outnet releases limited-edition items; Father’s Day gift options, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Seaport District is opening Seaport Studios, a two-level retail destination that will showcase a rotating cast of top emerging designers. The first wave will include Baja East, which has a cashmere ikat graffiti throw ($1,595), and Jennifer Fisher, with a large double-knot cuff ($435). Timo Weiland, Mykita and Solid & Striped are on deck for later in the summer. At 19 Fulton Street.

headline: Films of Jon Moritsugu, Upending Stereotypes With a Wig and a Sneer
abstract: The 1980s and 1990s films of Mr. Moritsugu, playing at Anthology Film Archives, gleefully lampoon notions of Asian-American domestic propriety.
lead_paragraph: When the ABC sitcom “Fresh Off the Boat” was being hailed this winter as a breakthrough in the presentation of Asian-Americans on screen, one constant reference point was “All-American Girl,” the 1994 series starring Margaret Cho.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Immigrants’ Lawsuit Over Post-9/11 Detention Is Revived
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Immigration Detention', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An appellate panel ruled that the detention of mostly Muslim immigrants, who say they were mistreated in a Brooklyn jail, may have violated their constitutional rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saying that high-ranking Bush administration officials may have taken part in grave constitutional violations after the Sept. 11 attacks, a federal appeals court in New York on Wednesday revived a long-running lawsuit brought by immigrants, most of them Muslim, who said they were subjected to beatings, humiliating searches and other abuses in a Brooklyn detention center.

headline: Explaining China in Its Own (Varied) Terms
abstract: Zhang Weiwei, whose ‘‘China model’’ theory of development has influenced top leaders, employs more Confucius and statistics than Marx to explain why China under the Communist Party is certain to succeed.
lead_paragraph: Over dinner at the Fuxuan Hotel in Shanghai, Zhang Weiwei explains why China under the Communist Party is certain to succeed, confounding the pessimistic predictions of Western naysayers.

headline: Review: ‘Killjoys’ on Syfy Has Bounty Hunters on Space’s Frontier
abstract: This science-fiction action series, laced with campy humor and steampunk flourishes, concerns the adventures of three entrepreneurs on a galactic hunt for renegade miscreants.
lead_paragraph: The Syfy channel might not be in many Emmy conversations, but in recent years it has served up satisfying show after satisfying show. On Friday it adds another, a cheeky series called “Killjoys.”

headline: The Delusions of Rachel Dolezal
abstract: Her performance of blackness may have been born of affinity, but was based on a lie. It’s a spectacular exercise in hubris, narcissism and deflection.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Dolezal, a woman with no known black heritage, has apparently, through an elaborate scheme of deception and denial, claimed for years to be a product of black heritage.

headline: Praying on the Eve of Ramadan
abstract: Ahead of the start of the holy month of Ramadan, Muslim worshipers in Indonesia attended prayers.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of the start of the holy month of Ramadan, Muslim worshipers in Indonesia attended prayers.

headline: Review: ‘Tentacle 8’ Ensnares a Security Analyst in a Maze of Secrets
abstract: John Chi’s movie takes off when a man who is suspected of having a hand in data loss escapes a secret detention center.
lead_paragraph: Sprawling and intricate, John Chi’s labyrinthine conspiracy thriller “Tentacle 8” is nothing if not ambitious (and in the wake of the Edward J. Snowden affair, somewhat timely). When Ray (Brett Rickaby), a National Security Agency analyst, is suspected of having a hand in a huge loss of data at the organization, he is thrown into a secret detention center and viciously beaten. A Pentagon consultant (Joshua Morrow) is determined to interrogate him, but before he can, Ray has escaped, aided by a nameless man in a town car. Ray learns of a covert group known as Tentacle 8, and soon he is on the run, determined to unearth information about it. His girlfriend, Tabitha (Amy Motta), a C.I.A. employee, may or may not be on his side.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘My Perfect Mind’ Softens Fear of the Fallible With the Stuff of Slapstick
abstract: This show, which takes its title from “King Lear,” is a deceptively jolly account of a traumatic chapter in the life of the actor Edward Petherbridge.
lead_paragraph: Having a stroke is like going to a carnival in “My Perfect Mind,” a deceptively jolly account of a traumatic chapter in the life of the actor Edward Petherbridge that opened this week at 59E59 Theaters. Finger painting, cannonball tossing, wacky costumes, silly vaudeville sketches and a perilously sloped funhouse-style stage (with a trap door) are among the diversions on offer in this production, part of the Brits Off Broadway festival.

headline: Review: Masaaki Suzuki Conducts Young Musicians in Bach
abstract: This Japanese early-music maestro led an orchestra and chorus made up of students and recent alumni from the Juilliard School and the Royal Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: With four vocal soloists, two violin soloists, a guest conductor, a guest concertmaster and a full chorus deployed for just six numbers, it was an odd program, the kind that only a school or a festival could typically afford. Or in this case, two schools and two festivals.

headline: Review: Confessions Abound in Ensemble Studio Theater’s One-Act Marathon
abstract: This third cycle of plays includes a tale about two Japanese courtesans and another about the trajectory of a father-daughter relationship.
lead_paragraph: Playwrights, appreciate your actors. Sometimes they’ll save you from yourself. That’s especially true at Series C of Ensemble Studio Theater’s Marathon of One-Act Plays, in which an exceptional team of performers shores up some of the weakest writing and makes the good plays even better.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Team Aims to ‘Weaponize’ Its Fund-Raising Total
abstract: The “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush hopes to “weaponize” its fund-raising total for the first six months of the year, the group’s top strategist told donors on a conference call.
lead_paragraph: The “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, now walled off from the candidate because of campaign finance rules, hopes to “weaponize” its fund-raising total for the first six months of the year, the group’s top strategist told donors on a conference call on Wednesday afternoon.

abstract: The composer George Benjamin is this year’s artist in residence at the Aldeburgh Festival, and his influence saturated the orchestra’s weekend concerts.
lead_paragraph: SNAPE, England — Most of Europe’s summer music festivals take place in settings fundamental to their character. Think of Verbier, perched high on a terrace in the Swiss Alps, exclusive and haughty. Or Salzburg, as over-righteous and over-visited by tourists as the Vienna Philharmonic that retreats there.

headline: Review: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ Embraces Fun and Folly of a Classic
abstract: Tamilla Woodard delivers a breezy production that is warm-blooded and frolicsome for Masterworks Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Poor Shakespeare, so often smothered by reverence when all his work wants to do is breathe. And breathe it does, deeply, in the breezy, joyously oxygenated “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” directed by Tamilla Woodard for Masterworks Theater Company.

lead_paragraph: When Fitbit begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, it will do so at a healthy valuation.

headline: Senator Urges Inquiry Into Airline Behavior
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut asked the Justice Department to investigate whether airlines were engaging in anticompetitive behavior and colluding to limit capacity and drive up fares.
lead_paragraph: Senator Richard Blumenthal asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to investigate whether airlines were engaging in anticompetitive behavior and colluding to limit capacity and drive up fares. In a letter to William J. Baer, the head of the department’s antitrust division, the senator highlighted several comments that airline chief executives made at a recent industry gathering that suggested the carriers might be pursuing anticompetitive behavior. In his letter, Mr. Blumenthal quoted the presidents of Delta Air Lines, Air Canada and American Airlines, who all spoke of capacity “discipline.” The letter also noted that the airlines had become more concentrated after several mergers in recent years that were all approved by the Justice Department. “Consumers are paying sky-high fares and are trapped inside an uncompetitive market with a history of collusive behavior,” the senator said in his letter.

headline: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Deadly Bombings in Yemen
abstract: The bombs, which ripped through mosques in the capital Sana during prayer times, were another attempt to inflame tensions during cease-fire negotiations in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — A branch of the Islamic State in Yemen claimed responsibility for a series of car bombings here in the capital that killed at least 30 people on Wednesday, adding a new layer of peril to a city terrorized for months by airstrikes as well as by antiaircraft fire that has fallen on civilian homes.

headline: Airbnb Is Said to Seek $1 Billion More in Financing
abstract: If the financing round is completed, Airbnb, which helps arrange short-term housing rentals, will have a valuation of $24 billion.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s elite start-ups have been on a fund-raising tear, and Airbnb has become the latest to try to add to its cash pile.

headline: ABC Announcers Prematurely Crown the Golden State Warriors
abstract: With under two minutes remaining in Game 6, which had an average viewership of nearly 23.3 million, ABC’s announcers said the Warriors were the champions.
lead_paragraph: With less than two minutes in Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals Tuesday night, ABC’s announcers handed the title to the Golden State Warriors. While it was reasonable to assume that they would not fritter away a 13-point lead, it was premature to unreservedly say so. A lot can happen in a short time. And it did.

headline: Amid Grief for Students, a Search for Answers After Balcony Collapse
keywords: ['Balconies and Terraces', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Foreign Workers', 'Buildings (Structures)']
abstract: After the accident that killed six students, two independent engineers said they had seen what they considered clear evidence that the balcony that fell in Berkeley, Calif., was ridden with dry rot and decay.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Across Ireland, flags flew at half-staff. At San Francisco International Airport, the families began arriving to retrieve the remains of their children, or visit the injured in the hospital. And in Berkeley — the city where the collapse of a balcony early Tuesday morning killed six students and injured seven more — building inspectors working into the night declared another balcony in the complex a hazard and ordered it removed.

headline: Foreign Groups Fear China Oversight Plan
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Philanthropy', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A proposed law would require international organizations to find a government sponsor, seek police approval for all “activities” and hire Chinese citizens for at least half of all staff positions.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A remarkable assortment of foreign organizations set up shop in China in the decades after its emergence from isolation under Mao Zedong, offering good will, money and expertise that helped link the nation more closely to the rest of the world and turn it into the global powerhouse it is today.

headline: No Charges Against Kansas Governor After Ethics Inquiry

lead_paragraph: A federal investigation into loans made to the re-election campaign of Gov. Sam Brownback by his lieutenant governor will not result in charges, the United States attorney’s office in Kansas said on Wednesday.

headline: When Will It End? Much Work Is Left as Albany Session Winds Down
abstract: Although the session was scheduled to end on Wednesday, lawmakers were taking bets on how long it would be extended, and hotels were quickly being booked.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — It was to be the last day of the legislative session, so tensions on Wednesday were understandably high on the Senate floor. With so much to be done, things had come to a standstill over an unexpectedly provocative bill: naming the wood frog as the official state amphibian.

headline: Dominican Republic Set to Deport Haitian Migrants
abstract: Even before a Wednesday night deadline to register with the government, migrant workers have been routinely seized and expelled.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — On Monday, Yayine Mesilus was snatched off the streets of her small village in the Dominican Republic and taken back to Haiti, from where she had migrated eight years ago with her little brother to look for work.

headline: Nelson Doubleday Jr., Publisher Who Owned the Mets, Dies at 81
abstract: He expressed his love for baseball on a grand scale when his family’s publishing business became majority owner of the last-place Mets in 1980 and committed millions to rebuilding the team.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Doubleday Jr., who shortly after taking over his family’s publishing business used it in 1980 to buy the lowly New York Mets and put the team on course to win the World Series in 1986, died on Wednesday at his home in Locust Valley, N.Y. He was 81.

headline: Drug Accelerated Growth in Children With Dwarfism, Pharmaceutical Firm Says
abstract: BioMarin Pharmaceutical says that in its preliminary study, 10 children with achondroplasia who got the highest doses of vosoritide grew at an average rate of 2.4 inches a year.
lead_paragraph: An experimental drug, vying to become the first approved treatment for dwarfism, improved growth in children by a significant amount in a preliminary study, the drug’s developer, BioMarin Pharmaceutical, said on Wednesday.

headline: Brian Williams to Stay at NBC, but Not as News Anchor
abstract: The network is expected to announce that Mr. Williams will move to a new role primarily at MSNBC, probably in a breaking-news capacity.
lead_paragraph: NBC is planning to announce on Thursday that Brian Williams will not return to his position as the anchor of its “Nightly News” show, four months after the network suspended him for exaggerating his experiences during a helicopter attack in Iraq, according to two people briefed on the decision.

headline: Rachel Dolezal Told to Quit 2nd Post
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The mayor of Spokane called for Rachel A. Dolezal to resign from a voluntary city body for breaching confidentiality rules, among other violations.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Rachel A. Dolezal, the former N.A.A.C.P. president here who has been under fire for falsely identifying herself as a black woman, emerged at the center of a separate controversy Wednesday when the mayor of Spokane, David A. Condon, called for her and two others to resign from the city’s Office of the Police Ombudsman commission.

headline: Woman’s Portrait Will Appear on the $10 Bill
abstract: The yet-to-be-named figure will appear on the note in 2020, the 100th anniversary of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Growing numbers of Americans are going cashless, but demands to finally put a woman on paper currency persist. And now the Treasury has announced that a portrait of a woman, to be determined soon, will grace the $10 bill.

headline: Plan to Train Iraqi Soldiers Is Hampered by Lack of Recruits, Defense Chief Says
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)']
abstract: The U.S. has fallen behind its goal of training 24,000 Iraqi security forces by this fall, having only trained 9,000 so far.
lead_paragraph: The United States has fallen behind its goal of training 24,000 members of Iraqi security forces by this fall because the Iraqi government has not provided enough troops to train, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Wednesday. Mr. Carter told the House Armed Services Committee that the United States military had trained only 9,000 Iraqis so far. “Our training efforts in Iraq have thus far been slowed by a lack of trainees,” Mr. Carter said. “We simply haven’t received enough recruits.” Last week the White House said the United States was adding another training site in Iraq, near Ramadi, where some 450 American troops would train Iraqi fighters, particularly Sunni tribesmen, in the war against the Islamic State group. Defense officials said the effort to train Syrian fighters to take on the militant group on the Syrian side of the border was also going slowly.

headline: Case of World Trade Center Parachutists Goes to Jury
keywords: ['Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: In closing arguments in Manhattan, prosecutors and defense lawyers both used the wording of the felony burglary law to try to prove their cases.
lead_paragraph: As sky divers and parachute jumpers, James Brady, Marko Markovich and Andrew Rossig have exposed themselves for years to potential peril.

headline: Kosovo: Slovenia Detains Ex-Premier
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: War crimes investigators in Serbia want to hold Former Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj accountable for the killings of Serbs while he was a commander of Western-backed insurgents in the late 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Former Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj of Kosovo was detained in a surprise move on Wednesday at an airport in Slovenia, where the police said they had acted on a warrant from Serbia. War crimes investigators in Serbia want to hold him accountable for the killings of Serbs while he was a commander of Western-backed insurgents in the late 1990s. In 2004 he was indicted on war crimes charges by the United Nations tribunal for Yugoslavia. But he was acquitted after two trials that were hampered by witness intimidation. Mr. Haradinaj now leads a political party in Kosovo, where many see him as a war hero. He said his arrest was evidently a “mess-up,” because for several years he had traveled widely without problem.

headline: First Horizontal Piece Is Placed Along the New Tappan Zee Bridge
abstract: Huge steel girders were lifted into place near the bridge’s Rockland County side; dozens more will be added before the bridge can be open to traffic at the end of 2016.
lead_paragraph: By definition, a bridge does not become a bridge until it has a horizontal span that leaps over water or land. On Wednesday, after months in which dozens of verticals — piles, piers and columns — have gradually been poking out of the Hudson River, the replacement for the aging Tappan Zee received its first horizontal structure and finally became a bridge.

headline: Michigan: Largest County Seeks Emergency Status
abstract: The Wayne County executive, Warren C. Evans, is asking the state to declare a financial emergency to help shore up the struggling fiscal picture for the county, the state’s most populous.
lead_paragraph: The Wayne County executive, Warren C. Evans, is asking the state to declare a financial emergency to help shore up the struggling fiscal picture for the county, the state’s most populous. Mr. Evans described deficits over a matter of years in the county’s general fund and an underfunded pension system as among the chief problems. If state officials agree to designate the county in an emergency, several outcomes are possible, including the installation of an emergency manager. Detroit, which is in Wayne County, was determined to be in a financial emergency before it sought federal bankruptcy protection, which it emerged from last year.

abstract: The Blue Jays kept firing baseballs at will up the gut of the Mets’ defense in Toronto at one of the two ballparks in the majors that have AstroTurf.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Only two ballparks in the major leagues have AstroTurf, and the Mets do not visit either very often. But Rogers Centre is one of them, so before their game Wednesday, the Mets were on the field, testing how it felt and played.

headline: In Iowa, Bush Addresses a Burning Question: Why ‘Jeb!’?
abstract: When asked by a voter if his newly unveiled campaign logo, which uses only his first name, was meant to dodge the family name, Mr. Bush insisted that was not the case. “It’s who I am,” he said.
lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa – Two days after announcing his entry into the presidential race, Jeb Bush engaged head-on perhaps the most glaring question about his campaign, when he was asked by a voter on Wednesday if his newly unveiled logo – “Jeb!’’ – was meant to dodge the family name.

lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — Few people understand the dynamics of the United States Open Cup match between New York City F.C. and the New York Cosmos on Wednesday night better than Mike Petke, the former coach of the Red Bulls.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes']

lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — A white gunman opened fire Wednesday night at a historic black church in downtown Charleston, S.C., killing nine people before fleeing and setting off an overnight manhunt, the police said.

abstract: Claudia Ficca and Davide Luciano's new photographic project reimagines scenes from the classic film using cherry pies, frozen peas and cupcakes.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Standout Summer Products With Year-Round Staying Power
abstract: These sophisticated, seasonal items won't lose their appeal come winter, spring and fall.
lead_paragraph: Each year, a slew of beach- and fruit-inspired beauty products hits the shelves in May and June, only to quickly disappear in favor of gourd- and spice-infused concoctions come fall. But this summer, a handful of sophisticated items have year-round staying power.

headline: Recipes From Storm King, Inspired by the Artists Lynda Benglis and Luke Stettner
abstract: For the art center's Summer Solstice party, chefs Peter Hoffman and Shelley Boris will create chilled borscht and grilled octopus.
lead_paragraph: For this year’s Storm King Summer Solstice event, a starlit dinner in the fields of the Hudson Valley art center, the chefs Peter Hoffman, of the restaurant Back Forty West in New York City, and Shelley Boris, of Fresh Company in Garrison, New York, sought inspiration right on-site. This summer’s exhibitions at Storm King include “Lynda Benglis: Water Sources,” which features large-scale sculptures and fountains, including the joyful, voluminous “Pink Lady” sculptures that gave rise to the chefs’ chilled borscht with lavender cream and beet crystals; as well as an indoor/outdoor exhibition of Luke Stettner’s work, including a “charcoal” installation that inspired their stewed and grilled octopus with tarragon, lemon and olive oil. Ahead of the celebration this Saturday, chefs Hoffman and Boris shared recipes for the two dishes exclusively with T.

headline: Few Vehicles Equipped for Easy Child Safety Seat Installation, Study Finds
abstract: Only 47 of 102 vehicles were rated Good or Acceptable by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, indicating flaws in the federally mandated Latch system.
lead_paragraph: Installing a child safety seat in a vehicle has been a confusing, sometimes difficult task for many parents. A new study released on Thursday has backed up many parents’ complaints, finding that only a handful of vehicles deserved the highest rating for ease of installation.

headline: Hong Kong Legislature Rejects Beijing-Backed Election Plan
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Elections', 'Law and Legislation', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: In the end, it was the pro-democracy camp that killed a proposal for direct election of the city’s top leader, citing Beijing’s limits on who could be a candidate.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In quiet negotiations as well as public protests, they have pleaded and demanded for nearly two decades that Beijing allow Hong Kong’s leader to be elected by the general public. But in a dramatic vote on Thursday, pro-democracy lawmakers here rejected a bill that could have been their last best chance to achieve that goal.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE ASTRONAUT WIVES CLUB Life magazine bought the rights to their stories. Jacqueline Kennedy invited them to the White House. Created by Stephanie Savage (“Gossip Girl”) from Lily Koppel’s book, this series ventures into the kitchens and boudoirs of the First Ladies of Space: seven women with iconic last names — Carpenter, Cooper, Glenn, Grissom, Schirra, Shepard and Slayton — who kept their families grounded while their men shot for the stars. “The series purports to tell the real story behind the Project Mercury publicity machine, but it is so enamored of the early-’60s aesthetic that it can’t resist adding its own flawless, cameo-faced gloss to its heroines,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. But the excitement “is found not in motel rooms or boozy barbecues but inside the command center at NASA, where early launches were terrifying.” The creators, she added, “may have wanted to avoid belittling their heroines in a space age version of ‘Desperate Housewives,’ but they did them a different disservice by sugarcoating them almost as much as NASA did some 50 years ago.”

headline: 60 Million People Fleeing Chaotic Lands, U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency finds that war and persecution have displaced a record number of people.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Nearly 60 million people have been driven from their homes by war and persecution, an unprecedented global exodus that has burdened fragile countries with waves of newcomers and littered deserts and seas with the bodies of those who died trying to reach safety.

headline: Elisabeth Elliot, Tenacious Missionary in Face of Tragedy, Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Elliot inspired generations of evangelical Christians by returning to preach the Gospel to the Indian tribe that had killed her husband.
lead_paragraph: Elisabeth Elliot, a missionary who inspired generations of evangelical Christians by returning to Ecuador with her toddler daughter to preach the Gospel to the Indian tribe that had killed her husband, died on Monday at her home in Gloucester, Mass. She was 88.

headline: Reactions to the Defeat of the Hong Kong Election Plan
abstract: Pro-democracy campaigners cheered its failure, while supporters of the Beijing-backed proposal vowed to use the defeat to campaign against pan-democratic lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s legislature voted down a plan on Thursday to change how the semiautonomous Chinese territory chooses its leader. The package would have allowed voters to directly elect Hong Kong’s top official in 2017, but pro-democracy politicians said the Chinese government-backed proposal placed too many controls on who could appear on the ballot.

headline: India’s Earliest Photographers
abstract: India’s early embrace of photography is the theme of an exhibit that examines the country’s traditions of modern art.
lead_paragraph: For someone who ended up with the title “Bold Warrior of Photography,” Raja Deen Dayal started out rather cautiously. Instead of quitting his job as a surveyor at the Public Works Department in Indore, India, once he discovered photography in the 1870s, he waited about a decade before taking a two-year furlough to see if he could handle it.

headline: Western Business Stands Up to China
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Foreign Investments', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Two proposals would crack down on nongovernmental organizations and enforce controls over ideology and culture, all in the name of national security.
lead_paragraph: While international human rights groups often protest China’s attempts to restrict freedoms of its people, foreign businesses, with profits on the line, have traditionally been less willing to do so. But now, many have joined Western governments in opposing Beijing’s latest plan to impose new controls on foreign organizations.

headline: The Patient and the Therapist: A Disconnect
abstract: Readers take issue with a Sunday Review article, “The Dowdy Patient.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Obama’s Plan to Send Advisers to Iraq Will Fail
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Keeping them holed up on “lily pads” defeats the purpose of training troops.
lead_paragraph: LAST week President Obama approved an additional 450 troops to join the roughly 3,000 already in Iraq. Living inside secure bases nicknamed “lily pads,” they will train Iraqi soldiers for a few weeks via lecture and drill instruction. The graduates will then be sent outside the wire to fight the Islamic State.

headline: Destructive Health Care Proposals
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation', 'Medical Devices']
abstract: House Republicans are moving two bills to repeal small but important provisions of the health care law.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated by their inability to repeal the Affordable Care Act and unable to produce a conservative alternative to replace it, House Republicans are moving two bills to repeal small but important provisions of the law — a tax on medical device manufacturers and an independent board to clamp down on out-of-control Medicare spending. The two bills would harm the federal budget and do nothing to help consumers, but were approved by the House Ways and Means Committee and are expected to pass the House on Thursday.

headline: A Rebuke to Military Tribunals
abstract: After a recent court ruling, almost no one who remains at Guantánamo can be constitutionally prosecuted by military tribunals.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Ali al-Bahlul, a propagandist for Al Qaeda who has been held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, since early 2002, was convicted by the military tribunal there and sentenced to life in prison. But officials had no evidence that Mr. Bahlul was involved in any war crimes, so they charged him instead with domestic crimes, including conspiracy and material support of terrorism.

headline: What It’s Like as a ‘Girl’ in the Lab
keywords: ['Research', 'Women and Girls', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Discrimination', 'Mentors', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Careers and Professions', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Science is like a medieval apprentice system where mentorship is everything. That’s the real problem with a Nobel laureate’s offhand remark.
lead_paragraph: IT’S 7 p.m. on a Friday night, and I’m still in the lab. Earlier in the day, as I was looking through old data, I unexpectedly found the answer to a question that I’d been trying to address for a year. It was one of those rare “eureka” moments in science. But it’s not as though in an instant a spotlight fell on the pictures of cells I’d been staring at, clearing up all mystery.

headline: Church Massacre Suspect Held as Charleston Grieves
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: After a 14-hour search, the suspect was caught some 200 miles away from the historic black church where nine people were killed.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The mass murder of nine people who gathered Wednesday night for Bible study at a landmark black church has shaken a city whose history from slavery to the Civil War to the present is inseparable from the nation’s anguished struggle with race.

headline: Test Yourself | The Chicago Blackhawks’ Latest Stanley Cup Win
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a June 15 article, “With Blackhawks’ 3 Stanley Cups in 6 Years, Chicago Runneth Over.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below, several paragraphs from a June 15 article, “With Blackhawks’ 3 Stanley Cups in 6 Years, Chicago Runneth Over.”

headline: Rare Direct Appeal to Xi Jinping Appears, Then Disappears, Online
abstract: An online video, quickly deleted from Chinese outlets, shows a woman being subdued by bystanders after she called out to President Xi Jinping’s motorcade in the southwestern province of Guizhou.
lead_paragraph: State news outlets showed enthusiastic crowds greeting President Xi Jinping as he toured the southwestern province of Guizhou this week. They carried the usual images of Mr. Xi leading his identically dressed entourage, as he shook hands and waved to well-wishing bystanders. Photos and videos seemingly shared by onlookers on Weibo, the microblogging platform, did not diverge from the script.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | N.B.A. Plays Its Final Note, but the Symphony Is Just Getting Started
abstract: How is N.B.A. basketball changing?
lead_paragraph: In “N.B.A. Plays Its Final Note, but the Symphony Is Just Getting Started,” Michael Powell writes about how N.B.A. basketball is changing.

headline: Mali Must Disarm the Militias
abstract: The government in Bamako must end its dangerous divide-and-rule tactics in the country’s conflict-ridden north.
lead_paragraph: Bamako, Mali — When French soldiers stormed into northern Mali in January 2013 to chase out militants aligned with Al Qaeda, Malians throughout the country stood to gain. The French, aided by the Chadian and Malian Armies, swiftly took back most of the territory controlled by the extremists. Their mission, Operation Serval, was held up as a rare example of a successful Western intervention against terrorist groups.

headline: After Looking Everywhere, a Jersey City Condo
abstract: Chris Maiurro and Kathryn Bringle searched for an apartment in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan, before ending up in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Chris Maiurro and Kathryn Bringle lived in a one-bedroom in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, the neighborhood where they had met seven years ago.

headline: Review: Pixar’s ‘Inside Out’ Finds the Joy in Sadness, and Vice Versa
abstract: Pete Docter’s new animated film, with the voices of television comedians like Amy Poehler, Mindy Kaling and Bill Hader, brings to life an 11-year-old’s interior drama.
lead_paragraph: Can movies think? This is a longstanding critical question, usually answered in the negative. Literature, the thinking goes, is uniquely able to show us the flow of thought and feeling from within, but the camera’s eye and the two-dimensional screen can’t take us past the external signs of consciousness. We can look at faces in various configurations of pleasure or distress, but minds remain invisible, mysterious, beyond the reach of cinema.

headline: Getting More Children to Play (No League Necessary)
abstract: Amid other concerns of the moment, Manfred is introducing an initiative intended to increase participation in all forms of the sport, from simple games like catch and stickball to organized youth leagues.
lead_paragraph: The crises in front of a commissioner can shift at any time. At the moment, Rob Manfred is closely monitoring a federal investigation into allegations that the St. Louis Cardinals illegally infiltrated the database of the Houston Astros. Of lesser concern, but still a potential embarrassment, is the possibility that eight Kansas City Royals will be voted to start the All-Star Game next month.

headline: In Eurozone, Growing Support for a Greek Exit
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Economists and government officials in Europe have begun to accept that little more is to be gained in this struggle to get Greece to play by the rules.
lead_paragraph: Of the countless writs and regulations that govern Europe’s currency club, one golden rule trumps them all: Membership is conditional.

headline: ‘The Festival of Insignificance,’ by Milan Kundera
abstract: Five friends in Paris stave off the seriousness of life in Milan Kundera’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: (Editors’ Note: To coincide with our review of Milan Kundera’s first novel in 13 years, we’re posting two related pieces from our archives, published in the Book Review on Nov. 30, 1980: an interview between Philip Roth and Milan Kundera, and John Updike’s review of Kundera’s “The Book of Laughter and Forgetting.”)

headline: Charleston Chief on Church Killings
abstract: Greg Mullen, the police chief of Charleston, S.C., says that a shooting on Wednesday at a historic African-American church that left nine dead was “unfathomable.”
lead_paragraph: Greg Mullen, the police chief of Charleston, S.C., says that a shooting on Wednesday at a historic African-American church that left nine dead was “unfathomable.”

headline: A Father and Son Embrace Meditation
abstract: Ethan Nichtern and his father, David, both teach meditation. The practice has shaped their bond through the years.
lead_paragraph: As a senior Buddhist meditation teacher, Ethan Nichtern, 36, is well versed in the practice. He grew up with a father, David Nichtern, a musician (“Midnight at the Oasis” may be his best known composition), who also teaches meditation. Their shared interest in the practice, they said, helped to smooth the inevitable challenges of any father-son relationship.

headline: Thursday’s Travel News and Tips
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including deals in Palm Springs and London and a a Louvre tour for kids.
lead_paragraph: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Pope Francis, in Sweeping Encyclical, Calls for Swift Action on Climate Change
abstract: He attributed environmental destruction to apathy, the reckless pursuit of profits, excessive faith in technology and political shortsightedness.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis on Thursday called for a radical transformation of politics, economics and individual lifestyles to confront environmental degradation and climate change, blending a biting critique of consumerism and irresponsible development with a plea for swift and unified global action.

headline: Pope Francis Aligns Himself With Mainstream Science on Climate
abstract: If anything, environmental scientists say, the pope may have bent over backward to offer a cautious interpretation of the scientific facts.
lead_paragraph: The new papal encyclical on the environment is a ringing call to action, a critique of consumerism and a prophetic warning about the dangers of ignoring what Pope Francis calls “the ecological crisis.”

headline: On Planet in Distress, a Papal Call to Action
abstract: Pope Francis is issuing an encyclical focusing on an issue of grand scope, the care of the planet. And though he sees the poor as most affected by the economic and political systems underlying the crisis, his 184-page document is an urgent call to action.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis is issuing an encyclical focusing on an issue of grand scope, the care of the planet. And though he sees the poor as most affected by the economic and political systems underlying the crisis, his 184-page document is an urgent call to action.

headline: ‘Folk’ Wisdom
keywords: ['English Language', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: How politicians describe themselves, and the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: Politics is a folksy business. We know politicians are real folks who care about real folks because they are always using the word “folks”: city folks, country folks, hardworking folks, younger folks, older folks, black folks, white folks; even “very kind folks in the media” (says Ted Cruz), “folks who are here undocumented” (Chris Christie) and “folks” who don’t “have a full regard for the right to privacy” (Rand Paul).

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Farmer in the Deli
abstract: Blunt talk and sandwiches at a Brooklyn bodega.
lead_paragraph: Near the northern border of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, at the corner of Myrtle and Adelphi, there is a grocery store called Farmer in the Deli, which is open all day and all night. In addition to a rather clunky pun for a name, Farmer also has a motto: “We don’t make sandwiches, we build them.” Both of these things are nearly meaningless but give you a sense of the bravado that distinguishes this bodega from all the others lining Myrtle Avenue.

headline: LeBron James Has Plenty of Virtues, but Humility Isn’t Among Them
abstract: The Cavaliers star said he was the greatest player in the world, but that distinction, even if true, wasn’t enough against the balanced Warriors.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Golden State Warriors are the N.B.A. champions. But in the aftermath of the Warriors’ convincing performance against the Cleveland Cavaliers, much of the focus was heaped on LeBron James, who turned in one of the most heroic performances in finals history yet failed to carry his team to a title.

headline: Today in Politics: The Congressional Money Wars Are Heating Up
abstract: The campaign trail remains active, but Jeb Bush canceled the last appearance of his announcement week blitz because of the mass shooting at a Charleston, S.C., church. In Congress, attention is returning to budget talks.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where trade is back on the agenda and President Obama heads to the West Coast. The campaign trail remains active, but Jeb Bush canceled the last appearance of his announcement week blitz because of the mass shooting at a Charleston, S.C., church. In Congress, attention is returning to budget talks.

headline: Comedy Central in the Post-TV Era
abstract: The network is in the middle of a creative renaissance — and a business-model crisis.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Cobb’s Comedy Club on the first Saturday in May, Trevor Noah, fresh from the stage, stood sweating through a blue T-shirt, beside a refrigerator stocked with energy drinks. He guzzled from a can as well-wishers popped into his dressing room, getting in their hellos and handshakes before Noah’s second set of the evening. Noah is a 31-year-old comedian from South Africa, and in September, he is scheduled to take over for Jon Stewart as host of “The Daily Show.” For this reason, Noah gave an especially warm welcome to one backstage visitor: Kent Alterman, the president of content and original programming at Comedy Central, the network Noah had just joined. Alterman had flown from Los Angeles, where he lives and works, to San Francisco, where Cobb’s is located, to watch Noah perform. He helped lead the search for Stewart’s replacement, but tonight would be his first time seeing Noah work a crowd in person. “I’ve known Trevor a few years now, and he’s someone we’ve had our eyes on,” Alterman said. “But I’ve never actually seen him do stand-up before.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Wall Street Loses ‘A Force of Nature’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Foreclosures', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mortgages', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Wall Street Loses ‘A Force of Nature’ | Fitbit Valued at $4.1 Billion Before Trading Debut | Greek Exit From Euro Appears More Likely | 6 Banks Face New Limits on Mortgage Operations
lead_paragraph: WALL STREET LOSES ‘A FORCE OF NATURE’  | With the death of James B. Lee Jr. on Wednesday, Wall Street lost one of its most colorful and influential deal makers,  Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in DealBook. Mr. Lee, a vice chairman of JPMorgan Chase, was an early pioneer of syndicated loans and played a key role in the world of leveraged buyouts and private equity, financing deals for Henry Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Stephen A. Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group and the late Theodore J. Forstmann of Fortsmann Little.

headline: ‘But Aren’t You Already Married?’ The Supreme Court, Same-Sex Marriage, and Kids
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Parenting', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: My wife and I are ready to toast marriage equality. But our children don’t need to know their family was ever unequal.
lead_paragraph: My wife and father have a wager on the pending Supreme Court marriage equality decision. Optimism is running strong on both sides: The bet assumes victory and is just a quibble over the split. My wife says 5-4; my father (always the idealist) says 6-3. The winner gets a bottle of 20-year-old port. “Not Champagne?” I asked. “Oh, we’ll be drinking that anyway,” my wife said. And we will. We have, in fact, already set aside a few bottles. But in the midst of our anticipatory reveling I’ve been wondering just how we’ll explain the decision to our children.

headline: Reactions to Hong Kong’s Decision
abstract: Hong Kong politicians react to their legislature rejecting a Beijing-approved proposal to change how the city chooses its top official.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong politicians react to their legislature rejecting a Beijing-approved proposal to change how the city chooses its top official.

headline: Candace Bushnell: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Sex and the City” and, most recently, “Killing Monica” went through an early Nietzsche and Camus phase: “For some reason, nihilism felt like the right sort of mentality for an 18- to 21-year-old.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Sex and the City” and, most recently, “Killing Monica” went through an early Nietzsche and Camus phase: “For some reason, nihilism felt like the right sort of mentality for an 18- to 21-year-old.”

headline: In Iceland, Seeking a Luxury Hotel Amid the Rustic Charm
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Adventure Travel']
abstract: A trip outside Rejkyavik, where minimalist aesthetics and raw nature coexist.
lead_paragraph: It was 3 a.m. by the time we turned down the desolate road that leads to the Ion Luxury Adventure Hotel, an hour’s drive east of Reykjavik, Iceland. Propped up by knock-kneed, tubular stilts, this ominously gorgeous Brutalist slab of glass, steel and concrete juts out from the base of Mount Hengill, an active volcano, over a mossy green lava field.

headline: Nino Cerruti’s Stylish Life, Told Through His Clothing
abstract: An exhibition during the Pitti Uomo men’s wear trade fair proves that, if it was elegant, Mr. Cerruti probably wore it first.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — “I hate the word elegant,” Nino Cerruti, arguably among the more elegant men of the 20th century and, at 84, perhaps also the 21st, said Tuesday morning. “It’s artificial.”

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Reinvention Continues With New Creative Director
abstract: The retailer has selected Katia Kuethe, former creative director of Lucky magazine.
lead_paragraph: The reinvention of Abercrombie & Fitch continues apace. After covering up the barely clad store staff with actual shirts, making the randy-teenagers-romping-the-fields ads G-rated, and bringing in a new men’s wear chief from Club Monaco, the retailer is capping it all off with the appointment of a new creative director: Katia Kuethe, former creative director of Lucky magazine.

headline: Kia and Hyundai Show Improvement in J.D. Power Quality Study
abstract: While the auto industry over all improved by 3 percent in initial quality, South Korean automakers improved by 11 percent, the J.D. Power study showed.
lead_paragraph: South Korean automakers, originally seen as laggards in quality, are quickly closing the gap with their competitors, a major study shows.
