headline: On Technology in Agriculture, Pope Francis’s Concerns are for Corporate Power, Not G.M.O. Risk
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Cereals', 'Encyclicals', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: The pope’s complaints about technology in agriculture, including G.M.O.s, focus on corporate behavior and social impacts, not biological peril.
lead_paragraph: Needless to say, there’s a lot to explore in Pope Francis’s encyclical, “Laudato Si’ — On the Care of Our Common Home,” so I’ll be doing a string of posts, as time permits, on particular sections. This is not a climate encyclical. It is about humanity’s relationship with the environment, including through agricultural practices. [Read Justin Gillis on the climate elements, and explore this annotation of environmental passages by Gillis and The Times’s religion reporter Laurie Goodstein.]

headline: Greece Deal Still Possible, Merkel Says
abstract: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said that Germany aimed to keep Greece in the eurozone and that there would be a deal with creditors if Greek leaders were willing.
lead_paragraph: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said that Germany aimed to keep Greece in the eurozone and that there would be a deal with creditors if Greek leaders were willing.

headline: Classical Playlist: Sibelius, Dvorak and Zorn
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: SIBELIUS: Complete Works for Mixed ChoirHeikki Seppanen, conductor; Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir(Ondine)If you mostly know Sibelius from his visionary symphonies, you might be surprised by the works on this two-disc set. The Finnish choral tradition was rich and active when Sibelius came of age as a composer in the late 1880s, and he wrote choral works all his life, from his student days in Helsinki until 1954 when, at 89 and three decades after his final symphony, he did an arrangement of a favorite Christmas song. The pieces on this rewarding recording range from folk songs suffused with Finnish character to enigmatic works with sometimes dark lyrics. There are festival and school songs, patriotic anthems, a cantata for an academic degree ceremony and, inevitably, two versions of “Finlandia.” Most of the pieces are a cappella. Many unfold in clear, block-chord settings of the texts. If you want to stump friends with a guessing game, play the beguiling, slightly strange “Glade of Tuoni” from this recording and ask them to identify the composer. You’ll win, as you will by picking up this album. (Anthony Tommasini)DVORAK: Symphony No. 9; VARÈSE: ‘Amériques’ Ludovic Morlot, conductor; Seattle Symphony(Seattle Symphony Media)It seems at first a bit perverse, pairing Dvorak’s warm and friendly “New World” Symphony with Varèse’s bellicose and blistering vision of new worlds. More fascinating in any case than the theme of the composers’ physical and psychic encounters with new worlds, whether fleeting or permanent, is the distance musical possibilities themselves had traveled in the mere three decades between the Dvorak (1893) and the Varèse (1922), the great watershed having been Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring” (1913), which Varèse mines for all it is worth. The live performances here do equal justice to the coziness and the riotous upheavals. (James R. Oestreich)JOHN ZORN: ‘Hen to Pan’Jay Campbell, cello; Stephen Gosling, piano; Michael Nicolas, cello; Chris Otto, violin; Tyshawn Sorey, drums(Tzadik)The one constant in this feverishly changeable recording of recent chamber works is Mr. Campbell, an amazing musician who’s game for both Mr. Zorn’s technical challenges and his permeating intensity. Much of this album is taken up by three iterations of “Ouroboros” (2014), a seething, frenetic duet for two cellos that can also be performed with an improvising drummer (here the skittering Tyshawn Sorey). The poise of the gorgeous piano trio “The Aristos” (2014) and the delicacy of “Occam’s Razor” (2013), for cello and piano, are mixed in with uncertainty and collapse. The extremes to which Mr. Zorn flings his performers and listeners are not in themselves new, or newly juxtaposed, but he writes with such sensitivity, assurance and joy that it always somehow seems fresh. (Zachary Woolfe)

headline: Theologian Condemns ‘Ecological Sin’
abstract: Metropolitan John Zizioulas of Pergamon says that the environmental crisis is a “spiritual problem,” during a news conference on Thursday about Pope Francis’ encyclical on climate change.

headline: U.S.G.A. Prizes the Flexibility of the Open Course; the Players Are Less Sure
abstract: After several days, if not weeks, of practice rounds, the United States Open begins Thursday, and the field is still plotting the appropriate approach to the eight-year-old Chambers Bay design.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Mike Davis, the executive director of the United States Golf Association, has heard the emotional critiques of the world’s best golfers as they assess the idiosyncratic layout of Chambers Bay Golf Course, the site of the United States Open.

headline: Daily Report: Uber Ruling Spurs Debate Over Workers
abstract: The ride-hailing company has long positioned itself as a “logistics company” and says its drivers are contractors, not employees.
lead_paragraph: In a ruling that fuels a long-simmering debate over some of Silicon Valley’s fastest-growing technology companies and the work they are creating, the California Labor Commissioner’s Office said that a driver for the ride-hailing service Uber should be classified as an employee, not an independent contractor, Mike Isaac and Natasha Singer report.

headline: Taliban Strike Crucial District in Afghanistan
abstract: The group overran Musa Qala at least temporarily, local residents said, demonstrating the insurgents’ power in an area that American and British troops had long fought to keep out of their control.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters overran part of a crucial district in the southern province of Helmand early Thursday, residents of the area said, demonstrating the insurgents’ growing power in an area that American and British troops had long fought to keep out of Taliban control.

headline: Checkmating the Presidential Debates
abstract: One group recommends a “chess clock” format, in which each candidate has 45 minutes of speaking time — and then must keep quiet.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a presidential debate in which the two finalists have far more power to clash on the show, partisan audience claques are barred, social media are offered innovative roles, and a “chess clock” format allows a candidate to slap an interruption of an adversary’s point for instant rebuttal. No less fantastic, imagine a format that scrapped the noxious post-debate “Spin Alley” where partisan cadres of campaign gurus immediately descend to massage news workers with corrective nuances, postscripts and bromides while the debate stories are still being written.

abstract: Police in Charleston, S.C., released a surveillance photo of the man suspected of killing nine people in a church on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Police in Charleston, S.C., released a surveillance photo of the man suspected of killing nine people in a church on Wednesday night.

abstract: An announcement from Gov. Scott Walker to officially join the crowded Republican presidential field is not expected until mid-July, partly because of the Wisconsin Legislature’s ’s stalemated state budget negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Scott Walker’s official entry into the presidential race came a step closer on Thursday when the Wisconsin governor sought contributions to a newly created “testing the waters” committee.

headline: With Tourist Missing, Worry Spreads on Camino de Santiago in Spain
abstract: An American, Denise Thiem, disappeared in April along the Catholic pilgrimage, which has drawn a record number of people in recent years.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Like many thousands of people from around the world, Denise Thiem, an American tourist, was inspired by a 2010 movie called “The Way” when she set out three months ago to walk the Camino de Santiago, an ancient Catholic pilgrimage whose popularity has grown significantly in recent years.

headline: Review: In William Larson’s ‘Fireflies,’ Fax Transmissions as Art
abstract: Mr. Larson’s “Fireflies” series consists of photographic art made by manipulating the technology of an early fax machine.
lead_paragraph: Before there was email or the Internet, there was the revolutionary fax machine. In a statement accompanying this show, the photographer William Larson describes seeing a demonstration of the technology in 1969, in which an image of “a well-known celebrity” (Muhammad Ali) was sent from Chicago to Philadelphia. The transmission took six minutes, and Mr. Larson, witnessing the event in Philadelphia, was impressed by the picture’s high quality. After this, he obtained a Graphic Sciences DEX 1 Teleprinter for the Tyler School of Art at Temple University, where he taught. From 1969 to 1978, he made the electro-carbon prints on view here.

headline: Vice Gets a New Columnist: A Founding Member of Pussy Riot
abstract: Nadya Tolokonnikova, an outspoken and in-demand critic of the Russian government and an advocate for prisoners’ rights around the world, will write biweekly, starting on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: After being an artist, activist, inmate, speaker and actor, Nadya Tolokonnikova is adding another title to her résumé: online columnist.

headline: Candidates React to Charleston Church Shooting
abstract: The church shooting in Charleston, S.C., happened as the city was the focus of attention in the presidential race. The Times’s live blog on the shooting captures reaction from the candidates.
lead_paragraph: The church shooting in Charleston, S.C., happened as the city was the focus of attention in the presidential race, with Hillary Rodham Clinton appearing in the area Wednesday and Jeb Bush scheduled there today (he canceled his appearance because of the events). The Times’s live blog on the shooting captures reaction from the candidates.

headline: 1915: British Hero Dies In Accident
abstract: From the Archives of the International Herald Tribune: 1915: R.A.J. Warneford, British hero aviator dies in an accident.
lead_paragraph: Flight Sub-Lieutenant R.A.J. Warneford, the gallant young British aviator who ten days ago destroyed a Zeppelin airship single-handed and returned safely to the British lines, to be rewarded with the Victoria Cross and the Cross of the Legion of Honor, is dead — killed by a fall while making a trial flight on a new machine at the Buc aerodrome near Paris. The tragic accident, which has cut short a career of great promise and robbed England of the valued servant who first pricked the Zeppelin’s bubble reputation of invulnerability to aeroplane attack, occurred at five o’clock on Thursday afternoon. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 19, 1915

headline: Thinking About the All Too Thinkable
abstract: Everyone beware, but especially the creditors.
lead_paragraph: The path toward non-Grexit — toward Greece and its creditors reaching a deal that keeps it in the euro — is getting narrower, although it’s not yet completely closed. I’ve been reticent on the subject, for fear of adding my bit to the crisis atmosphere, and I still intend to keep it cool. But there are a few things that seem to need saying.

headline: Dow Jones Begins New Round of Layoffs
abstract: Reductions at The Wall Street Journal eliminated reporting teams and some international bureaus, though the editor said jobs would be added in other areas.
lead_paragraph: Dow Jones, the parent company of The Wall Street Journal, began a sweeping round of job cuts on Thursday, including eliminating entire teams of reporters and closing international bureaus.

headline: Mr. Curry
abstract: Not quite British-style curries in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Not quite British-style curries in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Mr. Curry Speaks Its Own Language
abstract: Three nights a week, Mr. Curry creates a spectrum of flavors found only in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The curry at Mr. Curry, a wonderful, evanescent, not-quite-restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, owes allegiance less to a particular nation than to a state of mind.

headline: Distant British Past Is Also Present for Salisbury
abstract: Between the 800th anniversary of Magna Carta, a copy of which resides there, and summer solstice at Stonehenge, it’s big doings in Salisbury, England.
lead_paragraph: SALISBURY, England — Arthur Pendragon, in his robes and sword, his queen by his side, stood in the long shadow of Salisbury’s magnificent cathedral, which has Britain’s tallest spire and the best-preserved of the four surviving copies of Magna Carta. He was fulminating happily about the intrinsic rights of English men and women, prevented from free access to the other nearby magnificent place of worship, Stonehenge.

headline: Viewfinder: Claudia Ficca and Davide Luciano
abstract: Work from Claudia Ficca and Davide Luciano, who recreate scenes from “The Shining” using food.
lead_paragraph: Work from Claudia Ficca and Davide Luciano, who recreate scenes from “The Shining” using food.

headline: Fashion Is Unavoidable at Pitti Uomo
abstract: The men’s wear trade show included an alfresco show by Ports 1961, Massimo Giorgetti’s Pucci debut and a look back by Thomas Tait.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — During the Pitti Uomo trade show, men’s fashion is unavoidable. It spills into the streets, busy with the double-breasted jacket brigade. At the sacred aperitivo hour in the Piazza Ognissanti, the crowds sipping spritzers on the terrace of the St. Regis hotel were treated to an alfresco fashion show by Ports 1961. Guests on a balcony of the nearby Westin Excelsior watched, too, and there were faces pressed to the windows at office buildings and residences around the square.

headline: Fitbit Shares Surge 48 Percent in Market Debut
abstract: Shares of the maker of wearable fitness-tracking devices closed at $29.68 on Thursday, up sharply from the I.P.O. price of $20.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Fitbit soared in their trading debut on Thursday, even after the company priced its initial public offering above an already heightened range.

headline: Restaurant Report: Prima in Honolulu
abstract: The menu is divided between “not pizza” and pizza made in a hand-built brick oven from Naples.
lead_paragraph: When you pull up to this highly regarded restaurant in one of Honolulu’s sprawling suburbs, the first instinct is to double-check your GPS. The ambitious culinary experiment is bizarrely sandwiched in a plaza between a Foodland grocery store and a Baskin-Robbins.

headline: Blurring the Museum-Gallery Divide
abstract: Galleries are recruiting stars from the museum world to promote (and sell) their artists’ work.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Mark Rosenthal left his job as head of 20th-century art at the National Gallery in Washington to become an independent curator, museums around the country have sought his talents. Now art galleries are trying to hire him, too — but not just for his scholarship.

headline: Hotel Review: Praktik Bakery Hotel in Barcelona
abstract: The 74-room Praktik Bakery Hotel, with cheerful, inexpensive rooms, includes an artisanal bakery on the ground floor.
lead_paragraph: From 89 euros a night, or about $96 at $1.08 to the euro.

headline: With Charleston Shooting, a Time to Stop Teaching Children About the ‘History’ of Racial Violence
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: How many of your children have come home from school to tell you that black people “used to” be treated differently?
lead_paragraph: In the wake of violence and tragedies, I often find myself writing about, and thinking about, how to approach the topic with my children, who may be frightened by the facts or, at an older age, by our inability to offer a satisfying explanation for why people do the terrible things they sometimes do.

headline: Anish Kapoor Sculpture Vandalized at Versailles
abstract: An enormous, curved sculpture in the garden of Versailles was vandalized on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Vandals spray-painted an enormous, curved sculpture in the garden of the 17th-century palace of Versailles on Wednesday that its creator, Anish Kapoor, had once characterized as a sexual symbol of the “vagina of a queen taking power.”

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Vandals spray-painted an enormous, curved sculpture in the garden of the 17th-century palace of Versailles on Wednesday that its creator, Anish Kapoor, had once characterized as a sexual symbol of the “vagina of a queen taking power.”

headline: A Clip from the Film Eden
abstract: Félix de Givry and Greta Gerwig star in a film about the rise of electronic music in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Félix de Givry and Greta Gerwig star in a film about the rise of electronic music in Paris.

headline: Romancing Authors
abstract: Jonathan Galassi talks about his first novel, “Muse,” which is set in the world of New York publishing.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Galassi, the longtime head of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, didn’t stray far for the setting of his first novel, “Muse,” which takes place in the world of New York publishing. (Erica Wagner reviews “Muse” this week.)

headline: A Right Age to Change One's Sex?
abstract: How old should a person be before they have gender reassignment treatment or surgery?

headline: Israeli Police Investigate Arson at ‘Loaves and Fishes’ Church
abstract: The police said the attack on the church, which stands on the site where many Christians believe Jesus performed the miracle of the loaves and fishes, was a possible hate crime.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Catholic church at a revered site near the Sea of Galilee in northern Israel was damaged by fire early on Thursday, in what the police are treating as an arson attack and possible hate crime.

headline: Richard Zabel, Bharara’s Deputy, Moves to Elliott Management
abstract: Mr. Zabel, the deputy United States attorney in Manhattan, will become general counsel at the hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: If Preet Bharara’s office were adapted for a Hollywood script, Richard B. Zabel’s character would probably be akin to Dr. John Watson or perhaps Mr. Spock, a trusted lieutenant to a prominent leading man.

headline: Supreme Court Says Texas Can Reject Confederate Flag License Plates
keywords: ['Automobile Registration and License Plates', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The court ruled, 5 to 4, on Thursday that specialty license plates are the government’s speech and are thus immune from First Amendment attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that Texas did not violate the First Amendment when it refused to allow specialty license plates bearing the Confederate battle flag. Such plates, Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote for the majority, are the government’s speech and are thus immune from First Amendment attacks.

headline: Rob Delaney, a Hit on Twitter, Turns to Television With ‘Catastrophe’
abstract: Mr. Delaney brings his biting relationship comedy, which ran earlier this year in Britain, to Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Rob Delaney is onstage at the Bell House in Brooklyn, telling jokes about deviant sex acts with a car commercial smile.

headline: Limits on Church Signs Ruled Unconstitutional
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Signs and Signage', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The justices unanimously ruled that a town’s restrictions on the size of church signs violated the First Amendment, but they were divided on the rationale.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously ruled that an Arizona town had violated the First Amendment by placing limits on the size of signs announcing church services.

headline: In Brian Williams Decision, NBC Clings to the Past
abstract: NBC’s response seems to ignore the big changes in the media landscape, which have reshaped the relationship between newscasters and consumers.
lead_paragraph: In the end, NBC decided that it couldn’t bring him back or let him go.

headline: Ex-Rikers Captain Is Sentenced to 5 Years in Inmate’s Death
abstract: The captain, Terrence Pendergrass, had been convicted of violating the civil rights of the inmate, Jason Echevarria, for refusing to seek help for Mr. Echevarria after he swallowed a soap ball.
lead_paragraph: A former captain at Rikers Island was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison for violating the civil rights of an inmate, Jason Echevarria, who died after swallowing a soap ball under the captain’s supervision.

headline: When Doctors Don’t Talk to Doctors
abstract: Poor communication between doctors and patients is discussed relatively frequently. But what about confusion between the teams of doctors who share patients in the hospital?
lead_paragraph: I could tell my patient was dying. In the final stage of liver failure, she lay listlessly in her hospital bed, her skin ashen and her eyes dull. Intractable intestinal bleeding, likely related to her underlying disease, had landed her in the intensive care unit. Although all patients in intensive care are tenuous, it was clear she was worse off than most.

headline: Arianna Huffington Renews Contract for Four Years
abstract: Ms. Huffington’s contract had expired this year, and there was speculation she might leave after the publication’s parent company, AOL, was acquired by Verizon.
lead_paragraph: Arianna Huffington, a founder of The Huffington Post, has signed a new four-year contract to remain chairwoman, president and editor in chief of the publication, ending speculation that she might leave now that its parent company, AOL, was acquired by Verizon.

headline: 1940: Hitler And Mussolini Meet in Munich
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: 1940: Hitler and Mussolini meet in Munich
lead_paragraph: In the midst of Nazi military pomp, Fuehrer Adolf Hitler and his eleventh-hour ally Premier Mussolini met today [June 15] in Munich where on Sept. 19, 1938, ‘‘peace in our time’’ was arranged through the partitioning of Czecho-Slovakia. In a four-hour conference, they agreed ‘‘on the attitude to be assumed’’ by the German and Italian governments ‘‘towards the French requests for an armistice.’’ Traveling presumably in opposite directions, the two dictators left Munich soon after their meeting ended. — New York Herald Tribune, June 19, 1940

headline: Father’s Day — Solved!
abstract: Stumped about what to get Dad? Here are some suggestions, from the tried-and-true to the charmingly unexpected.
lead_paragraph: There are two types of fathers: those who say, “Don’t get me anything for Father’s Day” and mean it, and those who say the same thing and don’t.

headline: House Sends Trade Bill Back to Senate in Bid to Outflank Foes
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The vote is part of a strategy to advance prospects for a trans-Pacific accord by uncoupling the measure from a worker-assistance provision.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday approved a bill to give President Obama accelerated negotiating authority to pursue a sweeping, legacy-building trade agreement with 11 Pacific Rim nations, Part 1 of a complex legislative strategy devised by Republicans to get a trade package to Mr. Obama’s desk after Democrats derailed the measure in the House last week.

headline: London’s Most Ramshackle Saturday Market
abstract: A closer look at some of Netil Market’s regulars, who vend items out of sheds, vans and shipping crates.
lead_paragraph: Some of London’s most historic markets, such as Spitalfields, have been swept up in a wave of “regeneration” that leaves niche businesses withering in the wake of big brands. Smithfield, the capital’s 800-year-old meat market is the next (contentiously) earmarked for a facelift. Others, like Borough Market – nowadays more of a gourmet tourist destination than a local amenity — are victims of their own success. Which makes below-the-radar spots like Netil Market, a small community of creative start-ups in London Fields, to the east of the city, such a rarity. This motley assortment of sheds, vans and shipping crates, which sits in the shadow of the London Overground, has a charming, if ramshackle, feel. “There’s a barber, an optician, a jeweler and lots of street food vendors,” says Paul Firmin, a co-founder of the lifestyle boutique and scent brand Earl of East London, which launched on the market last summer. “It’s like a little modern-day High Street.”

headline: Papal Encyclical Heartens Proponents of Fossil-Fuel Divestment
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Encyclicals', 'Endowments']
abstract: By addressing the threat of climate change so forcefully, Pope Francis is likely to add momentum to the movement by big institutions to sell holdings tied to fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: The word “divestment” is nowhere to be found in the nearly 200 pages of the papal encyclical released Thursday, but by addressing the threat of climate change in such a forceful way, Pope Francis is likely to add momentum to the movement by big institutions to sell holdings tied to fossil-fuel stocks.

headline: Making Video Games For Everyone (Not Just the Able-Bodied)
abstract: A new game featuring a blind heroine highlights the need for more games designed with people with disabilities in mind.
lead_paragraph: In the video game “Perception,” sound is as important as sight — if not more so. Start the game’s trailer and you’ll enter the aural landscape of a haunted house, complete with flapping moths, creaking doors, a creepy talking doll and, amid it all, the regular taps of the heroine’s cane.

headline: Dylann Roof, Suspect in Charleston Shooting, Flew the Flags of White Power
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: The suspect in the mass shooting at a black church in Charleston, S.C., appears on his Facebook page in a jacket adorned with flags adopted as emblems by white supremacists.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, S.C. — The Facebook profile picture chosen by Dylann Storm Roof in May is thick with symbolism. It shows Mr. Roof, a scowling young white man, wearing a black jacket adorned with two flags — one from apartheid-era South Africa, the other from white-ruled Rhodesia — that have been adopted as emblems by modern-day white supremacists.

headline: New DNA Results Show Kennewick Man Was Native American
abstract: A new analysis, published in Nature, refutes the theory that the 8,500-year-old skeleton was a European. Instead, he was related to contemporary Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: In July 1996, two college students were wading in the shallows of the Columbia River near the town of Kennewick, Wash., when they stumbled across a human skull.

headline: F.C.C. Votes to Move Forward With Plan to Subsidize Broadband for Poor Americans
abstract: The agency on Thursday voted along party lines to move forward with a plan to amend a $1.7 billion phone subsidy program to cover broadband Internet.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday voted along party lines to approve a proposal to explore subsidizing broadband Internet for poor Americans. The plan, introduced last month by the agency’s Democratic chairman, Tom Wheeler, helps pave the way for sweeping changes to a $1.7 billion phone subsidy program.

lead_paragraph: The president discussed the shooting in Charleston, S.C., saying, “We as a country will have to reckon with the fact that this type of mass violence does not happen in other advanced countries.”

headline: Review: ‘True Detective,’ Season 2 on HBO, Plays a Symphony of Misery
abstract: There’s a lot of star power and screen charisma in the new season of this crime drama, but the four central characters live in a haze of gloom.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of people who insist that auteur-driven television series like “True Detective” are the 19th-century novels of the visual age. That’s certainly arguable, though in fairness, the compliment should go both ways — Balzac, Dickens and Trollope are the showrunners of the written word.

headline: The Real Town Behind ‘True Detective’ Season 2
abstract: A look at the California city that inspired the second season of “True Detective.”
lead_paragraph: Vernon, Calif., The Times wrote in 2011, “is a bleak, 5.2-square-mile sprawl of warehouses, factories, toxic chemical plants and meat processors that looks like the backdrop for ‘Eraserhead,’ the David Lynch movie set in an industrial wasteland.”

abstract: Need something to do? The Times’s arts team is here for you.
lead_paragraph: Looking for something to do this weekend?

headline: The Charleston Shooting: What Happened
abstract: Here is a rundown of what we know so far.
lead_paragraph: A 21-year-old white man is suspected of opening fire on a prayer meeting he had been attending at an African-American church in Charleston, S.C., on Wednesday night.  Nine people were fatally shot before he fled in a black sedan. (Our live blog has the latest.) This is security footage of him entering the church.

headline: Clues to the Mood for ‘True Detective,’ Season 2, on HBO
abstract: For the start of the second season, here are some literary and cinematic offerings to help put you in the prevailing mood.
lead_paragraph: Before the first season of HBO’s “True Detective,” all anyone really knew about the show was that it involved a grisly murder in Louisiana and that it featured two bona fide movie stars: Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson. Then it became a hit, stirring the Internet into a frenzy and earning 12 Emmy nominations.

headline: Painting’s First Time in New York? No Way, No How, Says Brooklyn Man
abstract: The Frick Collection said its display of Frederic Leighton’s masterpiece “Flaming June” was the first in New York City. But an East Flatbush man’s memory said otherwise.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that art history – even a small, relatively recent piece of it – is rewritten by a retired school-bus-company manager from Brooklyn. But that’s what happened this week, when Ed Miranda, of East Flatbush, read a review in The New York Times of an exhibition at the Frick Collection featuring Frederic Leighton’s lush Victorian masterpiece, “Flaming June,” which the museum said has made its maiden voyage to New York from its permanent home at the Museo de Arte de Ponce in Puerto Rico.

headline: Douglas Carter Beane Returns to His Childhood ‘Home’
abstract: The playwright took a bus from Manhattan to Reading, Pa., to revisit the theater that inspired his new play, “Shows for Days.”
lead_paragraph: READING, PA. — Douglas Carter Beane took the bus here from Manhattan because he still doesn’t drive, never has. He bypassed that rite of passage nearly 40 years ago, too busy making theater to care. As a teenager in Wyomissing, a comfortable suburb just across the Schuylkill, he dreamed of a future in New York City. Who would need a driver’s license there?

headline: Resurrecting Inge’s Aching Empathy in ‘Off the Main Road’
abstract: Inge enthusiasts are trying to bolster the playwright’s profile with the first full staging of a largely forgotten 1960s play at the Williamstown Theater Festival.
lead_paragraph: For much of the 1950s, William Inge was atop the Broadway heap. He wrote four successful plays. He won a Pulitzer and an Oscar.

headline: Weekday Car Traffic to Be Banned in Parts of Central and Prospect Parks
abstract: The closings, which pedestrian advocates have been seeking for decades, would banish cars from sections of the thoroughfares along the edges of both parks.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday that he will close large parts of New York City’s two most celebrated parks to car traffic on weekdays.

headline: Brian Williams Gets New Role at Lower Salary
abstract: NBC will move Mr. Williams to MSNBC as anchor of breaking news and special reports, removing him as evening news anchor because of “inaccurate statements’’ made in his reporting.
lead_paragraph: After four months of twisting in the wind, Brian Williams can finally get back to work at NBC, but not without a humbling blow. Mr. Williams’s return includes a demotion, a lower salary and an apology tour that began on Thursday with NBC News staff members in New York and Washington, and will continue on national television with an interview on the “Today” show on Friday.

headline: Time to Catch Up on Baseball
abstract: Now that the basketball and hockey playoffs are over, it’s time to test your knowledge of the baseball season so far.

abstract: Bruno Dumont’s “Li’l Quinquin” examines a French community during a rash of murders; “The Wire,” now available in a box set, dissects a drug-ridden city.
lead_paragraph: A onetime professor of philosophy, Bruno Dumont may be the most high-minded exponent of the discomfitingly visceral art films that have been called the New French Extremity or cinéma du corps.

headline: In Report on Data Collection Practices, WhatsApp and AT&T Fail the Test
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Software', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: In a report about data privacy published by the Electronic Frontier Foundation this week, tech companies like Yahoo, Apple and Adobe earned top marks, while WhatsApp and AT&T came in last.
lead_paragraph: In the post-Snowden era, tech companies are increasingly being rated not only for the quality of their gadgets and services, but also for how they handle government requests for customer data. In the Electronic Frontier Foundation’s annual report on data collection practices, tech companies like Yahoo, Apple and Adobe earned top marks, while WhatsApp and AT&T came in last.

headline: Still Deadlocked With Greece, Europe Sets Emergency Summit Meeting
abstract: Eurozone finance ministers said on Thursday that they had failed to reach a deal on Greece’s international bailout, and said that time was running out.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — European leaders will try again in an emergency summit meeting on Monday to break the deadlock between Greece and its international creditors after a meeting of eurozone finance ministers ended on Thursday with no deal on Greece’s bailout.

headline: Charleston Church Shooting Suspect Is Captured
abstract: Charleston’s police chief said that the suspect in the shooting at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church was caught in Shelby, N.C.

headline: Kacey Musgraves and Other ‘Tomatoes’ Give Country Its Bite
abstract: Country’s long-familiar war on women has reached fever pitch recently, even as the quality of music made by women has surpassed that of their male counterparts.
lead_paragraph: When Kacey Musgraves had her Nashville breakthrough two years ago, she was, depending on the angle you viewed her from, an outsider hero or a savvy infiltrator. Her musical tastes skewed toward the 1950s and the ’70s, and her subject matter skewed liberal — even when she was singing about marijuana or same-sex love, she did it under a traditionalist cloak.

headline: Who Can Identify Themselves as Black?  Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporter John Eligon describes how he explored broad questions raised when the former Spokane, Wash., N.A.A.C.P. president Rachel Dolezal said, “I identify as black.”
lead_paragraph: In the digital world, opinions travel with gigabit quickness. Everyone is a pundit and everyone has the right answer.

headline: Beyond Climate – A Hidden Gem in the Pope’s Encyclical on Making Social Media Matter
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Earth', 'Encyclicals', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Global Warming', 'Social Media']
abstract: A hidden gem amid Pope Francis’s climate and consumption concerns is his call to use global communication tools to foster human progress.
lead_paragraph: The main conversation around Pope Francis’s remarkable encyclical letter is appropriately on the core messages — that human-driven climate change is dangerous; access to energy matters; that consumptive capitalism is a problem, not a solution.

headline: Charleston Church Shooting Suspect Is Captured
abstract: Charleston’s police chief said that the suspect in the shooting at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church was caught in Shelby, N.C.
lead_paragraph: Charleston’s police chief said that the suspect in the shooting at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church was caught in Shelby, N.C.

headline: Denmark Votes in Close Race
abstract: Prime Minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt and the opposition leader Lars Lokke Rasmussen cast their votes Thursday in Copenhagen.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt and the opposition leader Lars Lokke Rasmussen cast their votes Thursday in Copenhagen.

headline: After Charleston Shooting, a Sense at the White House of Horror, Loss and Resolve
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After shootings in Charleston, S.C., and elsewhere, the promise President Obama’s election brought for improved relations among the races seems out of reach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The shooting massacre of a black pastor and his parishioners at a South Carolina church on Wednesday night once again confronted President Obama with a moment of racial turmoil in a country that for all its progress has yet to completely shed the burden of hatred and division.

headline: A Trove of 19th-Century Engravings Conjures a Lost World
abstract: Thousands of Rudolph Laubenheimer’s works, in storage for more than a hundred years, will head to auction this month.
lead_paragraph: In storage for more than a hundred years, thousands of 19th-century graphics and medals designed by Rudolph P. Laubenheimer, a self-described “engraver, die sinker and medailleur,” will be auctioned this month. The sale, run by Archives International Auctions in Manhattan on June 25, was initiated by his descendants in Maine and will offer part of the contents of Laubenheimer’s New York City workshop.

headline: Officer Fatally Shoots a Man Who Slashed Him in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Police officials said Officer Filippo Gugliara had been slashed at the base of his neck on his collarbone at a Q train station in Brighton Beach before firing at the 58-year-old attacker.
lead_paragraph: A 58-year-old man who attacked a uniformed New York City police officer with a knife near an elevated Brooklyn subway station on Thursday was shot dead by the officer after he refused to drop the knife, police officials said.

headline: Fishing Camps Move Beyond Tents
abstract: Fly-fishing camps at contemporary lodges include modern touches as well as access to private waters.
lead_paragraph: Historically a sport for bare-bones tent camping, fly fishing is upping its game, said Mike Fitzgerald, the president of Frontiers Travel, which specializes in fly-fishing trips and other excursions for the outdoorsy type.

headline: Canadian Senator Expelled From Party’s Caucus Over Claims of Affair With Teenager
abstract: The governing Conservative Party removed Don Meredith from its caucus after a newspaper reported that he had had an extramarital affair with a teenage girl.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The governing Conservative Party removed a member of Canada’s Senate from its caucus on Wednesday night after The Toronto Star reported that he had had an extramarital affair with a teenage girl.

headline: Hungary’s Plan to Build Fence to Deter Migrants Is Criticized
abstract: Plans to build a fence along the Hungarian-Serbian border have touched a nerve in Europe as debate rages over how to handle the soaring number of migrants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Union was supposed to be about breaking down borders and barriers. But critics say that message appears to have been lost on Hungary, which drew international condemnation this week for its government’s plans to erect a fence along the Serbian border to keep out migrants.

headline: Teva Ruling Clears Way for Generic Version of Multiple Sclerosis Drug
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Multiple Sclerosis', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: A federal appeals court on Thursday again invalidated a patent protecting Teva Pharmaceutical’s big-selling drug, Copaxone, which can cost $60,000 a year.
lead_paragraph: The first generic version of a multiple sclerosis drug went on the market Thursday, hours after a federal appeals court again invalidated a patent for the brand-name drug, Copaxone, a major moneymaker for Teva Pharmaceutical.

headline: In Athens, Austerity Makes Contemporary Art Palatable
abstract: Amid political and economic turmoil, Greek artists find inspiration, opportunity and a growing audience.
lead_paragraph: Austerity measures have been bad for Greeks, but good for tourism, which shot up 28.8 percent in the first three months of this year compared with the same period in 2014. Another beneficiary? Artists. Rent for studio space is significantly cheaper than in other European capitals, and the political and economic turmoil have provided plenty of artistic fodder — not to mention a frustrated, attentive audience. In the wake of these woes, artists, curators, critics and nonprofits are finding that contemporary art is having its moment in a city best known as the epicenter of the ancient world.

headline: The Murders at Mother Emanuel Church in Charleston
abstract: The crime raises disturbing questions about how another obsessed individual in America got his hands on another deadly weapon.
lead_paragraph: The shooting in Charleston on Wednesday night left nine people dead — nine worshipers who had come to the historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church for peace and evening prayers.  Witnesses said the white shooter was muttering deeply racist comments as he fired into the predominantly African-American congregation. If so, this was a crime bred by a particularly craven form of racial hatred. And it raises disturbing questions about how another obsessed individual in America got his hands on another deadly weapon.

headline: Royal Ascot Style Guide
abstract: The five-day Royal Ascot meet in England requires its patrons to adhere to strict dress codes.
lead_paragraph: The five-day Royal Ascot meet in England requires its patrons to adhere to strict dress codes.

headline: A Scrimshaw Collector’s Treasured Carvings
abstract: The collection of Thomas Mittler, who died in 2010, is subject to a book by his widow, and much of it is set to be sold at auction.
lead_paragraph: Collecting scrimshaw is a dicey hobby, given the prevalence of forgeries in the field — plastic resin copies are known as fakeshaw.

headline: In Basel, Resting Spots for the Weary
abstract: Amid the hubbub of the art fair, some booths are offering work that doubles as a place to sit down.
lead_paragraph: The sheer number of sectors at Art Basel — Galleries, Statements and Feature on the Messeplatz, plus the gigantic Unlimited and the intimate public art of Parcours, in a charming medieval courtyard across town — can make scurrying around to check out all the work a bit exhausting. It’s convenient, then, that the worldwide uptick in interactive art spectacles has provided fairgoers and exhibitors something that can ease weary bodies: a place to sit down.

headline: In Basel, Resting Spots for the Weary

headline: Hilary Masters, Novelist and Son of American Poet, Dies at 87
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: Mr. Masters, the son of Edgar Lee Masters, taught at Carnegie Mellon University for 32 years. His writing won praise for a keen sensitivity to ordinary life.
lead_paragraph: For a 7-year-old, Hilary Masters sounded precociously lyrical when he arrived in New York for the first time and remarked, “Oh, boy, Mom, what glory is ahead of me!”

headline: Currency Demotion Strikes Unwelcome Chord at ‘Hamilton’ Rehearsal
abstract: At a celebratory event for the coming Broadway show, Alexander Hamilton biographer Ron Chernow was critical of the Treasury Department for planning to give the Founding Father less prominence on the $10 bill.
lead_paragraph: The cast of “Hamilton” is feeling giddy. Their show, which begins performances on Broadway next month, is the talk of the town, and is selling well. Their subject, Alexander Hamilton, is resurgent in the popular imagination. But on Thursday, as they gathered to begin rehearsals, there was one sour note in the air: just a day earlier, the Treasury Department announced that it was going to redesign the $10 bill to feature a woman, keeping Hamilton on the currency, but presumably in a less prominent position.

headline: Currency Demotion Strikes Unwelcome Chord at ‘Hamilton’ Rehearsal
abstract: At a celebratory event for the coming Broadway show, Alexander Hamilton biographer Ron Chernow was critical of the Treasury Department for planning to give the Founding Father less prominence on the $10 bill.
lead_paragraph: The cast of “Hamilton” is feeling giddy. Their show, which begins performances on Broadway next month, is the talk of the town, and is selling well. headline: How the Search for Dylann Roof Unfolded
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: After a deadly shooting at Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., details of the case and suspect were released, intentionally and by mistake, and an arrest was made in less than 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: After a deadly shooting at Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., details of the case and suspect were released, intentionally and by mistake, and an arrest was made in less than 24 hours.

headline: Killings Add Painful Page to Storied History of Charleston Church
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, where nine people were killed in Wednesday’s shooting, is one of the oldest black churches in the South.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church is one of the oldest, most storied black congregations in the South. Its members met in secret in the years when black churches were outlawed here before the Civil War, and it contains a shrine to one of its founders, who helped organize a slave revolt in 1822.

headline: Killings at a Black Church in Charleston
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Readers express their horror and grief at what appears to be a racially motivated attack on a black church.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Long-Lost Merce Cunningham Work Is Reconstructed in Boston
abstract: The work, “Changeling,” last seen in Tokyo in 1964, will be performed at the Institute of Contemporary Art this fall.
lead_paragraph: Merce Cunningham used chance to choreograph his legendary solo dance “Changeling.” Now chance has given new life to this long-lost work.

headline: A Retrospective of Wall Painting in Chelsea
abstract: The exhibition “Hello Walls” brings together 16 artists at Barbara Gladstone’s two Chelsea galleries.
lead_paragraph: “When something’s painted directly on the wall, it has a certain immediacy and freshness,” said Mel Bochner, the conceptual artist whose word paintings were inspired partly by the psychological and political power of graffiti scrawled on walls during the 1968 student riots in Paris. “There’s no interference between the viewer and the experience.”

headline: Summer Wine: 20 for $20
abstract: It’s not a question of red or white or even pink. It’s about the proper weight and price.
lead_paragraph: Hot-weather drinking requires its own genre of wines: light, easygoing, blithe and, above all, refreshing. These sorts of wines are enjoyable year-round, but in the sweaty summer months, the desirable becomes the imperative.

headline: Gavin Brown Moving Gallery to Harlem
abstract: In Harlem, he plans three floors of exhibition space, one gallery a clean white box while others will retain their raw character.
lead_paragraph: Harlem may be far from the madding crowd of galleries in downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn. But this summer Gavin Brown is closing shop on Greenwich Street in the West Village and moving his gallery to a former brewery at 461 West 126th Street.

headline: A Pair of Kings Will Succeed Ken Watanabe in ‘The King And I’
abstract: Jose Llana and then Hoon Lee will portray the King of Siam opposite Kelli O’Hara in the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical revival.
lead_paragraph: When Ken Watanabe steps down from his role as the King of Siam in the Tony-winning revival of “The King and I” in July, he’ll be replaced by Jose Llana, who starred as Filipino President Ferdinand Marcos in the Public Theater’s smash “Here Lies Love.”

headline: A Pair of Kings Will Succeed Ken Watanabe in ‘The King And I’
abstract: Jose Llana and then Hoon Lee will portray the King of Siam opposite Kelli O’Hara in the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical revival.
lead_paragraph: When Ken Watanabe steps down from his role as the King of Siam in the Tony-winning revival of “The King and I” in July, he’ll be replaced by Jose Llana, who starred as Filipino President Ferdinand Marcos in the Public Theater’s smash “Here Lies Love.”

headline: An Exclusive Clip From Mia Hansen-Love’s ‘Eden’
abstract: The director’s new film, a fictionalized study of the French house music scene, stars Félix de Givry and features Greta Gerwig.
lead_paragraph: Take one glance at the title and premise of “Eden,” a fictionalized study of the French house music scene through the eyes of the up-and-coming D.J./producer Paul (Félix de Givry), and you might be expecting a completely different film. What could have been a hedonistic two-hour rave in the hands of others is instead, with Mia Hansen-Love at the helm, a hungover look at the morning after the party. The 33-year-old director, who’s built her career on tackling pain — loss, depression, suicide — had a major advantage when approaching the golden era of electronic music in France: she, and her co-writer and brother, Sven, lived through it.

headline: Violent History: Attacks on Black Churches
abstract: The killing of nine people at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., is among a long list of attacks targeting predominantly black churches in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The killing of nine people at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., is among a long list of attacks targeting predominantly black churches in the United States.

headline: Qaeda Branch’s Twitter Posts Appear to Show U.S. Hostage Before His Death
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A series of photographs on Twitter appeared to show the worker, Warren Weinstein, as a convert to Islam in the months before he was killed in an American drone strike.
lead_paragraph: A branch of Al Qaeda has posted a series of photographs on Twitter that appear to show Warren Weinstein, an American aid worker, in the months before he was killed in a United States drone strike while being held hostage in northwestern Pakistan.

headline: Carnegie Deli to Remain Closed at Least 2 More Weeks
abstract: The famed delicatessen, which its owner’s lawyer says will remain closed, has been shut since late April, when Con Edison discovered it had been stealing natural gas.
lead_paragraph: The Carnegie Deli, which was found in late April to have been stealing about half of the gas it used for cooking and heating, will remain closed for at least two more weeks, a lawyer for the owner said.

headline: An Ant With the Right Coat for 158-Degree Weather
abstract: A unique coat of hair covers silver ants of the Sahara and keeps them cool, a discovery with potential practical applications for humans.

headline: How to Find Hassle-Free Playing Fields With Priceless Views
abstract: Booking athletic fields in New York City can be difficult, but you can cut through the red tape in some parks.
lead_paragraph: The paperwork and fees for booking athletic fields in New York City can make playing ball feel more like applying to college. Avoid bureaucracy — and enjoy the waterfront views — at these uncomplicated places.

headline: Hats and Decorum Reign at Royal Ascot
abstract: The five days of racing at Royal Ascot attract not only some of the finest horses but also an elegantly dressed crowd that must adhere to strict dress codes.
lead_paragraph: The five days of racing at Royal Ascot attract not only some of the finest horses but also an elegantly dressed crowd that must adhere to strict dress codes.

headline: Want to See Royal Ascot Races? Bettor, Bring Your Top Hat
abstract: The five days of horse racing are fine, but so is the accompanying fashion display, which has strict rules and culminates on Ladies’ Day.
lead_paragraph: ASCOT, England — While Americans view the Kentucky Derby as the time and place to break out their best hats and go to the races, the overall finery on display pales in comparison to what one sees during the five-day Royal Ascot meet here.

headline: DNA May Help Track Ivory Poachers
abstract: DNA evidence from elephant dung, tissue and hair can help identify the origins of illegal ivory, researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: DNA evidence retrieved from elephant dung, tissue and hair can help identify the origins of illegal ivory, a new study finds. Researchers at the University of Washington and Interpol developed a method to extract DNA from samples of ivory, and compared the gene sequences with those obtained from dung and tissue samples.

headline: Seeking Travel Questions (Kids Only Need Apply)
abstract: If you’re a tween or teenager, post your questions about travel on our Facebook page, or submit your photos of a favorite souvenir to the Travel section on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Last year I wrote an essay about the importance of seemingly ordinary yet prized mementos — souvenirs I didn’t buy but, rather, found or was given, be it stones from the Irish Sea or a 2-cent euro coin that I spied on a Paris sidewalk. Some objects, like a little book of Shakespeare quotes, given to me by a British tour guide, I’ve had since I was a young student.

headline: ‘Lynda Benglis: Water Sources’
abstract: This exhibition runs through Nov. 8 at Storm King Art Center.
lead_paragraph: This exhibition runs through Nov. 8 at Storm King Art Center.

headline: Review: Lynda Benglis Celebrates the Fluidity of Nature at Storm King
abstract: The main attraction of Ms. Benglis’s exhibition is a quartet of gorgeous fountains.
lead_paragraph: The most compelling temporary exhibition produced by the Storm King Art Center in recent years, “Lynda Benglis: Water Sources” focuses on a heretofore unfamiliar but important dimension of Ms. Benglis’s distinguished career: creating working fountains. The show’s main attraction is a quartet of gorgeous fountains rising from temporary, circular pools embedded in the lawn outside the center’s home building.

headline: Missing a Father I Hardly Knew
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Death and Dying', 'Psychics and Psychic Phenomena']
abstract: Waiting for a big secret to be revealed provides ample time for insights into a relationship with a guarded parent.
lead_paragraph: The psychic started to laugh.

headline: Review: Tony Danza at the Café Carlyle Cabaret
abstract: Though more an entertainer than crooner, Mr. Danza interpreted a Sinatra favorite, “It Was a Very Good Year.”
lead_paragraph: Late in his show “Standards and Stories,” at Café Carlyle on Wednesday, Tony Danza, that talented eternally boyish guy from the neighborhood with the ingenuous grin and cocky attitude, pulled out an obscure ballad, “I Don’t Remember Ever Growing Up,” that hit an unexpectedly poignant note. Its composer, Artie Butler, wrote the music to that inescapable nightclub standard “Here’s to Life,” with lyrics by Phyllis Molinary. “I Don’t Remember Ever Growing Up,” whose narrator has reached an age when “life goes by at twice the speed of light, leaving you with just your memories,” is in the same vein of wistful summing up songs, although not half as good.

headline: Former Israeli Envoy Weighs In on Frayed Relations Between Obama and Netanyahu
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States International Relations', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Israeli apologies were in order after the former envoy, Michael B. Oren, wrote about President Obama’s dealings with Israel and Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Divvying up blame for the icy relationship between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has been a favored parlor game in both countries for years.

headline: Report Finds Growth in Arts Donations
abstract: According to Giving USA, donations rose 9.2 percent in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Gifts of $200 million and more helped boost Americans’ overall donations to the arts 9.2 percent in 2014, the highest increase in nine categories tracked by Giving USA, an annual report on charitable contributions.

headline: Report Finds Growth in Arts Donations
abstract: According to Giving USA, donations rose 9.2 percent in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Gifts of $200 million and more helped boost Americans’ overall donations to the arts 9.2 percent in 2014, the highest increase in nine categories tracked by Giving USA, an annual report on charitable contributions.

headline: For Automakers, Fuel Economy Targets May Be Less of a Stretch
abstract: A federal report found that hitting the corporate average of 54.5 miles per gallon might not be as difficult as the industry had feared.
lead_paragraph: WHEN David Key drove his new mostly aluminum-body Ford F-150 pickup home this year, he knew he had made the right choice.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: In 1979, The Times reviewed Abba’s sold-out show at Radio City Music Hall, the band’s New York debut.
lead_paragraph: 41 YEARS AGO

headline: Music Shows With a Brooklyn Feel, but Getting to Them Is a Hike
abstract: The Mountain Shows take musicians and listeners to the Hudson Highlands for performances staged along the Bull Hill trail.
lead_paragraph: THE mountain looms large in the imagination of musicians. Whether it’s in Strauss’s “Alpine Symphony,” Led Zeppelin’s “Misty Mountain Hop” or spirituals like “Go Tell It on the Mountain,” it has long represented ambition and perseverance, or an escape from the mundane, a conquest blown to mythic proportions.

headline: Amy Schumer to Open for Madonna’s Shows in New York
abstract: The comedian Amy Schumer will open three shows for Madonna in September.
lead_paragraph: Madonna announced on Thursday that Amy Schumer, the comedian of the moment, would open the New York dates on the singer’s “Rebel Heart” tour this fall, including shows at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 16 and 17, and one at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sept. 19. Tickets for all three shows are still available via Ticketmaster.

headline: Amy Schumer to Open for Madonna’s Shows in New York
abstract: The comedian Amy Schumer will open three shows for Madonna in September.
lead_paragraph: Madonna announced on Thursday that Amy Schumer, the comedian of the moment, would open the New York dates on the singer’s “Rebel Heart” tour this fall, including shows at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 16 and 17, and one at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sept. 19. Tickets for all three shows are still available via Ticketmaster.

headline: Review: Alvin Ailey Falters in Duet, Rises With Powerful Group Work
abstract: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented “A Case of You” and “No Longer Silent” in its continuing season at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater showed that a popular song, no matter how beloved, can kill a dance, and that a forgotten score can inspire a choreographer to explore an unfamiliar world. Continuing its season at the David H. Koch Theater on Wednesday, the company bookended two works by its founder — “Night Creature,” led by a beaming Hope Boykin, and “Revelations” — with a restaging of a duet and a new production of a powerful group work.

headline: Protecting the Babysitter
abstract: Confronting a father who hit on the babysitter; silencing a stylist and being the better person when it comes to parties.
lead_paragraph: Our 4-year-old son has a playmate whose parents have become friends. Our college-age babysitter met the playmate and her father at the playground. She reported that while the children were playing, the father asked for her phone number and to meet her for dinner. She said it was obviously not to discuss babysitting. My wife and I are conflicted about saying something to the wife. Regardless, there will be a huge elephant in the room when we next meet. What do you suggest?

headline: A Fearless Culture Fuels U.S. Tech Giants
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Innovation', 'Start-ups']
abstract: For all of Europe’s advantages, its technology sector lags that of the United States. A dread of failure may be one reason.
lead_paragraph: With this month’s announcement that the European Union is investigating Amazon for possible anticompetitive behavior in the sale of e-books, antitrust fervor in Europe seems to have hit fever pitch. Apple, Google and Facebook are all subjects of investigation, and Amazon is now the focus of at least three separate inquiries.

headline: Review: Stanley Cowell, in a Rare Performance at the Village Vanguard
abstract: Leading a band in an unusual weeklong run, Mr. Cowell showed off his dizzyingly broad command of jazz forms.
lead_paragraph: A standard description of a jazz performance begins with a couple of isolated moments or events. Somebody played something, it had meaning or an impact, time stopped, the audience smiled. The pianist Stanley Cowell is leading a band at the Village Vanguard for the first time this week, and describing his early set there on Wednesday in those terms is no problem.

headline: Demote Hamilton on the $10 Bill? Not So Fast, Treasury
abstract: A discussion about redesigning currency naturally leads to the question of what Andrew Jackson is doing on our money anyway.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department has announced that it intends to redesign the $10 bill and substitute a portrait of a famous American woman for Alexander Hamilton, one of the founding fathers. Many people think it’s about time a woman was featured on the nation’s paper currency, particularly after a pair of failed efforts to persuade Americans to use one-dollar coins, both of which happened to have women on them. But why choose to shove aside Mr. Hamilton? Binyamin Appelbaum, who writes about economic policy, and Josh Barro, who writes on financial issues for The Upshot, discussed it over email.

headline: University of Washington and Chinese University Unite to Form Technology Institute
abstract: With $40 million from Microsoft, the Global Innovation Exchange will open in fall 2016, and offer a master’s degree in technology innovation.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — With hometown companies like Amazon and Microsoft, this bustling region on the Puget Sound easily ranks in the top tier of technology hubs in the United States.

headline: Review: David Salle Paintings Deliver Colliding Culture at Skarstedt Gallery
abstract: The show has two distinct series, the “Late Product Paintings,” odes to art and commerce of the 1950s and ’60s, and “Silver Paintings,” which are monotypes made from photos taken in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: DAVID SALLE

headline: Arkansas Town Frets About Losing a Courthouse, and an Identity
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Mississippi County, Ark., has two county seats and two courthouses. Officials want to consolidate into one. But Osceola does not want to lose out.
lead_paragraph: OSCEOLA, Ark. — The baked stone floor tiles of the Mississippi County Courthouse here bear little traffic these days. The offices, which hold documents like marriage records in thick, bound books, are mostly quiet and empty. On the third floor, some of the courtroom’s ceiling tiles are browned by water or missing.

headline: ISIS-Imposed Fuel Embargo Threatens Syria’s Medical Centers
abstract: The Islamic State is preventing fuel from reaching rebel-held parts of northern Syria, as the Assad government targets medical facilities, activists and aid workers say.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic State fighters are preventing fuel shipments from reaching rebel-held parts of northern Syria, causing severe shortages that are grounding ambulances, paralyzing medical centers and shutting down bakeries, according to antigovernment activists and aid workers.

headline: Giants Display a West Coast Offense With a Crisper Edge at a Minicamp
abstract: Even with the injured star receivers Odell Beckham Jr. and Victor Cruz absent from camp, the Giants showed signs of becoming more comfortable with the offensive system implemented last season by Ben McAdoo.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants held their mandatory minicamp last June, their lack of familiarity with the West Coast offense being installed by the new coordinator Ben McAdoo was readily apparent. Play calls were met with confusion. Assignments were missed. Routes were run incorrectly. The out-of-sync quarterback Eli Manning misfired often.

headline: First Draft Focus: Faith, Freedom and Rand Paul
abstract: Senator Rand Paul spoke at the Faith and Freedom Coalition’s Road to Majority conference in Washington.

headline: First Draft Focus: Faith, Freedom and Rand Paul
abstract: Senator Rand Paul spoke at the Faith and Freedom Coalition’s Road to Majority conference in Washington.

headline: What I Love | Vikram Chatwal
abstract: The Manhattan hotelier’s home in Old Brookfield, N.Y., has space for his most cherished guests, his family.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan hotelier’s home in Old Brookfield, N.Y., has space for his most cherished guests, his family.

headline: New Rules Let Companies Sell Stakes to Investors of Modest Means
keywords: ['Private Placements (Non-Public Offerings) and Mini IPOs', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'Small Business', 'Venture Capital', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: Complex and controversial, the regulatory change allows businesses to advertise their offerings online, giving fans a chance to buy shares.
lead_paragraph: Growing companies seeking to raise up to $50 million have a new financing option, starting Friday: a process that will open some private businesses to a wide pool of new investors.

headline: Supreme Court Permits New Hearing for Mentally Disabled Inmate
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Jury System', 'Intellectual Disabilities', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The court ruled, 5 to 4, that the IQ of a death row inmate — 75 — and his difficulties with learning raised reasonable doubts about his intellectual capacity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday issued several decisions in criminal cases, including ones on the death penalty, testimony from children and jury selection.

headline: Jack Rollins Dies at 100; Managed Comedy Greats Like Woody Allen
abstract: Mr. Rollins, whose clients also included Robin Williams, Billy Crystal, David Letterman and Lenny Bruce, scouted talent and helped develop acts.
lead_paragraph: Jack Rollins, a producer and a sharp-eyed talent manager who saw more than a shy gag-writer in Woody Allen and believed that the manic improvisations of Robin Williams would crack up audiences, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 100.

headline: Bernie Sanders Draws Union Support Pressing Pensions Issue
abstract: With union members chanting “Bernie! Bernie” behind him, Senator Bernie Sanders sought to burnish his populist credentials for president as he introduced a bill to protect the pensions of millions of retirees from the threat of deep cuts.
lead_paragraph: With union members chanting “Bernie! Bernie!” behind him, Senator Bernie Sanders sought to burnish his populist credentials for president on Thursday as he introduced a bill to protect the pensions of millions of retirees from the threat of deep cuts.

headline: Review: George Caleb Bingham’s Serene Images of Rivers and Frontier Life, at the Met
abstract: “Navigating the West,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, offers idealized depictions of hardscrabble life.
lead_paragraph: Figuratively speaking, George Caleb Bingham tamed the Wild West. Working on paper and canvas, he gave a veneer of gentility and preternatural, even timeless calm to the Midwestern river valleys in the decades before the Civil War. The results still look very much alive, even radical today, feeling all-American both aesthetically and historically but with echoes of European painting.

headline: Houses of Parliament Are Crumbling, Report Finds, and There Is No Quick Fix
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: With renovation expected to take years and cost $6.2 billion or more, some even suggest finding another home away from London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Palace of Westminster, Britain’s gorgeous seat of Parliament, is crumbling, with leaky pipes, hazardous, antiquated wiring and roofs that threaten to collapse. It is slowly sinking into the banks of the River Thames. And then there is the asbestos, and the rats.

headline: Agencies, Hoping to Deflect Comets and Asteroids, Step Up Earth Defense
abstract: The goal is to learn how to better deflect comets and asteroids that might one day endanger cities or the planet as a whole.
lead_paragraph: In grappling with the threat of doomsday rocks from outer space, Hollywood has always been far ahead of the federal government, cranking out thrillers full of swashbuckling heroes, rockets and nuclear blasts that save the planet.

abstract: The White House discouraged participation, but that reportedly didn’t stop 70 American chief executives and officers. And the European turnout was even greater.

headline: Review: ‘Folk City’ at the Museum of the City of New York
abstract: This exhibition touches lightly on the many paradoxes and contradictions of the folk boom in New York.
lead_paragraph: A well-worn 12-string guitar that belonged to Lead Belly, scratched up from years of strumming, and the sounds of Pete Seeger picking a banjo and praising hard-working Americans greet a visitor to the new exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York. With photographs, documents, instruments, videos, manuscripts and plenty of songs for headphone listening, the show is a fond recap of the folk revival from its agitprop origins and idealistic fervor to its fleeting pop peak.

lead_paragraph: The Battle of Waterloo redrew Europe’s map 200 years ago.

headline: Review: ‘The Cartel,’ by Don Winslow, Continues a Drug Saga
abstract: Graphic violence is part of Mr. Winslow’s latest novel, which picks up where his “The Power of the Dog” ended.
lead_paragraph: On the opening page of “The Cartel,” Don Winslow mixes a baby’s cry with the sound of a helicopter’s blades in a predawn raid. That’s reminiscent of his 2005 novel, “The Power of the Dog,” which also used a baby on its opening page. “The baby is dead in his mother’s arms,” that book began, and went on to describe the horrific image of a bullet-riddled Madonna and child in Mexico. It was the first step into what would become Mr. Winslow’s drug war version of “The Godfather,” with all the grand ambition that implies.

headline: Review: Keely Garfield Mines Kitsch, and Past Material, in ‘Pow’
abstract: The choreographer arranges old snippets into something new and evocative at Roulette in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Anything by the choreographer Keely Garfield is worth watching multiple times. There is so much to see, so much to delight in and puzzle through, that once is rarely enough. Happily for her audience, Ms. Garfield, too, believes in revisiting her own material. In “Pow,” seen on Wednesday at Roulette in Brooklyn, she doesn’t restage her previous work so much as reimagine and repurpose it, arranging old snippets into something new.

headline: Joyce Ann Brown, Shackled by Her Name to Another’s Crime, Dies at 68
abstract: After her name was tied to a 1980 robbery and murder, the police learned of another woman with the same name. Yet Ms. Brown was wrongly jailed for the crime.
lead_paragraph: It was Joyce Ann Brown’s great misfortune that long before the 1980 robbery and murder that altered her life forever, she had been arrested on an unrelated charge.

headline: Review: Festival for Contemporary Performance Opens With Film, Boulez and Chaos
abstract: The pianist Marc Ponthus, the festival’s director, explored alternative concepts of narrative.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of a film shown on Wednesday at the opening event of the Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance at Mannes College the New School for Music, a piece of paper with the word “fracture” written on it is slowly burned. Viewers then see a pencil connecting the lines of Mallarmé’s poem “Un Coup de dés Jamais n’Abolira le Hasard” (“A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance”). The text is followed by images of a wild-looking score — whose chaotic flourishes and indecipherable passages are printed in seemingly random formation.

Many events feature audience participation, like a West Village singalong, featuring the music of J.S. Bach and his sons.

headline: Senate Passes, Then Blocks, Military Bill
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: The lawmakers’ action was seen as the first battle in a spending fight that could end in a government shutdown this fall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday passed a $600 billion defense policy bill that would rein in pension costs, ban the use of torture and authorize lethal offensive weapons for Ukraine. But it then immediately rejected a measure to pay for it, the first battle in a spending fight that could end in a government shutdown this fall.

headline: Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy Narrates a Scene From ‘The Tribe’
abstract: The director of “The Tribe” discusses a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Words are not spoken aloud in “The Tribe,” but volumes are expressed in this Ukranian feature set at a school for the deaf. The film, from Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy, uses a nonprofessional cast that communicates in sign language. In this scene, a new student (Grigoriy Fesenko) participates in a fight organized by a gang he is set to join. The sequence happens in one unbroken take and fills the screen with extras and intricate fight choreography.

headline: Deal Is Near on Far-Reaching Reforms at Rikers, Including a Federal Monitor
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The agreement would also prohibit guards’ striking prisoners in the head, put body cameras on guards and flag guards who repeatedly use force.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials have tentatively agreed to sweeping reforms that would remake Rikers Island, including the appointment of a federal monitor to oversee the jail complex, explicit prohibitions against guards’ striking prisoners in the head and even the introduction of body cameras worn by guards.

headline: Review: ‘Dope,’ a Teenage Comedy, Plays With Stereotypes
abstract: In Rick Famuyiwa’s film, Malcolm, a smart student and musician prepping for a Harvard interview, does a favor for a drug dealer and winds up with a gun and a backpack of contraband.
lead_paragraph: A coming-of-age story that is at once a parody of, and a tribute to, ’90s-vintage ghetto dramas, “Dope” wears its pop-culture obsessions on its sleeve. So does its hero, Malcolm (Shameik Moore), a teenager navigating his senior year of high school in a rough part of Los Angeles. And not only his sleeve: Malcolm’s whole look, from his high-top fade to his vintage Air Jordans, expresses a geeky commitment to hip-hop’s golden decade, which for him lasted from roughly 1988 until 2001 (that is, from “It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back” to “The Blueprint.”)

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 19, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Inside Out,” “Dope” and “The Overnight.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Inside Out,” “Dope” and “The Overnight.”

headline: Rand Paul and the VAT That Dare Not Speak Its Name
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Taxation', 'Value-Added Tax', 'Income Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: A closer look at the presidential candidate’s new proposal for what he is calling a business-activity tax.
lead_paragraph: In an op-ed in today’s Wall Street Journal, Senator Rand Paul announced his tax plan. While Herman Cain had his 9-9-9 plan, you can think of Mr. Paul’s approach as the 14.5-14.5 plan: He would replace all of today’s federal taxes with a 14.5 percent flat personal income tax and a 14.5 percent value-added tax.

headline: Review: In ‘The Overnight,’ Newcomers Try Hard to Make Friends
abstract: Bland meets bold in “The Overnight,” a comedy that coyly dips its toe and a few other body parts in the new sexual revolution.
lead_paragraph: Bland meets bold in “The Overnight,” a comedy that coyly dips its toe and a few other body parts in the new sexual revolution. With its couple-on-couple story, the movie comes across as a skittish redo of Paul Mazursky’s 1969 sex comedy, “Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice,” about two chummy straight married couples who end up between the sheets together. Mr. Mazursky’s dramatically shaded comedy is somewhat of a feature-long tease, despite its famous image of the four lined up in bed. (Bob and company aren’t the swingers that they try to be.) But it’s also a sharp exploration of the kind of middle-class social anxieties that vibrate through “The Overnight.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Overnight’
