headline: Memories Made, and Found, on a Moped
abstract: On a return trip to Bermuda, a son, now also a father, hopes to solve a longtime family mystery.
lead_paragraph: On a return trip to Bermuda, a son, now also a father, hopes to solve a longtime family mystery.

headline: Andrew McCarthy: My Return Trip to Bermuda
abstract: On a return visit to the island as a father, the actor and director hoped to solve a family mystery.
lead_paragraph: Our scooter zipped past a small sign and I caught a fleeting glimpse. My sleep-deprived brain latched hold of something and went scrolling back through the years. Could this be it?, I thought.

headline: Greek Premier’s Address at Russian Forum
abstract: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece addressed the St. Petersburg Economic Forum on Friday, as his country struggles to reach a deal with its creditors to avoid defaulting on debt payments.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece addressed the St. Petersburg Economic Forum on Friday, as his country struggles to reach a deal with its creditors to avoid defaulting on debt payments.

headline: Toddlers Have Sense of Justice, Puppet Study Shows
abstract: A new study has shown that 3- and 5-year-olds have a sense of so-called restorative justice, reacting to wrongs as if victimized themselves.
lead_paragraph: Children as young as age 3 will intervene on behalf of a victim, reacting as if victimized themselves, scientists have found.

headline: Greece and Its Creditors Pummel Each Other, but Fight Is Not Over Yet
abstract: Like prizefighters, the two sides of the negotiations over the Greek bailout have been circling each other, throwing punch after punch.
lead_paragraph: Like prizefighters, the two sides of the negotiations over the Greek bailout have been circling each other, throwing punch after punch.

headline: Breaking News: The Rush to Cover a Shooting in Charleston
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Social Media']
abstract: Steve Kenny, a night news editor, describes how the story of a mass shooting in a historic Charleston church came together in the first hours after the news broke.
lead_paragraph: Steve Kenny is a senior editor on the news desk.

headline: Brian Williams, in Raw Form, Delivers an Apology on ‘Today’
abstract: Instead of clearing the air, his appearance seemed to hand more ammunition to hardened media scolds.
lead_paragraph: He couldn’t say the L word.

headline: Giving More Globally, and Less Locally
abstract: Giving to international organizations has fallen even as overall philanthropy has rebounded after the recession. What could make Americans give more to global causes?
lead_paragraph: There was a lot of good news this week in the annual report on American philanthropy published by the Giving USA Foundation. Overall giving passed its prerecession peak, according to the organization’s calculations. Generosity in nearly every category was up, in some cases strongly.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: When I Grow Up
abstract: This week, Heather Havrilesky and Meghan Daum discuss new books about bringing up children and redefining adulthood; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Vendela Vida talks about her new novel, “The Diver’s Clothes Lie Empty”; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Heather Havrilesky and Meghan Daum discuss new books about bringing up children and redefining adulthood; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Vendela Vida talks about her new novel, “The Diver’s Clothes Lie Empty”; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Iran Still Aids Terrorism and Bolsters Syria’s President, State Department Finds
abstract: The country has been unwilling to moderate its foreign policy in the Middle East or bring Qaeda members to justice, an annual report released on Friday said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran continued its “terrorist-related” activity last year and also continued to provide broad military support to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, the State Department said Friday in its annual report on terrorism.

headline: Bain and Other Private Equity Firms to Buy Italian Payments Company
abstract: The consortium will pay about $2.4 billion to acquire the payment and clearing services company Istituto Centrale delle Banche Popolari Italiane.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A consortium of private equity firms that includes Bain Capital agreed on Friday to acquire the Italian payment and clearing services company Istituto Centrale delle Banche Popolari Italiane for 2.15 billion euros, or about $2.4 billion.

abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

lead_paragraph: This week, Heather Havrilesky, Meghan Daum and Vendela Vida.

headline: Jeb Bush Pledges Debate on Gay Marriage After Court Ruling
keywords: ['Constitutional Amendments', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, at a gathering of religious conservatives, said he was not content letting the issue of same-sex marriage fade away, “irrespective of what the courts say” about it.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush told a gathering of religious conservatives here on Friday that the debate over same-sex marriage should continue “irrespective of what the courts say,” signaling that he would not consider a Supreme Court decision favorable to gay rights as the last word on the subject.

headline: Jeb Bush Pledges Debate on Gay Marriage After Court Ruling
abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, at a gathering of religious conservatives, said he was not content letting the issue of same-sex marriage fade away, “irrespective of what the courts say” about it.

headline: Lawmakers Push to End Military Transgender Ban
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As several transgender service members have come out publicly in recent months, some legislators have begun to champion their cause.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the ban on openly gay troops repealed in 2011, the policies that prohibit transgender people from joining the armed forces have historically attracted minimal, if any, interest on Capitol Hill.

headline: Clinical Trial of Experimental Ebola Drug Is Halted
abstract: Tekmira Pharmaceuticals announced Friday that the trial of TKM-Ebola-Guinea had been stopped because it did not demonstrate a therapeutic benefit.
lead_paragraph: In a setback for efforts to combat Ebola, an experimental drug that researchers had considered one of the most promising potential treatments has not worked in patients in Sierra Leone, the drug’s developer said Friday.

headline: Jeremy Scott’s Moschino Collection
abstract: Mr. Scott presents his Moschino collection in Florence, Italy, with Katy Perry and ASAP Rocky in attendance.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Scott presents his Moschino collection in Florence, Italy, with Katy Perry and ASAP Rocky in attendance.

headline: At Moschino, Jeremy Scott Lightens Things Up
abstract: Mr. Scott showed his collection in a series of frescoed salons of the fabled Palazzo Corsini alongside the Arno, with Katy Perry and ASAP Rocky in attendance.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — “He’s the funniest man in the fashion industry,” Katy Perry said backstage at the Moschino show Thursday, held in a series of frescoed salons of the fabled Palazzo Corsini here alongside the Arno. She was talking about an old pal, the designer Jeremy Scott.

headline: In English, French Paper Urges Britain to Heed Waterloo and Stay in E.U.
abstract: In an unusual step, an editorial in Le Monde said Napoleon’s defeat 200 years ago offered a lesson on European unity and its peaceful rewards.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French, it seems safe to say, have had a hard time getting over Waterloo.

headline: Stephen Colbert’s Digital Nation
keywords: ['Television', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: Months from taking over CBS’s “Late Show,” Mr. Colbert and his writers are posting videos drawn from current events, like Donald J. Trump’s candidacy for president.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump arrived on an escalator and announced on Tuesday that he would seek the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, he set off a gold rush among late-night comedians who could not wait to satirize his bombastic, digressive declaration speech.

headline: Gap Grows Smaller, H.R.C. Picks a Pantsuit and Taylor Swift Is Always Ready for a Zip Line
abstract: Plus, Lucky reportedly folds, a heel of a mess and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Lindsey Graham’s Niece Recalls Dylann Storm Roof as ‘Strange’
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham’s niece, Emillie Boggs, recalls Dylann Storm Roof, the South Carolina shooting suspect, as “strange” from her days in grammar school with him.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The killing of nine people Wednesday at the historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church hit close to home for many South Carolinians.

headline: Quiz: How Toxic Is Your Work Environment?
abstract: Take the quiz and find out how your workplace compares to those I have studied.
lead_paragraph: Take the quiz and find out how your workplace compares to those I have studied.

headline: Usher and Justin Bieber Will Face Copyright Lawsuit
abstract: A federal appeals court ruled that a lawsuit claiming that Justin Bieber and Usher illegally copied parts of the song “Somebody to Love” can go forward.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of a song after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday. Devin Copeland (better known as the R&B singer De Rico) and his songwriting partner, Mareio Overton, filed a $10 million lawsuit against Mr. Bieber and Usher in 2013, saying that various versions of a song called “Somebody to Love” recorded by the artists shared beats, time signatures and lyrics with a song of the same title they wrote in 2008.Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of the song “Somebody to Love” after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday.

headline: Usher and Justin Bieber Will Face Copyright Lawsuit
abstract: A federal appeals court ruled that a lawsuit claiming that Justin Bieber and Usher illegally copied parts of the song “Somebody to Love” can go forward.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of a song after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday. Devin Copeland (better known as the R&B singer De Rico) and his songwriting partner, Mareio Overton, filed a $10 million lawsuit against Mr. Bieber and Usher in 2013, saying that various versions of a song called “Somebody to Love” recorded by the artists shared beats, time signatures and lyrics with a song of the same title they wrote in 2008.Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of the song “Somebody to Love” after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday.

headline: Hatred or Heritage?
abstract: Some say the Confederate battle flag breeds racism and should not be displayed. Others say it's merely a historical symbol.

headline: At Home, Many Seniors Are Imprisoned by Their Independence
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Heart', 'Stroke', 'Respiratory Diseases', 'ARTHRITIS', 'Medicaid', 'Home Health Care', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Almost two million Americans over age 65 rarely or never leave their homes. They are more likely to be minority women, and in poor health.
lead_paragraph: What she mourns most, says Solange DeLaPaz, are the mundane pleasures and rituals of her once-active life. A weekly manicure at the corner nail salon. Saturday excursions to Macy’s shoe department.

headline: Julie Johnston, a Late Call-Up for U.S., Continues Her Ascent
abstract: Johnston, 23, who supplanted Christie Rampone in the lineup this year, has been an unlikely revelation for the United States in the Women’s World Cup.
lead_paragraph: EDMONTON, Alberta — After leading the United States to the women’s under-20 world soccer championship in 2012, Julie Johnston met Christie Rampone, a fellow center back and the longtime captain of the senior national team.

headline: Selfies
abstract: Selfies with presidential hopefuls
lead_paragraph: Selfies with presidential hopefuls

headline: Vikram Chatwal’s Many-Roomed Getaway
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The Manhattan hotelier’s home in Old Brookville, N.Y., has space for his most cherished guests, his family.
lead_paragraph: When Vikram Chatwal, the Manhattan hotelier responsible for a string of boutique hotels including the Dream Midtown, escapes from SoHo to his country house in Old Brookville, N.Y., assorted family members are often there to greet him.

headline: Matchmaking Season for Republican Presidential Candidates and Economists
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Presidential hopefuls are auditioning economists, seeking policy advice, experience and connections, but most candidates have yet to team up with anyone in particular.
lead_paragraph: It’s the economists’ version of social networking.

headline: New York Prison Officer Is Placed on Leave Amid Escape Investigation
abstract: The move involving the officer at the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., came as the authorities said they were investigating a possible sighting of the two missing convicts.
lead_paragraph: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y. — A corrections officer at the maximum-security prison where two inmates escaped this month has been put on administrative leave in connection with the investigation, officials said on Friday, and the New York State Police said officers were investigating a possible sighting of the escapees.

headline: Popcast: Women and Country Music
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the women of country music.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s Popcast, we discuss the situation for women in country music right now. The occasion is Kacey Musgraves’ new album “Pageant Material” — for which, as Mr. Caramanica wrote in Arts and Leisure this week, “she’ll be pegged as an agent of change, a palliative for this genre’s many ills”—but also a recent statement by the country-radio consultant Keith Hill that women listeners, the prime demographic of country radio, preferred to hear male singers. To what degree is Ms. Musgraves’ album a satisfying response? Other singers discussed: Carrie Underwood, Miranda Lambert, Kelsea Ballerini, Ashley Monroe, Angaleena Presley, Laura Bell Bundy, Mickey Guyton, Jana Kramer, Cam, Maddie & Tae, Reba McEntire.

headline: No Time to Be Nice at Work
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: We’re rude at work, and it’s hurting profits, health and happiness.
lead_paragraph: MEAN bosses could have killed my father. I vividly recall walking into a hospital room outside of Cleveland to see my strong, athletic dad lying with electrodes strapped to his bare chest. What put him there? I believe it was work-related stress. For years he endured two uncivil bosses.

headline: Greek Pie on the Skinny Side
abstract: Homemade phyllo dough, to hold the feta and greens, should be so thin you can read a newspaper through it.
lead_paragraph: Aglaia Kremezi has no problem making phyllo dough at home in Greece whenever she makes anything pie-like. And she makes a lot of pies.

headline: Gun Control Voices in Congress All but Silent After Charleston Shooting
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Firearms']
abstract: The shooting in South Carolina has not drawn calls for gun control from lawmakers rebuffed in their efforts after 20 children were slain in Connecticut in 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the fatal shootings at a landmark black church in Charleston, S.C., Senator Joe Manchin III, who sponsored gun safety legislation that failed in Congress two years ago, released a statement lamenting “the nine souls who were lost.”

headline: TriBeCa Tower Inspired by a Glass Vase
abstract: Sales are about to begin at 111 Murray Street, a new 58-story residential skyscraper with sweeping views being developed by a group led by Fisher Brothers.
lead_paragraph: Yet another tall residential tower designed to stand out against the Manhattan skyline is poised to enter the market — this time in Lower Manhattan.

headline: A Brooklyn Record
abstract: A three-story brick townhouse in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, sold for $15.5 million, the highest price ever paid for a single residence in the borough.
lead_paragraph: A three-story brick townhouse in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, sold for $15.5 million, the highest price ever paid for a single residence in the borough.

headline: Two Israeli Men Are Attacked, and One Killed, Near Settlement in the West Bank
abstract: The attacker opened fire on a civilian vehicle near a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank on Friday, Israel’s military said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — A Palestinian man shot two Israeli men in a vehicle as they were leaving a spring near a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank on Friday, killing one and wounding another, Israel’s military said in a statement.

headline: Jason Schwartzman Shares a Few of His Many — and We Mean Many — Inspirations
abstract: The musician and star of “The Overnight” recommends his most beloved stores, people, films and more.
lead_paragraph: When Jason Schwartzman begins the conversation by announcing, “I’m a big fan of recommendations and lists,” it turns out that the 25 things he has chosen to discuss are only a tiny fraction of the potential recommendations he’s generated. (We whittled it down to 15.) Perhaps that shouldn’t be a surprise, coming from a musician and actor who has formed a longstanding cinematic collaboration with noted obsessive Wes Anderson. Schwartzman’s recommendations, in turn, serve as jumping-off points for more general discussions about social networks (the real-life ones, not websites and apps), aesthetic influences and finding lifelong friends through shared cultural interests. “My idea of fun is browsing,” he admits. To that end, he has cultivated an extensive network of recommenders; it is pretty rare to hear an actor mention that he’s become friends with a film critic.

headline: $15.5 Million, a Record for Brooklyn Real Estate
abstract: A brick townhouse in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn broke the record for the highest price ever paid for a single residence in the borough.
lead_paragraph: An enormous brick townhouse in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, suitable as both home and studio with its voluminous rooms, soaring ceilings and built-in four-car garage, sold to the photographer Jay Maisel for $15.5 million, according to city records, breaking the record for the highest price ever paid for a single residence in the borough.

headline: James Gaffigan Signs Up for More as Conductor of Lucerne Symphony
abstract: The young American conductor James Gaffigan has extended his contract as chief conductor of the Lucerne Symphony Orchestra through 2022.
lead_paragraph: The rising young American maestro James Gaffigan has extended his contract as chief conductor of the Lucerne Symphony Orchestra until 2022, the orchestra announced Friday.

abstract: New picture books include “Jampires” by Sarah McIntyre and David O'Connell, and “Rude Cakes” by Rowboat Watkins.
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Jampires” by Sarah McIntyre and David O'Connell, and “Rude Cakes” by Rowboat Watkins.

headline: Bloomberg’s Gun-Control Group Funds News Site After Shooting
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Gun Control', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: The news website, The Trace, is being primarily financed by former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s gun-control group. It went live on Friday, only two days after the Charleston, S.C., church shooting.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg’s gun-control group has started financing its own news website, only days after a shooting at a historic back church in South Carolina left nine people dead.

headline: For a Teacher, Back-to-Back Marathons, Then Fourth-Graders
abstract: Keila Merino finishes at the top of the pack in grueling 100-mile running races, but teaching in a poor Bronx school may be her greatest challenge.
lead_paragraph: The seventh time she ran the Boston Marathon, Keila Merino woke up early before the race and joined a few other runners at 5 a.m. at the finish line on Boylston Street. The group hooked a right on Hereford, a left on Commonwealth, and continued for the next 25-plus miles, finishing at the starting line.

headline: In Bed-Stuy Housing Market, Profit and Preservation Battle
keywords: ['Gentrification', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: In a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood in Brooklyn, investors and developers canvass the streets, looking for properties from which they might extract significant profits.
lead_paragraph: On many days when the weather is accommodating, William Scarbrough stands outside the dry cleaner where he works, on the corner of Stuyvesant Avenue and Halsey Street in Brooklyn, observing the pedestrian traffic that distinguishes Bedford-Stuyvesant as perhaps the city’s most frenetic real-estate frontier. A tall and slender man of 60, he has lived several blocks from the cleaners for close to a year now, during which he has watched investors and developers canvass the streets looking for properties from which they might extract significant profits.

headline: Barbecue Without the Frills, by the Banks of the Gowanus
abstract: The partners behind the pop-up restaurant Pig Beach NYC expanded the options for canalside dining in Brooklyn this month, in this case to the Gowanus Canal.
lead_paragraph: It’s a little bit Venice, a little bit Superfund cleanup site. The partners behind Pig Beach NYC earlier this month expanded the options for canalside dining in Brooklyn — in this case, to the banks of the (vastly improved) Gowanus Canal. Started by four veterans of national barbecue competitions and high-end Manhattan restaurants (Del Posto, Balthazar, Ed’s Lobster Bar), Pig Beach is a no-frills pop-up outdoor barbecue restaurant that runs from now until Halloween.

headline: Rand Paul Names Hedge Fund Chief Mark Spitznagel as Economic Adviser
abstract: Both share a similar outlook that the government should not play a role in the economy or the financial markets.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has appointed Mark Spitznagel, the hedge fund manager, as a senior economic adviser as he seeks the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Door Opens Slightly to Cuba, but Businesses Face Difficulty Getting In
abstract: For all the early optimism, businesses and advocates for engagement are increasingly finding that genuine normalization is still more aspiration than reality.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Six months after President Obama cracked open a more than five-decade Cold War stalemate with Cuba, American money, travelers and business executives are streaming onto the island and a United States flag is poised to fly over the de facto embassy in Havana any week now.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Hamptons Quandary
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Clintons’ Long Island vacation could contradict her populist economic message despite the fund-raising benefits.
lead_paragraph: For the past several summers, Bill and Hillary Clinton have done what New York City’s moneyed residents have done for decades: They spent their vacation amid the prime beachside real estate of Long Island.

abstract: The bride and groom, both astronomers, first connected as graduate students spending an evening in an observatory.
lead_paragraph: The bride and groom, both astronomers, first connected as graduate students spending an evening in an observatory.

headline: Brazil Arrests Head of Odebrecht in Petrobras Scandal
abstract: The investigation is looking into whether subcontractors may have colluded with top Petrobras executives to overbill the company and pay bribes.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazilian police on Friday arrested one of the country’s richest men, Marcelo Odebrecht, as the fallout broadens in an investigation into corruption at the state-run oil giant Petrobras.

headline: Beyond Mourning for Charleston
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gun Control', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: The tragedy of racism and violence will not end without, in the words of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., “continuous struggle.”
lead_paragraph: The horrific church shooting in Charleston, S.C., leaves the nation at an all too familiar juncture — uncertain whether to do something positive to repair society’s vulnerabilities or to once again absorb an intolerable wound by going through what has become a woeful ritual of deep grief followed by shallow resolve to move on toward … what? Toward the inevitable carnage next time.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says No to Granting ‘Fast Track’ Authority on Trade Deal
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would “probably not” vote for fast-track authority for the trade deal that President Obama is seeking, but she acknowledged that she once said positive things about “the potential” for the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would “probably not” vote for fast-track authority for the trade deal that President Obama is seeking, but she acknowledged that she once said positive things about “the potential” for the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement.

headline: Yemen Mediator Optimistic as Humanitarian Crisis Worsens
abstract: The United Nations mediator for Yemen’s talks with Houthi rebels said discussions yielded no progress, not even for a humanitarian cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In Yemen, hospitals are reeling from a stream of war-wounded. A million people have fled their homes. Hunger is rising so steeply that hospital admissions for malnutrition have more than doubled, while aid agencies say a de facto blockade has made it difficult to get food and fuel into the country, the poorest in the Arab world.

headline: A Marriage Made in the Heavens
abstract: The bride and groom, both astronomers, first connected as graduate students spending an evening in an observatory.
lead_paragraph: You could have excused Kate Grier and Thomas Beatty for having their heads in the stars the first evening they spent together back in March 2010.

headline: A Show Finds Humor in Gaza’s Headlines. Will Hamas Get It?
abstract: A new satirical video series in Gaza pokes fun at Palestinian leaders, and tests boundaries set by the Hamas-led government.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Men and women stood with suitcases at the port, waiting for a boat. Suspicious, Tarek, a 13-year-old tea seller, wandered over and asked, “Are they really leaving?” He had never seen anyone leave Gaza before, he explained.

headline: A ‘Street Nun’ Who Specializes in Redemption
abstract: Ana Martinez de Luco, 60, a Catholic nun, can be found in the thick of the action at a bustling can and bottle recycling center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “They call me the street nun,” said Ana Martinez de Luco, 60, a Catholic nun who does not wear a habit or robes, but rather a green apron and sandals and can be found in the thick of the action in the shantytown that is Sure We Can, a bustling can and bottle redemption center in a lot on McKibbin Street in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Norwegian Women Confess (Facetiously): We’re Terrible.
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Women and Girls', 'Comedy and Humor', "Women's World Cup (Soccer)"]
abstract: In a video, several players address prejudices about women’s soccer by admitting — with deadpan humor, and sometimes profanity — that they are all true.
lead_paragraph: Norway was one of the surprises of the group stage of the Women’s World Cup, with two wins and a 1-1 tie with the tournament favorite, Germany. But doubts about the team — and women’s soccer in general — remain, so the players have taken them on with an unexpected weapon: sarcasm.

headline: D’Angelo and Bobby Seale on the Past and Future of Political Protest
keywords: ['Music', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Amid a national conversation about racial injustice, an R&B star and a founder of the Black Panthers discuss the possibility of change.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, CALIF. — In early June, before the shootings in Charleston, S.C., the R&B singer D’Angelo stood beneath the blood-red awning of the It’s All Good Bakery here, peering into the window of the building that served as the first office for the Black Panther Party. At another stop, beneath a street lamp on Seventh Avenue, he stood where the group carried out its first observation of law enforcement.

headline: Professor Panther
abstract: Bobby Seale co-founded the Black Panther Party. The R&B star D’Angelo speaks out on racial injustice in his new album. The two met in Oakland, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Seale co-founded the Black Panther Party. The R&B star D’Angelo speaks out on racial injustice in his new album. The two met in Oakland, Calif.

abstract: Researchers at EcoHealth Alliance used mathematical models to gauge the effects of an outbreak on the distribution of food.
lead_paragraph: Starvation is a real threat during an extended pandemic, but it is very hard to predict when and where it will start, researchers report in an unusual new study.

headline: Does Greece Need More Austerity?
abstract: A chart you haven’t seen.
lead_paragraph: As many of us have noted, it’s hugely unfair when people claim that Greece has done nothing to adjust. On the contrary, it has imposed incredibly harsh austerity and substantial reforms on other fronts. Yet you might be tempted to argue that the results show that Greece hasn’t done enough — after all, last year it was running only a tiny primary budget surplus (that is, not counting interest), and this year it has slipped back into primary deficit. So more adjustment is needed, right?

headline: Heartfelt Donations Replace Wedding Party Favors
abstract: Brides and grooms are making donations to charity instead of giving table favors to guests.
lead_paragraph: If charity starts at home, and forming a home often starts with a wedding, why not turn the wedding into an event to raise money for charity?

headline: Spiritual Healing and Arts Festival in the Berkshires
abstract: The inaugural MassBliss Arts and Awareness Experience is running July 10 to 12 in the Berkshires in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The inaugural MassBliss Arts and Awareness Experience, running July 10 to 12 in the Berkshires in Massachusetts, bills itself as a spiritual healing and arts festival. Peace Poets, a spoken-word hip-hop group, and the Bread and Puppet Theater will be on stage, and there will be a class on Ethiopian music, and one for those interested in extending their voice range.

headline: China by Bike and Kayak
abstract: A new tour from Adventure Life allows travelers to explore China on foot, by bicycle and via kayak.
lead_paragraph: A new tour from Adventure Life allows travelers to explore China on foot, by bicycle and via kayak. On the Great Wall, Dynasties and Rivers trip, guests will hike the Jinshanling section of the Great Wall and through villages in the rice terraces of Longsheng; bike through Beijing hutongs, along Xi’an’s ancient city wall and by the Li River; and kayak on the Yulong River. The itinerary includes the Forbidden City and Summer Palace in Beijing, the Terracotta Warriors in Xi’an and Ping’an Village, inhabited by the Zhuang ethnic group.

headline: Steeped in Racial History, Charleston Ponders Its Future
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Discrimination', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Despite Charleston’s recent economic growth, which has brought in tourists, the same success has threatened the city’s shrinking black population.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The force of racial conflict shaped this city’s commerce, inspired a slave revolt and sparked the gunshots that started the Civil War. And this week, on a balmy Wednesday evening, it claimed the lives of nine black churchgoers who had gathered to study the Bible.

headline: The Politicization of CBO Begins
abstract: Apples, oranges, and the budget.
lead_paragraph: Update: Richard Kogan has contacted me to say that while the claim of a worsening budget situation is made at the beginning of the report, the analysis that follows is in fact clean and careful. So we’re talking about a misleading statement rather than a misleading analysis. And sources close to CBO insist that the misleading statement was careless drafting rather than deliberate politicization. OK, I guess.

headline: Singh’s Sporting Goods, for Cricket’s Serious Bowlers and Wicketkeepers
abstract: Singh’s Sporting Goods in Queens is the place to find New York’s cricket community buying everything needed to play and enjoy the world’s second most popular sport.
lead_paragraph: The pace at Singh’s Sporting Goods is as languid as a cricket match — some of which can last for five days. A customer might try 30 bats before deciding to think it over and return the following day. Another might wander in, take a seat and watch a game from New Zealand on the shop’s TV.

headline: Grant Park Prepares for Taste of Chicago 2015
abstract: The annual Taste of Chicago festival has a menu that includes Thai dishes, fried chicken and, of course, the city’s signature deep-dish pizza.
lead_paragraph: Chicago has been a culinary mecca for quite some time, so it’s only natural that the Taste of Chicago (referred to locally as “the Taste”) plays a major role in the city’s summer psyche. Now in its 35th year, the festival will be held from July 8 to 12 in Grant Park, centrally located between the downtown Loop and Lake Michigan. (There’s a preview day on June 24 in Daley Plaza across from Chicago City Hall.)

headline: An Angry Martin O’Malley Calls for an Assault Weapons Ban
abstract: Martin O’Malley, a Democratic candidate for president, emailed supporters calling for a new national assault weapons ban and other gun control measures after the shooting deaths in a South Carolina church this week.
lead_paragraph: Using an off-color word to describe his anger, Martin O’Malley, a Democratic candidate for president, called for a new national assault weapons ban and other gun control measures in an email sent to supporters after the shooting deaths at a South Carolina church this week.

headline: Marc Maron Discusses His Podcast Interview With President Obama
abstract: The comedian interviewed the commander in chief in his home garage on Friday for a podcast that will be released on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly six years that Marc Maron has hosted his popular podcast, “WTF With Marc Maron,” this idiosyncratic, inquisitive and self-deprecating comedian has interviewed hundreds of celebrated stand-ups and entertainers, including Louis C.K., Bob Newhart, Lena Dunham and Amy Poehler.

headline: Marc Maron Discusses His Podcast Interview With President Obama
abstract: The comedian interviewed the commander in chief in his home garage on Friday for a podcast that will be released on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly six years that Marc Maron has hosted his popular podcast, “WTF With Marc Maron,” this idiosyncratic, inquisitive and self-deprecating comedian has interviewed hundreds of celebrated stand-ups and entertainers, including Louis C.K., Bob Newhart, Lena Dunham and Amy Poehler.

headline: The Roller Coaster Couple
abstract: A passion for the thrilling rides is one of the few things that college students Lisa Guerrera and Rich O’Flanagan have in common, other than love.
lead_paragraph: They trotted up the ramp to the Cyclone, that grumpy old rattler of a roller coaster in Coney Island, Brooklyn, a young man and a young woman who would spend the day never more than a few inches apart.

headline: Watch: Victims’ Families Address Dylann Roof, Charleston Shooting Suspect
abstract: Relatives of churchgoers killed in the shooting appeared in court to confront the suspect with emotional tributes to their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of churchgoers killed in a shooting in Charleston, S.C., appeared in court on Friday to confront Dylann Storm Roof, the suspect, with emotional tributes to their loved ones.

abstract: Photos from Indonesia, Britain, India and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Indonesia, Britain, India and the United States.

headline: Financial Control Board Should Take Over Debt-Laden Puerto Rico, Lawmaker Says
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Puerto Ricans']
abstract: Representative Jeffrey D. Duncan of South Carolina has made one of the strongest calls yet for federal intervention into the island’s finances.
lead_paragraph: In one of the strongest bids yet for federal intervention into Puerto Rico’s fiscal woes, a member of Congress is calling for a control board to take over the island’s beleaguered government.

headline: Review: ‘Ballers,’ on HBO, Follows a Financial Guru to the Sports Stars
abstract: They’ve got game, they’ve got money: Now all that the football players in “Ballers” need is financial advising.
lead_paragraph: Given the place sports occupy in our culture, you’d think they would be right up there with doctoring and policing as fodder for television dramas and comedies. But “Arli$$” and “Friday Night Lights” notwithstanding, the number of scripted shows about athletics has always been relatively small. “Ballers,” a plodding football series that begins Sunday on HBO, suggests why.

headline: Review: ‘Poldark’ on PBS’s ‘Masterpiece’
abstract: The fast-moving eight-episode series is based on the novels by Winston Graham.
lead_paragraph: Sweeping, stirring, rousing, lush. These are the sorts of adjectives suggested by “Poldark,” the 18th-century potboiler that begins Sunday on PBS’s “Masterpiece.” It’s the kind of show in which every plot twist appears to require a shot of someone pounding on horseback along the Cornish coast, close to the cliffs and outlined against the sun.

headline: A Train Links Fashion Capitals, but Divides Passengers
abstract: Pitti Uomo’s fashion train featured oddball entertainment on the way to Milan.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, ITALY — The red carpet was rolled out. This is not a metaphor.

headline: Google to Remove ‘Revenge Porn’ Images From Search Results
abstract: If Google deems an image revenge porn, it will still be accessible to someone who knows the direct web address of the image. But once delisted from Google, the image could not be found through the search engine.
lead_paragraph: There are few types of information that Google isn’t busy organizing for its users. But on Friday, it said it would add another: so-called revenge porn.

headline: Google to Remove ‘Revenge Porn’ Images From Search Results
abstract: If Google deems an image revenge porn, it will still be accessible to someone who knows the direct web address of the image. But once delisted from Google, the image could not be found through the search engine.
lead_paragraph: There are few types of information that Google isn’t busy organizing for its users. But on Friday, it said it would add another: so-called revenge porn.

headline: Charleston Mayor Announces Vigil
abstract: Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston, S.C., announced a prayer vigil on Friday to honor the victims of Wednesday’s church shooting.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston, S.C., announced a prayer vigil on Friday to honor the victims of Wednesday’s church shooting.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Elections, City Councils', 'Families and Family Life', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: In this raw and unedited video, relatives of those killed in the church shooting Wednesday in Charleston, S.C., spoke at the bond hearing for the suspect, Dylann Roof.
lead_paragraph: In this raw and unedited video, relatives of those killed in the church shooting Wednesday in Charleston, S.C., spoke at the bond hearing for the suspect, Dylann Roof.

headline: Review: Ann Hampton Callaway Hits Redial in ‘On My Way to You’
abstract: Ann Hampton Callaway delves into romance in “On My Way to You” at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: A self-proclaimed “hopeless romantic” surrounded by “material girls”: That’s how the singer Ann Hampton Callaway described her younger self on Thursday evening at 54 Below, where she opened her new show, “On My Way to You.” That younger self was a demure piano bar entertainer whose rich, extravagantly gorgeous voice hovered on the brink of tears as she poured her heart out in classic ballads and lachrymose original songs.

headline: Afghan Parliament’s Term Is Extended After Squabbles Delay Elections
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani lengthened the term of the current Parliament, which was to expire on Sunday, to allow time to negotiate a new date and process for elections.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With Afghanistan’s fractious coalition government already struggling, a new deadline looms that could further hurt its credibility: The Afghan Parliament’s term is set to expire on Sunday, with no elections scheduled and no agreement on how to hold them.

headline: Nina Simone’s Time Is Now, Again
abstract: The musician broadened the parameters of the great American pop artist, and her work is coming back to prominence.
lead_paragraph: The feminist writer Germaine Greer once declared: “Every generation has to discover Nina Simone. She is evidence that female genius is real.” This year, that just might happen for good.

headline: A Thirty-Year American Road Trip
abstract: David Graham has made his life work taking witty, empathetic images of America that are layered with meaning.
lead_paragraph: David Graham has made his life work taking witty, empathetic images of America that are layered with meaning.

headline: Rise of Far-Right Party in Denmark Reflects Europe’s Unease
abstract: The anti-immigration Danish People’s Party took second in Thursday’s vote, underlining a growing crisis of confidence in the Continent’s traditional politics.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The surprisingly strong showing in elections on Thursday of Denmark’s anti-immigration, anti-Brussels Danish People’s Party has underlined a growing crisis of confidence in traditional political institutions and in the European Union itself.

headline: European Regulators Lay Out Demands and Fines in Google Antitrust Case
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Regulators say that Google uses its 90 percent market share in Europe to favor its own services over those of rivals like Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe’s antitrust authorities have threatened to impose significant fines on Google’s operations on the Continent if the company does not give rivals greater prominence in some search results across the 28-member bloc.

abstract: A White House picnic, two more names enter the 2016 race, and tragedy in Charleston, S.C.
lead_paragraph: A White House picnic, two more names enter the 2016 race, and tragedy in Charleston, S.C.

abstract: This week, Meghan Daum and Heather Havrilesky discuss new books about reaching adulthood, and Vendela Vida talks about her new novel.
lead_paragraph: This week, The New York Times Book Review features reviews of new books about childhood, parenting and the shifting definition of adulthood. A. O. Scott reviews Susan Neiman’s “Why Grow Up?”; Heather Havrilesky writes about “How to Raise an Adult,” by Julie Lythcott-Haims; and Meghan Daum assesses “The Prime of Life,” by Steven Mintz. Ms. Daum writes:

headline: Finding It Hip to Be Square
abstract: From a forthcoming collection of iPhone images by Robert Herman, “The Phone Book.”
lead_paragraph: From a forthcoming collection of iPhone images by Robert Herman, “The Phone Book.”

headline: Robert Herman Squares New Photos With Past Work, Using an iPhone App
abstract: A new project from Robert Herman explores world cities with images similar to analog work from past decades.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Robert Herman shot street photography mainly in New York and primarily on Kodachrome film. Mr. Herman was born in Brooklyn and raised on Long Island and began shooting on the city streets in the late 1970s while working as a set photographer. “There’s a lot of time between takes, so I started taking photos in the neighborhoods where we were shooting,” he said.

headline: N.R.A. Board Member Deletes Criticism of Victim in Church Massacre
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: An N.R.A. official said the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney, one of the nine people killed in Charleston, S.C., could have prevented the attack if he had not supported a ban on guns in churches.
lead_paragraph: Faced with an online backlash, a member of the National Rifle Association’s board deleted comments Friday criticizing the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney, a South Carolina lawmaker who was one of the nine people shot and killed  in the attack on his church in Charleston on Wednesday night.

headline: India and the Politics of Yoga
abstract: Prime Minister Modi’s goal for International Yoga Day is to promote India’s brand, not the Hindu religion.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — ATTENTION, downward-facing-dog enthusiasts. The International Day of Yoga is coming on Sunday. A brainchild of Narendra Modi, the Indian prime minister, it is being backed by more than 175 countries and heavily promoted worldwide. Last week, the Indian Embassy in Washington emailed me an invitation to celebrate on the National Mall, complete with a downloadable yoga “protocol” of exercises. Even Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, has been seen, shoeless, practicing his tree pose in Delhi.

headline: A Stylishly Secretive Store for Design-Obsessed Men in Los Angeles
abstract: Please Do Not Enter is both a curated boutique and art exhibition space for design-obsessed men.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — For much of the last year, the design-obsessed made their way to downtown, where they entered a 1920s-era Beaux-Arts building and rode the elevator to the 12th floor. There, a door sign read, confoundingly, “Please Do Not Enter,” but that is, in fact, the name of the store.

headline: Chambers Bay Has Even Leaders Scratching Their Heads
abstract: The high drama of the weekend rounds at the United States Open might be the race to see which of the world’s best golfers unravels the mysteries of Chambers Bay first.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Standing in the fairway, Jordan Spieth was on his way to a double bogey on the 18th hole, and he knew it. He had little interest in taking all the blame for that failing.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: ‘Ridin’ With Biden’ in 2016, but So Far the Vice President’s Not Aboard
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A group of Democrats in Chicago are mounting a Draft Biden campaign to persuade Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to seek the party’s nomination for president.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On the whiteboard at campaign headquarters in a spartan downtown office are listed the day’s tasks. No. 1: “Send out bumper stickers.”

headline: An App Offers Up-to-Date Schedules for Bus and Train Lines
abstract: Wanderu is set up to find travel options that get you as close as possible to a specific place. Results can be sorted by time and price.
lead_paragraph: If you’re lucky, you’re reading this somewhere other than Manhattan. For all that it’s been celebrated in song, summer in the city is often a miserable affair. (The lyrics of that Lovin’ Spoonful hit are worth a second listen.) Best to get away, and any app that can help you do that as quickly as Wanderu is worth the space it takes up on your home screen.

headline: Finding Lessons in a Past Escape as Another Manhunt Presses On
abstract: A State Police report on the search for Ralph Phillips, a convict known as Bucky who eluded capture for months in 2006, was prepared with the current situation in mind.
lead_paragraph: The inmate escaped, and he ran hard.

headline: White Terrorism Is as Old as America
abstract: Some of the country’s earliest antiterrorism legislation was passed to stop the Ku Klux Klan. So why do we assume that terrorists must come from somewhere else?
lead_paragraph: My grandmother used to speak of Klansmen riding through Louisiana at night, how she could see their white robes shimmering in the dark, how black people hid in bayous to escape them. Before her time, during Reconstruction, Ku Klux Klan members believed they could scare superstitious black people out of their newly won freedom. They wore terrifying costumes but were not exactly hiding — many former slaves recognized bosses and neighbors under their white sheets. They were haunting in masks, a seen yet unseen terror. In addition to killing and beating black people, they often claimed to be the ghosts of dead Confederate soldiers.

headline: Crushing Ivory to Save Elephants
abstract: The global ivory trade is responsible for the slaughter of as many as 35,000 African elephants annually.
lead_paragraph: The global ivory trade is responsible for the slaughter of as many as 35,000 African elephants annually.

headline: Summer Lovin’ Takes New York
abstract: Jan Benzel, a Metro editor, describes this year’s summer series, which she will be assigning and editing. The focus? Summer romance.
lead_paragraph: What’s this? Summer Love? In Metro space, where readers are more accustomed to reading about murder, prisons, misdeeds and the power struggle between the governor and the mayor?

abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.
