headline: Review: New York Theater Ballet Is at Home in St. Mark’s Church, Part of Danspace Project
abstract: Its “Legends & Visionaries 2015” season includes a world premiere by the American Ballet Theater dancer Gemma Bond.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost a year since New York Theater Ballet moved downtown to St. Mark’s Church, from its former headquarters in Murray Hill. Its current season, “Legends & Visionaries 2015,” part of Danspace Project’s Dance: Access series, is its first in the church sanctuary. On Thursday, the troupe seemed right at home amid the pillars and stained glass windows, looking radiant and grounded despite the past year’s upheaval. The move felt complete.

headline: ‘In the Wake: Japanese Photographers Respond to 3/11’
abstract: Art photographs at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, focus on the aftermath of a disaster in Japan.
lead_paragraph: Art photographs at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, focus on the aftermath of a disaster in Japan.

headline: Evening Hours | Summertime Sweetness
abstract: Threats of rain did not slow the partying.
lead_paragraph: Threats of rain did not slow the partying.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Bountiful Bow Ties
abstract: Men have a new knot: the bow tie, which has been spotted at polo matches, at the Belmont Stakes, at picnics and at dance events.
lead_paragraph: For generations, men have tried to get rid of the necktie noose around their necks. They haven’t succeeded. Now they have a new knot: the bow tie, which has been spotted at polo matches, at the Belmont Stakes, at picnics and at dance events. Along with the bow tie have come straw hats and suspenders. The trousers worn with these can be long or Bermuda length. It’s what’s on top that defines a new generation’s dress code for today’s casual weekend events. It stands in stark contrast to a few years ago, when men were flinging themselves into wrinkled shirts and cut-off jeans.

headline: Turning to a Ghostwriter for a Personal Toast
abstract: Hesitant public speakers are engaging their own private Cyranos to write toasts.
lead_paragraph: When Tom Ruggiero was asked to offer a toast at the wedding of his friends Jessie and Ben last year, he panicked. A 32-year-old real estate lawyer in New York, Mr. Ruggiero was not accustomed to public speaking.

headline: Review: Japanese Photographers Reflect on the Fukushima Catastrophe
keywords: ['Photography', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Art']
abstract: The disaster of March 11, 2011, is the ostensible subject of the images on display, but their deeper subject is fear and anxiety.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — What’s the purpose, what’s the effect of creating “art” photographs about natural disasters after they happen? News photographs will have already stirred up horror; will this be more of the same? The curators of “In the Wake: Japanese Photographers Respond to 3/11” at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, pose those questions and more in this provocative exhibition by 17 photographers who reacted to the earthquake, tsunami and breach of the Fukushima nuclear plant in northeastern Japan on March 11, 2011, after the news-media coverage.

headline: Max Robinson, a Largely Forgotten Trailblazer for Black Anchors
abstract: Few news reports mentioned the pioneering journalist who predated Lester Holt in the anchor’s chair.
lead_paragraph: When NBC announced on Thursday that Lester Holt would replace the beleaguered Brian Williams as anchor of “NBC Nightly News,” it was widely applauded.

headline: Review: Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Summons a Life During Wartime
abstract: The company debuted “Analogy/Dora: Tramontane,” about the experiences of Mr. Jones’s mother-in-law during World War II, at Montclair State University.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — At the start of World War II, Dora Amelan, a Jewish girl of 19, was living in Belgium. At the end of the war, she was still alive, though much of her family was not. The story of her survival is, in her telling, a story of luck but also of choices. That she spent much of the war in France helping others in internment camps and saving children did not save her from the kind of moral dilemmas that remain insoluble through a lifetime of remembering.

headline: He Hosts Miley and Rihanna, and Now He’s Getting a Taste of Their Fame
abstract: Richie Akiva, the night life impresario behind 1Oak and other celebrity magnets, still has a few late nights left in him.
lead_paragraph: Miley Cyrus posed with Sean Combs. Kendall Jenner hung out with Justin Bieber. Vanessa Hudgens chatted with Selena Gomez. John Legend and Chrissy Teigen held court in one corner, while Madonna danced in another.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Goes Timeless in Central Park
abstract: The weather plays a crucial role at the first two days of the Philharmonic’s parks concerts.
lead_paragraph: Two factors conspired against pleasantness at Wednesday evening’s New York Philharmonic concert, the start of the orchestra’s 50th season of programs in city parks: the weather and the music.

headline: Ceramic Skyline, on the Move
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Subways', 'Relocation of Business', 'Murals', 'Terra Cotta', 'Museums', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: At the New York Transit Museum, one can find a steel-dust stained terra cotta plaque showing the Brooklyn Bridge and New York Harbor, one of four that formed a mural.
lead_paragraph: For the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, last year’s 110th anniversary of brave New Yorkers’ first commute underground was cause for celebration, but for the New York Transit Museum, it also began a time of transition. The institution, just off Borough Hall, is moving its archives out of a Lower Manhattan storage space into a larger, 14,380-foot behemoth of a bunker in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn. And the museum recently announced that its longtime director, Gabrielle Shubert, is retiring.

headline: Review: ‘Most Dangerous Man in America (W. E. B. Du Bois)’ Focuses on Government Investigation
abstract: Amiri Baraka’s final play, by the New Federal Theater, combines history, biography and courtroom satire.
lead_paragraph: A history play, a biographical play, a documentary play and a courtroom satire, Amiri Baraka’s final work, “Most Dangerous Man in America (W. E. B. Du Bois),” by the New Federal Theater, is an unmusical grace note to Baraka’s vibrant, varied career.

headline: Review: ‘The Brink’ Stars Tim Robbins as a Sex-Crazed Secretary of State
abstract: This new HBO comedy series, which starts on Sunday night, also features Jack Black as a State Department bureaucrat in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Making jokes about the Middle East is not a safe bet.

headline: James Salter in The Times and Elsewhere
abstract: Mr. Salter, the author of “A Sport and a Pastime,” “Light Years” and other books, died on Friday at 90.
lead_paragraph: James Salter, the novelist whose careful prose style made him a favorite among fellow authors,  died on Friday in Sag Harbor, N.Y., at 90.

headline: Alex Rodriguez at No. 3,000, With Bullet and Asterisk
abstract: With 3,000 hits, Rodriguez became only the third player to reach that milestone and 600 home runs. The two others are Hank Aaron and Willie Mays.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez joined the 3,000-hit club in style on Friday at Yankee Stadium, in a familiar scene with a much different character in the starring role.

headline: How Ali Wentworth, Comedian and Author, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Wentworth, a comedian and author, has bagels with lemon with her husband and two daughters in the morning, and ends the day with a couple of television shows.
lead_paragraph: Even though the comedian Ali Wentworth is creating television pilots and writing books (her most recent, “Happily Ali After,” was published on June 9), she still has creative energy to burn. “I’ll wake up in the middle of the night and paint a bathroom or bake 300 homemade chocolate chip cookies,” she said. Having worked in television (“In Living Color,” “Seinfeld” ) and film (“It’s Complicated,” “Office Space”), Ms. Wentworth, 50, has become accustomed to the ebbs and flows of show business. On Sundays, she and her husband, George Stephanopoulos, 54, chief anchor for ABC News, shed their professional personas. They have two daughters, Elliott, 12, and Harper, 9, and a couple of dogs. They live on the Upper East Side.

headline: Alex Rodriguez, the Most Powerful in the 3,000-Hit Club
abstract: Alex Rodriguez became the latest player to reach 3,000 hits. His home runs make up 22 percent of those hits, a higher percentage than any other player on the list.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez became the latest player to reach 3,000 hits. His home runs make up 22 percent of those hits, a higher percentage than any other player on the list.

headline: English Class in Common Core Era: ‘Tom Sawyer’ and Court Opinions
abstract: The standards, which have been adopted by more than 40 states, mandated many changes to traditional teaching, but one of the most basic was a call for students to read more nonfiction.
lead_paragraph: In Harrison, N.Y., 10th graders read articles about bipolar disorder and the adolescent brain to help them analyze Holden Caulfield. In Springdale, Ark., ninth graders studying excerpts from “The Odyssey” also read sections of the G.I. Bill of Rights, and a congressional resolution on its 60th anniversary, to connect the story of Odysseus to the challenges of modern-day veterans. After eighth graders in Naples, Fla., read how Tom Sawyer duped other boys into whitewashing a fence for him, they follow it with an op-ed article on teenage unemployment.

headline: Federal Auditor Finds Broad Failures at N.H.T.S.A.
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The agency had weak management and undertrained staff, and it repeatedly missed opportunities to identify the deadly defect at the heart of a large recall of G.M. vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Even as evidence poured into the nation’s top auto safety agency pointing to dangerous defects in millions of vehicles, regulators repeatedly failed for years to root out problems and hold carmakers accountable, according to a long-awaited internal audit by the Transportation Department.

headline: Friday Night Music: Pavo Pavo
abstract: Something special and new.
lead_paragraph: I went to see Lucius at Celebrating Brooklyn on Saturday; for those who asked for a link, someone took quite good videos here and here. But let me feature the first opening act, a new band named Pavo Pavo. It was great to be part of the audience, most of whom, like me, didn’t know the band at all; little by little everyone began to realize that we were experiencing something special, that these very young musicians definitely have the magic:

headline: Airbag Death in Honda Rental Car Reveals a Gap
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Liability for Products', 'Law and Legislation', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The death was the first linked to Takata’s airbags involving a rental car, and it underscored the holes in safety regulations for used or rental cars.
lead_paragraph: Honda Motor confirmed on Friday that an airbag rupture killed the driver of a rented 2001 Civic in September 2014, making it the eighth death linked to faulty airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata.

headline: With an Activist Investor, ConAgra Is Primed to Be Carved Up
abstract: Jana Partners is ready to restructure ConAgra’s board and there may be some appetite for the company’s myriad brands.
lead_paragraph: ConAgra Foods’ smorgasbord is ready to carve. The conglomerate’s $6.8 billion acquisition of Ralcorp in 2013 left a bad taste with shareholders. The activist investor Jana Partners is ready to shake up the board. ConAgra’s myriad brands probably fit better elsewhere. The question is how to slice it.

headline: Testimony in James Holmes Trial of Gunfire and Loss
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Testimony of the death of a 6-year-old concluded the prosecution’s case against Mr. Holmes, who could face the death penalty over a theater shooting in Aurora, Colo.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — As the movie theater lights dimmed and the previews rolled, Ashley Moser shifted her 6-year-old daughter, Veronica, off her lap and into the seat next to her. Ms. Moser had just learned she was pregnant, and Veronica’s bony frame hurt her stomach, she testified on Friday. They were sitting side-by-side in the dark when the gunman walked in, lobbed a gas canister and opened fire.

headline: Please, Corporations, Experiment on Us
abstract: You don’t even need our consent.
lead_paragraph: CAN it ever be ethical for companies or governments to experiment on their employees, customers or citizens without their consent?

headline: Iowa Court Ruling Says Doctors Can Prescribe Abortion Drugs by Video
abstract: In a unanimous ruling, the Iowa Supreme Court struck down a rule preventing doctors from using telemedicine to dispense abortion-inducing pills in remote clinics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Iowa Supreme Court struck down a rule on Friday that would have prohibited doctors from using telemedicine to dispense abortion-inducing pills to patients in remote clinics around the state, saying the ban placed an “undue burden” on a woman’s constitutional right to an abortion.

headline: Mixed Effects Are Seen on an Affordable Care Act Repeal
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Gross National Product (GNP)', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said repealing the Affordable Care Act would increase federal deficits and the number of uninsured Americans, but it would also raise economic output.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said Friday that repealing the Affordable Care Act would significantly increase federal budget deficits and the number of people who are uninsured.

headline: Red Tape Untangled, Young Nepalese Monks Find Ride to Safety
keywords: ['Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Children and Childhood', 'Earthquakes']
abstract: Fifty-nine students, mostly boys, were airlifted by helicopter out of an isolated Buddhist monastery destroyed by the earthquake that struck Nepal in April.
lead_paragraph: LHO, Nepal — A dozen children, wearing the maroon robes of Buddhist monks, sat together on the packed earth of the village courtyard, solemn-faced and whispering. Behind them, vertical cliffs rose to snow-covered peaks. In front, a narrow valley opened up, sunlight glimmering off the gold paint of a Buddhist shrine where other monks were stacking a stone wall.

headline: Unicef Fears Surge in Child Trafficking After Nepal Quakes
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Human Trafficking', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Trafficking in Nepalese children was a problem before two earthquakes struck in April, but Unicef and the government fear the ensuing chaos may make a problem even worse.
lead_paragraph: Unicef expressed concern on Friday over a possible surge in the trafficking of Nepalese children who might have been orphaned, abandoned or sold in the nearly two months since two severe earthquakes struck Nepal.

headline: De Blasio Prods Graduates to Challenge Injustice (and Son to Take a Joke)
abstract: In a highly personal speech, Mayor Bill de Blasio addressed his son’s graduating class, offering emotional guidance to parents and challenging seniors to “not stand idly by” amid inequality.
lead_paragraph: The parents, anxious and proud, filed into their seats clutching flowers and cards, to be presented to students in private embraces after the ceremony.

headline: In First Batch of Released Cheney Papers, a Peek at a Polarizing Figure
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Responding to Freedom of Information requests, the National Archives and Records Administration released a trove of documents and photos from Dick Cheney’s time as vice president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In February 2008, an aide sent a news article to Vice President Dick Cheney reporting that former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell might vote for a Democrat for president. Sections were highlighted in yellow, and someone had circled a quotation from Mr. Powell in which he said America had lost “a lot” of prestige around the world.

headline: France: Mideast Peace on Agenda
abstract: The French foreign minister will travel to the Middle East for meetings that the government asserts will be an effort to restart peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: The French foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, will travel this weekend to Egypt, Jordan, Israel and the West Bank for meetings that the government asserts will be an effort to restart peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. Although the French are not talking publicly about it, the other pressing issue for Mr. Fabius is the proposed nuclear deal with Iran. Talks between Iran and its negotiating partners over Iran’s nuclear program are set to finish by the end of June. In Jordan, Mr. Fabius will meet with his Jordanian counterpart as well as with King Abdullah II.

headline: Mexico: Ex-Governor Charged
abstract: The former governor of the northeast Mexican border state of Tamaulipas has been indicted on money-laundering charges in South Texas, prosecutors said Friday.
lead_paragraph: The former governor of the northeast Mexican border state of Tamaulipas, Eugenio Hernández Flores, has been indicted on money-laundering charges in  South Texas, prosecutors said Friday. The charges stem from allegations by United States law enforcement agencies that Mr. Hernández had received bribes from the Zetas drug gang to allow it to operate freely in Tamaulipas while he was governor from 2005 to 2010. Mr. Hernández, 57, is a fugitive but he called in to a Mexican radio show on Friday to declare his innocence. The governor preceding him, Tomás Yarrington, also faces money-laundering and drug-trafficking charges. He, too, remains a fugitive.

headline: Hot Peppers Becoming a Cash Crop for Bronx Community Gardens
abstract: The Bronx Greenmarket Hot Sauce was developed last year to support local gardens through purchases of its main ingredient, serrano peppers.
lead_paragraph: The bright-green stalks and leaves are tended by a dozen teenage boys who water, lay mulch, pull weeds and wait.

headline: Genome Studies Show How Ebola Spread Initially
abstract: Scientists have developed a fuller picture of how the virus spread and evolved by tracking mutations in its genome.
lead_paragraph: After tracking tiny mutations in the genome of Ebola, scientists from around the world are developing a fuller picture of how the virus spread and evolved genetically during the world’s worst outbreak of the disease.

headline: Dominican Deadline Passes Without Mass Expulsion of Haitian Migrants
abstract: The expected mass deportation of Haitian immigrants in the Dominican Republic failed to materialize in the two days after the government’s deadline for them to normalize their status.
lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — A cloud of fear and uncertainty has settled over the Dominican Republic in the two days since the government officially closed the doors to migrant workers trying to normalize their status.

headline: Marijuana Is in the Air and on It, Too
abstract: A radio station is entering uncharted waters with its cannabis-themed format despite the legalization of recreational marijuana in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Some people who prosper in life choose to spend their hard-earned millions on private planes. Some buy a vineyard in Napa to indulge a love of wine. Some collect showpiece cars, or fulfill a dream of hiking Mount Everest.

headline: A Son, Known for His Kindness, Is Mourned After He Is Bludgeoned to Death
abstract: Bubacarr Camara was killed in broad daylight Thursday as he manned his family’s clothing and odd-and-ends store on the Upper West Side. No arrests have been made.
lead_paragraph: On an unassuming block of Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side, Bubacarr Camara was murdered on Thursday, bludgeoned to death in broad daylight, the police believe, as he worked at his family’s clothing and odds-and-ends shop. His body was discovered behind the register.

headline: Returning Home to Console, Lindsey Graham Joins the Mourning
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gun Control', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Senator Graham, a South Carolina Republican and a presidential hopeful, returned to his home state Friday to do what little he could to help as residents mourned nine murdered churchgoers.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Senator Lindsey Graham was in the passenger seat on Friday, preparing to make what would be the first of many difficult phone calls in the coming days.

headline: Pope Francis’ Climate Error
abstract: To control emissions, a carbon market is best.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — AMONG environmental activists, the international market for carbon credits is often compared to the medieval sale of indulgences. Pope Francis presides over the Roman Catholic church, the institution that created the market for indulgences, so you might expect him to be more sympathetic on this issue.

headline: 8 Indicted in Identity Thefts of Patients at Montefiore Medical Center
abstract: A hospital employee and seven others were indicted on Friday on charges of stealing the personal information of as many as 12,000 patients.
lead_paragraph: A Montefiore Medical Center employee and seven others were indicted on Friday on charges of stealing the personal information of as many as 12,000 hospital patients and using it to make purchases at luxury stores, the Manhattan district attorney said.

headline: Astros’ G.M. Jeff Luhnow Delegates With a Drive for Data
abstract: Before he found himself at the center of the St. Louis Cardinals’ hacking scandal, Luhnow rose through the ranks of baseball on the strength of his technological prowess.
lead_paragraph: The first time Jeff Luhnow returned to St. Louis as general manager of the Houston Astros, he had Chinese food for his pregame meal at Busch Stadium. He opened a fortune cookie and was struck by the wisdom of the words inside: “You will obtain your goal if you maintain your course.”

headline: How to Really Fix Rikers
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The city’s settlement with the Justice Department must address the culture of violence.
lead_paragraph: ON Monday, New York City is expected to settle a three-year-old class-action lawsuit by the Legal Aid Society over excessive use of force at Rikers Island. As a former chief of internal investigations at the Department of Correction, I am a defendant.

headline: Outrage vs. Tradition, Wrapped in a High-Flying Flag of Dixie
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: The debate has been renewed on social media and beyond about whether the flag should be displayed, and whether politicians should continue to defend it.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Stunned by the massacre at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, South Carolina has been abruptly forced to confront an issue that has bedeviled it for decades: the Confederate battle flag that flies above the grounds of the State House.

headline: A Flavorful Crust
abstract: Kyle T. Dolan fools me in a game I call “Guess the Seed Entry.”
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — When I don’t have a theme to become obsessed with in a puzzle, I play a little game that I like to call “Guess the Seed Entry.” It keeps things interesting for me, and I’m not always right.

headline: Black Church Is Target Again for Deadly Strike at the Heart
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: After the Civil War, black churches became what the scholar W. E. B. Du Bois and others have described as the “first social institution fully controlled by black men in America.” And before long, those institutions became targets.
lead_paragraph: In Atlanta, the former slaves sang their hallelujahs in an abandoned railroad boxcar. In Lincoln County, N.C., they called out to Jesus in a building made of old pine poles. Near Cartersville, Ga., they raised their voices to the heavens from a roofless barrel shop.

headline: Justice Kennedy on Solitary Confinement
abstract: In addressing the brutality of the punishment at length in an opinion, he raises a constitutional question some colleagues might prefer to avoid.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision in the case of Hector Ayala, who has been on California’s death row for 25 years, turned on the question of whether a judge could hear a prosecutor’s reasons for dismissing people from the jury pool without the defendant’s lawyer being present. On Thursday, the court ruled 5-4 that excluding the lawyer was a harmless error.

headline: Redevelopment of Manhattan’s Far West Side Gains Momentum
abstract: A frenzy of construction is taking place at the once industrial Hudson Yards district, where hundreds of workers are erecting office towers, a hotel, a mall and residential buildings.
lead_paragraph: Construction cranes are swinging across the skyline on the once industrial Far West Side of Manhattan where hundreds of workers are erecting four office towers, a hotel, a large mall and at least a half-dozen residential buildings.

headline: First Presidential Trip to Ethiopia Planned
abstract: Human rights groups questioned President Obama’s trip, saying that Ethiopia has silenced dissent with arbitrary arrests, mistreatment of detainees and repressive legislation.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will travel next month to Ethiopia to meet with African Union leaders and discuss ways to lift economic growth, strengthen democratic institutions and improve security, the White House announced on Friday. The visit, the first to Ethiopia by an American president, will follow a stop in Kenya, the home country of his father’s family. Human rights groups questioned the trip, saying that Ethiopia has silenced dissent with arbitrary arrests, mistreatment of detainees and repressive legislation.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Mood Turns Serious After Jason Day’s Health Scare
abstract: Stumbles have been a common sight on the slick surface at Chambers Bay this week, but Day’s episode of vertigo was a much scarier moment.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — The 115th United States Open had the wind briefly knocked out of it Friday afternoon when one of the leaders, Jason Day, fell in a heap on the ninth green. Day, sitting two strokes behind the pacesetters after a birdie at the eighth, was walking toward his ball, which had landed in a back bunker.

headline: Jamie Lovemark, an Unheralded Pupil, Shines While a Star Stumbles
abstract: Tutored by Chris Como, Lovemark put himself in contention at the United States Open, while Como’s more famous student, Tiger Woods, missed the cut.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — The player who was wild off the tee is finding fairways since he began working last year with Chris Como. But enough about Jamie Lovemark, the former Southern California star who has played his way into contention in his United States Open debut with rounds of 70 and 68 for a two-under-par 138.

headline: Radio D.J.s Offer Comfort and Community After Charleston Church Killings
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Radio', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Urban radio serves a special purpose when the nation is wounded by a crime with hosts like Ebro Darden of Hot 97 turning shows into sounding boards.
lead_paragraph: It was not a typical Friday morning at New York’s premier hip-hop radio station, Hot 97 — and not because of anything happening in the world of music.

headline: James Salter, a ‘Writer’s Writer’ Short on Sales but Long on Acclaim, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Salter wrote slowly, exactingly and, by almost every critic’s estimation, beautifully. But he never achieved the broad popularity he craved.
lead_paragraph: James Salter, whose intimately detailed novels and short stories kept a small but devoted audience in his thrall for more than half a century, died on Friday in Sag Harbor, N.Y. He was 90.

abstract: Two readers say many fraternities want to help change campus culture to reduce sexual assaults.

headline: The Endgame in Greece
abstract: It’s time to end useless displays of acrimony and brinkmanship to avoid a total collapse of the Greek economy.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of eurozone finance ministers on Thursday, which was billed as the last chance to stave off a Greek default and a Greek exit from the euro, collapsed in rancor and recriminations less than an hour after it started. Eurozone leaders then promptly scheduled a summit meeting for Monday to deal with the crisis. After five years of this, the world can be forgiven for not heeding the serial cries of “wolf.” Only this time, there really is a wolf at the door.

headline: Companies and Campaign Disclosure
abstract: A former S.E.C. commissioner writes that disclosure “comes at the expense of shareholders’ economic interest.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Uncertainty Mounting as Little Progress Is Seen in Albany on Rent Regulations
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The Assembly and Senate have agreed to extend the existing law, which had expired, until next Tuesday, but the chambers seem to be far apart on a long-term resolution.
lead_paragraph: Tenants have held protests and an all-night vigil in front of the governor’s office in New York City. Politicians are complaining about other politicians. A city board that decides on rent increases is wondering if it will have to postpone its annual vote.

headline: President Obama and Nancy Pelosi Share Stage After Setback
abstract: A week after Representative Pelosi helped derail one of President Obama’s most important legislative priorities, the two spoke to the nation’s mayors on Friday within moments of each other.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Days after Representative Nancy Pelosi helped derail one of President Obama’s most important legislative priorities, the two shared a stage, a solarium and some tight smiles on Friday as they spoke to the nation’s mayors and then at an exclusive fund-raiser.

headline: Holding On to a Special Ball, With No Apology
abstract: Zack Hample, who has made a name for himself by catching balls at major league stadiums, snagged Alex Rodriguez’s 3,000th hit on Friday at Yankee Stadium and refused to give it up.
lead_paragraph: Two security officials led the way through the Yankee Stadium crowd on Friday, and a group of reporters followed, as Zack Hample clutched the ball that was Alex Rodriguez’s 3,000th hit so tightly that his knuckles were white.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Is Climbing Statistical Ladders
abstract: At this point, Rodriguez seems to reach a major milestone or catch a memorable player in a major category almost daily.
lead_paragraph: At this point in Alex Rodriguez’s career, which has been marked by longevity and relatively steady production, he seems to reach a major milestone or catch a memorable player in a major category almost daily.

headline: Jacob deGrom Takes Shutout of Braves Into Eighth Before the Mets Fold
abstract: DeGrom took a two-hit shutout into the bottom of the eighth inning, when he was undermined by some resistance by the host Atlanta Braves and some shaky defense from his own infield.
lead_paragraph: On the same night on which Alex Rodriguez nicely rounded off his career hit total at a revered 3,000, the Mets’ Jacob deGrom came up with some impressive zeros of his own on Friday — at least for a while. The best starting pitcher for the Mets this season, deGrom took a two-hit shutout into the bottom of the eighth inning, when he was undermined by some resistance by the host Atlanta Braves and some shaky defense from his own work-in-progress infield in a 2-1 loss.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) GONE GIRL (2014) After losing their writing jobs in New York, Nick Dunne (Ben Affleck) and his wife, Amy (Rosamund Pike, in an Oscar-nominated portrayal), move to his small Missouri hometown to attend to his mother after her cancer diagnosis. Then she dies, and so does their marriage. So when Amy goes missing on their fifth wedding anniversary after what looks like a struggle, with broken glass and mopped-up blood, Nick is the prime suspect. And suddenly he and the town are trapped in a nationwide media circus. “At its strongest, ‘Gone Girl’ plays like a queasily, at times gleefully, funny horror movie about a modern marriage, one that has disintegrated partly because of spiraling downward mobility and lost privilege,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about David Fincher’s thriller, adapted from the novel by Gillian Flynn. “Yet, as sometimes happens in Mr. Fincher’s work, dread descends like winter shadows, darkening the movie’s tone and visuals until it’s snuffed out all the light, air and nuance.” By the movie’s second half, she added, “you may wish that Amy would stay gone.”

headline: Corrections: June 20, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, June 20, 2015.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 20, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve had so many African-American friends come to Charleston and say, ‘What a wonderful place. It’s gorgeous. I love it. But where are the black people?’”

headline: The People v. the Coal Baron
abstract: Don Blankenship, former chief of Massey Energy, will stand trial over safety violations related to a deadly mine explosion in West Virginia in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Don Blankenship always knew exactly what he wanted during the years he ran Massey Energy, once the sixth-largest coal company in the United States. He had specific and emphatic ideas about how to operate mines, how to treat employees and how to deal with regulators. When he issued instructions, he wanted them followed to the letter, and this wasn’t just true about his business.

headline: Obamacare and Labor Supply
abstract: Voluntary reductions in work can be good.
lead_paragraph: I was critical of CBO yesterday — probably excessively — for giving what seemed like undue cover for deficit scolds in its long-run budget projection. So credit where credit is due: the new report on the consequences of repealing the ACA is definitely not what the Congressional majority wants to hear. Despite including “dynamic scoring”, the report finds, unambiguously, that Obamacare reduces the deficit and repealing it would enlarge the deficit.

headline: Is Dot Earth Past its Prime?
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Earth', 'Music', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Sustainable Living', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: An MSNBC environment writer says Dot Earth should come to an end. What do you say?
lead_paragraph: [ It seems to be the summer of discontent. Greg Laden, who writes a spirited global warming blog, has published a rather biting critique of my approach to blogging and climate science. I’ve added a link, an excerpt and my responses at the end of this piece.]

headline: Boom in Treetop Parks Lets Visitors Learn the Ropes
abstract: Aerial rope courses have grown more popular in the U.S., offering challenges to vacationing families and adrenaline-rushers alike.
lead_paragraph: Fun in the trees was once reserved for the likes of Tarzan, but aerial rope courses now offer the thrill for everyone. These treetop attractions, originally developed in Europe in the late 1990s, involve trails of increasing difficulty and height, some as high as 50 feet.

headline: Never-Ending Construction Clamor
abstract: This week’s subjects include the din of endless construction; rules about unmarried couples sharing a co-op; and asbestos removal procedures.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Toxic Liquor in India Kills at Least 84
abstract: The dead lived in a Mumbai-area slum, and the toll was expected to rise. More than 30 people were hospitalized, many in serious condition, the police said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least 84 people have died after drinking toxic liquor in a Mumbai-area slum, the police said Saturday, as the toll continued to rise in the worst episode of its kind in more than a decade.

headline: Gap’s Fashion-Backward Moment
abstract: Sales are slumping at American clothing brands like Gap as foreign fast-fashion upstarts like H&M, Uniqlo and Zara lure away customers.
lead_paragraph: At 8:50 on a Wednesday morning, nearly two dozen shoppers hovered in front of H&M’s new global flagship store on the corner of West 34th Street and Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, eager to get inside as soon as the doors were unlocked at 9.

lead_paragraph: Don’t you love those T-Mobile TV commercials? The graphics are kind of punk, with lots of bold flashes of black, magenta and white. Everyone is cool and young and running around, flexing their muscles, chest-thumping, shouting. They’re rebelling! Against the Man!

lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Wednesday was a busy day at the Emanuel A.M.E. Church.

abstract: In treating heart attacks, doctors often say that "Time is muscle." Quick diagnosis and treatment can save lives and reduce or prevent damage to the heart.

headline: Mitt Romney, Jeb Bush and Ted Cruz Weigh In on Confederate Flag at South Carolina Capitol
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Mitt Romney demanded that South Carolina remove the Confederate flag flying above the grounds of its state Capitol on Saturday, calling it a “symbol of racial hatred.”
lead_paragraph: The future of the Confederate flag that flies on the grounds of South Carolina state capitol consumed the Republican Party’s presidential field on Saturday after Mitt Romney, its nominee for president in 2012, demanded its removal, calling it a “symbol of racial hatred.”

headline: For U.S. Open’s Leaders, Tuning Out Distractions Is a Challenge
abstract: Oftentimes, a tournament is won or lost in the hours before the leaders’ first ball is struck, so Sunday could feel like the longest day of the year for the last group to tee off at Chambers Bay Golf Course.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — For reasons having nothing to do with the summer solstice, Sunday will feel like the longest day of the year for the last group to tee off at Chambers Bay Golf Course. From first light to first drive, the hours stretch before the 54-hole leaders like a gangplank leading from familiar shores to the great unknown.

headline: Building a Better Valve
abstract: A new approach to replacing narrowed heart valves allows older and sicker patients to survive treatment.
lead_paragraph: With his smooth, fleshy face and twinkly eyes, Herbert Auspitz, 93, had an air of vigor, but he was fading fast. He had a fatal disease with a prognosis worse than that of most cancers: severe aortic valve stenosis. It is a narrowing of the valve that controls blood flow from the heart. There is no way to prevent it, and there are no drugs to treat it.

headline: Can Wikipedia Survive?
abstract: The rise of mobile devices is worsening a longtime shortage of volunteer editors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WIKIPEDIA has come a long way since it started in 2001. With around 70,000 volunteers editing in over 100 languages, it is by far the world’s most popular reference site. Its future is also uncertain.

headline: For Faithful, Social Justice Goals Demand Action on Environment
abstract: Many faith traditions are awakening to the burden that climate change is placing on poor people, and finding justification for caring for the environment in their scripture.
lead_paragraph: For an earnest young Christian named Ben Lowe, revelation came on the shores of Lake Tanganyika, in Africa. A relentless warming of the lake was reducing the catch of fish, the people were going hungry — and he had learned of scientific evidence that climate change was to blame.

headline: Ermenegildo Zegna’s Perfect Proportions for Spring 2016
abstract: This morning, Stefano Pilati kicked off the men’s shows in Milan with a standout collection for the brand.
lead_paragraph: This morning, Stefano Pilati kicked off the spring/summer 2016 men’s shows in Milan with a standout collection for Ermenegildo Zegna. In an age where designers are shifting away from tighter, form-fitting, cropped tailoring, Pilati mastered the new, more voluminous and relaxed silhouette with consistently perfectly proportioned looks.

headline: To Soften Image, Brazilian Police Ride In Atop Horned Beasts
abstract: “Being the guy on the buffalo makes me more approachable, making my job a little bit easier,” is how one officer in Marajó, Brazil, explained it.
lead_paragraph: MARAJÓ ISLAND, Brazil — Legends flourish about how the first Asian water buffaloes made it to this colossal island in the Amazon River Delta.

headline: Gaza Welcomes Break From Strife and Reopening of Border With Egypt
abstract: First, Egypt opened its border crossing, suggesting a thaw in relations between the Egyptian government and Hamas, and then news emerged that Hamas had begun quiet negotiations with Israel to extend a truce.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — For much of the past year, Gaza has sat in frustrated isolation as it struggled to recover from a devastating war with Israel. But for the people of the battered coastal enclave, the past week brought some welcome signs of relief.

headline: Studying the Students
abstract: Readers respond to “The Dangers of a Student Data Clampdown” (The Upshot, Economic View, June 14).
lead_paragraph: In “The Dangers of a Student Data Clampdown” (The Upshot, Economic View, June 14), Prof. Susan Dynarski of the University of Michigan said that pending laws to tighten the security and privacy of student data could block use of such data to assess and improve education. She cited one congressional proposal, by Senator David Vitter, that she said “would effectively end the analysis of student data by outside social scientists.”

headline: A Quick Fix in Baseball? Not So Fast
abstract: A reminder to anyone who tries to predict the baseball standings before the season: Do not fall for the team that made the splashiest moves.
lead_paragraph: Reminder to anyone who tries to predict the baseball standings before the season: Do not fall for the team that made the splashiest moves. This year, perhaps more than ever, proves the difficulty of a quick off-season makeover.

headline: A Month of Ties
abstract: My father’s ties deserved a second chance. So I wore them and kept a diary.
lead_paragraph: My father’s ties deserved a second chance. So I wore them and kept a diary.

headline: Venezuela’s Rising Team Unites a Country That Sorely Needs Better Times
abstract: These are hard days in Venezuela. But La Vinotinto, as the Venezuelan team is known for its wine-colored shirts, is one thing that crosses the political divide.
lead_paragraph: VALPARAISO, Chile — When Gabriel Cichero played soccer for the Red Bulls in 2008, he sometimes socialized with his fellow Venezuelans Johan Santana, who was playing for the Mets at the time, and Bobby Abreu, who was a Yankee.

headline: The Chinese Want Their Art Back
keywords: ['Art', 'ANTIQUES', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: The government, state-run companies, private collectors and even some criminals are all trying to secure antiquities pilfered years ago.
lead_paragraph: OVER the course of five days in March, Christie’s auctioned off the holdings of the dealer Robert H. Ellsworth, who, before his death last year at age 85, filled his 22-room apartment on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan with what was said to be one of the world’s most comprehensive private collections of Asian art, earning him the nickname “King of Ming.” The sale fetched $134 million, nearly four times the presale estimate of $35 million.

headline: Trade Winds Blow Ill for Hillary
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Candidate Clinton gives voters a distasteful reminder of what “Clintonian” means.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IT’S hard being Elizabeth Warren.

headline: Leave Hamilton Alone
abstract: No one deserves to be on our money more than Alexander Hamilton. Andrew Jackson is another matter.
lead_paragraph: I’M all in for the plan announced last week by the Treasury to put a woman on a piece of American folding money. But in bumping Alexander Hamilton from the center of the $10 bill, we would be exiling the man most responsible for our nation’s having a sound currency in the first place.

headline: What’s the Matter With Polling?
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Elections', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s gotten much harder to predict who will win an election, and 2016 will be harder still.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past two years, election polling has had some spectacular disasters. Several organizations tracking the 2014 midterm elections did not catch the Republican wave that led to strong majorities in both houses; polls in Israel badly underestimated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s strength, and pollsters in Britain predicted a close election only to see the Conservatives win easily. What’s going on here? How much can we trust the polls as we head toward the 2016 elections?

headline: A Rain of Bombs in the Nuba Mountains
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: A foxhole was supposed to be a safe haven from daily shelling by the Sudanese government. Instead, it became an inferno.
lead_paragraph: IN THE NUBA MOUNTAINS, Sudan — THE eight children in the Shanta family lived in a village of grass huts and had never turned on an electric light or worn a watch, never ridden a car or even a bicycle, never spoken on the telephone.

headline: Lift the Cuba Travel Ban
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The freer flow of people, goods and ideas could help nurture openness and reforms on the island.
lead_paragraph: Granted, Khartoum, Tehran, Damascus and Pyongyang are not terribly popular tourist destinations. But they are places Americans can visit without running afoul of federal law. Yet, traveling to Cuba for tourism continues to be banned. Getting there for approved purposes remains needlessly difficult and expensive.

headline: Love and Terror in the Black Church
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Our houses of worship are the site of particular power, and a magnet for violence.
lead_paragraph: AT the sprawling Friendship-West Baptist Church in Dallas one day last spring, I was met by five men with earpieces who escorted me to the pastor’s office. As I prepared to preach that morning, a rolling phalanx of bodyguards shadowed my every move — when I greeted parishioners in the church’s spacious narthex and even as I made a stop at the men’s room. We walked from the church study into the 4,200-seat sanctuary, the security team whispering into their wrists.

headline: Pope Francis’ Call to Action Goes Beyond the Environment
abstract: The pope has come down on the side of the catastrophists, and is really condemning the modern way of life.
lead_paragraph: IN Pope Francis’ sprawling new encyclical, “Laudato Si’,” there are many mansions: A meditation on biblical ecology, a discussion of environmental policy, a critique of consumerism, even a reflection on the perils of social media.

headline: Coping With Outbreaks of MERS
abstract: Hospital systems need to beef up their ability to identify and isolate those infected with the virus and their contacts.
lead_paragraph: A highly lethal contagious disease that has been detected in camels and humans in the Middle East is slowly spreading around the world and is causing havoc in South Korea. Known as the Middle East respiratory syndrome, or MERS, it has killed 35 percent of those it has infected. There have been 1,333 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS in more than two dozen countries; at least 471 people have died.

headline: Gay Marriage’s Moment
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: Many decades of bitter heartache and tenacious hope brought us to this juncture at the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the AIDS crisis? If you lived in a big American city during its spread, you were witness to constant sorrow and countless examples of gay people treated as second-class citizens.

headline: Flying Lessons From My Father
abstract: He taught me not to hold on to anything too tightly — especially something I love.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — BEFORE my first flight lesson, my father sat beside me in the small cockpit and told me the story of a flight instructor whose student stalled on descent, panicked and didn’t release the controls. They both died in the crash.

headline: What Is Whiteness?
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Discrimination', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Our search for understanding in matters of race automatically inclines us toward blackness. But the answers lie in the construction of whiteness.
lead_paragraph: THE terrorist attack in Charleston, S.C., an atrocity like so many other shameful episodes in American history, has overshadowed the drama of Rachel A. Dolezal’s yearslong passing for black. And for good reason: Hateful mass murder is, of course, more consequential than one woman’s fiction. But the two are connected in a way that is relevant to many Americans.

According to the White House, the private sector has since directed nearly $500 million to various projects aimed at expanding opportunity for this group.

headline: Fates Diverge for Homes That Touched Black History
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Both Montclair’s Israel Crane House and Red Bank’s T. Thomas Fortune House are on the National Register of Historic Places and both are civil rights landmarks. But while the Crane House is thriving, the Fortune House is threatened with demolition.
lead_paragraph: By the time Booker T. Washington made his way to Montclair in the 1910s, to speak to women at a budding YWCA for African-Americans, he was already familiar with a different part of New Jersey. His ghostwriter, the pioneering black journalist Timothy Thomas Fortune, lived in Red Bank from 1901 to 1908; local records document at least one trip Washington made to meet Mr. Fortune there.

lead_paragraph: New York State Police troopers converged on Saturday on a spot near Friendship, N.Y., in the southwestern part of the state, where they believed a resident caught sight of the two convicted murderers who staged an elaborate escape from the state’s largest prison.

abstract: Yokohama offers the classic Japanese dishes but mixes it up with cross-cultural creations.

That impression is amply reinforced most nights by the long wait for a table should you arrive without a reservation.

headline: Suit Has South Korea Looking Anew at Its Hard Line on Prostitution
abstract: The case follows a landmark decision that decriminalized adultery, and reflects continuing changes in the nation’s social attitudes toward sex.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jeong-mi, a 43-year-old prostitute in Seoul, says she knows about humiliation. She usually charges customers 20,000 to 30,000 won, or about $18 to $27 — roughly a third of what her younger competition gets. When desperate, she has gone as low as 10,000 won. She has felt people sneering.

headline: Corrections Officer Placed on Leave in Escape Inquiry Worked as Inmate Escort
abstract: The officer’s most recent assignment involved shuttling inmates, including the two who escaped, to their prison jobs.
lead_paragraph: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y. — A corrections officer placed on administrative leave over his possible role in the escape of two convicted killers had a job that gave him “routine” access to the prison tailor shop, where authorities believe the two murderers obtained the tools they used to break out, an official with knowledge of the case said.

headline: Carl Nesjar, Sculptor Who Added Dimension to Picasso, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Nesjar was for nearly two decades Picasso’s chosen fabricator — the artist who took the master’s drawings and scale models and gave them physical form as immense public sculptures.
lead_paragraph: Carl Nesjar was often called Picasso’s right arm, but in truth he was also his left arm and, Picasso being Picasso, very likely a third arm as well.

headline: Allen Weinstein, Historian of Alger Hiss Case, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Weinstein set out to write a book proving that Mr. Hiss did not pass government documents to the Soviet Union when he worked for the State Department in the 1930s, only to reverse his judgment in the face of the evidence.
lead_paragraph: Allen Weinstein, a historian of Cold War espionage whose 1978 book, “Perjury: The Hiss-Chambers Case,” marshaled a mountain of new evidence to argue that Alger Hiss was guilty as charged in one of the most famous spy trials of the postwar era, and who served as the ninth national archivist of the United States, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 77.

headline: How Did They Get Out? Testing the Tools the Escapees Could Have Used

headline: For a Blues Birthplace in Memphis, Challenging Next Steps

lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — It was for years an open secret that behind the blues music, barbecue trophies and neon signs of Beale Street, the small strip of clubs, restaurants and history that helped put Memphis on the map, a legal and political mess existed that tourists never saw.

keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computer Security', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Undetected for nearly a year, Chinese intruders executed a sophisticated hack that gave them “administrator privileges” in government networks. Their ultimate target: information on anyone seeking a security clearance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than five years, American intelligence agencies followed several groups of Chinese hackers who were systematically draining information from defense contractors, energy firms and electronics makers, their targets shifting to fit Beijing’s latest economic priorities.

headline: Symphony of Chain Saws Cuts Clean Through Central Park’s Calm
abstract: Central Park hosted a daylong contest to determine the best lumberjack in the United States, at least for this year.
lead_paragraph: Typically, an orchestra comprising cellists and violinists might play Mozart at the Naumburg Bandshell, a neoclassical concert stage near 72nd Street in Central Park built in 1923 to stimulate the public’s interest in classical music. Instead, on Saturday, tall, bearded, thick-necked men hacked at pine logs with axes and chain saws.

headline: Wait Lists Grow as Many More Veterans Seek Care and Funding Falls Far Short
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The number of veterans on waiting lists of one month or more is now 50 percent higher than it was during the height of last year’s problems.
lead_paragraph: One year after outrage about long waiting lists for health care shook the Department of Veterans Affairs, the agency is facing a new crisis: The number of veterans on waiting lists of one month or more is now 50 percent higher than it was during the height of last year’s problems, department officials say. The department is also facing a nearly $3 billion budget shortfall, which could affect care for many veterans.

headline: Sweet Briar Reaches Deal to Stay Open
abstract: A judge must approve a settlement that would allow Sweet Briar College, a women’s school in Virginia, to remain open for at least another year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sweet Briar College, the women’s liberal arts college in rural Virginia that announced it would close in August — setting off a storm of protest and lawsuits from students, faculty and alumnae — will remain open for at least another academic year under an agreement announced Saturday by the attorney general of Virginia.

headline: Lead Group Has Star Potential
abstract: Going into the final day of the United States Open, the top 14 golfers included two major winners and several others who may be the best players never to have won one.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — It is initially overwhelming, but the more you play it, the less intimidating and more accessible it seems, the former United States Open champion Jim Furyk said. He was talking about Chambers Bay, which measured 7,637 yards on Saturday, but he could have been speaking of the PGA Tour.

headline: Day Honoring Yankees Stars of Past Ends With an Old-Fashioned Rout
abstract: On Old Timers’ Day, the current edition of the Yankees hit five home runs, with Carlos Beltran accounting for two and Alex Rodriguez getting his 668th, in a 14-3 pasting of Detroit.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Tigers gave up early on Saturday, pulling some of their best players in the fifth inning of an eventual 14-3 loss to the Yankees in the Bronx. Many fans left early, too, but it was hard to blame them. The day’s most gripping moments took place before the first pitch.

headline: Unsteady Hands, but Steely Play by Jason Day
abstract: Day, who was felled by vertigo just a day before, sank a birdie putt on No. 18 that tied him with Jordan Spieth, Dustin Johnson and Branden Grace at four-under par headed into the final day of the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Jason Day made the birdie putt on the 18th green that gave him a tie for the lead at the 115th United States Open, but Day knew that rolling the ball into the hole was not going to be the hardest part.

headline: Design Secrets of eBay’s Tastemaker in Chief
abstract: Michael Moskowitz, the site’s chief curator and editorial director, gives T a tour of his curiosity-filled SoHo loft — and a list of his favorite saved searches for scoring hidden gems.
lead_paragraph: Though eBay has transformed the way people shop for design, the site interface itself has until recently been known for an absence of aesthetics. That is changing, however, with the company’s appointment of Michael Phillips Moskowitz. The erstwhile Stanford research associate signed on as chief curator and editorial director a year ago when the company bought his e-commerce startup, Bureau of Trade, a men’s wear-focused site offering carefully chosen vintage objects alongside, in the name of what he calls “conscientious consumption,” the origin stories behind them. Since then, he has spearheaded a series of initiatives to impart good taste into a platform that for years made users dig for it.

headline: The Real Dad Bod
abstract: To celebrate Father’s Day, we’re sharing a selection of stories from dads and the people who love them about what having a dad bod really means.
lead_paragraph: What makes a dad bod? College students describe it as an imperfect, but still attractive, male physique. But we asked Well readers to tell us about the original model — a body owned and operated by an actual dad. Many of you sent us stories about dad bods that reflect a life of experience, adventure and physical challenges.

headline: How Does an Uber Driver Take Family Leave?
abstract: More freelancers, contractors and entrepreneurs means even more people asking “How am I going to take parental leave when my kid is born?”
lead_paragraph: My wife and I recently welcomed our first child, and throughout the pregnancy, I anxiously tried to settle on my plan for paternity leave. It seemed that every day, a new study or article came out that focused on the importance of fathers bonding with their newborn children and the ways corporate America was (or wasn’t) stepping up to the plate to help. I understood all of this, but my new company, Fatherly, was barreling toward launch, and I wasn’t sure how to fulfill my obligations to my work and my new family at the same time.

headline: Lapses at Prison May Have Aided Killers’ Escape
abstract: The Clinton Correctional Facility had in recent years left some security posts unfilled and seen lapses in routine security procedures, current and former officials say.
lead_paragraph: DANNEMORA, N.Y. — By the time David Sweat and Richard W. Matt engineered their extraordinary escape from the maximum-security prison here, corrections officers were rarely shining lights over the faces of inmates during hourly bed checks, making it hard to know whether a living, breathing person was inside a cell.

headline: 1940: American Refugees Arrive Home
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Ships and Shipping', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Seizing a last chance to flee from the advancing German Army.
lead_paragraph: The United States liner Washington, ‘‘last chance’’ ship for Americans fleeing the war zone, arrived at 10:30 a.m. yesterday with 1,793 men, women and children, most of whom had passed fifteen long and harrowing minutes in lifeboats dangling over the liner’s side when the ship was threatened by a submarine June 11 off the northern coast of Portugal. To many, the submarine episode was less frightful than the ordeals they suffered while fleeing across Belgium and France, hardly a jump ahead of the German Army.

headline: Tell Us How Your Church Addressed the Pope’s Encyclical
abstract: The Times wants to know how places of worship in the United States and around the world are responding to Francis’ message on the environment and climate change.
lead_paragraph: The encyclical by Pope Francis released on Thursday did not merely present a papal view on the environment and climate change. It was also an urgent call to action. The document appeared intended to persuade followers around the world to change their behavior, in hopes of protecting a fragile planet.

headline: 1965: Army Occupies Algiers
abstract: From the archives of the Intentional Herald Tribune: Troops bear down on demonstrators protesting the ouster of President Ahmed Ben Bella in a coup.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Riot police and troops occupied the center of Algiers tonight after angry youths took to the streets here for the second time in 24 hours to protest the ouster of President Ahmed Ben Bella. The demonstration which broke out this afternoon — despite a government edict banning all mass gatherings — was dispersed after the police and army troops fired shots into the air.

abstract: The challenge for Republicans has been great as they seek to broaden their party’s appeal while also energizing white conservatives.

headline: Julie Kent Dances Her Farewell Performance to Ovations and Tears
abstract: As Ms. Kent danced a final “Romeo and Juliet” with American Ballet Theater, her fans and colleagues shared the experience on social media.
lead_paragraph: Her entrance applause was so loud, and lasted so long, that it must have been difficult to hear the orchestra during her first few steps. After the curtain went down on the last act, she received a 23-minute ovation and enough bouquets to stock a small flower shop. They were tributes to Julie Kent, who danced her farewell performance with American Ballet Theater on Saturday night after 29 years with the company — a final “Romeo and Juliet” — and stirred strong emotions among fans and fellow dancers. Through social media, the moment reverberated far beyond the Metropolitan Opera House. Here’s a sampling of how her fans and colleagues shared the experience on Twitter.

headline: Al Jazeera Journalist Held in Germany Awaits Verdict on Egyptian Arrest Warrant
keywords: ['Extradition', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'International Relations', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Ahmed Mansour is one of many figures whose arrest and extradition Cairo has demanded. His lawyers said the charges were politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — An Egyptian-British journalist working for the television news network Al Jazeera remained in German custody on Sunday pending a court ruling on the validity of an Egyptian arrest warrant that served as grounds for his detention at a Berlin airport over the weekend. His lawyers said the charges were politically motivated.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) TRUE DETECTIVE Three law enforcement officers (Colin Farrell, above; Rachel McAdams; and Taylor Kitsch) in a fictional Los Angeles suburb and a career criminal (Vince Vaughn) trying to go legit collide when a city manager is murdered — and a lucrative land scheme disrupted — in Season 2 of this anthology series, created and written by Nic Pizzolatto. “This time, Mr. Pizzolatto doubles down on much of what made the first season so distinctive,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “That doesn’t make it twice as good, though. Not nearly.” In the premiere of “Ballers,” at 10, Dwayne Johnson plays a former football pro trying to build a career out of giving financial advice to current players in Miami. The characters’ shenanigans make for “unrewarding, predictable drama, though the writers occasionally try for better,” Neil Genzlinger wrote. And in “The Brink,” a dark comedy at 10:30, the fate of the world rests in the hands of the secretary of state (Tim Robbins), a lowly foreign service officer (Jack Black) and a Navy fighter pilot (Pablo Schreiber) after a rogue general (Iqbal Theba) seizes control of Pakistan and its nuclear arsenal. The writers don’t go very near Islamic extremism or terrorism, Ms. Stanley wrote. “Instead,” she said, “the creators of ‘Brink’ take aim at American wrongdoing. So nobody is going to get in trouble because of this show. But people aren’t going to die laughing, either.”

headline: Invoking the Radical Spirit of Dorothy Day to Fight a Church Closing
abstract: Mercedes Sanchez is challenging the Archdiocese of New York to keep open the Church of the Nativity, in the East Village, because she believes it is what Day, who worshiped there, would do.
lead_paragraph: The Church of the Nativity on Second Avenue has always reminded Mercedes Sanchez of the East Village’s rough-and-tumble days, whether it was the homeless men who flocked there for meals, or the stories about Dorothy Day, the co-founder of the Catholic Worker movement who worshiped there until her death in 1980.

headline: Avoiding Apocalypse
abstract: Off-ramps from the road to hell.
lead_paragraph: Larry Summers has written a scary column warning that Greece may be on the verge of becoming a “failed state”. It’s a useful corrective to the extraordinary complacency I’m hearing from too many European officials. But I do think it’s worth pointing out that this need not happen, even if there is no deal.
