lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — If money talks, it was the stacks of crisp $100 bills that spoke loudest. An Indonesian smuggler said the Australian authorities had stopped his boat at sea and given him and his crew the cash, more than $30,000, to take his cargo of 65 migrants to Indonesia.

headline: Taliban and Afghan Government Dispute Status of Kunduz
abstract: Taliban insurgents said Sunday that they were on the verge of taking their first Afghan city, Kunduz. But the central government said there was no cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After Taliban insurgents said Sunday that they were on the verge of taking their first city, Kunduz in the far north of Afghanistan, officials there expressed alarm as residents began to flee the area. But the central government in Kabul said there was no cause for concern.

headline: Taliban Are Talking Peace, Though Not With Afghan Government
abstract: As they make battlefield gains, the insurgents are engaged in peace talks and showing signs of moving away from some of their hard-line stances.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban envoys have been busy over the past month, shuttling from conferences in one world capital to the next, in the biggest rush of activity on the Afghan peace front in years.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Has No Complaints About His Arm, and Neither Do the Tigers
abstract: Never before had Tanaka allowed three home runs in a major league game — Victor Martinez had one and J. D. Martinez two — and the 10 hits and seven runs he allowed both tied career highs.
lead_paragraph: The first home run Masahiro Tanaka allowed Sunday drew an audible gasp from the crowd. It was stunning both because it came off Tanaka, the Yankees’ ace, and because the homer was a sight to behold, a high-arcing drive off the bat of Victor Martinez that finally landed about five rows into the second deck at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Cigna Rejects an Overture From Anthem
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Anthem’s $47 billion takeover bid for Cigna comes as companies look to become even bigger to take advantage of the changes in the health insurance market.
lead_paragraph: The world of American health insurance may soon become even smaller, with the biggest companies seeking to become even bigger.

headline: Review: Van Morrison Finds New Meaning in Extensive and Nostalgic Catalog
abstract: Mr. Morrison, 69, has accumulated considerable mileage, but he was feisty and focused in his only United States show on his current tour, at Forest Hills Stadium in Queens on Friday.
lead_paragraph: “Road, the road, the road, the road, the road it never seems to end,” the newly knighted Sir Van Morrison sang on Friday night at Forest Hills Stadium in Queens, in the only United States show on his current tour. At 69, Mr. Morrison has accumulated considerable mileage. But he was feisty and focused in this show.

headline: Review: Twyla Tharp’s ‘The One Hundreds’: Math That’s Easy on the Eyes
abstract: Twyla Tharp’s “The One Hundreds,” in the River to River Festival, is made up of 11-second sequences. You do the math.
lead_paragraph: It was misty early in the evening on Saturday, and the lawn of Nelson A. Rockefeller Park in Battery Park City was damp as 100 volunteers danced en masse for 11 seconds. This extremely brief burst of activity was the finale of Twyla Tharp’s 1970 work “The One Hundreds.” The duration of the preceding part of the piece could be measured in minutes: about 20. That was less time than I spent waiting for a subway train on my way home afterward. But “The One Hundreds” was well worth the trip.

headline: Review: ‘Requiem for the Dead’ on HBO Explores Gun Violence in America
abstract: The church massacre in Charleston, S.C., gives this documentary extra topicality, but it also underscores the project’s voyeuristic shallowness.
lead_paragraph: A documentary about gun violence that has its premiere on HBO on Monday has been given extra topicality by the massacre in Charleston, S.C. That, though, isn’t necessarily to the film’s benefit. It might draw additional viewers, sure, but it also underscores the project’s voyeuristic shallowness.

headline: Gay-Themed Play About Oscar Wilde Hits a Kremlin Roadblock
abstract: A technicality has stalled a Moscow production of “Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde,” although the subject matter might be the bigger issue.
lead_paragraph: A plan to stage an American theater company’s gay-themed play in Moscow, with support from the United States government, has stalled amid tensions between the two nations and at a time of Kremlin hostility toward homosexuality.

headline: Review: ‘Dance My Life,’ Souleymane Badolo’s River to River Work, Feeds Off the Public
abstract: Mr. Badolo’s latest dance work incorporates ordinary passers-by who are unaware they are taking part.
lead_paragraph: Dancers are only some of the performers in the River to River Festival, which inhabits public spaces in Lower Manhattan for 11 days each summer. A dance in a plaza or park is also the dance of pedestrians walking by, of joggers, sightseers and other unwitting extras.

headline: Macedonia Government Is Blamed for Wiretapping Scandal
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: According to a European Commission report, the national security service acted on orders from the government. The prime minister reacted defiantly.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The national security service, acting on orders from Macedonia’s conservative and increasingly authoritarian government, was behind the wiretapping scandal that has the small nation on the edge of cracking, a new report says.

headline: Review: ‘Great Men Die Twice,’ a Collection of Sports Reporting by Mark Kram
abstract: This book highlights the energetic, inventive and slightly madcap prose of Mr. Kram, who wrote for Sports Illustrated in the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: The list of sportswriters whose career highlights are worth anthologizing is probably finite: Ring Lardner, Red Smith, Roger Angell, add a few others of your own. But one who shouldn’t be forgotten is Mark Kram, and not simply because he may be the greatest writer ever — of sports or anything else — whose name is a palindrome.

headline: ‘Most Dangerous Man in America (W. E. B. Du Bois)’ Focuses on Government Investigation
abstract: Amiri Baraka’s final play, by the New Federal Theater, combines history, biography and courtroom satire.
lead_paragraph: A history play, a biographical play, a documentary play and a courtroom satire, Amiri Baraka’s final work, “Most Dangerous Man in America (W. E. B. Du Bois),” by the New Federal Theater, is an unmusical grace note to Baraka’s vibrant, varied career.

headline: Review: In ‘Debutaunt,’ Mary John Frank Combines Theater and Dance
abstract: This interactive dance-theater work from Ms. Frank invites the audience to take part in a coming-of-age tradition.
lead_paragraph: “Pretty is as pretty does,” scolds a matron with a honeyed voice and a stranglehold smile at the beginning of Mary John Frank’s very pretty, somewhat slight “Debutaunt,” an interactive satire of Southern cotillion culture.

headline: Review: Three ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Performances, Including Julie Kent’s Farewell
abstract: Last week’s run of performances by American Ballet Theater of Kenneth MacMillan’s version of this ballet included three important performances as Juliet.
lead_paragraph: Hail, hail, hail and farewell. Last week’s run of Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet” by American Ballet Theater included three important performances as Juliet and a distinguished new Romeo. On Thursday evening the Russian ballerina Evgenia Obraztsova made her debut with this company; on Saturday afternoon the company soloists Misty Copeland and Joseph Gorak gave the performance originally planned for their joint debuts as the star-crossed duo (Ms. Copeland had also, on short notice, danced it earlier in the week); and on Saturday evening Julie Kent, Ballet Theater’s longest-serving principal dancer, took her departure from this company.

headline: Study Maps Concentrations of Antibiotics in Chinese Waterways
abstract: Rivers near Beijing and Tianjin in the north and in the Pearl River Delta in the south contain some of the highest concentrations of antibiotics in China’s waterways.
lead_paragraph: Rivers near Beijing and Tianjin in the north and in the Pearl River Delta in the south contain some of the highest concentrations of antibiotics in China’s waterways, according to a study that cites the overuse of the drugs in humans and farm animals.

headline: Hawaii’s State Bird
abstract: Joel Fagliano hands out Twitter handles.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — If you do not have a Twitter account, this puzzle might be a bit, well, puzzling for you. Even if you got the joke, it might be more than you were expecting on a Monday, but as the constructor, Joel Fagliano, remarks in his notes, there’s nothing wrong with a curve ball once in a while.

headline: A ‘Voodoo’ Resurrection
abstract: A look at rehearsals for the opera by the Harlem Renaissance composer H. Lawrence Freeman.
lead_paragraph: A look at rehearsals for the opera by the Harlem Renaissance composer H. Lawrence Freeman.

headline: ‘Voodoo,’ Opera by the African-American Composer H. Lawrence Freeman, Is Revived
abstract: The opera, which will be given its first performance since 1928, offers a glimpse of a nearly forgotten chapter of African-American operatic achievement.
lead_paragraph: He was described as a black Wagner in the late 19th century, went on to write more than 20 operas and formed the Negro Grand Opera Company, which he once conducted at Carnegie Hall. But after the pioneering African-American composer H. Lawrence Freeman died in 1954, he fell into obscurity, with his works unpublished, unrecorded and, for decades, unperformed.

headline: An Athlete Felled by Concussions, Despite Playing a ‘Safer’ Sport
abstract: The case of Curtis Baushke, who was knocked unconscious three times in 14 years while playing soccer, highlights the risks beyond boxing and football.
lead_paragraph: CLARKSVILLE, Tenn. — Months later, the father mustered the strength to sort through what was left in his dead son’s bedroom. A Little League photo collage. Mardi Gras beads from that soccer tournament in New Orleans. And a typewritten personal essay tucked into a yellow folder, with a single word pen-carved into its plastic cover:

headline: International Yoga Day Finally Arrives in India, Amid Cheers and Skepticism
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government attempted to give new life to the idea that yoga can help restore national pride and a return to ancient values could help illness.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It was a rare sight — after a brief speech to inaugurate International Yoga Day on Sunday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi descended from a huge stage in front of the presidential palace and took off his glasses and his shoes. He quietly took his place before a sea of schoolchildren and others, mats neatly arranged in a checkerboard as far as the eye could see, to begin what was billed as the largest yoga demonstration in a single venue in history.

headline: Review: ‘A Deadly Adoption’ Stars Kristen Wiig and Will Ferrell
abstract: Watching these comedians playing it straight, you realize that this movie isn’t very good even by Lifetime standards, which are not exactly lofty.
lead_paragraph: It was either a brilliant example of deadpan humor or a mediocre Lifetime movie. You sorely want to give the stars the benefit of the doubt and credit them with a comedic masterpiece, given their résumés. But, gosh, it sure looked like a mediocre Lifetime movie.

headline: What’s That Science Thing: Pluto Flyby Edition
abstract: What is the SWAP instrument aboard the New Horizons spacecraft and how much energy does it use? Try our quiz if you think you know the answer.
lead_paragraph: What is the SWAP instrument aboard the New Horizons spacecraft and how much energy does it use? Try our quiz if you think you know the answer.

headline: Crossing the Line Festival Announces 2015 Lineup
abstract: The interdisciplinary festival, organized by the French Institute Alliance Française, includes several premieres.
lead_paragraph: The interdisciplinary Crossing the Line festival, organized by the French Institute Alliance Française, has announced its 2015 lineup, which includes several premieres. The festival will run from Sept. 10 through Oct. 4 and begin with the United States premiere of “Suite n°2,” a concert by the French artist Joris Lacoste. The British artist Shezad Dawood will delve into the aftereffects of Hurricane Sandy in “It was a time that was a time,” a post-apocalyptic film shot in Far Rockaway, Queens; on Coney Island; and on Staten Island. The film’s world premiere will be on Sept. 11. Other artists from around the world also have premieres planned: The Brazilian artist Gustavo Ciriaco and the Austrian artist Andrea Sonnberger will bind themselves together and walk through Red Hook (Sept. 19-20); the New York choreographer Miguel Gutierrez will dance his way through the past, present and future in “Age & Beauty” (Sept. 16-26); and the French photographers Mazaccio & Drowilal, who repurpose images from popular culture, will have their first New York exhibition, at the French Institute’s gallery. More information is at fiaf.org/ctl.

headline: Justice Anthony Kennedy’s Tolerance Is Seen in His Sacramento Roots
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: Justice Kennedy, the onetime altar boy from Sacramento and conservative Republican, has advanced legal equality for gays more than any other American jurist.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — In the fall of 1987, a package arrived on the desk of Laurence H. Tribe, a Harvard law professor who had just lost a Supreme Court case on gay rights. It contained the legal opinions of Anthony M. Kennedy, a strait-laced, conservative Republican jurist from Sacramento who hardly seemed sympathetic to that cause.

headline: Hitler Paintings Are Sold at Auction for $440,000
abstract: Fourteen watercolor paintings and drawings presumed to be the work of a young Adolf Hitler were sold at auction in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen watercolor paintings and drawings presumed to be the work of a young Adolf Hitler were sold at auction in Germany for $440,000 (about 391,000 euros), the German news service Deutsche-Presse Agentur reported. The most expensive artwork, a watercolor signed by A. Hitler, of the Neuschwanstein Castle in Bavaria was sold to an unnamed buyer from China at the Weidler auction house in Nuremberg for over $113,000 (100,000 euros); a still life of carnations fetched over $82,000 (73,000 euros), according to Deutsche-Presse Agentur. The art dates from 1904 to 1922 and includes a female nude, scenes of Vienna and Prague, and a portrait of a girl. The collection sold for substantially more than the $143,00 paid at a British auction in 2009 for a group of 13 paintings attributed to Hitler. Last year, the Weidler auction house sold a watercolor said to have been painted by Hitler to an unnamed buyer from the Middle East for around $161,000.

headline: California Golf Trip Lands Obama in a Water-Use Debate
keywords: ['Golf', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Water', 'Drought']
abstract: President Obama returned to a beloved golf oasis in California for a getaway with friends, but a punishing drought in the state has raised questions about whether such oases can survive.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — With four fund-raisers and an awkward reconciliation with the House minority leader, Nancy Pelosi, behind him, President Obama returned to a beloved golf oasis here for a weekend getaway with friends.

headline: Archive of Captured Enemy Documents Closes
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Archives and Records', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The documents included detailed records of Saddam Hussein’s high command in Iraq and Qaeda records from Afghanistan; Pentagon officials say they are planning to transfer the archive to a civilian institution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a bold vision: The American military had captured a massive cache of enemy documents, including detailed records of Saddam Hussein’s high command in Iraq and Qaeda records from Afghanistan. With the strong support of Robert M. Gates, then the defense secretary, the plan was to set up a center where the documents and even captured audio recordings would be available to scholars outside government.

headline: A Show of Solidarity in Harlem Churches After Charleston Killings
abstract: Pastors spoke of hatred and offered hope on Sunday as worshipers felt compelled to attend services after last week’s massacre in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: The hurt could be felt in the solemnity of Sunday sermons and read on the faces of those seated in the pews for the first services in New York City since a white gunman killed nine black churchgoers last week during a Bible study in Charleston, S.C.

headline: Frederick P. Li, Who Proved a Genetic Cancer Link, Dies at 75
abstract: Dr. Li helped show a skeptical medical establishment that a dominant gene, passed from parent to child, was predisposing family members to various cancers.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Frederick P. Li, who helped prove to a doubting medical establishment that heredity and genetics play a major role in some forms of cancer, died on June 12 at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 75.

headline: States Take Few Steps to Fill Gap if Supreme Court Blocks Health Subsidies
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Just a few states have plans in place to create state health exchanges and provide subsidies to residents if the Supreme Court rules they can no longer be paid by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Supreme Court prepares to rule on whether to block health insurance subsidies in 34 states that use the federal insurance exchange, Pennsylvania and Delaware are the best prepared. They have submitted detailed plans for creating their own exchanges by next year, a move intended to keep subsidies flowing to their residents, though possibly with an interruption.

headline: The City From the Air
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poetic look at the miniature city as a plane travels down the Hudson and makes the great arc toward La Guardia Airport.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Fissures in E.U. Deepen From Strain of Migrant Influx and Greek Debt
abstract: A sense of disarray has surrounded the 28-nation bloc as it grapples simultaneously with two crises: a wave of desperate migrants fleeing war and poverty, and the prospect that Greece may default.
lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — As Europe struggles to keep Greece from default and to hold its common currency together, violent protests against immigration in Slovakia and election results in Denmark over the weekend have strengthened the forces of disunion unleashed by an impassioned debate over how to deal with a flood of migrants from conflict zones.

headline: Charles Correa, 84, Is Dead; Architect Fused India’s History With Modernism
abstract: Mr. Correa, whose works were notable for their imagination and breadth, created striking museums and university buildings in India and abroad and was deeply invested in India’s urban future.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Charles Correa, an American-trained architect who returned to his native India to pioneer a new, indigenous architectural style, melding 20th-century modernism with Indian traditions, died on Tuesday in Mumbai. He was 84.

headline: Pressure on Greece and a Senate Hearing on the Takata Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: This week, eurozone leaders turn up the heat on Greece, senators take up the giant Takata recall and Marissa Mayer faces Yahoo shareholders.
lead_paragraph: National leaders from eurozone nations are expected to come together in a summit meeting Monday evening to tell Greece to come to terms or face the prospect of becoming the first country forced out of the single-currency union. Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, who organized the emergency meeting in Brussels, warned Athens that it faced a critical choice on terms that had already been clearly outlined. Finance ministers from the 18 other countries in the eurozone are expected to hold another round of talks with Greece on Monday, before the meeting.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 22
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: In Charleston, a Millennial Race Terrorist
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Terrorism', 'Hate Crimes', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Some are even hesitant to call the Charleston killings a hate crime, despite many signs that it was that and more.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t have to do this,” said Tywanza Sanders to the young man who suddenly rose and drew a gun, and according to witnesses, said he was there “to shoot black people.”

headline: Cannes Lions Festival Shifts Focus Toward Ad Technology
abstract: Companies that had once operated on the fringes of the conference in France are now central to the event, which was created to showcase and award the best in advertising.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — Fetes on yachts. Magnums of rosé. Kim Kardashian.

headline: Engaging in a Softer Conversation About the Roar From New York’s Airports
abstract: After years of intense and frustrating lobbying, noise pollution activists say that airport leaders are finally starting to listen to them.
lead_paragraph: Susan Carroll has developed a tender relationship with the noise monitor on the roof of her apartment building in Queens. She refers to it as “my monitor” (even though she does not own it) and checks on it daily to make sure it is still working (even though she does not operate it).

headline: Sheldon Silver, Unbowed by Charges, Adjusts to Life After the Speakership
abstract: Since being arrested and indicted on federal corruption charges, the former speaker of the New York State Assembly has seen his influence wane. But that hasn’t sent him into hiding.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The last five months have not been kind to Sheldon Silver. Arrested in January, indicted in February and forced out as Assembly speaker in between, Mr. Silver has seen his influence in the Capitol wane.

headline: Health Insurers Brace for Supreme Court Ruling
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: About 6.4 million people could lose subsidies if the court decides the Affordable Care Act does not allow them in states without their own insurance marketplaces.
lead_paragraph: Their industry already upended with the passage of the federal health care law, insurance companies are facing another upheaval if the Supreme Court rules that millions of Americans are not eligible for subsidies to help defray the cost of their coverage.

headline: Few Echo Pope’s Environment Plea in Sunday Sermons
abstract: Around the world, few priests used their pulpits on Sunday to pass on the pope’s message on climate change, pollution and global inequality.
lead_paragraph: On the first Sunday after Pope Francis issued a landmark document on the environment, Roman Catholics attending Mass in Kenya, France, Mexico, Peru and the United States said they were thankful that he was using his pulpit to address climate change, pollution and global inequality.

headline: Women’s World Cup 2015: Cultural Victories to Go With On-the-Field Ones
abstract: A vast majority of countries still do not wholly support women’s soccer, but if Colombia defeats the United States on Monday it could signal a broader victory beyond just one game.
lead_paragraph: EDMONTON, Alberta — Colombia has already scored one of the greatest upsets in the history of the Women’s World Cup, defeating third-ranked France, 2-0, in group play. On Monday comes the hunt for a bigger trophy: the United States.

headline: Comcast and NBCUniversal Open Cross-Promotional Ad Strategy
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The campaign, called Symphony, has been opened to outside advertisers. The idea is to use Comcast’s multiplatform range of assets for ad campaigns.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft wanted to promote its Surface Pro 3 tablet during the last holiday season, it turned to NBCUniversal for help. Together, the companies came up with a sweeping marketing campaign, with pieces showing up across NBCUniversal’s broadcast and cable channels, social media platforms, websites and within the company’s shows.

headline: They Don’t Forgo the Fungo in College Baseball
abstract: All but abandoned by major league teams in the early 2000s, pregame infield practice lives on at the College World Series and at college stadiums all over the country.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — One of the lasting daily traditions at the College World Series began about 40 minutes before Louisiana State faced Cal State Fullerton on Tuesday afternoon. And hundreds of fans crowded around the railing at TD Ameritrade Park under sunny skies to see it.

headline: Gunther Schuller Dies at 89; Composer Synthesized Classical and Jazz
abstract: Mr. Schuller, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his orchestral work in 1994, coined the term Third Stream to describe music that drew on the forms and resources of both classical and jazz.
lead_paragraph: Gunther Schuller, a composer, conductor, author and teacher who coined the term Third Stream to describe music that drew on the forms and resources of both classical and jazz, and who was its most important composer, died on Sunday in Boston. He was 89.

headline: Brian Williams Scandal Shows Power of Social Media
abstract: As the NBC News anchor learned, even amateur sleuths can expose untruths and spread the outrage.
lead_paragraph: The soldiers who prompted Brian Williams’s fall from one of the most powerful jobs in the media had first tried to blow the whistle on him in 2003.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C. Said to Be Adding Andrea Pirlo of Italy
abstract: Pirlo, a 36-year-old midfielder, will join David Villa and Frank Lampard in giving New York City F.C. a load of both star power and international experience.
lead_paragraph: New York City F.C. has all but finalized negotiations with Andrea Pirlo, a 36-year-old Italian midfielder who is set to join the club at the end of the week as a third designated player, according to a soccer official who was briefed on the negotiations.

headline: N.H.L. Seems Likely to Boldly Expand to Las Vegas Strip
abstract: With a new arena being constructed and a wealthy businessman pursuing an expansion team, the N.H.L. in Las Vegas feels like a case of when, not if.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In a city built on chance, it feels like a safe bet that the N.H.L. will become the first major professional sports league to plant a franchise in this gambling and entertainment oasis in the desert.

headline: Nun in Central India Is Sexually Assaulted
abstract: The attack occurred after two masked assailants jumped a fence to enter a medical center, the police in Chhattisgarh State said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A 45-year-old nun was sexually assaulted in a medical center where she worked near the capital of the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh, a police official in the area said Sunday. The nun was found gagged and tied to a bed, he said.

headline: Review: ‘Ada/Ava,’ a Conjuring of Loneliness and Comfort in Plain Sight
abstract: “Ada/Ava,” from Manual Cinema and playing at 3LD, lets the audience in on the secrets behind the shadows in this spectral story of loss.
lead_paragraph: The common wisdom is that once magicians reveal the secrets of their trade, the magic disappears. But that’s hardly the case with the uncanny coven of young sorcerers who operate under the name Manual Cinema.

headline: ‘Poldark’ Season Premiere Recap: Woe v. Luck
abstract: Some guys get all the luck. Not Ross Poldark.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 1

headline: ‘True Detective’ Season 2 Premiere Recap: All the Gold in California
abstract: The HBO crime drama returned on Sunday with new gloomy detectives and a new sun-blasted setting.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 1, “The Western Book of the Dead”

headline: New Summer, and New Face at Top, for the Fresh Air Fund
abstract: Jenny Morgenthau is leaving the nonprofit, which sends thousands of New York City children to home stays and programs in suburban and rural areas; Fatima A. Shama will be the next executive director.
lead_paragraph: The Fresh Air Fund is preparing for a changing of its top leadership as it sends thousands of children from urban neighborhoods in New York City on vacations in the country this summer.

headline: Hundreds Mourn Debbie Frank, Westchester Fitness Heroine
abstract: Ms. Frank, who died of cancer on Thursday, trained dozens of exercise teachers, and was known for a tough but entertaining regimen.
lead_paragraph: LARCHMONT, N.Y. — Debbie Frank was not as celebrated among exercise gurus as, say, Jane Fonda or Richard Simmons, but in the tidy suburban towns of southern Westchester County and among hundreds of women and a few men whose bodies — and self-confidence — she helped transform, she was a local hero.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Jordan Spieth, Not Yet 22, Is 2 for 2 in This Year’s Majors
abstract: Spieth, who birdied No. 18 and won when Dustin Johnson missed a putt that would have forced a playoff, is the first man since Gene Sarazen in 1922 to have multiple major titles before turning 22.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Chambers Bay Golf Course had already served as the backdrop for one big event in the life of the 21-year-old Jordan Spieth. A month after Spieth won his first pro event as a PGA Tour rookie, he was a witness at a wedding on the grounds between his caddie, Michael Greller, and the former Ellie Morris.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 22, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “What lit the fire under this was the tragic death of my friend and his eight parishioners. It took my buddy’s death to get me to do this. I should feel ashamed of myself.”

headline: De Blasio Adds His Voice to Debate Over Dominican Deportation Law
abstract: In Washington Heights, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York spoke out against the government of the Dominican Republic, but found that his comments were not universally welcomed.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio went to Washington Heights in Upper Manhattan on Sunday to talk about international relations. The topic could hardly have been closer to home for the neighborhood, the center of the Dominican community in New York City.

headline: Jason Day Finishes Out of the Race, but Finishes Nonetheless
abstract: Day, who was found to have benign positional vertigo over the weekend, began the final round looking strong but faded on the demanding Chambers Bay course.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Jason Day looked steady on the practice tee before Sunday’s fourth round of the United States Open. Gone were the wobbly strides from Saturday. He stood straight and moved with a purpose. With powerful swings, he smashed soaring drives, and with precision, he fired crisp iron shots.

headline: Colette Marchand, Glamorous International Ballet Star, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Marchand played a highly visible role in the postwar creative ferment of French ballet and she was nominated for an Oscar for her role in John Huston’s “Moulin Rouge.”
lead_paragraph: Colette Marchand, a French ballerina whose long-legged glamour made her an international star in Roland Petit’s ballets in the 1940s and 1950s, and who was nominated for an Oscar for her role in John Huston’s “Moulin Rouge,” died on June 5 at her home in Bois-le-Roi, France. She was 90.

headline: Word of the Day | guise
abstract: This word has appeared in 334 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: guise • \ˈgiz\ • noun

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE FRENCH LIEUTENANT’S WOMAN (1981) Meryl Streep earned her third Oscar nomination portraying Anna, an actress whose love affair with a co-star, Mike (Jeremy Irons), mirrors the doomed relationship in 1867 England between Sarah, a lowborn governess, and Charles, a French naval officer, in the film they are making. Harold Pinter also received an Oscar nomination for his screenplay adaptation of John Fowles’s novel, to which he added the parallel story of Anna and Mike. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called this drama from Karel Reisz “an astonishingly beautiful film.”

headline: White Supremacist Who Influenced Charleston Suspect Donated to 2016 G.O.P. Campaigns
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: The campaigns of Ted Cruz, Rick Santorum and Rand Paul received donations from the leader of the white supremacist group tied to Dylann Roof, the suspect of the church shooting in Charleston, S.C.
lead_paragraph: The leader of a white supremacist group that apparently influenced Dylann Roof, the suspect in the killing of nine African-Americans in a Charleston, S.C., church last week, has donated tens of thousands of dollars to Republican campaigns, including those of 2016 presidential contenders such as Ted Cruz, Rick Santorum and Rand Paul, records show.

headline: Dustin Johnson’s Dream Turns Real on No. 18, Then Nightmare Sets In
abstract: After Johnson missed a 12-foot putt for eagle and a win on the last hole and pulled the 4-foot comebacker that would have forced an 18-hole playoff with Jordan Spieth, all he wanted to do was disappear.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Dustin Johnson walked arm in arm with his fiancée Sunday night toward the players’ locker room, and a swift exit from Chambers Bay Golf Course. Up the hill, the award celebration for the 115th United States Open was taking place without Johnson, who had tied for second with Louis Oosthuizen, one stroke behind the champion, Jordan Spieth.

headline: A 30-Year American Road Trip
abstract: David Graham has made his life work taking witty, empathetic images of America that are layered with meaning.
lead_paragraph: It’s summertime, so millions of Americans are gassing up the car, loading up the kids and hitting the highway for that most American of rituals: the road trip. Big skies, roadside attractions and unending byways feature deeply in the national mythology, and in the history of photography, too. For David Graham, exploring the nooks and crannies of this large country has been his life’s work.

headline: Slavery’s Long Shadow
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'States (US)', 'Welfare (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Despite changing attitudes on several fronts, race in America is an issue that won’t go away.
lead_paragraph: America is a much less racist nation than it used to be, and I’m not just talking about the still remarkable fact that an African-American occupies the White House. The raw institutional racism that prevailed before the civil rights movement ended Jim Crow is gone, although subtler discrimination persists. Individual attitudes have changed, too, dramatically in some cases. For example, as recently as the 1980s half of Americans opposed interracial marriage, a position now held by only a tiny minority.

headline: White Supremacists Without Borders
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Hate Crimes', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Dylann Roof is not simply an aberrant individual. Behind him lies a vicious movement.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — A VARIETY of clues to the motives of Dylann Storm Roof, the suspect in last week’s mass shooting at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., have emerged. First, we saw the patches he wore on his jacket in a Facebook photo: the flags of regimes in South Africa and Rhodesia that brutally enforced white minority rule.

headline: Who Owns Your Overtime?
keywords: ['Working Hours', 'Overtime', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A new change in federal overtime rules may not apply to you, but the way we value work matters to everyone.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE-NOTICED but important change in the American workplace is about to occur. Sometime in the next month, the Department of Labor is expected to announce an adjustment to the Fair Labor Standards Act. The change will raise the salary threshold for overtime. Currently, if you are a salaried employee and make less than $23,660 per year, you are eligible for time and a half pay for any hours over 40 per week. The update, which is likely to at least double that threshold, will affect millions of salaried employees.

headline: Morning Agenda: E.C.B.’s Awkward Spot in Greek Crisis
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: E.C.B.’s Awkward Spot in Greek Crisis | Cigna Rejects Anthem’s $47 Billion Bid | Altice Offers to Buy Bouygues Telecom for $11.3 Billion | Williams Companies Rebuffs $48 Billion Offer
lead_paragraph: E.C.B.’S AWKWARD SPOT IN GREEK CRISIS  | As billions of euros are being withdrawn from Greek banks, the European Central Bank has stepped in with emergency funding to keep the country’s banking system from collapsing. Yet as it acts as the savior of Greece’s financial system, the E.C.B. is also playing the role of the country’s scold, refusing to budge on debt relief,  Landon Thomas Jr. and Peter Eavis write in DealBook. “This tension in many ways mirrors Europe’s broader dilemma of how to handle Greece,” they write. “Should lending lines to the country be renewed, in the interest of keeping the eurozone intact? Or should Greece, having demanded too much from Europe, not be bailed out again?”

headline: 1965: Algerians Protest in Moscow
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Algerian students stage protest in Moscow in support of President Ahmed Ben Bella in 1965.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A group of Algerian students in Moscow called today [June 23] for the overthrow of the military regime headed by Col. Houari Boumedienne and the restoration of President Ahmed Ben Bella. A spokesman for the students met reporters outside the locked gate of the Algerian embassy in downtown Moscow. The spokesman declined to allow photos to be taken of the group of about 30 students who argued strongly against the statement condemning Col. Boumedienne’s takeover. It said, ‘‘We call on all Algerian people to rise against the military dictatorship which is being forced on them.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 23, 1965

headline: Putting Stents to the Test
abstract: Cardiologists often treat angina by opening arteries with stents, but drug therapy may be more effective.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have had stents — small wire cages — inserted in their coronary arteries to prop them open. And many are convinced the devices are protecting them from heart attacks. After all, a partly blocked artery is now cleared, and the pain in a heart muscle starved of blood often vanishes once the artery is open again.

headline: Surgery for Knee Pain May Not Provide Benefits
abstract: People in their 50s and older often get arthroscopic surgery for knee pain, but a new review of studies suggests that it has serious risks.
lead_paragraph: People in their 50s and older often get arthroscopic surgery for knee pain, but a new review of studies suggests that it has serious risks and no lasting benefits.

headline: Martha Stewart’s Media Empire Sold for Fraction of Its Former Value
abstract: Martha Stewart Living has been battered by the troubles that have afflicted many media companies, as readers and viewers shift to other titles.
lead_paragraph: At its peak, Martha Stewart’s media empire, built around her carefully curated and fussily decorated lifestyle brand, was worth well over $1 billion.

headline: Virginia Judge Approves Deal to Keep Sweet Briar College Open
abstract: A settlement brokered by Virginia’s attorney general will allow the school to remain open for at least another academic year with new leadership and $12 million from an alumnae group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A circuit court judge in Virginia on Monday approved a settlement that will allow Sweet Briar College to remain open for at least another academic year, as an alumnae group called on students and faculty to return to the financially troubled women’s college in rural Virginia.

headline: The New Serpentine Gallery Pavilion Surprises With a Cafe at Its Center
abstract: A little-known husband-and-wife team, whose studio sits in a woodland outside Madrid, created a playful and unpretentious design for the project’s 15th year.
lead_paragraph: In the same month that Carsten Höller has transformed London’s South Bank into the cultural equivalent of a theme park (giant slides are the centerpiece of his Hayward Gallery show, “Decision“) comes one of the most playful and unpretentious Serpentine Gallery Pavilions in its 15-year history. A series of supersynthetic tunnels comprised of fluorine-based plastic, this latest commission looks like a psychedelic space camp parked on the immaculate lawns of Kensington Gardens. It’s the colorful creation of the Spanish architects Selgas Cano, a little-known husband-and-wife team whose studio sits in a woodland outside Madrid. (Previous architects have included Oscar Niemeyer and Zaha Hadid.) The hope is that visitors to the pavilion, which opens to the public this week, will be propelled on a voyage of discovery (or at the very least, to the cafe that sits at its heart).

headline: Focus on the Opportunities, Not the Shoals
abstract: As in kayaking, focusing on financial rocks makes it difficult to see the opportunities we have some actual control over.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, I learned how to kayak. I practiced in the pool a few times before deciding to test my skills on the river. For one of my first trips, my wife and I traveled to the Snake River just below Jackson Hole, Wyo. We planned to paddle a stretch of the river known as Alpine Canyon. A friend who happened to be a very experienced paddler joined us.

headline: When Retirement Savings Are Unsafe
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Mutual Funds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Retirement', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Financial industry leaders are pushing back against the Labor Dept.’s proposal to require financial advisers to act solely in their clients’ best interests.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Labor is about midway through a public comment period on its “fiduciary rule” proposal to require financial advisers to act solely in their clients’ best interests when giving advice and selling investments for retirement accounts.

headline: Indonesia Court Rejects Convict’s Appeal
abstract: An Indonesian court on Monday denied clemency to a French man on death row for drug offenses, though his lawyer pledged to look for other legal options to overturn the decision.
lead_paragraph: An Indonesian court on Monday denied clemency to a French man on death row for drug offenses, though his lawyer pledged to look for other legal options to overturn the decision.

headline: 1940: Churchill Urges French to Fight
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Churchill appeals to Frenchmen to carry on the fight, in spite of the armistice, in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a desperate attempt to keep the French resistance wherever the will to resist still remains outside the areas held by the Germans, Prime Minister Winston Churchill early today appealed to all Frenchmen to carry on the fight. The British Prime Minister spoke over the head of the French Government and in effect urged Frenchmen to ignore its action in signing the armistice. This is the meaning of the calamity which the French government’s decision to accept the Germans’ terms is considered here to be. In his appeal, Churchill made it clear that British resistance would continue. — New York Herald Tribune, June 23, 1940

keywords: ['Olympic Games (2022)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Olympic Games']

lead_paragraph: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — The last time this happened — that is, the last time a former Soviet republic from Central Asia bid to host an Olympics — the entire thing was a joke. A lark. A laugh.

lead_paragraph: A leading privacy rights group wants the Federal Trade Commission to prohibit Uber from instituting changes to its privacy policy that the group says will allow the ride-hailing app to collect more detailed data about customers’ whereabouts and use their contact lists to send their friends promotional pitches.

headline: TV Analyst and Former Met Darryl Hamilton Is Fatally Shot
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Baseball']
abstract: Police in suburban Houston said they found the bodies of Hamilton, a former outfielder for the Mets, and Monica Jordan at a home.
lead_paragraph: Darryl Hamilton, an outfielder for the Mets on their last pennant-winning team, was shot to death on Sunday at a home in suburban Houston.

headline: Picture This? Some Just Can’t
abstract: Aphantasia, the inability to summon up mental images, is a little-known condition on the verge of wider study.
lead_paragraph: Certain people, researchers have discovered, can’t summon up mental images — it’s as if their mind’s eye is blind. This month in the journal Cortex, the condition received a name: aphantasia, based on the Greek word phantasia, which Aristotle used to describe the power that presents visual imagery to our minds.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: John Neumeier, Choreographer, Wins $400,000 Kyoto Prize
abstract: Mr. Neumeier, 73, has been the artistic director of the Hamburg Ballet since 1973.
lead_paragraph: The American-born choreographer John Neumeier, who has been the artistic director of the Hamburg Ballet since 1973, is one of the recipients of the 2015 Kyoto Prize, established in 1985 by the Inamori Foundation in Japan to honor “those who have contributed significantly to the scientific, cultural and spiritual betterment of mankind.”

headline: At Art Basel, a More Refined Kind of Pop-Up Club
keywords: ['Art', 'ART BASEL (FESTIVAL)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Recent years have seen the buttoned-up fair in a sleepy Swiss hamlet injected with some of the famous revelry of its sister spectacle in Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: It was quite late on Tuesday night in Switzerland — just hours before the next morning’s First Choice VIP opening of Art Basel — but the bar at the Grand Hotel Trois Rois was packed. Leonardo DiCaprio sauntered through, sucking on an e-cigarette. Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire who has dropped $240 million on Giacomettis in the past year, chatted casually with a few dealers. The artist Rirkrit Tiravanija never removed his red sunglasses amid the smoke-filled room; the fashion world darling Peter Brant II sat with a chair-hopping contingent of the cosmopolitan and well-groomed; and Larry Gagosian — the king of the world’s most powerful gallery empire — sat casually in a plush velvet booth, greeting well-wishers.

headline: Nikki Haley, South Carolina Governor, Calls for Removal of Confederate Battle Flag
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Gov. Nikki Haley’s call to remove the flag from Capitol grounds came in the wake of the killing of nine people in a Charleston church.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Gov. Nikki R. Haley called on Monday for South Carolina to do what just a week ago seemed politically impossible — remove the Confederate battle flag from its perch in front of the State House building here. She argued that a symbol long revered by many Southerners was for some, after the church massacre in Charleston, a “deeply offensive symbol of a brutally offensive past.”

lead_paragraph: Images from Almaty, Kazakhstan, which, along with Beijing, is try to be the host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics.

headline: Egyptian Women Defy Protest Ban to Call for Release of Political Prisoners
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Dozens of Egyptian women defied a nationwide ban on unsanctioned street protests on Sunday, rallying outside the presidential palace in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of Egyptian women on Sunday defied a nationwide ban on unsanctioned street protests, rallying for an hour outside the presidential palace in Cairo to demand the release of political prisoners.

headline: Fox Makes Its Debut at the Open, and at Times It Seems Like an Amateur
abstract: Greg Norman, in his first United States Open as the lead analyst, was only a symptom of Fox’s poor debut as the event’s broadcaster, a role that will last 11 more years.
lead_paragraph: For Greg Norman, it was a moment to define himself in his first United States Open as the lead analyst. Dustin Johnson was on the 18th green on Sunday with a chance to win if he sank an eagle putt. What was Norman’s assessment of the putt? Would it go left or right? What sort of speed should he put on it? Norman said nothing. Johnson missed.

headline: E.P.A. Warns of High Cost of Climate Change
abstract: The report, issued by the E.P.A. and the White House, calculated the cost of economic losses caused by drought and water shortages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the absence of global action to curb greenhouse gas emissions, the United States by the end of the century may face up to $180 billion in economic losses because of drought and water shortages, according to a report released Monday by the White House and Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Leopold Brothers Offers a Homegrown Version of Campari
abstract: The small-batch distiller is producing a spirit called Aperitivo; Patagonia is offering a salmon designed for camping; a gentler sriracha; and more.
lead_paragraph: Leopold Brothers, a small-batch distiller in Denver, has done an admirable job of making homegrown versions of classic European spirits like triple sec and maraschino. Now it has taken on Campari. This version, called Aperitivo, opens sweetly (less sweet than the Italian original), then comes across delightfully dry, bitter and citric. Its vibrant color is not artificial, but is from cochineal (insects): Leopold Brothers Aperitivo, $34.99 for 750 milliliters from klwines.com.

headline: Supreme Court Sides With Raisin Farmers in Property Rights Case
abstract: The court said a program dating to the Great Depression was an unconstitutional taking of private property by the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court  ruled on Monday that a government program dating to the Great Depression meant to increase raisin prices by keeping some of them off the market amounted to an unconstitutional taking of private property by the government.

headline: Jimmy Lee of JPMorgan Chase Remembered for Shaping an Industry
abstract: Mr. Lee, who died on Wednesday, was responsible for securing some of the bank’s most prominent deals.
lead_paragraph: James B. Lee Jr., a towering figure on Wall Street, was remembered at his funeral Mass on Monday as a father, a friend and an investment banker possessed of boundless energy, sprawling interests and a crackling wit, qualities that made him one of the most successful and beloved figures in his industry.

headline: Hundreds Die in Heat Wave in Southern Pakistan
abstract: Unusually high temperatures, reaching up to 111 degrees led to the deaths of at least 260 people over three days, many in the port city of Karachi.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan —  An intense heat wave has left at least 260 people dead over three days in southern Pakistan, mostly here in the port city of Karachi, officials said Monday, prompting the government to declare an emergency at hospitals and to ask the military to help respond to the crisis.

headline: Cancer Doctors Offer Way to Compare Medicines, Including by Cost
abstract: Alarmed by soaring prices for cancer drugs, the leading American oncology society has devised a “value framework” to evaluate treatments by effectiveness, side effects and cost.
lead_paragraph: Alarmed by the rapid escalation in the price of cancer drugs, the nation’s leading oncology society unveiled on Monday a new way for doctors and patients to evaluate different treatments — one that pointedly includes a medicine’s cost as well as its effectiveness and side effects.

headline: Lindsey Graham Calls for Removal of Confederate Flag From South Carolina’s Capitol
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham, the Republican presidential candidate from South Carolina, and Gov. Nikki Haley called on Monday for the Confederate battle flag to be removed from the state’s Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham, the Republican presidential candidate from South Carolina, called on Monday for the Confederate battle flag to be removed from the state’s Capitol.

headline: Justices Rule Police Must Obtain Warrant to Search Hotel or Motel Registries
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Police']
abstract: The Supreme Court made it harder for police to inspect lists of hotel and motel guests, and clarified rules on force against people awaiting trial.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday struck down a Los Angeles ordinance that allowed the police to inspect hotel and motel guest registries without permission from a judge. In a second decision, the court clarified the standards for excessive force claims against corrections officers from people awaiting trial.

abstract: The remote peninsula on the tip of Gotland has been transformed into a summertime playground, sporting a restaurant and a performance space.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you notice is the metal fence.

lead_paragraph: There are a lot of unusual paths from page to stage, but here’s one of the more meta: the imaginary show-within-a-show at the heart of a star-crossed television series is now being adapted for possible real world production.

abstract: A Human Rights Watch report pointed to cases in which those who protested bank-supported projects were harassed and intimidated by governments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A major human rights organization on Monday accused the World Bank of doing little or nothing when critics of its projects are harassed and intimidated by governments that benefit from its loans.

keywords: ['Art', 'Women and Girls', 'Bathing and Showering', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Privacy']
abstract: An exhibition in Paris brings together more than 100 works showing the bathing and grooming rituals of women, from the 16th century to the present.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A woman undressing to take a bath is at her most vulnerable — alone, half-nude, self-absorbed, unprepared for prying eyes.

headline: Grilled Chicken Breast in Three Simple Steps

lead_paragraph: Countless words are devoted every year to finessing the usual centerpieces of your summer barbecues: how to grill up the perfect burgers, juiciest steaks, flakiest fish, most tender pork butt.

headline: Humankind’s Existentially Lucky Numbers
abstract: Bump the dials just barely on figures like alpha’s value or the mass of the Higgs boson, and nothing like our universe could exist.
lead_paragraph: The Large Hadron Collider sprung back to life this month, smashing subatomic particles with nearly double the energy used to discover the Higgs boson, a landmark in understanding the makeup of the physical world. With the Higgs now in the bag, researchers are setting their sights on more exotic fare: signs of a new physics that not only describes the universe but explains why it is the way it is.

headline: 2013 And All That
abstract: Gotcha is the last refuge of failed economists.
lead_paragraph: Those who can, cite evidence to support their position; those who cannot play gotcha. Events have overwhelmingly supported a Keynesian view of the effects of fiscal policy, but the anti-Keynesians have responded, not by reconsidering their views, but by seeking to discredit the messengers. In particular, there’s a lot of “Krugman said X would happen, and it didn’t, so Keynesian economics is wrong.” And in particular particular, the experience of 2013 – when British growth accelerated, and US growth continued despite the budget sequester, is claimed as some sort of decisive experiment.

headline: In Milan, the Men’s Fashion Crowd Practices Magazine Diplomacy
keywords: ['Milan Fashion Week', 'Parties (Social)', 'Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: GQ celebrated Jim Moore’s 35th anniversary at the magazine, and Details commemorated the 15-year mark for its editor, Dan Peres. Both were can’t-miss.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — In fashion, as Heidi Klum has made a television career of opining, one day you’re in, and the next day you’re out.

headline: E.U. Begins Naval Operation in Mediterranean to Stop Trafficking of Migrants
abstract: The initial phase will involve surveillance, intelligence gathering and patrolling, and calls for the capture and destruction of ships used by traffickers.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The European Union on Monday began the first phase of a naval operation in the Mediterranean that aims to stop the trafficking of tens of thousands of migrants seeking better lives in Europe. The initial phase will involve surveillance, intelligence gathering and patrolling to identify and monitor human smuggling and trafficking networks in the south central Mediterranean. The operation, Eunavfor Med, based in Rome, also calls for the capture and destruction of the ships used by traffickers. Those phases, however, will require a United Nations Security Council resolution and the consent of the Libyan authorities.

headline: Cami Anderson, Picked by Christie, Is Out as Newark Schools Superintendent
abstract: Ms. Anderson, who oversaw the New Jersey city’s troubled public school system, had feuded openly with the mayor, teachers and many parents.
lead_paragraph: Cami Anderson, the superintendent of the Newark public school system who became a lightning rod in the debate over education reform in New Jersey and nationally, resigned on Monday, eight months before her contract was to expire.

headline: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland to Stay in Office While ‘Advanced’ Cancer Is Treated
abstract: The 59-year-old Republican, who came into office this year, said he would remain in office while undergoing “very aggressive chemotherapy treatment.”
lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland, a little-known former real estate executive whose upset victory in November thrust this overwhelmingly Democratic state into Republican hands for the first time in nearly a decade, announced Monday that he had a “very advanced” cancer of the lymphatic system but would continue to serve while undergoing treatment.

abstract: “Don’t Weigh Down the Light” is a post-folk record, with notes of the Renaissance madrigal tradition as well as an airier version of Sandy Denny.
lead_paragraph: MEG BAIRD

headline: In Spider-Man Toy Patent Case, Supreme Court Stands by Past Decision
abstract: The court, ruling against the toy’s inventor, left in place a widely criticized 1964 decision that said royalty payments after a patent expires were unlawful.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Writing for the majority in a patent case about a Spider-Man toy, Justice Elena Kagan concluded her decision with a quotation from a 1962 Spider-Man comic book: “In this world, with great power there must also come — great responsibility.”

headline: ‘Skylight’ Closes Out Run With Healthy Box Office
abstract: The revival of David Hare’s play set a theater record during its final week on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway revival of “Skylight” closed out its Tony-winning run with one more bragging right: the most revenue ever grossed in a single week at the John Golden Theater.

headline: Review: Graham Swift’s ‘England and Other Stories,’ a Darkness Across Time and Fates
abstract: As in his earlier works, an undertow of melancholy tugs at Mr. Swift’s characters in this new collection, with short, dense narratives that unfold into complex meditations.
lead_paragraph: An undertow of melancholy tugs at Graham Swift’s characters, threatening to pull them under — or at least backward. Time is a Möbius strip in his stories — time present contiguous with a Faulknerian time past and shadowed by secrets the reader only slowly pieces together. This is true of Mr. Swift’s early work, like “Waterland,” and his Booker Prize-winning novel, “Last Orders,” and it’s truer still of his new collection, “England and Other Stories.”

headline: Stream the New EP From Class Actress (With an Assist From the Disco Legend Giorgio Moroder)
abstract: The six-song album, which debuts here, tells the distinctly cinematic story of a Los Angeles party girl.
lead_paragraph: When the singer Elizabeth Harper, who records as Class Actress, signed to Casablanca Records — the storied disco label that relaunched as an electronic dance label as part of Republic in 2000 — she knew right away that she wanted to make her new EP (her third album as Class Actress) with a legend. “I started doing research on the history of Casablanca, and found that it was such an epitome of drugs and Hollywood glamour — it had a whole Studio 54 vibe. And Giorgio Moroder had written every hit on the label.”

lead_paragraph: Even as he fills his present as a baseball analyst at Fox Sports 1 and prepares to be part of the official activities at the All-Star Game in Cincinnati on July 14, Pete Rose cannot escape his past.

headline: ‘Oklahoma!’ Reimagined: Less Cornpone, but Fresh Cornbread
abstract: The director Daniel Fish’s take on this classic includes an immersive element, but it also tries to stay true to the feel of the 1940s Rodgers and Hammerstein original.
lead_paragraph: While the team behind the current Broadway revival of “The King and I” was pondering potential Tony Award acceptance speeches the day before the ceremony, the team responsible for a rather different Rodgers and Hammerstein production was in a rehearsal room in Brooklyn working on an opening scene.

headline: Gov. Haley on Removing Confederate Flag
abstract: Gov. Nikki R. Haley, Republican of South Carolina, on Monday called for removal of a Confederate battle flag from the State Capitol grounds.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Nikki R. Haley, Republican of South Carolina, on Monday called for removal of a Confederate battle flag from the State Capitol grounds.

headline: Grading the Common Core: No Teaching Experience Required
abstract: Testing groups point to strict training and criteria for Common Core grading, but the use of temps for increasingly complex tests is being questioned.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The new academic standards known as the Common Core emphasize critical thinking, complex problem-solving and writing skills, and put less stock in rote learning and memorization. So the standardized tests given in most states this year required fewer multiple choice questions and far more writing on topics like this one posed to elementary school students: Read a passage from a novel written in the first person, and a poem written in the third person, and describe how the poem might change if it were written in the first person.

headline: Review: ‘Hand Foot Fizzle Face’ Explores Futility and Disconnection
abstract: This production by the company Piehole translates Samuel Beckett’s “Foirades/Fizzles” into an experimental performance.
lead_paragraph: If you have $30,000 to spare, then you, too, can own a first edition of “Foirades/Fizzles,” an unlikely 1976 artist’s book by Jasper Johns and Samuel Beckett. Etchings and aquatints — some playful, some troubling — accompany five gnomic prose works, or “Fizzles,” that Beckett translated from the French.

headline: Iraqi Families Return to Fragile Stability in Tikrit After Liberation From ISIS
abstract: The Islamic State was driven from Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein and the largest city the terrorist group has lost in either Iraq or Syria.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When Umm Ahmed returned to her Iraqi hometown, Tikrit, in recent days she found a city devastated by fighting with militants from the Islamic State: buildings burned, shops looted, schools shuttered and hospitals inoperable.

headline: New York City Settles Suit Over Abuses at Rikers Island
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio committed to far-reaching reforms that include the appointment of a federal monitor and a new policy on the use of force by guards, a court filing said.
lead_paragraph: New York City has agreed to a settlement in the long-running legal battle over abuses at Rikers Island, the country’s second-largest jail system, federal and city officials said on Monday.

headline: The Times’s Policy on Racial Slurs: Editor’s Notebook
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Language and Languages', 'News and News Media']
abstract: In the wake of President Obama’s remarks to Marc Maron on racism, Philip B. Corbett, associate editor for standards, explains the Times’s policy on printing racial slurs.
lead_paragraph: When editors at The Times’s morning news meeting on Monday talked about President Obama’s podcast remarks to Marc Maron on racism, there was a brief discussion of how we would handle one part of the story:  the president’s use of a common racial slur in saying that racism wasn’t eradicated simply because such slurs were no longer used in polite conversation.

headline: Senior Republicans Follow Nikki Haley’s Lead on Confederate Battle Flag
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Senior Republicans called for folding up the Confederate battle flag after Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina said the Civil War symbol should be removed from the state Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Tongue-tied over the issue for nearly a week, senior Republicans jumped on the bandwagon Monday and called for folding up the Confederate battle flag after Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina said the Civil War symbol should be removed from the state Capitol.

headline: Review: Bang on a Can Marathon Stays as Eclectic and Playful as Ever
abstract: The yearly marathon is always attended by a charming mix of die-hards who stay for the whole thing (the better part of 11 hours on Sunday) and tourists who catch a few seconds on their way to 1 World Trade Center across the street.
lead_paragraph: A musician dropping an instrument during a performance would usually be cause for alarm. And at first, so it was, as the ensemble So Percussion played on Sunday during the Bang on a Can Marathon in the Winter Garden at Brookfield Place in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Review: In ‘At the Table,’ a Menu of Identity-Based Arguments
abstract: Michael Perlman’s play, presented by Fault Line Theater, convenes a group of dinner party guests who tussle over abortion, race and class.
lead_paragraph: Chris (Claire Karpen) has only just met this group of friends, so she probably shouldn’t make a scene. But dinner is over, the alcohol is flowing and Stuart (Craig Wesley Divino) — the smug one up there at the head of the table — is being obnoxious. When he tries to bait her into debating abortion rights, she tells him the issue is none of his business, because he is a man.

headline: The Scene
abstract: Brioni at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Brioni at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Makes and Models of Cars Affected by Takata Airbag Recalls
abstract: About 32 million cars are subject to recall for potentially defective airbags, and the problem has been blamed for at least eight deaths and more than 100 injuries. This list is of known recalls as of June 19.
lead_paragraph: About 32 million cars are subject to recall for potentially defective airbags, and the problem has been blamed for at least eight deaths and more than 100 injuries. This list is of known recalls as of June 19.
