lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will fly to Charleston, S.C., on Friday to attend the funeral of the pastor killed in the massacre at an African-American church last week, the White House said on Monday.

headline: Review: Aston Magna and Boston Early Music Festivals Offer Diverse Monteverdi Experiences
abstract: In Great Barrington, Mass., the Boston Early Music Festival revived “Orfeo,” in a stripped-down form, and the Aston Magna Music Festival performed the first program of its season.
lead_paragraph: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. — The mighty wind of Monteverdi that blew through Boston a couple of weeks ago found its way here, to western Massachusetts, over the weekend. Perhaps because it was countering eastward meteorological tendencies across the state, it arrived much depleted.

headline: Review: Bully Shows Righteous Fury and Quick Jabs on ‘Feels Like’
abstract: Alicia Bognanno’s voice brings a special weapon to the album’s early ’90s sound.
lead_paragraph: BULLY

headline: Blood Pressure, the Mystery Number
abstract: More than 58 million Americans take medicines to lower blood pressure, reducing their risk of heart attack and stroke. But experts aren’t certain how low blood pressure should go.
lead_paragraph: Almost half a century after rigorous studies showed medicines that lower blood pressure prevent heart attacks, strokes and deaths, researchers still do not know just how low blood pressure should go. More than 58 million Americans take these drugs, but this fundamental question remains unresolved.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: Make Music New York Teaches Buildings How to Sing
abstract: This festival on Sunday included klezmer, Bach and the premiere of “Concerto for Buildings,” which featured percussionists striking cast iron in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers generally don’t need much encouragement to make noise. But twice a year, at the summer and winter solstices, Make Music New York invites them to come together to play, sing and listen to an array of sounds as diverse as the city itself.

headline: A Possibly Lifesaving Guide to Heart Attacks
abstract: Some signs that you may be having a heart attack, and what you should do.
lead_paragraph: Tremendous progress has been made in treating heart disease, but it is still the biggest killer of Americans, accounting for one in seven deaths. Here are answers to some common questions about the symptoms and treatment of heart attacks and narrowed aortic valves.

headline: Berlin Philharmonic Selects Kirill Petrenko to Succeed Simon Rattle
abstract: The orchestra has given its approval to a leader with high standards who keeps a low profile for someone in his position.
lead_paragraph: When the Berlin Philharmonic announced on Monday that its next chief conductor would be Kirill Petrenko, the Russian-born music director of the Bavarian State Opera in Munich, the organization was awarding one of the most prestigious posts in classical music to a widely respected artist who has largely shunned the spotlight courted by some of his peers.

headline: Dunton Hot Springs
abstract: This remote getaway offers lavish meals and a nearby 1,600 acres to enjoy.
lead_paragraph: This remote getaway offers lavish meals and a nearby 1,600 acres to enjoy.

headline: Review: ‘Trisha Brown: In Plain Site’ Sends Dancers Gamboling in the Grass
abstract: At the River to River festival on Sunday, the company mixed music and stillness, old works and recent.
lead_paragraph: If you were taking a waterfront stroll along the bottom tip of Manhattan late Sunday afternoon, you may have happened upon seven people dressed in white, their limbs twisting gently in the breeze like the branches of the surrounding trees. This was not a color-coordinated group of tai chi practitioners. This was the Trisha Brown Dance Company, performing an excerpt from Ms. Brown’s final work, “I’m Going to Toss My Arms — if You Catch Them, They’re Yours” (2011).

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: Merce Cunningham’s ‘Crises’ Opens Dance at the New Whitney
abstract: The newly opened museum welcomed its first dance performance with this 1960 work, which looked right at home.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, the choreographer Merce Cunningham became an early exponent of what would become the Theater of the Absurd, alongside the playwrights Beckett, Ionesco and Pinter. With “Crises” (1960), he made a nonnarrative dance drama in which human behavior becomes inscrutable, absurd and dark. Its dances show one man and four women; what’s still startling is how wild, independent and driven the women are.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Poised to Hire Nearly 1,300 Police Officers
abstract: The hirings, a sharp shift for a mayor who has long been hesitant to expand the force, are a surprising addition in a $78.5 billion budget deal announced by city leaders.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in a sharp shift from his initial objections, is poised to hire nearly 1,300 additional officers for the New York Police Department, a surprising addition in a $78.5 billion budget deal announced by city leaders on Monday night.

headline: Data Mining Start-Up Enigma to Expand Commercial Business
abstract: After preparing open data for civic-minded projects, the company hopes to interest corporate clients in the insights that can come from public data sets.
lead_paragraph: The deaths of five people, including three children, in a raging fire that engulfed a home in New Orleans last November was “a terrible tragedy,” the city’s first deputy mayor, Andy Kopplin, said.

headline: Walter Scheib, Innovative Former White House Chef, Is Dead at 61
abstract: Mr. Scheib, who ran the mansion’s kitchen during the administrations of Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, had been missing for about a week after going on a hike.
lead_paragraph: Walter Scheib, who brought American cuisine prepared in a lighter style to the White House as its executive chef during the administrations of Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, was found dead on Sunday near a hiking trail outside Taos, N.M. He was 61.

headline: Computer Failure Leaves State Dept. Unable to Issue Visas
abstract: The country receives an average of 50,000 applications daily, and officials say that medical or humanitarian visas deemed priorities will be issued.
lead_paragraph: The United States has been unable to issue visas to travelers around the world for two weeks because of a computer hardware failure that remains unresolved, State Department officials said Monday.

headline: A Complicated Rescue
abstract: A man fell deep inside a cave in Spain, suffering such serious injuries that neither he nor his friends could get him out.
lead_paragraph: A man fell deep inside a cave in Spain, suffering such serious injuries that neither he nor his friends could get him out.

headline: Third-Party Groups Sue F.E.C. to Try to Open Up Presidential Debates
abstract: Advocates for third-party groups are accusing the Federal Election Commission in a lawsuit of failing to fairly regulate the presidential debate process.
lead_paragraph: As the 2016 presidential campaign gets into gear, one of the biggest debates so far has been about the debates. For some Democrats, such as Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, there aren’t enough planned. For lesser-known Republicans, the polling criteria could make it difficult for them to even get on the stage.

headline: F.B.I. Struggles to Pinpoint the Fingers Behind a Hacking
abstract: A slip-up led investigators to trace a breach of the Astros’ database to a home used by Cardinals employees, but identifying the intruder or intruders is more of a challenge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As F.B.I. agents try to build a case against personnel in the St. Louis Cardinals’ front office who are accused of breaking  into the network that housed the Houston Astros’ closely guarded baseball intelligence, they are struggling with one particular aspect of the investigation: determining who, specifically, had his hands on the keyboard.

headline: Hacking Grounds Flights of Poland’s National Airline
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'AIRPORTS', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL']
abstract: If confirmed, the attack would be one of the first instances in which flights were canceled or delayed because of a malicious hacking.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of flights of Poland’s national airline, LOT Airlines, were grounded for several hours on Sunday, stranding thousands of passengers at Chopin Airport in Warsaw, after what the airline described as a computer attack by unidentified outsiders.

headline: Takata Is Said to Have Stopped Safety Audits as Cost-Saving Move
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Internal company emails said that the audits were halted in 2009, a committee report said, a year after Honda had begun a recall to replace defective airbags.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of what would become the largest automotive recall in American history, the Japanese airbag manufacturer Takata halted global safety audits to save money, according to internal company emails cited in a report published on Monday by a Senate committee.

abstract: The move would allow New York’s Asian families to celebrate an important day with their children without harming attendance records.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration is expected on Tuesday to add the Lunar New Year to the New York public school calendar, allowing the city’s Asian families to celebrate an important holiday with their children without tarnishing attendance records.

headline: Stillbirth: Share Your Story
abstract: Stillbirth is not uncommon in the United States, but it remains shrouded in silence. We invite you to share your experience.
lead_paragraph: Stillbirth is not uncommon in the United States, but it remains shrouded in silence. We invite you to share your experience.

abstract: One in 160 pregnancies in the United States ends in stillbirth. Eleni Michailidis lost her baby, Alexander, at 38 weeks. This is her story.

abstract: After Dr. Eleni Michailidis delivered a stillborn son, she and her husband sought to honor their infant and the experience.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Eleni Michailidis, 38, gave birth to a stillborn son, Alexander, in February. Stillbirth is not uncommon in the United States, affecting 1 in 160 pregnancies, but the experience is rarely discussed. Dr. Michailidis’s narrative has been condensed and edited for space and clarity.

abstract: Sim Chi Yin says her story about miner afflicted with a serious lung disease has turned into a universal love story.
lead_paragraph: Sim Chi Yin says her story about miner afflicted with a serious lung disease has turned into a universal love story.

lead_paragraph: In one of the most striking speeches of his 2008 presidential campaign, Barack Obama spoke about his candidacy as evidence that the country could transcend its racially divisive roots.

abstract: The low-cost gym chain aims to become a publicly traded company in about two months.
lead_paragraph: Planet Fitness began a sprint toward the stock markets on Monday, filing for an initial public offering roughly two years after allying itself with a private equity firm.

headline: AirAsia Faces Red Tape and Tough Competition in India
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: AirAsia has exported its low-cost model to India, hoping to catch its hundreds of millions in first-time fliers. The move has proven harder than expected.
lead_paragraph: DELHI — When the fast-growing Malaysian carrier AirAsia wanted to expand, India looked like the ideal frontier.

headline: Risk of Extreme Weather From Climate Change to Rise Over Next Century, Report Says
abstract: More people will be exposed to floods, droughts, heat waves and other effects of climate change in the coming decades, according to a British medical journal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More people will be exposed to floods, droughts, heat waves and other extreme weather associated with climate change over the next century than previously thought, according to a new report in the British medical journal The Lancet.

headline: 3 Convicted of Misdemeanors in World Trade Center Jump
keywords: ['Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: A jury in State Supreme Court found James Brady, Marko Markovich and Andrew Rossig guilty of reckless endangerment but acquitted them of burglary, a felony.
lead_paragraph: Three sky divers who parachuted off the 1 World Trade Center tower were acquitted on Monday of the most serious felony charge against them but convicted of three misdemeanors after a two-week trial in Manhattan.

headline: WPP Bets on Music in Marketing Venture with Alex Da Kid
abstract: The new endeavor will create campaigns that connect musical artists to brands, blurring the line between marketing and entertainment.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — The advertising giant WPP has formed a joint venture with the music producer and songwriter Alex Da Kid, a move that represents a deeper push by the company into branded content.

headline: Georgia: $2.2. Million Penalty for Illegal DNA Testing
abstract: A jury in Atlanta awarded $2,225,000 on Monday to two warehouse workers whose employer required them to submit DNA samples in violation of the federal Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Atlanta awarded $2,225,000 on Monday to two warehouse workers whose employer required them to submit DNA samples in violation of the federal Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. The employer, Atlas Logistics Group Retail Services, was trying to identify someone who had been defecating in a warehouse. The two men were told to provide cheek swabs for DNA analysis. Neither was a match, and both sued. The case is the first brought under the act, which prohibits employers from obtaining genetic information about their employees.

headline: Unicef Report Describes Grim Trends for the Poorest Children
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Millennium Development Goals', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Population']
abstract: The United Nations Children’s Fund said improvements in national averages had obscured worsening trends among the world’s poorest children.
lead_paragraph: Unicef warned Monday of what it described as grim trend lines for the world’s poorest children over the next 15 years, saying in a new report that many millions face preventable deaths, diseases, stunted growth and illiteracy.

headline: Reversing Course, Pakistan Says Save the Children Can Stay
abstract: Pressure from Western allies will allow the aid agency to continue its operations, though on a smaller scale and with tighter restrictions.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Under pressure from Western allies, the government of Pakistan on Monday reversed its decision to expel Save the Children from the country, indicating that the aid agency could continue its operations albeit on a smaller scale and with tighter restrictions.

headline: Take Down the Confederate Flag, Symbol of Hatred
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The flag does not truly honor Civil War dead and South Carolina’s Legislature should remove the flag from the Capitol grounds.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina acted in the interest of her state and the nation on Monday when she called on the Legislature to remove the Confederate battle flag from the State Capitol grounds, after a white man charged with killing nine African-Americans was seen waving the flag in photographs.

headline: Lester Holt Reflects on Rise to NBC’s Anchor Chair
abstract: Mr. Holt, who had been sitting in as “Nightly News” anchor since Brian Williams was suspended, has officially gotten the job he had all but given up on.
lead_paragraph: When Lester Holt was a young broadcast journalist, he dreamed of one day sitting in the chair of the renowned news anchor Walter Cronkite.

headline: All-Star Votes Grow in Number, if Not in Value
abstract: The total number cast, 420 million, far exceeded the record of 391 million set in 2012, but the craziness continued as Royals players held down seven of the nine spots on the American League team.
lead_paragraph: Omar Infante has played 14 years in the major leagues, a career that should not make him a punch line. But Infante, simply by playing for the Kansas City Royals, has come to symbolize a ridiculous wrinkle in the fan voting for All-Star Game.

headline: Government in Ethiopia Is on Track to Win With 100% of Vote
abstract: Ethiopia’s governing party and its allies are poised to control every seat in the nation’s Parliament, according to official results announced Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ethiopia’s governing party and its allies are poised to control every seat in the nation’s Parliament, according to official results announced Monday by the country’s electoral board.

headline: With a Tap of Taylor Swift’s Fingers, Apple Retreated
abstract: Ms. Swift’s victory in a one-day battle against Apple this week showed she has a rare power to influence the music business.
lead_paragraph: In an age of depressed record sales, her albums sell by the millions. Her tours fill arenas around the world. And a complimentary tweet to her nearly 60 million followers can help kick-start another singer’s career.

headline: Karl-Anthony Towns Pursues Perfection From Atop the N.B.A. Draft Class
abstract: Towns, a former star at Kentucky who is continuing to take online classes there, is expected to be drafted No. 1 by the Minnesota Timberwolves on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: METUCHEN, N.J. — Two days before his only visit with the Minnesota Timberwolves, who are expected to select him No. 1 in Thursday’s N.B.A. draft, Karl-Anthony Towns dripped sweat in a shallow corner of the 3-point arc at St. Joseph’s High School.

headline: Optimism for an Agreement on Greek Debt, but Not for Long-Term Stability
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Fears remain that any easing of the Greek crisis when all 28 European Union leaders meet on Thursday and Friday will be short-term.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Greece and its European partners appeared on Monday night to be heading for a deal by the end of the week that would secure further funding for Greece and a likely promise of more debt relief in return for changes in the pension and tax systems, European Union officials said.

headline: The Loneliness of the Short-Seller
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Short Selling', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Six years into a bull market run, with stocks smashing one record after another, the naysayers known as short-sellers have all but lost their voice.
lead_paragraph: For some, they are the scourge of Wall Street. Yet short-sellers — investors who stake bets against stocks — are often the first to sound the alarm on a market’s froth or a company’s fraud.

headline: U.S. Says Drone Killed an ISIS Member Linked to Benghazi Attack
abstract: The Pentagon said that a “person of interest” in the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, died in coordinated airstrikes in Mosul, Iraq, on June 15.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American drone strike last week killed a midlevel operative with the Islamic State who had been a conduit for the militant group’s outreach to extremists in North Africa, Defense Department officials said on Monday.

headline: Sean Combs Arrested in Kettlebell Assault at U.C.L.A.
abstract: Sean Combs, known as Diddy, was charged with assault with a deadly weapon in connection with an incident involving a kettlebell at U.C.L.A.
lead_paragraph: Representatives for Sean Combs, the hip-hop mogul known as Diddy, who was arrested Monday and charged with assault with a deadly weapon at University of California, Los Angeles, said on Tuesday that his actions “were solely defensive in nature to protect himself and his son.”

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']

lead_paragraph: MALAKAL, South Sudan — In places where the fighting is fiercest, no one is even attempting to count the dead.

headline: Council of Conservative Citizens Promotes White Primacy, and G.O.P. Ties
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The massacre in Charleston, S.C., has propelled the organization back onto the national stage and embroiled the Republican Party in new questions about its ties to the group.
lead_paragraph: The Council of Conservative Citizens opposes “all efforts to mix the races,” and believes “that the American people and government should remain European in their composition and character.” It would severely restrict immigration, abolish affirmative action and dismantle the “imperial judiciary” that produced, among other rulings, the 1954 Supreme Court decision that integrated American education.

headline: Jordan Spieth Avoids Sting and Creates Buzz
abstract: Spieth, an American, tamed Chambers Bay Golf Course with his B-plus game, and he now heads to the British Open.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash. — Failing is not the worst feeling in the world. If Jordan Spieth’s Grand Slam hopes had disappeared in the cup along with Dustin Johnson’s eagle putt on the 18th hole of Chambers Bay Golf Course on Sunday night, he would have learned from the few poor shots he hit in the final round and moved on.

headline: New York Taxi Agency Passes Rules on Price Estimates for Ride-Hailing Apps
abstract: New Yorkers hailing rides through smartphone apps will get estimated fares for so-called surge pricing and itemized receipts.
lead_paragraph: Livery-cab passengers hailing rides through smartphone apps in New York City will get estimated fares for so-called surge pricing and itemized receipts, under rules passed Monday by the Taxi and Limousine Commission as it tries to keep pace with rapid changes in technology.

headline: Health Care Law Spurs Merger Talks for Insurers
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: All the deal-making in the health care industry is largely the result of the Affordable Care Act, which in effect caps hospitals’ and insurers’ profits.
lead_paragraph: President Obama signed the Affordable Care Act more than five years ago. At the time, members of the health care industry — hospitals, doctors and insurers — were anxious about what it would do to the business. Everyone had an opinion, but nobody knew for sure.

headline: One Dead as Druse Attack Israeli Ambulance in Golan Heights
abstract: It was the second time in 24 hours that Druse protesters stopped Israeli ambulances, amid mounting anger in their communities over the rebel assaults on Druse villages on the Syrian side.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Scores of Druse residents of the Golan Heights attacked an Israeli military ambulance late Monday as it transported two men wounded in the Syrian civil war, according to a military spokesman, killing one of the Syrians and critically injuring the other.

headline: Laura Antonelli Dies at 73; Popular, and Seductive, Italian Actress
abstract: Ms. Antonelli appeared in more than 40 films, often with matinee idols like Marcello Mastroianni.
lead_paragraph: Laura Antonelli, who by her own account was an “ugly, clumsy” teenager before transforming herself into one of Italy’s leading and most seductive film actresses, died on Monday at her seaside home in Ladispoli, west of Rome. She was 73.

headline: After Elk River Spill, Congress Will Vote on Bill Regulating Toxic Chemicals
keywords: ['Chemicals', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water Pollution', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Water']

lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — James Lewis still remembers the licorice smell of the water and how his skin itched when he showered.

headline: Daniel Villanueva, a Creator of Univision, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Villanueva was a former kicker for the Los Angeles Rams and Dallas Cowboys who built a Spanish-language broadcasting empire spanning the United States.
lead_paragraph: Daniel D. Villanueva, a former professional football player who as a founder of the Univision network built a Spanish-language broadcasting empire spanning the United States, died on Thursday in Ventura, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Holdouts From Rougher Era Endure at Lower East Side Club
abstract: At Los Amigos Fishing and Hunting Club, dominoes have replaced softball and outdoor expeditions, but some members bear the scars of knifings and shootings.
lead_paragraph: Despite its name, Los Amigos Fishing and Hunting Club, with headquarters in a disheveled storefront on a still-gritty corner of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, had not seen a gun in nearly a decade — the club’s upstate deer hunting trips and fishing expeditions forgone long ago as its members aged into their 60s, 70s and 80s. Tracking bucks had given way to pastimes no more vigorous than dominoes as the club slipped into its sixth decade on Rivington Street.

headline: Traveled Far and Wide
abstract: Jules P. Markey takes us on a trip.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — We have a word ladder by Jules P. Markey today, and this word ladder takes us back to the Bob HOPE and Bing CROSBY “ROAD to …” movie series.

headline: Monday at the Women’s World Cup
abstract: England earned its first knockout-stage win with a second-half comeback to defeat Norway, 2-1. The English will meet the Canadians in a quarterfinal on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S RESULTS

headline: Women’s World Cup: U.S., Helped by Red Card, Ejects Colombia
abstract: Goalkeeper Catalina Perez was given a red card in the 47th minute for taking down Alex Morgan, and the Americans prevailed with a stout defense and goals by Morgan and Carli Lloyd.
lead_paragraph: EDMONTON, Alberta — It began as a fascinating match of the establishment against the insurgent, an evolutionary tug of war in women’s soccer, with the United States trying to maintain its hold as a traditional power and Colombia trying to break through to a new era of parity.

headline: Panel Is Named to Investigate Handling of Allegations Against French Troops
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An independent panel will examine how the United Nations handled an inquiry into accusations that French peacekeepers sexually abused children in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: A former justice of Canada’s Supreme Court will lead an independent panel that will examine how the United Nations handled an inquiry into accusations that French peacekeepers not under United Nations command sexually abused children in the Central African Republic, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Monday. In a statement, he said the former justice, Marie Deschamps, would be joined on the panel by Hassan Jallow of Gambia, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda; and Yasmin Sooka, the executive director of the Foundation for Human Rights in South Africa. Mr. Ban created the panel because of questions over whether United Nations rights officials had acted appropriately when they learned of the accusations. The abuse is alleged to have taken place from December 2013 into mid-2014. Although the organization was quick to investigate the allegations, the French authorities did not learn about them until last July, when a United Nations human rights officer leaked the report to them.

headline: A Most Provençal Meal
abstract: Sommelier Laura Vidal and chef Harry Cummins's Paris Popup project comes to the Grand Hôtel Nord Pinus in Arles.
lead_paragraph: This summer, a British chef and a Montrealer sommelier aim to serve up the most Provençal meal in the south of France at a pop-up restaurant in the Grand Hôtel Nord Pinus in Arles. For her part, Laura Vidal, who founded the Paris Popup project with chef Harry Cummins in 2012, describes the four-course, prix-fixe bistro menu simply as an “ode to Provence.” But it is crafted almost entirely of local ingredients and with decidedly regional flavors. From the hotel’s dining room and an open-air terrace in the Place du Forum — a beautiful square beloved by locals in the small, ancient city that has recently been experiencing an intense revival of its traditional identity as a center for the arts (the Fondation Vincent Van Gogh reopened just last year there after an expansion and renovation) — the pair will serve lunch and dinner each Wednesday through Saturday until the end of August.

headline: In Pittsburgh, One Baker Requires a Whole Year to Create the Perfect Loaf
abstract: A centuries-old technique and carefully developed ingredients go into each batch of Bread and Salt bread.
lead_paragraph: Barely six months old, Pittsburgh’s Bread and Salt bakery is fast becoming known for its pane locale (local bread), made in a former slaughterhouse in the centuries-old Italian baking tradition of using organic flour, natural fermentation and local grain. Its owner and founder, the baker Rick Easton, acknowledges that the loaves’ “ugly, formless and dark” appearance belies their addictive flavor — which he accredits to the 100% stone-milled, high-extraction wheat flour crop he develops with a farmer in Weatherbury Farms in Avella, Pa. At the beginning of the season, Easton experiments with different wheat crops and handling techniques to find the right texture for bread he will serve that year. The result is a pane that feels like whole wheat, but the germ is retained so that the richness and natural oils produce “an incredible amount of flavor and sweetness. From a customer’s perspective, it’s great to be able to think about wheat in that way,” Easton explains. “People are used to this supermarket bread that has a two-hour process. My process is 24 hours, and then we’re talking about crop planning that went in a year ago. So last year, someone was thinking about the grain that you would eat today.” Below, Easton shares a recipe for enjoying his signature loaf — or your own favorite, local bread.

keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Uranium', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: It won’t actually buy us more time if Tehran decides to build a bomb.

In a recent interview with NPR, he said that the current breakout time is “about two to three months by our intelligence estimates.” By contrast, he claimed, the pending deal would shrink Iran’s nuclear program, so that if Iran later “decided to break the deal, kick out all the inspectors, break the seals and go for a bomb, we’d have over a year to respond.”

headline: ‘Who Sounds Gay?’
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Language and Languages', 'Voice and Speech']
abstract: This short documentary explores the reasons that some men sound stereotypically gay, whether they are or not.
lead_paragraph: For the last few years, I’ve wondered why some men “sound gay.” I began asking people for their thoughts on the subject, and received a surprising range of answers. Some people said the gay voice was a put-on, like a man in a conspicuously sparkly dress. Others thought gay men sounded gay just to let other gay men know they were. Some thought that every man who sounds gay is gay, even if he claims otherwise. A lot of people said, “Wow, I don’t know.”

headline: Brazil’s Shaken Optimism
abstract: The current economic and political crisis raises fears that recent economic gains will be washed down the drain.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Recent months have been pretty discouraging for Brazilians like me who were thrilled when Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva took over the office of president in 2003. Many of us believed that Partido dos Trabalhadores (Workers Party) would finally turn our nation into a fair country. But corruption scandals, an economic recession and opportunistic alliances with former rivals have replaced optimism with an old sinking feeling: The defeatism that had been dormant since the early 1990s is now knocking at the door again, whispering to us, “Nothing will ever work.”

headline: The Town Shrink
keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Trained as a psychiatrist, Mindy Thompson Fullilove now puts entire cities on the couch.
lead_paragraph: High Bridge, spanning the Harlem River and connecting Manhattan to the Bronx, is the oldest bridge in New York City. It is also an aqueduct, or used to be. Built in the 1840s, when public health officials across the country were battling cholera, it carried clean water from upstate to a growing urban population. In just a few decades, planners would build not just aqueducts but the so-called sanitary greens that today we call parks, including Highbridge Park, on the Manhattan side of the bridge. A side benefit of High Bridge was the walkway above the aqueduct that allowed Bronx pedestrians to reach Manhattan. By the 1960s, though, the aqueduct was no longer in use, and city planners, working to fight what was then called urban blight, decided to disconnect the boroughs. The Parks Department closed the old bridge, cutting off an artery.

headline: Talking With Rob Decker, a Real-Life Roller Coaster Tycoon
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Roller Coasters']
abstract: Decker, who works in theme park design for Cedar Fair Entertainment, talks about planning amusement parks and his favorite roller coasters.
lead_paragraph: From their earliest days, roller coasters have been designed to inspire awe (and an element of fear) among riders. Rob Decker, senior vice president of planning and design at Cedar Fair Entertainment, which operates 14 theme parks in the United States and Canada, tries to make sure that the roller coaster experience continues this tradition, while reinventing how theme parks can continue to attract visitors. “We have a broad group of guests,” Mr. Decker said. “We have roller coaster enthusiasts and our family audience, so we try to balance the two and create a great environment for everyone.”

headline: The Rabbit-Hole of ‘Relevant’
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'English Language', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'USA Freedom Act', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: For years, the N.S.A.’s data grab has hinged on a reading of the word that encompasses every aspect of our lives.
lead_paragraph: When a law has a name like “Patriot” or “Freedom,” it’s a sign that you should read the fine print. Somewhere down there, in the terraced subclauses of some forgettable subsection, is a word with a special meaning, a word that offers shelter and concealment to whatever it is that the law actually does. Consider the word “relevant.” You and I use the word to distinguish what matters (the relevant) from what does not (the irrelevant). But to the National Security Agency, there was no irrelevant. Pointing to one appearance of the word in a 2006 update of the USA Patriot Act, the agency argued it could demand records of any one of our phone calls, on the very slight chance of some distant connection to terrorism. A secret court agreed, ordering phone companies to serve up our records on an “ongoing daily basis’’ — 24 hours a day, hundreds of billions of calls in all. No one knew about it until Edward Snowden revealed the existence of the program in 2013. Earlier this month, President Obama signed the USA Freedom Act, which is supposed to close this loophole. Will it? That depends on a fresh pile of fine print.

headline: Can the Bacteria in Your Gut Explain Your Mood?
abstract: The rich array of microbiota in our intestines can tell us more than you might think.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen vials were rocking back and forth on a squeaky mechanical device the shape of a butcher scale, and Mark Lyte was beside himself with excitement. ‘‘We actually got some fresh yesterday — freshly frozen,’’ Lyte said to a lab technician. Each vial contained a tiny nugget of monkey feces that were collected at the Harlow primate lab near Madison, Wis., the day before and shipped to Lyte’s lab on the Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center campus in Abilene, Tex.

headline: NATO Refocuses on the Kremlin, Its Original Foe
abstract: Military training exercises this month in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, underline the seismic shift for an alliance that had been focused on threats far beyond its borders.
lead_paragraph: CAMP ADAZI, Latvia — After years of facing threats far beyond its borders, NATO is now reinvigorating plans to confront a much larger and more aggressive threat from its past: Moscow.

headline: The Patient I Abandoned
abstract: Therapy is rife with difficult goodbyes. But this was the hardest.
lead_paragraph: John was 7 when I met him, and dealing with more than any child could be expected to endure. For the first years of his life, he had been witness to his father’s alcoholic binges, which often involved shouting, breaking objects and hitting John and his mother. His mother struggled too, with depression and a crack addiction. When John was 5, the state’s Child Protective Services removed him from the home and placed him in a series of foster-care arrangements. Although his father disappeared, never to be heard from again, his mother underwent court-mandated substance-abuse treatment and was later allowed to see John in supervised visits. Eventually, she regained custody — which was right before he and I met.

headline: Today in Politics: South Carolina Takes Step Toward Folding Its Confederate Flag
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The conversation after the shooting in Charleston, S.C., almost immediately turned to the Confederate flag, which the gunman embraced in online postings and which hung at the state’s Capitol. On Monday, Gov. Nikki R. Haley called for it to come down.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. The conversation after the shooting in Charleston, S.C., almost immediately turned to the Confederate flag, which the gunman embraced in online postings and which hung at the state’s Capitol. headline: Pro-Democracy Demonstrators Decamp in Hong Kong

headline: Morning Agenda: Winners and Losers in Health Care Mergers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Executive Compensation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Short Selling', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Winners and Losers in Health Care Mergers | The Lonely Short-Seller | Signs of Progress in Greek Debt Talks | Martha Stewart’s Empire Sells for Fraction of Former Value
lead_paragraph: WINNERS AND LOSERS IN HEALTH CARE MERGERS | About a year and a half after the Affordable Care Act was signed into law, an analyst asked Mark T. Bertolini, Aetna’s chief executive, about possible mergers in the health care industry. Mr. Bertolini said, “I expect and we expect that consolidation will continue going forward here as health reform shakes out winners and losers in the process.” In the  latest DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin takes a look at the possible winners and losers as the health care industry moves toward consolidation on a large scale, especially as the country’s biggest health insurers, like Anthem and Aetna, set their sights on smaller rivals.

The show, which received Tony nominations for both Mr. Miles and Mr. Parker, as well as for best play, is at the Winter Garden Theater through July 5.

headline: James Horner, Film Composer, Dies at 61; His Score for ‘Titanic’ Was a Hit, Too
abstract: Mr. Horner, a multiple Oscar and Grammy winner, was flying solo in a single-turboprop plane that crashed and burned in Southern California.

He was 61.

headline: Luxury at Fendi, Etro, Canali and Kiton

abstract: Some of Milan’s fashion families take different approaches to pushing men’s fashion forward.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Among the elder-statesmen brands of Milan, the past is present. Family companies (some still held by families, others now passed into corporate hands) are a defining feature of the landscape here, and it’s not uncommon to chat with someone whose surname has been stitched onto garment labels for decades. But history is no longer enough to guarantee interest. Wrestling with tradition is a seasonal sport.

headline: 1965: Kennedy Urges Nuclear Ban
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Robert Kennedy stresses nuclear nonproliferation in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sen. Robert F. Kennedy today [June 23] called on the Johnson administration to give top priority to the problem of halting the spread of nuclear weapons — a problem he termed more urgent than the war in Vietnam. He added that at an ‘‘appropriate time and manner’’ the United States must ‘‘vigorously pursue negotiations on this subject with China.’’ ‘‘China is there, China will have nuclear weapons. And without her participation it will be infinitely more difficult, perhaps impossible in the long run to prevent nuclear proliferation.’’ Sen. Kennedy urged that in the ‘‘journey towards peace’’ the partial nuclear test ban treaty of 1963 be extended to cover certain underground tests. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 24, 1965

headline: In Mississippi, Hope Grows That Its Flag Will Fall Next

headline: The Ribbon, a Blue Ribbon Restaurant, Opens on the Upper West Side
abstract: Other new restaurants around town feature Cuban, Spanish and Latin American fare, as well as craft beer.
lead_paragraph: The Ribbon For Upper West Siders bemoaning the recent closing of Ouest and the area’s general scarcity of ambitious restaurants, this opening is well timed. It’s the latest entry from the Bromberg brothers, who own eight Blue Ribbon establishments around the city, and has the earmarks of the quintessential neighborhood restaurant. But its fried chicken, served only on Sunday and Monday evenings, may make it a destination. The large menu includes cheese plates, pâtés (and chopped liver), raw-bar items, latkes, rotisserie meats and a burger, but none of the sushi served at some other Blue Ribbons. “We’re going back to our roots: French, but also what we grew up with, like prime ribs at Grandma’s house,” said Eric Bromberg, who owns the restaurant with his brother, Bruce. You enter a spacious dark-wood bar area, with tables; a couple of steps lead down to the big windowed dining room. There’s an open kitchen where the chef, Martin Brock, works behind glass (opens Wednesday): 20 West 72nd Street, 212-787-5656, theribbonnyc.com.

headline: Chinese City Defends Dog Meat Festival, Despite Scorn
abstract: Yulin, home of an annual dog meat festival, has become the target of a growing animal rights campaign, making its residents feel increasingly under siege.
lead_paragraph: YULIN, China — It was the night before the summer solstice, and the tables at a streetside food stall here were set for the annual feast: steamed pumpkin, sautéed morning glory, smashed cucumbers and cold-skin rice flour noodles. At the center of each table were the two traditional dishes most essential to the celebration here: fresh lychees and heaping bowls of stewed dog, pungent with ginger, garlic, dried orange peels, bay leaves and fennel.

headline: Twelve Cabins, Private Hot Springs and One Large Teepee

lead_paragraph: Getting to Dunton Hot Springs is no small feat: Arriving from the small, mountainous town of Durango, Colo., drive west along the San Juan National Forest for a few hours. When you reach the even smaller town of Dolores, follow the West Dolores River down a winding county dirt road for 45 minutes to reach the microscopic town of Dunton. If you get there approaching sunset, a thin coil of smoke from a campfire might herald your destination.

headline: Tom Holland Is the New Spider-Man
abstract: The little-known British actor will be directed by a little-known filmmaker, Jon Watts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Talk about two itsy-bitsy guys climbing up the Hollywood spout: Sony Pictures and Marvel Studios on Tuesday announced that they had handed the next big-budget Spider-Man movie to an unknown director, Jon Watts, and that a little-known British actor, Tom Holland, had been cast in the title role.

headline: Britain Holds Rwandan Spy Chief on War Crimes Warrant from Spain
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Extradition', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Rwandan intelligence chief, Karenzi Karake, is wanted on war crimes charges involving genocide and the killing of Spanish aid workers in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The chief of Rwanda’s intelligence service, who is wanted in Spain on war crimes charges, was being held in London on Tuesday after his arrest prompted diplomatic and political protests and reopened debate about responsibility for killings in Rwanda two decades ago.

headline: When Parents Compare Siblings, the Results Can Show On Report Cards
abstract: New research suggests that a parent’s belief that one sibling is a better student than another can become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard for parents of more than one child not to compare them. Our minds like to sort and categorize, and the result is often either labeling (athletic, academic) or ranking (better than, stronger than, more able in one area or another). New research suggests that those thoughts, even if they stay unexpressed, may affect our children’s academic successes. The same research suggests that those parental expectations form early and aren’t affected by changes in a child’s performance.

headline: Southern Front Pages Reflect Shifting Politics
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'News and News Media', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: In South Carolina, newspapers boldly said the time had come to take down the Confederate flag, but the feeling was not shared across the South.
lead_paragraph: Throughout South Carolina, newspapers treated Gov. Nikki Haley’s call to remove the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the State House — a seismic shift in that state’s politics — as huge news.

headline: Scott Walker, Set for a Bigger Stage, Faces G.O.P. Revolt in Wisconsin
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker has promised to bring what he called “big bold leadership” to Washington, as he did in Wisconsin, but he faces a cloud over that story line: Republicans back home are in revolt.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — As Gov. Scott Walker prepares to announce his campaign for president next month, promising to bring what he calls “big bold leadership” to Washington, as he did in Wisconsin, he faces a cloud over that story line: Republicans back home are in revolt.

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

lead_paragraph: In the latest setback for Tidal, the new streaming music service from Jay Z, its top executive has left the company after just two months on the job.

headline: Karachi Heat Wave Death Toll Tops 650 During Ramadan Fast
abstract: Hospitals declared a state of emergency and authorities closed schools and offices in Karachi, where temperatures have risen to as high as 113 degrees Fahrenheit.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Karachi’s poor learned long ago to cope with the many adversities that afflict Pakistan’s most crowded and chaotic city, including flooding, street violence and political crises. But since a suffocating heat wave descended on Karachi three days ago, killing at least 650 people, they have found no respite and no escape.

Cuomo and legislative leaders reached a tentative deal on Tuesday on a range of knotty issues, including a new agreement on rent regulations covering about one million New York City apartments.

headline: Persecution and the Black Church
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Slavery (Historical)']
abstract: The Charleston massacre wasn’t, but also was, an attack on religious faith.
lead_paragraph: Now that a few days have passed, it’s worth saying something about the much-discussed initial response to the massacre at Charleston’s Emanuel A.M.E Church, in which a scattering of Republicans and Fox News personalities suggested that this was anti-religious violence, an anti-Christian attack, rather than the white supremacist violence (shaped by whatever demons occupy the shooter’s mind) that it quickly proved to be.

lead_paragraph: The debate over the Confederate battle flag has spilled into the world of commerce as major retailers including Walmart, Sears and eBay have banned the sale of merchandise bearing the Civil War symbol.

keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']

lead_paragraph: Entering a debate that has played out for years mostly in the political realm, many of the nation’s largest retailers abruptly decided this week to stop selling merchandise tied to the Confederate battle flag.

headline: Dick Van Patten, Harried Father on ‘Eight Is Enough,’ Dies at 86

lead_paragraph: Dick Van Patten, the cheerful, round-faced actor best known for his role as the firm if harried suburban father at the center of the hit television series “Eight Is Enough,” died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 86.

headline: A Two-Year, 100-Billboard Celebration of Going West
abstract: The public-art nonprofit LAND’s “Manifest Destiny” project spans 2,700 miles and has included commissions from John Baldessari, Jeremy Shaw, Eve Fowler and others.
lead_paragraph: Though blizzards and rent checks will always revive New Yorkers’ dreams of avocado trees and sunshine, for a certain set of creatives, the allure of the American West is so passé it’s history. Starting tonight, the “Manifest Destiny Billboard Project,” a two-year, 100-billboard journey from sea to shining sea along Interstate 10, kicks off its culminating festivities in Los Angeles. “Transit west has a long and speckled past, a combination of the best and worst things about what we do,” says the director of the public-art nonprofit Los Angeles Nomadic Division, Shamim Momin, who co-curated two Whitney Biennials before herself moving to California. The vision of manifest destiny, she says, has had “all sorts of applications over time, many of which have been devastating to different communities. And yet it is also so ingrained in the history of being American, the way we think about aspiration and ambition, achievement and taking. It ties to everything from the capitalist impulse to notions of exploration, and to the desire to know.”

headline: Where ‘True Detective’ and the Triangle Offense Meet
abstract: To help us better visualize the mysterious triangle offense, we turned to Joshua Walsh, the artist whose work defined the first season of HBO’s True Detective.
lead_paragraph: The deeper we went on the triangle offense, the more we felt as if we were inside some sort of antechamber of the “True Detective” Carcosa lair. So we tracked down Joshua Walsh, the artist whose work defined the first season of that HBO show, and invited him to contemplate the many mysteries of the triangle. What he came up with is a series of clocks based on the principles outlined in Tex Winter’s book, “The Triple-Post Offense.”

headline: Cherries Add a Sweet Touch to Tabbouleh
abstract: As a stand-in for tomatoes, the stone fruit adds a juicy surprise in every bite.
lead_paragraph: This year, I get two cherry seasons: the one that is just ending in California (and is coming into full swing in other parts of the country), and the one that I enjoyed in late May in France. Every year, usually in summer, I visit a dear friend in the Luberon region of Provence. I went earlier this time, and her cherry trees were heavy with fruit.

keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: Jonathan Fleming, who was cleared last year of a murder conviction after a decades-old phone receipt supporting an alibi emerged, has reached a $6.25 million settlement with New York City for years of imprisonment.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: What is clear to most in Charleston is that the issues that affect people’s lives, like access to good education, go far beyond what happens with a Confederate flag.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — From a wicker chair on the porch of her daisy yellow bungalow, Cheryl Lee panned from right to left, pointing to the houses on the block — the blue one, the brick one, the light green one — that had transitioned from black ownership to white.

headline: Why I Can’t Forgive Dylann Roof
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Terrorism']
abstract: What people are really asking for when they demand forgiveness from a traumatized community is absolution.
lead_paragraph: I DO NOT forgive Dylann Roof, a racist terrorist whose name I hate saying or knowing. I have no immediate connection to what happened in Charleston, S.C., last week beyond my humanity and my blackness, but I do not foresee ever forgiving his crimes, and I am wholly at ease with that choice.

headline: Indie Music, Illustrated
abstract: The French artist and T contributor Damien Florébert Cuypers sketched the entire lineup of Brooklyn’s Full Moon Fest.
lead_paragraph: This August, the one-day-only Full Moon music festival will celebrate its fifth anniversary (after four consecutive sold-out years) in a new location: a pop-up space, the Brooklyn Mirage, that will feature 20-foot living walls, tropical plants and beach sand imported from the South of France. For the occasion, the festival’s curators, Matte Projects, reached out to the French artist, illustrator and frequent T contributor Damien Florébert Cuypers to illustrate the festival’s entire indie-leaning 14-act lineup (rather than booking stadium-filler names, Full Moon operates as a boutique festival, opting for on-the-verge discoveries). Matte and Cuypers shared the illustrations exclusively with T.

headline: Review: American Ballet Theater’s ‘Swan Lake’ Adds Drama to Romance
abstract: The pairing of Gillian Murphy as Odette-Odile and Marcelo Gomes as Prince Siegfried flies above the show’s staging.
lead_paragraph: Last season, American Ballet Theater’s opening night of “Swan Lake” took a dramatic turn that had nothing to do with evil sorcerers transforming princesses into swans. Gillian Murphy, the company’s resplendent virtuoso, was injured during the second act; Hee Seo took over. On Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, drama occurred for all the right reasons: A particularly ravishing Ms. Murphy, joined again by Marcelo Gomes as Prince Siegfried, flew through the role of Odette-Odile with not only the strength she is known for, but also with wit, amplitude and finespun vulnerability.

lead_paragraph: LEWES, England — On a sunny day at the Glyndebourne Festival here, an hour’s train ride from London, bees buzz amiably through wildflowers, sheep bleat in the open pasture, and champagne glasses clink amid high-society chatter. Only the croquet lawn is safe from picnic tables, as patrons claim preferred spots early in the afternoon.

headline: Review: ‘Wild Women of Planet Wongo,’ a Musical Comedy With a Sci-Fi Bent
abstract: In this play, two astronauts deal with Wongo Weed and big-haired natives after landing on a planet ruled by women.
lead_paragraph: Bushwick, in Brooklyn, as it inches closer to being devoured by Williamsburg, can still look otherworldly in its more remote precincts. How appropriate then to find the quaint musical cum dance party “Wild Women of Planet Wongo” there on a desolate block at Brooklyn Fire Proof. Not to be confused with the Z-movie “Wild Women of Wongo,” from 1958, this spoof more recalls the seminal sci-fi cheese-fest “Cat-Women of the Moon,” from 1953.

headline: At the Milan Men’s Wear Shows, Sporty Parachute Nylon Gets an Update for Spring/Summer 2016
abstract: Brioni, Jil Zander and Z Zegna showed jackets in tailored silhouettes and a restrained palette that imbued the fabric with a new sophistication.
lead_paragraph: At this point, it’s no secret that athletic-wear and technical fabrics have infiltrated the world of high fashion. But there’s something new and refreshing about the billowing parachute-nylon coats that appeared in the shows for Brioni, Jil Sander and Z Zegna during this men’s fashion week in Milan. The flowing jackets, in a restrained palette of cool grays and blues and paired with sharply tailored silhouettes, imbue the sporty fabric with an air of minimal sophistication.

headline: Synthetic Drug Manufacturing Is an Open Secret in China
abstract: Dan Levin describes reporting his recent article on the Chinese chemical factories that produce illegal drugs to be sold internationally over the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Just before dawn on Dec. 29, 2013, the southern Chinese fishing village of Boshe awoke to a scene reminiscent of a Hollywood action flick: Over 3,000 police officers, backed by helicopters and speedboats, burst into traditional stone houses in search of illegal drugs. With cameramen in tow, the police destroyed 77 methamphetamine labs, seized three tons of crystal meth and more than 100 tons of meth ingredients. Among the 182 people arrested were a former local Communist Party chief and 13 other officials.

headline: Review: ‘First Peoples’ Finds the Drive to Explore in Our DNA
abstract: This new series from PBS suggests that our earliest ancestors bred with Neanderthals.
lead_paragraph: The narration is often overwrought, and so is the soundtrack, but “First Peoples,” a five-part science series beginning on Wednesday on PBS, certainly alerts you to one thing: If your most recent idea of paleoanthropology involves an image of one of the Leakeys dusting off an ancient fibula, you seriously need an update.

headline: A Reimagining in Washington Divides the Neighbors
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Redevelopment of an old water filtration site is expected to bring jobs, revenue and housing, but opponents prefer a park.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From her second-floor bedroom window two miles north of the United States Capitol, Doris Newton can gaze across a grassy field and reservoir at the Founder’s Library Clock Tower at Howard University, her alma mater. She fervently hopes the view won’t change.

headline: Review: Karen Mason, a Well-Seasoned Belter, at Don’t Tell Mama
abstract: The nightclub singer performed ballads like “I Made a New Friend,” a song that distilled the essence of her musical personality.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve come home at last!” Norma Desmond’s triumphant announcement in the semioperatic ballad, “As If We Never Said Goodbye,” from “Sunset Boulevard” has rarely been put to more powerful use than in Karen Mason’s show at the Midtown cabaret Don’t Tell Mama on Monday evening. Ms. Mason, who was a stand-in for three Broadway Normas — Glenn Close, Betty Buckley and Elaine Paige — captured the character’s scarily compelling essence in clawing body language. This dramatic tour de force was especially impressive because as a nightclub singer, Ms. Mason is utterly guileless.

headline: Grisly ISIS Video Seems Aimed at Quashing Resistance
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Terrorism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Propaganda', 'Kurds', 'Civilian Casualties']

headline: Review: ‘Souvenir Undone’ Beckons Its Audience Through Historic Fort Jay
abstract: Rachel Tess’s dance for the River to River festival invites audience members to move, too, as they follow the performance from space to space on Governors Island.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Tess, a Portland, Ore., choreographer now based in Sweden, is obsessed with relationships between forms: architecture and choreography, silence and sound, light and dark. Ms. Tess, a Juilliard graduate whose scenes resemble dioramas, may have discovered the performance site of her dreams at Governors Island, where, as part of the River to River festival, she presented “Souvenir Undone” on Friday at the Fort Jay magazine, a medley of arched brick rooms once used to store gunpowder.

headline: A Conversation With Barbara S. Fox
abstract: Ms. Fox is the founder and president of the Fox Residential Group, a boutique brokerage firm that does business mainly in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Fox is the founder and president of the Fox Residential Group, a boutique brokerage firm that does business mainly in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The firm, which was founded in 1989, has about 50 agents.

headline: Review: ‘What Happened, Miss Simone?’ Documents Nina Simone’s Rise as Singer and Activist
abstract: This documentary, directed by Liz Garbus, chronicles the life of Nina Simone, the singer-musician whose social circle and civil rights activism grew along with her fame.
lead_paragraph: Partway through “What Happened, Miss Simone?,” an often electric, bracingly urgent documentary on the singer-musician Nina Simone, we reach that catastrophic year 1968, and the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. On screen, photographs of other murdered black men flicker past — Malcolm X, the civil rights activist Medgar Evers and the Black Panther Fred Hampton — followed by a photo of a young black mourner holding a sign that reads: “You better kill all blacks.” I can’t be the only American who will despair at the relevance of those words in 2015.

abstract: Mr. Featherstone’s first pink plastic flamingo came off the assembly line in 1957.
lead_paragraph: Don Featherstone did not invent Phoenicopterus ruber: Nature took care of that eons ago. But what Mr. Featherstone did nearly six decades ago — in the process indelibly altering the landscape of midcentury America — was to cast the creature in plastic and attach slender, rodlike legs for planting it in the ground.

headline: Sorrowing Ireland Buries Its Own
abstract: The country showed its deep capacity for empathy at a time of shock and grief.
lead_paragraph: The bonds that knit a small country, its resemblance to a large and far-flung family, its citizens’ deep capacity for empathy — all of that was on full and stunning display last week in Ireland. It was a time of shock and grieving over the accident at an apartment building in Berkeley, Calif., that left six young Irish citizens dead and seven injured. Most were college students, working in the United States through the J-1 summer visa program. They were at a birthday party when a balcony gave way.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — There is no easy translation or even a firm concept of the word “coping” in French, so when it turned up last week in a question on the national exam to earn a high school degree, it set off a fracas among the 350,000 or so students who took the test.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The apartment building balcony that collapsed last week in Berkeley, Calif., killing six students, was supported by wooden beams with extensive rotting from water damage, city officials said Tuesday.

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Bishops are expected to discuss issues like same-sex unions and divorced Catholics at a Vatican meeting in October, while trying to stay true to church doctrine, a new report says.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A working paper released on Tuesday by the Vatican for a much-anticipated fall gathering of the world’s bishops laid the groundwork for fresh discussions on issues like the Roman Catholic Church’s ban on same-sex unions and the sacrament of communion for divorced Catholics who have remarried outside the church.

When she enrolled last fall as a freshman engineering student, she said, “I had my four years planned out, and everything was perfect.”

As the afternoon drew on and their retreat turned into a rout, the lingering upholders of the Confederacy watched as license plates, statues and prominently placed Confederate battle flags slipped from their reach.

headline: Chemical Safety Bill Advances
abstract: The House on Tuesday easily passed a measure that would make the first major changes in 39 years to a law intended to protect people from exposure to toxic chemicals.
lead_paragraph: The House on Tuesday easily passed a measure that would make the first major changes in 39 years to a law intended to protect people from exposure to toxic chemicals. The House voted. 398 to 1, to pass a bill designed to update and strengthen the 1976 Toxic Substances Control Act, which has been criticized as outdated and toothless by environmental advocates and the chemical industry. The Senate is expected to take up a companion bill next month. The bills would require the Environmental Protection Agency to begin studying the health effects of about 64,000 chemicals that are used in commerce. But public health advocates complain that the pace of study would be too slow.

headline: Mexico: Deadly Fire Hits Nursing Home
abstract: A fire Tuesday killed 16 residents of a nursing home on the outskirts of Mexicali, the capital of Baja California, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A fire Tuesday killed 16 residents of a nursing home on the outskirts of Mexicali, the capital of Baja California, officials said. Mayor Jaime Díaz said five people rescued from the home near the California border had been hospitalized. A local charity runs the home, Beautiful Twilight, which houses indigent elderly people. There was no immediate evidence of an electrical fault or gas leak, Mr. Díaz said, and investigators were theorizing that the fire had been intentionally set.

headline: A Timeline of Jews in Egypt
abstract: The number of Egyptian Jews has dwindled to only a few dozen today, from as many as 85,000 in the middle of the last century.

headline: Poland: British Teenagers Are Charged With Stealing From Auschwitz Site
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: The unidentified Britons were accused of stealing artifacts, including a razor, buttons and pieces of glass and cutlery, which once belonged to prisoners at the camps.
lead_paragraph: Two British teenagers have been charged with stealing items from the former Auschwitz-Birkenau death camps, the spokeswoman for prosecutors in Krakow, Poland, said Tuesday. The unidentified Britons, ages 17 and 18, were arrested Monday during a field trip to the Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum and accused of stealing artifacts, including a razor, buttons and pieces of glass and cutlery, which once belonged to prisoners at the camps. The maximum sentence for the theft of items of special cultural importance is 10 years in prison, said Boguslawa Marcinkowska, the spokeswoman. Still, she suggested that more likely penalties for the teenagers, who were released Monday, would include fines, conditionally suspended prison sentences and probation.

headline: Colombia: 17 Are Indicted in U.S. on Cocaine Trafficking Charges
keywords: ['Drug Cartels', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Members and associates of one of Colombia’s largest and most influential narcotics cartels, including its founder and current leader, have been indicted on drug trafficking charges.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen members and associates of one of Colombia’s largest and most influential narcotics cartels, including its founder and current leader, have been indicted on drug trafficking charges in New York and Florida, law enforcement authorities said on Tuesday. Officials in Miami unsealed indictments against the suspects, who are accused of being involved with the cartel, Clan Úsuga, and affiliate cartels and paramilitary groups. Officials say they shipped tons of cocaine to the United States as far back as 2003. The indictments were a result of a multiyear investigation carried out by law enforcement authorities in Colombia and the United States, and brought to 25 the number of people charged so far, officials said.

headline: Notes From One Artist’s Interior Monologue
abstract: Gordon Harrison Hull’s “emotional landscapes” will be on display at the Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery.
lead_paragraph: The multidisciplinary artist Gordon Harrison Hull describes his latest works as “emotional landscapes” that map a journey through his psyche; they are collected for an exhibition at the Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery, fittingly dubbed “Department of the Interior.” “The show has smaller, medium-sized and bigger pieces and they all come from a similar place,” he explains, “but the smaller ones are more intimate — they express one particular thought. Then, the medium pieces are an extrapolation of those and the bigger ones really go to town and express a lot of different emotions.”

headline: Colombia Military Accused of Deception on Civilian Deaths
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: Many generals and other high-ranking officers in Colombia’s armed forces may have known about a pattern of soldiers killing civilians and passing off the deaths as guerrilla casualties in the campaign against rebel insurgencies, according to a report to be released on Wednesday.

headline: Schools Chief in Newark Says Debate Lost Its Focus
abstract: Cami Anderson, in an interview one day after she resigned as schools superintendent, lamented that the fight over education reform had become “personalized.”
lead_paragraph: Cami Anderson knew the challenges when she arrived in Newark as its schools superintendent four years ago. In the city’s South Ward, for example, there were 12 elementary schools and not at a single one were more than 30 percent of students reading at or above grade level. Students were fleeing to charter schools, taking money from the traditional public schools with them. She had been warned that the city’s politics could be contentious, with a tradition of long and rancorous public meetings.

headline: More Americans Are Renting, and Paying More, as Homeownership Falls
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'United States Economy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Millions of Americans are unwillingly stuck in rental housing, even as the housing market is starting to improve.
lead_paragraph: WESTFIELD, N.J. — To Johnnie McDowell, the house on Livingston Street seems to taunt him every time he walks by. It’s nothing special: The two-story home is a bit shabby, and it’s been on and off the market in recent months without finding a buyer. Still, he cannot stop dreaming of a better life for his family as he imagines the extra space inside and his children and dog playing outdoors once he weeds the yard.

Mr. Bharara delivered on that promise on Monday, when the city agreed to sweeping policy changes to settle a long-running legal battle over abuses at the jail.

Days earlier someone had managed to take down one of the red, white and blue Chilean flags and replaced it with the traditional Mapuche flag in a peaceful but poignant protest.

headline: Tips for Keeping That Post-Vacation Feeling

Striving to hold on to it for as long as possible, she deployed various strategies including placing her used boarding passes front and center on her desk, and leaving receipts from the TV Tower in Berlin and the Eiffel Tower in Paris on a bedroom chest of drawers that she passes each morning.

headline: Fidgeting May Benefit Children With A.D.H.D.
abstract: Instead of telling children with hyperactivity and attention problems to sit still, perhaps we should encourage them to wriggle at will.
lead_paragraph: Instead of telling children with hyperactivity and attention problems to sit still, perhaps we should encourage them to wriggle at will, according to a new study of children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D. The study, in Child Neuropsychology, found that children with A.D.H.D. concentrate much better when they fidget than when they don’t.

headline: Walking Home
abstract: I wore my mother’s shoes to feel as if she was walking with me, helping me through those first days of her absence.
lead_paragraph: I’ve moved back into the house I grew up in, the house in which my mother died. Every sweep of the broom picks up stray hairs and dust: the small pieces of Mom that were left behind. Each time I empty the vacuum I throw a little more of her away. I have to pick and choose what to keep, and no one keeps the dust. I keep memories of her thumbs and how it felt to run my fingers over her knuckles. I keep a memory of the slight overlap of her front teeth. I keep other things, lists about her and how she was; cataloging is a vice of both lovers and the grieving.
