Bobby Jindal is going to make an announcement that many before him have already made.

headline: Confessions of a Seduction Addict
abstract: A compulsion to coerce men into relationships becomes self-destructive.
lead_paragraph: It started with a boy I met at summer camp and ended with the man for whom I left my first husband. In between, I careened from one intimate entanglement to the next — dozens of them — without so much as a day off between romances. You might have called me a serial monogamist, except that I was never exactly monogamous. Relationships overlapped, and those overlaps were always marked by exhausting theatricality: sobbing arguments, shaming confrontations, broken hearts. Still, I kept doing it. I couldn’t not do it.

headline: Documents on 2012 Drone Strike Detail How Terrorists Are Targeted
abstract: British files provided by Edward J. Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor, include information on how terrorism suspects are targeted and how drone strikes can go awry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early in 2012, worried that suicide bombers might pass through airline security undetected, American counterterrorism officials ordered a drone strike in Yemen to kill a doctor they believed was working with Al Qaeda to surgically implant explosives in operatives, according to British intelligence documents.

headline: Tell It About Your Mother
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Brain', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Magnetic Resonance Imagers', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: Can brain-scanning help save Freudian psychoanalysis?
lead_paragraph: In 1900, Sigmund Freud, a Viennese specialist in nervous disorders, began treating the 18-year-old daughter of a rich acquaintance. Freud, who was 44, was just beginning to practice psychoanalysis, a form of therapy that would become known as ‘the talking cure.’ The girl, whom Freud would later refer to as ‘‘Dora,’’ had a cluster of inexplicable symptoms: Her mood was low, she was prone to losing consciousness and, for weeks at a time, she could not speak above a whisper. Freud diagnosed hysteria, a term commonly used in fin de siècle Europe to refer to a disorder in which psychological stress was expressed through physical symptoms. Freud traced Dora’s condition in part to her father’s sexual infidelities that she had felt obliged, from early adolescence, to help orchestrate. When Dora told Freud, in the course of the analysis, that her father’s friend — Herr K., a married man decades her senior — had accosted her in his empty office building, trying to kiss her on her lips, Freud, trained in biology and swept up in his own scientific detachment, couldn’t empathize with her distress. One day, after only 11 weeks of treatment and still far from cured, she stood up at the end of a session, wished Freud a happy new year and never returned.

headline: Chop Suey’s Comeback
abstract: How an old-school Chinese-American favorite found a new audience in L.A.
lead_paragraph: If you walk in the east side of the recently renovated Grand Central Market in downtown Los Angeles, you are confronted by the snaking lines at the trendy Eggslut, which sells, as far as I can tell, glorified Egg McMuffins. If you enter on the west side of the blockwide building, however, you come across a time capsule: China Café, a lunch counter that serves Chinese-American food — egg fu yeung (a.k.a. egg foo yong), chow mein, chop suey and other old-fashioned former standards — to a clientele of mostly Latinos and hipsters.

headline: Portrait of a Lady
abstract: A picture of a woman is often made for the pleasure of others; in the work of photographers of modern Africa, it is for her.
lead_paragraph: A photographer working in a commercial studio in West Africa in the 20th century had a straightforward task: to please his clients. In that sense, the Malian photographer Seydou Keïta was — like his father, who worked as a blacksmith, carpenter, mechanic and electrician, among other jobs — a craftsman. He was paid by the public to make pictures. But like his esteemed Malian compatriot Malick Sidibé, Mama Casset of Senegal and Joseph Moise Agbodjelou of Benin, he produced such fine work that we now consider him a great African artist. These master photographers gave us panoramas of life in Bamako, Dakar and Porto-Novo, a vivid record of individual people, largely shorn of their names and stories but irrepressibly alive. Here are good clothes gracefully cut, glowing skin, beautifully coifed hair, polished shoes: all the familiar markers of a person taking pride in his or her appearance. Here’s someone who looks witty, here’s another who looks querulous, another who’s modest, or vain, or sweet. There we see a renegade bra strap slipping off a shoulder, there a large laughing man with a baby, a woman in a bathing suit, youths partying at night with their Afros, bell-bottoms, precious LPs and endless reserves of cool.

headline: How Do I Counter My Sister’s Abuse Claims Against Our Father?
abstract: The Ethicists consider how to reconcile two wildly conflicting stories about a deceased parent.
lead_paragraph: My sister has become a personality in the media primarily due to her colorful past. She gives lectures and has a self-help book coming out soon. One of her minor themes concerns our deceased father and is particularly nasty. Although there is no way to positively refute statements she has made, neither I nor my two brothers and my mother believe my father capable of the events my sister describes. My father was a kind and giving person. He has living brothers, sisters, nieces and nephews who loved him dearly and would be very upset by my sister’s claims. My husband suggests I confront my sister, but that will most likely not yield a fruitful outcome or change anything. My concern is to protect positive memories. I propose to write about him myself, posting my memories on the Internet. I would not attempt to refute my sister, merely focus on my father and memories of him. This seems the least aggressive path and least likely to create any stir around my sister or her supporters. Since the Internet seems destined to live forever, at least an alternative memorial for my father would exist. Your thoughts are appreciated. NAME WITHHELD

headline: Why Don’t the Poor Rise Up?
abstract: Is it because the idea of the collective good has given way to ‘individualization’? Whatever happened to e pluribus unum?

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Judge Halts Sysco’s Takeover of US Foods | Investors Look Beyond Greece | Ahold and Delhaize Agree to Merger | Dutch Defenses in Mylan-Teva Takeover War
lead_paragraph: JUDGE HALTS SYSCO’S TAKEOVER OF US FOODS | Sysco’s $3.5 billion bid to buy US Foods was dealt a potentially fatal blow after a federal judge issued a preliminary injunction against the deal,  Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The merger of the country’s two biggest food distribution companies, which was first proposed in December 2013, has been opposed by the Federal Trade Commission. The commission sued in February to block the deal on the grounds that it would reduce competition in 32 markets and lead to higher prices and worse service for customers like restaurants and schools. In his ruling on Tuesday, Judge Amit P. Mehta of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia sided with the F.T.C.

headline: Classical Playlist: Rihm, Brahms, Glass and Messiaen
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: RIHM: ‘Et Lux’ Paul Van Nevel, conductor; Huelgas Ensemble; Minguet Quartet(ECM)This eerie and uncomfortably hypnotic hourlong work for vocal ensemble and string quartet is a setting of the words of the Latin Requiem Mass, but not in any functional liturgical order. Instead, the text fragments, veiled by a gauzy haze of strings, appear like brittle remnants of a ritual half-forgotten. The Minguet Quartet plays the queasy dissonances and occasional snatches of almost-familiar tonal material with wonderful transparency; the voices of the Huelgas Ensemble are pure and airy conduits of the eternal light evoked in the title. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

abstract: While Mitt Romney’s Twitter post on the Confederate battle flag is credited with kick-starting the debate among Republicans and putting the issue at the forefront of the 2016 presidential campaign, the retweets he received were modest.

And they have found some exceptional numbers behind Mitt Romney and President Obama’s exchange over the Confederate battle flag.

abstract: The FarmLogs app allows farmers to enter planting dates, crop yield and other data on mobile devices and to share it easily via the web.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — One day in 2011, Jesse Vollmar’s uncle was complaining about how difficult the family farm’s new data management software was to use. Despite taking a course taught by a software provider, he still couldn’t figure out how to get it to keep track of seeding dates, rainfall, field yield or any of the other functions that mattered most.

headline: New York City’s Flag, Centuries in the Making, Turns 100
abstract: Thousands of New Yorkers descended on Lower Manhattan on June 24, 1915, to watch the official municipal flag be hoisted for the first time.
lead_paragraph: City fathers were flummoxed. Wherever they looked, on documents, statues, building facades and other public works, the Seal of the City of New York rarely looked the same. Moreover, nearly three centuries of bloviating at City Hall had apparently generated a lot of wind, but had yet to produce an official municipal flag.

headline: Cubs Fan Catches Foul Ball in One Hand With Baby in Other
abstract: Keith Hartley’s catch — snagging the ball at a Cubs-Dodgers game while bottle-feeding his 7-month-old son — was the most talked about highlight of the day.
lead_paragraph: For a couple of minutes there, the man every baseball broadcaster and reporter wanted to talk to was a 29-year-old employee of a financial firm.

headline: French Government Reacts to U.S. Spying
abstract: Stéphane Le Foll, the French government spokesman, spoke on Wednesday about documents released by WikiLeaks that alleged that the National Security Agency spied on French presidents and officials.
lead_paragraph: Stéphane Le Foll, the French government spokesman, spoke on Wednesday about documents released by WikiLeaks that alleged that the National Security Agency spied on French presidents and officials.

headline: Debt Talks May Be Defining Moment for Greece, and for Angela Merkel
abstract: Beyond economics, the outcome of the negotiations will have lasting ramifications for European unity and security, raising questions about the German leader’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With Greece embroiled in civil war and the shadow of Soviet domination looming over Europe in 1947, President Harry S. Truman called for “immediate and resolute action,” putting up hundreds of millions of dollars to keep Greece in the Western camp.

headline: Shabab Claim Responsibility for Deadly Car Bomb in Mogadishu
abstract: At least two people were killed in the Somali capital when militants detonated a vehicle loaded with explosives and engaged in a firefight, witnesses and officials said.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least two people were killed in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, on Wednesday when militants detonated a car loaded with explosives and then engaged in a firefight during an attack on foreign military trainers, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Donkey Kong Economics
abstract: Take that, austerians!
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg blazes new frontiers in article illustration; you can see why my beard is irreversible at the point. And I guess being portrayed as a master of Mixed Macroeconomic Arts isn’t the worst thing in the world.

headline: Schools Fear Gay Marriage Ruling Could End Tax Exemptions
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: If the Supreme Court finds a constitutional right to gay marriage, religious schools say they could lose tax-exempt status for opposing same-sex relationships.
lead_paragraph: Conservative religious schools all over the country forbid same-sex relationships, from dating to couples’ living in married-student housing, and they fear they will soon be forced to make a wrenching choice. If the Supreme Court this month finds a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, the schools say they will have to abandon their policies that prohibit gay relationships or eventually risk losing their tax-exempt status.

headline: Start-Ups Finding the Best Employees Are Actually Employed
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Mobile Applications', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Some on-demand companies are rejecting the practice of using independent contractors, like Uber drivers, and are hiring people they can train and hold accountable.
lead_paragraph: When Ron Johnson was pitching his idea for an e-commerce delivery company to venture capitalists last year, one of the sticking points was his vision for how to treat employees.

headline: Most of the Way With Obamacare
abstract: Big progress on the uninsured.
lead_paragraph: As we wait for King v Burwell – just how far are Republicans on the court willing to destroy the institution’s reputation on behalf of their party? – one question I found myself wondering about was how much of its original goal Obamacare has achieved. We know that the number of uninsured has dropped sharply; we also know that there are still a lot of uninsured. So how are we doing?

headline: 1965: Saigon Breaks With France
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Saigon severs diplomatic links with France in 1965.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — South Vietnam’s ruling military junta today [June 24] severed diplomatic relations with France and for the first time officially declared war against the Communist Viet Cong. The government also announced it was introducing harsh measures including: 1. Closing down all newspapers published in the country. Saigon alone has had 36 newspapers, but now the nation as a whole will only have two, one for civilians and one for soldiers. 2. Clamping an ‘‘anti-luxury’’ 10 p.m. to 2 a.m. curfew on the capital. Premier Nguyen Cao Ky warned that his government would deal severely with anyone who raised his voice in protest. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 25, 1965

headline: Businesses’ Doors Creak Open in a West Bank ‘Ghost Town,’ Decades After Massacre
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Once a thriving marketplace, al-Sahla Street had its businesses shuttered after a murderous rampage in 1994. Now a few are reopening. But how many, and how soon?
lead_paragraph: HEBRON, West Bank — It took Mohammad Abu Halaweh a good 10 minutes to pry open the rusted metal doors of his butcher shop for the first time in two decades. He had the key, an old-fashioned iron number as big as his hand. But he had to press a sandaled foot against the door and leverage his body weight to yank off a second lock. A handful of curious children had gathered by the time he finally finished the job with the help of a hammer.

headline: Rick Ross Arrested and Charged With Kidnapping
abstract: The rapper was being held on charges of kidnapping and aggravated assault in Fayetteville, Ga., the police said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Rick Ross was arrested on Wednesday in Fayetteville, Ga., and charged with kidnapping, aggravated battery and aggravated assault, the police said.

headline: A Cure for Hovering
abstract: A little boy finds independence despite his hovering family in a funny, refreshing new picture book.
lead_paragraph: Neglectful parents, too-busy parents, dead parents, parents who are just not in the picture, who knows why. … What would children’s literature be without them? Or rather: with them. It’s always a better story when children figure things out for themselves and adults are somewhere just offstage. But times have changed since the days when a 12-year-old and her 9-year-old brother could spend a couple of nights hiding out at the Metropolitan Museum, then head by train to the Connecticut home of one Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler, pretty much eluding the entire adult world. We’re deep into the hovering era now. As evidence I offer this: Overinvolved parents —like the ones you see at the playground giving their offspring detailed instructions on how to play — have even begun storming the plots of children’s books.

headline: Google’s Street View Takes Armchair Climbers Up El Capitan
abstract: Starting Wednesday, Google Maps, using its Street View technology, will offer web users views of El Capitan from a rock climber’s perspective.
lead_paragraph: For decades, El Capitan has been the most iconic rock climbing wall in the United States, if not the world. From the first ascent by Warren Harding and others in 1958 to the Dawn Wall climb by Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson in January, 3,000-foot El Capitan has been the vertical domain of climbing pioneers.

headline: Tweets From the Courtroom: Boston Marathon Bombing Victims and Families Address Tsarnaev
abstract: Before he was given a formal death sentence on Wednesday, families of the victims gave statements, one calling his Dzhokhar Tsarnaev‘s actions “disgusting.”
lead_paragraph: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev appeared in court on Wednesday to be formally sentenced to death for his role in the Boston Marathon bombing, and victims and families of the victims were there to speak to him.

headline: How to Eat on a Budget While Traveling
abstract: The Frugal Traveler discussed the delicious topic of Eating on the Road on the Travel Facebook page.
lead_paragraph: Food and travel are inseparable these days, but how do you approach choosing a restaurant (or shack or stand or ambulant vendor) in a strange city?

headline: Harvey Pollack, Inventive Statistician in N.B.A. From Day 1, Dies at 93
abstract: Pollack, who was associated mostly with the Philadelphia 76ers, was a mastermind of N.B.A. statistical innovation dating to the league’s creation in 1946.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Pollack, who tallied everything from triple-doubles to player tattoos as the mastermind of N.B.A. statistics going back to the league’s creation in 1946, died on Tuesday in Philadelphia. Mr. Pollack, the last still-active N.B.A. team employee from that inaugural season, was 93.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s ‘All Lives Matter’ Remark Stirs Backlash

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton is facing backlash for saying that “all lives matter” in an African-American church in Missouri on Tuesday, offending some who feel that she is missing the point of the “black lives matter” mantra.

headline: New York City Escalates the War on Rats Once Again
abstract: The city budget, expected to be finalized this month, includes $2.9 million in rat money, aimed at attacking large concentrations of the creatures called rat reservoirs.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, New York City’s white whale has been the common rat.

headline: Charleston Shooting Adds to Security Fears in Places of Worship
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The massacre last week in South Carolina has heightened anxiety among clergy members and the faithful, forcing black churches in particular to grapple with their vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: As Bishop Ernest C. Morris Sr. greeted worshipers arriving for services on Sunday at Mount Airy Church of God in Christ, a woman hurried over and asked a question on the minds of many parishioners at the large black church in Philadelphia: “Bishop, Bishop, are we safe this morning?”

headline: For the South, Against the Confederacy
abstract: On the distinctive appeal of a “backwards” region.
lead_paragraph: “The American South has always been the most barbaric, backward region in any developed democracy,” Vox’s Dave Roberts tweeted in the midst of a long day of Confederate flag talk on Twitter yesterday. “Can we admit that now?”

headline: A ‘Constellation’ of Light Above the Ruins of Bannerman Castle
abstract: An installation by the artist Melissa McGill on a tiny island in the Hudson River puts twinkling lights atop 17 tall poles.
lead_paragraph: POLLEPEL ISLAND, N.Y. — As the small aluminum workboat made a wide turn in the Hudson River, the decaying ruins of Bannerman Castle came into view, a dark tangle of tumbledown brick, concrete, scrap metal and weeds that was only partly illuminated on a sunny day last month.

headline: Kids in the Kitchen: Ketchup Chicken
abstract: An 11-year old learns to cook Stir-Fried Chicken with Ketchup in the first #NYTKidsCook.
lead_paragraph: We may set academic teachings aside for the hotter months, but that doesn’t mean learning stops. Summer is a great time to convey some life skills — the kind of thing that, during the school year, gets caught up in the rush of activities, sports and homework. Turning your children into your personal chefs takes time — but it isn’t just good for you, it’s good for them.

headline: Can the Knicks Find Their Dolph Schayes in the N.B.A. Draft?
abstract: New York has had a checkered record when selecting with the No. 4 overall pick in the draft.
lead_paragraph: Knicks fans were understandably upset when a season of what sometimes seemed like intentional losing did not earn anything more than the No. 4 pick in the N.B.A. draft. But a deep dive into the team’s past draft performance holds a glimmer of hope: The Knicks once made the best No. 4 pick in N.B.A. history. The only problem is, they failed to sign him.

headline: Allies in Asia Welcome U.S. Progress on Trade Deal
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A broad agreement on a trans-Pacific pact could come as early as next month, a Japanese official said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — American allies in Asia on Wednesday welcomed a United States Senate vote that appeared to clear the way for a final round of negotiations over a sweeping trans-Pacific trade pact and may have made it easier for governments to make politically risky concessions.

headline: Men’s Cross-Body Bags Are Back
abstract: After seasons of the backpack reigning supreme, the old standby is back — but more compact and without the clunk.
lead_paragraph: After seasons of the backpack reigning supreme, the idea of wearing a cross-body bag, as seen this morning at Lemaire (above), feels fresh again. The shoulder-straining messenger bags of yesterday these are not — compact and worn close to the body (almost like a harness), they complete a look instead of feeling like a clunky accessory.

headline: 1915: Rush of Recruits on Lord Kitchener’s Birthday
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Rush of Recruits on Lord Kitchener’s Birthday in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Lord Kitchener’s sixty-fifth birthday was celebrated today throughout the United Kingdom and the British Empire by a rush of recruits to ‘‘K. of K’s Army.’’ The Minister of War, who received hundreds of cables and telegrams, not only from his own countrymen but from ‘‘kin beyond the sea,’’ in the United States, expressed himself as deeply touched, but the reports from the recruiting stations, which told of thousands joining the colors to make the day memorable, were, he said, the finest tribute he had ever received. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 25, 1915

headline: Arthur Miller’s Screenplay ‘The Hook’ Finds a Home Onstage in England
abstract: Miller wrote “The Hook,” about a young dockworker who challenges corrupt union bosses, in 1950 and took it to Hollywood. But it was never produced.
lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, ENGLAND — The setting is Red Hook, Brooklyn, in the 1950s. The protagonist is an Italian immigrant who works as a longshoreman, a tragic hero who is also a working-class Everyman. The writer is Arthur Miller.

headline: Reading About the Confederacy
abstract: Five books offer a start in wading through volumes of history on the South and the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Faced with the horrific murders in South Carolina and the ensuing debate over the appropriateness of the Confederate flag, it’s even clearer than usual that history is not a dusty book on a shelf. There has been more written about the Civil War than you could read in a lifetime, or a hundred lifetimes. But for those interested in learning more about the Confederacy — its people, its soldiers, its descendants — these five books offer a start:

lead_paragraph: KENNER, La. — Gov. Bobby Jindal, who is Louisiana’s first nonwhite governor since Reconstruction but whose popularity plummeted as the state struggled with a $1.6 billion shortfall, announced Wednesday that he is running for president in 2016.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination. The first Indian-American governor in the United States, he came to the job in 2008 after three years in Congress. He had previously been president of the nine-member University of Louisiana System and has run the state’s Department of Health and Hospitals. Here are his positions on important issues.

headline: The Work of a Sculptor Beloved by Margaret Howell and J.W. Anderson
abstract: Barbara Hepworth’s new exhibition at the Tate Britain is accompanied by a capsule collection inspired by the artist.
lead_paragraph: “She is almost always photographed wearing overalls and an anorak,” explains assistant curator Inga Fraser of the subject of a new exhibition, “Barbara Hepworth: Sculpture for the Modern World,” which opens at the Tate Britain in London this week. Though handy for stashing the pebbles she liked to gather on walks she took at dawn along her favorite Cornish beaches, Hepworth’s self-imposed workwear uniform was more than a function of practical necessity: “As a woman sculptor in the early 20th century trying to be seen on equal terms with her male counterparts, Hepworth had to put her work before everything else. She saw style as secondary.”

headline: 36 Hours in Split, Croatia
abstract: Surrounded by mountains and sea, Split has it all: Roman ruins, trendy shops and fashionable restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Split, in central Dalmatia, has it all: Roman ruins and grand museums alongside fashionable cafes and trendy shops. But what makes this city most alluring is not just its proximity to the sandy beaches and rocky coves of nearby islands, but its location overlooked by mountains and edged by the deep blue Adriatic Sea.

headline: Scandinavian Design Sets Up Shop in a Historic Hamptons Hotel — and It’s All Up for Grabs
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The boutique and site Austere and the Maidstone have teamed up to make the entire experience of staying at the inn available to buy.
lead_paragraph: “My daughter calls that ‘my daddy’s swing,'” says Fredrik Carlstrom, pointing to Alexander Lervik’s Sense Light swing, affixed to the porch of the Maidstone hotel in East Hampton. In fact, the plexi-and-LED-lit version of the playground staple neither belongs to nor was crafted by Carlstrom, even if his daughter is, as he says, “very protective of it.” Rather, it’s an extension of the retail collaboration “Austere c/o the Maidstone,” currently overtaking the historic Hamptons inn. Last year, Carlstrom, who is by trade a marketing executive, launched Austere, a multichannel retail venture focusing mostly on Scandinavian heritage brands, which has been dubbed “a magazine you can walk into.” Austere exists as both a 5,000-square-foot store in Los Angeles and an active online portal, which on top of shilling wares satisfies customers’ curiosity with an editorial component that tells the tales of these Nordic brands and the region’s cultural values. “We noticed there are people who make things, people who sell things and people who talk about cool things,” explains Carlstrom, “No one was doing all of it. And so we’re trying to do that.”

headline: In Hostage-Terrorist Policy Shift, Obama Admits Failures

abstract: The president said the United States’ policy to not pay ransoms did not mean that officials could not communicate with abductors or help in other ways to free American hostages.

headline: He’s Back: Arnold Schwarzenegger on ‘Terminator Genisys’
abstract: The former governor discusses growing older, Hollywood action heroes and getting back into shape when you’re 67.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Arnold Schwarzenegger has proved to be a skilled reinventor. An Austrian-born competitive bodybuilder, he transformed himself into an internationally loved action star (breaking through as the title character in the 1982 film “Conan the Barbarian”) and later morphed into a politician as governor of California. Since leaving office in 2010, he’s weathered a sex scandal that ended his marriage to Maria Shriver and sought a toehold back in the film industry — winking at his older tough-guy status in “The Expendables” movies, playing an embattled sheriff in “The Last Stand” and going the low-budget indie route as a grizzled dad in the recent zombie movie “Maggie.”

headline: Academy Will Not Cut Number of Best Picture Nominees
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is keeping a flexible field of as many as 10 nominees for best picture, but did make some other small changes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After much speculation about a possible return to a system that limited Oscar best picture nominees to five, from the current flexible field of as many as 10, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences decided, more or less, to stand pat.

headline: Joy Williams Liberates Herself From the Civil Wars With ‘Venus’
abstract: Ms. Williams, previously half of the Grammy-winning duo Civil Wars, discusses the band’s breakup and her new solo album.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Joy Williams took the stage in London to perform material from her new album, “Venus,” for the first time. The location was no accident; the city was where Ms. Williams’s previous band, the Grammy-winning Civil Wars, played its last show in 2012. Since that appearance, she and her partner in the country-folk duo, John Paul White, have not spoken.

headline: Glen Campbell’s Sunset Tour
abstract: “Glen Campbell: I’ll Be Me,” Sunday on CNN, follows the musician as he performs while confronting the onset of Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: “Who is that?” a befuddled Glen Campbell asks his wife, Kim, as he watches home movies of himself as a younger man. “It’s you, honey,” she says. “It’s a movie about you.” To which he replies: “No kidding? I’ll be me.”

headline: At Bryant Park, a Free Modern Dance Festival
abstract: “Bryant Park Presents Modern Dance,” which runs through July 10, features Earl Mosley’s Diversity of Dance, BARE Dance and 10 Hairy Legs this Friday.
lead_paragraph: The annoying thing about being a dance fan in the summer is that when the rest of the city occupies sidewalk cafes, conquers rooftop bars and snuggles up to sunset on a park bench, you’re slinking into a dark theater and suddenly it’s night. Happily, New York has a growing list of free outdoor options to address that problem, at the same time making dance part of a broader public conversation and providing an ideal picnic backdrop to boot. There’s the River to River festival in Lower Manhattan, which just ended; the Battery Dance Festival, returning in August; and the Hudson River Dance Festival, new this year.

headline: ‘Stray Dog,’ Debra Granik’s Portrait of a Biker With a Past
abstract: Ms. Granik has filmed a documentary about Ron Hall, a Vietnam veteran and motorcyclist she directed in “Winter’s Bone.”
lead_paragraph: “Winter’s Bone,” the 2010 film by Debra Granik, is best known as providing the breakout role for Jennifer Lawrence, whose performance in it earned her an Oscar nomination. Less attention-getting in that movie was the work of Ron Hall, a biker with no acting experience but a cool nickname: Stray Dog.

headline: Weighing the Pros and Cons for 2 Escaped Convicts to Remain Partners in Crime
abstract: Hundreds of officers and countless citizens in New York State are on the lookout for two escaped killers. When do two men become one too many?
lead_paragraph: They cut holes in the backs of their cells together. They crept through prison crawl spaces together, burrowed through a pipe and climbed out of a manhole together. Disappeared together.

headline: Shania Twain Plays New York Arenas
abstract: The country star will have concerts at Madison Square Garden and Nassau Coliseum, part of a tour she says will be her last.
lead_paragraph: The last time Shania Twain embarked on an arena tour, she had a blockbuster album and momentum — as a country star with world-beating pop ambitions and production values to match. That was in 2003, when such a thing felt less familiar. (Taylor Swift was still a couple of years shy of 15.)

headline: Five Boroughs Music Festival Features Ekmeles Ensemble
abstract: The festival’s season finale showcases works by Mathias Spahlinger, Wolfgang Rihm and Christopher Fisher-Lochhead.
lead_paragraph: Voices and brasses: It’s not a musical combination that springs immediately to mind. But it’s the subject of an intriguing program on Monday night from the vocal ensemble Ekmeles, which specializes in modern and contemporary repertory that’s heard too little.

headline: Alabama’s Confederate Flags ‘Needed to Come Down’
abstract: “This is the right thing to do,” said Alabama’s governor of removing the flags.
lead_paragraph: Alabama, home of legendary segregationists like George Wallace and Bull Connor, broke with a highly visible part of its past this morning when workers emerged from the Alabama state Capitol building in Montgomery and banished four versions of the Confederate flag from the Capitol grounds.

headline: The Friends John Singer Sargent Painted
abstract: “Sargent: Portraits of Artists and Friends,” which gives a sense of the painter’s social circle, opens Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: John Singer Sargent may be known for squandering his considerable gifts on paintings of socialites that he dashed off with nearly effortless panache, but “Sargent: Portraits of Artists and Friends,” opening Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, sets him in a different milieu than that of the merely moneyed and pedigreed. Organized by the National Portrait Gallery, London, in collaboration with the Met, the exhibition of more than 90 paintings, watercolors and drawings places Sargent in the trans-Atlantic vanguard of art and culture of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Subjects include other artists like Claude Monet and Auguste Rodin and writers like Robert Louis Stevenson and Henry James. The collector Isabella Stewart Gardner appears in a portrait that rarely leaves the Gardner Museum in Boston. The Shakespearean actress Ellen Terry is pictured performing and in a formal portrait. These and other works, which reveal Sargent in unguarded moments responding to people he loved and admired, should be a crowd-pleaser. (Through Oct. 4; 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)

headline: A Beloved Amusement Park Gets a New Life in Albany
abstract: Two local businessmen spared the rides of Hoffman’s Playland from the auction block and moved them from a booming suburb to a rarely visited part of the city.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — James Wilkinson walked through the gates of this city’s new amusement park for the first time and had the place scoped out in about a minute.

headline: Bobby Jindal Draws Out His Announcement, Family in Tow
abstract: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana is giving his presidential announcement the slow-walk treatment.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana is giving his presidential announcement the slow-walk treatment.

headline: Campaign Swag
abstract: The online stores of 2016 presidential hopefuls elevate their brands and gather data about supporters.
lead_paragraph: The online stores of 2016 presidential hopefuls elevate their brands and gather data about supporters.

headline: For Lovebirds, a Look That Is Really Quick
abstract: Lovebirds can rotate their heads up to 2,700 degrees per second, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: Lovebirds can rotate their heads up to 2,700 degrees per second, researchers report.

headline: 2nd Prison Worker Is Charged as Search for Escaped Killers in New York Continues
abstract: Gene Palmer, a corrections officer recently placed on administrative leave after the prison escape, has been arrested and charged with promoting prison contraband, the State Police said.
lead_paragraph: CADYVILLE, N.Y. — A corrections officer recently placed on administrative leave after the escape of two convicted killers from a maximum-security prison in northern New York has been arrested, the State Police said Wednesday night.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Spring 2016 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Guys, Just Let Your Curls Down
abstract: Curly locks à la Celestin Boutin in the “Death in Venice” movie have emerged as the mop of choice this season, dominating spring/summer 2016 men’s shows like Prada in Milan and, today, Valentino in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Curly locks à la Bjorn Andresen in the 1971 movie “Death in Venice” have emerged as the mop of choice this season, dominating spring/summer 2016 men’s shows like Prada in Milan and, today, Valentino in Paris. The popularity of naturally curly models like Jack Mather and Serge Rigvava has certainly reinforced the trend.

headline: Rare Klimt Portrait Brings $39 Million at Auction
abstract: The full-length “Portrait of Gertrud Loew,” painted in 1902, exceeded its high estimate at a Sotheby’s auction in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A rare full-length portrait by Gustav Klimt sold for 24.8 million pounds with fees, or about $39 million, at a Sotheby’s auction in London on Wednesday.

headline: Reviews: New Books From Sarah Hall, Mia Alvar, Katherine Taylor and Others
abstract: England, upstate New York and Manila are among the settings authors have chosen for their new novels.
lead_paragraph: THE WOLF BORDERBy Sarah Hall432 pages. Harper. $25.99.

headline: New York City Schools to Expand Breakfast Program
abstract: Under the new program, which will begin this fall and ramp up over three years, a free breakfast of protein, a grain, fruit and milk will be served in most elementary school classrooms.
lead_paragraph: Students in New York City’s public elementary schools will be served breakfast in their classrooms starting in the fall, as part of the $78.5 billion budget deal announced this week by Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito.

headline: Saudi Bombing Only Fans Yemen’s Flames
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Saudi Arabia and its allies are nearly three months into a military campaign seeking to force the retreat of Houthi rebels. So far, it has not worked.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — For nearly three months, Saudi Arabia, along with its allies, has been bombing Yemen, its southern neighbor, hoping to force the retreat of Shiite rebels who have seized major cities and to return the country’s president from the Saudi guest mansion where he lives to the presidential palace.

headline: The Many Miseries of Yemeni Families
abstract: Children are terrified by noises. Finding food is a challenge. There’s rarely power. Many people in Yemen and beyond dream of an end to the fighting.
lead_paragraph: As the civil war in Yemen continues, many families say they are living in constant fear. Parents say that their older children have been wetting their beds at night, and that younger ones are so traumatized that they are sent running for cover by the sound of a door slamming.

headline: Jim Webb Criticized for Comments on Confederate Flag
abstract: Former Senator Jim Webb, the Democrat from Virginia, has struggled to generate much excitement over his potential presidential campaign, but on Wednesday he managed to attract some attention with some curious comments about the Confederate battle flag.
lead_paragraph: Former Senator Jim Webb, the Democrat from Virginia, has struggled to generate much excitement over his potential presidential campaign, but on Wednesday he managed to attract some attention with some curious comments about the Confederate battle flag.

headline: Review: ‘Man in Profile’ Studies Joseph Mitchell of The New Yorker
abstract: Thomas Kunkel’s biography covers Mr. Mitchell’s sparkling portraits of New York’s marginal people, as well as his breaking the rules of nonfiction and an epic case of writer’s block.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in North Carolina, Joseph Mitchell was not easily bored. He spent long days in deep concentration, exploring a swamp next to his family’s farm. Mitchell was so absorbed by the natural species in his backyard that we can imagine the charge to his curiosity when, at 21, he moved to the human carnival that was Depression-era New York City to pursue a newspaper career. The move was made to the consternation of his father — he wanted his oldest boy to remain in the generations-old business of tobacco and cotton farming — but to the great betterment of American letters.

headline: A Strong Swim Team
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Bathing Suits and Swimwear']
abstract: Plus: Hand-woven totes and saddle bags make for chic summer carryalls, rainbow prints are the breakout stars of the recent resort shows and more.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Hand-woven totes and saddle bags make for chic summer carryalls, rainbow prints are the breakout stars of the recent resort shows and more.

headline: App Smart | Make the Most of Summer
abstract: Summer is short, and cramming in the most fun requires a level of organization. New apps can do some of that for you.
lead_paragraph: Summer is short, and cramming in the most fun requires a level of organization. New apps can do some of that for you.

headline: Video Feature: Apps for Summer Travel, Concerts and Grilling
abstract: Specialized apps provide help with many seasonal pursuits, including planning vacation activities, packing for a trip and even grilling the perfect steak.
lead_paragraph: Summer has arrived, with long days and warm sun tempting us to experience the outdoors and traveling. Getting the right apps for your phone and tablet can help you have a great time.

headline: Four Wounded in Upper Manhattan Shooting
abstract: Two men, 25 and 17, were hit when gunfire erupted inside the Twenty Stars Deli on 132nd Street near Madison Avenue. Outside the deli, a 43-year-old man and a 24-year-old woman were struck.
lead_paragraph: Three men and a woman were shot in and around an Upper Manhattan deli on Wednesday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Racism’s Psychological Toll
keywords: ['Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: A conversation with the psychologist Monnica Williams on racial trauma and its consequences.
lead_paragraph: Our screens and feeds are filled with news and images of black Americans dying or being brutalized. A brief and yet still-too-long list: Trayvon Martin, Tamir Rice, Walter Scott, Eric Garner, Renisha McBride. The image of a white police officer straddling a black teenager on a lawn in McKinney, Tex., had barely faded before we were forced to grapple with the racially motivated shooting in Charleston, S.C.

headline: Canvas and Verse
abstract: “I Don’t Poem” features painters’ work alongside their poetry.
lead_paragraph: When the writer Claudia La Rocco asked several visual artists if they also wrote poetry, Don Voisine told her: “I don’t poem.” That cheeky response ultimately became the title of a book La Rocco edited featuring painters’ work alongside their verse. Its contributors include Voisine, who, it turns out, does, at least on occasion, poem.

headline: Letters: The Stranger
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Kamel Daoud’s “The Mersault Investigation,” a biography of Léon Blum and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Office Interior Design on a Dorm Budget
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Workplace Environment', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: The designer Brad Sherman’s specialty is creating cozy, functional offices for start-ups, using a little budget and a lot of resourcefulness.
lead_paragraph: Step off the office elevator and you’re immediately hit with the smell: a cooking aroma, something warm and inviting (corn chowder? bread?) wafting from a spacious, open kitchen with a wall of Waterworks cabinets.

headline: Ivan Nova Returns as Yankees Avoid a Phillies Sweep
abstract: Nova allowed three hits and no runs in six and two-thirds innings in his first start since Tommy John surgery in April 2014.
lead_paragraph: Thirty minutes before the first pitch was thrown at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, the center-field scoreboard showed a preview of the matchup between the Philadelphia Phillies’ ace, Cole Hamels, and Ivan Nova, who was making his first start since April 19, 2014.

headline: ‘Being Nixon’ and ‘One Man Against the World’
abstract: Two new books try to make sense of the life and presidency of Richard Nixon.
lead_paragraph: In May, to start the final broadcast of David Letterman’s late-night show, a dimly familiar yellow-tinged 1970s video began to play. “My fellow Americans,” Gerald Ford intoned, “our long national nightmare is over.” In specially recorded messages, Presidents Bush, Clinton, Bush and Obama then recited the famous line, which Ford had first spoken just after the disgraced Richard Nixon left the White House, the only president ever to resign. No one in the Letterman bit mentioned Nixon’s name, but his specter — as it so often does in our political culture — hovered over the whole thing.

headline: Tearing Down the Confederate Flag Is Just a Start
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: I’m all for celebrating the drawing down of the flag, but now let’s pivot from symbolic moves to substantial ones.
lead_paragraph: Suppose African-Americans marked their heritage with flags depicting Nat Turner’s rebellion of 1831, in which slaves massacred about 60 whites before the uprising was crushed? The flag wouldn’t be celebrating the murder of whites, of course, but would simply commemorate a factual milestone in black history!

headline: Les Bains, a Legendary Parisian Nightclub, Brought Back to Life
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restaurants']
abstract: An ’80s and ’90s hot spot attended by the likes of Mick Jagger and Yves Saint Laurent, has been revived as a club, restaurant and hotel.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Perhaps only in Paris would a past-its-prime nightclub be brought back from dereliction. But to Parisians of a certain age, Les Bains Douches was not just any old boîte de nuit.

headline: Video Review: The McLaren 650S Spider Is a $280,000 Thrill Ride
abstract: While Lamborghini and Ferrari are entrenched in pop culture. McLaren is a lesser celebrity, but with supercars like the 650S, it could soon be a household name.
lead_paragraph: THE McLaren 650S Spider is less of an automobile than it is equal parts Gerry Judah sculpture, Space Mountain thrill ride and carbon-fiber engineering shrine. There is no need for a vehicle like this, but thank the car gods it exists, for it brings great joy to those who glimpse and drive it.

headline: Review: A Mix of Sounds at the New York City Electroacoustic Music Festival
abstract: The festival features a combination of electronics and traditional instruments in 27 concerts over eight days at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: For those who like their music extra durational, it’s a rich week in New York. The Bang on a Can Marathon provided nearly 11 eclectic hours this past Sunday, and this coming Sunday the Whitney Museum of American Art is presenting — over eight hours — Conlon Nancarrow’s complete studies for player piano.

headline: Review: ‘Dragons: Race to the Edge,’ a Dark Animated Series on Netflix
abstract: The 13-episode series, based on the “How to Train Your Dragon” stories, is fairly dark for children’s fare.
lead_paragraph: Why leave a five-year gap between the events depicted in Part 1 of your animated theatrical trilogy and the events depicted in Part 2? So you can squeeze a few television series into the empty space.

headline: Amazon Echo, a.k.a. Alexa, Is a Personal Aide in Need of Schooling
abstract: The Amazon Echo is an artificially intelligent personal assistant answering to the name Alexa. It’s not yet heavy on the “intelligent,” but could one day be useful.
lead_paragraph: THIS week, I asked a friend for help: “Alexa, can you write this review for me?”

headline: The Persistence of ACA Denialism
abstract: No, it’s not the economy.
lead_paragraph: I guess people with strong political preferences have always had a hard time accepting facts that are at odds with those prejudices; but I do also think that it has gotten worse in modern America thanks to the closed information loop of movement conservatism and the incestuous amplification it brings. You see it in things like the rise of inflation trutherism; you also see it in the inability of many on the right to accept the reality that Obamacare really has covered a lot of previously uninsured Americans.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya, Spain and Elsewhere
abstract: France, Indonesia and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France, Indonesia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Ex-Advisers Warn Obama That Iran Nuclear Deal ‘May Fall Short’ of Standards
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a letter, five former members of President Obama’s circle of Iran advisers said a pending accord to stem Iran’s nuclear program might “fall short” of administration standards.
lead_paragraph: Five former members of President Obama’s inner circle of Iran advisers have written an open letter expressing concern that a pending accord to stem Iran’s nuclear program “may fall short of meeting the administration’s own standard of a ‘good’ agreement” and laying out a series of minimum requirements that Iran must agree to in coming days for them to support a final deal.

headline: June 24, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Libya, France, Indonesia and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Libya, France, Indonesia and Spain.

headline: ‘Jacob Lawrence: The Migration Series,’ by Leah Dickerman and Elsa Smithgall
abstract: The images in Jacob Lawrence’s Migration Series are perhaps the most recognizable images of ­African-Americans in the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: One by one, the people left. Cotton sacks shed in place, a silent seepage from the fields, a human rivulet, and then a flood of six million black refugees fleeing the terrors of the Jim Crow South from World War I to 1970, an Overground Railroad that churned for nearly three generations and transformed the culture and social geography of 20th-century America. This leaderless revolution would come to be known as the Great Migration, and it would reshape every Northern and Western city it touched. By the time it was over, a rural people had become urban, and a Southern people had spread themselves over the country. Yet it was largely unrecognized, invisible to a majority of Americans while it was underway and almost too big to grasp even for those who were part of it.

headline: Viewing Held for Pinckney
abstract: Mourners viewed the body of the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney, the pastor and state senator slain at the Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Mourners viewed the body of the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney, the pastor and state senator slain at the Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., on Wednesday.

headline: A Water-Friendly Design From the Young Architect Newly Anointed by MoMA PS1
abstract: Andrés Jaque’s “Cosmo,” on view all summer at the Queens art institution’s outdoor space, integrates aquatic plants and can purify 3,000 gallons of water.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations has predicted that by 2025, two-thirds of the world will lack sufficient water supply. It was this statistic that inspired the architect Andrés Jaque to develop “Cosmo,” his design for an outdoor installation which this past February earned first place in MoMA’s 16th annual Young Architect Program. The competition’s rules stipulate that submissions must integrate a sustainability element, and as the founder of the boutique design agency Office for Political Innovation, Jaque is no stranger to using his work to catalyze discussion. “Architecture has been very iconic over the last decade, so people can recognize it easily,” Jaque says. “But I wanted to make the way we deal with water recognizable. I took this opportunity to show that making our lives compatible with other things is not necessarily a punishment, but can be something enjoyable.”

headline: Extinction Up Close:  A Rare Turtle Under Assault from Poachers
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'Biodiversity', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Invasive Species', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Turtles and Tortoises']
abstract: A population of rare turtles on an island in the Philippines is under assault from poachers.
lead_paragraph: By now, you’ve likely heard about “Accelerated modern human–induced species losses: Entering the sixth mass extinction.”

headline: Summer Resident
abstract: Where does a great white shark go this time of year? Anywhere it wants to.
lead_paragraph: Where does a great white shark go this time of year? Anywhere it wants to.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Health Panel Recommends Cautious Approach to Meningitis B Vaccine
abstract: A committee convened by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention opted to let doctors decide on the vaccine, which is new and relatively costly.
lead_paragraph: A panel of health experts stopped short of recommending that all American adolescents and young adults be vaccinated against a dangerous strain of meningitis that has caused outbreaks at Princeton University and the University of California campus in Santa Barbara, opting instead to let doctors decide whether to give the vaccine.

headline: First the Flag, Now What About the Gun?
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After the murder of nine churchgoers in Charleston, real action on gun safety still looks unlikely.
lead_paragraph: The sudden abandonment of the Confederate flag by Southern politicians has raised the question of whether the Charleston gun massacre of nine churchgoers might also prompt action on gun safety. The early answer is don’t count on it.

headline: The Oscars of Fragrance: The Perfumed Envelope, Please
keywords: ['Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries']
abstract: Puttin' on the glitz, not to mention the spritz, at the annual Fragrance Foundation Awards.
lead_paragraph: “This carpet is garbage,” muttered one of 20-odd photographers last week at the ceremonial entrance to the Fragrance Foundation Awards (long known as the FiFis, like a disobedient poodle, though that nickname is now discouraged by its public-relations team, in the interest of gravitas). Many famous people have represented scents in one capacity or another. But only a smattering can be persuaded to attend the perfume industry’s most important annual event, its ultimate prize, its Oscars.

headline: John Kasich Appeals to Iowa as He Ponders White House Bid
abstract: As he hopscotched through events in Iowa, John Kasich, the two-term governor of Ohio, sought to disarm skeptics of his late-to-the-party exploration of a second White House effort.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — “Does anybody remember me?’’ John Kasich asked Iowans on his first visit to the state since an inglorious presidential bid in 1999, when he barely made an impression before dropping out.

headline: Kenji Kawano: 40 Years with the Navajo
abstract: A Japanese photographer who only knew about Native Americans from Hollywood westerns became a dedicated chronicler of the Navajo people.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese photographer who only knew about Native Americans from Hollywood westerns became a dedicated chronicler of the Navajo people.

headline: Review: The Royal Ballet Returns to New York With ‘The Dream’
abstract: The troupe presented Frederick Ashton’s 1964 take on Shakespeare’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”
lead_paragraph: The Royal Ballet remains one of the world’s finest ballet companies. The season it’s presenting at the David H. Koch Theater — the first time in that theater, and its first visit to New York in 11 years, the city that was its second home from 1949 to 1976 — is in some ways problematic. But at the opener on Tuesday, with a performance of Frederick Ashton’s Shakespeare-fairyland “The Dream” (1964), many aspects of style brightly flooded the theater.

headline: Review: DanceBrazil Offers a Middle Passage Lesson at the Joyce Theater
abstract: The hull of a slave ship is central to “Malungos,” a work by the Brazilian choreographer Jelon Vieira.
lead_paragraph: “Malungos,” a new work by Jelon Vieira, the founder and artistic director of DanceBrazil, represents the Middle Passage, the awful transit of enslaved Africans from their homelands to settlements in the New World. In the piece, performers bid sad farewells to ancestral grounds, but then, trapped in the hull of a slaver’s ship, they rediscover the bonding force of dance. “Malungo” was a word that slaves employed to address one another, a recognition of solidarity.

headline: Pursuit of Cash Taints Promise of Gene Tests
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Medicare', 'Doctors', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: As labs and research start-ups grow, the federal government is scrutinizing their relationships with doctors, as well as their payment and billing practices.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Scott Wilson often participated in medical studies, so the one being proposed by the New Orleans laboratory Renaissance RX seemed reasonable.

headline: Tour of a Greek Factory
abstract: With Greece virtually broke, the government is looking to raise taxes on businesses to fill its financial gap.
lead_paragraph: With Greece virtually broke, the government is looking to raise taxes on businesses to fill its financial gap.

headline: Review: Colleen Focuses on Precision With Fingers and Feet
abstract: Cecile Schott, the French musician who performs as Colleen, used a treble viola da gamba to recreate songs from her recent album at SubCulture.
lead_paragraph: At SubCulture in Manhattan on Tuesday night, Cecile Schott, the French musician who performs as Colleen, was preoccupied with precision. In her hands was a treble viola da gamba, an instrument largely associated with Baroque music. At her feet, a set of loop and delay pedals. She played a bit on her instrument, captured the sound with the pedals, then used that loop as a base from which to add layers and depth.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: The Internet of Things Has Vast Economic Potential, McKinsey Report Says
abstract: A new report from McKinsey says the Internet of things could be worth $11 trillion in 2025 — or a lot less, if companies don’t figure out what to do with all the data they collect.
lead_paragraph: The economic opportunity created by the so-called Internet of things has barely been scratched, according to a report released Wednesday.

headline: Updating an Internet Radio
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computer Security', 'Ratings (Parental Guidance)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: When URLs change, there are ways to bring in the radio station streams you’re looking for.
lead_paragraph: Q. My tabletop Internet radio occasionally drops a station I’ve been listening to for many months because the station changes its address — but the URL the radio uses never gets updated. Is there an Internet radio that lets me input the new stream address instead of searching its preprogrammed database?

headline: Review: Eiko Otake Holds a Mourning Service at Rush Hour
abstract: At the new Fulton transit center in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday, Ms. Otake performed a solo, site-specific show.
lead_paragraph: A strong wind was picking up on Tuesday afternoon as the choreographer Eiko Otake drifted along one side of the new Fulton Center in Lower Manhattan. In a pale yellow robe, with paler powdered skin and a bouquet of weeds in hand, she cut a striking image at rush hour, slower and ghostlier than anything around her. Onlookers trailed her with smartphones and cameras as she approached a propped-open door. She paused to shed her sandals, as if entering someone’s home.

headline: The Knights in Central Park
abstract: Scenes from a concert by the orchestral collective.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from a concert by the orchestral collective.

headline: Review: The Knights Are Spirited in Central Park, Despite Soggy Weather
abstract: This orchestral collective’s performance opened the season of free Naumburg Orchestral Concerts in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Write-ups of summer concerts in New York parks are often as much weather reports as reviews. So be it.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales This Week in New York
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Auctions', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: H. Stern reopens, while J. Crew, Madewell and Rag & Bone hold their anticipated sample sales.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, H. Stern reopens its Fifth Avenue store after a major renovation by the São Paulo and New York architecture firm Studio Arthur Casas to coincide with the Brazilian jeweler’s 70th anniversary. headline: In China, Stomachs Turn at News of 40-Year-Old Meat Peddled by Traders
abstract: The authorities have seized nearly half a billion dollars’ worth of smuggled frozen meat this month across China, some of it dating to the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: From rat meat masquerading as lamb to tainted milk to exploding watermelons, Chinese consumers have become inured to stomach-churning food scandals. But on Tuesday, countless people were forced to ponder the benefits of vegetarianism after news reports emerged that unscrupulous meat traders had been peddling tons of beef, pork and chicken wings that in some cases had been frozen for 40 years.

Now they are jeopardizing the nuclear agreement that would benefit them and the security of the region. The agreement, under negotiation with the United States, Britain, France, Russia, China and Germany, is supposed to be completed on June 30, though a delay is now considered likely.

headline: Iran: Captive’s Family Tries New Appeal
abstract: Relatives of Amir Hekmati, the Marine veteran imprisoned in Iran for nearly four years are traveling to Vienna, where talks are being held about Iran’s nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of Amir Hekmati, the Marine veteran imprisoned in Iran for nearly four years, left their Michigan home on Wednesday for a European trip that includes a stop in Vienna, where negotiators for Iran and six world powers are trying to complete an agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program. Mr. Hekmati’s sister Sarah and her husband were accompanied on the trip by Montel Williams, the television personality and veterans-rights advocate who has helped lead a campaign calling for the release of Mr. Hekmati and other Americans held in Iran. Mr. Hekmati, 31, the American-born son of Iranian immigrants, has been held in Tehran since he was seized by security agents there in August 2011 while visiting his grandmother. He was originally convicted of espionage and sentenced to death, but the charge was later reduced to helping a hostile power, with a 10-year imprisonment. Mr. Hekmati has asserted his innocence and described himself as a political hostage of Iran.

headline: A History of Hip-Hop and Fashion, as Told by Nas
abstract: The “Illmatic” rapper shares his rules of style with T ahead of the release of his film “Fresh Dressed.”
lead_paragraph: “Your coming of age is about representing who you are, and hip-hop music contains a message — it tells a story about who you are — and what you wear is also proof of it,” says the rapper Nasir Jones, a.k.a. Nas. It was with this in mind that he and a business partner, Sacha Jenkins — both onetime Queens residents currently in their 40s — set out to provide a cinematic reminder of “the importance of something that we’d grown up around and that is still strong in pop culture — clothes, fashion or what we call ‘gear.’”

headline: Watch Adam Scott Spoil “Star Wars” for His “Overnight” Co-Star Jason Schwartzman
abstract: The real-life pals hang at a playground and discuss the fate of Jon Snow.
lead_paragraph: In “The Overnight,” Jason Schwartzman and Adam Scott play L.A. dads whose chance meeting on a playground leads to a family fun night that takes a wild turn after the kids go to bed. The film is a wry examination of the issues facing young parents: namely, the ways in which couples make new friends, and the challenge of keeping romance alive once there’s a mortgage to pay. It’s also filled with raucous twists that are best left a surprise — a fact that might disappoint Schwartzman, who cops to loving spoilers in real life. In the video above, watch as Scott responds to his co-star’s admission by putting his own creative spin on the ending to “Star Wars,” including a mysterious cameo by the brooding “Game of Thrones” heartthrob Jon Snow. (We knew he wasn’t dead!)

headline: Ed Ruscha’s Recipe for a Cactus Omelet
abstract: The artist shares how to make one of his favorite breakfast staples, which he'll be serving at Doug Aitken's "Station to Station" in London beginning this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Desert life has always been on the periphery of Ed Ruscha’s work. In 1980, the artist constructed a fake resin boulder, dubbed “Rocky II,” which he hid in the Mojave Desert, the hunt for which is the subject of an upcoming feature film by Pierre Bismuth. In that same arid vein comes Ruscha’s latest, and equally unorthodox, outing: the recipe for a cactus omelet that will be served for lunch, for five consecutive Saturdays beginning this weekend, to visitors at the Barbican Art Gallery in London. It’s his quirky contribution to fellow Californian artist Doug Aitken’s collaborative exhibition, “Station to Station: A 30 Day Happening,” which also sees a series of art yurts (and Beck) installed at the Brutalist mecca this summer.

headline: Alice Temperley’s British Country House
abstract: The designer’s rural retreat, Cricket Court, is filled with family, disco balls and an array of antique knickknacks.
lead_paragraph: Cricket Court, the country house that the British fashion designer Alice Temperley owns with her husband and business partner, Lars von Bennigsen, fully reflects both her personal style and her brand. Located down the road from the cider farm on which Temperley and her three siblings, Mary, Mathilda and Harry, grew up in the magical West Country county of Somerset, Cricket Court is the headquarters of the family’s younger generation. (Temperley’s parents, Julian and Diana, still live on the farm, and have the only commercial license in the country to make cider brandy.) Its look, like its owner’s, is borne out of the Somerset hills and romantic summer fetes — the kind of life that inspires Temperley’s floaty, lacy, feminine designs, which are worn by everyone from Beyoncé to Florence Welch to the Duchess of Cambridge.

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 A.M. (FX) FLIGHT (2012) A veteran pilot (Denzel Washington, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance) manages to land a plane — at one point flying it upside down — after catastrophe strikes during a storm in this thriller from Robert Zemeckis. But his life takes a nose-dive when an inquiry reveals his lust for drinking and drugs, and suggests that he may not have been sober during his heroic feat. “He’s high as a kite, and you may be too, lifted by the contact high that great filmmaking gives you,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “It’s no surprise that ‘Flight’ has salvation in mind. The shock is how deep Mr. Zemeckis and Mr. Washington journey into the abyss and how long they stay there. It can be tough for stars to play such unrepentantly compromised characters, as Mr. Washington does brilliantly here.” And while “you can’t take your eyes off Mr. Washington,” who so normally excels at square-jaw decency, “this time you watch him with agony rather than just admiration.”

abstract: Now that the New York police commissioner and the mayor are finally on the same page, it’s time to deliver on what the city needs.
lead_paragraph: Stop the music — New York City’s budget dance is over, after a surprising final pirouette and bow from Mayor Bill de Blasio. In a deal announced Monday night, he gave in to the City Council and Police Commissioner William Bratton and agreed to expand the police force by 1,300 officers. A thousand will be used to bolster the force and introduce a new model of neighborhood policing, and 300 will form a new counterterrorism team.

headline: Who’s Speaking Up for the American Worker?
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: As the T.P.P. moves through Congress, factory workers whose jobs have vanished don’t know who’s looking out for them.
lead_paragraph: ROCKY MOUNT, Va. — A WOMAN came up to the book-signing table at an event at my local library Monday night. She did not have a copy of the newly released paperback of “Factory Man,” my book about what happened when 300,000 American furniture-making jobs were offshored to Asia.

headline: Test Your Grammar | A Review of the Movie ‘Dope’
abstract: This edition of Test Yourself, another experiment, asks students to revise sentences to correct errors.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been experimenting a bit this week with new formats for Test Yourself. On June 22 we tried out a punctuation quiz, and on June 23 a verb-tenses quiz.

lead_paragraph: TransUnion, one of the largest consumer credit reporting agencies in the United States, said on Thursday that its initial public offering was priced at $22.50 a share, valuing the company at about $4 billion.

headline: Insurance Subsidies Remain, but So Do Health Law Questions
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: They appear to have drawn substantial numbers of younger, healthier people into the new insurance markets, stabilizing premiums, even for those who pay the full cost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Affordable Care Act, saved by the Supreme Court for the second time in three years, has changed the fabric of health care in America, providing treatment and coverage to millions of the uninsured while transforming the insurance and hospital industries. But the law still faces stiff political resistance in many quarters and could yet return as an explosive issue in the 2016 elections.

headline: Despite Assurances, Bulgaria Fears a Spillover of Troubles From Greece
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Nobody knows what destructive forces could be unleashed if Greece fails to resolve its crisis, and Bulgaria — home to several Greek-owned banks — has much to lose.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — When Greece looked as if it might default on its debts early this year, Nikolay Stoyanov, a Bulgarian financial journalist, decided he had had enough of “Greek madness.” So he withdrew his modest savings from one of four big Greek-owned banks that do business in Bulgaria and moved it to his wife’s account at a German-owned lender.

headline: Cameron Payne, a Midmajor Player, Rises Above Snubs and Bigger Names
abstract: Payne, a spindly point guard from Murray State, was the fourteenth pick in the first round of the draft, higher than some players who once were rated far above him.
lead_paragraph: In the age of analytics and scouting services that leave no rock unturned, flying under the radar is difficult.

headline: Fran Fraschilla of ESPN Speaks Only English, but He’s Fluent in Foreign Scouting
abstract: Fraschilla traveled an unlikely path to become ESPN’s go-to source of information on international basketball prospects during the N.B.A draft.
lead_paragraph: Fran Fraschilla is not quite sure why ESPN tabbed him, in 2004, to become the network’s go-to source for information on international basketball prospects. But he has embraced that role.

keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Apologies', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Shigehisa Takada, the head of the Japanese auto supplier, offered his first public apology for the defective airbags that have killed at least eight.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For the first time since a crisis erupted over deadly defects in airbags made by his family’s company, the reclusive chief executive of the Japanese supplier Takata publicly addressed the issue on Thursday. He offered an apology but defended Takata’s products as fundamentally safe.

abstract: “DailyMailTV,” which is set to begin next year, will draw from the tabloid website’s content. Dr. McGraw may appear on the show periodically.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — Dr. Phil McGraw, the host of the daytime talk show “Dr. Phil,” is teaming up with the tabloid website DailyMail.com on a syndicated television show that will draw from the site’s celebrity-news-focused content.

headline: The Joy of (Just the Right Amount of) Sex
abstract: Sex makes people happy, but more isn’t always better.
lead_paragraph: Researchers long ago established a link between having sex and feeling pleased with yourself and the world. In a representative recent study of 1,000 women, for example, the participants ranked sex as No.1 among the activities that made them the happiest. Data from 16,000 American adults on incomes, sexual activity and happiness led economists to conclude in a much-­discussed 2004 study that increasing the frequency of intercourse from once a month to once a week increased happiness to the same extent as having an additional $50,000 in the bank.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The fashion brigade has arrived in Paris. Milan, the third leg of the European men’s wear tour came to a close on Tuesday, with one last major celebrity sighting to prick up your Instagram. Yes, that was Robert De Niro sitting front row at Giorgio Armani. Why? Who knows. Perhaps the operative question should be, Why not?

headline: Bonding Over Brain Surgery
abstract: When he talked about his work, I knew it meant he was giving me a window into his secret world.
lead_paragraph: My parents’ bedroom in my childhood home doubled as my dad’s neurosurgical haven, and it offered a glimpse into his work as a brain surgeon in the 1980s and ’90s. Various-size real human and primate skulls (available to medical students in the early 1970s), brain models and endless books surrounded their bedroom furniture. My mother, an artist, fed his passion and likened the room to his studio space, understanding that her husband’s true gallery was the operating room.

headline: Today in Politics: Obama Prepares to Speak Again in Wake of Violence
abstract: President Obama has a long-sought trade deal waiting to be signed in Washington, the city where Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has officially declared that he wants to move.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where President Obama has a long-sought trade deal waiting to be signed and to where Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has officially declared that he wants to move. But Mr. Obama’s focus now is on a landmark church in Charleston, S.C., and on the eulogy he has to give on Friday for a friend who was shot and killed along with eight others.

headline: Hotel Review: The Brice in Savannah
abstract: From the sunny yellow awnings to the unfailingly friendly bellhops, the hotel delivers a fresh and cheerful interpretation of Southern hospitality.

keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
