lead_paragraph: Who doesn’t remember a first love? Particularly when it’s forbidden. That moment is captured in this Op-Doc video about Tom Clark, who chronicles his love affair as a young, gay Mormon missionary in 1974.

headline: The Terror
abstract: It took years to get over a middle-school beat-down.
lead_paragraph: I got jumped at a pretty bad time in my life. Not that there’s ever a good time.

headline: ‘I Don’t Believe in God, but I Believe in Lithium’
abstract: My 20-year struggle with bipolar disorder.
lead_paragraph: The manila folder is full of faded faxes. The top sheet contains a brief description of my first medically confirmed manic episode, more than 20 years ago, when I was admitted as a teenager to U.C.L.A.’s Neuropsychiatric Institute: “Increased psychomotor rate, decreased need for sleep (about two to three hours a night), racing thoughts and paranoid ideation regarding her parents following her and watching her, as well as taping the phone calls that she was making.”

headline: Law and Symbolism at the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Censorship']
abstract: After upholding Texas’ right to reject a Confederate flag on its license plates, will the court now return to its dismantling of civil rights laws?
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday morning, as the country was just beginning to absorb the horror of mass murder at the Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., the Supreme Court handed down a decision that looked more relevant than it would have a day earlier. The subject was the Confederate flag.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Alternative Search Engines
abstract: Want to find what you didn’t know you were looking for? Don’t go to Google.
lead_paragraph: The moment Google announced it was letting users download their entire search histories, I clicked — and downloaded a cache of 128,948 searches, the sum total of my last 12 years, five months, one week and three days online. I fully expected to be reminded of those repeated requests for ‘‘Finnish gymnastics’’ and ‘‘comorbidity of insomnia and brain lesioning,’’ but what surprised me was how regularly I searched for other search engines: ‘‘alternative search engines,’’ ‘‘alt search engines,’’ ‘‘search engines that aren’t Google,’’ ‘‘search engines better than Google.’’

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Taxation', 'Value-Added Tax', 'Venture Capital']

That makes it likely that the Greek debt crisis will dominate a summit meeting of all 28 European Union leaders that will begin later on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Breaking Greece
abstract: What do the creditors think they’re doing?
lead_paragraph: I’ve been staying fairly quiet on Greece, not wanting to shout Grexit in a crowded theater. But given reports from the negotiations in Brussels, something must be said — namely, what do the creditors, and in particular the IMF, think they’re doing?

headline: The U.N.’s Gaza Report Is Flawed and Dangerous
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: A United Nations report on last summer’s Gaza war misses its target.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — AS a British officer who had more than his share of fighting in Afghanistan, Iraq and the Balkans, it pains me greatly to see words and actions from the United Nations that can only provoke further violence and loss of life. The United Nations Human Rights Council report on last summer’s conflict in Gaza, prepared by Judge Mary McGowan Davis, and published on Monday, will do just that.

headline: Why Honduras’s Judiciary Is Its Most Dangerous Branch
abstract: Honduras once had one of the world’s strictest presidential term limits. Thanks to its own Supreme Court, now it has none.
lead_paragraph: In April, Honduras’s Supreme Court invalidated the country’s rigid presidential term limit — and drastically undermined its Constitution.

headline: In Charleston Funerals, Remembering Victims of Hate as Symbols of Love
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: For a region grieving since a gunman killed nine people in a church last week, a new phase of mourning began Thursday, with the first two victims’ funerals.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — In life, they did not mingle with the powerful, leading modest lives centered on family and church. In death, the powerful turned out Thursday, along with the people who knew Ethel Lance and Sharonda Coleman-Singleton best, to celebrate a different kind of power they wielded.

headline: Fined for Having Baby, Unwed Couple Ask Chinese Public to Pitch In
abstract: Shen Bolun and Wu Xia, who are not married, celebrated the smooth delivery of a healthy girl in Beijing on Sunday, but it came at a price: A government fine of about $7,200.
lead_paragraph: Shen Bolun and Wu Xia, who are not married, celebrated the smooth delivery of a healthy girl in Beijing on Sunday. But the joyous event came with a price tag: a government fine.

headline: For a Child with a Learning Disability, There’s Such a Thing As Too Much Help
abstract: A full-time aide seemed like the perfect solution for my son — until he came to rely on her aid far too much.
lead_paragraph: As a kindergartner in a large public school, my son, who has a language-based learning disability, was mainstreamed in a general education classroom and shadowed throughout the day by an aide, or paraprofessional. We requested this additional support so my son could manage basic 5-year-old tasks that proved difficult for him. Being asked to line up with his classmates for recess, for example, wasn’t easy for my son. Although he heard the words, he didn’t necessarily understand their meaning straightaway. He needed time to process the information, then to respond. But in a school where academic rigor began on day one, there was no flextime for my son, who sauntered through his days with unhurried ease.

headline: Sally Mann: By the Book
abstract: The photographer and author of “Hold Still: A Memoir With Photographs” says her favorite novelist is Nabokov. “But wait — here comes Herman Melville in the homestretch. I think it’s a dead heat.”
lead_paragraph: The photographer and author of “Hold Still: A Memoir With Photographs” says her favorite novelist is Nabokov. “But wait — here comes Herman Melville in the homestretch. I think it’s a dead heat.”

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Check-check. One two-two-two-two-two. Hello hello hello.”

headline: She’ll Play the Jewish Mother, and Wants Other Asian-Americans to Get the Best Parts, Too
abstract: As the National Asian American Theater Company readies a revival of “Awake and Sing!,” a founder talks about the casting barriers her troupe is trying to surmount.
lead_paragraph: When the actress Mia Katigbak was a student at Barnard College in the 1970s, she was the only Asian-American studying theater and mostly got to play “maids and hookers,” she said. One day the department head asked her to join a Molière comedy. She would play the harpsichord from behind a screen, Ms. Katigbak recalls his saying, “because there were no Asians in France at that time.”

headline: Why Late First-Round N.B.A. Draft Picks Are a Bargain
abstract: The talent gap between top picks and later picks is smaller than the gap in their salaries, giving teams a strategic opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Rudy Gobert is still mad about where he was picked in the 2013 N.B.A. draft, and he has a point.

headline: Dreams in Plastic and Canvas at the Serpentine Gallery in London
abstract: The Serpentine Gallery unveils its latest pavilion, and looks to the future.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Every summer here since 2000, a temporary pavilion pops up on the front lawn of the Serpentine Gallery in Kensington Gardens. The structure — which is open to the public for more than three months — is one of the world’s top architectural commissions in terms of public exposure. Made of materials that might include wood, cork or canvas, it plays host to the gallery’s annual fundraising party and gives an internationally recognized architecture firm the chance to show its first work in Britain.

headline: China Aims to Move Beijing Government Out of City’s Crowded Core

abstract: The move is a recognition, urban planners and historians say, that the existing strategy has created ever-worsening traffic problems, and widespread destruction of Beijing’s monumental old city.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For more than 65 years, government officials here have tried to emulate China’s imperial rulers, working and living in the city center near the emperor’s old palace, the Forbidden City.

headline: Greece No Closer to a Deal as Debt Deadline Nears
abstract: For the fourth time in a week, a meeting of eurozone finance ministers ended without a resolution for Greece, which needs fresh funding.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With Greece’s bailout set to expire at the end of the month, it is becoming clear that negotiators mean to go down to the wire. The brinkmanship brings with it the risks of reaching no agreement at all, or a last-minute deal that might do little to solve Greece’s underlying economic problems.

abstract: The country’s government on Thursday sought to assure would-be contributors that the funds would be used effectively.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — As foreign donors and agencies pledged more than $3 billion in aid for Nepal on Thursday to support its post-earthquake reconstruction, the government sought to assure would-be contributors that the funds would be used effectively.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Ted 2’
abstract: Seth MacFarlane narrates the opening credit sequence from “Ted 2.”
lead_paragraph: Seth MacFarlane narrates the opening credit sequence from “Ted 2.”

headline: A Token of Affection With a Manhattan View
abstract: Robert Moyer wanted to surprise his wife with a pied-à-terre in New York. He found a rental near the High Line.
lead_paragraph: Cathy Lee loves surprises. So for her 50th birthday, her husband, Robert Moyer, surprised her with a railway trip on the Orient Express, from Venice to Budapest to London.

headline: ‘Playing to the Gallery,’ by Grayson Perry
abstract: Grayson Perry attempts to illuminate the complicated contradictions of modern art and the world of dealers, collectors and tastemakers that surrounds it.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, Britain suddenly developed a hugely popular appreciation for contemporary art, and the potter Grayson Perry has been one of its beneficiaries. Known for making vessels covered with erotic imagery and texts that address subjects like sex, war and child abuse, he’s the master of what the British magazine Ceramic Review once termed “shock art on a pot.” Perry’s frank-talking, cross-dressing persona only adds to his appeal: A long-married father of one, he speaks in a strong London accent and delights in appearing in women’s makeup and clothing.

headline: ‘Cy Twombly: Late Paintings 2003-2011,’ by Nela Pavlouskova
abstract: Cy Twombly’s last paintings celebrate his lifelong interest in flowers, Greek mythology, ships and the sea, and lines of enigmatic writing.
lead_paragraph: Painters in their old age present an interesting spectrum. André Derain and Giorgio de Chirico, who had been so shocking, drifted off after World War I in a conservative, neoclassical direction (De Chirico even faked his trademark earlier metaphysical paintings from time to time). Titian did some of his greatest work into his 80s; Jasper Johns continues to hold his own as a master. De Kooning painted despite dementia, with contested results.

headline: A Day With the Man Who Brings Museum Works to City Walls
abstract: Julien de Casabianca has hit the streets of over 17 cities with art that he photographed, printed in large proportions and then pasted onto whatever surfaces move him.
lead_paragraph: In 1877, William-Adolphe Bouguereau painted “Le Jeunesse et l’Amour,” a sensuous nude shouldering a playful angel, a work now hanging on the main level of the Musée d’Orsay. In early June, Julien de Casabianca pasted an oversize simulacrum of the figures on the wall of a nondescript building in the 18th Arrondissement. The wall just so happened to be between two food distribution businesses run by Muslim men. “I asked if it bothered him and he said no,” said de Casabianca, referring to one of the owners. “I often ask for their thoughts. It’s always a discussion. This time, one of the employees said, ‘Yeah, it’s a bit shocking.’ But then, voilà, it becomes a discussion about art. ”

headline: ‘Ted 2’ (With Movie Trailer): Seth MacFarlane Narrates a Scene
abstract: The director discusses the opening credits sequence.
lead_paragraph: Ted hasn’t quite cleaned up his act in this sequel. But the foulmouthed teddy bear has more pizazz than ever in the opening credits sequence for “Ted 2.”

headline: Search for Confederate Symbols Finds Them Aplenty in Washington
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The push to remove Confederate symbols is gaining momentum, and there are few places where those symbols are in more abundance than at the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just outside a dining room where senators gather for lunch hangs a large painting of John C. Calhoun, the 19th-century South Carolina statesman who once called slavery “indispensable to the peace and happiness” of Americans.

lead_paragraph: The media conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp said on Thursday that it planned to pursue an initial public offering for its online dating business, the Match Group.

headline: Clashes Erupt Across France as Taxi Drivers Protest Uber
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Strikes', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones', 'Chauffeurs and Drivers']
abstract: The anger is the latest in a series of challenges facing the service, which the taxi drivers contend creates unfair competition and operates outside French law.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Irate taxi drivers blocked roads, burned tires and attacked drivers who they thought were working for Uber, the ride-hailing company, during a day of protests Thursday that disrupted Paris and slowed traffic to a crawl.

headline: Daily Report: Hype Mingles With Promise in Gene Test
abstract: As labs and research start-ups grow, the federal government is scrutinizing their relationships with doctors, as well as their payment and billing practices.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Scott Wilson often participated in medical studies, so the one being proposed by the New Orleans laboratory Renaissance RX seemed reasonable, Reed Abelson and Julie Creswell write.

headline: Roger Ailes Signs New Contract to Head Fox News and Stations
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The move follows the announcement by 21st Century Fox that Mr. Ailes will report directly to Rupert Murdoch’s sons as they move into new roles.
lead_paragraph: Roger Ailes, the creator of the Fox News Channel, has signed a new multiyear contract as chairman and chief executive of Fox News and Fox Business Network and chairman of Fox Television Stations.

headline: Death Toll From Heat Wave in Karachi, Pakistan, Hits 1,000
abstract: Searing temperatures, which have been as high as 113 degrees, were below 100 on Thursday, but a sense of panic and crisis persisted in the city.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — The death toll reached 1,000 on Thursday in this southern port city as residents grappled with a devastating heat wave that has crippled life and overwhelmed the health care system.

headline: Can an Algorithm Hire Better Than a Human?
abstract: Start-ups say they can eliminate biases and create more skilled and diverse workplaces, but data science will probably need human supervision.
lead_paragraph: Hiring and recruiting might seem like some of the least likely jobs to be automated. The whole process seems to need human skills that computers lack, like making conversation and reading social cues.

headline: French Cabbies March Against Uber
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Taxi drivers on Thursday blocked access to major airports and train stations in Paris to protest Uber, an American ride-sharing app that has been accused of creating unfair competition.
lead_paragraph: Taxi drivers on Thursday blocked access to major airports and train stations in Paris to protest Uber, an American ride-sharing app that has been accused of creating unfair competition.

headline: ‘New Objectivity’ and ‘Max Beckmann: The Still Lifes’
abstract: Amid the turmoil that followed the Great War, German artists set out to create a new society.
lead_paragraph: With Germany in political turmoil at the end of the Great War, a group of hard-edge, realistic painters merged with a band of uninhibited Post-Expressionists in order to do nothing less than put an end to the old social order. These radical artists, who also included photographers, called themselves the November Group, inspired by the November Revolution of 1918, which brought about the Weimar Republic, Germany’s first democracy. Somehow they were confident that merely by rejecting the sentimentality of prewar German Expressionism, and substituting a more realistic, sober view of the life around them, they could not only bring about a new society, but usher in a “new man.”

headline: ‘The Contemporaries,’ ‘Painting Now’ and More
abstract: Holland Cotter reviews four new books about the 21st-century art world.
lead_paragraph: Everyone says the art world has changed, which is true, though your view of how, and how much, will depend on your entry point. Mine was long ago, in the early 1970s, when New York City was utterly unlike the High Line town of today. It was on the verge of bankruptcy. Physically, Manhattan was unraveling at the seams, and “urban renewal” had trashed vast stretches of the other boroughs, leaving working-class residents, many of them new immigrants, marooned.

headline: ‘Master Thieves’ and ‘The Art of the Con’
abstract: New books about the theft and forgery of artworks.
lead_paragraph: On March 18, 1990, at 1:20 in the ­morning, two men dressed in police uniforms demanded entrance to the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. When the guard at the front desk complied, they bound him and his partner in handcuffs. “This is a robbery,” the intruders announced. “Don’t give us any problems, and you won’t get hurt.” The senior guard was quick to respond. “Don’t worry,” he said. “They don’t pay me enough to get hurt.”

headline: ‘Mark Rothko: Toward the Light in the Chapel,’ by Annie Cohen-Solal
abstract: Annie Cohen-Solal argues that Rothko’s Jewishness is at the core of his life and art.
lead_paragraph: The contribution of Jewish writers, musicians, movie directors and art critics from Eastern Europe to American cultural life in the 20th century is undeniable and has been copiously documented. Jewish artists, however, have largely escaped this scrutiny. Perhaps this is strictly owing to a scarcity of significant figures until the rise of abstraction in the second half of the century, which occurred, first and foremost, because of Judaism’s notorious aniconism and its vexed relationship with art.

headline: ‘Marilyn Minter: Pretty/Dirty’
abstract: Marilyn Minter’s body of work is playful, nasty and full of surprise, and interested in confusing our networks of disgust and desire.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Minter is partial to spit, ­spatter and redheads. Hers is a “Black Mass brand of femininity,” in the words of the poet Eileen Myles, and she’s become best known for candy-colored shots of dirty feet in designer heels, puffy pubic hair, navels ringed with beads of sweat; paintings and photographs that blur high art and high fashion, photorealism and abstraction. It’s a body of work that’s playful and nasty and full of surprise.

headline: Montmartre/Montparnasse
abstract: Deborah Solomon on two new books that offer group portraits of the Paris art scene in its heyday.
lead_paragraph: Today, when the art world can seem like a subdivision of the investment banking business, it is easy to romanticize Paris in the early 1900s. When you think of the beginnings of modern art, you think back to a golden age of creativity, a time when every waking moment, it seemed, was ­devoted to painting and poetry and the carnal pleasures of the bohemian life.

headline: ‘Trompe L’Oeil,’ by Nancy Reisman
abstract: In Nancy Reisman’s new novel, a family is irrevocably changed when a child dies in a tragic accident.
lead_paragraph: Genuinely satisfying, heart-shaking novels combine an absolute narrative authority with an apparently effortless style. You question nothing, savor every phrase and nuance, live willingly within their pages from the first word to the last. They can also be slippery things: impossible to wrap up or pin down. Just read it, you urge the uninitiated, already envying them the experience to come.

headline: ‘Lynette Yiadom-Boakye’
abstract: Yiadom-Boakye’s paintings, which feature invented characters, summon the triumphs and its omissions of the genre of portraiture.
lead_paragraph: The figures who inhabit Lynette Yiadom-Boakye’s paintings reveal little of themselves. Seen mostly alone, sometimes interacting in pairs or small groups, they pose in bare grounds composed of loose brush strokes that turn emptiness into imminence. Her work taps a deep well in Western painting, recalling expressive devices in classic portraits by Velázquez, Manet and Degas, with one big difference: Nearly every one of Yiadom-Boakye’s characters is black. They are also entirely fictional, inventions of a British artist whose canny deployment of the genre of portraiture summons both its triumphs and its omissions.

headline: Obama Tells Heckler: ‘Shame on You’
abstract: The president responded to an activist who interrupted his speech on Wednesday at a White House event celebrating L.G.B.T. Pride Month.
lead_paragraph: The president responded to an activist who interrupted his speech on Wednesday at a White House event celebrating L.G.B.T. Pride Month.

headline: Lost and Founds Overflow at the End of the School Year
abstract: A single shoe. Underwear. By each June, as teachers and students prepare for summer, the detritus of the school year can reach impressive heights.
lead_paragraph: A tall seventh grader named Azalea Kelley stood in a Harlem classroom last week, surrounded by an explosion of fabric, footwear and the occasional piece of sports equipment, spilling from a clutch of plastic bins. As part of an after-school program, she and a dozen other students were ankle deep in the school’s lost and found, sorting it so that the spoils could be donated to a local church and a family shelter.

headline: New York Prison Escapee Traded Art for Favors From a Guard
abstract: Gene Palmer, an officer at Clinton Correctional Facility, described giving Richard Matt a screwdriver and pliers in exchange for a dozen elaborate paintings by the inmate.
lead_paragraph: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y. — The two convicted killers who broke out of a maximum-security prison in northern New York this month made their escape using rudimentary electrical and engineering skills, stealth and a canny ability to manipulate members of the prison staff.

headline: Review: E. L. James’s ‘Grey’ Goes Inside His Brain, and, Yes, His Pants
abstract: E. L. James continues to mine the “Fifty Shades of Grey” franchise, delivering the same story that is in the first book, but from Christian Grey’s point of view.
lead_paragraph: Condolences to the 1.1 million people who rushed out to buy E. L. James’s “Grey” in the first four days after its United States publication. All you got was a rehash of “Fifty Shades of Grey,” the first grand-slam effort by the same author (word used advisedly) to turn soft-core bondage porn into an e-book bonanza.

headline: Sara Mearns, in Her Prime at City Ballet, Inspires Debate and Awe
abstract: Ms. Mearns is probably the most talked-about ballerina in America and possibly the most argued-about ballerina anywhere.
lead_paragraph: The ballerina Sara Mearns, now 29, has entered her prime. She has surely become the most Dionysiac artist in an Apollonian genre, very probably the most talked-of ballerina in America and quite possibly the most argued-about ballerina anywhere.

headline: With Beijing’s Voting Plan Dead, Hong Kong Looks for Way Forward
abstract: A week after rejection of a proposal that would have let the public elect the top leader, the second-guessing, maneuvering and recriminations have begun.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In a meeting with Hong Kong’s pro-democratic legislators a few weeks ago, a group of European diplomats urged them to support something they had campaigned against for months: a plan, backed by Beijing, to let the public elect Hong Kong’s top official.

headline: ‘Vanishing,’ by Gerard Woodward
abstract: The narrator of Gerard Woodward’s novel is an enigmatic and eccentric artist employed by the British Army to help with camouflage during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Forget a “likable” character. Forget even mildly appealing. “Vanishing” is a book that sets out to destroy your sympathies for its narrator. This shape-shifting man is a baby and a bully, a liar and a layabout, a tease and a tormentor. He might even be a spy — unless, of course, he’s just woefully, dramatically misunderstood.

headline: Takata Chief Apologizes for Airbag Issue
abstract: Shigehisa Takada, chief executive of Takata, publicly addressed the company’s airbag defect issues for the first time on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Shigehisa Takada, chief executive of Takata, publicly addressed the company’s airbag defect issues for the first time on Thursday.

headline: ‘Listening to Stone: The Art and Life of Isamu Noguchi’
abstract: A biography of the great border-crossing sculptor.
lead_paragraph: The art of biography is not unlike the creation of sculpture. Out of a raw material of artifact and anecdote must emerge the semblance of living form. There may be no one right way to animate such matter. Certainly, there are plenty of wrongs: from hazy abstraction to overwrought realism, from misapplied attention to mannered application. Whatever the approach, however, the spirit of the subject must somehow guide the telling. For Isamu Noguchi, the great border-crossing sculptor of the last century, the art came, he said, from tapping into “the materiality of stone, its essence, to reveal its identity — not what might be imposed but something closer to its being.” The genius of “Listening to Stone: The Art and Life of Isamu Noguchi” is how its author, Hayden Herrera, inhabits the sculpturing hand of its subject. Rather than focus on the surface, Herrera gets “beneath the skin,” as Noguchi would say, to the “brilliance of matter.”

headline: Myanmar’s Military Uses Political Force to Block Constitutional Changes
abstract: The military, which controls a quarter of the seats, voted against a bill rescinding its veto power and refused to ease a rule that helps prevent the opposition leader from becoming president.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Myanmar’s military flexed its muscle on Thursday, blocking moves to rescind its veto power in Parliament and refusing to ease a rule that helps prevent Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader and Nobel laureate, from eventually becoming president.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Nationwide Health Care Subsidies
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Affirming a key element of the health care law, the justices ruled that it may provide nationwide tax subsidies to help poor and middle-class people buy insurance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that President Obama’s health care law allows the federal government to provide nationwide tax subsidies to help poor and middle-class people buy health insurance, a sweeping vindication that endorsed the larger purpose of Mr. Obama’s signature legislative achievement.

headline: The Future of Car Keys? Smartphone Apps, Maybe
abstract: Apps are increasingly performing the functions of keys, but experts say there are still kinks to be worked out before, and if, physical keys become extinct.
lead_paragraph: IT’S not fun getting into a car when the interior is 130 degrees, but that’s a typical problem during the summer for those who live in a city like Phoenix, where outside temperatures can regularly soar well past 100.

headline: A Reporter Obsessed: Seeing The Triangle From All Sides
abstract: Why did the Sports section run thousands of words dedicated to basketball’s triangle offense? Jason Stallman, the editor of the Sports desk, explains.
lead_paragraph: In late October, as Phil Jackson was about to begin his first season running the Knicks, Scott Cacciola, a reporter for the Sports desk, wrote a piece for us about how the team would deploy Jackson’s preferred method of putting the ball in the basket: the triangle offense. (Knicks fans groaned.) Scott’s article mentioned that the system was outlined in all its glory in 1962 by its creator, Tex Winter, in a 228-page book called “The Triple-Post Offense.” I absolutely did not want to read that thing, but I did like the idea of paying someone else to read it.

headline: On the Grid: Two New Books About Agnes Martin
abstract: Evasive and self-contradictory in person, Agnes Martin put all of herself into her work.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, a University of Pennsylvania undergraduate named Nancy Princenthal wrote to the artist Agnes Martin seeking information for an art history paper. Martin had spent the better part of the 1960s working in and around Coenties Slip in Lower Manhattan, inching out fine-gauge grids on paper or canvas. Up close, her work is all specificity: graphite and oil perhaps, line and rectangle, not quite perfect, again and again. Three steps back, it’s a barely-there perceptual field, luminous, ascetic and devoid of the subjective “I.”

headline: Burundi Students Enter U.S. Embassy as Political Tensions Escalate
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Scores of students, seeking refuge from the police, entered the safety of the U.S. Embassy complex.
lead_paragraph: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — Scores of students crawled under the gates and scaled the walls protecting the United States Embassy complex here on Thursday in a desperate attempt to escape from the local police, who had moved in to clear their street encampment and clamp down on antigovernment protests.

headline: ISIS Attacks Two Towns in Northern Syria
abstract: Islamic State militants set off car bombs in Kobani, where they had been driven out before by Kurdish guerrillas, and attacked the government-held city of Hasaka.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The militants of the Islamic State carried out two new offensives in northern Syria on Thursday, entering a provincial capital and detonating large bombs in the border town of Kobani, where intensive airstrikes by a United States-led coalition helped Kurdish forces rout the jihadists last year.

headline: Complaint Against Gene Palmer
abstract: Gene Palmer is accused of giving a screwdriver and pliers to at least one inmate in Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., and of burning paintings he received from the two inmates who escaped from the prison.
lead_paragraph: Gene Palmer is accused of giving a screwdriver and pliers to at least one inmate in Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., and of burning paintings he received from the two inmates who escaped from the prison.

headline: Regicide Relief
abstract: King goes down.
lead_paragraph: Update: Just to put this out there, and let my 60s roots show: Hey, hey, ACA, how many lives did you save today?

headline: ‘Destruction Was My Beatrice: Dada and the Unmaking of the Twentieth Century’
abstract: Jed Rasula uncovers why Dada didn’t expire along with the isms it either spawned or incorporated.
lead_paragraph: Jed Rasula’s history of Dada, “Destruction Was My Beatrice,” dispenses with a few old chestnuts of art history, chief among them the chronological fixation on Dada as a precursor to Surrealism, or a younger sibling of Futurism. The ordering by art critics of 20th-century avant-garde movements has required that they be both recognizable and dead. This has made them convenient and marketable, while draining away their revolutionary content. The art market embraced the products of every “ism” as soon as it recognized its distinct style. The only avant-garde that escaped the zombie line is Dada.

headline: Pan-Roasted Dogfish With White Whine and Garden Vegetables
abstract: Chef Joseph Realmuto of Nick & Toni’s in East Hampton demonstrates how to cook the local catch.
lead_paragraph: Chef Joseph Realmuto of Nick & Toni’s in East Hampton demonstrates how to cook the local catch.

abstract: “We should start calling this law Scotuscare.” — Justice Antonin Scalia, in his dissenting opinion on the Affordable Care Act subsidies case.
lead_paragraph: — Justice Antonin Scalia, in his dissenting opinion on the Affordable Care Act subsidies case decided at the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Mario Biaggi, 97, Popular Bronx Congressman Who Went to Prison, Dies
abstract: Mr. Biaggi had been a highly decorated police officer and a popular House member when he fell from grace in corruption scandals.
lead_paragraph: Mario Biaggi, a highly decorated former New York City police officer who became a popular 10-term Democratic congressman from the Bronx only to land in prison in a wave of corruption scandals in the late 1980s, died on Wednesday at his home in the Bronx. He was 97.

headline: Review: In ‘Ted 2,’ the Foulmouthed Bear Tries to Prove He’s Human
abstract: In a quest to be a husband and father, the character voiced by Seth MacFarlane aligns his struggle with that of enslaved black Americans.
lead_paragraph: At one point in the comedy dead zone known as Seth MacFarlane’s “Ted 2,” the title character — a stuffed toy bear voiced by Mr. MacFarlane — and his dimwitted best friend, John (Mark Wahlberg), visit a comedy club to engage in a favorite pastime: throwing bleak improv ideas at the comics onstage. So, seated in the back of the auditorium while cloaked in darkness, the friends start shouting out suggestions like 9/11, Robin Williams and Charlie Hebdo to the unnerved comics. The topics don’t mean anything to Ted and John, who, like Mr. MacFarlane, take great pleasure in making others squirm. They could have just as easily yelled gang rape, the Holocaust and dead puppies.

headline: Obamacare Ruling May Have Just Killed State-Based Exchanges
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: One result of the ruling is that even states that started their own exchanges, facing technical challenges, may let the federal government take over.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Supreme Court has ruled that health insurance consumers can receive federal subsidies regardless of their state’s role in running their insurance market, fewer states may stay in the game.

headline: ‘Basquiat and the Bayou’ and ‘Jean-Michel Basquiat: Now’s the Time’
abstract: Two recent exhibition catalogs situate the work of Jean-Michel Basquiat within our potent cultural poles.
lead_paragraph: In the American historical imagination, the North (even beyond our borders into Canada) symbolizes freedom, individual expression and progress, while the South conjures a mix of hospitality, religious fervor and persistent racial prejudice. It’s a cultural civil war that in some ways enables us to sidestep the more complicated realities of our national identity.

headline: Republicans Cite Health Care Ruling in Pushing Candidacies
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Rick Perry and Marco Rubio were among the first Republican presidential candidates to react to the Supreme Court’s ruling to uphold Affordable Care Act subsidies.
lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidates were quick to pivot off the Supreme Court’s ruling to uphold Affordable Care Act subsidies, arguing that the decision shows the need to replace President Obama with a member of their party.

lead_paragraph: LAO CAI, Vietnam — National flags rustled in the breeze on both banks of the Red River, but nothing else was moving at this normally bustling border crossing.

keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act “is here to stay,” said President Obama after the Supreme Court decision allowing the federal subsidies of health insurance premiums.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, President Obama has faced the sneers of political adversaries who called his health care law Obamacare and assailed his effort to build a legacy that has been the aspiration of every Democratic president since Harry S. Truman.

headline: After Bringing In Talent, Padres Are Still Trying to Draw It Out
abstract: Despite an influx of proven talent, the Padres’ results continued to be tepid, leading the new general manager, A.J. Preller, to make a managing change.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Ian Kennedy pitched against the San Diego Padres, he learned from their players how much respect Bud Black commanded as manager.

abstract: A Chinese-language newspaper has published messages from Hong Kong lawmakers that call into question the head of the Legislative Council’s neutrality and hint at the chaos and miscues during an important vote.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of June 18, the second day of a legislative debate over how Hong Kong would pick its next leader, Christopher Chung was at ease, even high-spirited.

headline: Museums Are Trying New Things in the Bedroom
abstract: Researchers at several house museums are trying to improve the historical accuracy of bedroom furnishings.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to house museums always ask for details about the original owners’ daily routines, particularly their sleeping habits. So researchers at several of these museums are improving the historical accuracy of furnishings in bedchambers where famous and forgotten lives began and ended.

headline: A Collector Cashes In on Vintage Toy Banks
abstract: Thousands of vintage toy banks, stored for decades in a Manhattan apartment, will be dispersed at auction.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of vintage toy banks, stored for decades in a Manhattan apartment, will be dispersed in a series of auctions starting on July 11 and 12. The collection, which William Werbell, a retired high school music teacher, and his wife, Elaine, began assembling in the 1950s, includes metal, plastic and ceramic coin containers shaped like hats, footwear, buildings, animals, weapons, appliances and gnomes.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: EVERYTHING I NEVER TOLD YOU, by Celeste Ng. (Penguin, $16.) When the prized daughter from a mixed-race Chinese and white home is found drowned in 1970s small-town Ohio, her family confronts the difficult questions left unanswered after her death. As our reviewer, Alexander Chee, wrote, the story is ultimately “about the burden of being the first of your kind — a burden you do not always survive.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE PRIME OF LIFE: A History of Modern Adulthood, by Steven Mintz. (Belknap/Harvard University, $35.) A professor shows that early marriage and childbearing have not been traditional cultural markers of being an adult.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: The Female Gaze
abstract: Young artists are examining girlhood in the age of the social media fun house.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the pop star Rihanna posted a series of photographs on Instagram from a shoot for the French magazine Lui. In the photos, she’s sporting striking tan lines — and little else. Instagram objected, and the photos were deleted. Shortly after, Rihanna posted another image of herself, this time Photoshopped into a demure yellow brocade jacket, emblazoned with the caption “Rih’s next magazine cover if it was up to Instagram.” Then, she deleted her account for about six months.

headline: Restaurant Report: Isolina in Lima
abstract: The restaurant, a stylish tavern in Barranco that opened in January, aims for authenticity.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese and Japanese have left distinctive marks on Peruvian cuisine — immigrant laborers having brought the wok and knife techniques that led to national dishes like lomo saltado and tiradito. But long before that, Lima’s culinary influences were derived from the Spanish and African slaves who cooked in their kitchens.

headline: Living With Cancer: Being Mortal
abstract: Too few cancer patients know how useful the book “Being Mortal” can be for those dealing with the difficult decisions presented by incurable disease.
lead_paragraph: Like many people with advanced-stage cancer, I wonder when I will decide about treatment, “Enough is enough.” In helping me formulate an answer to this question, Atul Gawande’s latest book, “Being Mortal,” will now play an indispensable part.

headline: Justices Back Broad Interpretation of Housing Law
abstract: The Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 vote, endorsed a legal theory that civil rights groups say is crucial to fighting housing discrimination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday endorsed a broad interpretation of the Fair Housing Act of 1968, allowing suits under a legal theory that civil rights groups say is a crucial tool to fight housing discrimination.

headline: The Dalai Lama to Appear at Glastonbury Festival
abstract: The Dalai Lama will visit the annual pop-music festival as part of his tour of the United Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Kanye West, Florence and the Machine, Pharrell Williams, and now, the Dalai Lama.

headline: Jason Schwartzman and Adam Scott on a Play Date
abstract: Two of the stars of “The Overnight” take a time-out in New York City to discuss childhood sleepover memories, movie spoilers and the fate of Jon Snow.

headline: The Supreme Court Saves Obamacare, Again
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The decision put an end to a preposterous legal claim and made a powerful defense of the law that has helped millions pay for health insurance.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, for the second time in three years, a majority of the Supreme Court rightly rejected a blatantly political effort to destroy the Affordable Care Act. The case challenging the law, King v. Burwell, was always an ideological farce dressed in a specious legal argument, and the court should never have taken review of it to begin with.

headline: Review: Misty Copeland Debuts as Odette/Odile in ‘Swan Lake’
abstract: Her performance in the epic double role was the first by an African-American with American Ballet Theater in New York, and celebrated for it.
lead_paragraph: When Misty Copeland made her New York debut in the double role of Odette/Odile in “Swan Lake,” the most epic role in world ballet, two aspects of the performance on Wednesday afternoon proved marvelous. One: that it all happened successfully. Two: the curtain calls.

headline: If Greece Defaults, Imagine Argentina, but Much Worse
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Currency']
abstract: The Greek debt crisis has similarities to Argentina’s default in 2001. But experts say a default would be much worse for Greece.
lead_paragraph: There may be a one-word explanation for why Greece will ultimately capitulate to European demands for more austerity:

headline: History Hints at What Awaits Max Scherzer After One- and No-Hitter
abstract: As the Nationals’ Scherzer prepares for a start at Philadelphia on Friday, one wonders: Will his two great starts lead to another, or will there be a letdown?
lead_paragraph: Max Scherzer’s amazing outings in his last two starts prompted much speculation that they were the best consecutive starts ever. A 16-strikeout, complete-game one-hitter, followed by a near-perfect game spoiled only by a hit batsman with two outs in the ninth, is as dazzling a pair of starts as you will find in baseball.

lead_paragraph: News footage of damaged towns in England and of the wreckage of German bombers after an air raid on June 1940. (britishpathe.com)

headline: Detroit Police Issue Warrant for Shepard Fairey’s Arrest
abstract: The police in Detroit issued a warrant for the street artist’s arrest on felony vandalism charges.
lead_paragraph: The artist Shepard Fairey is a wanted man in Detroit. Police there issued a warrant for his arrest on Friday, charging that Mr. Fairey, the street artist-who-turned-legit, had illegally tagged multiple buildings in May, causing more than $9,000 worth of damage. He is charged with two counts of malicious destruction of property, The Detroit Free Press reported, felonies “ which carry a maximum penalty of five years in jail, plus fines that could exceed $10,000.”

headline: California Set to Mandate Childhood Vaccines Amid Intense Fight
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The measure, approved by the Assembly, would end the religious and personal exemptions often sought by parents opposed to vaccinations
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO, Calif. — Schoolchildren in California would be required to be vaccinated unless there is a medical reason not to do so under a sweeping bill approved by the State Assembly on Thursday. The measure would end exemptions for personal or religious reasons, routinely requested by parents opposed to vaccines.

headline: Men’s Fashion Takes Paris by Storm
abstract: Day two of Paris fashion week... men. spring.
lead_paragraph: Day two of Paris fashion week... men. spring.

headline: Michael Wolff’s New Book Celebrates the Success of Old Media
abstract: Michael Wolff’s latest book is a thoughtful essay on the state of the cultural and financial wars besieging the media industry.
lead_paragraph: The idea of a publication of any new Michael Wolff book inevitably elicits discomfort in those likely to come into his line of fire. Mr. Wolff’s studied unpleasantness has emerged as a brand of sorts. USA Today has even capitalized on it, running an ad campaign for his column featuring a potential subject running away from his office via a rope and grappling hook just to avoid an interview with the feared columnist.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The comedian Aziz Ansari, whose “Modern Romance” is No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, is the third star of “Parks and Recreation” to achieve best-sellerdom.
lead_paragraph: Sparks and Recreation: With “Modern Romance” — new at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list — the comedian Aziz Ansari becomes the third star of NBC’s late, great sitcom “Parks and Recreation” to achieve best-sellerdom. (The others are Nick Offerman, whose “Gumption” is No. 15 in its fourth week on the list, and Amy Poehler, whose “Yes Please” is No. 2 on the monthly humor list after logging 26 weeks in hardcover nonfiction.) Ansari wrote “Modern Romance” with the N.Y.U. sociologist Eric Klinenberg, framing it as a comprehensive study of dating in the digital age. “Sociology, in a strange way, is similar to comedy,” he said on NPR recently. “It’s a lot about observation and making observations that resonate with people and trying to learn about why people do the things they do. And one idea that really applied to modern romance, in my opinion, was this whole notion of the paradox of choice. . . . Right now we have the most romantic options that any generation has ever had. And you would think, oh, more options, that’s better. But whenever you look at any studies they’ve done, they always find the more options people have, the harder it is for them to make a choice, and that when they do make a choice they’re less satisfied because they’re scared that they maybe chose the wrong thing. And whenever we talked to people about this in regards to dating, it totally resonated.”

headline: Southern States Resist the  Minimum Wage
keywords: ['Home Health Care', 'Minimum Wage', 'State Legislatures', 'States (US)', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Alabama and four other states are sending the message that employers should get to pay as little as possible.
lead_paragraph: As Alabama and South Carolina move to take down their Confederate flags, they and other southern states should also remove vestiges of slavery that are reflected today in poverty-level wages.

headline: Courtney Love Tweets Ordeal During Violent Uber Protests in Paris
abstract: The singer and actress used Twitter and Instagram to describe being held hostage during a strike by taxi drivers opposing the transportation service’s efforts to expand.
lead_paragraph: Courtney Love had what she called the scariest day of her life on Thursday, when the car in which she was riding was attacked during protests in Paris and she and her driver were held hostage, she said.

headline: Review: Art That Snorts, From Jannis Kounellis, at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise
abstract: Twelve live horses tethered to gallery walls highlight the brute power of art and its ability to transform space.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Brown’s Enterprise may be leaving its Greenwich Village home of a dozen or so years for Harlem, but not before bestowing a stupendous farewell gift on the art world. It has orchestrated the first re-creation in the United States of Jannis Kounellis’s “Untitled (12 Horses)” a legendary work of living installation art first executed in Rome in 1969. Accompanied by works by Rirkrit Tiravanija and Elaine Sturtevant, it is on view at the gallery through Saturday.

headline: For a Better Steak, Cook Directly on Charcoal

lead_paragraph: We’ve never been the kind of guys to worship outdoor grilling gear and technology. When we were growing up, Dad set the tone, making do with a rusty hardware store hibachi and a metal chimney. We’ve written about the ascetic thrill of using government-issue grills in state parks.

headline: Palantir Technologies Intrigues Investors Despite Its Mysteries
abstract: The privately held Palantir is reported to be valued at $20 billion, but getting an accurate reading of its worth in the public markets seems unlikely.
lead_paragraph: Palantir Technologies’ mystery inflates its valuation. The firm, a private data analytics company backed and beloved by government intelligence, is raising $500 million in fresh cash, giving it a potential valuation of $20 billion and landing it fairly high on the list of so-called unicorns.

headline: ‘Women Artists: The Linda Nochlin Reader’
abstract: A collection of 30 essays by the pioneer scholar of feminist art history Linda Nochlin.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, Linda Nochlin published her groundbreaking article “Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?,” a passionate and rigorous attack on nearly all the received ideas of her day. While it was necessary (she argued) to question “the unstated domination of white male subjectivity” that shaped the art historical canon, she found equally suspect the feminist impulse to resurrect forgotten or underappreciated women artists and elevate devalued “feminine” qualities. To get to the heart of the problem, it was necessary to question the notion of “greatness” or “genius” itself. Nochlin was then 40 years old. Two years before, she had experienced a feminist awakening when an acquaintance gave her a briefcase of radical feminist zines. A twice-married mother of two, teaching art history at Vassar College and leading what she had considered until then a fashionable and liberated life, she read until 2 a.m., light bulbs going off in her head. “I kept opening doors,” she would write later, “onto an endless series of bright rooms, each one opening off from the next, each promising a new revelation.”

headline: Chris Christie to Announce Decision on 2016 Campaign
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, who plans a Tuesday announcement, has been traveling the country under the banner of his political organization, Leadership Matters for America, delivering speeches on entitlement reform and education.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie will announce Tuesday in Livingston, N.J., whether he will run for president in 2016, a source close to his campaign confirmed.

lead_paragraph: GREENPORT, N.Y. — This harbor village that now beckons day-trippers from the North Fork’s wine country was once home to fleets of vessels that plied the whaling, oyster and commercial fishing trades.

headline: Sharing My Story With Patients
abstract: For many doctors, facts, figures and data are king. For me, feeling truly vulnerable for the first time has transformed my life and practice.
lead_paragraph: Her parents stare back at me and then at each other, their eyes wide and lips pursed. I repeat, “We should consider brain surgery for your child.”

headline: Hearing Yoko Ono All Over Again
abstract: Rediscovering Yoko Ono’s early recordings and innovations.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1962, Yoko Ono sat down at a piano onstage at the Sogetsu Art Center, then a hub of experimentation in the thriving Tokyo arts and music scene. She gently, almost imperceptibly, touched the keys. Soon she started breathing heavily, as if the all-but-inaudible playing had exhausted her. She smoked a cigarette, in slow motion.

headline: Review: Larissa Bates Explores Her Costa Rican Heritage
abstract: Ms. Bates has long made autobiography an element in her work.
lead_paragraph: This month, after more than a decade in New York, Monya Rowe will close her gallery and move it to St. Augustine, Fla. Originally in Brooklyn, then in Chelsea, and most recently on the Lower East Side, her gallery is one of a handful of independent-minded, tight-budget commercial spaces that function as alternatives to a corporatized art world mainstream. To sustain that model, Ms. Rowe has kept both her premises and the art she exhibits small. Her current show of work by Larissa Bates who, along with the painter Angela Dufresne, has been with the gallery from the start, is an example of this.

headline: Review: Kim Gordon’s ‘Design Office: The City Is a Garden,’ Scrawled Words in Critique
abstract: This antiseptic show looks as if it were formulated by a computer bot that mixes and matches Postmodernist art clichés.
lead_paragraph: Kim Gordon’s antiseptic show “Design Office: The City Is a Garden” looks as if it were formulated by a computer bot that mixes and matches Postmodernist art clichés. Ms. Gordon, better known as the charismatic frontwoman of the band Sonic Youth, intends a critique of high-end real estate development in New York City, but what she has wrought is unimaginative, conceptually facile and oddly impersonal.

headline: Think Like a Rat: Inside the Mayor’s Plan for Rodent Eradication
abstract: Matt Flegenheimer describes a day spent tagging along with New York City’s director of pest control as he reported recently on Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to rid the city of rats.
lead_paragraph: Some pronouncements require great political courage. Self-identifying as anti-rat is not among them.

headline: Review: Mira Dancy’s ‘Yes’
abstract: Ms. Dancy looks back to German Expressionism while setting her sights on female nudes who don’t have time for the male gaze.
lead_paragraph: The title of Mira Dancy’s second gallery show in New York is simple and open-ended: “Yes.” It reflects an artist giving herself permission to look back to German Expressionism while setting her sights on female nudes who don’t have time for the male gaze. She is preceded in different ways by Dana Schutz, Katherine Bernhardt and Ella Kruglyanskaya.

headline: Gene Palmer’s Sworn Statement to New York State Police

It also served as home to two remarkable visionaries, one a scientist, the other an artist, both influential in the way we see the world today.

abstract: Nearly a third of the world’s 37 largest aquifers are being drained faster than water can be returned to them, threatening regions that support two billion people, a recent study found.
lead_paragraph: From the Arabian Peninsula to northern India to California’s Central Valley, nearly a third of the world’s 37 largest aquifers are being drained faster than they are being replenished, according to a recent study led by scientists at the University of California, Irvine. The aquifers are concentrated in food-producing regions that support up to two billion people.

A crowd surrounds him, transfixed by his emphatic lamentations.

headline: You See a Suspicious Mole on a Stranger. What Next?
abstract: Plus: Dealing with a wedding without gifts; opinions about a boss’s love life; and more.
lead_paragraph: I am not a dermatologist. But I have seen enough articles and pictures of dangerous-looking moles to know when one should be checked. If I see something suspicious-looking on a friend, I speak up. But what about strangers? It’s awkward to say something. But if I keep quiet, I feel negligent and guilty, especially if the mole is in a hard-to-see place or the person don’t have someone in his life to spot it.

headline: When an Open Relationship Comes at a Price
abstract: If living “freely” was necessary to prove my love for my boyfriend, I was happy to comply. But it wasn’t that simple.
lead_paragraph: During college, I spent a few wonderful evenings making out with a longhaired poet. I spent a few weeks messing around with a gentle, funny religion student. I even briefly, if accidentally, dated a high school student (since when do 17-year-olds have beards?).

headline: Review: Lorraine O’Grady’s Gift for Language and Images
abstract: This show includes a series of collages from 1977 and prints of a 1982 performance piece about Ms. O’Grady’s life.
lead_paragraph: Born in 1934, Lorraine O’Grady came to art late, in her 40s, but she brought to it a writer’s ear for language and a painter’s eye for images, both evident in this show of her early work. In 1977, in response to a personal crisis, she composed a series of collages using cutout headlines from 26 consecutive issues of the Sunday New York Times. The subjects of some of the headlines reflect a specific cultural moment, with any sense of consistency disrupted by Ms. O’Grady’s scrambling of phrases.

headline: In Weighing Responses to Climate Change, Severity and Uncertainty Matter More than ‘Reality’
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Coast Erosion', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: A climate blogger thinks that because there is no uncertainty on climate basics, there’s no justification for examining the uncertainty about the severity of climate change.
lead_paragraph: As I noted in an update to a previous post, Greg Laden, who writes a spirited global warming blog, published a rather biting critique of my approach to blogging and climate science a few days ago. He’s both wrong in how he portrays my views of climate science and, to my mind, failing to recognize there can be more than one approach — in communication, technology, politics and other arenas — aimed at a common goal: in this case improving humanity’s intensifying two-way relationship with the climate system.

There are also growing questions about whether – after 19 months of negotiation – an agreement is even possible, given what appears to be a growing intransigence on the Iranian side.

headline: Review: In ‘A New Brain,’ Heading into Surgery and Singing the Whole Way
abstract: William Finn and James Lapine’s musical, revived at City Center, stars Jonathan Groff as a composer who learns that he needs immediate, possibly fatal surgery.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Groff was born to suffer incandescently. He has other talents, too. But put him in a spotlight with a heart full of anguish and eyes on the brink of floods, and his face blossoms into radiant beatitude, like a model posing for Rubens as a martyred saint.

lead_paragraph: Researchers have announced an advance that could double the capacity of fiber-optic circuits, potentially opening the way for networks to carry more data over long distances while significantly reducing their cost.

headline: Review: Richard Barrett Brings His Electronic Scores to Spectrum
abstract: A three-concert series at this Lower East Side performance space gives New York listeners a rare dip into a vivid, expressive, communicative repertory.
lead_paragraph: One measure of the esteem in which the British composer Richard Barrett is held at Spectrum, the Lower East Side performance space? An excerpt from the score for “tendril,” his 2013 piece for harp and electronics, is printed on the front of the space’s new T-shirts. A more traditional measure is the three-concert series Spectrum is devoting to Mr. Barrett’s work. It began on Wednesday with a riveting program featuring members of the ensemble TILT Brass. This was, for New York listeners, an all-too-rare dip into a vivid, expressive, communicative repertory. “I think it’s fairly easy to follow what’s going on,” Mr. Barrett said by way of introducing the first piece, “Aurora” (2010). That’s not entirely right — these are dense, complicated scores — but it captures the fundamental accessibility of his music.

headline: Clementa Pinckney, Called to Pulpit and Politics in a Life Cut Short
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Mr. Pinckney, who was killed last week in the basement of Charleston’s Emanuel A.M.E. church, often said he was summoned to the pulpit at an early age.
lead_paragraph: RIDGELAND, S.C. — The morning worship had ended at St. John A.M.E. Church, and as Clementa Pinckney walked through the simple country sanctuary with its 10 rows of pews, he was startled to hear a disembodied voice. It was soft, almost whispery, and yet clearly audible. “Preach,” it said. “I have called you to preach the Gospel.”

headline: Looking at the Birth of Lewis Carroll’s ‘Alice,’ 150 Years Old
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum celebrates the anniversary of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” with rare early documents.
lead_paragraph: THE chief virtue of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland,” G. K. Chesterton once wrote, was Lewis Carroll’s celebration of flux, an escape “into a world where things are not fixed horribly in an eternal appropriateness, where apples grow on pear-trees, and any odd man you meet may have three legs.”

headline: The Scene
keywords: ['Paris Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Dries Van Noten Men’s at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Dries Van Noten Men’s at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Photo Diary: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2016 Men’s
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from Paris Fashion Week, captured by Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Paris Fashion Week, captured by Schohaja.

headline: The Independent Art Fair Finds a Sleek Home in TriBeCa
abstract: The fair is moving from its old Chelsea building into a space at Spring Studios that will allow more flexibility for different types of artists and projects.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 2010 as an art fair that works very hard not to look or feel like an art fair, Independent has prospered in its home in the funky old building on West 22nd Street that once housed the Dia Center for the Arts, whose rough brick walls practically breathe downtown art history.

headline: Review: Doris Salcedo’s Forceful Political Art in Guggenheim Retrospective
abstract: The artist, who grew up in Colombia during an era when civic murder was a way of life, has made brutal memories the essence of a witnessing art.
lead_paragraph: Politically speaking, you don’t have to be a house to be haunted. All you need to be is someone who keeps an eye on the news; who pays attention to loss through violence; and feels a personal stake in that loss, as if it were happening to people you know and care about, to people who live in your home.

headline: Lower East Side Story
abstract: During the decades Clarence Elie-Rivera spent living and photographing on the Lower East Side, he watched it go from rough to rich.
lead_paragraph: During the decades Clarence Elie-Rivera spent living and photographing on the Lower East Side, he watched it go from rough to rich.

headline: Judge Delays Kansas Ban on 2nd-Trimester Abortion Procedure
abstract: Abortion opponents call evacuation and dilation ‘dismemberment abortion,’ but a suit brought on behalf of two doctors challenges the prohibition.
lead_paragraph: A Kansas state judge on Thursday temporarily blocked a new law that would have banned the most common method of abortion in the second trimester.

headline: Review: Joan Miró, ‘Oiseaux Dans l’Espace’
abstract: Miró’s American influences come through in this exhibition at Nahmad Contemporary.
lead_paragraph: “The Birth of the World,” Joan Miró’s clairvoyant masterpiece from 1927, presaged much of postwar American painting — the early date can elicit a double take when you see it at the Museum of Modern Art. Its expansive surface of thin gray pours and washes, and the delicate lines and shapes in black, red and white that dance across them, open a pathway to so much: the automatic drawing of Surrealism, the frank painterliness and scale of Abstract Expressionism and the lightness and elegance of Color Field painting.

headline: Review: ‘Sarah Charlesworth: Doubleworld’ Studies Perceptions Shaped by Photography
abstract: This exhibition at the New Museum traces a transformative exploration of the medium, covering 10 series of images made between 1978 and 2012.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, when Sarah Charlesworth characterized her interest in photography as “an engagement with a problem rather than a medium,” she spoke for many photo-based artists. Called the Pictures Generation, they were born around 1950 and emerged in the late 1970s and early ’80s, standing on the shoulders of the Conceptualists, and for them, photography was very much a “problem.” It sold products, objectified women, glorified men, mythologized nations and rarely told the truth. The Pictures artists were less focused on taking photographs than on making them — through appropriation, distortion and rephotography — to expose the medium’s many manipulations, fictions and tricks.

headline: A Guide to Gay Pride Weekend in New York
keywords: ['Culture (Arts)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Parades', 'Art', 'Music', 'Theater', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The cultural events listed here, many free, are geared primarily toward lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender audiences but have a wider appeal.
lead_paragraph: THE series of efficiently scheduled excursions that our colleagues in the Travel section of The New York Times call “36 Hours” have urged readers to go park hopping in Lima, honey shopping in Savannah and espresso sipping in Antigua. For Gay Pride weekend in New York, we set out to put a spin on the idea. We wondered just how much gay we could cram into three days, especially knowing that the Supreme Court’s coming decision on same-sex marriage could make this Pride month historic.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, June 28 to July 4, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
abstract: United States and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Clint Dempsey Receives Two-Year Ban From U.S. Open Cup
abstract: It was the second ban in a week for Dempsey, the United States national team captain, for tearing up a referee’s notebook during a match.
lead_paragraph: Seattle Sounders forward Clint Dempsey was barred from the United States Open Cup for at least two years on Thursday, his second punishment in a week for tearing up a referee’s notebook during a match in the tournament on June 16.

headline: June 25, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from the United States, Chile, Iran and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the United States, Chile, Iran and India.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Venture Capital Firm Formation 8 Creates Vehicle Focused on Asian Start-Ups
abstract: In a regulatory filing, Formation 8 said it would aim to raise up to $400 million for a special investment vehicle to finance new companies in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Since its inception, the investment firm Formation 8 has aimed at connecting American start-ups with Asian technology titans.

headline: “The Day of Struggle Against the U.S.”
abstract: One of the world’s most secretive nations makes no secret at all of its hostility to America.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s most secretive nations makes no secret at all of its hostility to America.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: The Supreme Court Keeps the Fair Housing Law Effective
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The effects of discrimination may be harder to detect, the justices say, but that does not make it less harmful.
lead_paragraph: Housing discrimination doesn’t have to be intentional to be illegal. That is the point of the Supreme Court’s ruling on Thursday interpreting the Fair Housing Act of 1968 in accord with clear congressional intent, and preserving a well-established and critical tool in the long-running battle to ensure a more integrated society.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: On the Jindal Campaign: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Reporter Manny Fernandez reports on Gov. Bobby Jindal’s announcement, in Kenner, La., that he will join the race for President.
lead_paragraph: KENNER, La. – Years ago in college, I overheard a fraternity leader tell one of his frat brothers that the secret to success is to “act as if”: Act as if you had it all figured out; as if you were a wise, swaggering senior even though you were really a naïve, nerdy sophomore.

headline: In N.H., Marco Rubio Is Pressed on Trade and Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Conservative voters challenged the Florida senator over his vote for what some have derided as “Obamatrade.”
lead_paragraph: SALEM, N.H. – Senator Marco Rubio defended his conservative credentials on two issues that are roiling the right – immigration and trade – as he returned to the campaign trail on Thursday.

headline: Review: From Royal Ballet, a Blend of Enchantment and Intensity
abstract: The Royal Ballet performed two sharply contrasting 1960s works, Frederick Ashton’s “The Dream” and Kenneth MacMillan’s “Song of the Earth,” at the Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: The diverse beauties and eloquence of Royal Ballet style became doubly evident on Wednesday, when the company presented a double bill of contemporaneous ballets by Frederick Ashton and Kenneth MacMillan that is the centerpiece of its season. The ballerina Marianela Nuñez was deeply impressive in MacMillan’s “Song of the Earth” (1965), the first performance of this important ballet in New York since 1976. As Titania in Ashton’s Shakespearean adaptation “The Dream” (1964), Sarah Lamb, more relaxed than she had been in Tuesday’s gala account of the same ballet, rose with the rest of the cast to make the ballet’s poetic comedy all the more spellbinding.

headline: Review: ‘Escher/Bacon/Rothko,’ a Dance Triptych From Zvi Gotheiner
abstract: The choreographer finds commonalities in the sensibilities of three extremely different visual artists and interprets them through dance.
lead_paragraph: Apart from being visual artists with powerful visions and immediately recognizable styles, M. C. Escher, Francis Bacon and Mark Rothko wouldn’t seem to have much in common. But each has been an inspiration to the choreographer Zvi Gotheiner, who has now made a three-part dance that sets his interpretations of those artists side by side like the panels of a triptych. The connecting sensibility is his.

headline: Hooray for Obamacare
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The reality of Obamacare is that it’s a tremendous success, which was conservatives’ big fear.
lead_paragraph: Was I on the edge of my seat, waiting for the Supreme Court decision on Obamacare subsidies? No — I was pacing the room, too nervous to sit, worried that the court would use one sloppily worded sentence to deprive millions of health insurance, condemn tens of thousands to financial ruin, and send thousands to premature death.

headline: Review: Roomful of Teeth Duels With Sounds of the Financial District
abstract: Roomful of Teeth performed in the financial district of Manhattan as part of River to River, in an opportunity to “animate the city” in a place preoccupied by commerce.
lead_paragraph: By 8 p.m. on any given weekday, most of the human bustle has drained out of the financial district in Lower Manhattan. On Wednesday evening, too, when an outdoor concert by the vocal ensemble Roomful of Teeth began on the elevated plaza at 28 Liberty Street, there was little traffic noise to contend with. Instead, the thrum of building generators, garbage compactors and air-conditioning units created a metallic haze from which the singers’ voices first emerged indistinctly, like figures seen through dry ice.

headline: Prison Term Sought for Private Eye Who Hacked Email
abstract: Despite a court recommendation otherwise, prosecutors want Eric Saldarriaga to serve time to send a message about illegal hacking.
lead_paragraph: In the end, the amount of money a New York private investigator made from people who paid him to illegally pilfer the emails of possibly dozens of people he was investigating was small — just $5,000.

headline: River to River Festival Heads for a Grand Finale
abstract: The festival ends this weekend with a range of offerings that include free concerts, dancing and one-of-a-kind performance art.
lead_paragraph: Resist the air-conditioned indoors. The River to River festival in Lower Manhattan ends this weekend with enough free entertainment to make you forget the temptation of a chilly movie theater.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 26-July2
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Humans’ Contemplates When Robots Are Routine Accessories
abstract: This AMC premiere asks what happens to the role of humans if robots live alongside them?
lead_paragraph: No one would blame you for being confused. A new series turned up Wednesday on the USA Network called “Mr. Robot” that is about humans. And on Sunday, AMC will unveil a series called “Humans” that is largely about robots. But if you can’t keep them straight, watch both. “Mr. Robot” is pretty darn good. “Humans” is too.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for June 26-July 2
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
