abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for June 26-July 2
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: FarmBorough Festival, a Country Music Kickoff in the Big City
abstract: This weekend’s three-day festival, starring Dierks Bentley, Brad Paisley and Luke Bryan, is a bet on New York’s growing country market, from the company behind Governors Ball.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago at Randalls Island, it was Ray-Bans, ironic T-shirts, snapbacks and Lana Del Rey. This weekend it’s cowboy boots, denim shorts, trucker hats and Brad Paisley. New York, home of hip-hop and downtown experimentalism, may not seem like the most hospitable place to host a major country music festival.

headline: Theater Listings for June 26-July 2
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: New York Asian Film Festival Features Ringo Lam, Hong Kong Crime Master
abstract: A highlight of the 14th annual New York Asian Film Festival, which begins on Friday, is the chance to see “City on Fire” and “Full Alert,” two classic cops-and-crooks films by Ringo Lam.
lead_paragraph: It’s been not quite 30 years since a group of young Hong Kong-based moviemakers, now in or near their 60s, reinvented the gangster film, infusing the motifs of the American crime drama with the balletic action, nimble style and thematic preoccupations of their hometown industry. John Woo began the process with “A Better Tomorrow” in 1986 and became the movement’s standard-bearer in the United States, eventually directing a string of big-budget Hollywood films. The prolific Johnnie To emerged later, with “Breaking News” and his “Election” films, and is now a major presence on the international festival circuit.

headline: Five Artists, Five Book Reviews
abstract: Must a book review take the form of prose — or can it be pure image? For this first art-themed issue of the Book Review, five pathbreaking contemporary artists create visual works of literary criticism, paying homage to the inspiration they’ve found in fiction, philosophy and poetry.
lead_paragraph: Must a book review take the form of prose — or can it be pure image? For this first art-themed issue of the Book Review, five pathbreaking contemporary artists create visual works of literary criticism, paying homage to the inspiration they’ve found in fiction, philosophy and poetry.

headline: Movie Listings for June 26-July 2
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Empty but Also Stocked, Hunting Cabins in Adirondacks Are Ideal Hideout for Escapees
abstract: The camps, tucked out of sight and often containing hunting weapons and nonperishable food, number in the thousands, further complicating the search for the Richard W. Matt and David Sweat.
lead_paragraph: OWLS HEAD, N.Y. — Locals call them hunting camps, and despite their rustic simplicity, or perhaps because of it, they are a beloved fixture of the deep woods in the Adirondacks.

headline: Rick Owens Fashion Show Is Overshadowed by a Model’s Message
abstract: A statement about Angela Merkel puzzles observers and gets the offender kicked off the runway.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was Look 25 that stood out, and not for any of the intended reasons.

headline: Charter Makes Its Case for 2 Mergers, Telling F.C.C. It’s No Comcast
abstract: Charter wants to buy Time Warner Cable and Bright House. In an F.C.C. filing, it outlined why its ownership would be beneficial, all the while dissociating itself from Comcast’s failed takeover.
lead_paragraph: Charter Communications, in an attempt to distinguish itself from Comcast and its failed takeover of Time Warner Cable, promised federal regulators on Thursday that a pair of deals totaling $67.1 billion would pose no threat to the growing market for online video because the combined company’s future depended more on broadband than on its legacy video business.

headline: Spare Times for June 26-July 2
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Midsummer Night Swing

headline: Review: Shakespeare and Love Cuddle Up in ‘The Princess of France’
abstract: Modern life among the overcultured and underemployed urban young in the latest from the Argentine writer-director Matías Piñeiro.
lead_paragraph: After a brief introduction from a radio announcer, “The Princess of France” opens with a burst of Schumann — the first movement of his “spring” symphony — that sets a mood of high emotional drama. The music accompanies, and almost overwhelms, an aerial view, shot from a rooftop, of a pickup soccer game. It starts out five on five, but the members of one team switch sides, leaving an overwhelmed goalie facing nine opponents.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 26-July 2
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Frolic!’

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 26, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Ted 2,” “The Princess of France” and “What Happened, Miss Simone?”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Ted 2,” “The Princess of France” and “What Happened, Miss Simone?”

headline: A Gem From Jacob deGrom and a Victory Don’t Mask the Mets’ Larger Problems
abstract: DeGrom held the Brewers scoreless for eight innings, got a hit and scored a run — all of which was necessary because the Mets’ offense scraped across only two runs.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Mets Manager Terry Collins held his hands out, palms up, hopping around, his eyes wide, pleading frantically with the second-base umpire, Larry Vanover.

headline: Review: ‘What Happened, Miss Simone?’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “What Happened, Miss Simone?”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “What Happened, Miss Simone?”

abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Princess of France.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Princess of France.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Ted 2’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Ted 2.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Ted 2.”

headline: The Roberts Court’s Reality Check
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The chief justice deftly demolished a cynically manufactured and meritless argument that would have made the court look like a partisan tool.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the Supreme Court moves in mysterious ways. The health care decision was not one of those times.

headline: State Dept. Gets Libya Emails That Hillary Clinton Didn’t Hand Over
abstract: The emails that Mrs. Clinton did not give to the State Department were said to be exchanges with her longtime confidant and adviser Sidney Blumenthal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department said on Thursday that 15 emails sent or received by Hillary Rodham Clinton were missing from records that she has turned over, raising new questions about whether she deleted work-related emails from the private account she used exclusively while in office.

headline: Review: ‘Advantageous’ Portrays a Future Where More Things Remain the Same
abstract: This science-fiction fantasy summons up a speculative new world where the greatest threat is the same that’s haunted the planet since time immemorial — people.
lead_paragraph: The past looks a lot like the present in “Advantageous,” a science-fiction fantasy in a deliberately subtle key. It’s set in the near future and big-city life appears to hum along very much as it does now, what with the digital billboards and soaring glass-and-metal towers and despite the occasional zippy, low-moving aircraft. The director Jennifer Phang never explains who’s piloting those sleek flying discs or setting off the periodic explosions that scarcely rock this world. The most urgent concerns for Gwen (Jacqueline Kim) throb out a familiar beat: child, career, enough water to live.

headline: Humana Said to Pursue Sale as Supreme Court Ruling Gives Insurers a Lift
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Humana, the smallest of the big five insurers, could reach a deal by next week. Among those in the running are two bigger competitors, Aetna and Cigna.
lead_paragraph: A new round of consolidation in the health insurance industry appeared closer as companies seek to grow larger, driven in part by cost-cutting and opportunities that are part of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: A Turning Point for Health Care — and Its G.O.P. Opponents
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Social Security (US)', 'States (US)', 'Medicare']
abstract: With the Supreme Court’s decision upholding Obamacare, Republicans avoid a no-win situation.
lead_paragraph: FOR the second June in four years, the Supreme Court, led by its conservative chief justice, John G. Roberts Jr., has affirmed the legal framework of the Affordable Care Act of 2010 — the signature achievement of the Obama-era Democratic Party and a national social policy landmark. In so doing, the Roberts court assured the permanent expansion of social protections in America, and also saved the Republican Party from a no-win explosion its own extreme right-wingers tried to ignite.

headline: Review: In ‘Batkid Begins’, a Boy’s Simple Wish Whips Up Frenzied Adulation
abstract: Dana Nachman documents the overwhelming response to a 5-year-old cancer patient’s wish to become Batman.
lead_paragraph: In the last few decades, the image of the cancer patient has transformed from that of private victim to public warrior. That extreme pendulum swing, however, is only one thread in the cord of concern woven by “Batkid Begins,” Dana Nachman’s awestruck documentary about the overwhelming response to a child’s simple wish.

headline: Sleuth Work Leads to Discovery of Art Beloved by Hitler
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Detectives (Private)']
abstract: German authorities have uncovered dozens of missing pieces of Nazi art, throwing rare light on the secretive market in which such works are traded.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The recent startling recovery of long-lost artworks made for Adolf Hitler and his chief architect, Albert Speer, began with a telephone call to a Berlin art dealer.

headline: Nurse Pleads Guilty to Taking Kickbacks From Drug Maker
abstract: Heather Alfonso of Connecticut accepted $83,000 to prescribe Subsys, a powerful painkiller made by Insys Therapeutics. Prosecutors appear to be looking more closely at the company.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut nurse has pleaded guilty to federal charges of accepting $83,000 in kickbacks from Insys Therapeutics, an Arizona drug manufacturer that sells the powerful painkiller Subsys, as prosecutors appear to be intensifying their investigation into the company, which is under scrutiny for its marketing practices.

headline: Review: In ‘K’na the Dreamweaver,’ a Princess Faces a Call to Duty
abstract: In this tale, a young woman in an indigenous clan in the Philippines must weigh love against filial obligation.
lead_paragraph: Fairy tales often concern themselves with definitions of bravery, qualities of true love or characteristics of a real princess. All three questions come up for K’na, princess of an indigenous Tboli family in the Philippines.

headline: Review: In ‘A Little Chaos,’ a Guileless Kate Winslet Offsets a Lavish Versailles
abstract: Ms. Winslet plays a gardener well ahead of her time in this Louis XIV-era costume drama directed by and starring Alan Rickman.
lead_paragraph: The silky growl and insinuating gaze of the British actor Alan Rickman make him a prime candidate to play a jaded aristocrat privy to every dirty secret within his purview, whether political or sexual. And in “A Little Chaos,” which Mr. Rickman directed, he portrays Louis XIV, the French king of kings, putting the finishing touches on Versailles, the royal chateau outside Paris where he moved his court, the better to exert control. The year is 1682.

headline: Review: In ‘A Borrowed Identity,’ Hearts Torn Between 2 Worlds in Israel
abstract: Eran Riklis’s film charts the struggles of an Arab-Israeli teenager making his way in an elite boarding school in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: There is sublime literary pacing in “A Borrowed Identity,” Eran Riklis’s well-observed adaptation of two autobiographical novels by the Arab-Israeli author and journalist Sayed Kashua (who wrote the script). The film examines the often frustrating struggles for Arabs trying to assimilate into Israeli culture, as experienced by Eyad (played at first by Razi Gabareen and later by Tawfeek Barhom), a bright child raised by a loving family, including a politically active father (Ali Suliman), in Tira, a predominantly Arab town in Israel.

headline: In a First, New Jersey Jury Says Group Selling Gay Cure Committed Fraud
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: In recent years, a number of states banned conversion therapy for minors, but this verdict was the first that could restrict it from being offered to adults as well.
lead_paragraph: In the first court verdict of its kind, a jury in New Jersey on Thursday found that a prominent group offering gay “conversion therapy” violated the state’s Consumer Fraud Act by claiming it could help men overcome unwanted homosexual urges.

headline: New Hampshire Poll Shows Bernie Sanders in Dead Heat With Hillary Clinton
abstract: While Mrs. Clinton has been popular in New Hampshire, her favorable ratings have dropped since February, while Mr. Sanders’s have been climbing, and a CNN/WMUR poll released on Thursday has them in a statistical tie.
lead_paragraph: The next time Hillary Rodham Clinton visits New Hampshire, she need not look over her shoulder to find Bernie Sanders; the Vermont Senator is running right alongside her in a statistical dead heat for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination, according to a  CNN/WMUR poll released on Thursday.

headline: 2015 N.B.A. Draft: Kristaps Porzingis Is a Big Project for the Rebuilding Knicks
abstract: Porzingis, a 7-foot-1 forward from Latvia who has spent the past three seasons with Cajasol Sevilla of the Spanish league, is regarded as a player with huge potential but may need time to develop.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson has been adamant about wanting to do things his way as president of the Knicks. So when it came to the N.B.A draft and his first opportunity to make a first-round selection, he maintained that he was not going to be swayed by public opinion or television draftniks or the potential reaction of the team’s long-suffering fans.

headline: Review: ‘The Midnight Swim’ Investigates a Mother’s Watery Death
abstract: Sarah Adina Smith’s chiller about three sisters at a lakeside home has one foot in its genre and one in a whole other place.
lead_paragraph: THE MIDNIGHT SWIM

headline: Rebels in Ukraine Cleansing Donetsk of ‘Perverted’ Art
abstract: Russian-backed separatists who seized control of an art space in the Ukrainian city of Donetsk last year apparently don’t like what they found there.
lead_paragraph: Russian-backed separatists who seized control of a modern art space in the Ukrainian city of Donetsk last year have destroyed a monumental sculpture there, according to the exiled directors of the center, known as Izolyatsia, or ‘Isolation.’

headline: Review: ‘Big Game’ Stars Samuel L. Jackson as a President in Dire Straits
abstract: In this adventure, a Scandinavian teenager encounters the American president, who has bailed out of a doomed Air Force One over the Finnish woods.
lead_paragraph: Yes, it’s about hunting, and a 13-year-old boy’s rite of passage through violence. But the irresistible fable-thriller “Big Game” — the second feature from the Finnish director Jalmari Helander (“Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale,” from 2010) — has got a heart.

headline: Patrick Macnee, 93, Dapper and Unflappable in ‘The Avengers,’ Dies
abstract: Mr. Macnee played many roles over the decades but was best known as John Steed on “The Avengers,” the 1960s British series.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Macnee, who wielded a lethal umbrella and sharp repartee as the dapper secret agent John Steed on the 1960s television series “The Avengers,” died on Thursday at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Review: ‘A Murder in the Park’ Challenges David Protess’s Innocence Project
abstract: Thirty years later, two overturned convictions around a 1982 double murder continue to draw scrutiny and legal action.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, when Anthony Porter was cleared of the 1982 murders of two teenagers in Chicago’s Washington Park and released from death row, the case drove Gov. George Ryan to suspend capital punishment in Illinois. Praise poured in for David Protess, a Northwestern University journalism professor, and the students in his Innocence Project, who contended that Mr. Porter couldn’t have been the killer and produced a videotape in which a man named Alstory Simon said he had done it.

headline: Jeb Hensarling’s Fight Against Ex-Im Bank Succeeds, for the Moment
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: With Congress in its July 4 recess, there are no opportunities left to save the bank’s charter before it expires — giving the divisive House chairman a temporary win.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year ago, an entrepreneur from California came before the House Financial Services Committee, a Purple Heart pinned to his lapel from his Marine Corps service in Vietnam, to plead for the Export-Import Bank — and by extension his livelihood.

headline: Review: In ‘Felt,’ Amy Everson Plays an Eccentric, Troubled Artist
abstract: In this film, a woman battles herself as she tries to recover from a trauma.
lead_paragraph: “Felt” is a movie of ambiguities, starting with its title. (Noun or verb?) But this vague, arty horror film from Jason Banker (“Toad Road”), who shares a story credit with his star, Amy Everson, is at once underwritten and overconceptualized. Reading about the filmmakers’ intentions is more rewarding than watching the results.

headline: Review: Noah Buschel’s ‘Glass Chin,’ an Updated Working-Class Noir
abstract: This story of a New York-area loan shark, restaurateur and boxing coach is full of hyperstylized shots, philosophizing speeches and no-way-out plotting.
lead_paragraph: “ ‘Ordinary’ is our enemy,” J. J., a loan shark/restaurateur/art investor/monologuist in a sharkskin-gray suit and skinny tie, says to the former boxer he torments in “Glass Chin.” That could be the filmmaking motto of the writer and director Noah Buschel in his latest movie-mad feature, replete with hyperstylized shots, philosophizing speeches and no-way-out plotting.

headline: Top State Court Backs New York City’s ‘Taxi of Tomorrow’
abstract: The legal battle over whether the city was allowed to choose the Nissan NV200 as the standard model ended with the decision by the Court of Appeals.
lead_paragraph: The Taxi of Tomorrow will become New York City’s standard taxi — maybe not tomorrow, but soon.

headline: Review: ‘Escobar: Paradise Lost’ Stars Benicio Del Toro as Drug Lord
abstract: In this fictional account of the Colombian kingpin, Pablo Escobar pulls an American surfer into his circle.
lead_paragraph: Some historical figures, like the drug lord Pablo Escobar, loom so much larger than life that even an experienced director might hesitate to approach them head on, choosing instead to refract legend through the gaze of a less dazzling sidekick. In “Escobar: Paradise Lost,” no one is less likely to dazzle than Nick, the Canadian surfer who serves as our colorless conduit to Colombian crime.

headline: Review: ‘The Little Death’ Plays With Narrative Form and Fetish
abstract: Josh Lawson’s polite sex comedy has the soul of a sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Early on, “The Little Death” helpfully explains that its title comes from the French idiom for orgasm. That eagerness to enlighten characterizes this comedy’s gentle, considerate tone. It also underscores why, in the end, the film doesn’t work.

headline: Women’s World Cup 2015: France and Germany to Meet Earlier Than Expected
abstract: Friday’s match between top-ranked Germany and third-ranked France is a quarterfinal, meaning one of the teams will be going home sooner than expected.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S GAMES

headline: Harold Battiste, Musician, Mentor and Arranger, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Battiste lent his expertise to a long list of future stars, founded a collective record company and taught at universities.
lead_paragraph: Harold Battiste Jr., who was raised on Lasalle Street in New Orleans to the rhythms of the nearby Dew Drop Inn and went on to become a jazz musician and educator, a recording industry pioneer, and a mentor and arranger who advanced the careers of Sonny and Cher, Sam Cooke, Dr. John and others, died on June 19 at his home in New Orleans. He was 83.

headline: Review: ‘Fresh Dressed’ Follows Hip-Hop From the Streets to the Runway
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: This documentary charts how hip-hop fashion initially absorbed what was around it, and then eventually became the inspiration for everyone else.
lead_paragraph: From the beginning, hip-hop fashion has been about a tug of war between relatability and aspiration. Early in the new documentary “Fresh Dressed,” DMC of Run-DMC says about his group’s street-influenced style, “Dressing this way lets them know, “Oh, he’s just like me.”

headline: Jason Rezaian’s Life in Iranian Prison Is ‘Ever More Difficult’
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Asked how her son was coping in prison, Mr. Rezaian’s mother said, “He tells me it’s getting harder and harder.”
lead_paragraph: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran for nearly a year, is finding prison life “ever more difficult” and has only recently become aware of the global support for him, including a plea for his release from Muhammad Ali, Mr. Rezaian’s mother, Mary, said on Thursday.

headline: End of a Pastoral Shortcut for Central Park’s Drivers
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: In an effort to protect the park’s bikers, joggers, bird-watchers and pedestrians, as well as limit air pollution, the city will shut the miles of north and southbound drives that sprawl along the parkland above 72nd Street.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers engage in many behaviors to satisfy their compulsion for expedience — dialing up for a carton of General Tso’s when they really could be cooking, spending $4 for a latte when the coffee maker at home sits idle, e-hailing Uber when the subway is right there.

headline: Putin Breaks Silence With Call to Obama Touching on Ukraine and ISIS
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The Russian president called to talk about the battle against ISIS, while the American president focused on the separatist war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama spoke with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Thursday in their first direct contact in four months as the United States and Russia try to manage their conflict over Ukraine while still working together on other issues like Syria and Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Review: In ‘Runoff,’ a Rural Family Hits Desperate Times
abstract: Kimberly Levin’s directorial debut centers on the Freemans (Neal Huff and Joanne Kelly), struggling to raise a family and save their farm and business.
lead_paragraph: Anyone naïve enough to daydream about fleeing the pressures of the city for a simpler life running a farm is strongly advised to see “Runoff.” The movie is the impressive directorial debut of Kimberly Levin, a former biochemist who knows a thing or two about agricultural chemistry. Filmed in Kentucky, this story of the Freemans, a rural family struggling to survive in the face of brutal pressure from agribusiness, is a Halloween nightmare.

headline: A PBS Show, a Frustrated Ben Affleck, and a Loss of Face
abstract: Mr. Affleck had asked the host of a PBS genealogy program to omit the discovery of a slave-owning ancestor. The plea was exposed by the Sony hacking and WikiLeaks.
lead_paragraph: In January 2014, Henry Louis Gates Jr. was over the moon.

headline: Lawmakers Agree to Help Veterans Agency Fill a Budget Gap
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A plan for legislation to allow the Department of Veterans Affairs to shift money to fill a budget shortfall, which threatens health care for patients, wins support from Republican lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican lawmakers said Thursday that they would support legislation allowing the Department of Veterans Affairs to shift money from another program to cover a $2.5 billion budget shortfall that would otherwise threaten medical care for many patients in coming months.

headline: Review: In ‘Max,’ a Shellshocked Dog Reverts to His Heroic Self
abstract: Boaz Yakin’s film, a blend of detective story and animal tale, depicts the healing of a slain marine’s military dog under the care of the man’s brother.
lead_paragraph: One of the most memorable televised arguments Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert ever had was about “Benji the Hunted” and Stanley Kubrick’s “Full Metal Jacket.” Ebert gave thumbs up to “Benji” and thumbs down to “Full Metal,” the opposite of Siskel’s votes. The two critics then fell into a contentious debate about the inherent relativism of movie reviewing, with Ebert insisting that every film needs to be judged in its proper context. “Benji the Hunted,” he claimed, was good for what it was, which was a sentimental children’s movie about a brave dog. “Full Metal Jacket” may have been a superior movie, but as the much-anticipated work of a master filmmaker, it fell short of the standard of greatness.

headline: Review: In ‘7 Minutes,’ From Jay Martin, a Bank Robbery Plan Implodes
abstract: Three friends decide to commit a crime, greatly underestimating the difficulty.
lead_paragraph: The title of Jay Martin’s tightly wound debut film, “7 Minutes,” is the time that three aspiring bank robbers imagine it will take to pull off a heist that might net them a half-million dollars. These naïve co-conspirators — Sam (Luke Mitchell), a former high school football star with a pregnant girlfriend and a nightmarish factory job; his drug-dealing older brother, Mike (Jason Ritter), who is married with a small child; and his best friend, Owen (Zane Holtz) — fantasize that robbing Sam and Mike’s crooked uncle’s bank will be a snap.

headline: India: Severe Flooding Kills Dozens
abstract: At least 41 people have been killed in severe flooding caused by heavy monsoon rains that have lashed part of the western state of Gujarat.
lead_paragraph: At least 41 people have been killed in severe flooding caused by heavy monsoon rains that have lashed part of the western state of Gujarat, officials said Thursday. Thousands of houses were destroyed in seven districts in the southwestern part of Gujarat, said Bipin Bhatt, the director of the state’s disaster management authority.

headline: N.B.A. Draft: Karl-Anthony Towns Is No Surprise at No. 1, but Then Comes a Scramble
abstract: The manic opening minutes of Thursday’s draft at Barclays Center spawned one of the most entertaining first rounds in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after Karl-Anthony Towns walked across the stage, down the steps and off toward his new career in Minnesota as the N.B.A. draft’s No. 1 overall pick Thursday, activity began to buzz in two separate corners of the designated players’ area, the first rumblings that the night might veer quickly from expected.

headline: Defense Tries to Put Focus on Sanity of Aurora Gunman
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: A psychiatrist who examined James E. Holmes after his shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater said that Mr. Holmes did not have the capacity to distinguish right from wrong.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A psychiatrist who examined James E. Holmes in jail days after Mr. Holmes carried out a shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater testified Thursday that the gunman had a “psychotic mental illness” that revealed itself through delusions, severe anxiety and a stark emotional disconnect from the world.

headline: George Winslow, Child Actor Who Had a Moment With Marilyn, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Winslow made his film debut as Teenie in “Room for One More,” with Cary Grant, but his most memorable scene was in “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.”
lead_paragraph: George Winslow, a child actor with a deep, raspy voice and deadpan delivery who made a big move on Marilyn Monroe in “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,” died on June 14 at his home in Camp Meeker, Calif. He was 69.

headline: Remembering the Rev. Clementa Pinckney
abstract: Mourners remembered the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney on Thursday as his body lay in repose at the Capitol in Columbia, S.C.
lead_paragraph: Mourners remembered the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney on Thursday as his body lay in repose at the Capitol in Columbia, S.C.

headline: Phil Austin (a.k.a. Nick Danger) of Firesign Theater Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Austin was not only a voice-over artist but a writer, producer and guitarist for the comedy troupe, which was popular starting in the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: He pronounced his name “Regnad Kcin,” because from behind his desk that’s how he read it, backward, through his glass office door. But listeners to Firesign Theater radio broadcasts and record albums knew him as Nick Danger, the loopy fictional detective who strode “out of the fog, into the smog,” focusing his third eye, hidden under his hat, on solving crime.

headline: Review: Leon Bridges Reveals Classic Soul and Something More Personal
abstract: Mr. Bridges, who performed at the Music Hall of Williamsburg on Wednesday, is a singer with all the trappings of a star of a golden era of music that can stand up to some reinterpretation.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday night, Leon Bridges was wearing a drapy, short-sleeved, wide-collared shirt tucked into high-waisted, form-fitting slacks held up with a thin belt. The look was somewhere between 1957 and 1963, as was the sound. Mr. Bridges is a soul man of the classic sort — or, at least, that’s how the sales pitch goes.

headline: Pen Without Ink
abstract: Erin Rhode makes her New York Times crossword debut with an opening that brought a tear of joy to my eye.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I can’t tell you how much I loved this puzzle, but I loved it a lot.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Sees No Need to Set Aside More Airwaves for Smaller Cell Carriers
abstract: Tom Wheeler, head of the Federal Communications Commission, says the agency is already doing enough to increase competition among wireless companies.
lead_paragraph: The country’s top communications regulator on Thursday rejected calls to dedicate more airwaves for smaller wireless carriers in an auction expected next year.

headline: New York’s First Gay Pride Parade
abstract: Looking back at a front page article in The New York Times from 1970, a year after the Stonewall riots.
lead_paragraph: 45 YEARS AGO

headline: 2015 Women’s World Cup: Loss of Megan Rapinoe and Lauren Holiday Complicates Task for the U.S.
abstract: Rapinoe and Holiday — half of the team’s starting midfield — each picked up their second yellow card of the tournament on Monday, leading to suspensions for the game Friday against China.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Jill Ellis interrupted a reporter’s question halfway through a news conference at TD Place Stadium late Thursday afternoon. Her arms were folded tightly in front of her, at rest on a table behind a dazzlingly blue, strategically placed sports drink. She had a warm smile on her face.

headline: A Victory for Same-Sex Marriage, With Roots in New York
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In 2013, Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote, “New York acted to enlarge the definition of marriage to correct what its citizens and elected representatives perceived to be an injustice that they had not earlier known or understood.”
lead_paragraph: Friday morning, sitting in her apartment on lower Fifth Avenue, Edith Windsor was dialed into a conference room at a Midtown Manhattan law firm to hear the news that Supreme Court had decided that people of the same sex were entitled to marry.

headline: Texas Dept. of Housing and Community Affairs v. Inclusive Communities Project
abstract: The Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 vote, endorsed a legal theory that civil rights groups say is crucial to fighting housing discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 vote, endorsed a legal theory that civil rights groups say is crucial to fighting housing discrimination.

headline: Review: ‘The Set Up: Saya Lei’ Interprets the Works of a Burmese Master
abstract: A practitioner of the Mandalay style was the inspiration for this production, part of the River to River Festival.
lead_paragraph: In dance collaborations, cultural exchange can be dangerous: There is always the potential for appropriation, the killing of a technique or the watering down of a tradition. Knowingly, the contemporary American choreographers Wally Cardona and Jennifer Lacey go for danger.

headline: Washington Reacts to Health Care Ruling
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Democrats tell their Republican colleagues to stop resisting the Affordable Care Act, and Republicans pledge to continue fighting.
lead_paragraph: Democrats tell their Republican colleagues to stop resisting the Affordable Care Act, and Republicans pledge to continue fighting.

headline: Health Law Ruling Elicits Sighs of Relief and Vows to Continue Fighting
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Recipients of health insurance subsidies, as well as hospitals and health centers across the country, were elated as some Republican lawmakers pledged continued opposition to the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats said it was finally time to accept that the Affordable Care Act was here to stay. Republicans vowed to keep trying to get rid of the law, but conceded that at this point, their best chance would be by winning back the White House next year.

headline: Ex-Friend of State Senator Tells of a Cover-Up
abstract: State Senator John L. Sampson threatened to silence people cooperating with investigators, a key witness testified at the senator’s obstruction trial.
lead_paragraph: State Senator John L. Sampson threatened to silence people cooperating with investigators, a key witness testified on Thursday at the senator’s obstruction trial.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 26, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 26, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Congress passed the Affordable Care Act to improve health insurance markets, not to destroy them.”

headline: Word of the Day | arrhythmic
abstract: This word has appeared in six New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: arrhythmic • \a-ˈrith-mik\ • adjective

headline: Nets Select Chris McCullough, a Slim Prospect of Their Own
abstract: Picking 29th in the first round, the Nets selected McCullough, a 6-foot-9 forward who had his freshman season at Syracuse cut short by a knee injury after just 16 game.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks took a tall, thin prospect with their first pick in Thursday’s N.B.A. draft. Hours later, the Nets basically did the same. Picking 29th in the first round, the Nets selected Chris McCullough, a 6-foot-9 forward who hails from the Bronx, played at several preparatory schools and then had his freshman season at Syracuse cut short after just 16 games when he tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee in January.

headline: Astros’ Starter Shines as Bats Fall Silent
abstract: There were no home runs in the Astros’ 4-0 victory over the Yankees on Thursday, which was surprising because the teams ranked at the top of the major leagues in home runs.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When Houston Astros catcher Hank Conger was acquired from the Los Angeles Angels in November, he was used to watching players like Mike Trout, Albert Pujols and Josh Hamilton — established sluggers who were expected to hit the ball out of the park.

headline: How a Love Story Triumphed in Court
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A Cincinnati real estate agent, his deceased husband's aunt and their funeral director found themselves at the center of Obergefell vs. Hodges, the biggest Supreme Court same-sex marriage case in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: A Cincinnati real estate agent, his deceased husband's aunt and their funeral director found themselves at the center of Obergefell vs. Hodges, the biggest Supreme Court same-sex marriage case in U.S. history.

headline: In Supreme Court Case, a Couple Not Recognized in Life or Death
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: When the Supreme Court decides whether to establish a national right to same-sex marriage, the love story of Jim Obergefell and John Arthur will be front and center.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court makes its decision, expected in the coming days, on whether to establish a national right to same-sex marriage, the love story of Jim Obergefell and John Arthur will be front and center. As the lead plaintiff in the case against Ohio’s ban on gay marriage, Mr. Obergefell, 48, has become a very public face of the national movement.

headline: Celebrating Love, Grieving Loss as Charleston Funerals Begin
abstract: For a region grieving since a gunman killed nine people in a Charleston church last week, a new phase of mourning began Thursday, with the first of the victims’ funerals, for Ethel Lance.
lead_paragraph: For a region grieving since a gunman killed nine people in a Charleston church last week, a new phase of mourning began Thursday, with the first of the victims’ funerals, for Ethel Lance.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Disney) TEEN BEACH 2 (2015) Their endless summer has ended. In this sequel to the 2013 Disney Channel smash musical, it’s been three months since Mack (Maia Mitchell) and Brady (Ross Lynch) surfed 50 years into the past and onto the set of “Wet Side Story.” But in real life, the only epic wave is the one drowning their love. Enter Lela (Grace Phipps) and Tanner (Garrett Clayton), reprising their Annette Funicello-Frankie Avalon impression, and a magic necklace that zaps them into the present, where Lela discovers an aptitude for calculus, a taste for flavored lip gloss and a desire to be more than a dreamboat’s girlfriend. But if she and Tanner don’t return to 1962, Mack and Brady might never meet. Like the original, “Teen Beach 2” mashes up “Beach Blanket Bingo,” “Back to the Future,” “Grease” and “Glee” in bubble-gum tracks like “Best Summer Ever” and “Gotta Be Me.” Its big-kid stars are young adults by now, but it’s still the little kids (and their parents) who will want to sing along.

headline: To Police New York in the Future, Bratton Looks to His Past
abstract: With New York set to add nearly 1,300 new officers, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton and Mayor Bill de Blasio spoke on Thursday about the reinvigorated approach to community policing that the reinforcements would aid.
lead_paragraph: It has been billed as a blueprint for policing New York in the decades to come, an opportunity to get more officers back into the city’s neighborhoods and connected to the people they are assigned to serve. And as William J. Bratton, the police commissioner, laid out his vision for the future on Thursday, he made it clear that it was very much informed by the experience of the past.

headline: Things to Do in Westchester, June 28 to July 4, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘Escape From East Berlin,’ Reissued Five Decades Later
abstract: Robert Siodmak’s 1962 film, released on DVD by Warner Archive, depicts the derring-do of 29 East Germans who tunneled under the Berlin Wall a few months after its construction.
lead_paragraph: Scores of film artists fled Nazi Germany during the 1930s and found their way to Hollywood. Only a handful of these refugees returned after World War II to make German-language films.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, June 28 to July 4, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, June 28 to July 4, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Documentary Filmmakers Talk About Manipulation in Their Work
abstract: Nonfiction filmmakers say that making something “more true” sometimes means playing with time or production methods.
lead_paragraph: The opening of “Cartel Land” drops viewers into an outdoor Mexican meth lab at night; the head chef sits down for an interview. The scene might be enough of a jolt to viewers, but what they won’t know — unless they’re familiar with meth cooking — is that it was shot over two nights. The filmmaker, having gone to great lengths to secure access once, insisted on going back a second time to film more of the days-long drugmaking process.

headline: 9 Killed When Plane Carrying Cruise Passengers Crashes in Alaska
abstract: The dead in the accident involving the chartered floatplane included eight people from the Holland America cruise liner Westerdam and the pilot, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Emergency workers recovered the remains of nine people killed when a small plane slammed into a cliff in rural Alaska the day before, defying wind, rain and low cloud cover on Friday to retrieve the bodies from a steep rock face, according to emergency officials and media reports.

headline: Penelope Spheeris Reissues ‘Decline of Western Civilization’ Films
abstract: Little seen upon their first release, the three music documentaries, which have grown in stature, have been assembled in a box set.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of “The Decline of Western Civilization Collection” as a pristine extras-filled box set from Shout Factory this week is to budding punks what a new “Star Wars” movie is to, well, all the other kids: something they never thought they’d get to experience in their lifetimes.

headline: Restaurant Review: Quenas in Harrison Offers Tastes of Peru, With Asian Influences
abstract: A bit of cultural history as well as coastal geography are reflected in the menu offerings.
lead_paragraph: Where to begin? Perhaps with the small, informal dining room of Quenas, a family-run restaurant in Harrison, its soaring walls splashed in deep red and decorated with Peruvian memorabilia. Or, on a warm summer evening, with a cold Peruvian beer or a glass of sangria sipped under umbrellas on the patio. Or maybe just fast-forward to dessert, putting aside for now the savory Peruvian dishes this kitchen turns out.

headline: Corrections: June 26, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, June 26, 2015
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Review: Rincón Taqueria in Norwalk
abstract: The restaurant, hidden in plain sight, is an unpretentious place that serves freshly made dishes in huge portions at what feel like Depression-era prices.
lead_paragraph: Those who dine out frequently enjoy discovering a sleeper, an unpretentious gem of a restaurant tucked away from the beaten path. Well, I have a sleeper for you, but it’s hidden in plain sight in a small strip mall on the Post Road on the south edge of Norwalk.

headline: A Farmer Reclaims Liberian Roots in New Jersey
abstract: A growing market for ethnic foods is allowing an immigrant in Buena Vista Township to reconnect with his homeland.
lead_paragraph: Morris Gbolo spends a lot of time thinking about the home-cooked dinners he and his wife, Ernestine, used to enjoy before they fled their home amid civil war in Liberia 12 years ago.

headline: Picnics to Go Are Growing in the Hamptons
abstract: A growing number of companies are using artisanal ingredients and interesting flavors to create lunches to enjoy outdoors.
lead_paragraph: The local harvest may be delayed by an unusually cold spring this year, but as the sweet corn, heirloom tomatoes and summer squash come to market, several new picnic purveyors on the East End will be dreaming up ways to enjoy them alfresco. For many of us, a French baguette and a hunk of artisanal cheese from the Village Cheese Shop in Mattituck make a magnificent movable feast. But recently, picnic options from East Marion to Southampton have expanded, reflecting a locavore-inspired mission: Food that is grown in these fields can also be savored in them.

headline: Lower East Side Story
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Men and Boys', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Photography', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Youth']
abstract: During the decades Clarence Elie-Rivera spent living and photographing on the Lower East Side, he watched it go from rough to rich.
lead_paragraph: The bad old days of the Lower East Side seem almost as quaint, and as distant, as the neighborhood’s heyday a century ago, when its streets were abuzz with immigrants spilling out of overcrowded tenements.

headline: The Robert E. Lee Problem
abstract: The debate over flying the Confederate flag prompts another question over Southern heritage: Should we honor the Confederate general?
lead_paragraph: The debate about the Charleston Bible study shooting has morphed into a debate about the Confederate battle flag and other symbols of the Confederacy. This is not a trivial sideshow. Racism is not just a personal prejudice and an evolutionary byproduct. It resurfaces year after year because it’s been woven by historical events into the fabric of American culture.

headline: In Karachi, a Fatal Mix of Heat and Piety
abstract: Fierce temperatures and strict adherence to fasting rules during the holy month are killing hundreds of Pakistanis.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — WHEN I go to buy my drinking water, I don’t ask for water. I ask for Nestlé. Then I drive home with five 20-liter plastic bottles and make sure that we make every cup of tea, and all our ice, from this water. Like other people in this city, I believe the tap water is poisonous. During the summer, many of us follow the practice of putting out a water cooler on the street for passers-by. There are chic restaurants, cafes and art galleries in my neighborhood, but not a single public source of clean drinking water. Street vendors, security guards, trash pickers and maids rushing from one job to another often stop by to have a drink from this cooler. Like most such water coolers, mine is secured with a padlock; even the plastic tumbler is tied to it with a small chain.

headline: Cinven Agrees to Buy a Majority Stake in Synlab
abstract: The European private equity firm will buy a controlling share in the German laboratory testing company, in a deal that values Synlab at about $2 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Funds advised by BC Partners have agreed to sell a majority stake in Synlab, one of Europe’s largest independent providers of laboratory services, to the European private equity firm Cinven.

headline: When Public Housing Is Across the Street
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Developers in New York City are building on land they might once have shunned, next to public housing developments.
lead_paragraph: This spring, city officials announced they would encourage private developers to build on land inside public housing complexes, potentially making luxury apartments their neighbors.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Supreme Court Allows Nationwide Health Care Subsidies
abstract: What rationale did Chief Justice Roberts give for the court’s decision?
lead_paragraph: Note: We’re experimenting with a new format for this feature. Tell us what you think!

headline: Europcar Shares Decline in Early Trading After Paris I.P.O.
abstract: The French rental car company sold about $985 million in an offering of 71.8 million shares, which was priced late Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shares of Europcar, a French rental car company, declined more than 3 percent in early trading in Paris on Friday after its initial public offering.

headline: Test Your Grammar | Aerial Courses in the Trees
abstract: Below, the first several paragraphs of a June 20 Travel article, “Boom in Treetop Parks Lets Visitors Learn the Ropes.” In each paragraph, there is a phrase in bold. Decide if that phrase is fine the way it is, or if it should be revised to correct errors.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been experimenting a bit this week with new formats for Test Yourself. On June 22 we tried out a punctuation quiz, on June 23 a verb-tenses quiz and on June 25 our first grammar quiz.

headline: J. K. Rowling Says Harry Potter Play Will Open Next Summer
abstract: “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child,” a new stage play centered on the blockbuster series, will be staged at the Palace Theater in the West End of London.

We were members of the Dhamar Survey Project, started by the University of Chicago and named for a historic town in highland Yemen.

keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Humana Said to Pursue Deal to Sell Itself | Prison Term Sought for Email Hacker | Greek Bailout Talks Go Down to the Wire | Calpers’s Private Equity Fees Under Scrutiny
lead_paragraph: HUMANA SAID TO PURSUE DEAL TO SELL ITSELF | Humana, the smallest of the big five health insurers in the United States, could reach an agreement by next week to sell itself to another insurer, according to a person briefed on the matter,  Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. Among the suitors are Aetna and Cigna, which have both been the targets of takeovers themselves as insurance companies look to cut costs through consolidation and take advantage of the opportunities that are part of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: ‘Post Time’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: What are the instances in which perception changes, in which we suddenly see our parents in a different light? Reading this poem, I thought of what I’ve come to understand about my own father’s life that I could not before his death, and how a long-ago moment between us now seems like a “last-minute window,” when any outcome was still possible.

headline: How to Go Undercover
abstract: Be a listener, not a talker.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Learn to walk the walk and talk the talk,’’ says Cody Carlson, who wore a hidden miniature video camera during the year and a half he worked stints at places like a dairy farm in upstate New York, a pork producer in Pennsylvania and two egg farms in Iowa. His goal was to capture irrefutable evidence of mistreatment that animal rights groups could later use in lawsuits and public-awareness campaigns. Before going undercover, the 31-year-old Carlson spent weeks in anthropologist mode, observing livestock auctions, volunteering at pet stores, studying the lingo and aesthetics that would allow a New York City kid to blend in at hog barns.

headline: Why I’m Afraid of Therapy
abstract: An author fears losing control of her own story.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my father was fascinated by people talking about themselves. Books, movies, television — if it had an extended scene of self-analysis, he was reading it or watching it. Part of this enchantment was pure anthropological interest: My father grew up poor in Honolulu, a third-generation Japanese-American who’d gotten up and out of his neighborhood. His idea of culture was shaped largely by his discovery of writers and filmmakers — Philip Roth, Woody Allen, Wallace Shawn — whose definition of an intellectual life included exposing their own fantasies and grotesqueries to an audience that was assumed to be (and in fact was) interested, even beguiled, by them. To my father, the very idea of talking about himself to a stranger for 50 minutes must have seemed equal parts horrifying and seductive, the equivalent of spending a day eating nothing but fudge.

headline: Why Was This Patient Walking on Pins and Needles?

headline: Michael Bach’s Preservation Through Photography
abstract: Finding relief in front of the lens.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, Michael Bach quit taking photos, for good, or so he believed. After graduating from the Yale School of Art, Bach had spent two decades as a teacher and a landscape photographer until he had a mental breakdown that culminated in a suicide attempt. He sold all his equipment, including his large-format camera. ‘‘I felt like a failure,’’ Bach said. ‘‘I didn’t want anything around me to remind me of photography.’’

headline: Today in Politics: G.O.P. Finds Much to Add to Justices’ Final Say on Health Care Law
abstract: It was déjà vu once again for Republicans as the Supreme Court granted another lifeline to the health care law by upholding the subsidies that underpin it.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the Supreme Court has taken over both the Capitol and the campaign trail. Its ruling in favor of a central provision of the Affordable Care Act prompted declarations of victory from the White House and increased pledges to repeal the law from the Republicans looking to move in.

headline: Finding Paradise in Turkey’s Munzur Valley
abstract: Deep in the rugged heart of eastern Anatolia, the resilient Alevi Kurds open their hearts and homes to a visitor.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the rugged heart of eastern Anatolia, the Munzur River flows from the base of a skyscraping limestone massif, wending its way into the world across a grassy valley cradled between dog-toothed peaks and forested hills. The water is impossibly clear and numbingly cold and, to most of those who visit its source, sacred. “It’s easy to feel close to God here,” I was told by one follower of the mystical Alevi religion, who, like hundreds of other women, men and children, had come to the springs — called Munzur Gozeleri — on a scorching July afternoon.

headline: Singleminded
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: As I decrease my medications, the urgency I feel around men and relationships subsides.
lead_paragraph: I’m almost unmedicated. Each morning, I take just 100 milligrams of bupropion. At bedtime, I take a quarter milligram of lorazepam. I’ve eliminated trazodone. And I’m single. My ex and I are friends again — we were friends for years before we dated — and now that my heartbreak has receded, I don’t miss the upstream swim of that relationship. I still pop awake in the middle of the night, and often stay awake for two or three hours, but there’s a peacefulness to my days now. Summer is helping. It always does.

abstract: The fashion and sports worlds are more intertwined than ever, with designers sending track suits and jerseys down the runway (and inviting ballers into the front row).
lead_paragraph: At the spring/summer 2016 men’s wear shows in London, Milan and Paris, the athletic trend shows no signs of abating, with heavy-hitting designers including Louis Vuitton, Valentino and Prada showing looks that could seamlessly transition from the runway to the three-point line. (In a decidedly retro twist, this spring’s defining luxury item may well be a track suit or pair of tiny, shiny shorts.) The love for the ballers, it seems, is mutual: another trend that’s only gaining steam is the appearance of athletes like Carmelo Anthony and Amar’e Stoudemire at men’s fashion week shows and parties, having left their jerseys at home in favor of sharp, dapper duds. Game recognize game, after all.

The president of the United Arab Republic came to Cairo airport with visiting Chinese Premier Chou En-lai to welcome President Sukarno of Indonesia.

headline: The Price of Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Will the victory at the Supreme Court blind us to our history of life in the margins?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision affirming the right to same-sex marriage across the United States is a joyous moment for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender Americans. Recognition of our equal dignity, and of our right to the same legal protections straight couples enjoy, is a civil rights milestone. But it could also be the swan song for the movement for gay freedom that began after World War II.

The misguided majority, he says, “orders the transformation of a social institution that has formed the basis of human society for millennia, for the Kalahari Bushmen and the Han Chinese, the Carthaginians and the Aztecs. Just who do we think we are?”

headline: Recalling Sarah Charlesworth’s Photographs
abstract: Laurie Simmons and Cindy Sherman discuss their friend’s art.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Charlesworth did not like being called a photographer. She preferred to speak of herself as “someone who makes art with photographs,” alluding to her practice of sitting at a table and sifting through images from her extensive source files. She would mix and match pictures and rephotograph them in new configurations. Unlike earlier photographers, who spoke of the pursuit and capture of trophy images as if they were hunting big game, Ms. Charlesworth favored the grand indoors.

That will change when he joins the BBC broadcast team for the second week of Wimbledon, where Roddick won plenty of fans but never a title despite three appearances in the singles final.

abstract: The Democratic candidate will raise money in the popular gay resort town on the northern tip of Cape Cod.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton transformed her H-and-an-arrow campaign logo into a gay-rights rainbow on Friday to mark the Supreme Court’s same-sex marriage ruling. She issued a statement calling the court’s decision “an affirmation of the commitment of couples across the country who love one another.” Her campaign sells a variety of branded “Hillary” items timed to June’s Gay Pride Month.

headline: A Legoland Builder Turns Her Childhood Hobby Into an Adult Art Form
abstract: The Yonkers’ Discovery Center builder has recreated Picasso’s “Guernica,” the fashion editor Anna Wintour and even characters from the series “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: Pablo Picasso’s birthday was coming up and Veronica Watson wanted to celebrate. She was standing in her workshop at the Legoland Discovery Center in Yonkers last October, where she serves as the master model builder, and was scanning online through the artist’s paintings.

headline: Dylann Roof Had AR-15 Parts During Police Stop in March, Record Shows
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The police in Columbia, S.C., questioned Mr. Roof and found ammunition and a forearm for an AR-15 rifle in his car trunk, but no crime was committed, the authorities say.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Dylann Roof, the man accused of killing nine people this month in a shooting rampage at a storied church in Charleston, S.C., was questioned by an officer earlier this year while hanging around a park, according to a police record released Friday. The officer found parts for a semiautomatic rifle in the trunk of Mr. Roof’s car.

headline: ‘Drunk Wedding’ Faced Too High a Bar to the Big Screen
abstract: Paramount Pictures’ microbudget comedy “Drunk Wedding” had a successful screening and the studio’s support, but it was still left at the altar.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the spring of 2013, Paramount Pictures held a research screening at a multiplex here for a new comedy called “Drunk Wedding.” The studio’s vice chairman was so eager to learn the results that he attended in person.

headline: Richard Matt, Escaped Prisoner in New York Manhunt, Is Fatally Shot
abstract: Richard W. Matt, one of the convicted murderers who staged an elaborate escape from New York’s largest prison nearly three weeks ago, was fatally shot on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Richard W. Matt, one of the two convicted murderers who engineered an elaborate escape from New York’s largest prison, was shot and killed on Friday by a federal agent, the authorities said, ending one prong of a three-week manhunt that spread over large stretches of the state’s northern terrain.

headline: Roger Federer Still in the Mix at Wimbledon, His Lawn of Dreams
abstract: Federer is aiming for an eighth title at Wimbledon, his favorite tournament, and if he gets it, at 33 he will be the oldest men’s champion of the Open era.
lead_paragraph: With age 34 right around the corner and English grass back under his feet, is this the last big chance for Roger Federer to win a Grand Slam tournament?

abstract: Cities throughout the South have streets, schools and parks named for Confederate generals.
lead_paragraph: A plaque on the exterior of the Hotel Monaco in Alexandria, Va., honors “the first martyr to the cause of Southern independence.”

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled this morning that same-sex marriage is a Constitutional right. Members of the fashion world took to social media to show their support. Here are some of their responses.

abstract: Republican candidates seem to have no intention of letting this issue go.
lead_paragraph: Just as you could hear the cheering start in front of the Supreme Court building as the TV news reporters were still leafing through the decision upholding marriage equality today, it took mere moments for the right wing to provide the predictable backlash.

lead_paragraph: The enthusiastic crowds that have been greeting Bernie Sanders on the campaign trail have been matched by online donor excitement.

headline: The Bronx Zoo’s Loneliest Elephant
abstract: The arguments over Happy’s isolation open up a bigger debate: whether it is right to keep intelligent, family-oriented and behaviorally complex animals in captivity.
lead_paragraph: On a gray day in mid-June, at the edge of a leafy enclosure in the Bronx Zoo’s Wild Asia habitat, an elephant named Happy stood very still, gazing over the fence. There were a few logs scattered around, some grass and shrubs, and a concrete-lined pool. A green ball was marooned at the water’s edge.

headline: Review: Boney James Performs with Panache in Smooth Cruise Kickoff
abstract: This contemporary jazz star’s sold-out, two-set appearance was his only New York City tour stop.
lead_paragraph: Forty minutes into his sold-out first set on the Smooth Cruise on Wednesday, Boney James dialed up his crowd work with the efficient panache of a retail politician. First came the selection of a woman from the audience, who needed no cajoling to strut onstage and start dancing in a comically suggestive face-off with Mr. James and his tenor saxophone.

headline: Review: A Mix of Sounds at the New York City Electroacoustic Music Festival
abstract: The festival features a combination of electronics and traditional instruments in 27 concerts over eight days at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: For those who like their music extra durational, it’s a rich week in New York. The Bang on a Can Marathon provided nearly 11 eclectic hours this past Sunday, and this coming Sunday the Whitney Museum of American Art is presenting — over eight hours — Conlon Nancarrow’s complete studies for player piano.

headline: Glastonbury Festival Celebrates Its 45th Anniversary
abstract: Michael Eavis, the English dairy farmer who founded this vast, bucolic arts event, talks about its early days and the ingredients of its success.
lead_paragraph: PILTON, England — Michael Eavis pulled his beat-up Land Rover off the muddy track and onto the grass. “Look at this land we’ve got,” he said.

headline: As a Landmark, Stonewall Gets C– for Looks but A for Meaning
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Stonewall Riots (1969)']
abstract: As the home to a turning point in the gay-rights movement, the Stonewall Inn, is made a city landmark, the preservation movement makes a shift to consider New York buildings that resonate culturally, if not architecturally.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning after nearly two hours of testimony from bureaucrats, academics and activists of the old guard — speeches variously formulaic and spirited — the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission unanimously voted to grant landmark status to the Stonewall Inn, the Greenwich Village bar that is recognized as the home of a turning point in the gay-rights movement. In their comments, many referred to President Obama’s 2013 inaugural address, which cited Stonewall, along with Selma and Seneca Falls, as monumental signposts of the country’s continuing struggle for broader equality. Even the Real Estate Board of New York, the powerful lobbying group that can look upon preservation the way vegans regard a rib-eye, sent a representative to stand in support of the distinction.

headline: Grenades, Fear and Uncertainty Become Routine as an Election Nears in Burundi
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: With the independent news media largely forced into silence, rumor is often taken as fact and political tension can quickly lead to street violence.
lead_paragraph: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — When the order came to leave their protest camp, the students voiced the same refrain.

headline: The Story of New York’s First Black Police Officer, Told With the Help of Langston Hughes
abstract: The story of Samuel J. Battle, the first black officer in the New York Police Department, is being told in a new book by Arthur Browne, a veteran newspaper reporter and editor.
lead_paragraph: It is odd that Samuel J. Battle, the first black officer in the New York Police Department, is not a larger part of our city’s lore. He was a giant man — 6-foot-3 and nearly 300 pounds — who more than 100 years ago led the integration of the department, then essentially an Irish-American enclave.

headline: Friday Night Music: Got To Admit It’s Getting Better
abstract: Can’t get no worse.
lead_paragraph: Well, it has been a pretty good few days: health reform, marriage rights, fair housing, and a long-overdue recognition that fighting for slavery was wrong. And for some reason, I find myself reaching back to the past. Maybe it’s because Justice Scalia told us to go ask the nearest hippie. Maybe because today’s Times real-estate-section report on “what it’s like to live in …” features the town where I grew up. (I remember the split-level ranches — those were the fancy houses. We had an ordinary, small ranch on a slab foundation — no basement. I believe my parents bought it for $15,000.)

headline: Skyscraper
abstract: How high can a Lego tower go?
lead_paragraph: How high can a Lego tower go?

headline: Grandma’s Hand
abstract: On Avenue C in the East Village, Adela Ferguson’s authentic Puerto Rican food has warmed the hearts of many who long for the dishes of the island.
lead_paragraph: On Avenue C in the East Village, Adela Ferguson’s authentic Puerto Rican food has warmed the hearts of many who long for the dishes of the island.

headline: Casa Adela in East Village Is the Home of the Magical Rotisserie Chicken
abstract: Adela Ferguson’s restaurant has been serving authentic Puerto Rican food in Alphabet City since the neighborhood was known as Loisaida.
lead_paragraph: It was a sunny weekday lunchtime on Avenue C, and as always, there was a lot of activity on the sidewalk outside Casa Adela. Three smiling men in faded T-shirts and loose jeans sat on plastic chairs next door, chatting in front of neatly graffitied shutters. Maritza Lopez, 54, stood in the shade with three of her grandchildren in navy blue school T-shirts, each clutching a white plastic bag with “Thank You” printed in red. Inside were foam containers full of rice and black beans, half a rotisserie chicken and avocado salad.

headline: Review: String Orchestra of Brooklyn Plays a Program of Spare Works at Roulette
abstract: The concert, “Dimensions of Time and Silence,” featured works by Morton Feldman, Krzysztof Penderecki and Scott Wollschleger.
lead_paragraph: Concert programs often feature works with starkly contrasting styles, but an imaginative lineup at Roulette on Thursday by the String Orchestra of Brooklyn included three pieces that created a consistent mood.

headline: Review: Jeremy Jordan, Take-No-Prisoners Heartthrob, Has a New Cabaret Act
abstract: The actor is deploying his go-getter charm at 54 Below with a phalanx of show business talent.
lead_paragraph: Not since the young Harry Connick Jr. blazed across New York nightclub and concert stages in the late 1980s have I seen a male entertainer as ferociously determined as Jeremy Jordan to conquer the world. On Wednesday evening, this grinning heartthrob of Broadway (“Newsies”) and television (“Smash”) stampeded through 54 Below with a show business cavalry led by his musical director and pianist, Benjamin Rauhala.

headline: Earth as Art – From Near (Inside a Stone) and Far (the Space Station)
abstract: Seeking meaning in abstract photographic views of Earth from orbit or inside a split stone.
lead_paragraph: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly, who is 91 days into a yearlong mission as commander of the International Space Station, has been posting strings of photographs of our remarkable planet on Twitter using the hashtags #EarthArt and #YearInSpace. Here are a few examples from earlier in June:

headline: How Simon Doonan Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Doonan, a writer and the creative ambassador of Barneys New York, and his husband, the designer Jonathan Adler, enjoy Shelter Island for its small-town ambience.
lead_paragraph: As the creative ambassador of Barneys New York, Simon Doonan — who is also a humor writer and an author — spends much of his week attending store events and hobnobbing with notables. On weekends, the British expat removes his ambassadorial sash and relaxes on Shelter Island, where he shares a beachfront home with his husband, the designer Jonathan Adler, and their rescue dog, Foxylady. Mr. Doonan, 62, and Mr. Adler, 48, were instrumental in designing their “rustic modern, Big Sur-style” home. They chose the area for its small-town, “hokey” vibe.

headline: Review: John Kelly Revives ‘Love of a Poet’
abstract: This performance artist and singer has remade his “Love of a Poet,” based on Robert Schumann’s song cycle “Dichterliebe.”
lead_paragraph: Manicured uniformity is bred into the bones of Governors Island, with its red brick buildings and military past. Waves lap at its edges, the Lower Manhattan skyline rises close across the bay, and yet romance is scarce. But this weekend, the River to River festival has imported a supply.

headline: The Legacy of Coal in England
abstract: A photographer captures the cultural and social life of his home, the country’s once thriving coalfields.
lead_paragraph: A photographer captures the cultural and social life of his home, the country’s once thriving coalfields.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Two Reasons to Visit Inwood: Dyckman Farmhouse Museum and Darling Coffee
abstract: The Dyckman Farmhouse Museum, in Inwood, reopened June 5 after a six-month sprucing up. Nearby is Darling Coffee, featuring desserts and ceremonious pour-overs for coffee obsessives.
lead_paragraph: The confluence of the Harlem and Hudson Rivers shapes a pocket of land at the northernmost tip of Manhattan, a portal to the island’s oldest forest once roamed by Native Americans. In the 1600s, warring Lenapes and Mohawks and a smallpox epidemic cleared the way for a Dutch settler, Jan Dyckman. He exercised his ax skills to sever virgin trees and built a homestead that still beats in the heart of Inwood.

headline: Sci-Fi Writers Find Warmer Climate Amid Cuban Thaw
abstract: This week, Cuban science fiction hits a new mark with the United States publication of “A Planet for Rent” by the writer José Miguel Sánchez, a.k.a. Yoss.
lead_paragraph: José Miguel Sánchez discovered Conan the Barbarian as a 10-year-old boy in Havana. Before long, he was wearing giant boots and sporting a mane of long hair, inventing a personal style that he calls “medieval-rocker” — risky behavior in a society that shuns individualism.

abstract: Givenchy Men’s at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Givenchy Men’s at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: An Old-Fashioned Bartender Known for His Pour and His Personality
abstract: Patty Ford, 61, who has tended bar at Wollensky’s Grill in Midtown Manhattan for 30 years, has attracted a slew of loyal customers with both his pour and his irreverent personality.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve never worked a day in my life,” said Patty Ford, 61, leaning over the bar at Wollensky’s Grill so that his raspy voice could be heard over the low roar of the after-work crowd on a recent weeknight.

headline: Review: Bette Midler Is Still Naughty and Bawdy, but Reflective, Too
abstract: In four decades of stardom, Ms. Midler has gone the distance, from “The Divine Miss M,” who went against the cultural tide, to her current tour, “Divine Intervention.”
lead_paragraph: Bette Midler’s smile is a sight to behold. Even glimpsed from afar on the stage of Madison Square Garden, that radiant grin — shockingly intimate, concupiscent, goofy and forgiving — suggests: “You can’t fool me. We’re all human beings playing dress-up and putting on a show. So why not have fun, let our hair down and be a little naughty so long as no one gets hurt?”

headline: Review: Mark Morris Conducts at Tanglewood, and Offers a Debut
abstract: Mr. Morris’s company introduced a work titled “The,” set to one of Bach’s “Brandenburg” Concertos.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — The Tanglewood Music Center is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year, and the opening-night concert in Seiji Ozawa Hall on Thursday was a curious mix of familiar elements and unusual arrangements. The program began and concluded with one of Bach’s “Brandenburg” Concertos — the same one, with different instrumentation.

headline: Exes Explain Ghosting, the Ultimate Silent Treatment
abstract: Breaking up by virtually disappearing is becoming an increasingly popular, if frustrating, way to ditch a relationship.
lead_paragraph: It was not long ago that Sean Penn and Charlize Theron were a happy couple: appearing together at fashion shows and film festivals, hugging on the beach. Recently, though, it was reported that Ms. Theron had stopped responding to Mr. Penn’s calls and text messages. She was “ghosting” him.

abstract: An unauthorized biography of a former Columbia president; a tale of murder in 19th-century Brooklyn; a story of the early New York Yankees; a biography of a boxer in the 1930s.

lead_paragraph: Since General Motors began recalling 2.6 million older small cars with defective ignition switches last year, federal regulators have been criticized for their failure to thoroughly investigate the problem despite receiving clear warnings from vehicle owners.

headline: The Real Rough-Talking Priest Behind ‘On the Waterfront’
abstract: The Rev. John M. Corridan a Jesuit priest who fought corruption and the exploitation of longshoremen in New York Harbor, advised Budd Schulberg, who wrote the film’s screenplay, and Elia Kazan, its director.
lead_paragraph: Q. Was the role of the priest who was played by Karl Malden in the movie “On the Waterfront” based on a real priest?

headline: Saving the Cows, Starving the Children
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party talks about economic growth. So why is it letting religion get in the way of nutrition?
lead_paragraph: London — GANDHI famously denied himself food. And by starving himself to protest British rule, he ultimately made India stronger. But India’s leaders today are using food as a weapon, and they are sacrificing not themselves, but others. Their decisions threaten to make India’s children — already among the most undernourished in the world — weaker still.

abstract: Andrew Sullivan, one of the most prominent voices about same-sex marriage, briefly revived his blog, The Dish, to comment on the Supreme Court’s decision on the issue. He talks here about why.

The fancy hats popularized by the British royal family have been rejected in favor of functionality. Worn by people headed for weekend boat rides, these hats recall a more romantic moment in fashion. Some prefer parasols but those tie up the hands. Straw fedoras,are popular, too.
