abstract: There is a lot to enjoy in this bubbly, bodacious production of the “The Producers” now at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport.
lead_paragraph: A Max Bialystock who looks like Mel Brooks. A Leo Bloom who sings mellifluously and mewls comically. A curvy Ulla with a sweet smile and a mischievous twinkle. Confetti. What’s not to like about the bubbly, bodacious production of “The Producers” now at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport?

headline: Was This the Right Way to Legalize Gay Marriage?
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s dissenters raise a reasonable point about today’s historic decision.
lead_paragraph: Justice Anthony Kennedy’s majority opinion in today’s momentous 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision bringing marriage equality to every state in the country shows that he likes to let his pen soar: “Changed understandings of marriage are characteristic of a Nation where new dimensions of freedom become apparent to new generations,” he writes, adding that it “demeans gays and lesbians for the State to lock them out of a central institution of the Nation’s society.”

headline: Norman Lear and Seth MacFarlane and Their TV Families
abstract: The producers discuss “Family Guy,” “All in the Family” and the people who don’t get their humor.
lead_paragraph: At 92 years old, and right on time, Norman Lear, the legendary television writer and producer, jogged up the steps of Baltaire, a restaurant in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles. Seth MacFarlane, a fellow sitcom creator and filmmaker, followed soon after — in more ways than one.

headline: The Nation’s First Planned Burial Ground
abstract: Grove Street Cemetery in New Haven, where Eli Whitney, Noah Webster and other notable figures lieare buried, was started because of epidemics of yellow fever and scarlet fever and opened in 1797.
lead_paragraph: Every Fourth of July, a column of the Governor’s Foot Guard in Connecticut, one of the country’s oldest military units, marches in procession through the gates of the New Haven Burial Ground, one of the country’s oldest operating cemeteries. In their red jackets and thick gold epaulets, the men proceed to the grave of David Humphreys, an aide-de-camp to George Washington during the Revolutionary War. Speeches are given, chests are puffed and afterward onlookers snap selfies with the guards.

abstract: It’s not for all of us, but at least now everyone has the right to the unique pleasures of married life.
lead_paragraph: FOR an institution that has, especially in recent weeks and years, been subject to such extensive and vigorous public debate, marriage is strangely unknowable — that is, any particular marriage is mysterious, to anyone outside it.

headline: The Allure of the Prison Break
abstract: Tunnels are just exits. It’s human frailty that helps prisoners escape.
lead_paragraph: IN my time as a rookie prison officer at Sing Sing, in Ossining, N.Y., I had to pass through 10 locked gates to reach the housing block where I worked. I would think about how I might escape if I were a prisoner there.

headline: Conservative Lawmakers and Faith Groups Seek Exemptions After Same-Sex Ruling
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The governors of Texas and Louisiana were among those calling for stronger legal protections for individuals, businesses and religious-affiliated institutions that object to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Within hours of the Supreme Court decision legalizing same-sex marriage, an array of conservatives including the governors of Texas and Louisiana and religious groups called for stronger legal protections for those who want to avoid any involvement in same-sex marriage, like catering a gay wedding or providing school housing to gay couples, based on religious beliefs.

headline: Nepal: Rough Terrain and Bad Weather Led to Helicopter Crash, Report Says
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The crash of a United States Marines helicopter in Nepal that killed 13 people in May was caused by bad weather and the geography of the region, the Nepalese Army said.
lead_paragraph: The crash of a United States Marines helicopter in Nepal that killed 13 people in May was caused by bad weather and the geography of the region, the Nepalese Army said in a statement Friday. The UH-1 Huey helicopter had been on a relief mission to aid people affected by a major earthquake in April when it lost radio contact after a second earthquake hit the region. In the statement, the army said that a joint investigation by Nepalese and American military officials found that hilly terrain and bad weather caused the helicopter’s pilot to strike hard rock at 11,200 feet in the Kalinchowk area, east of the capital, Kathmandu. The Marines and Nepal’s army had originally said that six Marines and two Nepalese Army officials had been killed, but earlier this month Nepal’s army announced that five civilians had also been on the flight.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) JOHN WICK (2014) A fabled hit man (Keanu Reeves) unleashes mayhem on a Russian mobster (Alfie Allen) who has killed the puppy that was the last gift from his recently deceased wife (Bridget Moynahan) in this savage adventure directed by Chad Stahelski (Mr. Reeves’s stunt double in “Constantine” and two “Matrix” films). Willem Dafoe, John Leguizamo, Ian McShane and Michael Nyqvist provide backup. “Brilliant in its simplicity, the setup of ‘John Wick,’ like the rest of the movie, passes swiftly and efficiently,” Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in The New York Times, making the film a critics’ pick. “Harboring few ambitions beyond knock-your-socks-off action sequences, this crafty revenge thriller delivers with so much style — and even some wit — that the lack of substance takes longer than it should to become problematic. Until then, we’re content to tag along as John, revealed as the ne plus ultra of former assassins, comes out of retirement and into the cross hairs.” His quest, she added, “may be one-note, but that note could not be more perfectly pitched.”

headline: Face It, Your Brain Is a Computer
abstract: For most neuroscientists, this is just a bad metaphor. But it’s still the most useful analogy that we have.

Descartes thought that the brain was a kind of hydraulic pump, propelling the spirits of the nervous system through the body. Freud compared the brain to a steam engine. The neuroscientist Karl Pribram likened it to a holographic storage device.

headline: Serena Williams and ‘Le Coach’ Seek a New Wimbledon Triumph
abstract: Since she hired her French coach, Patrick Mouratoglou, in June 2012, Williams has compiled a 193-14 record, winning 7 of 12 Grand Slam tournaments.
lead_paragraph: Wimbledon, true to Rudyard Kipling’s famous words inscribed at the All England Club, has indeed been the scene of triumph and disaster for Serena Williams and her coach, Patrick Mouratoglou.

headline: Louisville Slugger Craftsman Retires After 46 Years of Turning Out Hits
abstract: Danny Luckett, who is believed to have made more than two million bats for Louisville Slugger, takes decades of highlights with him into retirement.
lead_paragraph: Danny Luckett did some woodworking in high school. Other than that, his main qualification for a job that would help many major league hitters was simply saying yes to the man at the employment office.

headline: Does a Pistol Belong in Your Stock Portfolio?
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Firearms', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Gun Control', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: After the Charleston shooting, individual investors still hold shares in gun companies, which have seen a rise in sales and stock prices following similar tragedies.
lead_paragraph: A white man sat in a historic black church in Charleston, S.C., on June 17 and then proceeded to gun down nine people in a Bible study group. That mass murder has prompted national soul-searching on racism and renewed calls for stricter national gun control regulations.

headline: Kerry, in Vienna, Begins Effort to Complete Nuclear Accord With Iran
abstract: The secretary of state faced a deadline that American officials have almost conceded that the parties will not meet.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Secretary of State John Kerry began on Saturday what the Obama administration hopes will be the final push for a nuclear accord with Iran, just three days before a deadline for concluding an agreement.

headline: Red Bulls and New York City F.C. Will Meet but Their Approaches Don’t
abstract: While the Red Bulls have moved away from their strategy of making splashy player acquisitions, N.Y.C.F.C. has stolen that page from their playbook.
lead_paragraph: The players and coaches from the Red Bulls and New York City F.C. crossed paths for only a few minutes on Thursday. Sharing a podium as they changed places at a news conference promoting their game Sunday at nearly sold-out Yankee Stadium, the two players and their coaches awkwardly held team scarves for the kind of posed photos that most news organizations do not publish.

headline: ‘He’s Jesus Christ’
abstract: Most of the world has abandoned the civilians being bombed daily in Sudan’s Nuba Mountains. But Dr. Tom Catena saves lives there daily.
lead_paragraph: IN THE NUBA MOUNTAINS, Sudan — IF you subscribe to the caricature of devout religious believers as mostly sanctimonious hypocrites, the kind who rake in cash and care about human life only when it is unborn, come visit the doctor here.

headline: How to Help Dr. Tom Catena
abstract: Dr. Tom Catena is an American physician trying to save lives in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan. Here’s how you can support him.
lead_paragraph: My June 27 column was about an amazing American physician trying to save lives in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan, even as he’s being bombed by the government. I’m sure some readers will want to support his work, so let me explain how you can go about doing that.

headline: When Reporters Write Books, Does The Times Win, Too?
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Books and Literature', 'News and News Media']
abstract: It’s understandable that so many reporters like to write books, but is it really possible to serve two masters — the paper and the bookselling business?
lead_paragraph: WRITING books must be in the DNA of Times journalists. Even the paper’s founding editor, Henry J. Raymond, cranked them out, including his “History of the Administration of President Lincoln” in 1864. The next year, he returned with another, which boasted an equally catchy title: “The Life and Public Services of Abraham Lincoln.”

headline: An Audio Tour of Your Apartment
abstract: To hear your landlord laugh at your request for a new stove, press the star key.
lead_paragraph: HELLO! And welcome to your apartment. The goal of this audio guide is to foster a deeper appreciation of the place that, given your liberal arts degree and tenuous employment prospects, you certainly won’t be moving out of anytime soon. The guide will provide a historical overview of the events, traditions and sheer human drama that have made this place a must-see destination for journalists, scholars and that guy who delivers your Seamless orders. We hope it will give you a fresh and exciting perspective on Apartment 2B. Headset on? Ready? Good. Press 1, then the green arrow, to get started.

headline: Art in Public Spaces
abstract: Readers debate whether public art is a welcome cultural amenity or an unwelcome intrusion in our parks and plazas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Magical Thinking in the Sahel
abstract: Mali forced me to reckon with the supernatural.
lead_paragraph: ONE morning last fall in Philadelphia, I wired a payment to a marabout, a West African holy man, in Mali. Payment for what exactly? That depends.

headline: The Fight for Health Care Isn’t Over
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: It is imperative that in 2016 voters elect people to Congress who will support health care reform.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision upholding health insurance subsidies for low-income Americans in every state will almost certainly not stop attempts by Republicans to destroy or impede the Affordable Care Act piece by piece.

headline: Belated Protection for Some Close Relatives
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Monkeys and Apes']
abstract: It is heartening to learn that the Fish and Wildlife Service is at last strengthening regulations to safeguard captive chimpanzees.
lead_paragraph: Fascination with chimpanzees, humans’ close relatives in evolution, has long been the cause of enormous injury and destruction. So it is heartening to learn that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is at last strengthening regulations to protect captive chimps and curb their use in medical research, the entertainment industry and the pet trade.

headline: South Sudan’s Agony
abstract: Because of its historical role, the United States has a special responsibility to help end the tragedy.
lead_paragraph: South Sudan must rank among the most astounding failures in Africa, if only because the country is not even four years old. Already a political and ethnic struggle between the president, Salva Kiir, and his former vice president, Riek Machar, has escalated into one of the cruelest, most intractable and most senseless wars on the African continent, one that has grown relentlessly worse.

headline: Pete Docter
abstract: The director of “Inside Out” on the joys of stride piano, pen nibs and making sugar cookies with just the right frosting.
lead_paragraph: Pete Docter is a director, writer, animator and voice actor for Pixar Animation Studios, part of the Walt Disney Company. His latest credit is “Inside Out,” about the inner workings of a young girl’s brain, which he directed and co-wrote.

headline: Regulating Sex
keywords: ['Sex', 'Sex Crimes', 'Law and Legislation', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: It’s not just campuses that are challenging the definition of rape. Many states are redefining the law.
lead_paragraph: THIS is a strange moment for sex in America. We’ve detached it from pregnancy, matrimony and, in some circles, romance. At least, we no longer assume that intercourse signals the start of a relationship. But the more casual sex becomes, the more we demand that our institutions and government police the line between what’s consensual and what isn’t. And we wonder how to define rape. Is it a violent assault or a violation of personal autonomy? Is a person guilty of sexual misconduct if he fails to get a clear “yes” through every step of seduction and consummation?

headline: John Roberts, the Umpire in Chief
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: He has enraged both the left and the right, but the chief justice’s conception of the court’s role is entirely consistent.
lead_paragraph: LIBERALS and conservatives were exercised and confused by the combination of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s vote to uphold the Affordable Care Act’s tax subsidies on Thursday and his dissent from the Supreme Court’s decision recognizing a constitutional right of same-sex marriage on Friday. Both sides accused him of voting politically: On Thursday he was taken to task by the right, and on Friday by the left.

headline: A Heated Debate Over De-escalation
abstract: Seattle police officers attended a mandated training session in de-escalation techniques in May. In the classroom, many officers appeared skeptical of the techniques they were being taught.
lead_paragraph: Seattle police officers attended a mandated training session in de-escalation techniques in May. In the classroom, many officers appeared skeptical of the techniques they were being taught.

headline: Long Taught to Use Force, Police Warily Learn to De-escalate
abstract: Seattle is one of many cities where police departments are changing their training tactics after a series of fatal shootings around the country increased scrutiny on police operations.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Officer Corey Papinsky was recently showing a group of Seattle police officers how to reduce the chance of using force against a citizen during a suddenly antagonistic encounter.

headline: The Nets Focus on Themselves, Not the Knicks
abstract: Instead of worrying about the Knicks, the Nets quietly went about doing as much as they could with what they had in the N.B.A. draft.
lead_paragraph: Two days before the recent N.B.A. draft, the Nets hosted a tour of their new training ground — the Hospital for Special Surgery Training Center in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn.

headline: Wally Backman Serves Up Good News With an Appetizer of Humor
abstract: Backman, the manager of the Class AAA Las Vegas 51s, has played practical jokes on some of his players when they have been called up to the major leagues with the Mets.
lead_paragraph: About a week and a half ago, Logan Verrett was sitting in the Las Vegas 51s’ bullpen, palling around with some teammates during a game, when his manager, Wally Backman, motioned for him. Backman had a stern look on his face, and Verrett had a feeling he was in trouble.

headline: Marc Maron, at BAM, Finds That Happy Also Gets Laughs
abstract: The comic is known for being gloomy, but after a week that included an interview with President Obama, Mr. Maron was noticeably upbeat.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, the comedian Marc Maron walked onstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s opera house, groused about the imposing size of the theater (he said he expected to “disappoint the structure”) and then leveled with his audience.

headline: Next Fight for Gay Rights: Bias in Jobs and Housing
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Law and Legislation', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: Exhilarated by the Supreme Court’s endorsement of same-sex marriage, gay rights advocates have turned their sights on what they see as the next big battle: antidiscrimination laws.
lead_paragraph: Exhilarated by the Supreme Court’s endorsement of same-sex marriage, gay rights leaders have turned their sights to what they see as the next big battle: obtaining federal, state and local legal protections in employment, housing, commerce and other arenas, just like those barring discrimination based on race, religion, sex and national origin.

headline: Rangers Swap Forwards and Trade Away Cam Talbot
abstract: The Rangers acquired three draft picks from the Oilers in exchange for goaltender Cam Talbot and sent forward Carl Hagelin to the Ducks for Emerson Etem.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers were especially active on the trade front on Saturday, sending the backup goaltender Cam Talbot to the Edmonton Oilers for three draft picks, dealing the speedy forward Carl Hagelin to Anaheim for forward Emerson Etem and acquiring goaltender Antti Raanta from Chicago.

headline: Europe’s Moment of Truth
abstract: Tsipras, rightly, refuses to fall on his sword.
lead_paragraph: Until now, every warning about an imminent breakup of the euro has proved wrong. Governments, whatever they said during the election, give in to the demands of the troika; meanwhile, the ECB steps in to calm the markets. This process has held the currency together, but it has also perpetuated deeply destructive austerity — don’t let a few quarters of modest growth in some debtors obscure the immense cost of five years of mass unemployment.

headline: Cherries Add a Dash of Sweetness
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, adds cherries to grains and more.
lead_paragraph: Cherry season is hitting its stride, and fresh cherries will be available for only a few short months. Martha Rose Shulman uses cherries to add a dash of sweetness to tabbouleh, along with farro pilaf, smoothies and bread pudding.

headline: Size of Manhunt Area for Second Prison Escapee Is Significantly Expanded
abstract: The authorities on Saturday expanded to 22 square miles the search area for David Sweat, who escaped from the Clinton Correctional Facility.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officers on Saturday significantly expanded the area where they were searching for the remaining inmate who broke out of a maximum-security prison in northern New York this month, suggesting that officials had developed doubts that he recently had been with his partner, who was killed on Friday.

headline: At the Women’s World Cup, a New Leader Inspires a New Attitude for the U.S.
abstract: As Carli Lloyd showed against China, she can be the engine that makes the U.S. team run at full speed and the leader who may decide how far it will go.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — From the outside, Abby Wambach looked like a motivational genius.

headline: Suspect in Attack in France Had Ties to Radical Islamist
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Yassine Salhi, who the authorities say decapitated his boss before setting off an explosion at a chemical plant on Friday, belonged to the circle around a radical Islamist.
lead_paragraph: VÉNISSIEUX, France — The man who the authorities say decapitated his boss before setting off an explosion at an American-owned chemical plant near Lyon first came to the attention of the French intelligence services at least nine years ago, after he became part of the circle of a radical Islamist.

headline: Mass Funeral Held in Kuwait for 27 Killed in Bombing
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Terrorism', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Mosques', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The police said they were interrogating a number of people with possible links to the attack, which was claimed by an affiliate of the Islamic State group.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Kuwaitis, both Sunnis and Shiites, marched Saturday in a funeral procession for the 27 victims of a suicide bombing at a Shiite mosque during communal prayers the day before, an attack claimed by the jihadists of the Islamic State group.

lead_paragraph: A protester climbed a 30-foot flagpole and removed the Confederate battle flag from its perch outside the South Carolina State House early Saturday, before she was arrested and the flag replaced, the police said.

headline: Getting In the Final Word

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']

headline: Straddling Old and New, a South Where ‘a Flag Is Not Worth a Job’
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The massacre at a church in Charleston, S.C., this month casts the tensions between the Old South and the New into sharp relief.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In a rambling home at the edge of a salt marsh, a proud graduate of the Citadel, the storied Southern military college whose cadets fired the opening salvo of the Civil War, was deep in prayer with a Bible study group.

headline: Youth Chorus Unites Israelis and Palestinians, at Least for a Few Hours
abstract: The Jerusalem Youth Chorus, established in 2012, is one of the few coexistence initiatives to weather the hatred and violence that have erupted on both sides over the past year.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Avital Maeir-Epstein and Muhammad Murtada Shweiki live about 150 yards apart in Abu Tor, a Jerusalem neighborhood that straddles the pre-1967 armistice line, a mostly invisible but politically charged marker of this city’s Israeli-Palestinian divide.

headline: As Left Wins Culture Battles, G.O.P. Gains Opportunity to Pivot for 2016
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Many party officials see an opening to turn the election toward economic and national security issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A cascade of events suggests that 2015 could be remembered as a Liberal Spring: the moment when deeply divisive and consuming questions of race, sexuality and broadened access to health care were settled in quick succession, and social tolerance was cemented as a cornerstone of American public life.

headline: Walter Shawn Browne, Fast-Moving Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Browne was an aggressive, animated grandmaster and six-time United States champion who dazzled spectators with his world-class ability at speed chess.
lead_paragraph: Walter Shawn Browne, an aggressive, animated chess grandmaster and six-time United States champion who dazzled spectators with his world-class ability at speed chess, died on Wednesday in Las Vegas, where he had been competing in the 50th National Open. He was 66.

headline: Trying to Placate All, Iran Leader Zigs and Zags on Nuclear Talks
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s ambiguity, meant to keep the moderate opposition happy while placating the hard-liners, has been part of his strategy for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Persian carpets were rolled out in the Beit-e Rahbar, the downtown Tehran offices of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Tuesday, a sign that important guests were on their way.

headline: Remembering What Made Ornette Coleman a Jazz Visionary
abstract: The funeral service at Riverside Church in Manhattan for the saxophonist and composer, who died on June 11 at age 85, was a joyful and music-filled affair.
lead_paragraph: Friends, family and admirers gathered at Riverside Church in Manhattan on Saturday to celebrate the life of Ornette Coleman, the visionary jazz musician who died on June 11 at the age of 85. The service was largely a joyful and music-filled affair with performances and speeches by many well-known artists, including Yoko Ono, Pharoah Sanders, Cecil Taylor and Savion Glover.

headline: Taiwan Water Park Blast Leaves Hundreds Injured
abstract: No deaths were reported, but at least 516 people were injured when a cloud of colored powder erupted into a huge fireball during a live event at the park northwest of Taipei.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hundreds of people were injured at a water park in Taiwan on Saturday when a cloud of colored powder ignited in the air over a crowd during an event, erupting into a huge fireball.

headline: Mets’ Steven Matz Anticipates Debut, if Not Microphone
abstract: Matz, who put up stellar numbers in Class AAA, was unprepared for his first big league news conference, but he was ready to become a member of a six-man rotation when he debuts for the Mets on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Since April, Steven Matz has flashed big league potential at Class AAA Las Vegas, putting up overwhelming numbers against minor league batters.

headline: Yankees Rally on Teixeira’s Double After Tanaka Lets Early Lead Slip Away

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When Brian McCann belted a first-inning grand slam, and Chris Young followed with a two-run homer an inning later, it seemed an embarrassment of riches for the Yankees with their ace, Masahiro Tanaka, on the mound.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (AMC) HUMANS Gemma Chan, above, stars as Anita, an exquisite specimen of artificial intelligence, or “synth” — one of the must-own gadgets populating a present-day London in a parallel universe — who has been purchased by an exasperated husband (Tom Goodman-Hill) after his wife’s work schedule proves more than he and their three messy offspring can handle. But with her silky ebony hair, lithe limbs and ability to charm man and child alike, Anita isn’t exactly the kind of help a frazzled middle-aged woman (Katherine Parkinson) wants to encounter at the breakfast table before she’s had her morning shower. Meanwhile, across town, the government has issued a new elder-care bot (Rebecca Front) to George Millican (William Hurt), an aging scientist involved in the creation of the synths who wants to hold on to his outdated model, Odi (Will Tudor), with his memories of George’s dead wife. “There’s a lot going on in this show,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “Some of it is familiar from previous takes on artificial life, some of it is innovative, but all of it is involving, well written and well played.”

headline: 1940: Hong Kong Civilians Prepare To Leave
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain planned to evacuate the wives and children of British army and naval officers from Hong Kong in 1940.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — All sailings from Hong Kong were canceled yesterday [June 28] when the British Secretary of State for the Colonies Lord Lloyd advised the Hong Kong government that it may be necessary to remove women and children from Hong Kong because of the increasing gravity of the situation. The Hong Kong government broadcast the message indicating that the British Foreign Office was adopting a firm attitude with regard to Japanese demands that the Burma-Yunnan highway be closed to transport of military supplies to the provisional Chinese government capital at Chungking.

headline: 1965: Dutch Princess To Marry German Diplomat
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The announcement of a royal engagement caused an uproar in the Netherlands in 1965.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — Queen Juliana of the Netherlands with ‘‘great joy’’ today formally announced the engagement of Crown Princess Beatrix to Claus von Amsberg, 38, a German diplomat and former German soldier. In a television announcement to the nation, the queen said she had ‘‘real confidence’’ in the marriage of her 27-year-old daughter and Mr. Amsberg, a former member of the Hitler Youth movement, who served briefly in a German tank regiment at the end of World War II.

headline: Review: ‘Voodoo,’ by Harry Lawrence Freeman, Has First Staging Since 1928
abstract: Completed by the African-American composer around 1914, the opera was revived by Morningside Opera, Harlem Opera Theater and the Harlem Chamber Players.
lead_paragraph: There is a fit of jealousy in Harry Lawrence Freeman’s opera “Voodoo,” revived on Friday and Saturday for its first performances since 1928, that seems ridiculous when it’s described. Lolo, a Louisiana plantation worker and Voodoo priestess, snatches a protective amulet out of the hands of her rival for the love of the man she adores, destroying it.

And these leviathans now drive much of the action of “SeaWife,” a folk musical produced by Naked Angels and performed at the Melville Gallery of the South Street Seaport Museum.

abstract: The other shoe drops hard.

Grexit isn’t a hard stretch from here — the much feared mother of all bank runs has already happened, which means that the cost-benefit analysis starting from here is much more favorable to euro exit than it ever was before.

headline: Chris Squire, Founding Bassist With the Rock Band Yes, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Squire was the only member to have played on every one of Yes’s albums and participated in every one of its tours.
lead_paragraph: Chris Squire, the influential rock bassist who was a founding member of the celebrated British band Yes, died on Saturday in Phoenix. He was 67.

headline: Seeking Genuine Discovery on Music Streaming Services
abstract: I have a recurring problem with most streaming-service playlists: Though I keep listening out of animal curiosity for what comes next, I am almost never surprised.
lead_paragraph: One day last week I woke up and decided I wanted to have the best morning ever.

headline: Yankees Pay the Price for Miscommunicating on Another Routine Fly
abstract: Brett Gardner and Garrett Jones allowed a ball to drop between them in the outfield, helping the Astros gain a split of a weekend series.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — One of the most rudimentary drills at the most elementary levels of baseball involves learning how to handle a fly ball hit between fielders. There are rules that dictate which fielders have priority. Sometimes coded words are used — not simply “I’ve got it” — to erase any confusion.

headline: Royal Ballet’s Focus on British Choreography Exposes Its Limits
abstract: Dances by no fewer than seven British choreographers composed the company’s closing program, which played four performances at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: In recent years a remarkably high number of British choreographers have been working internationally: Richard Alston, David Bintley, Christopher Bruce, Michael Clark, David Dawson, Wayne McGregor, Ashley Page, Liam Scarlett, Christopher Wheeldon, Matthew Bourne. I’ve even heard New Yorkers suggest that there should be a British choreography festival here. Instead, the Royal Ballet has brought us a season comprised almost entirely of British choreography. Even its sole non-British work, the “Beau Gosse” solo from Bronislava Nijinska’s 1924 ballet “Le Train Bleu,” has a strongly British connection: It was created for the Anglo-Irish dancer Anton Dolin (born Patrick Kay), who in the 1980s reconstructed it and another Nijinska solo for the Royal British soloist Stephen Beagley.

headline: Review: ‘Larry Kramer in Love & Anger,’ Portrait of the Rebel as Gay Activist
abstract: A documentary examines the playwright, a founder of the Gay Men’s Health Crisis, and a man noted for the passion of his convictions.
lead_paragraph: On its surface, Monday night’s HBO documentary, “Larry Kramer in Love & Anger,” seems like a perfect postscript to a historic week for gay rights, marked by the Supreme Court’s affirmation of same-sex marriage. The film even culminates in a wedding, with Mr. Kramer, the AIDS activist and playwright, marrying his longtime partner, David Webster.

headline: Urgent Recall for Some Jeep Grand Cherokees and Dodge Durangos

headline: Review: Kevin Kwan’s ‘China Rich Girlfriend’ Skewers Vulgar Wealth in Asia
abstract: The second volume in what has been projected as a gossipy, good-humored trilogy features tales of the young and superrich as they squander huge sums of money.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Kwan’s brand of giddy wealth porn arrived in 2013 with “Crazy Rich Asians,” not a moment too soon to rescue a worn-out and useless genre. The vulgar rich had taken over reality TV, fictionalized TV (which seemed tepid by comparison), the occasional freakish documentary (like “The Queen of Versailles”) and the kind of fiction that heard its sell-by knell when “Bergdorf Blondes” and all its copycats came along. There was nothing new to be said about crass New Yorkers, Texans, Hollywood types or even tech billionaires, whose excesses weren’t usually that showy. A whole money-wasting continent had been milked dry.

headline: Joni Mitchell Suffered Aneurysm, but Can Speak, Conservator Says
abstract: Joni Mitchell’s conservator released a statement on Sunday denying speculation about the singer’s deteriorating health.
lead_paragraph: For the past few weeks, various reports have been swirling about Joni Mitchell’s medical condition, with the singer David Crosby saying on Friday that she was unable to speak after suffering an aneurysm. In her first statement since April, Ms. Mitchell’s conservator, Leslie Morris, responded in a statement on Sunday, saying that Ms. Mitchell had an aneurysm but that she was speaking and recovering well.

headline: You’re Better Than This, Europe
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Shirking the obligation to protect refugees betrays our core values.
lead_paragraph: STRASBOURG, France — DURING the last seven decades, European countries have painstakingly tried to rebuild a continent once shattered by war and atrocities according to the values of solidarity and human rights. We built institutions to prevent the crimes of the past and we made a commitment to help those in need of protection.

headline: Marva Collins, Educator Who Aimed High for Poor, Black Students, Dies at 78
abstract: At Westside Preparatory School in Chicago, which she opened in 1975, Ms. Collins set high academic standards, emphasized discipline and promoted a nurturing environment.
lead_paragraph: Marva Collins, a former substitute teacher whose success at educating poor black students in a private school she founded made her a candidate for secretary of education and the subject of a television movie, died on Wednesday in a hospice near her home in South Carolina. She was 78.

But even as voters weigh their options for a new leader, and look ahead to a change of direction for the country, their departing president has other plans.

headline: As Charleston Church Mourns, Biden Adds His Prayers
abstract: The Rev. DePayne Middleton-Doctor was memorialized, after what the authorities described as the racially motivated murder of nine people inside one of the Deep South’s most historic churches.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — On Sunday afternoon, hours after the weekly worship service, the pews of Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church filled again, and this city turned anew to the rite, now sadly familiar, of mourning another victim of a massacre.

headline: Tunisian Gunman Showed Subtle Signs of Radicalization
abstract: Seifeddine Rezgui, the Tunisian student who shot 39 tourists at a seaside hotel on Friday, was a break-dancer in his youth but turned to extremism while in college.
lead_paragraph: GAAFOUR, Tunisia — The Tunisian student who shot 39 tourists at a seaside hotel on Friday was a silent loner who showed signs of radicalism in the past year but hid his real intentions, according to relatives, neighbors and the student’s Facebook page.

headline: China and India Are Sitting Out Refugee Crisis
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Asia’s giants could play leadership roles but see it as a losing issue that could diminish their clout and bilateral interests.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When a deadly earthquake rocked Nepal in April, China and India rushed to send relief supplies and search-and-rescue teams. But when another humanitarian crisis — boats bearing thousands of migrants — appeared off Southeast Asian shores a month later, Asia’s two most populous countries said and did little. Instead, offers to resettle the migrants came from Gambia and the United States.

headline: 5 Days That Left a Confederate Flag Wavering, and Likely to Fall
abstract: Through churches, social media and the relatives of the nine African-Americans who were killed in Charleston, S.C., a campaign converted or tamed opponents.
lead_paragraph: Inside the old granite State House in South Carolina, one day after the massacre in a Charleston church, an African-American receptionist politely gave everyone who called to complain about the Confederate battle flag the same response: “Sorry, there’s nothing to be done.”

headline: Combative Maine Governor Becomes a Party of One
abstract: Gov. Paul R. LePage of Maine has generated a bipartisan backlash in the Legislature, and even talk of impeachment, with a rough style and a flurry of vetoes.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Me. — When Paul R. LePage, Maine’s combative governor, was seeking re-election last year, he told voters that his days of intemperate remarks were over. At a debate, Mr. LePage, who is of French descent, memorably said: “Even a Frenchman can be taught to cool down.”

headline: Astros’ New Inclination Is to Flatten Their Hill
abstract: Tal’s Hill at Minute Maid Park, an embankment in center field that has been the site of spectacular catches and comical tumbles alike, will be removed after this season.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — This season will be the 16th and last for Tal’s Hill, an embankment in deep center field that is the distinctive feature at Minute Maid Park. This month, the Houston Astros announced that the hill would be removed, the fences would be moved in, and a restaurant and bars would be constructed in its place, a $15 million investment in the name of improving the fan experience.

headline: Polo Fades in India on the Backs of Endangered Ponies
abstract: The decline of polo and of the Manipuri pony, which was once used in warfare and is now endangered, began when state patronage for polo players ended, around the time of India’s annexation of Manipur.
lead_paragraph: The Indian state of Manipur, the birthplace of modern polo, is home to the oldest active polo ground, Mapal Kangjeibung. Here, the “game of kings” is the province of the common man: Masons, laborers, government employees and police officers populate the roughly 20 active polo clubs in Imphal, the capital.

lead_paragraph: Just days after state legislators agreed to extend rent regulations for another four years, New York City’s Rent Guidelines Board is scheduled to vote on Monday evening on whether to increase rents for more than one million rent-stabilized apartments.

headline: A Paris Designer Sets up a Creative Commune in the Hollywood Hills
abstract: Bernhard Willhelm — known for his zany prints and creative cuts — recently relocated his home and studio to Los Angeles, bringing his entourage (and their wild ways) along for the party.
lead_paragraph: “I have an enormous need for freedom,” says Bernhard Willhelm. “I realized that I like being not too comfortable, but rather the opposite.” Earlier this year, the Bavarian-born fashion designer and provocateur — known for his outlandish prints and silhouettes and an ongoing shoe collaboration with Camper — uprooted his studio from Paris to a rustic 1957 house built into a steep hill in Hollywood’s Beachwood Canyon. Now, rather than the click-clack of heels along the boulevards, he hears hummingbirds as he works alongside his familial team, including his business partner, Jutta Kraus, who lives with him, and other designers and assistants who came along from Paris. “I think this choice turned out to be very spontaneous and a bit naïve, too, but it’s always been that way in my life,” says Wilhelm, who had visited California only once before making the move. “Germans make rational decisions and sometimes I decide to do emotional ones.”

headline: Paris’s New Korean Joint, From Some of the City’s Coolest Expats
abstract: The owners of Candelaria, Glass and Le Mary Celeste recently opened Hero, where diners are encouraged to get messy.
lead_paragraph: Emerge from the metro at the Strasbourg Saint-Denis station and you can’t help but instantly catch sight of the neon pink sign beaming the word “Hero.” The neighborhood’s colorful, late-night reputation might lead some to assume the sign marks yet another sex shop or dive bar. Instead, this spot beckons a hungry crowd.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5 P.M. (Lifetime) WHILE YOU WERE SLEEPING (1995) Lucy (Sandra Bullock), a lonely Chicago train station clerk, leaps to the rescue when Peter (Peter Gallagher), the object of her unspoken desire, is pushed onto the train tracks and falls into a coma. But after a nurse mistakenly identifies her as Peter’s fiancée, she suddenly finds herself surrounded by the family she never had — including his charmingly suspicious brother, Jack (Bill Pullman). When a romantic comedy is “as breezy and adorable” as this one from Jon Turteltaub, “it’s time to fall in love,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “This is a formula film, but it has the kind of good cheer and fine tuning that occasionally give slickness a good name.” Ms. Bullock, above with Micole Mercurio, left, Monica Keena and Jack Warden, brings “a warm smile and a winning array of mannerisms to her role,” she added. And “as Jack does a perpetual slow burn in Lucy’s presence, Mr. Pullman smolders with consummate ease,” engaging in “the graceful teamwork that really makes this story click.”

headline: The Satirical Relief After China’s Pressure-Cooker College Exam

abstract: President Obama has an opportunity to shed more light on major political donors.

headline: ‘The Full Catastrophe,’ by James Angelos
abstract: As the debt crisis drags on, Greece grapples with austerity.
lead_paragraph: On a December night in 2009, two ­larcenous officials in Pangaio, in the mountains of northern Greece, lured the town’s mayor to a rendezvous on a quiet coastal road. Fearful that state auditors were about to expose the three men’s systematic looting of the municipal treasury, they shot their co-conspirator to death with an Uzi submachine gun to silence him, then jammed his corpse into the trunk of his car, where it was found three days later. The killers were sentenced to lengthy jail terms, but — this being Greece, a country notorious for its bloated work force and a safety net that even protects the jobs of convicted criminals — they continued drawing a portion of their salaries while sitting in prison. “They Murdered the Mayor but Still Get Paid!” ran the headline in one Greek newspaper.

headline: ‘By the People’ and ‘Wages of Rebellion’
abstract: George Packer on new books by Charles Murray and Chris Hedges about collective discontent in America.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, it wasn’t hard to find Americans who thought a revolution was coming. At the depths of the recession, in hard-hit places like the North Carolina tobacco country or the exurbs of Tampa Bay, I met plenty of people who believed we were one power blackout or gas shortage away from civil unrest, political violence, even martial law. The feeling didn’t conform to strictly partisan lines, and the objects of wrath included bêtes noires of both the left and the right: banks, oil companies, federal and state governments, news media. At Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, a Tea Party couple visiting from rural Virginia was surprised to find a patch of common ground with Occupiers — at least until the discussion turned to actual policies. The anger was populist, which is ideologically capacious. The enemy was bigness, feathering its own nest and conspiring against the little guy.

headline: Highball Season
abstract: Bartenders share recipes for their seasonal takes on the fast, simple and lower-proof cocktail.
lead_paragraph: Highballs are gaining real estate on craft cocktail bar menus around the world thanks to their quick-prep appeal: By definition, a highball should be relatively fast and easy to make, as well as lower in proof. Stylistically, the drinks range from old-school, Phillip Marlowesque whiskey and sodas, to more deconstructed iterations, often featuring just one unexpected ingredient. And an approach centering on fresh juice — citrus, seasonal syrups, infusions — is big this summer.

headline: A Mellow Summer in Asheville (With Moog Music)

lead_paragraph: While the beach may be a preferred destination for Independence Day travelers, Asheville, N.C., a city that rests seamlessly among the Blue Ridge Mountains, puts a unique spin on summer relaxation. With the Pisgah National Forest nearby, as well as the scenic grounds of the Biltmore Estate, a French Renaissance chateau built by George Washington Vanderbilt, the North Carolina Arboretum and the Carl Sandburg Home in Flat Rock, among many other sites, the region embraces tranquillity. The city (with roughly 87,000 residents) is also known for its quirky characteristics, with its liberal political leanings in a traditionally conservative region, along with its numerous streetside music performances.

Hertz, who was taken prisoner by Viet Cong guerrillas Feb. 2, is under a threat of retaliatory execution if the Saigon government puts to death a terrorist arrested for the March 30 bombing of the U.S. embassy. headline: A Ring That Builds on One Italian Brand’s Heritage

And I always say that we keep opening stores to make Roberto happy, so he can build them.” That know-how led to the creation of a standout ring from the duo’s Capri Girl collection, a curved, diamond-encrusted screw in gold or silver. “We’ve always been nongraphic, very feminine and romantic,” Scognamiglio says, “so this marks an evolution” — a little bit Dolce Vita, a little bit rock ‘n’ roll.

Social media erupted in applause at the sight of an African-American woman wresting the emblem of hate from its place of pride so soon after an avowed white supremacist had been charged with murdering nine black parishioners at a church in Charleston.

headline: An Ocean Mystery in the Trillions
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Marine Biology']
abstract: Much is still not known about the bristlemouth, the planet’s most plentiful vertebrate. What’s more, the ocean, making up 99 percent of the biosphere, may hold untold undiscovered species.
lead_paragraph: Habitats on land — rain forests, steppes, woodlands, deserts, alpine meadows, all well explored over the centuries — make up less than 1 percent of the planet’s biosphere. Why so little? The band of life is narrow. Fertile soil goes down only a few feet, and even the tallest trees stretch up only a few hundred feet. Birds can fly higher, but must return to the surface for nourishment.

headline: Review: ‘The Quartet,’ by Joseph Ellis, Details the Constitution’s Gang of Four
abstract: A history describes how Washington, Madison, Hamilton and Jay led the 1787 Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia into producing a document for nation-building.
lead_paragraph: More than two centuries after the ratification of the Constitution, the historian Joseph J. Ellis writes in his absorbing new book, “The Quartet,” “a mystic haze has formed” around that document. Much as he captured the human beings behind the marble masks of the founders in earlier books, so he examines here the contingent roles that fortune, visionary ideals and pragmatic politics all played in forging a framework for the fledgling nation, a set of ideas and institutions that would become a model of representative government.

headline: Review: ‘SILENT dialogue,’ From Dai Jian, Dances From Room to Room at the Met
abstract: This three-hour work features nine dancers roaming the art museum and interacting with the audience.
lead_paragraph: If you were browsing the Melanesian artifacts in Gallery 354 of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night, you might have been alarmed by a sudden onrush of people in white jumpsuits. They swarmed the long, cavernous room like flocking birds, darting among glass-encased statues and masks. Dropping to the floor, they slithered toward an outcropping of New Guinea totem poles and draped their limbs over the display’s protective railing, flirting with its tacit mandate: Don’t touch the art.
