headline: Think Like a Doctor
abstract: Documents that are part of this week’s Think Like a Doctor were accidentally published ahead of schedule.
lead_paragraph: Documents that will be part of this week’s “Think Like a Doctor” column were accidentally published ahead of schedule. Please check back Wednesday, July 1, 2015 for the full column.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Disney Merges Consumer Product and Interactive Units
abstract: The restructuring that joins Disney Consumer Products and Disney Interactive reflects growing overlap between the two businesses.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Children do not separate their toys into two piles — traditional and digital — and now the Walt Disney Company won’t either.

headline: Greeks Rally Against Austerity Rules
abstract: Thousands of anti-austerity demonstrators gathered outside the Parliament building in Athens to show their support to the Greek government in its negotiations with international creditors.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of anti-austerity demonstrators gathered outside the Parliament building in Athens to show their support to the Greek government in its negotiations with international creditors.

headline: Review: ‘The Bad Doctor’ and ‘Graphic Medicine Manifesto’
abstract: Two intriguing new works make a case, in entirely different ways, for how graphic depictions of care are creating a new scholarly discipline.
lead_paragraph: A small hourglass stands next to the computer on Dr. Iwan James’s office desk. No symbolism is intended — the device is actually a cheap 10-minute egg timer, exactly the length of a routine appointment in Dr. James’s general practice in a small Welsh town. It was donated by an annoyed patient specifically to embarrass the doctor.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Celgene to Pay $1 Billion for Biotech Collaboration With Juno
abstract: As part of the deal, Celgene will acquire 9.1 million shares of Juno, a leader in cancer drugs that use patients’ immune systems to attack tumors.
lead_paragraph: Celgene, a leading biotech company, said on Monday that it would pay about $1 billion to start a collaboration with Juno Therapeutics, a leader in the hot new area of cancer drugs that harness patients’ immune systems to attack tumors.

headline: A Scientific Ethical Divide Between China and West
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Medicine and Health', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Confucianism']
abstract: Some experts worry that medical researchers are stepping over established ethical boundaries in Beijing’s effort to lift its scientific standing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is spending hundreds of billions of dollars annually in an effort to become a leader in biomedical research, building scores of laboratories and training thousands of scientists.

headline: Review: The Whitney’s Conlon Nancarrow Festival is an Enchanting Tribute
abstract: “Anywhere in Time,” the 11-day festival at the new Whitney Museum, included a seven-hour marathon of Conlon Nancarrow’s studies for player piano.
lead_paragraph: Has there ever been an engine of delight more focused and industrious than Conlon Nancarrow? This sui generis composer restricted himself almost entirely to a single medium, and an eccentric one: the player piano, that mechanical parlor ghost into which rolls of paper dotted with holes are fed.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center and Sony Music Team Up for Blue Engine Records
abstract: Jazz at Lincoln Center will release the recordings from its vaults through an agreement with a division of Sony Music.
lead_paragraph: Jazz at Lincoln Center has shelves upon shelves of recordings from concerts it has presented since its founding in 1987, including a studio recording featuring the pianist Chick Corea, a musical Mass with a gospel choir written for the 200th anniversary of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York and concerts with the saxophonists Sherman Irby and Ted Nash.

headline: Study Suggests That Google Has Its Thumb on Scale in Search
keywords: ['Search Engines', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Researchers presented 2,690 web users with two different versions of Google and found that the users preferred results that linked to rival sites.
lead_paragraph: Google entices people to search by promising links to the best that the web has to offer. But research released Monday, led by top academics but paid for by one of Google’s rivals, suggests that Google sometimes alters results to play up its own content despite people’s preferences.

headline: Review: Syd tha Kyd, Betwixt and Between on ‘Ego Death’
abstract: The latest release from the Internet (made up of two Odd Future alums) is infused with sexual swagger.
lead_paragraph: THE INTERNET

headline: Pictures of the Day: Burundi and Elsewhere
abstract: Burundi and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Burundi and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: ‘Spirits of the Air & Heroes’ Takes on Legend and Fairy Tale
abstract: Christopher Williams’s choreography, shown in the Dig Dance series, works with opera music and feminist themes.
lead_paragraph: Does the choreographer Christopher Williams, with his fascination for ancient myths and legends, breathe a different air than the rest of us? His world is one of fairies and gods, where dancers curve their arms and backs in juicy opposition to their lower bodies, and the stage sometimes looks like a sculpture garden coming to life.

headline: June 29, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Burundi, Egypt, Spain and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Burundi, Egypt, Spain and Greece.

headline: Solid Sound Festival
abstract: Images of performers at the festival.
lead_paragraph: Images of performers at the festival.

headline: Wilco Tinkers and Experiments at a Festival It’s Happy to Share
abstract: The Solid Sound Festival in North Adams, Mass., is determinedly upbeat, inclusive and family-friendly, and it features a convergence of grown-up indie tastes.
lead_paragraph: NORTH ADAMS, Mass. — “This is my son Spencer,” Jeff Tweedy said onstage at the Solid Sound Festival on Sunday night, presenting his new band, Tweedy, by introducing its 19-year-old drummer. A moment later he caught himself, observing that this crowd probably didn’t need to be briefed. But he went on, “just in case somebody wandered in,” he said, “and didn’t realize it was a cult gathering.”

headline: Review: Pianist Ursula Oppens Seamlessly Connects the Classics With New Music
abstract: In a solo recital at Bargemusic, Ms. Oppens performed recent pieces alongside works by Schubert, Beethoven and Scriabin.
lead_paragraph: Ursula Oppens is an eloquent pianist who has long been a persuasive advocate of new music, which she presents not as a discipline separate from the interpretation of the classics but as an extension of that work. The connection felt especially organic in the solo recital she presented at Bargemusic on Friday evening.

headline: Seattle’s Little ‘Up’ House Faces Razing After Buyers Back Out
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Movies', 'Land Use Policies', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The house, popular with locals and tourists for its resemblance to the one in the Disney movie, could be demolished after a recent sale fell through.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Edith Macefield’s tiny house in the old waterfront neighborhood of Ballard — likened by many people to the house in the Disney movie “Up,” in spirit and architecture — will have to be torn down or hauled away, its owner said on Monday.

headline: AC/DC Songs Will Be Added to Streaming Services Like Apple Music
abstract: Signaling the general acceptance of online music, the band, which has long resisted the digital business, will sign on with services like Spotify and Rdio.
lead_paragraph: One sign that streaming music has now fully entered the mainstream: AC/DC is on board.

headline: Turkey Uneasy as U.S. Support of Syrian Kurds Grows
keywords: ['Kurds', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Ankara is said to be weighing options like setting up a buffer zone within Syria in an effort to contain the ambitions of the Kurds.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The United States has stepped up its military support for Syrian Kurdish militias fighting the Islamic State, efforts that have angered Turkey, a longtime ally and NATO member, which is now weighing new measures to contain the ambitions of the Kurds, including a buffer zone within Syria.

headline: New York City Board Votes to Freeze Regulated Rents on One-Year Leases
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: The move, unprecedented in the 46-year history of the Rent Guidelines Board, was the first decision on rent levels by a nine-member panel appointed in its entirety by Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: The board that regulates rents for more than one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City voted on Monday night for a freeze on one-year leases, an unprecedented move in its 46-year history.

headline: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Appeal in Google-Oracle Copyright Fight
abstract: A years-long copyright fight between Google and Oracle will continue. At issue are the bits of code that help pieces of software work together, called Application Programming Interfaces.
lead_paragraph: Many in the tech community expressed dismay at a Supreme Court decision on Monday not to hear the appeal of a copyright decision against Google.

headline: Brash Personality Seen as Chris Christie’s Main Asset
abstract: The New Jersey governor is no longer a potential front-runner in the 2016 Republican presidential primary race, but he is expected to stand out in the field.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump makes the rest of the Republican presidential primary field look responsible, Chris Christie threatens to make the others look boring.

headline: At the Supreme Court, a Win for Direct Democracy
abstract: The Constitution has its holes, but in the Arizona redistricting case, the justices found a fix.
lead_paragraph: IN 2000, voters in Arizona adopted a state constitutional amendment that created an independent commission to draw congressional districts. But the commission immediately faced a legal challenge: the United States Constitution gives the power to state legislatures (and to Congress) to regulate national elections — not to the voters. Can the word “legislature” in the Constitution mean voters themselves?

headline: Making a Confederate Flag Invisible
abstract: Removing the Confederate flag from the public square is but a first step toward deeper reflection on race.
lead_paragraph: Removing the Confederate flag from the public square is but a first step toward deeper reflection on race.

headline: Germany’s Prolific Offense vs. United States’ Stingy Defense
abstract: The matchup between Germany and the U.S. features the tournament’s best offense and defense. Which side will come out on top?
lead_paragraph: The matchup between Germany and the U.S. features the tournament’s best offense and defense. Which side will come out on top?

headline: U.S. Tells Iran That Preliminary Nuclear Deal Must Stand
abstract: A senior American official declined to say if the United States might agree to adjust some elements of the Lausanne framework in return for new Iranian concessions.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The United States warned Iran on Monday, in both English and Persian, that a preliminary agreement reached two months ago in Switzerland must remain the basis for a final nuclear deal.

headline: Peace Eludes South Sudan as Rivals Hold Talks
abstract: A spokesman for the rebels said that “progress is being made” in negotiations to end South Sudan’s civil war, even as forces had seized the strategic city of Malakal.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Even as South Sudan’s president, Salva Kiir, and his longtime rival, the rebel leader Riek Machar, met here at the behest of Kenya’s president to end South Sudan’s civil war, Mr. Machar’s forces captured the strategic city of Malakal.

headline: Fast-Food Restaurants Should Raise Minimum Wage, New York Panel Says
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Restaurants', 'Living Wage', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The three-man panel said it was not yet ready to make a complete recommendation.
lead_paragraph: The minimum wage for fast-food workers in New York should be raised substantially, maybe even to $15 an hour, a state panel appointed to study the issue said on Monday.

headline: Ahead of the World Cup Semifinals, Close Quarters for the Players
abstract: Germany and the United States were sharing a hotel before meeting Tuesday with a chance to advance to the finals on the line.
lead_paragraph: AHEAD OF SEMIS, CLOSE QUARTERS

headline: Russia: Officials Meet on Syrian Crisis
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Russia’s foreign minister said Monday that he would meet Tuesday with Secretary of State John Kerry to discuss the crisis in Syria and rising attacks by extremists.
lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia said Monday that he would meet Tuesday with Secretary of State John Kerry in Vienna to discuss the crisis in Syria and rising attacks by extremists. The announcement coincided with a visit to Moscow by Foreign Minister Walid al-Moallem of Syria for talks with Mr. Lavrov and President Vladimir V. Putin.  Mr. Putin pledged continued support for Syria, and said all the countries in the region should pool their efforts in “fighting the evil that is the Islamic State.” Mr. Moallem questioned the likelihood of a joint regional effort. “I know that Putin is a man who works miracles,” he said, “but an alliance with Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Qatar and the United States would require a very big miracle.”

headline: Low-Ranked Briton Wins, Surprising Even Himself
abstract: Liam Broady, ranked 182nd in the world, rallied from two sets down to knock off the Australian Marinko Matosevic, 5-7, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2, 6-3.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — During his postmatch interview on Monday, Liam Broady noted that being a 21-year-old from Manchester, England, playing in his first Grand Slam event could explain some of the saucy language he used that led to a warning from the chair umpire.

headline: Colorado Court Rules Use of Public Funds for Private Schools Is Unconstitutional
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Vouchers', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Colorado Supreme Court ruled that a school district’s voucher program violated a plank of the state constitution that explicitly prevents public money from going to religious schools.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Colorado’s highest court on Monday struck down a voucher program that allowed parents in a conservative suburban school district to use taxpayer dollars to send their children to private schools.

headline: U.N. Council Extends Troops’ Presence in Darfur
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: The council agreed unanimously to keep peacekeepers in Sudan’s Darfur region for at least another year, but did not reach a consensus on how to help gain custody of Sudan’s president.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — United Nations peacekeepers will remain in the Darfur region of Sudan for at least another year, the Security Council decided in a unanimous vote on Monday.

headline: AOL in Deal With Microsoft to Take Over Display Ad Business
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Search Engines', 'Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: AOL will take over management and sales of display, mobile and video advertising that appears on Xbox, Skype and other Microsoft products in several countries.
lead_paragraph: When the deal for Verizon to buy AOL was announced last month, executives from both companies said AOL was an appealing acquisition because of its advertising technology. On Monday, AOL showed some of the value in announcing a deal with Microsoft.

headline: Israel to Build Fence Along at Least Part of Jordan Frontier
abstract: The plan will move Israel closer to completely surrounding itself with physical barriers.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israel has built fences on its frontiers with Lebanon, Syria and Egypt. It has constructed barriers through parts of the occupied West Bank and along the border with Gaza.

headline: F.B.I. Opens Investigation Into New York Prison Where 2 Escaped
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prison Escapes', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The investigation, which is focused on drug trafficking and other possible criminal conduct, is likely to raise the scrutiny of prison officials and the apparent lack of oversight before the escape.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation in Albany has opened a corruption inquiry focusing on employees and inmates at the maximum-security prison in northern New York State where two convicted killers escaped this month, one official with knowledge of the matter said on Monday.

headline: Fitting Effort by Lleyton Hewitt in Wimbledon Farewell
abstract: As Hewitt faced Jarkko Nieminen at Wimbledon, someone’s sentimental journey had to end, and it turned out to be Hewitt’s despite the Australian extending the fifth set after saving two match points.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — On one side of the net Monday was Lleyton Hewitt, playing in his final Wimbledon. On the other side of the net was Jarkko Nieminen, playing in his final Wimbledon.

headline: Ben Wattenberg, Neoconservative Author and PBS Host, Is Dead at 81
abstract: Mr. Wattenberg was a self-professed neoconservative and PBS commentator who was wary of a Democratic move to the left.
lead_paragraph: Ben Wattenberg, an author, a PBS television commentator and a professed neoconservative who vainly urged his fellow Democrats to court the nation’s centrist voters at a time when the party was moving to the left, died Sunday in Washington. He was 81.

headline: Obama Making Millions More Americans Eligible for Overtime
keywords: ['Overtime', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The move by the White House restores the overtime threshold to about where it was in 1975 in terms of purchasing power.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced Monday night a rule change that would make millions more Americans eligible for overtime pay.

headline: Squabbling, Hesitation and Luck Had Roles in Manhunt for New York Prison Escapees
abstract: A week distinguished by DNA discoveries and well-organized sweeps was the final stage of a 23-day slog that was hampered, at times, by missed signals.
lead_paragraph: After tunneling out of maximum-security cells, Richard W. Matt and David Sweat waited for the Jeep, driven by a cooperating prison employee, that would take them to Mexico.

headline: 3 U.S. Churches Weighing Divestment Resolutions in Support of Palestinians
abstract: Delegates to the annual gatherings for the United Church of Christ, the Episcopal Church and the Mennonites are expected to vote this week.
lead_paragraph: Delegates to annual gatherings this week of three United States churches with millions of members were considering resolutions to divest from companies deemed supportive of Israeli occupation in the Palestinian territories, or to boycott products made in Israeli settlements. Votes on resolutions at the Cleveland synod of the United Church of Christ and the Episcopal Church’s general convention in Salt Lake City were expected to come up for votes on Tuesday, representatives of those churches said Monday. A resolution at the Mennonites’ meeting in Kansas City, Mo., was scheduled for Wednesday. Advocates of the Boycott, Divest and Sanction movement seek to pressure Israel economically over the Palestinian issue. Many advocates for Israel consider the movement a guise for anti-Semitism and for delegitimizing Israel.

headline: Loads of Debt: A Global Ailment With Few Cures
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Beyond Greece and Puerto Rico, heavy borrowing is bogging down the economies of Brazil, Turkey, Italy and China.
lead_paragraph: There are some problems that not even $10 trillion can solve.

headline: Women’s World Cup: When These Two Stars Clash, the Gloves Are On
abstract: The semifinal match between the Americans and the Germans will pit Hope Solo, whom many consider the world’s best goalkeeper, against Nadine Angerer.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — When Germany, the world’s top team, meets the United States, the world’s second-ranked squad, in a Women’s World Cup semifinal game Tuesday, there will be a matchup of goalkeepers befitting the stakes.

headline: Court Lets Some Charities Avoid Rules on Birth Control Coverage
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Nonprofit Organizations']
abstract: An order bars the Obama administration from enforcing the rules against some religious groups until the Supreme Court decides whether to hear an appeal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued an order on Monday that allows certain nonprofit religious groups to avoid compliance with federal rules concerning insurance coverage of contraceptives for women.

headline: Boston’s Revised 2024 Olympics Bid Criticized as Incomplete
abstract: Sought by Massachusetts Gov. Charlie Baker, the overhauled plan to attract the Games lacked key pieces of information, including insurance against cost overruns, identities of venues and plans for an athletes’ village.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Suppose your teacher told you that an assignment was due by a certain day. You stayed up half the night, produced a nice-looking package a day before the deadline and patted yourself on the back for handing it in early.

headline: Police Department to Redefine Chokehold to Match City Council Bill
abstract: The department has not dropped its opposition to the legislation, which would criminalize police use of the maneuver.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department is poised to narrow its definition of a chokehold, adopting language from a City Council bill aimed at criminalizing police use of the maneuver.

headline: Jack Carter, Comedian Who Brought His Rapid-Fire Delivery to TV, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Carter was a comic and an actor possessing a rapid-fire delivery, a barrage of one-liners and impressions, a dancer’s light-footedness and a more than passable singing voice.
lead_paragraph: Jack Carter, a motor-mouthed comedian who became one of television’s first stars in the late 1940s and continued working, as both a comic and an actor, well into the 21st century, died on Sunday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Review: In Beckett’s ‘Happy Days,’ a Woman Buried Deep by Inertia
abstract: Brooke Adams and Tony Shalhoub star in this production at the Flea Theater, directed by Andrei Belgrader.
lead_paragraph: The wattage of Winnie’s smile is what makes it so disconcerting — that and the way it lights up her eyes as she chatters on, her willful cheer sparkling in the sun like the diamonds that glint from her earlobes.

headline: Review: ‘Shows for Days,’ With Patti LuPone as a Diva With Depth
abstract: Douglas Carter Beane’s new play, at Lincoln Center, draws on his memories of working at a community playhouse as a teenager.
lead_paragraph: Though she has been known to chew scenery into sawdust, Patti LuPone shrewdly resists making a feast of her high-calorie role in “Shows for Days,” the unresolved new comedy by Douglas Carter Beane that opened on Monday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.

headline: Impressive Show of Courage
abstract: A smooth and easy Tuesday offering by Susan Gelfand.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — You will barely need me for this, that’s how easy and smooth this one by Susan Gelfand went down. Like crossword pudding. The good kind, not the bland, hospital kind.

headline: The Hard Line on Greece
abstract: Greece is in a standoff with the European Union, and everyone is trying to “war game” the outcome. Who is bluffing? The Greeks or the E.U.?
lead_paragraph: In July 2012, Timothy F. Geithner, the United States Treasury secretary at the time, traveled to Sylt, an island off Germany in the North Sea.

headline: A Divided Court on Three Big Rulings
abstract: Dissents in a death penalty case included reasons to end all executions. The justices were also split in redistricting and environmental decisions.
lead_paragraph: An interesting thing happened on the way to Monday morning’s predictable Supreme Court ruling upholding Oklahoma’s use of a controversial lethal-injection drug.

headline: Yankees Set for Rare Shutout From All-Star Starting Lineup
abstract: For the first time in 16 years and the second time since 1992, it appears there will not be a Yankee in the American League’s starting lineup.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Back-to-back seasons without the playoffs, declining television ratings and plummeting road attendance are signs that the Yankees have lost some luster.

headline: No Evidence of Hate Crimes in Fires at Black Churches
abstract: At least two of the fires that struck six churches last week were arson, investigators say, adding there are no indications that any of the fires were connected.
lead_paragraph: After a deadly racist attack in South Carolina and heated debates about Confederate symbols, a string of fires at black churches in the South has put congregations on edge. But officials say they have found no evidence that the blazes were hate crimes.

headline: U.S. Lifts Ban on Bahrain Aid
keywords: ['Firearms', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The ban on security assistance to Bahrain was imposed after the nation’s crackdown on demonstrators in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Monday lifted its ban on security assistance to Bahrain that was imposed after the nation’s crackdown on demonstrators in 2011.

headline: Women’s Teams Still Struggle for Fans
abstract: Even the highest-profile women’s sports leagues in the United States continue to face the problem of how to attract wider audiences and greater news media coverage.
lead_paragraph: The Liberty will be in Chicago on Tuesday night to take on the Sky in an important W.N.B.A. game. The United States women’s soccer team will be in Montreal for a critical World Cup match against Germany.

headline: Harold Feinstein Dies at 84; Froze New York Moments in Black and White
abstract: Although Mr. Feinstein immortalized a period in the history of Coney Island, especially, he turned his lens on a wide variety of subjects.
lead_paragraph: Harold Feinstein, whose celebrated series of black-and-white photographs of Coney Island in the 1950s established him as one of the most accomplished recorders of the American experience, and who went on to experiment with color and new digital techniques, died on June 20 at his home in Merrimac, Mass. He was 84.

headline: 13 Metro-North Workers Accused of Cheating on Conductor Exams
abstract: Prosecutors said the defendants stole copies of tests and their answers, then distributed them to other candidates who had yet to take the exams.
lead_paragraph: A dozen current and former employees of the Metro-North Railroad were brought into state court in Manhattan in handcuffs on Monday on charges that they cheated on the exams required to become a train conductor or locomotive engineer.

headline: Charleston Church Mourns One More Beloved Victim
abstract: The historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church held its last funeral Monday for one of the nine victims of what authorities have described as an assault rooted in racism.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — It was just after 10:30 on Monday morning, as yet another hearse stopped in front of Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, when the crowd on Calhoun Street grew quiet.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 30, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “While most humans wish to die a painless death, many do not have that good fortune.”

headline: Tom Adler’s Home Sweet Surf Abode
abstract: The publisher, who releases a new book today, shares with T his view of the nearby break and personal collection of projects and mementos.
lead_paragraph: Like any good hideout, the publisher Tom Adler’s redwood-frame house on Padaro Lane near Carpinteria, Calif., keeps a view of its own freedom. Though the longtime surfer doesn’t quite “chase it like he used to,” the window due south from his writing desk, past a large painted portrait of the poet Sadakichi Hartmann, opens onto a stretch of the Pacific Ocean, where Adler “surfs when there’s surf.” To live for decades at famed breaks like Rincon Point and this one “has been a charmed life, and on top of that I’ve had friendships,” says the former creative director, of finding long-riding waves as a teenager and never leaving.

headline: Senior Tech: A Tablet for Aging Hands Falls Short
abstract: The AARP RealPad promises “no confusion and no frustration” for older adults. Starting with the on button, it delivers the opposite.
lead_paragraph: A tablet can be the perfect gateway gadget when it comes to connecting an aging mom, dad or tech-reluctant grandparent with the rest of the wired world. Small, light and simple, a tablet requires less technical skill and manual dexterity than, say, a laptop or a smartphone.

headline: Word of the Day | coddle
abstract: This word has appeared in 17 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: coddle • \ˈkä-dəl\ • verb

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) TALK TO HER (2002) In Pedro Almodóvar’s tragic comedy, two men — Benigno (Javier Cámara), a nurse, and Marco (Darío Grandinetti), a journalist — share an unusual friendship while they care for their girlfriends: Alicia (Leonor Watling), a dancer, and Lydia (Rosario Flores), a matador, who are both comatose. But their devotion isn’t what it seems: Benigno is obsessive, with no real ties to Alicia. And suddenly romance is tinged with horror. “Like all great doomed affairs, ‘Talk to Her,’ ” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times, “is full of lovely, sweet suffering. And when it’s over, the realization of how much the movie means to you really sinks in; you can’t get it out of your heart.”

headline: Farm Waste and Animal Fats Will Help Power a United Jet
keywords: ['Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Air Pollution', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Later this summer, United Airlines will begin using fuel generated from farm waste and oil from animal fats to help power its commercial flights.
lead_paragraph: Sometime this summer, a United Airlines flight will take off from Los Angeles International Airport bound for San Francisco using fuel generated from farm waste and oils derived from animal fats.

headline: Yankees’ Rallies Hit Snags, Courtesy of Mike Trout’s Glove
abstract: Trout hit his 20th homer of the season for the Angels, but his three spectacular catches in center field did more damage to the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Yankees’ most severe problem Monday night was not the way they swung the bat, pitched, fielded or ran the bases. Their 4-1 loss to the Los Angeles Angels could be traced to a single shortcoming: They hit the ball in the vicinity of Mike Trout.

headline: 2 Dead After Self-Immolation on Japanese Bullet Train
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Immolation', 'Railroads', 'High-Speed Rail Projects']
abstract: A 71-year-old man doused himself and parts of the train’s interior with a flammable liquid before setting himself afire, witnesses said. A woman also died.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A 71-year-old man burned himself to death aboard a Japanese high-speed train on Tuesday in what appeared to be a deliberate act of self-immolation, the authorities and witnesses said. A second passenger on the train, a woman, also died.

headline: Chinese Lawyers Worry New Rules Will Limit Clients’ Defenses
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Human rights lawyers in China, who sometimes face the risk of assault for doing their jobs, say that proposed new limits on courtroom behavior could add the threat of jail to their worries.
lead_paragraph: Chinese lawyers fear that proposed changes to laws governing courtroom behavior will restrict their ability to do their jobs. Lawyers in human rights cases, who already face the threat of assault if they challenge the court authorities, say the additional threat of jail will limit their ability to offer robust defenses for their clients.

headline: Corrections: June 30, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, June 30, 2015
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Making a Confederate Flag Invisible

abstract: Removing the Confederate flag from the public square is but a first step toward deeper reflection on race.

headline: ‘Something Must Be Done About Prince Edward County,’ by Kristen Green
abstract: After Prince Edward County closed its public schools, black children had no access to education.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 10, 1959, black students in Prince Edward County, Va., watched as school buses full of white children rolled through the streets, delivering their charges to the newly opened Prince Edward Academy. To resist court-mandated desegregation, the local school board shuttered the public schools, but not before white volunteers stripped classrooms of desks, books, and supplies for the new academy. Local Jaycees ripped out the high school stadium’s goal posts and transplanted them to the white-only academy’s football field.

headline: New Jersey Could Be a Tough State for Chris Christie to Win
abstract: The governor’s standing in his state has plummeted as complaints grow that he has spent too much time planning a presidential run and not enough addressing the state’s needs.
lead_paragraph: LIVINGSTON, N.J. — The breakup has been a long time coming. For two years, he has spent more and more time away, openly flirting with others in what looked a lot like a trial separation. At home, he got an increasingly chilly reception.

headline: Arianna Huffington’s Improbable, Insatiable Content Machine
abstract: She did more than anyone else to invent the Internet news business. After a decade, despite setbacks, she is still setting the pace.
lead_paragraph: One morning in March, a dozen Huffington Post staff members gathered around a glass table in Arianna Huffington’s office. They had been summoned to deliver a progress report to Huffington, the site’s president, editor in chief and co-founder, on a new initiative, What’s Working. It was created to help the site cover solutions, rather than focusing only on the world’s problems — or as Huffington explained in an internal memo in January, to ‘‘start a positive contagion by relentlessly telling the stories of people and communities doing amazing things, overcoming great odds and facing real challenges with perseverance, creativity and grace.’’

headline: Chris Christie on the Issues

Known for his blunt, blustery demeanor, he has said his ability to win twice in a heavily Democratic state makes him an attractive candidate for the party in the 2016 general election. Here are his stands on a variety of important issues.

headline: Things You May Not Know About Chris Christie
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie is, to many New Jerseyans, the very definition of an open book. But his biography still manages to contain a few surprises.

But some of the more infrequently recounted parts of his life story might still come as a surprise to many people in his own state, not to mention voters in the Republican primaries.

headline: Chris Christie Announces Run, Pledging ‘Truth’ About Nation’s Woes

lead_paragraph: LIVINGSTON, N.J. — Gov. Chris Christie declared an uphill candidacy for president on Tuesday with New Jersey-style swagger, unconcealed disgust for Washington and a high regard for his own candor, vowing that “there is one thing you will know for sure: I say what I mean and I mean what I say.”

headline: Change Comes From the Margins
keywords: ['Art', 'Philosophy', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Those forced to the margins of society can make the most profound change to the status quo.
lead_paragraph: In 1916, Hugo Ball, the German writer who would soon become a founding member of the Dadaist movement, wrote the following account of his first meeting with the men who would be his artistic and philosophical compatriots: “An Oriental-looking deputation of four little men arrived, with portfolios and pictures under their arms: repeatedly they bowed politely. They introduced themselves: Marcel Janco the painter, Tristan Tzara, Georges Janco, and a fourth gentleman whose name I did not quite catch.”

headline: Joy of a Black Planet
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Travel Noire, a resource for black globe-trotters, continues an online tradition of pulling together like-minded communities.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, Zim Ugochukwu was traveling on the Jagriti Yatra, a 15-day train trip through India for aspiring entrepreneurs. Her time in India wound up sparking an idea for a start-up, though perhaps not in the way the trip’s organizers intended. Ugochukwu was struck by the fact that, out of a group of about 500, she was one of just three African-Americans. She thought about how mainstream travel publications, even those online, weren’t speaking to them or their experiences. ‘‘When I searched ‘black travel’ on Google, I saw a black suitcase,’’ she said. ‘‘That’s not what I meant.’’

headline: America’s ‘Postracial’ Fantasy
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'English Language', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: For millions of mixed-race people, identity fits more than one box, but we still see one another in black and white.
lead_paragraph: On Father’s Day, my dad and I had brunch with some close friends of mine. The conversation soon turned to their two sons: their likes, their dislikes, their habit of disrupting classmates during nap time at nursery school. At one point, as I ran my hand through one of the boys’ silky brown hair, I asked whether they consider their kids biracial. (The father is white; the mother is South Asian.) Before they could respond, the children’s paternal grandmother, in town for a visit, replied as if the answer were the most obvious thing in the world: ‘‘They’re white.’’

headline: Why Television Is Still King for Campaign Spending
abstract: Despite the rise of digital devices, Americans continue to watch an amazing amount of television.
lead_paragraph: Presidential campaign staffers like to talk about a digital strategy, and with good reason. But television continues to occupy the vast majority of most campaigns’ budgets.

headline: Dale DeGroff on the Origin of Cocktails, Katrina and the Rainbow Room
abstract: DeGroff on the best cocktails when traveling, and New Orleans and New York drinking cultures.
lead_paragraph: Dale DeGroff is one of the world’s foremost cocktail experts. His book “The Craft of the Cocktail,” published by Clarkson Potter in 2002, is regarded as an essential bartending guide. He is the founding president of the Museum of the American Cocktail in New Orleans, which reopened earlier this year. Mr. DeGroff is also a consultant working with bars and restaurants through the Beverage Alcohol Resource group, including the new Oleanders in Brooklyn.

headline: The Importance of Hide-and-Seek
abstract: It’s a game. But it’s also what we need in life: the freedom to be found.
lead_paragraph: I’ve found myself wondering lately which of my patients were lucky enough as children to play hide-and-seek with their parents. When it’s played as it’s meant to be, it’s such a delightful game. Kids ask to play it, though, only when they’re confident that they’ll be found. In that way, it’s a bit like psychotherapy: Only when patients feel hopeful that their experiences and feelings will be understood does the work begin in earnest.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Hard-Line Stance on Greece
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Private Equity', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: A Hard-Line Stance on Greece | Few Cures for Heavy Debt Loads | Muted Response to Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis | K.K.R. Settles Over ‘Broken Deal’ Expenses
lead_paragraph: A HARD-LINE STANCE ON GREECE | Greece has until 6 p.m. E.D.T. on Tuesday to make a 1.6 billion euro, or $1.8 billion, payment to the International Monetary Fund, but in an interview on state television on Monday night, the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, strongly suggested that Greece would not make that payment,  Andrew Higgins and Alison Smale write in The New York Times. Late Monday, Jean-Claude Juncker, the head of the European Union’s executive branch, offered Mr. Tsipras a last-minute proposal that presented the possibility of a concession on demands for cuts in bonus payments for the poorest pensioners, European officials said. In return, Mr. Tsipras would have to accept all of the other creditors’ demands, which he had already turned down, and request an emergency meeting of eurozone finance ministers on Tuesday. So far, Mr. Tsipras has not responded publicly.

headline: Sean Scully Fills a Spanish Monastery With Bursts of Color
abstract: The Irish-American artist is showing some of his abstract works in a 1,000-year-old monastery in Spain.
lead_paragraph: MONTSERRAT, Spain — On a hot day in June, the craggy slopes of Montserrat towering above him, the Irish-American painter Sean Scully walked toward the entrance of a small monastery about an hour’s drive from Barcelona. Inside, 22 of his artworks, including six abstract canvases with his signature bands and blocks of color, energize a space that is more than 1,000 years old.

headline: 1915: Germans Using Wireless Code
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Germans are using a wireless station in Long Island in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The New York edition of the Herald charges that the Germans are making use of the wireless station at Sayville, Long Island, to inform their submarines off the English coast of the departure of vessels from the American side. The station is under government censorship, and the transmission of military information is forbidden. It said that the messages, although purporting to be ordinary commercial telegrams, conceal a military code. The Washington correspondent of the Herald takes the government to task in connection with Germany’s forthcoming answer to the Lusitania Note, which is expected to be favorable. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 1, 1915

headline: Argentine City Aims to Stand Out With Rebellious Spirit (and Coke) in a Cup
abstract: Residents of Córdoba, a city of 1.3 million in the interior, pride themselves on doing things differently from their countrymen — even at the bar.
lead_paragraph: CÓRDOBA, Argentina — Backstage at a dance hall, a percussionist, Hugo Núñez, unzipped his rucksack and pulled out two bottles: one of fernet, a bitter Italian liqueur, the other of Coca-Cola. After mixing them in a plastic pint glass, Mr. Núñez sank his lips into the sepia-colored froth and guzzled. That Friday night, the sequence would be repeated by young revelers in bars and dance halls across this city.

headline: Convict Conducted Dry Run of Breakout the Night Before Escaping
abstract: An official said that one of the inmates, David Sweat, also said that he and Richard W. Matt began sawing through their cells about six months before they fled.
lead_paragraph: One of the two convicted killers who escaped in early June from a maximum-security prison in northern New York, setting off a three-week manhunt, conducted a dry run of the breakout the night before they fled, two officials with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: French Prosecutor Seeks Terrorism Charges Against Suspect in Decapitation Attack
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Yassine Salhi is accused of beheading his boss and attempting to cause a major explosion last week at a chemical and gas company’s plant.

headline: 1965: Pakistan and India Pull Troops
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Pakistan and India pull troops from the border in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Pakistan and India today [June 30] began withdrawing troops all along the border on which the two armies have faced each other since the partition of India in 1947. The withdrawal of the 30 divisions was made under an informal ‘‘gentleman’s agreement’’ between the two governments after the formal settlement of their dispute in the Rann of Kutch, the desert wasteland between India and West Pakistan which has been the scene of fighting since January. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 1, 1965

abstract: She becomes the first African-American female principal dancer in the company’s 75-year history.
lead_paragraph: Misty Copeland was fast becoming the most famous ballerina in the United States — making the cover of Time magazine, being profiled by “60 Minutes,” growing into a social media sensation and dancing ballet’s biggest roles on some of its grandest stages. But another role eluded her: She was still not a principal dancer.

headline: A Traffic Accident. A Fire. And Then Their Romance Was Really Tested.
abstract: Nico De Rosa had just left his first meeting with Laurie Smolenski when a minivan slammed into his Vespa. That was just the first calamity.
lead_paragraph: Blood was spilling from cuts on his back and arms, his Vespa was a twist of metal and plastic, his mind was woozy and emergency personnel were swarming the scene.

headline: Dirty Water and Open Defecation Threaten Gains in Child Health
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Infant Mortality', 'Millennium Development Goals', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A report by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children’s Fund says that one in three people in the world have no sanitation facilities.
lead_paragraph: Dirty drinking water and open defecation, particularly in rural areas of many developing countries, are threatening to subvert gains in child survival rates and other health measurements, two major United Nations agencies said Tuesday in a joint report on global progress in sanitation.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 1 | Gender, Race and Shifting Perceptions of Identity
abstract: Bryson W.’s winning essay from our first week, on Caitlyn Jenner, Rachel Donezal and attempts to label identities in “airtight boxes,” and a list of runners-up and honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: Each Friday through Aug. 14 we are posing a simple question to teenagers: What interested you most in The Times this week?

keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Failing to pay the International Monetary Fund holds big negative repercussions with Greece’s other creditors.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Greece on Tuesday added its name to a roster that includes some of the world’s poorest and worst governed nations, including Iraq, Sudan, Somalia and Zimbabwe.

headline: The Chat: Chris Christie’s Announcement Speech, Instantly Analyzed
abstract: Chris Christie cast himself as an anti-Washington candidate and as a strong leader for a nation craving authority after years of fecklessness and weakness.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced his campaign for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday with a speech at his old high school in Livingston, N.J. Over instant messages, two New York Times political correspondents analyzed Mr. Christie’s remarks in real time, as they did with the campaign announcements of several other 2016 candidates. Here is an edited version of their chat.

keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'USA PATRIOT Act']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court ruled late Monday that the National Security Agency may temporarily resume its once-secret program that systematically collects records of Americans’ domestic phone calls in bulk.

headline: A Chef and Her Bluefish
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fishing, Sport', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Chefs']
abstract: The chef April Bloomfield makes a case for the bluefish, an underrated local treat that is as satisfying to cook as it is to catch.
lead_paragraph: I love fishing, though I have to admit I’m not very technical. I pick up tips where I can and somehow still manage to catch fish.

headline: Cuba Wins W.H.O. Certification It Ended Mother-to-Child H.I.V. Transmission
abstract: The island nation was the first country to receive the distinction, which requires 95 percent of elimination targets to be met, for H.I.V. and syphilis transmission.
lead_paragraph: Cuba became the world’s first country on Tuesday to win World Health Organization certification that it had eliminated mother-to-child transmission of both H.I.V. and syphilis. Despite its poverty, Cuba provides basic health care to all citizens. Since the 1980s it has successfully suppressed its H.I.V. epidemic, initially through forced quarantine and, since 1993, by widespread testing and treatment.

headline: Ruling That Apple Led E-Book Pricing Conspiracy Is Upheld
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A federal appeals court said it agreed with a 2013 decision that Apple conspired with publishers to raise prices for e-books.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld a ruling that determined Apple to be the leader of an industrywide conspiracy among book publishers to raise prices of digital books.

headline: Chris Christie’s Town Hall Bluntness to Be Tested
abstract: Chris Christie once again deploys his bluntness to the home state crowd. Will it play elsewhere?
lead_paragraph: In announcing his presidential bid Tuesday, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey laid out the type of campaign that should sound familiar to anyone who has attended of his trademark town halls: blunt, direct and saying exactly what’s on his mind, those offended be damned. The question is whether it will prove effective outside of New Jersey.

headline: A Death the Supreme Court Should Remember
abstract: A former inmate’s death soon after his exoneration drives home Justice Breyer’s concerns about capital punishment.
lead_paragraph: Early on Monday morning in New Orleans, Louisiana, Glenn Ford died of lung cancer. He was 65.

headline: Leonard Nimoy Is Remembered at Symphony Space

headline: What You Get for … $2,900,000

lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a clapboard house in Key West, a loft in Dallas and a converted church in South Carolina.

headline: Veteran Luke Ridnour Rapidly Adds Four Teams to His Résumé
abstract: Luke Ridnour, a 12-year N.B.A. veteran, has become so dispensable because of a $2.75 million nonguaranteed contract that is useful in making deals fit league rules.
lead_paragraph: Everything about Luke Ridnour’s N.B.A. career was fairly nondescript until a week ago. Over 12 seasons, he was gainfully employed by five organizations, averaging 9.3 points and 4.5 assists as he played for the likes of the Milwaukee Bucks and the Minnesota Timberwolves. A steady-handed point guard, he was also capable of shooting well from beyond the 3-point line.

headline: Timing of Christie’s Announcement Has Fund-Raising Advantages
abstract: Though Chris Christie announced his presidential campaign on Tuesday it will be more than three months before rival candidates, the press, and potential supporters know whether he has had any fund-raising success.
lead_paragraph: In fund-raising, as in politics, timing is everything.

headline: Met Extends Show on China’s Fashion Influence
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s “China: Through the Looking Glass” has drawn more than 350,000 visitors since opening, and will be extended through Labor Day.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s “China: Through the Looking Glass,” an exploration of China’s influence on Western fashion and the largest show ever organized by the museum’s Costume Institute, has proven so popular that it will be extended three weeks, through Labor Day, Sept. 7, museum officials said Tuesday.

headline: Right Divided, a Disciplined Left Steered the Supreme Court
abstract: The court’s liberals spoke with one voice, and the conservatives with many. The result was one of the most left-leaning terms in recent years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The stunning series of liberal decisions delivered by the Supreme Court this term was the product of discipline on the left side of the court and disarray on the right.

abstract: A car-averse traveler finds freedom in the driver’s seat, covering 700 miles and three states over three days.
lead_paragraph: A car-averse traveler finds freedom in the driver’s seat, covering 700 miles and three states over three days.

headline: Gov. Chris Christie’s Phony Truth-Telling
abstract: There are lines between brash and belligerent, open and obnoxious, and, most important, between “telling it like it is” and fabricating a record.
lead_paragraph: On his new website, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey portrays himself as a guy who gets attacked for “telling it like it is,” but that’s what his mom told him to do from her deathbed.

headline: China Pledges to Halt Growth of Carbon Emissions in Climate Plan
abstract: China, the world’s top greenhouse gas emitter, pledged to wean its economy off fossil fuels and reach “the earliest possible peak” in emissions.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China, the world’s biggest greenhouse gas polluter, pledged on Tuesday to wean its economy away from reliance on fossil fuels as it grows, and to try to bring the rise in its carbon emissions to an earlier end.

headline: Two First-Round Upsets Shake Up Women’s Draw
abstract: The women’s draw was hit with upsets as No. 3 Simona Halep and No. 12 Eugenie Bouchard, a finalist at Wimbledon last year, were defeated by opponents ranked outside the top 100.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — At least this time, Eugenie Bouchard had a reason. After months in an inexplicable downward spiral, Bouchard tumbled out of Wimbledon in the first round Tuesday afternoon with another demoralizing loss.

headline: Delaware Art Museum Completes Sale of Artworks to Repay Debt
abstract: The museum, which was censured last year for selling works from its collection to pay down debt, said it had completed private sales of two paintings.
lead_paragraph: The Delaware Art Museum, which has come under withering criticism for deciding to sell up to four works from its collection to pay down construction debts, announced Monday that it had privately sold one of its most important paintings, Winslow Homer’s “Milking Time,” as well as Andrew Wyeth’s “Arthur Cleveland,” for amounts that it did not disclose.

headline: Willis-Towers Watson Merger to Insure Against Market Turmoil
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']

headline: Chris Christie’s Path to Relevance
abstract: Although his campaign is a long shot, he could nonetheless be a big influence in the Republican primary fight. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie is highly unlikely to win the nomination. The reasons, like his moderate-conservative views and the ethics scandal over bridge traffic in New Jersey, have been summarized elsewhere.But many candidates with little or no chance to win the nomination nonetheless play a big role in presidential primaries, and Mr. Christie could be one of them. He could drain votes from Jeb Bush, widening the opening for Marco Rubio or even improving Scott Walker’s odds to win both Iowa and New Hampshire.

headline: Witness Describes Attack on NATO Convoy
abstract: A suicide bomber attacked a convoy of foreign troops serving with NATO in the Afghan capital, Kabul.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber attacked a convoy of foreign troops serving with NATO in the Afghan capital, Kabul.

headline: Zadie Smith to Collaborate on a Screenplay
abstract: The novelist Zadie Smith will write her first screenplay, with the French director Claire Denis.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Amid the superheroes, dinosaurs, cyborg assassins and male strippers of the summer movie season comes a drop of sustenance for the cinematic intelligentsia: the French director Claire Denis will make her first English-language film, and she is collaborating on its screenplay with the British novelist Zadie Smith.

headline: Global Climate Pact Gains Momentum as China, U.S. and Brazil Detail Plans
abstract: President Obama and President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil pledged to increase the use of wind and solar power, and Brazil said it would restore nearly 30 million acres of Amazon rain forest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five months before a United Nations summit meeting aimed at forging a historic global accord to cut climate-warming emissions, significant signs of progress toward an agreement are emerging.

headline: Report Shows Widespread Mistreatment by Health Workers During Childbirth
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls', 'Medicine and Health', 'Hospitals']
abstract: The abuses inflicted on women around the world as their babies are born are forcing some to stay at home instead of going to a hospital.
lead_paragraph: They are slapped and pinched during labor, yelled at, denied pain medicine, neglected and forced to share beds with other women who just gave birth. And that is just a partial list of the abuses and humiliations inflicted on women around the world as their babies are born.

headline: A Hat Maker Beloved by Madonna, Sia and Gigi Hadid — and Bob Dylan, Too
abstract: Los Angeles-based Nick Fouquet’s bold techniques have included using fire and paint, distressing felt and reinventing classic shapes altogether.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles-based Nick Fouquet is in many ways the ultimate California dude — tall and lanky, with a shaggy blond mane that simply begs to have a hat put on it — but don’t call him a milliner. His approach to hat making is anything but traditional. “I’ve always wanted to do my own thing,” he says, “and it’s such a niche market and undervalued accessory. To me, hats are the pinnacle of elegance. I’m not here to reinvent them — but to do it with my twist; not over-the-top or dramatic, like a milliner might.”

headline: Historic Football, Florence’s Brutal Sport
abstract: Images of calcio storico in Florence, Italy, a centuries-old competition with few rules and the sort of human wreckage generally associated with the gladiators.
lead_paragraph: Images of calcio storico in Florence, Italy, a centuries-old competition with few rules and the sort of human wreckage generally associated with the gladiators.

headline: French Telecom Company Orange in Deal That Lets It Part With Israeli Provider
abstract: The agreement comes after an Orange executive’s comments about wanting to get out of Israel’s cellular market caused a diplomatic storm.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The French telecommunications company Orange has reached a deal allowing for a parting of ways with an Israeli mobile service provider, weeks after a squabble over a possible withdrawal of the brand from Israel’s cellular market caused a diplomatic storm.

headline: A Most Dangerous Game
abstract: Welcome to calcio storico, a centuries-old competition in Florence with very few rules and the sort of human wreckage generally associated with the gladiators.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — Last Tuesday, about 24 hours before he jammed his fingers into another man’s nose, dropped his elbow across another man’s neck and put another man’s feet where one’s ears are supposed to be, Rodrigue Nana considered, just for a moment, the basic notion of fear.

headline: Friends With ISIS: How To Tell One Young Woman’s Story
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Poh Si Teng describes some of the considerations that went into her recent video about a young woman in rural Washington who had befriended an Islamic State sympathizer through the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Like most developing stories, nothing was for certain. Earlier this year I went to rural Washington State to meet a young woman who had befriended Islamic State sympathizers over the Internet.

headline: Goldman Sachs to Pay $7 Million Penalty Over Options Glitch
keywords: ['Futures and Options Trading', 'Stock Options and Purchase Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The S.E.C. says the 2013 erroneous trading highlights the need for Wall Street firms to maintain better systems to prevent technological glitches that can roil markets.
lead_paragraph: For a Wall Street bank that prides itself on not making mistakes, an incident when Goldman Sachs erroneously sent thousands of stock options trades into the market two summers ago was embarrassing and costly.

headline: California Mandates Vaccines for Schoolchildren
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown signed a law on Tuesday to prohibit immunization exemptions based on personal or religious beliefs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California on Tuesday became the largest state in the country to require schoolchildren to receive vaccinations unless there are medical reasons not to do so, as Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation that ended exemptions for personal or religious reasons.

headline: Candidates Try Hard Sell to Lift Fund-Raising Totals
abstract: Presidential candidates are working sell to get donors to give more dollars ahead of Tuesday night’s first-quarter deadline for reporting fund-raising totals.

headline: Social Media Reaction to Misty Copeland’s Historic Promotion
abstract: Reaction to Misty Copeland’s promotion to principal dancer at American Ballet Theater.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Misty Copeland became the first African-American woman to be promoted to the role of principal dancer at American Ballet Theater. On her Instagram account, Ms. Copeland, who has over 500,000 followers, posted a photo and a short video of the moment she received the news.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Union Fees
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Government Employees', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Collective Bargaining']
abstract: The justices took on a case against public-sector unions that could deal a severe blow to organized labor.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to decide whether public-sector unions may require workers who are not members to help pay for collective bargaining. A ruling against them could deal a severe blow to organized labor.

headline: France Orders 2 Uber Executives to Stand Trial
abstract: The Paris prosecutor’s office accused the company of illegally organizing taxi services through its low-cost UberPop ride-hailing option.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Paris prosecutor’s office said Tuesday that two senior Uber executives in France had been ordered to stand trial on behalf of the company on charges including “deceptive commercial practices” and illegally organizing taxi services through its low-cost UberPop ride-hailing option.

lead_paragraph: A traditional Frogmore feast in South Carolina.

abstract: In the term that ended Monday, the Supreme Court’s more right-leaning wing exhibited more fractured voting than it had in recent terms.
lead_paragraph: In the term that ended Monday, the Supreme Court’s more right-leaning wing exhibited more fractured voting than it had in recent terms.

headline: United Church of Christ Approves Divestment to Aid Palestinians
abstract: The church, a mainline Protestant denomination with about one million members, was one of three voting this week on divestment measures over Israel’s occupation of Palestinian territories.
lead_paragraph: The United Church of Christ, one of the largest Protestant denominations in the United States, overwhelmingly approved a resolution Tuesday calling for divestment from companies that profit from Israel’s occupation or control of Palestinian territories, and a boycott of products from Israeli settlements.

headline: A Crowdfunding Campaign Tries to Save Greece
abstract: It is a nice gesture, a crowdfunding expert says. It is also totally impossible.
lead_paragraph: Greece was on the edge of a deadline to pay 1.5 billion euros (about $1.75 billion) back to the International Monetary Fund, and a crowdfunding campaign called Greek Bailout Fund wanted to help.

headline: Market Report
abstract: Pillows so pretty you’ll want to take them outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Pillows so pretty you’ll want to take them outdoors.

headline: Liberia Confirms New Ebola Case
abstract: Dr. Bernice Dahn, Liberia’s new minister of health, said on Tuesday that the country had confirmed its first case of Ebola since it was declared free of the virus more than a month ago.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Bernice Dahn, Liberia’s new minister of health, said on Tuesday that the country had confirmed its first case of Ebola since it was declared free of the virus more than a month ago.

headline: Donald Trump: An American Tale
abstract: The grandson of an immigrant, Mr. Trump now slanders immigrants.
lead_paragraph: I don’t have a lot to add to the story of Donald Trump, his slander against Mexican immigrants and the ensuing self-induced immolation of his media empire, except to note that what we have here is a classic American immigrant story.

headline: Israeli Man Dies in Attack Near West Bank Settlement
abstract: An Israeli man, shot while riding in a car, died Tuesday as Israel blamed Palestinian television for inciting a recent wave of violence.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli man died Tuesday after being shot in the West Bank the night before. Palestinian gunmen are suspected in the attack on the victim, Malakhi Rosenfeld, 26, a student at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, and three other Israelis as they rode in a car near an Israeli settlement. Also Tuesday, Israeli security guards shot and wounded a Palestinian man at the Kalandia crossing between Jerusalem and the West Bank city of Ramallah. The Israeli police said the man had run at the guards and ignored warnings to stop. Israel’s defense minister, Moshe Yaalon, blamed a recent wave of attacks on programs on Palestinian television that he said incited violence.

headline: Jake Wobbrock of AnswerDash: Lead With Strengths, and Weaknesses
abstract: Looking for job applicants with aptitude, the intelligence and ability to do the job; an optimistic attitude; and appetite, a hunger for the job opportunity.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Jake Wobbrock, founding chief executive and chief scientist of AnswerDash, a provider of automated customer service for websites, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Court Allows N.Y.U.’s Contested Expansion Plan to Go Forward
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: New York State’s Court of Appeals upheld a lower-court ruling, most likely ending a long battle over the plan, which would add four buildings in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: The state’s highest court on Tuesday upheld a lower court ruling allowing New York University to move forward with its expansion plan, most likely ending a long battle with neighbors, elected officials, preservationists and faculty members.

headline: Gunman at Tunisian Beach Hotel Trained With Museum Attackers
abstract: The man who killed 38 people last week had spent time in a militant camp in Libya, overlapping with two men who killed 22 in March, security officials said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The gunman who massacred 38 foreign tourists at a beachside hotel on Friday trained with a militant group in Libya this year alongside two Tunisians who later killed 22 people at the national museum, security officials confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: President Forced to Watch Marriage-Ruling Celebrations on TV
abstract: President Obama expressed wistful regret that he was not able to celebrate with the crowds outside of the White House that had gathered hours after the Supreme Court struck down limits on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Even President Obama is sometimes forced to watch events around the White House – ones he helped create – only on TV.

headline: The Magic of Hobo Packs
abstract: Self-contained, often foil-wrapped meals cooked in hot coals are an easy option for outdoor cooking.
lead_paragraph: Boy Scout camp introduced both of us to hobo packs, bundles of cut-up ingredients wrapped in foil packets and cooked in the coals of a campfire. Ours combined ground beef, potatoes, carrots and a ton of ketchup.

headline: Chris Squire Made Prog Rock Rock
abstract: The visionary bassist poured a Stones-like street fighting spirit into Yes’s ethereal music.
lead_paragraph: At 14, it was easy to like Led Zeppelin and the Rolling Stones. And I did. These bands were like audio-visual packages tailored explicitly for my hormone and confusion levels, spackle kits for my hole-ridden sense of self. Because straight-up, blues based rock and roll is the prima materia of teen rebellion. So it was then, and so shall it be until the end of Spotify.

headline: Sepp Blatter Won’t Attend Women’s World Cup Final
abstract: Blatter, the president of FIFA, the world governing body of soccer, is citing “personal reasons,” his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Blatter Will Skip Final

headline: Patience Spent, de Blasio Accuses Cuomo of Hurting New York City Out of ‘Revenge’
abstract: In an unusually outspoken interview, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a fellow Democrat, had been acting out of pettiness and a desire for revenge.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in candid and searing words rarely employed by elected officials of his stature, accused Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday of stymieing New York City’s legislative goals out of personal pettiness, “game-playing” and a desire for “revenge.”

headline: For Black Principal Dancers, Rarefied Air
abstract: With her promotion at American Ballet Theater, Misty Copeland joins only a handful of African-Americans at major companies who became principals. Here’s a look at a few of them.
lead_paragraph: With her promotion at American Ballet Theater, Misty Copeland joins only a handful of African-Americans at major companies who became principals. Here’s a look at a few of them.

headline: Obama Downplays Dangers of Greek Crisis
abstract: President Obama said on Tuesday that Greece defaulting on its debts is concerning, but is primarily a problem for Europe.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said on Tuesday that Greece defaulting on its debts is concerning, but is primarily a problem for Europe.

headline: Disney Names Its First Female Chief Financial Officer
abstract: Christine M. McCarthy, who has most recently been Disney’s treasurer, will succeed James A. Rasulo, who stepped down in early June.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Adding another female executive to its predominantly male senior ranks, the Walt Disney Company on Tuesday named Christine M. McCarthy as its next chief financial officer, succeeding James A. Rasulo.

headline: In England, Glenn Ligon Brings Together the (American) Works that Have Influenced Him
abstract: Included in the show are pieces by Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline and 40-some others.
lead_paragraph: “What holds all this work together — I realized every single one of these artists is American,” Glenn Ligon reflects. “And they’re all loans from the Tate’s collection.” Obama’s favorite artist has landed in England with an exhibition he’s curated — a personal constellation, really — all culled from British holdings. “It’s an attempt to show the community around an artist,” says the abstract painter, who has more recently branched out as a multihyphenate practitioner. “Glenn Ligon: Encounters and Collisions” clusters 45 artists whom Ligon explains “were very influential in the beginning of my career,” as well as now. Traveling from Nottingham Contemporary — “which has really built a strong reputation in the last four or five years,” explains Thomas Dane, Ligon’s longtime English gallerist — the intimate retrospective docks in Liverpool today at the Tate’s waterfront warehouse complex. It goes up alongside “Blind Spot,” an exhibition of a series of black pourings by Jackson Pollock — “the man of the hour,” Ligon jokes, moments before his own opening.

headline: Justice Dept. Report Says Police Escalated Tensions in Ferguson
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The report describes a chaotic scene in which the police violated people’s constitutional rights and it was often unclear who was in charge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When heavily armed police officers swarmed the streets of Ferguson, Mo., after the fatal shooting last year of a young, unarmed black man, they only worsened tensions and made it harder to regain public confidence and control, a draft report from the Justice Department has concluded.

headline: Knicks Think Big as Free Agency Is Set to Begin
abstract: The Knicks will be focused on size and players who complement their triangle offense as Phil Jackson continues to remake the roster.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson, the president of the Knicks, has been clear about his priorities in free agency: size, size and size.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Lonely Hearts Club
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Single Persons']
abstract: The marriage equality ruling is a triumph, but not so great for the uncoupled.
lead_paragraph: Now all of us single people are pathetic, not just the straight ones. “Marriage responds to the universal fear that a lonely person might call out only to find no one there,” writes Justice Anthony M. Kennedy in the majority opinion of the Supreme Court in Obergefell v. Hodges. As I read that bit alone in my apartment, I choked on my coffee.

headline: Tourism in Greece Remains Steady During Debt Crisis
abstract: Credit and debit cards issued by foreign banks are being accepted throughout the country without any additional regulations.
lead_paragraph: With Greece reeling over fears of default and the weeklong closure of its major banks and stock market, travelers are likely wondering how these major financial disruptions will affect their ability to use currency throughout the country. While native Greeks are currently limited to daily A.T.M. withdrawals of 60 euros per account, tourists do not face similar restrictions. (However, many A.T.M.s have been running out of money, forcing people to try other machines, which have been plagued by long lines.)

abstract: Jeb Bush’s time away from public life has been good for him, at least financially, as he and his wife, Columba, reported adjusted gross income of $7.3 million on his 2013 tax return, the last of 33 years of returns that he released on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: After he left office as governor of Florida, Jeb Bush’s net worth grew to at least $19 million from $1.3 million, a significant leap in wealth that reflects the power of his connections and the breadth of his entrepreneurial pursuits.

abstract: Light, citrusy scents now have much bolder competition.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in late May, around the time I replace boots with sandals in my closet, I put away all of my perfumes with notes of incense and amber, tobacco and musk; in their place appear fragrances with coconut and night-blooming flowers.

headline: U.S. Leaves the Markets Out in the Fight Against Carbon Emissions
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Even though a trade in permits helped reduce sulfur dioxide pollution, at a lower cost than with other methods, lawmakers have resisted using them against carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, by an overwhelming majority, Congress amended the Clean Air Act to establish a market for electric utilities to trade the right to emit sulfur dioxide, one of the main contributors to acid rain.

headline: Lufthansa Offers Compensation to Families of Germanwings Crash Victims
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: Lufthansa proposed on Tuesday to pay $28,000 each in emotional damages to the German victims’ families, an amount dismissed as inadequate by lawyers for the families.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than three months after a Germanwings airliner crashed into a French mountainside, killing everyone aboard, the airline’s parent company, Lufthansa, made its first proposal to pay for emotional damages on Tuesday, offering the German victims’ families $28,000 each. Lawyers for the relatives immediately dismissed the figure as inadequate.

headline: Deep Below Croatia Lurks a New Species of Centipede
abstract: The species, named after the Greek god of the underworld, lives some 3,600 feet underground.
lead_paragraph: The world’s deepest-dwelling centipede — found as much as 3,600 feet below the surface — is in Croatia, a new study in ZooKeys reports. The centipede was found in three caves in the Velebit mountain range, along the Adriatic Coast. It has powerful jaws with poison glands and long, curved claws that allow it to clutch its prey. And like other cave-dwelling arthropods, it has elongated antennas, trunk segments and leg claws. Researchers named the centipede Geophilus hadesi, after Hades, the Greek god of the underworld.
