lead_paragraph: A freshman quarterback at Florida State has been charged with battery after an altercation at a Tallahassee, Fla., bar in which he punched a woman in the face, the police said.

headline: Review: In ‘Terminator Genisys,’ Ageless Cyborgs and a Deathless Franchise
abstract: Arnold Schwarzenegger returns, it’s 1984 again, and Sarah Connor is at risk once more.
lead_paragraph: In a scene in “Terminator Genisys” that’s on heavy rotation in the movie’s ads, the old Arnold Schwarzenegger goes up against the new. The older version has the smoothly pampered skin of the best beauty treatments that Hollywood money can buy, with scarcely a visible line etching his sharply angled and ironed facial planes. Now, though, the new movie’s cyborg has abruptly come deadpan to deadpan with an unlined, recently minted identical twin that, like the original Terminator in 1984, has entered without any clothes. It’s strange to see Old and Young Arnold go at it, their refrigerator-size bodies slamming against each other in what plays like an intimate existential clash.

headline: Apple Music Makes Debut With D.J. Carrying the Flag
abstract: If Apple Music is successful, it could deliver billions of dollars in revenue to the music industry and establish streaming music as a stable business.
lead_paragraph: “Into the unknown we go,” the D. J. Zane Lowe said just after noon on Tuesday, as he began his first show on Beats 1, the Internet radio station that is a big feature of Apple’s new music service.

headline: U.S. and Cuba Agree to Reopen Embassies, Officials Say
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States and Cuba will announce an agreement to reopen embassies in each other’s capitals, formally restoring diplomatic relations, according to administration officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Cuba will announce an agreement on Wednesday to reopen embassies in each other’s capitals, formally restoring diplomatic relations more than a half-century after they were ruptured, according to administration officials.

headline: Zuckerberg Takes Questions in Facebook Session Marred by Tech Troubles
abstract: Facebook’s chief responded to ordinary users and celebrities like Arnold Schwarzenegger about the nature of happiness and the future of social media, but the session went offline for several minutes.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg may run Facebook, but that does not mean he actually controls the social network.

headline: Review: ‘Cinderella’ Returns to the American Ballet Theater Stable
abstract: An extraordinarily detailed three-act version of this Frederick Ashton choreography returned to the company’s repertory at the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: The 20th century saw four choreographic masters of the male-female duet: Fred Astaire, George Balanchine, Frederick Ashton and Merce Cunningham. Ashton’s are almost all to do with love of one kind or another. On Monday, as his 1948 treatment of Prokofiev’s three-act “Cinderella” returned to American Ballet Theater’s repertory, I marveled again at many of its choreographic features but especially at its two pas de deux for the heroine and her Prince. Hee Seo was Cinderella, Cory Stearns her Prince.

headline: Seattle Police Investigating 2 Officers Shown in Report
abstract: The inquiry concerned comments they made during a training session that was featured in a video and an article in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Police Department said Tuesday that it was investigating two officers featured in a video and an article in The New York Times about the department’s efforts to retrain officers to eliminate unnecessary force during confrontations with civilians.

headline: Spain’s New Public Safety Law Has Its Challengers
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of Assembly', 'Law and Legislation', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Demonstrators can face hefty fines under a law that forbids unauthorized gatherings around Parliament, making amateur videos of the police and insulting officers.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain has been the epicenter of some of the largest protests in Europe against government austerity cuts, including a youth-led mobilization that called itself the “indignants,” which took over Madrid’s main square in May 2011 as a precursor to the Occupy Wall Street movement.

headline: Review: ‘Magic Mike XXL,’ Fleshing Out a Sequel With Heart as Well as Pecs and Abs
abstract: Channing Tatum returns in this comedy, which transports the audience to a world of sexual intrigue that feels as safe and wholesome as a child’s birthday party.
lead_paragraph: Alone in his workshop one night, Mike Lane receives a visit from the muse. Though he’s still played by Channing Tatum, Mike is no longer the Magic Mike we met in the movie of that name a few years back. He’s an entrepreneur with a fledgling custom-furniture business. The dream that beguiled him in “Magic Mike” — to quit the stripping game and work with his hands instead of his abs and his glutes — has come true.

headline: Donna Karan Steps Down, in Major Shift for Fashion
abstract: After “much soul searching,” a major force in American fashion is leaving the helm of the house she founded.
lead_paragraph: In a major shift for American fashion, Donna Karan, the 66-year-old founder and chief designer of Donna Karan International, a brand that defined the way American working women dressed for decades, announced on Tuesday that she was leaving the helm of the house that bears her name.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘A Poem Is a Naked Person’ Is a Jam Session of a Documentary
abstract: Les Blank’s film, made in the early 1970s and now receiving a United States theatrical release, looks at the mystery of Leon Russell.
lead_paragraph: As he appears in “A Poem Is a Naked Person” — a documentary made in the early ’70s and now receiving a belated and welcome United States theatrical release — Leon Russell is an enigma wrapped in a mystery and wearing his signature top hat. With silver hair and an air of sagacity belying his youth at the time (he was born in 1942), Mr. Russell seems to have sprung from the commingled imaginations of J. R. R. Tolkien and Mark Twain. He’s a wizard and a mountebank, an old-timey song-and-dance man dabbling in ancient magic.

headline: Review: ‘Mala Mala’ Shares Experiences of Being Transgender in Puerto Rico
abstract: The directors of this documentary, Dan Sickles and Antonio Santini, interview prostitutes, drag queens, small-business owners and activists about their transitions and relationships.
lead_paragraph: “Mala Mala,” a survey of transgender individuals in Puerto Rico, is nothing if not timely. With Laverne Cox, the Amazon series “Transparent” and Caitlyn Jenner, the topic of gender identity has gone mainstream.

headline: Review: Ekmeles Performs Chamber Works Written for Voices and Brass Instruments
abstract: The new-music vocal ensemble performed several chamber works in a concert that was the close of the Five Boroughs Music Festival’s season.
lead_paragraph: In the necrology for the year 1616, the names of Shakespeare and Cervantes stand out. The death of a young German girl that same year might have barely passed notice.

headline: Facebook Sweetens Terms for Buyers of Video Ads
abstract: Advertisers are given the option to pay for video ads only if users view them for at least 10 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is giving advertisers the option to pay for video ads only if users view them for at least 10 seconds, as the social media company faces pressure over how it charges for ads. Facebook on Tuesday began offering the new ad-buying feature to bigger advertisers.

headline: Escapees’ Fraternizing With Prison Workers Doesn’t Surprise Experts

lead_paragraph: Shortly after Richard W. Matt and David Sweat were discovered missing from their cells in the honor block of Clinton Correctional Facility in northern New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo sought to tamp down any suggestions of complicity by prison staff members.
